title: CASE OF PETROVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1964 and lives in Šabac.
- The applicant was employed by “Zorka -mineralna đubriva” AD.
- On 3 July 2003, the Šabac Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant unpaid salary and costs.
- On May 17, 2007, the applicant applied for the enforcement of the court decision.
- On May 18, 2007, the enforcement order was issued.
- On February 19, 2008, the enforcement was stayed because of the debtor's ongoing restructuring.
- On March 2, 2010, the applicant urged the court to continue the enforcement proceedings.
- On June 1, 2010, the court informed the applicant that the debtor was still undergoing restructuring, and the enforcement proceedings can't be continued.
- On July 10, 2002, the Privatisation Agency began the debtor's restructuring as part of the privatization process, and it is still ongoing.

title: CASE OF DÜLEK v. TURKEY
facts:
- Ms Gazal Dülek, a Turkish national, was arrested on suspicion of aiding and abetting the PKK
- The applicant was interrogated without the presence of a lawyer and made a statement admitting her involvement with the PKK
- The applicant denied the accusation and the statement made before the prosecutor and the police
- The Istanbul State Security Court convicted the applicant and sentenced her to three years and nine months’ imprisonment, which was later quashed by the Court of Cassation
- The State Security Courts were abolished, and the case against the applicant was transferred to the Istanbul Assize Court
- The applicant was convicted of membership of an illegal organization and sentenced to six years and three months' imprisonment, which was upheld by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF JALBĂ v. ROMANIA
facts:
• The applicant is a civil servant working for the Galaţi mayor's office as head of the technical department.

• An article was published in the local online newspaper Antidotul by journalist I.G accusing the applicant of protecting the Maxi-taxi Mafia in Galaţi without proper examination of the transport legislation in force at the time.

• The journalist portrayed the applicant as a “slyboots,” an “old fox in a sneaky business,” and one of the “fellows with maxi-taxi businesses” interested in “filling up his bank accounts.”

• The applicant lodged a general tort-law action against the journalist, seeking RON 10,000 (approximately EUR 2,800) in compensation for non-pecuniary damage.

• The Galaţi district court allowed the applicant's action and ordered the journalist to pay the requested compensation.

• The journalist appealed on points of law and the Galaţi County Court, sitting as a final-instance court, allowed the appeal and dismissed the applicant's action.

• The prosecution dismissed the applicant's criminal complaint against the journalist, and the applicant did not appeal against the decision before the domestic courts.

title: CASE OF NECULA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and is currently detained in Mărgineni Prison.
- He was detained on 22 November 2003 on charges of aggravated murder and placed in Mărgineni Prison. 
- The Dâmbovița County Court convicted him of aggravated murder and sentenced him to twenty-two years’ imprisonment.
- He lodged his first application before the Court alleging that his rights under Article 3 of the Convention had been violated on account of the material conditions of his detention in Mărgineni Prison.
- Applicant’s complaint concerning the material conditions of detention was communicated to the Romanian Government but he failed to submit any observations.
- The Court decided to strike the application out of its list of cases. 
- The cells were small and overcrowded, toilets were not separated from the cells, were uncovered and smelled badly because there was no running water.
- The applicant lacked sufficient physical exercise and his food was inadequate and low in calories. 
- During his detention, the applicant stayed in several detention cells. 
- All the detention cells where the applicant had stayed had been connected to electricity, heating and water supplies.
- The cells had individual beds and were adequately furnished for the detainees to be able to eat their meals and store their personal belongings. 
- The detainees had permanent access to drinking water and bathed twice a week in specially designated areas.
- The applicant received a diet which was served in accordance with the regulation in force. 
- Hygiene in the cells was the detainees’ responsibility and they were provided regularly with cleaning materials by the prison authorities. 
- The applicant contended that his rights to adequate medical assistance, to correspondence, to working, and educational activities, as well as to access to running water, and adequate detention conditions, had been breached.
- By a decision of 19 September 2011 the judge responsible for the execution of prison sentences attached to Mărgineni Prison dismissed the applicant’s action. 
- By decisions of 10 January and 13 September 2012 the judge responsible for the execution of prison sentences attached to Mărgineni Prison allowed the applicant’s actions seeking to be allowed to receive several food items.

title: CASE OF FERREIRA ALVES v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- Applicant's birth year and place of residence
- Institution of disciplinary proceedings by Ethics Council of Porto against applicant on 3 June 2005
- Complaint introduced by a client on 29 May 2002 for breach of professional secrecy
- Dismissal of the case on 4 March 2011 due to a previous decision in 2009 being dropped as time-barred.

title: CASE OF SZÉCHENYI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1976 and 1977 and live in Budapest.
- On 28 June 2001, they brought a real estate action against their mother and grandmother.
- On 23 November 2006, a first-instance decision was given.
- On 12 June 2007, the appeal judgment was adopted.
- In November 2009, the Supreme Court's decision on the applicants' petition for review was served.

title: CASE OF CSERNY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Budapest.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant on charges of fraud and forgery on 27 April 1995.
- The bill of indictment was preferred on 9 October 2000, and the first hearing took place in 2003.
- On 8 April 2010, the Pest Central District Court found the applicant guilty of the crimes he was charged with.
- The Budapest Regional Court acquitted him on 27 May 2011 on his appeal.
- The judgment became final on 4 July 2011.

title: CASE OF TURUL KFT. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is a limited liability company based in Lovas.
- The Veszprém County Administrative Office rejected the applicant's request for a building permit.
- The reason for rejection was that the project was not in line with the historical neighborhood of Veszprém town.
- The applicant challenged the decision in court on 21 June 2001.
- On 25 March 2003, the Veszprém County Regional Court overruled the administrative decision.
- The case was remitted to the administrative authorities.
- On 2 March 2007, the request by the applicant was rejected again.
- On 18 April 2007, the applicant renewed its action.
- On 31 October 2007, the Regional Court rejected the application, holding that the administrative decisions were according to the law.
- On 25 February 2009, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's petition for review.

title: CASE OF DAJBUKAT AND SZILAGYI-PALKO v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants are a mother and daughter, born in 1927 and 1956 respectively. They live in Cluj-Napoca.
- They lived in an apartment rented from the State in a nationalised building from 1960.
- On 16 December 1996, they bought the apartment from the State under Law no. 112/1995.
- In a final decision of 3 August 1998, the County Court noted that the State had acquired ownership of the building without legal title.
- The former owner lodged actions for annulment of sale purchase contracts against persons who bought apartments in the same building.
- In a May 2001 judgment, the Cluj County Court annulled the sale purchase contract.
- The first applicant's husband died during the proceedings, so their daughter continued the case.
- The Cluj Court of Appeal rejected the applicants' appeal on 19 October 2001.
- The High Court of Cassation and Justice remitted the trial of the appeal on points of law to the lower court in September 2006.
- In a final judgment of 19 April 2007, the Cluj Court of Appeal annulled the contract concluded on 16 December 1996.
- The Court of Appeal dismissed actions for annulment of contracts lodged by the former owner against other apartment owners in the same building.

title: CASE OF BAYRAM GÜÇLÜ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Samsun.
- On 14 July 1999, Istanbul State Security Court issued an order for his arrest in suspicion of trafficking illegal drugs while he was living in the Netherlands.
- Later, a prosecutor in Amsterdam had filed an indictment against him.
- The Istanbul prosecutor requested the Netherlands to extradite him back to Turkey for criminal proceedings.
- The Istanbul prosecutor accused the applicant of trafficking cocaine, and he was a member of a criminal organization.
- The Amsterdam Criminal Court found him guilty, and he served 33 months of his sentence in the Netherlands.
- Upon release, he was deported to Turkey, where he was arrested and remanded in police custody.
- The applicant was interrogated and questioned by the police and the public prosecutor, in the absence of a lawyer, and he admitted some allegations.
- Later, he was taken before the investigating judge, who remanded him in custody, still in the absence of a lawyer.
- The applicant denied the statements he had given to the police, and the prosecutor filed another indictment accusing him of trafficking heroin, still a member of a criminal organization.
- The Istanbul State Security Court found him guilty of trafficking cocaine, relied on his statements and others, and forensics reports.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF ZAYIDOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was a journalist and editor-in-chief of Azadliq newspaper
- On 7 November 2007, the applicant had a verbal altercation with a woman in front of a publishing house
- The verbal altercation turned into a physical altercation with a man who intervened and the applicant
- The applicant informed the media of the incident and stated that he had been attacked because of his activities as a journalist and had been set up
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant under Article 221.1 (hooliganism) of the Criminal Code
- The applicant was suspected of deliberate infliction of less serious injury to health and hooliganism
- The applicant was remanded in custody for a period of two months on the grounds that he posed a danger to society
- The applicant's request for bail was dismissed, and the preventive measure of remand in custody was upheld
- On 7 March 2008, the applicant was sentenced to four years in prison
- The applicant was released by presidential pardon on 17 March 2010.

title: CASE OF NOVRUZ ISMAYILOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is serving a sentence of imprisonment in Baku.
- The applicant was a founder and chairman of the supervisory board of the private Borçalı Bank and Borçalı Association.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant for tax evasion on 19 April 2004.
- The applicant participated in various investigative steps but failed to comply with requests to assist the investigation.
- On 28 September 2004, the applicant was charged under Articles 178 (fraud), 179 (embezzlement), and 313 (forgery by an official) of the Criminal Code.
- The prosecutor requested the application of the preventive measure of remand in custody because of the seriousness of the applicant’s alleged criminal acts and the possibility of his absconding or obstructing the investigation.
- The Khatai District Court ordered the applicant's detention for three months on 28 September 2004.
- The Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal on 5 October 2004, finding that re-detention was justified.
- The investigator requested an extension of the applicant’s detention on 16 December 2004.
- The Khatai District Court extended the length of the applicant’s remand in custody by a period of two months until 28 February 2005.
- The applicant's lawyer claimed that the record of the hearing on 23 December 2004 had been falsified.
- The Court of Appeal found no reason to quash the Khatai District Court's decision on the extension of the detention period on 6 January 2005.
- The prosecutor filed the indictment with the Assize Court on 12 May 2005.
- On 31 January 2006, the Assize Court convicted the applicant of fraud, embezzlement, and tax evasion and sentenced him to nine years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF NOSOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are former policemen entitled to social payments due to their involvement in a conflict resolution operation in 1992.
- They sued the regional internal-affairs department for social-payments arrears, which were eventually enforced between 2004 and 2005.
- They sued the department for pecuniary damage due to delays in enforcement, and were awarded and paid sums to cover inflation losses.
- They announced a demonstration in Svoboda Square in Vladikavkaz on 30 September 2003, protesting against the failure to settle the social-payments debt.
- The demonstration was declared unlawful on 11 October 2003 by the Leninskiy District Court of Vladikavkaz due to a risk of terrorist activities and other offences being committed, not being authorised by Russian law, and violating the rights of others.

title: CASE OF FIRSTOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested and charged with theft.
- He was remanded in custody in the Inza Town police station and later transferred to Inza temporary detention facility IZ-73/3.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to five years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant was taken to the police ward twenty-two times during the pre-trial investigation and court proceedings.
- The conditions of detention in the police ward were poor, including inadequate sleeping arrangements, poor lighting, lack of lavatory facilities, poor ventilation, and insufficient food.
- The applicant brought an action in tort against the police station administration and the Ministry of Finance of the Russian Federation, claiming that the conditions of his detention caused a serious deterioration in his health.
- The Inza District Court partly allowed the applicant’s action and awarded him RUB 500 (approximately EUR 15) in compensation for non-pecuniary damage, but the Ulyanovsk Regional Court upheld the judgment.
- The applicant later lodged an action seeking compensation for damage to his health and loss of earnings, but this was dismissed by the Inza District Court and later upheld by the Ulyanovsk Regional Court.

title: CASE OF OVSJANNIKOV v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant was an entrepreneur, a member of the Narva City Council, and chairman of its financial committee at the time of the events.
- A criminal investigation was initiated on 27 October 2010, regarding influence peddling in the municipalities of Ida-Viru County.
- The applicant was arrested on 12 July 2011 for prejudicing free competition, influence peddling, demanding bribes, and money laundering.
- On 13 July 2011, the prosecutor requested detention for the applicant due to a reasonable suspicion that he could compromise the ongoing investigation by tampering with the evidence or exerting pressure on witnesses or other suspects.
- The Viru County Court remanded the applicant in custody on 14 July 2011, citing sufficient evidence, such as documentary evidence, witness statements, and surveillance materials.
- The applicant requested release on bail, which was rejected on the grounds that he might continue to commit offenses and exert influence over witnesses, as per the Viru County Court’s decision of 5 September 2011.
- On 12 December 2011, the Viru County Court dismissed the applicant’s request for release, again citing that if at liberty, he might tamper with evidence and influence the other accused and witnesses.
- The applicant was released from custody on 11 January 2012 and was subjected to a prohibition on leaving his place of residence as a preventive measure.
- A prosecutor drew up a statement of charges against five suspects, including the applicant, on 30 August 2012, and on 10 December 2012, the applicant was prosecuted together with four other accused. The criminal case is still pending before the domestic courts.

title: CASE OF SHISHKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and is serving a prison sentence in Russia.
- The applicant was arrested in March 2004 and sentenced to administrative detention for 15 days for disorderly behaviour.
- The applicant was remanded in custody in April 2004 and transferred to various detention centres throughout the year.
- The cells the applicant was detained in were overcrowded, lacked basic facilities, and were often filled with smoke due to smoking.
- The applicant was not provided with adequate food, water, or hygiene facilities.
- The conditions of his detention prompted the applicant to lodge numerous complaints and lawsuits against various public authorities.
- The applicant's claims for compensation and improvement of conditions of detention were largely denied due to technicalities and lack of evidence.

title: CASE OF GHEORGHE PREDESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Romania.
- The applicant was placed in pre-trial detention on suspicion of murder and convicted of murder in 2007.
- The applicant was held in various prisons and prison hospitals from 2007-2012, and transferred 47 times between eight of these facilities.
- The applicant claimed that other inmates had tried to poison him and beat him with encouragement or help from prison authorities.
- The applicant was diagnosed with delusional disorder in 2007 and prescribed medication, which he refused to take, resulting in regular hospital admissions and discharges.
- The applicant made repeated complaints about attempted poisoning, and once requested to be placed in a cell alone.
- The ANP tested the quality of food and water daily and found no issues in the applicant's case.
- The applicant slept in a bathtub and on a toilet seat to avoid poisoning.
- Criminal complaints lodged by the applicant against prison staff were dismissed, citing lack of evidence and the applicant's mental health issues.
- The applicant was involved in a violent incident in Târgu Jiu Prison in 2008 and received medical care, but no criminal complaint was filed.

title: CASE OF BĒRZIŅŠ v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Riga.
- The Department for the Combat of Organised Crime received information about the applicant's alleged involvement in the sale of drugs.
- A test purchase of drugs was made on 24 and 26 March 2004.
- The applicant was apprehended by police officers after the test purchase on 26 March 2004, and claims to have been repeatedly hit and pushed, resulting in bodily injuries.
- The applicant was later taken to the hospital for chest pain and other injuries.
- The applicant was questioned as a suspect and later put in temporary detention.
- The applicant was found guilty of unauthorised acquisition, possession, and transport of narcotic and psychotropic substances on a large scale, with intent to sell, and sentenced to eight years and six months' imprisonment.
- The applicant made a representation to the court about ill-treatment during his arrest on 26 March 2004.
- The application for criminal proceedings in respect of the infliction of injuries during his arrest was refused by the Internal Security Office of the State Police.

title: CASE OF VĂDUVA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The Ministry of the Interior informed Prosecutor’s Office about drug dealing suspicions involving the applicant.
- The phone of those involved was tapped by the prosecutor and undercover agents were assigned.
- T.T. and L.G. were apprehended while trying to sell drugs and confessed to drug trafficking, implicating the applicant.
- The police searched the applicant’s apartment and car without a warrant and arrested him.
- The applicant was placed in pre-trial detention, released pending trial in 2003, and then placed in pre-trial detention again for 25 days.
- The applicant was accused of drug trafficking and went to trial alongside T.T. and L.G.
- The court acquitted the applicant due to lack of solid evidence but convicted T.T. and L.G.
- The conviction was later overturned and the case was re-examined.
- The Court of Appeal convicted the applicant and sentenced him to 10 years in prison.
- The applicant appealed on points of law but the conviction was upheld by the High Court.

title: CASE OF KILYEN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Mr Laszlo Kilyen was born in 1972 and lives in Murgeşti.
- On 10 May 2003 police officers T.M. and L.C.V. entered the applicant's yard in his absence without his permission, they took note of the chassis series of two cars found in the applicant's shed and looked in several boxes which contained spare parts for cars.
- The officers disclosed their identities to the applicant's neighbour, K.M., and informed him that they were carrying out an investigation into the theft of two cars. They also left a summons for the applicant to report to the police station as soon as possible.
- On 15 May 2003, the applicant lodged a complaint against the two police officers for the crime of trespassing under Article 192 of the Criminal Code.
- The prosecutor investigating the case decided to discontinue the proceedings against the two officers on 8 July 2003.
- The applicant appealed against the prosecutors' decisions before the Târgu Mureş Court of Appeal.
- The Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's appeal on 27 February 2004.
- The appeal by the applicant on points of law (recurs) against this decision was dismissed on 28 May 2004 by a final judgment of the High Court of Cassation and Justice.

title: CASE OF S.J. v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicant arrived in Belgium in 2007
- The applicant claimed asylum in July 2007 and stated that she fled due to pressure to have an abortion from the family of the child’s father
- The applicant was appointed a guardian due to being a minor 
- The applicant had already lodged an asylum application in Malta before arriving in Belgium
- The Maltese authorities accepted responsibility for the applicant’s asylum application 
- The applicant remained in Belgium for a request for leave to remain and ensuing proceedings 
- In 2009, the Aliens Office decided to examine the applicant’s asylum application itself 
- The Commissioner General rejected the applicant’s asylum application due to inconsistencies in her account 
- The Aliens Appeals Board upheld the Commissioner General’s decision 
- The applicant was diagnosed as HIV positive during an antenatal examination in 2007 
- The applicant gave birth to her first child in September 2007 and received treatment to prevent HIV transmission 
- The applicant received ARV treatment at a hospital in Brussels in 2008 
- The applicant was monitored by the not-for-profit association Lhiving in 2008 
- The applicant gave birth to her second child in 2009 
- The University Hospital issued multiple medical certificates addressing the applicant’s treatment and medical needs 
- The applicant’s request for leave to remain on medical grounds was refused in 2008 but declared admissible in 2009 
- The Aliens Office began exploring the possibilities for treatment in Nigeria in 2009 and refused the request in 2010 
- The applicant was ordered to leave Belgium in 2010 after the rejection of her request to have her residence status regularised 
- The applicant lodged a request for a stay of execution and an application to set aside the decision

title: CASE OF DZHABRAILOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals who are close relatives of individuals who disappeared after alleged unlawful detention by servicemen during a special operation in areas under the full control of the Russian federal forces.
- The applicants have had no news of their missing relatives since the alleged arrests, and official investigations have remained pending for several years without achieving any tangible results.
- The relevant State authorities were unable to identify the State servicemen allegedly involved in the arrests or abductions, and the Government did not challenge the allegations as presented by the applicants.
- The first four applicants are the parents and sisters of Mr Yakub Dzhabrailov, who was abducted from his own house by armed Russian servicemen in December 2001 and has not been seen since.
- The second four applicants are the family of three brothers who were abducted from their houses in Gudermes in October 2002 by camouflaged servicemen and taken to a temporary detention center guarded by FSB officers.
- The investigation has mainly consisted of requests for information and formal requests for operational search measures to be carried out by counterparts in various parts of Chechnya and other regions of the North Caucasus, with no tangible progress.

title: CASE OF KOROVINY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant was arrested and detained in custody in 2009 for a drug-related offense.
- He was found to be suffering from schizophrenia requiring compulsory psychiatric treatment.
- His detention was repeatedly extended by the court.
- He was eventually relieved of criminal responsibility and admitted to a psychiatric hospital where he attempted to escape and was held in inhumane conditions.
- The hospital's psychiatrists recommended his transfer to a specialist psychiatric hospital under intensive supervision.
- The court granted the hospital's request for transfer without informing the first applicant's legal guardian or lawyer.
- The transfer was later found to be unlawful and quashed on appeal.
- After a lengthy legal process, the first applicant was eventually discharged from the hospital and his treatment changed to outpatient monitoring and psychiatric treatment.
- The conditions of his confinement in the hospital were found to have violated statutory standards.

title: CASE OF LUČIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The applicant was accused of rape by J.N. in 1999.
- J.N. identified the applicant as her rapist and the applicant was arrested.
- The applicant admitted to having sexual intercourse with J.N. but argued it was consensual.
- J.N.'s lawyer requested the applicant's detention, alleging that he was trying to contact J.N. and threatening her to withdraw her complaint.
- The investigating judge opened an investigation on charges of rape but refused to order the applicant's detention due to lack of evidence.
- J.N. gave oral evidence before the investigating judge, reiterating her accusation.
- The Zagreb County State Attorney's Office appealed the refusal to detain the applicant, which was granted and then denied.
- Witnesses were heard, medical reports were commissioned, and evidence was gathered.
- J.N. failed to appear at multiple hearings, causing delays and requests for international legal assistance to establish her whereabouts.
- The trial court found the applicant guilty of rape and sentenced him to one year's imprisonment.
- The Supreme Court quashed the first-instance judgment and ordered a retrial due to the Zagreb County Court's failure to secure J.N.'s presence.
- Another trial was held, J.N. was properly summoned but failed to appear again, and the applicant was found guilty and sentenced to one year's imprisonment.

title: CASE OF ŠTRUKELJ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lived in Ljubljana
- The applicant served his prison sentence in the closed section of Ljubljana prison from 30 March 2009 to 23 December 2009.
- The applicant was held in different cells during this period: 
  - Cells 5 and 7 measured 18 sqm and 16.8 sqm respectively and had 5 sleeping places. 
  - Cell 120 measured 18 sqm and had 6 sleeping places. 
  - Cells 98 and 124 measured 8.8 sqm and had 2 sleeping places. 
- The number of prisoners held in the cells varied.
- The applicant had thirty-three consultations with a general practitioner during his imprisonment, as well as five dental appointments and five treatments by a psychiatrist.
- The data showed that the average temperature in the cells in the late afternoon during July and August 2009 had been approximately 28oC, exceeding 30oC on seven days.
- Sentenced prisoners in the closed section of the prison were locked up in their cells and were only able to leave them if they applied for certain activities, most of which were to take place in the recreation room.

title: CASE OF ČETIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Ljubljana. 
- The applicant served his prison sentence in the closed section of Ljubljana prison from May 28, 2009, to February 27, 2010. 
- He was held in three different cells during his detention: cell 2, cell 129, and cell 121. 
- During his imprisonment, the applicant had three consultations with a general practitioner and one dental appointment. 
- Sentenced prisoners in the closed section of the prison were locked up in their cells and were only able to leave them if they applied for certain activities, most of which were to take place in the recreation room. 
- From 26 October 2009 to 13 January 2010, the applicant was placed under a stricter regime. 
- The average temperature in the cells in the late afternoon (5-5.30 p.m.) in the second half of July and August 2009 had been approximately 28oC, exceeding 30oC on seven days.

title: CASE OF FAZLI ASLANER v. TURKEY [Extracts]
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Ankara. 
- In 1993, the applicant passed a local competitive examination for a post of head registrar but was placed on the reserve list due to insufficient ranking. 
- In 1997, the applicant applied to be appointed to the post of head registrar at the Eskişehir Administrative Court but was refused. 
- The Administrative Court upheld the applicant’s claims, but the Ministry of Justice appealed on points of law against that judgment. 
- The Fifth Administrative Proceedings Division of the Supreme Administrative Court subsequently quashed the judgment. 
- The Administrative Court decided to maintain its initial judgment (ısrar kararı). 
- Following a fresh appeal, the case was referred automatically to the General Assembly of the Administrative Proceedings Divisions of the Supreme Administrative Court (Danıştay İdari Dava Daireleri Genel Kurulu). 
- The General Assembly quashed the judgment delivered by the Administrative Court. 
- The applicant submitted a request for rectification of the General Assembly’s judgment, which was rejected.

title: CASE OF DİLİPAK AND KARAKAYA v. TURKEY [Extracts]
facts:
- Applicants are journalists working for Akit daily newspaper in Istanbul.
- Erkaya family brought a civil action for damages against applicants for articles critical of Admiral Güven Erkaya.
- Applicants' addresses were not found by the postal service but were ascertained by police.
- Judgment was served through publication in the press on one of the applicants.
- Civil Court ordered applicants to jointly pay a sum of 30,000 Turkish liras in damages and interest.
- The judgment was not served on one of the applicants due to the change of address.
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the appeal on points of law against the impugned judgment.
- Applicants sought to reopen the proceedings, citing the new fact that senior army officers had been taken into pre-trial detention for an attempted coup d'état.

title: CASE OF GRANDE STEVENS AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- FIAT signed a financing agreement with eight banks, which stated that the banks could obtain 28% of FIAT's share capital if FIAT failed to reimburse the loan
- Mr Gianluigi Gabetti, chairman of Exor, wanted to ensure Exor remained the controlling shareholder in FIAT and consulted a lawyer specialising in company law, Mr Grande Stevens
- On 12 August 2005, Mr Grande Stevens asked the CONSOB about a possible scenario to avoid a takeover bid, without mentioning Merrill Lynch International Ltd due to confidentiality concerns
- On 23 August 2005, the CONSOB requested information from Exor and Giovanni Agnelli about the expiry of the financing contract and any initiatives taken, and also received a copy of the equity swap contract and negotiations with Merrill Lynch International Ltd
- On 24 August 2005, press releases were issued to reply to the CONSOB's request for information, stating that Exor had not initiated or examined any initiatives, and it wished to remain FIAT's reference shareholder, without mentioning the equity swap contract with Merrill Lynch International Ltd
- From 30 August to 15 September 2005, negotiations continued with Merrill Lynch International Ltd to amend the equity swap contract
- On 17 September 2005, the agreement on amending the equity swap contract was concluded
- On 20 September 2005, FIAT increased its share capital and the new shares were acquired by the eight banks, while Exor continued to hold a 30% stake in FIAT
- On 20 February 2006, the CONSOB accused the applicants of market manipulation and imposed administrative fines and bans on assuming responsibility for listed companies
- The applicants appealed to the Turin Court of Appeal, which reduced some of the penalties but dismissed their other complaints.

title: CASE OF MICROINTELECT OOD v. BULGARIA
facts:
- In 2000, the applicant company entered into contracts with two sole traders to operate a billiards club and electronic games club, respectively.
- Both contracts involved the sale of alcoholic beverages and detailed profit-sharing arrangements.
- The tax authorities carried out inspections at the billiards club and electronic games club in July 2002.
- The inspections revealed that the sole traders were selling alcohol without the requisite licenses, and the authorities impounded alcohol from both clubs.
- The applicant company was not notified of these events, and instead, the sole traders objected and sought judicial review of the impounding.
- The applicant company attempted to intervene in both sets of proceedings as a third party, arguing that it was the owner of the forfeited alcohol, but its applications were denied by the courts.
- The courts found that the impounding of the alcohol could not be challenged separately and that the impounded alcohol had been properly forfeited.
- The courts also found that the contractual relations between the applicant company and the sole traders were irrelevant to the administrative-penal proceedings.

title: CASE OF DURALIYSKI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants are two brothers from Plovdiv born in 1973 and 1983 respectively.
- The applicants were made beneficiaries under their father's life insurance and accident insurance policies in September 2003.
- The father died in June 2004 due to an allergic reaction to a wasp sting.
- The insurance company refused to pay out on the claim, stating that a "wasp sting" was not covered by the accident insurance policy.
- The applicants brought a claim for compensation under the Commerce Act in 2005 and were initially successful.
- The insurance company appealed the decision, claiming that the allergic reaction did not fall under the "accident" category as defined in the insurance policy.
- In May 2006, the Sofia City Court dismissed the applicants' claim on the grounds that no copy of the insurance policy had been produced and that the circumstances could not be properly established.

title: CASE OF GORBULYA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of facts in bullet points are:

- The applicant was born in 1973 and lived until his arrest in St. Petersburg. He is serving a sentence of life imprisonment.
- On 18 May 2006, the Kalininskiy District Court of St. Petersburg found the applicant guilty of unintentional manslaughter and sentenced him to ten years’ imprisonment.
- On 10 December 2008, the St. Petersburg City Court, by the jury verdict, found the applicant guilty of several counts of aggravated robbery and murder and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- From 23 December 2002 to 8 October 2010, the applicant was detained in temporary detention facility IZ-47/1 in St. Petersburg, known as “Kresty”.
- The conditions of the applicant's detention in Kresty were extremely overcrowded, with cells accommodating from five to nine inmates, and consisted of cells that did not have a table or chair and a concrete platform served as a bed.
- The applicant lacked privacy even when using the toilet, had limited ventilation, and it was extremely cold in winter.
- The appellate court upheld the sentence, and the applicant's detention conditions were challenged numerous times with minor improvements.
- From 10 December 2008 until 8 October 2010, the applicant was kept in solitary confinement, alone in 8-square-metre cells equipped with two sleeping places, after which he was transferred to correctional facility IK-56.
- Until 28 June 2012, the applicant was detained in cells measuring 18 square metres and shared a cell with another inmate.
- The applicant was allowed a daily walk of no more than two hours in one of the five recreation yards.

title: CASE OF ALLAHVERDIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant, born in 1985 and living in Baku, was a student at the Azerbaijan State Oil Academy at the time of the events.
- He and his girlfriend, accompanied by three other persons, travelled from Baku to Ganja to get married there on 15 March 2008.
- On the same day, the father of the applicant's girlfriend lodged a complaint with the police alleging that his daughter had been kidnapped.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on 16 March 2008 on the basis of the complaint.
- On 17 March 2008, the applicant returned to Baku and was arrested on 19 March 2008 upon voluntarily presenting himself to the police station.
- On 21 March 2008, the Narimanov District Court remanded the applicant in custody for a period of three months.
- On 3 April 2008, the Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the Narimanov District Court’s decision of 21 March 2008.
- On 14 June 2008, the Narimanov District Court extended the applicant's remand in custody by one month.
- On 20 June 2008, the Baku Court of Appeal upheld the Narimanov District Court’s decision.
- On 29 July 2008, the Assize Court held a preliminary hearing and rejected the applicant's request to replace his remand in custody with another preventive measure.
- On 19 March 2009, the Assize Court found the applicant guilty of kidnapping together with a group of persons and sentenced him to two years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF ABDU v. BULGARIA [Extracts]
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant and his friend were involved in a fight with two Bulgarian youths outside a shopping centre in Sofia.
- The two Bulgarian youths fled before the police arrived, but were arrested and remanded in custody for breach of the peace.
- The police initiated a preliminary investigation and interviewed the parties involved and an eyewitness.
- The applicant claimed that the fight started because the Bulgarians insulted them by calling them “Negros” and brandished a knife.
- M.V. claimed that the fight started because one of the Sudanese youths had shoved him with his shoulder.
- R.G. confirmed that one of the Sudanese men had pushed his friend and that blows had been exchanged on both sides, and M.V. had his face bloodied.
- The eyewitness stated that he had seen one of the Bulgarians trip up one of the Sudanese men.
- The applicant had injuries, including a swollen nose and finger, and a contusion to the knee. The injuries were caused by blows struck by blunt instruments and could have been occasioned in the course of a fight.
- The public prosecutor decided not to bring a criminal prosecution for racist violence because it had not been established that M.V. and R.G. had acted for reasons linked to the applicant’s and his friend’s racial origins.
- The higher prosecutor confirmed the district prosecutor’s decision to not prosecute.
- The applicant's lawyer requested a copy of the criminal case file, but the district prosecutor refused to supply the copies.

title: CASE OF GÁL v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on charges of aggravated fraud and other crimes.
- The Pest Central District Court ordered the applicant’s detention on remand.
- The Budapest Regional Court upheld the first-instance decision.
- The investigating judge of the Pest Central District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 27 March 2008.
- The applicant’s pre-trial detention was prolonged at statutory intervals.
- The Budapest Regional Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention for two months.
- The pre-trial detention was terminated on 16 December 2011.
- The applicant was found guilty of fraud, corruption, misappropriation of public funds, abuse of power, and forgery of private documents.

title: CASE OF MÁTRAINÉ TÖRŐ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant was a professional staff member of the Hungarian Police since 1994.
- The applicant was warned in early 1997 that her employment might be terminated in a few months.
- The applicant was interviewed at another police department and found suitable for a new position within the counter-terrorism unit.
- From 1998 onwards, the applicant was ordered to undergo, annually, a medical aptitude test of a kind different from what she had formerly been subjected to.
- On 13 February 2001, the applicant commenced her regular annual medical examination but, by the order of her supervisor, she interrupted the test.
- Subsequently, the applicant was ordered to take part, afresh, in another medical examination on 27 May 2001.
- As a result of the latter examination, she was qualified as ‘unfit’ for the position she held and dismissed from service.
- On 28 February 2002, the applicant lodged an action with the labour court claiming that her employment had been unlawfully terminated.
- The Budapest Labour Court found for the applicant on 21 September 2005 and ordered the employer to pay compensation.
- On appeal, the Budapest Regional Court quashed the first-instance decision and remitted the case to the Labour Court on 14 April 2006.
- In the resumed proceedings, the Labour Court rejected the applicant’s action on 16 January 2008.
- On appeal, the Regional Court upheld this decision on 15 October 2008.
- The Supreme Court confirmed the second-instance decision on 7 April 2010.

title: CASE OF MALYUGIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and lived in St Petersburg.
- On 19 May 2006, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of organizing a criminal gang and placed in a poorly maintained IVS.
- The applicant's detention was authorized by domestic courts on the following day and was regularly extended until his release.
- On 1 June 2006, the applicant was transferred to a remand prison IZ-47/1 in St Petersburg, which was overcrowded.
- The applicant was regularly transported by prison van between the remand prison and the court premises to participate in the hearings.
- On 19 May 2011, the St. Petersburg City Court ordered to release the applicant and on 14 June 2011 acquitted him of all charges.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDR VLADIMIROVICH SMIRNOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and lives in the Russian Federation.
- On 5 December 2002, the applicant was stopped by the police and detained in a holding facility for vagrants on the grounds of lack of identity documents.
- The applicant was detained and held alternately in various facilities until 23 December 2002, and was questioned off the record about his alleged involvement with a terrorist group plotting to instigate a revolt to reinstate a communist state. During those question sessions, the applicant was beaten and tortured.
- The applicant was examined by a medical specialist who noted that he had no bodily injuries. On arrival at the Kakhovka police temporary detention facility, a medical expert recorded no bodily injuries and noted that the applicant had made no complaints of ill-treatment.
- The applicant was questioned as a witness in connection with unidentified proceedings. He explained that he was a member of a Russian-based NGO and was in Ukraine to distribute their newspaper and other materials, participate in public activities organised by opposition political forces in Ukraine, and promote networking with local leftist groups.
- The applicant participated in a confrontation with a resident who confirmed having communicated with the applicant’s associates and having received the newspaper.
- The applicant was arrested in Mykolayiv on suspicion of a terrorist offence and was subsequently remanded in custody following a court order.
- The applicant signed documents confirming that he understood his rights as a suspect.
- The applicant was indicted for membership of a terrorist group and participation in a terrorist act.
- The applicant was found guilty of affiliation with a criminal association plotting the reinstatement of a communist state in Ukraine by violent means, distribution of the newspaper and participation in a terrorist act. He was sentenced to eight years’ imprisonment.
- The conditions of the applicant’s detention were inadequate, according to him.

title: CASE OF BERGER v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was held in remand prison IZ-42/2 in the Kemerovo Region from 1 March 2005 to 21 September 2011.
2. The prison was overcrowded and cell 219 was designed for 12 people but housed up to 18 individuals.
3. The applicant was isolated from other detainees and kept in virtually solitary confinement since October 2011.
4. The applicant claimed that on several occasions he had been beaten by prison wardens.
5. The applicant was transferred from the remand prison to a prison hospital to undergo medical treatment from 12 June to 7 September 2005, from 29 October to 27 November 2009 and from 7 to 15 December 2010.
6. The applicant complained to the regional prosecutor about the conditions of his detention and challenged the prosecutor's reply before the courts.
7. On 28 April 2011, the Kuznetskiy District Court of Novokuznetsk rejected the applicant's claims.
8. On 21 June 2011, the Kemerovo Regional Court upheld the above judgment on appeal.

title: CASE OF ZINCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983.
- In December 2002, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of involvement in violent crimes committed by members of the Odessa Komsomol seeking to revive the communist state by violent means.
- The applicant signed a waiver of his right to legal assistance during his questioning as a suspect and his confrontation with G.
- The applicant was indicted for membership of a criminal association planning a revolutionary war against the constitutional order and for participating in two fund-raising robberies for the benefit of the organization.
- The applicant was transported to the Odessa no. 21 pre-trial detention centre on 23 February 2003, where he remained in detention until November 2005.
- The applicant often felt exhausted during the trial because of poor detention conditions, lack of catering arrangements, and sleep deprivation.
- On 19 July 2004, the Regional Court found the applicant guilty of belonging to a criminal association as a member of which he had taken part in two armed robberies.
- On 26 July 2005, the Supreme Court held a hearing in the applicant's case, acquitted him of having set a vehicle on fire, and upheld the other convictions.
- In November 2005, the applicant was transported to the Gubnyk colony to serve his sentence.

title: CASE OF ANDREY YAKOVENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lived in Odessa. He is currently serving a prison sentence in Ukraine.
- In summer 2002 the applicant ran for the Odessa Regional Council and, following the election campaign, the State Security Service of Ukraine (“SSU”) put in place secret surveillance measures against him.
- On 15 December 2002, the SSU arrested the applicant in Odessa on suspicion of having organized a criminal group formed of Komsomol members and having planned and directed several violent crimes committed by its members.
- On the afternoon of 16 December 2002, the applicant signed a notice of his rights as a suspect and expressed the wish to have a lawyer.
- On the same date, the applicant was questioned and denied having taken part or having been aware of any criminal activity by these individuals.
- The applicant was remanded in custody and transferred to Mykolayiv pre-trial detention center (SIZO).
- On 21 December 2002, a lawyer was admitted to the proceedings as the applicant’s representative.
- On 25 December 2002, the applicant was indicted on a number of charges, including organizing and directing a terrorist group with a view to re-establishing a communist state by violent means.
- During the trial, the applicant acknowledged that he had supported communist ideas and had taken part in publishing and distributing propaganda.
- The applicant also complained about the conditions of his detention, including inadequate medical care and lack of privacy, and alleged that he and his co-defendants had been subjected to ill-treatment.

title: CASE OF KIISA v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant filed for divorce and division of joint property on October 10, 2003.
- The defendant submitted his arguments on January 15, 2004.
- Several preliminary hearings took place between April 2004 and January 2006.
- The Harju County Court delivered a partial judgment in September 2006 and a final judgment in January 2013 concerning the division of joint property.
- Both parties lodged appeals with the Supreme Court, which refused to hear the case on August 1, 2013.

title: CASE OF ZHULIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- On 10 December 2008, the applicant was charged with aggravated fraud and was remanded in custody.
- On 4 February 2010, the Arzamas Town Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to five years and six months in prison and a fine.
- The applicant appealed the verdict, citing procedural irregularities and incorrect evaluation of evidence.
- On 9 April 2010, the Nizhniy Novgorod Regional Court upheld the verdict, but reduced the sentence by one month.
- The applicant was held in the temporary detention centre of Arzamas in the Nizhniy Novgorod Region for various periods, regularly being taken in and out of custody to attend court or receive medical care.
- The applicant was held in a cell measuring 5.3 sq. m in the basement of the detention centre along with another inmate, with no window, table, or bench, and a toilet that was not partitioned from the rest of the cell. Outside exercise was not available.
- The applicant filed an action regarding the poor conditions of detention, and the Arzamas Town Court ruled that the conditions were subpar and violated Russian law.

title: CASE OF KIISA v. ESTONIA
facts:
- Two applicants, one from Tallinn and one from Luiste village, Rapla County, were married from 1989 to 2006.
- The first applicant gave birth to their child K. on 20 September 2002, and the second applicant was listed as the child's father on the civil status records.
- The divorce and division of marital property were lodged on 10 October 2003.
- Alimony was sought for the child on 25 October 2004, which led to preliminary hearings and requests for evidence.
- The second applicant, on 27 April 2005, requested a separate action to contest the civil status record and establish that he is not the father of the child.
- The alimony proceedings were suspended on 14 October 2005 until the filiation action's judgment was delivered.
- DNA analyses of the child and the second applicant have been ordered, but the mother did not take the child for testing, while the filiation action was, in the end, dismissed on 10 May 2012.
- On 14 June 2007, the first applicant requested the resumption of alimony proceedings, which was granted on 20 June 2007, followed by a compromise proposal and evidentiary submissions of the parties between September and November 2007.
- On 11 January 2008, the Harju County Court ordered the second applicant to pay EEK 3,000 (EUR 192) monthly in alimony, which was upheld by the Tallinn Court of Appeal on 9 May 2008.
- The Supreme Court quashed the Court of Appeal's judgment on 19 November 2008 and remitted the case for a new examination to the first-instance court.
- The case continued with the first applicant amending her statement of claim, interim measures being ordered, new evidence submitted, and a hearing on 3 June 2010.
- Finally, on 6 October 2010, the Tallinn Court of Appeal set the monthly alimony amount at EEK 3,550 (EUR 227), which was challenged but refused leave to appeal on 26 January 2011.

title: CASE OF KARBYSHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was found guilty of inflicting grave bodily harm which caused the death of the victim and was sentenced to a prison term.

- The applicant appealed, claiming that the proceedings had been unfair and that the court had applied domestic law and assessed the evidence erroneously.

- The Irkutsk Regional Court quashed the conviction on appeal and remitted the case to the first-instance court for a fresh examination.

- The Ust-Ilimsk Town Court found the applicant guilty of the same offence and gave him a custodial sentence.

- The applicant alleged that the Town Court had applied domestic law and assessed the evidence erroneously, and that it had rejected the majority of the motions lodged by the defence.

- The applicant complained about the change of his counsel during the proceedings.

- The Irkutsk Regional Court rejected the applicant’s complaint and upheld the judgment on appeal.

- The applicant was detained in severely overcrowded remand prison IZ-38/2 of the Irkutsk Region from 26 September 2005 to 9 January 2009.

- The applicant claimed he had contracted tuberculosis during his stay at the remand prison.

- The applicant was transferred to a different prison and a penitentiary medical facility for treatment of his tuberculosis at different times.

title: CASE OF VERSHININ v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Irkutsk.
- The applicant was held in the temporary detention facility (IVS) of Angarsk in the Irkutsk Region during several periods between 21 May and 11 December 2008.
- The IVS was severely overcrowded, with up to eight detainees occupying a 12 sq. m cell.
- The cell was not equipped with either tables or benches.
- Bed linen was not distributed, and drinking water and daily walks were not available.
- The Irkutsk Regional Prosecutor acknowledged that the conditions of the applicant’s detention violated the relevant domestic legislation between May 2008 and May 2009, in response to the applicant’s complaint.

title: CASE OF STAROKADOMSKIY v. RUSSIA (No. 2)
facts:
• The applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder on January 31, 1998.

• On February 6, 1998, the applicant was charged with aggravated murder.

• Other individuals were also accused of violent crimes and the proceedings were joined into one case.

• The applicant studied the case file in June and July of 1999 and requested a trial by a jury.

• On 19 July 1999, the case was submitted to the City Court for trial.

• The City Court decided to send an inquiry to the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation as there were no juries in the City Court.

• The proceedings were suspended pending a decision by the Constitutional Court on 17 February 2000.

• On 13 April 2000, the Constitutional Court ruled that the change of venue was incompatible with the Russian Constitution.

• The case file was returned to the Supreme Court, which decided on 6 September 2000 that the City Court was competent to try the case.

• The first hearing was scheduled on 13 October 2000 before a bench consisting of a professional judge and two lay judges.

• The trial judge ordered that the applicant be removed from the courtroom on 12 March 2003 for contempt of court during the reading out of the indictment.

• The trial bench, presiding judge M, and lay judges O and L found the applicant guilty of conspiracy to commit murder, among other offenses, on 27 October 2004, and sentenced him to ten and a half years’ imprisonment.

• The Supreme Court upheld the conviction on 15 November 2005 but reduced the applicant’s sentence to ten years’ imprisonment.

• The applicant brought several proceedings under Article 125 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

title: CASE OF DANILOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 in the Russian Federation and is currently serving a prison sentence in Ukraine.
- In December 2002, the applicant and three of his acquaintances were implicated in a number of crimes committed as members of a criminal association affiliated with the Odessa Komsomol, including illegal arms handling, terrorism, assault, and robbery with a view to preparing a communist revolution.
- The applicant and another associate started shooting at the officers with firearms when six armed officers of the SSU and two officers of the “Berkut” unit arrived at a flat in Mykolayiv occupied at the material time by the applicant and three of his acquaintances, and ordered them to lie on the floor. As a result of the shooting, several officers sustained bodily injuries and damage to their protective gear.
- The applicant was suspected, in particular, of attempting to murder law-enforcement officers.
- The applicant complained of being beaten by police officers in the evening of 13 December and the morning of 14 December 2002.
- The Leninskyy police collected reports from eight police officers who had been on duty on 13 December 2002 by way of an internal investigation of the applicant’s ill-treatment allegations.
- On 15 January 2003, the applicant was diagnosed with suspected accumulation of blood in the pleural cavity (hemothorax), dystrophy, and post-traumatic neuropathy of the wrists, and prescribed treatment.
- On 19 July 2004, the Regional Court convicted the applicant of distribution of materials propagating violent revolt against the constitutional order; membership of a criminal association; several armed robberies; attempted murder of police officers; smuggling; and illegal handling of firearms and explosives. The applicant was sentenced to fourteen years’ imprisonment.
- On 26 July 2005, the Supreme Court upheld the applicant’s conviction and sentence in principle, having made some amendments to the text.

title: CASE OF PAKSHAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in the Tyumen region.
- On 2 May 1997, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder.
- He was given a written note explaining his rights.
- The applicant was questioned at 6.30 p.m. on the same day without a lawyer and was threatened to confess.
- The arrest record was read out to him at 8.20 p.m. on the same day.
- On 3 May 1997, the applicant was brought to the scene of the crime where he repeated his confession and gave details of the murder without a lawyer.
- On 8 May 1997, the applicant was provided with a lawyer.
- At the trial, the applicant retracted his confession and denied the murder.
- He was convicted of murder and sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment on 15 January 2001.
- The reliance on the applicant’s confession statement was lawful according to the Khanty-Mansiskiy Regional Court on 18 October 2006.

title: CASE OF ÖCALAN v. TURKEY (No. 2) [Extracts]
facts:
- The applicant, a Turkish national, was born in 1949 and is currently held in İmralı Prison.
- The applicant was arrested by the Turkish security forces in an aircraft in the international area of Nairobi airport on 15 February 1999.
- On 23 February 1999, the applicant appeared before a judge of the Ankara National Security Court, who ordered that he should be detained pending trial.
- By a judgment of 29 June 1999, the Ankara National Security Court found the applicant guilty of carrying out acts designed to bring about the secession of part of Turkey’s territory and of leading a gang of armed terrorists for that purpose, and sentenced him to death under Article 125 of the Criminal Code.
- By Law no. 4771, published on 9 August 2002, the Turkish Grand National Assembly abolished the death penalty in peacetime (that is to say except in time of war or of imminent threat of war) and made the necessary amendments to the relevant legislation, including the Criminal Code.
- By a judgment of 3 October 2002, the Ankara National Security Court commuted the applicant’s death sentence to life imprisonment.
- In May 2007 and January 2010, delegations from the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture and Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment (“CPT”) visited İmralı Prison.
- Before 17 November 2009, the applicant’s cell which he occupied alone measured approximately 13 sq. m, and the time granted to him to leave his cell and use the exercise yard (measuring approximately 45 sq. m), which is walled in and covered with mesh, was limited to one hour daily.
- Since 17 November 2009, the applicant has been on his own in a cell with an area of 9.8 sq. m (living space), with a further 2 sq. m of sanitary facilities, comprising a bed, a small table, two chairs, a metal cupboard, and a kitchenette with a washbasin.
- The applicant apparently spends a great deal of time outside his cell, depending on his choice of collective activity, up to a maximum of 38 hours per week, including a maximum of ten hours in the company of the other prisoners.
- Since 20 March 2010, the applicant, like the other İmralı inmates, has been allowed ten minutes’ telephone calls to the outside every fortnight.

title: CASE OF SZABO AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1962, 1964, and 1974 and lived in Târgu Mureş.
- On 15 January 1997, a criminal investigation was opened against them and two others, and on 4 April 1997, they were indicted for trespassing, inflicting grievous bodily harm causing the death of the victim, and making false statements to the police.
- The Mureş County Court adjourned the proceedings nine times between 13 May 1997 and 21 April 1998.
- The applicants were convicted of inflicting grievous bodily harm causing the death of the victim and trespassing on 5 June 1998.
- The applicants and the prosecutor appealed against the judgment.
- The Târgu Mureş Court of Appeal sent the case back for a new retrial on the merits on 16 May 2001.
- The proceedings were adjourned eleven times between 23 October 2001 and 17 September 2002.
- The Mureş County Court decided to change the legal classification of the crimes to aggravated murder on 29 November 2002.
- The Târgu Mureş Court of Appeal upheld the judgment delivered by the Mureş County Court on 22 April 2003, convicting the applicants of inflicting grievous bodily harm causing the death of the victim and trespassing.
- The High Court of Cassation and Justice remitted the case to the Court of Appeal on 17 June 2004.
- The Târgu Mureş Court of Appeal convicted the applicants of the crime of aggravated murder on 19 April 2005.
- The High Court of Justice and Cassation convicted the applicants of the crime of murder on 9 November 2005, and the rest of the provisions of the judgment delivered on 22 April 2003 by the Mureş County Court were upheld.

title: CASE OF STOYANOV-KOBULADZE v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963.
- The applicant was convicted twice of fraud, in 1986 and in 1987.
- Until 1992, the applicant lived in the town of Gabrovo. From 27 May 1992 onwards, he lived at an address in Sofia.
- On 26 October 1993, the applicant registered as a sole trader. The applicant did not engage in any business activities until 1995.
- In 1995, in particular from 20 April to 17 May, on the territory of the town of Varna and in his capacity as a sole trader, the applicant developed a quasi-banking activity.
- On 17 May 1995, the applicant left Bulgaria and moved to Georgia, where he married a Georgian national in 1997. He has two children.
- On an unspecified date in 1995, but after the applicant’s departure from the country, criminal proceedings were instituted against him and an accomplice on charges of large-scale fraud.
- On an unspecified date, an indictment was filed at Varna District Court. The proceedings were conducted in the absence of the applicant and his accomplice.
- In a judgment of 28 October 1996, the Varna District Court found the applicant guilty of fraud and sentenced him to a ten-year term of imprisonment.
- No appeal was lodged against the judgment and it became final on 11 November 1996.
- On 22 October 2004, the applicant was arrested at the Bulgarian border and taken to Kremikovtsi Prison to serve his sentence.
- On 1 July 2005, the applicant submitted a request to the Supreme Court of Cassation for reopening and suspension of his sentence.
- In a decision of 13 January 2006, the Supreme Court of Cassation terminated the proceedings on the grounds that the case file had been destroyed and a procedure for its restoration would need to be instituted.
- On 12 April 2007, the Supreme Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant’s request for reopening and suspension of his sentence as ill-founded.
- The applicant was released from prison on 31 March 2011 after serving six years and five months of his sentence.

title: CASE OF MEMISHAJ v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1944 and worked as an accountant for Tirana City Hall.
- On 10 December 2001, he was dismissed from his job, which was later quashed by CSC.
- Following a final decision of the Supreme Court, the applicant was offered employment on 10 March 2006.
- The Tirana District Court ordered the city hall to pay the applicant’s salary for the period between 10 December 2001 and the date of reinstatement in May 2003.
- In 2003, an enforcement writ was issued in respect of both decisions.
- On 31 March 2006, the Constitutional Court acknowledged that there had been a breach of the applicant’s right of access to court on account of the non-enforcement of the Supreme Court’s decision.
- On 10 March 2006, the Tirana City Hall appointed the applicant to a position in a maintenance company.
- The CSC quashed the appointment decision on 15 May 2006.
- In 2004 and 2006, the applicant sought the payment of accrued interest arising from the delay in the payment of his salary.
- On 9 April 2008, the Tirana District Court found in the applicant’s favour and ordered the Tirana City Hall to pay the applicant salary arrears and accrued interest.
- On 31 March 2010, the Tirana City Hall paid the salary arrears.
- On an unspecified date in 2010, the applicant lodged a fourth civil action seeking the payment of accrued interest for the period between 9 April 2008 and 31 March 2010 and the payment of social security contributions by the Tirana City Hall.
- On 30 June 2010, the Tirana District Court found in his favour and ordered the Tirana City Hall to pay accrued interest and social security contributions.

title: CASE OF BODOR v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Velké Dravce, Slovakia.
- The applicant and his former spouse found employment in Hungary and settled there in 2004.
- Their child was born in Hatvan, Hungary, in 2007.
- The wife lodged a divorce action and a custody claim with the Hungarian Hatvan District Court on 18 June 2008.
- The applicant filed an objection contesting the jurisdiction of the Hungarian courts.
- The District Court held a hearing and dismissed the case, accepting the applicant’s argument.
- The Hungarian Heves County Regional Court quashed the first-instance decision on 19 February 2009.
- The District Court rejected the applicant’s jurisdictional objection on 10 March 2010.
- The first hearing on the merits was held by the Hatvan District Court on 5 October 2010 in the absence of the applicant.
- On 28 April 2011 the Hatvan District Court dissolved the applicant’s marriage and ordered him to pay child maintenance.
- The Hungarian Eger High Court upheld the first-instance decision on 15 February 2012.
- The applicant lodged a petition for review, which was rejected on 14 May 2013.

title: CASE OF SÁRA ANNA KOVÁCS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Siófok.
- On 11 January 2002, the applicant was dismissed from the civil service.
- On 20 February 2002, the applicant challenged her dismissal before the Budapest Labour Court.
- On 15 May 2003, the court found for the applicant, establishing that her dismissal had been unlawful, and awarded her compensation.
- On 17 March 2004, the Budapest Regional Court upheld in essence the first-instance decision, increased the award, but dismissed the remainder of the applicant’s compensation claims and remitted the case to the first-instance court as to the applicant’s claim regarding the amount of certain additional allowances.
- On 5 September 2005, the Supreme Court annulled the second-instance decision and remitted the case to the Labour Court.
- In the resumed proceedings, on 7 June 2007, the Labour Court dismissed the applicant’s action.
- On 29 October 2008, the Budapest Regional Court reversed the first-instance decision and awarded compensation to the applicant.
- This decision was upheld by the Supreme Court on 31 March 2010.
- The applicant’s further pecuniary claims, also originating in the labour dispute, were finally adjudicated on 16 January 2013 by the Budapest High Court.

title: CASE OF LAMBERTNÉ BÁRSONY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and resides in Miskolc.
- On 20 April 1998, the applicant filed a lawsuit to divide the common-law property with Mr F.
- The case was initially heard by the Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén County Court, then on appeal by the Debrecen Court of Appeal. 
- The Supreme Court issued the final verdict on March 2, 2010.

title: CASE OF RAKSSÁNYI v. HUNGARY
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1942 and resides in Hévíz.
• A case was brought against the applicant in 2001 by a plaintiff who demanded the payment of some unpaid dues or fees.
• The case went through first and second instance judgment.
• On 20 January 2011, the Supreme Court reached the final decision in the case.

title: CASE OF ABBAS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant's year of birth is 1959 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant was involved in a civil proceeding related to the division of matrimonial property.
- The legal action began on February 14, 2004, before the Budapest IV/XV District Court.
- The case was continued before the Budapest Regional Court and concluded on March 9, 2010, with the Supreme Court's decision.

title: CASE OF WARE v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1952 and lives in Hegyesd.
- Dispute: Trespass dispute.
- Legal Action: Applicant brought an action before the Tapolca District Court on 15 April 2001.
- Judicial Decisions: Veszprém County Regional Court and the Supreme Court rendered decisions in the case.
- Final Judgment: Supreme Court served a final judgment on the applicant's lawyer on 12 August 2009.

title: CASE OF LAKAT v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Dabas.
- The applicant's father brought an action in compensation and other claims before the Pest Central District Court in 1985.
- The applicant joined the litigation in 1986.
- The case was interrupted multiple times between 1995 and 2004 due to the deaths of respondents.
- The applicant's father died in 2007, and the court again interrupted the proceedings pending the entry into litigation of the successor, who was later found to be the applicant herself.
- The case is still pending before the Pest Central District Court.

title: CASE OF BARNA v. HUNGARY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Budapest.
- On 25 January 2006, the applicant brought an action in compensation in the context of water damage in her condominium.
- On 18 March 2010, the Buda Central District Court found for the applicant after holding several hearings and obtaining expert evidence.
- On 6 October 2010, the Budapest Regional Court reversed this judgment.
- On 2 June 2011, the Supreme Court rejected the applicant's petition for review without an examination on the merits, since it did not meet the statutory requirements.

title: CASE OF WALCH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Budapest. 
- In August 2006, the applicant filed a case for unlawful dismissal and damages before the Pest County Labour Court. 
- The case went through a first-instance and second-instance judgment. 
- On 17 September 2013, the highest court, Kúria, gave a final judgment in part of the claims and remitted the rest to the first-instance court. 
- As of now, the case is still pending.

title: CASE OF KULCSÁR v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Debrecen. 
- The applicant was party as creditor to liquidation proceedings 
- The proceedings started before the Hajdú-Bihar-County County Regional Court on 12 March 1999 
- The case was terminated by the Debrecen Court of Appeal on 24 October 2007 (service: 29 November 2007).

title: CASE OF BARTHA v. HUNGARY
facts:
A. The Circumstances of the Case:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Budapest.
- The case concerns a warranty dispute initiated by the applicant on 5 April 1993.
- The case was first heard by the Buda II/III District Court.
- After a remittal, on 23 May 2002 the District Court gave judgment.
- Site inspections were carried out in the applicant's flat during the proceedings.
- The applicant failed to attend several hearings and did not co-operate with the experts working on the case.
- On appeal, on 17 January 2007 the Budapest Regional Court decided on the case.
- This judgment was served on the applicant on 31 January 2007.

B. Relevant Domestic Law:
- Act no. III of 1952 on the Code of Civil Procedure, as amended by Act no. XIX of 2006 provides the complaint procedures for protraction of proceedings.
- A written complaint can be filed with the court hearing the case.
- Complaints can be filed where the law prescribes a time-limit for the court, and it has elapsed without any result.
- Complaints can also be filed where the court has failed to comply with its obligation to complete the proceedings within a reasonable time.
- Complaints cannot be filed against orders related to evidentiary acts or decisions subject to a separate legal remedy.
- The court hearing the case shall examine the complaint within eight days from its receipt.
- The court can take appropriate measures to terminate the situation complained of within thirty days.
- If the court finds the complaint ill-founded, it shall transmit the complaint to the adverse party who may file observations on it within eight days from its receipt.
- A complaint challenging an omission of the district court shall be adjudicated by the regional court sitting in a committee of three professional judges.

title: CASE OF BRYDA v. POLAND
facts:
- Applicant applied for early-retirement pension for persons raising seriously ill children requiring constant care
- Applicant had worked for 21 years and paid social security contributions
- Applicant submitted medical certificate from specialist doctor stating that her child suffered from mild intellectual disability and required constant care
- Applicant was granted pension initially but was later discontinued due to doctor's report
- Applicant appealed against the decision and lost in all instances of domestic court
- Applicant resigned from employment to receive pension and was unemployed without benefit after revocation of pension
- Applicant's income in 2003 was 19.17% of the average salary in Poland at the relevant time.

title: CASE OF CONTOLORU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and was the director of a local bank branch.
- On 25 August 2003, the applicant was arrested and charged with several economic crimes such as approving loans without respecting the legal requirements, abuse of office, fraud, forgery and conspiracy to commit crimes.
- On 27 July 2007, the applicant was acquitted of all the charges against him by the Sibiu County Court which was finally upheld by a judgment of the High Court of Cassation and Justice on 2 November 2011.
- The investigating prosecutor requested the Gorj County Court to confirm the applicant's pre-trial detention for a total period of thirty days.
- The applicant appealed against all the decisions extending his pre-trial detention, alleging that there was not enough evidence from which to acquire a reasonable suspicion that he had committed the offences, and there was no proof that if released he would present a danger to public order.

title: CASE OF MATYTSINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Khabarovsk.
- In 1997 the Department of Justice of the Irkutsk Region registered a non-profit non-governmental association, “The Art of Living”.
- The association operated without a license, but was told by the Committee that it did not require one.
- Ms S.D., a participant in the association's program, experienced serious psychological problems which resulted in hospitalization and was attributed to her participation in the program.
- Investigations were conducted and various expert opinions were given, but no conclusive answer was given on whether or not the association's activities were considered medical and required a license. The applicant was eventually charged.

title: CASE OF ENACHE v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts are:

- The applicant was born in 1977 and is currently detained in Giurgiu Prison.
- In a final judgment by the Dolj County Court, the applicant was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder.
- The material conditions of detention in Craiova Prison were described by the applicant as being inhuman and degrading.
- The applicant alleged that those conditions had had a negative impact on his physical and psychological well-being.
- The Government’s account states that the applicant was held alone in a cell measuring 9.03 sq. m, in which three rows of bunk beds were installed each measuring 1.90 m by 0.80 m. 
- The applicant alleged a severe lack of drinking water, and of hot and cold water in general.
- The heating was provided for only two hours in the morning and two in the evening, which was not enough to heat the cell. 
- The food was insufficient and of very poor quality.
- There was not enough light in the cell.
- The applicant was systematically handcuffed every time he was taken out of his cell.
- The applicant alleged that the conditions in the prison had led to chronic depressive psychopathy and gastritis and duodenitis.
- The applicant was transferred to Poarta Albă Prison and subsequently to Giurgiu Prison.
- The applicant declared that he no longer wished to correspond with the E.C.H.R.
- The applicant claimed that authorities continuously refused to ensure that his correspondence reached the Court, even threatening him.

title: CASE OF LULI AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
