1. Three applications lodged with the Court by the same applicants
2. Case was divided into three applications
3. Applicants have inherited property rights to multiple plots of land
4. Restoration and compensation decisions were made by Durrës Restitution and Compensation of Properties Commission and Durrës Regional Agency 
5. Decisions were quashed and remitted for re-examination 
6. Proceedings pending before Tirana District Court 
7. Applicant brought civil proceedings for vacation of property 
8. Court ruled against applicant and recognized others as legal owner 
9. Applicant lodged civil action seeking nullity of legal acts, but was found to have no locus standi by Court of Appeal and Supreme Court

title: CASE OF AUREL RĂDULESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Jilava Prison.
- On 11 October 2011, the applicant was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment by the High Court of Cassation and Justice.
- Since 23 September 2009, the applicant has been detained in various detention centers, including Bucharest police station, Rahova and Jilava Prisons.
- The applicant alleged that he had been kept in overcrowded cells in poor conditions of hygiene and detained with inmates who smoked inside the cell in all three prisons. He claimed that his health had deteriorated and he had been diagnosed with tuberculosis.
- The government provided details on the surface area of each cell and the number of detainees in each cell where the applicant was detained.

title: CASE OF BOKAL v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant instituted civil proceedings against M.P. and N.M regarding the validity of a sale contract.
- The court rejected the applicant’s proposal to enter a note on dispute in the Land Register.
- The Ljubljana Higher Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the decision of 20 August 1997.
- The case was reported to the Ministry that the case could not be given priority.
- The applicant requested the court to schedule a hearing in April 1998.
- The applicant requested the court to give priority to her claims which she lodged with the court in March 2000.
- A third party intervener joined the proceedings in June 2000.
- The court issued its judgment partially upholding the applicant’s claim in June 2004.
- The Ljubljana Higher Court returned the file to the first instance court in December 2005.
- The judgment of 4 June 2004 and the applicant’s appeal were served on the first defendant by posting them on the court’s notice board in March 2006.
- The Ljubljana Local Court dismissed the applicant’s request for an interim order in March 2006.
- The Ljubljana Higher Court dismissed the applicant’s appeals against the judgment of 4 June 2004 and the decision of 20 March 2006 in June 2006.
- The Supreme Court rejected the applicant’s appeal on points of law on procedural grounds in October 2008.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional appeal in November 2009.

title: CASE OF BEGANOVIC v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lives in Semič.
- The applicant served his prison sentence in Ljubljana prison from 1 July 2009 to 4 November 2009.
- Between 1 July 2009 and 23 September 2009, the applicant was held in the closed section of Ljubljana prison.
- From 23 September 2009 to 4 November 2009, the applicant was held in the semi-open section of Ljubljana prison.
- All cells in the closed and semi-open sections had five sleeping places and one double casement window.
- Sentenced prisoners in the closed section of the prison were locked up in their cells and were only able to leave them if they applied for certain activities.
- The cell doors in the semi-open section of the prison were unlocked, except during specific hours at night.
- From 9 December 2009 to 1 April 2010, the applicant was held in the closed section of the Section Novo mesto.
- During his imprisonment, the applicant had three consultations with a general practitioner and one psychiatric treatment.
- The average temperature in the cells in the late afternoon in the second half of July and August 2009 had been approximately 28oC, exceeding 30oC on seven days.

title: CASE OF SLEMENŠEK v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and lived in Brežice.
- The applicant served his prison sentence in the closed and semi-open sections of Ljubljana prison from 29 February 2008 to 29 December 2010.
- The applicant was held in the closed section from 29 February 2008 to 11 July 2008, from 20 October 2008 to 3 February 2009, and from 14 July 2009 to 29 December 2010.
- The applicant was held in the semi-open section from 11 July 2008 to 20 October 2008 and from 3 February 2009 to 14 July 2009.
- The cells in the closed and semi-open sections contained five sleeping places and one window. According to the applicant, five prisoners were being held in each of the cells during his detention.
- The applicant was held in different cells during his imprisonment, which varied in size and contained 5 sleeping places.
- The prisoners in the closed section of the prison were locked up in their cells and were only able to leave them if they applied for certain activities, most of which were to take place in the recreation room. There was, however, only one 50‑square-metre recreation room per floor which was to be used by ten inmates at most.
- The cell doors in the semi-open section were unlocked, except from 9.45 p.m. (on Fridays, Saturdays and before holidays from midnight) until 6.00 a.m. (on Saturdays, Sundays and during holidays until 8.30 a.m.). 
- The applicant had forty-nine consultations with a general practitioner, seven visits to a dentist, treatment by a psychiatrist on eight occasions, and by a psychologist on five occasions during his imprisonment.
- The cells' average temperature was approximately 28oC in the late afternoon in the second half of July and August 2009, exceeding 30oC on seven days.

title: CASE OF ŠABIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Novo mesto.
- The applicant served his prison sentence from 24 November 2008 to 25 March 2010.
- He was held in the semi-open and closed sections of Ljubljana prison as well as in the open section Ig, Ljubljana prison.
- The cells in the closed and semi-open sections contained five sleeping places (two bunk beds and one single bed).
- The cells had one 107 x 110 cm double casement window, which the prisoners could freely open or close.
- During the out-of-cell time, sentenced prisoners in the closed section of the prison were locked up in their cells and were only able to leave them if they applied for certain activities.
- The cell doors in the semi-open section of the prison were unlocked, except from 9.45 p.m. until 6.00 a.m.
- From 12 July 2009 to 15 July 2009 and from 16 November 2009 to 25 March 2010, the applicant was held in the open section in cell 2 measuring 40 square metres.
- In the open section, cells were open twenty-four hours per day and prisoners could move around freely, except when sleeping.
- The open section had a capacity for twenty-seven prisoners in five cells.
- The prisoners shared sanitary facilities with five showers, five washbasins in the lavatory, three toilets on the ground floor, and four toilets on the first floor of the section and a laundry room with a washing machine and a dryer, which prisoners could freely use.
- During his imprisonment, the applicant had twenty-five consultations with a general practitioner and visited a dentist on two occasions.
- The average temperature in the cells in the late afternoon (5-5.30 p.m.) in the second half of July and August 2009 had been approximately 28oC, exceeding 30oC on seven days.

title: CASE OF OSHLAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 in Almaty, Kazakhstan and currently resides in Moscow.
- In the 1990s the applicant was an entrepreneur in Almaty.
- The applicant was detained in Almaty on August 3, 2004, on charges of involvement in the murder of Mr. Ch., which had been committed in 2001. The applicant was beaten while in detention.
- The Almaty City Court acquitted the applicant and two other men of the murder charges on September 27, 2005.
- In November 2005, the applicant moved with his family to Moscow.
- On December 20, 2005, the Supreme Court of Kazakhstan quashed the judgment of the Almaty City Court upon appeals by the victim's family and the prosecutor's office.
- On February 14, 2006, the Almaty City Court ordered the applicant's remand in custody and put him on the wanted list by the Kazakh authorities.
- On May 3, 2009, the applicant was arrested by Moscow police and remanded in custody in Moscow.
- On June 1, 2009, the Kazakhstan Prosecutor General's Office sent a request to the Russian Prosecutor General's Office for the applicant's extradition.
- On August 28, 2009, the Moscow City Court upheld the extradition order.
- The applicant lodged an appeal with the Supreme Court of Russia, which upheld the extradition order on October 13, 2009.
- On October 29, 2009, the Court indicated to the respondent Government that the applicant should not be extradited to Kazakhstan until further notice.
- The term of the applicant's detention was extended until November 3, 2010.
- As of May 18, 2010, no appeal had been lodged against the decision to extend the term of the applicant's detention.

title: CASE OF SOTOŠEK v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1939 and lives in Ljubljana.
- On 1 December 1993, the applicant filed a lawsuit against his employer and four defendants before the Ljubljana Labour and Social Court.
- In 1994, the Convention came into force in respect of Slovenia.
- On 4 August 1994, company K. responded to the claim.
- On 28 March 2003, the court requested the applicant to amend his claim.
- On 14 April 2003, the applicant withdrew the action against the second, third, fourth and fifth defendant and proposed to determine another court with subject matter jurisdiction.
- On 23 September 2003, the Supreme Court rejected the applicant's request to determine another court.
- Between 2004 and 2006, several hearings were held.
- On 21 September 2006, the Labour and Social Court partially upheld the applicant’s claim and dismissed the remainder of the claim, and both parties appealed.
- On 18 January 2007, the Higher Labour and Social Court dismissed the appeals and issued a decision that an appeal on points of law would not be allowed in the present case, and the applicant appealed.
- On 24 April 2007, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the decision that appeal on points of law was not allowed.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, which was dismissed by the Constitutional Court on 17 October 2008.

title: CASE OF DZHULAY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- M.'s house in Pyryatyn was burgled on 3 March 2003, and M., his mother, his wife, and his niece were present. M. and M.S. sustained bodily injuries, and various items of property, including jewellery, were stolen.
- The applicant was arrested on 24 April 2003 in Kyiv and was subsequently transported to Pyryatyn, where he confessed to the burglary.
- The applicant was formally arrested on suspicion of having committed the crime on 9 May 2003.
- An identification parade was carried out on 12 May 2003, in which the victims identified the applicant as one of the burglars. The parade was conducted in the absence of the applicant's lawyer.
- On 9 November 2004, the Pyryatynskyy District Court sentenced the applicant to nine years’ imprisonment with confiscation of his property.

title: CASE OF ARTEMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was a former police officer who was arrested on suspicion of kidnapping and extortion.
- The District Court remanded the applicant in custody without specifying any time-limit due to the seriousness of the alleged crimes and the risk that the applicant may interfere with the administration of justice, continue criminal activities, or abscond.
- The applicant was charged with armed kidnapping and being an accessory to extortion committed by an organized group.
- The applicant's detention was repeatedly extended based on the need to complete the investigation, check alibis, and familiarize the accused with the case file materials.
- The City Court justified the extensions of the detention by referencing the seriousness of the charges, potential risk of flight, and the need to prevent the obstruction of justice.
- The applicant and his lawyer were frequently absent from the appeal hearings and were not informed of the dates of some hearings.

title: CASE OF MAGYAR KERESZTÉNY MENNONITA EGYHÁZ AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants are religious communities and individuals who originally existed and operated lawfully in Hungary as Churches registered by the competent court in conformity with Act no. IV of 1990 (“the 1990 Church Act”).
- There are several religious communities active in Hungary since 1998, and others since 1981, 2004, and 2007, respectively.
- Some applicants were involved in charity activities outsourced by the municipality of Szolnok and had to terminate their corresponding contract with the municipality, allegedly sustaining damages as a consequence.
- On December 30, 2011, Parliament enacted Act no. CCVI of 2011 on the right to freedom of conscience and religion and the legal status of Churches, denominations and religious communities (“the 2011 Church Act”). It entered into force on January 1, 2012, and was subsequently amended on several occasions, most recently on August 1 and September 1, 2013.
- The 2011 Church Act removed the status of "Church" from all religious communities, except those listed in the Appendix to the law. These rejected communities could continue their activities as associations.
- Several applicants filed requests to have the minister responsible register them as Churches. However, these applications were refused on the ground that – despite the decision of the Constitutional Court – the 2011 Church Act precluded the registrations requested.
- After the Constitutional Court’s decision, several applicants applied to the National Taxation and Customs Agency seeking to be reissued with the number necessary to remain entitled to the 1% of income tax which taxpayers may donate to Churches.
- Several applicants regained their status as Churches pursuant to the Constitutional Court’s decision.

title: CASE OF DHAHBI v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lived in Marsala (Trapani).
- At the relevant time, the applicant was a Tunisian national who had entered Italy on the basis of a lawful residence and work permit.
- The applicant was employed by company A, insured with the National Social Security Agency (INPS), and had a family of his wife and four minor children.
- The applicant applied for payment of the family allowance provided for by section 65 of Law no. 448 of 1998 on 24 May 2001.
- The applicant argued that, under the association agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, the allowance was due to him even though he did not have Italian nationality.
- The Marsala District Court rejected the applicant’s application in a judgment of 10 April 2002.
- The Palermo Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal in a judgment of 21 October 2004.
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant’s appeal in a judgment of 15 April 2008, stating that the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement referred only to social-security benefits and not to social-assistance benefits, to which Tunisian citizens resident in Italy were not entitled.

title: CASE OF KENZIE GLOBAL LIMITED LTD v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is a UK-based company
- Applicant was a creditor of company C who, in turn, was a creditor of company P
- Applicant and company C agreed to assign the debt owed by company P to the applicant company
- Company P became bankrupt and the insolvency procedure was initiated
- Applicant requested to replace company C as the creditor of company P
- The request was granted by the Chişinău Economic Court
- Company C appealed against the decision, stating that the agreement of 1 October 2005 was faulty
- The Supreme Court of Justice upheld the appeal and reversed the judgment of the lower court
- The Supreme Court held that the person who had signed the agreement of 1 October 2005 on behalf of company C had acted ultra vires because she was on maternity leave
- The decision of the Supreme Court of Justice was final and the applicant company was excluded from the list of creditors of company P.

title: CASE OF MINASYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Yerevan
- Criminal proceedings were instituted due to a fight between two groups, resulting in one death and two injuries
- Applicant turned himself in and surrendered two guns, was arrested and taken into custody
- Applicant was charged with aggravated murder, aggravated infliction of serious injuries, and illegal possession of firearms
- The court granted the motion for detention based on the nature and gravity of the imputed offence
- The Criminal Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Regional Court for detention, finding that there was sufficient evidence to raise a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed an offence
- The District Court extended the applicant's detention multiple times, citing concerns of absconding, obstruction of proceedings, and possibility of committing new crimes
- The prosecutor modified the charges against the applicant to attempted murder and aggravated hooliganism
- The Kotayk Regional Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to three years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF KARAGJOZI AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
1. The Tirana Commission recognized the applicant's inherited title to a plot of land measuring 1,214 sq. m, which remains unenforced.
2. The Mat Commission recognized the applicant's title to a plot of land measuring 7,984 sq. m, of which 4,797 sq. m were restored, but 3,187 sq. m were occupied and the compensation was to be made in State bonds.
3. The Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant's appeal in a case related to a different plot of land.
4. The Tirana Commission recognized the applicant's inherited title to a plot of land measuring 1,154.62 sq. m, which was occupied by a stadium, and the applicant would be compensated in one of the ways provided for by law.
5. The Tirana Commission recognized the applicant's inherited title to a plot of land measuring 8,900 sq. m, of which 7,727 sq. m were to be restored. Still, as 1,173 sq. m were occupied by buildings belonging to the Urban Transportation Company, the applicant would be compensated in-kind.
6. The UTC later sold the buildings along with the plot of land to a third party, and the Commission decision that had restored the applicant the plot of 7,727 sq. m was annulled by the domestic courts.
7. The applicant sold three plots of land between 2003 and 2004, all measuring 2,558 sq. m, to third parties.
8. Construction began on four buildings on the applicant's plot of land on 12 November 2007.
9. The Vlora Commission recognized the applicants' inherited title to a plot of land measuring 3,600 sq. m, of which two warehouses and two plots of land, measuring 820 sq. m, were restored, but 2,240 sq. m were occupied by buildings.
10. The Korça Commission recognized the applicants' inherited title to a plot of land measuring 2,250 sq. m, of which 278 sq. m were restored, and 1,972 sq. m were occupied. The applicant would be compensated in State bonds.
11. The Tirana Commission recognized the applicants' inherited title to a plot of land measuring 10,056.7 sq. m, which was occupied by a national park, and the applicants would be compensated in one of the ways provided for by law.
12. The Durrës Commission recognized the applicants

title: CASE OF LAYIJOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was accused of being a drug dealer and was arrested on 16 March 2005.
- The applicant was allegedly beaten, punched, kicked, and hit with a truncheon by police officers during his arrest.
- The applicant claimed that the police officers planted cannabis-based substances on his person and in his car during a search conducted on 17 March 2005.
- The applicant was repeatedly beaten after his arrival at the Zagatala District Police Station.
- An oval-shaped bruise was found on the applicant's neck in a forensic report stating that it was caused by a hard blunt object, which corresponded to 17 March 2005.
- A knife was recovered in a new search of the car conducted on 25 March 2005 after the applicant informed the investigator that there was a knife in his car.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the applicant’s conviction under Article 234.1 of the Criminal Code, reducing his sentence to two years’ imprisonment, and decided to calculate the beginning of the corresponding sentence from 17 March 2005.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s judgment of 22 December 2006 on 19 June 2007.

title: CASE OF RADU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was a lecturer at the Police Academy, aged 34 and married.
- The relationship between the applicant and her superiors was tense.
- The applicant underwent artificial insemination, became pregnant with twins and was hospitalized from 4 to 20 August 2003 due to an increased risk of miscarriage.
- The President of the Police Academy requested information from the Center for Family Doctors regarding her medical leave, and the CFD informed the applicant's employer that she had been hospitalized on account of an increased risk of miscarriage, carrying twins, had hepatitis B, and obstetrical complications.
- The applicant suffered a miscarriage, and her doctor mentioned stress as a factor that contributed to it.
- The applicant initiated civil proceedings against the CFD and the Police Academy and claimed compensation for a breach of her right to private life.
- The Centru District Court dismissed the applicant's action, and the Chişinău Court of Appeal upheld the applicant's appeal and quashed the judgment.
- The CFD appealed to the Supreme Court of Justice, which upheld the appeal and dismissed the applicant's claims against the CFD, holding that the CFD had acted in accordance with the law when providing the applicant's employer with medical information about her.

title: CASE OF HASAN YAZICI v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant, a professor of medicine, accused Professor Dr I.D. of plagiarizing in his book entitled Mother’s Book.
- The applicant presented a two-page report to the Ethics Committee of the Turkish Academy of Sciences, asserting that Professor Dr I.D. had committed plagiarism and asking for certain actions to be taken.
- Professor Dr M.T.H. also made similar allegations of plagiarism against Professor Dr I.D. in his book The History of the University in Turkey, 2nd edition, 2000.
- The applicant published an article entitled ‘Ethics of Science and plagiarism’ in which he renewed his claims of plagiarism against Professor Dr I.D. and suggested that the latter should apologize for the plagiarisms he had committed.
- The Ankara Civil Court of First Instance ordered an expert report to determine the veracity of the applicant’s assertion that the plaintiff had committed plagiarism.
- The first expert report concluded that there had been no plagiarism and that the plaintiff’s personality rights had been violated.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment of the first-instance court, stating that the allegations of plagiarism needed to be investigated further.
- The court appointed new experts who submitted a report concluding that there was no plagiarism, as the plaintiff’s book was not a copy of Dr. Spock’s book.
- The court awarded compensation to Professor Dr I.D. as the applicant’s assertion had constituted an unlawful attack on the plaintiff’s personality rights and scientific career.

title: CASE OF ASALYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a Palestinian who lived in Gaza until 2008 and has lost about 25 relatives to Israeli attacks.
- He was directly targeted and severely injured in an Israeli missile attack in 2007, which left him paraplegic.
- He was brought to Turkey by a humanitarian organization to receive better medical care.
- He married a Turkish national and was granted a temporary residence permit.
- In August 2009, the applicant was detained and informed that his residence permit had been canceled and he was to be deported from Turkey due to allegations of involvement in acts of international terrorism.
- The applicant was detained in poor conditions, and his lawyer applied for his release and sought a stay of execution of the deportation order.
- The applicant applied for asylum in Turkey, claiming that he was in danger of being tortured or killed if returned to Gaza or Israel.
- An interim measure was applied by the Court to halt the applicant's imminent deportation.
- The Ankara Administrative Court quashed the deportation decision in April 2010, and the Supreme Administrative Court upheld this decision in December 2010.
- The applicant was eventually granted a long-term residence permit in 2013 based on evidence of a genuine family life in Turkey.

title: CASE OF DJUNDIKS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1939 and is from Liepāja.
- He was certified as Category 3 disabled in 1983 and Category 2 disabled in 2004.
- He was administratively detained by municipal police on August 19, 2003.
- The circumstances of the detention are disputed between the parties.
- The applicant alleges that he was physically assaulted by police officers and sustained injuries to his left eye, left leg, and other parts of his body.
- The government maintains that the police officers found the applicant lying on the stairs between the ground and 1st floor, and that he appeared to be heavily intoxicated.
- The applicant was treated for his injuries at a hospital in Liepāja and was diagnosed with a hip fracture.
- The police issued an administrative detention report on the basis of section 171 of the Code of Administrative Violations.
- The police conducted an internal investigation and concluded that the applicant "could have sustained" his injuries by falling on the stairs of the apartment building.
- The Liepāja police initially declined to institute criminal proceedings and later refused to do so following additional investigation.

title: CASE OF REMUS TUDOR v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1966.
- In 1990, he was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- He was held in different detention centers. No information is available about his places of detention before April 8, 2009.
- He was detained in Jilava Prison from April 8, 2009, until November 10, 2011, and then transferred to Giurgiu Prison.
- The applicant and the Government disagreed on most aspects of the conditions of detention in Jilava Prison.
- The applicant alleged that he occupied overcrowded cells and complained of unsatisfactory sanitary conditions, low temperatures, no hot water, and sharing cells with smokers and drug users.
- The Government supplied details of the cells in Jilava Prison where the applicant was detained and the number of inmates he shared the cell with.
- The applicant was detained in smoking cells and did not ask to be transferred to a non-smoking cell.
- The Government claimed that the prison authorities signed contracts for rodent and pest control, and disinfection of the cells was carried out regularly. The quality of drinking water was tested regularly, and the food was fresh and of good quality.

title: CASE OF STEFANETTI AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicants worked in Switzerland for varying periods of time and transferred their contributions to Italy.
- Italy changed its pension system from a contributory one to an earnings-based one in 1982.
- The applicants requested that their pensions be calculated based on the contributions paid in Switzerland, in accordance with the 1962 Italo-Swiss Convention on Social Security.
- The INPS used a theoretical remuneration instead of real remuneration, resulting in a lower pension for the applicants.
- The applicants instituted judicial proceedings, but their claims were rejected due to the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006.

title: CASE OF MLADINA D.D. LJUBLJANA v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant is the publisher of Mladina magazine
- Parliament examined a draft law on same-sex civil partnerships in June 2005 and later adopted the Registration of Same-Sex Civil Partnerships Act.
- During the parliamentary debate, certain deputies of the SNP took the floor in order to express their disagreement with the proposed draft.
- Mladina published an article summarising the parliamentary debate, with criticisms of the SNP's conduct and remarks made during the debate.
- S.P. brought a defamation claim for damages against the applicant company, claiming that he had suffered severe mental distress due to the offensiveness of the article.
- The Ljubljana District Court partially upheld S.P.'s claim and ordered the applicant company to pay him damages.
- The Ljubljana Higher Court dismissed the applicant company’s appeal and upheld S.P.’s appeal in respect of the text to be published in Mladina informing the public of the judgment, but dismissed his claim for greater damages.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant company’s complaint, holding that the lower courts had struck a fair balance between its freedom of expression and S.P.’s personal dignity.

title: CASE OF BROSA v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant published an article in a local newspaper concerning the political orientation of an association.
- The association responded by describing the applicant's statements as "intellectually weak and crude" and "pamphlets constituting a public danger."
- The applicant distributed a leaflet with the headline "Don’t vote for an agitator" in which he claimed that the association was a particularly dangerous neo-Nazi organization and that F.G. provided a cover for them.
- F.G. requested a civil injunction prohibiting the applicant from distributing the leaflet, which was granted by Kirchhain District Court and upheld by the Marburg Regional Court.
- The applicant claimed that the courts violated his freedom of conscience, his freedom of expression, and his right to a fair trial, and lodged a constitutional complaint with the Federal Constitutional Court, which was refused to be admitted.

title: CASE OF ANATOLIY RUDENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant created a local NGO and several newspapers in 2005-2006.
- Applicant was suspected of interfering with gas pipeline repairs in July 2006 and extortion from a local politician in January 2006.
- Two criminal cases were joined and applicant was detained in June 2007.
- Expert examination on June 11, 2007, revealed indications of a paranoid personality disorder with a tendency towards “forming fixed ideas”.
- Inpatient forensic psychiatric examination was conducted in June 2007 and the Court of Appeal dismissed applicant’s appeal against the detention order.
- Another case was opened against him on suspicion of extortion in June 2007.
- Forensic psychiatric examination was conducted in December 2008 and another one in February 2009. 
- Applicant was found guilty of extortion from Ms B. in June 2009 and required involuntary medical treatment in a mental facility.
- Decision of the first-instance court on the applicant’s guilt was quashed in December 2009 and the case was remitted for fresh examination.
- Another forensic psychiatric examination of the applicant was ordered in October 2010. 
- Charges against the applicant regarding interference with gas pipeline repairs and extortion from Mr S. were dropped in April 2011. 
- The applicant was found guilty of extortion from Ms B. and was ordered to be admitted to a psychiatric hospital for treatment.

title: CASE OF GAYRATBEK SALIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1988, ethnic Uzbek, and residing in Suzak, Jalal-Abad Region, Kyrgyzstan, presently detained in the Moscow Region, Russia following an extradition process.
- Inter-ethnic violence broke out in Kyrgyzstan in June 2010 between Kyrgyz and Uzbek groups. The applicant fled from Kyrgyzstan to Russia, allegedly due to ethnic violence, leaving his next-of-kin in his home country.
- The applicant was charged in Kyrgyzstan with several serious violent offenses committed during inter-ethnic rioting in Suzak in June 2010.
- The applicant was convicted by the Meshchanskiy Court of robbery in 2011 and imprisoned in Russia. The Kyrgyz authorities placed him on an international wanted list.
- On March 2012, he was arrested by Russian police and was put into custody in response to the extradition request by Kyrgyzstan.
- The applicant sought refugee status in Russia on April 2012, but the request was rejected by the Moscow Department of the Federal Migration Service of Russia in August 2012.
- The Kyrgyz authorities issued an amended list of charges against the applicant, where illegal use of firearms, murder, robbery, destruction of property, and participation in rioting aggravated by ethnic hatred were included.
- The transport prosecutor's office for the Moscow-Yaroslavl railway ordered the applicant's remand in custody pending receipt of an extradition request, which was eventually granted by the Deputy Prosecutor General of Russia in February 2013.
- The applicant appealed against the extradition order, citing potential risks of torture and ill-treatment upon his return to Kyrgyzstan, but his appeals were all dismissed, and the extradition order was enforced in June 2013.
- The applicant's application for temporary asylum was later dismissed but was subject to re-examination, the result of which is unknown.

(Note: Some bullets include multiple pieces of information from different paragraphs to give a comprehensive overview of the case.)

title: CASE OF ISMAILOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and resided in Arzamas, Nizhniy Novgorod Region before his arrest in 2012.
- The accused resided in Uzbekistan before April 2011 and visited Russia on several occasions to earn money.
- He was accused by the Andizhan Town Court of being involved in prohibited organizations such as the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan and the O’zbekiston Islomiy Harakati.
- He was charged with attempting to destroy the constitutional order of Uzbekistan and creating an Islamic State in Russia.
- The Uzbek court ordered his arrest and put him on a cross-border wanted list.
- On 13 September 2012, he was arrested in Arzamas, Nizhniy Novgorod Region, and detained pending extradition to Uzbekistan.
- On 9 April 2013, the Russian Prosecutor's Office refused the Uzbek authorities' extradition request, and the extradition proceedings were discontinued.
- On 13 March 2013, he was arrested in the yard by officers of the local department of the Federal Migration Service in connection with a violation of immigration laws (Article 18-8 of the Code of Administrative Offenses (“the CAO”)) and taken into custody.
- He was found guilty by the Arzamas Town Court of breaching immigration laws.
- On 13 March 2013, the court ordered his administrative removal from Russia and imposed a fine of 3,000 Russian roubles (RUB).
- The Court indicated to the Government, under Rule 39 of the Rules of Court, that the applicant's administrative removal and extradition should be suspended until further notice.
- The Nizhniy Novgorod Regional Court upheld the administrative removal order on 26 March 2013.

title: CASE OF LYUBOV STETSENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was registered on the waiting list for war veterans in need of improved housing conditions in 1982.
2. A judgment was given in the applicant's favour in 1995, obliging the town council to allocate a well-furnished flat for rent with living space of no less than nine square metres per person.
3. The town council failed to enforce the judgment, resulting in fines.
4. The applicant was registered on another waiting list for disabled war veterans in need of improved housing conditions in 1995.
5. The judgment was amended twice by way of supervisory review in 1996 and 2000 respectively.
6. The applicant was provided with a two-room flat in 2000, and another flat was offered to her in 2008.
7. The enforcement proceedings were discontinued in 2008, but the Bailiff Service found that the town council had failed to enforce the judgment in 2010.
8. The Bailiff Service ordered the town council to pay fines for failure to enforce the judgment within set time-limits in 2010.
9. The enforcement proceedings were ultimately discontinued in 2010, acknowledging that the applicant had exercised her right to obtain housing in accordance with the writ of execution.

title: CASE OF NUSRET KAYA AND OTHERS v. TURKEY [Extracts]
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicants were held in different prisons at different times.
- They had applied for lifting restrictions that prevented them from using the Kurdish language in telephone conversations.
- The sentence-execution judges from Erzurum and Bolu had dismissed their applications.
- The courts had found that the practice of the prison authorities was in conformity with the law and the procedure.
- The Rules on the enforcement of sentences and preventive measures had been mentioned as a legal basis for conducting telephone conversations in Turkish with exceptions for those who did not understand the language.
- Inmates had to indicate on the telephone call form if the other person did not understand Turkish.
- Research would be carried out at the inmate's expense to verify the information given on the form, following which the inmate could be authorized to speak in Kurdish.

title: CASE OF VARJONEN v. FINLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lived in Pomarkku.
- On 9 June 2005, the applicant’s husband was injured in a car accident and received insurance benefits from an insurance company.
- The insurance company refused his applications for compensation for rehabilitation on 2 and 5 March 2006.
- The husband appealed against these decisions on 30 March and 4 April 2006 to the Insurance Court.
- The husband died on 3 August 2006 but the applicant decided to continue the appeals.
- The Insurance Court rejected the appeals on 3 May 2010, and no appeal lies against this decision.
- On 26 February 2010, the applicant complained to the Parliamentary Ombudsman about the excessive length of proceedings in the Insurance Court.
- On 17 November 2011, the Ombudsman replied and accepted that the case was exceptionally extensive, complex, and time-consuming.
- On 20 October 2010, the applicant initiated extraordinary proceedings before the Supreme Court, requesting that the decisions of the Insurance Court be quashed because the referendary in the Insurance Court had been biased.
- On 29 July 2011, the Supreme Court dismissed this application for being outside its competence.
- On 5 October 2011, the applicant lodged an extraordinary appeal with the Supreme Administrative Court, claiming that the proceedings before the Insurance Court had been flawed due to the partiality of the referendary and the wrong application of law.
- On 31 May 2012, the Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the complaint concerning the wrong application of law and rejected the partiality complaint after having examined it.

title: CASE OF NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant's personal information: born in 1971 and residing in Balástya.
- The applicant's divorced wife filed a case against him to end his custody rights.
- The Pest Central District Court changed the applicant's access rights and rejected the rest of the case on 29 June 2011.
- The court used the expert psychologist's statement as evidence.
- The Budapest High Court confirmed the previous verdict on 4 July 2012.

title: CASE OF BRUNNER v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Szigetszentmiklós. 
- On 20 June 2003, the applicant was indicted for fraud.
- On 15 December 2010, he acquitted by the Budapest Regional Court. 
- On 20 June 2012, the Debrecen Court of Appeal confirmed the applicant’s acquittal.

title: CASE OF KVACSKAY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and resides in Budapest.
- On 19 May 2002, the applicant filed a lawsuit regarding a real estate dispute in the Tapolca District Court.
- After two remittals, the Tapolca District Court issued a verdict on 9 June 2011, which was partially overturned by the Veszprém County Regional Court on 28 February 2012 (service: 14 March 2012).
- On 22 May 2012, the proceedings were concluded with a rectification order.

title: CASE OF CSABUDA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Diósjenő
- Applicant filed for divorce and division of matrimonial property in 1996
- The case was processed by several district and regional courts
- The procedure ended on 6 July 2012.

title: CASE OF KIS AND BOZA v. HUNGARY
facts:
1. The applicants were born in 1959 and live in Budapest.
2. The applicants started labour-law litigation on 27 October 2003.
3. The litigation concerned their resignation and its legal and pecuniary consequences.
4. The Budapest Labour Court gave judgment on 21 May 2009.
5. The judgment partially found for the plaintiffs.
6. The Budapest Regional Court reversed part of the decision on 9 June 2010.
7. The Kúria upheld the second-instance decision on 18 January 2012.

title: CASE OF PALÁSTI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Budapest.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant and his associates for embezzlement and other offences on 16 June 1998.
- On 7 June 2002, a bill of indictment was preferred.
- A first instance judgment was adopted on 17 November 2009, and the Budapest XX/XXI/XXIII District Court imposed only a fine, considering the lapse of time as a mitigating factor.
- The judgment was quashed on appeal, and in the resumed proceedings, the lapse of time was again appreciated as a mitigating factor.
- The case was then resumed before the Budapest High Court, which convicted the applicant on 23 April 2013 and imposed only a fine, finding the lapse of time to be an important mitigating factor.
- Currently, an appeal by the public prosecutor is pending before the Budapest Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF GRESPIK v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Budapest.
- On 22 February 2002, the applicant was dismissed from the civil service.
- The applicant was reinstated and obtained damages on 22 March 2002.
- The Prime Minister revoked the applicant's mandate to preside over the Authority on the same day.
- Four sets of proceedings ensued from this labour dispute.
- The friendly settlement was annulled by a final judgment of the Baranya County Regional Court on 3 November 2005.
- The Baranya County Regional Court established the unlawfulness of the revocation of the applicant’s mandate on 22 March 2002 on 2 February 2010.
- The Zalaegerszeg Labour Court found the sanction imposed on the applicant to be unlawful on 3 April 2007.
- The proceedings concerning the applicant's claim for salary arrears and the Authority's action for the reimbursement of compensation are still pending.

title: CASE OF NECKOV v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1943 and lives in Miskolc.
- Litigation started in 2003 between the applicant and his ex-spouse to terminate common ownership of their marital property.
- The case was heard at second instance by the Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén County Regional Court.
- The final decision was given by the Supreme Court on 8 November 2011.

title: CASE OF SZABÓ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Balkány.
- The applicant brought an action before the Debrecen Labour Court on 11 November 2004.
- The applicant claimed she was unlawfully dismissed from public service.
- The Labour Court found against her on 14 November 2007, stating reasons for dismissal were real and relevant.
- The Hajdú-Bihar County Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 10 April 2008.
- The Supreme Court also rejected her petition for review on 11 November 2009.
- The applicant’s criminal accusations against third parties were ineffective.

title: CASE OF LAGUTIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were targeted in undercover operations by the police conducted as test purchases of drugs.
- The applicants were convicted of drug dealing.
- The applicants are brothers who worked as vendors in a video and audio rental kiosk at the time of their arrest.
- The police received information that the applicants were involved in drug dealing.
- The first test purchase was made, and after positive confirmation, the applicants were charged.
- The applicants disputed the police version of events, claiming entrapment.
- The court cross-examined the undercover police officer and witnesses giving accounts of test purchases.
- The applicant in a separate case was accused of selling drugs, which he denies and claims entrapment.
- The first-instance court found the applicant guilty of selling drugs, and he was sentenced to six years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed on the grounds of police entrapment.
- The Supreme Court of the Republic of Chuvashiya dismissed the appeal, and the applicant's sentence was reduced to five years and eleven months’ imprisonment.
- The Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Republic of Chuvashiya reduced the applicant's sentence to five years and nine months’ imprisonment.
- The applicant in a separate case is a woman who was also convicted of drug dealing.

title: CASE OF MARIJA BOŽIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born on 18 November 1940 and lived in Lipovača, Croatia.
- From 1 January 1980 to 30 November 1992, the applicant was insured as an agricultural entrepreneur in Klokočevik.
- In November 1992, the applicant moved to Lipovača, a self-proclaimed entity established on the territory of Croatia, and stopped contributing to the Croatian Pension Fund.
- The applicant made payments of HRK 4,978 in 1998 and HRK 11,663 in 2000 in respect of pension contributions.
- In 2002, the Croatian Pension Fund decided that the applicant had ceased to have the insured person status and refused her request for a pension.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's action in 2006. The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's complaint in 2009.
- In 2012, the applicant instituted administrative proceedings with the Vukovar Office of the Croatian Pension Fund and made various requests.
- In 2012-2013, the Central Office of the Croatian Pension Fund accepted the applicant's appeals and recognised her pension-qualifying period from 1 January 1980 to 31 May 2000.
- On 21 March 2013, the Vukovar Office of the Croatian Pension Fund decided that the applicant had the right to a pension as of 1 August 2011.

title: CASE OF UDOVIČIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Cubinec
- Applicant lives in the house, part of which is occupied by a bar and a shop run by a company
- Applicant owns 59.63% of the house, while the company owns 40.37%
- Applicant's flat is adjacent to the bar on the ground floor
- Reconstruction work carried out by the company had not required any additional planning permission or authorization
- Applicant appeals against the decision of the building inspector and found company had demolished a load-bearing wall and made a hole in the façade
- Ministry of Construction remits the case to the building inspector as he had not established all the relevant facts
- Building inspector finds that the construction carried out was within the scope defined by the existing planning permissions
- Administrative action taken by the applicant in the Administrative Court challenging the decision
- Company applies to the County State Administration Office for operating licences to run a bar and shop
- Applicant complains to the County Office about the decision
- County Office dismisses the complaint as ill-founded
- Applicant lodges an appeal with the Ministry of Tourism and the Ministry quashes the decision of the County Office
- Applicant challenges the decision of the ministry by bringing an administrative action in the Administrative Court
- Applicant's request for disqualification of the officials who had previously participated in the proceedings was not decided upon
- Administrative Inspectorate urged the County Office to adopt a decision on the applicant’s complaints
- Company closes the shop after informing the County Office
- Administrative proceedings are still pending
- County Office instigates administrative proceedings to ascertain whether the noise emanating from the bar and the shop exceeded the permitted levels under the relevant law
- EL submits a report finding that the noise insulation did not satisfy the necessary requirements
- Applicant lodges an appeal with the Ministry of Health challenging the decision of the County Office
- Administrative action taken in the Administrative Court against the decision of the Ministry of Health
- Applicant and her husband complain to the sanitary inspector about the level of noise coming from the bar

title: CASE OF HAUPTMANN v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant's wife made a claim for spousal maintenance on 19 November 1993.
- The District Court issued an interim order requiring the applicant to pay provisional maintenance on 24 March 1994.
- The interim order was confirmed by the Regional Court on 7 July 1995.
- The applicant's wife sought to amend her claim and requested another interim order for provisional maintenance on 29 September 1994.
- The District Court issued a fresh interim order on 6 July 1995.
- The court dismissed an appeal by the applicant against the interim order on 18 September 1995.
- The presiding judge of the Regional Court was excluded from the case for bias, and a replacement judge took over the case.
- The applicant and his wife agreed on provisional maintenance during an oral hearing on 20 March 1998.
- The applicant submitted a request to have the proceedings accelerated on 6 May 1998.
- The District Court granted the divorce and found the applicant largely responsible for the breakdown of the marriage on 20 August 1999.
- The main maintenance proceedings were stayed by agreement on 6 December 1999.
- The applicant requested that they be continued on 25 May 2000, and further oral hearings were held between 2000 and 2004.
- The applicant lodged applications for an appropriate time-limit to be imposed on the District Court on 19 December 2001 and 16 July 2004, but they were never decided.
- The applicant's wife sought another interim order on 8 October 2004.
- The Regional Court rejected the applicant's application under section 91 of the Courts Act on 9 May 2005.
- The District Court issued an interim order partly awarding the applicant's wife provisional maintenance on 28 July 2006.
- An appeal by the applicant was partly allowed by the Regional Court on 29 June 2007.
- The applicant challenged the application for enforcement, which was dismissed on 7 June 2010.
- The case file was missing between 9 July 2010 and 10 February 2011.
- The applicant and his wife agreed to stay the proceedings on 18 April 2011 but the applicant requested that they be continued on 29 November 2011.
- The applicant applied to have the provisional maintenance order varied on 12 October 2011.
- The Regional Court quashed the District Court's decision on 21 March 2012 and referred the matter back

title: CASE OF CARIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Petrinja.
- On 9 October 2000, the applicant filed a civil action seeking payment of unpaid pension instalments.
- On 4 July 2002, the proceedings were stayed pending the outcome of parallel administrative proceedings before the Croatian Pension Fund.
- The Sisak County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 16 January 2003.
- On 5 January 2012, the proceedings resumed.
- On 10 February 2012, the Sisak Municipal Court adopted a judgment, and the applicant appealed.
- On 31 May 2012, the Sisak County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal and upheld the first-instance judgment.
- The applicant lodged a request for the protection of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time on 24 November 2011.
- The Sisak County Court found a violation of the applicant’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time on 24 January 2012, awarded him HRK 4,500 in compensation, and ordered the Sisak Municipal Court to decide on the applicant’s case within six months. 
- The three-member panel of the Supreme Court reduced the amount of compensation awarded to HRK 500 on 4 June 2012.
- The Constitutional Court declared the applicant's constitutional complaint inadmissible on 18 October 2012.
- The Croatian Pension Fund rejected the applicant’s appeal on 13 July 2001.
- The Administrative Court quashed the second-instance decision and remitted the case to the Central Office on 2 March 2006.
- The Central Office quashed the first-instance decision and remitted the case to the Sisak Regional Office on 8 May 2006.
- The Sisak Regional Office adopted a new decision on 18 September 2006, and the applicant again appealed.
- The Central Office dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 3 April 2007.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s subsequent administrative action on 7 July 2011.
- The applicant lodged a request for the protection of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time on 12 May 2011.
- The Supreme Court found a violation of the applicant’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time on 5 October 2011 and awarded him HRK 6,500 in compensation.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal as ill-founded on 7 September 2012.

title: MILADINOV AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Applicants were born and raised in Macedonia.
- All applicants were entrepreneurs.
- All three applicants were charged with money laundering in relation to a bankruptcy case.
- Some accused were bankruptcy trustees, trial judges, lawyers, notaries and civil servants.
- Nine of the accused, including the applicants, were placed in pre-trial detention for 30 days.
- Appeal by the first and second applicants was dismissed but the order for pre-trial detention replaced with an order for house arrest for the second applicant.
- Multiple extension orders of 30-day detention and house arrest granted based on risk of absconding, the possibility of reoffending and interfering with the investigation.
- Skopje Court of Appeal dismissed the appeals and ruled that there were sufficient reasons for the applicants’ continued detention.
- The Skopje Court of Appeal found that there were no grounds to justify their detention and ordered the first and third applicants’ release.
- No further information was provided about the criminal case against the applicants.

title: CASE OF BUDCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1932 and lives in Gorlivka, Ukraine
- From 1953 to 1966, the applicant worked in a mine
- Applicant requested clarification on section 43 of the Mining Act which should cover his gas and electricity bill
- The applicants requests were ignored by his former employer and the relevant state enterprise
- The applicant was advised to go to court in order to lodge his claims against the mining companies
- The case was brought to court on April 2003
- The Tsentralno-Miskyy District Court decided against the applicant
- Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision
- The Supreme Court rejected an appeal on points of law
- Tsentralno-Miskyy District Court ordered the applicant to settle his heating debts
- District court decision was upheld by the Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal
- Supreme Court of Ukraine rejected the request of the applicant for leave to appeal on points of law
- Applicant was informed that no mechanism was set up to handle the compensatory payments requested
- The mechanism for implementing section 43-8 of the Mining Act would be set up as per Ministry of the Coal Industry of Ukraine
- Ministry of Labour and Social Policy of Ukraine informed the applicant that he has no right to any compensation payments as the mine where he worked is in liquidation
- Applicant decided to file a case against the Tsentralno-Miskyy Department of Labour and Social Policy 
- Donetskyy Regional Administrative Court refused to examine the applicant's claim and upheld by the Donetsk Administrative Court of Appeal and the Higher Administrative Court respectively.

title: CASE OF PEREVEDENTSEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants' son was drafted into the army to perform two years' mandatory military service.
- The son described various abuses in letters he sent home, including extortion, beatings, deprivation of sleep, etc.
- The son was asked to pay money to more senior conscripts and owed a total of RUB 2000.
- In a letter, the son expressed his intention to go on the run because of the abuse he was subjected to by the more senior conscripts.
- The son was found dead with a noose around his neck on February 16th, 2004.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted into the death of the son under Article 110 of the Russian Criminal Code (Incitement to suicide).
- The causes of the incident were listed as possible suicide or failure to take necessary measures by the unit officials for the psychological monitoring of soldiers in need of increased psychological and pedagogical care.
- Witnesses gave conflicting statements regarding the son's attitude and actions leading up to his death.

title: CASE OF DUŠKO IVANOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was apprehended by police without a court warrant and in the absence of witnesses.
- The police found 13 keys and a mobile phone on the applicant during the search.
- Two separate search warrants were issued for two apartments and other premises owned by the applicant's father.
- Seven packages containing an unknown substance were found in apartment no. 10, which belonged to the sister of another person.
- The locking system of the padlock securing cellar no. 10 had been damaged and could be opened with any object, including all keys confiscated from the applicant.
- Five packages found in cellar no. 10 contained 2.296 kg of heroin and the remaining 0.991 kg found in the other two packages contained two substances that were often mixed with heroin.
- The fingerprint found on one of the packages matched the applicant’s right middle finger.
- The Ministry of Interior lodged a criminal complaint accusing the applicant of drug trafficking.
- The applicant denied connection to the drugs found in the cellar and claimed that he was forced to touch them during police searches.
- The trial court found the applicant guilty of drug trafficking and sentenced him to two-and-a-half years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF L.H. v. LATVIA
facts:
1. The applicant gave birth via Caesarean section at Cēsis District Central Hospital in 1997.
2. Tubal ligation was performed during surgery without the applicant's consent.
3. The applicant sued the hospital for damages in 2005, and her claim was upheld in 2006.
4. The Cēsis hospital requested the Inspectorate of Quality Control for Medical Care and Fitness for Work (MADEKKI) to evaluate the applicant's childbirth treatment in 2004.
5. The MADEKKI initiated an administrative inquiry and obtained medical files from three institutions for the period from 1996 to 2003.
6. The applicant declined to comment but referred the MADEKKI to her legal representative.
7. The MADEKKI issued a report on the applicant's medical treatment during childbirth, which the applicant's representative attempted to annul by lodging a claim with the Administrative District Court.
8. The court terminated the proceedings with regard to annulling the report but dismissed the remainder of the application as ill-founded.
9. The applicant appealed, claiming that the MADEKKI had acted unlawfully and had violated her right to respect for her private life.
10. The Administrative Regional Court upheld the first-instance court's judgment, and the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law.
11. The Senate of the Supreme Court held that the MADEKKI had acted within its sphere of competence and in accordance with the law concerning the processing of sensitive personal data.
12. Sections 10 and 50 of the Medical Treatment Law and Sections 7 and 11 of the Personal Data Protection Law governed the MADEKKI's work and permitted the collection and processing of sensitive data concerning patients.

title: CASE OF TERNOVSKIS v. LATVIA
facts:
• The applicant was employed as a border guard in the State Border Guard Service from 1992.
• His promotion to head of the Jelgava section was certified in 1998.
• He applied for security clearance to work with State secrets, filling in a questionnaire in 1997.
• The Constitution Protection Bureau invited him to attend a “discussion” in respect of his application in 1998.
• The applicant was refused the first category security clearance in 1999.
• A judgment in 1999 established that he had been recruited as a KGB “agent” but had not knowingly collaborated with the KGB.
• He was dismissed from service on the basis of the refusal of his security clearance.
• He sought a review of the decision concerning his clearance in 1999 and appealed to the Prosecutor General.
• His appeal was dismissed, and the Prosecutor General’s decision was final.
• He attempted to obtain access to the materials in the investigation file on the basis of which he had been refused clearance.
• He complained about his dismissal from service to three levels of courts of general jurisdiction.
• He lodged an appeal on points of law, which was dismissed.
• He lodged a complaint of unconstitutionality with the Constitutional Court, which declared the legal provisions in question constitutional.

title: CASE OF ŠIMECKI v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and lives in Mirkovci.
- The Krk Municipal Court issued a first enforcement order against the applicant's movable assets for unpaid mobile telephone bills.
- The second enforcement order was ordered by way of attachment of the applicant's earnings.
- The applicant lodged an appeal against both enforcement orders, arguing that she could not have made the calls due to being in prison and her mobile phone being seized.
- The Koprivnica County Court declared the appeal inadmissible as lodged out of time, and dismissed the applicant's request for rectification.
- The Constitutional Court declared the applicant's complaints inadmissible.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Supreme Court about the length of the enforcement proceedings.
- The Rijeka County Court found a violation of the applicant's right to a hearing within a reasonable time and awarded her compensation.

title: CASE OF ZENKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Facts bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1983 and lives in Blagoveshchensk.
- On 11 March 2006, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of fraud.
- On 12 March 2006, the Blagoveshchensk Town Court of the Amur Region authorised the applicant’s detention.
- The applicant remained in custody pending the investigation and trial, with several extensions of pre-trial detention.
- On 17 December 2007, the Town Court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to ten years’ imprisonment.
- On 5 February 2010, the applicant was released on parole.
- From 11 March 2006 to 11 March 2008, from 19 February to 19 March 2009, and from 28 May to 20 August 2009, the applicant was detained in remand prison no. 28/1 in Blagoveshchensk.
- The Government’s submissions as regards the conditions of the applicant’s detention included detailed descriptions of the cell conditions, meal quality, ventilation, heating and water supply, natural light, artificial lighting, toilet location, distance from sleeping places and dining area, cleaning and disinfection, outdoor exercise, and daily confinement hours.
- On an unspecified date, the applicant complained to the regional prosecutor’s office about the appalling conditions of his detention, and the prosecutor’s office inspected the remand prison.
- The irregularities found in the course of the inspection included numerous violations of governing conditions of detention in the remand prison, such as insufficient number of tables, benches, cabinets for food storage, and sinks in some cells; lack of artificial ventilation, stands for drinking-water tanks, and screens separating the toilet from the rest of the cell; absence of radio; and inadequate disinfection measures leading to infestation of insects such as bed bugs and cockroaches. Moreover, many cells required complete refurbishment due to issues such as mould, flaking plaster, and cracks, and the lack of forced ventilation contributed to humid and stuffy air, non-compliance with temperature standards, and absence of radio in some cells.

title: CASE OF TIKHONOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's son, Andrey Tikhonov, was drafted into the army in 1999 and was convicted of violence against his military superior.
- On April 14, 2001, A.T. was found dead in the unit’s canteen, with a belt around his neck and numerous bruises and abrasions on his body.
- A post-mortem examination revealed that A.T. had died of strangulation and had been emotionally unstable.
- Polygraph tests were conducted on A.T.'s fellow recruits, and their statements were consistent with Sgt Kudryashov's.
- Moreover, the criminal investigation concluded that A.T. committed suicide due to acute psychogenic depressive reaction.
- The Garrison Prosecutor set aside the decision in light of the applicant's complaint and ordered the investigation to be reopened.
- The investigator was instructed to question various people, including A.T.'s parents and girlfriend, and to study A.T.'s personality to find the reason behind his brother's suicide.

title: CASE OF NIZAMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Four applicants detained in Moscow, born between 1979 and 1992
- Moved from Uzbekistan to Russia in 2011-12 to seek employment
- Charged by Uzbek authorities with participation in an extremist religious group and attempting to overthrow the state's constitutional order
- Arrested at Vnukovo airport in Moscow in November 2012
- Russian General Prosecutor refused the request for extradition in March-April 2013, citing a ban on extradition in respect of persons charged with an offence not punishable under the Russian criminal law
- Moscow City Court upheld expulsion orders, but suspended their execution until further notice
- Applicants lodged applications for asylum in Russia, but decisions to refuse refugee status were made, citing that they are not running the risk of being subjected to persecution in Uzbekistan

title: CASE OF SERGEY CHEBOTAREV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant had an altercation with Ms K. in a bar and was accused of beating her and stealing her gold rings.
- The police produced a memorandum linking the applicant to organized crime, which influenced the decision to arrest him.
- The applicant was charged with aggravated armed robbery but was later released on his own recognisance.
- The charge was later amended to aggravated disorderly conduct and the applicant was sentenced to two years in prison.
- The applicant complained about inhuman conditions of detention in facility IZ-56/1 in Orenburg.

title: CASE OF PAULET v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant was born in 1984 and lived in Leeds.
- The applicant arrived in the United Kingdom on 26 January 2001 and lived illegally at an address in Bedford.
- The applicant obtained three jobs using a false French passport and earned a total gross salary of £73,293.17 between April 2003 and February 2007.
- The applicant applied for a provisional driving licence using the same false passport.
- The applicant pleaded guilty to three counts of dishonestly obtaining pecuniary advantage by deception, having a false identity document with intent, driving whilst disqualified, and driving a motor vehicle without insurance.
- The applicant was sentenced to concurrent terms of fifteen months’ imprisonment for the first four counts together with a consecutive sentence of two months’ imprisonment for the offence of driving whilst disqualified.
- The trial judge recommended the applicant for deportation.
- The prosecution sought a confiscation order under section 6 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 in respect of the applicant’s earnings.
- The trial judge imposed a confiscation order in the sum of £21,949.60 upon the applicant with a consecutive sentence of twelve months’ imprisonment to be served in default of payment.
- The applicant sought an extension of time within which to appeal to the Court of Appeal against the imposition of the confiscation order.
- The Court of Appeal granted the applicant an extension of time and leave to appeal.
- The Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the confiscation order and found that the decision to seek a confiscation order did not constitute an abuse of process.
- The Court of Appeal found that the link between the applicant’s earnings and his criminal offences, in the context of the wider public interest, was plainly established.
- The applicant applied for asylum in the United Kingdom, but his application was refused by the Secretary of State for the Home Department, and a deportation order was served on him.

title: CASE OF TARANENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The National Bolshevik Party occupied the President's Administration building in Moscow on 14 December 2004.
- The applicant was not a member of the Party but came to witness and gather information for her master's thesis.
- The applicant was arrested and charged with the attempted violent overthrow of the State and destruction of others' property.
- The applicant's requests for release from detention were denied multiple times, citing the gravity of the charges and risk of absconding or interfering with the investigation.
- The applicant and her co-defendants were found guilty of participation in mass disorder and sentenced to three years' imprisonment, but the sentence was suspended for the applicant.
- During her detention, the applicant was held in overcrowded cells and had health issues but received medical treatment.

title: CASE OF MAVRIČ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- Applicant's age and residence
- Police fine for verbal and physical assault against Š.S.
- Applicant disputes hitting Š.S. in the head
- Request for judicial review and hearing of two witnesses
- Rejection of request for judicial review by Local Court
- Constitutional appeal based on lack of information and opportunity to be heard
- Rejection of constitutional appeal by Constitutional Court

title: CASE OF GLANTZ v. FINLAND
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Klaukkala.
- The tax inspector conducted a tax inspection of the applicant’s attorney’s office in 2006.
- The tax authorities accused the applicant of receiving disguised dividends from his company during the tax years 2000 to 2004.
- The applicant sought rectification, but his request was rejected by the Tax Rectification Committee, the Helsinki Administrative Court and the Supreme Administrative Court.
- The applicant was convicted of embezzlement and tax fraud in 2009 and sentenced to a prison sentence of 2 years and 8 months, as well as ordered to pay the taxation authority EUR 214,168.38 plus interest.
- The applicant appealed to the Helsinki Appeal Court and the Supreme Court, but his appeals were rejected.
- The applicant lodged an application for an extraordinary appeal with the Supreme Court, requesting that the execution of the prison sentence be stayed, but his request was denied.
- The Supreme Court refused the applicant’s request for the reopening of the case and the Chancellor of Justice declined to investigate the matter.

title: CASE OF NYKÄNEN v. FINLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Espoo.
- In 2005, the tax inspector conducted a tax inspection in a company.
- The tax authorities considered that the applicant had received 33,000 euros (EUR) as disguised dividends from that company during the tax year 2003.
- An additional tax and a tax surcharge (veronkorotus, skatteförhöjning) of EUR 1,700 were imposed.
- The applicant sought rectification from the local Tax Rectification Committee (verotuksen oikaisulautakunta, prövningsnämnden i beskattningsärenden).
- The Tax Rectification Committee rejected the applicant’s application on 25 January 2006.
- The Kuopio Administrative Court rejected the applicant’s appeal on 29 May 2008.
- The Supreme Administrative Court refused the applicant leave to appeal on 1 April 2009.
- The public prosecutor brought charges against the applicant of, inter alia, tax fraud concerning the tax year 2003 on 19 August 2008.
- The Tuusula District Court convicted the applicant of tax fraud on 13 February 2009 and imposed a suspended prison sentence of 8 months.
- The Helsinki Appeal Court convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to 10 months in prison on 25 March 2010.
- The Supreme Court refused the applicant leave to appeal on 1 September 2010.

title: CASE OF McDONALD v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant suffered a stroke in 1999 which left her with severely limited mobility and has had several falls since.
- The applicant requires assistance with toileting, particularly at night due to a small and neurogenic bladder, and is unable to access a toilet or commode unaided.
- The Independent Living Fund denied the applicant's request for full day and night support as she ceased to be eligible when she turned 65 in 2008.
- A local authority care plan listed the applicant's need for "assistance with toileting, when it's required during the night".
- The local authority reduced the applicant's weekly care from GBP 703 to GBP 450 and suggested providing incontinence pads in lieu of night-time care.
- The applicant sought judicial review of the local authority's decision, citing a breach of her assessed and eligible needs and her right to respect for her private life under Article 8 of the Convention.
- A "holding compromise" allowed the applicant to continue receiving night-time care five days a week until September 2011 when it was completely withdrawn.
- The Court of Appeal found that the local authority had breached its statutory duty to provide assistance with using a commode between November 2008 and November 2009 but had mitigated this by arranging with the applicant's partner for nighttime care.
- The Supreme Court found that the local authority had reassessed the applicant's needs in 2009 and there was no interference with her Article 8 rights from that point onwards. The majority opinion concluded that the local authority had respected the appellant's personal feelings and desires while also taking into account her safety, independence, and responsibilities towards all their other clients. Lady Hale dissented, arguing that the approach taken was irrational.

title: CASE OF MEĆAVA v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1947 and lives in Smederevo.
- The applicant was employed by “HP Fagram DP”, a socially-owned company based in Smederevo (hereinafter – “the debtor”).
- The Smederevo Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant certain sums in respect of salary arrears, social security contributions and procedural costs on 30 September 2003.
- On 22 October 2003, the judgment became final.
- On 9 January 2004, the applicant lodged an application for enforcement of the above court decision with the Smederevo Municipal Court.
- The court allowed the application and issued an enforcement order on 17 March 2003.
- The Požarevac Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor on 1 September 2004, leading to the ongoing enforcement proceedings before the Smederevo Municipal Court being stayed.
- On 22 November 2004, the applicant duly registered a claim for the sums specified in the judgment referred to above.
- On 26 April 2005, the Commercial Court accepted the applicant’s claim, but his right to separate settlement from the immovable property of the debtor was contested.
- The applicant was instructed to initiate separate civil proceedings to secure his right to separate settlement of his claim but he did not initiate them.
- On 3 April 2008, the Commercial Court adopted the decision on the final distribution of the company’s insolvency assets, classifying the applicant into the fourth sequence of payment.
- In the course of the insolvency proceedings, the final judgment in the applicant’s favor was partially enforced.

title: CASE OF LÁSZLÓ MAGYAR v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently detained at Szeged Prison.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant and his accomplices in 2002 for various violent crimes committed in different villages.
- The investigation showed that the applicant and his co-defendants had committed a series of burglaries against elderly people, tying them up, beating or threatening them until they disclosed the location of their valuables, and leaving them tied up alone in their houses. Some victims died.
- The bill of indictment proposed the hearing of 72 witnesses and two forensic medical experts, and the applicant was indicted on multiple counts of serious offenses, including murder, robbery, and infringement of personal liberty.
- The Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court convicted the applicant of murder, robbery, and other offenses, and he was sentenced to life imprisonment without eligibility for parole.
- The Debrecen Court of Appeal remitted the case to the Regional Court on appeal, and an amended bill of indictment was preferred.
- The Regional Court again convicted the applicant and sentenced him to life imprisonment without eligibility for parole, along with a co-defendant who claimed he was unable to commit one of the crimes due to a surgical procedure.
- The Debrecen Court of Appeal re-characterized the applicant's offenses but upheld his sentence of life imprisonment without eligibility for parole.
- The co-defendant's sentence was mitigated due to his cooperation and expression of remorse.
- The Supreme Court upheld the sentence of life imprisonment without eligibility for parole.
- The applicant submitted that his cell was overcrowded and did not meet basic standards.

title: CASE OF BINIŞAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was electrocuted while performing a customs inspection for a private exporting company, and suffered burns to 70% of his body, requiring 138 days of medical care.
- The accident occurred while the applicant was on top of one of five freight wagons, conducting an inspection on an industrial railway track.
- A special commission investigated the accident and found that several concurrent causes led to the accident, including improper organization of the inspection procedure, failure to observe health and safety regulations, and lack of proper training for performing duties on railway tracks.
- The commission held several parties responsible for the accident, including the manager of the exporting company, the applicant's superior and the company itself for not providing proper training to employees, and the National Railway Company for not observing health and safety regulations.
