- The National Railway Company was held liable by a lower court for the accident, but this decision was later overturned. The manager of the National Railway Company was found guilty of forgery, abuse of office, and using forged documents in a separate criminal case related to the accident.

title: CASE OF ILGAR MAMMADOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is a political figure involved in various organizations.
- The applicant posted a comment on his blog insulting members of the National Assembly, which sparked retaliation from parliamentarians.
- The applicant announced his intention to consider standing as a candidate in the upcoming presidential election.
- Rioting broke out in Ismayilli in January 2013, allegedly sparked by an incident involving a minister's son.
- The government blamed two individuals for the rioting and denied ownership of a hotel believed to be associated with the incident.
- The applicant visited Ismayilli and described the situation on his blog.
- The applicant later published information on his blog revealing that the Chirag Hotel was owned by the minister's son, contradicting government denial.
- The government accused the applicant of inciting social and political destabilization in Ismayilli and summoned him for questioning.
- The applicant denied the accusations, stating that the government was attempting to pressure him for political reasons.

title: CASE OF MUSTAFA ERDOĞAN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- First applicant is Mustafa Erdoğan born in 1956
- Second applicant is Haluk Kürşad Kopuzlu born in 1975
- Mustafa Erdoğan was a professor of constitutional law
- Haluk Kürşad Kopuzlu was the editor of quarterly publication Liberal Thinking
- Liberte A.Ş. is a joint-stock company and publisher of Liberal Thinking
- Buhay Baytekin applied to the Court on behalf of the publishing company.

title: CASE OF BAKA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was elected as President of the Supreme Court for a six-year term on June 22, 2009.
- He also served as President of the National Council of Justice, with an obligation to express an opinion on parliamentary bills affecting the judiciary.
- The applicant expressed his views on several issues affecting the judiciary, including the Nullification Bill, the retirement age of judges, amendments to the Code of Criminal Procedure, and the Organisation and Administration of the Courts Bill.
- Though he expressed his views in a professional capacity, several politicians criticized him for trying to exert influence over the legislative process.
- Several Bills were submitted to Parliament proposing amendments to the constitution and the Organisation and Administration of the Courts Bill. These Bills, if enacted, would have resulted in the termination of the applicant's mandate as President of the Supreme Court.
- On 1 January 2012, the applicant's mandate as President of the Supreme Court was terminated, three and a half years before its normal date of expiry.
- Péter Darák was subsequently elected as the new President of the Kúria, and Tünde Handó as President of the National Judicial Office.

title: CASE OF RADKOV AND SABEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1972 and 1966 and were serving life imprisonment at Lovech prison.
- They brought proceedings against the Ministry of Justice under the State and Municipalities Responsibility for Damage Act.
- Sofia City Court examined the case and allowed fellow inmates to be questioned as witnesses.
- A special court hearing was held on 26 January 2007 in Lovech prison with the applicants brought in handcuffs and shackles.
- Handcuffs were not removed despite one applicant's discomfort, while witnesses' handcuffs were removed.
- The hearing lasted for about an hour.

title: CASE OF ALBERGAS AND ARLAUSKAS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The first applicant was assigned a plot of land in 1994 for constructing a house, based on their status as a deportee’s family member.
- The first applicant purchased the plot of land from the State in 1995 by paying a specified amount and made the registration in his name.
- The first applicant sold the bought plot in 1997 to the second applicant by receiving a sum of cash.
- The second applicant had a dispute with R.A over fencing of the plot, leading R.A to file a counterclaim to restore her ownership rights to the disputed plot.
- The courts granted the second applicant’s claim and annulled the land sale contracts of 1995 and 1997 and assigned the plot of land back to the State.
- The Supreme court overturned the decisions of the lower courts in favor of restoring the ownership rights to R.A as the local authorities had not been allowed to sell the land before the ownership rights had been restored to former owners under the developed principle of priority for former owners’ rights.
- The applicants applied to the National Land Service regarding their incurred loss but were dismissed.
- The administrative and civil courts also dismissed the claim of the applicants, citing that they had purchased the plot of land in "bad faith".
- Finally, the applicants paid the second applicant and did not appeal against the decision of the Vilnius City First District Court that dismissed their claim against the municipality.

title: CASE OF GOŁAWSKI AND PISAREK v. POLAND
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1961 and 1956 respectively and live in Warsaw.
- On 2 June 1997, civil action was lodged against a third party for protection against copyright infringement.
- The motion to secure the claims was dismissed on 15 September 2000.
- The case had multiple hearings held on specific dates.
- On 30 May 2007, the Łódź Regional Court awarded the applicants 1,000 Polish Zlotys (PLN) and dismissed the remaining claims.
- On 13 December 2007, the Łódź Court of Appeal quashed and remitted the first-instance judgment.
- The first hearing after re-examination was held on 29 October 2008.
- On 11 March 2013, the Łódź Regional Court found in part for the applicants and dismissed the remainder.
- The proceedings appear to be pending before the second-instance court.
- Applicants lodged multiple complaints under section 5 of the 2004 Act.
- Each applicant was awarded PLN 3,000 (approx. 700 euros (EUR)) by the Łódź Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF HOSZOWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Kraków.
- The applicant became a party to proceedings for division of joint property.
- On 18 December 1995, the Kraków–Śródmieście District Court gave a severance order and decided to examine the applicant’s motion in separate proceedings.
- The proceedings have been pending before the first‑instance court since 18 December 1995.
- The applicant lodged three complaints under section 5 of the Law of 17 June 2004 on complaints about a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time.
- On 26 November 2008, the applicant sought a finding that the length of the proceedings had been excessive and claimed 10,000 Polish zlotys (PLN) in compensation.
- On 2 February 2009, the Kraków Regional Court granted the applicant PLN 1,000 acknowledging that the proceedings had indeed been lengthy.
- On 7 July 2010, the Kraków Regional Court allowed another applicant’s complaint under the 2004 Act and awarded the applicant PLN 2,000 in compensation.
- In 2012, the applicant again lodged a complaint under the 2004 Act, seeking a finding that the length of the proceedings had been excessive and claiming PLN 20,000 in compensation.
- On 14 August 2012, the Kraków Regional Court awarded the applicant PLN 2,000 in compensation, holding that the trial court had failed to act in an effective and diligent manner, in particular in the light of the overall length of the proceedings in issue.

title: CASE OF KOPNIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are former husband and wife and their two children, who live in Stavropol.
- The building they lived in was declared unsuitable for habitation in 1986 and was at imminent risk of collapse by 2003.
- The district court acknowledged the building's critical state and ordered the Council to rehouse the applicants within ten days and provide suitable housing.
- The offer of rehousing from the Council's temporary stock was refused by the applicants, and enforcement proceedings were terminated due to the impossibility of enforcing the judgment.
- The district court found that the flat offered by the Council was unsuitable and quashed the decision to terminate the enforcement proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the Council's failure to comply with the judgment, but their complaint was dismissed.
- The Council offered housing to three of the applicants, but they refused on the grounds of non-compliance with housing standards.
- The applicants lodged claims seeking to oblige the Council to provide them with suitable housing, which were rejected, but eventually all four applicants were provided with social housing in accordance with the new Housing Code.
- The non-pecuniary damage awarded to the first applicant was transferred to their bank account.

title: CASE OF AKRAM KARIMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a practising Muslim from Uzbekistan who has regularly travelled to Russia for seasonal work since 1996.
- In absentia, the applicant was charged with incitement of national, racial, ethnic or religious hatred, and producing and disseminating documents containing threats to national security and public order in Uzbekistan.
- The applicant was placed on the wanted list of the Bukhara Regional Department of National Security, Uzbekistan, and was subsequently detained by the police in Moscow on 17 March 2012.
- The government of Uzbekistan requested the applicant's extradition, and the prosecutor of the Meshchanskiy District of Moscow detained him for the extradition proceedings on 19 March 2012.
- The applicant was placed in SIZO No. 4 in Moscow and was later denied release on multiple appeals.
- The six-month maximum period of detention permitted by domestic law was reached on 17 September 2012, and the applicant was released before being re-arrested for administrative offences relating to his residence in Russia.
- The prosecutor of the Russian Federation informed the prosecutor of Moscow on 18 September 2012 that the request for extradition to Uzbekistan had been refused.
- The case file was submitted to the Meshchanskiy District Court of Moscow on 19 September 2012, and the applicant's counsel argued that the applicant's removal to Uzbekistan would be unlawful due to the risk of torture and ill-treatment, and the pending refugee status proceedings.

title: CASE OF KHANUSTARANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Achisu, the Republic of Dagestan.
- On 31 January 2005, the applicant applied to the district court for readjustment of compensation for the damage to his son's health awarded by judgments of 13 August and 4 December 2002 against OAO Dagenergo.
- On 19 April 2005, the Sovetskiy District Court of Makhachkala allowed the claim, and the court awarded the applicant 61,607 Russian roubles in readjustment.
- On an unspecified date, the company initiated supervisory review proceedings.
- On 6 October 2005, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Dagestan Republic quashed the judgments of 19 April and 20 May 2005 and remitted the case.
- On 22 November 2005, the Sovetskiy District Court of Makhachkala ruled against the applicant, finding the new legislation inapplicable to the case at hand.
- On 10 February 2006, the Supreme Court of the Dagestan Republic upheld that judgment on appeal.
- The applicant was a party to several sets of civil proceedings.
- In 1999, he brought an action in connection with an injury sustained by his son.
- On 13 August 2002, the district court allowed the applicant's claim.
- On 19 December 2002, the district court issued a writ of enforcement.
- On 25 April 2006, the applicant sued the Department of Education of Izberbash at the Izberbash Town Court on a work-related matter.
- The applicant sought reinstatement in his job and work-related benefits.
- On 16 August 2006, the town court rejected the applicant's action in full.
- The applicant was also engaged in a housing dispute.
- On 27 January 2003, the Izberbash Town Council refused to provide him with housing.

title: CASE OF SAMAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Penza.
- The applicant sued the Penza town administration and the Penza committee for municipal property management.
- The applicant sought to obtain free of charge the title to a plot of land under the office building he owned.
- On 16 November 2005, the District Court held for the applicant and ordered the town administration to establish his title to the land at issue. 
- The judgment was not appealed against and became final.
- On 7 March 2006, the Penza town administration lodged an application for supervisory review. 
- On 19 June 2006, the Presidium of the Penza Regional Court quashed the judgment of 16 November 2005. 
- The Presidium considered that the District Court had incorrectly established the facts of the case and erroneously applied the domestic material law.
- The case was remitted to the District Court for consideration anew. 
- On 10 August 2006, the District Court dismissed the applicant's claim in full. 
- The applicant did not appeal, and the judgment became final.

title: CASE OF KUZMIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1937 and retired military serviceman
- Justice of the Peace of the 2nd Court Circuit of Novocherkassk ordered the recovery of applicant's pension arrears
- Applicant brought a second claim seeking a further adjustment to his pension
- Novocherkassk Town Court allowed the claim and awarded compensation to the applicant
- Respondent authority appealed the judgement but later withdrew their statement of appeal
- Respondent authority requested re-examination of the case in light of newly discovered circumstances
- Rostov Regional Court quashed the judgment and transferred the case for fresh examination by a different court
- Applicant did not attend the hearing and the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Rostov rejected the claim as having no basis in law

title: CASE OF HABIMI AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
1. Protests broke out in several prisons across the country demanding the enactment of amnesty-related legislation in November 2006.
2. Violent conflicts occurred on November 22, 2006, between radical and moderate groups of prisoners in Nis Penitentiary.
3. The prevailing group of prisoners demanded that all prison staff vacate the dormitories, and almost 600 prisoners were left unsupervised.
4. The governor formed a crisis team on the same day, and a large-scale intervention was deemed necessary.
5. On November 24, 2006, more than 330 special police officers entered the Nis Penitentiary to restore order.
6. A total of 79 prisoners were found to have sustained injuries, most of which were slight in nature.
7. The applicants claimed that they were physically abused during the intervention, leading to various injuries.
8. Several violent clashes between groups of prisoners resulted in serious injuries and a criminal prosecution in the past.
9. The NMPPO rejected the applicants' criminal complaints as it considered the force used to be lawful and proportionate.
10. The pre-trial chamber ordered for the applicants to be heard despite the initial negative opinion expressed by the investigating judge.
11. Several applicants recounted the alleged abuse suffered at the hands of police officers and/or prison guards but could not identify the police officers because of their visors.

title: CASE OF LÓPEZ GUIÓ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Spanish national living in Madrid.
- He had a child with a Slovak national who was born in Slovakia in 2009.
- In July 2010, the mother took the child from Spain to Slovakia and never returned.
- The mother petitioned the District Court in Slovakia for an order governing parental rights and responsibilities in August 2010.
- The court issued an interim order in September 2010, placing the child with the mother and requesting the applicant to contribute to maintenance.
- The District Court established that the child's place of habitual residence was in Spain and the Slovakian courts did not have jurisdiction.
- The applicant complained about the removal and retention of the child by the mother before the Spanish Central Authority responsible for implementing the Hague Convention.
- The applicant lodged an application under the Hague Convention for the child's return to Spain in October 2010.
- The District Court ordered the child's return to Spain in November 2010, which the mother appealed.
- The Regional Court dismissed the mother's appeal in January 2011 and affirmed the order for the child's return to Spain.
- The mother lodged an appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court in February 2011, which was declared inadmissible in March 2011.
- The mother filed a petition to have the Hague Convention proceedings reopened in June 2011, which was dismissed in October 2011.
- The mother did not abide by the order for the child's return to Spain despite the applicant's request to do so in February 2011.

title: CASE OF KHADZHIEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
1. The applicant worked as deputy chair of the Central Bank of Turkmenistan and became a member of the political movement “Watan” in 2000.
2. Due to his political activity, members of the applicant’s family were subjected to persecution in Turkmenistan, with his sister being tortured and murdered in prison in 2006.
3. On 10 March 2004, the Bulgarian authorities granted humanitarian status to the applicant under the Asylum and Refugees Act 2002.
4. In 2002, the Turkmen authorities charged the applicant with embezzlement and forging documents, and filed a request with the Bulgarian authorities for his extradition.
5. The Varna Regional Court initially granted detention orders but later refused the extradition request in 2003, citing lack of evidence and potential violation of Article 3 of the Convention.
6. The applicant lodged claims for damages against the police and the Chief Prosecutor’s Office, which were partially upheld in a series of judgments and appeals between 2004 and 2007.
7. In 2007, the Turkmen authorities renewed their request for extradition, citing the same charges, but the Varna courts refused extradition again, citing procedural obstacles and risk of violating the applicant’s rights.
8. However, the applicant was later placed in provisional detention for forty days in 2007, based on a new prosecutor’s decree and a risk of absconding and reoffending, despite earlier termination of the criminal proceedings against him in 2004.

title: CASE OF ROSSI AND VARIALE v. ITALY
facts:
- Applicants were born in different years and live in different cities.
- The applicants inherited a plot of land in Crispano, which was recorded in the land register as Folio no. 2, Parcel no. 44.
- The Mayor of Crispano issued a decree authorizing the municipality to take possession of 416 square meters of the applicants' land for the construction of a road.
- The authorities took physical possession of the land on 23 March 1982.
- The applicants brought an action for damages against the Crispano Municipality in the Naples District Court in 1990, alleging that the occupation of the land was illegal and claimed a sum corresponding to the market value of the land and a further sum in damages for the loss of enjoyment of the land and compensation for the demolition of buildings and the destruction of crops present on the land.
- An expert valuation of the land was ordered, and in a report submitted on 5 November 1996, the market value of the land was identified to correspond to 73,682 Italian lire (ITL) per square meter.
- The Naples District Court declared the possession of the land to be unlawful on 31 May 2000, and the applicants were entitled to compensation for the loss of ownership caused by the unlawful occupation.
- The court considered the land as building land and awarded the applicants compensation in the sum of ITL 61,339,393, plus additional compensation for the unavailability of the land during the period of lawful occupation and compensation for the demolition of buildings and destruction of crops.
- The Municipality appealed against the order before the Naples Court of Appeal, which awarded the applicants EUR 48,899.90 for the loss of ownership and EUR 7,090.90 as compensation for the period of lawful occupation. 
- The judgment became final on 31 October 2004.

title: CASE OF YİĞİTDOĞAN v. TURKEY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Kocaeli.
- On 25th July 1999, he was arrested on suspicion of being a member of an illegal organisation, and the police had to use force to arrest him as he tried to escape.
- The applicant underwent medical examination twice, and the reports indicated no indication of ill-treatment except for a healing scratch.
- The applicant was transferred to Istanbul and claimed to have been ill-treated during his police custody there.
- The police searched the applicant's residence and found several guns and cartridges.
- The applicant was examined by a doctor who noted a swelling, a bruise, and a scratch on his right elbow as well as another scratch on his arm.
- The applicant was kept in police custody, and his police custody was extended for three days.
- The applicant made statements to the police in the absence of a lawyer, and later in front of the investigating judge retained them.
- The applicant underwent several medical examinations, with one doctor recommending an orthopaedic consultation and another recommending a urological consultation.
- The applicant claimed that he had been severely beaten during his arrest and had been subjected to electric shocks, hung by the arms, hosed with cold water, and sexually assaulted during his seven-day police custody.
- Although the applicant had asked the court to obtain the medical reports, they were not produced in court, and the applicant's lawyer appealed to obtain them.
- Eventually, the Istanbul Assize Court found the applicant guilty, and the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment.

title: CASE OF JÁHNY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Ajka.
- The applicant and Pápa és Vidéke ÁFÉSZ, a legal person, concluded a lease contract on 22 July 1990.
- The applicant failed to pay the monthly rental fees between October 1993 and October 1994.
- Pápa és Vidéke ÁFÉSZ terminated the lease contract on 26 October 1994.
- Pápa és Vidéke ÁFÉSZ lodged a compensation claim with the Veszprém County Regional Court against the applicant in November 1994.
- The first-instance court ordered the applicant to pay the overdue rental fees (approximately 1,600 euros (EUR)) and accrued interests to the plaintiff.
- On appeal, the Budapest Court of Appeal upheld the judgment on 2 December 2003.
- The applicant's petition for review with the Supreme Court was rejected on 8 December 2005. 
- The decision was served on the applicant on 26 January 2006.

title: CASE OF ŠEMIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Ljubljana.
- The applicant served a prison sentence in Ljubljana prison from 16 July 2009 to 31 December 2010, but he was released on 27 December 2010.
- The applicant was held in a closed section of the prison from 16 July 2009 to 23 September 2009 and from 24 February 2010 to 27 December 2010.
- The applicant was held in different cells ranging from 17.47 square meters to 18 square meters, including a separate sanitary facility that measures 1.68 to 1.72 square meters.
- The number of prisoners held in the same cell as the applicant varied from two to six.

title: CASE OF EGIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- D.P.V. brought a civil action against M.V. seeking to be declared joint owner of a house and surrounding land on an island off the coast of Croatia, and payment of DEM 30,000.
- The Biograd na Moru Municipal Court ordered an onsite inspection of the property, including an expert valuation.
- The expert assessed the value of the property at HRK 208,575.66.
- The Municipal Court declared D.P.V. owner of a one half share of the property and ordered M.V. to pay DEM 30,000.
- M.V. lodged an appeal and later an appeal on points of law and a constitutional complaint.
- The Supreme Court noted that the value of the half share of the property had not been assessed and requested the Municipal Court to determine its value.
- M.V. died and bequeathed all her property to the applicant, who later took over the proceedings.
- The parties argued over the value of the dispute, with the plaintiff setting it at HRK 10,000 and the defendant at least HRK 101,000.
- The Municipal Court issued a decision setting the value of the ownership claim to HRK 10,000.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the plaintiff’s claim for DEM 30,000 and declared the appeal on points of law concerning D.P.V.’s ownership claim inadmissible ratione valoris.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against the Supreme Court’s decision, which was dismissed by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF HIT D.D. NOVA GORICA v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant company operates gaming and entertainment centres in Slovenia.
- The managing director instituted disciplinary proceedings against an employee, N.N., for excessive and irresponsible use of company funds.
- The disciplinary board terminated N.N.'s employment, which she appealed.
- The lower court dismissed N.N.'s appeal, but the Higher Labour and Social Court ordered the applicant company to reinstate her.
- The case went to the Supreme Court, which remitted it to the Higher Labour and Social Court for fresh consideration.
- The Higher Labour and Social Court ordered the case to be remitted to the first-instance court for further examination.
- Eventually, the Koper Labour Court declared the termination of N.N.'s employment null and void and awarded compensation for lost wages and benefits.
- The applicant company lodged a constitutional appeal, which was refused by the Constitutional Court in a three-judge panel.

title: CASE OF KOLAR v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Maribor
- On 16 January 1992, the applicant filed a case against the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Spatial Planning, requesting an injunction against the construction of a dam
- The applicant later changed the claim to payment of pecuniary damages
- The court scheduled three main hearings before the Convention came into force in respect of Slovenia, and two more hearings were held in 1996
- Two additional hearings were adjourned due to the applicant's health problems
- On 30 March 1999, the court held the last main hearing and dismissed the applicant's claim, after which the applicant made an appeal
- On 14 September 1999, the Maribor Higher Court remitted the case back to the first instance court
- Five hearings were held in the new proceedings between 11 January 2001 and 7 November 2002
- On 11 July 2006, the Maribor Higher Court granted the applicant's claim in part, and both parties made an appeal on points of law
- On 8 May 2008, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's claim by upholding the defendant's appeal on points of law
- The applicant made a constitutional complaint, which was dismissed by the Constitutional Court on 28 November 2008.

title: CASE OF AKOPYAN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and resides in Kharkiv.
- In 1985 she got married and gave birth to her first daughter. In 1987 she gave birth to her second daughter.
- The applicant’s relationship with her husband deteriorated and in August 1994 she and her daughters moved into a house rented by her husband in the village of Pisochyn.
- In late November or the beginning of December 1994, the applicant’s husband took the children back to Kharkiv. The applicant was left alone.
- On 17 December 1994, the applicant was admitted to Kharkiv Regional Psychiatric Hospital due to signs of a mental disorder.
- Between January 1995 and November 1997, the applicant repeatedly asked to be discharged from the psychiatric hospital and lodged complaints about her internment.
- On 7 November 1997, the applicant escaped from the psychiatric hospital and found shelter with some acquaintances. By that time she was divorced.
- On 23 December 1997, at the applicant’s request, she was admitted to Kharkiv Municipal Psychiatric Hospital for in-patient psychiatric assessment. Her mental health was found to be normal, and she was discharged on 4 February 1998.
- Following the applicant’s complaint, criminal proceedings were instituted against P., the applicant’s doctor, on suspicion of unlawful placement of the applicant in a psychiatric hospital.
- An expert panel conducted a forensic psychiatric examination and found that the applicant was not suffering from any mental illness.
- The case file was destroyed in a fire at the court house in 2000 but was remitted to the prosecutor’s office for supplementary investigation.
- The applicant filed civil claims seeking compensation for the damage sustained as a result of her unjustified hospitalisation.
- The Chervonozavodsky District Court of Kharkiv found that the applicant had been wrongly diagnosed, mistakenly treated, and unable to freely exercise her rights or manage her life during her wrongful stay in the psychiatric hospital.
- The court awarded the applicant UAH 7,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF TERESHCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant was born in 1964 and is serving a prison sentence in the Voronezh Region.
- On 19 September 2002, a search of the applicant's flat was carried out, and he was charged with drug trafficking.
- On 19 September 2003, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of causing bodily harm to another person.
- On 23 September 2003, Judge M. of the Talovskiy District Court, the Voronezh Region ("the District Court") authorized the applicant's continued detention.
- On 27 November 2003, the District Court convicted the applicant of drug trafficking.
- In February 2004, the District Court issued a decision admitting the applicant's mother, K., as the applicant's lay defender in the appeal proceedings concerning the drug-trafficking conviction.
- On 22 November 2004, the District Court convicted the applicant of causing bodily harm resulting in the victim's death.
- On 31 March 2005, the Voronezh Regional Court ("the Regional Court") quashed the judgment of 22 November 2004, ordering a retrial.
- On 7 September 2005, the District Court discontinued the case against the applicant on charges of drug trafficking, because the prosecutor had dropped the charges.
- On 24 January 2006, the District Court convicted the applicant of causing bodily harm resulting in the victim's death, and on 20 April 2006, the Regional Court upheld the conviction and sentence.
- Between 2002 and 2009, the applicant lodged numerous complaints, initiated proceedings against various public officials and accused them of criminal offences, contesting criminal proceedings against him or complaining about the conditions of his detention.
- The applicant was detained in various detention centers on numerous occasions between September 2003 and 2008.
- The applicant complained about the physical conditions of the Talovskiy TDC, including inadequate bedding, lack of facilities for shower and outdoor exercise, and one meal a day, among others.
- The applicant's complaints about his repeated and prolonged detention in the Talovskiy TDC were rejected as unfounded, and the President of the District Court declined jurisdiction to deal with his complaints.

title: CASE OF MARGARETIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant is a police officer from Osijek, born in 1969.
- On March 23, 2012, he was arrested for suspected conspiracy and abuse of power.
- He was detained for two months under Article 123 § 1(2) and (3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure for risk of collusion, risk of reoffending, and as it was necessary to collect further physical evidence.
- The State Attorney's Office also opened an investigation against him and six other suspects for suspected conspiracy and abuse of power and authority.
- The applicant and the State Attorney's Office lodged appeals against the investigating judge's decision on the applicant's detention.
- The Zagreb County Court allowed the appeal of the State Attorney’s Office and reversed the investigating judge’s decision on the applicant's conditional release on bail.
- There were concerns that the applicant might coordinate his defence with the second suspect, who was still at large, and that he might interfere with the seizure of further physical evidence and suborn nine witnesses.
- The applicant's detention was extended several times because of the risk of collusion, and there were concerns that he might suborn witnesses.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint against the decision on his detention as ill-founded, endorsing the reasoning of the lower courts.

title: CASE OF MIHAI LAURENȚIU MARIN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and is currently detained in Măgineni Prison. 
- The applicant stated in his initial letters that he had been detained in overcrowded and unheated cells. 
- The applicant was detained and transferred between a number of prisons, including Poarta Albă and Măgineni Prisons. 
- Records concerning the cells the applicant had been detained in and the number of detainees he had shared the cells with between 2006 and 2010 were destroyed in accordance with domestic legislation. 
- The applicant was detained in several cells in Poarta Albă and Măgineni Prisons, with living spaces ranging from 1.62 to 5.03 square meters. 
- The prisons had central heating systems, with heating schedules based on available supplies and outdoor temperatures. 
- Each cell had electrical power and was furnished with individual beds, tables, chairs, and benches.

title: CASE OF VOICU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was a lawyer and senator living in Bucharest.
- The Anti-Corruption Department of the Prosecutor's Office accused the applicant of accepting money for trading in influence related to cases pending before the High Court of Cassation and Justice.
- On 11 December 2009, armed individuals handcuffed the applicant and took him to the prosecutor's office, where he was informed of the allegations.
- The applicant was initially prevented from leaving town for 30 days but was eventually placed in pre-trial detention.
- The applicant appealed for conditional release multiple times, but the court repeatedly extended his detention.
- The applicant was held in several different cells throughout his detention. The cells were overcrowded, lacked basic hygiene, and had poor living conditions.
- The applicant was transported in a prison van for two hours without proper heating or lighting on one occasion.

title: CASE OF MARIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant's wife gave birth to a stillborn child at a publicly owned hospital.
- The hospital assumed responsibility for the body after the applicant and his wife did not want to take it.
- An autopsy carried out by the hospital showed the child had died due to gestational complications.
- The hospital disposed of the child's body the same way as other clinical waste and cremated it with a contractor.
- The applicant and his wife sought damages from the hospital for distress caused by the improper disposal of their child's body.
- The hospital argued it acted in accordance with regulations governing clinical waste disposal.
- The lower courts dismissed the case, holding that, in compliance with the law, the hospital and the contractor had disposed of the child's body with other clinical waste.
- The courts found no obligation for the hospital to inform the parents about the burial of the stillborn child.
- The Supreme Court, as well as the Constitutional Court, affirmed the decisions of the lower courts.

title: CASE OF COUDERC AND HACHETTE FILIPACCHI ASSOCIÉS v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicants are the publication director and publisher of Paris Match, a weekly magazine.
- On May 3rd, 2005, the Daily Mail published claims by Ms C. that Albert Grimaldi, the reigning Prince of Monaco, was the father of her son.
- Paris Match published an interview with Ms C. on May 5th, 2005, in which she presented her son as having been born from her intimate relationship with the Prince.
- The Prince served notice to refrain from publishing the article, but Paris Match went ahead anyway.
- The Prince brought proceedings against Paris Match on the basis of Article 8 of the Convention and Articles 9 and 1382 of the Civil Code, seeking compensation for invasion of privacy and infringement of his right to protection of his image.
- The Nanterre tribunal de grande instance allowed the Prince's claim, awarding him 50,000 euros in damages, and ordering that the judgment be printed on the magazine's front page.
- The Versailles Court of Appeal upheld the judgment and ordered the publication of a statement on the front page of Paris Match.
- The applicants appealed on points of law, but the Court of Cassation dismissed the appeal.
- The interview and disputed photographs were also published in the German magazine Bunte, and the Prince's case against that magazine was dismissed by the German courts.
- The German courts placed the public's right to information over the Prince's interests in protection of his private life.

title: CASE OF JELIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- In November 1991, five armed men in camouflage uniforms and balaclavas took the applicant's husband, Vaso Jelić, of Serbian ethnic origin, from their house in Sisak.
- The applicant reported the incident to the police the same evening.
- Vaso Jelić's body was found on the banks of the river Kupa in Sisak in February 1992. An autopsy showed that he had been shot dead.
- The Sisak Police lodged a criminal complaint, but no further investigative measures were taken until September 1999.
- In September 1999, a witness told the Prevention of Terrorism Unit in the Criminal Justice Section of the Sisak County Police that 54 Serbs had been killed in Sisak and 29 in Kinjačka, and about 500 had disappeared.
- The witness also said that Đ.B., then Head of the Sisak Police, had expressed surprise that one of the victims had been killed, given that he had not been on the list for liquidation.
- The applicant reiterated her statement to the police in December 2000.
- The police interviewed several witnesses in 2001 and 2002, who implicated Đ.B. and other members of the police in the killings of Serbs.
- In 2011, Đ.B., V.M., and D.B. were arrested and charged with war crimes against the civilian population.
- V.M. was found guilty in 2013 and the applicant's claim for compensation was dismissed.

title: CASE OF BIBLICAL CENTRE OF THE CHUVASH REPUBLIC v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The Chuvash Christian mission "Voice of Truth" was registered as a religious organization in 1991 under the RSFSR Religions Act of 25 October 1990, belonging to the Pentecostal movement of the Christian faith.
- In 1998, it was renamed the Biblical Centre of the Evangelical (Pentecostal) Christians of the Chuvash Republic and had the right to found institutions of professional religious education, spiritual educational institutions, including Sunday schools for youth and children, and to establish non-commercial organizations pursuing educational aims.
- The Biblical Centre founded the Middle Volga Biblical College and a Sunday school, which were not registered as legal entities, and students were trained as pastors, preachers, missionaries, Sunday school teachers, preceptors, biblical signers for the deaf, and youth leaders. The subjects taught at the College included theology, exegesis, homiletics, apologetics, history of Christianity, basics of pedagogy, theory of music, memorization, and others.
- In 2007, a prosecutor conducted an inspection of the premises and found violations of fire safety regulations and health and hygiene standards.
- The director of the Biblical Centre was found guilty of conducting educational activities without authorization and was sentenced to pay a fine.
- The applicant organization was found liable for violating sanitary rules and hygienic requirements and received a warning.
- The Novocheboksarsk town prosecutor filed a claim for dissolution of the Biblical Centre, alleging illegal educational activities.
- The Supreme Court ordered the dissolution of the applicant organization and removal from the State Register of Legal Entities.
- The Supreme Court held that the educational activities conducted by the applicant organization without a license amounted to a gross and repeated violation of the requirements of the Education Act and Religions Act.

title: CASE OF CHUPRIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently serving a prison sentence in correctional colony IK-3 in the Ryazan Region.
- On 10 June 2004, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder and charged with aiding and abetting murder.
- On 12 June 2004, the court authorized his detention pending investigation.
- The court then extended the applicant’s detention until 26 September 2004, 26 November 2004, and subsequently until 1 August 2005.
- Charges against the applicant for murder were dropped, and instead, charges of kidnapping and robbery were brought against him in November 2004.
- On 27 April 2006, he was convicted of kidnapping and sentenced to nine years' imprisonment, but the judgment was quashed before being remitted for retrial. This retrial was again quashed on 13 July 2006.
- The applicant was released from detention in December 2006, but he was remanded in custody again on 26 January 2007.
- He was convicted of kidnapping on 28 June 2007 and sentenced to six years' imprisonment.
- The applicant brought proceedings for damages against the Federal Treasury and the Ministry of Finance for his unlawful detention from 12 October to 26 December 2006, but the claim was rejected.

title: CASE OF PRIMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- On 10 April 2006, a group informed the district authorities of a public demonstration they planned to hold in the village of Usukhchay on 25 April 2006
- The demonstration aimed to criticise corruption and the misuse of public funds by the local administration and draw attention to law-enforcement agencies' inactivity.
- The park in Usukhchay was not supposed to admit more than 500 people according to the administration.
- On 19 April 2006, a group of people armed with wooden sticks, iron rods and similar objects arrived at the police roadblock and pushed them out of their way.
- The second applicant was arrested on 21 April 2006, suspected of committing a crime under Article 212 § 3 (“Mass riots”), and Article 318 § 1 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation. He was released on 20 June 2006.
- On 25 April 2006, a group of about 1,000 people gathered. The police opened fire with automatic rifles, tear gas, smoke bombs and stun grenades to disperse the demonstration.
- One person was shot dead, five people were severely injured.
- The police had to use two stun grenades, twenty-three tear-gas grenades, thirty-six rubber bullets, and fired 747 shots from automatic rifles above the heads of the crowd.

title: CASE OF L.M. v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant has suffered from a psychotic disorder for a number of years.
- The present case concerns two consecutive periods of confinement in psychiatric hospitals between July 2005 and January 2006.
- On 10 July 2005, the applicant broke into an unoccupied house and was admitted to the Idrija Psychiatric Hospital.
- The applicant signed a consent form for confinement and psychiatric treatment and was diagnosed with schizophrenia.
- The Idrija Local Court appointed a lawyer to represent the applicant at a confinement hearing.
- The applicant continued her treatment and agreed to therapy.
- She gave power of attorney to a lawyer on 30 July 2005 who informed the hospital that the applicant did not consent to her medical treatment.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against her involuntary confinement and an application for a review of the constitutionality of sections of the Health Services Act and Non-Contentious Civil Procedure Act.
- On 12 August 2005, the applicant was discharged from the Idrija Psychiatric Hospital.
- On 15 August 2005, the applicant was taken to the Ljubljana Psychiatric Hospital for treatment.
- The Ljubljana Local Court appointed a lawyer to represent the applicant in her involuntary confinement proceedings.
- The applicant appealed against her confinement and dismissal of interlocutory order application.
- On 9 September 2005, the Ljubljana Higher Court allowed the applicant's appeal and remitted the case to the first-instance court.
- On 22 September 2005, the applicant lodged a supervisory appeal with the Ministry of Justice regarding the proceedings before the Ljubljana Local Court.

title: CASE OF KARAIVANOVA AND MILEVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were acknowledged as heirs to their father's rights over a plot of land by the sea coast in the area around Sozopol, acquired in the 1930s pursuant to legislation allocating agricultural land to refugees.
- The land was considered abandoned in the 1950s and later entered in the register of state-owned property. During the same period, the municipality of Stara Zagora took over the use of the land and constructed a student summer camp.
- In 1991, following the enactment of the Agricultural Land Act, the applicants applied for the restitution of the land. The Sozopol agricultural land commission held that the land was to be restored in its "actual boundaries".
- The applicants did not assume actual possession of the land, which remained occupied by the student camp.
- The Sozopol land commission reversed its earlier decision concerning the same property and refused to restore the land to the applicants. The applicants brought a judicial review, arguing that the decision was unlawful and should be quashed.
- The Burgas District Court quashed the decision of the land commission and held that the applicants were entitled to have the 879 square meters of land restored "in actual boundaries". It found that the applicants were entitled to the restitution of the land and there was no evidence to establish that any lawful construction works were carried out prior to the ALA's entry into force.
- The Stara Zagora municipality contested the lower courts' conclusion that it had not itself become an owner of the land. The Supreme Court pointed out that former owners of agricultural land were not entitled to restitution in kind where construction carried out on it prevented its return.
- The Regional Court dismissed the applicants' rei vindicatio claim, accepting the Stara Zagora municipality's objection that section 10b of the ALA prohibited restitution of land in cases where "a complex of construction works" had been put in place on the plot.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation upheld the Regional Court's judgment, finding that the land could not be returned to its former owners due to the presence of permanent and temporary buildings forming part of a "complex of construction works." The applicants did not seek compensation in lieu of restitution.

title: CASE OF ZAMFIRACHI v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant, Adrian Richart Zamfirachi, is a Romanian lawyer from Bucharest.
- On 23 April 2010, he was placed in pre-trial detention for twenty-nine days on charges of organizing a criminal group and trading in influence.
- The applicant claimed that he was handcuffed to a co-accused when brought before the courts, and that his pre-trial detention was degrading.
- The post-sentencing judge dismissed the applicant's complaint about his restraint, finding that detainees had to be restrained when passing through public areas.
- From 23 April to 27 July 2010, the applicant was detained in cells of the Bucharest Police Department (Arestul Direcției Generale a Poliției Municipiului București).
- The applicant claimed that he was detained in a cell with five other inmates with a squat toilet, no sink, and no proper means of washing himself or cutlery.
- On 31 May 2010, the applicant's cell was disinfected with chemical substances, and all six inmates began to feel unwell afterwards.
- The Government claimed that the cell was equipped with six beds, a table with chairs, a sink, and a shower which were separated from the rest of the cell by a curtain. The cell was cleaned by the inmates.
- The applicant claimed that the court-house cells where he was held during court hearings lacked windows, running water, and functioning sanitary facilities.
- The Government claimed that court-house cells in the Bucharest Court of Appeal were substantially renovated and fitted with modern equipment and facilities, including sanitary facilities, permanent running water, ventilation system, and heating system.
- The applicant claimed that he was transported to court hearings in unheated and unventilated cars for a period of more than 200 days.
- The Government claimed that the vehicles used to transport detainees were equipped with metal nets or grids and locks to protect police escort officers. They were in adequate condition with overhead windows for light and ventilation, as well as heating and electrical equipment.

title: CASE OF UNIYA OOO AND BELCOURT TRADING COMPANY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Criminal case against Mr Golovkin
- Seizure and destruction of the first consignment of alcohol belonging to Belcourt and Uniya
- "Special ruling" of the Baltiyskiy District Court
- Criminal investigation of the destruction of the alcohol
- Complaints by Uniya, Belcourt, and Mr Golovkin under Article 125 of the CCrP
- Tort claims by Belcourt and Uniya against the state and related proceedings
- Seizure, expert examination, and destruction of the second consignment of alcohol
- Attempts by Uniya to obtain and sell the second consignment of alcohol
- Tort claims by Uniya against the state
- Seizure of additional 37,184 bottles of alcohol and compensation proceedings
- Other court proceedings related to the seizure of the alcohol
- Information on the status of the applicant companies.

title: CASE OF SHEKHOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and is serving a sentence in a correctional colony in the Chelyabinsk region.
- On 14 March 2002, the applicant was arrested and charged with double murder and attempted murder.
- During the trial, the applicant was represented by State-appointed counsel, Mr A.
- On 8 October 2003, the Chelyabinsk Regional Court convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to twenty-five years and eleven months’ imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed, unassisted by counsel, asking for a reduction of the sentence from murder to manslaughter, claiming self-defence.
- On 23 January 2004, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the conviction, reduced the sentence to twenty-five years and five months’ imprisonment, and counsel Mr A did not attend.
- In April 2004, the applicant was transferred to correctional colony no. 16/9, where he remained until January 2005.
- Court documents, including the text of the Convention, were sent to the applicant in April 2004.
- On 6 July 2004, a deputy head of the Omsk Department of Execution of Sentences strongly advised the applicant against submitting an application to the Court, and he was put in a disciplinary cell for eight days.
- On 10 July 2004, the Court’s letter of 8 April 2004 was received, and on 23 June 2004, the applicant sent an improvised application form to the Court.
- On 9 August 2004, the head of correctional colony no. 10 issued a threat to the applicant if he continued to complain.
- On 18 August 2004, the applicant was temporarily transferred to medical correctional facility no. 10 in Omsk for anti-tuberculosis treatment.
- On 15 October 2004, the applicant handed a sealed envelope containing a letter to the Court to the medical correctional facility’s administration.
- The applicant complained to various State authorities about the opening of and the failure to dispatch his letters to the Court.
- On 11 October 2007, the medical correctional facility’s administration received another letter from the Court addressed to the applicant acknowledging receipt of his correspondence.

title: CASE OF PALACHEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant worked as chief accountant in the finance department of Kaspiysk Town Council from 1980 until her dismissal in 1993.
- In 1993, the Sovetskiy District Court ordered her reinstatement and payment of salary arrears for her enforced absence from work, which was subject to immediate enforcement.
- The Ministry of Finance issued an order for her reinstatement, and the applicant received the salary arrears awarded in 1993 in December 1993 or February 1994.
- The applicant resigned in February 1994, claiming that she had done so under pressure.
- The applicant brought a court action against the Kaspiysk finance department for delay in execution of the 1993 judgment and lodged additional claims.
- The Kaspiysk Court rejected the claims lodged by the applicant and found that the judgment of 1993 had been executed, but the Supreme Court of the Republic of Dagestan quashed the decision and remitted the case for fresh examination.
- The case underwent multiple examinations and amendments to the claims, during which the Town Court and the Supreme Court of the Republic of Dagestan disagreed on jurisdiction and the calculation of salary arrears and indexation.
- The case was finally discontinued in November 2004 due to the applicant's failure to appear in court.

title: CASE OF GURGACH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant brought proceedings against the Murmansk Regional branch of the Pension Fund seeking to have his pension recalculated.
- The applicant relied on the provisions of the 1993 Act on Guarantees and Compensations for Persons Working and Residing in the Far North.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of Murmansk granted the applicant’s claim and found that the Far North Act remained in force and was applicable to the dispute at stake.
- The Murmansk Regional Court dismissed the appeal and upheld the judgment.
- The district court ordered the judgment to be enforced by the Oktyabrskiy District Department of the Pensions Fund.
- The bailiffs’ service recovered RUB 1,642.64 from the District Department, which was paid to the applicant.
- The constitutional court reviewed constitutionality of certain legal provisions concerning calculation of the pensions and clarified how to apply the law.
- The District Court granted the request by the District Department of 14 April 2004 to reopen the case.
- The District Court examined the case afresh and dismissed the applicant’s claims.
- The District Court ordered the applicant to reimburse RUB 1,642.64 paid to him under the judgment of 10 June 2002.

title: CASE OF KASTELIC v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1962 and lives in Ljubljana
- Applicant allegedly insulted police officer S. the day after receiving a penalty notice for not using a seat belt, indecent behavior, failure to comply with a public official's lawful order, and failure to submit identity papers; the fine was €991.12
- On 22 October 2009, the applicant filed a request for a judicial review
- On 15 September 2010, the Ljubljana Local Court rejected the request for judicial review on the basis of S.'s statement and because the applicant failed to submit any evidence
- On 11 October 2010, the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal challenging the Local Court's findings of fact and complaining that she had not been heard
- On 2 November 2010, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicant's constitutional appeal as inadmissible

title: CASE OF PETEK v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Žalec.
- On 4 May 2008, the applicant had a motorcycle accident where he was severely injured.
- On 29 July 2008, the police fined the applicant 460 EUR and six penalty points for failing to adjust his speed according to the road conditions.
- On 1 August 2008, the applicant lodged a request for judicial review, denying that he exceeded the speed limit and arguing that the accident happened due to an obstacle on the road that he was unable to avoid due to the road's conditions.
- On 20 May 2009, the Slovenske Konjice Local Court rejected the applicant's request without holding a hearing, stating that he had been driving carelessly and should have expected the road's conditions.
- On 24 August 2009, the applicant proposed to the Supreme State Prosecutor's Office to file a request for the protection of legality.
- On 21 September 2009, the Supreme State Prosecutor's Office notified the applicant that it would not use this legal remedy, having found no violation of legislative provision.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal and a petition for a review of the constitutionality and legality of the Minor Offences Act.
- On 22 June 2011, the Constitutional Court rejected the constitutional appeal and the petition as inadmissible.

title: CASE OF TIJARDOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Split.
- The applicant's father-in-law was granted a specially protected tenancy on a derelict flat.
- In 1983, the applicant's father-in-law was granted a specially protected tenancy on another flat at Kvaternikova 1, and the family moved into it.
- In 1991, a law was enacted to regulate the sale of publicly-owned flats previously let under a specially protected tenancy.
- The applicant continued living in the flat with her two children after her husband's death in 1994.
- The specially protected tenancy was abolished under the new law.
- The applicant requested to purchase the flat she occupied under the new law, which was declined by the owner, and she brought a civil action seeking a judgment in lieu of the contract of sale.
- The claim was dismissed by the Split Municipal Court in 2009, and the Town of Split lodged a counter-claim, seeking the applicant's eviction.
- The judgment was upheld on appeal by the Split County Court in 2010.
- The Supreme Court declared the applicant's appeal inadmissible in 2012.
- The applicant lodged two constitutional complaints in 2011 and 2012, but they were declared inadmissible in 2013.

title: CASE OF PETROVA v. LATVIA
facts:
• The applicant’s son, a Latvian national, was born in 1979 and died in a car accident in 2002, leaving his mother to apply for remedies. 

• Following the accident, the son was transported to Riga's First Hospital, where surgery was performed on his head, but his condition remained critical. 

• In order to save his organs, a transplantation operation was carried out immediately upon the son’s death without the knowledge of his mother or consent. 

• Upon being informed at a later point that her son’s organs had been removed, the applicant lodged complaints with various authorities, claiming that she was not informed about her son’s health condition, and was not asked for permission to transplant his organs. 

• The complaints of the applicant were examined by the Security Police, the Prosecutor's office, and the National Human Rights Bureau, and all concluded that medical practitioners had complied with the domestic law.

title: CASE OF PETKOV AND PROFIROV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1981 and 1980 respectively and lived in Burgas.
- On March 4, 2007, the police arrested a third person named Mr V. whose name was on a national list of wanted persons.
- Later, on the same day, police officers entered the hotel room of the applicants and searched it.
- The applicants were taken to a police station, where they were questioned for about ten minutes.
- The detention orders were presented to the applicants under section 63(1)(1) of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Act drawn up, which merely referred to section 63(1)(1) and to the Criminal Code provision concerning theft.
- The applicants wished to call their lawyer but were not allowed to do so despite providing the phone number.
- The applicants were not further questioned or summoned while in custody, and they were released the following day.
- On August 9, 2007, the applicants applied for judicial review of the detention orders of March 4, 2007.
- In two judgments dated October 31, 2007, the Stara Zagora Administrative Court found the detention orders lawful.
- Following appeals by the applicants, in two final judgments - on April 24, 2008, and July 3, 2008 - the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the lower court's judgment.
- On December 6, 2007, the first applicant and a friend of his, Mr D., were arrested.
- While in custody, the first applicant was not questioned or summoned for any reason.
- The first applicant applied for judicial review of the detention order on the day of his release.
- In a judgment of 18 February 2008, the Burgas Administrative Court found the disputed detention order lawful.
- Following an appeal lodged by the applicant, in a final judgment of March 9, 2009, the SAC upheld the lower court's judgment.
- In a judgment of 20 March 2008, the Burgas Administrative Court allowed Mr D.’s application for judicial review of his detention order and the order was subsequently quashed.

title: CASE OF A.K. v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant discovered she was pregnant in October 2001.
- In January 2002, during her eighteenth week of pregnancy, the applicant was referred by her gynecologist for an alpha-fetoprotein test to check for potential fetal abnormalities.
- The applicant did not attend the appointment for the test in January 2002.
- The applicant regularly attended appointments with her gynecologist and general practitioner from February to June 2002.
- The applicant gave birth to a daughter with Down's syndrome in June 2002.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Inspectorate for Quality Control of Medical Treatment in July 2002 regarding the quality of the antenatal medical care provided by her gynecologist.
- Dr. L, the applicant's gynecologist, was given an administrative fine for failing to ensure that the test was carried out.
- The applicant claimed that Dr. L had falsified her medical records to conceal her failure.
- The applicant lodged a claim for damages against A. Hospital in August 2005, alleging negligence on the part of Dr. L.
- The Riga Regional Court dismissed the applicant's civil claim in January 2006, finding no causal link between the actions of Dr. L and the birth of the applicant's child.
- The applicant appealed the decision, arguing that Dr. L had been obliged to take all medical steps to establish whether her unborn child was healthy and that damages ought to be paid.

title: CASE OF YARASHONEN v. TURKEY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant fled Russia following the alleged killing of his father and brother by Russian security forces.
- He entered Turkey illegally and possessed no passport.
- He was arrested at Atatürk International Airport in Istanbul and placed in custody at the police station in the airport.
- He met with his lawyer on 17 February 2011 and another lawyer on 13 April 2011, who advised him to speak to the officers in charge at the removal centre about his asylum request and his health problems.
- He applied for asylum on 18 April 2011.
- He was released from detention and granted an asylum-seeker certificate on 29 April 2011.
- He was diagnosed with tuberculosis pleurisy on 9 June 2011 and received in-patient treatment at the hospital until 15 June 2011.
- The Kumkapı Removal Centre was severely overcrowded at the time of his detention with problems of hygiene, and he contracted a serious bacterial infection.
- The Government submitted that the Kumkapı Removal Centre had a capacity of 300 persons, and the detainees had the right to outdoor exercise in suitable weather conditions.

title: CASE OF CATALDO AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points are:

- Italy changed its pension system from a retributive one to a contributory one in 1995.
- Mr Cataldo, who had transferred contributions he had paid in Switzerland to Italy, requested the INPS to establish his pension according to the 1962 Italo-Swiss Convention on Social Security.
- The INPS used a theoretical remuneration instead of the actual remuneration for pension calculation, resulting in a significant reduction in Mr Cataldo's pension.
- Several other individuals in the same situation as Mr Cataldo contested their pension calculation and succeeded in getting remuneration-based pension calculations.
- Law no. 296/2006 came into force on 1 January 2007.
- Mr Cataldo's claim was rejected by the Lecco Tribunal in 2008 due to the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006, which was considered legitimate by the Constitutional Court.
- Mr Maggioni, Mr Ribulotta, Mr Marinaro, Mr Centamore, and Mr Maccarinelli, who had transferred contributions from Switzerland to Italy, also contested their pension calculation and instituted judicial proceedings.
- Mr Maggioni won in the first instance but lost in the Milan Court of Appeal due to the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006.
- Mr Ribulotta won in the first instance but lost in the Milan Court of Appeal due to the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006.
- Mr Marinaro won in the Milan Court of Appeal on the time-bar issue but lost on the merits due to the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006.
- Mr Centamore lost in the first instance due to the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006.
- Mr Maccarinelli lost in the first instance due to the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006.

title: CASE OF AZIENDA AGRICOLA SILVERFUNGHI S.A.S. AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
Here are the main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicants are agricultural firms operating in northern and/or disadvantaged areas in Italy.
- In the 1980s, the Italian legislator instituted norms to favour economic activity in general and agricultural activity specifically.
- Certain laws provided benefits, including a concession and exemptions, in relation to contributions paid by employers in the agricultural sector.
- The INPS issued a circular stating that the concession and exemption could not be accumulated.
- The applicant companies only benefited from the exemption and not the concession, contrary to what they believed was provided for in the law.
- Court cases were instituted and consistent case-law in favour of the agricultural firms was established by the Italian courts.
- Law no. 326 of 24 November 2003 was enacted, providing that benefits could not be accumulated.
- The applicant companies requested the INPS to return monies it held contrary to what was provided for by law.
- Administrative and judicial proceedings were instituted to recover monies due.
- Courts found in favour of the applicant companies, but the INPS appealed to the Court of Cassation.
- The Court of Cassation allowed the INPS’s appeal based on Law no. 326/03, and each party was to bear its own costs for the entire proceedings.

title: CASE OF BIRAGHI AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- Italy changed its pension system from retributive to contributory in 1995.
- Applicants requested their pensions to be established based on contributions paid in Switzerland.
- INPS used theoretical remuneration instead of actual remuneration to calculate the pensions, leading to a reduction in the pension amount.
- Applicants filed judicial proceedings in 2005/6, which were rejected by the domestic courts.
- Various individuals in the same position as the applicants had been successful in similar claims.
- Law no. 296/2006 entered into force on 1 January 2007 while the applicants' proceedings were pending.
- Several judgments were passed in favor of and against the applicants based on the entry into force of Law no. 296/2006.
- Applicants did not further appeal deeming it futile given the judgment of the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF GRZONA v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a Polish national born in 1956 who lives in Radom.
- The applicant and his wife filed a motion for dissolution of co-ownership of a civil association and for division of its property.
- The civil association's business activity involved a petrol station.
- The district court allowed a motion for an expert report on the value of the property.
- M.J., a co-owner and a party to the proceedings, submitted additional documents later included in the expert's report, which the applicant alleged were forged.
- As a result of the allegations, criminal proceedings were opened against M.J. and the civil proceedings were stayed pending their outcome.
- The criminal proceedings against M.J. ended with a guilty verdict of submitting forged documents to the court in question.
- The applicant lodged a motion to resume the civil proceedings once the criminal proceedings against M.J. were concluded.
- A new expert report was submitted on expenses incurred by co-owners.
- The district court granted ownership of the property to M.J. and ordered him to pay the applicant and his wife an equivalent of their share in the property.
- Both parties appealed, causing the case to be remitted back to the district court.
- Another expert report was requested.
- The district court granted ownership of the petrol station to M.J. and ordered him to pay the applicant and his wife an equivalent of their share in the property in ten instalments.
- The applicant lodged a claim for damages under Article 417 of the Civil Code, seeking compensation for costs incurred during the impugned proceedings and for loss of earnings.
- The Radom Regional Court dismissed the applicant's civil action, stating that he failed to prove that the unduly long procedure had been caused by the courts' unlawful actions or omissions as required by Article 6 of the Civil Code.
- The court admitted that the proceedings had been long but noted the unusually complex character of the case, caused by the lack of diligence of both parties in conducting their business, influencing the length of the proceedings.
- The applicant appealed, but the Lublin Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal.

title: CASE OF MENNESSON v. FRANCE [Extracts]
facts:
- The first and second applicants are a married couple who were unable to have a child due to the second applicant's infertility. 
- They underwent IVF using the gametes of the first applicant and an egg from a donor, with the intention of implanting the embryos in the uterus of a surrogate mother. 
- The surrogate mother was found to be carrying twins and in a judgment, the first applicant was declared the "genetic father" and the second applicant the "legal mother". The birth certificates were drawn up accordingly. 
- The first applicant attempted to register the birth certificates in France but was rejected and the case was sent to the public prosecutor's office. 
- A preliminary investigation was conducted which led to the institution of proceedings against the first and second applicants for false representation infringing the civil status of children. 
- The case was dismissed in 2004 on the grounds that the acts had been committed on US territory, where they were not considered an offense, and therefore did not constitute a punishable offense in France.
- In 2003, the Créteil public prosecutor instituted proceedings against the first and second applicants to have the entries in the register of births, marriages, and deaths annulled, arguing that surrogacy agreements were null and void according to French public policy.
- The Créteil tribunal de grande instance initially declared the action inadmissible, but the decision was overturned by the Paris Court of Appeal and the entries were ordered to be annulled. 
- The Court of Appeal found that the judgment of the Supreme Court of California indirectly validating a surrogacy agreement contravened French concept of international public policy. 
- The applicants appealed on points of law, alleging violation of the children's best interest and their right to a stable legal parent-child relationship, as well as breaches of Article 8 and Article 14 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF EGAMBERDIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Uzbekistan in 1975.
- In 2009, he applied for Russian nationality using a false name and forged passport, which was granted.
- In 2009, he was charged by the Uzbekistan National Security Service for membership of an extremist organization and possession of extremist material.
- In 2013, he was arrested for using a false identity document to cross the Russian border and detained pending extradition proceedings.
- In 2013, an extradition request was received from the Uzbek prosecutor for his alleged membership in an extremist organization.
- His extradition was adjourned on the grounds that criminal proceedings against him in Russia should be completed first.
- He was sentenced to a fine and administrative removal from Russia on the charge of illegal residence in Russia.
- The Court granted his request to apply interim measures under Rule 39 to prevent his expulsion to Uzbekistan.
- He was found guilty of using two false passports and illegal border crossing in 2013, and a fine was imposed.
- In 2013, he applied for refugee status in Russia; the application was refused in 2013 and a hierarchical appeal was rejected in 2013.
- He was arrested in 2013 pending expulsion under the expulsion order.
- A District Court in Moscow rejected his appeal in 2014.

title: CASE OF SHCHERBINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Kustanay, in the Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic in 1970
- He served in the Soviet Army from 1988 to 1990
- In 1990, he enrolled at a military academy in Russia
- He returned to Kazakhstan in 1992
- In 1998, he was convicted in Kazakhstan for armed robbery
- He fled to Russia in 2001 while on leave from a prison
- He lived and worked in Russia under a false name, using a false passport
- He was arrested in Russia in 2007 for forgery of an official document
- The Kazakh authorities requested his extradition in 2007 and again in 2011
- In 2011, the applicant challenged the decision to extradite him, claiming that he risked being subjected to ill-treatment in Kazakhstan
- The courts in Russia upheld the decision to extradite him
- The applicant requested Russian nationality, but was told that he was not eligible.

title: CASE OF KRUPKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are Jehovah's Witnesses belonging to various congregations in Moscow
- Jehovah’s Witnesses in Moscow were banned in 2004 by Moscow Courts
- Applicants signed a rental contract for holding religious meetings in academy's assembly hall
- The police arrived during the annual celebration of the Memorial of the Lord’s Evening Meal
- Police officers declared the meeting illegal, ordered to disperse, and escorted the male individuals to a station
- The applicants were collectively photographed and their identity documents were taken away
- Applicants sought a declaration that the police had unlawfully disrupted a service of worship, removed religious literature, took them to the police station, photographed and detained them
- The district court held that the police had lawfully stopped the service of worship
- The district court considered that the police officers had acted unlawfully in detaining the applicants
- The applicants lodged an appeal, but on 22 March 2007, the Moscow City Court quashed the District Court's judgment except for detaining the applicants
- The City Court upheld the remainder of the judgment and dismissed the applicant's arguments.

title: CASE OF GABLISHVILI v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple, born in 1981 and 1987 respectively, who live in Syktyvkar in the Komi Republic of Russia.
- The first applicant, a Georgian national, arrived in Russia in 1999 and received a residence permit in 2001.
- The first applicant's parents have lived in Syktyvkar since the early 2000s and acquired Russian nationality in 2005 and 2008, respectively.
- On 26 August 2011, the first applicant married the second applicant, a Russian national, and on 28 June 2012, the second applicant gave birth to their son.
- On 14 November 2011, the first applicant was found guilty of using drugs and fined, and an administrative expulsion from Russia was ordered.
- The first applicant's residence permit was revoked on 10 June 2011 due to his HIV-positive status but later reinstated by a court on 28 February 2012.
- On 23 June 2012, a new decision to revoke the first applicant's residence permit was issued.
- On 20 January 2012, the Federal Service for Drug Control issued an exclusion order against the first applicant.
- The Syktyvkar Town Court quashed the exclusion order on 20 July 2012, but the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic overturned this decision on 11 October 2012.
- The first applicant had several previous administrative convictions, including drug use, disorderly conduct, drunkenness, and driving offenses.
- The current whereabouts of the first applicant are unknown, and there is no information on whether the expulsion or exclusion order has been executed.

title: CASE OF SUKHANOV AND ILCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Both applicants were born in 1938 and live in Ukraine.
- Both applicants are entitled to a special supplement to their pensions as children of war.
- The first applicant sued the Pension Fund and State Treasury for pension recalculation and compensation.
- The Lugansk Regional Administrative Court rejected claims for 2006 but ordered a recalculation for 2007-08.
- The Donetsk Administrative Court of Appeal upheld the decision for the first applicant.
- The Higher Administrative Court dismissed the first applicant's appeal.
- The second applicant sued the Pension Fund for pension recalculation.
- The Zhovtovodsky Town Court ordered a recalculation for the second applicant from 9 July 2007.
- The Dnipropetrovsk Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision for the second applicant.
- The second set of proceedings claimed payment of the supplement starting from 3 March 2010.
- The Zhovtovodsky Town Court ordered a recalculation from 3 March 2010.
- The Dnipropetrovsk Administrative Court of Appeal upheld the decision for the second set of proceedings.

title: CASE OF LIVADA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lived in Balakliya.
- On 7 October 2003, the applicant was admitted to a hospital to undergo treatment for drug addiction.
- On 11 October 2003, the police bought a certain amount of cannabis from the applicant while he was in the hospital, and additional quantities of the drug were seized after a search.
- On the same day, the police arrested the applicant under Article 263 of the Administrative Offences Code for a violation of the drug circulation rules and detained him for three days.
- On 14 October 2003, the applicant was arrested and detained further under Articles 106 and 115 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 17 October 2003, the court ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention as a preventive measure.
- On 10 August 2006, the first-instance court found the applicant guilty of the crimes under Articles 307 § 2 and 309 § 2 of the Criminal Code and sentenced him to five years’ imprisonment and confiscation of property.
