- On 10 April 2007, the Court of Appeal upheld the findings of the first-instance court and reduced the sentence to three and a half years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF BUCIAŞ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- In 1994, the applicants' father offered a mortgage on his immovable property to H.M.C. for a loan.
- The mortgage was registered with the land registry on 3 June 1994.
- As the applicants' father failed to reimburse the loan, his property was sold at auction on 31 May 1996, to T.T.T. and T.T.S.
- The ownership was transferred to the successful bidders whose right was entered in the land register.
- The applicants’ father challenged the forced sale on 1 July 1996, and the proceedings were recorded on 5 January 1998.
- On 30 December 1998, T.T.T. and T.T.S. sold the property to S.R., despite the pending proceedings initiated by the applicants' father.
- On 26 April 2000, the Oradea Court of Appeal allowed the father's action to annul the forced sale, but he could not get possession of the property due to its sale to S.R.
- The applicants sought the annulment of the sale agreements by lodging a case with the Oradea District Court invoking the principle quod nullum est, nullum producit effectum.
- The Oradea District Court dismissed the case on 25 October 2001 stating that the last buyer, S.R., had bought the property in good faith.
- The applicants appealed, claiming that S.R. was not in good faith as he knew about the annulment proceedings, which were entered in the land register.
- The Bihor County Court allowed the appeal on 22 May 2003, stating that the annulment of the forced sale should have resulted in the annulment of subsequent acts done by parties having such knowledge.
- The Oradea Court of Appeal allowed an appeal on points of law lodged by the buyers on 8 April 2004, stating that S.R. had entered into the contract in good faith.

title: CASE OF A.B. v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a Swiss journalist named Mr A.B. who published an article in L'Illustre magazine on 15 October 2003 called "Tragedy on the Lausanne Bridge."
- The article was about criminal proceedings against a motorist named M.B. who had killed three pedestrians and injured eight others on 8 July 2003 by ramming his car into them before throwing himself off the Lausanne Bridge.
- The article included records of interviews and correspondence from M.B.'s case file, which were obtained by an unknown person who gave them to the magazine.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant, not by M.B. but by the public prosecutor, who accused him of publishing secret documents.
- The Lausanne investigating judge sentenced the applicant to one month's imprisonment, suspended for one year, but this was later replaced by a fine of 4,000 Swiss francs.
- The applicant appealed on points of law but was unsuccessful, and the decision to convict him was upheld by the Federal Court.

title: CASE OF RIĐIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- All applicants were employed by Rudnik bakra Majdanpek, a copper mining company based in Majdanpek
- Between 2001 and 2005 they all instituted separate civil suits against the debtor, seeking pecuniary redress on various grounds.
- The first applicant was ordered to be paid salary arrears, pension, disability, health and other insurance contributions due for the same period, and legal costs.
- The second applicant was ordered to pay salary arrears, pension, disability, health and other insurance contributions due for the same period, and legal costs.
- The third applicant was ordered to pay salary arrears and statutory interest, as well as legal costs.
- The fourth applicant was ordered to pay salary arrears and statutory interest, as well as legal costs.
- The fifth applicant was ordered to pay salary arrears and statutory interest, as well as legal costs.
- The sixth applicant was awarded compensation for the non-pecuniary damage suffered due to a labour-related injury, plus statutory interest, and his legal costs.
- The enforcement proceedings for all applicants were stayed on 18 January 2006, and resumed in May 2011.
- None of the applicants sought compensation for any non-pecuniary damages suffered due to the length of the enforcement proceedings in question.
- As of April 2014, the debtor appeared to be a company predominantly comprised of State or socially owned capital and was still in the process of being restructured.

title: CASE OF ISAKOVIĆ VIDOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant is a medical doctor born in 1967 who lived in Serbia at the time of the incident.
- On 2 September 1997, the applicant and her neighbor got into a physical altercation following a verbal conflict between the neighbor and the applicant's mother. The neighbor allegedly punched the applicant, causing her to suffer injuries to her head.
- The applicant filed a criminal complaint in respect to the event while the neighbor and his wife brought a private criminal action against the applicant for insult and defamation, and making serious threats.
- The Municipal Court joined the two sets of proceedings, and the applicant lodged a civil compensation claim within the criminal proceedings.
- Numerous hearings were held between April 1998 and May 2000, with the applicant suffering a concussion, a contusion, and pursuing medical attention for two months.
- The Municipal Court convicted both the applicant and the neighbor, sentencing them to a fine and imprisonment, respectively, but instructed the applicant to pursue her civil claim in a separate suit.
- The convictions were overturned, and a new trial was scheduled, but the case against the neighbor was terminated as time-barred.
- The applicant never pursued a separate civil compensation claim, and she and her family moved to Slovenia in 2008.

title: CASE OF DIMITROV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Four individuals are making the application: Mr Raycho Angelov Dimitrov, Ms Anita Rumenova Velyanova, Mr Raycho Dimitrov Dimitrov and Ms Adriana Georgieva Dimitrova
- The event that led to the application is the death of their relative, Mr Angel Raychov Dimitrov (alias Chorata), who died during a police operation against him on November 10, 2005.
- The police officers involved in the operation were investigated and tried on charges of aggravated murder and ultimately acquitted.
- The applicants are Mr Dimitrov’s son, de facto spouse, and parents.
- The Minister of Internal Affairs ordered a nationwide police operation to trace and arrest persons who had committed serious offenses following a high-profile assassination in Sofia.
- Mr Dimitrov was suspected of distributing narcotic drugs and pimping.
- The officers were told to proceed with caution when making arrests to avoid any risk to the life and health of arrestees and passer-by.
- The officers who were to take part in the operation were split into three groups, one to find Mr. Dimitrov and check for evidence of drug trafficking in his car, another to search a hotel run by his family with a view to uncovering evidence of drug trafficking and prostitution, and a third to search Mr. Dimitrov’s home again with a view to uncovering evidence of drug trafficking.
- The officers did not present a search warrant, and it was later established that no such warrant had been applied for.
- Mr Dimitrov was found in his car, and the officers started hitting him on the head and body. The beating continued for about ten to fifteen minutes.
- The officers caused Mr Dimitrov’s death by pushing him against the ground.
- The investigation was taken up by a prosecutor from the Blagoevgrad Regional Prosecutor’s Office and an investigator from the Blagoevgrad Regional Investigation Service. 
- An autopsy was carried out on Mr. Dimitrov’s body, and the experts’ conclusion was that Mr. Dimitrov had a number of abrasions and bruises on the head, body, and limbs.

title: CASE OF PARENIUC v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was a tax inspector at the Edineț tax authority.
- Z., the owner of a small shop, filed a criminal complaint against the applicant for soliciting a bribe.
- A police undercover operation was set up, and Z. offered the applicant money marked with special powder, which resulted in the applicant being arrested with the marked money found in her coat pocket.
- Four more counts of bribe-taking were added to the charge against the applicant, based solely on statements from alleged victims after the undercover operation.
- The Edinet District Court convicted the applicant of taking a bribe but acquitted her of the other counts, and the court did not examine her allegation of entrapment.
- The Balti Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal without considering her entrapment claim, and the prosecutor's office's appeal changed the penalty to a criminal fine and suspended sentence.
- The Supreme Court of Justice dismissed the applicant’s appeal, but her extraordinary appeal was allowed, and the case was sent back to the Balti Court of Appeal.
- The Balti Court of Appeal acquitted the applicant, finding inconsistencies in Z.'s statements and no evidence proving the applicant knew about the money placed in her pocket.
- The Supreme Court of Justice ordered the Balti Court of Appeal to re-examine the appeals against the original judgment of March 9, 2005.
- The Balti Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal, and the prosecutor's appeal was allowed.
- The Supreme Court of Justice dismissed the applicant's point of law appeal without considering her claim of entrapment.

title: CASE OF GERASIMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Russian nationals obtained binding judicial decisions ordering State authorities to provide them with housing or various services
- Enforcement of those judgments was considerably delayed, with some remaining unenforced to date
- Mr Mikhail Yefimovich Gerasimov's basement was ordered to be repaired and utilities to be supplied by court order, which was enforced after several court proceedings
- Mr Andrey Gennadyevich Shmakov was ordered to be provided with appropriate housing, which was ultimately enforced through a monetary award
- Ms Lyubov Mikaylovna Baranova was ordered to be provided with heating supply, which was ultimately enforced by installing an individual gas heating device in her flat
- Ms Tatyana Salikhzanovna Kostyleva was ordered to be provided with comfortable housing, but the enforcement of the judgment is still pending due to a lack of available flats
- Mr Yuriy Vasilyevich Starostenkov was ordered to be provided with a car for rehabilitation purposes, which was ultimately enforced after imposing a fine on the debtor authority
- Mr Anatoliy Arturovich Zakharchenko was ordered to be provided with housing, and ultimately received a flat located in the Saint-Petersburg suburbs after the communication of the present application to the Russian Government
- Ms Marina Yevgenyevna Troshina requested data from the land register, which was delayed in enforcement due to the reorganization of the respondent authority

title: CASE OF BLAGA v. ROMANIA
facts:
1. The applicant is from Suwanee, USA and married D.B. in Georgia in 1993. They had three children with joint custody.

2. The Forsyth County Court issued an injunction in 2007 forbidding the applicant and his wife from removing their children from the jurisdiction without express permission.

3. The applicant signed a notarized form in 2008 authorizing his wife to take their children on a short trip to Romania and return them to the USA.

4. The applicant's wife failed to return the children and instituted divorce and custody proceedings in Romania.

5. The applicant filed for divorce and custody of his children with the Superior Court of Forsyth County in December 2008.

6. The Superior Court of Forsyth County dismissed the applicant's case for lack of jurisdiction and insufficient notice in January 2011.

7. The Georgia Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal in December 2011.

8. The applicant submitted a request for the return of his children to the USA under Article 3 of the Hague Convention, claiming that his children had been unlawfully removed from U.S. territory.

9. The Romanian Ministry of Justice contacted the applicant's wife to express their position on a potential settlement and voluntary return of the children to the USA.

10. A psychological evaluation report was produced based on tests and an interview with the children, with a conclusion that the children were well-balanced emotionally and willing to communicate.

11. The Bucharest County Court adjourned the proceedings so that the applicant's wife could prepare her defence, the children could receive psychological counselling and social inquiry, and the court could prepare for deliberation.

12. The Braşov Guardianship Authority produced a social inquiry report which concluded that the mother knew best and was most responsive to the children's needs, and that they wished to stay in Romania with their mother.

13. The Bucharest County Court adjourned the proceedings several times and eventually dismissed the applicant's action in November 2009.

14. The applicant submitted a request for a statement on the delay in the proceedings in February 2010, citing breach of his right to a trial within a reasonable time.

15. The Bucharest County Court acknowledged the applicant's request and informed him that the judgment had been reasoned and communicated to the parties.

title: CASE OF MIHĂILESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and is currently detained in Iaşi Prison.
- On 8 February 2012, the applicant was detained pending trial on charges of human trafficking and placed in the Bacău Police Department’s detention facility.
- The applicant stated that in the Bacău Police Department’s detention facility, he had been forced to sleep on the floor and eat without cutlery while sharing a cell with smokers.
- In Bacău Prison, the applicant slept in overcrowded, damp, and infested cells, was forced to eat sitting on the floor, and had no access to natural light or ventilation.
- The applicant was detained in several cells in Bacău Prison, which he shared with up to fourteen other detainees.
- The cells had bathrooms, toilets, and showers and were fitted with windows for natural light and ventilation.
- Every detainee was assigned a bed and provided with a mattress, a blanket, and a pillow.
- The detainees were responsible for cleaning the cells and had access to running water. They were allowed a minimum of three hours’ outdoor exercise per day.
- On 24 April 2012 and an unspecified date, the applicant brought two sets of criminal proceedings against some of the staff members and the medical personnel of the Bacău Police Department’s detention facility.
- The applicant challenged some of the interlocutory judgments delivered by the post-sentencing judge before the domestic courts but subsequently withdrew his challenges.
- On 9 September 2013, the Bacău Prison authorities allowed the applicant's request to be categorized as a vulnerable detainee and transferred him to a cell reserved for vulnerable detainees.

title: CASE OF GEORGIA v. RUSSIA (I)
facts:
B. Alleged existence of an expulsion policy specifically targeting Georgian nationals: 

- Allegation of a policy of targeted expulsion of Georgian nationals
- Specific focus on Georgian nationals


C. The impugned events according to the witness statements: 

- Events described by witnesses
- Witnesses provide details about the events in question


D. The impugned events according to various international governmental and non-governmental organisations: 

- Events described by International governmental and non-governmental organisations
- Details of the impugned events according to various sources

title: CASE OF R & L, S.R.O. AND OTHERS v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The first applicant owns a five-storey tenement house in Brno, with one shop on the ground floor and one flat on each remaining floor.
- Three of the four flats have regulated rent, with monthly rent ranging from CZK 1,392 to CZK 2,037, while the fourth flat has a fixed monthly rent of CZK 5,200.
- The first applicant sues the State for damages due to the difference between regulated and usual rent from February 2002 to the end of January 2004, amounting to CZK 229,563.
- The first applicant's action is dismissed by the Prague 1 District Court, the Prague Municipal Court, the Supreme Court, and the Constitutional Court.
- The second applicant owns a tenement house in Prague consisting of eleven flats, with seven flats having regulated rent.
- The second applicant sues the State for damages due to the difference between regulated and usual rent from January 2002 to December 2004, amounting to CZK 1,358,964.
- The second applicant's action is dismissed by the Prague 1 District Court, the Prague Municipal Court, the Supreme Court, and the Constitutional Court.
- The third applicant owns a tenement house in Brno consisting of seven flats, with three flats having regulated rent.
- The third applicant sues the State for damages due to the difference between regulated and usual rent from July 2002 to August 2005, amounting to CZK 906,575.
- The third applicant's action is dismissed by the Prague 1 District Court, the Prague Municipal Court, the Supreme Court, and the Constitutional Court.
- The fourth applicant owns a tenement house with regulated rent in Domašov nad Bystřicí.
- The fourth applicant lodges an action for payment of the difference between regulated and usual rent from February to July 2006, amounting to CZK 14,514.
- The fourth applicant's action is dismissed by the Olomouc District Court and the Ostrava Regional Court.
- The applicants own a tenement house in Prague with regulated rent in one flat.
- The applicants attempt to increase the rent from CZK 2,396 to CZK 9,000 monthly, which is refused by the tenants.
- The applicants lodge an action for payment of the rent increase for the period from July 2003 to December 2004, amounting to CZK

title: CASE OF ANTAYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are two Chechen families living in the Kurgan Region.
- Attitudes towards the Chechen minority have worsened after 2000.
- On 8 March 2006, a fight occurred between the third and eighth applicants and Mr A.B.
- In March 2006, the police questioned Mr A.B. and opened a criminal investigation file under Article 119.
- On 24 March 2006, a search of the applicants’ homes was conducted without producing a search warrant.
- The police officers beat and insulted the applicants, including threatening to harm their genitals.
- At the Antayev family’s house, a 7.62 mm calibre cartridge was allegedly found by the police.
- The second applicant suffered a spinal fracture as a result of the beating.
- The eighth applicant was strangled with a rope and taken to the police station without access to medical or legal assistance.
- The police found a hunting gun and cartridges, an unloaded hand pistol, knives, and videotapes during the search at the Vashayev family’s house.

title: CASE OF MALA v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant was granted child maintenance in 1994, which her former husband failed to pay.
2. The outstanding arrears to the applicant amounted to UAH 7,546 as of 24 January 2006.
3. The bailiff issued a fresh report on 1 April 2006, assessing the total arrears at UAH 667.50 as of 31 March 2006.
4. The applicant challenged the accuracy of the bailiff's report before the Khortytskyy Court on 11 April 2006.
5. The Khortytskyy Court invalidated the impugned report as erroneous on 24 May 2006.
6. The arrears owed by S. to the applicant were reassessed at UAH 6,606 as of 1 June 2006.
7. The Bailiffs’ Service terminated the child maintenance enforcement proceedings on 19 October 2006.
8. The applicant lodged a civil claim against S. for penalties for late child maintenance payments on 26 January 2006.
9. The Khortytskyy Court allowed the applicant’s claim in part and awarded her UAH 141.58 in penalties on 3 April 2006.
10. The Zaporizhzhya Regional Court of Appeal upheld the Khortytskyy Court’s decision of 3 April 2006 on 23 May 2006.
11. The Supreme Court rejected the applicant's request for leave to appeal in cassation on 21 November 2006.
12. The applicant sought to recover the child maintenance arrears on 21 November 2006 and 26 April 2007.
13. The Court of Appeal quashed the decision of the Khortytskyy Court and ordered S. to pay her UAH 4,964 in arrears on 26 April 2007.
14. The Supreme Court rejected her request for leave to appeal in cassation on 19 July 2007.
15. The applicant sought an increase of the child maintenance to be paid by her former husband from 28 April 2006 onwards.
16. The court allowed her claim in part and assessed the amount of monthly child maintenance at UAH 165 from 3 May until 2 October of that year.

title: CASE OF AMADAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant and his family are of Chechen ethnic origin and reside in the Chastoozerskiy district of the Kurgan Region, Russia.
- There was mounting ethnic tension in the district after the start of the armed conflict in Chechnya.
- On 18th May 2002, the applicant’s car was stopped by a group of police officers and later he was shot and beaten by a group of men, including Mr. S.K.
- Mr. U.B., who was with the applicant, was also beaten by a group of up to 70 men at the sausage factory, including Mr. A.I., the manager.
- The perpetrators were not identified until June 2002 when Mr. Ye.P. was identified and confessed to his involvement in the attack.
- The facts of the case were investigated by the Chastoozerye ROVD and a criminal investigation was opened under Article 111, part 3, (intentional infliction of serious injuries committed by a group of persons or as a result of conspiracy).
- The investigation was suspended and resumed on five occasions between August 2002 and June 2004.
- The case file contained 255 pages of documents in two volumes by 2006.
- The investigation was suspended again on 10th August 2011, since the perpetrators could not be identified.

title: CASE OF JATAIRWAYS, A.D. BEOGRAD v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- Proceedings were instituted against the applicant company by forty-seven former employees for their dismissal from work.
- The court held one hearing by the time the Convention came into force in Slovenia.
- The applicant company changed its address without informing the court, which led to the court ordering to serve all further court’s writings on the applicant company through a notice board.
- The court held a hearing and decided that the dismissal of the employees was illegal and ordered the applicant company to acknowledge their rights and pay them outstanding salaries.
- The Higher Court upheld the illegality of dismissal but annulled the remainder of the first instance court’s decision and remitted the case back to the first instance court.
- The court’s writings were served on the applicant company, which later authorized a Slovenian lawyer to represent it in the proceedings.
- The first instance court held a hearing and decided to examine the claims separately for some of the plaintiffs.
- The court dismissed the applicant’s objection against an interim order and subsequently, the Higher Labour and Social Court quashed this decision and remitted the case back to the first instance court.
- The first instance court upheld the plaintiffs’ claims concerning the payment of outstanding salaries, and the Higher Labour and Social Court partially upheld the applicant company’s appeal, modifying the decision of the first instance court in the part concerning the payment of interest and dismissing the remainder of the appeal. 
- Both the applicant company and plaintiffs lodged an appeal on points of law, which the Supreme Court dismissed, upholding the decision of the Higher Court.
- The applicant company lodged a constitutional appeal, which was dismissed by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF DUBINSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was suspected of coordinating an organized group involved in residential burglaries and car thefts.
- The Pskov Regional Court authorized tapping of the applicant’s telephone, a search of his home, and the interception of his communications.
- On 10 August 2007, the police intercepted the applicant’s mobile phone communications with T. while stealing a Lada car in the settlement of Dedovichi, Pskov Region.
- On 27 March 2008, the police intercepted another mobile phone communication between the applicant and T. in which they were stealing a Lada car in the town of Opochka, Pskov Region.
- The applicant was charged with a car theft, and on 30 March 2008, he was brought before the Opochka District Court, Pskov Region, where he was not remanded in custody.
- On 23 May 2008, the Dedovichi District Court further extended the applicant’s detention until 24 July 2008.
- On 21 August 2008, the Velikiye Luki Town Court extended the applicant’s detention until 17 November 2008.
- On 7 November 2008, the Town Court extended the applicant’s detention until 30 December 2008.
- On 3 June 2009, the Town Court reclassified the charges against the applicant and found him guilty of the theft of two cars committed by a group of persons and causing significant financial detriments to the car owners and forgery of car licence plates and sentenced him to three and a half years’ imprisonment.
- On 26 August 2009, the Regional Court quashed the applicant’s conviction on appeal and remitted the matter for fresh consideration.
- On 31 August 2010, the Town Court found the applicant guilty of the theft of two cars and sentenced him to one year and five months’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF HARAKCHIEV AND TOLUMOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Mr Harakchiev (born in 1968) is serving a whole life sentence in Stara Zagora Prison, having been convicted of multiple violent offences including armed robbery, attempted murder, and murder.
- Mr Tolumov (born in 1954) is serving a life sentence in Plovdiv Prison.
- Mr Harakchiev was convicted eight times of non-violent offences between 1992 and 2005.
- Mr Harakchiev's cell is in the high-security wing reserved for life prisoners, and he has been subject to various disciplinary punishments.
- Conditions in the prison include inadequately sized cells, lack of running water and toilets, poor ventilation and hygiene, and low-quality food.
- Mr Harakchiev has brought multiple claims for damages against the authorities.

title: CASE OF MIŠKOVIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant lives in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
- The Republika Srpska was ordered to pay the applicant 7,000 BAM for non-pecuniary damage and 600 BAM for pecuniary damage by a judgment of the Prijedor Court of First Instance.
- The Banja Luka Court of First Instance issued a writ of execution on August 24, 2001.
- The Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina found a breach of Article 6 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention on December 20, 2005.
- The applicant did not claim compensation but even if she had done so, her claim would most likely have been refused.
- On April 25, 2012, the applicant informed the authorities that she agreed to be paid the principal debt and default interest in bonds. Government bonds were then issued to the applicant on May 31, 2012. The applicant sold all of her bonds on the Stock Exchange on September 17, 2012.

title: CASE OF MILINKOVIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Banja Luka.
- The Republika Srpska was ordered to pay 34,000 convertible marks (BAM) in non-pecuniary damage and legal costs to the applicant.
- A writ of execution was issued on 29 June 2009.
- The applicant complained of non-enforcement to the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
- On 16 January 2013, the Constitutional Court found a breach of Article 6 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention.
- The final judgment in favor of the applicant remains unenforced to this day.

title: CASE OF M.P.E.V. AND OTHERS v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The first and second applicants were born in 1969, and the third and fourth applicants in 1986 and 1999 respectively. They live in Geneva.
- The first and second applicants married on 25 December 1988 in Ecuador and brought up the third and fourth applicants together. The third applicant is the second applicant’s daughter and the first applicant’s stepdaughter; the fourth applicant is the first and second applicants’ daughter.
- Between 1995 and 1999 the applicants sought asylum in Switzerland on three occasions. Each time their applications were rejected they returned to Ecuador.
- On 1 January 2002 the applicants, having re-entered Swiss territory, filed a fresh request for asylum. The first and second applicants claimed that they had been tortured and had received death threats from the Ecuadorian police after the first applicant had attended two political demonstrations in Quito.
- On 4 February 2002 the Swiss Federal Office for Refugees (“the Refugee Office”) rejected the applicants’ request.
- On 1 March 2005 the first applicant was convicted of selling stolen goods and was given a three-month suspended prison sentence and fined 2,000 francs (CHF). 
- On 27 November 2009 the Refugee Office granted the third applicant a residence permit on humanitarian grounds. She then withdrew her asylum request and applied for Swiss citizenship, which was granted on 17 September 2012. 
- On 20 March 2012 the Refugee Office, following a fresh examination of the facts, rejected the remaining applicants’ request for asylum. 
- On 7 September 2012 the Federal Administrative Court partially reversed the Refugee Office’s decision.
- The court considered that sending one of the applicants back would amount to an uprooting of excessive rigidity and granted temporary residence to the fourth applicant and her mother in Switzerland.
- Regarding the first applicant, the Federal Administrative Court considered his expulsion to be lawful due to his criminal record.

title: CASE OF BENKŐ AND SOÓSNÉ BENKŐ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1937 and lived in Budapest.
- On 23 April 2002, she filed a case for the dissolution of common ownership.
- On 22 November 2007, the Budapest Regional Court issued a partial judgment.
- The Supreme Court quashed the partial judgment on 25 June 2008.
- The case was terminated by the Budapest Regional Court on 1 December 2011.
- On 6 March 2012, the applicant's lawyer communicated with the Court regarding the intention to lodge an application.

title: CASE OF YERLİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lived in Adana.
- On 5 July 2001, the applicant and his relative were arrested by the police and beaten up by a police officer at the street stand where they were selling CDs.
- As a result of a punch to his ear, the applicant’s eardrum was perforated.
- On 7 July 2001, the Adana Police Station received a complaint about damaged CDs being sold.
- On 10 July 2001, the Adana Forensic Medicine Institute reported that the applicant’s left eardrum had been perforated as a result of physical trauma.
- On 18 July 2001, the applicant submitted the names of his witnesses to the investigating authorities.
- On 20 May 2002, the Tarsus Assize Court decided to quash the decision not to prosecute the police officer.
- On 14 August 2002, the suspect M.T. gave his statement before the criminal court and denied all charges.
- On 18 March 2003 and 29 September 2003, witnesses testified before the criminal court.
- On 17 September 2007, the criminal court decided to acquit the police officer on the ground of insufficient evidence.
- On 8 February 2010, the Court of Cassation quashed the decision of the first instance court on the ground that the limitation period had expired, and ordered the discontinuation of the proceedings against the police officer.

title: CASE OF STOIAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- On 19 September 1999, the applicant was pulled over by a police patrol and asked to produce an identity card.
- The applicant did not have his identity card and told the police officers that his name was Vasile Stoian.
- The police officers asked the applicant to get out of his car and after a few minutes, he got back into his car and drove off abruptly, hitting one of the police officers.
- The applicant alleges that he left because the police officers had physically abused and insulted him. However, the police officers involved in the incident contested the applicant’s account of events.
- The police officers chased the applicant and after a collision, they handcuffed him and carried out a body search and a search of his car.
- The police officers invited reporters from the “Antena 1” television channel to come and film the incident and within 30 minutes, a group of television reporters had arrived and started taking images of the applicant handcuffed and covered in blood.
- The police officers continued their search and found the applicant’s driving license inside the bag.
- The applicant claimed that the police officers had carried out the search of his bag after breaking its lock despite the fact that he had expressed his intent to open the bag and give them his identity documents.
- The applicant underwent a medical examination and presented injuries that could have been caused by being hit with a hard object.
- The prosecutor’s office held that the four police officers had behaved abusively towards the applicant and in order to cover up their actions they had fabricated false evidence.
- On 19 September 1999, the applicant lodged a criminal complaint against the four police officers involved in the incident for theft, bodily injury, and insult.
- On 19 February 2001, a criminal investigation was initiated against the four police officers from Ilfov Police Inspectorate for abuse of authority, forgery of official documents, use of forged documents, and instigation to false testimony.
- The military prosecutor held that the police officers had subjected the applicant to ill-treatment, causing him injuries which needed medical treatment and had tried to cover up their criminal activity by drafting reports which did not reflect what had actually happened and had forced the witnesses to make false statements.
- On 19 August 2004, the prosecutor’s office attached to the Bucharest Court of Appeal decided to discontinue the investigation, stating that there was no evidence that the police officers had subjected the applicant to ill-treatment.

title: CASE OF TANDA-MUZINGA v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and lives in Venissieux.
- In 2000, the applicant was granted refugee status under the mandate of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Cameroon, and his certificate of refugee status showed that he was accompanied by his wife and children.
- The applicant's third child was born in Yaoundé in 2004 while he was absent as he had left Cameroon to claim asylum in France.
- The OFPRA rejected the applicant's claim on 19 July 2004, but he appealed and was granted refugee status in 2007.
- The applicant applied for long-stay visas for his family members on 26 June 2007, but the visa was not issued due to the doubtful authenticity of his children's birth certificates.

title: CASE OF STATILEO v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and owned a flat in Split.
- In 1955, a certain Ms P.A. was awarded the right to live in the flat under the Decree on Administration of Residential Buildings of 1953.
- P.A. and her cousin I.T. lived in the flat until P.A. moved out in 1973.
- I.T. continued to live in the flat with her husband and son, Ig.T., after P.A. moved out until 1996.
- In 1996, a new Lease of Flats Act was passed which abolished the specially protected tenancy.
- The applicant refused to conclude a new lease contract with I.T. stipulating the protected rent pursuant to the new law.
- I.T. brought a civil action against the applicant in 1997 to obtain a judgment in lieu of such a contract.
- The applicant brought an action in the same court seeking to obtain a judgment ordering I.T. and her son to vacate the flat.
- By a judgment of 2 September 2002, the court found in favour of I.T. and her son, ordering the applicant to conclude a lease contract with them.
- On 28 June 2006, the appeal by the applicant was dismissed by the Požega County Court.
- On 17 September 2009, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint.
- The monthly protected rent for the flat changed over time, in line with the increase in the construction price index.
- The applicant refused to receive the protected rent, so I.T. had to deposit it with a court.
- The condominium fee paid into the common reserve fund by the owner of the flat was set at HRK 102.81 on 1 January 1998 and has not been changed since.
- The applicant had never declared any income from renting out the flat.

title: CASE OF AXEL SPRINGER AG v. GERMANY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant company is a public limited company that publishes the mass-circulation daily newspaper Bild.
- Following a heavy election defeat in the Land of North Rhine-Westphalia, Federal Chancellor Gerhard Schröder announced that parliamentary elections would be brought forward to autumn 2005.
- Schröder called a vote of confidence on July 1, 2005, and lost it, resulting in the dissolution of the Bundestag on July 21, 2005.
- The elections were held on September 18, 2005, and none of the main political parties emerged victorious with a sufficient majority.
- On 9 December 2005, it was announced that Schröder had been appointed chairman of the supervisory board of the German-Russian consortium NEGP, which aimed to build a gas pipeline to supply Russian gas to western Europe.
- On 12 December 2005, Bild published an article questioning whether Schröder had resigned as Chancellor because he had been offered lucrative positions by the Russians.
- Schröder sought an injunction in the Hamburg Regional Court to prohibit any further publication of the article, which was granted in a judgment of 24 June 2005, and subsequently upheld by the Hamburg Court of Appeal in a judgment of 8 April 2008.

title: CASE OF RAKHIMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and resided in the Moscow Region prior to his arrest.
- He arrived in Russia and settled in Moscow in 1999.
- Between 1 and 18 November 2009, he travelled to Uzbekistan.
- The National Security Department of the Samarkand Region of Uzbekistan brought criminal proceedings against him on 3 March 2010, charging him with alleged membership of Hizb ut‑Tahrir and making calls to overthrow the constitutional order of Uzbekistan.
- On 17 April 2013, he was arrested by the police in Moscow as a person wanted by the Uzbek authorities.
- On 30 July 2013, the Kuntsevskiy Inter‑District prosecutor’s office ordered his release from detention, and he was immediately apprehended by the police at the exit of the remand centre and taken into custody for violating immigration laws.
- He was found guilty of breaching immigration regulations and fined 2,000 Russian rubles.
- He was ordered to be administratively removed from Russia and detained in a special detention centre for foreigners of the Moscow Department of the Interior until his administrative removal.

title: CASE OF LEMO AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- Applicants moved into flats in Mlini as employees of Mlini Hotels
- Protected Tenancies (Sale to Occupier) Act was enacted in 1991
- Mlini Hotels were privatised after 1991
- Applicants sought to purchase their flats from Mlini Hotels but their requests were refused
- Mlini Hotels brought separate civil actions for eviction against each applicant in the municipal court
- The court accepted the plaintiff's claims and dismissed applicants' counterclaims
- Applicants appealed, but their appeals were rejected by Dubrovnik County Court
- Applicants lodged constitutional complaints against lower courts' judgments
- Applicants were forcefully evicted on 19 November 2010.

title: CASE OF M.S. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and is serving a sentence in the Mordoviya Republic.
- The police organized a fake drug deal with the help of a close friend of the applicant to arrest him for drug dealing.
- The applicant denies the allegations and claims that he was set up by his friend and the police.
- The applicant was convicted of drug dealing based on the testimonies of his friend, police officers, one of the attesting witnesses, and forensic evidence.
- The applicant has alleged ill-treatment during his arrest, transport, and detention.
- The applicant was transported to various court hearings and detention facilities in vans and trains.
- The applicant was diagnosed with stage 2 asymptomatic HIV infection during his detention in a remand prison.
- The applicant underwent medical examinations and treatment for various health conditions during his detention.

title: CASE OF BUGLOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and is currently serving life sentence.
- On 22 October 1999, the Donetsk Kuybyshevsky District Prosecutor’s Office initiated a criminal investigation into a series of murders accompanied by robberies and identified the applicant and another person as possible perpetrators.
- The police issued an internal search notice in which the applicant was described as a dangerous criminal, and his picture was shown on television as a previously convicted person who was wanted by the police in connection with multiple robberies.
- On 31 January 2000, the applicant and Mr L. were arrested.
- The applicant refused to give a statement in his first questioning as a suspect and as an accused.
- During questioning, Mr L. confessed to eight murders, revealing places near the applicant’s country estate where bodies of several victims and murder weapons were hidden, stating that the applicant had taken part in those crimes.
- The applicant was provided legal counsel on 14 February 2000, and all major procedural actions were conducted in the presence of his lawyer from that date.
- On 16 December 2002, the applicant was found guilty and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- The applicant's appeal was dismissed on 29 May 2003, and his allegations of ill-treatment were found to be unsubstantiated.
- After his arrest, the applicant was placed in several detention centers, and he complained about the conditions of his detention in several letters.
- The monitoring of his correspondence, including with the Court, by the prison administration was subject to automatic monitoring and even punishment for sending complaints through unauthorized channels.

title: CASE OF CULI v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Jarmina.
- The applicant applied to the Vinkovci Municipal Court for enforcement of a final judgement by which her former husband was ordered to pay her alimony.
- On 18 November 2008 the first-instance court issued a writ of execution ordering the former husband to pay the applicant various amounts.
- The writ of execution was served on the Vukovar Regional Office of the Croatian Pension Fund for enforcement.
- D.C. appealed against the writ of execution and the applicant responded to his appeal.
- The first-instance court held a hearing on February 12, 2009, at which both parties gave their statements.
- On February 24, 2009, the first-instance court instructed the former husband to institute separate civil proceedings.
- The applicant appealed against the decision of February 24, 2009.
- On 19 August 2009 the Vukovar County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal and returned the case-file to the first-instance court.
- On 7 January 2010, the Vukovar County Court dismissed D.C.’s appeal.
- The final writ of execution became, and the Croatian Pension Fund transferred various amounts to the applicant's account.
- The applicant lodged a request for the protection of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time, complaining about the length of the enforcement proceedings.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s request, considering that the proceedings had not been excessively long.
- The applicant’s appeal was dismissed by a three-judge panel of the Supreme Court.
- The applicant’s subsequent constitutional complaint was declared inadmissible by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF STÖTTINGER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- Applicants born in 1952 and 1958, living in Neukirchen.
- Applicants own agricultural real estate in Upper Austria.
- Request for building permit for agricultural building, stables, riding hall and premises for brandy production.
- Expert opinion found project not in compliance with zoning plan.
- Appeal dismissed based on opinion that project was uneconomical and merely a hobby.
- Objections filed and decision quashed by Regional Government.
- Building requests dismissed after obtaining supplementary expert opinions.
- Municipal Council lodged complaint with Administrative Court.
- Suspension of appeal proceedings and objections filed against it.
- Complaint lodged against Regional Government’s decision.
- Applicants filed second application against Municipal Council’s failure to decide anew.
- Municipal Council requested additional information on economic business concept.
- Administrative Court ordered Municipal Council to decide on applicants’ appeal.
- Municipal Council dismissed appeal and refused construction permit.
- Government dismissed appeal due to economic inviability.
- Administrative Court dismissed complaint as unfounded.

title: CASE OF BESEDA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Rostov-on-Don.
- The applicant, an army officer, sued the military unit he had served in.
- The Pyatigorsk Garrison Military Court granted the applicant’s claims and awarded various monetary allowances and indemnities.
- The judgment was not appealed and became final.
- The allowances and indemnities were paid to the applicant on different dates.
- The applicant’s name was put on the list of persons eligible for housing.
- Enforcement proceedings began on 11 February 2004, and the military unit was requested to remove the character reference and provide information on alimony payments.
- The military unit informed the bailiff that the execution of these parts of the judgment was outside of its competence.
- The Garrison Court rejected the request for clarification of the judgment regarding the obligation to remove the character reference.
- The Head of the social department of the Military Commissariat confirmed that the character reference was not in the applicant’s record.
- The authorities’ obligation to provide information on the payment of alimony was never executed.
- The Garrison Court adjusted the sums paid to the applicant in accordance with the inflation rate and awarded him additional amounts.
- The applicant’s military unit was disbanded and a successor was named as the new defendant.
- The writ of execution was sent to the Federal Treasury and was eventually enforced.

title: CASE OF YAKOVLEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Russian national and lives in Saratov.
- On 1 June 1994, the applicant’s father deposited an unspecified amount of money in her name with the Savings Bank of the Russian Federation.
- The deposit was to be kept for at least ten years and was redeemable after the applicant had reached the age of sixteen. The interest rate was fixed at 190 per cent per annum.
- The Savings Bank reduced the interest rate later, which the father considered unlawful, and filed a civil claim against the bank.
- The Frunzenskiy District Court of Saratov found in favor of the applicant's father, and the Saratov Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal.
- The Savings Bank lodged an application for supervisory review, which was rejected by the Saratov Regional Court.
- Mr Yakovlev died before the case could be settled.
- The Savings Bank filed a new application for supervisory review, alleging that Mr Yakovlev’s claim should have been dismissed as premature because the maturity date had not yet been reached.
- The Presidium of the Saratov Regional Court quashed the previous judgment and dismissed the claim.
- The Presidium found that a new decision could be made in the case because the claim had been filed on behalf of the applicant's underage daughter, who was now represented by her mother.
- On 2 May 2005, the applicant turned sixteen.
- The Savings Bank offered to pay the applicant 28,928 Russian roubles but it is unknown whether she accepted the offer.

title: CASE OF LUKINYKH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant subscribed to a State savings scheme in the 1990s to receive a passenger car in 1994 but never received it despite paying its full value.
- The applicant sued the authorities to claim the full monetary value of the special-purpose settlement orders for purchasing a car.
- On 19 August 2002, the Yakutsk Town Court allowed the applicant's action and awarded her 115,000 Russian roubles against the Ministry of Finance of the Russian Federation.
- On 18 September 2002, the Supreme Court of the Sakha (Yakutiya) Republic upheld the judgment, but it remained unenforced.
- On 16 September 2004, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Sakha (Yakutiya) Republic reviewed the lower courts' judgments and dismissed the applicant's claim in full, stating that the lower courts had misapplied the domestic law.

title: CASE OF OLEG ZHURAVLEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was found guilty of corruption and abuse of powers and sentenced to custodial sentence.
- The applicant appealed, alleging innocence and unlawful prosecution among others.
- The judgment was quashed on appeal and remitted for a new hearing.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to 5 years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant lodged an appeal, complaining about the assessment of evidence and excessive severity of penalty.
- The sentence was reduced to 4 years’ imprisonment on appeal.
- The applicant was held in an overcrowded remand prison with up to 10 inmates in a cell measuring only 23 sq. m.
- The applicant submitted evidence including complaints to the prison management and statements from three cellmates.

title: CASE OF ZORNIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Sarajevo.
- The applicant actively participates in the political life of the country.
- She stood as a candidate of the Social Democratic Party of Bosnia and Herzegovina for election to the parliament of one of the Entities in 2002.
- The applicant does not declare affiliation with any of the “constituent people” (namely, Bosniacs, Croats and Serbs).
- She is ineligible to stand for election to the second chamber of the State parliament (the House of Peoples) and to the collective Head of State (the Presidency) due to her status as a citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina without declaring affiliation with any specific group.

title: CASE OF TSVETELIN PETKOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant got married in 1993 and recognized paternity of his wife's child, whose biological father was unknown.
- The marriage ended in divorce in 1997, and in 1999 the applicant brought a claim to declare his recognition of paternity null and void, claiming that the signature on the declaration was not his.
- The court declared the recognition of paternity null and void in 2001.
- In 2002, the applicant's former wife brought a claim for the establishment of paternity and child support.
- The applicant was not found at his address, and a lawyer was appointed ex officio to represent him.
- The court declared the applicant the biological father of the child in 2002, based on witness testimony and the date of the child's birth, and ordered him to pay child support.
- The applicant was notified of the judgment, but his ex officio lawyer did not appeal it.
- The applicant found out about the judgment in 2004 and requested a reopening of the case on the ground that he had been deprived of the opportunity to participate personally in the court proceedings.
- The request for reopening was rejected in 2005 by the Supreme Court of Cassation, which concluded that the applicant's right to participate in the proceedings had not been violated.

title: CASE OF PETROVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant's son, Dejan Petrović, was born in 1973 and died on February 15, 2002, in hospital, a month after reportedly having fallen from the window of a police station in Belgrade.
- Dejan Petrović was arrested on suspicion of having snatched a woman’s handbag and was kept overnight in police custody.
- The following morning, Dejan Petrović was questioned by three police officers and allegedly confessed to committing the robbery and hiding money in his home.
- Dejan Petrović was taken back to the Vračar police station to be questioned further, where he rushed forward, jumped head first through a closed window, and fell out into the courtyard, causing severe injuries.
- Dejan Petrović died from sepsis and cardiac arrest on February 15, 2002.
- The autopsy report stated that Dejan Petrović’s death had been violent and caused by damage to his brain, rib and femur fractures, and complications thereafter.
- Three police officers were acquitted of gross misconduct in disciplinary proceedings and later in criminal proceedings for their involvement in the incident.

title: CASE OF JOVANOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants were former employees of "Društveno preduzeće Industrija mesa 'Crvena zvezda'" in Kragujevac.
- The Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings against the debtor on 15 October 2002.
- The applicants submitted claims for the payment of salary arrears and related employment benefits.
- The court accepted some of the applicants' claims, while the remainder of their claims were instructed to initiate a regular civil suit.
- The debtor ceased to exist on 26 February 2010.
- Court decisions rendered in favor of the applicants on certain dates became final on an unspecified date and are only partly enforced to date.

title: CASE OF BUTIUC AND DUMITROF  v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1978 and served a prison sentence from 2005 to 2010 for drug trafficking.
- The first applicant alleged severe overcrowding, lack of hygiene, heating, bedclothes, and infestations during his detention.
- The first applicant alleged strip-searches were conducted regularly on groups of prisoners in the prison yard, even during the winter, with prisoners being bullied by guards.
- The Government submitted that Poarta Albă Prison had been built in 1949 and that no changes were made to the size of the cells.
- The Government stated that all prisoners had unrestricted access to water and sanitary facilities, while access to showers was allowed twice per week.
- The Government submitted that internal prison regulations provided that prisoners could bring or buy their own hygiene products or bedclothes.
- The Government stated that Poarta Albă Prison had its own heating system with wood-burning stoves and a heating program which provided adequate warmth.
- Potable water and food were tested regularly and according to documents submitted to the Government by the prison governor, were in compliance with hygiene standards. 
- The applicant Andrei Dumitrof no longer wished to pursue his application, which led to the case being struck out of the list of cases by the Court.

title: CASE OF MARKU v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1931 and lives in Laç.
- In 2002, the applicant lodged an application to have his status as a war veteran recognized.
- On 15 January 2003, the Central Commission on War Veterans informed the applicant that it had stopped receiving applications in September 2001.
- In 2003, the applicant lodged an application for leave to appeal out of time which was allowed by the Lezha District Court on 13 May 2003.
- On 19 June 2003, the applicant requested the Central Commission to have his status as a war veteran recognized.
- On 14 July 2003, the Central Commission informed the applicant that it had ceased to operate on 30 July 2002 and could not examine his application.
- On 9 December 2004, the applicant was informed that the end date for the Central Commission’s operations had been extended to 31 December 2006.
- In 2005, the applicant lodged a civil action with the Tirana District Court for the legal recognition of his time and status as a war veteran.
- On 1 February 2006, the District Court allowed the action and recognized the applicant’s war veteran status.
- On 14 February 2006, the Central Commission appealed against the District Court’s decision.
- On 1 February 2007, the Tirana Court of Appeal upheld the District Court’s decision and an enforcement writ was issued on 12 March 2007.
- On 26 September 2007, the bailiff’s office concluded the enforcement proceedings on the grounds that the judgment was of a declaratory nature.
- On 5 March 2008, the applicant lodged a civil claim requesting the Central Commission to pay him the financial entitlements he was eligible to under domestic law.
- On 23 October 2008, the Tirana District Court dismissed the claim.
- Appeals lodged by the applicant with the Tirana Court of Appeal, Supreme Court, and Constitutional Court were dismissed on 8 December 2009, and 10 February and 18 May 2012 respectively.

title: CASE OF ALIŠIĆ AND OTHERS v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA, CROATIA, SERBIA, SLOVENIA AND "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicants had foreign currency savings in Ljubljanska Banka Sarajevo and Investbanka before the dissolution of the SFRY
- They were unable to withdraw their savings, leading to a complaint under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 and Article 14 of the Convention     
- The SFRY had a system of basic and associated banks, with Ljubljanska Banka Ljubljana as one of the associated banks
- Foreign currency deposits earned high interest and were guaranteed by the State
- Banks could redeposit foreign currency with the National Bank of Yugoslavia (NBY) to shift currency risks
- Ljubljanska Banka Sarajevo was given dinar loans by the NBY and was allowed to transfer the difference between foreign currency deposits and withdrawals to Ljubljanska Banka Ljubljana
- The redepositing system was stopped in 1988 with the declaration of dinar convertibility
- Emergency measures restricted withdrawals of foreign-currency deposits in 1990
- After the dissolution of the SFRY, foreign-currency savings were placed under a special regime, commonly referred to as "old" or "frozen" foreign-currency savings
- Bosnia and Herzegovina assumed the statutory guarantee for "old" foreign-currency savings but withdrawals were exceptionally allowed on humanitarian grounds
- Liability for "old" foreign-currency savings in banks and branches situated in Bosnia and Herzegovina's territory was assumed by the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1997 but savings remained frozen
- In 2004 the FBH excluded liability for foreign-currency savings in branches of Ljubljanska Banka Ljubljana and Investbanka and undertook to pay savings in domestic banks only
- In 2006, liability for "old" foreign-currency savings in domestic banks passed from the Entities to the State, and proceedings concerning such savings ceased.

title: CASE OF SVINARENKO AND SLYADNEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The two applicants were born in 1968 and 1970 respectively.
- Mr Svinarenko is currently serving a sentence of imprisonment in the Murmansk region, while Mr Slyadnev lives in the settlement of Sinegorye in the Yagodninskiy district of the Magadan region.
- Several sets of criminal proceedings were brought against a Mr Grishin by the Far Eastern Federal Circuit Investigation Department of the Investigation Committee at the Ministry of the Interior in 2002.
- Mr Svinarenko was accused of robbery with violence against Mr A.S. and Mrs T.S. in September 2002 as a member of a gang led by Mr Grishin, and of the illegal acquisition, storage, transportation and carrying of ammunition.
- Mr Slyadnev was charged with establishing and participating in an armed gang under Mr Grishin’s leadership that committed several crimes including robbery with the use of weapons and violence, illegal storage and transportation of precious metals, extortion, and illegal acquisition, storage, transfer, transportation, and carrying of firearms by an organised group.
- The applicants were found not guilty by a jury and were released in the courtroom on 22 June 2004.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation quashed the judgment on appeal on 7 December 2004 due to the fact that some of the jurors had concealed information about their family members’ criminal records, and the presiding judge failed to sum up all the evidence in his directions to the jury, among other reasons. The case was remitted to the Magadan Regional Court for fresh examination.
- The applicants were ordered to be detained on remand on 6 December 2005 due to their previous convictions, the serious charges against them, and fears expressed by some of the victims and witnesses during previous proceedings. Their detention was extended for similar reasons.
- The first applicant was found not guilty in November 2006, while the second applicant was convicted of extortion and “arbitrary unlawful acts” with the use of violence against two persons and was sentenced to seven years in prison.
- The case was remitted for a fresh examination by the Supreme Court in June 2007 due to an abuse of their rights by the defendants and their lawyers during the previous trial, which was held to have unlawfully influenced the jury’s verdict.
- The first applicant was detained on remand in August 2007 in connection with an unrelated set of criminal proceedings.

title: CASE OF CENTRE FOR LEGAL RESOURCES ON BEHALF OF VALENTIN CÂMPEANU v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- Valentin Câmpeanu, a man of Roma ethnicity, was born on 15 September 1985 to an unknown father and an abandoned mother who died in 2001. He was placed in an orphanage, the Corlate Centre.
- In 1990, Mr Câmpeanu was diagnosed as HIV-positive and later diagnosed with “profound intellectual disability, an IQ of 30 and HIV” and classified as belonging to the severe disability group.
- In 2003, the Dolj County Child Protection Panel ordered that Mr Câmpeanu should no longer be cared for by the State and be transferred to the Poiana Mare Neuropsychiatric Hospital (“the PMH”) despite a recommendation to transfer him to the Neuropsychological Recovery and Rehabilitation Centre.
- On 5 February 2004, Mr Câmpeanu was admitted to the Cetate-Dolj Medical and Social Care Centre (“the CMSC”), where he was in an advanced state of “psychiatric and physical degradation”, was dressed in a tattered tracksuit, with no underwear or shoes, and did not have any antiretroviral medication or information concerning his medical condition.
- During his stay at the CMSC, Mr Câmpeanu became agitated and violent and was transferred back to the PMH, where he was placed in an isolated, unheated and locked room without proper care, treatment, or nutrition. The PMH failed to provide him with the most basic treatment and care services.
- Mr Câmpeanu died on 20 February 2004 due to cardiorespiratory insufficiency. Although an autopsy was mandatory, it was not carried out.
- The case was brought to the attention of the authorities by the Centre for Legal Resources (“the CLR”), who submitted criminal complaints alleging criminal offences by various employees and institutions. An investigation was eventually opened by the prosecutor’s office but was transferred to the Criminal Investigation Department of the Dolj County Police Department.
- A forensic report concluded that Mr Câmpeanu received correct and appropriate medical treatment, but it was unclear whether he had taken his medication due to his “advanced state of psychosomatic degradation.”

title: CASE OF KIM v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Uzbek SSR in 1962 and had been living in St Petersburg, Russia since 1990, without acquiring any nationality.
- On 19 July 2011, he was stopped by the police for an identity check and was found guilty of an administrative offence and ordered for expulsion from Russia with a fine of 2,000 RUB.
- The applicant had no passport or identity documents, and his interviews revealed that he was born in Tashkent and had a residence there.
- The Embassy of Uzbekistan was requested to issue return certificates, but no reply was received despite numerous requests.
- The lawyer's inquiries to the Embassy of Uzbekistan regarding the applicant's nationality and ability for removal to Uzbekistan received no response.
- The applicant filed for an order discontinuing the enforcement of the expulsion order, but it was rejected by the court.
- The applicant's detention was challenged as being unlawful, but the courts ruled that it was legal.
- On February 5, 2013, the consular department of the Embassy of Uzbekistan informed that the applicant was not an Uzbek national.
- The applicant was released on July 29, 2013, on the expiry of the two-year limit for enforcement of the administrative expulsion decision.
- The detention centre was overcrowded with an eight-story building to accommodate 176 inmates, housing around 300-400 people.
- The cells were shared by five to seven people, and there was a lack of access to essential amenities like a sink, drinking water, and toilets and showers.
- The detainees were allowed outside only once every two or three weeks for twenty to thirty minutes, and there was no recreational facility available.

title: CASE OF KADIRZHANOV AND MAMASHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- Applicants are of Uzbek ethnic origin and fled Kyrgyzstan to Russia to avoid ethnically motivated violence after inter-ethnic clashes in 2010.
- Mr. Kadirzhanov arrived in Russia in July 2010 and did not apply for refugee status or temporary asylum until June 2012.
- Mr. Kadirzhanov was charged in absentia by Kyrgyz authorities with violent crimes relating to the inter-ethnic violence in June 2010.
- Kyrgyz authorities requested Mr. Kadirzhanov's extradition from Russia, and he was detained in Orel in May 2012.
- The Kyrgyz authorities provided diplomatic assurances that he would not be subjected to torture or mistreatment, and that he would have access to legal assistance.
- The Russian authorities extended Mr. Kadirzhanov's detention until November 2013 and upheld the extradition order, dismissing his appeal regarding the alleged risk of ill-treatment.
- Mr. Mamashev arrived in Moscow in August 2010 and did not apply for refugee status or temporary asylum until April 2012.
- The Kyrgyz authorities charged him in absentia with violent crimes relating to the inter-ethnic violence in June 2010.
- The Kyrgyz authorities requested Mr. Mamashev's extradition from Russia, and he was detained in Moscow in February 2012.
- The Kyrgyz authorities provided diplomatic assurances and further guarantees to the Russian authorities that he would not be mistreated and that Russian diplomatic staff could visit him during his detention in Kyrgyzstan.
- The Russian authorities extended his detention until August 2013 and granted the extradition request despite his appeal against it.

title: CASE OF OMELCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a Ukrainian national serving a prison sentence for murder and robbery.
- The victim, Ms V., was found dead with multiple knife wounds on a street in Simferopol in October 2004.
- A fingerprint found on the victim's notebook cover, which belonged to the applicant, led the police to suspect him.
- The applicant was questioned as a witness and then as a suspect and confessed to the murder and robbery.
- The applicant waived his right to legal representation during questioning.
- The applicant alleged that his confession was obtained under pressure, threats, and ill-treatment and that the police held him unlawfully without documenting his arrest.
- The applicant was released and then arrested and detained for ten days for breaching public order, during which he was further questioned without legal representation.
- The charges against the applicant were reclassified from simple murder to murder for profit.
- The applicant was convicted of murder and robbery and sentenced to fifteen years' imprisonment based on physical, forensic, and witness evidence, as well as his initial confessions.
- The Supreme Court of Ukraine quashed the conviction and remitted the case for additional investigation, noting issues with the admissibility of the applicant's confessions and discrepancies in the evidence.
- The ARC Court subsequently reconvicted the applicant based on evidence that included his confessions, and the Supreme Court of Ukraine upheld the conviction.

title: CASE OF OSAKOVSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Kharkiv.
- F., a cashier in a game-machines arcade, was found unconscious with head injuries and died shortly afterwards in August 2003.
- The applicant was arrested on 8 June 2004 by the district police of Kharkiv and confessed to having inflicted injuries on F. and robbed the arcade.
- The applicant alleges that the confession was false and given as a result of ill-treatment by police officers who had applied electric current to his body, suffocated him in a gas mask, and applied various other unspecified torture techniques.
- On 10 June 2004, the applicant was indicted on charges of causing fatal injuries to F. and robbing the arcade, and on the same date, the District Court remanded the applicant in custody.
- In July 2004, the Kharkiv Psychiatric Hospital diagnosed the applicant with a mixed personality disorder that did not prevent him from understanding the meaning of his actions or controlling them.
- On 31 July 2004, the applicant retracted his previous confessions, claiming that they had been given under duress from the police, and pleaded innocent.
- In August 2006, the District Court acquitted the applicant of charges related to F.’s death after finding procedural breaches in conducting the reconstruction of the crime scene.
- In May 2004, a woman named D. was found dead in a river, and in August 2004, the Chuguiv Prosecutor’s Office identified the applicant as a potential suspect.
- On 21 September 2004, the applicant confessed to killing D., and on 9 October 2004, he was indicted but subsequently cleared of the charges.
- On 14 December 2004, during a court hearing in the first set of criminal proceedings against the applicant, he complained of ill-treatment in the SIZO with a view to making him confess to D.’s murder.

title: CASE OF YAVOROVENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Domestic courts delivered decisions in favor of the applicants.
- The decisions were final and enforceable.
- Applicants were entitled to receive pecuniary amounts or have certain actions taken in their favor.
- Applicants faced issues with obtaining enforcement of the decisions.
- Some applicants made submissions regarding unrelated factual and legal matters.

title: CASE OF RADOVANOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Šabac.
- The applicant was employed by "Zorka-mineralna đubriva" AD, a socially/State-owned company based in Šabac (hereinafter – "the debtor").
- On 10 April 2001, the Šabac Municipal Court gave effect to a settlement made by the applicant and the debtor, requiring the debtor to pay the applicant certain sums in respect of salary arrears and costs of proceedings.
- The applicant lodged an application for the enforcement of the court's decision with the Šabac Municipal Court on 25 March 2003.
- The court allowed the application and issued an enforcement order on the same date, but the enforcement proceedings were stayed on 4 April 2003 because the debtor was undergoing restructuring.
- The applicant requested the court to continue the enforcement proceedings on 11 May 2007, which the court did on 6 July 2007.
- The enforcement proceedings were stayed again on 24 June 2008, as the debtor was still undergoing restructuring.
- The applicant requested the court to continue the enforcement proceedings again on 26 March 2010, and the court considered this request to be a fresh application for the enforcement of the decision of 10 April 2001, ordering the applicant to submit a copy of that decision again.
- The court terminated the enforcement on 30 January 2012 when the applicant failed to comply with the request to submit a copy of the decision.
- On 3 July 2003, the Šabac Municipal Court ruled in favor of the applicant and ordered the debtor to pay him certain sums in respect of salary arrears and costs of proceedings, which became final on the same date.
- The applicant lodged an application for the enforcement of this court decision on 29 September 2004, and the court issued an enforcement order on 30 September 2004.
- The enforcement proceedings were stayed on 4 January 2005 because the debtor was undergoing restructuring.
- The applicant requested the court to continue the enforcement proceedings on 11 May 2007, which the court did on 4 October 2007.
- The enforcement proceedings were stayed again on 3 March 2008 because the debtor was still undergoing restructuring.
- On 10 July 2002, the Privatization Agency ordered the restructuring of the debtor as part of the privatization process, which is still ongoing.

title: CASE OF ATAYKAYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is the father of Tarık Ataykaya, who died on 29 March 2006.
- Tarık Ataykaya was struck on the head by a tear-gas grenade and died a few minutes later.
- The object extracted from Tarık Ataykaya's head was a plastic cartridge from a tear-gas grenade of type no. 12.
- Many illegal demonstrations took place in Diyarbakır between 28 and 31 March 2006, during which a number of demonstrators were killed.
- During the incidents, nine people died, and over 200 members of the police force and 214 higher-ranking officers, a doctor, a nurse, two journalists and an ambulance driver were wounded.

title: CASE OF BOKAN AND OTHERS v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- Applicants are residents of Bosnia and Herzegovina
- The Republika Srpska was ordered to pay for war damage in five judgments by Banja Luka Court of First Instance
- The amounts in convertible marks (BAM) became final on different dates, for each judgment
- Writs of execution were issued by the court
- Some of the applicants filed complaints of non-enforcement to the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, citing the breach of Article 6 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention
- Breach of compensation was found in some complaints by the Constitutional Court
- The applicants were informed about options for the settlement of the Republika Srpska's public debt, and they agreed to be paid legal costs in cash and the principal debt and default interest in bonds
- Government bonds were issued on different dates
- Some of the applicants have already sold some or all of their bonds on the Stock Exchange.

title: CASE OF CORNEA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Curchi.
- The applicant was head of female patient services at the Orhei Psychiatric Hospital, temporarily replacing the hospital's chief physician who was suspended from his position.
- In October 2005, the hospital ordered the transfer of the applicant and another doctor, V.C., to different positions. V.C. challenged the order, which ultimately led to his reinstatement as head of female patient services.
- The applicant was not involved in the legal proceedings that resulted in V.C.'s reinstatement and only learned of them after they were concluded.
- The applicant's subsequent appeal against the judgment was dismissed by the courts, and he took up a lower-paying position as a result.

title: CASE OF GRAFESCOLO S.R.L. v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is a company incorporated in Moldova.
- The Vadul lui Voda local council adopted a decision concerning the sale of a plot of land with a greenhouse on it to the applicant company on 13 February 2003.
- In March 2003, a contract was entered into for that purpose between the local council and the applicant company.
- On 15 June 2006, the local council adopted a decision revoking its previous decision.
- The applicant initiated proceedings against the local council.
- On 25 December 2006, the Vadul lui Voda local council introduced a counter action seeking the termination of the contract of sale between it and the applicant company.
- The applicant company opposed the action of the council.
- On 13 April 2007, the Ciocana District Court rejected the applicant’s action but accepted that of the local council and declared the contract of sale null and void.
- The court held that the rules governing time limitation contained in the new Civil Code should apply.
- The Chişinău Court of Appeal upheld the appeal lodged by the applicant company on 5 September 2007, and dismissed the counter action lodged by the local council.
- The local council lodged an appeal on points of law.
- On 16 January 2008, the Supreme Court of Justice upheld the appeal on points of law lodged by the local council and quashed the judgment of the Court of Appeal.
- The Supreme Court did not state any position in respect of the applicant company’s initial defence concerning the statute of limitations, and its judgment was final.

title: CASE OF A.D. AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants are ethnic Uighur Muslims from Xinjiang, China
- They left China due to the pressure and fear of persecution as practising Muslims of Uighur ethnic origin.
- Second applicant was arrested in Istanbul for overstaying his visa and deported.
- Chinese authorities provided a list of suspects that included all five applicants, citing them as members of the East Turkestan Islamic Movement, a terrorist organization.
- Applicants were banned from entering Turkey and detained in the Kumkapı Foreigners’ Admission and Accommodation Centre.
- The National Intelligence Agency considered their continued presence in Turkey as problematic in terms of the Government’s international relations.
- The Ministry of the Interior rejected their asylum claims, stating that they did not meet the criteria required for obtaining asylum seeker status.
- Applicants filed an objection to the Ministry’s decision.
- The applicants' lawyer was continuously denied access to their files.
- The applicants were released from detention for an unknown reason and were later rounded up again without any explanation.

title: CASE OF BULATOVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lived in Podgorica.
- On 8 May 2001, the applicant murdered X and immediately left the country.
- On 6 March 2002, the applicant was found guilty of murder and sentenced to twenty years in prison.
- On 27 June 2002, the applicant was arrested in Spain pursuant to an international arrest warrant and placed in custody.
- On 14 May 2003, he was extradited to Montenegro.
- On 3 February 2004, the criminal proceedings against the applicant were re-opened.
- On 10 April 2009, the High Court found the applicant guilty, sentenced him to fourteen years’ imprisonment and ordered him to pay the costs of the proceedings as well as court fees.
- On 29 January 2010, the Court of Appeal quashed the judgment and ordered a retrial.
