- On 4 October 2010, the High Court found the applicant guilty, sentenced him to fourteen years’ imprisonment, and ordered him to pay the costs of the proceedings and court fees.
- On 21 March 2011, the Court of Appeal upheld that decision, and the applicant was transferred to prison.
- On 19 September 2011, the Supreme Court dismissed an appeal on points of law lodged by the applicant.
- The applicant had been detained in overcrowded cells with poor conditions and lack of basic amenities such as water and exercise.
- He had also complained about the length of his detention, and in 2010, he applied for an assessment of the constitutionality of Article 572 of the Criminal Procedure Code 2003.
- The applicant's sentence was reduced by six months following an amnesty granted to him by the President, and on 19 August 2013, his sentence was further reduced, and he was released on 27 August 2013.

title: CASE OF AMURUBA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant born in 1975 and lives in Tiszalök
- Arrested in Spain on charges of drug trafficking on 11 November 2002
- Sentenced to four years’ imprisonment on 2 May 2003, then granted leave and subsequently absconded
- European arrest warrant issued by the Hungarian Miskolc District Court for suspected involvement in drug trafficking network operating between Spain, Hungary, and South America
- Recaptured by Spanish police on 8 August 2005 and obligated to serve the remainder of the Spanish sentence
- Temporarily extradited to Hungary on 3 April 2006 for six months where pre-trial detention was ordered, then transferred back to Spain on 29 September 2006 to complete sentence
- Definitively extradited to Hungary on 20 November 2006 and pre-trial detention ordered on 21 November 2006
- Detention prolonged at statutory intervals on the grounds of risk of absconding and repetition of crime
- Applicant’s appeals dismissed on 27 December 2006 and 11 June 2008
- Request for termination of pre-trial detention or its replacement by a less stringent measure rejected by Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén County Regional Court on 4 June 2009, upheld by Debrecen Court of Appeal on 16 July 2009
- Convicted of aggravated drug trafficking by the Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén County Regional Court and sentenced to eight years’ imprisonment, a ten-year ban from Hungary, and confiscation of assets on 12 June 2009
- Judgment quashed on 9 June 2010 by Debrecen Court of Appeal and applicant’s pre-trial detention reordered on grounds of risk of absconding and repetition of offences
- Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision on 5 August 2010
- Pre-trial detention prolonged for fear of absconding and repetition of crime on 4 October 2010 and 1 June 2011
- Sentenced to seven years’ and six months’ imprisonment, confiscation of property, and a five-year ban from Hungarian territory on 25 January 2012
- Sentence increased to nine years and six months and the ban to ten years by Court of Appeal on 11 July 2012
- Applicant alleges ill-treatment by staff of Miskolc Prison on 3 December 2012 but has not submitted any evidence to support this allegation.

title: CASE OF AL NASHIRI v. POLAND
facts:
1. The USS Cole was bombed in 2000.
2. The MV Limburg was also bombed.
3. The CIA used combined interrogation techniques for High-Value Detainees.
4. The conditions of detention at CIA detention facilities were at issue.
5. The HVD Program was eventually closed.
6. The Polish Government provided information in written and oral submissions.
7. Applicant's facts supplemented by Abu Zubaydah v. Poland and public domain materials.

title: CASE OF ČALOVSKIS v. LATVIA
facts:
Facts of the case:
- The applicant was indicted on five counts of conspiracy to violate the criminal laws of the United States, which included bank fraud, wire fraud, access device fraud, computer intrusion, and aggravated identity theft.
- The charges were based on allegations that the applicant and his co-conspirators had created and distributed malicious software known as the “Gozi Virus” to steal login credentials for online bank accounts and other internet-based accounts.
- The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York issued a warrant for the applicant’s arrest in relation to the offences listed in the indictment.
- The Latvian authorities arrested the applicant on 4 December 2012, pursuant to the United States’ request for his extradition.
- The applicant alleged that he was deprived of an opportunity to contact a lawyer for legal assistance until 1.20 p.m. on 4 December 2012.
- On 6 December 2012, the applicant and his lawyer contested the contents of the extradition request and asked that a more lenient measure than detention be imposed on the applicant.
- The investigating judge ruled that the applicant be detained under section 702 of the Criminal Procedure Law (“pre-extradition detention”).
- The applicant submitted several complaints to the courts and the prosecution to lift his pre-extradition detention or substitute it with a different security measure.
- On 10 October 2013, the applicant was released from pre-extradition detention as the purpose of detention had ceased to exist.

title: CASE OF HUSAYN (ABU ZUBAYDAH) v. POLAND
facts:
1. Information supplied by the Polish Government 
2. Facts supplied by the applicant 
3. Standard procedures and treatment of “High-Value Detainees” 
4. Conditions of detention at CIA detention facilities 
5. Closure of the HVD Programme

title: CASE OF KAPLAN AND OTHERS v. NORWAY
facts:
1. The first applicant is of Kurdish ethnic origin and lived in Turkey during violent conflicts in the early 1990s.
2. He fled Turkey in 1993 and applied for asylum in Denmark, which was later rejected. He then applied for asylum in Norway in 1998.
3. The first applicant was convicted of aggravated assault in Norway in 1999 and sentenced to 90 days in prison, of which 60 days were suspended.
4. The decision regarding the first applicant's expulsion from Norway was not implemented until 2006, despite his conviction in 1999.
5. The second applicant, the first applicant's wife, and their children also applied for asylum in Norway, which was later rejected but eventually granted on humanitarian grounds due to their daughter's health condition.

title: CASE OF BRINCAT AND OTHERS v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicants were full-time employees at the Malta Drydocks Corporation from the 1950s/60s to early 2000, and were constantly and intensively exposed to asbestos during their employment.
- Asbestos in its various forms was one of the substances kept in stock in Malta Drydocks’ storerooms, and ships incorporating asbestos as part of their structure regularly entered the docks and were repaired there by workers.
- The presence of asbestos particles would settle on the workers’ clothing, and it could also affect the lives of their family members, creating further anguish and affecting their private and family life.
- The employees of MDC had not been informed about nor protected from the dangers of asbestos in any way at the time, despite Malta becoming a member of the International Labour Organisation and the World Health Organisation raising awareness regarding the dangers of asbestos since the 1950s.
- The first publicly available information concerning the fatal consequences of asbestos at MDC appears to be the judicial acts and judgment relating to a lawsuit brought in the names of Mary Pellicano, and in that case, MDC’s responsibility for the death of Paul Pellicano was established.
- Following that judgment, no action was taken save that employees were assured that adequate ventilation and the wearing of fabric masks would protect them from asbestos.
- The applicants underwent medical tests, and most of them revealed bilateral pleural plaques (extensive in some cases) compatible with asbestos exposure, pleural thickening, reticulo-nodular interstitial parenchymal texture in the lungs, and in some cases also pulmonary fibrosis, all of which are consistent with asbestosis.
- Mr Attard died in 2006 as a result of a malignant cancer linked to exposure to asbestos (mesothelioma).
- The applicants instituted separate constitutional redress proceedings, complaining of a violation of Articles 2, 3 and 8 of the Convention in that the State had failed to protect them from unnecessary risks to their health, which also constituted inhuman treatment and an interference with their private and family life.
- The first-instance constitutional jurisdiction discharged the defendants, thus dismissing the applications on the grounds of non-exhaustion of ordinary domestic remedies.
- The Constitutional Court upheld the first-instance decisions, stating that the applicants should have pursued ordinary remedies under the Civil Code before instituting constitutional redress proceedings.

title: CASE OF MAMADALIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is an ethnic Uzbek born in 1989 living in Grozny
- He moved from his hometown of Jalal-Abad, Kyrgyzstan to Dagestan and later to Grozny where he worked at a telephone repair service
- In 2011, he went to Kyrgyzstan to attend his sister’s wedding and was later suspected of murdering one of his passengers from Kyrgyz ethnic origin
- Criminal proceedings were brought against him and four others, and he was charged in absentia and ordered to be remanded in custody by the Jalal-Abad Town Court allegedly in the absence of his lawyer
- The applicant was eventually arrested in Grozny, and the Leninskiy District Court of Grozny extended his detention until 24 October 2012 and later until 24 January 2013
- The Deputy Prosecutor of the Republic of Chechnya ordered the applicant’s release on condition that he did not leave his place of residence without permission from an interim measure by the Court
- An extradition request was lodged by the Deputy Prosecutor General of Kyrgyzstan seeking to extradite the applicant to Kyrgyzstan for prosecution on charges of murder, and the Deputy Prosecutor General of the Russian Federation granted the request
- The applicant appealed against the extradition decision to the Supreme Court of the Republic of Chechnya and the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation, but both appeals were rejected. 
- The applicant also submitted a request for refugee status, which was rejected as ill-founded, and his subsequent appeals were dismissed. 
- The applicant was eventually granted temporary asylum by the Department of FMS in the Republic of Chechnya until 15 August 2014.

title: CASE OF DRAGIN v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of incitement to aggravated murder.
- The investigating judge remanded the applicant in custody due to the risk of collusion, risk of reoffending, and seriousness of charges.
- The applicant's detention was extended several times due to the risk of reoffending and seriousness of charges.
- The Supreme Court reversed the decision of the Rijeka County Court and ordered the applicant's detention only under the risk of reoffending.
- The trial court found the applicant guilty of incitement to aggravated murder and unlawful possession of firearms and explosives, sentencing him to six years and three months' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF REMETIN v. CROATIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born on 8 September 1989 and lives in Dubrovnik.
- On 4 March 2008, the police received an anonymous call informing them that a mass fight was planned near a school in Dubrovnik.
- When the police arrived at the scene, they found the applicant injured in the school with an injury on his forehead and took him to the hospital. 
- The applicant stated that he had been hit on the head with a rock and had not been involved in any fighting.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint on 23 May 2008 alleging that he had been injured by a group of hooligans in front of his school.
- The police interviewed several people and obtained a medical opinion recommending that the applicant undergo further neurological examination.
- The police discovered that a group of boys went to the school to take revenge, throwing rocks and causing minor injuries to the applicant and others.
- The applicant underwent another medical examination finding no damage to his brain but an inflammation of his sinuses.
- The police indicted the applicant and seven other people on charges of breach of the public peace and order in connection with a fight in a bar on 19 December 2010.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint on 16 March 2011 against three individuals alleging they attacked him and his friend in a bar, and had been attacked by individuals from the same group in 2008.
- The State Attorney’s Office rejected the applicant’s criminal complaint against one individual but indicted two others on charges of violent behavior.

title: CASE OF LYAPIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
• In February 2008, thefts occurred in the Volodarskiy District of the Nizhniy Novgorod region.
• On the night of April 24-25, 2008, police officers U. and K. apprehended the applicant, who had entered a garage cooperative in Ilyinogorsk.
• The police found homemade lock-picking tools on the applicant and his truck had stolen items.
• The applicant claimed that he was coerced into confessing to the garage thefts and suffered ill-treatment by police while in custody.
• The applicant suffered several injuries, including burn wounds, bruises, and a closed fracture of the left ribs.
• The applicant was sentenced to five days' administrative detention, and an investigator imposed a restraining order on him.

title: CASE OF ALIYEVA AND ALIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
• The applicants’ son, E.A., was murdered in Kiev, Ukraine on 1 June 2001.
• G.A., an Azerbaijani national working at the Azerbaijani embassy in Ukraine, was charged with the murder but released on account of ill health.
• R.A., a major general of the Azerbaijani army, was identified as the actual perpetrator of the crime and was later charged with the murder.
• Criminal proceedings against R.A. were dismissed by the Military Prosecutor’s Office of the Republic of Azerbaijan on the grounds of insufficient evidence.
• The applicants repeatedly requested an effective investigation but were not informed of the progress of the case. 
• The investigation was extended, despite the identification of the perpetrator.

title: CASE OF JANNATOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
Facts:

- The applicant was born in 1971 and lived in Baku.
- On 23 June 2004, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of complicity in an armed robbery and two murders committed on 13 November 2002.
- The applicant was repeatedly subjected to ill-treatment in police custody from 23 to 26 June 2004, with the aim of extracting a confession from him.
- The perpetrators of his ill-treatment included police officers, an investigator, and the head of the investigating department at the Prosecutor General’s Office.
- On 25 June 2004, the applicant showed his injuries to his lawyer and complained about the ill-treatment. His lawyer asked for a forensic expert examination of the applicant.
- The applicant was questioned by the investigator on 25 and 26 June 2004 and admitted to his involvement in the crime.
- The applicant denied his involvement in the crime during the trial and claimed that his statements during the investigation were extracted under torture.
- The Assize Court convicted the applicant of complicity in aggravated murder, aggravated robbery, banditry, and illegal possession of weapons on 29 March 2005 and sentenced him to thirteen years' imprisonment.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the Assize Court's judgment on 27 May 2005.
- The Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' judgments on 27 February 2007.

title: CASE OF SHTEFAN AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Domestic courts and labour disputes commissions made decisions in favour of the applicants. 
- The decisions granted various pecuniary amounts or required certain actions to be taken. 
- The decisions became final and enforceable, but the applicants were unable to enforce them timely. 
- Some of the applicants made submissions about factual and legal matters not related to non-enforcement issues.

title: CASE OF TERSHIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is of Chechen ethnic origin and is currently serving a prison sentence in Azerbaijan.
- In 2009, he was arrested while attempting to illegally cross the border from Azerbaijan to Russia with others.
- He was convicted and sentenced to 14 years’ imprisonment by the Assize Court for serious criminal offences committed in Azerbaijan in 2009.
- He was charged and remanded in custody in absentia by the Vedeno District Court of the Chechen Republic for being an active member of an illegal armed unit operating in Chechnya.
- He applied for asylum in Azerbaijan in January 2012, which was rejected by UNHCR in September 2012 after an interview.
- The Russian Deputy Prosecutor General requested the Azerbaijani Prosecutor General’s Office to extradite him for carrying out necessary procedural steps in the criminal proceedings pending in Russia.
- The Azerbaijani First Deputy Prosecutor General granted the extradition request and ordered the applicant’s “temporary extradition” to Russia for a period of three months.
- He lodged an appeal against the temporary extradition order with the Sabayil District Court, arguing the risk of torture or ill-treatment if he was extradited.
- The Sabayil District Court dismissed his appeal, mentioning that the Russian authorities’ extradition request provided the necessary assurances and his request for refugee status had been rejected by UNHCR.
- He lodged an appeal against this decision with the Baku Court of Appeal, which was dismissed, and no further appeal was allowed.

title: CASE OF JAEGER v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and is currently serving a prison sentence.
- On October 10, 2010, the applicant was searched by two prison guards in the stairwell of his accommodation block in Tartu Prison.
- The applicant claimed he was asked to lower his trousers and underpants twice and lift his sexual organ in the sight of other detainees and other transparent windows.
- The applicant claimed 25,000 kroons for non-pecuniary damages, but the prison administration rejected his claim, stating that the search was conducted in private.
- The Administrative Court found the prison guard's statement to be reliable and rejected the applicant's claim. The Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal, and the Supreme Court also rejected his appeal. 
- The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal's finding that the applicant's privacy had not been infringed, but one judge delivered a separate opinion stating that it damaged a person's dignity and could cause feelings of insecurity, anguish, and degradation. 
- The applicant had three reprimands on record at the time of the search and received twenty additional disciplinary punishments in the following years.

title: CASE OF NEMTSOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a professional politician who has held many high-ranking positions.
- A public demonstration was scheduled on 10 December 2010, and the organisers submitted a notice to the mayor of Moscow.
- The event was authorised with a limit of 1,000 participants and a designated area to gather.
- Another group of individuals submitted a notice of an alternative public demonstration to occur at the same time and place, which was not authorised.
- On the day of the authorised event, the applicant addressed the participants with a speech criticising the criminal conviction of Mikhail Khodorkovskiy, the former owner of Yukos oil company, and other corrupt practices in the state administration.
- When leaving the event with his daughter, the applicant saw someone being arrested and was also arrested.
- The circumstances of the applicant’s arrest were disputed.
- The applicant alleged the existence of various video recordings of his arrest, as well as an official video kept at the Moscow Department of the Interior.
- The applicant was detained in a solitary and poorly equipped cell at a police station until 2 January 2011, when he was transferred to another detention facility.
- The applicant’s detention conditions were subject to conflicting accounts between the applicant and the government.
- The Justice of the Peace scheduled a hearing for the applicant on 2 January 2011.
- The applicant stood throughout the hearing, which lasted for over five hours.
- Various motions were lodged by the applicant, including requests for video recordings and a witness examination.
- The court denied the applicant’s motion to admit video evidence and call Police Colonel B. for witness examination.

title: CASE OF TRABELSI v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and is currently in Rappahannock Prison in Virginia, USA.
- On 14 September 2001, an arrest warrant was issued against the applicant after a search of his home led to the discovery of false passports, weapons, ammunition, and chemical formulae for making explosives, as well as a detailed plan of the US Embassy in Paris.
- A search of a Brussels café where the applicant was a regular customer revealed 59 litres of acetone and 96 kilograms of sulphur powder.
- The applicant admitted to the charges and was sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment by the Brussels Regional Court for attempting to blow up the Kleine-Brogel Belgian army base, forgery, and instigating a criminal conspiracy to attack persons and property.
- The United States issued an extradition request for the applicant on the charges of conspiracy to kill US nationals and other terrorist-related charges carrying a maximum of life imprisonment. The extradition was granted after the Brussels Court of Appeal declared the warrant enforceable, and the Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF DZEMYUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant owns a house and land near a proposed cemetery. 
2. The cemetery was proposed to be built on land previously occupied by garages. 
3. Environmental concerns were raised about the proximity of the cemetery to residential buildings, wells, and rivers. 
4. Despite court orders, burials continued at the site. 
5. The applicant suffered health issues and two of his neighbors died while living near the prohibited cemetery. 
6. The applicant requested to be resettled but was not provided a suitable option.

title: CASE OF RUDYAK v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts of the case are:

- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Gadyach.
- On 25 February 2004, the applicant was arrested in Gadyach for drug trafficking by the Kharkiv Chervonozavodskiy District Police Drug Squad.
- The applicant was ill-treated by police, and a police officer hit him in the left eye upon his arrest.
- On 19 July 2004, the Gadyachskiy District Court convicted the applicant of unlawful possession of weapons and drug trafficking and sentenced him to five years’ imprisonment. He was released the same day.
- On 27 November 2004, the applicant was diagnosed with a cataract and a subatrophy of the left eyeball, and his only recommendation was to avoid hypothermia.
- On 19 April 2005, the applicant was again arrested in Gadyach for selling drugs to D. and was allegedly beaten by the police for three days after his arrest because he asked for a lawyer. A gas mask with lit cigarettes was also put on his face pending investigation.
- On 22 April 2005, criminal proceedings on drug trafficking charges were instituted against the applicant, and he was remanded in custody on 29 April 2005.
- On 11 August 2006, the Chervonozavodskiy Court convicted the applicant of unlawful possession of weapons and drug trafficking and sentenced him to six and a half years’ imprisonment, later quashed on 10 January 2008 and resulted in the applicant being convicted again on 20 November 2008 with a sentence of five years and six months’ imprisonment.
- On 25 May 2010, the applicant was released.
- Between 17 and 28 January 2011, the applicant was admitted to a hospital and diagnosed with hypertension, chronic cholecystitis, a cyst of the left kidney, and optic subatrophy in the left eye.
- While in detention, the applicant was examined by an ophthalmologist and other specialists on numerous occasions, and he complained of pain in his left eye and general weakness.
- On 27 February 2010, the applicant complained of hypertension and was offered examination and treatment in the prison hospital, which he refused.

title: CASE OF SZÉL AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were members of the Hungarian Parliament and the opposition party LMP.
- On 21 June 2013, Parliament held a final vote on a new controversial law.
- Ms Lengyel placed a small, golden wheelbarrow filled with soil on the table in front of the Prime Minister during the final vote.
- Ms Szél and Ms Osztolykán stretched a banner in front of the Speaker’s pulpit containing the inscription “Land distribution instead of land robbery!” during the final vote.
- The Speaker proposed a fine for the three applicants, which was later approved without debate by the plenary on 26 June 2013.
- A constitutional complaint was filed and rejected by the Constitutional Court on 4 November 2013.
- The Constitutional Court held that parliamentary disciplinary law concerned Parliament's interior business and MPs' conduct as parliamentarians rather than citizens' rights or obligations.

title: CASE OF KARÁCSONY AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were members of the Hungarian Parliament and the opposition party Párbeszéd Magyarországért.
- During a plenary session on 30 April 2013, Mr Karácsony and Mr Szilágyi showed a billboard in the session hall displaying the text “FIDESZ [the party on government]. You steal, you cheat, and you lie.”
- On the same day, Mr Szilágyi made a speech in the general debate on Bill no. T/10881 amending Certain Smoking-related Acts, accusing the government parties of corruption.
- The Speaker presented a proposal to fine Mr Karácsony 50,000 Hungarian forints (HUF) and Mr Szilágyi HUF 185,520 (approximately EUR 600) for having gravely disrupted the plenary proceedings, in application of section 49(4) of Act no. XXXVI of 2012 on Parliament.
- On 21 May 2013, during the final vote on Bill no. T/10881, Mr Dorosz and Ms Szabó presented a billboard with the text “Here Operates the National Tobacco Mafia.”
- The Speaker submitted a proposal to fine them HUF 70,000 (EUR 240) each, for gravely disrupting the plenary proceedings, in application of section 49(4) of Act no. XXXVI of 2012 on Parliament.
- A constitutional complaint was filed by MP E.N., a member of the opposition party Jobbik, and rejected by the Constitutional Court on 4 November 2013.

title: CASE OF VALERIAN DRAGOMIR v. ROMANIA
facts:
1. Large-scale criminal investigation initiated against 94 police and customs officers for corruption-related offences.
2. Criminal group formed at border checkpoints for acts of corruption and smuggling cigarettes from Serbia.
3. Applicant was a customs officer at the Moravița border checkpoint at that time and was considered to be part of the criminal group by the investigation authority.
4. Applicant and other officers received orders to appear before the NAP on suspicion of being part of a criminal group and bribery.
5. Search carried out at the applicant’s home and residences of other officers under suspicion.
6. Applicant and 93 other police and customs officers taken by bus to NAP headquarters in Bucharest.
7. Applicant kept in a room under permanent guard at NAP headquarters, not allowed to have contact with his lawyer or purchase food.
8. Prosecutors informed each suspected officer of the charges against them and invited them to give a statement in the presence of a lawyer of their own choosing.
9. Applicant refused to give a statement as he was deprived of sleep for over 30 hours.
10. Applicant remanded in custody for 24 hours and request to place him in pre-trial detention lodged with the competent court.
11. Court granted the request for pre-trial detention for 29 days, citing the reasonable suspicion of committing alleged crimes and their gravity and nature.
12. Applicant lodged an appeal against his pre-trial detention, which was dismissed by the High Court of Cassation and Justice.
13. Pre-trial detention extended twice by the Bucharest Court of Appeal and upheld by the High Court of Cassation and Justice.
14. Applicant released from detention after three months.
15. Proceedings on the merits are still pending.
16. Applicant claimed improper conditions of hygiene and being placed in a cell measuring 16 square metres.
17. Government claimed the applicant was detained in a cell measuring 14.57 square metres with seven other detainees, with separate sanitary facilities in the cell.

title: CASE OF SZKÓRITS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1929 and lived in Budakalász.
- He had joint title to a plot of land that was possessed by a Socialist ‘collective farm’.
- A plan for the division of such properties was adopted following the adoption of Act no. II of 1993 on Land Settlement and Land Distribution Committees.
- The applicant was granted ownership of a plot of land by the Regional Office of Agriculture, but he couldn't enter into possession of it.
- The applicant brought a trespass claim before the District Notary, but it was dismissed.
- The respondents initiated the correction of the land register maps, and it was found that the plot granted to the applicant did not exist in reality.
- The applicant's civil action was stayed for the duration of the remapping proceedings.
- The remapping proceedings confirmed that the applicant had originally been granted a plot that had been registered with topographic and editing errors.
- The applicant finally obtained possession of the land in question in 2009, ten years after acquiring it.
- The applicant lodged an official liability action against the District and the County Land Registries, which was dismissed by the Buda Surroundings High Court in 2012.
- The appellate proceedings were suspended due to the applicant's death in 2012, with a view to the successor's joining the case.

title: CASE OF ATUDOREI v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant, a Romanian national, suffered physical and psychological abuse from her family from an early age.
- Her parents were aggressive towards her and took her to a psychologist for not achieving high grades in school.
- Her parents continued to abuse her after discovering she attended weekly yoga classes organized by a group called the Movement for Spiritual Integration into the Absolute (MISA).
- The authorities in Romania allegedly condoned public intolerance of MISA and police reportedly abused individuals who practiced yoga and were members of MISA.
- In March 2004, a negative press campaign and police operation targeted MISA, and its leader faced criminal charges for alleged sexual corruption of minors.
- The applicant was hospitalized against her will on 30 July 2003, diagnosed with reactive depression and anxiety after conflicts with her parents, and given psychotherapy and medical treatment.
- Her parents took her to a different psychiatric hospital on 3 February 2005, where she was diagnosed with an "evolving borderline disorder" and given psychotropic drug treatment before being discharged on 1 April 2005.
- The applicant brought criminal proceedings against her parents for unlawful deprivation of liberty and challenged decisions not to initiate criminal proceedings against them, but these were dismissed.
- She managed to leave her grandparents' house on 10 October 2005 and married her fiancé on 5 November 2005.
- The applicant brought disciplinary proceedings against a psychiatrist involved in her forced hospitalization and treatment, but this was also dismissed.

title: CASE OF MOCANU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
• Mr Anca Mocanu and Mr Marin Stoica reside in Bucharest, Romania.
• The Association “21 December 1989” was formed on 9 February 1990 and based in Bucharest.
• The association supports the individuals injured during the violent annihilation of the anti-totalitarian protests in Romania in December 1989 and the families of those who lost their lives during those events.
• The crackdown on anti-government protests took place from 13 to 15 June 1990 in Bucharest. 
• The crackdown led to civilian casualties, including the death of Mrs Mocanu’s husband, Mr Mocanu, who was killed by a shot fired from the headquarters of the Ministry of the Interior. 
• On 16th September 1998 and 17th June 2009, the prosecutor’s office of the Supreme Court of Justice issued decisions that comprised the main facts concerning the crackdown on anti-government protests. 
• Thousands of miners transported to Bucharest to stop the anti-government protests. 
• The President of Romania invited miners to University Square to fight against the demonstrators. 
• The violent events of 13 and 14 June 1990 resulted in more than a thousand victims. 
• Political party headquarters, along with the headquarters of the applicant association, were attacked and ransacked. 
• The criminal proceedings into the unlawful killing by gunfire of Mr Velicu-Valentin Mocanu are still pending. 
• University Square considered a symbolic location for the fight against the totalitarian regime of Nicolae Ceauşescu. 
• From 25 February 1990, demonstrations were held every Sunday to denounce the non-democratic attitude of those in power.
• Unauthorised “marathon demonstrations” began on 22 April 1990 in University Square which lasted fifty-two days. 
• On 13th June 1990, the police arrested and brutalised demonstrators in University Square. 
• Workers from the factories of a large metallurgical company in Bucharest moved towards University Square to help the police in their clearance operation. 
• After the police operation, the army intervened, and several armoured vehicles were sent to the headquarters of the Ministry of the Interior. 
• On the same evening, three persons were shot dead in the Ministry of the Interior. 
• The applicant was brutally arrested by a group of armed individuals and taken by force into the television building, where he was beaten and threatened with firearms.

title: CASE OF IVINOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant has cerebral palsy and uses a wheelchair.
- In 1968, the applicant was deprived of her legal capacity due to her physical illness and intellectual underdevelopment.
- Her legal capacity was fully restored by a ruling of the Zagreb Municipal Court on 10 July 1979.
- In 2009, the Pešćenica Social Welfare Centre requested a partial deprivation of the applicant's legal capacity to prevent her from disposing of her assets.
- The Centre claimed that the applicant's condition had worsened after undergoing an operation on her head on 9 September 2008.
- Evidence was presented, including unpaid bills, to support the Centre's request.
- The Centre appointed Ms J.T. as the applicant's legal guardian in the proceedings before the Zagreb Municipal Court.
- The Municipal Court heard the applicant and established that she acted autonomously and had meaningful responses.
- A psychiatric report commissioned for the proceedings concluded that the applicant lacked sufficient intellectual capacity to adequately protect her own rights and interests and that of others.
- The Municipal Court partially deprived the applicant of her legal capacity.
- The applicant lodged an appeal, which was dismissed by the Bjelovar County Court.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint, which was also dismissed by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF BLJAKAJ AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- Five individuals are involved in the case, with ages and residential information provided.
- The first applicant is the husband, the second and third applicants are children, and the fourth and fifth applicants are sisters of the late M.B.B.
- M.B.B. represented M.N. in divorce proceedings against A.N.
- A.N. had a history of alcohol abuse, violent behaviour and unlawful possession of firearms.
- A.N. had been convicted of a minor offence of family violence, as well as making serious death threats to his wife in separate cases.
- A police report on 21 March 2002 documented harassment allegations made by M.N. against her husband, with warnings given to cease the harassment.
- On 22 March 2002, the police were informed of A.N.'s suicidal tendencies and were asked to seek help from the Slatina Health Centre and the Slatina Social Care Centre.
- On the same day, A.N. kicked and shot his wife in public, while also killing M.B.B.
- During the investigation, numerous people were interviewed about A.N.'s behaviour and intentions, including his children, M.B.B.'s secretary, and other witnesses.
- A.N.'s brother-in-law reported A.N.'s anger towards M.B.B., but never mentioned any intention of murder.
- A call to the hospital regarding A.N.'s suicidal tendencies was received at around 9:40 a.m. on the day of the shooting.

title: CASE OF PETIMAT ISMAILOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are Russian nationals and close relatives of people who disappeared after allegedly being arrested by servicemen in the Chechen Republic.
- The alleged abductions were carried out during curfew hours, at night, or early in the morning, in areas under the full control of Russian federal forces.
- Official investigations were opened but have been pending for several years without achieving any tangible results.
- State authorities were unable to identify the State servicemen allegedly involved in the arrests or abductions.
- The applicants complained to law-enforcement bodies.
- The document provides summaries of the facts relevant to each individual complaint based on statements provided by the applicants, their relatives, and/or neighbors to the Court and to the domestic investigative authorities.

title: CASE OF MAKAYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is from Grozny, Chechnya and her son, Mr Apti Zaynalov, was born in 1980.
- In October 2005, Mr Apti Zaynalov was convicted of belonging to an illegal armed group.
- On 25 June 2009, the applicant returned to Grozny from Saratov and was informed by her son that he was going to study in Egypt and had to go to Moscow to finalise certain formalities.
- On 26 June 2009, the applicant received a message from her son on her mobile phone saying that he would be flying to Egypt the next day.
- The applicant alleged that her son had been abducted in June 2009 by unknown servicemen and had disappeared in July 2009.
- On 3 July 2009, Memorial staff member Mr G. had gone to Achkhoy-Martan Hospital together with Mr Apti Sh.’s uncle, Mr I. Sh. They had found a patient under guard in the hospital’s surgical department who was about thirty years old, had bruises on his face, his head was bandaged, and he was covered by a sheet displaying red stains.
- On 19 July 2009, the applicant claims to have recognised her son being led out of Achkhoy-Martan Hospital by armed men, put into a car, and driven away.

title: CASE OF RAKHIMBERDIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant hired as a guard for a shipment of onions from Tajikistan to Siberia in 2005.
- Russian customs officials found more than 73kg of heroin hidden in rubber containers concealed within the shipment.
- Applicant was taken to an organized crime department in Rubtsovsk police station under police guard and stayed the night on a mattress in the corridor.
- Criminal case was instituted on 2 August 2005; applicant searched, and a small package of heroin was found in his bag.
- Applicant was formally remanded in custody following the record of his arrest, charged with drug smuggling.
- During the hearing, applicant’s counsel questioned police officers and raised the issue of his unrecorded detention from 1-2 August 2005.
- Rubtsovsk Town Court found the applicant guilty of drug smuggling and sentenced him to ten years in prison in a high-security facility.
- Altay Regional Court acquitted him of the smuggling charge but upheld his conviction on the possession charge, that was commuted to three years in prison.
- Counsel complained to the Rubtsovsk town prosecutor about the applicant’s unrecorded detention, and an internal inquiry was carried out that found the allegation of unlawful detention unsubstantiated.
- An investigator refused to open a criminal investigation into the applicant’s complaint of unlawful detention, but a Town Court held it was not lawful or justified. Another inquiry was ordered, which also found that the applicant had not been detained against his will. The investigator’s decision was upheld by both the Town Court and Altay Regional Court.

title: CASE OF AVANESYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Stavropol Region.
- On 22 March 2006, a judge authorized the taking of “operational-search measures” on the basis of a police chief's application, without the applicant's knowledge.
- Two officers came to the applicant’s house on the same day but he was away, the police showed the authorization to the applicant’s father, he had a heart attack and died before the ambulance arrived.
- No items were found in the “inspection” of the applicant's home, according to the “inspection record”.
- The applicant complained to the Georgievsk district prosecutor’s office on 29 March 2006, but the investigator refused to investigate the case.
- The supervisory-review application against the judicial authorization was unsuccessful.
- The applicant also complained to the Constitutional Court, which rejected his complaint on September 18, 2007.

title: CASE OF S.B. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant underwent dental work for bridges and crowns on 20 teeth which was supposed to be completed by Dr. A.D.
- The bridgework did not fit well, causing pain and bleeding gums when she tried to eat or close her mouth.
- The dentist repeatedly dismissed her complaints and claimed that the work was perfect.
- The applicant's state of health worsened, and she was unable to afford further dental treatment.
- The dentist issued a certificate of guarantee for the work in January 2002, but did not make any changes to the bridges.
- In July 2002, the applicant asked for a medical expert examination and submitted a complaint to the Ministry of Health.
- She went through several examinations conducted by different dentists and institutions.
- The medical expert report revealed that the bridges were not fitted correctly and caused complications that could be considered permanent physical disabilities.
- The investigation against Dr. A.D. was initially terminated in 2005 but was later reopened and remitted to the court.
- The defendant was acquitted based on the expert report of 2003, and the charges were not reclassified.

title: CASE OF CEVAT SOYSAL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in Germany in 1962.
- On July 7, 1999, the Ankara Magistrates’ Court ordered the applicant’s in absentia arrest, suspecting him of being a member of the illegal organisation PKK.
- The applicant was captured on July 13, 1999 in Moldova and taken to Turkey where he was interrogated until July 21, 1999.
- In July 1999, the applicant was publicly accused of being a terrorist and the "second man of the PKK."
- On July 23, 1999, the applicant was remanded in custody by a judge at the Ankara State Security Court.
- A bill of indictment was filed against the applicant on August 9, 1999, accusing him of being a leading member of the PKK.
- The applicant was accused of issuing instructions for hundreds of bombings and engaging in other violent activities.
- The first hearing on the merits of the case was held on September 16, 1999.
- The applicant's lawyer requested the removal of transcripts of alleged telephone conversations from the case file during the second hearing on October 14, 1999.
- The first-instance court repeatedly requested copies of statements from witnesses until May 2001.
- The applicant's lawyer requested a comparative voice analysis, which was granted, during the hearing held on December 21, 2000.
- TRT, the national public broadcaster, failed to find appropriate experts to conduct the voice analysis in April 2001.
- The request for a comparative voice analysis was withdrawn by the applicant's lawyer on July 23, 2001.
- The public prosecutor submitted observations on the merits of the case on December 12, 2000.

title: CASE OF O.G. v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Riga.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant on 3 March 2004 for Internet fraud.
- The applicant underwent two inpatient psychiatric examinations during the pre-trial investigation and was found to have full mental capacity on both occasions.
- On 3 October 2006, the Riga City Vidzeme District Court found the applicant guilty and gave him a suspended six-month prison sentence.
- On 13 March 2007, the Riga Regional Court decided to request an outpatient psychiatric assessment due to the applicant's aggressive behavior and illogical statements during the appeal hearing.
- On 27 April 2007, a psychiatrist found that the applicant was suffering from chronic paranoid schizophrenia and recommended outpatient treatment.
- On 18 June 2007, the Riga Regional Court decided to initiate proceedings to apply a compulsory measure of a medical nature and conducted the case in the applicant's absence with his mother as his legal representative.
- On 20 August 2008, the Riga Regional Court ordered the applicant's involuntary inpatient treatment in a psychiatric hospital as he was considered a danger to society.
- On 22 October 2009, police officers took the applicant to a psychiatric hospital and he was informed by doctors that he had been brought in on the basis of a decision of the Riga Regional Court.
- On 28 December 2009, the Riga Regional Court decided to continue the applicant's involuntary inpatient treatment.
- The applicant was released from the hospital on 7 June 2010 on the basis of a decision of the Riga Regional Court ordering his treatment as an outpatient.

title: CASE OF ATİMAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Van.
- Gendarme officers from the Hakkari Mountain Commando Brigade blocked the road near the village of Armutdüzü in the Yüksekova district.
- A lorry, in which the applicant was travelling, was stopped on suspicion of fuel smuggling.
- According to the report drafted by the gendarme officers, the driver attempted to escape and the gendarme officers fired a warning shot in the air and then fired at the tyres of the lorry to stop it. According to the applicant, they were driving down a steep hill at high speed, and as the brakes had failed, they could not stop.
- The applicant was wounded in the hip and his cousin in the leg during the incident as a result of ricochet bullets.
- The search of the two lorries resulted in finding smuggled fuel.
- The decision not to prosecute was based on the conclusion that the use of force had been legal pursuant to Article 11 of Law no. 2803 on the establishment, duties and jurisdiction of the gendarmerie and section 39 (i) of the Regulation on the Duties and Powers of the Gendarmerie.

title: CASE OF VAJNAI v. HUNGARY NO.4
facts:
- The applicant is a left-wing politician living in Budapest, born in 1963.
- On 18 May 2009, the applicant participated in a peaceful demonstration wearing a five-pointed red star on his jacket.
- A police patrol present at the demonstration asked the applicant to remove the star, which was confiscated.
- The applicant's complaint to the Head of National Police was not successful.
- The applicant challenged the measure in court.
- The Budapest Regional Court dismissed his action on 29 June 2010, citing a contravention of section 269/B of the Criminal Code.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Regional Court's decision on 8 June 2011, stating that the police measure had been lawful, despite a previous judgment by the European Court of Human Rights in the case of Vajnai v. Hungary.
- The applicant paid legal costs totaling 1,115 euros.

title: CASE OF NOÉ, VAJNAI AND BAKO v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1970, 1963 and 1989 and live in Paks and Budapest respectively.
- Mr Vajnai was Vice-President and Ms Noé and Mr Bakó were activists of the Workers’ Party (Munkáspárt).
- On 21 December 2008, the applicants organized an event to demonstrate against consumerism, draw attention to poverty, point out the shortcomings of market economy, and demand free internet access for all.
- To express their affiliation with Communism, four persons displayed a sheet and a flag with a five-pointed red star and distributed leaflets with their political message, depicting red stars.
- A police patrol called on the applicants to terminate the demonstration and committed them to Budapest VI District Police Department for interrogation.
- The Independent Police Complaints Board dismissed the applicants’ complaints against the police measures on 4 March 2009.
- The applicants’ further complaints against the measures were dismissed by the District Police Department on 22 May 2009.
- The display of the red star contravened section 269/B of the Criminal Code, despite a previous judgment, and the applicants' identity check and committal to the police department was justified.
- The Supreme Court upheld the decision of the lower courts.
- The applicants incurred legal costs of 2,760 euros.

title: CASE OF HORVÁTH AND VAJNAI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1942 and 1963 and live in Budapest.
- Mr Vajnai was Vice-President and Mr Horváth was a member and activist of the Workers’ Party.
- The party had no known intention of participating in Hungarian political life in defiance of the rule of law.
- Mr Vajnai placed a five-pointed red star and a sickle-and-hammer logo on the Party’s web page.
- The applicants participated in a peaceful demonstration commemorating the 1945 Soviet liberation of Hungary from Nazi occupation. 
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against them for the offence of having worn totalitarian symbols in public.
- Mr Vajnai appeared in court wearing a five-pointed red star on several occasions, including in the context of previous criminal proceedings against him.
- The applicants were convicted and sentenced, and Mr Vajnai was ordered to pay a criminal fine and costs.
- The judgment was upheld on appeal.
- The European Court of Human Rights held that prosecution for having worn a red star amounted to a violation of the applicant’s freedom of expression.
- The applicants challenged the judgment before the Supreme Court, but their petition was dismissed.

title: CASE OF Á.A. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant lives in Budapest.
- On 1 July 2002, the applicant concluded an employment contract with a State-owned specialised financial institution.
- On 27 July 2003, the Hungarian Government adopted Government Decree no. 2173/2003. (VII. 29.) on the remuneration of senior professionals within business entities under majority State control.
- The applicant’s employment contract was amended as per the Decree.
- On 30 June 2010, the applicant’s employment was terminated by mutual agreement.
- Under this agreement, the applicant’s former employer paid the applicant, after taxes, a net amount of 13,879,643 Hungarian forints (HUF).
- Under new legislation, the gross amount corresponding to the above payment was subsequently taxed at a 98% rate in its part exceeding HUF 3.5 million.
- The income tax and social security contributions already paid were deducted from the tax payable.
- The applicant had to pay an additional HUF 11,296,051 as special tax until 20 May 2011.

title: CASE OF P.G. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant concluded an employment contract with a State-owned financial institution in 2006.
- The applicant's contract was amended in 2009 to provide severance payment in case of ordinary dismissal.
- The applicant's employment was terminated by mutual agreement on 22 June 2010.
- The applicant was paid a net amount of 17,994,127 Hungarian forints (HUF) (approximately 58,800 euros (EUR)), which amounted to seven months' salary.
- The gross amount corresponding to the payment was taxed at a 98% rate in its part exceeding HUF 3.5 million under new legislation.
- The applicant had to pay an additional HUF 14,162,433 as special tax until 20 May 2011.

title: CASE OF KARIN ANDERSSON AND OTHERS v. SWEDEN
facts:
- The applicants own property close to Umeå, in the vicinity of a Natura 2000 area, and most of them live there permanently or on a part-time basis.
- The National Rail Administration applied to construct a 10km long railway section in a river area in the north of Sweden, which concerned certain areas that were or were going to be part of Natura 2000.
- Some of the applicants, including Ms Carina Granberg, Ms Agneta Holmström, Mr Gustaf Härestål, Mr Björn Höjer, Ms Inga-Britt Höjer, and Mr Christer Skoog, own properties within the recommended "corridor."
- The Government granted permission for the railway construction in the proposed "corridor" with conditions, including the adoption of railway plans and environmental compensation measures.
- Individual property owners, including some of the applicants, petitioned for a judicial review of the case, claiming that the decision violated Swedish regulations on nature conservation, contravened Swedish law, and applicable European Union law, including the Habitats Directive.
- The Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the petitioners' locus standi, but one judge dissented.
- The NRA applied for permits to construct the railway in the specific Natura 2000 area and to Environmental Court to construct two bridges.
- The Environmental Court granted all permits to NRA while being bound by the Government's decision on the permissibility of the railway project.
- The Environmental Court of Appeal quashed the Environmental Court's judgement and referred the cases back to it.
- The Government affirmed the permissibility of the railway plan for the specific stretch chosen within the permitted corridor, and the Supreme Administrative Court rejected the petition, finding the Government's decision binding.

title: CASE OF PREZHDAROVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
Here are the main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicants are spouses, born in 1968 and 1965 respectively, and reside in Pazardzhik.
- The first applicant took a bank loan to set up a computer club in a garage owned by the applicants, and the second applicant helped in running the club.
- The clients of the computer club pay one Bulgarian lev (BGN) per hour to use the computers rented by the first applicant.
- The first applicant failed to renew his contracts with the distributors and on 3 April 2004, the police conducted a check and warned the first applicant not to distribute software illegally.
- On 9 November 2004, the local sanitation department ordered the computer club be closed down.
- In January 2005, a manager of a company that distributed computer games filed a complaint with the district prosecutor stating that the applicants were illegally reproducing and distributing certain types of games to their clients.
- The district prosecutor ordered the police to conduct an inquiry into the computer club and secure the evidence, including search and seizure of the computers, in case software was used illegally.
- On 21 February 2005, the police conducted the search-and-seizure operation and seized the applicants' computers after finding that a number of computer games had been installed on them, and the first applicant failed to present documents to prove his title to the games.
- The search-and-seizure operation was approved by a District Court judge on 20 February 2005, and the first applicant's application not to approve the search-and-seizure record was returned as inadmissible.
- The applicants requested the return of the computers, which were necessary for their other professional activities, but the district prosecutor refused to return them, and the court upheld the prosecutor's order.
- In November 2005, the first applicant was charged with the unlawful distribution of computer programs, computer games, and films, and in December 2008, he was convicted, sentenced to imprisonment suspended for three years and fined BGN 4,000, and the computers were confiscated.

title: CASE OF ANZHELO GEORGIEV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants worked for a private company, one of the main internet service providers in the city of Varna.
- The Varna District Public Prosecutor initiated criminal proceedings against someone suspected of disseminating materials in violation of intellectual property laws through the company's servers between January and May 2008.
- A police operation was carried out in two of the company's offices to search and seize illegal software pursuant to the prosecutor's order.
- The parties disagree on whether excessive force was used by some of the officers during the operation.
- The applicants complained of being ill-treated during the operation and submitted medical certificates as evidence of their injuries.
- Employees of the company who were present during the operation provided additional statements about their experience, accusing the police of using physical force and intimidation tactics. 
- Statements were taken from police officers and staff members of the company during a preliminary inquiry into the complaints, but no other investigative steps were taken.

title: CASE OF BULGARU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained in Cricova prison and was serving a ten-year sentence at the time of the events.
- In August 2008 a murder was committed in the same detention facility where the applicant was detained, and he was one of the suspects.
- The applicant was taken to the Chişinău Central police station for questioning in December 2008 and was ill-treated after refusing to confess to the murder.
- From 21 January to 23 January 2009, the applicant was subjected to a range of violent acts, including being beaten, suspended on a metal bar, and tied up with his arms and feet together behind his back, resulting in injuries such as kidney pain and blood in his urine.
- The applicant attempted suicide by cutting the veins in his wrist on 21 January 2009, and he was taken to the hospital for medical treatment where he was given stitches and a bandage. After returning from the hospital, the ill-treatment continued and intensified.
- On 30 January 2009, the applicant was transferred back to Cricova prison as a result of his lawyer's involvement.
- On 12 February 2009, the applicant's state of health deteriorated, and he was hospitalised in a prison hospital, where he was diagnosed with severe radial neuropathy of the right arm.
- The applicant's lawyer filed a complaint with the prosecutor's office about the ill-treatment, but it was dismissed as ill-founded on 31 July 2009.

title: CASE OF HANSEN v. NORWAY
facts:
- Applicant lives in Nesoddtangen, Norway.
- In 1989, the Applicant’s wife bought a property named Ekheim from him for 6,400,000 Norwegian kroner (NOK).
- On 3 November 1995, Mrs B. and the applicant concluded an agreement with a joint ownership of 50% each for the Ekheim estate.
- The City Court found against the applicant and in favour of the respondent, concluding that the marital agreements were valid and that the joint ownership agreement was invalid. The applicant did not appeal against this judgment.
- In 2005, Mrs B. sold the Ekheim estate to Ekheim Invest AS, a limited liability company, for NOK 15,000,000.
- On 28 June 2007, the applicant claimed that he had title to 50% of the Ekheim estate and sought an order for the latter to convey 50% of the property to him.
- The applicant appealed against the City Court’s judgment of 21 January 2008 to the Borgarting High Court and was warned that his appeal will not succeed.
- The High Court refused the admission of the applicant’s appeal on 12 June 2008, as it found it clear that the appeal would not succeed.
- The applicant then appealed against the High Court’s decision to the Supreme Court, arguing notably that the refusal of admission of the appeal lacked reasons.

title: CASE OF MISAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lived in Vladivostok. She died on April 16th, 2007.
- The military prosecutor's office had opened criminal proceedings against the applicant's father, a naval officer, on suspicion of document forgery.
- On March 14th, 2003, the acting prosecutor issued a warrant to search the applicant's flat to find documents and objects exposing her father's involvement in criminal activity. The police came to the applicant's flat and broke down the door. They searched the flat, seized documents, and ended the search around 11 p.m.
- On March 18th, 2003, the applicant lodged a complaint before the Frunzenskiy District Court of Vladivostok, claiming that the search had been unlawful.
- On April 21st, 2003, the Military Court of the Vladivostok Garrison examined the applicant's complaint and found that the search was carried out in accordance with the law. The court rejected the applicant's complaint.
- The applicant appealed, but the Military Court of the Pacific Fleet upheld the judgment on July 7th, 2003. The court noted that there was no evidence of any breaches of procedure and that the search of the applicant's flat was justified.

title: CASE OF CHURCH OF SCIENTOLOGY OF ST PETERSBURG AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants consist of a group of Russian citizens studying Scientology and six individual members.
- The second applicant applied for registration of the “Church of the Scientology Mission in St Petersburg” in 1995, but it was left unconsidered.
- The applicants submitted a new application for registration in 2002, however, it was refused by the Justice Department citing technical grounds relating to the application documentation and the need to conduct a State expert religious study.
- The Justice Department issued a formal refusal of the resubmitted application in September 2002 citing eight different technical grounds and claiming that the confirmation of the applicant group’s existence in St Petersburg for at least fifteen years was “unreliable”.
- The applicants resubmitted a corrected application in October 2002, which was refused due to the eight new technical grounds and the claim that an unspecified expert religious study had concluded that the applicant group was non-religious in nature.
- The Justice Department declined to provide clarification when asked about the basis for its claim regarding the “unreliability” of the group’s existence and to provide a copy of the religious study.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of St Petersburg gave judgment in December 2005, holding that the refusal had been lawful as the applicants had not supplied sufficient evidence to prove that there was only one religious group of Scientologists in St Petersburg that included them and the letter confirming the existence of the group was not issued by a competent authority.
- The St Petersburg City Court rejected the applicants' appeal in May 2006, endorsing the first-instance court’s findings.

title: CASE OF VENIAMIN TYMOSHENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicants were employed as aircraft cabin crew by AeroSvit Airlines.
- Applicants were members of the company's trade union.
- National Mediation and Reconciliation Service registered a collective labour dispute between employees and management regarding various demands.
- Some demands were resolved, while the others were legitimate according to the NMRS Labour Arbitration Court.
- AeroSvit cabin crew decided to embark on industrial action due to non-compliance with demands by the employer.
- General meeting of AeroSvit employees announced a strike of 150 aircraft cabin crew members to resolve the labour dispute.
- Strike committee was appointed by the meeting.
- Management of AeroSvit lodged a claim against the trade union to declare the strike unlawful.
- Boryspil City Court issued an injunction prohibiting the strike committee from holding the strike.
- On 6 October 2011, the Boryspil Court found the strike to be unlawful and banned it.
- Trade union challenged the Boryspil Court's injunction before the Kyiv Regional Court of Appeal, but the judgment was upheld.
- The right to strike and the procedure for its exercise are laid out in Section 18 and other sections of the Resolution of Labour Disputes Act.
- Strikes at transport enterprises may take place only in certain circumstances, according to Section 18 of the Transport Act.
- The lack of regulation of transport employees' right to strike has been identified as a concern by the Ukrainian Parliament Commissioner for Human Rights.

title: CASE OF KOKSHAROVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Russian national born in 1930.
- On 19 February 2001, the applicant filed a court action for compensation of health damage against the Social Security Fund of the Russian Federation.
- On 4 April 2001, her claim was dismissed by the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Arkhangelsk, but the decision was later quashed on appeal and remitted for a fresh examination.
- On 3 June 2002, the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Arkhangelsk granted the applicant's claim and ordered the Social Security Fund to calculate and pay compensation and index-link future payments.
- Although the judgment was not appealed and became final, no lump-sum compensation was paid to the applicant.
- On 18 December 2002, the President of the Arkhangelsk Regional Court lodged an application for supervisory review of the case and suspended the execution of the judgment.
- On 25 December 2002, the Presidium quashed the judgment of 3 June 2002, stating that the first instance court had incorrectly applied the domestic law.
- The case was remitted for a fresh examination to the first instance court, which dismissed the applicant's claim on 25 June 2003.
- On 28 July 2003, the Arkhangelsk Regional Court upheld the judgment.

title: CASE OF SMERTIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lived in Balezino in the Republic of Udmurtiya prior to his arrest.
- On 29 December 2005, the applicant was arrested on drug-related charges and taken to the local anti-narcotics unit. They were beaten by policemen and then questioned in the absence of a lawyer according to the applicant's claim.
- On 8 November 2006, the Balezinskiy District Court of the Republic of Udmurtiya found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to two years and ten months’ imprisonment. He did not appeal against the judgment.
- During several periods between 29 December 2005 and 9 November 2006, the applicant was held in IVS Balezino, a temporary detention facility located in the Udmurtiya Republic. He submitted that the facility had been overcrowded and lacked basic facilities.
- The applicant lodged a number of complaints seeking to bring the detention conditions to the attention of domestic authorities. The actions were acknowledged by the prosecutor and the regional Ministry of Interior.
- The applicant brought a civil claim for compensation in connection with the inadequate conditions of detention and was awarded 3,000 Russian roubles by the Supreme Court of Udmurtiya.
- On 27 February 2007, the applicant lodged the first letter with the Court, containing a detailed description of the conditions of his detention in the IVS Balezino.
- The applicant sent the completed application form, and any necessary supplementary documents on 30 October 2007, which reached the Registry on 12 November 2007.
- The Rules of Court were amended on 11 December 2007, 22 September, and 1 December 2008, with the introduction of newer time limits.

title: CASE OF VOLYANYK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant worked as a deputy chief guard in a State-owned company called "Lviv Railways"
- The applicant was suspected of covering up thefts from the company's premises in conspiracy with S. and D. against bribes.
- On 3 November 2009, the Galytskyy District Court of Lviv ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention.
- The court stated that the applicant committed serious crimes, did not admit guilt, and might influence or obstruct witnesses and the investigation if at liberty.
- The Lviv Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision on 9 November 2009.
- The applicant's detention was extended until 26 February 2010, stating not all accomplices were detained, and the investigative authorities kept receiving complaints.
- The detention was prolonged until 26 April 2010, stating the accused committed serious crimes and refused to testify.
- The court found that the applicant might influence witnesses, obstruct the investigation, or abscond.
- The applicant's detention was prolonged until 26 July 2010 to carry out a number of investigative measures in the case.
- The Sykhiv District Court of Lviv held a preliminary hearing on 17 August 2010 in the applicant's criminal case and upheld the applicant's preventive measure without providing a reason or setting a time limit.
- On 16 February 2012, the Sykhiv Court released the applicant against an undertaking not to abscond, allowing the applicant's request for a change of preventive measure on health grounds.

title: CASE OF PINA E MOURA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Batalha (Portugal).
- On 15 March 2006, the applicant requested the recognition of an easement through Court of Porto de Mós.
- The applicant rectified the initial application on 24 May 2006 and 27 June 2007 upon request of the Court of Porto de Mós.
- The defendants informed the Court of Porto de Mós that one of the defendants had died on 28 April to 2 May 2006.
- On 9 January 2008, the Court stayed the proceedings, pending the outcome of the inheritance proceedings in relation to the deceased defendant.
- The applicant applied to the Court for leave to continue the proceedings against the widow of the deceased defendant on 28 January 2008 (incidente de habilitação de herdeiros).
- On 30 July 2008, the applicant requested that the proceedings continue against M. as an heir of the deceased.
- The applicant’s lawyer resigned on 18 November 2008, and a new lawyer was appointed on 10 March 2009.
- On 20 March 2010, the Court of Porto de Mós requested the applicant to provide information about the relationship between M. and the deceased defendant.
- On 15 July 2010, the Court of Porto de Mós decided that the deceased defendant’s widow and M. should replace him in the proceedings concerning the proceedings of inheritance.
- The Court of Porto de Mós resumed the main proceedings on 8 November 2011, taking into account its decision of 15 July 2010.
- The applicant’s representative resigned on 23 October 2012, and a new representative was appointed on 19 December 2012.
- On 7 February 2013, the judge gave directions (despacho saneador) setting out the matters that had already been established and those that remained outstanding, and the case was set down for hearing on 7 June 2013 with two more hearings scheduled for 12 July and 13 September 2013.
- On 29 November 2013, the court of first instance partially found in favor of the applicant.
- On 28 January 2014, the applicant appealed against the decision to the Coimbra Court of Appeal (Tribunal da Relação).
- The proceedings are still pending at second instance.

title: CASE OF JEUNESSE v. THE NETHERLANDS
facts:
- Applicant met and started a relationship with Mr W. in March 1987.
- Applicant and Mr W. cohabited in Suriname in September 1989.
- Mr W. travelled to the Netherlands in 1991 and was granted Netherlands nationality in 1993.
- The applicant filed unsuccessful requests for a Netherlands visa for visiting a relative between 1991 and 1995.
- The applicant filed a sixth visa request in 1996 and entered the Netherlands in 1997, not returning to Suriname.
- The applicant filed for a residence permit in 1997 but failed to appear in person, leading to a decision to leave the Netherlands.
- The applicant filed an objection and applied for a provisional measure but was rejected in 2001.
- The applicant married Mr W. in 1999, and two children were born, both holding Netherlands nationality.
- The applicant made unsuccessful requests for a residence permit on the basis of the three-year policy and for special and individual circumstances.
- The applicant’s appeal against the decision was rejected in 2009.
- The applicant’s husband was found guilty of offences under the Opium Act and sentenced to seven months’ imprisonment in 2009.
- The applicant’s appeal to the Administrative Jurisdiction Division of the Council of State against the judgment of the provisional-measures judge was dismissed in 2010.
- The applicant filed a fifth request for a residence permit in 2010 with the Minister of Justice.

title: CASE OF ĎURĎOVIČ AND TRANČÍKOVÁ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicants are husband and wife, Mr D. Ďurďovič and Ms M. Trančíková.
- They alleged that they were the owners of real property which had been included in the assets of an insolvent company.
- The claim was dismissed by the Stará Ľubovňa District Court on 16 August 2006.
- The Prešov Regional Court upheld the first-instance court’s judgment on 24 April 2008.
- The applicants lodged an appeal on points of law on 9 July 2008.
- On 30 November 2009, the Supreme Court rejected the appeal on points of law.
- The applicants complained of a breach of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention regarding the proceedings leading to the District Court’s judgment of 16 August 2006, the Regional Court’s judgment of 24 April 2008, and the Supreme Court’s decision of 30 November 2009.
- The Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible on 23 September 2010.

title: CASE OF BEGHELURI AND OTHERS v. GEORGIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- Applicants are Jehovah's Witnesses who suffered alleged violence and assault on thirty occasions.
- 160 complaints were lodged with investigation authorities, yielding no concrete results.
- Several acts of religiously motivated violence were carried out with direct or indirect involvement of police and authorities.
- Complaints were ignored by law enforcement authorities and courts in several cases.
- Various human rights organizations, media, and public defenders reported repeated violence against Jehovah's Witnesses.
- Applicants produced statements of more than 100 victims and witnesses of alleged violence, along with photographs, video recordings, and auditors' reports.
- The first part of the application concerns 20 applicants who suffered violent attacks during a religious meeting, and several checkpoints were set up to block their entry.
- The second part concerns ten applicants who were beaten and robbed by Orthodox believers during an attack in Marneuli.
- The third part concerns eight applicants who were attacked by private individuals and faced harassment and pressure from the investigators who refused to take action.

title: CASE OF KONOVALOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was pregnant and admitted to the hospital for delivery.
- The hospital booklet warned patients of potential involvement in clinical teaching.
- Doctors noted complications with pregnancy and put the applicant on drug-induced sleep.
- Contractions were monitored and medicine was prescribed to improve blood flow to the placenta.
- The applicant objected to the presence of medical students during delivery.
- Delivery was conducted in the presence of doctors and medical students.
- The child was diagnosed with light asphyxia and placed in special care.
- The applicant sought compensation for non-pecuniary damage and a public apology.
- An expert examination found no intentional delay in delivery or adverse effect from presence of students.
- The District Court and City Court rejected the applicant's claims for compensation.

title: CASE OF LISEYTSEVA AND MASLOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Facts related to the first applicant's case:

- The first applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Petrozavodsk, in the Republic of Kareliya.
- The first applicant was an employee of the municipal unitary enterprise “Avtokolonna 1126” in Petrozavodsk, the Republic of Kareliya.
- The company had “the right of economic control” over the assets allocated to it by the town administration in order to carry out its statutory activities.
- The town administration withdrew unspecified assets of an aggregate value in excess of 25,000,000 Russian roubles (RUB) from the company’s economic control and immediately allocated them to the same company for temporary use free of charge under a loan agreement.
- The town administration requested the legislative body of the Republic of Kareliya to consider the allocation of additional funds to cover the company’s debt in 2004, but to no avail.
- The company was restructured in the form of a spin-off and transferred the assets mentioned in paragraph 8 above to the newly created municipal unitary enterprise “Avtokolonna 1126 Plus”.
- The applicant sued her employer for salary arrears.
- The applicant obtained a writ of execution in respect of the award.
- The remainder of the judgment debts has not been paid to the applicant.

Facts related to the second applicant's case:

- The second applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Mezen, in the Arkhangelsk Region.
- The applicant was an employee of the municipal unitary enterprise “Zhilishchno-Kommunalnoye Khozyaystvo of Mezen” in the Arkhangelsk Region.
- The district administration was responsible for setting the tariffs of the company’s services and was also a major consumer of its services.
- The company was put in a difficult financial situation as a result of the actions of the owner.
- The company was restructured in the form of a spin-off, creating a new municipal unitary enterprise “MUP ‘Mezenskiye Teplovyye Seti’ (Mezen Heating Supply Systems) of the Mezenskiy District” (hereafter, “MUP ‘MTS’”).
- On the spin-off balance sheet approved by the Head of the Mezen district administration on 20 April 2006, the unpaid salary debt was not transferred to the newly created company.
- The director of the company which employed the applicant became

title: CASE OF SULTYGOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are close relatives of disappeared persons allegedly arrested by Russian servicemen in areas under full control of Russian federal forces.
- Official investigations were opened but suspended and resumed multiple times without tangible results.
- State authorities were unable to identify the servicemen allegedly involved in the arrests or abductions.
- The Government did not challenge the allegations presented by the applicants but stated that there was no evidence to prove beyond reasonable doubt that State agents had been involved.
- Five applicants are involved, residing in Switzerland, Sweden, and Chechnya.
- Two men disappeared after being detained in a pit covered with stones and broken glass, while another man was released and warned not to share any information about the detention.
- The investigation was opened in 2001, suspended and resumed several times, and is still pending.
- One applicant's son was abducted in the presence of several witnesses by a group of armed men, and search operations were conducted on the construction site by law-enforcement agencies.

title: CASE OF CHANYEV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and lives in Izmayil.
- On 28 November 2012, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of having murdered Mr S. earlier the same day.
