- On 30 November 2012, the investigating judge of the Reni Local Court ordered the applicant’s pre-trial detention until 27 January 2013.
- On 25 January 2013, the investigating judge extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention until 27 February 2013.
- On 26 February 2013, the indictment in the applicant’s case was approved.
- On 27 February 2013, the indictment and the criminal case file were forwarded by the prosecutor to the court.
- On 14 March 2013, the investigating judge rejected the applicant's request for release.
- On 25 March 2013, the Odessa Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision of 14 March 2013.
- On 15 April 2013, the Izmayil Local Court ordered the applicant's continued detention.
- On 5 November 2013, the applicant was found guilty of murder and sentenced to eleven years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF BAYTAR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant went to Muş prison to see her brother who was being held there in connection with a case related to the PKK.
- A piece of paper was found on the applicant during the body search, which was an unsigned letter dated 24 April 2001, written by a member of the PKK and addressed to another member.
- The applicant was taken into police custody and questioned the following day. She stated that she had picked up the object in question in Van at the bus stop where she was waiting for the bus to Muş and thought that it might have some value.
- The applicant signed her statements with her fingerprint as she was illiterate.
- The applicant was remanded in custody, released, and subsequently, arrested again in connection with the case after visiting her brother.
- On the day of the incident, the staff responsible for body searches discovered a sixteen-page document in the lining of the applicant’s dress that contained information about the PKK’s strategy and its activities in prisons, about the conduct to be adopted vis-à-vis the prison authorities, and about prison staff.
- The applicant was questioned and stated that she had found the impugned object in the prison waiting room.
- The applicant was assisted by a lawyer and an interpreter at the various hearings before the State Security Court of Van.

title: CASE OF POP-ILIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- The Vlasotince Municipal Court ruled in favor of the applicants on April 13, 2006.
- AD Retex, a privately owned company, was ordered to reinstate the applicants to their former jobs and pay their salary arrears and relevant social insurance contributions as well as their legal costs.
- By July 11, 2007, the judgment became final after being amended on appeal.
- On July 27, 2007, the applicants filed for enforcement of the judgment.
- On August 6, 2007, the Vlasotince Municipal Court accepted and issued an enforcement order.
- On December 3, 2007, Leskovac District Court upheld this decision on appeal.
- The Vlasotince Municipal Court carried out an assessment of the debtor's movable assets in January 2008.
- On April 21, 2008, the Vlasotince Municipal Court excluded certain movable assets from the enforcement proceedings in response to a third party's request.
- On May 26, 2008, the Vlasotince Municipal Court obtained an additional report regarding the value of the debtor's movable assets.
- On April 22, 2010, the Leskovac High Court ordered the re-examination of the third party's exclusion request lodged in respect of the debtor's assets.
- The Leskovac Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings on January 21, 2011, in respect of AD Retex, and on June 3, 2011, the applicants' claims were confirmed in their entirety.
- On June 16, 2011, the debtor's assets were sold as part of the insolvency proceedings.
- Enforcement proceedings were stayed on June 12, 2013.
- The insolvency proceedings before the Leskovac Commercial Court are still pending, and the applicants have yet to be paid, apparently as a consequence of two related civil suits brought by other creditors.
- On April 26, 2010, the applicants lodged an appeal with the Constitutional Court, maintaining that they had suffered a breach of the right to a fair trial within a reasonable time and a violation of their property rights.
- On April 4, 2012, the applicants noted the adoption of the amendments to the Constitutional Court Act and specified their compensation claims accordingly.
- On March 27, 2013, the Constitutional Court found that the applicants had suffered a violation of their right to a fair trial within a reasonable time and a violation of their property

title: CASE OF NIKOLIĆ-KRSTIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Leskovac.
- On 5 September 1994, the Municipal Court ordered the debtor to reinstate the applicant and pay her outstanding salary and all work-related benefits for the period following her unlawful dismissal.
- On an unspecified date, the applicant filed a request for the enforcement of the judgment.
- On 19 December 1995, the applicant was reinstated. However, as the debtor refused to pay the outstanding judgment debt, the applicant filed a new request for enforcement.
- On 18 November 1997, the Municipal Court ordered the enforcement by debtor account transfer in the total amount of 72,076.55 Yugoslav dinars (YUM) for salary arrears and all work-related benefits, for the period from 1 May 1992 until 31 December 1995, together with statutory interest and YUM 550 for legal costs.
- On 1 October 1999, the Municipal Court ordered the enforcement by auctioning of the debtor's specified movable assets.
- On 12 May 2001, the enforcement proceedings were discontinued in view of the pending liquidation proceedings.
- On 18 November 2005, the Commercial Court rejected the applicant's claims against the debtor and instructed her to initiate a new set of civil proceedings.
- The applicant did not initiate a new set of civil proceedings as instructed.
- Bankruptcy proceedings are still pending, and the debtor is still predominantly socially-owned.

title: CASE OF BONDARENCO v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Chișinău.
- In 1989 the Chişinău Local Council let an apartment to the applicant.
- In 2000 the Local Council declared the building to be under threat of collapse and was eventually demolished.
- The applicant brought an action against the Chişinău Local Council seeking the allocation of an apartment in lieu of the old one.
- The Rîşcani District Court ruled in favor of the applicant and ordered the Chişinău Local Council to provide her with an apartment in a final judgment of 18 March 2003.
- The judgment of 18 March 2003 of the Rîşcani District Court has not been enforced to date despite complaints made by the applicant between 2003 and 2004 about the failure to enforce it.

title: CASE OF YILMAZ YILDIZ AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants are Turkish nationals born in 1972, 1965, and 1961, respectively, living in Niğde and Mardin. 
- Yılmaz Yıldız is a health officer and the branch chairman of the Health and Social Services Workers’ Union (SES) in Niğde. 
- Kamiran Yıldırım and Mehmet Metin Çılgın are also members of the SES in Mardin. 
- On 4 February 2005, several SES members demonstrated in front of the Niğde Social Security Institution (SSK) Hospital, and Yılmaz Yıldız read out the SES's press statement which criticizes the transfer of hospitals incorporated in the SSK to the Ministry of Health. 
- On 25 February 2005, the second and third applicants, along with thirty others, gathered in the Mardin SSK Hospital yard, and the second applicant read out the SES press statement. 
- Police did not prevent anyone from entering the yard during either gathering, nor did they interfere with the demonstrations or the reading of press statements. 
- According to police reports, the demonstrators had been warned verbally that their gatherings were illegal and ordered to disband to protect public order and safety. 
- The applicants were charged with intentionally disobeying orders issued by the authorities aimed at protecting public order and safety. 
- The Mardin and Niğde Magistrates' Court convicted the applicants as charged and imposed on them administrative fines of 100 Turkish liras. 
- The applicants appealed against the courts' decisions, but the Mardin and Niğde Assize Court dismissed their appeals. 
- Applicants paid the fines on 23 August 2005 and 11 October 2005.

title: CASE OF ÇARKÇI v. TURKEY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and is currently serving a sentence in Kandıra Prison.
- The applicant was wounded by a gunshot on 17 July 1996 in the vicinity of a jewellery shop, which had been robbed by a group of people allegedly including him.
- On 18 July 1996, when the gendarmerie took statements from the applicant, he admitted that he had been involved in the armed robbery, and that he had used a gun during the robbery after the shop owner had begun firing.
- On 25 July 1996, the investigating judge ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention.
- The applicant was not represented by a lawyer while being questioned in custody and subsequently by the public prosecutor and the judge.
- On 9 August 1996, the public prosecutor at the Bakırköy Assize Court filed an indictment against the applicant and three other people, charging them with armed robbery and murder.
- On 21 February 1997, the public prosecutor at the Istanbul State Security Court filed a second indictment against the applicant and eight other people, accusing them of being members of the THKP-C (Turkish People's Liberation Party/Front) and of attempting to undermine the constitutional order by force.
- The applicant challenged the veracity of his statements taken between 17 and 22 July 1996, and claimed that they had been taken by the gendarmerie while he was unconscious in hospital.
- In 2008, the Istanbul Assize Court convicted the applicant under Article 146 § 1 of the former Criminal Code of attempting to undermine the constitutional order by force and sentenced him to "aggravated" life imprisonment (without the possibility of parole).
- On 11 March 2009, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF STANKIEWICZ AND OTHERS v. POLAND
facts:
- The first and second applicants are journalists working for the daily newspaper "Rzeczpospolita", and the third applicant is the newspaper's publisher.
- A chief executive of a pharmaceutical company approached the journalists with allegations that the Head of the Private Office of the Minister of Health demanded a bribe.
- The journalists published an article recounting two meetings between the Head of the Private Office, representatives of the pharmaceutical company, and the director of a private osteoporosis clinic. They alleged that the Head of the Private Office demanded a bribe in exchange for helping the pharmaceutical company place its drug on the list of refunded drugs.
- Before publishing the article, the journalists spoke to the people involved, including the Head of the Private Office.
- The Head of the Private Office denied the allegations but admitted to attending the meetings.
- The Minister of Health also denied the allegations and supported the Head of the Private Office.
- The journalists included comments from a Deputy Minister of Health who stated that the Head of the Private Office should not have been involved in business meetings.
- The article also included a critical report on the professional and political career of the Head of the Private Office.
- The Head of the Private Office filed a civil suit against the journalists for infringement of his personal rights, but the court dismissed the claim.
- The court found that the article was based on reliable and verified information provided by the pharmaceutical company and was in the public interest.

title: CASE OF PAPLAUSKIENĖ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1932 and lives in Vilnius.
2. The Vilnius Region Administration restored the applicant's property rights to 0.23 hectares of land in June 2002.
3. The plot of land was sold for 76,000 Lithuanian litai (LTL) to two private buyers, E.T. and D.Z., in July 2002.
4. In August 2003, the Vilnius Region Administration found a mistake had been made in granting the plot of land to the applicant.
5. The public prosecutor initiated civil proceedings in June 2004 to have the decision of 18 June 2002 and sale contract annulled on the ground that part of the same plot had already been sold by the State to a private buyer.
6. Criminal proceedings had been instituted into possible forgery of the documents.
7. Ownership of the plot was awarded to R.G., and the applicant was ordered to pay LTL 76,000 to E.T. and D.Z.
8. The applicant had to borrow money to pay LTL 76,000 and to cover other legal expenses.
9. The applicant brought a claim against the State for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage.
10. The Supreme Administrative Court granted the applicant's claim in part, awarding her LTL 838 for pecuniary and LTL 2,000 for non-pecuniary damage.
11. The Vilnius Region Administration restored the applicant's property rights in April 2009 by granting her a new plot of land of 0.23 hectares.

title: CASE OF KESZELI v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1952 and lives in Šaľa.
• On 31 May 1994, the applicant claimed a sum of money from a bank.
• On 16 September 2005, the applicant lodged an application challenging the length of the proceedings in court.
• The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 30 April 2007, examined as an appeal on points of law, which became final on 11 June 2007.
• On 27 January 2010, the above decision was quashed by the Constitutional Court and the case was remitted to the Supreme Court for re‑examination.
• On 23 September 2010, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint regarding the length of the proceedings.
• The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the first-instance judgment on 7 June 2011.
• The cassation chamber of the Supreme Court quashed that decision on 25 April 2013.
• On 19 June 2014, the Supreme Court again dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the first-instance judgment.
• The applicant indicated that he intended to lodge an appeal on points of law after the service of the Supreme Court’s decision.

title: CASE OF MOSTIPAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence for charges of abducting, raping and murdering S.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of the crime and taken to a police station where she was questioned by an investigator in the presence of a lawyer.
- Prior to the questioning, she wrote a statement admitting to S.’s abduction, which she claims was coerced.
- The applicant alleges that she was physically and psychologically tortured by police officers who urged her to confess and hit her on the head and stomach, handcuffed her, pushed her to the floor, attached a wire to her leg, and electrocuted her.
- The applicant was later taken to a temporary detention centre, where she was noted to have numerous bruises and scratches, and underwent a forensic medical examination that revealed injuries consistent with blunt solid objects.
- Despite complaints and an additional inquiry, no criminal investigation was opened into the applicant's allegations of ill-treatment.
- The applicant was found guilty of the charges after an initial trial, but her conviction was quashed on appeal due to violations of her right to defence.
- During the second trial, the applicant admitted to participating in S.’s abduction and battery but denied any involvement in the rape and murder; she also claimed she was forced to confess and subjected to ill-treatment while in police custody.
- The Regional Court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced her to sixteen years’ imprisonment but reclassified the charges on appeal and reduced her sentence by two years. The court also acknowledged the inadequacy of the inquiry into the allegations of ill-treatment.

title: CASE OF CHERNETSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Beloozerskiy (Moscow Region).
- On 20 March 2002, the applicant allegedly robbed a shop in Moscow with two others.
- The shop’s owner and assistant caught the applicant and disarmed him.
- The applicant claimed that the bags and handgun did not belong to him.
- The applicant was arrested and taken to the Lefortovo police station in Moscow.
- The applicant wrote a “voluntary confession” acknowledging his participation in the robbery.
- The applicant denied his involvement in the robbery.
- Allegedly, the police officers physically abused and threatened the applicant in order to extract a confession.
- The applicant sustained injuries on his head, chest, and lower back.
- The applicant and his counsel lodged complaints with the investigator, Ms. K., and requested a medical examination and visual examination to establish how the injuries were inflicted.
- The investigator rejected their request for a visual examination.
- A prosecutor refused to institute criminal proceedings, citing insufficient evidence to support the allegations.
- The supervising prosecutor set aside the decision and instructed that the case be further investigated.
- The medical expert found that the applicant had sustained injuries from the beating and could not determine the exact time of the injuries.
- The prosecutor refused to institute criminal proceedings again, citing the inability to establish when and how the injuries were inflicted.

title: CASE OF ADEISHVILI (MAZMISHVILI) v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lived in the Ivanovo Region.
- In 1991, at the age of fifteen, he moved to Russia from Georgia with his parents. 
- On 18 November 1999, he was found guilty of extortion and theft of a passport and sentenced to three years and one month imprisonment.
- In 2005, he was found guilty of theft and sentenced to three years’ imprisonment. 
- He was in a relationship with a Russian national and had two daughters. 
- In June 2007, he was found administratively liable for failing to have his residency in Russia duly authorised. 
- The court granted his request to confirm he had been residing permanently in Russia since 1991.
- On 8 July 2008, he received a Russian passport in the name of Shota Petrovich Adeishvili.
- In 2010, he was found to have unlawfully acquired a Russian passport and was ordered to be expelled from Russia to Georgia.
- He was held in a special detention centre in Ivanovo from 9 July 2010 to 7 February 2011.
- Cells were overcrowded and equipped with a bucket, with no toilet or washbasin.
- Food was provided three times a day but was of poor quality.
- The applicant had no access to any form of entertainment.
- The applicant declared a hunger strike twice.
- He was allowed one hour of outdoor exercise daily.
- Showers were infrequent, and laundry was limited to cold water.

title: CASE OF VOROBYEV v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main facts described in the document are:

- The applicant was born in 1972 and lived in Kerch.
- In 2000, he contracted pulmonary tuberculosis, but it remains unknown whether he received any treatment for it while at liberty.
- On 31 January 2009, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of armed robbery and was allegedly physically ill-treated at the police station.
- On 27 April 2009, he was found guilty of unlawful possession of a weapon and armed robbery, sentenced to nine years’ imprisonment, and ordered the confiscation of all his property.
- The applicant did not appeal against the judgment, but on an unspecified date, he lodged a cassation appeal with the Supreme Court.
- Between 1 February and 26 March 2009, the applicant was held in the Simferopol Temporary Detention Facility (ITT), and between 26 March and 7 July 2009, he remained in the medical unit of the Simferopol Pre-trial Detention Facility (SIZO).
- According to the applicant, the conditions of his detention in the ITT and the SIZO were deplorable.
- The applicant underwent several medical tests and treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis while in detention.
- The applicant alleged that his eyesight had deteriorated as a result of the anti-tuberculosis treatment and that he had been allergic to the medication.

title: CASE OF GORDIYENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1957, lives in Kherson
- Applicant sustained a craniocerebral injury in 1980, underwent surgery for a brain hematoma
- Applicant sustained another craniocerebral injury in 1993 and started to suffer from epileptic attacks
- Applicant designated as Category 2 disabled due to poor health
- On March 24, 2006, T. allegedly punched the applicant in the face and threw other punches at him
- After a complaint was made, a forensic medical expert noted that the applicant had sustained a minor bruise caused by a blunt object
- The Police Department refused to open a criminal investigation, but the District Prosecutor’s Office instituted criminal proceedings against T.
- Multiple investigations were conducted but no criminal charge was filed against T. until a civil case, in which T. was ordered to pay the applicant 2,000 Ukrainian hryvnias.
- On April 18, 2008, the applicant was attacked with a knife but the assailant could not be identified due to lack of evidence. 
- On September 20, 2010, the applicant was involved in an incident with court security guards and police officers in which he was handcuffed, dragged, and punched in the head, resulting in injuries that were classified as minor. 
- The police completed an internal inquiry which found that the evidence was contradictory and the District Prosecutor’s Office was responsible for taking further action. 
- The District Court closed an administrative case against the applicant for a violation of public order on the court premises. 
- A forensic medical expert reported that the injuries identified on the applicant could have been sustained in the manner described in his account of the incident.

title: CASE OF KOSUMOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was a mother and widow living in Kharachoy.
- On 7 June 2003, a police convoy was driving along a road when they were attacked and a vehicle was blown up, killing two officers and injuring others.
- After the attack, unidentified forces started firing mortars, causing one civilian woman (the applicant's daughter) driving a truck to be killed, and two FSB officers were wounded.
- A death certificate was issued for the applicant's daughter.
- The applicant's husband found out about their daughter's death after her funeral and died two days later.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated for negligent homicide, but the investigation was unsuccessful in identifying those responsible for the attack.
- The applicant made several enquiries to the authorities about the investigation but received no clear information.
- The proceedings were suspended and then resumed several times over the following years.
- Witnesses were questioned, including former officers of the Vedenskiy District ROVD and officers involved in the investigation.
- The investigation found that the decision to suspend the investigation in August 2003 was unlawful and incomplete.

title: CASE OF EDUARD SHABALIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Yefremov, Tula Region.
- On 8 November 2002, criminal proceedings were opened against the applicant, who was suspected of murder. The same day he gave an undertaking not to leave town.
- On 11 November 2002, the applicant was arrested and subsequently remanded in custody.
- On 20 November 2002, the applicant was formally charged with murder and the illegal acquisition, keeping and wearing of a handgun and ammunition. 
- On 28 February 2003, he was committed to stand trial before the Town Court.
- His detention was extended by court order on several occasions.
- On 26 May 2004, the applicant was convicted of murder and sentenced to six years’ imprisonment, but the judgment was later quashed, and the case was remitted to the first-instance court for fresh examination.
- On 25 August 2004, the Tula Regional Court noted in the operative part of its judgment that the preventive measure applied to the applicant should “remain unchanged”.
- On 6 October 2004, the applied requested for release, but it was dismissed by the Town Court.
- On 15 August 2005, supervisory review proceedings were initiated in respect of the detention order of 21 August 2003.
- In January 2006, the applicant was convicted as charged and sentenced to eleven years’ imprisonment, which was later reduced to eight years and six months’ imprisonment. 
- It appears that in 2010, he was released on probation, having served only part of his sentence.

title: CASE OF ŠTERJOV AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Civil proceedings for determination of title to land were initiated by the predecessors and two of the applicants in 1982
- Between 1984 and 2001, the predecessors died and the other applicants stepped in on their behalf, except for the fifth to eighth and tenth to twenty-first applicants
- Two of the original applicants died, and their heirs applied to continue the proceedings in their name
- The final decision of the Štip Court of Appeal listed the plaintiffs as the first, second, third, fourth, ninth, and twenty-second applicants, as well as the predecessors of the remaining applicants.

title: CASE OF MIHAJLOV RISTOV AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Civil proceedings were initiated by the applicants and two other individuals for determination of title to plots of land on 15 March 1982.
- Domestic proceedings on behalf of two of the individuals were pursued by their respective heirs after their deaths.
- The ninth applicant died before the application was introduced, but the application was pursued on his behalf by his heir.
- The first applicant died on 21 December 2004, and the application was pursued on his behalf by his heirs.
- The proceedings ended on 7 March 2008 with a judgment of the Štip Court of Appeal, which listed the plaintiffs as the heirs of the first applicant, the second to eighth applicants, the heir of the ninth applicant, and the tenth to twelfth applicants.
- An appeal on the points of law was rejected by the Supreme Court.

title: CASE OF GORESKI AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1929, 1952, 1956 and 1949 respectively.
- Second and third applicants live in Prilep.
- On 12 September 2000, the applicants initiated restitution proceedings.
- On 20 July 2001, the applicants lodged a "silence of administration" appeal.
- Restitution Commission dismissed their claim and awarded them compensation on 5 October 2005.
- Administrative Court upheld the restitution order on 12 December 2008.
- On 23 February 2008, the applicants were requested to specify the type of compensation.
- On 3 March 2009, the applicants refused to decide compensation until their case was decided by the Court.

title: CASE OF SULDIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving his prison sentence in Pechora prison.
- A judge at the Supreme Court of Bashkortostan ordered the interception of the applicant’s telephone calls on 20 December 2001.
- The applicant was arrested and remanded in custody on suspicion of several counts of theft and aggravated murder on 19 January 2002.
- The applicant, the chief security officer of the joint stock company “Bashneft,” was accused of repeatedly stealing petroleum products from a gas-processing plant belonging to ”Bashneft” and killing a presumed accomplice to cover up the criminal activity.
- The applicant pleaded not guilty, while some of his co-defendants also confessed to having falsely accused the applicant during the pre-trial investigation under pressure from police officers.
- The court found the applicant guilty as charged on 16 June 2003 and sentenced him to twenty years’ imprisonment.
- The court relied on statements by witnesses, recordings of telephone conversations, and expert examinations to establish the applicant’s guilt.
- The applicant complained in his appeal that the court did not secure the attendance of key witnesses, and the audio records of telephone conversations were not officially certified and could be forged.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the judgment on 24 September 2003, finding that the first-instance court had correctly assessed the facts established during the court proceedings and reached the right legal conclusions.
- The applicant was held in pre-trial detention facilities and later transported to Mikunsky ULIU prison in the Komi Republic to serve the rest of his sentence.

title: CASE OF BUBNIK v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Koper.
- On 17 November 1995 the applicant instituted civil proceedings before the Koper District Court concerning the division of joint property.
- On 24 September 1997 the Koper District Court rejected the applicant’s claim on procedural grounds. The applicant appealed.
- On 18 February 1998 the Koper Higher Court partially upheld the appeal of the applicant and remitted the case back to the first instance court.
- On 14 August 2001 the Koper District court issued a partial judgment. Both parties appealed.
- On 22 October 2002 the Koper Higher Court dismissed the appeals.
- On 1 March 2007 the Koper District Court issued a judgment concerning the remainder of the applicant’s claim. The applicant appealed.
- On 18 November 2008 the Koper Higher Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal concerning the decision on the main issue. The court however annulled the decision on the costs of proceedings and remitted that issue back to the first instance court.
- On 18 August 2008 the Koper District Court issued a decision on the costs of proceedings. The applicant appealed.
- On 18 November 2008 the Koper Higher Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
- On 29 September 2008 the applicant lodged an application for settlement with the State Attorney’s Office with a view to reaching an agreement on just satisfaction on account of the delays in the civil proceedings.
- On 26 May 2008 the State Attorney’s Office dismissed the applicant’s claim.
- On 25 November 2009 the applicant, relying on Act on the Protection of the Right to a Trial without Undue Delay (“the 2006 Act”), lodged a claim with the Koper Local Court seeking compensation in the amount of EUR 5,800 for non-pecuniary damage incurred as a result of the length of the civil proceedings.
- On 25 November 2010 the Koper Local Court dismissed the applicant’s claim. The applicant appealed.
- On 17 January 2011 the Koper Higher Court upheld the applicant’s appeal and remitted the case back to the first instance court.
- In the course of proceedings, the State on 5 April 2011 acknowledged the claim of the applicant in the amount of 1,200 EUR.
- On 16 November 2011 the Koper Local Court gave a judgment. 
- The court found that the applicant’s right to a trial within

title: CASE OF MAKOVOZ v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lived in St Petersburg before the events of the case.
- In 2004, several criminal cases were opened against the applicant on suspicion of kidnapping, extortion, and planning an assassination.
- The Supreme Court of Russia found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to a total of twenty-three years’ imprisonment.
- Starting from 10 March 2004, the date of his arrest, the applicant was detained in various custodial facilities in connection with the criminal proceedings against him.
- Cell 456 measuring 8 sq. m accommodated up to three inmates. The applicant further claimed that he had been denied the necessary medical treatment there.
- On 1 February 2010, Ms Klykova, the applicant’s representative at that time, lodged an application form complaining about the criminal proceedings against the applicant.
- In letter of 19 April 2010, Ms Klykova informed the Court that between 15 January and the end of February 2010, the applicant had been held in the St Petersburg remand prison and described the conditions of his detention there.
- In letter of 26 October 2012, the applicant further complained about the conditions of his detention in various custodial facilities between 10 March 2004 and 22 December 2011.

title: CASE OF ISTRATOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lived in Novocheboksarsk before the arrest.
- On 20 November 2008, the applicant was suspected of rape and remanded in custody.
- The applicant was held in remand prison IZ-77/3 in Moscow from 22 November 2008 to 7 September 2009.
- The parties submitted different information about the material conditions of his detention.
- The applicant claimed that the cell was overcrowded and the food was of low quality.
- The detainees were allowed to take a shower only once per week.
- The Government submitted a number of certificates that demonstrated that the applicant was held in four cells with adequate conditions.
- The applicant brought a civil claim for compensation in connection with inadequate conditions of detention.
- The Khoroshevskiy District Court of Moscow established that the applicant's argument about overpopulation was substantiated.
- Mr Istratov was always provided with a separate sleeping place, and the number of detainees never exceeded that of sleeping places.
- On 12 May 2009, the Khoroshevskiy District Court of Moscow found the applicant guilty and gave him a custodial sentence.
- On 12 August 2009, the Moscow City Court upheld the conviction on appeal.
- On 21 April 2009, the applicant lodged the first letter with the Court.
- On 4 December 2009, the completed application form was submitted.

title: CASE OF GASANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr Ruslan Nushravanovich Gasanov was a Russian national, born in 1979 and from Vyshniy Volochek.
- He was arrested on 20 April 2006 on suspicion of drug-related offences.
- He was detained in police ward (IVS) of Vyshniy Volochek several times between July 2006 and May 2008.
- Cells in the ward where Mr Gasanov was detained were overcrowded and unhygienic.
- On 29 January 2009, Mr Gasanov was found guilty by the Supreme Court of Russia and was given a custodial sentence.
- In 2012, the Government acknowledged that Mr Gasanov had been detained in conditions that did not meet the requirements of Article 3 of the Convention and proposed to pay him 5,000 euros as just satisfaction.
- On 5 September 2012, Mr Gasanov died.
- His grandmother and aunt intended to pursue his application before the Court.
- On 31 October 2012, the Government requested the Court to strike the application out of its list of cases because of Mr Gasanov's death.

title: CASE OF VOROBYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and was living in Nizhny Novgorod before the events of the case.
- On September 23, 2005, the applicant was arrested and charged with multiple crimes, including robbery, theft, forgery, and extortion.
- On April 11, 2008, the Nizhniy Novgorod Regional Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to custody.
- On August 21, 2008, the Presidium of the Regional Court quashed the previous judgment and remitted the case for fresh examination, ordering the applicant's detention to continue for another three months.
- The authorized period of the applicant's detention was extended on multiple occasions, citing the gravity of the charges and the possibility of absconding.
- On November 24, 2009, the Regional Court found the applicant guilty of several grave offenses and sentenced him to six years and one month's imprisonment.
- The applicant was detained in remand prison IZ-52/1 of Nizhniy Novgorod between September 24, 2005, and January 14, 2009, during which he alleged poor sanitary conditions and severe overcrowding in the cells.

title: CASE OF REUS AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- All applicants are relatives of Mr I. Cheban.
- I. Cheban was struck by a car and died in a hospital on 23 December 2000.
- The police initially refused to open criminal proceedings on 30 December 2000.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted on 16 January 2001.
- Investigations were terminated and quashed multiple times due to incomplete evidence and lack of thorough investigation.
- On 6 April 2005, the Chernivtsi regional police department terminated the investigation again.
- The decision was upheld by courts in 2006 and 2007.

title: CASE OF MYSIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of theft of documents, death threat, murder and robbery.
- The applicant was allegedly subjected to beatings while in police custody.
- On 9 July 2004, the applicant was placed in remand prison IZ-27/1 in Khabarovsk.
- On 18 July 2005, the applicant was transferred to a special section designed for detention of persons sentenced to life imprisonment.
- The applicant stayed in several cells of that section until his departure to a correctional colony on 19 December 2007.
- The parties disagreed on many aspects of the material conditions of the applicant’s detention during that period.
- The Government claimed the applicant was accommodated in four cells, each measuring 8.1 sq. m and with 2 sleeping places, and they were not overcapacity.
- Each cell had a window covered by metal bars which allowed sufficient access to natural light and fresh air. Two light bulbs, one for daytime and another for night-time lighting were installed in the cells. Running water was available at all times. Toilet pans were located at between 1 and 1.3 m from beds and dining tables and separated from the rest of the cells by a 1.5 meter-high brick partition. The applicant was allowed daily hour-long outdoor exercise. He could take a shower and wash his clothing once a week.
- The applicant claimed that all cells were located in the semi-basement of the remand prison, were poorly lit and ventilated, and the metal shutters on the windows blocked access to natural light and fresh air. Heating did not function, and drinking water was available only on request from the prison guards. The toilet pan was not separated from the living area, and the courtyard for outdoor exercise was very small.
- The applicant complained several times to the regional prison authority and regional prosecutor about the conditions of his detention.
- On 25 July 2006, the Supreme Court of Russia found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to life imprisonment.

title: CASE OF BELOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lived in Bolshaya Kivara in the Republic of Udmurtiya before his arrest.
- On 13 July 2005, the applicant was arrested and charged with murder.
- On 18 April 2006, the Supreme Court of the Republic of Udmurtiya found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to fifteen years and six months’ imprisonment.
- During several detention periods between 13 July 2005 and 19 January 2007, the applicant was held in IVS Votkinsk, a temporary detention facility located in the Udmurtiya Republic.
- The conditions of detention in the facility were overcrowded, unsanitary, and without adequate bedding or food.
- The sanitary-epidemiological service inspected the detention facility and recommended that the conditions be improved.
- The applicant complained to various authorities about the conditions of his detention.
- The Votkinsk Town Court found that some allegations of inadequate conditions of detention were substantiated but rejected the claim.
- On 19 June 2006, the applicant lodged his first letter to the Court, complaining about violations of Articles 6 and 13 of the Convention in the criminal proceedings against him.
- On 17 August 2006, the applicant despatched the completed application form.
- In his letter of 3 April 2007, the applicant gave a detailed account of the conditions of his detention in IVS Votkinsk, alleging that they violated Article 3 of the Convention.
- By letter of 23 May 2012, the Registry informed the applicant that his complaint had been more than ten pages long and requested him to submit a summary application form listing the complaints.
- On 6 August 2012, the applicant lodged the application form, including the complaint about the conditions of his detention in IVS Votkinsk.

title: CASE OF PIPUŠ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant signed a lease contract and lodged a civil claim against the tenants for breaching the provisions of the contract.
- The claim was dismissed by the Maribor Local Court and the applicant's appeal was rejected by the Maribor Higher Court.
- The applicant subsequently lodged a constitutional appeal, which was rejected.
- The applicant lodged a claim for non-pecuniary damage due to the delays in the civil proceedings.
- The Celje Local Court found that the applicant's right to a trial within a reasonable time had been breached and ordered the State to pay EUR 4,320 to the applicant.
- The Celje Higher Court modified the first-instance judgment regarding default interests and the costs of the proceedings and dismissed the remainder of the appeal.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, which was rejected by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF LOSEVSKIY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1978, 1979 and 1970 respectively
- On 27 April 2005, the Krasnoflotskiy District Court of Khabarovsk remanded the applicants in custody.
- The applicants were charged with forgery and legalization of money committed by an organized group.
- On 14 March 2007, the Industrialniy District Court convicted the applicants at first instance.
- The applicants' detention on remand was not based on relevant and sufficient reasons. 
- The detention orders cited the gravity of the charges as the main reason for detention but did not mention specific and relevant facts capable of corroborating the existence of security risks.
- The domestic courts did not consider the possibility of applying alternative measures of restraint or did not consider them seriously.
- Extensions were approved without verifying compliance with the special diligence requirement.
- The detention orders employed repetitive standard formulae, notwithstanding changes in the applicants' situation or developments in the proceedings.
- The trial court also issued collective detention orders in respect of the co-defendants that did not contain an analysis of their individual situations.

title: CASE OF MATÚZ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is a television journalist, employed by the State television company, and was the chairman of the Trade Union of Public Service Broadcasters.
- The applicant was in charge, as editor and presenter, of a periodical cultural programme called Éjjeli menedék, which involved interviews with various figures of cultural life.
- According to his work contract, the applicant was bound by professional confidentiality.
- The appointment of a new cultural director had apparently led to censorship of the programme, and the editor-in-chief of Éjjeli menedék had addressed a letter to the board stating this.
- In 2004, the applicant published a book called "Az antifasiszta és a hungarista – Titkok a Magyar Televízióból" (The Antifascist and the Hungarista - Secrets from the Hungarian Television) which contained various in-house letter exchanges between the cultural director and the editor-in-chief concerning the suggested changes in the programme.
- On 11 November 2004, the applicant was dismissed from employment for breaching the confidentiality clause contained in his labour contract.
- The Budapest Labour Court dismissed the applicant’s action, stating that he had breached his obligations under point 10 of his work contract by publishing information about his employer without its consent.
- The Budapest Regional Court dismissed the appeal on the same grounds as the Labour Court.
- The Supreme Court found against the applicant, stating that he had indeed breached the contract by means of the unauthorised publication of internal documents of his former employer.

title: CASE OF CSÁSZY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Budapest
- On 31 August 2010, the applicant was apprehended at his home at 8:04 a.m.
- The house search was conducted on the premises until 11:12 a.m.
- The applicant requested to attend a funeral later that day and alleged his request was "unofficially" dismissed, while the Government denied the allegation
- On completion of the house search, the applicant was committed to the offices of the Central Investigating Prosecutor’s Office, about seven kilometers away from the cemetery in question
- From 1.35 p.m., the applicant was interrogated as a suspect of attempted misappropriation of funds
- The applicant formally requested to attend his stepmother's funeral at 2:15 p.m. on the same day
- The request was rejected with the reasoning that its granting would have contravened the purpose of the arrest
- The interrogation ended at 2:29 p.m. on the same day
- The applicant complained to the Attorney General, who rejected the complaint on 10 September 2010, citing the relevant decree that did not allow arrestees to attend funerals.

title: CASE OF MURAT VURAL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant poured paint on statues of Atatürk on multiple occasions
- The applicant was charged with contravening the Law on Offences Committed Against Atatürk 
- The trial court initially sentenced him to a total of twenty-two years and six months imprisonment, which was later reduced to thirteen years, one month and fifteen days 
- The applicant appealed, arguing that he had exercised his freedom of expression guaranteed in Article 10 of the Convention 
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the appeal, and the applicant served his sentence until he was released conditionally in 2013.

title: CASE OF T. AND A. v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants arrived in Turkey from Iran and were planning to fly to the UK
- Second applicant prevented from boarding due to alleged mismatch in passport photo, both taken for questioning
- First applicant signed report alleging accompaniment of false identity, public prosecutor informed but did not order police custody
- Second applicant kept at airport until transferred to police station and criminal laboratory to establish identity
- Second applicant's passport confiscated and released later that day after authenticity established
- First applicant's photograph and fingerprints taken, questioned by police officers on suspicion of helping second applicant travel with false passport
- First applicant detained until deportation on 13 November, alleged poor conditions of detention
- Criminal complaint lodged against officers for abuse of power and unlawful deprivation of liberty, no criminal proceedings brought against them
- First applicant claimed overcrowding and poor hygiene in detention room, government contended room had sufficient lighting and ventilation, lists of detainees provided by government.

title: CASE OF HÁBENCZIUS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant had a laptop with her which she bought in the United States for approximately 1,500 EUR.
- The applicant did not declare the laptop to the airport customs authority as she believed it was exempt from customs duty.
- The customs authority seized the laptop and charged the applicant with smuggling, despite her indicating that she had no intention of importing the laptop into Hungary.
- The prosecutor proposed discontinuing the seizure of the laptop and ordering the applicant to pay its value instead of its confiscation.
- The court found the applicant guilty, imposed a fine and ordered the release of the laptop on payment of its 'value equivalent to confiscation'.
- The applicant requested a hearing for her acquittal, but no hearing took place and the laptop remained under seizure.
- The case was later discontinued as statute-barred and the laptop was released.
- The applicant could have imported the laptop without paying customs duty on repatriation, but it had become technically outdated and worthless, so she decided to have it returned to the USA.

title: CASE OF DIGRYTĖ KLIBAVIČIENĖ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant acquired a plot of land for residential use in 2000.
- A public prosecutor applied to have the sale contract and related legal acts of the authorities annulled in 2002.
- The claim was dismissed by the Vilnius 1st City District Court in 2003, but the case was remitted for re-examination and dismissed again in 2005.
- In 2005, it was established that the sale of the plot had breached Government Resolution no. 260 of 9 March 1999 and the Law on Territorial Planning.
- The transfer of title to the applicant was annulled, and the land was returned to the State while the applicant received back the money she had paid for it.

title: CASE OF ALIEV v. TURKEY
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Istanbul.
2. The applicant arrived in Turkey in 2006, with a dispute over whether he entered legally.
3. The applicant was apprehended in Edirne while trying to flee to Greece illegally.
4. The applicant attempted to seek asylum numerous times while staying at the Gaziosmanpaşa Accommodation Centre, which was allegedly ignored by national authorities.
5. The applicant was granted asylum seeker status by the Ministry of the Interior on 24 September 2010.
6. The applicant was released from Gaziosmanpaşa Accommodation Centre on 27 September 2010.
7. The applicant was arrested on suspicion of attempted burglary on 1 October 2010, despite being ordered to stay in Kırklareli.
8. The applicant was detained in prison-like conditions at Fatih police station, where there were issues with overcrowding, lack of blankets, insufficient heating, and no provision for outdoor exercise.
9. The applicant was transferred to Kumkapı Removal Centre pending his deportation, following which he was conditionally released on 19 October 2010 and instructed to go to Kırklareli.
10. The applicant was apprehended in Edirne close to the Greek border while attempting to flee to Greece once again on 12 November 2010.
11. The applicant alleged that he was forcefully pushed by one of the officers against the radiator and was severely beaten up once he landed on the floor at Gaziosmanpaşa Accommodation Centre on 1 December 2010.
12. The applicant was diagnosed with alcohol poisoning, as well as widespread corneal erosion and a retrobulbar hemorrage.
13. The Kırklareli public prosecutor decided not to bring any charges in relation to the applicant’s injury in the light of his statement of 23 December 2010.
14. The applicant’s request for asylum was rejected by the Ministry of the Interior on 18 May 2011.

title: CASE OF ERLA HLYNSDÓTTIR v. ICELAND (No. 2)
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant is an Icelandic national who is a journalist working for the newspaper DV.
- DV published an article about a criminal case involving Mr Y and his wife, Mrs X, in which Mr. Y was accused of sexually abusing several female patients at the Christian rehabilitation centre called Byrgið.
- The article included interviews and comments made by Ms A, one of the women who had pressed charges against Mr Y, and Mr B, the financial manager at Byrgið.
- Ms A described how Mrs X was actively involved in the sexual activities organized by Mr Y and even sought sexual encounters with female patients.
- Both Ms A and Mr B stated that Mrs X was aware of Mr Y's abusive behaviors towards the patients, and it was inappropriate for her to work with children.
- Mrs X filed defamation proceedings against the applicant, Ms A, and Mr B, claiming that statements made and published by them amounted to libel in breach of Articles 234, 235, and 236 of the Penal Code.
- The applicant, Ms A, and Mr B were held responsible for defamation by the District Court, and the applicant was ordered to pay Mrs X ISK 100,000 in compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- Mrs X and the applicant both appealed against the District Court's judgment to the Supreme Court.

title: CASE OF MARIAN CHIRIȚĂ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is of Roma ethnic origin and is currently detained in Jilava Prison.
- On 11 February 2002, he was placed in detention in Arad Prison, and on 12 October 2007 was convicted of drug trafficking and sentenced to twelve years and three months’ imprisonment.
- The applicant was found to be a heroin addict with sequels of tuberculosis and psychopathic tendencies upon his initial placement in Arad Prison.
- The applicant was diagnosed with arterial hypertension, coronary heart disease and dyslipidaemia on 8 August 2006.
- On 30 March 2009, the applicant asked the Bucharest District Court to suspend his sentence for medical reasons due to his heart condition, which required surgery that was not possible within the prison health system.
- The Bucharest Institute of Forensic Medicine recommended bypass surgery in a public hospital for the applicant.
- The applicant's request to suspend his prison sentence was rejected by the Bucharest District Court on 1 October 2009, but the Bucharest County Court ordered his admission, under escort, to a cardiovascular centre run by the Ministry of Health to receive the necessary treatment.
- The applicant was recommended open-heart surgery without delay after a new assessment of his heart condition on 7-28 October 2010.
- The Bucharest District Court rejected the applicant’s action to suspend his prison sentence on 22 March 2011, and the Bucharest County Court dismissed the appeal on points of law with final effect on 3 May 2011. 
- The applicant has not undergone a new coronary angiography as recommended by the specialist doctor on 25 January 2011 to date.

title: CASE OF MUSAEV v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and currently lives in Aksaray, Turkey.
- On 2 April 2011, the applicant was taken into custody as part of a murder investigation.
- On 4 April 2011, the applicant was detained for overstaying his visa after giving his statement to the criminal court.
- On 5 April 2011, the applicant was transferred to Fatih police station and placed in a custodial cell for five days.
- On 10 April 2011, the applicant was sent to Kumkapı Removal Centre with the intention of being deported. The centre was severely overcrowded.
- On 12 April 2011, the applicant lodged an application for refugee status with UNHCR.
- On 27 April 2011, the applicant claimed asylum from the Ministry of the Interior.
- On 29 April 2011, the applicant was granted a temporary residence permit in Aksaray as an asylum seeker and released from Kumkapı Removal Centre on the same day.
- The applicant's applications for asylum and refugee status are still pending before the domestic authorities and UNHCR, respectively.

title: CASE OF NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Budapest.
- On 17 April 2007, the applicant was questioned as a suspect on charges of theft.
- On 25 June 2008, the Budapest XIV/XVI District Public Prosecutor’s Office indicted the applicant for theft.
- On 14 October 2011, the Pest Central District Court acquitted the applicant.
- The first-instance judgment was upheld on appeal by the Budapest High Court on 8 October 2012. This judgment was served on the applicant on 19 October 2012.

title: CASE OF FURCHT v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and was detained in Hagen Prison when lodging his application. 
- The police authorized criminal investigations against S. and five other persons (not including the applicant) for drug trafficking. 
- The police sought to establish contact between S. and undercover agents via the applicant, who was a friend of S. but had no criminal record. 
- The undercover agents established contacts with the applicant and arranged purchases of drugs (cocaine and amphetamine) from S. 
- The applicant was arrested on 12 March 2008 after delivering the drugs to the undercover agents, and convicted of two counts of drug trafficking, leading to a five-year imprisonment term.

title: CASE OF VINTMAN v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1968 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Sokal Prison no. 47 in the Lviv region.
2. In February 2000, the applicant was detained on suspicion of several counts of robbery and murder.
3. The applicant claimed that he had been beaten by the police.
4. On 13 September 2000, the Zaporizhzhya Regional Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to life imprisonment for murder. 
5. The Court dismissed the applicant’s allegation of ill-treatment.
6. On 21 December 2000 the Supreme Court of Ukraine upheld the judgment. 
7. On 30 October 2009, the applicant’s sentence was commuted to fifteen years’ imprisonment. 
8. The applicant was transferred to Vinnytsya Prison no. 1, which had a section for life prisoners, on 6 December 2001. 
9. The applicant and his mother requested his transfer to a prison closer to his home to make it easier for her to visit him.
10. All Mrs Kapiton’s requests were rejected.
11. On 10 December 2009, the applicant was transferred to Sokal Prison no. 47. 
12. The applicant's mother complained to the prosecution authorities and the Prison Department about the routine monitoring of his correspondence by the prison administration. 
13. The applicant's correspondence was subject to monitoring under the legislation in force.
14. The prison administration had "withheld some letters written by [the applicant], because their content did not comply with the requirements of the Instruction on Review of Prisoners’ Correspondence".
15. During the period from 16 August 2002 to 30 September 2009 the Vinnytsya prison administration dispatched sixty-nine letters from the applicant.

title: CASE OF STOJANOVSKI AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1943, 1937, and 1965 respectively and live in Skopje.
- In 1950 two plots of land were confiscated from the applicants’ predecessor and a third person, and divided into several new plots, including plot no. 2943/6.
- Two separate sets of restitution proceedings were instituted by ten individuals and the applicants in respect of property confiscated from their predecessors concerning former plots of land, including parts of plot no. 2943/6.
- On 24 June 2002, the Restitution Commission granted the restitution claim in the relevant part and returned the relevant part of plot no. 2943/6 to the claimants.
- After the restitution order had become final, the public prosecutor and the Solicitor General requested that the Appeal Commission declare it null and void for the part concerning plots nos. 2943/3 and 2943/6. The Appeal Commission granted the requests.
- On 5 November 2004, the Supreme Court quashed the Appeal Commission’s decision and ruled that the relevant part of plot no. 2943/6 should be restored into the claimants’ possession.
- On 3 March 2004, the Restitution Commission granted the applicants’ restitution claim concerning the relevant part of plot no. 2943/6 and awarded them monetary compensation in state bonds.
- The applicants appealed against this decision, but on 27 February 2006, the Appeal Commission dismissed their appeal and confirmed the Restitution Commission’s decision.
- The applicants challenged this decision by way of an appeal on points of law, but on 26 June 2008, the Administrative Court dismissed their appeal and ruled that the plot in question could not be restored into the applicants’ possession.

title: CASE OF MAMAZHONOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1968 in Uzbekistan.
- In 2008, he fled Uzbekistan with a forged Kyrgyz passport under an assumed name.
- On 6 September 2009, he obtained a Russian passport using forged documents.
- He was indicted by the investigative authorities of Uzbekistan on charges of terrorism, inciting religious hatred, encroaching upon the constitutional order, illegally crossing the State border, organising a criminal group, producing and disseminating material threatening public security and order, participating in religious extremist, separatist, and fundamentalist movements, and smuggling.
- According to the Uzbek investigative authorities, he had been actively involved in operating the terrorist organisation ‘Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan’.
- He was apprehended in June 2012 at Orenburg railway station by officers of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Anti-Extremism Department and Federal Security Service (FSB).
- On 12 July 2012, an extradition request under the CIS Convention on Legal Assistance and Legal Relations in Civil, Family and Criminal Matters of 1993 was lodged by the Prosecutor General’s Office of Uzbekistan.
- On 12 November 2012, the Deputy Prosecutor General of the Russian Federation authorised the extradition request in respect of the charges of terrorism, participating in an armed group, and illegally crossing the Uzbek border.
- On 10 July 2012, a criminal investigation was initiated by the Russian authorities in respect of the use of forged identification papers by the applicant.

title: CASE OF V.P. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1975 and lives in Chisinau, Moldova. 
- On 28 October 2006, the applicant married Ms E.P. also a national of Moldova. 
- On 15 June 2007 she gave birth to their son, A.P. 
- Relations between the couple deteriorated and Ms E.P. moved to the town of Cahul, in Moldova, where her parents lived with the boy. 
- On 22 August 2008 Ms E.P. initiated divorce proceedings before the Rîșcani District Court of Chisinau. 
- On 13 September 2008, while the proceedings were still pending, Ms E.P. left Moldova with the child and settled in Moscow, Russia. 
- On 28 October 2008 Ms E.P., by letter, informed the court and the police that she was opposed to any contact between the applicant and their son. 
- On 31 October 2008 Ms E.P. obtained a certificate of “temporary residence registration” with the Russian Immigration Authority in Moscow. 
- In the following months, Ms E.P. did not take part in the proceedings before the Moldovan courts; however, she was represented by a lawyer. 
- On 27 April 2009 Ms E.P. returned to Moldova with the boy allowing the applicant to see the child twice. 
- On 12 May 2009 Ms E.P. left for Russia again, taking the child with her. 
- On 18 June 2010 Ms E.P. married Mr A.G. in Moscow. 
- On 15 September 2010, a judge of the Moscow City Court refused to examine the validity of the judgment of 28 October 2009 for the purposes of enforcement on the territory of Russia. 
- On 1 February 2011, the ruling of 15 September 2010 was quashed by the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation. 
- On 7 April 2011, the Moscow City Court granted the application and ordered the enforcement of the judgment of 28 October 2009 on the territory of Russia.

title: CASE OF MELA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Lagos, Nigeria.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of robbery on Sept 27, 2007.
- The Krasnogvardeiskiy District Court of St Petersburg authorised his detention pending investigation on Sept 28, 2007.
- On Oct 9, 2007, the applicant was charged with robbery.
- The applicant lodged a complaint against the investigator on Oct 22, 2007, claiming that he had been charged belatedly.
- The District Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint on Oct 26, 2007.
- On Nov 1, 2007, the St Petersburg City Court upheld the court order of Sept 28, 2007.
- On April 1, 2008, the District Court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to four years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant was released on Sept 26, 2011.
- The investigator in charge of his case seized the applicant’s Nigerian passport, which was supposed to be filed together with the other materials concerning the criminal investigation. However, the passport was lost.
- During the applicant’s detention, he was held in different detention facilities, including remand prisons and correctional colonies.
- The conditions of detention reported by the applicant include overcrowding, sharing cells with infected and non-infected inmates, non-functional ventilation, poor quality of food, inadequate access to toiletries, mattresses and bed sheets, excessive lighting and limited daily exercise time.
- The Government provided a different version of the conditions of detention, including specific details on the dimensions of cells and dormitories, access to ventilation, daylight, temperature, lighting, access to outdoor exercise, number of inmates per cell or dormitory, individual beds, and sanitary facilities.
- The applicant disputed the Government's version and highlighted issues of overcrowding, lack of individual beds, inadequate access to sanitary facilities, and limited shower time.

title: CASE OF BOBROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was arrested on suspicion of drug-related offences
- Test purchase of heroin involved his girlfriend, Ms P. acting on instructions from State agents and supervised by the police
- Applicant was pushed to the floor and handcuffed during the arrest
- The applicant was allegedly beaten up by officers R. and K. in the presence of their superior S. and other officers
- The applicant’s hands were allegedly attached to a radiator with handcuffs while the officers beat and kicked him
- A plastic bag was allegedly put over the applicant’s head to restrict his air supply
- The applicant was subjected to insults and threats to confess
- The applicant was diagnosed with a closed rib fracture on 3 September 2004
- The applicant complained to the prosecutor’s office about the ill-treatment on 6 September 2004
- A preliminary criminal inquiry was instituted on 13 September 2004
- An investigator from the prosecutor’s office refused to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers on 23 September 2004
- The applicant was convicted on 11 December 2004 and sentenced to imprisonment and a fine
- The conviction was upheld on 25 February 2005
- The decision to not institute criminal proceedings was quashed on 24 March 2005 and an additional inquiry was ordered
- Criminal proceedings were refused again on 16 April 2005
- Another additional inquiry was ordered on 19 December 2005
- Criminal proceedings were refused for the third time on 6 January 2006
- The decision of 6 January 2006 was quashed
- Criminal proceedings were refused again on 4 April 2007
- The applicant’s request for supervisory review was granted on 28 August 2008
- The charge was reclassified as an attempt to supply drugs and the sentence reduced to six years and six months
- The applicant’s complaint concerning the ill-treatment was received on 6 September 2004
- The complaint was examined under Article 125 of the Russian Code of Criminal Procedure on 18 September 2009 and dismissed
- The applicant was conditionally released from prison in 2009.

title: CASE OF CAVANI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Italy, while the second and third applicants were born in 2003 and 2004 respectively and apparently live with their mother in Hungary.
- In June 2004, the first applicant's wife took the second and third applicants from Italy to Hungary without the first applicant's consent.
- The family was supposed to return to Italy in August 2004, but the first applicant's wife refused to leave and kept the children with her.
- As of the date of introduction of the present application, the first applicant had been unable to see his daughters since 2005.
- Despite several court orders, including an enforcement order against the first applicant's ex-wife and a European arrest warrant, the children remained in Hungary.
- On an unknown date, the Criminal Court of Modena sentenced the ex-wife to 18 months' imprisonment, suspended, and the marriage was annulled.

title: CASE OF URTĀNS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a sentence in Daugavgrīva Prison.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant for two burglaries in August 2010.
- The applicant was officially declared a suspect on 3 September 2010.
- An investigating judge issued a warrant for his arrest and detention on 6 September 2010.
- The applicant was arrested on 9 September 2010.
- An appeal brought by the applicant was upheld on 27 September 2010.
- The applicant's detention was reviewed on 12 November 2010, and it was decided that it should continue.
- The applicant was charged with the two burglaries on 9 December 2010.
- The case was forwarded for adjudication on 20 December 2010.
- The applicant's detention was reviewed and retained on 12 January 2011.
- During a hearing on 18 February 2011, the applicant requested a change in the security measure applied to him, but it was dismissed.

title: CASE OF TIREAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1957 and is currently detained in Timişoara Prison.
- He was charged by DIICOT with aggravated fraud and organising a criminal group on 28 December 2009, and placed in police custody for twenty-four hours.
- The Cluj County Court allowed the request by DIICOT to detain the applicant pending trial for thirty days on 29 December 2009, and his pre-trial detention was subsequently extended to cover the entire duration of his trial.
- The applicant was convicted of aggravated fraud and organising a criminal group, and sentenced to four years' imprisonment by the Cluj County Court on 5 December 2011.
- In his initial letters to the Court, the applicant contended that he had been beaten up by police officers during the criminal investigation opened against him in 2009.
- The applicant brought civil proceedings against the Romanian Ministries of Finance and Justice in 2010, seeking financial compensation for inadequate medical treatment during his pre-trial detention.
- The applicant was detained in several prisons and prisons hospitals from January to November 2010, during this time, he was detained in a non-smoking cell.
- The applicant refused medical treatment for his chronic and psychiatric problems.
- The applicant was released from pre-trial detention on 18 January 2011 under the condition not to leave the country pending the outcome of the criminal proceedings opened against him.
- The applicant was detained once again on 10 June 2013 following his conviction of 24 September 2012, and was incarcerated in Timişoara Prison.

title: CASE OF ION CÂRSTEA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was a lecturer at Craiova University.
- The newspaper Republica Oltenia published an article accusing the applicant of bribery, blackmail, child sex abuse, and sexual deviance.
- The article included two photographs showing a man and a woman having sex, with the handwritten words "the man in the photos is Ion Cârstea, university as. [assistant] at the electrotechnical faculty".
- The article also mentioned complaints made about the applicant by his students and pending trials he had against his university superiors.
- The article included statements from various sources, including a photographer who accused the applicant of blackmail, and allegations of a special relationship between the applicant and the university dean.
- The applicant sued the journalist and editor-in-chief of the newspaper for defamation and claimed 1 billion lei for non-pecuniary damage and 500,000,000 lei for pecuniary damage.
- The lower court acquitted the defendants and rejected the applicant's compensation claim, but the decision was overturned on appeal.
- It was discovered that the article was written by the editor-in-chief under a pseudonym, but he still did not appear before the court.
- The lower court held that the article was a shocking way of exercising freedom of expression and that the defendant had not acted in bad faith.
- The final court dismissed the applicant's appeal and held that the article was drawing attention to the behaviour of a public figure and that the journalist wanted to expose backstage games and interests in higher education.

title: CASE OF ŚLUSARCZYK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant, a Polish national born in 1971, was arrested on suspicion of robbery on 27 December 2000.
- On 29 December 2000, the Sosnowiec District Court remanded him in custody.
- During the investigation, the applicant’s detention was extended on several occasions.
- On 28 February 2003 the Sosnowiec District Court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to 7 years in prison.
- The applicant’s appeal was heard on 23 April 2004, and the case was remitted.
- The applicant was charged with robbery and battery committed in an organized criminal group on 26 April 2004.
- On several occasions, the Częstochowa Regional Court further extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention relying on the need to obtain evidence from several further witnesses.
- On 10 January 2008 the Częstochowa Regional Court convicted the applicant, and he served his prison sentence from 7 December 2006 to 10 January 2008.
- The applicant remained detained in the third set of criminal proceedings against him.
- The applicant was classified as a “dangerous detainee” by the Katowice Remand Centre Penitentiary Commission on 27 May 2004.

title: CASE OF NOSKO AND NEFEDOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- Both applicants were targeted in undercover operations to investigate bribe-taking.
- The applicants admitted to receiving money in return for promises to render certain services.
- The applicant in Zarechnyy was targeted for the illegal acceptance of money for issuing and extending false sick-leave certificates.
- The applicant in Cheboksary was accused of abetting bribery by altering the results of a forensic medical report in exchange for money.
- The applicants contested the reasons for the undercover operations and the circumstances leading to them.
- The outcome of the trials differed for each applicant, with one receiving a suspended sentence and the other being sentenced to imprisonment.

title: CASE OF DAVYDOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Saransk.
- The applicant brought civil proceedings against the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Mordoviya in 2005 seeking compensation for damage to his health caused during his service in the police.
- On 7 November 2005 the Leninskiy District Court of Saransk found in the applicant’s favour and ordered the Ministry to pay the compensation.
- Starting from 1 November 2005, the Ministry was ordered to make monthly compensation payments to the applicant of RUB 6,892.92.
- However, on 12 October 2006, following a request lodged by the Ministry, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Republic of Mordoviya quashed the final judgment by way of supervisory review and dismissed the applicant’s claims.

title: CASE OF SHVYDKA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a member of an opposition party and lives in Kyiv.
- She participated in a public gathering organized by her party on Independence Day.
- She detached part of the ribbon from a wreath laid by the President of Ukraine at a monument to a famous Ukrainian poet and public figure during the ceremony. 
- Her actions were video recorded by a police officer and photographed by several people.
- She was apprehended and taken to the police station where her actions were deemed as "petty hooliganism" by the court and sentenced to ten days' administrative detention. 
- The applicant's lawyer lodged an appeal on her behalf, arguing that her actions were an expression of her civil position and not prompted by hooligan motives. 
- The Kyiv City Court of Appeal upheld the first-instance court's decision in a final ruling.

title: CASE OF SOCIEDADE DE CONSTRUCOES MARTINS AND VIEIRA, LDA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant is a Portuguese limited liability company, with two managing partners.
- An investigation into the company's fiscal activity between 1994 to 1997 began on 17 September 1999.
- Two sets of fiscal criminal proceedings were instituted before the Porto and Barcelos Criminal Courts.
- The applicants were made defendants in both sets of proceedings on 20 December 1999.
- Charges were brought against the applicant company and third applicant in the Porto Criminal Court on 5 November 2003.
- The trial began on 27 September 2005, but the hearing was adjourned to October and then to 27 March 2006.
- The applicant company's and third applicant's representative resigned on the day of the hearing, leading to an adjournment.
- The applicant company and third applicant gave power of attorney to the same lawyer in June 2006.
- On 14 November 2006, the applicants informed the Porto Criminal Court that they had sought a judicial review before the Porto Administrative and Fiscal Court of a tax adjustment applied to them regarding the applicant company's fiscal activity between 1994 and 1997.
- On 29 November 2006, the Porto Criminal Court suspended the fiscal criminal proceedings in accordance with Article 50 § 1 of the Legal Framework for Non-Customs Tax Offences.
- The applicants applied to the High Council of Magistrates for an order to have the criminal proceedings expedited on 19 December 2008.
- The High Council of Magistrates dismissed their application on 5 May 2009.
- On 28 April 2003, the public prosecutor of the Barcelos Criminal Court brought charges against the three applicants for tax fraud and abuse in relation to activities that had taken place between 1994 and 1996.
- The applicants contested the proceedings on 1 October 2003 and requested them to be suspended until a final decision was adopted in relation to the judicial review pending before the Porto Administrative and Fiscal Court.
- The Barcelos Criminal Court suspended the proceedings on 17 November 2003.
- The proceedings were suspended again on 23 April 2007 until a final decision was adopted by the Porto Administrative and Fiscal Court.
- On 10 October and 27 October 2006, the applicants instituted proceedings in tort against the State in the Porto and Braga Administrative and Fiscal Courts, claiming damages for the excessive length of the criminal proceedings.
- According to the latest information received on 14 February 2014,

title: CASE OF SIGAREV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Kursk.
- On 16 December 2008, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of misappropriation of funds and abuse of power.
- On 17 December 2008, the applicant was charged with abuse of power and fraud.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Kursk authorised the applicant’s detention pending investigation.
- The court extended the applicant's detention on multiple occasions until he was found guilty, citing reasons such as the gravity of the charges, the risk of interference with the investigation, and pressure on witnesses.
- The applicant was found guilty of two counts of abuse of power and two counts of embezzlement on 23 July 2010 and sentenced to four and a half years in prison.
- The applicant was released on parole on 27 April 2011.
- The regional prosecutor’s office issued a writ of execution noting that the applicant had been unlawfully detained for several hours after the expiration of his detention order on 14 March 2010.

title: CASE OF MENDES v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1953 and lives in Barcelos (Portugal).
- Applicant requested permanent disability with respect to work on 21 September 2007 as a consequence of a labor accident.
- Public Prosecutor initiated the conciliatory stage of the proceedings, and medical examinations were requested.
- Hearing with a view to the agreement took place on 19 January and continued on 26 February 2009, but it ended without an agreement.
