- On 22 January 2014, the Moscow Region Department of the Federal Migration Service rejected the applicant’s application for refugee status.
- On 21 February 2014, the applicant challenged the decision of 22 January 2014 before the Federal Migration Service, with no reply.
- On 6 August 2014, the applicant lodged an application for temporary asylum, and the proceedings are still pending.
- The applicant is currently detained and awaiting administrative removal to Uzbekistan.

title: CASE OF ANTHONY AQUILINA v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1948 and lived in Milton, Ontario, Canada.
- Malta has had different legislative regimes to regulate housing since 1931.
- The applicant inherited a property in Gozo, which was registered as a "decontrolled dwelling house" in 1960.
- In 1979, an amendment to the HD Ordinance restricted landlords from raising rents or changing lease terms for Maltese citizen tenants living in homes.
- In 1998, the rent for the premises was further reduced to EUR 65.22 per year.
- Laws enacted in 2009 and 2010 aimed to eliminate restrictive lease regulations.
- The rental value of the property in 2013 was estimated to be EUR 2,900 per year, and the sale value was EUR 58,000.
- The applicant took constitutional redress proceedings in 2005, claiming a breach of property rights under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention.
- The Civil Court rejected his complaint in 2008, and the applicant appealed.
- In 2009, the Court declared the applicant's application inadmissible.
- The applicant instituted constitutional redress proceedings again in 2010, and the Civil Court rejected his complaint in 2011, ruling that the matter had already become res judicata.
- The Constitutional Court upheld the first-instance judgment.

title: CASE OF PANKRATYEV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984.
- The applicant was arrested on 15 October 2009 by Darnytskyy District Police Department of Kyiv for a robbery and charged on the same day.
- On 16 October 2009, the Darnytskyy Court ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention for two months.
- On 10 November 2009, the applicant was also charged with murder.
- On 10 December 2009, the Darnytskyy Court extended the applicant's pre-trial detention to three months.
- On 13 January 2010, the Darnytskyy Court extended the applicant's pre-trial detention to four months.
- On 13 February 2010, the case was referred to the Kyiv Court of Appeal for consideration on the merits.
- On 14 April 2011, the Kyiv Court of Appeal convicted the applicant of robbery and murder and sentenced him to 14 years’ imprisonment and confiscation of his property.
- On 13 September 2011, the Higher Specialised Court for Civil and Criminal Matters sent the case for a fresh trial.
- On 24 December 2013, the applicant was sentenced to 12 years’ imprisonment and confiscation of his property for robbery and murder.

title: CASE OF PADURA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's husband and his friend were attacked by a group of young men, resulting in his husband's grievous head injuries.
- Three of the attackers (K., Dz., and Sh.) were interviewed by the police and admitted to beating the two men.
- The investigation began with charges of disorderly conduct but later included charges of individual infliction of grievous bodily injury.
- The case against Dz. was time-barred, and the charges of disorderly conduct against K. were dropped as time-barred.
- K. was found guilty of bodily injury resulting in death and sentenced to seven years in prison.
- The court noted several shortcomings during the investigation and requested relevant measures to be taken.

title: CASE OF KUSHNIR v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1983 and his present place of residence is unknown.
2. In 2005 the applicant was found guilty of fraud and sentenced to two years’ restriction of liberty.
3. In 2007 criminal proceedings were instituted against him on suspicion of robbery, theft and illegal drug dealing.
4. On 21 October 2009, the court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to four years’ imprisonment.
5. The applicant was detained as a suspect from 8 to 23 March 2007 and from 10 September 2007 to 21 October 2008.
6. On 3 July 2009, the applicant was summoned to the police station and was arrested upon arrival, and detained overnight.
7. On 4 July 2009, a criminal case was opened against the applicant on suspicion of having robbed someone.
8. On 7 July 2009, the investigator applied to the Shevchenkivskyy Court for an order remanding the applicant in custody pending trial.
9. On 6 March 2012, the court convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to six years’ imprisonment.
10. The applicant alleged ill-treatment while in custody.
11. The applicant suffered from tuberculosis, HIV, and chronic viral hepatitis B and C.
12. The applicant was given in-patient treatment in the SIZO medical unit.

title: CASE OF KHISMATULLIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a prison sentence for murder.
- The applicant was arrested and allegedly ill-treated by police officers, leading to a confession to murder.
- Forensic medical examination recorded bruises and abrasions on the applicant's body.
- The applicant complained of chest pain on multiple occasions and was found to have a bruised breastbone and later a breastbone fracture.
- The applicant was convicted and sentenced to eleven years' imprisonment, which was later reduced on appeal.
- The applicant complained of ill-treatment to the prosecutor's office, but criminal proceedings were not instituted due to lack of evidence.

title: CASE OF BIRYUCHENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals charged with different criminal offences and placed in detention.
- The applicants were detained for approximately six months without a court order after their cases had been submitted to the trial court.
- The applicants’ individual circumstances, including their arrests, detentions, and appeals, are detailed.
- The Constitutional Court found that the challenged provisions of the new Criminal Code of Procedure complied with the Constitution of the Russian Federation but their practical interpretation by the courts may have contradicted their constitutional meaning.

title: CASE OF ONAR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are 10 individuals who live in Batman and were born between 1964 and 2000.
- On June 26, 2005, one of the applicants' son and the others' brother, A.O., drowned in the Batman Stream at the age of 14 while swimming.
- The applicants claim that the uncontrolled draining of sand from the stream changed its ecological balance and led to A.O.'s drowning.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the company conducting the sand mining business and the Batman Governor's office which issued necessary permits to run the sand mine, but it was later decided not to prosecute.
- The applicants sought compensation for both pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages after concluding that the authorities and the company failed to take necessary safety measures to protect A.O.'s right to life.
- The trial court rejected the applicants' legal aid request despite them being unemployed and living on state benefits and help from neighbours.
- The trial court asked the applicants to pay a court fee of TRY 214.76 within ten days, which they failed to pay, resulting in the case being discontinued.

title: CASE OF BUZADJI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1947 and lives in Comrat.
- The applicant was the director of a State company referred to as “B-G”.
- The company owed a private company 594,067 United States Dollars (USD) plus penalties as a result of purchasing liquefied gas from that private company.
- The applicant was dismissed from his job on 26 May 2006.
- Thirteen different criminal investigations were initiated against the applicant and his two sons.
- The debt to the private company was fictitious.
- On 2 May 2007, the applicant was arrested, and on 5 May 2007, he was formally charged with defrauding B-G.
- The applicant appealed his detention, citing the ongoing civil proceedings and his medical conditions.
- The Chişinău Court of Appeal upheld the decision and extended the applicant’s detention pending trial.
- The Buiucani District Court rejected a further application by the prosecutor for an extension of the applicant’s detention pending trial and accepted the applicant’s request by ordering that he be placed under house arrest for thirty days.
- On 29 June 2007, the Chişinău Court of Appeal quashed the decision placed the applicant under detention pending trial for twenty days.
- The Buiucani District Court extended the applicant’s detention pending trial by twenty days.
- On 20 July 2007, the Chişinău Court of Appeal changed the preventive measure to house arrest.
- On 12 March 2008, the same court decided to release the applicant on bail.

title: CASE OF D'ASTA v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicants are joint owners of a plot of agricultural land in Casteltermini.
- A portion of their land was taken via public-interest declaration for the construction of a road in 1989.
- The authorities took physical possession of the land in 1991.
- In 1998, the applicants brought an action for damages against the Casteltermini Municipality alleging that the possession of the land was illegal and that the construction work had been completed without formal expropriation of the land and payment of compensation.
- An expert valuation of the land was ordered by the court on an unspecified date.
- The expert report in 2001 concluded that the occupied land covered a surface area of 124.87 square metres and could be classified as building land with the market value of €6.20 per square metre, for a total of €773.88 on the date the occupation became unlawful.
- The Agrigento District Court declared in 2003 that the possession of the land, which had been initially authorised, had become unlawful as of 4 June 1993.
- The court used the expert valuation report to award the applicants compensation in the sum of €773.88, plus statutory interest for the loss of ownership caused by unlawful occupation.
- The court further awarded the applicants €37.43 as compensation for the damage occasioned by the unavailability of the land during the period of lawful occupation (13 July 1989) until loss of ownership (4 June 1993).
- The judgment became final in March 2004.

title: CASE OF DMITRIJEVS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lived in Riga.
- In 1995, he was arrested and in 1998 was given capital punishment.
- The sentence was changed to a 15-year imprisonment in 1999.
- The applicant was transferred to a medium regime prison in March 2001.
- Prison administration decided to apply a more stringent regime to the applicant in July 2005.
- On an appeal by the applicant, the decision was revoked by a decision of the Jelgava Court.
- The recommendation by Pārlielupe Prison to transfer the applicant was approved by the Prisons Administration.
- The order was executed on October 18, 2005, which was against the original decision of July 27, 2005.
- The applicant was transferred to Daugavpils Prison where he was able to enjoy only a limited number of rights.
- On October 26, 2005, the Prisons Administration adopted a decision to transfer the applicant to Jēkabpils Prison.
- The applicant complained about his transfer, and the District Administrative Court found that the transfer was carried out without a lawful basis.
- The court awarded him compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The Regional Administrative Court partly upheld the decision and awarded the applicant compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The Supreme Court quashed the appellate court’s decision and discontinued the administrative proceedings.
- The applicant was released from prison on July 14, 2010.
- The applicant's prison file was destroyed on March 15, 2013.

title: CASE OF BUTI AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Domestic courts delivered decisions in favour of the applicants
- The decisions entitled the applicants to pecuniary amounts and/or actions by State authorities
- The decisions were made on specific dates (as listed in the appended table)
- The applicants were unable to enforce the decisions within a reasonable timeframe

title: CASE OF EFENDIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and was a former head of the Ganja City Police Office and the Dashkasan District Police Office.
- In 2001, he was found guilty of various crimes and sentenced to life imprisonment, but later considered a political prisoner by the Council of Europe.
- He was released from prison in 2005 by a presidential pardon decree, but later in 2005, he was arrested again on charges of obstructing the police and possession of weapons.
- The police found weapons and ammunition, including guns, an assault rifle, a pistol, cartridges, and a grenade, buried in the garden of the applicant's house in Bayan, Dashkasan.
- The applicant was charged with conspiring to organise mass disorder, illegal possession of weapons, and conspiring to usurp State power by force, under Articles 28, 220.1, 228, and 278 of the Criminal Code.
- He was subjected to electric shocks twice in the temporary detention facility of the Organised Crime Unit of the Ministry of Internal Affairs.
- The court sentenced him to five years' imprisonment under Article 228.2.2 of the Criminal Code, and his appeal was dismissed.
- He claimed his innocence and alleged that all the evidence had been fabricated, and the weapons found in his garden did not belong to him.

title: CASE OF BELENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Krasnoobsk, Novosibirsk Region.
- The applicant’s daughter, Oksana Vladimirovna Belenko, was born in 1983 but is now deceased.
- Oksana complained of feeling ill on 14 August 2003 and was taken to the town hospital the next morning. She was then admitted to a psychiatric clinic due to signs of serious psychiatric disorder.
- Oksana was diagnosed with schizophrenia by doctors at the clinic and was further confined to the clinic by order of the District Court on 20 August 2003.
- Oksana received treatment in the clinic until 31 August 2003. Her medical condition was very serious.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint regarding the allegedly inadequate treatment of her daughter on 4 November 2003. The inquiry was reopened on 30 October 2003.
- Oksana died on 7 December 2003 as a result of cerebral oedema, related to her psychiatric condition and aggravated by pneumonia. The case was reopened multiple times, with conflicting expert opinions on the cause of death.

title: CASE OF ELBERTE v. LATVIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts of the case:

- The applicant is the widow of Mr Egils Elberts, a Latvian national who died in a car accident on 19 May 2001.
- Mr Elberts' body was transported to Sigulda Hospital where an autopsy was carried out, revealing numerous injuries to his head and chest.
- After the autopsy, a piece of tissue was removed from Mr Elberts' body without the knowledge or consent of his family.
- The removal of tissue was part of an agreement between the Forensic Centre and a German pharmaceutical company for the purpose of scientific research.
- The removal of tissue from deceased persons selected by the Forensic Centre had been ongoing since 1994.
- The removal was carried out without obtaining the explicit consent of either the donors or their relatives.
- A criminal inquiry was opened in March 2003 into the illegal removal of organs and tissue from deceased persons.
- The inquiry was discontinued and resumed multiple times due to the statutory limitation period and differences in the interpretation of domestic law.
- The inquiry established that the experts at the Forensic Centre had breached provisions of the Law and that the removal of tissue had been unlawful.
- The removed tissue was used for transformation into other products to be used for patients not only in Latvia, but also in other countries.

title: CASE OF JOVIČIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- All applicants worked for the debtor, Raketa-Putnički Saobraćaj AD.
- Applicants filed civil claims for unpaid salaries and social security contributions.
- Court ordered the debtor to pay certain sums to the applicants.
- Insolvency proceedings were opened for the debtor.
- Applicants reported their claims to the insolvency administration.
- Court partially accepted the applicants' claims.
- Debtor's property was sold, with remaining assets advertised for sale.
- Insolvency proceedings are ongoing.
- The debtor was privatised in 2002.
- The privatisation was annulled in 2007.
- The state owned 58.18% of shares in the debtor after the privatisation was annulled.
- The state sold its shares to a private company in 2008.

title: CASE OF EVT COMPANY v. SERBIA
facts:
- On 28 April 1995, the applicant filed a civil suit against S.M. for the payment of debt.
- On 2 February 2005, the Commercial Court in Leskovac ordered the debtor to pay 6,590 Serbian dinars, plus statutory default interest and RSD 92,442 for the costs of the civil proceedings.
- On 24 October 2005, the applicant company filed a request for the enforcement of the Commercial Court judgment by means of an inventory, valuation and sale of the debtor’s movable assets.
- On 16 March 2006, the bailiff made an inventory of certain movable assets found on the debtor. On 30 March 2006, the said property was seized. On 28 April 2006, the debtor sought the return of the seized property, and it was returned to the debtor on the same day.
- In the meantime, from 20 July 2006 to 28 May 2007, the bailiff visited the debtor’s house and business premises six times, but no further attempts were ever made to make an inventory of her movable assets. No further steps were ever made to enforce the order.

title: CASE OF SILVESTRU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested and detained on suspicion of rape and ill-treatment in April 2008.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to twelve years' imprisonment in December 2009.
- The applicant was detained in Prison no. 13 in Chișinău where the conditions were allegedly very poor.
- The United Nations Human Rights Council's report found that some of the institutions visited by the Special Rapporteur were heavily overcrowded, with poor hygienic conditions, restricted access to health care, and lack of medication.
- The Human Rights Centre found issues with adherence to cell size regulations, personal hygiene, food quality, overcrowding, and unsanitary conditions in Moldovan prisons.

title: CASE OF RIMSCHI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and lived in Chişinău.
- On 21 July 2009, he was arrested and charged with producing counterfeit money.
- He remained in custody pending investigation and trial.
- Detention warrants were prolonged every month initially and every three months after the case reached the Ialoveni District Court.
- The reasons given for the detention were that he had been accused of a serious offence punishable with imprisonment of up to fifteen years, that the criminal case was complex, and that he might interfere with the investigation or collude with other co-accused, abscond, or reoffend.
- Before the present application, the last two extensions of detention took place in May and August 2011.
- The applicant argued that there was no risk of him interfering with the investigation and agreed to be placed under house arrest if he could not be released.
- He also argued that detention could not last longer than six months according to Article 186 § 8, other than in exceptional cases.
- The Ialoveni District Court dismissed his arguments, extended his detention, and stated that the case was exceptional within the meaning of Article 186 § 9.
- On 30 January 2012, he was convicted and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment.
- His appeal was dismissed by the Court of Appeal on 10 April 2013, and the Court has not been informed about the proceedings before the Supreme Court of Justice.

title: CASE OF VÉKONY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant operated a grocery store selling excise taxed products such as tobacco and alcohol
- Government passed a law in 2012-2013 making tobacco retail a state monopoly
- Tobacco retailers would become licensed through a concession tender, with new requirements to limit access of minors to tobacco products
- Applicant applied for a concession but was informed that he did not obtain one, leading to the termination of his family's business
- No compensation is available for former holders of tobacco retail licences who lost part of their livelihood

title: CASE OF UĞUR v. TURKEY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants are two brothers born in Istanbul in 1985 and 1987.
- Their neighbor, B.S., was shot in the street on November 23, 2002, and died on arrival at the hospital.
- The police officers arrived at the hospital and detained the applicants and their friends.
- The necessary formalities concerning their detention at the police station were not complied with.
- The applicants were ill-treated while detained at the police station through physical violence, including stripping, dousing with cold water, kicking, punching, and beating with truncheons.
- The police officers questioned the applicants in contravention of the applicable procedure, which stipulates that the presence of a lawyer is compulsory during the questioning of minors.
- The applicants made an official complaint against the police officers on November 29, 2002.
- The criminal proceedings against the police officers were not conducted diligently and were intentionally allowed to become time-barred.
- The applicants were forcibly pressured to withdraw their complaints and tell the authorities that their allegations of ill-treatment had been fabricated.
- The information provided by the national authorities showed that the applicants were substance users and had regular problems with the police.

title: CASE OF MARIAN MACIEJEWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was a journalist with “Gazeta Wyborcza - Gazeta Dolnośląska”.
- The article published by the applicant described the alleged theft of valuable hunting trophies from the office of a former bailiff of the Wrocław‑Krzyki District Court, Mr H.J.
- The court and the prosecutor's office did not take an interest in solving the case, despite the evidence provided by the journalist.
- The investigation into the irregularities of the auction sale of properties resulted in the remanding in custody of the bailiff, H.J. for two years.
- The prosecutor's investigation into the theft of antlers was discontinued.

title: CASE OF IUSTIN ROBERTINO MICU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lives in Bucharest.
- The National Anticorruption Department instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant and three other co-accused for bribe-taking and abetting bribe-taking.
- The applicant was shown a warrant to appear and informed that he would be taken to the N.A.D.'s premises.
- The applicant was heard as an accused by the prosecutor at N.A.D.’s offices from 12 noon to 9.34 p.m.
- The applicant was informed that he had been charged with bribe-taking.
- The N.A.D. placed the applicant in police custody for twenty-four hours commencing at 9.15 p.m. for bribe-taking.
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the N.A.D.'s request to detain the applicant pending trial.
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal convicted the applicant of bribe-taking and sentenced him to three years’ imprisonment.
- The Court of Cassation acquitted the applicant and noted that he had been held in police custody for twenty-four hours.
- The applicant brought criminal proceedings against the prosecutors investigating his case for abuse of office, perjury, unlawful arrest, and improper investigation.
- The applicant brought criminal proceedings against the prosecutor L.P. for abuse of office against the public interest, incitement to the unlawful exercise of a profession and to perjury, incitement to unlawful perversion of justice, and incitement to the retention and destruction of documents.

title: CASE OF MANIC v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant is a British citizen who met a Lithuanian citizen, V.T., in the UK in 2005, and they had a son, A.M., in 2007.
- After spending time in Lithuania, V.T. returned with their son to the UK but then wrote to inform the applicant that their relationship was over and took their son’s belongings back to Lithuania, where she remained with their son.
- The applicant claimed that his son had been abducted, and initiated proceedings before the Vilnius Regional Court to have the child returned to the UK, which was A.M.'s usual place of permanent residence.
- The Vilnius Regional Court acknowledged that both of the parents had custody rights in respect of the boy, but ruled that the child should stay in Lithuania, citing factors such as better living conditions in Lithuania and the mother's greater ability to care for the child.
- The applicant then started new proceedings in the High Court of Justice in England and Wales, where V.T. was allowed to take their son to live in Lithuania permanently, and the applicant was granted parental contact.
- The contact order established by the HCJ set out three stages of contact, including a stage where the mother brought the child to the UK for paternal contact, subject to the applicant paying the sum of GBP 3,000.
- During the first stage of contact, the child's guardian ad litem raised concerns about the applicant's "obdurate attitude" towards the judgment and order issued by the HCJ and the increased risk of the child being abducted by his father.

title: CASE OF TRANČÍKOVÁ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant brought an action before the Trnava District Court to recover a lorry belonging to her and asked the court to order the defendant to return the vehicle to her.
- The District Court dismissed the action, stating that the applicant failed to show that she had lawfully acquired title to the vehicle and that the defendant had lawfully acquired the vehicle by way of purchase from the receiver connected to the insolvency of the vehicle’s previous owner. 
- The applicant lodged an appeal, which was dismissed by the Regional Court without holding a hearing. 
- The Supreme Court declared the applicant’s appeal inadmissible without examining the merits of the case.
- The applicant lodged a complaint against the ordinary courts’ decisions with the Constitutional Court, which was also declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF RUBINS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1947 and was a professor and head of the Department of Dermatological and Venereal Diseases of the Faculty of Medicine of Riga Stradiņa University.
- The Council of the Faculty of Medicine decided to merge the Department of Dermatological and Venereal Diseases and the Department of Infectious Diseases, resulting in the abolition of the applicant’s position.
- The applicant criticised the decisions taken by the deputy dean and sent emails regarding the alleged lack of democracy and accountability in the University’s leadership and alleged mismanagement of finances.
- The applicant also spoke in unfavourable terms about several representatives of the management of the University, making inflammatory claims about their personal lives.
- The applicant proposed amendments to the constitution of the University to address the issues he had raised, but his request was not upheld.
- The applicant received a notice of termination of employment based on an email he sent which was considered to contain inappropriate demands, elements of blackmail, and undisguised threats.
- The applicant’s claim for reinstatement and compensation was initially granted in part by the Kurzeme District Court but later dismissed on appeal by the Riga Regional Court.
- The courts considered the applicant to have failed to observe basic ethical principles and to have breached his duty to treat colleagues with respect.

title: CASE OF HOHOLM v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Norwegian citizen married to a Slovak national (A.).
- They have two children.
- In May 2004, the applicant left the family home, and an interim order granted joint parental responsibility of the children to both parents and placed them in A.’s care.
- On 8 July 2005, A. left Norway for Slovakia with the children, in violation of the interim order.
- The Vesterålen District Court ruled that the children be returned to Norway, and this judgment was ultimately upheld, but the return orders were subsequently quashed twice by the Supreme Court.
- The final court decision dismissed the applicant’s petition for the return of the children based on the fact that the children had spent more than half of their lives in Slovakia and were now integrated there.
- The applicant alleged a violation of his rights under Articles 6 (fairness and length) and 8 of the Convention, and their constitutional equivalents, with respect to the legal proceedings. A complaint to the Constitutional Court was declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF PAWLAK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Łódź.
- On 6 June 2007, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of committing a number of offenses in an armed organized criminal group.
- The Łódź District Court remanded the applicant in custody on 15 June 2007.
- The applicant's detention on remand was extended multiple times by different courts, citing the risk of the applicant fleeing and the need to apprehend other members of the criminal group and obtain additional evidence.
- The charges against the applicant were severed to a separate set of proceedings as he was to undergo a psychiatric examination.
- The Łódź Prosecutor of Appeal lodged a bill of indictment against the applicant with the Łódź Regional Court on 16 June 2009.
- The Regional Court held numerous hearings, some of which were adjourned due to absences of some of the co-accused and problems with the sound system in the court room.
- The applicant’s detention on remand was lifted on an unspecified date in late August 2011, but he remained in custody as pre-trial detention was imposed on him in a separate set of proceedings.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant are still pending before the first-instance court.
- The applicant lodged a complaint about the length of the criminal proceedings with the Łódź Court of Appeal on 25 February 2011, seeking compensation.

title: CASE OF BRAJER v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and is currently detained in Łódź Remand Centre.
- On 25 September 2006, the Łódź District Court ordered the applicant’s detention on remand for a period of three months.
- He was charged with several counts of extortion and drug-trafficking committed in an organized and armed criminal group.
- The bill of indictment comprised 94 charges brought against 28 defendants, and the prosecution authorities requested that 318 witnesses be heard before the court.
- Subsequently, his detention on remand was extended by the Łódź Regional Court, the Łódź Court of Appeal, and the State Prosecutor.
- The courts repeated the grounds previously given for the applicant’s detention, including the strong suspicion that the applicant had committed the offenses in question and the likelihood of a heavy prison sentence being imposed on him.
- The courts noted that keeping the applicant in detention on remand was necessary to secure the proper conduct of the proceedings due to the complex character of the case and the considerable number of co-accused involved who could have obstructed the proceedings.
- The trial was eventually opened on 18 January 2010 after the hearing scheduled for November and December 2009 did not take place due to several reasons.
- The bill of indictment was only finally read out to the defendants at the hearing held on 27 May 2010.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant are still pending at first instance.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Łódź Court of Appeal under the Law of 17 June 2004 on complaints about a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time (ustawa o skardze na naruszenie prawa strony do rozpoznania sprawy w postępowaniu przygotowawczym prowadzonym lub nadzorowanym przez prokuratora i postępowaniu sądowym bez nieuzasadnionej zwłoki – “the 2004 Act”), seeking a finding that the length of the criminal proceedings against him had been excessive and PLN 20,000 in compensation.
- The Łódź Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s complaint, finding that the Łódź Regional Court had conducted the proceedings in a correct and timely manner considering the complexity of the case and the number of co-accused who had actively tried to obstruct the proceedings.

title: CASE OF MASŁOWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and is currently detained in Łódź Remand Centre.
- The applicant was arrested on 29 November 2006 on suspicion of committing a number of offences in an armed organised criminal group.
- The Łódź District Court remanded the applicant in custody until 28 February 2007 on the grounds of strong suspicion of having committed the accused offences, risk of fleeing, and the anticipated heavy prison sentence.
- The applicant’s pre-trial detention was extended multiple times by the Regional Court and Court of Appeal on the basis of a reasonable suspicion, the risk of fleeing or obstructing proceedings, and the complexity of the case and criminal group structure.
- On 18 March 2009, the State Prosecutor lodged a bill of indictment against the applicant, charged with extortion and drug-trafficking committed in an organised and armed criminal group.
- The bill of indictment comprised 94 charges brought against 28 defendants, with the prosecution authorities requesting that 318 witnesses be heard before the court.
- The Łódź Court of Appeal extended the applicant’s detention on remand multiple times until 30 September 2011.
- The trial was eventually opened on 18 January 2010, after multiple adjournments due to various reasons  such as sick leaves of the presiding judge, problems with sound system in the court room, and severance order.
- The bill of indictment was only finally read out to the defendants at the hearing held on 27 May 2010.
- The Regional Court took evidence from the accused and continued taking evidence in 2011 and 2012, during which some of the accused gave evidence, with multiple adjournments due to various reasons.
- The applicant was released on bail and police supervision on 17 August 2011, with a bail condition that he paid PLN 20,000.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant are still pending before the first-instance court.
- On 27 April 2011, the applicant lodged a complaint with the Łódź Court of Appeal under the Law of 17 June 2004 on complaints about a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time (ustawa o skardze na naruszenie prawa strony do rozpoznania sprawy w postępowaniu przygotowawczym prowadzonym lub nadzorowanym przez prokuratora i postępowaniu sądowym bez nieuzasadnionej

title: CASE OF TOMCZYK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and is currently detained in Łódź Remand Centre.
- On 25 September 2006, the Łódź District Court ordered the applicant’s detention on remand for a period of three months.
- The applicant was charged with a number of offences committed with an armed organised criminal group.
- The courts repeatedly extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention based on the gravity of the offences and the likelihood of a heavy prison sentence being imposed on him.
- The trial was opened on 18 January 2010, with subsequent scheduled hearings adjourned due to absences of some of the co-accused and problems with sound system in the court room.
- The Łódź Regional Court gave a severance order in May 2010 and decided to determine charges against two co-accused separately.
- The bill of indictment was finally read out to the defendants at the hearing held on 27 May 2010.
- The Regional Court held fourteen hearings until the end of 2010, during which some of the accused gave evidence, with five of the scheduled hearings adjourned due to sick-leaves of the accused and one hearing was adjourned because of the motion for disqualification of the presiding judge lodged by one of the co-accused.
- In 2011, of the twenty-nine hearings scheduled, eleven took place with fifteen hearings adjourned due to justified absences of the parties and three hearings cancelled due to sick-leaves of the presiding judge and lay judges.
- On 28 September 2011, the Łódź Court of Appeal dismissed the lower court’s motion to extend the applicant’s pre-trial detention, and the applicant’s pre-trial detention was lifted on 30 September 2011. 
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant are still pending before the first-instance court.
- On 27 July 2011, the Łódź Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s complaint about the length of the criminal proceedings against him being excessive and refused to award him compensation.

title: CASE OF KUROWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained in Łódź Remand Centre.
- On 25 September 2006, the Łódź District Court ordered the applicant's detention on remand.
- The applicant was charged with a number of offences committed with an armed organised criminal group.
- The applicant was serving a prison sentence imposed in another set of criminal proceedings against him at the time of detention.
- The District Court relied on a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed the offences and the gravity of the offences in question.
- The applicant's appeal against the decision of 25 September 2006 was dismissed by the Łódź Regional Court.
- The Łódź Regional Court and Court of Appeal extended the applicant's pre-trial detention.
- The applicant served a prison sentence imposed by the Łódź Regional Court in separate criminal proceedings against him.
- The State Prosecutor lodged a bill of indictment against the applicant with the Łódź Regional Court.
- The Regional Court scheduled hearings, which were often postponed or adjourned due to various reasons.
- The applicant was released on bail and police supervision on 19 August 2011.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant are still pending before the first-instance court.
- The applicant requested to take part in his grandfather's funeral, which was denied by the Łódź Regional Court.
- The applicant lodged a complaint about the length of the criminal proceedings against him and sought compensation, which was dismissed by the Łódź Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF IGBAL HASANOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lived in Jalilabad before his arrest.
- The arrest was made following allegations made by two previously arrested persons to the Organised Crime Unit of the Ministry of Internal Affairs that the applicant was a drug dealer and had sold them narcotic substances.
- Heroin packets were found on the applicant and an acquaintance when they were searched by the police while driving in Baku, along with other narcotic substances found inside the car.
- The applicant was arrested and held at the department for narcotics-related crime until 9 a.m. on 9 June 2008, after which he was taken to the temporary detention facility of the OCU.
- The applicant was ill-treated by four police officers in the temporary detention facility of the OCU during the night of 10 to 11 June 2008, and then returned to the investigator for further interrogation in the latter’s office on 11 June 2008.
- The applicant was charged with criminal offences and remanded in custody for a period of three months on 11 June 2008 after complaining of ill-treatment by police officers, which was not addressed in the court’s decision.
- The applicant appealed against the first-instance court’s decision of 11 June 2008 and lodged a separate complaint with the Narimanov District Court about his alleged ill-treatment, which was dismissed due to a lack of evidence.
- The applicant was convicted on all counts and sentenced to nine years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF DRAGOJEVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and worked as a sailor for a shipping company headquartered in Croatia.
- Police and the State Attorney’s Office for the Suppression of Corruption and Organised Crime (OSCOC) investigated possible drug trafficking involving several individuals in Croatia in 2007.
- The OSCOC requested and obtained authorization from an investigating judge to use secret surveillance measures to tap the applicant’s telephone and monitor him covertly.
- Secret surveillance measures were also extended to the use of another telephone number by the applicant on the same request of OSCOC and on the same day the investigating judge granted it.
- The OSCOC requested the use of secret surveillance measures to be extended for a further three months, which was granted by the investigating judge.
- The investigating judge discontinued the use of secret surveillance measures in respect of the applicant on August 7, 2007, but later received a request for new secret surveillance measures against the applicant, which was granted.
- The applicant was arrested and detained on suspicion of drug trafficking on January 16, 2009. The Dubrovnik Police Department lodged a criminal complaint against him the next day.
- The applicant was indicted for drug trafficking and money laundering on March 10, 2009.
- The applicant’s pre-trial detention was extended several times under Article 102 § 1 (3) and (4) of the Code of Criminal Procedure on the grounds of risk of reoffending and gravity of charges.
- The applicant’s objection against the indictment was dismissed and his request to exclude evidence obtained by secret surveillance measures was also dismissed.

title: CASE OF CLEVE v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant and his former partner have been in a custody and contact dispute regarding their daughter.
- The daughter was placed in a home in 2004.
- The applicant was accused of raping his daughter by the mother in 2006, but proceedings were initially discontinued.
- The applicant was charged with fifteen counts of serious sexual abuse of children and sexual abuse of a person entrusted to him for upbringing, specifically his daughter, committed between 2002 and 2004.
- The applicant was acquitted of all charges on account of insufficiency of proof by the Münster Regional Court.
- The inconsistencies in the daughter's testimony, including the number and place of acts, and the time frame, were so marked that it was impossible to establish precise facts.
- The witness A. had made an impression of being authentic to the court, but inconsistencies in her statements prevailed.
- The judgment was served on the applicant's counsel in 2008 and became final.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Federal Constitutional Court, which declined to consider it in 2009.

title: CASE OF MALIKA YUSUPOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicants are Russian nationals and close relatives of individuals who disappeared after allegedly being unlawfully detained by servicemen during special operations in areas under the full control of the Russian federal forces.
- The events concerned took place in different parts of Chechnya.
- The applicants complained of the abductions and official investigations were opened but remained pending for several years without achieving any tangible results.
- State authorities were unable to identify the State servicemen allegedly involved in the arrests or abductions.
- The investigation was repeatedly suspended and resumed.
- Each individual application has a summary of the events.
- The first applicant is the mother, the second applicant is the brother and the third applicant is the sister of Mr Arbi Yusupov, who disappeared after being detained with the second applicant by armed military servicemen.
- The investigation into Mr Yusupov's abduction has been pending since 2002 despite multiple suspensions and resumptions.
- The second account concerns the abduction of Mr Khasan Khadzhiyev.

title: CASE OF ESHONKULOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and lived in Moscow.
- The applicant was arrested in Moscow on 27 April 2013 after an arrest warrant was issued by a criminal court in Uzbekistan.
- The applicant was charged with participation in banned religious organizations, dissemination of ideas of religious extremism, and organization of illegal departure of persons to foreign countries, including for training in terrorist camps in Pakistan.
- The Simonovskiy District Court of Moscow approved the applicant’s detention pending extradition on 30 April 2013.
- On 22 October 2013, the Russian Prosecutor General granted the request of his Uzbekistani counterpart for the applicant’s extradition.
- The applicant’s detention was extended until 27 October 2013 following the receipt of the extradition request.
- The applicant was detained for an infringement of migration rules upon release order communication.
- Counsel submitted an appeal against the extradition decision on 1 November 2013 regarding no assessment of the risk of torture.
- The Moscow City Court rejected the challenge to the extradition decision on 28 November 2013, finding no evidence that the applicant would be subject to unlawful prosecution or torture in Uzbekistan.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation rejected the final appeal against the extradition order on 19 February 2014.
- The Simonovskiy District Court of Moscow found him guilty of having been an unlawful resident in Russia.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the District Court’s judgment, refusing to take into account the arguments about the risk of ill-treatment that the applicant would face in Uzbekistan.
- The Russian Federal Migration Service rejected the applicant's asylum application on 24 September 2013.
- The Basmannyi District Court of Moscow dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 16 December 2013, finding that he had not produced sufficient evidence of the risk of persecution.
- The applicant appealed to the Moscow City Court, and on 20 June 2014, on the alleged risk of ill-treatment, it held that there were no grounds to assume that the claimant would face a real risk of inhuman treatment.

title: CASE OF M.A. v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lived in Vittorio Veneto.
- The applicant and D.P. had a daughter who was born in December 2006 and had joint custody under Italian law.
- D.P. left the family home on 31 January 2008, taking their daughter with her.
- The applicant applied to Venice Youth Court for sole custody and a travel ban in respect of their daughter.
- The Venice Youth Court issued a travel ban but D.P. had already left for Austria with their daughter.
- The Leoben District Court dismissed the applicant’s application for his daughter’s return under the Hague Convention on the grounds of grave risk to the child’s well-being.
- The Judenburg District Court granted D.P. sole custody of the child.
- The Venice Youth Court ordered the child's return to Italy, gave the mother the choice to return with her, and ordered the Vittorio Veneto social services department to provide accommodation if the mother chose to return.
- The Leoben District Court dismissed the application for the child's return on the grounds of grave risk to the child's well-being.
- The Leoben Regional Court granted the applicant's request for enforcement of the Venice Youth Court's order in January 2010.
- The Supreme Court dismissed D.P.'s appeal and stated that the Austrian courts must enforce the return order and take necessary steps without conducting any review of the merits of the decision.
- The Venice Youth Court refused to grant an application by D.P. for the enforcement of its judgment to be stayed, and the Leoben District Court asked the applicant to submit appropriate evidence for accommodation and support.
- The Venice Youth Court withdrew D.P.'s custody rights and awarded the applicant sole custody, ordering the child's return to reside with the applicant in Vittorio Veneto.

title: CASE OF MALMBERG AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant had a dispute with private individuals over a contract of sale for a flat.
- The Vasileostrovskiy District Court awarded the applicant interest on the amount of USD 13,250, but the St Petersburg City Court dismissed the applicant's claims in their entirety.
- A private individual brought proceedings against the applicant seeking recovery of a debt in the amount of 1,116,619 Russian roubles (RUB).
- The Leninskiy District Court of Ulyanovsk ordered the applicant to pay the amount of the debt in full, as well as interest in the amount of RUB 10,000 and the court fee in the amount of RUB 2,861.19.
- The Ulyanovsk Regional Court dismissed the applicant's appeal and upheld the judgment.
- The Tavda Town Administration brought proceedings against the applicant for recovery of "unjust enrichment" in the amount of RUB 175,276.40 resulting from the use of a plot of urban land for a period of two years and interest in the amount of RUB 17,704.57.
- The Tavda Town Court found for the claimant and ordered that the applicant repay the sum gained through unjust enrichment and interest as claimed, as well as the court fee in the amount of RUB 3,529.80.
- The Sverdlovsk Regional Court dismissed the applicant's appeal and upheld the Town Court's judgment.
- The applicant brought proceedings against the Moscow department of the Federal Service for State Statistics for refusing to employ her for the campaign of the population census on the ground of her disability and claiming damages in the amount of RUB 356,145. The Basmanniy District Court of Moscow dismissed her claims in full, and the Moscow City Court upheld the judgment.

title: CASE OF SHKARUPA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lived in Novosibirsk.
- On 8 April 2003, he was arrested on suspicion of murder and placed in pre-trial detention.
- The Berdsk District Court extended his detention several times until 12 August 2004 and convicted him on 11 August 2004, ordering him to remain in detention until his conviction became final.
- On 15 December 2004, the Novosibirsk Regional Court quashed his conviction and sent his case back for fresh examination, ordering that the preventive measure applied to him should remain unchanged.
- The applicant requested release pending trial in March 2005, but the court ordered the extension of his detention until 15 June 2005 due to the seriousness of the charges against him and the fact that he was a foreign national.
- On 15 March 2006, the Berdsk District Court ordered the applicant's release subject to undertaking not to leave a specified place, and he was acquitted on 19 May 2006.
- The applicant claimed compensation for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage resulting from his unlawful prosecution and detention, and he was awarded RUB 500,000 (approximately 12,500 euros).
- The cells in the temporary detention facility of the Berdsk Office of the Interior where the applicant was held were overcrowded, lacked basic hygiene facilities, had no windows, and had insufficient lighting and ventilation.
- The cells were infested with bedbugs, and there were no tables and chairs provided.
- Daily walks outside the cells were irregular and did not last for more than fifteen minutes.
- The police officers of the Berdsk Office of the Interior assaulted and insulted the applicant and his cellmates during an inspection of their cell on 30 August 2005.

title: CASE OF CHOPENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and is currently serving a life sentence in Dnipropetrovsk.
- On 23 June 2005, a young woman named O.K. was found hanged on a tree in a forested area near a bus station. Her mobile phone, earrings, and ring were missing, and she had had sexual intercourse shortly before her death.
- On 27 June 2005, the police took the applicant to the police station for questioning in connection with the investigation into O.K.’s death. He signed a confession statement stating that he had met O.K. at a bus station and asked her to have sex with him in the nearby forest. O.K. had agreed to his proposal and voluntarily given him her ring and earrings after intercourse. As he was leaving, she had threatened to complain that she had been raped and robbed. He had grabbed her by the neck, causing her to lose consciousness, and took her mobile phone before leaving the scene.
- On 28 June 2005, the applicant was questioned by an investigating officer of the Apostolovskiy District Prosecutor’s Office and gave further details of his encounter with O.K. He stated that after she had lost consciousness, he had taken the cord from her umbrella, tied it around her neck and hung her on the tree.
- The applicant was indicted for non-aggravated murder on 7 July 2005 and on 23 September 2005, the charges against him were reclassified as aggravated murder, rape, and robbery.
- On 16 December 2005, the Regional Court found the applicant guilty of rape, theft, robbery, and aggravated murder. The court dismissed the applicant’s allegations of ill-treatment as unsubstantiated and sentenced him to life imprisonment.

title: CASE OF ALBAKOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's son, Batyr Albakov, was taken from the flat where he was staying by armed men who claimed to be officers of the Nazran District Department of the Interior.
- Batyr Albakov was taken to a police station to complete an identity check and was wearing black trousers and a black-and-white striped shirt with short sleeves at the time.
- Batyr Albakov left with the men in two silver VAZ 2110 cars, and the applicant's neighbor witnessed their departure.
- The applicant saw several silver VAZ cars parked at the premises of the operational search unit (ORB-2) on the same day with men in camouflage uniforms, among whom she identified three of the men who had fetched her son.
- On 21 July 2009, the applicant learned on the internet that her son had been shot dead by State servicemen in the course of a counter-terrorist operation in a forest close to Arshty, a village in the Ingushetiya Republic.
- The forensic examination of Batyr Albakov’s body documented seven gunshot wounds, which were determined to be the cause of his death. The examination also noted five bruises on the deceased’s legs and arms.
- On 1 November 2009, the investigator closed criminal case no. 09600099, citing forensic evidence and the statements made by the applicant and her family, concluding that sufficient evidence collected in the course of the criminal investigation indicated that Batyr Albakov had attempted to kill a law-enforcement agent and the case should be closed in view of his death.
- The criminal investigation into the circumstance of Batyr Albakov’s death was re-opened on 14 May 2012 after two military officers who had participated in the operation conducted by Ministry of the Interior forces on 21 July 2009 testified that Batyr Albakov had opened gunfire against their military unit and they had had to put an end to his attack and had shot back at him. He had died in the exchange of gunfire.

title: CASE OF M.A. v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was attacked and raped by three men on 3 November 1983.
- The men were arrested and charged with aggravated rape.
- The proceedings were delayed due to absences of defendants and their counsel.
- One of the defendants was never located and the charges against him were eventually dropped.
- One defendant was found guilty and sentenced to one year in prison, which was later reduced to two-and-a-half years, and a civil case was settled for €15,000.

title: CASE OF ZELENIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was accused of selling heroin.
- The Federal Drug Control Service was informed of the sale by an informant.
- The Service arranged a covert operation to conduct a test purchase on February 6th, 2006.
- The officer waited outside the applicant's flat for him to leave and then forcibly dragged him onto the staircase.
- The applicant alleges that he was beaten and kicked by the officers while the government claims he was resisting arrest.
- The neighbours observed the officers assaulting the applicant.
- The officers claimed that the applicant voluntarily agreed to an inspection, while the applicant claims he was forced into agreement.
- The officers found syringes with traces of heroin during the inspection.
- The applicant was handcuffed during the inspection and then released to sign a report.
- The applicant suddenly ran towards a cupboard, and it fell on him, causing injuries.
- The applicant was formally detained as a suspect in a temporary detention cell.
- The DCS officers reported to their superior the legitimate use of physical force during the applicant's arrest.
- The district prosecutor's office refused to initiate criminal proceedings against the DCS officers, citing the applicant's resistance.
- The applicant was diagnosed with a closed cerebral injury resulting from the arrest and transferred to a remand prison.
- The pre-investigation inquiry into the alleged ill-treatment resumed multiple times.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Krasnoyarsk convicted the applicant of drug-related crimes and sentenced him to six years’ imprisonment.
- The Krasnoyarsk Regional Court upheld the conviction.
- The district prosecutor's office refused to open a criminal investigation into the alleged ill-treatment.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Krasnoyarsk upheld the refusal on judicial review.
- The Investigative Department of the Investigative Committee of the Prosecutor’s Office of Russia for the Krasnoyarsk Region quashed the decision.
- The Investigative Unit of the Investigative Department of the Investigative Committee of the Prosecutor’s Office of Russia for the Kirovskiy District of Krasnoyarsk refused to open a criminal case again.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Krasnoyarsk upheld the refusal on judicial review.
- The applicant was released on probation on March 23rd, 2009.

title: CASE OF YURIY RUDAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Chernyanka, a village in Belgorod Region.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the management of the Kristall-Group holding for loan fraud and fraud.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant, director general of the holding, on suspicion of fraud and loan fraud.
- The applicant was arrested on 18 November 2007 in Kursk.
- The Sverdlovskiy District Court of Belgorod decided to remand the applicant in custody on 19 November 2007.
- The applicant was charged with two counts of fraudulently obtaining a loan on 27 November 2007.
- The Belgorod Regional Court upheld the detention order on appeal on 28 November 2007.
- The District Court extended the applicant's detention multiple times until 10 January 2009.
- The case file was remitted to the trial court on 7 April 2009.
- The District Court convicted the applicant of setting up fraudulent loans and tax evasion on 7 September 2009.

title: CASE OF LOLAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and was a police officer until 2005.
- A submachine gun disappeared from the police station on 25-27 February 2008.
- On 28 February 2008, police officers brought the applicant to the police station, handcuffed him to a chair, and beat him overnight. They used electric wires on his ears to force him to confess to stealing the sub-machine gun. The applicant was released the next day.
- On 3 March 2008, the applicant had a medical forensic examination which attested to his injuries.
- The applicant complained to the prosecutor's office about the events of 28-29 February 2008 on 3 March 2008.
- On 4 April 2008, the Vladikavkaz Investigation Department refused to institute criminal proceedings based on the applicant's allegations.
- On 5 June 2008, a senior investigator set aside the decision of 4 April 2008 and instructed further investigation.
- On 15 June 2008, the Vladikavkaz Investigation Department again refused to institute criminal proceedings based on the applicant's allegations.
- On 6 August 2008, the Iristonskiy District Prosecutor's Office allowed the applicant's complaint and forwarded the materials to the Vladikavkaz Investigation Department to set aside its decision.

title: CASE OF NOGIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and lived in Syktyvkar.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant on suspicion of aggravated rape.
- The applicant was held in pre-trial detention in remand prison SIZO no. 1 of Syktyvkar from 8 August to 9 November 2006.
- On 9 November 2006, the applicant was released subject to an undertaking not to leave a specified place.
- On 8 December 2006, the Syktyvkar Town Court convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to two years and six months’ imprisonment.
- On the same date, the applicant was detained in SIZO no. 1 of Syktyvkar.
- The applicant has been suffering from an insulin-dependent form of diabetes since the age of four.
- On 24 April 2006, the applicant underwent a medical examination in connection with his eyesight problems at a municipal clinic at his place of residence. 
- On 8 May 2009, the applicant was admitted to the ophthalmology department of a public hospital for cataract surgery.
- On 10 July 2009, a research clinic for eye problems in Moscow diagnosed the applicant as having a complicated immature cataract, proliferative diabetic retinopathy, retinal detachment in respect of his right eye, and neo-vascular terminal glaucoma and advanced retinal detachment in respect of his left eye.
- On 14 July 2009, the applicant underwent surgery on the cataract in his right eye.
- Following his conviction, the applicant was admitted a number of times to prison hospitals for examination and treatment.
- The applicant was regularly examined by a doctor, an endocrinologist, and an ophthalmologist.
- In autumn 2006, while the applicant was being held in pre-trial detention in SIZO no. 1 of Syktyvkar, the remand prison doctor prescribed him a special diet.
- According to the applicant, between April and July 2007 and then from early 2008 onwards, he did not receive a special diabetic diet in the correctional facility.
- Throughout his detention, the applicant's eyesight steadily deteriorated because he was denied the necessary surgical intervention.

title: CASE OF N.D. v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1986 and lives in Loka pri Žusmu.
- Applicant was raped by her eldest uncle J.D. in 1992.
- J.D. forced the applicant to engage in regular sexual intercourse until 1994.
- Applicant reported the abuse to the school counsellor in 2000.
- J.D. was indicted with sexual assault on a person under 14 years old in 2002.
- Applicant sought compensation for non-pecuniary damage in 2008.
- J.D. was found guilty and sentenced to three years and four months imprisonment in 2009.
- Applicant's right to trial within a reasonable time was breached and awarded €4,000 in compensation in 2011.

title: CASE OF RUMMI v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant is a widow of a man who was involved in a criminal case
- A man attempted to smuggle 105 kg of waste containing precious metals into Estonia, but it was seized by authorities
- R was asked to give an expert opinion on the value of the metals, and he gave two reports - one with a significantly lower value, which was discovered to be fraudulent
- R was arrested and later committed suicide while in detention
- The police discontinued criminal proceedings against R due to his death, but implicated the applicant as having committed an offence under Article 175 § 1 of the Criminal Code
- Items containing precious metals were found in R's home and workplace, and it was believed he had been involved in smuggling and purchasing them illegally
- The police ordered the substance to be confiscated and transferred to the State.

title: CASE OF KUPPINGER v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant is the father of a son born out of wedlock in 2003.
- The mother refused the applicant any contact with his son shortly after his birth.
- The applicant unsuccessfully attempted to establish contact in 2004.
- The Frankfurt/Main District Court ordered weekly supervised contact between the applicant and his son in 2007.
- The District Court suspended the applicant’s contact rights in 2009, which was amended in 2010.
- The Court found that the length of the proceedings violated the applicant’s right to a trial within a reasonable time in 2011.
- The Frankfurt Court of Appeal granted the applicant's right to see his son on six specific dates in 2010.
- The supervisor reported that the child refused to have contact with the applicant on several occasions.
- The applicant requested the District Court to impose an administrative fine on the mother for interfering with contact in 2010.
- The District Court imposed an administrative fine of EUR 300 on the mother for having contravened the contact order six times in 2010.
- Both parties lodged complaints against the District Court’s decision.
- The Court of Appeal rejected both parties’ complaints in 2011.
- The applicant’s constitutional complaint was refused for adjudication by the Federal Constitutional Court in 2011.

title: CASE OF KALININ v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Yoshkar-Ola, the Mari-El Republic.
- The applicant was dismissed from military service on 28 October 1999.
- The applicant challenged his dismissal order in court.
- On 22 February 2001, the Military Court allowed the applicant’s challenge of his dismissal in part.
- The court annulled the respective orders of the commander of the military unit no. 69795 and obliged the commander to change the date of the applicant’s dismissal to 6 March 2000.
- The court ordered the military unit to pay all the allowances and reimburse the applicant’s legal expenses. 
- On 25 May 2001, the judgment was upheld on appeal by the 3rd Garrison Military Court and entered into force.
- On several occasions, the applicant sent complaints to various authorities arguing that the above–mentioned judgments in his favour had been unfair. 
- On 8 July 2008, the amounts awarded were paid to the applicant in part.
- According to the Government, on 16 January 2009, the judgment was enforced in full.

title: CASE OF KOSMATA v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the case facts:

- The applicants are the mother and sister of Mr K.
- Mr K. was seriously injured and subsequently died on 9 March 2006 while cleaning an extruder machine at a mill operated by company O.
- On 10 March 2006, a committee was appointed to conduct a special inquiry into the circumstances of the fatal accident with K.
- It was determined by the committee that K. had been working as an independent contractor instead of an employee of the company.
- The Zavodsky District Court of Mykolayiv established on 20 November 2006 that the contract between K. and company O. had been an employment contract.
- The Mykolayiv Regional Prosecutor’s Office issued a number of decisions to refuse the criminal proceedings against company O.’s managers.
- Finally, on 30 March 2012, Z. was indicted for breach of safety regulations which caused the death of Mr. K.

title: CASE OF ZAVORIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lived in Kemerovo.
- On 1 March 2008, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of causing grievous bodily injuries to Mr K.
- On 3 March 2008, the Tsentralnyy District Court of Kemerovo remanded him in custody.
- On 10 October 2008, the applicant and other persons were charged with running of a criminal syndicate, extortion, and other offenses.
- On 18 March 2010, the case was sent for trial to the Kemerovo Regional Court.
- On 28 May 2013, the Kemerovo Regional Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to six years' imprisonment.
- On 11 February 2014, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation quashed the conviction and remitted the case for a new trial. It decided that the applicant should stay in custody.
- On 28 April 2014, the Kemerovo Regional Court returned the case to the prosecutor so that certain procedural defects could be remedied. It also extended the applicant's and other defendants' detention for a further three months, referring mainly to the gravity of the charges but also to the wording of the Supreme Court's decision of 11 February 2014.
- The defendant A.L. Zavorin filed an application for release on an undertaking to appear and to be of good conduct, relying on the fact that his prolonged detention in the present proceedings was deemed to be unjustified in the framework of the proceedings on his application before the European Court of Human Rights, and that the [Russian] Government offered him compensation, which he refused.
- On 28 July 2014, the senior investigator of the Investigations Committee ordered the applicant's release, noting that he had spent in custody more than seventy-six months, whereas the Code of Criminal Procedure set the maximum duration of pre-trial detention at eighteen months.

title: CASE OF ĐURIĆ AND OTHERS v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- Banja Luka Court of First Instance ordered Republika Srpska to pay several amounts in respect of war damage and legal costs to the applicants.
- The Court issued writs of execution to enforce the judgments.
- The applicants complained of non-enforcement to the Constitutional Court.
- On 16 January 2013, the Constitutional Court found a breach of the Convention and Protocol in some cases but denied compensation claims.
- Some cases are still pending before the Constitutional Court.
- Some applicants were paid legal costs and default interest.
- Under the new settlement plan, all cases were scheduled for enforcement at different times ranging from 2014 to 2030.

title: CASE OF GÖZÜM v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant adopts child E. born in 2003 to Ms. S.Ö.
- Gözüm was registered as E.'s surname.
- Registrar refused to indicate the applicant’s forename under the heading “mother”.
- Applicant applied to replace the forename “S.” by her own.
- Application was dismissed by the Üsküdar District Court.
- Applicant appealed on points of law.
- A new regulation entered into force, enabling a single adoptive parent to have his or her forename registered in the place of that of the biological parent.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the decision of the court below without mentioning the legislative reform.
- Applicant applied to the registry office for the registration of her forename as that of the mother of E.
- The request was granted, and the record entries concerning the child were amended with immediate effect.

title: CASE OF MESUT YURTSEVER AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were held in the F-type prison in Tekirdağ.
- The prison education board decided not to deliver editions of the Azadiya Welat daily newspaper to the applicants on various occasions.
- The Board based their decision on section 62 § 3 of Law No. 5275, which prohibits the delivery of publications considered obscene or a threat to prison security to convicted prisoners.
- The publications were in the Kurdish language, and the prison had no staff capable of translating that language.
- The applicants appealed against the decisions, stating that they violated their right to receive information and their right to freedom of expression.
- The post-sentencing judge and the Tekirdağ Assize Court dismissed their appeals, relying on the State Prosecutor's opinion that a translation of those publications was required to assess their conformity with section 62 § 3 of Law No. 5275, and that there was no legal provision requiring the prison to finance the translation costs.
- The applicants argued that the ban on the newspaper was arbitrary and violated their rights. They stated that the newspaper was subject to statutory review and that it should be delivered to them.
- The Assize Court ruled that the impugned decisions had been unobjectionable in procedural and legal terms, and dismissed the appeals.

title: CASE OF ATEŞOĞLU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lived in Kars.
- The applicant was arrested on 27 April 2002 by police officers in Kars on suspicion of robbery.
- At the police station, the applicant was allegedly forced to make self-incriminating statements and ill-treated by police officers by pulling his ears, hitting, and beating the soles of his feet.
- On 29 April 2002, the Kars Public Prosecutor visited the applicant in police custody and found bruises on the soles of applicant's feet and oedema behind his ears.
- The applicant identified four police officers who ill-treated him and made a complaint with the prosecutor.
- The applicant was released after appearing before the public prosecutor.
- The applicant was examined by a hospital doctor who found scars on his left arm, bruises and oedema behind his left ear, and bruises on both of his palms and on the soles of his feet. The doctor expected the injuries to heal in five days.
- The prosecutor initiated criminal proceedings against four police officers under Article 245 of the former Criminal Code. The applicant joined as a civil party.
- The Kars Criminal Court declined jurisdiction and referred the case to the Assize Court on 9 May 2002.
- The Kars Assize Court found the police officers guilty of torture under Article 243 of the former Criminal Code, and sentenced them each to one year imprisonment, reduced to ten months, and banned them from public service for five months.
- The pronouncement of the judgment was suspended in accordance with Article 231 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

title: CASE OF KITANOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1988 and both applicants live in Skopje.
- On June 10, 2009, at around 1:30 a.m., the first applicant was driving a car belonging to the second applicant, coming back home from a discotheque, when two traffic police officers signaled him to stop.
- Instead of stopping, the first applicant made a U-turn and accelerated away, followed by 15 police officers in four police cars and several cars from the “Alfa” special mobile police unit.
- A police car with flashing lights was used to block the street to stop the first applicant but he drove around the roadblock, and M.D. fired two shots from an automatic rifle in the direction of the car’s right front tire.
- Z.G fired two shots from his pistol towards the car’s back right tire while jumping aside to avoid being hit by the car.
- The first applicant’s car stopped 100 meters beyond the roadblock, and he was arrested by several police officers who hit him, beat him with truncheons, and punched and kicked him in the face, head, stomach, and back.
- After his arrest, the first applicant was taken to the hospital, where he was diagnosed with contusions and scrapings on the back and forearm, caused by an assault by the police officers.
- The first applicant complained that the police had overstepped their powers by having used firearms and beaten him up, but in a report, the superior police officer considered the use of physical force to be justified.

title: CASE OF ASİYE GENÇ v. TURKEY
facts:
- Ms Asiye Genç was taken to Gümüşhane public hospital, while she was pregnant and in pain by her husband.
- She gave birth to a premature baby boy, Tolga Genç, by Caesarean section, who weighed 2.5 kg.
- Tolga began showing signs of respiratory distress right after birth.
- The doctors decided to transfer the baby to KTÜ Farabi public hospital, located in Trabzon as there was no suitable neonatal unit in Gümüşhane public hospital.
- KTÜ Farabi public hospital refused to admit Tolga on 1 April 2005 at around 1.15 a.m. on the grounds that there were no places available in the neonatal intensive care unit.
- Tolga was transferred to Trabzon Medico-Surgical and Obstetrics Centre where no incubator was available and advised to go back to KTÜ Farabi public hospital.
- Upon their arrival at KTÜ Farabi public hospital, the doctors again refused to admit the premature baby, owing to a lack of available places in the neonatal unit.
-   A fresh attempt was made to drive Tolga to the TMOC where, towards 3.30 a.m., he died in the ambulance. 
- Two investigations, one criminal and the other administrative, were opened after Mr and Ms Genç filed a complaint on 6 April 2005, including a call for the conviction of two doctors from the KTÜ Farabi public hospital.

title: CASE OF NESHKOV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Mr Neshkov was born in 1971 and is currently detained in Belene Prison
- Mr Tsekov was born in 1973 and is currently detained in Stroitel, an open-type prison hostel attached to Burgas Prison
- Mr Simeonov was born in 1976. He was detained in Burgas Prison until 15 July 2014, when he was released; his current whereabouts are unknown
- Mr Yordanov was born in 1962 and is currently detained in Atlant, a closed-type prison hostel in Troyan attached to Lovech Prison
- Mr Zlatev was born in 1965 and is currently detained in Burgas Prison
- Since his incarceration, Mr Neshkov has been placed successively in Varna Prison (2002-05), Lovech Prison (2005-06), Vratsa Prison (2006-14), and Belene Prison (2014-present)
- Mr Neshkov was placed in Varna Prison on 19 June 2002 in execution of eight separate criminal sentences. In a decision of 25 October 2007 of the Lovech District Court these were combined into an aggregate sentence of twenty-eight years and eleven months’ imprisonment
- In the course of his stay in Varna Prison Mr Neshkov was kept in the prison’s high-security area, Group 3 (life prisoners and other prisoners under special regime) on the ground floor, in cells nos. 15, 19, 19a, and 24
- According to Mr Neshkov, the cell windows were covered with metal sheets, which did not permit sunlight or fresh air to come in, and the cells were not equipped with a ventilation system. None of these cells was equipped with a toilet.
- The Government said that they had no records on the exact amount of time spent by Mr Neshkov in each of these four cells. Mr Neshkov submitted that he had spent two years in cell 19a
- According to the Government, all inmates in Varna Prison, including Mr Neshkov, were provided with adequate health care. Varna Prison had a medical centre, and where necessary inmates were consulted by outside medical doctors
- On 29 June 2005, Mr Neshkov was transferred to Lovech Prison, then on 11 October 2006 to Vratsa Prison, and then on 23 May 2014 to Belene Prison, where he is currently housed. He did

title: CASE OF YAGNINA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and lives in Voyvodinovo.
- The applicant worked as a driver and developed dysfunctions of the nervous system before 1985.
- Between 1985 and 2000 the applicant underwent seven medical re-examinations, diagnosed with several chronic diseases.
- On 14 November 2000, the TEMC assessed the applicant's loss of ability to work at 40%, which was not sufficient to entitle her to a disability pension.
- The NEMC declared the applicant fully fit to work in a decision of 14 February 2001.
- The Sofia City Court appointed a medical expert who on the basis of his report, on 27 December 2002, quashed the NEMC’s decision of 14 February 2001.
- The NEMC assessed the applicant’s reduced ability to work at 30% in its decision of 9 October 2003.
