- On 6 January 2005, the Sofia City Court quashed the NEMC’s decision of 9 October 2003 and remitted the case to it.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the Sofia City Court’s judgment in a final judgment of 15 July 2005.
- In a decision of 28 October 2005, the NEMC assessed the applicant’s reduced ability to work at 40%, which did not entitle her to a disability pension.
- The payment of the applicant’s disability pension was discontinued as of 2 October 2000 and there is no information about what happened after the 28 October 2005 NEMC decision.

title: CASE OF PARADISO AND CAMPANELLI v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple who attempted in vitro fertilisation without success before resorting to gestational surrogacy.
- The couple entered into a gestational surrogacy agreement with a Moscow-based company, resulting in the successful implantation of two embryos into a surrogate mother who had no genetic link to the child.
- The surrogate mother gave written consent for the child to be registered as the applicants' son, and the applicants were registered as the baby's parents in accordance with Russian law.
- The applicants were placed under formal investigation and were accused of "altering civil status," forgery, and breaching adoption laws.
- The State Counsel's Office asked that proceedings to free the child for adoption be opened, claiming that the child had been abandoned.
- The Youth Court removed the child from the applicants based on DNA testing, which showed no genetic link between the child and the second applicant, and the fact that the applicants had paid a large sum of money (49,000 euros) for the surrogacy.
- The Campobasso Court of Appeal dismissed the applicants' appeal, and the child was placed in a children's home.
- At the time of the memorandum (May 2012), the child had not yet been declared available for adoption, and the interim attachment of the Russian birth certificate was ordered as essential evidence in the case.

title: CASE OF GÜLAY COŞKUN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant underwent cardiac surgery on 15 May 2001, during which her heart valve was replaced by a mechanical valve.
- The applicant's heart condition did not improve after the operation, and she suffered from a disturbing noise caused by the mechanical valve.
- In 2003, the applicant discovered that the mechanical valve used in her operation was banned by the Ministry of Health due to severe production defects.
- The applicant decided to bring compensation proceedings against the Ministry of Health, the Retired Civil Servant’s Fund, the Ege University Hospital, and the doctors who operated on her.
- The applicant applied for legal aid for the court fees but was denied because she did not fulfil the prerequisite required by Article 465 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
- The court ordered the applicant to pay TRL 3,364,900,00 (approximately EUR 20,600) in court fees within one month, but she failed to do so.
- Consequently, the İzmir Administrative Court decided to discontinue the proceedings.

title: CASE OF CIORCAN AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
1. The applicants are 37 Romanian nationals of Roma origin who live in the Apalina neighbourhood in Reghin.
2. On 7 September 2006, Augustin Biga and his friend had a quarrel with a policeman, R.O., who filed a complaint against them for insulting behaviour.
3. The chief of the Mureş County police ordered several police officers to go to Apalina to summon the two men before the prosecutor, warning of a large crowd armed with weapons.
4. Seven special forces officers, two local police officers, and four plain-clothes officers went to Apalina in a van and two cars.
5. The police officers used tear gas to disperse the crowd, then started shooting.
6. Six state agents suffered injuries requiring medical treatment between 5 and 14 days.
7. More than 25 Roma were reportedly injured and/or shot.
8. Ms. Susana Ciorcan and 12 other applicants suffered injuries confirmed by medical certificates, including gunshot wounds and excoriation wounds.
9. A criminal investigation against the special force officers for the attempted murder of Susana Ciorcan was launched.
10. Expert examinations were carried out on the guns, cartridge cases, and bullets used by the state agents during the incident.
11. A criminal complaint was filed against the special forces officers for abusive conduct and causing bodily harm by 27 victims of the incident.
12. The criminal records of the Roma who made statements to the prosecutor were checked and added to the investigation file.

title: CASE OF KINCSES v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is a practicing lawyer and member of the Békés County Bar Association.
- The applicant filed a notice of appeal before the Battonya District Court and questioned the judge’s competence to exercise duties of a judge.
- The motion was transferred to the Békés County Regional Court and the Vice-President indicated that the applicant’s submissions should give rise to disciplinary proceedings.
- The applicant was fined HUF 170,000 for having committed a deliberate disciplinary offence for breaching ethical obligations by disrespecting the court’s dignity.
- The applicant’s argument that the disciplinary measure had infringed his procedural right, exercised in his capacity as defense counsel, to lodge a motion for bias was rejected by the courts.

title: CASE OF ATILGAN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are Turkish nationals who live in Istanbul.
- They are owners, executive directors, editors-in-chief, editors, and members of the technical staff of various publications.
- Nine publications were issued on a daily, weekly, biweekly or bimonthly basis.
- The publications were suspended for periods ranging from fifteen days to one month between 23 June 2010 and 15 February 2012.
- The suspension was decided by the Istanbul Assize Courts under section 6 (5) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (Law no. 3713).
- The grounds for suspension were that the newspapers had published propaganda in favor of various illegal organizations.
- All copies of the relevant issues were seized.
- The applicants raised objections to the suspension orders but were dismissed shortly afterward by the Istanbul, Assize Courts.
- The applicants and their representatives were not permitted to participate in any of the proceedings held before the Assize Courts.
- The details of the proceedings are listed in the appended table.

title: CASE OF SAYĞI v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant's husband, Mustafa Sayğı, disappeared on 3 June 1994 after being stopped and apprehended by soldiers near Yoğurtçu village.
- Mustafa Sayğı's mother-in-law submitted a petition to the prosecutor, informing him about the incident and requesting to find her son.
- The prosecutor carried out an investigation and identified and questioned soldiers who had been based at the military station at the time of the disappearance.
- The prosecutor concluded that Mustafa Sayğı had been unlawfully detained by the military but couldn't indict the military personnel responsible for the unlawful detention due to the expiry of the statutory time-limit.
- Mustafa Sayğı's elder brother claimed that his brother was buried in an area near Yoğurtçu village and bones, fabrics, a small axe, and the remains of a red motorbike were found during the excavation.
- Gendarmerie forensic experts examined the metal parts and established that they belonged to a motorbike. The bones were later found to be animal bones.
- The investigation was closed, and the applicant lodged an objection with the court arguing that the investigation was incomplete and requesting it to be continued. The objection was later rejected.

title: CASE OF RINAS v. FINLAND
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts include:

- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Vantaa.
- In 1998, the applicant's Finnish company underwent a tax inspection and was found to have no irregularities.
- In 2004 and 2005, the applicant's foreign companies were similarly subjected to tax inspections.
- Tax surcharges were imposed on the applicant on various occasions between December 2005 and June 2006, for having received disguised dividends from foreign companies.
- The applicant sought rectification of these decisions from the local Tax Rectification Committee, but these applications were rejected in October 2006.
- The applicant appealed against this rejection in December 2009 to the Helsinki Administrative Court, which upheld the earlier decision.
- The applicant appealed against this decision to the Supreme Administrative Court, which refused leave to appeal in September 2012.
- The tax authorities requested an investigation into the applicant's potential aggravated tax fraud in April 2005.
- Charges against the applicant were brought in November 2008 for aggravated tax fraud purposes.
- The applicant was convicted of aggravated tax fraud by the Vantaa District Court in June 2009 and sentenced to a suspended prison sentence of 1 year and 6 months.
- The applicant appealed this conviction to the Helsinki Appeal Court in August 2009 and the judgment was partially quashed with a reduced sentence, compensation amount, as well as the raising of the question of ne bis in idem.
- The applicant then appealed to the Supreme Court in February 2011, which granted leave to appeal the charges concerning the tax years 2002 to 2004 in September 2011.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Appeal Court's judgment in May 2012, stating that the taxation decisions for the tax years 2002 to 2004 had not yet become final.

title: CASE OF SIKUTA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Budapest. 
- On 1 July 2002, the applicant signed an employment contract with a State-owned financial institution. 
- On 6 May 2010, the applicant terminated his employment contract with the employer, and the agreement was mutual, which came into effect from 30 July 2010. 
- On May 17, 2010, the employer paid the applicant a net amount of 4,997,020 Hungarian forints (HUF) (approximately 16,100 euros (EUR)), including his salary due until the termination of his employment, payment for unused annual leave, and an additional five months’ salary.
- The gross amount corresponding to the above payment was later taxed at a 98% rate in its part exceeding HUF 3.5 million because of new legislation. 
- As a result, the applicant had to pay an additional HUF 2,144,160 (approximately EUR 6,900) as a special tax until 20 May 2011.

title: CASE OF AKHVERDIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1972 and lived in a house in Khutor settlement of Baku.
- The applicant acquired private ownership of the house on 8 October 2005, but the plot of land underneath was not registered as formal ownership.
- The Head of the BCEA issued an order on 14 May 2004 for the development of various plots, including the neighbourhood where the applicant's house was located.
- In 2009, the NDEA proposed to relocate the inhabitants of the area specified in the BCEA order and offered the applicant an occupancy voucher for a new five-room flat in compensation for his house.
- The applicant refused to accept the offer and filed a lawsuit against NDEA, BCEA, the Ministry of Finance, and Azyevro LAU LLC.
- The Narimanov District Court rejected the applicant's claims, citing the BCEA order of 14 May 2004 and various provisions of the old 1982 Housing Code.
- The court found that the issuance of an occupancy voucher in the applicant's name for a new five-room flat constituted compensation for his house.
- The court also considered the compensation given to the applicant as fair because the new flat was larger and had a higher market value than the applicant's old house.
- The court rejected the applicant's claim for non-pecuniary damage, finding that he had not demonstrated that he had suffered any moral damage.

title: CASE OF MALYK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and was the director of a limited liability company, B.
- The company took out bank loans in 2007 and 2008 for production activities.
- The composition of the shareholders and management of the company was allegedly changed on the basis of forged documents.
- The company failed to repay the loans and refused the banks’ requests for repayment.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the managers and owners of company B. and the forgery of documents in October 2009.
- Witnesses, including employees of the banks, shareholders, and staff of company B., provided details of the role of the applicant in arranging the loan agreements and changing the shareholders and management.
- The applicant was arrested and detained on 27 November 2009, based on allegations made by eyewitnesses.
- The applicant challenged his arrest and detention in court, arguing that the alleged events had taken place a long time ago and there was no risk that he would abscond since he had previously voluntarily appeared before the investigator.
- The district court ordered that more information concerning the applicant’s personality, family status, and lifestyle be produced before deciding on the application of a preventive measure.
- The applicant was released against a written undertaking not to abscond on 7 December 2009.
- The district court found that the applicant’s arrest had been unlawful and his detention had not been justified and necessary in the circumstances of the case on 29 January 2010.
- The Zhytomyr Regional Court of Appeal quashed the decision and remitted the case to the district court for fresh consideration on 23 February 2010.
- The district court dismissed the applicant’s complaint on 15 March 2010, and the applicant appealed against that decision.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decision of 15 March 2010 on 7 April 2010.
- The Supreme Court rejected the applicant’s appeal on points of law as inadmissible on 11 May 2010.

title: CASE OF STOLYAROVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant bought a flat in Moscow in 2005.
- The flat was previously owned by the City of Moscow and allocated to Mr P. as social housing before his death in 2001.
- Mr M. moved into the flat after the exchange of flats authorized by Moscow City Housing Authorities.
- Mr S. was registered as living in the flat after Mr M. moved out and signed a social tenancy contract with the Moscow Housing Department in 2004.
- The ownership of the flat was transferred to Mr S. under the privatisation scheme in September 2004, and he sold it to the applicant in March 2005.
- The Moscow Department of the Interior imposed an "informational ban" on the flat in January 2005.
- The Moscow Housing Department instituted proceedings in 2009 to declare null and void all the transactions related to the flat exchange and to terminate the applicant's title to the flat, evict her, and return the flat to the City of Moscow.
- The applicant submitted a counterclaim seeking to have her title to the flat recognized, stating that she had purchased the flat in good faith.
- The District Court granted the claim of the Moscow Housing Department in December 2010, which was subsequently quashed by the Moscow City Court in 2011.
- The District Court again granted the claim of the Moscow Housing Department in 2012, and the Moscow City Court upheld it on appeal, leading to the applicant's potential eviction.

title: CASE OF A.V. v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- Applicant was born in 1982 and lives in Kyiv.
- He was arrested on a street in Kyiv on the evening of December 29, 2006.
- He was taken to the Shevchenkivskyy District Police Department of Kyiv, where he was asked to empty his pockets in the presence of two attesting witnesses.
- Bags containing cocaine were found on him.
- The applicant alleged that the police officers planted drugs on him and assaulted him during the arrest process.
- The police detained and arrested him under Article 263 of the Administrative Offences Code for violating drug circulation rules.
- The applicant wrote a confession that he unlawfully bought cocaine for personal use, which he claims was dictated by one of the police officers.
- The applicant was held in bad sanitary and hygienic conditions during his stay in the police department from December 29, 2006, until his release on January 5, 2007.
- On January 2, 2007, the police received a report stating that the substance seized from the applicant contained 1.18 grams of cocaine.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against him on January 2, 2007, for illegally purchasing and storing narcotic drugs in large quantities, an offence pursuant to Article 309 § 2 of the Criminal Code.
- On January 5, 2007, the prosecutor refused to approve the investigator’s application to have the applicant placed in pre-trial detention, and he was released on a written undertaking.
- On June 8, 2008, the District Court found the applicant guilty of illegally purchasing and storing narcotic drugs in large quantities, and sentenced him to three years’ imprisonment, which was later suspended.
- The applicant appealed the decision, but the Kyiv Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court dismissed his appeal.

title: CASE OF A.N. v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and is currently serving his sentence in prison.
- A man was murdered on 15 November 2004 in Dymytriv, Donetsk Region, which resulted in a criminal investigation.
- The applicant claims that on 12 December 2004, he was taken by police officers to some premises where he was interrogated and tortured with the aim of extracting a confession to the murder.
- On 14 December 2004, the applicant wrote a confession admitting that he had committed the murder.
- On the same day, he was provided with a lawyer and questioned as a suspect, during which the applicant submitted his version of events to the investigator's questions.

title: CASE OF YEVGENIY PETRENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1988 and is serving a prison sentence.
- An adolescent named R disappeared on 28 February 2004 and was later found dead on 18 March 2004.
- The District Prosecutor’s Office opened a criminal investigation into the murder.
- The police searched the applicant’s home and seized seven knives, clothes, and other items.
- The applicant was questioned as a witness in the murder case without a lawyer present.
- The applicant was questioned about the fraudulent theft of a mobile phone and arrested on suspicion of that crime.
- The applicant confessed to the murder, stating that he had attended a meeting with the victim earlier that day and brought a knife, which he used to stab and cut the victim’s throat.
- The applicant alleged that his confession was the result of psychological pressure and physical ill-treatment from police officers.
- The case was consolidated, and the applicant was charged with aggravated murder and fraudulent theft of a mobile phone; his accomplice was charged with concealment of murder.
- The applicant’s defense counsel changed multiple times.
- The applicant’s conviction for murder and his accomplice’s conviction for concealment of murder were quashed and remitted for fresh consideration.
- The applicant’s allegations of ill-treatment were examined by the Regional Prosecutor’s Office, but the decision not to open an investigation was quashed multiple times for further enquiries.

title: CASE OF UZEYIR JAFAROV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is an independent journalist from Baku who criticized the government's security and defense policies in his articles.
- The applicant wrote an article that criticized a colonel in the army for corruption and illegal activities.
- The applicant was present at a hearing for the editor-in-chief of his newspaper, who was convicted of defamation and sentenced to two and a half years in prison.
- The applicant was attacked by two men as he was leaving the newspaper office on the same day as the hearing.
- The applicant was hospitalized for seven days because of the attack and suffered from a cranial injury and contusions on the upper lip.
- The Yasamal District Police Office instituted criminal proceedings in connection with the attack and questioned the applicant.
- The applicant identified one of his attackers as a police officer from the Yasamal District Police Office.
- The criminal proceedings were later suspended because the perpetrator could not be identified.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Prosecutor General, but the investigation was not effective.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Yasamal District Court, which was dismissed.
- The Baku Court of Appeal upheld the Yasamal District Court's decision.

title: CASE OF APOSTU v. ROMANIA
facts:
Facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Târgu Mureș born in 1968
- A criminal investigation was started against the applicant, his wife, and three businessmen for corruption committed during his time as mayor of Cluj Napoca by the Anti-Corruption Department of the Prosecutor’s Office (the “DNA”)
- The prosecutor sought authorization for the interception of the applicant’s telephone calls, which were later admitted as evidence
- The applicant’s home and office were searched on 9 November 2011, and he was taken to the DNA’s Cluj headquarters for investigation
- On the same day, he was ordered to be remanded in custody and was held in pre-trial detention until at least 6 January 2012, with extensions justified by the nature and severity of the offenses, the continuous nature of such offenses, and the possibility that the applicant might obstruct the course of justice
- He lodged appeals against the interlocutory judgments, but all appeals were dismissed
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant for corruption, trading in influence, complicity in money laundering and forgery, and repeated complicity in and incitement to money laundering and forgery are still pending
- Excerpts of conversations, as well as pieces of evidence from the prosecution file, were published in several newspapers even before the applicant and his co-defendants were committed for trial
- The applicant complained of inadequate conditions of detention during his pre-trial detention, including overcrowding, low temperatures, and poor hygiene

Conditions of detention:
- The applicant was held in a 5 sq m cell with four tiers of bunk beds during his pre-trial detention
- He complained of no access to toilets, lack of natural light and ventilation, and noxious smells
- The government claimed he was held in cells with appropriate furnishing, artificial and natural light, and ventilation through wire netting-covered windows
- The applicant spent one hour per day outside of the cell and was allowed two showers per week
- He was detained alone in two cells and detained with no more than three other detainees in other cells
- The applicant complained of overcrowding in Gherla Prison, where he was held for some periods, and claimed low temperatures and poor hygiene
- The government claimed he was detained in cells designed for vulnerable detainees (persons who held official functions) with adequate heating and ventilation, two showers per week, and proper food distribution
- He was admitted to the hospital wing of Dej Prison and later transferred to

title: CASE OF ILIEVA AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1928, 1949, 1958, and 1954 respectively.
- Ancestors of the applicants owned agricultural land collectivized after 1945.
- In 1964, municipal authorities decided to allocate land for the construction of a hotel in Ribaritsa.
- In 1985, a proposal to expropriate the land from the agricultural co-operative was rejected by a commission created by the Government.
- The hotel was constructed between 1962 and 1968, consisting of a main building, ten bungalows, and maintenance buildings.
- In 1987, the state-owned enterprise “Pochivno delo na SO” was created to manage the hotel.
- In 1995, the company “Pochivno delo na SSHP” EOOD was created to take over the assets of the enterprise; the company became the owner of the assets, including the hotel.
- In 1991, the applicants applied for the restitution of the land formerly owned by them following the Agricultural Land Act (ALA).
- The Teteven agricultural land commission restored the applicants’ property rights to several plots, including one of 8,290 square meters on which the hotel had been constructed, in a decision of 25 July 1995.
- In 1996, the land commission amended its previous decision, and the plot on which the hotel had been constructed was not mentioned, considered a tacit refusal for restitution.
- The Teteven District Court quashed the decision in 1998, stating that the land commission had no valid legal grounds and restored the applicants’ property rights to the plot of land.
- The applicant obtained a notarial deed based on the judgment in 1999.
- In 1998, “Pochivno delo na SSHP” EOOD brought an action against the applicants seeking a declaratory judgment it was the owner of the land.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation's final judgment in 2005 held that “Pochivno delo na SSHP” EOOD had become the owner of the plot since its transformation in 1995 as it had previously used and managed the property.
- The courts concluded that they were free to conduct an indirect judicial review of the restitution decision and found that the preconditions for restitution had not been met, leading to compensation in lieu of restitution for the applicants.
- The compensation was effected by compensation bonds in 2006, with a face value

title: CASE OF BOCHAN v. UKRAINE (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant claimed title to part of a house and land based on arguments that it was constructed at her and her late husband’s expense, her husband lawfully obtained title to the property which she subsequently inherited, it was not sold to Mr M. despite there having initially been an agreement with the applicant’s son to that effect, and the sales contract on which Mr M.’s claim to the property was based was forged.
- The domestic courts found that Mr M. had bought the foundations of the part of the house in question from the applicant’s son in 1993 and had subsequently built it at his own expense. Mr M. was the lawful owner of that part of the house and had the right to use the land on which it had been constructed.
- The Supreme Court ordered a reassignment of the case after disagreeing with the findings of the lower courts as to the facts and before the new assessment of facts and taking of evidence by the lower courts took place.
- There was a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention due to the circumstances in which the applicant’s case had been reassigned and to the lack of sufficient reasoning in the domestic decisions.
- The domestic courts had afforded no reply to the applicant’s submissions concerning the reliability of the witnesses’ statements and the validity of the documentary evidence, which had been decisive for the outcome of the case.
- The complaints regarding the length of the proceedings and a violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 taken in conjunction with Article 14 of the Convention were dismissed as unsubstantiated.
- The applicant was awarded 2,000 euros (EUR) by way of just satisfaction in respect of non-pecuniary damage. 
- The Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe has not yet concluded the supervision of the execution of the judgment under Article 46 § 2 of the Convention.
- The applicant lodged a new “appeal in the light of exceptional circumstances” with the Supreme Court, which was declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF FURMAN v. SLOVENIA AND AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant lived with M.P. in an extramarital relationship from 1991 to 1997, and they had a daughter in 1993.
- The applicant and M.P. separated in 1997 and agreed on the amount of child maintenance to be paid by the applicant for their daughter, as well as a provisional contact schedule.
- When they could not agree on a more permanent contact schedule, the applicant requested that the Centre issue an order determining his contact rights.
- M.P. stopped letting the applicant have contact with their daughter on April 13, 1998.
- A series of hearings and appeals followed, including requests for information on M.P. and their daughter's whereabouts, and attempts to serve legal documents.
- On February 7, 2007, the Maribor District Court issued a contact schedule allowing the applicant to visit his daughter every two weeks, which was later modified to allow visits only in Graz.

title: CASE OF KHLOYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of organizing a criminal group to commit various crimes.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court remanded the applicant in custody multiple times, citing the gravity of the charges against him, risk of absconding, reoffending, and obstructing justice.
- The court found that detention was necessary due to the applicant's potential influence on the prosecution's main witness and his connections to the criminal underworld.
- The applicant's potential to tamper with witnesses and plot a defense was also cited as a reason for detention.
- The applicant's health was mentioned as a defense argument, but the courts were not convinced that his release was warranted.
- The applicant suffered from chronic viral hepatitis C, acute gastritis, and diabetes while in custody.
- The applicant was diagnosed with infiltrative pulmonary tuberculosis while in custody and received treatment.
- The applicant was tested and found to have developed multi-drug resistance, and his chemotherapy regimen was amended as a result.
- The applicant requested the Court's intervention to authorize his transfer to a specialized medical facility due to the inadequacy of medical assistance he was receiving in custody.

title: CASE OF MIFOBOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant alleged in letters that she had a "special relationship" with the mayor, was destined to protect people in high office, and was being persecuted by employees of the mayor’s office.
- On 17 April 2008, the MRPC asked the Magadan Town Court to order an involuntary psychiatric examination of the applicant.
- On 11 October 2008, the applicant was brought to the police station and then transferred to the MRPC for urgent treatment.
- On 17 October 2008, the Magadan Town Court terminated proceedings on the MRPC’s application because the applicant agreed to undergo the necessary treatment voluntarily and signed the consent form in the courtroom.
- On 20 May 2010, the applicant was interned in the MRPC following a clinical psychiatric evaluation report diagnosing her with progressive paranoid schizophrenia.
- On 26 May 2010, the Magadan Town Court ordered the involuntary hospitalisation of the applicant.
- On 6 July 2010, the Magadan Regional Court upheld the lower court’s authorization in full.

title: CASE OF OGORODNIK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and is currently serving a sentence of imprisonment in Berdychiv Prison no. 70.
- At the time of the events the applicant had four criminal convictions for theft, in particular. He had been released from prison in October 2007.
- From January 2008 onwards, a number of armed robberies and thefts were committed in the Kyiv and Vinnytsia regions.
- On 16 July 2008 the Vinnytsia Police Department for Combating Organised Crime, having received some preliminary reports concerning the possible involvement of the applicant in the aforementioned crimes, arrested him together with his brother and an acquaintance. 
- Several guns, gas sprays, some jewellery and several pairs of gloves were found in the car.
- The applicant confessed to several counts of theft and robbery. He also wrote a note stating that he had no complaints against the police and that no physical or psychological coercion had been applied to him.
- The Zamostyanskyy District Court of Vinnytsia found the applicant guilty under Article 185 of the Code of Administrative Offences and sentenced him to ten days’ administrative detention.
- The applicant was examined by doctors after his admission to the Vinnytsia Temporary Detention Facility (ITT). The examination revealed scratches and bruises on his right shoulder.
- The investigator detained the applicant on suspicion of banditry, numerous counts of theft and armed robbery, money laundering, hooliganism, and illegal arms possession and handling.
- On 7 August 2008 the applicant was taken to the Brovary Town Police Department in the Kyiv region. He underwent a standard initial medical examination there. 
- On 11 September 2008 the applicant was transferred from Brovary to Vyshgorod. 
- On 16, 22 and 26 September 2008 the applicant reiterated his earlier confessions and confessed to yet more crimes. 
- The Vinnytsia Regional Prosecutor’s Office issued a ruling announcing its refusal to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers of the local police department. 
- The applicant complained to the Minister of the Interior that he had been subjected to various kinds of ill-treatment and humiliation in all the detention facilities. 
- The investigation had consisted mainly of questioning of the police officers involved, who had denied any ill-treatment of the applicant.
- On 19 November 2008 the Vinnytsia Regional Prosecutor’s Office refused to institute criminal proceedings against the officials of the Vinnyts

title: CASE OF ČIKANOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and worked for the Borovo Municipality until 16 January 1991.
- On 28 March 1991, the applicant brought a civil action against the Borovo Municipality seeking reinstatement and salary arrears.
- By a partial judgment of 15 October 1996, the Vukovar Municipal Court annulled the decision on the applicant’s dismissal and ordered his reinstatement within eight days of the judgment becoming final.
- On 5 December 1996, the defendant appealed against the partial judgment.
- The Vukovar Municipal Court declared the defendant’s appeal inadmissible as having been lodged outside the statutory time-limit.
- The applicant took early retirement on 30 September 1997.
- In the resumed proceedings concerning the salary arrears, the Vukovar Municipal Court found for the applicant.
- The Vukovar County Court reversed the first-instance judgment, dismissing the applicant’s action in its entirety.
- The Supreme Court quashed the second-instance judgment and upheld it in part.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against the Supreme Court’s judgment.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint.
- The Vukovar Municipal Court ordered the Borovo Municipality to pay the applicant salary arrears for the period between 1 March 1991 and 29 December 1996.
- The Vukovar County Court upheld the first-instance judgment.

title: CASE OF RAZZAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a migrant worker who arrived in Voronezh in 2002, and he was born in 1971.
- On 26 April 2009, three police officers in plain clothes knocked the applicant to the ground, handcuffed him, and pushed him into their unmarked car without explanation.
- The police officers took him to the Zheleznodorozhniy district police department of Voronezh and subjected him to various acts of physical violence, including hanging him on a metal bar, punching him, and subjecting him to electric shocks via wires attached to his ears and genitalia.
- Four men in masks and rubber gloves undressed the applicant completely and hung him by a rope on the door of the office, head down, while they squeezed his testicles and threatened him with an intravenous injection.
- The ill-treatment continued until the next morning when the applicant was placed in a cell for administrative detainees at the same police station.
- The applicant confessed to the murder of a certain D., but no criminal proceedings were brought against him.
- The applicant was given a medical certificate diagnosing him with bruising of the soft tissue of his face and his rib cage, and a forensic medical report noted that he had various bruises and injuries inflicted on him during his detention.
- The district investigative committee initially refused to institute criminal proceedings, but eventually opened criminal proceedings against unidentified police officers at the Zheleznodorozhniy ROVD.

title: CASE OF GORDEYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant lodged an action against his former employer, seeking reinstatement in a job and work-related benefits.

- The Khanty-Mansiysk Town Court held in the applicant's favour, but the Regional Court reversed the judgment and remitted the case to the Town Court for a fresh examination.

- The institute was liquidated on 13 August 2002.

- The respondent was replaced by the Academy as the defendant following the applicant's request.

- The trial was postponed several times due to various reasons, including the applicant's health problems and requests for additional documents and witnesses.

- The Town Court partly granted the applicant's action, awarding him arrears and non-pecuniary damage, and ordering his immediate reinstatement.

- Both the respondent and the applicant appealed the decision.

- The Regional Court affirmed the judgement, as to the reinstatement and non-pecuniary damage, reversing and remanding it for a new trial as to the arrears.

- The District Court awarded the applicant the arrears, which were later upheld on appeal.

- The sums awarded to the applicant were paid by the Academy.

- The Presidium amended the judgments of both lower courts as to the applicant's immediate reinstatement, declaring that he should be considered dismissed due to the liquidation of the employer organization.

title: CASE OF KÜCHER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Schalchen.
-  On 8 September 1999, the Salzburg Federal Police Authority issued fifteen preliminary penal orders against the applicant for infringements of the Motor Vehicle Act and EU Regulations.
- On 27 December 2000, the Salzburg Federal Police Authority issued six penal orders against the applicant.
- On 4 December 2001, the Salzburg Independent Administrative Panel sentenced the applicant to pay a fine of a total amount of 21,500 Austrian Schillings, and to contribute to the costs of the first and second instance proceedings.
- On 12 September 2006, the Administrative Court quashed the appeal decision.
- On 3 January 2007, the Independent Administrative Panel issued a fresh decision and quashed four of the penal orders.
- On 6 February 2007, the applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court complaining about the length of the proceedings and lack of an effective remedy and asked for just satisfaction.
- On 10 June 2008, the Constitutional Court refused to deal with the complaint on the grounds that it did not raise an important legal question.
- On 30 July 2008, the applicant applied for his complaint to be referred to the Administrative Court, which was done on 8 August 2008.
- On 24 October 2008, the Administrative Court refused to deal with the complaint because the fine imposed did not exceed EUR 750.

title: CASE OF BÉLÁNÉ NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Baktalórántháza.
- In 2001, her loss of capacity to work was assessed at 67% as of 1 April 2001, and she was granted a disability pension.
- The level of the applicant’s disability was subsequently changed to 40% on 1 December 2009, and her entitlement to the disability pension was withdrawn as of 1 February 2010.
- In 2011 the applicant requested another assessment of her disability and it was assessed at 45%.
- As of 1 January 2012, a new law on disability allowances entered into force, introducing additional applicability criteria.
- The applicant submitted several requests for disability allowances or pensions, however, she did not meet the requisite criteria and her requests were dismissed.

title: CASE OF PENCHEVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Applicants are a mother and son from Germany.
- In 2009, they traveled to Germany with the first applicant's husband for a traineeship.
- The father took the child to Bulgaria in 2010 and subjected both applicants to psychological abuse.
- The mother interrupted her training and returned to Bulgaria to seek protection against the father.
- She was granted a restraining order which prevented the father from having contact with the child for a certain period.
- The mother filed for divorce and was granted parental rights due to the father's fault.
- She filed for permission to travel with the child to Germany for a year, which was initially granted.
- The father appealed but lost and the permission was upheld.
- The mother then filed a new request to travel with the child to Germany and other EU countries for three years without the father's consent.
- The request was granted by the Ruse District Court and was not appealed, becoming enforceable.

title: CASE OF DIMITROVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Word of Life is an international religious organisation based in Uppsala, Sweden
- Three non-profit organisations affiliated with Word of Life were registered by the Sofia City Court under the Persons and Family Act, but they were later deleted from the registry of non-profit organizations
- The prosecutor’s office adopted a decision stating that the “sect” had an influence on its followers which increased the risk of suicide and other psychological problems, and therefore ordered the restriction of the right of members from assembling to promote their beliefs and from continuing to operate the Bible study center.
- The police searched the applicant's flat, as she was a member of Word of Life, and seized various items such as audio tapes with religious content, notebooks with sermons, brochures, books, magazines and video tapes.
- The police issued a warning order instructing the applicant not to host further meetings of members of the religious community.
- The Sofia District Court partially allowed the applicant's action and awarded her 25,000 Bulgarian levs. However, on appeal, the Sofia City Court upheld the District Court's findings under the 1988 Act and dismissed the claim for damages.

title: CASE OF COLAC v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant and a third party were indicted for prostitution and unlawful deprivation of liberty involving five underage girls.
- The Iaşi District Court adjourned the proceedings fifteen times due to issues with summoning witnesses who had either left the country or could not be found.
- The court relied on testimonial evidence, including statements from the five girls, minutes of witness confrontations, a search report, lists of telephone calls, medical documents, and statements from the accused.
- The court read out witness statements given at the pre-trial stage but could not hear several witnesses during the trial, including C.R., G.C.R., I.A.P., F.P.D., I.I.C. T.E.P., and M.M.K.
- The Iaşi District Court found the applicant guilty of procurement but acquitted him of unlawful deprivation of freedom. The conviction was based on corroborated evidence, such as witness statements and phone records.
- The applicant appealed the judgment to the Iaşi County Court, which partially upheld his appeal, and then appealed on points of law to the Iaşi Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF COJOCARU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is a journalist and chief editor of a local magazine.
- The applicant wrote an article about the mayor of Paşcani which listed ten points advocating the mayor’s resignation.
- The article contained references to the mayor’s activities and was published in the magazine.
- The mayor lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant for insult and defamation and sought civil damages.
- The court convicted the applicant of defamation and ordered him to pay a criminal fine and compensation to the mayor and publishing company.
- The court noted that a journalist has an obligation to act in good faith and provide accurate and credible information.
- The applicant appealed on points of law but the Iaşi County Court upheld the previous decision.
- The court of appeal confirmed the lower court’s finding and held that the article contained defamatory statements about the mayor.
- The court noted that the applicant had persisted in his criminal behavior despite previous convictions for similar facts.

title: CASE OF KIIVERI v. FINLAND
facts:
- The applicant owns 90% shares in a construction and decoration company.
- The tax authorities accuse the company of tax fraud and off-the-books salaries.
- Tax authorities impose additional taxes and surcharges for tax years 2002, 2003, 2005, and 2006.
- Police investigate the applicant.
- Applicant is charged with accounting offenses and aggravated tax fraud for two counts over several years.
- District Court of Tampere convicts the applicant and orders him to pay the tax authorities EUR 685,080 in compensation and bans him from business for six years.
- The applicant appeals the District Court's judgment to the Court of Appeal of Turku.
- The Court of Appeal upholds the conviction and increases the compensation amount by EUR 20,000.
- The Supreme Court dismisses the part that concerns the tax year 2002 but upholds the lower court's judgment.
- The applicant lodges an extraordinary appeal, which the Supreme Court refuses in March 2013.

title: CASE OF ÖSTERLUND v. FINLAND
facts:
- The applicant had two companies that were subject to a tax inspection in 2004 and 2005.
- The tax authorities imposed additional taxes and tax surcharges on the applicant for the tax years 2000 to 2003 for receiving disguised dividends from the companies.
- The applicant sought rectification from the local Tax Rectification Committee and lodged a material appeal with the Helsinki Administrative Court.
- The Tax Rectification Committee rejected the applicant's applications for rectification concerning the tax years 2002 and 2003.
- The Helsinki Administrative Court cancelled some of the tax surcharges for tax years 2001 to 2003 and quashed the relevant tax decisions, but upheld taxation decisions for tax years 2002 and 2003.
- The applicant appealed against the Administrative Court's decision, but the Supreme Administrative Court refused leave to appeal.
- The public prosecutor brought charges against the applicant for aggravated tax fraud concerning the tax years 2001 to 2003, and the District Court convicted the applicant of aggravated tax fraud, but dismissed the charges as far as they concerned the disguised dividends for lack of proof.
- The applicant appealed to the Turku Appeal Court, which upheld the District Court judgment.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Appeal Court judgment, finding that charges of aggravated tax fraud could be examined even if taxation proceedings became final while criminal proceedings were still pending.

title: CASE OF SANADER v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was accused of participating in a group that shot and killed twenty-two prisoners of war in Petrinja in September 1991.
- The police noted that the applicant was not available for arrest as he lived in an area outside Croatia's effective control.
- The applicant and three others were ordered to be detained and arrest warrants were issued.
- Several witnesses testified about the applicant's brother's involvement in the killings and named one of the accused as a direct perpetrator.
- One witness claimed to have seen the applicant with the group.
- The Sisak County State Attorney's Office requested the accused be tried in absentia.
- The applicant's legal-aid lawyer made no objections to the witness statements during the trial.
- The applicant was convicted and sentenced to twenty years' imprisonment.
- The Supreme Court allowed an appeal and ordered a retrial due to insufficient reasoning.
- The proceedings were adjourned multiple times as the defence lawyer could not be summoned.
- The trial court found the applicant guilty again, based on witness statements and autopsy reports.
- The applicant's legal-aid lawyer lodged another appeal, claiming the judgment lacked sufficient reasoning.
- One of the accused was apprehended and given a retrial in his presence.
- The applicant's conviction became final and an arrest warrant was issued.
- The applicant asked for the proceedings to be reopened and submitted evidence from six people claiming he was not present in Petrinja at the time of the events.
- The Sisak County Court asked Serbian authorities to question witnesses who lived in Serbia and obtained statements that excluded the possibility of the applicant's involvement in the crime.
- The applicant's request for a retrial was dismissed by the Sisak County Court and later the Supreme Court.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court, which was declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF YUDITSKAYA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The five applicants are lawyers from Perm Bar working at Biznes i Pravo law firm.
- The law firm has a reception area, five offices, and a conference room. Each lawyer had his or her own computer, and there was also one computer shared by all lawyers.
- In January 2005, the director of Kirov Perm Factory paid a bribe of 300,000 roubles to a bailiff, T., who in turn asked his brother, lawyer I.T., to sign a fictitious legal assistance contract with the Factory to "legalise" the transaction.
- On 6 May 2005, the Leninskiy District Court of Perm issued a search warrant authorising a search of the "Biznes i Pravo" law firm's premises to seize documents related to the bribery.
- On 16 May 2005, the investigators conducted a search of the applicants' premises and took away all the desktop and laptop computers, copying the entire contents of their hard disks. The computers were returned one week later.
- The applicants appealed against the District Court's decision, arguing that the legal assistance contract had been signed by I.T. in his personal capacity as a lawyer rather than by the "Biznes i Pravo" law firm, and that the search and seizure had violated their attorney-client privilege. However, their appeal was dismissed by the Perm Regional Court on 23 June 2005.

title: CASE OF PODVEZKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976.
- On 29 December 2009, a police investigator charged the applicant with fraudulent appropriation of property and placed him on the list of wanted persons.
- On 27 April 2010, the applicant was arrested and informed of the charges.
- On 29 April 2010, the applicant’s pre-trial detention was ordered by a court.
- On 25 June 2010, the applicant was released under a written undertaking not to abscond.
- In February 2011, the case was referred to the District Court for trial.
- On 4 April 2011, the District Court changed the preventive measure:
- The court considered that the applicant could influence witnesses, conceal or remove traces and evidence of the crime.
- It believed that he could behave negatively and his isolation was necessary.
- On a number of occasions, the applicant requested the District Court to change the preventive measure in his respect and release him.
- On 5 July, 19 August, 23 November 2011 and 17 January 2012, the District Court dismissed the applicant’s requests maintaining the impugned preventive measure.
- The court ordered imprisonment and confiscation of the applicant’s property on 30 January 2012.
- The Kharkiv Regional Court of Appeal and the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court of Ukraine upheld the judgment on 9 April 2013 and 6 February 2014 respectively.

title: CASE OF GUSEVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant is a member of the Animal Protection Society in Vidin.
- On various occasions, the applicant requested access to information from the mayor of Vidin related to animal protection activities.
- The mayor required the third party's explicit written consent to provide the applicant with access to the information requested.
- The Vidin Regional Court allowed the applicant's claims in all three cases.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the Vidin Regional Court's decisions.
- The mayor refused to provide the information requested even after court orders to do so.

title: CASE OF POPOV AND CHONIN v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants are heirs to owners of afforested islands in the Danube, measuring over 1 million square meters in total.
- The land was nationalised in 1948 and the heirs applied for restitution in 1998.
- The Valchedram land commission acknowledged the heirs' right to restitution or compensation, but later legislative changes only allowed for compensation in the form of equivalent State-owned land.
- The Montana district initially allotted land to the heirs, but in 2007 the District Court found it to be inadequate and specified other suitable plots in adjacent districts.
- The Montana Agriculture Department then refused to allot land in Montana and the heirs went to court again, resulting in further suitable plots being identified and allocated in 2013.
- The afforested area referenced in one of the judgments was public property and could not be provided as compensation.

title: CASE OF GÜNAY v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1979 and was detained in Kırıkkale F-type prison at the time of the introduction of the application
- Applicant was arrested by police officers from the anti-terror branch of Istanbul police on April 24, 1999.
- On April 30, 1999, the applicant was taken before a judge who ordered pre-trial detention.
- On May 6, 1999, a bill of indictment was filed against the applicant and two others, charging them with carrying out activities on behalf of the PKK.
- In 2004, the case was transferred to Istanbul Assize Court.
- On May 7, 2007, the applicant was convicted of planning and executing the bombing of a shopping center, causing the death of thirteen innocent people and the injury of numerous persons, and was sentenced to aggravated life imprisonment.
- On May 7, 2009, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment.
- The relevant domestic law and practice in force at the material time can be found in the case of Şefik Demir v. Turkey (dec.), no. 51770/07, §§ 11-15, 16 October 2012.

title: CASE OF ILONA KOVÁCS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Budapest.
- On 1 September 2006, the applicant challenged an administrative decision taken by the Budapest XIV District Mayor’s Office regarding the revocation of her car's registration document.
- On 10 September 2010, the Budapest Regional Court invalidated the administrative decision.
- The administrative proceedings to have the registration document reissued have been dragging on since then.

title: CASE OF NÉMETH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Budapest.
- In March 2003, the applicant sued Budapest IX District Municipality for public information release in a real estate dispute.
- The case went through the Pest Central District Court, the Budapest Regional Court, and the Budapest Court of Appeal.
- The case was suspended on 19 March 2011 because of a preliminary question in another pending procedure.
- The litigation is still pending.

title: CASE OF DOMOKI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Debrecen. 
- Criminal proceedings were conducted against the applicant on charges of fraud. 
- The criminal proceedings lasted from 2000 to 5 July 2010. 
- The proceedings were conducted by the Debrecen District Court, the Hajdú-Bihar County Regional Court, and the Supreme Court. 
- On 5 July 2010, the applicant was acquitted of the charges.

title: CASE OF BALÁZS AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1975, 1975, and 1976, and live in Szigethalom, Budapest, and Budapest, respectively.
- In March 2003, criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicants on charges of blackmailing.
- The Pest Central District Court acquitted the applicants in a decision that became final and binding on 17 February 2012.

title: CASE OF JÁNOS DÁNIEL SZABÓ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Szigethalom.
- Criminal proceedings for disorderly conduct were carried out against the applicant from 13 December 2004 until 4 April 2012.
- The proceedings included a remittal ordered by the Pest County Regional Court.
- The first judgment by the District Court on 29 March 2010 considered lapse of time as a minor mitigating factor.
- The second and final judgment was given by the Regional Court on 4 April 2012, was a simplified decision, and did not contain any considerations about mitigation.

title: CASE OF HELHAL v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and is serving a thirty-year prison sentence for murder, attempted murder, and assault involving a weapon.
- He suffered a fractured spine in March 2006 while attempting to escape from prison.
- He has encountered substantial difficulties due to his physical condition at various prisons throughout his incarceration.
- He applied to have his sentence suspended on medical grounds, citing inadequate facilities and medical care.
- Two experts concluded that his condition was not incompatible with imprisonment, but that he required regular physiotherapy which was not available at his current prison.
- His application for suspension of his sentence was dismissed by the Post-Sentencing Court and the Limoges Court of Appeal.
- The applicant has received various medical treatments, including escorted leaves for consultations, medical appointments, hospital stays, technical assistance from nurses, and psychiatric consultations.
- The applicant has raised concerns about the humiliation he experiences during full body searches and being dependent on a prison orderly for basic needs.
- The applicant has limited access to physiotherapy and has been denied the opportunity to purchase necessary medical equipment.

title: CASE OF M.S. v. CROATIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant had been receiving financial assistance from a social care centre for several years.
- The applicant’s family doctor submitted a medical report to the social care center about her polymorphic health problems.
- The social care center filed a request to divest the applicant of legal capacity in court.
- The request to divest the applicant of legal capacity was withdrawn after the applicant engaged in psychiatric treatment.
- The applicant went to see her family doctor complaining of severe lower-back pain.
- The applicant was hospitalized and diagnosed with acute psychotic disorder, systemic delusional disorder and delusional dysmorphic disorder.
- The applicant was physically restrained and tied to a bed.
- The R. County Court instituted proceedings for the applicant’s involuntary retention and appointed a lawyer.
- The judge visited the applicant on the same day and provisionally extended the applicant’s involuntary retention.
- The court ordered the applicant’s involuntary retention in the hospital until a month later.
- The applicant lodged appeals to the decision of involuntary retention before a three-judge panel of the R. County Court.
- The applicant addressed a handwritten complaint to the hospital’s director and the director of the R. Clinical Hospital Centre.

title: CASE OF DZHABBAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was suspected of involvement in a number of crimes including extortion and kidnapping
- The FSB agents received information indicating that the applicant had beaten someone to death
- The applicant was asked to come to the FSB premises to make a photocopy of his passport
- The applicant was handcuffed and beaten by FSB officers at the FSB premises
- The applicant was examined by a doctor who documented his injuries
- The applicant was transferred to a temporary detention centre and then to remand prison
- The applicant was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to eight years’ imprisonment
- The applicant submitted an appeal against the decision not to institute criminal proceedings in respect of the alleged ill-treatment
- The Military Court upheld the decision not to institute criminal proceedings
- The FSB officers responsible for the belated recording of the applicant’s arrest were subjected to disciplinary sanctions
- The applicant lodged another complaint seeking criminal prosecution of the FSB officers who had subjected him to ill-treatment
- Military investigator K. refused to institute criminal proceedings against the alleged perpetrators
- The first deputy military circuit prosecutor decided to refer the applicant’s complaint for an additional inquiry
- Military investigator K. issued a new decision refusing to institute a criminal investigation into the applicant’s allegations of ill-treatment
- The head of the military investigating unit quashed the decision and ordered a further inquiry into the applicant’s allegations.

title: CASE OF ZHYZITSKYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant, currently serving a prison sentence, is accused of murdering his wife, from whom he was separated, who was found with multiple stab wounds on May 1, 2007.
- The applicant confessed to the murder of his wife during questioning by the police, which was documented as that of a witness, however he later described it as coerced by the police, who allegedly threatened and physically abused him with electric shocks.
- The applicant was examined by medical experts after his confession who found bruises and injuries, which he explained as sustained while working on a construction site, but he later complained to the prosecutor’s office of ill-treatment by the police.
- The prosecution refused on six occasions to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers involved in the alleged ill-treatment of the applicant.
- The applicant was found guilty of his wife's murder and sentenced to 13 years of imprisonment, after which he appealed against the judgment, but the appeal was dismissed.

title: CASE OF KALININ v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1967 and lived in Velikiy Novgorod.
- The applicant was arrested for theft and remanded in custody on 13 April 2011.
- On 31 May 2011, he was additionally charged with more counts of theft and illegal possession of firearms.
- On 24 August 2011, a further 27 counts of theft were added to the charges against him.
- The Valdayskiy District Court of the Novgorod Region found the applicant guilty as charged on 29 September 2011, but the conviction was quashed by the Regional Court on 6 December 2011.
- The applicant's pre-trial detention was ordered multiple times by different courts, and the reasons for detention and alternative preventive measures were not mentioned in the available information.
- The Government acknowledged that the applicant had been detained for 1 year and 5 months without sufficient grounds, and offered to pay him compensation of 2,960 euros.
- The applicant accepted the compensation but pointed out that further extensions of his detention had taken place, and the global duration of his detention amounted to two years seven months and seventeen days.
- The Government refused to amend their declaration to include the entire duration of the applicant's pre-trial detention, citing the applicant's failure to show due diligence in informing the Court about his conviction.

title: CASE OF KOVAL v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lived in Aksay.
- The applicant sued Russian military authorities seeking recovery of pension arrears.
- On 12 August 2004, the Rostov-on-Don Military Circuit Court granted the applicant’s claim and ordered the Military Commission of the Rostov Region to pay the applicant 204,870.78 Russian roubles.
- The respondent military commission issued a payment order but later revoked it and seized the writ of execution due to a check held by a military prosecutor’s office, and no funds were transferred to the applicant’s account.
- The respondent authority sought restoration of the term for challenging the judgment by way of the supervisory review procedure, but the claim was rejected.
- The court confirmed that the writ of execution had been seized during the inquiry and found that no duplicate could be issued as the time-limit for its submission for execution had expired.
- The judgment remained unenforced up to the date of the applicant’s death in 2010.
- The applicant’s widow sought substitution of her late husband in the enforcement proceedings, but the Rostov-on-Don Military Circuit Court rejected her claim.
- The applicant’s widow sought reinstatement of the term for appealing against the decision of 10 August 2012, and the request was granted. 
- The judgment remains unenforced to date.

title: CASE OF HALDIMANN AND OTHERS v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- Four applicants, born in 1953, 1950, 1969, and 1969, reside in different places.
- In 2003, the third applicant, an editor of the Kassensturz television programme, prepared a report on life-insurance products practices, which was based on complaints from viewers and the annual reports of the Private Insurance Ombudsman.
- The applicants recorded a meeting between a customer and an insurance broker using hidden cameras.
- The applicants invited the company to comment on the criticism of the broker's methods and assured them that his face and voice would be disguised and, therefore, not recognizable. Before the program was broadcasted, the broker's face was pixelated, and his voice was distorted.
- The broker brought a civil action seeking an injunction preventing the broadcast from being aired. However, the court dismissed the action, and the program was broadcast with the broker's disguised face and voice.
- The applicants were found guilty of recording the conversations of others and breaching confidentiality or privacy by means of a camera.
- The applicants appealed to the Federal Court based on the right to freedom of expression, but the Court allowed the appeal only on the charge of breaching confidentiality or privacy by means of a camera.
- The Court of Appeal found the applicants guilty of breaching confidentiality or privacy by means of a camera, and they were given suspended penalties of twelve to four day-fines of CHF 350, CHF 200, CHF 100, and CHF 30, respectively, which were slightly reduced from the previous penalties.

title: CASE OF KARAAHMED v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The incident took place on Friday, 20 May 2011, in front of the Banya Bashi Mosque in the centre of Sofia, in which leaders, members and supporters of the Bulgarian political party Ataka clashed with Muslim worshippers who had gathered around the mosque for the regular Friday prayer.
- The case concerns the investigation into that incident.
- The Banya Bashi Mosque was built in 1576 and is currently the only operating mosque in Sofia.
- Ataka is a Bulgarian political party founded in April 2005.
- In 2006, Ataka began a campaign against the noise emanating from the loudspeakers installed on Banya Bashi Mosque.
- On Friday, 29 April 2011, supporters of Ataka mounted loudspeakers on a car and circled close to the mosque, playing recordings of church bells and Christian chants during the regular Friday prayer.
- On Friday, 20 May 2011, worshippers and Ataka supporters clashed, resulting in injuries to police officers, worshippers, and Ms. D. Gadzheva, an Member of Parliament for the party.
- An investigation was opened to determine whether there had been any offences committed under Article 164 § 1 of the Criminal Code (the prohibition on hate speech motivated by religion).

title: CASE OF MIHAYLOVA AND MALINOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Applicants are daughter and mother, born in 2001 and 1980 respectively, residing in Samokov.
- Boris Mihaylov, first applicant's father and second applicant's partner, was a Roma man and a victim of the police action that took place on August 3, 2004.
- KK notified the police about the three men trying to open a parked lorry in the centre of Samokov.
- Two on-duty police officers, Chief Sergeants S and M, received the information and reached the spot while following another call.
- The police car drove towards the lorry, and the men tried to run away, but the police caught up with them.
- During the chase, Chief Sergeant S caught up with Boris Mihaylov, and a fight took place, resulting in two shots being fired, killing Boris Mihaylov.
- An investigation was initiated to determine whether Chief Sergeant S's actions were a disproportionate reaction to the attack.
- An autopsy report confirmed that death was caused by a gunshot from a close range, resulting in severe cerebral trauma and cardiovascular insufficiency.
- The investigation found a handgun, a folding knife, and a mobile phone from the scene but could not determine their ownership.
- Eye witnesses gave inconsistent statements regarding the presence of a warning shot, how many shots were fired, and whether Boris Mihaylov was holding a knife.
- A camera installed above the entrance door of a private security company nearby could have captured the incident, but it was broken or not functioning.

title: CASE OF NUHOVIĆ AND KURTANOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in different years and live in Novi Pazar.
- Ms Fatima Nuhović, late wife and mother of applicants, was employed by the debtor.
- On 13 July 2004, Municipal Court ordered debtor to pay Ms Fatima Nuhović due salary arrears, and later it became both final and enforceable.
- On 3 April 2006, enforcement of the judgment was ordered by the Municipal Court in Novi Pazar to transfer money on Ms Nuhović's request, and judgment became final at an unspecified date.
- Ms Fatima Nuhović passed away on 25 December 2011, and inheritance proceedings were instituted shortly after that.
- On 25 October 2013, the Commercial Court in Kraljevo initiated insolvency proceedings regarding the debtor, and applicants submitted their claim on 5 January 2014, which is still pending.

title: CASE OF TOMOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- All applicants were employed by Raketa-Putnički Saobraćaj AD
- Applicants sought payment of salary arrears and social security contributions
- Final court decisions were obtained by applicants
- Insolvency proceedings were opened on 12 July 2010
- Enforcement proceedings against the debtor were terminated
- Applicants reported their claims to the insolvency administration
- Claims were accepted by the court on 8 June 2011
- Some of the decisions at issue had been partially enforced in the insolvency proceedings
- Insolvency proceedings are still ongoing
- The debtor was privatised on 27 December 2002
- The privatisation was annulled on 17 July 2007
- The State owned 58.18% of shares in the company following annulment
- The State sold its shares to a private company on 11 December 2008.

title: CASE OF GAVOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Čajetina.
- He was employed by Raketa-Putnički Saobraćaj AD, a company based in Užice.
- He sought payment of salary arrears and social security contributions through a civil claim.
- The Municipal Court in Užice ordered the debtor to pay the applicant a certain sum on 10 July 2007.
- Due to non-compliance from the debtor, an enforcement request was submitted.
- Insolvency proceedings were initiated by the Commercial Court in Užice on 12 July 2010, leading to termination of enforcement proceedings.
- The applicant submitted a claim to the insolvency administration and it was accepted by the court on 8 June 2011.
- The decision was partially enforced during insolvency proceedings as of 31 July 2014.
- The debtor was a socially-owned company and was privatised on 27 December 2002.
- Privatisation was annulled on 17 July 2007 due to the buyer's failure to fulfil contractual obligations.
- The State acquired 58.18% shares of the company following the annulment.
- The State sold its shares to a private company on 11 December 2008.
- The insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF LUČIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Karan.
- Applicant was employed by Raketa-Putnički Saobraćaj AD, a company based in Užice.
- The applicant brought three separate civil claims against the company, seeking payment of salary arrears and various social security contributions.
- The Municipal Court in Užice rendered decisions on 31 August 2007 and 19 September 2007, ordering the debtor to pay the applicant certain sums. Both decisions became final on 9 October 2007.
- The applicant submitted an enforcement request due to the debtor's failure to fulfill its obligations from these decisions.
- On 15 May 2009, the Municipal Court in Požega issued an enforcement order to that effect.
- On 23 July 2009, the Municipal Court in Užice rendered a decision in the third set of civil proceedings brought by the applicant ordering the debtor to pay him an additional sum from the outstanding debt. On 2 September 2009 this decision became final.
- Again, due to the debtor's failure to fulfill its obligations from this decision, the applicant submitted an enforcement request.
- On 29 September 2009, the Municipal Court in Požega issued an enforcement order to that effect.
- On 12 July 2010, the Commercial Court in Užice opened insolvency proceedings for the debtor, resulting in the termination of all ongoing enforcement proceedings against the debtor.
- The applicant reported his claim based on the court decisions to the insolvency administration.
- On 8 June 2011, the court accepted the applicant's claim.
- The insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor are still ongoing.
- The debtor, which operated as a socially-owned company, was privatised on 27 December 2002.
- On 17 July 2007, the privatisation was annulled because the buyer in question had failed to fulfil his contractual obligations.
- Following the annulment of the debtor's privatisation, the State owned 58.18% of shares in the company.
- On 11 December 2008, the State sold its shares to a private company.

title: CASE OF CIOBANU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
-Facts relate to the death of Alexandru Ciobanu, who died in a car accident while working as a taxi driver on April 6, 2008. 

-The accident occurred in Hîncești, on a two-way street with a speed limit of 40 k.p.h. and a solid line in the centre of the road indicating no overtaking.

-The victim was driving his Lada and had slowed down, indicated a left turn, and turned to the left when a speeding BMW hit it from behind. The impact was so powerful that the victim’s car was lifted spinning up in the air at a height of several meters and was propelled onto a lamp post on the left side of the road. 

-The grey car driver submits that the victim, whose car had been parked on the right-hand side of the road, had started to turn left without looking out or indicating.

-The police conducted an immediate examination of the scene, and a criminal investigation was initiated the next day.

-The applicant requested a technical forensic investigation to determine various factors, including the speed of the grey car, judging by the damage to both vehicles.

-There were discrepancies between the statements of eyewitnesses and the grey car driver’s version of events.

-Three separate forensic technical investigations were carried out, with varied findings.

-On March 23, 2009, the Hâncești Prosecutor’s Office discontinue the criminal investigation into the circumstances of Alexandru Ciobanu’s death, accepting the grey car driver's version that the victim had been responsible for the accident. The applicant appealed, but her appeal was dismissed.

title: CASE OF PROMO LEX AND OTHERS v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- On 29 January 2009, a person was arrested for protesting peacefully in front of the Prosecutor General’s Office.
- The applicant organisations decided to hold a demonstration in response to this event.
- On 2 February 2009, the first and second applicants lodged a notification with the municipality authorities stating their intention to conduct a demonstration.
- On 3 February 2009, the first and second applicants organised a protest in front of the Prosecutor General's Office, with approximately 20 individuals taking part.
- During the demonstration, the protesters were attacked by six men wearing masks who physically assaulted them and sprayed tear gas and paint over them. The third applicant sustained numerous injuries.
- Four uniformed police officers observed the gathering from the beginning but did not intervene when the clash occurred.
- The organisers lodged a criminal complaint with the Prosecutor General’s Office, and a criminal investigation was initiated. All six attackers were identified, but only two were given suspended sentences.

title: CASE OF ZAICHENKO v. UKRAINE (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant instituted numerous sets of proceedings before domestic courts
- The Dnipropetrovsk Regional Administrative Court received rude letters from the applicant about judges involved in his cases
- The court drew up an administrative offence report stating the applicant was in contempt of court
- The Krasnogvardiyskyy Court ordered an in-patient forensic psychiatric examination of the applicant to establish legal accountability
- The applicant was taken by the police to the Krasnogvardiyskyy District police station for three hours before being taken to the psychiatric hospital
- The psychiatric hospital was unable to conduct the examination due to a lack of collateral history and personality documents
- The applicant appealed the ruling and referred to the statement that it was not amenable to appeal as another indication of its unlawfulness and arbitrariness
- The police were instructed to collect information on the applicant's personality for the psychiatric hospital to establish his mental state
- The local hospital confirmed the applicant had no psychiatric medical history or psychiatric monitoring
- The ruling was appealed and dismissed without examining it on the merits
- The Krasnogvardiyskyy Court ordered a further in-patient forensic psychiatric examination of the applicant, which was later discontinued as time-barred
- The applicant brought administrative and civil claims against the psychiatric hospital and requested a copy of the examination report, both of which were partially allowed
- The applicant also complained to the prosecutor's office about judicial officials and police officers involved in his case, but a criminal investigation was not opened
- The applicant alleged theft of property when he was in the hospital, and the police opened a criminal case in respect of the alleged theft.

title: CASE OF KHALIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts include:

- The applicant is currently detained in Moscow.
- He lived with his family in Uzbekistan until 2011 when his friend was arrested and his apartment was searched.
- The applicant left Uzbekistan and moved to Moscow, where he lost his passport.
- He was charged by Uzbek authorities with attempting to overthrow the constitutional order and membership of a banned radical Islamic organisation.
- The applicant was put on the wanted list and eventually arrested in Moscow in 2013.
- He was detained pending extradition until May 2013, with the detention order being extended until October 2013.
- Uzbekistan submitted an extradition request, including diplomatic assurances of a fair trial and no further charges or handover to a third State without Russian consent.
- The applicant was released after the time-limit for his detention pending extradition expired but was charged with an administrative offense and ordered to be expelled from Russia.
- He sought refugee status citing the risk of torture but his request was rejected.
