- The applicant appealed the rejection but the court found he did not produce sufficient evidence and had applied for asylum only after his arrest.

title: CASE OF PRILUTSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's son participated in a driving game called "AutoQuest" in 2006 and died in a car accident which occurred during the game.
- The police opened an investigation under Article 286 § 3 of the Criminal Code.
- The applicant was admitted to the proceedings as a victim.
- The police refused to institute criminal proceedings against the organizers of the driving game.
- P. was diagnosed with a chronic mental disability which developed after the accident and needed to undergo mandatory psychiatric treatment. 
- The case was remitted for additional pre-trial investigation by the Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal.
- The investigative authorities considered that P. had violated traffic regulations and caused the accident which resulted in the deaths of his three passengers.

title: CASE OF YEVGENIY BOGDANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and lives in the town of Akhtubinsk, in the Astrakhan Region.
- Since 2002 the applicant has been infected with hepatitis C.
- On 20 December 2002, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of knifepoint rape with an accomplice.
- The Town Court remanded him in custody pending trial.
- The court extended the applicant's detention several times until 30 June 2005.
- The court cited the seriousness of the charges and the risk of absconding for extending the detention.
- The investigating authorities unnecessarily extended the investigation, which led to the detention being extended.
- The applicant's cell was overcrowded, unsanitary, and had poor ventilation.
- The cell did not have a lavatory pan, running water, or other basic amenities.
- The applicant and his cellmates had two meals a day of poor quality at 2 p.m. and 6 p.m.

title: CASE OF BARYSHEVSKYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is from Konotop and was born in 1975.
- On 8 January 2009, the Konotop Transport Prosecutor's Office initiated proceedings against him.
- On 9 January 2009, the applicant was arrested and taken to the Konotop Temporary Detention Facility (“the ITT”).
- The Konotop Court extended the applicant's detention for up to ten days on 12 January 2009.
- On 19 January 2009, the Konotop Court ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention for several reasons, including his potential to evade the investigation, the seriousness of his alleged crime, and his health status.
- The applicant was transferred to the Sumy Pre-Trial Detention Centre on 26 January 2009.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decision to keep the applicant detained several times in 2009 and 2010.
- The applicant was found guilty of misappropriation of property and abuse of authority on 23 February 2010 and sentenced to five years and one month of imprisonment. However, the Court of Appeal later quashed this judgment on 18 May 2010 and remitted the case for retrial.
- Various court hearings and appeals followed, and as of 31 March 2014, the case was still pending before the trial court.
- The applicant suffered from various health issues, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, myocardial fibrosis, ventricular dilation, obesity, fatty hepatosis, chronic cholecystitis, and chronic pancreatitis.
- The applicant received medical attention and treatment regularly while in detention. He repeatedly complained about headaches, stomach aches, and other medical issues, and received diagnoses and medication. However, the facility where he was detained did not have specialists in certain areas, and his state of health remained a concern.

title: CASE OF BARSUKOVY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants are from Donetsk and were born in 1938 and 1972 respectively.
- Yaroslav Barsukov, the first applicant’s grandson and the second applicant’s son, died in a road accident on 13 October 2001.
- The police identified the driver (O.F.) and questioned several eyewitnesses.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against O.F. on suspicion of negligence in driving.
- Both applicants were admitted to the proceedings as injured parties.
- The police discontinued the investigation on 26 November 2001, citing a lack of evidence that O.F. was at fault for the accident.
- The Barsukov family complained about the perfunctory investigation, and the case was remitted for further investigation.
- The proceedings were discontinued on several occasions between January 2002 and June 2008 due to insufficient evidence, but these decisions were subsequently overturned by higher authorities.
- The Deputy Minister of the Interior informed the first applicant in May 2005 that an internal investigation into the quality of work in the Donetsk Police Department had been carried out.
- The Donetsk Regional Prosecutor’s Office requested a review of the quality of investigation in Yaroslav Barsukov's case in June 2005 and identified several omissions in the investigation.
- O.F. was indicted in April 2008, and the trial began in June of that year.
- The trial had numerous adjournments or rescheduled hearings due to various reasons, such as witnesses' failure to appear, health-related and other absences of the defendant party, and administrative reasons.
- The court found O.F. guilty of a negligent offense but did not prosecute him further based on the Amnesty Act of 2011.
- The decision was not appealed against.

title: CASE OF S.Z. v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was threatened to be sold as a prostitute by two men during a journey on 19 September 1999.
- The applicant was held against her will for 48 hours, repeatedly beaten and raped by several men.
- A criminal investigation was instituted for abduction, false imprisonment, and rape. Two police officers were identified but not charged.
- The investigation was closed and sent back several times for additional evidence and investigation.
- Seven defendants were committed for trial on charges of false imprisonment, rape, incitement to prostitution, or abduction for the purposes of coercing into prostitution.
- The Blagoevgrad District Court convicted five of the defendants and ordered them to pay the applicant damages.
- The Blagoevgrad Regional Court set aside one conviction and terminated the proceedings against the accused on the grounds that they had become irrevocably time-barred. The classification of the offence for two defendants was amended, and the sentence reduced.
- The Guidelines of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe on eradicating impunity for serious human rights violations require member states to combat impunity through an effective investigation of serious human rights violations.

title: CASE OF DIMITROVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants are the widow and the son of Mr Konstantin Dimitrov Dimitrov, who died in December 2003.
- In 2001, the Sofia regional public prosecutor’s office opened proceedings against the applicants under Chapter Three of the Citizens’ Property Act.
- The proceedings were discontinued in 2002 by a prosecutor from that office.
- New proceedings were opened at an unspecified date seeking the forfeiture of assets allegedly acquired with “unlawful” income.
- The Sofia Regional Court ordered the forfeiture of certain properties valued at approximately USD 40,000.
- Both parties lodged appeals.
- The Sofia Court of Appeal ordered the forfeiture of additional properties valued at approximately USD 286,000.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation refused to accept the appeal for examination.
- The properties were surrendered to the State, and the applicants paid fees, costs, and the value of the remaining forfeited properties to the State budget.
- Tax authorities probed into the income received by the first applicant and her husband between 1997 and 2002, giving decisions in 2004.
- The decision in respect of the first applicant was partly quashed in 2007 by the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF PISAROGLU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and lives in Chișinău.
- The applicant was arrested on July 19, 2010, on charges of trafficking in human beings and held in detention on remand in Prison No. 13 in Chișinău until March 15, 2011.
- The cells were overcrowded, dirty, and cold, with no access to daylight or fresh air, no bedding, very poor quality food, showers only once a week, only cold water, and clothes had to be washed and dried in the cell.
- The Special Rapporteur's report on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment compiled following his visit to Moldova revealed that progress has been achieved in improving detention conditions but some institutions were heavily overcrowded, and poor hygienic conditions and restricted access to health care were common problems.
- The Human Rights Centre in Moldova found that detainees did not receive the minimum daily food requirements and the issuing of items of personal hygiene provided for by Government decision no. 609, and there was a failure to adhere to the statutory cell size in the living blocks of the institution.
- Overcrowding comes directly within the Ombudsman's remit as part of the National Mechanism for the Prevention of Torture, which on many occasions has recognized overcrowding in the country's prisons.
- Overall, prisons in Moldova did not conform to current national and international standards, and budget constraints upon the State did not allow for their reconstruction or renovation.

title: CASE OF M.C. v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of robbery and subsequently charged with three counts of similar offenses. 
- The applicant was additionally charged with the sexual abuse of a minor and with having recorded a pornographic image of the minor. 
- The applicant was detained on remand for a significant length of time. 
- The applicant was convicted of the charges and sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment, a fifteen-year ban on working with minors, and a five-year order preventing the applicant from frequenting any place or institution connected with the care or education of minors. 
- The applicant reported being abused by fellow inmates while in custody, but the staff did not initially take action. 
- An inquiry showed that the applicant had been ill-treated by fellow inmates and that the ill-treatment had been mostly psychological in nature. 
- The inquiry found no shortcomings on the part of prison guards and medical staff. 
- A criminal complaint was filed, but investigations were initially discontinued due to lack of evidence. 
- The applicant filed a private bill of indictment against the alleged perpetrators, but the proceedings were discontinued on various grounds including ne bis in idem and the expiry of the limitation period.

title: CASE OF KOTIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974.
- In 2003, he and his family settled in Germany.
- He held various managerial positions in German companies between 2003 and 2008. He was also a co-owner and the president of a company registered in Ukraine called L.
- On 27 May 2005, the applicant enquired whether certain business activities undertaken by the director of company L. had been lawful.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on 14 April 2008 in connection with a financial fraud allegedly committed by him in April 2005.
- The applicant was put on the national list of wanted persons on 19 April 2008.
- The applicant was arrested on 13 November 2008 when he arrived at the migration service department in Kharkiv to exchange his international travel passport for a new one.
- He was questioned by the investigator in the Shevchenkivskyy District Police Department of Kyiv on 14 November 2008.
- On 4 December 2008, the Kyiv Court of Appeal dismissed the prosecutor’s appeal and upheld the decision of 24 November 2008.
- The applicant challenged before the District Court the investigator’s decisions to initiate criminal proceedings against him on 6 July 2009.
- On 8 December 2011, the investigator closed both sets of criminal proceedings, finding that the charges against the applicant had not been proved and that there had been no corpus delicti.

title: CASE OF Y.Y. v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a transgender person who feels male despite anatomical female sex
- The applicant underwent psychological counseling since childhood
- At the age of 24, the applicant applied for gender reassignment surgery
- The District Court granted confidentiality of proceedings
- The court heard evidence from the applicant's family and medical experts
- The medical committee found that the applicant was transgender and should live with a male identity from a psychological perspective
- The court requested information on the applicant's ability to procreate
- Medical reports found that the applicant had female phenotype but was not permanently unable to procreate
- The District Court refused the applicant's request for gender reassignment surgery on the ground of procreation ability
- The Court of Cassation upheld the District Court judgment
- The applicant lodged a fresh application for gender reassignment surgery
- Medical reports established that gender reassignment was necessary for the applicant's mental health
- The applicant was living as a man and experienced difficulties due to the discrepancy between his gender identity and legal identification
- A committee of psychiatrists authorized gender reassignment surgery
- The Mersin District Court granted the applicant's request for gender reassignment surgery

title: CASE OF HALIL ADEM HASAN v. BULGARIA
facts:
1. The applicant has been sentenced 11 times in criminal proceedings.
2. The applicant is currently serving a life sentence without commutation in Lovech Prison.
3. The applicant brought proceedings seeking compensation for his alleged unlawful detention, which was dismissed by two levels of court.
4. The applicant was detained in Lovech and Varna Prisons, under the “special regime” which involved heightened security and locked cells.
5. The applicant was allowed to use the common toilet and wash his hands three times a day, apart from the daily hourly walk.
6. The cells were not equipped with toilet facilities or taps and wash basins.
7. The Government did not dispute poor hygiene conditions in Varna Prison.
8. The applicant claimed poor quality food and insufficient medical services.
9. The applicant claimed no opportunities for social contact or occupational activities.
10. The lower courts found that the administration of Lovech and Varna Prisons did not unlawfully cause the applicant non-pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF BUJKOVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Sutomore.
- The applicant instituted civil proceedings against the Municipality of Bar concerning a plot of land on 24 April 2000.
- The Court of First Instance ruled partly in favor of the applicant but was quashed by the High Court.
- The applicant filed a request for reopening of proceedings and an appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court on 16 September 2004.
- The proceedings continued with several hearings and judgments until 7 February 2013, when the Supreme Court upheld the Court of First Instance's ruling against the applicant.

title: CASE OF VARGA AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were detained in different prisons in Hungary.
- On December 31, 2013, the prisons in Hungary were overcrowded with an overcrowding rate of 144%.
- Mr Varga was severely overcrowded in Baracska Prison, kept in solitary confinement for 11 days in unsanitary conditions without adequate water and suffering from hygiene problems and skin infections.
- Mr Lakatos was held in a small cell in Hajdú-Bihar County Prison with insufficient privacy offered by a curtain separating the toilet from the living area. He was later transferred to another prison, Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Prison, with no ventilation.
- Mr Tóth was placed in pre-trial detention in a cell with three other detainees, initially in Hajdú-Bihar County Prison and later in Budapest Prison. Both cells offered insufficient privacy with only a curtain separating the toilet from the living area.
- The applicant started serving his sentence at Márianosztra Prison, sharing a cell with 8-10 inmates and having a surface area of 25.7 square meters.
- Mr Fakó was held in Pálhalma Prison with 13 other inmates with gross living space ranging from 1.5 to 2.2 square meters per person. The cell was infested with bugs, lice, and cockroaches.
- Mr Kapczár has been held in 14 different cells with occupancy rates varying from 2.4 to 3 square meters gross living space per inmate. The toilets in those cells were separated from the living area only 18 months ago, and ventilation issues were not resolved.

title: CASE OF WRONA v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking and membership in an organised criminal group on 19 September 2007.
- The Wejherowo District Court remanded the applicant in custody on 21 September 2007.
- The applicant's pre-trial detention was repeatedly extended by various courts until 20 May 2011 when the Gdansk Regional Court lifted the detention and imposed police supervision and a prohibition on leaving the country.
- The court proceedings involved multiple accused and numerous charges of drug trafficking and membership in an organised criminal group, resulting in voluminous documentation and numerous witnesses.
- The court repeatedly justified the detention based on the need to secure proper conduct of the proceedings, the likelihood of a heavy prison sentence, and concerns about tampering with evidence or obstruction of proceedings due to charges of membership in an organised criminal group.
- The applicant served a prison sentence in another set of criminal proceedings between 2008 and 2009.
- The proceedings are ongoing, with the applicant's detention lifted in 2011.
- The applicant filed a complaint about the length of the proceedings and his deprivation of liberty, but the appeal court rejected it for failing to indicate concrete inactivity or deficient activity on the part of the authorities.

title: CASE OF SILIQI AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
- Four applicants born between 1933-1941 reside in Albania and USA respectively.
- The Tirana Restitution and Compensation of Properties Commission recognized applicants' property rights over a plot of land measuring 2,461.97 sq. m and decided to restore the property on 30th December 1994.
- Since a third party had constructed buildings on the land, the Commission ruled for the third party to pay rent for the land or re-purchase the land, and recognized applicants' right to first refusal of the buildings.
- The applicants filed a civil claim with the Tirana District Court on 18th February 1997 seeking annulment of a 1996 sale contract entered between the State and the third party over two plots of lands measuring 197 sq. m and 195 sq. m, and sought the payment of rent by the third party pursuant to the 1993 Property Act.
- On 24th April 2002, the Supreme Court dismissed applicants' claims and their right to first refusal as regards the buildings that were granted by the Commission. It also decided that the applicants are entitled to compensation in regard to the plot of land measuring 2,461.97 sq. m to be determined in accordance with the 1993 Property Act.
- On 22nd October 2004, The Constitutional Court concluded that there has been no violation of the applicants' right to a fair trial.
- To date, no compensation has been paid.

title: CASE OF LYALYAKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was conscripted into the army and sent to Military Units in Kovrov and Volgograd.
- Personal relationships among the servicemen in the unit were tense and violent.
- On 4 June 2007, the applicant and junior sergeant V. ran away from the unit which led to a search operation and their recapture.
- The applicant made another escape attempt during a stopover but was caught and faced harsh treatment including being stripped of his clothes, put in the cargo compartment of a military truck, and made to stand naked in front of other servicemen.
- On 6 June 2007, the battalion commander condemned and reprimanded the applicant and V. with public humiliation.
- The applicant was asked to prepare an explanatory note and was threatened with execution by the commander.
- The applicant was diagnosed with a personality disorder and discharged from the army.
- The complaint of ill-treatment by the applicant and junior sergeant V. was initially dismissed but later challenged and quashed.

title: CASE OF ADŽIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant is from Charlotte, North Carolina.
- The applicant married a Croatian national, K.A., in Sarajevo in 2008.
- K.A. gave birth to their son, N.A., in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2008, and later moved to the United States to join the applicant.
- In 2011, K.A. and their son went on summer holiday to Croatia, but K.A. decided to remain there and file for divorce, seeking custody of their son.
- The applicant requested the Croatian Central Authority to contact K.A. and seek the voluntary return of their son, until an official request could be made under the Hague Convention.
- K.A. agreed to an interview with the local social welfare centre, where she stated that she had been subject to psychological abuse by the applicant, and that she wanted contact between the applicant and their son to be supervised by a child welfare professional.
- The United States Central Authority officially requested the return of the child under the Hague Convention, but K.A. opposed the request, stating that returning to the United States would not be in their son's best interest.
- The court ordered the local social welfare centre to submit a report on K.A. and their son, and the potential effects of returning N.A. to the United States.
- The report found that K.A. was taking adequate care of their son, that he was emotionally attached to his mother, and that separation from her to return to the United States would be traumatic for him.
- The court dismissed the applicant's request for the return of the child, citing potential psychological harm and the ongoing divorce proceedings as factors.
- The applicant appealed the decision, alleging procedural errors and misapplication of the Hague Convention.
- The appeal was allowed, and the case was remitted back to the first-instance court.
- The applicant sought and was granted the withdrawal of the first-instance judge for alleged bias in favour of K.A.
- The applicant requested the review of Skype conversations with his son and a provisional measure to prevent K.A. from removing their son from Croatia.
- The court ordered the local social welfare centre to assess if their son was settled in his new environment.
- The applicant proposed an examination by independent experts, which the court eventually approved.
- The applicant and K.A. both submitted evidence and made statements on various issues, including K.A.'s ability to return to the United States and their son's attachment to his mother.
- The applicant argued that K.A.'s conduct in the proceedings

title: CASE OF KOPANITSYN v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was arrested on suspicion of robbery.
2. The applicant claimed that he was beaten during an interview to extract a confession.
3. The detention of the applicant was authorized and extended multiple times due to the gravity of the charges, the possibility of absconding, and the complexity of the criminal case.
4. The applicant was placed in an overcrowded and unsanitary remand prison for a period of time.
5. The applicant was found guilty and given a custodial sentence.
6. The applicant sent a complaint to the Court through the prison postal service, which was incorrectly sent to the Administration of the President of Russia instead of the Court.
7. The Moscow Prosecutor's Office considered the applicant's allegations unfounded, and the applicant was instructed to await a final decision in his case before complaining to the Court.
8. The applicant sent another complaint to the Court, which was eventually received and examined.
9. The decisions of the lower courts regarding the handling of the applicant's correspondence were upheld on appeal.
10. The applicant later sent letters to his representative while serving his sentence in a correctional colony.

title: CASE OF PUSHCHELENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- All applicants were prosecuted in Russia for various crimes, arrested, and detained pending investigation and trial. 
- Mr Pushchelenko and Mr Isachkov were co-defendants in the same criminal proceedings regarding the murder of Mr G. 
- Mr Fobyanchuk was arrested for his involvement in a number of criminal cases, including murder, attempted murder, and illegal dealing in explosive substances. 
- Mr Kasyanov was also arrested on suspicion of murder and illegal sale of a weapon. 
- Mr Lysenko was charged with multiple crimes, including murder, kidnapping, bribe-taking, and illegal dealing in firearms. 
- The trials of all applicants were pending, and they remained in custody as of the dates of their last letters. 
- The detention orders used stereotyped formulae without addressing specific facts or considering alternative preventive measures. 
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation quashed the judgment of the trial of Mr Pushchelenko and Mr Isachkov on appeal on account of procedural irregularities and ordered a retrial. 
- A previous case, Idalov v. Russia, found a violation of Article 5 § 3 of the Convention on account of the excessive length of the applicant’s detention.

title: CASE OF SERDYUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's son, Eduard Kryvonis, was found dead with numerous injuries on a village street on 13 March 2002.
- Forensic assessment indicated that he died between 2 and 4 a.m. on that date.
- Investigation into the case was ordered by the prosecutor's office on 11 April 2002.
- Several confessions and retractions were made by suspects in the case, including Z. and L. in October 2002, and D. in August 2005.
- Complaints about the protracted nature and various deficiencies of the investigation were made by the applicant on numerous occasions.
- The investigation is still pending as of 2011.

title: CASE OF CHINEZ v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants, three brothers, went to a police station to report a crime but got involved in a dispute with a taxi driver.
- The dispute escalated with the police present, and the applicants were hit and handcuffed.
- At the police station, the applicants were punched and kicked by police officers.
- Medical reports confirmed injuries sustained by the applicants, including electrical burns and haematomas.
- The applicants brought criminal proceedings against the police officers involved, claiming abusive behavior, unlawful arrest, and misconduct.

title: CASE OF TÓTH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and resides in Budakalász.
- The applicant had been employed with a State-owned gambling service provider for over 20 years.
- The applicant’s employment was terminated by mutual agreement on June 29, 2010, with effect from June 30, 2010.
- As part of this agreement, the employer paid the applicant a gross sum of 21,573,086 Hungarian forints (HUF), subject to payroll burdens.
- Following new legislation, the severance payment received by the applicant was taxed at a 98% rate on the portion exceeding HUF 3.5 million.
- Income tax and social security contributions paid earlier were deducted from the tax payable.
- The applicant paid an additional HUF 10,756,341 (around EUR 34,000) in special tax on May 3, 2011.

title: CASE OF KEPECS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1947 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant was employed with a State-owned gambling service provider from 1 October 2003.
- On 28 June 2010, the applicant’s employment was terminated as of 27 October 2010.
- The employer paid the applicant severance payment, subject to payroll burdens, which consisted of payment for unused annual leave and an additional two months’ salary.
- Under new legislation, the severance payment was subsequently taxed at a 98% rate in its part exceeding 3.5 million Hungarian forints (HUF).
- The income tax and social security contributions already paid were deducted from the tax payable.
- The applicant paid an additional HUF 3,588,701 (approximately 11,300 euros (EUR)) in special tax on 17 May 2011.

title: CASE OF MACHER v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Budapest.
- On 17 August 2009 the applicant was appointed as deputy general manager of a State-owned company limited by shares.
- The applicant’s employment was terminated by mutual agreement as of 30 August 2010.
- Under this agreement the applicant received severance payment, subject to payroll burdens.
- The severance payment was subsequently taxed at a 98% rate in its part exceeding 3.5 million Hungarian forints (HUF).
- The income tax and social security contributions already paid were deducted from the tax payable.
- Thus, the applicant paid an additional HUF 1,492,898 in special tax on 5 September 2011.

title: CASE OF MESTER AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- 5 individuals are involved in the case
- They were born between 1953 and 1980 
- They were employed as civil servants in government ministries/state-owned companies 
- Their employment was terminated between 2010 and 2014 
- They received severance payments ranging from HUF 2,500,000 to HUF 25,900,000 
- The severance payments were subject to a 98% tax rate for the part exceeding HUF 3.5 million 
- The four individuals had to pay additional tax, ranging from HUF 1,400,000 to HUF 11,100,000 after the new legislation was introduced.

title: CASE OF PATARICZA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Budapest. 
- On July 1, 2003, the applicant was appointed as the managing director of a state-owned company. 
- On September 15, 2010, his employment was terminated, and he received a severance payment of HUF 13,294,125 (approximately EUR 42,000). 
- A new legislation subjected the severance payment to a 98% tax rate on amounts exceeding HUF 2 million. 
- The applicant paid an additional HUF 5,365,275 (approximately EUR 16,800) in tax on May 3, 2011.

title: CASE OF IGNATESCU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Domestic courts delivered decisions to applicants on specific dates.
- Decisions entitled the applicants to receive pecuniary amounts and/or have certain actions taken by State authorities in their favour.
- The applicants were unable to obtain enforcement of the decisions in due time.

title: CASE OF VLAD AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Domestic courts made decisions in favor of the applicants.
- The decisions included payment of pecuniary amounts and/or certain actions to be taken by State authorities.
- The applicants were unable to enforce the decisions within a reasonable time. 
- A table is included in the appendix with the relevant dates.

title: CASE OF KOLAKOVIC v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on 8 September 2009, and 15 kg of cannabis was found in a hotel room where he was arrested.
- He and several other suspects were charged with drug trafficking and possession.
- Bail requests were made but repeatedly rejected by the courts.
- The applicant lodged constitutional redress proceedings, complaining of a violation of his rights under Article 5 § 3 of the Convention.
- The Constitutional Court found a breach of his rights under Article 5 § 3, but did not order release or take other action.
- The bail deposit was eventually reduced to EUR 5,000.
- The applicant made various requests to alter the conditions of his bail, including permission to return to the UK to see his family, but they were denied due to the lack of financial guarantees. 
- Numerous hearings were held between September 2009 and July 2010, during which evidence was produced, witnesses gave statements, and experts were appointed.

title: CASE OF KULIK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant arrested on suspicion of stealing cucumbers and for an administrative offence.
- After arrest, applicant alleges beatings and false confession by police.
- Hospital records show numerous bruises on applicant's body, concussion, and possible nose fracture.
- Another suspect complains of ill-treatment and noise on the same day at the police department.
- Applicant seeks medical treatment, further medical examinations show medium severity injuries.
- Prosecutor initially declines to open criminal proceedings but later orders further pre-investigation enquiries.
- Criminal proceedings against the theft of cucumbers end, but prosecution examines alleged ill-treatment case.
- Investigations are repeatedly suspended due to lack of identification of perpetrators until 2009 when disciplinary proceedings instituted against investigators.

title: CASE OF GALLARDO SANCHEZ v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant, Mr Manuel Rogelio Gallardo Sanchez, is a Venezuelan national who lives in Cape Town (South Africa).
- On 19 April 2005, the applicant was taken into custody by the Rome police pending extradition by the Greek authorities who accused him of arson.
- The arrest was made on the basis of an arrest warrant issued by the Athens Court of Appeal on 26 January 2005 under the European Convention on Extradition of 13 December 1957.
- On 9 June 2005, the Ministry of Justice received the Greek authorities' request for extradition, which was accompanied by all the required documents.
- The extradition hearing was scheduled for 15 December 2005 but was postponed at the request of the applicant's representative to 12 January 2006.
- The Court of Appeal approved the extradition by a decision of 12 January 2006, deposited on 30 January 2006, without any prior investigation.
- On 3 March 2006, the applicant appealed on points of law, arguing that the request for his extradition was sent by the Greek authorities after the forty-day time-limit provided for in Article 16 § 4 of the European Convention on Extradition and that the charges laid against him were not based on serious indications of guilt.
- In a judgment of 11 May 2006, deposited with the registry on 18 September 2006, the Court of Cassation dismissed the appeal.
- On 9 October 2006, the Minister of Justice signed the extradition order, and on 26 October 2006, the applicant was extradited to Greece.
- The document includes relevant provisions of the European Convention on Extradition, namely Articles 8, 9, 12, and 16.

title: CASE OF STETTNER v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a surgeon who started kidney-transplant operations at Hospital no. 4 in Lublin.
- In 1998, the applicant was diagnosed with sleep apnoea.
- On 1 June 2006, the applicant was violently arrested by five armed plain-clothes police officers and charged with ten counts of accepting material benefits from patients.
- The applicant was remanded in custody until 1 September 2006 and then until 1 December 2006.
- The applicant's continued detention was upheld due to the reasonable suspicion of crime, the severity of the potential penalty, and the need to secure the proper conduct of the proceedings. The court found that non-custodial measures would not have been sufficient.

title: CASE OF POP AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants were born between 1953 and 1974 and lived in Baia Mare.
- The applicants' telephone conversations were secretly monitored by the Cluj Military Security Department on suspicion of their involvement in a Schengen visa trafficking network.
- The first two applicants were army officers and the last two were civilians.
- The applicants were questioned and detained without being charged or assisted by legal representation.
- Criminal investigations and charges were brought against the applicants.
- The first-instance court convicted the applicants of complicity in bribery and aiding an offender and sentenced them to prison terms.
- The convictions were quashed on appeal and a retrial was ordered.
- The domestic authorities failed to meet the formal requirements for the secret monitoring of the applicants' telephone conversations.
- The fourth applicant argued that no criminal investigation had been opened against him.
- The Military Court of Appeal dismissed the applicants' appeal and upheld the convictions.
- The fourth applicant appealed on points of law.

title: CASE OF ASSOCIATION FOR THE DEFENCE OF HUMAN RIGHTS IN ROMANIA – HELSINKI COMMITTEE ON BEHALF OF IONEL GARCEA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Mr Ionel Garcea was born in 1973 and died on 19 July 2007 in Rahova prison hospital. He had no known relatives.
- At the material time, Mr Garcea was serving a seven-year sentence for a rape which he had consistently denied having committed. On the date of the criminal conviction, the courts found that he had full legal capacity (discernământ) and was thus capable of taking decisions and acting freely upon them.
- Mr Garcea was held in Jilava and Rahova prisons and prison hospitals. He was diagnosed with epilepsy, personality disorder (impulsive and explosive), polymorphic psychosis and phlebitis of both legs.
- In 2002, when he started serving his sentence, Mr Garcea contacted APADOR‑CH from the police headquarters to inform them of his arrest.
- Mr Garcea received regular check-ups for his mental illness. He was admitted on ten occasions to the psychiatric ward of the prison hospitals for a few days each time.
- On 4 August 2004 Mr Garcea inserted a nail in his forehead. On 9 August he was taken to the psychiatric ward of Jilava prison hospital and then to a civilian hospital. The nail was ultimately removed and on 13 August 2004 he was discharged from the civilian hospital and sent back to the psychiatric ward of Jilava prison hospital.
- In May 2005, after a week’s stay in Rahova prison hospital where, according to the medical record, he did not receive any treatment for his phlebitis, Mr Garcea was transferred to Rahova Prison.
- In June 2005 Mr Garcea was operated on in a civilian hospital in order to have metal fragments removed from his head (pieces of nails which he had inserted into his forehead).
- Mr Garcea alleged that, in August 2004, he had been beaten up by the prison intervention force and then handcuffed and chained to a hospital bed for two weeks.
- In August 2005, members of the APADOR-CH paid Mr Garcea another visit. He complained to them that he had been beaten up on several occasions by the warders.
- In June 2007, while he was being held in Jilava hospital, Mr Garcea inserted another nail into his forehead. On 7 June 2007 he was operated on in a civilian hospital. He was then sent to the Rahova prison hospital with a diagnosis of sepsis, post-extraction symptoms and

title: CASE OF SÜLEYMAN DEMİR AND HASAN DEMİR v. TURKEY
facts:
- Two applicants, a father and son, from Hakkari were involved in the case
- On 17 July 2007, the first applicant was taken to the Çukurca Gendarmerie Station where he was subjected to ill-treatment by officers M.C. and İ.D.
- The officers accused the first applicant of providing support to the PKK and making propaganda for a political party, the DTP. They attached a hand grenade to his face using box tape, forced an object into his nose and mouth, and threatened to gouge out his eyes.
- The ill-treatment and accusations continued for approximately one hour with accompanying threats to kill him and his family members.
- After his release, the first applicant was examined at a hospital in the nearby town of Çukurca where a report was drawn up setting out his injuries.
- On 18 July 2007, the first applicant filed a criminal complaint with the local prosecutor, alleging that he had been beaten and threatened at the Çukurca Gendarmerie Station.
- Criminal proceedings were brought against the officers İ.D. and M.C. and those proceedings are still pending.
- A medical report issued at Çukurca Hospital recorded the first applicant’s injuries.
- Following several referrals, criminal proceedings were instigated before the Van Military Court against İ.D. and M.C.
- Witnesses testified on the incident and its aftermath, including the second applicant, a village guard, and a headman.
- A medical expert stated that it was not possible to establish the cause of the injuries.
- The case was referred back and forth between different courts, with the proceedings still ongoing.

title: CASE OF MILENA FELICIA DUMITRESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint against I.L. for aggravated theft, rape and unlawful deprivation of liberty.
- The applicant presented a medical certificate showing physical violence.
- I.L. was arrested and remanded in custody.
- Witnesses were heard to support the applicant's allegations.
- The prosecutor's office decided to discontinue the criminal proceedings against I.L. but remitted the case for additional investigation concerning the offence of bodily injury.
- The investigation into the allegation of rape was discontinued.
- The court dismissed the criminal complaint due to the expiration of the limitation period.

title: CASE OF ZAIEŢ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Săvârșin. 
- She was adopted on 25 February 1972, at the age of seventeen. 
- The applicant’s adoptive mother also had another adopted daughter, H.M. The applicant’s mother died in 1986. 
- In 2003, the two sisters were jointly granted title to ten hectares of forest, based on their entitlement through adoption to inherit land which had been expropriated from their grandmother. 
- Subsequently, the applicant brought an action for division of the land between the sisters. 
- H.M. brought an action for annulment of the applicant’s adoption, claiming that the main aim pursued by her adoptive mother when she had sought to adopt the applicant had been to ensure emotional and financial support for her in old age and help with everyday activities. 
- The applicant's lawyer argued that H.M. did not prove a legitimate and current interest in seeking the annulment of her sister’s adoption. 
- On 7 December 2004, the Suceava County Court declared the applicant’s adoption void, stating that it had not had a purpose envisioned by the Family Code. 
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law, but the judgment of the court of first instance was upheld by the Suceava Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF GAMBULATOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the mother of Mr Vakhit Gambulatov, who was born in 1976.
- Mr Vakhit Gambulatov and Mr Ramzan S. were arrested on 28 June 2001.
- The applicant spent every day next to the military commander’s office waiting for her son’s release.
- The applicant's son was not released and was transferred elsewhere.
- The applicant has had no news of her son since.
- The investigation into the whereabouts of the applicant’s son is still pending.

title: CASE OF ZHEBRAILOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Three applicants: Ms Isita Zhebrailova, Mr Shuddi Vakhayev, and Mr Salavdi Zhebrailov
- Ms. Zhebrailova and Mr. Vakhayev are parents of Mr. Balavdi Zhebrailov, and Mr. Salavdi Zhebrailov is Mr. Balavdi Zhebrailov's brother.
- On 25 April 2005, a group of four armed men, believed to be law enforcement officers, abducted Mr. Balavdi Zhebrailov and Mr. Salavdi Zhebrailov from the applicants' property in Gekhi.
- The Zhebrailov brothers were physically assaulted and taken to the premises of the 2nd Regiment of the Road Police of the Ministry of the Interior of the Chechen Republic.
- The third applicant was beaten and released in the vicinity of the "northern market" in Grozny on 26 April 2005.
- The applicants have had no news of Mr. Balavdi Zhebrailov since his abduction.
- The investigation in case no. 47041, which was opened to look into the events of 26 April 2005, is still ongoing.
- Several supervising prosecutors pointed out the investigators' failure to inspect the premises of the 2nd regiment and verify the involvement of its officers in the crime.
- The investigators re-interviewed several individuals, including eyewitnesses and residents of Gekhi.
- The investigation in case no. 47041 was suspended several times but was ordered to be resumed by supervising prosecutors.

title: CASE OF VOLKOV AND ADAMSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were targeted in undercover operations conducted by the police for distribution of counterfeit software under sections 7 and 8 of the Operational-Search Activities Act of 12 August 1995 (no. 144-FZ).
- Applicant Mr. Volkov agreed to perform computer repairs and installed software on an undercover police officer’s computer for 3,300 roubles.
- Mr. Volkov was charged with copyright infringement and found guilty with a suspended sentence of one year and three months’ imprisonment with one year’s probation.
- Mr. Volkov’s appeal was dismissed and his conviction was upheld.
- Applicant Mr. Adamskiy was asked to install several computer programmes by an undercover police officer and downloaded several unlicensed programmes from the internet.
- Mr. Adamskiy was charged with copyright infringement and found guilty with a suspended sentence of one year and six months’ imprisonment with one year’s probation.
- Mr. Adamskiy’s conviction was upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF ÖNER AND TÜRK v. TURKEY
facts:
- Senanik Öner and Ferhan Türk were born in 1952 and 1951, respectively, and live in Diyarbakır.
- On 21 March 2007, both attended Newroz celebrations in Kızıltepe and made speeches about the problems of Kurdish people.
- The applicants were charged with disseminating terrorist propaganda of an illegal organization, the PKK.
- On 15 April 2008, the Diyarbakır Assize Court sentenced them to one year and eight months’ imprisonment.
- On 28 December 2011, the Court of Cassation upheld the first-instance court’s judgment.
- The Diyarbakır Assize Court revised its judgment on 12 October 2012, following an amendment to the law, and suspended their sentence.

title: CASE OF DAVTYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant worked as the executive director of the Credit Service Bank from 1997 to 1999.
- The prosecutor instituted criminal proceedings against the former management of the Bank for embezzlement of funds entrusted to it in June 2001 by another company.
- The applicant was arrested and charged with embezzlement through abuse of his official capacity and official falsification as the executive director of the Bank causing damage to the Bank and its clients.
- The applicant was placed in pre-trial detention for a period of two months and his detention was subsequently extended.
- The applicant was found guilty under Article 179 § 3 (1) and Article 325 § 1 of the new CC and sentenced to six years’ imprisonment without confiscation of property.
- The applicant suffered from various medical issues, including a throat tumour, asthma, Quincke's oedema, and allergies, while in detention.
- The applicant's lawyers filed applications for his release on health grounds, but the Court of Appeal postponed the examination of the requests in order to establish certain essential circumstances.

title: CASE OF NALBANDYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
1. The applicants were born in 1961, 1964, and 1988 respectively.
2. The first and second applicants were serving prison sentences during the submission of their application.
3. The third applicant lived in Vardenis, Armenia.
4. The first and second applicants were married and the third applicant was their daughter.
5. Criminal proceedings were instituted on 8 June 2004 against the first applicant for murder.
6. The first applicant was unlawfully kept without his arrest being formally recorded and was beaten by police officers to confess.
7. The first applicant was found guilty of disobeying lawful orders of police officers and sentenced to 15 days’ imprisonment.
8. The second and third applicants were also pressured and coerced to confess to the murder or to incriminate each other.
9. A complaint was filed by the second applicant and others alleging that the first applicant had been unlawfully detained and that the applicants’ family had been terrorized by the local law-enforcement officers.
10. The second applicant was invited to the Vardenis Police Department where she was beaten and forced to testify against the first applicant.
11. The third applicant was humiliated by the police officers, threatened with rape and pressured to admit to involvement in the murder.
12. On 9 July 2004, the first and second applicants were formally arrested in connection with the murder and refused the services of a lawyer.
13. The second applicant participated in an investigative measure at the scene of the crime on 10 July 2004.
14. A confrontation was held between the second and third applicants, during which the second applicant admitted to committing the murder and stating that the third applicant had helped her dispose of the body.
15. The third applicant underwent a medical examination and was found to have been beaten.
16. The criminal proceedings in their part concerning the third applicant were terminated for lack of evidence of her involvement in the crime.
17. The first and second applicants were found guilty of murder and sentenced to nine and fourteen years’ imprisonment, respectively.
18. Lawyer S. lodged an appeal arguing that the applicants had been deprived of effective legal assistance and their conviction was based on coerced confession statements.
19. The examination of the case commenced at the Criminal and Military Court of Appeal but the hearings were conducted in an atmosphere of constant disorder, including threats and physical abuse towards the applicants' relatives and their lawyers.
20. A scuffle broke out between the victim’s and the applicants’ relatives at a hearing on 22 June

title: CASE OF HELSINKI COMMITTEE OF ARMENIA v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant organisation is a non-governmental human rights organisation based in Yerevan.
- On 12 May 2007 a third person, L.G., who was apparently a witness in a murder investigation, died while at a police station.
- On 19 February 2008, a presidential election was held in Armenia, which was followed by mass post-election rallies and protests and an intense standoff between the authorities and the supporters of the opposition, resulting in clashes and at least ten persons being killed.
- On 1 March 2008, a state of emergency was declared by the President of Armenia for a period of 20 days, during which all public assemblies were banned.
- On 6 May 2008, the applicant organisation applied to the Mayor of Yerevan, notifying its intention to hold a mourning march on the first anniversary of L.G.’s death.
- On 8 May 2008, the Mayor decided to ban the planned event, with reference to Sections 9 § 4 (3) and 13 § 1 (3) of the Assemblies, Rallies, Marches and Demonstrations Act (“the Act”).
- By a letter of 12 May 2008, this decision was posted to the applicant organisation. On the same date the police prevented the organisers from holding the planned event.
- On 13 May 2008, the applicant organisation received the letter of 12 May 2008.

title: CASE OF RIBIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Zagreb.
- On 25 April 1992, the applicant married Z.J.
- On 9 October 1993, Z.J. gave birth to their son, I.R.
- In December 1993, Z.J. moved out with their son and avoided contact with the applicant.
- On 19 February 1996, Z.J. sought divorce, custody and maintenance for their son.
- The applicant ignored local social welfare center's calls to attend interviews necessary for the preparation of a report.
- On 7 July 1997, the proceedings were suspended for three months to reach an amicable solution.
- The hearing scheduled on 20 April 1998 was adjourned because the applicant didn't attend it.
- On 26 February 2000, the applicant met with his son for the first time after Easter of 1995, and reached an agreement with Z.J. regarding contact schedule.
- On 26 October 2001, the court dissolved the marriage, awarded custody to Z.J., and granted access rights to the applicant.
- The case was remitted by the Zagreb County Court on 12 February 2002.
- On 23 July 2004, the court again granted the applicant access rights and issued a detailed contact schedule.
- Z.J. obstructed the exercise of access rights, and the applicant applied for enforcement of the judgment on 12 May 2005.
- On 30 November 2006, the court issued a writ of execution, but it was discontinued on 14 February 2007 due to the applicant's failure to advance the costs.
- The applicant applied for enforcement of the judgment again on 23 April 2007.

title: CASE OF IREZIYEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are 3 brothers: Salambek, Imaddi, and Sidyk Ireziyev
- In May 2002, Salambek's brother Aslan, along with Their nephew Khaseyn Suleymanov, were taken in two APCs and a UAZ car by masked men speaking unaccented Russian.
-The Applicants followed the tracks of the vehicles to the Avtury collective farm and were informed that Aslan had been taken to the Main Federal Military Base in Khankala.
-Mr Khaseyn Suleymanov was later released, but Aslan has not been seen since the abduction.
-The Criminal investigation is still pending.

title: CASE OF ORLOVSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and detained in Odessa.
- On an unspecified date in 2006, K. confessed that the applicant had participated in the murder of Z. in 2002.
- On 28 July 2006, the applicant was arrested by police who also seized his car.
- Explosives were found in the car during police search on 30 July 2006.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted on August 1, 2006, for the illegal possession of explosives and the murder of Z.
- On August 4, 2006, the applicant was remanded in custody for ten days.
- On August 10, 2006, the applicant was formally charged with possessing illegal explosives and taking part in the murder.
- On August 11, 2006, the applicant was remanded for two months by the Kyivskiy Court.
- The court noted that the gravity of the charges against the applicant constituted a sufficient basis for the fear that he would abscond or interfere with the investigation if released.
- The applicant appealed against the detention order.
- On 17 August 2006, the Odessa Court of Appeal rejected the applicant’s appeal.
- The court noted the gravity of the charges and the fact that the investigative authority was located in Odessa whereas the applicant resided in Crimea.
- On 23 February 2007, the applicant lodged an objection against the investigative authority’s request to extend his detention.
- On 26 February 2007, the Odessa Court of Appeal allowed the investigative authority’s request and extended the applicant’s detention.
- On 18 December 2007, the applicant was indicted on charges of participation in an armed gang(Banditry).
- On 14 August 2008, the applicant objected against the investigative authority’s request to extend his detention.
- On 16 December 2008, the Kyiv Court of Appeal further extended the applicant’s detention until 19 February 2009.
- On 18 March 2009, the Odessa Court of Appeal held a preparatory hearing and rejected the applicant’s request for release.
- On 15 June 2011 and 18 October 2011, the applicant’s requests for release were rejected by the Odessa Court of Appeal.
- The applicant was found guilty on October 18, 2011, and was sentenced to fourteen years’ imprisonment with confiscation of his property.
- The applicant was denied the possibility of meeting or corresponding with his family

title: CASE OF KIRPICHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lived in Donetsk.
- On 28 January 2003, the applicant sustained two knife cuts, which were allegedly inflicted by two strangers.
- On 29 January 2003, the applicant was arrested at his home by three police officers and taken to the Proletarskiy District Police Station in Donetsk for questioning in connection with a murder of L.S., an adolescent girl.
- The applicant was appointed legal-aid lawyer O., who advised him to remain silent and left him alone during the actual questioning.
- The applicant refused to make any statement concerning the offence of which he was suspected during questioning.
- The applicant complained of being tortured by the police officers before and after being brought to the police station. He alleged that they had used methods such as putting plastic bags filled with cigarette smoke over his head, twisting his fingers, stepping on his hands, beating him, punching him while pressing a book against his body, and suspending him handcuffed face down between two desks.
- On the same day, an ambulance team was called to provide the applicant with medical assistance for his wounds.
- On 30 January 2003, the applicant complained to the District Prosecutor’s Office of having been tortured by the police officers.
- On 31 January 2003, the Proletarskiy District Court ordered the applicant’s detention for ten days pending the investigation against him.
- On 3 February 2003, the District Prosecutor’s Office refused to institute criminal proceedings regarding the applicant’s allegations of ill‑treatment by the police.
- The applicant complained to various authorities about being held in a cell with an inmate suffering from tuberculosis before his transfer to the SIZO.
- In March 2003, investigator A.D. of the District Prosecutor’s Office, who was investigating L.S.’s murder and the theft from her flat, organized a confrontation between the applicant and several police officers implicated by him in his ill-treatment.
- On 4 April 2003, the SIZO neurologist diagnosed the applicant as suffering from post-traumatic neuritis of the peroneal nerve.
- On 22 April 2003, the District Prosecutor’s Office again refused to institute criminal proceedings regarding the applicant’s allegations of ill‑treatment by the police.
- In May 2003, while the applicant was studying his criminal case file, investigator A.D. hit him in the face.
- On 16 May 2003, police officer V.D., who was

title: CASE OF SOLOMUN v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and worked as a police officer in Sisak.
- He was assigned to a post in the Dvor Police Station in 1998, and Dvor was an area receiving special state support, entitling employees to a special salary uplift.
- In 2000, amendments were made to the Special State Support Act, which only guaranteed the special salary bonus to those who both lived and had their registered domicile in an area receiving special state support.
- The applicant was assigned to a post in Sisak in May 2001.
- The applicant brought an action against the state seeking payment of a salary bonus on 29 September 2000.
- The Sisak State Attorney’s Office objected to the Hrvatska Kostajnica Municipal Court’s territorial jurisdiction.
- The applicant claimed to have lived in Majur, within an area receiving special state support, and had authorization to use a police car during his tenure in Dvor.
- The Hrvatska Kostajnica Municipal Court accepted the applicant’s civil action in 2003 and ordered the state to pay compensation for his special salary bonus.
- The Sisak State Attorney’s Office appealed the decision, but the Sisak County Court upheld the first-instance judgment.
- Enforcement proceedings were opened against the state, and the judgment was fully enforced in 2004.
- In 2005, the request for the protection of legality was approved, and the case was remitted to the Sisak County Court.
- The Sisak County Court accepted the Sisak Municipal State Attorney’s Office appeal in 2006, reversing the first-instance judgment and ordering the applicant to repay the amount received from the state.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint against the Sisak County Court’s decision in 2010.
- The applicant repaid the total amount of HRK 28,700 back to the state in 2013, pursuant to the proceedings.

title: CASE OF PAVLOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1959, 1950, and 1952, respectively, and live in Brestovec Orehovički and Krapina, respectively.
- I. Ku., the applicants’ predecessor, filed a civil action against M.K. in 1990 in the Zagreb Municipal Court seeking his eviction from a flat and reimbursement of the costs of the proceedings.
- The applicants took over the proceedings as plaintiffs in 2001 after I. Ku.'s death, while M. K. also died during the proceedings and was replaced by I. Kr. as the defendant.
- I. Kr. brought a counterclaim against the applicants, seeking either a specially protected tenancy of the flat at issue or compensation for investments in the flat he had made in the amount of HRK 95,000.
- The Zagreb Municipal Court allowed the applicants' action in part on June 12, 2007, ordering the eviction of I. Kr. from the flat while dismissing the remainder of their civil action and I. Kr.’s counterclaim for compensation of the investments in the flat. Each party was ordered to bear their own costs.
- The Zagreb Municipal Court dismissed I. Kr.’s civil action for a specially protected tenancy in a supplementary judgment on 10 October 2008.
- The appeals by both parties to the Zagreb County Court challenging the first-instance judgment of the Zagreb Municipal Court were dismissed on February 2, 2010. As regards the applicants’ arguments concerning the costs of proceedings, the Zagreb County Court noted that they failed to set out the request for reimbursement of costs.
- The applicants challenged the Zagreb County Court's judgment with a constitutional complaint on April 14, 2010.
- The Constitutional Court declared the applicants’ constitutional complaint inadmissible on September 23, 2010, on the grounds that the contested judgment was not susceptible to constitutional review as it did not concern the merits of their civil rights or obligations.

title: CASE OF CESTARO v. ITALY
facts:
Facts in bullet points:

- The applicant is from Rome and was born in 1939.
- The G8 Summit was held in Genoa on July 19-21, 2001.
- The Genoa Social Forum (GSF) was a coordinating group formed by non-governmental organizations to organize an "anti-globalization" Summit in Genoa during the same dates as the G8.
- Such demonstrations have been organized since the meeting of the World Trade Organization in Seattle in November 1999.
- Law No. 349 of 8 June 2000 assigned the task of organizing the preliminary meetings and the Final Summit of the Heads of State and Government scheduled for July 2001 to a plenipotentiary body set up within the Prime Minister’s Office.
- Substantial security measures were put in place in Genoa.
- Different groups were expected to take part in the demonstrations depending on the danger they posed.
- Disorder occurred during the evening of July 19, 2001.
- Several demonstrations took place on July 20, with disorder occurring throughout the day.
- The Diaz-Pascoli School accommodated a press unit and temporary lawyers' offices, while the Diaz-Pertini School housed an Internet access point and was used as a night accommodation center for demonstrators.
- Young people dressed in black had gone into the Diaz-Pertini School and taken material from the site linked to the ongoing works in the school, according to residents in the area who reported to the police.
- On the evening of July 21, 2001, police conducted a search of the Diaz-Pertini School in order to secure evidence and possibly arrest the Black Bloc members responsible for unlawful damage.
- The police unit that broke into the school violently assaulted the occupants, causing injuries and damage.
- Journalists filming events inside and outside the Diaz-Pertini School were forced to stop filming and broadcasting, and their equipment was seized.
- The ninety-three persons occupying the school were arrested and charged with conspiracy to commit unlawful damage and destruction.

title: CASE OF RAGUŽ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1940 and lives in Dubrovnik.
- On 18 February 2003, the Municipal Court ordered V.T. to pay the applicant 2,500 Euros plus interest on account of debt and 187,750 Serbian dinars for the costs of the civil proceedings.
- On 23 August 2003, the District Court reduced the award in respect of costs to RSD 97,250 and upheld the first-instance judgment for the remainder.
- The judgment became final on 5 September 2003.
- On 23 October 2003, the Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the judgment by seizure and sale of the debtor's movable assets.
- On 21 December 2004, the Municipal Court informed the applicant that the enforcement was impossible due to the debtor's indigence.
- On 11 October 2007, the Municipal Court stayed the enforcement proceedings because of the debtor's death.
- On 20 June 2008, the Municipal Court rejected the applicant's request to continue the enforcement proceedings.
- On 16 April 2009, the Municipal Court invited the applicant to provide the names and addresses of proposed debtors, indicate the debtor's heirs, propose the means of enforcement and details and proof of ownership concerning immovable assets, all within three days, failing which his request would be rejected.
- On 27 August 2009, the Municipal Court rejected the applicant's request for continuation of the enforcement proceedings because of his failure to abide by the orders. 
- According to the Government, there are eight heirs of the deceased debtor, the names and addresses of which have been known.

title: CASE OF VERETCO v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on 28 November 2012 and charged with child trafficking.
- He was accused of recruiting and travelling with four minors to Ukraine for agricultural work.
- The prosecutor applied for the applicant’s detention in custody on 30 November 2012, citing the risk of absconding, interference with the investigation, and reoffending.
- The Centru District Court issued an arrest warrant for thirty days’ custody on the same day, rejecting the applicant’s request for access to supporting evidence attached to the request for detention and his medical records.
- The Chișinău Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 6 December 2012.
- The Centru District Court extended the applicant’s detention by thirty days on 26 December 2012, dismissing his claims about his health as unsubstantiated and stating that his medical records were not acceptable evidence.
- The Chișinău Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Centru District Court on 11 January 2013.
- The Centru District Court refused an application to extend the applicant’s detention and released him under judicial control on 24 January 2013.
- The parties dispute the applicant’s medical condition, with the applicant claiming he suffered from broken ribs and post-traumatic pneumonia.
- The applicant’s medical records and doctor’s statements confirmed his diagnosis and recommended inpatient treatment, but the court rejected the medical records as evidence and the government disputed his diagnosis.
- The government submitted medical reports indicating that the applicant had not presented any complaints or requested medical assistance during detention, and had a satisfactory overall state of health.

title: CASE OF HILL v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Arundel.
- In 2006, he was convicted of assault occasioning grievous bodily harm against the same victim he had previously offended.
- A pre-sentencing report identified the Enhanced Thinking Skills (“ETS”) and Controlling Anger and Learning to Manage it (“CALM”) courses as appropriate for him, and attendance at these courses would take around two years.
- On 23 November 2006, he was sentenced to an indeterminate sentence for public protection (“IPP sentence”) with a minimum term of fourteen months and twelve days.
- He was detained in HMP Lewes and was required to complete the ETS course before his release.
- On 15 February 2008, a first Parole Board Review was held, and the panel didn't direct his release, suggesting the completion of the ETS course and assessment for the CALM course in closed conditions.
- The applicant undertook the ETS course in 2009 and completed it in June of the same year.
- On an unknown date, the Parole Board hearing scheduled for August 2009 was deferred to November 2009 in order to allow for the completion of the post-ETS course report.
- The CALM course was completed by the applicant in October 2011.
- The Parole Board held an oral hearing on 13 April 2012, and the applicant was released on 15 May 2012.

title: CASE OF TCHOKONTIO HAPPI v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Paris.
- She has been living with her daughter and brother in a flat in the Paris area since 2003.
- The Paris mediation commission found that the applicant and her relatives were living in indecent and insalubrious conditions.
- The Paris mediation commission earmarked their case as a priority for urgent rehousing.
- She had not received any offer of accommodation taking account of her needs and capacities six months after the date of that decision.
- The applicant lodged an application with the Paris Administrative Court seeking an order for the State to provide her with housing, on pain of a fine.
- On 28 December 2010, the Administrative Court instructed the prefect of the Île-de-France region to rehouse the applicant, her daughter and her brother, on pain of a fine of 700 euros (EUR), payable to the urban development fund for the Île-de-France region, for each month’s delay from 1 February 2011 onwards.
- A safety architect employed by the Paris Police Commissioner’s Office noted that the kitchen ceiling in the flat was in a dangerous state, and the applicant's request for rehousing should therefore be granted as a matter of particular urgency.
- On 31 January 2012, the Administrative Court assessed the interim amount of the fine for the period from 1 February 2011 to 31 January 2012 and ordered the State to pay EUR 8,400 into the urban development fund for the Île-de-France region.
- As matters stand, the applicant and her family have still not been rehoused.

title: CASE OF VAMVAKAS v. GREECE (No. 2)
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1953.
- In 2006, the Athens Criminal Court of Appeal convicted the applicant of fraud and forgery, and sentenced him to eight years in prison.
- The applicant, assisted by lawyers, appeared in person at a hearing held in February 2009.
- The proceedings were adjourned and rescheduled several times, and the applicant was informed that he would not be summoned to appear at one of the hearings.
- The applicant did not attend a hearing in May 2009 but informed the court in writing that he would be represented by his lawyers. However, they did not attend either.
- The court appointed an official counsel for the applicant and adjourned a hearing to allow him to familiarise himself with the case file.
- The Criminal Court of Appeal reduced the applicant's sentence to seven years' imprisonment in May 2009.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law in June 2009, complaining of an erroneous application of the relevant legislation and of violations of Articles 6 and 7 of the Convention.
- The appeal on points of law was dismissed by the Court of Cassation in February 2010 on the grounds that the applicant had failed to appear at the hearing.
- The applicant claimed that his appointed lawyer had assured him that he would attend the hearing, but did not inform him of the reasons for his absence.
- The applicant learned of the judgment of the Court of Cassation in October 2010.

title: CASE OF A.T. v. LUXEMBOURG
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and was detained in London at the time he lodged his application.
- On 9 October 2009, the Public Prosecutor ordered an investigation against the applicant on charges of rape and indecent assault on a girl under the age of sixteen.
- On 4 December 2009, the applicant was arrested in the United Kingdom under a European Arrest Warrant.
- On 17 December 2009, the applicant was surrendered to the Luxembourg authorities.
- On the morning of 18 December 2009, he was questioned by the investigating judge in the presence of an interpreter.
- It transpired from the case file that the applicant, who had been remanded in custody, was released on 10 March 2010 by the Luxembourg District Court.
- By a judgment of 31 March 2011, the criminal division of the District Court sentenced the applicant to a seven-year prison term accompanied by a three-year partial probation period.
- On 7 February 2012, the criminal division of the Court of Appeal upheld the first-instance judgment.
- On 22 November 2012, the Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF CHINNICI v. ITALY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1945 and lives in L’Aquila.
- The applicant owned a plot of land designated as industrial land in L’Aquila.
- Regional authorities granted the Consortium permission to occupy a portion of the applicant’s land in order to begin the construction of an industrial compound.
- The regional authorities issued an expropriation order in respect of the land.
- The consortium offered the applicant a global sum of 106.400.000 Italian lire (ITL) (equivalent to EUR 55,000) as compensation for the expropriation and compensation for the period during which the land had been occupied before the expropriation order had been issued.
- On 14 August 1992, Law no. 359 of 8 August 1992 came into force and laid down new criteria for calculating compensation for the expropriation of building land.
- The Court of Appeal held that the applicant was entitled to compensation in the sum of EUR 77,556.40, as calculated according to the criteria laid down in Law no. 359 of 1992. Moreover, the Court of Appeal held that the applicant was entitled to compensation for the period during which the land had been occupied before the expropriation order had been issued, in the sum of EUR 12 778,37.
- By a judgment delivered on 24 January 2013, filed with the court registry on 12 March 2013, the L’Aquila Court of Appeal acknowledged the Constitutional Court’s judgment no. 348 of 24 October 2007, whereby Article 5 bis of Law no. 359 of 8 August 1992 had been declared unconstitutional, and held that the applicant was entitled to compensation corresponding to the full market value of the property.
- The Court of Appeal concluded that the applicant was entitled to compensation in the sum of EUR 108,578.96 (equivalent to ITL 210,236,000), which reflected the market value of the land at the time of the expropriation (1991), plus statutory interest. It did not, however, adjust the amount for inflation.

title: CASE OF BOTEZATU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is a police officer who was entitled to social housing by a court order.
- The court order was issued on 21 July 2004, upheld by the Chișinău Court of Appeal on 19 October 2004, and became final on 4 November 2004.
- Enforcement proceedings were instituted on 11 May 2005 but were delayed for over seven years.
- The applicant sought enforcement of the final judgment in his favour and compensation for non-pecuniary and pecuniary damages and expenses.
- The Ministry of Finance disputed the validity of the lease contracts submitted by the applicant to support his claim for pecuniary damage.
- The Rîșcani District Court acknowledged that there had been a violation of the applicant’s rights under Article 6 of the Convention and of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention resulting from the non-enforcement of the final judgment in his favour for over seven years and granted his claims in full.
- The Chișinău Court of Appeal upheld the appeal, acknowledging a violation of the applicant’s right under Article 6 of the Convention resulting from the non-enforcement of a final judgment for a period of 78 months and awarded the applicant compensation.
- The municipality issued the applicant with an occupancy voucher on 8 August 2012, and the final judgment was enforced on that day.
- The applicant did not dispute the enforcement of the final judgment.

title: CASE OF TORAN AND SCHYMIK v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants are serving prison sentences in Germany for drug trafficking, after being convicted by Romanian authorities.
- One of the applicant's acquaintances was in custody for drug-related offenses and agreed to contact the applicants to arrange a drug transaction.
- Undercover agents were authorized to purchase drugs with the help of the acquaintance, due to strong indications of drug trafficking activity within the unknown suspects' network.
- The undercover agents were provided with €35,000 to purchase the drugs, which the applicants handed over to them in exchange for 5,000 Ecstasy pills.
- The applicants claimed they had no knowledge of the drugs, but video evidence showed them removing the drugs from a hidden compartment in their vehicle.
- The applicants were caught in flagrante delicto and placed in custody, where they initially pleaded not guilty but later changed their plea.
- S.R.B., the acquaintance, admitted to cooperating with the police and contacting the applicants to arrange the transaction.
- The applicants were sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment for drug trafficking, but their sentence was later reduced to seven years on appeal.
- The applicants were remanded in custody in different prison facilities and shared cells with multiple inmates, but had access to basic facilities such as clean water and sanitary facilities.

title: CASE OF MEZHIYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Russian national who lived in Grozny with her husband, who was a bus driver.
- In March 2001, the applicant and her husband were working on route no. 7 when they saw a military convoy pass by and decided to cross a bridge that had been closed earlier that day. 
- When the applicant and her husband's bus moved towards the bridge, there was a powerful explosion at the edge of the bridge under the front left wheel of the bus on the driver’s side. 
- The explosion caused the applicant's husband to die in the hospital after a delay in medical care and the applicant to lose her left arm above the elbow. 
- An investigation was opened and closed several times, with some witness statements contradicting the government's explanations for the explosion.

title: CASE OF MITOVI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1972, 1949, and 1950 respectively.
- The first applicant married Mrs. J.S.M. in Skopje on 19 September 2008.
- Mrs. J.S.M. gave birth to their daughter, M.M., on 30 August 2010, in Australia.
- Relations between the first applicant and Mrs. J.S.M. became strained in 2011, and Mrs. J.S.M. left to Skopje with M.M.
- Mrs. J.S.M. filed for the dissolution of the marriage on 10 October 2011.
- The first applicant requested specific rights in respect of contact with his daughter on 6 December 2011.
- In January 2012, interim custody of the child was given to Mrs. J.S.M. with specified contact rights given to the first applicant.
- The decision was quashed on 8 April 2012, and the Centre was ordered to reconsider the facts taking into consideration the child's best interests.
- On 16 May 2012, the first instance court dissolved the marriage and granted custody of M.M. to the mother.
- The first applicant appealed several times for contact rights with his daughter, but the enforcement of the decisions was obstructed by the child's mother.
- The Centre confirmed the contact rights of the second and third applicants on 21 January and 21 April 2014.
