- Mrs. J.S.M was found guilty of child abduction on 12 December 2014.

title: CASE OF KHAMRAKULOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant is a Kyrgyz national of Uzbek ethnic origin.
- He left Kyrgyzstan for Russia after the mass disorder and inter-ethnic clashes that took place in the region in June 2010.
- The Kyrgyz authorities charged the applicant in absentia with violent crimes committed in June 2010.
- On 25 January 2013, the applicant was arrested in Russia, and the Kyrgyz authorities confirmed their intention to seek his extradition.
- On 20 February 2013, the Deputy Prosecutor General of Kyrgyzstan sent his Russian counterpart a letter containing assurances that the applicant would benefit from legal assistance, and would not be tortured or subjected to inhuman or degrading treatment.
- The applicant challenged the extradition decision before the courts.
- The Moscow City Court and Supreme Court of Russia upheld the extradition order.
- The applicant applied for refugee status on 25 March 2013, but the Moscow migration authority refused to grant it on 9 July 2013.
- The applicant appealed to the FMS, but it upheld the refusal decision on 6 September 2013.
- The Basmannyy District Court of Moscow upheld the decision to refuse the applicant’s application for refugee status on 22 January 2014.
- The Moscow City Court upheld that decision on appeal on 20 May 2014.

title: CASE OF GAL v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a private entrepreneur in the food supply sector in Poltava.
- The police investigated the forgery of food quality certificates and overpricing of foodstuffs for school catering, and as part of the investigation, they questioned the applicant's associates and family members.
- The police arrested the applicant on suspicion of a financial offense on 5 November 2010.
- The applicant was remanded in custody for up to ten days without specific reasons on 8 November 2010.
- The District Court remanded the applicant in custody with no maximum duration on 15 November 2010, referring to gravity of charges, risk of interference with investigation, and personal characteristics without any further explanation.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the first-instance court's decisions on 23 November 2010 and 18 January 2011.
- The applicant's detention was extended for up to three months on 29 December 2010, and he was released on 25 March 2011.

title: CASE OF PISARI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are parents who live in Pirita, born in 1970 and 1973 respectively.
- The case concerns the killing of their 18-year-old son, Vadim Pisari, by a Russian soldier V.K. at a peacekeeping security checkpoint.
- Vadim Pisari drove his friend's car across a bridge with checkpoints controlled by Russian, Moldovan, and Transdniestrian peacekeeping military forces.
- Vadim Pisari didn't stop at the checkpoints and continued to drive despite being ordered to stop by V.K.
- V.K. fired three single shots towards the car, aiming at its tyres, causing one bullet to hit Vadim Pisari and killing him.
- The Moldovan authorities conducted a criminal investigation and instituted a criminal investigation, but the Russian military transferred V.K. to a military unit in Bryansk.
- The Russian authorities conducted a parallel investigation, and a commission was created to investigate the incident.
- The Russian soldier suspected of having shot Vadim Pisari was cleared of the accusations against him, and the proceedings were terminated.
- The applicants requested a copy of the decision adopted by the Russian authorities but were informed that they could not receive it since they were not a party to the proceedings.

title: CASE OF CATALINA FILIP v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Bucharest.
- The case is linked to the events of December 1989.
- Military operations conducted in Romania caused many civilian victims and injuries.
- The applicant's husband was shot and killed on December 25, 1989.
- Criminal investigations were conducted into both the death of the applicant's husband and the violence in Bucharest during December 1989.
- The investigation into both cases was delayed due to various reasons.
- The criminal investigation is still pending.
- The applicant instituted civil proceedings seeking non-pecuniary damage.
- The proceedings were initially dismissed but later reinstated.
- The Romanian Ministry of Public Finances was ordered to pay the applicant RON 50,000 in non-pecuniary damages and court fees were refunded.

title: CASE OF PIPER v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant was born in Essex in 1948.
- On 31 January 1999, he was arrested in the Netherlands for attempted cocaine importation.
- On 3 February 1999, he was charged following transfer to the United Kingdom.
- The prosecution obtained a restraint order and appointment of a receiver under the 1994 Act to seize and preserve the applicant’s assets for future confiscation.
- The applicant challenged the admissibility of telephone interception evidence, but the House of Lords delivered its judgment against him on 24 March 2000.
- During the first trial, a prejudicial document was discovered within the jury bundle, and the jury was discharged on 31 August 2000.
- The retrial commenced on 6 April 2001, and on 5 June 2001, the applicant was found guilty and sentenced to 14 years’ imprisonment.
- The prosecution served notice of its intention to seek a confiscation order prior to the sentencing hearing, as provided for under the 1994 Act.
- The defense failed to serve a written response to the prosecution's statement within the six-week period prescribed by the judge, and a further procedural hearing took place on 9 October 2001.
- The defense's new representative sought an adjournment of three weeks to allow new counsel to receive papers and take instructions from the applicant.
- The defense argued abuse of process on the basis that an undertaking had been given and was then reneged upon, but the judge ruled that there had been a misunderstanding between counsel, and no abuse arose.
- The case was adjourned further in December 2002 and February 2003 on the applicant's application under section 3 of the 1994 Act, the “exceptional circumstances” being the pending House of Lords appeals.
- In September 2004, the applicant lodged an out-of-time appeal with the Court of Appeal against his conviction.
- On 17 November 2006, the applicant abandoned his appeal against conviction.

title: CASE OF TODIREASA v. ROMANIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and is from Piatra Neamţ.
- The applicant served a seventeen-year prison sentence for fraud and tax evasion starting on 27 November 2001.
- He was detained in Bacău, Iaşi, Galaţi, Brăila, and Vaslui Prisons from 10 August 2010 to 22 April 2014.
- The applicant alleges that the detention conditions of the prisons amounted to physical and psychological torture, including overcrowding, inadequate heating and insulation, defective sanitary installations and no proper bathrooms, presence of bed bugs and other parasites, insufficient daylight and electricity, dirty and worn-out mattresses and sheets, and very poor quality food.
- The applicant alleges that his constant transfers between prisons and different cells aggravated the inhumane conditions of his detention. He also shared cells with mentally ill detainees.
- The Government denies the allegations made by the applicant.
- The specific details submitted by the Government with respect to each prison are as follows:
- Bacău Prison: The applicant was held in the old detention block of Bacău Prison until 13 August 2010 in a cell of 2.46 sq. m of personal space. No insect infestations were reported in 2010.
- Iaşi Prison: The applicant was held in three different cells measuring from 19.3 sq. m to 33.3 sq. m, which he shared with seven and twenty-five other prisoners respectively. During the second period, the cells had been provided with showers, hot water was available daily for two hours, television sets had been installed, and a self-service canteen was created. Disinfection operations were conducted at least twice a year, within the limits of the budget.
- Galaţi Prison: The applicant was held in four different cells measuring approximately 24 sq. m, which accommodated twelve to fifteen prisoners. The cells had their own bathrooms with a toilet and shower, and cold water, which was also used for drinking, was available daily. Access to hot showers was possible twice per week. Cleaning products were provided monthly, and mattresses were renewed in August 2012. Food was usually provided, but budgetary limitations sometimes led to certain products being missing.
- Brăila Prison: The applicant was held in a cell measuring 21.73 sq. m together with twelve other prisoners. Heating and food were provided according to legal norms, and prisoners' meals were served in their cells. The applicant's cell had

title: CASE OF MORICE v. FRANCE
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant is a Paris-based lawyer and member of the Paris Bar.
- Bernard Borrel, a French judge seconded to Djibouti as a technical adviser, was found dead in October 1995. Djiboutian authorities concluded it was suicide by self-immolation.
- Borrel's widow disputed the finding of suicide and filed a complaint as a civil party in March 1997. The investigation into the cause of death and two investigations into premeditated murder were joined in April 1997.
- A former senior officer and member of the Djiboutian Presidential Guard, who had found asylum in Belgium, disclosed certain revelations about Borrel's death in November 1999. His testimony was recorded, but he later accused the investigating judges of pressurizing and intimidating him to withdraw his testimony. Proceedings were brought against the public prosecutor of Djibouti and the head of the country's secret services for procuring false evidence.
- Three professional unions of judges and prosecutors joined the proceedings as civil parties in February 2000.
- The investigating judges accepted a request to take evidence from the witness, A., in March 2000 but refused to agree to an on-site reconstruction.
- The Indictments Division of the Paris Court of Appeal ordered an on-site reconstruction in the presence of the civil parties in June 2000 and appointed a new investigating judge, Judge P., to continue the investigation.
- In January 2000, the Paris tribunal de grande instance found the State liable for gross negligence on the part of the courts service on account of the disappearance of a "Scientology" file from the office of Judge M., who had also been responsible for the judicial investigation into the "Scientology" case for which the applicant also represented the civil parties.
- The CSM dismissed a plea of nullity from Judge M. and, on the merits, reproached her for a certain lack of rigour or a failure to keep track of the case sufficiently but did not impose any disciplinary penalty on her in December 2001.
- Judge P. found a card addressed by the public prosecutor of Djibouti to Judge M. in an envelope containing a video-cassette of a site visit; the contents of the card revealed an intimate relationship that was regrettable, given the public prosecutor was directly subordinate to the head of the executive's regime, who was suspected of being the instigator of Borrel's murder according to the applicant and another lawyer.

The case is still

title: CASE OF KHAVA AZIYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Khava Aziyeva, Aysha Aziyeva, and Abdurrakhman Aziyev, relatives of Rizvan Aziyev.
- Rizvan Aziyev was arrested and convicted for illegal armed groups in 2005 and released in 2008.
- The first applicant was previously married to A.Kh., who was wanted for active membership in illegal armed groups and was killed in a special operation in 2009.
- On October 31, 2009, a large group of armed men arrived at the applicants’ house and demanded that the first applicant call her brother without mentioning the police were waiting for him.
- Mr. Rizvan Aziyev was abducted and witnesses saw a group of men resembling police officers take him away.
- The Leninskiy district department of the interior denied any involvement into the events.
- The investigators did not identify the perpetrators, and the investigation into the abduction was suspended.

title: CASE OF KAGIROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant is the brother of Mr Rustam Kagirov, who was born in 1979 and suffered from a disability due to removal of one of his lungs.
- Mr Rustam Kagirov had religious beliefs and had studied at an “Islamic Institute” in Grozny, potentially making him a target for suspicion by the authorities.
- On an unspecified date in the autumn of 2004, Mr Rustam Kagirov was allegedly apprehended by officers from the 7th Company of the 2nd Regiment of the Chechen traffic police and tortured for two days.
- On 17 May 2009, Mr Rustam Kagirov was abducted by three armed men in black uniforms who forced him into the back seat of a black VAZ Priora vehicle with registration number A 720 AT 95.
- The applicant saw the abduction take place and followed the abductors in his car, but the police at a nearby roadblock did not stop the Priora vehicle, and the abductors escaped.
- The applicant complained of the abduction to the Achkhoy-Martan District Prosecutor’s Office and the Achkhoy-Martan District Department of the Interior.
- The Achkhoy-Martan Inter-District Investigations Department of the Prosecutor’s Office of the Russian Federation in the Chechen Republic opened an investigation into the abduction under Article 126 § 2 of the Criminal Code.
- The investigation was suspended for failure to identify the perpetrators but was later resumed.
- The investigation involved questioning witnesses, examining the crime scene and seizing the detainees’ registration log of the Shatoy ROVD, among other steps.
- The investigators did not find any evidence indicating Mr Rustam Kagirov’s whereabouts or the identity of the perpetrators.

title: CASE OF MIKHALCHUK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lives in Moscow.
- On 17 April 2003, the police arrested the applicant on suspicion of robbery and extortion and took him to the Yuzhnoye Tushino police station in Moscow.
- The applicant was allegedly beaten by police officers to make him confess to criminal offenses at the police station.
- On 18 April 2003, the prosecutor's office instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant on suspicion of several criminal offenses, including robbery and extortion.
- The applicant was released on the same date.
- On 24 April 2003, an investigator from the prosecutor’s office ordered that the applicant be taken to the police station for questioning.
- On 28 April 2003, the deputy prosecutor quashed the decision to release the applicant and ordered his pre-trial detention.
- On 19 May 2003, following the applicant's statement that he had been beaten by police officers, the investigator ordered a forensic medical examination of the applicant. The investigator refused to open criminal proceedings into the applicant’s complaints that he had been beaten by police officers on 17 April 2003.
- On 20 June 2003, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 28 July 2003.
- The criminal case against the applicant was referred to the District Court for trial.
- On 4 August 2003, the District Court set the preliminary hearing of the case for 19 August 2003.
- On 12 January 2004, the District Court dismissed the applicant’s request for release and extended his and his co-defendant’s detention until 16 April 2004.
- On 14 July 2004, the District Court found the applicant guilty of several criminal offenses, including robbery and extortion, and sentenced him to ten years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant submitted, among other things, that he had confessed to the crimes after being beaten by police officers and that the investigator had refused to institute criminal proceedings against them.
- On 19 October 2004, the City Court upheld the applicant’s conviction.
- Following the applicant’s repeated complaints about the ill-treatment by police officers on 17 April 2003, on 4 May 2005, the prosecutor’s office informed the applicant that it was open to him to challenge the decision of 31 May 2003 in court. 
- On 16 June 2005, the Presidium of the City Court, by way of a supervisory review,

title: CASE OF NAGIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was charged with unlawful possession of explosive materials in connection with a bomb explosion that occurred in Moscow on 15 November 2007.
- The applicant was initially questioned by Azerbaijani police then again by Russian police.
- The applicant lodged a complaint about an alleged misappropriation of his property and subsequently made complaints to various State authorities about the lack of progress in the case.
- On 18 September 2008, the applicant was arrested by the Organised Crime Department (OCD) and was not allowed to contact his family or a lawyer, and his arrest was not documented.
- The applicant's whereabouts were unknown, and a criminal complaint was lodged with the police station related to his disappearance on 21 September 2008.
- On 24 September 2008, the applicant's brother was allowed to visit him in the temporary detention facility of the OCD. However, the applicant's family was not informed of the reasons for the applicant's arrest and detention.
- The applicant was detained in the temporary detention facility of the OCD from 18 September to 2 October 2008 and forced to change his statement in a criminal case concerning the misappropriation of his property.
- The Narimanov District Court in Azerbaijan ordered the application of the preventive measure of remand in custody in respect of the applicant for a period of two months and subsequently extended it for another two months.
- The applicant appealed against the Narimanov District Court's decisions, including the extension of his detention and the refusal to replace his remand in custody with the preventive measure of house arrest.

title: CASE OF ŠABLIJ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant's identity was the subject of controversy at the national level.
- The applicant was arrested on charges of conspiracy and murder and was remanded in custody.
- The applicant was indicted to stand trial and his request for release was dismissed.
- The applicant was acquitted on appeal, and while he was still in detention, he requested release, which was also dismissed, leading him to file a complaint under Article 127 of the Constitution.
- The Constitutional Court found a violation of the applicant's right to a "speedy" review of the lawfulness of his detention by the District Court and awarded him reimbursement of his legal costs as just satisfaction.

title: CASE OF MASLÁK  v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lived in Pružina.
- The applicant was charged with several offenses, mainly of a violent nature and with an organized crime background, between October 29, 2007, and March 12, 2009.
- He was arrested on September 27, 2008, and remained in custody until his release on April 1, 2010.
- By a submission dated May 20, 2009, the applicant requested release, which was rejected by the OSP and subsequently fell to be examined judicially by the Special Court.
- On July 16, 2009, the Special Court dismissed the applicant’s request for release, which was appealed by both the applicant's lawyer and himself.
- On August 25, 2009, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s interlocutory appeal against the Special Court's decision to dismiss his request for release.
- The applicant filed a complaint under Article 127 of the Constitution with the Constitutional Court on November 4, 2009.
- The Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible for being in essence manifestly ill-founded on June 17, 2010.

title: CASE OF RAKIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Kraljevo.
- On 6 November 2008, Municipal Court ordered certain sums to the applicant.
- On 5 March 2009, District Court quashed one part of the judgment and remitted it for retrial. Another part was amended.
- The relevant part of the judgment of 6 November 2008, became final and enforceable on 20 April 2009.
- On 28 December 2009, the applicant filed request for enforcement of the judgment.
- On 29 January 2010, Court of First Instance ordered applicant to remedy some shortcomings in her request for enforcement.
- On 26 April 2010, the enforcement proceedings were stayed.
- On 5 September 2011, the applicant requested the Court of First Instance to continue with the enforcement.
- On 26 September 2011, the Court of First Instance issued an enforcement order.
- On 17 May 2012, the enforcement order was quashed on appeal.
- On 19 June 2012, the applicant informed the enforcement court of the debtors’ new names.
- On 17 September 2013, the Court of First Instance issued a fresh enforcement order.
- On 13 December 2013, the enforcement order was upheld on appeal.
- On 30 April 2014, the Court of First Instance ordered the applicant to provide further details about the debtors’ names. 
- The judgment of 6 November 2008, as amended on 5 March 2009 is yet to be enforced.

title: CASE OF I.P. v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was in a relationship with O.P. for over a year.
- The relationship became problematic because O.P. became jealous and violent.
- On May 10, 2010, O.P. assaulted the applicant and forced her into his car, where he threatened and physically attacked her several times.
- O.P. took the applicant to his house, where he raped and sodomized her against her will.
- Medical reports confirmed that the applicant had bruises and injuries all over her body, while semen was found only in her vagina.
- Despite the evidence, the prosecutor twice refused to initiate criminal proceedings against O.P., claiming that the sexual intercourse was consensual and that the applicant could have resisted if she wanted to.
- After an appeal, a judge ordered a fresh investigation and new medical reports were obtained.
- O.P. admitted to slapping the applicant but denied raping or sexually assaulting her on May 10 or 11, only admitting to having consensual sex on May 7-9.
- The case was dismissed again by a prosecutor in April 2011, claiming that the sexual intercourse was consensual and that the applicant willingly came to O.P.'s house, despite evidence to the contrary.
- The applicant's appeals were ultimately rejected.

title: CASE OF SULTAN DÖLEK AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Mustafa Döleksoy was found dead in his summer house
- The initial assumption was that he died due to a cerebral hemorrhage caused by head trauma resulting from a fall in his kitchen
- Mustafa Döleksoy's siblings and mother submitted an objection to the prosecutor as they believed their brother's death was suspicious
- The prosecutor requested a full post-mortem examination to be carried out due to a clump of hair found in the left hand of Mustafa Döleksoy
- The investigation focused on Mustafa Döleksoy's wife and her sister as they had threatened Mustafa and been involved in other similar deaths
- The cause of Mustafa Döleksoy's death could not be established due to the advanced state of decomposition of the body
- The prosecutor decided to close the case due to a lack of evidence
- The first applicant objected to the prosecutor's decision and appealed to the Tarsus Assize Court, but was rejected 
- The first applicant requested the hair samples for private DNA tests, but the prosecutor refused to hand them over.

title: CASE OF DELIJORGJI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- Massive explosion occurred at a demilitarisation facility claiming 26 lives and leaving 265 others wounded.
- The applicant is the administrator of the private company that carried out the demilitarisation process.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant and 28 other persons following the explosion.
- The applicant was remanded in custody on 17 March 2008, with no time-limits imposed on the length of his detention.
- On 13 March 2009, the prosecutor sent the case against the applicant for examination to the Supreme Court.
- On 3 November 2010, the Supreme Court remitted the case for re-hearing by a different bench.
- The applicant’s lawyer lodged a second request for his release on 6 December 2010 on the ground that the time-limits laid down by Articles 262 and 263 § 2 (c) of the CCP had expired.
- On 7 February 2011, the applicant’s lawyer requested his release again and the District Court ordered his immediate release.
- On 12 March 2012, the Tirana District Court found the applicant guilty of a “breach of the rules on explosive, flammable or radioactive substances” and sentenced him to 10 years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant was released on 19 March 2013, after serving his sentence.

title: CASE OF DOROSEVA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on 11 November 2009 at around 11.30 p.m. on suspicion of possession of drugs.
- The applicant claimed to have been ill-treated by the police officers who arrested her and held until the next morning.
- A medical report dated 13 November 2009 showed that the applicant had numerous bruises on the face, arms, and hips, and a broken nose.
- On 15 November 2009, a neurologist determined that the applicant had also suffered concussion.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint concerning her ill-treatment by the police on 14 January 2010.
- The application was denied by the prosecutor's office on 1 April 2010, and the decision was upheld on 15 October 2010.
- An investigating judge from the Rascani District Court upheld the appeal on 29 November 2010.
- After the investigation was reopened, a forensic medical examination conducted on 30 December 2010 found that at least six different blows with a hard blunt object had produced the applicant's injuries.
- On 20 May 2010, the Rascani Prosecutor's Office again denied to initiate criminal proceedings.
- This decision was upheld by a higher prosecutor on 26 September 2011, and by an investigating judge from the Rascani District Court on 1 November 2011.

title: CASE OF FERRARI v. ROMANIA
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant is a military pilot from Buenos Aires with a child born in August 2005.
- The family's permanent residence was in Argentina but they traveled due to the applicant's various work assignments.
- The wife and child joined the applicant on a UN mission to Cyprus in September 2006 and later travelled to Spain before deciding in 2007 that the wife and child would go to Romania for a few months.
- The parents agreed that the wife and child would return to Argentina before the expiration of the child's passport, but the wife was unable to make the arrangements on time.
- The wife sought the applicant's consent to request a Romanian passport for the child, but the applicant refused, and the wife informed the applicant that she would not return with the child to Argentina.
- On 4 December 2007, the applicant requested the return of the child under the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (“the Hague Convention”).
- On 8 July 2008, the County Court granted the applicant's request and ordered the mother to return the child to the habitual residence in Buenos Aires.
- On 22 December 2008, the Ministry requested the assistance of a bailiff for enforcement of the final decision.
- In February 2009, the Bucharest Court of Appeal granted the mother's request, quashed the return order, and sent the case back for re-examination of the appeal on points of law.
- On 4 May 2009, the Court of Appeal dismissed the initial request for the return of the child, citing the child's integration into his new environment in Romania and the father's inability to take proper care of the child due to his job as a military pilot.
- In September 2011, the Bucharest District Court granted custody of the child to the mother and awarded the applicant visiting rights, which was upheld on appeal in 2012.
- The applicant traveled to Romania several times to spend time with his child.

title: CASE OF MILIĆ AND NIKEZIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicants were detained in a cell with five other detainees at the IECS.
- On 27 October 2009, the first applicant was to be transferred to a disciplinary unit and the cell was searched.
- The first applicant claimed that he was beaten, handcuffed, and sworn at by several guards in the corridor outside the cell as well as two rows of guards positioned along the corridor as he was being taken away.
- The second applicant claimed that he protested against this abuse, was beaten by four guards, and then taken to the corridor outside the cell where eight other guards continued to beat him.
- The government claimed that the applicants had resisted the actions of the prison guards and had tried to prevent them from performing their duties, which had triggered the guards’ intervention.
- The first applicant refused to be examined by a prison doctor.
- The second applicant was examined by the prison doctor after the Deputy Ombudsman had made a request to that effect.
- The State prosecutor asked the Court of First Instance to establish the elements of criminal offenses of torture and ill-treatment and ordered evidence to be heard from a number of individuals, including the prison guards, and the second applicant.
- An external forensic doctor confirmed that the second applicant had light body injuries, namely a 10-day old hematoma measuring 8 x 15 cm on the back of his left thigh and a hematoma on the lower lid of each eye.
- The applicants and their families lodged criminal complaints and requests for an investigation with the State prosecutor and the Court of First Instance.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the applicants’ appeal on procedural grounds.
- Disciplinary proceedings were instituted against three prison guards who were found responsible for abusing their position and exceeding their authority.

title: CASE OF COJAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and is currently detained in Giurgiu Prison
- The applicant was placed in pre-trial detention on 19 May 2010
- The applicant was convicted on 6 May 2011 and sentenced to eighteen years’ imprisonment
- The applicant was held in pre-trial detention facilities of the Bucharest Direction of Criminal Investigations until 16 November 2010
- The applicant was then transferred to Rahova Prison and stayed there until 13 August 2012
- The overall conditions of detention described by the applicant were overcrowded cells, lack of natural light and fresh air, no refrigerator for food, and having to share cells with individuals arrested of violent crimes with no means of summoning the guards
- According to official prison records, the cells in the police detention facilities had a table and chairs, a squat toilet, sink, and shower separated from the living space by a curtain
- They had access to running water, natural and artificial light, and personal hygiene products
- According to official information the cells in Rahova Prison were all 21 sq. m and contained eight beds, a table, chairs, and a support for a TV set. There was a bathroom adjacent to the cell, and they had access to exercise for two hours daily in the interior courtyard and outdoor and indoor sport facilities.

title: CASE OF MITRINOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant lives in Skopje and presided over a three-judge panel of the Skopje Court of Appeal on 6 December 2010.
- On that day, the panel granted an appeal and replaced an order for detention on remand with an order for house arrest.
- On 9 December 2010, the State Public Prosecutor challenged this decision by means of a request for the protection of legality (барање за заштита на законитоста).
- On 10 December 2010, the Supreme Court accepted the prosecutor’s amended request and stated that two judges had disclosed professional misconduct.
- Judge J.V. requested that the State Judicial Council (SJC) establish professional misconduct in respect of the applicant and Judge I.L.
- On 23 December 2010, the SJC set up a Commission for determination of professional misconduct by the applicant and accepted it as timely, complete, and admissible.
- On 23 February 2010, the plenary of the SJC initiated professional misconduct proceedings against the applicant and temporarily suspended him from the office of judge.
- On 18 May 2011, the plenary of the SJC dismissed the applicant from the office of judge for professional misconduct.
- The applicant appealed against that decision before the Appeal Panel within the Supreme Court and sought withdrawal of judge J.V. and all the Supreme Court judges.
- On 13 September 2011, the Appeal Panel dismissed the appeal and confirmed the SJC’s decision dismissing him from the office of judge.

title: CASE OF ISLAMOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a mother of two sons, Mr Apti Islamov and Mr Said-Emi Islamov.
- The brothers worked as policemen at the Zavodskoy district department of the interior in Grozny.
- On 14 October 2000, the brothers and two of their colleagues were driving in a car and stopped at checkpoint no. 160 which was staffed by police officers from the Special Task Unit.
- The four men were arrested in the presence of their colleagues and taken to an unknown location.
- The investigation was initiated by the Chechnya prosecutor's office, which led to the questioning of on-duty officers who had manned the checkpoint and other witnesses.
- The investigation was suspended and resumed multiple times, but the whereabouts of the four men remain unknown.
- The Government denies any involvement of State agents and suggests that the detention might have been carried out by people who introduced themselves as representatives of power structures.

title: CASE OF YAREMENKO v. UKRAINE (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a life sentence in Zhytomyr Prison.
- The applicant was prosecuted for two counts of murder in 2001.
- The applicant was initially questioned with his lawyer present on 27 January 2001.
- On 1 February 2001, the applicant was questioned by a police officer and was coerced into confessing to a crime from 1998 by signing a waiver of his right to counsel.
- On 2 February 2001, the criminal cases in respect of the 1998 and 2001 crimes were joined, and the applicant participated in a videotaped on-site reconstruction of the 2001 crimes where he made statements concerning the circumstances of the 2001 crimes but denied involvement in the 1998 crime.
- The applicant was removed from his first lawyer, and a new one was appointed on 9 February 2001, and on an unknown date investigating prosecutor G. replied to lawyer O. Kh., stating that his request of 2 February 2001 for a medical examination of the applicant could not be granted since he had been removed from the case.
- The applicant confessed to having committed the 1998 crime with a new lawyer on 7 February 2001.
- The applicant made complaints about being coerced into signing a waiver and being deprived of legal assistance of his own choosing during part of the proceedings in a letter to the General Prosecutor’s Office dated 4 March 2001.
- On 18 April 2002, the Supreme Court of Ukraine upheld the judgment of the appellate court in the case, finding no evidence of a violation of the right to defence or of any other substantial violation of criminal procedure law that could provide a basis for quashing the judgment of the appellate court.
- The applicant lodged an application with the Court on 13 August 2002, alleging that he had been subjected to ill‑treatment in police custody and that his complaints in that regard had not been given due consideration.

title: CASE OF CUNHA MARTINS DA SILVA COUTO v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Porto
- Applicant and I. dissolved their marriage and I. obtained custody of children
- On 28 November 2008, Porto Family Court granted the applicant contact rights with children 
- On 27 May 2009, I. suspended applicant's contact rights 
- On 5 June 2009, applicant lodged an application with Porto Family Court seeking to regain contact with his children 
- From June 2009 to Jan 2012, the applicant made several requests to regain visitation rights and to spend holidays with his children 
- On 14 July 2009, Family Court suspended applicant's right to visit his children for three months citing social report 
- Requests for visitation rights continued till September 2009 to January 2012 
- In March 2010, a psychological assessment was ordered by Family Court 
- Mediation hearing scheduled for Nov 2010 but did not take place due to I.'s refusal
- On 30 March 2011, hearing took place and both parties agreed that applicant could visit his children at Family Court premises 
- On 25 November 2011, Family Court requested another social report 
- On 10 May 2012, a new hearing took place where applicant and I. reached an agreement concerning visitation rights

title: CASE OF FERREIRA ALVES v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant is a lawyer born in 1953 and living in Matosinhos.
- The Porto Ethics Council of the Portuguese Bar Association initiated disciplinary proceedings against the applicant on 22 February 2008.
- The complaint was made by the Administrative Central Court of the North, and the proceedings were numbered 100/2008.
- The complaint related to the applicant's request to have a judgment from the European Court of Human Rights translated and paid by the domestic court in four different tort actions against the State.
- The applicant was summoned to the disciplinary proceedings on 10 March 2008 and presented his submissions on 13 March 2008.
- The Ethics Council dismissed the case on 9 November 2012, for being time-barred.

title: CASE OF ALVES v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 in Slovenia and lives in Braga, Portugal.
- On 22 November 2006, the applicant filed a liability action for damages against her previous lawyer, F., for professional negligence, in the Braga court.
- On 25 January 2007, F. requested the intervention of his insurance company in the proceedings.
- On 11 July 2007, the court accepted the insurance company's intervention in the case.
- On 28 April 2008, the judge absolved F. of the case due to the applicant's lack of legal capacity, but the Guimarães Court of Appeal reversed the decision on 4 December 2008, and the case returned to the Braga court.
- On 29 October 2010, the Braga Court partially found in favor of the applicant.
- The parties appealed against the decision to the Guimarães Court of Appeal, which dismissed the appeals on 20 October 2011.
- On 29 May 2012, the Supreme Court dismissed the appeals.

title: CASE OF BUCHYNSKA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Zhytomyr.
- Two men entered the applicant’s house, tied the applicant and took the valuables belonging to her and other household members. One of them shot the applicant and the bullet remains in her head.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated by police, crime scene examined, fingerprints and other evidence collected, and the applicant was admitted as an injured party.
- Several identification parades were conducted and various persons identified; V.P. was identified as the unmasked offender.
- I.K., V.P.’s partner, acknowledged to police that she had seen a revolver in his possession and he had left home for an appointment with his friend S.K. on the day of the incident. 
- Various witnesses identified S.K. as V.P.’s friend and he was questioned several times as a witness. 
- The investigation was suspended and resumed several times. The applicant informed the investigator that she suspected her cousin O.M. to be the masked offender, but the complaint was ignored, and she was not informed of the decisions.
- O.M. and S.T. were arrested and charged but were discharged due to lack of evidence on several occasions. 
- The case was transferred and requests to locate and question S.K. and V.P. as witnesses were made repeatedly. 
- S.K. was arrested in connection with other crimes and confessed to the incriminated offense in the applicant’s case, as well as divulging V.P.'s involvement. 
- The proceedings concerning V.P. were closed due to his death. 
- A bill of indictment was signed accusing S.K. of numerous episodes of criminal activity, and he was committed to stand trial before the Korolyovskiy District Court in Zhytomyr.

title: CASE OF MISYUKEVICH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Nizhniy Tagil.
- On 19 August 2009, the Leninskiy District Court of Yekaterinburg convicted the applicant of massive fraud, and sentenced him to five and a half years in prison.
- The applicant was represented by his counsel during the trial.
- On 3 September 2009, the applicant lodged an appeal.
- On 23 October 2009, the Sverdlovskiy Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal. 
- The applicant could follow the appeal hearing by video link from Yekaterinburg remand prison IZ-66/1, and neither the counsel nor the prosecutor attended the hearing.
- The applicant was held in Yekaterinburg remand prison IZ-66/1 from 19 August 2009 to 27 October 2009. 
- According to the applicant, conditions of detention there were inhuman and degrading due to overcrowding.

title: CASE OF SERGEY LEBEDEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were targeted in undercover operations by the police 
- The operations were in the form of a test purchase of drugs 
- The activities were conducted under sections 7 and 8 of the Operational-Search Activities Act of 12 August 1995 (no. 144-FZ)
- The operations resulted in their criminal conviction for drug dealing
- The applicants disagreed with their conviction 
- They argued that the police incited them to commit drug-related offenses

title: CASE OF MELNICHUK AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- Four applicants, two of whom are father and daughter, and the other two are husband and wife, all live in Rivne, Ukraine.
- On 24 December 1989, the first and second applicants, along with their respective spouses, were driving in a column of five cars in southern Romania, along with 15 other Soviet citizens.
- A Romanian army unit was dispatched to block the road, suspecting that the foreign cars belonged to possible terrorists.
- The tourists did not understand what was happening and did not get out of the cars when asked to surrender, following which the soldiers started shooting without any warning.
- The shooting resulted in the death of the first applicant's wife and another close relative, and the injury of seven others, including the last two applicants.
- An investigation was initiated in 1990, during which several investigative measures were taken, including questioning of witnesses and victims, medical evaluations, and taken statements from military staff involved in the incident.
- In 1991, a decision not to institute criminal proceedings was taken on the grounds that the soldiers had been led to believe that the tourists were terrorists, and had shot them in self-defence.
- The decision was quashed in 1994 by the Supreme Court, who ordered the opening of criminal proceedings against Lieutenant Colonel S. for aggravated murder.
- On 7 April 1997, Colonel S. was formally charged and questioned by the military prosecutor, and underwent a psychiatric evaluation.
- In August 1998, it was ordered that the criminal investigation should be in rem to allow all relevant persons to be investigated.
- The investigation was discontinued on time-barred grounds in 2005 but was later resumed in 2007 after intervention by two victims.
- The investigation concerning the incident was joined to the main criminal investigation file concerning the December 1989 events, in which over a hundred persons were already charged.

title: CASE OF MANGO v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1929 and lived in Moiano.
- The applicant was the owner of a plot of land in Moiano.
- A decree was issued to take possession of a portion of the applicant's land for the construction of a road.
- The authorities took physical possession of the land on 14 July 1987.
- The applicant brought an action for damages against the Moiano Municipality in 1990.
- An expert valuation of the land was ordered, which concluded that the occupied land covered a surface area of 109 square metres.
- The court declared that the possession of the land had become unlawful as of 14 July 1990 and that the land had been irreversibly transformed by the public works.
- The court determined that the applicant was entitled to compensation for the loss of ownership caused by the unlawful occupation.
- The court awarded the applicant compensation for the damage occasioned by the unavailability of the land during the occupation period, the damage caused by the building works, and the decrease in the value of the adjoining land.
- The judgment became final in May 2006.

title: CASE OF RUSSO v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1943 and lived in Rome.
- The applicant was the owner of a plot of land in Randazzo (Catania), recorded as Folio no. 57, Parcels no. 24, 28, 31, 32, 35 and 360.
- Regional administrative authorities approved a land development plan for the construction of a road on the applicant's land.
- The Mayor of Randazzo issued a decree authorizing the municipality to take possession of a portion of the applicant's land.
- The authorities took physical possession of the land on 2 April 1984.
- The applicant brought an action for damages against the Randazzo Municipality in July 1991, alleging illegal occupation of the land and completion of construction work without formal expropriation and payment of compensation. They claimed a sum corresponding to the land's market value and another for damage during the lawful occupation period.
- The court ordered an expert valuation of the land, which concluded that the market value of the taken land amounted to ITL 9, 000,000.
- The Catania District Court declared on 26 May 1999 that the possession of the land had become unlawful as of 2 April 1990, and the applicant was entitled to compensation.
- The Catania District Court awarded the applicant ITL 2,339,600 as compensation for the damage occasioned by the unavailability of the land during the period of lawful occupation and ITL 5,150,000 as compensation for the decrease in the value of the adjoining land.
- The Municipality appealed against the judgment before the Catania Court of Appeal, while the applicant lodged a cross-appeal.
- By a judgment delivered on 30 July 2002, the Court of Appeal reduced the amount to be awarded as compensation concerning the adjoining land to 4,950,000 ITL and upheld the remainder of the Catania District Court's judgment.
- The judgment became final in September 2004.

title: CASE OF S.L. AND J.L. v. CROATIA
facts:
- Two sisters born in 1987 and 1992 respectively concluded a real estate agreement with B.P. to buy a villa in P in June 1997. The villa was in poor condition as people who had no legal basis had ruined it.
- On 17 December 1997, the sisters acquired ownership of the house for an amount of 450,000 Croatian kunas (HRK).
- In April 2000, the sisters' mother V.L. requested permission from the relevant Social Welfare Centre to sell the house. She, along with her husband, was interviewed at the Centre in April 2000 and stated that they intended to sell the house due to a lack of necessary funds.
- In October 2001, Z.L., the father of the second applicant, was convicted of attempted murder and unlawful possession of firearms. During the proceedings, his defence lawyer was M.I, a lawyer practising in P.
- On 15 October 2001, M.I. submitted a request to the Centre seeking authorisation for a real estate swap agreement between the applicants and a certain D.M., who was in fact M.I.’s mother-in-law.
- On 13 November 2001, the Centre gave its authorisation for the swap agreement, whereby the applicants would transfer their ownership of the house to D.M. while the latter would transfer her ownership of the flat and a garage to the applicants.
- On 16 December 2001, the applicants, represented by V.L., concluded the real estate swap agreement with D.M. before a Public Notary in P., and the applicants thereby transferred their ownership of the house to D.M. while the latter transferred her ownership of the flat and the garage to the applicants.
- On 17 November 2004, the applicants, represented by Z.L. as their legal guardian, brought an action against D.M.in the P. Municipal Court (Općinski sud u P.), asking the court to declare the swap agreement null and void (ništav).
- On 19 March 2007, the P. County Court dismissed the applicants’ appeal as ill-founded, endorsing the reasoning of the first-instance court.
- The applicants then lodged an appeal on points of law before the Supreme Court on 8 June 2007, and on 19 December 2007, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicants’ appeal on points of law as ill-founded.
- A report by the Ministry of Social Policy and Youth of 30 January 2014 submitted to

title: CASE OF ILIEVSKA v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Kriva Palanka.
- On April 24th, 2009, the applicant underwent surgery for stomach cancer and subsequent chemotherapy.
- On October 29th, 2009, the applicant's husband requested medical assistance from Kriva Palanka hospital for her anxiety and distress. Dr. M, a general practitioner, and Dr. C.T, a specialist in neuropsychiatry in Kriva Palanka hospital, instructed for her to be transferred to a psychiatric clinic in Skopje with police assistance.
- An ambulance, accompanied by two police officers, arrived at the applicant's house on October 29th and transferred her to the Bardovci psychiatric hospital in Skopje until October 31st, 2009.
- The applicant was malnourished, dehydrated, had several hematomas, and was burdened with depressive ideas and paranoid attitudes towards her husband and subsequently discharged from the psychiatric hospital without being treated or examined, according to the notice of her discharge dated November 2nd, 2009.
- Following her discharge from the hospital in Skopje, the applicant was admitted to the Kriva Palanka hospital where a medical certificate was issued at her request. The certificate stated that she had injuries inflicted by kicks and blows, and scratches on her body.
- The applicant brought criminal charges of medical malpractice against Dr. C.T, V.S., a nurse, and two police officers, including M.N. and I.A., for their alleged role in inflicting ill-treatment and mild bodily injury.
- The public prosecutor contacted the Ministry of Interior with a request for further information regarding the incident, and a "special report" was submitted by the Sector for Internal Control and Professional Standards within the Ministry of Interior.
- The statements in the report confirmed that the applicant's husband had explained her condition to the doctors M. and C.T., and police officers M.N. and I.A. regarding her mental health state.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDR DMITRIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Kozelsk, Kaluga region.
- The applicant was arrested on 20 April 2003 on suspicion of infliction of bodily injuries that led to death.
- The Kozelskiy district court of the Kaluga region authorised the applicant’s continued detention on 22 April 2003.
- On 18 June 2003, the district court extended the applicant’s detention.
- On 20 July 2003, the prosecutor’s office decided to release the applicant from custody.
- The applicant was released under an undertaking not to leave his place of residence on 22 July 2003.
- On 19 May 2004, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to ten years and six months’ imprisonment.
- On 20 July 2004, the Kaluga regional court ordered a re-trial and the applicant remained in custody.
- From October 2004 to January 2005, the district court repeatedly returned the case to the prosecutor.
- The applicant was detained until 20 April 2005 without any reasons given by the district court.
- On 7 April 2005, the district court convicted the applicant and ordered a re-trial.
- On 25 July 2005, the district court rejected the request for the applicant's release and extended his detention until 1 November 2005.
- The applicant was released under an undertaking not to leave his place of residence on 26 October 2005.
- On 20 December 2005, the district court convicted the applicant again and sentenced him to seven years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant underwent compulsory psychiatric treatment in 2008.
- The applicant stayed in different cells in IZ-16/1 during August and October 2008.
- The cells had a certain number of sleeping places and windows that let in enough light.
- The temperature in the cells was around +20 degrees Celsius.
- The Government submitted certificates and statements by other detainees to claim that the number of inmates in the cells did not exceed the number of sleeping places.

title: CASE OF EMIN HUSEYNOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is an independent journalist with a Category 2 disability and chairman of the Institute for Reporters’ Freedom and Safety (“IRFS”).
- On June 14th, 2008, the applicant, along with his two colleagues R.A. and M.H. attended a gathering organized by the “Che Guevara Fan Club,” which was interrupted by the police.
- The police officers at the gathering took the applicant and others to the police station when they refused to produce their identity cards.
- The applicant identified himself as a journalist and the chairman of the IRFS, showed his identity card, and requested the release of his colleagues.
- The applicant was taken into custody, and four police officers allegedly used force against him, punched and kicked him in the stomach.
- At the police station, the applicant was threatened and mistreated by the police officers, who allegedly used force against him and hit him in the neck, causing him to lose consciousness.
- The applicant was taken to the hospital by others present at the police station, and he was diagnosed with traumatic brain injury and contusion of the soft tissues around the nape of his neck.
- The incident attracted significant public and media interest, and human rights organizations expressed concern over the applicant’s arrest and ill-treatment by the police.
- A criminal inquiry was launched into the applicant's mistreatment by the police.
- The spokesman for the Ministry of Internal Affairs denied the allegations of police mistreatment made by the applicant.

title: CASE OF KHOLODKOV AND KHOLODKOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Vitaliy Kholodkov was found dead in his office on 18 May 2002 with a gunshot wound to his head.
- Some of his personal belongings, including two mobile phones were missing.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted by the Prosecutor's office on the same date, and the first and the second applicants were admitted to proceedings as injured parties.
- The applicants complained to authorities that the investigation was ineffective.
- The investigation had several suspensions and resumptions due to lack of useful leads.
- V.R. was placed on the wanted list as a potential suspect, and the case was transferred to the Donetsk Regional Police Department for further investigation.
- In September 2011, police arrested V.R. and O.B., who had confessed to having beaten and killed Kholodkov.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against A.S. on suspicion of having contracted O.B. and V.R. to assault Kholodkov.
- A verdict was reached in the Kuibyshevskiy District Court in Donetsk convicting A.S. and O.B. of the offense, but the verdict was quashed on appeal.

title: CASE OF IDENTOBA AND OTHERS v. GEORGIA
facts:
- A non-governmental organisation planned to organise a peaceful march for LGBT rights in Tbilisi, Georgia
- The organisation informed the authorities of the route and requested protection due to anticipated protest from those opposed to the LGBT community
- The march was met with aggressive counter-demonstrators who verbally and physically attacked the LGBT marchers
- The police did not effectively intervene and some of the LGBT marchers were detained briefly
- Criminal investigations were opened into the attacks against some of the LGBT marchers, but as of the latest available information, they are still pending and the victims have not been granted victim status.

title: CASE OF LUPENI GREEK CATHOLIC PARISH AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Applicants belong to the Eastern-Rite Catholic Church
- Greek Catholic parishes owned various properties until 1948
- Uniate Church dissolved by Legislative Decree no. 358/1948
- Properties belonging to Uniate Church were transferred to the State except for parish property
- Parish property was transferred to Orthodox Church under Decree no. 177/1948
- After the fall of the communist regime, Decree no. 358/1948 was repealed by Legislative Decree no. 9/1989
-  Legal status of property for Uniate parishes was to be determined by joint committees made up of representatives of both Uniate and Orthodox clergy
- Applicant parish, diocese, and archpriesthood were dissolved on the basis of Legislative Decree no. 358/1948
- The applicant parish was legally re-established on 12 August 1996
- Orthodox Church and Greek Catholic Church convened meetings of a joint committee, composed of senior representatives of the two denominations
- The Orthodox side refused to return the properties and referred to the wishes of the majority of the adherents
- Ministry of Culture and Religious Affairs initiated a meeting on fraternal dialogue
- Second applicant brought proceedings before the domestic courts against the Arad Orthodox Archdiocese and Lupeni Orthodox Parish
- Hunedoara County Court declared the action inadmissible
- An appeal against that judgment was dismissed
- High Court of Cassation and Justice sent the case back for a fresh examination of the merits
- The county court dismissed the applicants' action
- The appeal court allowed the appeal and dismissed the applicants' action
- The High Court of Cassation and Justice dismissed the applicants' appeal.

title: CASE OF CĂPITAN AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Domestic courts made decisions in favour of the applicants.
- The decisions entitled the applicants to monetary compensation or actions from State authorities.
- The decisions were not enforced within the required timeframe.
- The applicants were unable to obtain enforcement of the decisions.

title: CASE OF FĂLIE v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Bucharest.
- In 1999, the applicant purchased a house and the land on which it was built in Bucharest, which was adjacent to land purchased by two other third parties in 1948.
- On 13 November 2001, the applicant lodged a civil action against the two third parties to obtain demarcation of adjacent land and return of 11 sq. m. land illegally occupied by them.
- Bucharest District Court in a judgment of 4 April 2002 held that the defendants had been illegally occupying the land since 1965 and ordered them to return the land to the applicant.
- The defendants lodged an appeal with the Bucharest County Court. The court ordered a new expert report. On 22 May 2003, the court dismissed the appeal.
- The defendants lodged an appeal on points of law later.
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal on 26 November 2003 allowed the appeal on points of law, quashed the decisions of the first two courts, and dismissed the applicant’s action. Both parties had smaller land areas than mentioned in their contracts of acquisition, and the court invited them to reach a friendly settlement. Fresh action was allowed only if they could not reach an agreement.

title: CASE OF NIKOLOVA v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant owned a plot of undeveloped land that was expropriated by the Municipality.
- The expropriation was carried out to construct a storehouse for the benefit of the then socially owned company K.
- The Municipality requested the court to determine the amount of compensation to be paid to the applicant.
- The first-instance court ordered the State to pay the applicant compensation, but the judgment was later quashed and remitted for fresh consideration.
- The final judgment ordered the company M.K., the successor to company K., and the Public Road Fund to pay compensation to the applicant.
- The Supreme Court later overturned the first- and second-instance courts’ judgments and dismissed the order for compensation to be paid to the applicant.
- The applicant later lodged a request against the Municipality and was granted compensation by the court, which was upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF MUKHITDINOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in Uzbekistan and left for Saudi Arabia in 1992.
- He has been living in Russia since 1997 and acquired Russian nationality in 2001.
- His Russian nationality was cancelled in 2013 due to fraud.
- He forfeited his Uzbek nationality in 2013 due to an unaccounted absence.
- He was charged with illegal crossing of the Uzbek State border in 1998.
- He was also charged with involvement in The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan in 2009.
- An arrest warrant was issued for him in Uzbekistan in 2009.
- He was arrested in Russia in 2013 and his detention was extended.
- His extradition was approved by the Russian Prosecutor General in 2013, despite concerns of ill-treatment or torture in Uzbekistan.
- His detention was challenged and he was released in 2014, but the Supreme Court rejected his challenge to the extradition decision.
- He was taken from his home in July 2014 by officers of the Federal Migration Service and his whereabouts became unknown.
- A criminal case was instituted into his disappearance in August 2014.

title: CASE OF HAJRUDINOVIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Jesenice.
- Insolvency proceedings were instituted against the applicant's employer, S., on 15 April 1998.
- On 29 April 1998, the receiver in insolvency terminated the applicant's employment contract with the company S.
- The applicant lodged a claim for a redundancy payment in the insolvency proceedings, which was disputed by the receiver. The Kranj District Court referred the applicant to labour proceedings on 11 September 1998.
- The applicant instituted proceedings before the Kranj Division of the Labour and Social Court on 22 December 1998.
- The Kranj Labour and Social Court dismissed the claims of four workers similar to the applicant's in 1999, stating that workers who lost their jobs due to their employer's insolvency before Section 19 of the 1999 Act became effective were not entitled to redundancy payment.
- In 2000, several constitutional review applications were filed against Section 19 of the 1999 Act.
- On 5 October 2001, the Constitutional Court dismissed motions to review the constitutionality of Section 19 of the 1999 Act, clarifying that the right to a redundancy payment was already envisaged in the general labour legislation.
- On 14 July 2003, the parties settled, and on 13 July 2006, the applicant filed a claim for compensation for damage sustained due to delays in the proceedings.
- On 27 September 2007, the Ljubljana Local Court rejected the applicant's claim. The Ljubljana Higher Court overturned the judgement on appeal and remitted the case back to the first-instance court.
- On 8 May 2008, the Ljubljana Local Court rejected the applicant's claim again, and on appeal, the Ljubljana Higher Court dismissed the appeal on 5 November 2008.
- The Constitutional Court granted the applicant's constitutional appeal on 27 May 2010 and remitted the case to the higher court.
- On 25 October 2010, the Ljubljana Local Court rejected the applicant's claim, applying the provisions of the 2006 Act by analogy, and taking into account the case law of the ECtHR.
- The Ljubljana Higher Court dismissed the applicant's appeal on 13 April 2011, and the Supreme Court refused to grant the applicant leave to appeal on points of law, and the

title: CASE OF ZAVODNIK v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1938 and lives in Ravne na Koroškem
- In 1993, the applicant's former employer company Z.R. transferred him to another company
- The applicant instituted proceedings against the company Z.R. on 20 April 1993 before the Maribor Court of Associated Labour
- The Convention came into force in respect of Slovenia on 28 June 1994
- The applicant's case was transferred to the Slovenj Gradec division of the Maribor Labour Court in September 1995
- Between February 1996 and March 1997, the court held five hearings
- On 13 March 1997, the Maribor Labour Court established that the applicant's transfer had never taken effect, and that his employment with company Z.R. had continued
- The court ordered company Z.R. to re-employ the applicant and pay him the salary due and applicable benefits backdated to the day of his transfer. The remainder of the claim was dismissed
- In a decision of 16 April 1999, the Slovenian Pensions and Disability Insurance Institute recognized the applicant's right to a pension as of 1 February 1999
- The employment relationship with Z.R. terminated as of that date because they had still not re-employed him
- On 17 June 1999, the judgment of 13 March 1997 was upheld by the Higher Labour and Social Court and became final
- On 6 April 2000, the applicant instituted enforcement proceedings before the Slovenj Gradec Local Court since company Z.R. had not executed the court's judgment
- On 5 July 2000, the Slovenj Gradec District Court decided to institute bankruptcy proceedings against the company Z.R.
- On 31 August 2000, the applicant lodged a claim in the bankruptcy proceedings for the judgment of 13 March 1997
- On 5 December 2000, the Maribor Higher Court instructed the receiver to institute proceedings in respect of the disputed part of the applicant's claim
- On 8 April 2003, the receiver withdrew his claim against the applicant
- As a result, on 5 May 2004, the Slovenj Gradec District Court stayed the contentious proceedings
- On 1 February 2005, the receiver accepted the applicant’s claim in the full amount
- In 2006, ownership of the hotel complex, R.V., was transferred to the company Z

title: CASE OF ILIE GUȚĂ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The document contains a table listing the applicants and their relevant details.
- The applicants complained about non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions that entitled them to pecuniary amounts or certain actions by State authorities.
- Some of the applicants also raised other complaints under different provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF DRĂGUNĂ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A list of applicants is provided along with details of their applications.
- The applicants complained about the conditions of their detention being inadequate.

title: CASE OF IGNATKINA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant reported being beaten by Z. on 16 December 1999.
- District Police refused to investigate on 22 December 1999.
- Applicant renewed criminal complaint on 18 January and 1 February 2000.
- Forensic medical examination on applicant ordered on 22 March 2000 revealed head injury, concussion, haemorrhage, and could have been inflicted by Z.
- Criminal investigation instituted on 5 April 2000.
- Witnesses questioned and reconstructions of events carried out between April and May 2000.
- District Prosecutor's Office urged police to accelerate investigation on 14 February 2001.
- Investigation suspended and quashed multiple times between 2001 and 2003.
- Medical examination on 24 June 2003 revealed head injury, concussion, and hearing deterioration due to the beating.
- Criminal case sent to court on 17 August 2003.
- Civil claim for compensation filed on 6 October 2003.
- Criminal case sent back for additional investigation on 10 November 2003.
- Medical examination confirming injuries on applicant conducted on 10 January 2004.
- Additional forensic medical examination refused on 19 January 2004.
- Z. issued passport for travel abroad on 10 March 2004.
- Criminal case sent to court on 9 April 2004.
- Criminal case remitted back to police after court found unable to rule on Z.'s guilt on 10 November 2004.
- General Prosecutor's Office of Ukraine requested Z.'s extradition on 27 October 2009.
- Z. extradited to Ukraine on 22 June 2010.
- Criminal case sent to court again on 21 January 2011.
- Judgment of 14 May 2012 convicts Z. and orders him to pay compensation to the applicant.
- Criminal case remitted for additional investigation on 19 July 2012.
- Pre-trial investigation completed again on 14 November 2012.
- Criminal proceedings terminated as time-barred on 12 December 2012.
- Case remitted to District Court for fresh consideration on 5 September 2013.
- Criminal proceedings suspended again on 17 October 2013 due to Z.'s absconding.

title: CASE OF TÓTH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant’s employment was terminated unlawfully, as per the Budapest Labour Court judgment dated 24 August 2004.
- The applicant lodged claims for unpaid wages and other claims against his former employer on 19 October 2004.
- The Pest County Labour Court rejected the claim on 5 May 2006.
- The second-instance court quashed the judgment and transferred the case to the competent Budapest Regional Court on 24 January 2007.
- The Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s claim on 28 November 2008.
- The Budapest Court of Appeal upheld, in essence, the first‑instance decision on 14 September 2010.
- The Supreme Court reversed the previous decision and awarded the applicant 2,053,440 Hungarian forints in salary arrears.

title: CASE OF BERKI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Budapest.
- On 30 March 2004, the applicant was detained on suspicion of misuse of illegal pornographic material.
- The Budapest IV/XV District Court acquitted the applicant on 9 April 2008, after holding three hearings.
- The Budapest Regional Court upheld the acquittal on 17 March 2009, upon appeal.

title: CASE OF Y. v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant arrived in Slovenia in 2000 with her family, who had married a Slovenian.
- Between July and December 2001, the applicant was allegedly sexually assaulted by X, a family friend, repeatedly.
- The applicant told her mother about the assaults in July 2002 and her mother immediately lodged a criminal complaint against X.
- Police questioned X and three other individuals in relation to the allegations.
- Following a request by the applicant's mother, a judicial investigation was requested in respect of X based on charges of sexual assault on a minor below the age of fifteen.
- X was summoned to appear before the court and refused to give an oral statement. He later submitted a written statement denying the charges.
- An expert in gynaecology found the applicant's hymen was intact and concluded that there was nothing to indicate with certainty that the applicant had had sexual intercourse with X at the time in question.
- An expert in clinical psychology concluded that the applicant had exhibited all the symptoms of a victim of sexual and other kinds of abuse.
- X was indicted for sexual assault and multiple hearings were scheduled and postponed.

title: CASE OF YEGOROV v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and resides in Ukraine.
- From 25 June 2002 to 19 September 2013, the applicant was continuously deprived of his liberty in Slovakia on various charges, including murder and conceiving a criminal and terrorist group.
- The applicant's pre-trial detention in the second period was due to the charge of murder, of which he was acquitted on 27 July 2011.
- Following his release on the same day, he was re-arrested on the charge of conceiving, setting up and supporting a criminal and terrorist group and was later remanded pending trial.
- His detention on this charge ended with the applicant’s release on 22 February 2012.
- Upon his release, he was immediately re-arrested and detained pending trial on another charge of murder, which ended with his release on 17 September 2013.
- The applicant was then transferred to a detention centre for foreigners and was expelled to Ukraine on 19 September 2013.
- The applicant lodged complaints and appeals, including an interlocutory appeal against his detention, but they were dismissed as unfounded or inadmissible.

title: CASE OF NEDYALKOV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in different years and live in different villages/cities
- Predecessor of the applicants owned agricultural land in the village of Kranevo, which was collectivized after 1945
- The fourth applicant sought restitution of land after the Agricultural Land Act was adopted in 1991
- The Balchik agricultural land commission allowed only partial restoration of the heirs' rights
- The Balchik District Court quashed the relevant part of the land commission's decision, recognizing the heirs as the "owners" of all of the land claimed by them
- The land commission restored a plot of 1,180 square meters to the heirs, which was allocated to the fourth applicant and his sister after agreeing on the partition of the restituted land
- The plot was held by several private persons who had obtained title to the land legally
- The rei vindicatio action brought by the fourth applicant and his sister was disallowed by the Supreme Court of Cassation
- The domestic courts found that the documents referred to "a non-existent plot under a non-existent plan"
- The defendants were entitled to hold the land as its owners
- The applicants have not sought compensation in lieu of restitution in kind.

title: CASE OF ERLA HLYNSDÓTTIR v. ICELAND (No. 3)
facts:
- Ms Erla Hlynsdóttir is an Icelandic journalist.
- The Director of Public Prosecutions issued an indictment against two individuals for importing cocaine into Iceland.
- The accused had driven the vehicle to a garage, where the substance had been removed.
- The newspaper DV published an article on the ongoing criminal proceedings against Mr A and his co-accused before the Reykjavík District Court.
- The Reykjavík District Court acquitted both Mr A and his co-accused of all charges, and on 29 May 2008 the Supreme Court upheld the acquittal.
- Mr A lodged defamation proceedings before the Reykjavík District Court against the applicant and Mr S.M.E.
- By a judgment of 26 June 2009 the District Court found for the applicant and the editor.
- On 21 October 2008 Mr A lodged defamation proceedings before the Reykjavík District Court against the applicant and Mr S.M.E.
- By a judgment of 11 March 2010, the Supreme Court overturned the District Court judgment.
- The Supreme Court ordered the applicant and the editor jointly and severally to pay the appellant ISK 100,000 in compensation for non-pecuniary damage. 
- After his acquittal, Mr A initiated proceedings before the domestic courts, seeking compensation from the Icelandic State for unlawful detention during the above-mentioned criminal investigation. 
- The Supreme Court found the detention to have been justified even though he was later acquitted. 
- In April 2009, Mr A was again arrested for involvement in importing drugs into Iceland, and in December 2009 he was sentenced by a final judgment to ten years´ imprisonment for his part in the crime.

title: CASE OF KYRIACOU TSIAKKOURMAS AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are a family living in various cities in Cyprus
- A Turkish Cypriot named Ömer Gazi Tekoğul was arrested in possession of drugs, which led to protests from the authorities of the “Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus”
- The arrest of Mr Tekoğul is disputed, with the Republic of Cyprus authorities maintaining that it was lawful
- The first applicant is a building contractor who employed Turkish Cypriot workers
- On the morning of 13 December 2000, the first applicant was detained by the “TRNC” authorities in a disputed series of events
- The first applicant was physically assaulted and abducted by four men in civilian clothes, and taken to the “TRNC”
- The first applicant was then interrogated by unknown individuals and taken to a hospital for medical examination, during which he claims he was mistreated
- The first applicant was charged with drug possession and thrown into custody for eight days without being informed of his rights.

title: CASE OF RUSLAN YAKOVENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Korolivka, in the Kyiv Region.
- The applicant was found guilty of inflicting grievous bodily injuries on Mr N. on 12 May 2006 by the Bila Tserkva Court.
- The Bila Tserkva Court applied a more lenient sanction to the applicant and sentenced him to four years and seven months’ imprisonment, taking into account his guilty plea and remorse.
- The court decided to include the period from 20 October 2005 to 3 May 2006 in the served part of the applicant’s sentence during which he had been detained in another criminal case.
- The court ruled that the applicant should remain in a pre-trial detention centre (“SIZO”) as a preventive measure until the judgment became final.
- The applicant's sentence expired on 15 July 2010, but his request for release was rejected by the SIZO administration, and no reply was received to their request for permission to release him subject to an undertaking not to abscond.
- The applicant’s lawyer applied once again for the applicant’s immediate release on 19 July 2010 and argued that there were no grounds for continued detention.
- The appeal time-limit expired on 27 July 2010, and the judgment became final.
- The SIZO administration wrote to the applicant’s lawyer on the same day that the court had to authorize the release and prevent the change in respect of the applicant.
- The final judgment was enforced on 29 July 2010, and the applicant released.
- The State Prisons Department wrote to the applicant’s lawyer on 5 August 2010, stating that there had been no violation of the Code of Criminal Procedure in response to his complaints regarding the delayed release of the applicant.

title: CASE OF VELCHEVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1927 and lives in Ribaritsa village.
- Her father owned agricultural land that was incorporated into an agricultural cooperative in the 1950s.
- In 1991, the applicant applied for the land restitution according to the Agricultural Land Act.
- The land commission refused the restitution and granted compensation instead, which was challenged by the applicant in 2004.
- The Teteven District Court overturned the decision of the land commission in 2005 and granted the restitution in kind of two plots of land.
- No appeal was lodged against the District Court’s judgment, which entered into force on 26 September 2005.
- The Agriculture and Forestry Department took another decision in February 2006, which was nullified by the Lovech Regional Court in October 2006 for contradicting the 2005 judgment.
- The Agriculture and Forestry Department adopted a new decision in October 2006, restoring the applicant’s rights to three plots of land, but it is unclear whether the applicant received it or not.

title: CASE OF BRATANOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Las Vegas, United States of America.
