- Her mother owned a plot of agricultural land of 1,000 square metres which was expropriated in 1952 and subsequently included in the urban territory of the Bankya district of Sofia.
- The applicant is her mother's sole heir.
- In 1992, following the adoption of the Agricultural Land Act, the applicant requested that her property rights to the plot be restored.
- The Bankya land commission required the presentation of a plan of the plot and a certificate to continue the procedure, as it had become part of the urban territory.
- The applicant requested the Bankya district mayor to issue the required documents, but they were not issued despite her submission of various necessary documents.
- The applicant applied for judicial review of the mayor's refusal in February 2007.
- The Sofia Administrative Court initially dismissed the application as inadmissible but later, on appeal by the applicant, ordered the mayor to issue the documents.
- The mayor instructed the applicant to submit additional documents, and in February 2010, refused to issue them.
- In a new judgment of June 2011, the Sofia Administrative Court dismissed the application for judicial review.
- Upon further appeal, the Supreme Administrative Court set aside the above judgment.
- The mayor was ordered to issue the documents sought by the applicant, which were prerequisites for the resumption of the stayed restitution procedure.
- In August 2014, a judge from the Supreme Administrative Court imposed a BGN 1,000 fine on the Bankya district mayor for his failure to comply with the court's order.

title: CASE OF COMPCAR, S.R.O. v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant company purchased real property from a State-owned enterprise acting through a receiver in insolvency.
- The property was sold directly and not through a public auction with the consent of the insolvency court.
- The sale was approved by the insolvency court and registered in the land registry, transferring the title to the applicant company.
- The City of Košice claimed that the property had not been registered as its own and therefore did not belong to the seller, rendering the sale void.
- Both the district and regional courts unanimously concluded that the applicant company had acquired the property in good faith and dismissed the claimant’s action.
- The claimant filed a petition with the Office of the Prosecutor General requesting an extraordinary appeal. The Prosecutor General challenged the judgments in the Supreme Court, which ultimately quashed the judgments and remitted the case to the first-instance court for a new determination.
- The Constitutional Court declared the applicant company’s complaint manifestly ill-founded and found no irregularities in the Supreme Court’s decision and reasoning or underlying procedure.

title: CASE OF DRAFT - OVA A.S. v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant company was established in 1993 in the Czech Republic.
- The present case concerns claims against a Slovak gas company from 1998.
- Promissory notes were issued by the defendant's director in the name of the company for large amounts of money, which were contested by the company.
- The defendant was transformed into a joint-stock company and privatized with a clause that the State would indemnify investors for any loss incurred due to the promissory notes.
- The applicant company relied on a promissory note for over €11 million signed by the director in the name of the defendant, which was upheld by the District Court and the Regional Court.
- The defendant filed a petition for an extraordinary appeal on points of law with the Office of the Prosecutor General, which was accepted, and the enforceability of the payment order was suspended.
- The defendant argued that the applicant company had acquired the promissory note in bad faith or with gross negligence.
- The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, quashed the judgment, and remitted the case to the District Court for a new determination.
- The applicant company challenged the Supreme Court's judgment in the Constitutional Court, invoking its rights to a fair trial, property protection, legal certainty, and rule of law.

title: CASE OF PSMA, SPOL. S R.O. v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant company entered into a contract with Slovak Radio to act as an exclusive agent for the sale of broadcasting time for advertising purposes.
- The contract was amended several times and was valid until December 2007.
- The relationship between the applicant company and the principal began to deteriorate when the principal was not content with the amount of business acquired by the applicant company in 2003.
- The principal issued the applicant company with a bill for the difference between the estimated profit and the real profit from such business which the applicant company did not pay.
- The principal terminated the contract due to the applicant company's failure to pay the bill.
- The applicant company challenged the validity of the notice of termination of the contract in court but later withdrew the action.
- The principal sued the applicant company for the payment of the difference between the estimated profit and the real profit.
- The applicant company demanded indemnity for termination of the contract calculating it as the average yearly commission for the preceding five years.
- The applicant company sued the principal for the indemnity amount and late-payment interest.
- The District Court granted the applicant company's claim in full.
- The Regional Court upheld the District Court's judgment acknowledging the applicant company's entitlement to indemnity except for the part related to barter transactions.
- The PG challenged the judgments by way of an extraordinary appeal.
- The Supreme Court allowed the extraordinary appeal, quashed the judgments of both the District Court and the Regional Court, and remitted the matter to the former for new examination.
- The applicant company contested the Supreme Court's decision of 12 August 2009 by lodging a complaint with the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF L'TRADING AND INVEST LINES KFT v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant involved in property litigation since 6 March 1996. 
- Proceedings suspended due to pending construction authority proceedings. 
- First hearing held in 1999. 
- Court separated proceedings on 2 December 2004. 
- Counterclaim of the applicant rejected on 27 June 2006. 
- Budapest Regional Court quashed the decision on 27 March 2007. 
- Resumed proceedings found partly in favor of the applicant on 27 January 2010. 
- Budapest Court of Appeal upheld the judgment on 1 January 2010. 
- Applicant lodged a petition for review. 
- Supreme Court reversed the judgment on 9 November 2011. 
- Decision served on the applicant on 1 March 2012.

title: CASE OF BECKER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was stopped by the police while driving his car on a public road.
- The applicant underwent a breathalyser test, which was discontinued after nine attempts to measure the amount of alcohol. Only one attempt produced a valid result.
- The Melk District Administrative Authority (DAA) withdrew the applicant’s driving licence for a period of four months to secure road safety.
- The DAA observed that the applicant had refused to undergo the breathalyser test, as he had made four invalid attempts out of five.
- The Lower Austria Regional Government dismissed the applicant’s appeal, stating that refusing to undergo a breathalyser test was as serious as driving under the influence of alcohol because it prevented the authorities from verifying whether a person was actually drunk.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Administrative Court and requested an oral hearing.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint, stating that on the basis of the evidence before them, the applicant had refused to undergo the breathalyser test.
- The applicant was fined for refusal to take the breathalyser test, but the fine expired after 15 months.

title: CASE OF TYCHKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lived in Volgograd.
- On 15 August 2001, criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on suspicion of large-scale fraud.
- On 28 September 2001, the applicant was arrested and remanded in custody.
- On 2 October 2001 and 22 July 2002, charges were brought against the applicant.
- On 7 August 2002, the criminal case was submitted to the District Court for trial.
- On 8 October 2002, the first hearing was held. It was presided over by judge A.
- On 26 November 2002, the applicant was released from custody.
- On 30 December 2002, the case was transferred to judge G., and the trial was restarted.
- Between March and June 2003 and between June 2004 and January 2005, the hearings were adjourned due to non-attendance or requests for more time.
- On 19 January 2003, an unrelated criminal case was opened against the applicant on suspicion of storing firearms and narcotic drugs. He was remanded in custody again on 20 January 2003.
- On 19 June 2003, the District Court convicted the applicant of storing firearms and narcotic drugs and sentenced him to eight years’ imprisonment.
- On 28 March 2005, judge G. went on maternity leave, and on 26 April 2005, the case was transferred to judge S. The trial was restarted.
- Between May and November 2005, the hearings were adjourned due to non-attendance.
- On 16 December 2005, judge S. resigned, and on 14 February 2006, the case was transferred to judge M. The trial was again restarted.
- Between March and June 2006, the hearings were adjourned due to non-attendance.
- On 19 July 2006, judge M. resigned, and the case was transferred to judge Mar. The trial was restarted.
- Between November 2006 and June 2008, the hearings were adjourned due to non-attendance.
- On 6 August 2008, the District Court of Volgograd found the applicant guilty of complicity in large-scale fraud and sentenced him to three years and six months’ imprisonment. The final sentence under both verdicts was set at nine years’ imprisonment.
- On 1 December 2009, Volg

title: CASE OF LUTSENKO v. UKRAINE (No. 2)
facts:
- Mr Yuriy Vitaliyovych Lutsenko, a Ukrainian national born in 1964, served as Minister of the Interior from 2005 to 2006 and from 18 December 2007 to 11 March 2010.
- In November and December 2010, criminal proceedings were instituted against him for suspicion of abuse of office and exceeding his official powers.
- The two criminal cases were joined together, and on 27 February 2012, he was sentenced to four years’ imprisonment.
- Mr Lutsenko appealed the first-instance judgment, but it was upheld by the Kyiv Court of Appeal in May 2012.
- He was transferred to Mena colony in Chernihiv Region to serve his prison sentence from 31 August 2012 to 7 April 2013.
- On 7 April 2013, he was released after the former President of Ukraine issued a decree of pardon, which included Mr Lutsenko.
- Before his arrest, Mr Lutsenko was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 and chronic gastritis and pancreatitis.
- During his detention, he complained of various health problems to the prison doctors, who examined him regularly.
- On 21 April 2011, Mr Lutsenko went on a hunger strike in protest at his continued pre-trial detention.
- He was transferred to the SIZO medical unit on 6 May 2011, and then to the Kyiv Clinical Emergency Hospital on 10 May 2011, where he was diagnosed with several medical conditions. He ended his hunger strike on 23 May 2011.

title: CASE OF WALLNÖFER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1933 and lived in Innsbruck.
- The applicant was the manager of Alpenland Holland B.V., a company registered in the Netherlands dealing with artwork.
- The Innsbruck Tax Authority informed the Innsbruck Public Prosecutor of the suspicion of tax fraud by the applicant in connection with the sale of several pieces of artwork by Alpenland Holland B.V.
- The Innsbruck Regional Court issued an order for the applicant’s home to be searched, and the applicant was notified of the investigations against him.
- The Innsbruck Tax Authority submitted its final report to the Innsbruck Public Prosecutor.
- The Innsbruck Public Prosecutor issued an indictment against the applicant concerning the suspicion of tax fraud during the years 1989, 1990, and 1992.
- The Innsbruck Regional Court held several oral hearings.
- The Supreme Court quashed the judgment upon a plea of nullity by the Innsbruck Tax Authority and referred the case back to the first instance for a re-trial.
- The Innsbruck Regional Court convicted the applicant of tax fraud and sentenced him to a fine.
- The Supreme Court referred the case back to the first instance again.
- An expert was commissioned to determine the assessment base for the calculation of the taxes.
- Further oral hearings were held, and the length of the proceedings was noted.
- The indictment was withdrawn by the Innsbruck Public Prosecutor because the statutory time-limit for the prosecution of the offence had expired.
- The Procurator General’s Office lodged a plea of nullity for the preservation of the law regarding the judgment.
- The Supreme Court held that the judgment had violated the applicant’s rights under Article 6 § 2 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MASHCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
• The applicant's husband was reported by an ambulance team to have died of a head injury on 20 June 2003.
• The police examined the scene, and the body was forensically examined.
• A medical certificate was released on 23 June 2003, stating that the husband died from a head injury.
• On 30 June 2003, the Gagarinskiy District Prosecutors’ Office in Sevastopol concluded that the death was accidental and that there were no grounds to initiate criminal proceedings.
• In September 2003, the applicant appealed against the decision, stating that the inquiry had been perfunctory.
• On 26 February 2004, the court revoked the disputed decision.
• On 30 April 2004, the District Prosecutor’s Office took a fresh decision not to institute criminal proceedings.
• Between 2004 and 2011, nine more decisions were taken not to institute criminal proceedings.
• In 2011 and 2012, the District Prosecutor’s Office took fresh decisions not to institute proceedings since there was no evidence of criminal wrongdoing.
• The applicant argued that throughout the proceedings, the District Prosecutor’s Office failed to keep her informed, provide her with copies of decisions, and respond to her queries.

title: CASE OF PANCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in St Petersburg.
- In 1995, a criminal case was opened against the applicant on suspicion of fraud and bribery.
- On 31 August 1995, investigators searched the applicant’s home and office and confiscated items and money.
- On 10 March 1998, the applicant sued the Prosecutor’s Office for the return of his possessions but the proceedings were adjourned pending the outcome of the criminal case.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of St Petersburg established that the searches of 31 August 1995 were unlawful in November 2000 and January 2001.
- Civil proceedings were resumed in July 2002.
- On 4 February 2004, the criminal proceedings against the applicant were discontinued and prosecutors returned some of the applicant’s possessions but the rest had already been disposed of.
- The European Court of Human Rights found that the length of the criminal proceedings against the applicant was unreasonable on 8 February 2005.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court partly upheld the applicant’s claims on 9 March 2005 and remitted the case for a fresh examination on 18 May 2005.
- On 13 February 2007, the applicant submitted an amended statement of claims, including a request for damages, costs, and expenses.
- On 3 October 2007, the St Petersburg City Court awarded the applicant damages and costs and expenses but dismissed his claim for loss of profit and acknowledged that the investigative authorities had illegally removed and disposed of his property.
- The judgment was enforced in January 2008.

title: CASE OF KOBERNIK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Bataysk, Rostov Region.
- In 1987, the applicant suffered from extensive exposure to radioactive emissions during the Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster.
- In 1993, the applicant was granted the status of a disabled person and awarded a monthly compensation.
- In 2002, the applicant brought proceedings against the Bataysk Social Security Office seeking indexation of the compensation amount and payment of respective arrears for the previous years.
- On 21 January 2003, the Bataysk Town Court ordered the increase of the monthly allowances due to the applicant.
- On 16 April 2003, the judgment was upheld on appeal by the Rostov Regional Court and entered into force.
- On 4 December 2003, the Presidium of the Rostov Regional Court quashed the judgment of 21 January 2003.
- On 25 December 2003, the Bataysk Town Court reduced the multiplier to 1.25, recalculated the compensation amount and reduced it to RUB 3,125.
- On 20 January 2010, the Bataysk Town Court awarded the applicant pecuniary damages in the amount of RUB 76,061.40 for the period from 1 July 2000 to 4 December 2007.

title: CASE OF DİCLE AND SADAK v. TURKEY [Extracts]
facts:
- Mr Hatip Dicle and Mr Selim Sadak were MPs in the Grand National Assembly of Turkey and members of the DEP political party
- Mr Hatip Dicle and Mr Selim Sadak were arrested and sentenced to fifteen years’ imprisonment for belonging to an illegal organization
- The European Court of Human Rights found a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention on account of the lack of independence and impartiality of the State Security Court
- Act No. 4793 reforming a number of previous Acts came into force, providing for the reopening of criminal proceedings following a finding of a violation by the European Court of Human Rights
- The applicants requested the reopening of proceedings on the basis of the judgment delivered by the Court in their case
- The Ankara State Security Court reiterated its judgment of 8 December 1994 but the Court of Cassation later quashed the judgment and sent the case to the Ankara Assize Court
- The Assize Court upheld the conviction but reduced the applicants’ sentence to a prison term of seven years and six months
- Mr Hatip Dicle applied to the Ankara Assize Court for a document establishing that he had served his full prison term.

title: CASE OF SARGSYAN v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Nagorno-Karabakh was an autonomous region of Azerbaijan SSR before the dissolution of the USSR.
- The population of Nagorno-Karabakh consisted of mostly ethnic Armenians, and they demonstrated for unification with Armenia in 1988.
- Moscow placed Nagorno-Karabakh under direct rule in 1989.
- Azerbaijan declared independence from the USSR in 1991, and Nagorno-Karabakh declared independence from Azerbaijan the same year.
- A full-scale war escalated in 1992, and ethnic Armenians gained control of almost the entire territory of Nagorno-Karabakh and seven adjacent Azerbaijani regions.
- The parties have not signed a formal agreement on the Basic Principles for settlement, and a peaceful solution has yet to be reached.
- The applicant, an ethnic Armenian, claims to have lived in the Shahumyan district of Azerbaijan SSR until his forced displacement in 1992.
- The applicant submitted evidence of the house and outhouses he owned in Gulistan, a village in the Shahumyan district.

title: CASE OF CHIRAGOV AND OTHERS v. ARMENIA
facts:
- Nagorno-Karabakh was an autonomous region of the Azerbaijan SSR at the time of the USSR's demise.
- Although Nagorno-Karabakh and the Armenian SSR were separated by Azerbaijani territory, demonstrations were held to demand incorporation of Nagorno-Karabakh into Armenia.
- The USSR government placed Nagorno-Karabakh under Moscow's direct rule, but later returned control of the region to Azerbaijan.
- On 2 September 1991, the Soviet of the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast announced the establishment of the "Republic of Nagorno-Karabakh" and declared that it was no longer under Azerbaijani jurisdiction.
- In early 1992, the conflict escalated into a full-scale war with the ethnic Armenians conquering several Azeri villages, including the district of Lachin.
- The district of Lachin was attacked many times, and on 17 May 1992, the town was captured by forces of Armenian ethnicity, which resulted in villagers fleeing.
- Mr Elkhan Chiragov was born in 1950 and lived in the district of Lachin, where his ancestors had lived for hundreds of years. He claimed his possessions included a large furnished house, beehives, livestock, and handmade carpets.

title: CASE OF VASIL HRISTOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Oryahovo.
- On 13 June 2002, he, his son, and his brother were attacked by a group of men and beaten with bats and metal rods. The applicant was left unconscious with a traumatic brain injury and broken skull and a dislocated finger. 
- Both injuries, necessitating his hospitalization for several days, were classed as intermediate bodily harm under Bulgarian law.
- On the same day, the police opened criminal investigation and carried out an inspection of the scene of the attack. 
- The applicant, his son, and his brother explained that the family had been in a dispute with K.K., who had been buying snails from them. 
- A man named T.K. said that in the days preceding the attack, members of the applicant's family had been threatening K.K. 
- K.K. was charged after this date for his participation. 
- On 21 March 2003, the prosecutor discontinued the proceedings against K.K. 
- On 31 October 2005, the prosecutor once again stayed the criminal proceedings on the grounds that the perpetrators had not been identified. 
- On 9 June 2006, the investigator once again interviewed the applicant and his son. 
- On 2 December 2009, the Oryahovo district prosecutor’s office indicted the two men, having separated the material concerning the remaining attackers, who had not been identified, into a new case file. 
- On 20 April 2012, the Oryahovo District Court convicted the two accused of causing bodily harm to the applicant, and ordered them to pay 10,000 Bulgarian levs (BGN) in compensation for non-pecuniary damage. 
- On 9 October 2012, the District Court's judgment was quashed by the Vratsa Regional Court, which remitted the case to the prosecution. 
- In a decision of 3 December 2012, the prosecutor in charge once again ordered a stay of the criminal proceedings.
- Following inquiries by the prosecution, in letters of 8 April and 25 June 2013 and 24 March 2014 the local police directorate stated that none of the persons searched for had been identified.

title: CASE OF RAFAILOVIĆ AND STEVANOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Varna. The second applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Sokobanja.
- The first applicant ran a transport business as a sole proprietor from 1979 to 1995 and provided transport services to the Pocerski Metković local community in Šabac in 1990 and 1991.
- On an unspecified date in 1994, the applicant, along with two other traders, brought an action against the local community requesting payment for services provided.
- On 11 May 2001, the Valjevo Commercial Court ordered the local community to pay the applicant 24,400 Serbian dinars (RSD) with interest, but the judgment remains unenforced to date.
- The second applicant ran an installation business “Instalaterska radnja Sokosat” as a sole proprietor and entered into a contract with the Sokobanja local community.
- On 17 April 2003, the Zaječar Commercial Court partly upheld an enforcement order and ordered the local community to pay the business (i) the amounts of RSD 342,098.80 of debt and RSD 18,672 for the costs incurred within the enforcement proceedings.
- On 13 March 2007, the Municipal Court suspended the enforcement proceedings as the exact ownership in respect of the system was unclear, and instructed the applicant to initiate a new set of proceedings to determine the debtor’s exact ownership in respect of the system, and settle the applicant’s claim in that direction.
- The judgment of 17 April 2003 and the decisions of 2 February and 25 March 2005 remain unenforced to date.

title: CASE OF B. AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1960, 1979 and 1987 respectively and live in Petrinja.
- On 9 August 1991, V.B. was beaten up and taken to the Sisak Hospital where he died soon afterwards.
- V.B. was the applicants’ respective husband and father.
- The Sisak County State Attorney’s Office lodged a criminal complaint against a person or persons unknown.
- On 20 June 2011, the Sisak County Police lodged a criminal complaint against Đ.B., V.M and D.B..
- On 16 December 2011, the Osijek County State Attorney’s Office lodged an indictment against V.M. and D.B..
- On 9 December 2013, V.M. was found guilty of war crimes against the civilian population.
- On 10 June 2014, the Supreme Court upheld the conviction of V.M. and increased his sentence to ten years’ imprisonment.
- The claim of the applicants for compensation was dismissed on 6 April 2005 and was upheld on appeal by the Sisak County Court and the Supreme Court on 11 September 2008 and 19 May 2010 respectively.

title: CASE OF YAIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a mentally disabled person.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of having committed a murder on 19 September 2003.
- The applicant's mother informed the investigator that the applicant suffered from a mental disease.
- From 19 September to 25 October 2003, the applicant confessed to the murder he was arrested for and five other murders during questioning conducted in the presence of counsel.
- The Kopeysk Town Court remanded the applicant in custody on 20 September 2003 upon the investigator’s request.
- The Tsentralniy District Court extended the applicant’s detention multiple times until 25 November 2004 on the grounds that he was suspected of an especially serious criminal offence, might abscond, reoffend, interfere with the witnesses, or obstruct the investigation.
- A psychiatric expert examination of the applicant was ordered on 4 March 2004.
- The commission of experts concluded on 16 July 2004 that the applicant was in an acute phase of the disease and was not able to account for his actions.
- On 11 February 2005, the Chelyabinsk Regional Court ordered compulsory treatment of the applicant in a psychiatric institution of a specialized type with intensified supervision until the improvement of his condition.
- The Chelyabinsk Regional Court extended the applicant’s detention multiple times until 22 January 2006 on the grounds that he was suspected of an especially serious criminal offence and the consideration of his case on the merits was still pending.
- On 25 October 2005, the Tsentralniy District Court of Chelyabinsk ordered the applicant’s transfer to a psychiatric institution until the improvement of his condition.
- The medical commission of the psychiatric hospital concluded on 22 September 2006 that the applicant’s condition had improved so that he could be transferred back to the judicial and investigation authorities.
- On 19 April 2007, the commission of experts delivered the results of an inpatient psychiatric expert examination and concluded that at the time of the crimes the applicant was in a state of insanity.
- The Chelyabinsk Regional Court extended the applicant’s detention on 22 August 2007 for three months with reference to the expert’s report of 19 April 2007 and to the fact that he was suspected of an especially serious criminal offence.

title: CASE OF FANZIYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the mother of Ms Madina Eneyeva who died in 2007.
- Ms Eneyeva was arrested on suspicion of theft and taken to the police station. 
- The circumstances of what happened next are in dispute. 
- According to the applicant, Ms Eneyeva was beaten by the police officers until she fainted and was then thrown out of a window. 
- Ms Eneyeva died of complex internal injuries later that day. 
- There were several investigations into her death which were repeatedly suspended, and no one has been held responsible.

title: CASE OF MEHDIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1961 and worked as a journalist in Nakhchivan.
- The applicant wrote critical articles about the Speaker of the Parliament of the Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic, Vasif Talibov.
- The applicant was accused of publishing defamatory articles about the Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic and was arrested by agents of the Ministry of National Security.
- The applicant was taken to MNS premises in Sharur and was tortured by five men.
- The applicant was subsequently taken to the office of the head of the district department of the MNS who demanded that he become a member of the ruling political party and write defamatory articles about opposition leaders, but the applicant refused.
- The applicant was arrested again, this time by the police, on 23 September 2007, and was sentenced to fifteen days’ administrative detention for obstructing the police.
- During his detention, the applicant was deprived of food and water and was forced to spend nights outside.
- The applicant was beaten by the Minister of National Security of the NAR while in detention.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint with the Sharur District Prosecutor’s Office, but no action was taken in respect of his complaints.
- The applicant made representations to the Judicial Legal Council, which forwarded his complaint to the Sharur District Court, asking the court to examine the complaint and to take necessary measures.

title: CASE OF USHAKOV AND USHAKOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple born in 1976 and 1988 respectively
- The first applicant is serving a sentence of imprisonment in Kholodnogirska penitentiary no. 18
- At the time of the events, the applicants lived in a two-room apartment with the second applicant's mother, who had a pending judicial dispute with a certain Mr L. regarding the inheritance of a house
- On 27 June 2008, Mr L. was found dead in his house with multiple stab wounds and cuts, and a broken window and hoe nearby
- The applicants were taken to the police station and questioned regarding their whereabouts and actions on 26 and 27 June 2008
- The first applicant underwent a forensic medical examination the next day, where multiple bruises and sores on his body were found and assessed as having possibly originated from the impact of blunt objects such as glass fragments
- The first applicant alleged that he was coerced and ill-treated by the police to confess to the murder, while the Government maintained that he had not been subjected to any ill-treatment
- The second applicant was threatened by the police with a drug-related offense if she did not testify against her husband
- The police officers who allegedly ill-treated the applicants were investigated and new charges were opened against them after the initial one was discontinued
- The first applicant underwent further forensic medical examination in December 2008 to establish the origin of his injuries

title: CASE OF OPREA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The appendix contains a list of applicants and their application details.
- Applicants claimed inadequate conditions of detention.
- Some of the applications raised complaints under other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ERCAN BOZKURT v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant and his brothers went to collect leaves and twigs on Darkolink hill in Bitlis on 10 November 2000.
- The sledge pulled by their oxen detonated a landmine.
- The applicant and his brother E.B. were injured and taken to a health care center in Güroymak by the gendarmerie.
- The applicant had both legs amputated below the knee.
- It is believed that the landmine was planted by members of the PKK.
- The hill where the incident took place had been used in the past by security forces and village guards for surveillance purposes.
- The applicant filed an action for compensation against the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of the Interior before the Güroymak Civil Court of First Instance.
- The court found that the State could be held responsible for the damage sustained on account of the “social risk” doctrine.
- The applicant brought a new action for compensation before the Van Administrative Court, but the proceedings were discontinued due to his failure to pay the postal costs.
- The administrative court's decision became final by reason of the applicant's failure to appeal.
- The Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's appeal request on the grounds that he failed to lodge his compensation claim within the relevant statutory time-limit.

title: CASE OF CARAIAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1940 and lives in Bucharest.
2. The applicant was remanded in custody for 24 hours on suspicion of intellectual forgery and use of forged documents.
3. The applicant was subsequently detained for five days pending trial on account of the seriousness of the offenses.
4. The applicant's pre-trial detention was extended by 25 days due to the seriousness of the offenses and the need to protect public order.
5. The Alba Iulia Court of Appeal allowed the applicant's challenge and released him under judicial supervision.
6. The Sibiu Prosecutor's Office indicted the applicant and other co-accused for bribery, influence peddling, complicity in fraud, intellectual forgery, and use of forged documents.
7. The Sibiu County Court heard the applicant, his co-accused, and witnesses, and allowed the request for documentary evidence and an expert financial report.
8. The Sibiu County Court acquitted the applicant on the basis of evidence.
9. The Alba Iulia Court of Appeal quashed the judgment, convicted the applicant of several charges, and sentenced him to three years' imprisonment.
10. The Court of Cassation allowed the applicant's appeal, quashed the previous judgments, and referred the case for the investigation to be carried out again.
11. The Sibiu Prosecutor's Office referred the case to the National Anticorruption Prosecutor's Office.
12. The National Anticorruption Prosecutor's Office discontinued the criminal proceedings for bribery and influence peddling but referred the case for the investigation of complicity in fraud and forgery of privately signed documents.
13. The Sibiu Prosecutor's Office discontinued the criminal investigation as the actions were time-barred.
14. The applicant challenged the decision, and the Sibiu Prosecutor's Office reopened the criminal investigation but discontinued it again due to the applicant's actions being time-barred.
15. The applicant appealed against the decision, which was dismissed, and the prosecutor's decision was upheld based on the available evidence.

title: CASE OF COSTEL GACIU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Gherla.
- The applicant was arrested on 29 March 2009.
- The applicant was held in the Cluj County Police detention centre for four months until 28 July 2009, when he was transferred to the Gherla Maximum Security Prison.
- The applicant alleged that during his detention, he was held in severely overcrowded cells with poor hygiene, and lacked access to water, sanitary facilities, ventilation, and natural light.
- The applicant requested conjugal visits from his wife, but his requests were refused by the prison authorities, citing that no right to such visits was provided for prisoners in pre-trial detention.
- The applicant was allowed a maximum of seventy-two visits throughout his entire detention period of one year and ten months, and he was visited by his wife sixty-seven times.

title: CASE OF KOVÁROVÁ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant lodged an action seeking a ruling that a meeting of flat owners was illegal and the decisions taken there were invalid.
- The defendant was an entity referred to as a community of owners of residential and non-residential premises in the building and ceased to exist on 14 December 2007.
- The District Court discontinued the proceedings because the defendant had no legal successor.
- The Bratislava Regional Court upheld the first-instance decision.
- The applicant appealed on points of law and argued that the courts prevented her from pursuing the case before them. The appeal was declared inadmissible by the Supreme Court.
- The Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible and observed that if the winding up of the defendant was declared void, the applicant could seek reopening of the proceedings.
- The applicant challenged the judgments by way of a complaint to the Constitutional Court, which is still pending.
- Another individual brought proceedings against the defendant seeking a ruling to declare void a decision taken at a meeting of flat owners in the block held in September 2007. After two dismissals, the complaint was challenged by the claimant to the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF SIDABRAS AND OTHERS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Mr Juozas Sidabras was a sports instructor and had worked for the Lithuanian branch of the KGB from 1975 to 1986.
- In 1999 the Lithuanian authorities concluded that he was subject to restrictions under the KGB Act and he was dismissed by the tax authorities.
- Mr Sidabras claimed that his dismissal and inability to find employment were unlawful and brought an administrative action against the security intelligence authorities.
- The domestic courts dismissed his claims, but the European Court of Human Rights found a violation of Article 14 of the Convention in conjunction with Article 8 due to the ban on Mr Sidabras seeking employment in various branches of the private sector.
- The Court ordered the State to pay Mr Sidabras 7,000 euros as compensation for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage and costs.
- The Lithuanian Parliament was preparing amendments to the KGB Act to prevent similar violations of the Convention.
- In 2006 Mr Sidabras sought pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages of LTL 257,154 and LTL 500,000 respectively, claiming his employment rights had continued to be violated.
- The Vilnius Regional Administrative Court dismissed his claims as unsubstantiated and the Supreme Administrative Court subsequently upheld this decision.
- The Court found that the KGB Act had not been applied to Mr Sidabras' ability to find employment in certain areas of the private sector and there was no proof that he had been prevented from obtaining a private sector job after the Court's judgment.

title: CASE OF NISKASAARI AND OTAVAMEDIA OY v. FINLAND
facts:
- The first applicant is a journalist who works for a magazine based in Helsinki.
- The Finnish national public service broadcasting company aired two documentaries in its MOT series about mould-infested houses and the protection of forests.
- The first applicant criticised the documentaries' contents on two separate internet discussion sites.
- The first applicant also published a four-page article in Seura magazine on the same topic.
- The complainant reported the matter to police and pressed charges against the first applicant for defamation.
- The Espoo District Court dismissed all charges against the first applicant and the compensation claim directed against the applicants.
- The complainant appealed to the Helsinki Appeal Court and the court convicted the first applicant of defamation.
- The Supreme Court refused the applicants leave to appeal.

title: CASE OF FARKAS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant initiated a payment warrant procedure for repayment of debts on 21 July 1997
- The procedure developed into court proceedings due to debtor's protest
- The procedure was suspended on 16 April 1999 due to other pending court proceedings
- The pending court proceedings ended in July 2003
- The first-instance court partly found for the applicant on 21 December 2003
- The Budapest Regional Court quashed the decision and remitted the case on 10 March 2005
- The Budapest IV/XV District Court partly found for the applicant on 23 November 2007
- The second-instance court found for the applicant on 25 September 2008
- The Supreme Court upheld this decision on 14 May 2009
- The ruling was served on the applicant on 27 August 2009.

title: CASE OF SAYDULKHANOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a mother of Mr Muslim Saydulkhanov, born in 1982, and they lived in Vedeno, Chechnya.
- Mr Saydulkhanov worked as a policeman at the Argun district department of the interior in the Vedeno district department of the State Pension Fund.
- Mr Saydulkhanov was abducted on an unspecified date in September 2002 by a group of servicemen from the ‘Vostok’ battalion of the Russian federal forces.
- On or around 7 or 8 January 2004, a group of men in camouflage uniforms arrived at the Pension Fund’s building looking for Mr Saydulkhanov.
- On 13 January 2004, Mr Saydulkhanov disappeared on his way to work at the Pension Fund.
- Mr Saydulkhanov’s father found out in the morning of 14 January 2004 that his son was missing and was allegedly detained at the Vedeno military commander’s office.
- The applicant and her husband visited the head of the ‘Vostok’ battalion, Mr Sulim Yamadayev, who promised to assist them in the search for their son in exchange for 10,000 American dollars (USD).
- In 2011, criminal proceedings were again resumed.
- Witnesses reported that armed men in camouflage uniforms had arrived at the Pension Fund’s building and asked about the security routes of the building's guards prior to the abduction.

title: CASE OF ISAYEVA v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lived in Baku at the time of the events
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant for fraud in April 2009
- Criminal proceedings were terminated in August 2009 due to difficulty locating the applicant
- The applicant was invited to the police station as a witness and was then taken to a drug rehabilitation center where she tested positive for drug use
- Narcotic substances were found on her person during a body search and she was arrested
- The applicant was charged with possession of narcotics and the prosecutor requested preventive measure of remand in custody
- The Sabail District Court ordered the applicant's detention for two months due to the gravity of the alleged criminal acts and the possibility of her absconding
- The applicant did not appeal against the detention order
- Criminal proceedings were reinstituted against the applicant for fraud and the two criminal proceedings were joined
- The Sabail District Court extended the applicant's remand in custody by one month citing a possibility of absconding or obstructing the investigation
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal against the extension
- The Assize Court convicted the applicant of fraud and illegal possession of narcotic substances and sentenced her to ten years' imprisonment
- The applicant appealed and claimed her defense rights had been violated during the investigation
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's request to quash the Assize Court's judgment
- The Supreme Court found that the applicant's defense rights had been violated and quashed the decision of the Baku Court of Appeal
- The case was remitted to the first-instance court and later remitted to the prosecution authorities for a new investigation due to violation of the applicant's defense rights
- The applicant's remand in custody was extended several times, and her requests for replacement of remand in custody with house arrest were dismissed by the courts.

title: CASE OF KHOROSHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a life sentence in Solikamsk, Perm Region.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of banditry, robbery, and aggravated murder on November 21, 1994.
- The applicant was held in various remand prisons from November 21, 1994, to the summer of 1995.
- On October 13, 1995, the Perm Regional Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to death which was later commuted to life imprisonment on May 19, 1999.
- From 1995 to 1999, the applicant served his sentence in a special cell for death row inmates in a remand prison.
- From October 1999, the applicant served his sentence in a special-regime correctional colony for life prisoners in Perm Region.
- The applicant's family consisted of his parents, brother, grandmother, wife, and son.
- Family visits were not allowed from November 1994 until 1999, except for one visit from his wife after the first-instance judgment in his criminal case.
- The applicant was allowed short-term visits every six months from 1999 onwards, but physical contact was restricted.
- Long-term family visits were not allowed until October 2009.
- The applicant lodged complaints with the Constitutional Court but all proved unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF SERCE v. ROMANIA
facts:
Facts of the case:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently detained in Giurgiu Prison.
- Convicted of aggravated murder in 2005 and sentenced to eighteen years’ imprisonment.
- Letters to the Court describe inhumane conditions and lack of personal hygiene supplies and cleaning.
- Not included in any educational or work activities during detention.
- Diagnosed with type II diabetes and a sleep disorder in 2008.
- Detained in cells shared with multiple other prisoners with limited personal space.
- Disinfection operations for bugs performed two or three times per year in 2005, 2007, and 2008.
- Food provided was adequate and adapted to his diabetes.
- Participated in educational and recreational activities whenever necessary, but reduced participation due to his state of health.
- Transferred to Giurgiu Prison in 2009 and currently held with five other prisoners in a cell of limited size.
- Provided with basic hygiene supplies and prisoners responsible for cleaning cells.
- Received a menu adapted for his diabetes.
- Participated in cultural and religious activities during detention.
- Requested transfer to Turkish prison in 2007 and 2011, but both requests were rejected by the Bucharest Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF GRABOWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of committing several armed robberies with the use of a machete.
- He was initially detained in a police establishment for children in Cracow.
- The Cracow-Krowodrze District Court instituted an inquiry to determine whether the applicant had committed the offences and placed him in a shelter for juveniles for three months.
- The applicant appealed his placement and argued that he had mental difficulties.
- The Cracow Regional Court upheld the decision of the lower court, considering the gravity of the alleged offences he committed.
- The applicant's case was ordered to be examined in correctional proceedings.
- The applicant requested immediate release, but the court dismissed the request, stating that the circumstances excluded the possibility of altering the security measure.
- The Cracow-Krowodrze District Court informed the applicant's counsel that they did not prolong the applicant's placement in the shelter for juveniles.
- The court found the applicant guilty of the offences and ordered his placement in a correctional facility, which was suspended for two years with a court guardian during the probationary period.
- The applicant's placement in a shelter for juveniles was quashed, and he was released on the same day.

title: CASE OF EFTIMOV v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant is a surgeon working at Strumica Hospital
- On 8 June 1997, the applicant treated Z.R.'s broken and injured arm
- Z.R. complained of pain in the arm and was referred to the children’s clinic in Skopje
- Z.R. was diagnosed with a serious bacterial infection and had his right hand amputated on 19 June 1997
- The applicant was investigated and indicted for aggravated medical malpractice on 19 April 2000
- The trial court acquitted the applicant on 10 July 2001 and 13 December 2004, but those judgments were quashed by the appellate court on 30 January 2002 and 9 March 2005, respectively
- On 13 September 2006, the trial court found no grounds for intentional commission of a criminal offense and acquitted the applicant
- On 13 December 2006, the appellate court requalified the charges and dismissed them as time-barred, stating that the degree of the applicant’s guilt was not correctly established in the proceedings before the trial court
- On 21 March 2007, the Supreme Court remitted the case to the appellate court
- On 8 October 2007, the appellate court dismissed the charges as time-barred
- Both the applicant and the public prosecutor lodged appeals, and on 26 March 2008, the Supreme Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to one year’s imprisonment
- The applicant started serving the prison term on 1 April 2009, but on 6 October 2009, the trial court replaced the prison sentence with a conditional discharge, which became final on 14 October 2009.

title: CASE OF V.M. AND OTHERS v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicants are a Romani family from Serbia, consisting of Mr V.M., Mrs G.S.M. and their four children, one of whom had died before the application was lodged.
- The eldest daughter had been born with mental and physical disabilities, including epilepsy.
- The family left Serbia for France in March 2010, where they lodged an asylum application that was rejected in June of the same year.
- They then returned to Serbia and subsequently moved to Belgium, where they lodged another asylum application in April 2011.
- The Belgian authorities made a request for France to take charge of the family under the Dublin II Regulation, which France initially refused but later accepted.
- The applicants were ordered to leave Belgium for France, where the authorities issued a notice of final refusal of their asylum application.
- The family left France because of extreme poverty and a lack of access to medical care for their disabled daughter.
- The applicants also argued that they had suffered discrimination and ill-treatment in Serbia because of their Roma ethnicity.
- The Aliens Appeals Board set aside the decisions refusing the applicants' residence permits and ordering them to leave the country on the ground that the Aliens Office had not established the legal basis on which it considered that France was responsible for examining the family's asylum application.
- The applicants lodged an application for leave to remain on medical grounds in Belgium, which was declared inadmissible due to a lack of specificity in the medical certificate.

title: CASE OF M.N. AND OTHERS v. SAN MARINO
facts:
- Criminal proceedings were instituted in Italy in or before 2009 against named individuals charged with various crimes, including conspiracy, money laundering, tax evasion and fraud.
- Mr EMP was suspected of managing a network of companies which were involved in money laundering for Italian clients by impeding the identification of the real source of the money entrusted to them.
- The San Marino authorities were requested to assist in obtaining documentation and carrying out searches in various banks, fiduciary institutes and trust companies, in accordance with Article 29 of the Bilateral Convention on Friendship and Good Neighbourhood between Italy and San Marino of 1939.
- The Commissario della Legge accepted the request in conjunction with the crimes of conspiracy, money laundering, aggravated fraud and embezzlement with the aim of fraud, and ordered an investigation in respect of all banks, fiduciary institutes and trust companies in San Marino.
- The applicants were served with the relevant notification following the investigation and implementation of the exequatur decision.
- The applicants lodged a complaint before the judge of criminal appeals against the Commissario’s decision concerning the seizure of documents related to them on the basis that they were not persons charged with the criminal offences at issue.
- The judge of criminal appeals declared the complaints inadmissible, stating that the appellants lacked juridical interest.
- The third-instance criminal judge confirmed the appeal decision in that the appellants lacked juridical interest and rejected the question of constitutional legitimacy of law no. 104/2009.
- The Commissario held that the objection requesting the revocation of the exequatur decision was to be discontinued in view of the findings of the third-instance criminal judge.
- The Commissario held that its exequatur decision of 27 November 2009 had already applied a limitation on the use of the seized documents.

title: CASE OF RUTKOWSKI AND OTHERS v. POLAND
facts:
1. Poland enacted the Law of 17 June 2004 on complaint about breach of the right to have a case examined in judicial proceedings without undue delay.
2. The Law on complaint about breach of the right to have a case examined was altered to include investigations conducted or supervised by a prosecutor and in judicial proceedings.
3. The remedies introduced by the 2004 Act were effective for complaints of excessive length of proceedings.
4. Over 600 Polish cases involving complaints of excessive length of proceedings were rejected on the grounds of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies.
5. At least 100 well-founded applications were lodged with the Court each year regarding complaints of breaches of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time.
6. Currently, 650 cases involving mainly, or at least partly, complaints about the length of civil and criminal proceedings are pending before the Court.
7. A lack of domestic remedies led to the Court's award being significantly less than what the applicant should have received. 
8. The applicant lodged an application for the securing of evidence with the Łódź District Court, but the legal process encountered several delays before a judgment was finally given in 2005.

title: CASE OF SHAMOYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant is disabled and relies on a disability pension.
- She filed a claim against her neighbor for a construction built inside their multi-flat house in order to install a wooden ramp for her wheelchair.
- The applicant modified her claim to ask for the construction to be allocated to her to install the ramp.
- The Armavir Regional Court dismissed the claim due to lack of evidence that the construction could be dismantled and that a wooden ramp could be installed in its place.
- The Civil Court of Appeal dismissed the claim on appeal, stating that the construction did not belong to the applicant and an opinion suggested a ramp from the balcony side was technically better.
- The applicant's appeal on points of law to the Court of Cassation was not admitted for examination as it was not lodged by an advocate licensed to act before the court.

title: CASE OF MORARI AND SPIRIDONOV v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1969 and 1965 respectively and live in Chişinău.
- One applicant was a police officer from 1991 to 2012, retired.
- On 27 February 2008, the Chișinău Court of Appeal obliged Chișinău municipality to provide social housing to the police officer and his family under Article 35 (1) of the Law on Police Forces.
- The judgment was upheld by the Supreme Court of Justice on 11 June 2008 and became final on the same day.
- Between 2008 and 2012, the police officer lodged numerous complaints about the failure to enforce the judgment in his favour, which remains unenforced to date.
- The second applicant was a police officer from 1988 to 2005 and retired.
- On 6 May 2008, the Chișinău Court of Appeal obliged the Chișinău municipality to provide social housing to the retired police officer and his family under Article 35 (1) of the Law on Police Forces.
- The judgment was upheld by the Supreme Court of Justice on 23 July 2008 and became final on the same day.
- Enforcement proceedings were instituted on 16 June 2008, which remain unenforced to date.

title: CASE OF MARTZAKLIS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants are HIV-positive and detained in Aghios Pavlos Hospital in Korydallos Prison
- The applicants are (or were) detained as convicted prisoners at the time of the application to the Court
- The applicants were detained pursuant to various judgments and decisions by criminal courts
- The courts did not grant suspensive effect to their appeals
- The applicants complained of their conditions of detention in the hospital, including overcrowding, unhygienic facilities, poor nutrition, exposure to low temperatures, smoking, and lack of access to medical specialists and treatment
- The hospital staff did not provide sufficient information or care to the HIV-positive detainees
- The detainees were not held separately from convicted prisoners
- An inquiry was ordered by the prosecutor after a leaked video on conditions of detention

title: CASE OF MAFALANI v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence in Lepoglava.
- I.P., a well-known Croatian journalist, and his business associate N.F. were killed by an explosion of an improvised device placed under I.P.’s car, which was parked in front of his publishing company.
- The State Attorney’s Organised Crime Office indicted several persons on charges of conspiracy to kill I.P. and for putting that into action.
- The applicant was indicted for having participated in the group by aiding and abetting the direct perpetrators.
- The Zagreb County Court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to sixteen years’ imprisonment.
- The police arrested the applicant and several other persons.
- The ATJ (antiterrorist team of the Special Police Forces) stormed into the applicant’s flat, where he was at the moment together with his sister and grandmother.
- According to the applicant, immediately after breaking into the flat, the AJT officers threw him on the floor and started punching him over the head and body.
- Following the applicant’s arrest, he was taken to a remote place by a river, where he was beaten up and his head was immersed in the water, forcing him to confess to the murders of I.P. and N.F. and some other crimes.
- The applicant was taken to the Police Detention and Escort Unit (Jedinica za zadržavanje i prepratu) for a rest.
- The applicant was examined in Zagreb Prison Hospital and diagnosed with contusions of head, nose and shoulder and a nose fracture without dislocation, as well as a distortion of a metal implant in his hand related to an old injury.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint with the Zagreb Municipal State Attorney’s Office against unidentified perpetrators alleging ill-treatment during his arrest and stay in the police station.
- On 31 January 2012, the applicant instituted civil proceedings in the Zagreb Municipal Civil Court against the State claiming damages in connection with his alleged ill-treatment by the police during his arrest and stay in the police station.

title: CASE OF EL KHOURY v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant, Mr Boutros Yaacoub El Khoury, was born in 1977 and was detained in Berlin's Moabit prison at the time of lodging his applications.
- The Berlin Tiergarten District Court issued an arrest warrant against the applicant on August 2, 2005, on suspicion of two counts of drug trafficking.
- Two additional arrest warrants were pending against the applicant in Germany, one relating to a further offence of drug trafficking and the other, dated July 1, 2004, relating to forgery of identification papers.
- The applicant was remanded in custody in Berlin Moabit prison after he was extradited to Germany on September 8, 2006, and his detention on remand was subject to reinforced security conditions.
- The prosecution authorities relied primarily on statements made by one of the applicant's co-suspects, A.K., to describe the facts underlying the drugs-related offences allegedly committed by the applicant.

title: CASE OF TOLMACHEV v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant was fined for breaking a glass panel of a bus shelter.
- The applicant contested the decision and argued he did not commit the act and challenged the assessment of witness statements.
- The police did not present the applicant for identification by a witness.
- The applicant's summons to appear at court could not be served on him personally.
- The County Court refused to examine the applicant's complaint due to his absence at the hearing.
- The court concluded that the applicant's parents were communicating with him and his counsel, and thus he must have been aware of the court hearing and summons.
- The court found that the applicant's participation was required to properly examine the case, and adjourning the hearing would not serve any purpose as the applicant was not to return to Estonia within a month.
- The applicant's counsel appealed the decision, but it was upheld by the Tartu Court of Appeal.
- No appeal lay against the Court of Appeal's ruling.

title: CASE OF A.K. v. LIECHTENSTEIN
facts:
- The applicant and F.H. have been in legal disputes regarding property rights in two corporations.
- An interim injunction was granted to prohibit registration of changes made in a shareholders' meeting.
- The Court of Appeal quashed the decision and remitted the case for further investigation.
- A fresh identical interim injunction was issued to secure F.H.'s claim in the main proceedings.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against the Court of Appeal's decision.
- The applicant filed a motion for bias against all five judges of the Constitutional Court.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the motion for bias and allowed the applicant's constitutional complaint regarding the unreasonable length of the proceedings.
- The applicant complained about the judgment in a new application to the Court.

title: CASE OF NAZARENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant's daughter, A., was born in 2007.
2. The applicant and A.'s mother, N., divorced in 2010.
3. In 2011, A. was supposed to reside with the applicant during even weeks and with her mother during odd weeks, with some exceptions.
4. The applicant discovered bruises on A.'s body in March 2011 and suspected that she had been abused by N.'s new partner.
5. A. lived with the applicant and her paternal grandmother for the following year, during which N. was allowed to visit.
6. Both the applicant and N. applied to the court for a residence order in respect of A.
7. On 19 May 2011, the court granted N.'s application and found that A. should primarily live with her, as it was in A.'s best interests.
8. The childcare authority believed A. should reside with the applicant.
9. After criminal proceedings against N. were opened, she was ordered to return A. to her.
10. The applicant applied twice more for a residence order for A. and the custody of her was terminated when a paternity test confirmed he was not her biological father.

title: CASE OF GHEDIR AND OTHERS v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicants were born between 1937 and 1985 and lived in Villepinte and Drancy.
- The first applicant was identity-checked at the railway station and was later accused of throwing stones at trains.
- Two police officers from the Mitry Mory police station arrived at the scene and called for reinforcements just as five SUGE officers arrived.
- The first applicant was forced to the ground, handcuffed and frisked before being placed in a police vehicle.
- The version of events provided by witnesses diverges, with some describing a violent arrest.
- The first applicant complained of nausea, bleeding from the chin, and lost consciousness after being taken into custody.
- The first applicant underwent several operations and was hospitalized for a long period. He suffered from neurological after-effects, which included impaired motor skills and cognitive and behavioral disorders.
- The four police officers sent as reinforcements, D.F., N.T. R.D. and A.H., stated that they had witnessed a kneeing incident.
- The first applicant was formally charged, and the SUGE officers were charged on the ground of intentional violence causing permanent disability.
- Various witnesses, including train passengers and individuals who were with the applicant on the day in question, provided their versions of events.

title: CASE OF GAZSÓ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Telki.
- Litigation was in progress between the applicant and his former employer from 25 February 2002 to 18 May 2005.
- The former employer was obliged to re-employ the applicant.
- The applicant did not accept the position offered to him.
- New litigation started on 5 January 2006.
- On 18 November 2008, the Budapest Labour Court dismissed the applicant's action.
- On 9 July 2010, the Budapest Regional Court found for the applicant.
- The respondent pursued a petition for review before the Kúria.
- On 29 February 2012, the Kúria reversed the appeal judgment and found for the respondent.

title: CASE OF KUTTNER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Traun.
- On 21 January 2005, the applicant was sentenced to six years’ imprisonment for having deliberately caused severe bodily harm to his 80‑year-old mother.
- The applicant had been convicted on seven previous occasions, four of which involved similar offences of violence.
- The Linz court ordered the applicant’s detention in an institution for mentally ill offenders in addition to the term of imprisonment.
- On June 7, 2005, the Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal against his sentence.
- On 31 March 2006, the Steyr Regional Court ordered the applicant to remain in the institution from which he had requested his release.
- On 10 January 2007, the applicant applied for the lifting of the order to detain him at Garsten detention centre.
- On 23 June 2007, the applicant filed an application with the Court of Appeal for the setting of a time-limit for the Regional Court to decide on his request to lift the detention order.
- On 31 July 2007, the Regional Court ordered the continuation of his detention in an institution for mentally ill offenders.
- On 16 August 2007, the applicant appealed against this decision to the Court of Appeal maintaining his view that the placement in a psychiatric institution was no longer justified.
- On 10 September 2007, the Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
- On 28 February 2008, the applicant again applied for the order for psychiatric detention to be lifted, and to be transferred to an ordinary prison.
- On 10 September 2009, the Regional Court ordered the termination of the applicant’s psychiatric detention, suspended the remaining seven months of his prison sentence and released him subject to a number of conditions.

title: CASE OF CIPRIAN VLĂDUȚ AND IOAN FLORIN POP v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Two brothers, born in 1982 and 1974 respectively, are accused of drug trafficking.
- In the summer of 2004, the first applicant was contacted by an undercover police agent who wanted to buy ecstasy from him.
- The prosecutor gained knowledge of the first applicant's alleged involvement in drug trafficking in September 2004.
- The first applicant brought a batch of drugs into the country in September and sold drugs to the undercover agent in October.
- The second applicant helped his brother with the drug transaction in December 2004, fearing retaliation from the Dutch seller.
- Police agents apprehended the two applicants and recovered a bag containing several thousand ecstasy tablets from the bushes.
- The applicants were taken to the police station, arrested, and later committed to trial.
- The tablets purchased by the undercover agent were tested and confirmed to contain MDMA.
- The defence counsel requested an independent expert evaluation of the tablets but was denied.
- The court accepted evidence produced by the prosecutor, including transcripts of recorded conversations, some of which were not produced before the court by the prosecutor.
- The court convicted both applicants and sentenced them to prison.
- The second applicant repeatedly requested access to his file throughout the proceedings but received no response from the court.
- The first applicant's drug addiction was examined by experts who concluded that he did not need to be placed in a special drug withdrawal program and was compatible with detention.

title: CASE OF MAMCHUR v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and has a second-highest officially recognized degree of disability.
- The applicant has a daughter, A.M., who was born on 5 May 2002.
- A.M. lived with the applicant until October 2005 when her mother, who had cancer, moved to live at her mother's flat with A.M.
- In April 2006, the mother lodged a claim against the applicant seeking maintenance payments.
- The Desnyanskyy District Court allowed the claim, finding that A.M. was living separately from the applicant, and he was not contributing to her upbringing.
- A.M.'s mother died in June 2006 and her grandmother, V.K., took her away from Chernigiv without informing the applicant of their whereabouts.
- The applicant lodged complaints and requests seeking assistance in his daughter's return but was unsuccessful.
- V.K. lodged a request with the Desnyanskyy District Council asking that she be appointed as A.M.'s tutor. The request was granted in December 2006.
- The applicant made claims seeking the return of his daughter, which were rejected by the courts.
- The applicant also sought the cancellation of the tutelage decision, which was also rejected.

title: CASE OF TEMCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was a former rector of a State-owned university before his arrest.
- The applicant was medically examined and diagnosed with type-2 diabetes before his arrest.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of receiving bribes and detained in the temporary detention facility.
- The District Court ordered the applicant's detention, stating he might abscond, hinder the investigation or continue his criminal activities without providing any concrete facts.
- The applicant was transported to the remand centre.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decision to detain the applicant.
- The applicant's detention was extended twice by the District Court, relying on the same grounds.
- The applicant was sentenced to imprisonment for bribery, but the sentence was later modified to five years' suspended imprisonment.
- The applicant made several requests for release during detention, citing his health conditions.
- The medical treatment provided by the SIZO was inadequate for the applicant's chronic illnesses.
- The applicant was diagnosed with multiple health conditions while in detention, including ischemic heart disease, hypertensive diseases, chronic pancreatitis, and kidney cyst.
- The applicant's diabetes treatment was modified, and he received insulin injections.
- The SIZO medical unit did not have sufficient equipment and staff to provide specialist medical treatment.
- The applicant requested the Court to oblige Ukraine to transfer him to a specialist hospital, which was refused.
- The Court ordered the Government to ensure that the applicant received treatment in specialised institutions.
- The applicant was hospitalised due to a sudden deterioration in his health, which the SIZO staff was unable to deal with.
- The applicant refused to undergo treatment in local hospitals and only agreed to go to a specific hospital in Kyiv.
- The applicant's diabetes treatment was modified by an endocrinologist from hospital no. 3.

title: CASE OF SAMACHIȘĂ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was driving to Galați with a friend in a car registered in the USA.
- They visited a friend and returned to the car, finding it surrounded by police officers and curious civilians.
- The police officers detained the applicant aggressively and hit him repeatedly, refusing to check his identity papers.
- The applicant was handcuffed and hit while in detention, losing his dentures and eventually fainting.
- Forensic reports showed that the applicant had suffered various injuries, including damage to his dental prosthesis, as a result of the police officers' actions.
- The applicant brought criminal proceedings against the police officers, but they were discontinued on the grounds that the police officers had not committed the offences of which they had been accused or that the alleged offences were not provided for by criminal law.
- The decision was challenged before the superior prosecutor, who dismissed the applicant's challenge.
- The applicant appealed against the decision before the domestic courts, arguing that the authorities had failed to investigate how the injuries attested by the forensic expert reports had been caused.
- The Galați District Court dismissed the applicant's appeal and upheld the decision of 3 February 2009.

title: CASE OF MASLÁK AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The three applicants were born between 1979 and 1984 and reside in Pružina.
- Since 2007, they have faced multiple charges related to alleged violent offenses and organized crime.
- The applicants were arrested, remanded, released, and re-arrested and re-remanded several times.
- The first applicant requested release on 2 May 2010, which was dismissed on 25 June 2010 after interlocutory appeals.
- The second and third applicants requested release on 10 May 2010, which was dismissed on 15 July 2010 after interlocutory appeals.
- The applicants lodged a constitutional complaint on 27 September 2010, which was declared inadmissible on 9 November 2011.
- The applicants lodged a fresh request for release on 22 December 2010, which was dismissed on 7 February 2011 after interlocutory appeals.
- The applicants were remanded in detention pending trial on a charge of extortion on 1 April 2011.
- The applicants challenged the detention order by means of an interlocutory appeal, which was dismissed on 21 April 2011 after interlocutory appeals.
- The applicants challenged the decisions before the Constitutional Court on 15 June 2011, which was declared inadmissible on 13 December 2011.
- The applicants were indicted to stand trial on the charge in question on 27 September 2011 and were released on 15 November 2011.
- The proceedings on the merits are still pending.

title: CASE OF GÉGÉNY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently detained at Sátoraljaújhely Prison.

- On 19 October 2001, he started to serve his prison sentence at Szeged Prison.

- He spent 63 months with eleven other inmates in three different cells measuring 27 square metres each, including sanitary facilities.

- The cells were equipped only with one tap and a toilet, separated from the living area only by a curtain.

- The dining table was fixed to the floor just a metre away from the toilet.

- The applicant had a daily one-hour-long outdoor activity.

- The yards were closed premises measuring 40 by 20 metres, about 100-150 persons being taken to the yard at a time.

- He attended secondary school classes three times a week, six hours on each occasion.

- On 30 January 2006, the applicant was transferred to Budapest Prison Unit “B”.

- His cells (nos. 316, 130, 325, 211, and 206) measured 27 square metres and were occupied by him and seven other men.

- Detainees were permitted to take a shower once a week.

- Between 12 May 2010 and 27 May 2011, the applicant continued to serve his sentence in Unit “A” of Budapest Prison.

- Throughout his detention, the applicant had no out-of-cell activities other than a daily one-hour walk in the yard of the prison facility, gym exercise twice a week for about 50 minutes each time and a weekly visit to the library for about 15 minutes.

- The inmates were allowed one shower per week.

- On 27 May 2011, the applicant was transferred back to Unit “B” of Budapest Prison.

- Since 16 June 2013, the applicant has been detained at Sátoraljaújhely Prison with three other inmates in a cell measuring 8 square metres.

title: CASE OF NIKOLAY KOZLOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant obtained an award of remuneration arrears in 2001
- The applicant sued the insolvency manager of a company in 2003 for the recovery of the remuneration awarded to him
- The Novocheboksarskiy Town Court of the Republic of Chuvashiya dismissed the applicant’s claim in 2004
- The Supreme Court of the Republic of Chuvashiya upheld the judgment of the Novocheboksarskiy Town Court in 2005
- The applicant lodged a claim for non-pecuniary damages for excessively long examination of his claim against the insolvency manager in 2004
- The Supreme Court of the Republic of Chuvashiya returned the applicant’s claim in 2004, directing him to lodge the claim with a district court
- The Supreme Court of Russia dismissed the applicant’s claim in 2004 on the ground that it could not be examined in the course of civil proceedings
- The applicant lodged a claim against the Treasury of the Russian Federation and the Novocheboksarskiy Town Court seeking non-pecuniary damages in an unspecified date
- The Leninskiy District Court of Cheboksary dismissed the applicant’s claim without examination on the merits in 2004
- The District Court noted that the procedure for challenging the actions of a judge required a special legal framework which had not yet been set up
- The Supreme Court of the Republic of Chuvashiya dismissed the applicant’s appeal in 2004 stating that procedural rules for resolution of the issue raised by the applicant had not yet been established.

title: CASE OF SHUMIKHIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lived in Perm region prior to his arrest and conviction.
- He is currently serving a prison sentence in a correctional colony in the Yamalo-Nenetskiy Autonomous region.
- On 20 February 2005, the police arrested him on suspicion of triple murder and attempted murder.
- On 21 February 2005, Chusovskiy District Court of the Perm Region ordered that he be placed in detention.
- On 21 June 2005, the Perm Regional Court found him guilty of triple murder and attempted murder, and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- The applicant was represented by state-appointed counsel at the investigation stage and before the first-instance court.
- On 29 June 2005, he appealed against his conviction to the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation.
- On 14 November 2005, the applicant asked the Supreme Court to appoint legal counsel to defend him during the appeal proceedings.
- On 18 November 2005, the Supreme Court examined the applicant’s appeal, but he was not assisted by legal counsel at the appeal hearing.

title: CASE OF METALLA AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The Shijak Commission recognised the applicants' inherited title to a plot of land measuring 1,020 sq. m, of which 747 sq. m were restored.
- The remaining plot of land measuring 272 sq. m was occupied, and the applicants would be compensated in one of the ways provided for by law.
- The Shkodër Commission recognised the applicant's and other heirs’ inherited title to a two-storey building and to a plot of land surrounding the building measuring 500 sq. m.
- The plot of land measuring 500 sq. m was occupied, and the applicant and the heirs would be compensated in one of the ways provided for by law, and the building should be restored to them.
- The applicant claimed to have instituted two legal actions against a third party for the vacation and restoration of his property, but he discontinued those actions.
- The Commission decision in all cases remains unenforced.

title: CASE OF BOLOTINY v. RUSSIA
facts:
