- First applicant born in 1953 and second applicant born in 1957, both live in Izhevsk
- First applicant suffered extensive exposure to radioactive emissions in 1986 due to involvement in Chernobyl disaster operations
- Causal link between applicant's disability and involvement established by experts in 1996
- First applicant entitled to monthly payments in compensation for health damage under domestic law
- First applicant brought court proceedings against local authorities to adjust monthly payments in line with minimum wage increase from 1996-2000
- Oktyabrskiy District Court allowed claim in part on 3 May 2000, ordered payment of debt accrued from underpayment from federal budget
- Enforcement proceedings opened by bailiffs' office on 13 June 2000 but discontinued on 10 December 2003 due to respondent authority's lack of funds
- Amount awarded paid in full to first applicant on 24 May 2004
- First applicant entitled to additional housing as victim of Chernobyl disaster, brought action against local authorities 
- Oktyabrskiy District Court ordered Ministry of Architecture, Construction and Housing Policy to grant separate room to first applicant on 15 November 2004
- Judgment not appealed and entered into force ten days later
- Ministry of Construction did not execute judgment due to lack of available housing
- Respondent authority informed first applicant on 31 January 2005 that distribution of social housing to victims of Chernobyl disaster had been transferred to Ministry for Disaster Relief of Udmurtia
- First applicant filed claim on 20 April 2005 to alter mode of enforcement of judgment to monetary compensation, granted on 11 May 2005 and awarded RUB 230,000 
- Ministry for Disaster Relief of Udmurtia to pay compensation at expense of federal budget 
- Federal Treasury Department proposed actions against Ministry for Disaster Relief of Russian Federation on 27 July 2006 as debtor did not enforce judgment
- State compensations for acquisition of housing to victims of Chernobyl disaster provided only in form of housing certificates since 25 April 2007
- Oktyabrskiy District Court ordered indexation of awarded amount to RUB 547,400 on 29 August 2008 
- Award granted by judgment of 15 November 2004 as amended by indexation order of 29 August 2008 has not been paid to date.

title: CASE OF JOVIČIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant's gold and car were seized in 1992 in customs offence proceedings.
- The customs offence proceedings were discontinued in 1996, and the seized property was returned to the applicant in 1997.
- The applicant claimed pecuniary losses against the State in 1997.
- The Koper District Court dismissed the applicant's claim in 1999, and the applicant appealed to the Koper Higher Court and then the Supreme Court.
- In 2004, The Constitutional Court remitted the part concerning pecuniary damages in respect of the car back to the first instance court.
- The district court postponed the hearing several times due to the applicant's pending application with the European Court of Human Rights.
- In 2008, the Koper District Court dismissed the applicant's supervisory appeal.
- The State Attorney's Office dismissed the applicant's claim in 2009.
- The applicant lodged a claim for compensation in 2010, but it was dismissed by the Koper Local Court and the Koper Higher Court in 2012 and 2013.

title: CASE OF R.S. v. POLAND
facts:
- Applicant is a Polish national who lives in Zurich and works as a software specialist.
- Applicant married M.S. in 1994 and they have two children together, born in 1998 and 2002.
- In 2007, the applicant began an affair with H and in February 2008, he and M.S. separated.
- M.S filed for divorce on 24 September 2008 and took the children to Poland for school holidays on 4 October 2008. She did not return as scheduled.
- The applicant consented to the children's trip to Poland and was informed about the travel plans.
- M.S. was granted temporary custody of the children during the divorce proceedings, and the applicant was not informed nor summoned to the court session concerning the interim custody order.
- The applicant filed a request for return of his children under the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction on 24 October 2008.
- The Krakow Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s request to stay the execution of the interim custody order, and his appeal against this decision and against the interim custody order was dismissed by the Kraków Court of Appeal.
- The Kraków Regional Court dissolved the applicant’s marriage in July 2012 and granted full parental authority to M.S, with limited parental rights to the applicant.
- The applicant lodged an appeal, arguing that his visiting rights during holidays and summer vacation should have been regulated by the court.
- The Kraków Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal, upholding the first instance’s judgment.
- The Kraków District Court held the first hearing in the proceedings under the Hague Convention on 17 December 2008, and on 11 February 2009, the Kraków District Court refused to grant the applicant’s request for the children’s return to Switzerland.
- The applicant appealed against the first-instance decision, but the Kraków Regional Court dismissed the appeal.

title: CASE OF OLIARI AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- Two applicants, who were in a committed stable relationship, declared their intention to marry, and requested the issuance of marriage banns from the Civil Status Office of the Trent Commune.
- Their request was rejected, and they challenged the decision before the Trent Tribunal, arguing that Italian law did not explicitly prohibit same-sex marriage and that such a position would be unconstitutional.
- The Trent Tribunal rejected their claim, stating that a marriage between persons of the same sex lacked one of the most essential requirements to render it a valid legal act and that there was no fundamental right to marry.
- They appealed to the Trent Court of Appeal, which considered it relevant to make a referral to the Constitutional Court in connection with the claims of unconstitutionality of the law in force.
- The Italian Constitutional Court in judgment no. 138 of 15 April 2010 declared inadmissible their constitutional challenge to articles of the Italian Civil Code.
- The Constitutional Court noted that homosexual unions, understood as a stable cohabitation of two people of the same sex, who have a fundamental right to freely express their personality in a couple, obtaining recognition of the relevant rights and duties, could be achieved in ways apart from the institution of marriage between homosexuals.
- The Court of Appeal rejected the applicants’ claims in full.
- Two other couples also requested the issuance of marriage banns and were rejected on the basis of the law and domestic jurisprudence.
- The Milan Tribunal rejected their claim, considering it legitimate for the Civil Status Office to refuse a request to have marriage banns issued for the purposes of a marriage between persons of the same sex, in line with the finding of the Constitutional Court judgment no. 138 of 15 April 2010.

title: CASE OF SATAKUNNAN MARKKINAPORSSI OY AND SATAMEDIA OY v. FINLAND
facts:
Bullet points of the main descriptions of the facts are:

- The applicant companies are based in Kokemäki.
- The first applicant company has been publishing Veropörssi magazine annually since 1994.
- In 2002, the magazine published taxation data of 1.2 million persons, which made up a third of all taxable individuals in Finland.
- The second applicant company started an SMS-service in 2003 that allowed people to obtain tax information about specific individuals from the magazine's database.
- The Data Protection Ombudsman advised the companies to stop publishing taxation data in 2003 but they declined, citing their freedom of expression.
- The Data Protection Ombudsman requested that the Data Protection Board forbid the companies from processing taxation data in 2003, but the request was dismissed in 2004.
- The Administrative Court also rejected the appeal in 2005, finding that the derogation provided by the Personal Data Act concerning journalism applied to the case.
- The Supreme Administrative Court requested a preliminary ruling from the Court of Justice of the European Union in 2007.
- In 2008, the Court of Justice of the European Union found that the activities in question constituted "processing of personal data" to which the Directive applied.
- The Court of Justice of the European Union also found in 2008 that activities involving the processing of personal data such as those relating to personal data files, which contained solely material already published in the media, also fell within the scope of the Directive.
- The Supreme Administrative Court referred the case back to the Data Protection Board in 2009 and requested that it forbid the processing of taxation data in the manner and to the extent carried out in 2002.
- The Supreme Administrative Court found in 2009 that the publication of the whole database collected for journalistic purposes could not be regarded as journalistic activity and that the public interest did not require such publication of personal data to the extent seen in the present case.
- The SMS-service was shut down after the decision of the Supreme Administrative Court was served on the applicant companies.
- The Data Protection Board forbade the companies to process taxation data and to forward this information to an SMS-service in 2009.
- The applicant companies appealed against the decision of the Data Protection Board to the Helsinki Administrative Court in 2010.
- The Turku Administrative Court rejected the companies' appeal in 2010, and the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the judgment in 2012.

title: CASE OF DERYAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is one of the heirs of Mr Serkis Gövderelioğlu, who bought goods from a bankrupt estate in 1988.
- The sale was annulled in 1996 due to non-payment of the instalments.
- The court ordered Gövderelioğlu to return the goods, but he did not comply.
- In 2001, the bankrupt estate filed a case against Gövderelioğlu’s heirs for the recovery of goods or their equivalent value.
- The applicant argued that the case had been lodged outside the statutory time-limit.
- Experts valued the goods at approximately EUR 45,000 to EUR 245,000.
- The court ordered Gövderelioğlu’s heirs to return the goods and pay a sum of money based on the value of the disposed goods with statutory interest.
- The applicant appealed and argued that the action for recovery should have been dismissed due to being outside the time-limit, and the court acted unlawfully in awarding interest and not hearing the witnesses.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the Şişli Court without holding a hearing or answering the applicant’s objections.
- The applicant's request for rectification of the decision was rejected by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF REISNER v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant purchased 650 German Certificates in Demirbank through the German stock market.
- On 6 December 2000, the Banking Regulation and Supervision Board transferred the management and control of Demirbank to the Savings Deposit Insurance Fund due to insufficient assets and to prevent threats to the financial system.
- The Fund confiscated all properties belonging to Demirbank, and sold it to HSBC for 350,000,000 USD on 20 September 2001.
- Cıngıllı Holding A.Ş., the main shareholder of Demirbank, brought administrative proceedings against the Board and the Fund on various occasions, seeking to challenge the transfer and the sale of Demirbank.
- The Supreme Administrative Court found that the takeover of the bank by the Fund had been in accordance with section 14(3) of the Banking Activities Act.
- The Joint Administrative Chambers of the Supreme Administrative Court later held that the Board should have carried out an objective evaluation of the bank’s financial situation and ordered Demirbank to take specific measures before transferring its management and control to the Fund.
- The court also quashed the decision regarding the transfer of Demirbank to the Fund.
- The applicant brought compensation proceedings against the Agency before the Supreme Administrative Court, seeking the annulment of the Board’s implied rejection of his compensation claim but was dismissed.
- The applicant later initiated administrative proceedings to enforce the Supreme Administrative Court judgment and to claim compensation for his lost shares.
- The court held that the execution of the judgment dated 5 November 2004 could not be secured as Demirbank's shares had ceased to exist following its sale to HSBC. The Fund rejected the applicant's request for compensation. 
- The Istanbul Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's case as out of time.

title: CASE OF CINGILLI HOLDİNG A.Ş. AND CINGILLIOGLU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were the main shareholders of Demirbank, which was ranked as the fifth largest private bank in Turkey in 1999.
- The Banking Regulation and Supervision Board decided to transfer the management and control of Demirbank to the Savings Deposit Insurance Fund in December 2000, as the assets of the bank were insufficient to cover its liabilities and the continuation of its activities would threaten the security and stability of the financial system.
- The applicant company brought administrative proceedings against the Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency, seeking the annulment of the decision.
- The Ankara Administrative Court dismissed the case as it lacked jurisdiction and transferred the case to the Supreme Administrative Court.
- The Supreme Administrative Court initially dismissed the case, but after an appeal, it held that the Board had acted unlawfully by not ordering Demirbank to take specific measures before applying section 14(3) of the Banking Activities Act.
- The annulment of the decision resulted in the agreement entered into by the Fund and HSBC on 20 September 2001 being declared null and void.
- The Agency informed the second applicant that it would be impossible to enforce the judgments as Demirbank had been sold to HSBC and struck off the commercial register.

title: CASE OF ZACHAR AND ČIERNY v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicants are currently serving prison terms
- A criminal investigation was opened into suspected trafficking in drugs
- A warrant was issued for the search of non‑residential premises 
- The police seized drug related items and a quantity of cannabis
- The applicants were taken to the police station and subsequently questioned by the police
- No lawyer representing the applicants or any other parties was present
- The applicants were charged with conspiracy to possess and traffic in drugs
- Their police statements were transcribed on pre-printed forms
- The applicants were remanded in custody pending trial
- The charge against the applicants was reclassified to an aggravated form of the same offence
- The applicants were indicted to stand trial on the aggravated charge
- The applicants were found guilty and sentenced to six years and eight months imprisonment
- The applicants lodged an appeal and a subsequent appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF K.F. v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicant is a Kurdish man from Syria who entered Cyprus illegally in 2005 and applied for asylum on 17 February 2005. 
- The Asylum Service dismissed his application on 13 August 2008 on the grounds that he did not fulfill the requirements of the Refugee Law. 
- He appealed the decision, but it was also dismissed on 11 May 2011 by the Reviewing Authority.
- In his appeal, the applicant claimed that he had participated in a demonstration in Syria in 2004, was arrested and detained, and that he had fled Syria after his girlfriend was killed. 
- The Supreme Court upheld the decisions of the Asylum Service and the Reviewing Authority on 31 January 2012. 
- In 2010, the applicant and other Kurdish failed asylum seekers organized a demonstration in Nicosia, which resulted in the encampment. 
- The authorities took action to remove the protesters from the area and on 28 May 2010 deportation instructions were given by the Minister of Interior for Syrian-Kurdish failed asylum seekers.

title: CASE OF DONPRUT S.R.L. v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is a taxi cab company from Chişinău with approximately ninety employees.
- The company’s licence was withdrawn by the Licensing Chamber due to its failure to comply with certain regulations.
- The company initiated court proceedings seeking to overturn the withdrawal of its licence.
- The Chişinău Court of Appeal found in favour of the applicant company, stating that the withdrawal of the licence was in breach of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention.
- The Licensing Chamber appealed against the judgment, which was subsequently quashed by the Supreme Court of Justice.

title: CASE OF A.H. AND J.K. v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple, Syrian nationals of Kurdish origin, living in Cyprus
- Second applicant entered Cyprus illegally in 2004 and applied for asylum the next day
- First applicant entered Cyprus illegally in 2007 to join her fiancé and they got married soon after
- Asylum applications were dismissed on the grounds of lack of well-founded fear of persecution or serious harm
- Appeals were dismissed in 2010, citing contradictions and lack of plausibility in the second applicant's claims
- Second applicant brought a judicial review proceeding which was also dismissed in 2013
- In May 2010, the applicants took part in a protest against the restrictive policies of the Cypriot Asylum Service, forming a camp of 150 Kurds from Syria
- On 31 May 2010, the Minister of the Interior gave instructions to proceed with the deportation of failed Syrian-Kurdish asylum seekers
- On 11 June 2010, a large-scale operation was organized to remove the protesters and detain those who were in the Republic unlawfully
- Applicants and 44 others were arrested and placed in detention centers, charged with the criminal offense of unlawful stay in the Republic under section 19(2) of the Aliens and Immigration Law.

title: CASE OF NASSR ALLAH v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and his current whereabouts are unknown.
- On 29 December 2012, the applicant fled Syria and on an unspecified date entered the Russian Federation. He applied for asylum but left the country before his application was examined.
- On 4-5 May 2013, the applicant crossed the Latvian border on foot and was stopped by the State Border Guard Service on 5 May 2013.
- On 7 May 2013, an initial interview was conducted with the assistance of an Arabic-speaking interpreter, and on 16 May 2013, a personal interview took place.
- On 3 October 2013, the Asylum Affairs Division decided to refuse the applicant’s asylum application but granted him subsidiary protection status and issued a temporary residence permit for one year.
- The applicant lodged an appeal against the decision with the administrative courts but failed to appear at scheduled hearings on 27 January and 25 February 2014.
- On 5 May 2013, the applicant was detained under section 51(2)(1) of the Immigration Law, but he refused to sign the detention record. On 7 May 2013, he was detained under section 9(1)(1) and 9(1)(2) of the Asylum Law and was placed in a closed facility in Daugavpils. 
- On 10 May 2013, a judge ordered his detention for two months, and on 8 July 2013, the judge authorised the extension of his detention for a further two months. 
- On 4 October 2013, the applicant was informed that he had been granted subsidiary protection status, and on 7 October 2013, he was ordered to be released by the State Boarder Guard Service. 
- On 13 August 2013, the applicant complained to the Ombudsman about his prolonged detention.

title: CASE OF H.S. AND OTHERS v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicant participated in demonstrations following the events in Qamishli in March 2004, was arrested twice, and was subjected to physical violence.
- The applicant left Syria illegally in 2006 and applied for asylum in Cyprus, but his application was discontinued due to non-compliance with the Refugee Law.
- The applicant left Syria again in 2008, applied for asylum in Cyprus, but his application was dismissed on the ground that he did not have a well-founded fear of persecution.
- The applicant claimed that he had converted to Christianity and was persecuted in Syria due to his faith.
- The applicant claimed that he left Syria because he was harassed and ill-treated by the Syrian Security Police due to his origin and his connections to the Yekiti party.
- The applicant left Syria illegally again in 2007 and applied for asylum in Cyprus, claiming he left Syria due to restrictions on singing non-Arabic songs and fear of arbitrary detention.
- The applicant's claims were found to lack credibility by the Asylum Service and the Reviewing Authority, and his application for asylum was dismissed. 
- The applicant was granted a temporary residence permit in 2007, which was later revoked in 2009, and was requested to leave Cyprus.

title: CASE OF MEIMANIS v. LATVIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is on trial for attempting to take a bribe with two other individuals.
- The applicant learned about an operational investigation opened in respect of his co-defendant, A.S.
- The interception of A.S.'s and A.B.'s telephone conversations was authorized by relevant authorities.
- A specialized prosecutor replied, stating that no interception of telephone conversations had been carried out in respect of the applicant in the context of the operational investigation but his conversations were recorded if he was speaking to a person whose conversations were intercepted.
- The applicant requested prosecution authorities to review the lawfulness of the operational measures, but the prosecutor rejected the applicant's complaint.
- The applicant lodged an individual constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court alleging incompatibility of certain laws with the Latvian Constitution and the European Convention on Human Rights.
- The Constitutional Court initiated proceedings with regard to certain laws' compatibility.
- The applicant requested to see the case materials, written submissions, and the judge's preliminary opinion, among other things.
- The President of the Constitutional Court informed the applicant that the parties could see the case materials after the decision concerning adjudication had been taken.
- The Constitutional Court conducted closed preparatory meetings to examine the case materials and decided to examine the case by means of a written procedure.

title: CASE OF GRUJOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and is currently detained in Belgrade Central Prison.
- He was arrested in the Netherlands in 2003 for crimes unrelated to the current case and was later arrested in Austria in 2006.
- The Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Serbia requested his extradition for several sets of criminal proceedings against him unrelated to the present case.
- He was suspected of having participated in aggravated murder with unauthorised use of another person’s vehicle and forgery on 24 March 2006, and an investigation was opened against him in January 2007.
- The applicant was extradited to Serbia in July 2007.
- The applicant was indicted on 31 December 2007, and the trial began in May 2008, with several adjournments and delays.
- He was found guilty in April 2014, but the High Court’s judgment was quashed and remitted for a re-trial on 31 October 2014.
- The applicant’s detention was repeatedly extended on the grounds of the risk of absconding, the risk of obstructing the course of justice, the risk of reoffending, and the gravity of the criminal offenses he was accused of, with the grounds for detention changing over time. 
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal in December 2011, which was rejected in September 2012.
- The applicant’s subsequent constitutional appeals containing the same complaints were rejected in September and October 2012, and November 2013.

title: CASE OF FRISANCHO PEREA v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Maryland, USA.
- In 1999, the applicant married A., a Slovak national, and they had three children.
- A. took the children to Slovakia in 2010 without the applicant's consent and filed for divorce and custody of the children there.
- The applicant filed an application for the return of the children to the United States as their habitual residence, relying on the International Private and Procedural Law Act, the Council Regulation (EC) No. 2201/2003, and the Hague Convention.
- The Bratislava Regional Court dismissed an appeal filed by A. and upheld the return order.
- However, the Constitutional Court suspended the enforceability of the return order pending the outcome of the proceedings on the merits of the complaint filed by A.
- The Bratislava Regional Court subsequently quashed the return order and remitted the case to the District Court for a new determination.
- The proceedings on the merits were terminated by the District Court on the ground that the children and A. had established residence in Hungary.

title: CASE OF G.S. v. GEORGIA
facts:
- Applicant's personal information
- Applicant's partner leaves Ukraine for Russia in mid-2005
- Couple's child L. remains in Ukraine with his mother
- Applicant and partner have another child, T. in September 2006
- Child T. dies in an accident on 22 July 2010
- Applicant allows her partner to take L. to Georgia for the summer holidays in 30 July 2010
- Applicant learns on 13 August 2010 that L. will be staying in Georgia and not returning to Ukraine
- Applicant tries to persuade her former partner to allow their child to return to Ukraine for two months with no avail
- L. stays in Georgia with his uncle and grandfather while his father travels occasionally to visit him
- L. is diagnosed with an adjustment disorder and undergoes treatment
- The District Court of Kharkiv orders L.'s return to Ukraine on 22 March 2011
- The Ministry of Justice of Ukraine initiates child return proceedings under the Hague Convention in October 2010
- The Ministry of Justice of Georgia institutes proceedings on behalf of the applicant before the Tbilisi City Court on 2 December 2010
- Social workers visit L. on 10 February 2011 and observe his living conditions and emotional state
- Social workers set up and attend three meetings between the mother and son in April 2011
- Social workers note L.'s problematic behavior and his emotional relationship with his parents
- L. undergoes psychological examination and is diagnosed with insufficient emotional relationship with his parents
- Tbilisi City Court refuses the applicant's request on 16 May 2011
- The decision is overturned on 27 October 2011 by the Tbilisi Court of Appeal which orders L.'s return to Ukraine
- G. Ch. appeals against this decision on points of law, alleging incorrect interpretation of the Hague Convention and the facts of the case
- The Supreme Court allows the appeal on points of law on 22 August 2012, reversing the judgment of 27 October 2011.

title: CASE OF GALAMBOS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is a retired army general born in 1953 from Budapest.
- He was apprehended on 28 June 2011 on charges of spying and placed under house arrest on 1 July 2011.
- On 14 July 2011, his pre-trial detention was ordered by the court for fear of absconding.
- The applicant was detained at Budapest Penitentiary’s Maglódi Facility and experienced disturbances of his night rest because of the light.
- Although he demonstrated that he could have absconded during house arrest but had not, his request for release was denied.
- The court insisted on the argument that, due to his connections abroad, there was a risk that he might abscond.
- The investigation was terminated on 30 September 2011, but on 11 November 2011, the Military Bench of the Budapest Court of Appeal quashed a previous detention order and remitted the case to the Budapest High Court.
- The applicant was in pre-trial detention until 6 April 2012, then home arrest until 13 March 2013, followed by release but restricted to the village of Szada.
- The applicant filed several requests for release and appeals against decisions prolonging pre-trial detention or house arrest. Still, those decisions reiterated the risk of absconding due to his foreign connections.
- Prosecutorial motions were communicated to the defense late, either during the hearing or not at all.
- On 5 July 2013, the applicant was convicted of spying and sentenced to two years and 10 months’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF LJAJIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1957, 1984, 1989 and 1991, respectively, and live in Novi Pazar.
- The applicants’ late wife and mother, Ms Sadija Ljajić, worked for a socially-owned capital company called “Raška” Holding kompanija AD Novi Pazar.
- On 14 December 2005, the Municipal Court in Novi Pazar ordered the debtor to pay Ms Sadija Ljajić a certain amount on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings.
- On 10 October 2006, the Municipal Court in Novi Pazar ordered the enforcement of the judgment of 14 December 2005 by means of a bank transfer and ordered the debtor to pay Ms Ljajić the enforcement costs.
- Ms Sadija Ljajić passed away on 24 April 2013, and on 9 September 2013, the Novi Pazar First Instance Court declared Mr Fuad Ljajić as her sole inheritor.
- Some of the applicants no longer intend to pursue their application before the Court.
- On 25 October 2013, the Commercial Court in Kraljevo opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor (St. 17/2013), and Mr Fuad Ljajić submitted his claims for the payment of the amount ordered by the judgment of 14 December 2005 on 5 January 2014.
- The insolvency proceedings are still pending.

title: CASE OF PATRANIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is detained in correctional colony no. 2 in the Tatarstan Republic.
- The applicant has been suffering from multiple sclerosis since 1999 and was designated as having Category 1 disability.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of active membership of an organised criminal group and murder in 1999.
- The applicant's health deteriorated significantly and rapidly in detention and he was released in September 2012 due to his condition.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to ten years' imprisonment in May 2013, and was taken into custody again in October 2013.
- The applicant's condition continued to deteriorate, and despite several medical examinations, medical assistance was deemed inadequate by independent medical experts.
- The applicant was released in March 2015 due to his condition, and documents from both the applicant and government officials were presented to provide evidence for different positions regarding the adequacy of the medical care provided.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDR SHEVCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Volzhskiy, Volgograd Region.
- Applicant was arrested on 1 October 2010, on suspicion of drug offenses.
- Applicant was charged with two episodes of attempted drug trafficking, allegedly committed on 7 and 8 September 2010 in conspiracy with others.
- Kirovskiy District Court, Astrakhan granted the investigator’s request for detention until 1 December 2010.
- A further set of criminal proceedings was initiated against the applicant on 8 October 2010, on suspicion of drug offenses allegedly committed between the beginning of September and 1 October 2010.
- On 23 November 2010, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 20 January 2011.
- On 15 March 2011, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 20 May 2011.
- On 12 May 2011, the applicant was charged with illegal purchase and storage of particularly large quantities of narcotic drugs without intent to sell.
- On 17 May 2011, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 20 June 2011.
- On 16 June 2011, the District Court further extended the applicant’s detention until 16 September 2011.
- On 5 September 2011, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 29 February 2012.
- On 14 February 2012, the Sovetskiy District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 29 May 2012.
- On 2 April 2012, the Sovetskiy District Court found the applicant guilty of purchase and storage of drugs and sentenced him to three years’ imprisonment.
- On 13 February 2013, the Tagilstroyevskiy District Court, Nizhniy Tagil, granted the applicant’s request for early release.

title: CASE OF BATALINY v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. Applicants' personal details
2. First applicant's medical condition and treatment in hospitals
3. Refusal by doctor to admit first applicant
4. First applicant's attempted suicide and subsequent hospitalization in psychiatric hospital
5. Alleged beating of first applicant by hospital staff and patients
6. Criminal proceedings initiated for beatings (criminal case no. 82906) 
7. Criminal proceedings initiated for unlawful placement in psychiatric hospital (criminal case no. 401966)
8. Forensic psychiatric examination findings
9. Investigator's failure to take action challenged in court
10. Head of psychiatric hospital involvement in proceedings as a defendant
11. Bill of indictment submitted and case returned for additional investigation
12. Investigation discontinued and reopened multiple times
13. Information provided to applicants regarding discontinuation of proceedings due to procedural time-limit.

title: CASE OF ANDONOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1948 and is a surgeon in Kumanovo.
- On September 17th, 2004, the applicant parked his car and received an illegal parking ticket.
- The applicant followed a police car and flashed his lights, trying to discuss this issue with the police officers.
- The officers insulted, hit and kicked the applicant until he was hospitalized with injuries including a fracture of two spinal vertebrae.
- The investigating judge heard oral evidence from the parties involved, witnesses, and medical experts.

title: CASE OF SERIKOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1991 and lives in Kharkiv.
- On 16 May 2008, the applicant was arrested by police officers G. and B. of the drug crimes unit and taken to the Kharkiv City Police Department.
- Officer G. drew up a report following the search of the applicant's personal effects, according to which a package containing a marijuana substance was found on the applicant.
- The applicant alleged ill-treatment to make him confess; he was threatened with rape, kicked, and hit on the head and torso, and threatened with weapons. He was subjected to a “Palestinian hanging,” and he lost consciousness several times.
- The applicant sought medical aid at the Kharkiv City Hospital, where he was diagnosed with concussion and contusion of the soft tissues of the head and rib cage.

title: CASE OF D.P. v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant claims non-pecuniary damages due to involuntary confinement in a psychiatric hospital on two occasions. 
- The territorial jurisdiction of the case is delegated to the Kranj District Court. 
- The applicant lodges multiple requests to exclude judges from the case. 
- The Kranj District Court imposes a fine on the applicant for abusing procedural rights, but it is annulled on appeal. 
- The Kranj District Court upholds the applicant's claim in part, but both parties appeal. 
- The Ljubljana Higher Court modifies the judgment, dismissing the claim for the first confinement and remanding the case back to the district court for the second confinement. 
- The Supreme Court allows the applicant's appeal on points of law regarding the time-barred claim for the first confinement. 
- The proceedings are still pending before the Kranj District Court. 
- The applicant raises a further claim for non-pecuniary damages due to the length of the proceedings, which is dismissed as premature. 
- The Supreme Court allows the applicant's appeal on points of law regarding the possibility of claiming compensation for a violation of the right to a trial without undue delay before the termination of the main proceedings. 
- The Constitutional Court dismisses the applicant's constitutional complaint.

title: CASE OF VORONKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1939 and worked as a store keeper at a car park operated by the municipal company, Arsenal.
- The Arsenal company was founded in 1996, responsible for the assets allotted to it and competent in providing various services.
- The company only operated a car pound and stored impounded vehicles.
- The company was ordered to be liquidated, and its assets were transferred to another municipal company.
- The applicant was dismissed from his job and brought proceedings against his former employer seeking damages.
- The courts established that the applicant's dismissal was unlawful and awarded him damages.
- The Arsenal company was declared insolvent, and no assets were revealed to satisfy the creditors' claims.
- The enforcement proceedings were discontinued and the applicant's request for an injunction of a VAZ car was unsuccessful.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that the Committee should be involved in the case as a respondent, and that his request for an injunction had remained unanswered.
- The appeal was dismissed, and it was later acknowledged that the notification of the appeal hearing was sent to the wrong flat.

title: CASE OF ZAMMIT AND ATTARD CASSAR v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicants are two individuals who live in Zabbar and Birkirkara respectively.
- They own a property in Zabbar called Cressi-Sub Store, which is used as a storage facility for a nearby shop.
- The property was leased to a company registered in Malta called E. for EUR 862 a year, although there was no evidence of a lease agreement being signed.
- The applicants informed E. in 2002 that they wished to increase the rent to EUR 7,000 a year; however, E. did not agree and failed to apply to the Rent Regulation Board (RRB) as required by law.
- The RRB eventually dismissed the applicants' request to increase the rent in 2008, based on the opinion of two court-appointed architects that the current rent was already more than 40% over and above the rent level at which the premises were or could have been leased before 4 August 1914.
- The applicants' claim that their rights under Article 6 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention had been breached was initially upheld by the Civil Court (First Hall) in 2010 but later reversed by the Constitutional Court in 2011.
- The law was subsequently amended in 2010 to increase the rent applicable to commercial leases by 15% per year from 2010 onwards, with a further 5% increase per year from 2014 onwards.
- Consequently, the rent payable to the applicants increased to EUR 1,505 in 2013.

title: CASE OF RYZHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Mr Ry. was found dead in a pond on 13 October, 2008
- A post-mortem examination concluded that Mr Ry. had drowned and had bruises and sores on his chest
- Police refused to institute criminal proceedings in the case fifteen times between October 2008 and February 2013
- All those rulings were quashed by the prosecution authorities or courts
- The case was registered in the Unified Register of Pre-Trial Investigations on 7 February 2013
- The police terminated the criminal investigation twice, both decisions were quashed
- The pre-trial investigation was ongoing as of April 2014

title: CASE OF KHLAIFIA AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1983, 1987, and 1988, respectively. Mr Khlaifia (the “first applicant”) lives in Om Laarass (Tunisia); Mr Tabal and Mr Sfar (the “second applicant” and the “third applicant”) live in El Mahdia (Tunisia).
- On 16 and 17 September 2011, the applicants left Tunisia with others on board rudimentary vessels heading for the Italian coast. After several hours at sea, their vessels were intercepted by the Italian coastguard, which escorted them to a port on the island of Lampedusa.
- The applicants were transferred to an Early Reception and Aid Centre (Centro di Soccorso e Prima Accoglienza – “CSPA”) at Contrada Imbriacola where, after giving them first aid, the authorities proceeded with their identification.
- They were accommodated in a part of the center reserved for adult Tunisians. According to the applicants, they were held in an overcrowded and dirty area and were obliged to sleep on the floor because of the shortage of available beds and the poor quality of the mattresses.
- The applicants remained in that center until 20 September when a violent revolt broke out among the migrants.
- The premises were gutted by fire, and the applicants were taken to a sports complex on Lampedusa for the night. At dawn on 21 September, they managed, together with other migrants, to evade the police surveillance and walk to the village of Lampedusa.
- The applicants remained on the ships until 27 and 29 September 2011, respectively, when they were taken to Palermo airport pending removal.
- Before being put on the aircraft, the migrants were received by the Tunisian Consul. According to the applicants, the Consul merely recorded their identities in accordance with agreements between Italy and Tunisia of April 2011.
- These orders were accompanied by a record of service, each with the same date, also drafted in Italian with an Arabic translation. In the space reserved for the applicants’ signatures, both documents contain the handwritten indication “(the person) refused to sign or to receive a copy.”
- In so far as the complainants had alleged that the way in which the migrants had been treated had been detrimental to their health, the judge noted that the investigations had found that nobody on the ships had applied for asylum. Those who, at the Lampedusa CSPA, had expressed an intention to do

title: CASE OF M. AND M. v. CROATIA
facts:
- First applicant born in 1976 and second applicant in 2001 and they both live in Zadar
- Second applicant married I.M. on 23 June 2001
- First applicant born to the second applicant on 4 September 2001
- Second applicant filed for divorce, custody and maintenance for first applicant in 2006
- Eight criminal complaints filed against second applicant and I.M. between 2006 and 2008
- Parents granted a divorce with custody of the first applicant given to I.M. by judgment of 24 August 2007
- Child protection measure imposed on first applicant until 31 August 2008
- First applicant allegedly physically abused by I.M. on 1 February 2011
- Ophthalmologist diagnoses first applicant with bruising of the eyeball and eye socket tissue
- First applicant reports past physical and psychological violence by father
- Statements given to police by first applicant, I.M. and I.P.

title: CASE OF BEKERMAN v. LIECHTENSTEIN
facts:
- The applicant brought considerable assets into five different foundations set up by him in Liechtenstein.
- Proceedings have been ongoing since 2001 relating to property rights to these assets.
- Applicant's mother and sisters claimed that the applicant had not been the owner of the assets he had brought into the foundations.
- On 30 August 2001, the Regional Court prohibited the H. foundation and the applicant from disposing of assets amounting to more than three million euros deposited with P. bank.
- The Court of Appeal quashed the Regional Court's decision to dismiss the applicant's request for legal aid and granted him legal aid on 21 July 2004.
- On 28 December 2004, the Regional Court ordered the H. foundation to pay the applicant's sisters some EUR 240,000 each.
- In 2005, both R. and K. and the H. foundation lodged an appeal with the Court of Appeal against the Regional Court's judgment.
- On 25 March 2009, the Court of Appeal, allowing the H. foundation's and the applicant's appeal, dismissed the action brought by R. and K.
- On 1 October 2009, the Supreme Court allowed the appeal on points of law lodged by R. and K. and remitted the case to the Court of Appeal.
- On 2 April 2014, the Court of Appeal terminated the proceedings and noted that the parties had agreed on a settlement.

title: CASE OF SÕRO v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1948 and lives in Tartu.
- Estonia lost its independence due to the Treaty of Non-Aggression between Germany and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in 1939 and the Soviet army's invasion in 1940.
- After Estonia regained independence in 1991, the Estonian government passed a law requiring persons standing in elections or seeking certain high positions to take a written oath of conscience affirming that they had not been in the service or agents of security, intelligence, or counterintelligence services of countries which had occupied Estonia.
- In 1994, Estonia and Russia concluded a treaty on the withdrawal of Russian troops from Estonia, which Russia agreed to withdraw by 31 August 1994.
- On 6 February 1995, the Riigikogu passed the Procedure for Registration and Disclosure of Persons who Have Served in or Co-operated with Security Organisations or Intelligence or Counterintelligence Organisations of Armed Forces of States which Have Occupied Estonia Act (“the Disclosure Act”), which required the Estonian Internal Security Service to register persons who served in or cooperated with security, intelligence, or counterintelligence organizations of armed forces of states which have occupied Estonia.
- The names of registered persons were made public unless they themselves made a confession about that to the Estonian Internal Security Service within one year of the Disclosure Act's entry into force.
- The applicant worked as a driver for the Committee for State Security from 1980 to 1991 and was registered pursuant to the Disclosure Act on 27 February 2004.
- The Estonian Internal Security Service published an announcement about registered persons in Riigi Teataja Lisa, which was also published on the Internet.
- The applicant challenged the legality of the published announcement, arguing that it contained misinformation and violated his rights.
- The Tallinn Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's complaint, stating that the information contained in the announcement corresponded to the information in the notice presented to the applicant, and the publication did not violate the applicant's rights.

title: CASE OF DİLİPAK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a writer, journalist, and human rights activist from Istanbul.
- He wrote an article criticizing high-ranking officers in the armed forces who were about to retire and suggesting that they set up a political party on retirement.
- The Military Prosecutor’s Office applied to prosecute him under Article 95 §§ 4 and 5 of the Military Criminal Code for damaging hierarchical relations within the army and undermining confidence in commanding officers.
- The Military Court declined jurisdiction, stating that the offense was not military in nature and referred the case to the non-military courts for denigration of the State armed forces.
- The Military Court of Cassation quashed the decision and referred the case back to the Military Court, stating that the case should be assessed under Article 95 § 4 of the Military Criminal Code.
- The Military Court of First Instance once again declined jurisdiction in favor of the non-military courts, invoking new legislation on the press.
- The Military Criminal Code was amended and military court jurisdiction for trying civilians was abolished.
- The case was referred to multiple courts before finally being referred to the Bakırköy 2nd Criminal Court.
- The Bakırköy 2nd Criminal Court declared the proceedings statute-barred under Article 95 § 4 of the Military Criminal Code.

title: CASE OF LARI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant's daughter was found dead in P.'s office in a gas company.
- A forensic medical report concluded that the daughter's death was a result of medicinal intoxication and found haemorrhages on her body.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted to investigate the crime of incitement to commit suicide.
- The investigation was closed and found no evidence of a crime, but was later reopened due to insufficient investigation.
- The investigation has been repeatedly delayed and suspended, with the case still pending.

title: CASE OF JAVOR AND JAVOROVÁ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicants were spouses born in 1952 and 1954 respectively. 
- The first applicant died in 2013. 
- The second applicant expressed her wish to continue the application both in her own name and in the name of her late husband. 
- The applicants lodged a criminal complaint with the Bratislava V District Office of Investigation on 11 October 2002. 
- They alleged that an individual, A., had obtained an amount of money from them in return for the promise of arranging for the renovation of the flat in which they lived, and had not kept that promise. 
- On 3 December 2002, the second applicant joined the proceedings as a civil party to claim damages. 
- A criminal investigation was opened on 23 January 2003. 
- A sworn expert was appointed on 13 March 2003 to establish the value of the pecuniary damage allegedly sustained by the applicants. 
- On 4 November 2004, A. was charged but the charges were quashed by the Bratislava V District Office of the Public Prosecution Service (“the PPS”) on 10 January 2005. The matter was thus remitted to the investigation stage. 
- The applicants complained about the delay in the proceedings. 
- On 14 January 2010, the investigator decided to terminate the proceedings as there was no criminal case to answer. 
- The District Office of the PPS upheld this decision on 1 February 2010. 
- The applicants lodged a complaint under Article 127 of the Constitution with the Constitutional Court, challenging the length of the proceedings. 
- On 25 March 2010, the Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible.

title: CASE OF MILKA v. POLAND
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1957 and was detained in Dąbrowa Górnicza.
2. The applicant was detained on remand in 2007 and 2008.
3. The applicant served his sentence in various detention centres and prisons.
4. The applicant refused to undergo body searches and faced disciplinary penalties.
5. The applicant received reprimands, was forbidden to receive food parcels, and was placed in solitary confinement.
6. The applicant appealed against the disciplinary penalties.
7. The court dismissed the appeals and upheld the challenged decisions.
8. The applicant finished serving his sentence on 10 June 2013 and was released from prison.

title: CASE OF KAYTAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant in absentia for being a member of the PKK, an illegal armed organization in March 2002.
- The applicant was arrested in Syria and handed over to the Turkish authorities on 15 August 2003.
- The applicant was questioned in the absence of a lawyer on 18 August 2003 and gave a detailed statement regarding his activities in the illegal organization.
- The applicant was taken to the Erzurum State Security Court, remanded in pre-trial detention and charged under Article 125 of the former Criminal Code with seeking to destroy the constitutional order and unity of the Turkish State and to remove part of the country from the State’s control on 20 August 2003.
- The applicant retracted the statements he had made to the gendarmerie and the public prosecutor, alleging that he had been under psychological pressure during his interrogation on 9 December 2003, at the fifth court hearing.
- A Forensic Medicine Department of Erzurum Atatürk University issued a report stating that the applicant would have serious difficulty in using a firearm with one hand on 27 February 2004.
- The applicant requested a new report from the Istanbul Forensic Institute on 4 May 2004 which was refused by the trial court.
- The case was transferred to the Erzurum Assize Court as State Security Courts were abolished by Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004.
- The Erzurum Assize Court convicted the applicant on 21 September 2004 and sentenced him to “aggravated life imprisonment” by relying on his confession and the established accusations against him. 
- The Court of Cassation upheld the conviction on 7 January 2005.

title: CASE OF LULI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Tirana.
- The Tirana Commission recognized the applicant’s inherited title to a plot of land measuring 23,500 sq. m, of which 5,000 sq. m were restored, on 31 May 1996. 
- They would be compensated by an equivalent plot of land within their property in respect of a plot of land measuring 966 sq. m, of which 188 sq. m were occupied with illegal constructions.
- The right of first refusal of a public building measuring 444 sq. m situated within the plot of land measuring 966 sq. m was recognized.
- One of the ways provided for by law would compensate the applicant and other heirs in respect of another plot of land measuring 3,961 sq. m. 
- The applicant and other heirs' inherited property rights in respect of the remaining plot of land measuring 13,454 sq. m were not examined in detail at that stage.
- The applicant's and other heirs' inherited title over a plot of land measuring 6,154 sq. m, of which the first plot of land was part, was registered into the land register on 30 April 1997. 
- The applicant has not yet received any compensation regarding the first and second plots of land.
- The Tirana Commission recognized the applicant’s and other heirs’ inherited title to another plot of land measuring 2,900 sq. m on the same day.
- Since the entire plot of land was occupied, it decided that the applicant and other heirs would be compensated in one of the ways provided for by law. 
- The applicant has not yet received any compensation regarding the fourth plot of land.

title: CASE OF KOVYAZIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The three applicants participated in a public demonstration against rigged presidential elections on 6 May 2012 at Bolotnaya Square.
- Clashes between the police and protestors occurred, leading to the closure of the meeting and the dispersal of participants by the police.
- Criminal proceedings were opened by the Moscow city department of the Investigative Committee of Russian Federation to investigate the suspected mass disorders and violent acts against police.
- All applicants were arrested and charged with participation in mass disorders, with the second and the third applicants also charged with violent acts against the police officers.
- The first applicant was exempted of liability under the Amnesty Act, while the second and the third applicants were convicted as charged.
- The complaints in the case concern various aspects of the applicants' pre-trial detention.
- The first applicant dropped out of university and worked as a video-operator for a newspaper and filmed the event at Bolotnaya Square.
- He claimed he did not take part in any disorders or clashes with the police, and submitted the footage to the newspaper.
- The applicant was later detained and charged with participation in mass disorders and accused of breaching public order during the demonstration.
- The court ordered his pre-trial detention until 5 November 2012 and granted extensions, citing the gravity of the charges, the personality of the accused, and the likelihood of absconding, continuing criminal activity or obstructing the investigation.
- The Amnesty Act was passed in December 2013, leading to the request for termination of criminal proceedings against him and his release from detention. 
- The second and third applicants also had their pre-trial detention extended for the same reasons.

title: CASE OF ANDONOSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lives in Prilep.
- He was a taxi driver who parked his car on a taxi post at the Prilep bus station on 25 July 2007.
- Three Albanian nationals (“the migrants”) approached him and asked him to drive them to the village of Vitolište, Mariovo.
- Only one of them told the applicant that they were going to Vitolište to work, while the other two did not speak during the journey.
- The police stopped them at a place called Sliva, and all of them were arrested, including the applicant.
- An investigating judge of the Prilep Court of First Instance opened an investigation against the applicant and P.K. on grounds of a reasonable suspicion of migrant smuggling.
- The public prosecutor withdrew the charges against the applicant for lack of evidence, but P.K. was convicted of migrant smuggling.
- The trial court ordered confiscation of the applicant’s car, as the means by which the criminal offence had been committed.
- The applicant appealed, but the Bitola Court of Appeal dismissed his appeal and upheld the confiscation order.
- The public prosecutor notified the applicant that there were no grounds to institute legality review proceedings.

title: CASE OF TOMAYLY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Korenovsk.
- The applicant was held in remand prison IZ-23/1 in Krasnodar between 6 October 2005 and 21 December 2005.
- The prison was overcrowded and the applicant's cell held up to eight inmates despite measuring only eighteen sq. m.
- Cell 187, measuring ninety-six sq. m, was designed for twenty-eight individuals and housed up to thirty-six prisoners.
- On 19 October 2005, the Korenovskiy District Court of the Krasnodar region convicted the applicant of embezzlement and sentenced him to five years and six months’ imprisonment.
- On 21 December 2005, the Krasnodar Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal.
- Between 21 December 2005 and 20 April 2006 the applicant served his sentence in the IK-9 facility, a correctional colony located in the Krasnodar Region.
- The dormitory in which the applicant slept measured 198 sq. m and accommodated up to seventy inmates despite offering forty-nine sleeping places.

title: CASE OF SERGEYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lives in Moscow.
- On 13 August 2008, the Taganskiy District Court found the applicant guilty of corruption and sentenced him to three years' imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed and on 13 October 2008, the Moscow City Court reduced the sentence to one and a half years' imprisonment.
- The prison where the applicant was held, IZ-77/2 in Moscow, was overcrowded between 21 November 2007 and 3 November 2008.

title: CASE OF BORDENCIU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained in Târgu Jiu Prison for a twenty-five-year sentence for murder since 1998.
- The applicant alleges that the conditions of his detention in Târgu Jiu Prison since his incarceration in 1998 amounted to torture, including severely overcrowded cells, worn-out furniture, no natural light or ventilation, bed bugs, poor quality food, and smokers.
- The applicant submitted a medical certificate issued by the prison doctor on 17 March 2014, indicating various health issues.
- The Government submitted that the applicant had been held for unspecified periods of time in different cells of the Târgu Jiu Prison infirmary block, describing the dimensions and amenities of each cell.
- The Government submitted that all of the cells contained adequate furniture and that disinfection operations took place whenever the presence of insects was reported.

title: CASE OF ABDURAKHMANOVA AND ABDULGAMIDOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are the wife and mother of Mr. Abdurakhman Abdurakhmanov.
- The second applicant visited her relatives in Makhachkala.
- Mr. Abdurakhman Abdurakhmanov was abducted in front of witnesses in Kaspiysk by a group of armed men who identified themselves as the police.
- The first applicant was shown a warrant for her son's arrest signed by an investigator of the FSB.
- The applicants made numerous complaints to various law-enforcement agencies regarding the abduction and whereabouts of Mr. Abdurakhman Abdurakhmanov.

title: CASE OF NIŢULESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant recommended R.C.A. who was hired temporarily as an inspector by the Moreni City Council
- R.C.A. succeeded in the competition for a permanent position but faced tension and scrutiny at work
- R.C.A. allegedly gave DEM 1,000 to the applicant for protection as she claimed to be persecuted and sexually harassed by her superiors
- The applicant claimed the money was given as a loan and it was a common practice in their workplace
- R.C.A. denounced the applicant to the police for influence peddling after she asked for the money back
- The prosecutor's office authorized R.C.A. to record conversations between herself and the applicant
- The applicant handed over USD 400 to R.C.A. in a meeting on 2 February 2002
- A criminal investigation was initiated against the applicant but discontinued and later reopened
- R.C.A. expressed concern about the integrity of the transcripts of the recordings
- R.C.A. refused to provide the court with the original tapes and equipment used for recording the applicant
- The applicant was acquitted by the county court on the ground that the recordings were not executed in accordance with the law
- The prosecutor's office appealed against the judgment and the Court of Appeal ordered an expert technical report on the authenticity of the tape recordings
- The appeal was dismissed on the ground that the applicant could not be convicted on the basis of recordings obtained in breach of the law
- The prosecutor's appeal on points of law was allowed by the High Court of Cassation and Justice, convicting the applicant of influence peddling based on R.C.A.'s statements and the audio tapes.

title: CASE OF NABIL AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were intercepted and arrested by border police while entering Hungary via Serbia, on different dates.
- They were detained since they failed to prove their identities or their legal residence in Hungary.
- They were ordered for expulsion to Serbia and a ban on entry to the territory of Hungary for three years.
- The execution of the expulsion order was suspended for a maximum period of six months or until the expulsion became feasible.
- The applicants applied for asylum on 9 November 2011, claiming that they were persecuted in their home country by the terrorist organisation Al-Shabaab.
- Their case was admitted to the “in-merit phase” by a decision of the asylum authority on 12 December 2011, in view of the fact, among other things, that there existed no “safe third country” in their respect.
- The applicants were detained at various police departments' guarded accommodations, and their detentions were extended several times.
- The Nyírbátor District Court extended the applicants’ detention on the ground that there are substantial grounds for believing that the applicants would hinder or delay the implementation of the expulsion order.
- The applicants’ asylum applications were dismissed on 19 March 2012, but they were granted subsidiary protection.
- The applicants’ detention ended on 24 March 2012.

title: CASE OF ILKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Bersenevka, Republic of Mordovia.
- A criminal investigation was opened on 5 March 2009 after a complaint that two policemen had extorted money from S. by threatening to open a criminal case against him.
- The applicant was implicated in the crime on 23 March 2009 and charged in absentia on 2 April 2009 with kidnapping and extortion.
- The applicant's name was put on the list of wanted persons on 3 April 2009, and his whereabouts were unknown until 6 May 2010 when the investigating authorities established his temporary address.
- The applicant was arrested on 1 July 2010 after voluntarily appearing at the prosecutor's office for questioning, despite claiming that the authorities had no grounds to put his name on the list of wanted persons as they had failed to verify his whereabouts or issue a request for questioning.
- The applicant was placed in pre-trial detention from 2 July 2010 until 8 September 2011, except for a period when he underwent medical treatment.
- The applicant was detained in cells measuring 6 metres by 5.5 metres with eight bunk beds, a table, two benches, and a metal cabinet. The toilet provided no privacy.
- The applicant suffers from chronic gastritis and post-traumatic brain dysfunction and was eligible for a special food regime, which was allegedly not provided.
- The applicant was transported in various prison vans of different types and capacities, sometimes with up to 27 other detainees, with insufficient ventilation and no toilet facilities during the journey.
- The applicant spent eight hours in a dirty, poorly ventilated, and poorly lit holding cell at the court-house during trial days.

title: CASE OF BOUYID v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicants are brothers who live with their parents, their brother and two sisters.
- They alleged that they had been slapped in the face by police officers.
- The events took place against a background of tense relations between their family and certain officers in the police station.
- The first applicant had been standing with a friend in the street outside the door of the building when a plain-clothes policeman asked him to show him his identity card.
- The first applicant had refused to comply, and the officer had grabbed him by his jacket and taken him to the police station. The officer had then slapped him in the face as he was protesting about his arrest.
- The first applicant sustained injuries on his left cheek and external auditory canal.
- The government disputed the allegations and claimed that the officer had no choice but to take him to the police station for identification.
- The second applicant was at the police station and was being interviewed about an altercation involving him and his mother together with a third party, and Officer P.P. had slapped him in the face after asking him not to lean on his desk.
- The applicants' family had been harassed by the Saint-Josse-ten-Noode police force.
- They had systematically reported to the judicial authorities or police all the incidents of which they had been victims, and had filed complaints.
- Officer A.Z. and Officer P.P. were charged with using violence against individuals in the course of their duties and, in particular, with intentional wounding or assault, and with engaging in arbitrary acts in breach of the rights and freedoms guaranteed by the Constitution.
- The case against the officers was discontinued without any evidence that would justify the taking of further measures.
- The Committals Division, endorsing the grounds set out in the Crown Prosecutor’s application, discontinued the proceedings.

title: CASE OF UDVARDY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Komló.
- The applicant was interrogated on 19 February 2003 for forgery of private documents.
- The Public Prosecutor preferred a bill of indictment on 8 October 2004.
- The Public Prosecutor extended charges against the applicant in June 2005 with fraud.
- The Komló District Court acquitted the applicant in respect of fraud on 23 March 2010 and found him guilty in forgery of private documents.
- The Baranya County Court acquitted the applicant of all charges on 20 May 2011 after an appeal by the Public Prosecutor.

title: CASE OF NEMESNÉ FONYÓDI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Győr.
- The ex-husband initiated a civil lawsuit against the applicant for dissolution of marital property and return of present on 21 February 2003.
- The court separated the claim into two proceedings and dismissed the claimant’s claim for the return of present.
- The first-instance court delivered the judgment in respect of the dissolution of the marital property on 13 January 2010.
- The Budapest Court of Appeal delivered the final and binding judgment on 7 July 2011, amending the first-instance judgment in several aspects.
- Both the applicant and the claimant challenged the judgment before the Supreme Court, which upheld the judgment on 2 October 2012.

title: CASE OF LÁZÁR v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1948 and reside in Budapest
- Applicants were engaged in a legal dispute with housing cooperative and two individuals over property ownership rights
- Competent courts dismissed applicants' several claims for title
- Applicants filed an action for damages against housing cooperative and two individuals on 15 October 2002
- Procedure was suspended on 17 December 2004 due to other pending proceedings before the land registry authority
- First-instance court found partly in favor of applicants on 9 March 2010 after several hearings
- On appeal, the Budapest Court of Appeal reversed the judgment and dismissed the applicants’ claim on 30 November 2010.

title: CASE OF DÉRY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant was a judge at the Budapest Labour Court and the Pest Central District Court.
- The employer pursued the applicant's appraisal, which resulted in her inadequacy for judicial service.
- From 1 July 2004, the applicant worked as a judicial secretary.
- The employer ordered further appraisals of the applicant, which she contested.
- The applicant initiated a labor lawsuit against her employer on 25 March 2005.
- The Székesfehérvár Labour Court partly found for the applicant on 15 December 2008.
- The Fejér County Court upheld the judgment on 30 September 2009.
- The Supreme Court upheld the judgment on 17 January 2011.

title: CASE OF KAVAKLIOĞLU AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The case relates to a series of conflicts between the Ulucanlar prison staff and some of the leftist prisoners dating back to 1996
- The prison was overcrowded and inadequate facilities were a central issue for the complaints and actions of the prisoners
- A plan was drawn up in 1996 to deal with potential riots and breakouts by the leftist prisoners
- No practical action was taken until 1998, despite escalating criminal activities in the prison
- The leftist prisoners gradually took over Ulucanlar Sector 3 from September 1998 onwards
- There were two search operations in September 1998, and some items were confiscated, but dormitories 4 and 5 and the female dormitory were excluded from the searches 
- The situation was reported as becoming worse after January 1999, with continuing complaints of possession of firearms and tunnel digging 
- On 19 July 1999, the prisoners of dormitories 1-3 held the Deputy Governor and Head Warden hostage until released with no injuries

title: CASE OF N.P. v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is a single mother living in Chișinău with her daughter and mother.
- On 22 September 2011, the police removed the applicant's daughter from her home and placed her in the care of the Municipal Children’s Hospital “V. Ignatenco” due to severe alcohol intoxication of the applicant.
- C.I., a salesman in a shop near the applicant's house, called the police due to the applicant and her mother drinking alcohol, fighting, and neglecting the child.
- The Ciocana Police Office reported the unsanitary conditions of the child's living environment, absence from pre-school, and begging food from neighbors.
- The Ciocana Child Protection Committee concluded that A.’s return to her biological family would put her life and health in danger, placed her in the Municipal Children’s Centre, and initiated proceedings to withdraw the applicant’s parental authority.
- A. was diagnosed with “residual encephalopathy with delayed motor skills, mild leg movement disorder, thyroid gland disease, decreased need for sleep (“hyposomnia”), urinary insufficiency and disorder of the function of the pancreas” and was prescribed treatment.
- On 14 February 2012, the Ciocana District Court decided to withdraw the applicant’s parental authority relying essentially on the arguments of the Child Protection Service.
- The applicant appealed multiple times but ultimately lost the case.

title: CASE OF CONIAC v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant, as administrator of four commercial companies, signed contracts with different commercial companies for the supply of merchandise, and issued cheques as payment.
- A criminal investigation was initiated against the applicant for fraud in connection with the cheques.
- The prosecutor’s office informed the applicant that the criminal investigation initiated against him was going to be discontinued.
- A seller lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant.
- The prosecutor ordered criminal proceedings to be instituted against the applicant on charges of fraud, and the investigation took place in the absence of the applicant.
- The applicant’s wife instituted divorce civil proceedings against him, and by a final judgment, the Focșani District Court allowed her claim and pronounced the divorce.
- The applicant was found guilty of fraud and was imposed a three-year prison sentence suspended on probation.
- The prosecutor’s office and the applicant appealed against the judgment.
- The Galați Court of Appeal partly allowed the appeal lodged by the prosecutor and increased the sentence to four years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed on points of law, and the High Court of Cassation and Justice dismissed the appeal as unfounded.
- The applicant served his prison sentence between 25 October 2006 and 3 December 2008 on probation.
- The Bacău Court of Appeal acquitted the applicant in another set of criminal proceedings against him for fraud in connection with similar acts.
- The applicant lodged two criminal complaints against the expert who had prepared a technical expert report in the criminal proceedings against him.
- The applicant lodged a complaint regarding the prosecutor's decisions of 22 December 2009 and 29 November 2013 by which the criminal complaints against the expert had been discontinued.

title: CASE OF METIN GÜLTEKİN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants born in 1960, 1963, 1988 and 1986 respectively and live in Zonguldak
- Toğay Gültekin born in 1983 and started doing his compulsory military service in August 2003
- On 17 March 2004, Toğay Gültekin was examined by a doctor at his regiment and decided to refer him to a hospital
- On 22 March 2004, Toğay Gültekin was diagnosed with fulminant hepatitis and was sent to the Haydarpaşa GATA Hospital in Istanbul
- On 27 March 2004, Toğay Gültekin died at the GATA Hospital
- No autopsy was performed on Toğay Gültekin
- An investigation was carried out at the military unit where Toğay Gültekin had been doing his military service
- Applicants initiated compensation proceedings against the Ministry of Defence
- Applicants argued that Toğay Gültekin had not received prompt or adequate medical care in his regiment
- The Military Administrative Court appointed three medical experts to clarify whether the military authorities had acted negligently
- The medical experts concluded that no delays, fault, or negligence existed in Toğay Gültekin's medical treatment
- The Military Administrative Court dismissed the applicants' claim, and the applicants' request for rectification was also refused.

title: CASE OF MÜDÜR DUMAN v. TURKEY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was the director of the Eminönü district branch of HADEP in Istanbul.
- A demonstration was organized in Istanbul in support of Abdullah Öcalan, the leader of the PKK.
- The police identified some participants as members of HADEP, including the demonstrators who chanted slogans supporting Öcalan.
- The Istanbul State Security Court issued a search warrant for four branches of HADEP to obtain evidence concerning the PKK.
- The police found illegal publications, and flags/symbols of the PKK in the Eminönü branch office of HADEP, which was signed by the applicant.
- The applicant denied responsibility for the items found in the office and was taken into custody.
- The applicant was questioned by the public prosecutor and charged with praising and condoning acts punishable by law.
- The Istanbul Criminal Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to six months’ imprisonment and a fine.
- The applicant appealed against the judgment, claiming he was not duly reminded of his right to request a lawyer and that he missed the hearing.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the fine but upheld the remainder of the judgment.
- The applicant started serving his sentence on 31 January 2003 and was released on parole on 13 April 2003.

title: CASE OF KARPYUK AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants were members and supporters of the Ukrainian National Assembly and the Ukrainian National Solidarity Organisation.
- In late 2000 and early 2001, opposition groups launched a campaign against the then President Leonid Kuchma, including rallies and demonstrations.
- On 9 March 2001, the applicants and other supporters participated in a political rally near the Shevchenko monument in Kyiv, without giving advance notice to authorities.
- The protesters attempted to break through police cordon to disrupt the flower-laying ceremony and attacked the police. Clashes between police and protesters ensued, and several police officers were injured.
- The applicants were arrested and charged with organising and participating in mass disorder. A number of law enforcement officers who had been assaulted or injured were recognised as aggrieved parties in the proceedings.
- During the trial, pre-trial investigation statements were read out, in which witnesses accused the applicants of inciting and directing attacks on the police. The applicants pleaded not guilty.

title: CASE OF STIBILJ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants are a mother and daughter who live in Ajdovščina, born in 1921 and 1949 respectively.
- In 1989, a land consolidation programme was adopted by the Ajdovščina Municipality Land Consolidation Commission, which included the applicants' land.
- The applicants appealed against this decision to the Slovenian Surveying and Mapping Authority in March 1989.
- The Commission amended the land consolidation programme in November 1990, but the second applicant appealed against it.
- The first applicant's predecessor appealed in December 1990 for the Authority to decide on the matter within a prescribed time-limit.
- The Authority granted the first applicant's predecessor's appeal in February 1991 and remitted the case to the Commission for further consideration.
- The Convention became operational in respect of Slovenia in June 1994.
- The Authority granted the second applicant's appeal against the decision of November 1990 in November 1994.
- The applicants lodged informal motions before the Commission asking for expedited proceedings in December 1994 and March and April 1996.
- The applicants each lodged a separate appeal with the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Food in April 1997 for the Commission's failure to adopt a decision within the prescribed time-limit.
- The applicants brought an action before the Administrative Court for the Ministry's failure to decide on the matter at issue within the prescribed time-limit in September 1997.
