- The Administrative Court allowed the applicants' actions and ordered the Ministry to decide on the matter at issue within thirty days in September 1999.
- In August 1999, the Administrative Unit adopted new decisions on the applicants' land.
- The applicants appealed against these decisions in September 1999, and their appeals were allowed in August 2000.
- The applicants brought actions for judicial review before the Administrative Court against the Ministry's decisions in November 2000.
- The first applicant's predecessor died in January 2001, and the first applicant inherited a part of his land, including plots subject to land consolidation proceedings.
- The Administrative Court allowed the applicants' actions for judicial review, annulling the Ministry's decisions of May 2007 in June 2009.
- The Ministry issued a decision annulling the Administrative Unit's decision of August 1999 in April 2013.
- The land consolidation proceedings were still pending on the date of the Government's last communication with the Court.

title: CASE OF TURBYLEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Ukhta, the Komi Republic, born in 1970.
- In April 2005, a jewellery shop and other premises in a commercial centre in the Sosnogorsk district of the Komi Republic were robbed, and a woman guard was attacked and injured.
- Investigator A. initially opened and then suspended a criminal case due to the lack of identification of a person to be charged.
- R. reported on 25 August 2005 that her boyfriend B. had committed the robbery with Zh. and the applicant, leading to the reopening of the case.
- The police arrested B., Zh., and the applicant on 26 August 2005. The applicant reported ill-treatment by police officers.
- The police demanded that the applicant confess to the robbery, and operative officer G. punched and kicked him. The applicant signed a confession statement, fearing further violence.
- The prosecutor reopened the case on 5 December 2005, ordering a full investigation of the applicant's allegations of ill-treatment while in police custody.
- Several decisions to terminate the proceedings due to lack of evidence were set aside, and the investigation was reopened by the deputy prosecutor of the Komi Republic on several occasions.
- At trial, the applicant denied the charges and alleged that his confession was coerced through physical and psychological coercion by the police. The co-defendant, B., testified that the applicant had no involvement in the robbery.
- The applicant's wife confirmed that he sustained injuries on the day of his arrest.

title: CASE OF GORSHCHUK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lives in Nizhniy Novgorod.
- A man with multiple injuries was found in a public garden in Nizhniy Novgorod and an investigation started into the murder.
- On 14 September 2007, the applicant was arrested at a house in the village of Druzhkovo in the Nizhniy Novgorod region along with others who were interviewed by police officers about the murder.
- The applicant was allegedly beaten and demanded to confess to the murder but refused, written two statements concerning the origin of his injuries.
- The applicant was taken to pre-trial detention facility SIZO-52/1 with severe injuries, and he requested an inquiry to be carried out.
- Two police officers allegedly threatened the applicant to confess and admitted to the murder, but he signed a confession and later retracted it.
- The investigator refused to institute criminal proceedings for abuse of power, citing the missing constituent elements of a crime.
- The head of the Investigative Committee revoked the investigator’s decision and ordered an interview of the applicant and officers involved, records concerning the applicant’s state of health, and the gravity of harm to his health be assessed.
- The applicant’s allegations were refuted by the statements of the investigator in the murder case, police officers and others, as well as his own statement that he received the abrasion on his chin and bruising to his chest "on 14 September on Sovetskaya Street in the village of Druzhkovo."
- The court dismissed the applicant's appeal against the decision not to open a criminal case and held that it could not be examined in review proceedings.
- The Nizhniy Novgorod Regional Court quashed that decision and terminated the proceedings on the grounds that an examination of the applicant's appeal against the investigator's decision in separate proceedings could have prejudiced the legal assessment of his confession as evidence.
- Medical opinions obtained by the applicant's representative concluded that the injuries could have been inflicted by a blunt object on 14 or 15 September 2007.

title: CASE OF ŻUK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant and her husband had equal shares in their common property under the statutory regime of common marital property.
- The Szczecin Town Council held that the applicant's husband was determined a candidate to purchase two plots of land in 1989.
- The decision on the sale of the land was appealed by J.S., W.K. and W.H.
- The decision of 20 November 1989 was upheld by the Szczecin Governor on 16 April 1993.
- A new local land development plan was adopted by the Szczecin municipality on 16 May 1994.
- On 27 March 1998, the Szczecin Governor gave an administrative decision transferring ownership of the land concerned to the Agency of Agricultural Property of the State Treasury.
- The applicant and her husband requested the Szczecin Municipality to sell the property concerned to them in 2003.
- The Szczecin District Court dismissed the claim on 28 November 2003, and the Szczecin Regional Court allowed the appeal on 15 April 2004.
- On 14 May 2007, the Szczecin District Court held that the statutory conjugal property of the applicant and her husband created ex lege by their marriage on 6 January 1979, had been replaced by a separate marital property regime as from 1 January 2004.
- The claim against the State Treasury and the municipality of Szczecin was dismissed by the Szczecin District Court on 30 July 2009.

title: CASE OF STASIK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant's wife left the matrimonial home and moved to Zakopane with their son in April 2007.
- The applicant lodged an application with the Zakopane District Court for the establishment of contact on 22 November 2007.
- The applicant withdrew the application due to the parties' agreement to establish the contact arrangement by way of a friendly settlement.
- The applicant requested that the Zakopane District Court regulate his contact with his child again on 4 July 2008.
- On 3 September 2008, the Zakopane District Court issued an interim contact order, allowing the applicant to visit the child at the mother's home on specific days and times.
- The cases for separation and divorce were subsequently joined and a hearing was held on 25 August 2009.
- On the same date, the Siedlce Regional Court issued an interim contact order pending the outcome of the divorce proceedings.
- Both parties lodged appeals against the interim contact order.
- The Siedlce Regional Court dissolved the applicant's marriage on 26 March 2013, granting the parental rights of the applicant to be limited and the child's place of residence to be with the mother.
- The applicant filed for enforcement proceedings concerning contact arrangements multiple times.

title: CASE OF VALIO SHIPPING COMPANY v. ALBANIA
facts:
- Applicant company is a shipping company in liquidation incorporated under Greek Law in 1991, with its legal seat in Kallithea, Greece.
- The Vlora District Court decided on March 13, 1995, that the applicant company’s vessel had been unlawfully seized.
- On December 1, 1995, the applicant company brought a civil action against the local Treasury office, the district prosecutor’s office, and the local Customs Administration, seeking compensation for the damage caused by the unlawful seizure.
- On July 4, 1996, the Vlora District Court dismissed both civil actions.
- On November 14, 1996, the Tirana Court of Appeal quashed that decision and ordered the local Treasury office to pay the applicant company 1,621,575 USD for damages.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision on July 30, 1997, and an enforcement writ was issued at the request of the applicant company on October 27, 1997.
- The Customs Administration and the district prosecutor lodged a request for supervisory review on April 22, 1999.
- On August 8, 2000, the bailiff discontinued the enforcement proceedings.
- The applicant company withdrew its enforcement request on February 3, 2005.
- From 2006 to 2008, the bailiff unsuccessfully sought the enforcement of the decision from the local Treasury office and the Ministry of Finance.
- To date, the final decision remains unenforced.

title: CASE OF SERGEY DENISOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested in August 2012 for suspicion of selling heroin.
- The Sverdlovskiy District Court of Krasnoyarsk authorized his placement in custody for two months.
- The court reasoned that the applicant was charged with a serious criminal offence, and his lack of stable income and previous conviction for a similar crime made him a flight risk.
- The applicant's arguments about his employment, role as a breadwinner, and permanent place of residence were dismissed.
- The applicant's poor health was also not considered sufficient for his release.
- The applicant did not appeal against the detention order.
- The applicant's detention was extended multiple times after that, with reasons such as the gravity of the charges, criminal history, and risk of absconding, re-offending or tampering with witnesses.
- The applicant was diagnosed with HIV infection, as well as penile cancer of the first degree and chronic hepatitis C (HCV).
- The applicant regularly received antiretroviral drugs and was monitored for his HIV infection during his detention.
- The case file provided no information about whether the applicant received treatment for hepatitis C.
- The applicant complained to the Regional Prosecutor about his antiretroviral drugs being taken after his arrest.
- The applicant's requests for a forensic medical examination to determine whether he should be detained on remand were denied.

title: CASE OF AŽDAJIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Ruše.
- K.R. sent a letter to the applicant on 11 November 2006, asking her to repay a loan within thirty days of receipt of the letter, threatening court proceedings if the applicant failed to pay.
- The applicant refused to accept the letter and sign the notice of receipt on 13 November 2006. K.R. also sent the letter via ordinary mail on the same day.
- The applicant replied to K.R. on 20 November 2006, stating that she did not owe K.R anything.
- K.R. filed a claim against the applicant on 13 December 2006, claiming repayment of the loan (totaling 14,000 euros) allegedly given to the applicant by K.R. in 2004.
- The postman left two delivery slips in the applicant's mailbox in January 2007, but the applicant claims she did not find them when she returned from Namibia on 24 March 2007.
- On 14 September 2007, the Maribor District Court issued a default judgment ordering the applicant to pay 14,000 euros with interest to K.R within fifteen days.
- The applicant filed an appeal against the decision and application to reinstate the proceedings on 28 September 2007.
- The Maribor District Court rejected the applicant's application to reinstate the proceedings on 13 December 2007, and the higher court confirmed the decision on 9 September 2008.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law on 11 November 2010.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's constitutional complaint on 22 May 2012.
- K.R. initiated enforcement proceedings against the applicant after the decision became final and withdrew the application for enforcement after the applicant paid her 4,000 euros.

title: CASE OF KHARLAMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1948 and is a tenured professor in physics department of the Orel State Technical University.
- The president of the university called for an election of the academic senate, which was to take place later that year.
- The applicant spoke at the conference protesting that he and his colleagues in the physics department were not consulted or informed about the process of the nomination of candidates to the academic senate.
- The university sued the applicant for defamation on the grounds that his speech had undermined the university's reputation.
- The district court found the applicant guilty of defamation and awarded the university damages, court fees, and directed the applicant to read the refutation at the following university conference.
- The applicant appealed the decision, which was partly amended by the regional court.

title: CASE OF FARTUSHIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1985 and lived in Sarov, in the Nizhniy Novgorod region.
- An all-terrain vehicle and a car were stolen from private garages in Sarov in February and April 2008, respectively.
- Applicant was contacted by police officer V. and requested him to come to office no. 320 at the Sarov police station at 2 p.m. for questioning.
- In office no. 320, police officer V. and the chief of the criminal investigation unit of the Sarov UVD, B., demanded that he confess to the thefts. 
- Following his refusal, he was taken to a nearby office, shackled, and beaten up by B.
- The applicant claimed he was beaten up by the police, and he was not given food or drink. He felt unwell and vomited blood.
- On 6 May 2008, the applicant’s wife filed a complaint with the Sarov town prosecutor and the head of the Sarov town police department.
- On 8 May 2008, the applicant was brought before a judge, who ordered that he be remanded in custody.
- The applicant and a number of other persons were charged with the theft.
- On 7 May 2008, the applicant lodged a complaint with the Sarov town prosecutor, alleging that he had been unlawfully deprived of his liberty and ill-treated in police custody.
- On 22 May 2008, the investigator ordered that no criminal proceedings be instituted in respect of the applicant’s complaints of unlawful detention and ill-treatment.
- On 6 June 2009, the most recent decision not to open a criminal case on the grounds that elements of a crime in the acts were missing.

title: CASE OF VUJICA v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Graz.
- The applicant married Mr S.V. in Vienna in 1997 and they lived there until 2006, when they moved to Komletinci (Croatia).
- The applicant gave birth to three children: E.V. in 1999, F.V. in 2001, and L.V. in 2006.
- The applicant and S.V. separated in 2009, and the applicant took the children with her to Graz, Austria, after collecting them from S.V.'s parents in Vienna.
- S.V. initially agreed to let the children stay in Austria but changed his mind after the summer of 2010 when he refused to return them to the applicant after their visit to Croatia.
- The applicant sought the return of her children through the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which was forwarded to the Vinkovci Municipal Court in Croatia. 
- The Vinkovci Social Welfare Centre intervened, interviewed S.V. and the children, and concluded that it was in the children's best interest to remain with their father in Komletinci.

title: CASE OF KOROŠEC v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Ljubljana.
- The applicant suffers from progressive spinal muscular atrophy and needs twenty-four hour assistance with all his daily activities.
- In 2006, the Pensions and Disability Insurance Institute of the Republic of Slovenia awarded the applicant an assistance and attendance allowance (hereinafter “the allowance”) of 70% of the reference amount.
- The applicant's general practitioner applied for an increase in the allowance on 28 May 2009, stating the applicant’s worsening condition, referring to the deterioration of the applicant’s respiratory functions.
- On 9 July 2009, the first-instance disability commission of the Institute reported that the applicant did not need permanent, professional, medical assistance.

title: CASE OF TSELOVALNIK v. RUSSIA
facts:
• Applicant convicted of attempted drug trafficking, sentenced to 10 years and 6 months in prison in Kemerovo.

• Applicant diagnosed with hepatitis C prior to arrest, but initial medical check-up did not reveal any diseases.

• Later, a certificate from a civil hospital attested that the applicant was suffering from hepatitis C.

• Applicant complained of severe pain in knees, but only suggested rheumatoid polyarthritis and deforming osteochondrosis.

• After many complaints, the applicant was diagnosed with articular syndrome linked to hepatitis C.

• Applicant complained to prison authorities about the lack of proper medical assistance and requested forensic medical examination or admit to a prison hospital.

• Prison administration replied that medical examinations, including X-ray examination, did not reveal any articular pathology, and that they were equipped to address the applicant’s health problems.

• Applicant transferred multiple times between prisons; complained of deterioration in health, and painful joint movements.

• The applicant was placed in detention without any warm clothes, despite complaining about the cold.

• The applicant was finally diagnosed with multi-level osteochondrosis, osteoarthrosis of the knee joints, a soft tissue disorder of the shoulder, and lumbodynia.

• The applicant had to repeatedly ask for the medical care he needed.

• Medical panel found that applicant’s diseases posed no risk to his life; but later doctors suspected that he might have infiltrative tuberculosis in his left lung.

• The applicant claimed that his health complaints had been systematically ignored, that his condition had deteriorated in detention, and that he had not been receiving the treatment prescribed to him in December 2012.

title: CASE OF S.H. v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant is a mother of three children.
- The children were hospitalized due to the accidental ingestion of medication.
- The children were removed from their family and placed in an institution by the court order.
- The parents admitted to difficulties in looking after the children due to the applicant's depression and medication.
- The psychiatrist submitted a report on the applicant's mental health, her willingness to undergo psychotherapy, and her strong emotional bond with the children.
- The Integrated Working Group on Adoption proposed returning the children to their parents and introducing a family support project.
- The court ordered an expert assessment of the applicant's and the children's father's capacity for exercising their parental role.
- The court declared the children available for adoption and interrupted the parents' reunion with their children.
- The parents appealed against the decision of declaring the children available for adoption.
- Each child was placed in a different foster family by the court order.
- The Rome Court of Appeal upheld the declaration of availability for adoption.
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant's appeal and confirmed the availability for adoption.
- The applicant requested the Rome Youth Court to cancel the declaration of availability for adoption.
- The Rome Youth Court dismissed the applicant's request. 
- The outcome of the adoption procedure concerning the children is unknown.

title: CASE OF BREMNER v. TURKEY
facts:
Main descriptions of facts:

- The applicant is a correspondent and volunteers at a bookshop in Australia at the time of the events. 
- He appeared in a television documentary in Turkey about covert religious activities. 
- The documentary showed him meeting with a man who had responded to an advertisement for free Christian books and discussing Christianity with him and others. 
- The documentary was critical of proselytizing activities and referred to the applicant as a "pedlar of religion." 
- The applicant was remanded in custody briefly after the documentary was filmed and subsequently found innocent of insulting Allah and Islam. 
- He filed an action for damages against the television presenter and producers, which was initially dismissed but later taken up by the Court of Cassation. 
- The Court of Cassation found that the applicant's right to respect for his private life had been violated by the filming and broadcast of the documentary, but the Assembly of Civil Chambers of the Court of Cassation upheld the finding of the first-instance court that the documentary was of major public interest and that a fair balance had been struck between merits and formal aspects.

title: CASE OF ÜNSPED PAKET SERVİSİ SAN. VE TİC. A.Ş. v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant company runs logistics services.
- On 23 June 2007, a lorry belonging to the applicant company was stopped for inspection at the Yambol customs post.
- 500,060 tablets, 3,564 grams of white tablets containing ephedrine hydrochloride and 6,880 pills containing testosterone enanthate were discovered and seized from the lorry by authorities.
- Criminal proceedings were opened against the driver of the lorry.
- On 26 June 2007, the applicant company asked the Yambol Regional Prosecutor to return its vehicle. The request was rejected on the grounds that the lorry had to be retained as material evidence until the end of the criminal proceedings.
- The applicant company again applied to the Yambol Regional Prosecutor’s Office on 3 August 2007, asking that the lorry be returned. The request was not replied to as the case file was no longer with the prosecution service.
- In the meantime, the lorry driver concluded a plea bargain agreement with the prosecutor. The terms included a one-and-a-half-year prison sentence for the driver and the forfeiture of the lorry.
- On 8 August 2007, the applicant company asked the criminal court competent to approve the plea bargain agreement not to confiscate its lorry.
- On 14 August 2007, the Yambol Regional Court confirmed the plea bargain agreement in which the driver confessed that he was guilty of smuggling and accepted the forfeiture of the transported drugs and the lorry.
- The decision was not subject to appeal and became enforceable on the same day.
- On 26 May 2008, the applicant company brought proceedings seeking damages against the lorry driver.
- The Office found the driver liable to pay EUR 110,116.75 to the applicant company for the damage his actions had caused. However, the applicant company could not collect any of this amount as the lorry driver had no assets at the time.

title: CASE OF AKKOYUNLU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant started his compulsory military service in Şırnak in 2001.
- On 25 July 2001, the applicant contacted the infirmary of his regiment, complaining of severe pain in his left eye.
- The military doctor was absent, and the applicant was given eye drops by a soldier who had no medical qualifications.
- The pain became persistent, but he was not relieved of his sentry duties during that period.
- On 2 August 2001, he was diagnosed with a corneal ulcer at the Cizre State Hospital.
- The applicant was transferred to the Diyarbakır Military Hospital, where he completely lost the sight in his left eye, and underwent several operations from 13 August 2001 to 18 July 2002.
- A medical report in July 2002 concluded that the applicant was no longer medically fit for military service and that he was eligible for an ocular prosthesis.
- In October 2002, the applicant instituted proceedings before the Supreme Military Administrative Court, seeking compensation from the Ministry of the Interior for the damage he had suffered to his eye during his compulsory military service.
- He claimed 30,000,000,000 Turkish liras (TRL) in respect of pecuniary damage and TRL 30,000,000,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- The Gendarmerie High Command argued that on 25 and 26 July 2001, the applicant had been examined at the infirmary of his regiment by military doctor İ.H.Ş., who had prescribed medication for him.
- The administrative court appointed three university professors from the ophthalmology department of Gazi University’s Faculty of Medicine as experts, who concluded that there were no delays, shortcomings, mistakes or negligence in the steps taken in treating the applicant.
- On 18 May 2005, the Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s claim, holding that no fault could be attributed to the military authorities in the treatment of the applicant.
- On 21 September 2005, the Supreme Military Administrative Court refused the applicant’s rectification request.
- According to a medical report of 9 October 2009 issued by the Haseki Hospital, the applicant was deemed to be suffering from a permanent disability as a result of the loss of sight in his left eye.

title: CASE OF MICLEA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant and his friends were involved in a fight with a group of people outside a bar
- The police were called to stop the fight and took the applicant and his friends to the police station to give statements
- The applicant saw a police officer behave roughly with an arrestee and commented on it, leading to him being taken to a back office where he was handcuffed to a radiator and punched and kicked by two police officers
- The applicant suffered injuries that required nine days of medical treatment
- The applicant lodged a complaint against the two police officers for abusive investigative conduct and bodily harm, but the case was closed after conflicting statements from witnesses and police officers.

title: CASE OF JOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Belgrade.
- On 7 July 2008, the applicant was arrested in Croatia on suspicion of war crimes against the civilian population.
- On 9 July 2008, an investigating judge of the Osijek County Court ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention.
- The applicant was indicted on charges of war crimes against civilians and remained in detention.
- On 15 March 2011, the applicant was found guilty and sentenced to five years' imprisonment.
- On 22 February 2012, the Supreme Court remitted the case to the County Court on procedural grounds and extended the applicant's detention.
- On 2 April 2012, the Supreme Court extended the maximum period of the applicant's pre-trial detention.
- On 18 April 2012, the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against the decision of 2 April 2012.
- On 1 June 2012, the County Court found the applicant guilty after retrial and extended his detention until the first-instance judgment became final.
- The applicant appealed to the Supreme Court, which dismissed his appeal on 15 June 2012.
- On 20 July 2012, the applicant challenged the decision of the County Court on his detention of 1 June 2012 before the Constitutional Court.
- On 8 January 2013, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's constitutional complaint against the decisions extending his detention.
- On 14 January 2013, the Constitutional Court declared the applicant's earlier constitutional complaint inadmissible.

title: CASE OF HAÁSZ AND SZABÓ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were on an excursion to Lake Balaton and decided to spend the night in their car parked in a car park next to a pizzeria.
- An unknown person telephoned a volunteer law enforcer about their suspiciously moving car.
- The police officer and volunteer investigated and found the applicants’ car parked in front of a private house.
- Officer K. shot at the applicants’ car, hitting it twice, while they were attempting to exit a private garden, eventually hitting Officer K.'s car in the process. 
- The criminal investigation against Officer K. was discontinued, but disciplinary proceedings were initiated against him for his unprofessional conduct.
- The applicants challenged the lawfulness of the police measures.
- The prosecutor found that Officer K.'s use of firearms was lawful, while Officer K.'s conduct had been unprofessional.
- The Veszprém County Public Prosecutor’s Office dismissed the applicants’ complaint.
- Meanwhile, the Head of Balatonfüred Police Department dismissed the applicants’ complaint about the actions of Officer K.
- The applicants have been suffering from psychological troubles since the incident.

title: CASE OF V.R. v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1992.
- On 8 May 2013, he was arrested on suspicion of sexual abuse and indecent behaviour towards two children.
- On 10 May 2013, the County Court ordered his pre-trial detention under Article 123 § 1(2) and (3).
- On 17 May 2013, the applicant's appeal was dismissed by a three-judge panel of the County Court.
- On 6 June 2013, the applicant's detention was extended under Article 123 § 1(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 12 June 2013, the applicant appealed, alleging numerous procedural flaws when his pre-trial detention was extended.
- On 14 June 2013, the appeal was dismissed, and it was served on the applicant's representative on 26 June 2013.
- On 5 July 2013, the applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court challenging the decisions on his pre-trial detention.
- On 8 July 2013, the applicant was indicted in the Municipal Court on charges of sexual abuse and indecent behaviour.
- On the same day, the Municipal Court extended his pre-trial detention under Article 123 § 1(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 10 July 2013, the applicant challenged the decision by lodging an appeal with the County Court.
- On the same day, the Constitutional Court declared the applicant's complaint of 5 July 2013 inadmissible.
- On 19 July 2013, the County Court quashed the decision of 8 July 2013 extending the applicant's pre-trial detention and remitted the case to the Municipal Court for re-examination.
- On 22 July 2013, the Municipal Court released the applicant from detention, imposing a number of conditions on his release.

title: CASE OF VROUNTOU v. CYPRUS
facts:
- In 1974, the Republic of Cyprus approved a scheme of aid for displaced persons and war victims. 
- Displaced persons were entitled to refugee cards, which made them eligible for benefits including housing assistance. 
- The term "displaced" was defined as any person whose permanent home was in occupied areas or had been evacuated due to the National Guard's needs. 
- Non-displaced women whose husbands were displaced and children whose fathers were displaced could be registered on the respective refugee cards. 
- The applicant's mother has been a refugee since 1974 and holds a refugee card. 
- The applicant applied for a refugee card but was rejected because her father was not displaced. 
- The applicant filed a recourse before the Supreme Court, claiming a violation of the principle of equality safeguarded by the Constitution and breach of the Convention. 
- The single judge and a panel of five judges of the Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, stating that they could not extend legislative arrangements without the approval of Parliament, and the House of Representatives could not enact legislation incurring expenditure. 
- A similar challenge was rejected by the Supreme Court in another case involving the non-extension of refugee cards to the children of displaced women.

title: CASE OF PERİNÇEK v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- Main descriptions of facts: 
   - B. The statements that are in question
   - C. The criminal proceedings against the applicant related to these statements
   - D. The 2008 criminal proceedings against the applicant in Turkey
   - E. Other materials presented by the participants in the proceedings.

title: CASE OF L.M. AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Syrian nationals or had their habitual residence in Syria
- The applicants were detained at a detention centre for foreign nationals in the town of Maloyaroslavets, Kaluga Region (ОСУСВИГ – “the detention centre”), run by the local Federal Migration Service (“FMS”)
- The applicants were found guilty of administrative offences (breach of immigration rules and working without a permit) and ordered to pay fines of between 2,000 and 3,000 Russian roubles (RUB) and their expulsion to Syria
- The applicants all stated in court that they feared for their lives if returned to Syria and referred to information about the ongoing and widespread conflict there
- The Kaluga Regional Court rejected all three appeals on 27 May 2014, following which the expulsion orders entered into force
- A.A. escaped from the detention center on 25 August 2014 and their whereabouts remain unknown
- The three applicants applied for refugee status and temporary asylum in Russia, which were either refused or terminated.

title: CASE OF NABID ABDULLAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is a Kyrgyz national of Uzbek ethnic origin, born in 1961
- In June 2010, he was the head of the territorial board of a municipal authority in a town where most residents were ethnic Uzbeks
- Criminal proceedings were opened against him in June 2011 for violent crimes committed during the interethnic clashes of 2010
- The applicant left Kyrgyzstan for Russia in March 2012 and was arrested there in March 2013
- The Kyrgyz authorities requested his extradition for prosecution and trial
- The applicant argued that his ethnic origin would expose him to a serious risk of torture
- The Russian courts rejected his appeal against extradition, finding no personal risk of torture, and ordered his detention pending extradition
- The applicant lodged a request for refugee status with Russia's FMS, which was rejected
- He was released on 7 March 2014 after the Court's indication under Rule 39.

title: CASE OF GAFGAZ MAMMADOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Baku.
- The opposition group Ictimai Palata planned a peaceful demonstration to be held on 19 June 2011.
- They informed BCEA of the date, time, place, and purpose of the demonstration.
- BCEA refused to authorize the holding of the demonstration at the place indicated by the organizers.
- The applicant attended the demonstration, but police started to disperse it.
- Gafgaz Suleyman oglu Mammadov was arrested at around 6.10 p.m. during the dispersal operation.
- An “administrative-offence report” was issued by police officer H.H. in respect of the applicant.
- The applicant refused to sign the report.
- The applicant was never served with a copy of the administrative-offence report.
- The applicant was not given access to a lawyer after the arrest or while he was kept in police custody.
- The applicant was brought before the Sabail District Court on 20 June 2011.
- He refused the assistance of a State‑funded lawyer and insisted on hiring a lawyer of his own choice, but the judge disregarded his request.
- The court convicted him under Article 310.1 of the CAO and sentenced him to five days’ “administrative” detention.
- The applicant lodged an appeal before the Baku Court of Appeal, arguing that his conviction was in violation of his rights.

title: CASE OF ABAKAROVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant was born in 1991 and lives in Zakan-Yurt, Chechnya.
- The facts of the case are connected to Isayeva v. Russia, no. 57950/00, 24 February 2005, and Abuyeva and Others v. Russia, no. 27065/05, 2 December 2010.
- Katyr-Yurt, Chechnya, was considered a “safe zone” since the start of operations by the Russian military and security forces in Chechnya in the autumn of 1999, with up to 25,000 persons living there, including local residents and internally displaced persons from elsewhere in Chechnya.
- On 4 February 2000, the village was captured by a large group of Chechen fighters escaping from Grozny. The Russian military forces carried out an assault, using indiscriminate weapons such as heavy, free-falling aviation bombs, artillery, missiles, and other weaponry. The residents of the village were provided neither with sufficient time to prepare to leave nor with safe exit routes to escape the fighting.
- The applicant’s family travelled to Katyr-Yurt, where they were staying with an unknown family when airstrikes started on 4 February 2000. They went into a cellar while the shelling of the village continued. Later in the afternoon, the applicant’s father decided it was too dangerous to stay in Katyr-Yurt and that they would drive to Achkhoy-Martan. 
- When they were on the road, the applicant lost her conscious awareness of what was happening and found herself lying in the road. Their car was burning. She saw her sister, brother, and cousin. They were all alive but wounded and burned. The applicant could not see her parents. Her whole family died in the attack.
- In September 2000, the prosecutor’s office initiated an investigation into the events of 2-7 February 2000 in Katyr-Yurt in response to a complaint by the applicant in the Isayeva case. The investigation was closed, and the case was reopened in 2007 under the number 44/00/0026-05. 
- In June 2007, the investigation was closed again, and the decision confirmed the deaths of 46 and the wounding of 53 local residents. The applicant's name was not listed among the 95 individuals who had been granted victim status. 
- The applicant suffered from

title: CASE OF BELOZOROV v. RUSSIA AND UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in the town of Feodosiya, the Autonomous Republic of Crimea.
- On 19 September 2000, the Prosecutor’s office opened a criminal investigation into the murder of a businessman.
- By a decision of 30 October 2000, the Prosecutor’s office ordered the applicant to appear as a witness in this case.
- On 1 and 2 November 2000, the Prosecutor’s office ordered the applicant’s apartment in Feodosiya to be searched and dispatched a team of police officers from the Department of Criminal Investigations of the Moscow City Department of the Interior to Ukraine.
- On 3 November 2000, police officer Kov. and the two Russian police officers, Ti. and Go., located and arrested the applicant, and his apartment was searched.
- On arrival, the applicant was formally arrested by the same two officers and detained on suspicion of murder.

title: CASE OF MITKOVA v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant is suffering from multiple sclerosis.
- The Ministry of Health issued a certificate allowing a transfer of funds for medical treatment abroad based on a medical report from the Skopje Neurology Clinic.
- The applicant underwent medical treatment in the United States.
- The Skopje Neurology Clinic issued a report stating that it was impossible to treat the disease in the State due to the critical state of the applicant’s health.
- The applicant requested ex post facto referral for treatment abroad, which was initially dismissed and later partially granted after administrative and judicial proceedings.

title: CASE OF URBÁN v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1940 and is a resident of Zsámbék.
- On 10 October 2006, the applicant filed a medical negligence compensation claim against a hospital.
- The Pest Central District Court rejected the claim.
- On 29 November 2011, the Budapest Regional Court upheld the district court's decision.
- The applicant appealed to the Kúria.
- The Kúria upheld the decision on 13 March 2013.
- The judgment was served to the applicant on 30 May 2013.

title: CASE OF ISTVÁN NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1945 and lives in Novaj.
- The applicant brought an official liability action on 12 May 2003 in relation to a former administrative procedure concerning a land dispute.
- The first instance court dismissed the claim on 13 September 2007.
- The second-instance court found for the applicant and pronounced the liability of the administrative authority on 31 January 2008.
- The first-instance court delivered a judgment on 23 December 2009 concerning the amount of damages.
- On appeal, the Budapest Court of Appeal upheld this decision on 3 June 2010.

title: CASE OF DUBOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1968.
- Applicant convicted of murdering his girlfriend by the Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic.
- Sentenced to 13 years' imprisonment in a high-security facility.
- Conviction upheld on appeal by the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation.
- Applicant is serving his sentence in the IK-11 facility, Nizhniy Novgorod Region, since 31 January 2011.
- The sleeping area in IK-11 was severely overcrowded.
- Each prisoner had less than two square meters of personal space.
- The Government submitted infringement reports showing severe overcrowding in IK-11 until 2013.

title: CASE OF PEÁGICS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is from Budapest and was born in 1942.

- On 26 November 2002, the applicant filed a claim for a divorce and the dissolution of marital property.

- On 12 October 2004, the divorce was granted, but the remaining claims were not resolved.

- On 15 April 2013, the Buda Central District Court made its decision on the remaining claims.

- On 21 April 2014, the Budapest Regional Court upheld the Buda Central District Court's decision on appeal.

title: CASE OF PINTÉR v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant's birth year of 1954 and residence in Csengőd.
- Action brought about the inheritance by the applicant's father's second wife on 13 February 2004.
- First instance court's partial finding for the applicant on 21 December 2007.
- Szeged Court of Appeal quashing the first-instance decision and remitting the case.
- Second-instance court quashing the decision again on 22 February 2010, confirmed by the Supreme Court on 8 December 2010.
- Bács-Kiskun County Regional Court's partial finding for the applicant on 27 May 2010.
- The judgment becoming final on 4 September 2010.

title: CASE OF ISTOMIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and is detained in Mozzhukha, Kemerovo Region.
- On 15 July 2009, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of large-scale embezzlement.
- On 16 July 2009, the applicant was formally charged with the crime.
- On 17 July 2009, the Tsentralnyy District Court of Kemerovo remanded the applicant in custody pending investigation.
- The judge found that the applicant was suspected of a serious crime, his involvement in embezzlement was confirmed by the evidential material in the case file, he might put pressure on witnesses or he might interfere with investigation.
- On 10 November 2009, the Zavodskoy District Court of Kemerovo extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- The court referred to the gravity of the charges, reiterated that the applicant might threaten witnesses or interfere with investigation, and observed that the applicant might re‑offend or abscond.
- On 26 November 2009, the Kemerovo Regional Court upheld the detention order of 10 November 2009 on appeal.
- The applicant remained in custody pending investigation and trial until his release on 24 June 2010.
- On 5 November 2013, the applicant was found guilty of the charge.

title: CASE OF CSÁK v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is from Budapest and was born in 1948.
- The applicant was interrogated on 14 March 1997 as a suspect of breach of duty and other offenses.
- The applicant was acquitted on 5 November 2008 after criminal proceedings and a remittal.
- The acquittal was upheld on appeal on 26 November 2009.
- The applicant's petition for review was rejected by the Supreme Court on 13 December 2010.

title: CASE OF KURUSHIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and is detained in Smolensk.
- Between 25 July and 1 August 2005, the applicant was held in IZ-76/1 remand prison in Yaroslavl in connection with the criminal proceedings against him.
- The applicant's cell was equipped with four sleeping places and accommodated up to seven inmates.
- The applicant was allowed to take a one-hour daily walk in a recreation yard measuring eight square meters.
- After his conviction had become final, the applicant served his sentence in the IK-5 facility, a correctional colony located in the Smolensk Region.
- Between 9 and 20 January 2007, the applicant was held in disciplinary cell no. 4.
- The cell he was held in measured twelve square meters and offered six sleeping places but actually accommodated up to thirteen inmates.
- During his detention in this cell, the applicant was taken, together with twenty-five other inmates, for a one-hour daily walk to an outside recreation area.
- According to the documents provided by the Government, disciplinary cell no. 4 measured 15.4 square meters, contained eight sleeping places but accommodated only six inmates.
- The outside yard provided 4.8 square meters for each inmate.

title: CASE OF PATYI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant lodged a claim for violation of his personality rights against several respondents on 15 August 2005.
- The Budapest Regional Court partly found for the applicant.
- On appeal, the Budapest Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision.
- The applicant lodged a petition for review.
- The Kúria upheld the previous decisions on 24 October 2012.

title: CASE OF VASILIAUSKAS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born on 21 October 1930 and lived in Tauragė.
- The Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact was signed between USSR and Germany, attributing Lithuania and other Baltic States to USSR’s sphere of interest.
- The Soviet army invaded Lithuania on 15 June 1940 and removed the government and formed the country under the direction of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
- A partisan movement began in Lithuania in 1944, with the goal of liberation and re-establishment of independent Lithuania.
- The applicant studied at LSSR MGB School in Vilnius from 1950 to 1952 and worked as an operational agent for the MGB from 1952 to 1953 and for the KGB from 1953 to 1964.
- The applicant participated in the operation to capture or liquidate two Lithuanian partisans in the Šakiai area in 1953 and personally eliminated one of them.
- The head of the Šakiai district MGB reported to the head of the Kaunas region MGB that the applicant had contributed to the success of the operation during which “two bandits had been liquidated”.
- The applicant and M.Ž. were charged with genocide in 2001 for participating “in the physical extermination (killing) of inhabitants of Lithuania who belonged to a separate political group”.
- The Kaunas Regional Court found the applicant guilty of genocide and sentenced him to six years’ imprisonment. The applicant appealed against his conviction. 
- The Court of Appeal upheld the conviction and sentence of the applicant for genocide.

title: CASE OF DVORSKI v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lives in Rijeka.
- On 13 March 2007, three murders, an armed robbery, and an arson attack were committed in Vežica, a residential neighbourhood of Rijeka.
- On the same day, a number of people from Vežica were brought in for questioning at the Rijeka Third Police Station of the Primorsko-Goranska Police Department (Policijska uprava Primorsko-goranska, Treća policijska postaja Rijeka – “Rijeka Police Station”).
- The applicant was brought to Rijeka Police Station for questioning, blood samples were taken from him for DNA analysis, and the police searched his flat and seized a number of his personal items.
- Later the applicant was formally arrested in connection with the above-mentioned offenses.
- The applicant’s mother contacted a lawyer, G.M., to represent her son, but the police officers refused to let him see the applicant.
- The applicant was never informed by the police that G.M. had been instructed to represent him and had come to Rijeka Police Station.
- At around 1.30 p.m. the applicant’s father signed a power of attorney in favor of G.M. to defend his son. A legal trainee, B.P., then tried to submit the power of attorney to the police but was told to leave.
- Upon investigation, the applicant had confessed to the charges against him and had been questioned in the presence of a lawyer chosen by the police, which the applicant disputed. 
- An investigation was opened in respect of the applicant, L.O. and R.Lj. on suspicion of having committed the three aggravated murders and arson in Vežica on 13 March 2007.

title: CASE OF SIMEONOVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and is currently serving a life sentence in Sofia Prison.
- On July 2, 1999, a bureau de change in Burgas was robbed and two staff members were killed by two armed individuals.
- The Burgas investigatory department instigated criminal proceedings against the applicant, Mr Lyuben Simeonov, on the same day for armed robbery and homicide.
- The applicant was arrested on October 3, 1999, in Sofia by a special unit of the Interior Ministry and transferred to Burgas.
- The applicant was placed in detention for 24 hours on October 4, 1999, suspected of having committed the armed robbery and the two murders of July 2, 1999, aided and abetted by a certain A.S.
- The applicant was not assisted by a lawyer for the first three days of his detention and was questioned about the robbery and the murders.
- On October 6, 1999, an official lawyer was appointed to defend the applicant, and he was formally charged with committing armed robbery and murder and placed in detention. He refused to answer the investigator’s questions.
- On October 21, 1999, assisted by his two lawyers, the applicant confessed to the criminal offences.
- On January 4, 2000, the applicant and A.S. retracted their confessions, and their lawyers requested a fresh interrogation of their clients.
- The Burgas regional prosecutor’s office drew up the indictment on May 17, 2000, and committed the applicant and his accomplice for trial before the Burgas regional court.
- The court found the applicant guilty of armed robbery and murder and imposed the heaviest sentence available under the Bulgarian Criminal Code, a whole-life sentence, which was upheld by the appeal court.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law on December 17, 2003.
- The applicant was held in deplorable conditions in Burgas Provisional Detention Facility, which was later renovated and redeveloped between 2002 and 2009 to bring the conditions of detention into line with the detainees’ human dignity.

title: CASE OF AFET SÜREYYA EREN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was taken into custody in 1999 on suspicion of membership in an illegal organization.
- The applicant alleges that she was tortured by police officers for four days.
- A forensic doctor's report noted that the applicant had been hung by her arms and had her head banged against a wall.
- The applicant denied all accusations and complained of ill-treatment before both the Istanbul public prosecutor and the Istanbul State Security Court.
- The applicant filed a complaint against the police officers of the Security Branch accusing them of torture.
- The investigation was reopened, and two police officers were charged with inflicting ill-treatment on the applicant.
- The court held that the acts of ill-treatment or torture had to be inflicted with the intention to extract information to fall under Article 243 of the former Criminal Code and did not apply in this case.
- The court discontinued the proceedings against the accused police officers due to the prosecution period being time-barred.

title: CASE OF BALÁZS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant and his girlfriend were insulted by three men in a club because of their Roma origin.
- A fourth person, presenting himself as a police officer, got into a fight with the applicant after being questioned about his attitude using offensive and vulgar language.
- The applicant suffered bruises on his chest, back, neck and face, while the police officer had bruises on his temple and a haematoma around his right eye.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint against the police officer, who posted on social media that he had been "kicking in the head a gypsy lying on the ground."
- The Public Prosecutor’s Office opened a criminal investigation against the police officer for the offence of “violence against a member of a group” within the meaning of section 170 (1) of the Criminal Code.
- The investigation was discontinued, considering that there was no evidence substantiating that the police officer had attacked the applicant out of racial hatred.
- The Csongrád County Regional Public Prosecutor’s Office upheld the decision of discontinuation, stating that while it was likely that the action had racist motives, it could not be proven unequivocally and beyond any doubt that the police officer ill-treated the applicant precisely because of his Roma origin.
- The police officer was convicted of disorderly conduct and placed on one-year probation.

title: CASE OF DİLEK ASLAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant and her friends were distributing leaflets in Kars.
- A man attempted to seize the leaflets without showing his identity documents and held two of the applicant's friends around their necks.
- Around thirty police officers arrived and arrested the applicant and her friends using force and hitting the applicant on various parts of her body before putting her in a police vehicle.
- In the police vehicle, a police officer sat on her head and continued to hit her, while other police officers touched various parts of her body and made sexually suggestive comments.
- The applicant was taken to hospital and had skin erosions, red patches (erythema) and sensitive areas on her head, face, shoulders, lower back, abdomen, and wrist.
- The applicant was taken to a police station where she was threatened with rape and her requests for information about the reasons for her arrest and for a lawyer were refused.
- The applicant's release was secured by a lawyer who arrived at the police station the same afternoon.
- The police documented that members of TAYAD were distributing leaflets and that the applicant and her friends had resisted arrest and injured a police officer.
- The applicant and her friends denied resisting arrest and hurting the police officer.
- The Kars Criminal Court convicted the applicant of obstructing the police officers in the execution of their duties and insulting them and sentenced her to eleven months and twenty days’ imprisonment, which was suspended for a period of five years.
- The Kars public prosecutor decided that no proceedings should be brought against the police officers accused of abuse of office, and the applicant's objection against the decision was dismissed by the Ardahan Assize Court.

title: CASE OF SAGHATELYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant worked as a judge at Gegharkunik Regional Court.
- The Minister of Justice filed a motion with the Council of Justice seeking to have the applicant dismissed from her post under Section 30 (8) of the Law on the Status of a Judge.
- The Council of Justice formed a commission to examine the factual basis of the motion and to report back to the Council.
- The Council of Justice recommended to the President of Armenia that the applicant be dismissed.
- The President of Armenia issued a decree dismissing the applicant from her post.
- The applicant lodged a claim seeking to annul the President’s Decree of 30 April 2004 as unlawful, arguing that her dismissal from work had been in violation of a number of provisions of domestic law and various European instruments relating to the status of a judge.
- The Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan decided under Article 109 of the Code of Civil Procedure to terminate the proceedings on the ground that the applicant’s claim was not subject to examination by the courts of general jurisdiction.
- The Civil Court of Appeal examined and dismissed the applicant’s claim as unsubstantiated.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment of the Court of Appeal and decided to terminate the proceedings on the same grounds as the District Court.
- In proceedings unrelated to this case, the Constitutional Court found the second paragraph of Article 160 § 1 of the CCP to be unconstitutional.

title: CASE OF MULINI v. BULGARIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the case facts:

- The applicants are the parents of Angel Georgiev, who died aged 23 on 26 December 1993.
- Angel Georgiev was stabbed in the back and left to die.
- The criminal proceedings related to Angel Georgiev's death lasted for several years, involving multiple investigations, interviews, and court hearings.
- Two suspects, K.S. and O.V., were charged with murder, but K.S. was eventually acquitted, and O.V. was acquitted after multiple trials and appeals.
- The national courts found it difficult to establish who had committed the murder, as there were no eyewitnesses and the murder weapon was never found.
- There were several plausible versions of the facts preceding Angel Georgiev's death.
- The applicants joined the proceedings as private prosecutors and civil claimants.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation upheld the lower court's judgment in a final judgment in 2007, endorsing its reasoning that there was no conclusive evidence that O.V. had committed the offence.

title: CASE OF MILENKOVIĆ AND VELJKOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The applicants were born in 1957 and 1966 and worked for a socially-owned company based in Vladičin Han.
- The Vladičin Han Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicants specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, with orders for enforcement and payment of enforcement costs.
- The Privatisation Agency ordered the restructuring of the debtor on 18 February 2004.
- The Leskovac Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor on 30 January 2014.
- The applicants reported their claims to the insolvency administration and the proceedings are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF ŠERIFOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1961, 1960 and 1949 and live in Novi Pazar.
- They worked for DP “Raška Holding Kompanija” AD, a socially-owned company based in Novi Pazar.
- The Novi Pazar Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the first applicant specified amounts in 2003, 2004, and 2005 on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings.
- Similar orders were given for the second applicant by the Tutin Municipal Court in 2007 and 2012, and for the third applicant by the Novi Pazar Municipal Court in 2008.
- The Privatisation Agency ordered the restructuring of the debtor on 5 January 2004.
- The Kraljevo Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor on 11 September 2013.
- The applicants duly reported their respective claims based on the above-mentioned judgments to the insolvency administration, and the proceedings are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF DRAGI PETROVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Vladičin Han.
- The applicant was employed by “DPPK Delišes”, a socially-owned company based in Vladičin Han (“the debtor”).
- The Vladičin Han Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant specified sums in respect of salary arrears, social security contributions and procedural costs on 7 October 2003, 28 January 2004 and 21 September 2004.
- These judgments became final on 6 November 2003, 15 March 2004 and 26 October 2004, respectively.
- The Vladičin Han Municipal Court issued enforcement orders with regard to the said judgments on 12 August 2011, 2 September 2011 and 17 August 2011, respectively.
- The Vranje Court of First Instance found that the debtor had no assets against which the enforcement could be carried out and requested the applicant to propose a new inventory of the debtor’s assets within 45 days for the judgments of 28 January 2004 and 21 September 2004.
- The applicant did not propose a new inventory of debtor’s assets, and the enforcement proceedings were stayed for the judgments of 28 January 2004 and 21 September 2004 by the decision of the Vranje Court of First Instance on 10 May 2013.
- The enforcement proceedings initiated based on the judgment rendered by the Vladičin Han Municipal Court on 7 October 2003 continued and are still pending.

title: CASE OF RAKIĆ AND SARVAN v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1976 and 1948 respectively and live in Požega.
- They were employed by Raketa-Putnički Saobraćaj AD, a socially-owned company based in Užice.
- The Požega Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the first applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings on 26 June 2006. This judgment became final on 7 July 2006.
- On 15 August 2006, the Požega Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the above judgment and further ordered the debtor to pay the first applicant the enforcement costs upon the applicant's request.
- The Požega Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the first applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings on 22 September 2006, which became final on 8 October 2006. On 19 October 2006, the Požega Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the said judgment and further ordered the debtor to pay the first applicant the enforcement costs upon the applicant's request.
- On 22 January 2008, the Požega Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the first applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings, which became final by 2009. On 24 September 2009, the Požega Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the above judgment and further ordered the debtor to pay the first applicant the enforcement costs upon the applicant's request.
- The Požega Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the second applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings on 19 June 2006. This judgment became final on 5 July 2006. On 21 August 2006, the Požega Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the said judgment and further ordered the debtor to pay the second applicant the enforcement costs upon the applicant's request.
- The Požega Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the second applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings on 21 September 2006. This judgment became final on 6 October 2006. On 17 October 2006, the Požega Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the said judgment and further ordered the

title: CASE OF KHALIKOVA v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is an Azerbaijani national of Tatar origin who was born in 1964 and lives in Baku.
- She owned a flat in a building classified as an architectural monument.
- The Baku City Executive Authority issued an order to demolish buildings in the area behind Heydar Aliyev Palace and construct a park complex. A natural person, named Rufan Kazimov, was asked to negotiate with the residents and provide compensation for relocation.
- The BCEA began to construct fences around the building in which the applicant resided, verbally instructing residents to leave their homes in exchange for compensation of 1,500 Azerbaijani manats (AZN) per sq. m of their property.
- The applicant refused to leave her flat, and on November 19, 2010, her building was surrounded by BCEA employees and police officers who unlawfully evicted her, detained her at a police station, and destroyed her property.

title: CASE OF TURGUNOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 in Osh, Kyrgyzstan and is an ethnic Uzbek.
- In June 2010, there was an outbreak of ethnic violence in Osh, resulting in approximately 400 deaths.
- The applicant arrived in Russia on 15 July 2010 and has since not returned to Kyrgyzstan.
- On 9 April 2012, the Osh Police charged the applicant with several offenses, including participation in mass riots.
- The Osh Town Court issued an arrest warrant for the applicant on 10 April 2012 and placed his name on the cross-border wanted list on 20 April 2012.
- The applicant was arrested in St Petersburg on 23 January 2013 and has been held in custody since then, with extensions.
- The Kyrgyzstan Prosecutor General's Office requested the applicant's extradition on 11 February 2013, based on allegations of several crimes.
- The applicant's lawyer submitted a letter objecting to extradition, citing concerns of inhumane treatment & requesting reference to international organizations reports.
- On 24 July 2013, a deputy Prosecutor General of the Russian Federation granted the request for the applicant's extradition.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that he belonged to an ethnic Uzbek community that faced persecution, and he would be at risk of torture and inhumane treatment.
- On 25 February 2014, the Supreme Court of Russia rejected the applicant's appeal and endorsed the lower court's reasoning regarding extradition.
- The applicant had requested refugee status in Russia, but the St Petersburg Regional Office of the Federal Migration Service refused his request on 29 May 2013. 
- The Basmanniy District Court and Moscow City Court both rejected the applicant's complaints.
- The applicant had also asked for temporary asylum in Russia, which was dismissed, and filed an appeal against the decision. The outcome remains unknown.

title: CASE OF LYUBUSHKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant, a police officer, was arrested on suspicion of extortion on 6 October 2004.
- On 8 October 2004, he was remanded in custody by the Khabarovsk Zheleznodorozhniy District Court.
- The Khabarovsk Regional Court upheld the decision of 8 October 2004 on appeal on 21 October 2004.
- The applicant's pre-trial detention was repeatedly extended until 7 December 2006.
- On 26 October 2006, the jury delivered a not-guilty verdict, and the applicant was ordered to be immediately released.
- The Regional Court granted the applicant's claims for compensation for pecuniary damage in part on 9 April 2008.
- On 8 October 2014, the Khabarovsk Tsentralniy District Court granted the applicant's claims for compensation for non-pecuniary damage in part, awarding him RUB 500,000.

title: CASE OF ANNAGI HAJIBEYLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was nominated to stand as a candidate in the parliamentary elections of 7 November 2010 and applied for registration as a candidate in the single‑mandate Saatli Electoral Constituency No. 62.
- The applicant submitted to the Constituency Electoral Commission ("the ConEC") fourteen signature sheets containing 675 voter signatures collected in support of his candidacy.
- The ConEC refused the applicant's request for registration as a candidate on the grounds that a number of submitted supporting signatures were invalid, and that the remaining valid signatures numbered fewer than 450.
- The CEC dismissed the applicant's complaint and upheld the ConEC decision of 11 October 2010.
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal, and the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal as unsubstantiated.

title: CASE OF S.M. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was promised employment as a personal assistant by an official of the Derbent town administration.
- The applicant was forced to have sexual intercourse with the official on several occasions between 10 and 17 July 2009.
- On 17 July 2009, the official and another man raped the applicant in his office.
- The official threatened to harm the applicant’s family if she complained to anyone.
- The investigator initially rejected the request to open an investigation into the rape.
- The investigation into the alleged rape was repeatedly refused until 17 June 2014.
- The applicant was charged with bringing false charges against the official.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant were terminated due to lack of evidence.

title: CASE OF LUNEV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and was placed under house arrest in Bryanka, Ukraine in June 2013.
- In January 2012, he was arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking and placed in Starobilsk Pre-Trial Detention Centre (SIZO).
- The applicant was diagnosed with several medical conditions, including HIV, chronic bronchitis, toxic encephalopathy, neuropathy caused by prolonged drug use, and tuberculosis residual changes.
- Between January 2012 and January 2013, the applicant did not ask for any medical assistance in the SIZO.
- The applicant was found unconscious in his cell on 9 January 2013 and needed urgent medical treatment.
- The applicant was diagnosed with acute serose meningoencephalitis and was treated at a hospital from 9 to 11 January 2013.
- The applicant was sentenced to six and a half years’ imprisonment on 19 February 2013.
- The applicant was diagnosed with HIV (clinical stage 3), chronic bronchitis, residual effects of tuberculosis, and toxic encephalopathy while in detention.
- The applicant was released on 19 June 2013 and placed under house arrest.
- In January 2013, the applicant was allegedly beaten by two policemen in the ITT, later causing abdominal trauma, but the investigation was inconclusive.

title: CASE OF SAVINOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1970 and moved to the town of Illichivsk, Ukraine, in June 2013.
• The applicant was conditionally sentenced to two years of imprisonment in August 2006 for drug-related offenses and then sentenced to one year in prison for stealing in May 2007.
• In June 2008, the applicant was convicted of inflicting grievous bodily harm and sentenced to eight and a half years of imprisonment.
• The applicant was diagnosed with HIV as early as 1996 and spent time in an infectious diseases hospital in September 2003 while at liberty.
• The applicant was placed in the Illichivskyy Pre-trial Detention Facility in December 2006.
• The applicant was detained in Izmayilskyy Temporary Detention Centre between 15 January 2007 and 25 December 2008 and between 10 March and 4 May 2009.
• While in detention, the applicant underwent numerous medical examinations and treatments but was diagnosed with HIV at clinical stage 4 with tuberculosis of the lymphatic glands and oropharyngeal candidiasis in August 2012.
• The applicant was transferred to the infectious diseases department of the Dariyivska Correctional Colony Hospital in September 2012.
• An NGO provided the medication needed for the applicant's antiretroviral treatment that lasted until February 2013.
• The Head of the Golaprystanska Correctional Colony lodged two requests under Article 84 of the Criminal Code for the applicant's release in February 2013.
• The Golaprystanskyy District Court refused both requests on the grounds of the applicant's criminal behaviors and danger to society.
• On 20 June 2013, the Kherson Regional Court of Appeal released the applicant due to reasons of his severe health conditions.
• The applicant was finally released on 26 June 2013.

title: CASE OF SOKIL v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and has a history of drug use since 1996.
- While in detention, he was diagnosed with hepatitis C and hepatic cirrhosis, HIV-positive, and tuberculosis.
- The applicant was sentenced in 2010 to five years in prison for drug-related offences and theft, but was released early due to his poor state of health.
- After being sentenced to four years in prison in 2012, the applicant was diagnosed with post-tuberculosis residual changes and received medical care.
- The applicant requested an appropriate medical examination and treatment, but his request was refused.
- In 2013, the applicant was transferred to a specialized tuberculosis hospital where he received numerous tests and treatments and was diagnosed with other diseases.
- The applicant's CD4+ cell count dropped from 762 (18.4%) to 467 (14.3%) between April and December 2012.
- The applicant was discharged with a diagnosis of post-tuberculosis residual changes, HIV (clinical stage 4), chronic hepatitis in unstable remission, and chronic thrombophlebitis after his health improved.
- The applicant's CD4+ cell count was 314 (14.8%) in December 2013.
- In January 2014, the applicant was released from detention having served his sentence.

title: CASE OF SERGEY ANTONOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant arrived at Buchanska Correctional Colony No. 85 in September 2013 to serve a sentence and has not informed the court of his current whereabouts.
- The applicant has been suffering from various health problems, including HIV, tuberculosis, oropharyngeal candidiasis, and chronic hepatitis type C since at least 2009.
- Upon arrival at the SIZO, the applicant underwent an initial medical examination and was registered with the Kyiv City Aids Prevention and Control Centre.
- The applicant was diagnosed with HIV at clinical stage 4, post-tuberculosis residual changes, oropharyngeal candidiasis, and chronic viral hepatitis type C in November 2012.
- The applicant was prescribed antiretroviral therapy (ART) in February 2013 but refused to take the medicine on some occasions in March and April, claiming that the drugs did not agree with him.
- The applicant was diagnosed with tuberculosis relapse, extra-pulmonary tuberculosis, HIV infection at clinical stage 4, chronic hepatitis of the mixed type, and other diseases in February 2013.
- The applicant's condition was stable between June and July 2013, with a positive dynamic while undergoing treatment.
- In October 2013, the applicant was transferred to Buchanska Correctional Colony No. 85 to serve a sentence and was diagnosed with HIV infection, hepatitis in the stage of remission, and post-tuberculosis residual changes (category 5.1).
- The applicant claimed to have been subjected to psychological pressure by the SIZO authorities and their medical staff to sign a paper stating that he refused ART treatment and had no complaints. The prosecutor's office and the Kyiv Department of the State Prison Service found no evidence of any wrongdoing. Inmates B. and F. testified that the applicant was provided with medical assistance when he requested it.

title: CASE OF MARIN TEODORESCU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A table with the list of applicants and relevant application details is appended to the document.
- The applicants expressed their dissatisfaction with the lengthy civil proceedings.
- Some of the applicants also made complaints about other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ROŞIU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The document contains a table with a list of applicants and their relevant application details.
- The applicants made complaints about inadequate conditions of detention.
- Some of the applications had additional complaints related to other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF IULIAN MOCANU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A table is appended to the document, listing the applicants and application details.
- The applicants complained about the long duration of criminal proceedings.
- Some of the applicants also have complaints about other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF GUDZ v. UKRAINE
facts:
• The applicant's mother was found with grave bodily injuries on 29 June 2010, and she succumbed to those injuries on 1 July 2010.
• The police instituted a criminal investigation into her death on 7 November 2010.
• On 16 November 2010, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of having beaten his mother which resulted in her death.
• On 19 November 2010, the Sokal Court extended the applicant’s detention until 26 November 2010.
• On 26 November 2010, the Sokal Court ordered the applicant’s detention on remand until 26 January 2011.
• On 24 December 2010, the Sokal Court rejected the applicant's request for release and ordered him to remain in detention.
• On 17 March and 10 July 2011, the applicant lodged two more requests for release which were rejected by the Sokal Court.
• On 30 January 2012, the Sokal Court granted the applicant’s request for release, and he was released on the same day.
• As of 26 March 2014, the criminal case against the applicant remained pending before the Sokal Court.

title: CASE OF CURELARIU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Two applications were made
- The details of the applications can be found in a table
- Both applications were made due to inadequate conditions of detention

title: CASE OF R.E. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1989 and lives in Newtownabbey, Northern Ireland
- Solicitors in Northern Ireland became aware that their private consultations with detainees in police stations and prisons could be the subject of covert surveillance due to a previous criminal case
- There were judicial review proceedings initiated due to a breach of the common law right to legal and professional privilege, the statutory right to a private consultation with a lawyer, and Articles 6 and 8 of the Convention
- The Divisional Court of the High Court of Justice in Northern Ireland found that the covert surveillance of lawyer-client consultations was permitted by the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 (“RIPA”) but required an enhanced authorisation scheme
- The House of Lords agreed with the Divisional Court and criticized the Secretary of State for not taking action to ensure that covert surveillance of legal consultations was not treated as directed surveillance
- Following the House of Lords decision, the Regulation of Investigatory Powers (Extension of Authorisation Provisions: Legal Consultations) Order 2010 and a revised Covert Surveillance Code of Practice (“the Revised Code”) came into effect which required directed surveillance of consultations between a detainee and his or her professional legal adviser, representative or medical practitioner to be treated as intrusive surveillance
- The applicant was arrested in connection with the murder of a Police Constable and interviewed by police officers in the absence of a solicitor or an appropriate adult during which he gave information which led to the recovery of the gun used in the murder
- The applicant's solicitor obtained an assurance from the police that his consultations with the applicant would not be subject to covert surveillance during his detention
- The PSNI refused to give an assurance that the applicant's consultations would not be subjected to covert surveillance during a later arrest which led to a judicial review application
- The Divisional Court of the High Court of Justice in Northern Ireland dismissed the applicant's claim, finding that the surveillance operation could only be justified if it was truly proportionate and necessary, and the Revised Code was sufficiently clear
- The Divisional Court certified four questions of law of general public importance but leave to appeal to the Supreme Court was refused, ending the case

title: CASE OF BRÂNDUŞE v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Şomoşcheş, Arad County.
- The applicant was serving a prison sentence for fraud, imposed by two decisions of the Timişoara Court of Appeal.
- The applicant was held mainly in Arad and Timişoara Prisons. In 2008, he spent a few days in cell no. 309 of Jilava Prison.
- The applicant was exposed to passive smoking in the Arad County Court detention room on 15 December 2008.
- The applicant was held in cell no. 309 in Jilava Prison from 29 May to 1 June 2008 and from 16 to 18 June 2008.

title: CASE OF KONI v. CYPRUS
facts:
