- The applicant’s husband filed for divorce on the grounds that their marriage had irretrievably broken down due to five years of separation.
- The applicant requested additional time to file her defence to the petition in a directions hearing on 14 June 2006 and the hearing was adjourned to 4 October 2006.
- The applicant applied for legal aid on 14 June 2006, which was fixed for a hearing on 15 September 2006. The hearing was adjourned because the applicant asked for an extension; it was fixed for 19 October 2006.
- On 4 October 2006, the applicant requested a further extension for filing her defence to the petition on the grounds that her legal aid application was pending. The court granted the extension but directed the applicant to file her defence by 1 November 2006.
- Although the legal aid application was adjourned to 21 December 2006, the failed to file her defence or appear in court on 1 November 2006. The husband’s petition for divorce was granted ex tempore in court.
- The applicant’s legal aid application hearing was held on 21 December 2006, and the applicant was not present in court. The application was dismissed.
- The applicant appealed the Family Court’s decision on grounds that the court violated Article 30 of the Constitution, the Law on Legal Aid, and the rule of natural justice. She also cited the case-law of the Cypriot courts and Airey v. Ireland by the European Court of Human Rights on the corresponding provisions of Article 6 of the Convention.
- The hearing on the appeal took place on 6 March 2009, and the applicant’s written submissions were adopted.
- On 30 June 2009, the Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, stating that the appellant’s claim of a violation of the law and natural justice was vague and unsubstantiated. The court also pointed out that the judgment was due to the applicant’s indifference to respond to the court’s directions and her failure to appear before the court.

title: CASE OF A.L. (X.W.) v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant claims to be a Russian national, but the Government claims he is a Chinese national.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder of a Chinese policeman in 1996 while in possession of a false Russian passport.
- The Smolninskiy District Court ordered the applicant’s detention pending extradition to China, as he was identified as X.W., on Interpol’s list of wanted persons, and suspected of a crime under Article 232 of the Chinese Criminal Code.
- The Chinese authorities did not submit an official extradition request within the thirty-day time-limit established by the Bilateral Treaty on Extradition of 26 June 1995.
- The applicant was detained in a detention centre for aliens, held in punishment and solitary confinement cells, and suffered poor conditions, including being handcuffed, having no access to a toilet, being in damp and cold conditions, and not having access to reading or writing material.
- The applicant was served with a decision by the Interior Department declaring the undesirability of his presence in Russia and ordering him to leave, and challenged the decision before the Smolninskiy District Court, which found the decision lawful, well-reasoned and justified.

title: CASE OF HAJRULAHU v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and resides in Germany.
- On 15 July 2005, an anti-tank mine exploded in the courtyard of a police station in Skopje, causing considerable material damage.
- On 16 August 2005, a search of the home and other property belonging to the applicant’s father was ordered and the police found weapons and explosives.
- The applicant was arrested on 16 August 2005, for not possessing any identification document, and having suspicious movement in the vicinity of buildings which are targets for criminal offenses.
- On 16 August 2005, the applicant was brought before the investigating judge and confessed to being involved in the incident of 15 July 2005, and having stolen the weapon and the bullets.
- The investigating judge appointed a lawyer to represent the applicant, found of his own motion that the applicant’s detention had been lawful, and ordered that the applicant, F.R. and R.S. be detained on remand for thirty days.
- On 19 August 2005, the applicant asked to give evidence before the investigating judge and claimed that he was intimidated by the police to force him to testify.
- The investigating judge ordered an immediate expert examination of the applicant to determine the type, origin and date of the injuries.
- On 9 September 2005, the public prosecutor lodged an indictment against the applicant and F.R. on terrorism charges; and on 26 September 2005, an indictment on the same charges was lodged against R.S.

title: CASE OF CHMIL v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant, born in 1936, was the head of a territorial election commission and lived in the town of Ananyiv, Ukraine.
- On the day of the first round of presidential elections, the applicant met four police officers on his way to the territorial election commission headquarters. They had a verbal confrontation.
- The applicant claimed that the police officers physically assaulted him when they reached Ananyivskyy District Police Station.
- According to the Government, the applicant grabbed a police officer's uniform and the grille of the security door and started shouting that he was being beaten. He then talked to the head of the police station and left.
- The applicant phoned a prosecutor and complained about the events. He said police officers had pushed him into the corridor of the police station, knocked him to the ground, and started to kick him.
- Police officers K., L., P., and D. were involved in the incident. Police officer Sa. saw the applicant grab the door grille and shout as if somebody had been hitting him.
- Forensic medical expert B. examined the applicant and concluded that his account of being severely beaten by five police officers was doubtful as it contradicted the results of the physical examination.
- The Ananiyivskyy District Prosecutor's Office initially refused to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers due to a lack of evidence.
- The Odessa Regional Prosecutor's Office overturned that decision, and the Ananiyivskyy District Prosecutor's Office later instituted criminal proceedings against the police officers for abuse of power.

title: CASE OF USTIMENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant lodged an administrative claim seeking an increase in his pension.
- The District Court allowed the claim, and the defendant received a copy of the judgment.
- The defendant lodged an appeal after the time-limit for appeal had expired, and it was dismissed.
- The defendant complied with the judgment on 1 August 2011 and increased the applicant's pension.
- The defendant lodged a second appeal and then a third appeal requesting an extension of the time-limit for submission.
- A panel of the Court of Appeal extended the time-limit for appeal, and then the Court quashed the judgment of 1 December 2010 and rejected the applicant's claim.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the prosecutor's office alleging that Judge N. had intentionally failed to inform him about the appeal proceedings.
- The prosecutor's office made an entry to investigate the suspicion of offences.
- The prosecutor's office decided to discontinue the investigation, and the District Court and the Dnipropetrovsk Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision.

title: CASE OF BELJKAŠ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant's personal information: born in 1977 and lives in Kranj.
- The applicant was detained in the remand section of Ljubljana prison from 26 May 2010 to 6 November 2012.
- Cell no. 89 described: one day with four other inmates, with 3.33 square metres of personal space.
- Cell no. 82 described: 783 days, 382 days with four other inmates with 3.27 square metres of personal space, 100 days with five other inmates with 2.73 square metres of personal space, 301 days shared with two or three other inmates with more than 4 square metres of personal space.
- Cell no. 88 described: 111 days, 36 days with four other inmates with 3.07 square metres of personal space, 58 days with three other inmates with 3.84 square metres of personal space, 17 days shared with two other inmates with more than 4 square metres of personal space.
- Cells equipped for six detainees with bunk beds, tables, chairs, and cupboards.
- Detainees confined to cells day and night, with two hours of daily outdoor exercise, and an additional two hours per week in a recreation room.
- Cell temperature: average of approximately 27.5oC to 28.6oC in the late afternoon in July and August, with temperatures exceeding 30oC on multiple days.

title: CASE OF ARAPOVIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Ljubljana.
- He was detained in the remand section of Ljubljana prison from 1 June 2011 to 16 July 2012.
- He was held in cell no. 82 measuring 16.37 square metres.
- For 212 days he was held with four other inmates with 3.27 square metres of personal space.
- For 9 days he was held with five other inmates with 2.73 square metres of personal space.
- For 190 days he shared the cell with two or three other inmates with more than 4 square metres of personal space.
- The cell for six detainees, where the applicant was held, was equipped with three bunk beds with a total of six sleeping places, one large and one small table, six chairs and a set of cupboards for each of the detainees.
- On 14 November 2011 the sixth bed was removed.
- Detainees could freely open or close windows in cells.
- The general characteristics of the cells and sanitary conditions can be found in the Mandić and Jović v. Slovenia judgment.
- Detainees in the remand section were confined to their cells day and night, save for two hours of daily outdoor exercise, and an additional two hours per week in a recreation room.
- On 9 February 2011 the time spent outdoors was extended to two and a half hours per day and in November 2011 the outside yard was covered by a roof.
- The average temperature in the cells in the late afternoon in July and August 2011 had been approximately 27oC, exceeding 30oC on ten days.
- In the second half of June and the first half of July 2012, the temperature had been 30oC, exceeding 30oC on twelve days.

title: CASE OF IZMUTDIN ISAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in the Lipetsk Region.
- From 20 May 2008 to 17 July 2008 the applicant was held in the IZ‑44/1 remand prison in the Kostroma Region in connection with the criminal proceedings.
- The cells in which the applicant was held were overcrowded.
- The Government and the applicant have different views of the cells in which he was held.
- On 20 October 2008 the applicant sent his first letter to the Court.
- The Registry sent an application package to the applicant by letter of 14 November 2008.
- On 4 May 2009 the applicant dispatched the application form which reached the Registry on 10 August 2009.

title: CASE OF MISHURA AND GAYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1945 and lives in Barcelona.
- The first applicant filed an action against the Astrakhan Regional Military Commissariat to increase his pension and military-related benefits, which was dismissed by the Justice of the Peace of the 3rd Court Circuit of the Kirovskiy District of Astrakhan on April 2005.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Astrakhan granted the first applicant's action in part and awarded him a lump sum of 49,215 Russian roubles on June 2005.
- On February 2006, the Presidium of the Astrakhan Regional Court quashed the previous judgment of June 2005 and upheld the initial judgment of April 2005.
- The second applicant was born in 1939 and lived in Ozersk, Russia. She was the widow of Mr Lev Gayev who died of cancer in 1985.
- The Tsentralnyy District Court of Chelyabinsk acknowledged that Mr Gayev had been exposed to radioactive emissions following a nuclear accident at the Mayak power plant in 1957 on June 2005.
- The second applicant sued the Ozersk Social Security Office for monthly compensation in connection with the loss of her breadwinner in August 2006.
- The Ozersk Town Court of the Chelyabinsk Region rejected her claim on the ground of her failure to show financial dependence on her husband on the day of his death on October 2006.
- The Chelyabinsk Regional Court partly granted the second applicant's claim and held that the Ozersk Social Security Office should pay monthly compensation on December 2006.
- The Presidium of the Chelyabinsk Regional Court quashed the appeal judgment on December 2006 and remitted the matter to the appeal court on July 2007.
- The judgment of December 2006 was executed between March 2007 and August 2007.
- On August 2007, the Chelyabinsk Regional Court held a new appeal hearing and rejected the second applicant's claim.

title: CASE OF MYUMYUN v. BULGARIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in the village of Gorno Sahrane.
- On 20 February 2012, officers went to the applicant's house, in connection with a complaint about a burglary.
- The applicant was not home but was told to appear at the police station for inquiries.
- At the police station, the applicant was taken to a room where he was beaten by three officers.
- The beating caused injuries and bruises on the applicant's body and face.
- The applicant was forced to sign a statement that he knew nothing of the burglary.
- Criminal proceedings were opened against the officers who ill-treated the applicant.
- The prosecuting authorities decided to waive the officers' criminal liability and replace it with administrative penalties.
- The applicant requested that the officers be charged under different criminal provisions but his requests were denied.
- The officers were fined and not disqualified from working as police officers.
- The officers appealed against the judgment but their appeal was fully upheld.
- The applicant brought a claim for damages against the Stara Zagora Regional Police Directorate and was awarded non-pecuniary damages.
- The judgment has not yet become final.

title: CASE OF HADŽIMEJLIĆ AND OTHERS v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years and are currently in the Drin social care home.
- One of the applicants was deprived of legal capacity on 23 November 2006 due to paranoid schizophrenia.
- The same applicant was placed under guardianship on 26 December 2006 and placed in Drin on 23 January 2007.
- A constitutional appeal was lodged on 13 June 2011 concerning the lawfulness of the detention.
- On 25 April 2013, the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina found that the applicant had been held in psychiatric detention without a decision of the competent civil court and that there had been a breach of Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.
- The Visoko Social Work Centre asked the Kiseljak Municipal Court to examine the necessity of the applicant's placement in Drin on 3 June 2014.
- The same applicant has not yet been released from Drin.
- Another applicant was recommended by the Psychiatric Clinic in Sarajevo to be placed in Drin on 15 September 2004 due to schizophrenia.
- On 25 March 2005, the applicant was deprived of legal capacity.
- On 2 September 2011, a constitutional appeal was lodged concerning the lawfulness of the detention.
- On 25 June 2013, the Constitutional Court found that the applicant had been held in psychiatric detention without a decision of the competent civil court and there had been a breach of Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.
- The applicant received a monetary award on 25 September 2013.
- The same applicant had not been released from Drin.
- The Kiseljak Municipal Court concluded that the applicant's current state of health did not warrant continued confinement in Drin on 29 November 2013.
- The decision was upheld on 18 March 2014.
- On 6 May 2014, the Vareš Social Work Centre informed the Visoko Municipal Court that the applicant's continued placement in Drin was in his best interest for reasons of social protection.
- The same applicant had not been released from Drin.
- The last applicant was treated for schizophrenia in different intervals in 1997, 1998, and 1999 at the Psychiatric Clinic in Tuzla.
- On 2 March 2000, the applicant was placed under guardianship by his cousin and on 10 June 2010, by his sister.

title: CASE OF CHYŁA v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant has a history of criminal convictions and was wanted by law-enforcement authorities.
- An international search warrant was issued for the applicant on suspicion of committing several crimes.
- The applicant was arrested by Italian police and handed over to the Polish authorities.
- The Lublin District Court remanded the applicant in custody, citing the serious nature of the offences, the likelihood of a heavy prison sentence, and the risk of absconding or obstruction of proceedings.
- The applicant’s appeals against detention, extension of detention, and requests for release were unsuccessful.
- The Lublin District Court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to nine years’ imprisonment and a fine.
- The applicant’s pre-trial detention was repeatedly extended and classified as “dangerous detainee”.
- The applicant was subjected to full body strip-searches and had restricted visiting rights and limited access to activities.
- The dangerous detainee status was lifted on 25 November 2010.

title: CASE OF MIĶELSONS v. LATVIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was the chairman of a State-owned joint stock company.
- A criminal investigation was opened into suspected unlawful activity by the company's officials.
- The applicant's apartment was searched on 15 June 2010 at 7 a.m.
- The applicant was allowed to telephone his lawyer during the search.
- The applicant was arrested at 11.15 a.m. on suspicion of abuse of office with intent to obtain a material benefit and assisting money laundering.
- The applicant was interviewed on 15 June 2010.
- The investigating authorities performed thirty searches in total that day and arrested several individuals.
- A decision declaring the applicant a suspect and an application for his pre-trial detention were served on him on 17 June 2010.
- The applicant was denied access to the case file during the detention hearing.
- The investigating judge ordered the applicant's detention pending trial on 20 June 2010.
- The applicant's lawyer lodged an appeal against this decision on 21 June 2010.
- The appeal was dismissed by the Regional Court on 6 July 2010.
- The applicant was released on bail on 18 August 2010.
- The applicant's complaint regarding his arrest was dismissed on 11 October 2010.

title: CASE OF STANKIEWICZ AND OTHERS v. POLAND (No. 2)
facts:
- The first and second applicants are a journalist and editor-in-chief, respectively, of the daily newspaper Rzeczpospolita.
- The third applicant, Gremi Media sp. z o.o. (formerly Presspublica sp. z o.o.), is the publisher of Rzeczpospolita.
- In October 2004, the Polish government submitted a draft amendment to the Tax Act (Ordynacja Podatkowa) to the Sejm.
- One of the amendments proposed consisted of limiting what could be used as evidence in tax proceedings to material collected in criminal proceedings, but only once they had been concluded.
- On 14 and 15 September 2005, the first applicant wrote three articles describing the possible consequences of the amendment, the legislative process leading to its adoption, and the role of a former senior civil servant, who was a well-known expert on tax law and a member of the legislative committee.
- The first two articles stated that the amendment that was passed had been introduced by Ms D.S, during a subcommittee meeting.
- The third article disclosed the Deputy Minister of Finance’s outrage after Rzeczpospolita disclosed the story behind the change in the law that helped the petrol mafia.
- Ms D.S. lodged a claim for the protection of her personal rights against all three applicants seeking compensation.
- The Regional Court dismissed her claim.
- The Warsaw Court of Appeal allowed the appeal and action, ordering the applicants to publish an apology and pay PLN 20,000 to charity.
- The Supreme Court quashed the judgment and remitted the case to the appellate court.
- Final ruling ordered the applicants to publish an apology and pay PLN 20,000 to charity.

title: CASE OF OLSZEWSCY v. POLAND
facts:
1. The applicants’ son M.O. was apprehended by the border patrol and taken to the police station. 
2. M.O. was drunk but was not taken to the sobering-up centre and was released without being charged with any offence.
3. The applicants’ son disappeared after leaving the police station and was found dead 20 days later due to hypothermia.
4. There were inaccuracies and shortcomings in the post-mortem examination and expert opinions.
5. The investigation was discontinued twice due to insufficient evidence until it was resumed after the applicants' request.

title: CASE OF HODOROG v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Balatonszabadi.
- Act no. CXXXIV of 2012 on the Repression of Smoking of the Youth and on Tobacco Retail was enacted on 11 September 2012 and published on 24 September 2012. 
- Tobacco retail was to become a State monopoly according to the Act which will be exercised through a State-owned company, ND Nemzeti Dohánykereskedelmi Nonprofit Zrt, and retailers would be authorized through a concession tender.
- Those previously engaged in tobacco retail had no privileges in the tender as per the Act.
- The Act was amended on several occasions and the final version was enacted on 6 June 2013 with entry into force on 1 July 2013.
- Government Decree no. 181/2013. (VI.7.) which contained the detailed rules for the operation of the future concession-holders was published on 8 June 2013.
- The applicant, a tobacco retailer active in business since 2008, applied for a concession and paid the relevant application fee.
- The applicant was informed in a letter sent by ND Zrt on 10 July 2013 that she did not obtain a tobacco retail concession.
- The refusal was not subject to any legal remedy.
- No compensation is available for ex-tobacco-retailers who, by not being awarded a concession, lost part of their livelihood.
- The applicant pursued a constitutional complaint, but it could not provide any material redress.
- The applicant submitted that others in comparable situations were granted concessions which difference in treatment cannot be explained by any circumstance other than political adherence.

title: CASE OF NAGMETOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's son attended a public gathering where allegations of corruption against local public officials were raised.
- Officers of the special mobile unit fired warning shots and dispersed the gathering using firearms, including tear gas grenades.
- The applicant's son was wounded by a tear gas grenade and died of his wounds, while five other people were seriously wounded, and many others were arrested and injured.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated but producing ballistics reports was hindered due to the absence of adequate facilities, equipment, and appropriate material for testing.
- The investigation was suspended on several occasions before being resumed, but the evidence extracted from the victim's body was lost, and the perpetrator could not be identified.

title: CASE OF BUZURTANOVA AND ZARKHMATOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants: a sister and wife of the allegedly abducted person
- Person allegedly abducted: Mr. Akhmed Buzurtanov, a well-known martial arts trainer and sportsman
- Abduction allegedly occurred on the evening of December 6, 2012, in the vicinity of the Permanent checkpoint no. 105, also known as “Chermenskiy krug”
- Mr. Akhmed Buzurtanov's car was found damaged on December 7, 2012
- Applicants found Mr. Akhmed Buzurtanov’s training shoe, socks, and hat in a street in the neighborhood 
- The President of Ingushetia stated in a meeting held on 17 or 20 December 2012 that Mr. Akhmed Buzurtanov had been aiding a member of an illegal armed group and had been involved in illegal activities
- The applicants have had no news of Mr. Akhmed Buzurtanov since his alleged abduction
- Criminal case no. 21/1908 opened into the events under Article 105 of the Criminal Code (murder) on the same day 
- Forensic examination ordered on evidence collected from the car and the crime scene
- Applicants were granted victim status in the criminal case
- Requests made to obtain lists of calls from mobile phones and the detective work started to verify the theory that Mr. Akhmed Buzurtanov had been abducted by residents of Beslan after being attacked on 24 June 2012

title: CASE OF QING v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant in December 2010 on allegations of aiding illegal immigration, money laundering, and forgery.
- In April 2011, the applicant sent letters to the authorities to inform them that she knew she was being investigated and was available to present herself to judicial authorities to be questioned and considered as a defendant.
- An arrest warrant was issued against the applicant on June 9, 2011, as there was sufficient ground for believing that she might abscond, obstruct the investigation or continue the alleged criminal activity.
- The applicant was arrested on June 14, 2011, and was held in pre-trial detention for 19 months until January 2013, despite repeatedly requesting release or replacement of the remand with police supervision.
- The court ended up placing her under house arrest with electronic surveillance in January 2013 before finally releasing her altogether, but she was convicted of aiding illegal immigration in February 2013 and sentenced to five years in prison.

title: CASE OF YAGUBLU v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is Deputy Chairman of the Musavat Party and a columnist for the Yeni Musavat newspaper.
- Rioting broke out in Ismayilli on 23 January 2013 after an incident involving the son of the Minister for Labour and Social Protection and the nephew of the Head of the Ismayilli District Executive Authority.
- On 24 January 2013, the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the Prosecutor General’s Office blamed E.S. and E.M. for the rioting, accusing them of inciting people to riot.
- On 24 January 2013, the Yeni Musavat newspaper sent the applicant on a mission to Ismayilli to cover the events in question.
- The applicant was arrested approximately twenty minutes after arriving in Ismayilli and was sent back to Baku that same day.
- The applicant was questioned twice by investigators, but the Government failed to provide the Court with copies of the documents relating to these proceedings.
- On 4 February 2013, the applicant was charged with criminal offences under Articles 233 and 315.2 of the Criminal Code.
- On 4 February 2013, the Nasimi District Court ordered the applicant to be detained for a period of two months pending trial.
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the detention order.
- The applicant requested to be put under house arrest, but the Nasimi District Court dismissed the request.
- The applicant’s arrest and the institution of criminal proceedings against him attracted significant public and media interest both inside the country and internationally.

title: CASE OF CHUKAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Russian national who sold drugs to B. and O. on or around 22 December 2003.
- B. and O. sold a quantity of those drugs to a police officer taking part in an undercover operation on 1 March 2004.
- The Voronezh branch of the Federal Drug Control Service instituted criminal proceedings against B. and O. and they submitted that they had purchased drugs from the applicant, who lived in Astrakhan.
- The FSKN instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant, and a “test purchase” was carried out with the help of B. and two undercover police officers.
- During the covert operation, the police arrested the applicant, and he was searched. The search resulted in the discovery of a quantity of heroin and money.
- Investigator L. refused to provide him with a lawyer immediately after his arrest.
- The applicant was remanded in custody by the Kirovskiy District Court and his detention was extended on several subsequent occasions.
- The applicant was charged with drug offences on 11 June 2004 and testified, denying all the charges against him.
- The trial took place in the District Court between April and October 2005, and the applicant was represented by counsel. Witnesses testified in court for both sets of charges, and pre-trial statements of witnesses who could not attend the hearing were also read out in court.
- The applicant was convicted of drug trafficking and sentenced to 11 years and six months’ imprisonment with a fine after the trial.

title: CASE OF BASYUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant's daughter and granddaughter were hit by a car driven by Ms M. while crossing the road on 4 September 2005.
- Ms Ye. dies from the injuries sustained in the accident on 21 November 2005.
- Three additional witnesses identified by the applicant state that the collision had taken place at the pedestrian crossing.
- Ms M. and her father undertook to pay the applicant UAH 101,000 in respect of pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage caused by the traffic accident. In exchange, the applicant's family undertook not to seek initiation of criminal proceedings and not to lodge any claims or complaints against Ms M.
- On 24 March 2009 the regional prosecutor quashed the decision not to initiate criminal proceedings and opened a criminal case against Ms M. on suspicion of a breach of traffic rules causing the death of the applicant’s daughter.
- On 10 May 2012 the investigator terminated the proceedings for want of evidence of the driver’s guilt.
- On 6 June 2012 the regional prosecutor quashed the above decision and ordered additional investigation. As of 29 November 2013 the investigation was ongoing.

title: CASE OF ANTIMONOVA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants provided in an appended table.
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- Applicants claimed there was a lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF PAVLOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and details are provided in an appended table.
- Applicants claimed excessive length of civil proceedings.
- Applicants claimed lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Other complaints raised under other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SHARRA AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The Vlora Commission recognized the applicant's and other heirs' inherited title to a number of plots of land measuring 46,750 sq. m, of which 900 sq. m were restored to them.
- The Commission could not determine the boundaries of a plot of land measuring 13,750 sq. m and did not decide on the recognition of the applicant's inherited property rights.
- The Court delivered its judgment in the case of Eltari v. Albania, no. 16530/06 as regards the authorities' failure to pay compensation in respect of a plot measuring 10,500 sq. m, which was part of the Commission decision.
- The applicants in each case were to be compensated in one of the ways provided for by law, as the plots of land were occupied.
- The authorities have not paid any compensation in any of the cases, ranging from plots of land measuring 576 sq. m to 150,000 sq. m.

title: CASE OF COUDERC AND HACHETTE FILIPACCHI ASSOCIÉS v. FRANCE
facts:
- Applicants are the publication director and the publishing company of Paris Match.
- Ms Anne-Marie Couderc was born in 1950 and lives in Levallois-Perret. 
- Hachette Filipacchi Associés has its registered office in Levallois-Perret.
- On May 3, 2005, the Daily Mail published an article headlined “Is this boy the heir to Monaco?” revealing Ms Coste's claim that her son's father was Prince Albert Grimaldi of Monaco.
- The article mentioned a forthcoming publication in Paris Match and set out its core elements.
- On the same day, Prince Albert served notice on the applicants to refrain from publishing the Paris Match article.
- On May 4, 2005, the German weekly magazine Bunte published an interview with Ms Coste. 
- It was illustrated by two photographs of the Prince: in one of them, he was pictured alongside Ms Coste, and in the other, he held the child in his arms.
- On May 5, 2005, Paris Match published an article consisting of an interview with Ms Coste who stated that the father of her son was Prince Albert. 
- The article described the circumstances in which Ms Coste had met the Prince, their intimate relationship, their feelings, and the manner in which he had reacted to the news of Ms Coste’s pregnancy and had behaved towards the child at his birth and subsequently.

title: CASE OF ŞAKIR KAÇMAZ v. TURKEY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Tokat Prison.
- On 30 September 2001, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of membership of an illegal organisation and during his arrest, he attempted to swallow some pieces of papers and resisted the police officers.
- The applicant was examined by a doctor at the Diyarbakır State Hospital, who noted several injuries on his body.
- The applicant was diagnosed with pharyngitis and examined by a doctor at the anti-terror branch.
- The applicant confessed to his involvement in Hizbullah and was questioned by multiple investigators.
- The applicant was authorized for further detention at the anti-terror branch for a period of ten days.
- The applicant underwent multiple medical examinations and treatments while detained.
- The proceedings against the applicant commenced and he was sentenced to life imprisonment for membership of the Hizbullah and activities attempting to undermine the constitutional order by force.
- The applicant made complaints of ill-treatment during his detention and underwent further medical examinations.
- The applicant suffered from hearing loss as a result of his injuries.

title: CASE OF ÇAMLAR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was arrested in London on suspicion of drug trafficking.
- The Crown Court acquitted the applicant of all charges.
- The public prosecutor in Turkey filed an indictment accusing the applicant of involvement in drug trafficking.
- The applicant denied his involvement during the trial, requested certain witnesses to be heard, and was released pending trial.
- The court deferred the examination of the case to subsequent hearings multiple times.
- The applicant was found guilty based on evidence obtained during another set of proceedings and sentenced to twenty-four years' imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed the judgment, but the Court of Cassation upheld it, stating that the offence differed from that concluded in the UK.
- The applicant requested a reassessment of his case following the entry into force of the new Criminal Code, and his sentence was reduced to twenty years' imprisonment.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment and ordered a new hearing.
- The İzmir Assize Court sentenced the applicant to twenty years and ten months of imprisonment and a fine, and the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment with a minor procedural correction.

title: CASE OF SAHAKYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and lives in Yerevan. 
- On 30 August 2007, the applicant was arrested and charged under Article 112 § 1 of the Criminal Code with intentional infliction of a grave injury. 
- On 1 September 2007, the Erebuni and Nubarashen District Court of Yerevan placed the applicant in pre-trial detention. 
- On 28 September 2007, the same court decided, upon the applicant’s motion, to release him on bail. 
- On 4 October 2007, the investigator decided to cancel bail and detain the applicant. 
- On 22 October 2007, the Erebuni and Nubarashen District Court of Yerevan decided, upon the applicant’s appeal, to quash the investigator’s decision and release the applicant. 
- On 13 December 2007, the Erebuni and Nubarashen District Court of Yerevan acquitted the applicant. 
- On 21 April 2009, the applicant instituted civil proceedings against the Ministry of Finance, seeking pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage in connection with the criminal proceedings against him, including his detention. 
- On 25 September 2009, the Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan awarded him 215,100 Armenian drams (AMD) as compensatory damages. 
- On 4 December 2009, the Civil Court of Appeal reduced the amount of compensation for pecuniary damage to AMD 96,800 and terminated the proceedings on non-pecuniary damages. 
- On 1 July 2011, the Court of Cassation dismissed the appeal and upheld the decision of the Civil Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF EL KAADA v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1988 and lived in Gladbeck (Germany). When lodging the application, he was detained in Essen Prison.
- On 9 October 2008, the Gladbeck District Court convicted the applicant of several counts of extortion, robbery, burglary, embezzlement, and assault. The court suspended the execution of the sentence and granted probation with conditions, which was to run until 16 October 2010.
- On 15 June 2009, the Gladbeck District Court issued a detention order against the applicant based on the strong suspicion that he had committed a burglary on 31 May/1 June 2009 in a hotel in Gladbeck.
- On 22 October 2009, the Gladbeck District Court, relying on section 26 § 1 of the Juvenile Courts Act, revoked the suspension on probation of the applicant's prison sentence granted in that court's judgment of 9 October 2008.
- On 19 January 2010, the Gladbeck District Court convicted the applicant of burglary, committed on 31 May/1 June 2009 in a hotel in Gladbeck, and sentenced him to one year's imprisonment. The judgment became final on 2 June 2010.

title: CASE OF KORKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of involvement in fraudulent property transactions carried out by an organized group.
- The Ostankinskiy District Court of Moscow granted the investigator's request to remand the applicant in custody during the investigation, considering the seriousness of the crime and the risk that he might abscond, continue his criminal activities, or interfere with the administration of the criminal proceedings.
- The applicant was charged with multiple counts of fraud, money laundering, and criminal threatening including death threats.
- The District Court extended the applicant's detention multiple times until the trial, citing the seriousness of the charges and the risk of interference with the establishment of the truth.
- The trial started in July 2007, and the judge left the deliberations room on 20 March 2009, starting the public pronouncement of the judgment, which was completed on 10 April 2009. The applicant was acquitted of one count of fraud and found guilty of four counts of fraud and two counts of money laundering and sentenced to nine years' imprisonment.
- The applicant was detained temporarily in a detention cell at the police station and then in remand prisons from July 2005 to an unspecified date in 2009, allegedly in severely overcrowded cells with insufficient beds, no privacy in the bathroom, low-quality food, and bad smell emanating from the toilet.
- The applicant described poor conditions of detention during court hearings in a poorly lit and ventilated holding cell, severely overcrowded with no free access to a toilet. The conditions of detention reportedly improved after the District Court moved to a new building in June 2008.

title: CASE OF BIMURADOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the sister of Mr Magomed Bimuradov, who was abducted from a street in Chechnya by a group of armed masked men in 2002.
- The abductors allegedly belonged to the federal forces.
- Mr Magomed Bimuradov has been missing since his abduction.
- There were witnesses to the abduction, but their statements were not given to the official investigation.
- The government submitted a criminal case file into the abduction, but denied any involvement of State servicemen in the disappearance.
- The investigation was opened and closed multiple times, and is currently still pending.
- The witnesses saw a suspicious white VAZ-2106 car without a registration number driving around the village on the same day as the abduction.

title: CASE OF NAIMDZHON YAKUBOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on 30 June 2004 on suspicion of drug dealing.
- The Podolskiy Town Court of the Moscow Region remanded him in custody.
- The Town Court found him and his co-defendant guilty on 11 March 2005, sentencing him to fourteen and a half years’ imprisonment.
- The Regional Court quashed his conviction on 25 April 2005 and remitted the matter to the Town Court for fresh consideration due to a conflict of interest.
- The Town Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention until 8 November 2005, which was upheld on appeal.
- The applicant was found guilty on 9 December 2005 and was sentenced to eleven years’ imprisonment.
- The supervisory review granted by the Regional Court on 26 September 2006 quashed the appeal judgment of 17 April 2006 and remitted the matter for fresh consideration.
- The Regional Court quashed the applicant’s conviction of 9 December 2005 on 16 April 2007 and remitted the matter for retrial, in which the preventive measure applied in respect of him and his co-defendant should remain unchanged.
- On an unspecified date, the Town Court extended the applicant’s detention until 27 July 2007.
- On 6 May 2008, the Regional Court upheld the findings of the lower court as regards the lawfulness and reasons underlying his detention and considered it possible to release him on bail, which was not paid.
- On 1 August 2008, the Town Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to ten and a half years’ imprisonment, which was upheld on appeal on 19 February 2009.
- The prosecutor lodged an appeal against the court order of 10 January 2008, and the appeal decision of 18 March 2008, on 25 April 2013, arguing that the applicant’s detention from 27 October 2007 to 10 January 2008 had been unlawful. The outcome of the appeal was not reported.

title: CASE OF ZAKHARIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first, second, and third applicants were born in 1979, 1974, and 1974 respectively, while the fourth applicant’s date of birth is unknown. The fourth applicant is the common-law wife of Mr Pavel Aleksandrovich Bazhenov (“the fourth applicant’s partner”).
- On 14 October 2003, the first and third applicants, and the fourth applicant’s partner were arrested on suspicion of murder and later allegedly physically assaulted by police officers seeking to extract self-incriminating statements.
- A forensic medical examination on 15 October 2003 revealed that the first and third applicants had sustained injuries, while the fourth applicant’s partner had a closed nose fracture, which amounted to slight damage to his health.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of Irkutsk authorised the detention of the first, third, and fourth applicants on 16 October 2003, citing the gravity of the charges and the risk that they might interfere with the administration of justice. The three applicants were placed in remand prison IZ-38/1 in Irkutsk.
- The first and third applicants’ detention was extended several times until 5 June 2004 on the same grounds, and on 24 October 2003, they were charged with aggravated murder.
- The first applicant alleged that he had been beaten, tortured with electric wires, and deprived of food and sleep between 14 and 16 October 2003. On 21 October 2003, he attempted suicide by cutting his left forearm; on 4 November 2003, he attempted suicide again by cutting his neck with a blade.
- On 11 November 2003, the third applicant was beaten and tortured by police officers, causing him to jump out of a third-floor window in an attempt to escape. He was later diagnosed with a fracture to his right upper arm and contusions on his thorax and spinal cord.
- The fourth applicant’s partner was ill-treated by other inmates in detention facilities, deprived of food and sleep, and threatened with murder and rape. He was raped by other inmates and the act was videotaped, and he was blackmailed with the tape. On 5 February 2004, he was found hanged.
- The applicants complained to the prosecutor’s office about their ill-treatment, but the Deputy Prosecutor of Irkutsk Region refused to open criminal proceedings against the police officers on 20 November 2003 despite evidence of physical injuries.
- The lawfulness

title: CASE OF BUTKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of facts:

- The applicant was born in 1976 in Havana, Cuba, and lived in the Moscow region prior to his arrest on 6 April 2007.
- On 6 June 2008, the Moscow Regional Court convicted the applicant of armed robberies, illegal possession of firearms and other offenses and sentenced him to twelve and a half years of imprisonment.
- The applicant was detained in various facilities from April 2007 to after 7 December 2010, including remand prisons and correctional colonies in Moscow and Omsk regions.
- The Government submitted certificates and reports regarding the conditions in the detention facilities, including the number of detainees, the living space, hygiene facilities, and other amenities.
- The applicant disputed the Government's factual submissions and provided a detailed description of the conditions in one of the units where he was detained, including overcrowding, lack of ventilation, restrictions on movement, limited access to hygienic facilities, and poor recreation opportunities.
- The applicant also alleged ill-treatment while quarantined in another facility and poor conditions in the dormitory of the unit where he was later transferred.

title: CASE OF SAKIT ZAHIDOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
• The applicant was an independent journalist, satirist, and poet.
• On June 23, 2006, the applicant met a friend at Gozel Mekan café in Baku where they had a meal and took a taxi home.
• Four plain-clothes agents of the NDMIA stopped the taxi, dragged the applicant into a jeep, and arrested him without informing him of the reasons for his arrest.
• The agents planted some drugs on the applicant during the arrest.
• During the search at the NDMIA, 9.264 grams of a substance similar to heroin were found in his left trouser pocket, and he was charged with illegal possession of a large quantity of narcotic substances with intent to sell.
• The applicant denied that he uses narcotic substances and that the drugs found belonged to him.
• The investigator ordered a forensic medical examination to establish whether the applicant was a drug addict.
• The chemical expert issued an opinion that the submitted substance was home-made heroin.
• The applicant claimed that the police had fabricated the criminal case against him and planted the drugs.
• Despite his claim, the Assize Court ruled that the police officers had followed proper procedure and found him guilty.

title: CASE OF MOROZOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and was arrested in 2004 on suspicion of murder
- The applicant was detained in the Morozovsk police station's temporary detention center at four separate occasions (7-24 July, 17 Aug-8 Oct, 24 Oct-16 Nov, 4-16 Dec)
- The applicant's detention conditions involved a small cell with no ventilation, insufficient lighting, and extreme temperatures
- The applicant was not provided with adequate bedding, cups, eating utensils, or toiletries and there were no pest control measures in place
- The applicant was fed once a day with wholly inadequate food
- The applicant had sustained a head injury prior to his arrest, and did not receive adequate medical treatment for it while detained
- The applicant contracted tuberculosis and was housed with someone with the open form of the disease
- The applicant spent time in multiple detention facilities from 2004 to 2005: Novocherkassk, Ryazan, and Yekaterinburg.
- Detention conditions in Novocherkassk involved a small and overcrowded cell with no ventilation, unsanitary conditions, and a lack of drinking water.
- It was unclear how many inmates were housed in the same cells with the applicant in Ryazan and Yekaterinburg.
- The applicant made a complaint to various public authorities alleging inadequate medical assistance and poor detention conditions.
- The complaints weren't successful in initiating criminal proceedings against the alleged poor conditions of the applicant's detention in the IVS.
- The applicant initiated civil proceedings in 2007, but did not comply with the court's requests and the claims were left unexamined.

title: CASE OF MALIKOV AND OSHCHEPKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are pensioners who sued the Pension Fund for miscalculating their pensions.
- The Akhtubinsk Town Court granted the applicants’ claims on 26 July 2002.
- The Astrakhan Regional Court confirmed this judgment on appeal on 3 September 2002.
- The Akhtubinsk Town Court delivered a new judgment clarifying that the applicants’ pensions should be recalculated as from 19 December 2001 on 27 January 2003.
- The Presidium of the Astrakhan Regional Court rejected the supervisory-review application lodged by the Pension Fund against the judgment of 26 July 2002 on 26 January 2005.
- The Supreme Court of Russia quashed the judgments of 26 July 2002, 3 September 2002, and 26 January 2005 on 3 March 2006 and rejected all the applicants’ claims.
- The applicants applied for the reopening of proceedings on unspecified date.
- They argued that the decision of the Court to strike the application out of its list of cases on 18 September 2012, following the acknowledgment of a violation of their rights by the government, constituted a newly discovered circumstance entailing the reopening of proceedings in their case.
- The Supreme Court observed on 15 March 2013 that no reopening was required in the applicants’ case.
- The applicants’ supervisory-review application was dismissed on 8 July 2013 by the Presidium of the Supreme Court.
- The Deputy President of the Supreme Court refused the applicants’ request to bring a supervisory review application on their behalf under Article 391.11 of the Code of Civil Procedure on 18 September 2013.
- The applicants sought pension arrears under the judgment of 26 July 2002 for the period between 19 December 2001 and 3 March 2006 with their subsequent indexation.
- Their complaint under Chapter 25 of the Code of Civil Procedure was left without consideration by the Taganskiy District Court of Moscow on 7 November 2013.
- The Moscow City Court confirmed this judgment on appeal on 26 December 2013.

title: CASE OF SHULGA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's wife died in a bicycle accident in 2003. 
- The driver of the car, P., was questioned and testified that he was temporarily blinded by an approaching car and did not see the bicycle until it was too late. 
- Criminal proceedings were instituted for an alleged breach of traffic rules causing a person's death. 
- An expert concluded that the applicant's wife died from a basal skull fracture. 
- The proceedings were terminated for the absence of evidence of a crime, but the case was remitted for additional investigation several times. 
- An auto-technical forensic examination was conducted and concluded that the applicant's wife breached the traffic rules by riding a bicycle without lights. 
- The applicant brought claims for damages against P., but they were dismissed due to procedural shortcomings. 
- The applicant also participated in local elections, which were invalidated and later rejected on appeal.

title: CASE OF KALEYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lives in Norilsk.
- The applicant was convicted in 1998 and 2000, was released on parole in 2002, but was arrested again in 2003 for a drug-related crime.
- The police seized drugs, an audio system, and RUB 9,000 from the applicant during the arrest.
- The town court retroactively upheld the seizure of the audio system and RUB 9,000 for securing an eventual confiscation order, and a sum of RUB 1,500 was also seized.
- The applicant was charged with drug-related crimes, and the investigation file was transferred to the town court for trial.
- The applicant's retained lawyer Mr B. failed to attend a trial hearing, and the town court appointed Ms V. to represent him. The applicant did not indicate any failings on the part of Ms V. to the trial court.
- The applicant decided to replace Mr B. with Ms M. as his retained lawyer.
- The town court convicted the applicant of a drug-related offence and procurement and possession of firearms and sentenced him to ten years’ imprisonment. The court ordered that RUB 10,500 and the audio system be confiscated as “unlawfully acquired”.
- The conviction for procurement and possession of firearms was later quashed, and the applicant's sentence for the drug-related crime was reduced to nine years and six months’ imprisonment.
- The applicant sent an introductory letter to the Court, but no specific complaint was raised.
- The sum of RUB 10,500 was added to the State budget, and the audio system was sold for RUB 2,274.30; the proceeds were added to the State budget.
- The town court brought the applicant’s sentences for the crimes committed in 2000 and 2004 into conformity with the amendments in law.
- The presidium of the regional court mitigated the sentences on technical grounds and declared the judgments unlawful in the part concerning confiscation of the applicant’s property, which it remitted for a fresh examination in the first instance.
- The town court decided that RUB 10,500 should be repaid and the audio system should be returned to the applicant. The decision became final and enforceable, but it remained unenforced as the audio system had been sold and the money sent to the State budget.
- The applicant requested a copy of the trial record, but the request was denied as the applicant had already been provided with a

title: CASE OF M. ÖZEL AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Eight applicants were born between 1927 and 1966.
- In October 1994, the Çınarcık Municipal Council decided to raise the height of apartment blocks from five to six storeys in the Kocadere area.
- Municipal councillors discussed the legality of the six-storey buildings and the need to correct past mistakes.
- The Directorate General for Research and Implementation of the Ministry of Housing and Public Works received complaints about the unlawfulness of the buildings constructed by V.G. in Çınarcık.
- The Housing Ministry repeatedly ordered the municipality to take legal action against the illegal buildings and their developers, but no action was taken.
- In the earthquake of August 1999, seventeen buildings were destroyed in Çınarcık, and at least 195 people died in the Çamlık and Kocadere estates.
- Inspection reports showed buildings that were poorly constructed, using unsuitable materials and lacking proper foundations.
- An expert opinion found that one collapsed building had been constructed without proper technical control and inspections, and with several major defects.

title: CASE OF RADEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and is serving a life sentence in Varna Prison.
- On November 10, 1989, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to death, which was later reduced to life imprisonment.
- The applicant was placed under a “special regime” to serve his sentence.
- The applicant has been held in cells not equipped with sanitary facilities and was only allowed to go to the toilet three times a day.
- The applicant has been permanently locked in his cell.
- The most restrictive “special regime” was lifted in 2005.
- The applicant demonstrated anti-social behavior and periodically engaged in conflict with other inmates.
- The applicant has been disciplined twenty-six times for breaching internal rules
- The applicant complained that he was serving his sentence in inadequate material conditions.

title: CASE OF DIMITROV AND RIBOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Two applicants born in 1974 and 1979 serving whole life sentences in Burgas Prison.
- Arrested in November 2001 on suspicion of murder and remanded in custody.
- Found guilty of murder resulting from terrorist activity in December 2004.
- Sentenced to whole life imprisonment initially under the “special regime”.
- Serving sentences in permanently locked individual cells measuring 1.5 by 3 metres, under heightened security supervision.
- Allowed out of cells for 1-2 hours a day for exercise in the prison courtyard.
- Parties diverge in respect of material conditions.
- According to the applicants, material conditions are poor (scant daylight, a light bulb on 24 hours, no toilets in cells, inadequate food, hygiene, and medical treatment).
- According to the Government, material conditions are good (equipped with toilets, adequate light, regular cleaning, good food, hygiene, and medical treatment).
- Prisoners have access to a bathroom with hot running water six times a day.
- They can visit the prison library, chapel, and engage in unspecified group activities.
- Mr. Ribov has participated in group activities while Mr. Dimitrov has refused to do so without giving any reason.

title: CASE OF SEYFETTİN GÜNEŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and is serving a sentence in Batman prison.
- The applicant was taken into police custody in April 2000 on suspicion of being a member of Hizbullah, an illegal organisation.
- The applicant claimed to have been arrested on 4 April 2000 while the arrest report stated that he was taken into custody on 7 April 2000.
- On 6 April 2000, the applicant underwent a medical examination which revealed old scar tissue measuring 3 cm on his upper right wrist.
- On 10 April 2000, the applicant was questioned by the police without a lawyer being present and acknowledged being a member of Hizbullah.
- On 11 April 2000, the applicant was examined again by a doctor before being brought before a judge, where he denied the veracity of his statements to the police.
- On 27 June 2000, the applicant gave evidence to the Diyarbakır State Security Court, maintaining that he had been beaten and given electric shocks to his genitals while in police custody.
- In 2004, State Security Courts were abolished and the case against the applicant was transferred to the Diyarbakır Assize Court.
- On 13 February 2008, the Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicant of being a member of an illegal organisation and sentenced him to ten years’ imprisonment.
- On 24 June 2009, the applicant’s lawyer lodged an appeal against the judgment.
- On 30 September 2009, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment.
- On 25 October 2010, the applicant filed a petition with the Batman public prosecutor’s office, requesting an investigation into his ill‑treatment while in police custody in April 2000.
- On 2 December 2010, a doctor from the Diyarbakır branch of the Forensic Medical Institute conducted an examination on the applicant and drafted a detailed report. 
- On 28 November 2011, the Batman public prosecutor decided not to prosecute the officers on duty at the Batman police station at the relevant time or the three doctors who had issued the medical reports on 6, 9 and 11 April 2000 due to the statutory time-limit provided in Article 102 of the former Criminal Code which was ten years for prosecutions for torture.
- On 8 January 2001, while the applicant was in custody, his hip was broken while he was playing volleyball. He had surgery twice

title: CASE OF SIMONOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- All applicants were employed by RTB Bor - a socially-owned company based in Majdanpek (hereinafter “the debtor”).
- The debtor failed to fulfil its obligations towards its employees.
- Applicants filed separate civil suits to seek payment for salary arrears and social security contributions.
- Applicants were granted final court judgments to receive certain sums of money.
- Final court judgments were fully enforced between June and August 2011.
- The debtor is a company predominantly comprised of State or socially owned capital and is still in the process of being restructured.

title: CASE OF MIKHAYLOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant participated in a non-authorised public gathering on 25 November 2007 and was accused of disobeying a police order.
- The applicant was suspected of an offense under Article 19.3 of the Code of Administrative Offences and Article 20.2 of the CAO.
- The applicant requested an adjournment to retain counsel and study the case material.
- The justice of the peace dismissed the applicant's request for free legal assistance as the CAO contains no rule concerning provision of legal assistance to the defendant.
- The applicant was found guilty of both offenses and ordered to pay a fine.
- The applicant's appeal and request for free legal assistance were dismissed.
- The Constitutional Court of Russia declared the applicant's application inadmissible and found that the issue of free legal assistance in CAO cases may acquire constitutional significance in situations where the degree of actual intrusion into constitutional rights and freedoms, by way of prosecution under the CAO, becomes comparable to measures prescribed by criminal law.

title: CASE OF ALEXANDRESCU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the case facts include:

- The case is similar to two previously presented cases and belongs to the same historical context and domestic criminal proceedings.
- The applicants participated in anti-communist demonstrations in Bucharest between 21 and 23 December 1989.
- A criminal investigation was opened in 1990 regarding the use of violence against civilian demonstrators during the crackdown.
- The applicants were interviewed as witnesses and later joined the proceedings as civil parties, citing psychological suffering.
- Medical certificates submitted by the applicants indicated no medical symptoms, but it could not be ruled out that they suffered psychological trauma.
- The criminal investigation is still pending before prosecuting authorities.
- The military prosecutor's office decided not to institute criminal proceedings with regard to the acts committed by the military on 18 October 2010.
- Separate criminal investigations were opened in 1990 for the crackdown on anti-government demonstrations between 13 to 15 June 1990.
- The applicants participated in the demonstrations where they allegedly suffered injuries.
- Criminal proceedings were joined and then relinquished to the military prosecutor's office at the High Court of Cassation and Justice.
- A decision not to bring a prosecution was adopted on 17 June 2009, and the appeal was dismissed on 3 September 2009 by the head prosecutor. These decisions were upheld in several judgments of the High Court of Cassation and Justice.

title: CASE OF SINIŠTAJ AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
1. Seven applicants were born between 1946 and 1980 and reside in Montenegro, Canada, and the USA.
2. The applicants were arrested in 2006 on suspicion of anti-constitutional activities, preparing actions against the constitutional order and security of Montenegro, and illegal possession of weapons and explosives.
3. The applicants maintain that they were ill-treated during police detention, including beatings, food deprivation, verbal abuse, and threats.
4. The investigating judge noted injuries sustained by some of the applicants during interrogation.
5. The applicants filed criminal complaints against unknown police officers for torture and ill-treatment.
6. The Internal Control Division of the Police Directorate found no grounds to establish the involved officers' responsibility.
7. All applicants, save for the third one, were found guilty of anti-constitutional activities and the preparation of actions against the constitutional order and security of Montenegro.
8. The first applicant received the longest sentence of six years' imprisonment, while the remaining applicants received shorter sentences or fines.
9. The High Court based the judgment on evidence such as the first applicant's diary, expert witness opinion, and statements from police officers and some co-accused.

title: CASE OF VERDEȘ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and is currently detained in Timişoara Prison.
- On 10 May 2013, he was detained in Jilava Prison Hospital after receiving a five-year sentence for aggravated theft.
- From May 2013 to November 2014, he was examined, tested and treated regularly for his HIV condition in prison and civilian medical centres and hospitals.
- The applicant stated that he had not received adequate medical treatment for his illness on account of lack of funding.
- During his detention in Jilava Prison Hospital and after his transfer to Timişoara prison, the applicant had signed a number of contradictory statements as to whether or not he was a smoker.
- Detainees allowed to serve their prison sentence in a semi-open detention regime could spend time outside their cells from 8 a.m. to 12 p.m. and from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m.
- The applicant did not lodge a complaint with the post-sentencing judge or domestic courts concerning the conditions of his detention or a breach of his rights as a detainee.

title: CASE OF PALIUTIS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant requested a change of classification of his land from agricultural to residential use.
- Tauragė District Municipal Council granted the applicant’s request and prepared a detailed area plan.
- The Tauragė County Administration refused to approve the plan on the ground that it had not been prepared in accordance with the domestic laws governing the planning process.
- The applicant submitted a complaint to the State Inspectorate for Planning and Construction, which held that the TCA's refusal had been unfounded.
- The Klaipėda Regional Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s claim, stating the TCA’s decision was no longer valid.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the applicant's appeal and returned the case for re-examination by the first‑instance court.
- The Klaipėda Regional Administrative Court again dismissed the applicant's claims, stating the TCA's refusal was no longer valid due to the Inspectorate's decisions.
- The Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's appeal, stating there was no need to examine the applicant's request to order the TCA to approve the plan.
- The applicant later submitted a new request, which was approved in 2012.

title: CASE OF NOREIKIENĖ AND NOREIKA v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of facts:

- Applicants are a married couple from Ramučiai, Kaunas Region, born in 1965 and 1961 respectively.
- In 1993, the first applicant was assigned a plot of land measuring 1.97 hectares for individual farming.
- In 1996, she was authorized to buy the land for a nominal price of investment vouchers and 6 Lithuanian litai.
- In 2004, the first applicant signed a land purchase agreement, and the plot was subsequently registered in both applicants' names.
- In 2005, a third party brought a civil claim seeking restoration of his ownership rights to the land, arguing that it had been assigned and sold unlawfully.
- In 2006, the Kaunas District Court allowed the claim and annulled the administrative decisions and land purchase agreement, ordering the return of LTL 129 to the applicants.
- In 2006, the Kaunas Regional Court quashed the lower court's decision and dismissed the claim.
- In 2007, the Supreme Court quashed the decision and remitted the case to the Kaunas Regional Court for re-examination.
- In 2007, the Kaunas Regional Court upheld the first-instance decision and allowed the claim.
- In 2007, the Supreme Court refused to examine the applicants' cassation appeal.

title: CASE OF PAUKŠTIS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1937 and lives in Vilnius.
- The applicant's father bought a plot of 1.975 ha of land in territory which is now part of the city of Vilnius in the 1930s. The property was nationalised in the 1940s.
- In 1991 the applicant asked the Lithuanian authorities to restore his rights to his father’s land. In 1992 the Vilnius city authorities restored his property rights by conferring on him a right to obtain a plot no bigger than 0.2 ha to build an individual house.
- On 16 September 1999, the authorities transferred into the applicant’s ownership, without any payment, a plot of 0.18 ha in Vilnius city to build a house.
- On 2 April 2001, the Constitutional Court held that the limiting of the return of land in natura, if vacant and consequently of no particular societal value, was in breach of Article 23 of Constitution, which protects the right to property.
- Relying on the Constitutional Court’s ruling, on 4 May 2001 the applicant asked the Vilnius city authorities to stop distributing or selling the land which he claimed to be that of his father, given that he could now claim a bigger portion of that land.
- On 31 July 2003 the National Land Service informed the applicant that the land formerly owned by his father was State redeemable land.
- In August 2003 the Seimas (parliamentary) Ombudsman, the National Land Service, and in March 2005 a prosecutor, found that the transfer of plot no. 171 to M.P. by the Vilnius authorities had been negligent and in breach of the law, because this had been done after the Constitutional Court’s ruling of 2001.
- In January 2004 the Vilnius county authorities informed the applicant that his father’s land was to be bought by the State.
- In March and July 2004, the National Land Service confirmed the above value for 1 ha of land in Vilnius as had been established by the Methodology set out by the Government.
- By a decision of 15 June 2006 the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court dismissed the claim as unfounded.
- By a ruling of 15 February 2007, the Supreme Administrative Court fully upheld the lower court’s decision.
- On 1

title: CASE OF TUNAITIS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was assigned a plot of land by local authorities for the construction of a house in 1989.
- The validity of the decision to assign the land was confirmed by the Kaunas City Council in 1991.
- The applicant obtained a building permit between 1992 and 1994 but had to suspend building works due to the worsening economic situation.
- In 1994, the applicant bought the land for a nominal price of 24 "single-use investment vouchers" and 98 Lithuanian litai (approximately 28 euros).
- Third parties, V.P. and T.I., brought a civil claim in 2006 to restore their ownership rights to the land, claiming it was assigned and sold unlawfully to the applicant.
- The Kaunas City District Court allowed the civil claim in 2007, ordering the annulment of administrative decisions assigning the land to the applicant and the land purchase agreement. The land was returned to the State.
- The decision was upheld by the Kaunas Regional Court in 2008, and the Supreme Court refused to examine the applicant's cassation appeal on the ground that it did not raise any important legal issues.
- The applicant requested an investigation in 2008 to determine if V.P. and T.I. had produced false documents proving their ownership rights, but the prosecutor refused to launch an investigation.

title: CASE OF ANNEN v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant campaigned against abortion.
- The applicant distributed leaflets in the vicinity of two medical practices, accusing them of performing "unlawful abortions."
- The leaflets were also distributed to nearby letterboxes.
- The leaflets contained statements about the legality of abortions, international criminal law, and quotes from various sources.
- The leaflet referred readers to a website operated by the applicant.
- The doctors sued for civil injunction against the applicant to stop him from mentioning them on the leaflets and website.
- The Ulm Regional Court granted the injunction.
- The Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's appeal.
- The applicant filed for a constitutional complaint.
- The Federal Court of Justice refused the applicant's request for legal aid.
- The Federal Constitutional Court refused to admit the complaint for adjudication in 2009.
- The Court granted a further constitutional complaint in a separate set of proceedings in 2010.
- The civil injunction violated the applicant's freedom of expression according to the Federal Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF MAHAMED JAMA v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1996 and was detained in Lyster Barracks, Ħal Far.
- She entered Malta in an irregular manner by boat on 27 May 2012.
- She was registered by the immigration police and presented with two documents in English, one containing a Return Decision and the other a Removal Order.
- She was further provided with an information leaflet entitled “Your entitlements, responsibilities and obligations while in detention” in Arabic, a language she did not understand.
- She claimed to have told the authorities that she was sixteen years old, but during the registration process, her age was recorded as twenty-six (born 1986).
- By the date of the introduction of the application (4 February 2013), no date had been set for her appeal hearing by the Immigration Appeals Board (“the IAB”).
- She applied for asylum under Article 8 of the Refugees Act, Chapter 420 of the Laws of Malta.
- She was interviewed by three members of AWAS staff to assess the veracity of her claim that she was a minor.
- She was subjected to a further age verification (FAV) test - an X-ray of the bones of the wrist.
- The applicant had not received a written decision informing her of the outcome of the age assessment procedure.
- The applicant was detained in Hermes Block in Lyster Barracks which she considered prison-like and basic.
- The facility was shared by too many people and she only received basic items for personal hygiene and no regular supply of warm clothes.
- Detainees had little to do all day and limited access to open air.
- The physical conditions of detention and their impact on the physical and mental well-being of detainees were exacerbated by other factors.
- The applicant was granted subsidiary protection in Malta and released on 7 February 2013.

title: CASE OF BASENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Kyiv.
- On 24 February 2002, the applicant was travelling on a tram and was approached by two ticket inspectors (Mr G. and Mr S.) employed by the Kyivpastrans municipal enterprise, who questioned the validity of his ticket.
- There was a disagreement between the applicant and the inspectors regarding the ticket's validity, and the applicant was asked to get off the tram to resolve the dispute at a tram depot.
- While on their way to the depot, S. kicked the applicant, and in response, the applicant sprayed the inspectors with tear gas and was kicked in the left knee, resulting in a fracture.
- The police investigator initially refused to institute criminal proceedings into the incident, noting that S. was on sick leave from work and could not be contacted. However, on 18 December 2002, the District Prosecutor’s Office instituted criminal proceedings on suspicion of deliberate infliction of bodily injuries of medium gravity.
- The investigation was repeatedly suspended and resumed due to the failure to identify the perpetrator, but the charges were eventually announced to S. in September 2007.
- Despite having the opportunity to study the case file, the applicant refused it and was absent during the preliminary and merits hearings.
- S. was convicted as charged and sentenced to two years’ imprisonment, suspended for two years with probation.
- The applicant also lodged a civil claim against the transport company seeking damages but was rejected by both the first-instance and appeal courts.

title: CASE OF CENGİZ AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Mr Cengiz is a lecturer at the Law Faculty of İzmir University and is an expert and legal practitioner in the field of freedom of expression.
- Mr Akdeniz is a professor of law at the Law Faculty of Bilgi University.
- Mr Altıparmak is an assistant professor of law at the Political Science Faculty of Ankara University and director of the university’s Human Rights Centre.
- YouTube is a video-hosting website on which users can upload, view and share videos.
- On 5 May 2008, under section 8(1)(b), (2), (3) and (9) of Law no. 5651 on regulating Internet publications and combating Internet offences (“Law no. 5651”), the Ankara Criminal Court of First Instance made an order for the blocking of access to the website http://www.youtube.com and the IP addresses 208.65.153.238-208.65.153.251 providing access to the website.
- The court held that the content of ten pages on the website (ten video files) infringed Law no. 5816 prohibiting insults to the memory of Atatürk.
- Mr Cengiz lodged an objection against the blocking order of 5 May 2008, relying on his right to freedom to receive and impart information and ideas.
- Mr Akdeniz and Mr Altıparmak, as YouTube users, also lodged an objection against the blocking order of 5 May 2008, arguing that there was a public interest in having access to YouTube and that the blocking of such access seriously impaired the very essence of their right to freedom to receive information and ideas.
- The Ankara Criminal Court of First Instance dismissed the applicants' objection on 9 June 2010.
- The Ankara Criminal Court upheld the decision of 9 June 2010 on 2 July 2010.
- The Ankara Criminal Court of First Instance adopted a further decision concerning YouTube, ordering the blocking of access to the website http://www.youtube.com and forty-four other IP addresses belonging to the site.
- The second and third applicants lodged an objection against the additional blocking order of 17 June 2010.
- The Ankara Criminal Court of First Instance dismissed the objection on 1 July 2010.
- Prior to the order of 5 May 2008, the domestic courts had already made thirty-four orders blocking access to YouTube on account of illegal content hosted by the site.
- The Government indicated that in the period before and after the order

title: CASE OF TADZHIBAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant is a Kyrgyz national of Uzbek ethnic origin who fled to Russia after mass disorder and inter-ethnic clashes in Kyrgyzstan in June 2010.

• The applicant arrived in Russia in August 2010 and received a temporary residence permit.

• He was charged in absentia with involvement in riots and other offenses in Kyrgyzstan after his departure from the country.

• The applicant was placed on a list of fugitives in Kyrgyzstan and Russia.

• He was arrested by the transport police in Russia in October 2012 and subsequently detained.

• The Kyrgyz authorities sought his extradition which was granted, but it was later quashed.

• The Russian Supreme Court upheld the extradition order providing guarantees against torture or ill-treatment.

• The applicant applied for refugee status but was denied as he did not meet the necessary criteria.

• The decision to refuse him temporary asylum was upheld in July 2014 by the Moscow City Court.

title: CASE OF ŠOŠ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Zagreb.
