- On May 19, 2011, the police lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant for participating in an organized international drug-trafficking scheme.
- The State Attorney’s Office opened an investigation on May 20, 2011, based on evidence collected during the preliminary investigation and international legal assistance.
- The applicant and nine other defendants were indicted on drug trafficking charges on May 16, 2012.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant are still pending.
- The applicant was arrested on May 19, 2011, and remanded in custody for one month.
- The investigating judge extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention multiple times, citing grounds of risk of collusion, risk of reoffending, and gravity of charges.
- The applicant challenged the decisions on his pre-trial detention before a three-judge panel and appealed to the Supreme Court.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against the decisions on his pre-trial detention before the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF ŽILINSKIENĖ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1943 and lives in Šilėnai, in the Šiauliai Region.
- L.S.G. was recognized the right to the restoration of title to 4.07 hectares of land in the Radviliškis area, which had been nationalized by the Soviet regime.
- L.S.G. transferred the right to the restoration of title to 2.07 hectares of the land to the applicant.
- The value of the plot of land transferred to the applicant was estimated at LTL 2,124 (EUR 615), and the applicant was awarded the right of title to 1.78 hectares of land of equivalent value.
- The prosecutor instituted an investigation in 2004 and later requested the annulment of the agreement between the applicant and L.S.G., claiming that L.S.G. did not have the right to the restitution of the land.
- The court granted the prosecutor's request, declared the agreement null and void, confiscated the plot of land from the applicant, and returned it to the state.
- The court held that the right of title had been transferred to the applicant for free and did not award her any compensation.
- The appellate court upheld the decision of the lower court, noting that property unlawfully obtained for free could be confiscated from an owner.
- S.D., a former official in the Radviliškis Land Department, was charged with several counts of forgery of documents and abuse of office in relation to the restoration of property rights.

title: CASE OF BLESA RODRÍGUEZ v. SPAIN
facts:
Here are the main descriptions of the facts in bullet points: 

- The applicant is a professor at the Faculty of Pharmacy, La Laguna University.
- The university lodged a complaint against the applicant, accusing him of committing forgery by presenting a falsified curriculum vitae in a public tender.
- The criminal investigation was suspended on 6 February 2004 as no objective reasons existed to believe that the crime had been committed.
- An appeal by the university led to the continuation of the proceedings, and the applicant appealed against it, which was declared inadmissible.
- On 8 June 2010, the case was sent for trial and the bench of the Audiencia Provincial that would try the applicant was composed of judges A., S., and G.
- The trial bench was modified with one judge substituted as a member, and the applicant was informed.
- The same Audiencia Provincial bench found the applicant guilty on 27 July 2010.
- The applicant appealed to the Supreme Court, claiming lack of impartiality on the part of two of the judges sitting on the bench.
- The Supreme Court found that the applicant had failed to challenge the judge and that the circumstances alleged by the applicant did not fall within any of the grounds for challenging the composition of the trial bench.
- The Supreme Court reduced the sentence imposed on the applicant by the Audiencia Provincial due to the excessive duration of the criminal proceedings.
- The applicant filed an amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court, which was declared inadmissible as the applicant had failed to raise his complaints of lack of impartiality in previous judicial proceedings.

title: CASE OF YAROSHOVETS AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants, except for one who died, were born between 1978 and 1982 and currently live in Kyiv.
- The applicants, who were police officers, were co-defendants in criminal proceedings against them for ill-treatment, theft, extortion and abuse of power.
- The applicants were arrested and detained from 14 October 2005 until the end of October 2005 when they were placed in the Kyiv Temporary Detention Centre.
- The courts at three levels of jurisdiction ordered the applicants' continued detention until the pre-trial investigations were completed and the case was referred to the Desnyanskyy District Court of Kyiv for trial on 12 December 2006.
- The applicants were repeatedly denied release during the trial, which started on 23 January 2007, with some court decisions offering no explanation for the refusal.
- The District Court delivered a new judgment on 13 August 2010, finding the applicants guilty of several counts and sentencing them to five years' imprisonment with a ban on holding office in a law-enforcement capacity for three years and confiscation of property.
- On 16 September 2014, the Court of Appeal quashed most of the judgment, found the applicants guilty of seven counts, and sentenced them to four and a half years' imprisonment, excluding the deceased applicant.
- The Court of Appeal held that there had been no violation of the applicants' rights at the initial stage of the investigation.
- The inquiry into the first applicant's allegations of ill-treatment was initially rejected as unfounded in November 2005, then re-examined multiple times before being rejected again as unsubstantiated in May 2007.

title: CASE OF BICI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1926 and lives in Durrës.
- The applicant’s father was the owner of two plots of agricultural land, which were expropriated by the communist regime.
- The Durrës District Court acknowledged the existence of the applicant’s inherited property rights to a plot of agricultural land measuring 72,000 sq. m in accordance with Article 388 of the Civil Code.
- The applicant lodged an application with the Durrës Property Restitution and Compensation Commission seeking the recognition, restitution, and/or compensation of the property.
- From 2001 to 2008, the applicant requested several authorities to recognize his property right and restore the property to him.
- The Durrës Prefecture and the Commission stated that the application had been pending since 1996.
- The Commission confirmed that no decision had been taken in relation to the application of 26 September 1996.
- The Commission returned the applicant's application of 26 September 1996, stating that no decision could be taken on the strength of the District Court’s decision of 19 September 1996.

title: CASE OF AMIRKHANYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1941 and lives in Yerevan.
- A third person, G., owned a plot of land, which was separated by a fence and used by another person, J.
- On 21 April 1998 G. concluded an agreement with J., according to which she gave a part of her plot of land, measuring 285 sq. m., to him, but the plot of land actually used by J., as separated by the fence, was 38.75 sq. m. bigger than the 285 sq. m. plot given by G.
- Another agreement was reached between G. and J., according to which G. gave her consent for J. to become the owner of the whole plot of land used by him, as separated by the fence, but J.’s ownership rights were officially registered only in respect of the plot of land measuring 285 sq. m.
- On 28 April 1998 the applicant bought the larger plot of land from J. and, since the fence was still in place, continued to use the 38.75 sq. m. strip of land.
- In 2004 G. instituted proceedings against the applicant, seeking to take the 38.75 sq. m. strip of land used by the applicant, claiming her ownership rights.
- On 14 December 2006 the Erebuni and Nubarashen District Court of Yerevan granted the claim, ordering the applicant to release the strip of land to G.
- On 9 March 2007 the Civil Court of Appeal granted the appeal and dismissed G.’s claim, finding that she had relinquished her rights in respect of the strip of land in favor of the applicant.
- On 26 March 2007 G. lodged an appeal on points of law against the judgment of 9 March 2007 with the Court of Cassation, but it was returned as inadmissible for lack of merit.
- On 7 September 2007 G. lodged another appeal on points of law with the Court of Cassation against the judgment of the Court of Appeal of 9 March 2007, alleging violations of substantive and procedural law.
- On 1 October 2007 the Court of Cassation decided to admit the appeal for examination.
- On 12 December 2007 the Court of Cassation decided to quash the judgment of the Court of Appeal of 9 March 2007 and remit the case for a fresh examination.
- On

title: CASE OF KUSHCH v. UKRAINE
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant was born in 1969 and lives in Kyiv.
- Before his detention, he held the post of director of a joint-stock company in charge of the reconstruction of a city tram line in Kyiv financed from the local budget.
- On 20 July 2010, criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on suspicion of municipal property embezzlement.
- On 21 July 2010, the investigator invited the applicant to give some explanations and arrested him the same day.
- The investigator relied on Article 115 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and stated that the witnesses directly indicate the applicant as the one who committed the crime.
- On 28 July 2010, a charge of embezzlement was brought against the applicant.
- On 29 July 2010, the Golosiyivskyy Court ordered his pre-trial detention (for two months) as a preventive measure pending trial.
- On 5 August 2010, the Kyiv City Court of Appeal found against the applicant.
- On 16 September 2010, the Golosiyivskyy Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention to four months.
- On 19 November 2010, the Court of Appeal allowed another application of the investigator for extension of the applicant’s pre-trial detention, this time to five months.
- On 21 December 2010, the Court of Appeal extended the applicant’s detention to seven months.
- On 6 March 2012, the Podilskyy Court allowed the applicant’s request for release subject to an undertaking not to abscond, having regard to the deterioration of his health and his need for specialised medical treatment.
- The applicant has a long history of a number of illnesses and underwent inpatient medical treatment prior to his detention.
- The applicant was diagnosed with a number of medical conditions while in detention.
- The SIZO administration informed the applicant’s lawyer that the applicant required an additional examination in a civilian hospital and, possibly, inpatient medical treatment.
- The applicant requested the Court to apply Rule 39 of the Rules of Court in his case and to indicate to the Government the necessity of his urgent medical examination and treatment in a civilian hospital.
- The applicant’s requests for release were rejected several times by the courts.

title: CASE OF ROMAN ZAKHAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is an editor-in-chief of a publishing company and a chairperson of a non-governmental organization
- The applicant subscribed to the services of several mobile-network operators
- The applicant claimed that mobile-network operators had installed equipment permitting the Federal Security Service to intercept all telephone communications without prior judicial authorization, violating his right to privacy
- The Vasileostrovskiy District Court dismissed the applicant’s claims, stating that the installation of such equipment had not interfered with the privacy of the applicant’s communications
- The applicant appealed and claimed that judicial orders and an addendum proved that the mobile-network operators and law-enforcement agencies were technically capable of intercepting all telephone communications without obtaining prior judicial authorization, and routinely resorted to unauthorized interception
- The St Petersburg City Court upheld the judgment on appeal, stating that the applicant had failed to prove that his telephone communications had been intercepted
- An NGO asked the Prosecutor General’s Office to carry out an inspection of the Ministry of Communications’ Orders in the sphere of interception of communications, but the request was refused.

title: CASE OF MIRONOVAS AND OTHERS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Mr Petrulevič was serving a prison sentence at the time of application and had been detained in overcrowded cells with poor conditions.
- He filed a civil claim for damages in 2009, which was initially rejected by the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court but later restored by the Supreme Administrative Court.
- The Vilnius Regional Administrative Court acknowledged that he had been held in overcrowded cells for just under a year and a half and suffered degradation of his dignity.
- The Supreme Administrative Court recognized that he had been held in inadequate conditions on account of overcrowding for 564 days, which degraded him and was in breach of Article 3 of the Convention. It awarded him LTL 8,000 for non-pecuniary damage.
- Mr Mironovas was held in overcrowded rooms at the Prison Department Hospital in Vilnius that had poor hygiene conditions, and the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court partly accepted his complaint, resulting in LTL 2,000 in compensation.
- Mr Ivanenkov filed a damages claim against the Alytus Correctional Home for degrading conditions resulting from overcrowding and inadequate sanitary facilities. The Vilnius Regional Administrative Court awarded him LTL 2,300. The Supreme Administrative Court observed that the finding of a violation of his rights was sufficient just satisfaction.

title: CASE OF DUDAYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant and her family lived in one courtyard in Grozny
- The family included the applicant, her husband, their sons, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren
- Federal servicemen arrived at the applicant's home in the early hours of 9 July 2002
- They shot at the applicant's house and threw grenades
- One of the applicant's sons, who was a police officer, fired back and managed to escape the house
- The servicemen stormed the building about two hours later
- The applicant's son was shot dead in front of his family
- The applicant's husband was taken away in an armoured personnel carrier and has been missing ever since
- The servicemen set the family's house and car on fire
- The investigation into the incident was opened and closed several times due to a failure to identify the perpetrators

title: CASE OF SAGAYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Ms Khava Sagayeva is the applicant, who is the sister of Mr Khasan Sagayev. 
- Mr Khasan Sagayev was taken from the applicant's house by a group of masked and armed servicemen in August 2000. 
- The military commander informed the authorities that Mr Khasan Sagayev was taken to the military base in Khankala. 
- The investigation into the abduction was suspended and later resumed in 2009. 
- The applicant has not seen Mr Khasan Sagayev since his abduction. 
- The applicants, Ms Roza Mukayeva and Mr Khamzat Mukayev, are the parents of Mr Rasul Mukayev. 
- Mr Rasul Mukayev was allegedly taken from their house by armed servicemen in 2004. 
- The investigation into the abduction of Mr Rasul Mukayev was suspended and later resumed in 2005 and 2011. 
- Both applicants have not seen Mr Rasul Mukayev since his abduction. 
- The Government did not contest the facts as presented by the applicants but stated that there was no unequivocal evidence confirming the alleged involvement of state servicemen in the incidents.

title: CASE OF KASHPRUK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is detained in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk, Sakhalin Region.
- The applicant is accused of three counts of aggravated sexual assault and one count of being an accessory to traffic safety violation causing the death of two or more persons.
- The applicant did not appear at a preliminary hearing scheduled by the Yuzhno-Sakhalinskiy Town Court on June 4, 2007.
- The Town Court ordered the applicant’s detention instead of his undertaking not to leave his place of residence, and the detention order contained no time-limits.
- On June 8, 2007, the applicant was arrested and remanded in custody.
- The applicant appealed against the order on June 6, 2007.
- The Regional Court quashed the detention order on appeal and released the applicant on July 18, 2007.
- On July 26, 2007, the applicant was placed under an undertaking not to leave his place of residence.

title: CASE OF LEONG POY v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Lisbon.
- The case concerns a dispute between the applicant and company C.C. over the execution of a works contract for building a house.
- The applicant sued company C.C. in the Oeiras Civil Court in May 2007.
- Between May and October 2007, both parties submitted submissions in reply and new submissions, with company C.C. arguing that the court had already decided on the same subject in a previous case.
- In August 2008, the Oeiras Civil Court gave directions and concluded that it had already decided on the same subject, but the Lisbon Court of Appeal revoked the decision in May 2009.
- On July 2011, the Oeiras Civil Court held the first hearing, and several witnesses testified in the next ten hearings until September 2011.
- On September 2011, the Oeiras Civil Court ruled against the applicant.
- In January 2012, the applicant challenged the ruling before the Lisbon Court of Appeal, which upheld the first-instance judgment in January 2013.
- The applicant then appealed to the Supreme Court of Justice in March 2013, which dismissed the appeal for being lodged out of time, and the decision was upheld in July 2013.

title: CASE OF EUROATLANTIC AIRWAYS - TRANSPORTES AÉREOS, S.A. v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The case concerns a dispute between a Portuguese airline company and an Israeli company over a wet lease contract.
- The applicant filed civil proceedings in the Lisbon Civil Court against the company in 2009.
- The court held a preliminary hearing in 2010 to settle the case, but it was not possible.
- Several hearings were conducted, and both parties submitted evidence and documents to the court.
- The court made a decision on the factual basis of the case in October 2011.
- In July 2012, the Lisbon Civil Court ruled against the applicant and annulled the contract.
- The applicant appealed the first-instance judgment on October 2012.
- The Lisbon Court of Appeal partially ruled in favour of the applicant on February 2014.
- The Supreme Court of Justice finally adopted a judgment in favour of the applicant in October 2014.

title: CASE OF KULYUK AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are pensioners
- They successfully sued the authorities for miscalculating and adjustment of their pensions
- The judgments became final
- The defendant authorities’ applications for supervisory review were allowed by the Presidia of Regional Courts or the Supreme Court of Russian Federation
- The judgments delivered in the applicants’ favour were quashed by the higher courts considering that the lower courts misapplied the material law.
- Some of the judgments remained unenforced or partially enforced until the date of their quashing or were enforced with delay.

title: CASE OF KLIMOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are Russian citizens
- They brought court actions against authorities to recover the monetary value of state promissory notes for purchasing Russian-made cars
- Domestic courts granted their actions and awarded them compensation, payable by the Ministry of Finance
- Judgments were upheld on appeal but remained unenforced
- Supervisory review courts, upon applications from the Ministry of Finance, quashed the judgments in applicants' favor and dismissed their actions, stating lower courts had incorrectly interpreted and applied domestic law

title: CASE OF KOVALENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants participated in the cleanup operation at Chernobyl and were registered as disabled.
- The applicants were entitled to different social benefits.
- The applicants successfully sued the authorities for inflation adjustment of the benefits received.
- The judgments from the lower courts became final.
- The Presidia of Regional Courts allowed the defendant authorities' applications for supervisory review and quashed the judgments.
- The Regional Courts claimed that lower courts misapplied the material law.
- Some judgments remained unenforced until their quashing or were enforced with delay.

title: CASE OF TIKHONOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and was detained in prison in Vinnytsya.
- An elderly man was found killed in his house in the village of Pavlysh in the Kirovohrad Region.
- The police arrested the applicant for minor acts of disorderly conduct and exerted psychological pressure and physical violence to extract a confession to the murder.
- The applicant confessed to the murder and participated in a reconstruction of the crime before he was placed in pre-trial detention.
- The case was referred to the District Court for the applicant to be tried, and the court remitted the case to the Petrove District Prosecutor for additional investigation due to procedural violations committed by law-enforcement officers.
- The Kirovohrad Regional Court of Appeal upheld the District Court's decision, and the applicant was provided with a legal-aid lawyer.
- The District Court found the applicant guilty of murder and sentenced him to nine years' imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed against his conviction, but the Kirovohrad Regional Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

title: CASE OF ASLLANI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant worked at a bakery in Resen owned by Z.C.
- On 20 March 2008, police officers arrived at the bakery to check work and residence permits.
- G.S., a police officer at the time, arrived later and ill-treated the applicant during an interview at the police station.
- the applicant was diagnosed with facial injuries and a broken nose, for which he received medical treatment.
- The applicant and Z.C. lodged complaints of ill-treatment by police officers.
- An investigation was opened into the allegations, but the charges against G.S. were later withdrawn due to lack of evidence.
- The applicant brought a private indictment against G.S. on charges of ill-treatment and bodily injury.

title: CASE OF BALOGH AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- List of applicants and their representatives given in table.
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- Applicants complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF POLGÁR AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
• A table is appended with a list of applicants, their representatives and the relevant details of the applications.
• The applicants have complained about inadequate conditions of their detention.
• The applicants have complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF BOTA AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- List of applicants with representative and application details
- Complaints of inadequate conditions of detention
- Complaints of lack of effective remedy in domestic law

title: CASE OF LIGETI AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- List of applicants, their representatives and relevant details in the appended table.
- Applicants complained of the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Applicants complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- Applicant in no. 30412/12 raised a complaint under another provision of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SCHATSCHASCHWILI v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and was detained in Rosdorf Prison, Germany when he lodged his application.
- On 14 October 2006, the applicant and an unidentified accomplice robbed two Lithuanian nationals, L. and I., in a women's flat in Kassel, Germany.
- The women kept valuables and cash in their flat as they used it for prostitution.
- The perpetrators returned to the flat that evening, overpowered L., and pointed a gas pistol at both women.
- The applicant forced the women to hand over approximately 1,100 euros and six mobile phones.
- On 3 February 2007, the applicant, acting jointly with several accomplices, robbed two female Latvian nationals, O. and P., who were temporarily resident in Germany and working as prostitutes, in their flat in Gottingen.
- One of the applicant's co-accused had passed by O.'s and P.'s flat in Gottingen the day before to verify whether the two women were the flat's only occupants and whether they kept any valuables there.
- The applicant and a further accomplice gained access to O. and P.'s flat by pretending to be potential clients, while one of their co-accused waited in a car parked close to the building and another waited in front of it.
- Once inside the flat, one accomplice produced a knife while the applicant threatened to shoot the women with a gas pistol.
- P. jumped from the balcony and the applicant abandoned the chase after a few minutes.
- One accomplice overpowered O. and removed EUR 300, as well as the contents of her wallet (EUR 250).
- The court relied on the pre-trial statements made by O. and P. in the course of their police interviews and before the investigating judge, which showed that they had given detailed and coherent descriptions of the circumstances of the offence.

title: CASE OF BONO v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicant is a lawyer at the Paris Bar and acted for S.A. in criminal proceedings on a charge of criminal conspiracy.
- The domestic security agency received intelligence indicating that S.A. was involved in preparing an act of terrorism on French territory and he was arrested in Damascus in 2003.
- The French investigating judges issued an international letter of request to the Syrian military authorities for the purpose of questioning S.A. in 2004.
- During the questioning in Syria, S.A. was allegedly tortured.
- The investigating judges issued an international arrest warrant and S.A. was extradited and remanded in custody in 2004.
- S.A. and two others were committed to stand trial before the Paris Criminal Court on charges of participating in a criminal conspiracy for the preparation of an act of terrorism.
- The applicant requested in his written pleadings that documents obtained through torture by the Syrian secret services, be excluded from the file.
- The court excluded the documents obtained through the international letter of request and sentenced S.A. to nine years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant was charged with disregarding the essential principles of honour, tactfulness and moderation governing the legal profession, for his pleadings accusing the investigating judges of complicity in acts of torture committed in Syria.
- The Disciplinary Board of the Paris Bar Association dismissed all the charges against the applicant, but later the decision was quashed, and he was issued with a reprimand accompanied by disqualification from professional bodies for a period of five years.

title: CASE OF FÁBIÁN v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and resides in Budapest.
- The applicant was a civil servant under the Budapest XIII District Municipality since 1 July, 2012.
- An amendment to the 1997 Pension Act which took effect on 1 January, 2013 stated that the disbursement of old-age pensions will be suspended for those beneficiaries employed within certain categories of the public sector.
- On 2 July, 2013, the disbursement of the applicant's pension was suspended in accordance with the Pension Act's new rule.
- The applicant's appeal with the National Pension Board was unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF IVKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was arrested on suspicion of attempted drug trafficking on 16 October 2007.
2. The town court convicted the applicant of attempted drug trafficking and sentenced him to six years’ imprisonment.
3. The applicant’s request for a re-examination of his case was granted by the Supreme Court of Russia, which reduced his sentence to five years and six months’ imprisonment.
4. The applicant was released from detention on 15 May 2013.
5. The applicant was arrested again on 15 July 2013, on suspicion of another episode of attempted drug trafficking.
6. The applicant was diagnosed with recurrent smear-positive infiltrative tuberculosis of the upper lobe of his left lung with MBT, and was prescribed protiocomb.
7. The applicant had contracted hepatitis C and tuberculosis before his arrest.
8. The applicant died on 11 October 2014 due to tuberculosis in institution no. LIU-15.
9. The applicant was not married, but had a partner, Ms Yusupova.

title: CASE OF LOPES DE SOUSA FERNANDES v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant's husband was admitted to the Vila Nova de Gaia Hospital on November 26, 1997, for a nasal polypectomy.
- He was discharged on November 28 but returned to the emergency department suffering from violent headaches.
- He was diagnosed with bacterial meningitis and later transferred to the hospital's intensive care unit.
- His condition improved, and he was discharged to the general medical ward on December 5, 1997.
- He suffered from severe abdominal pain and diarrhoea, and on January 25, 1998, he was readmitted to the Vila Nova de Gaia Hospital. Bacteriological tests revealed the presence of the Clostridium difficile bacterium.
- He was discharged on February 3, 1998, but returned to the hospital on February 17, 1998, suffering from chronic diarrhoea and microcytic anaemia.
- He was later diagnosed with a perforated viscus, and his condition deteriorated. He underwent surgery on March 7, 1998, but died the following day from septicaemia caused by peritonitis and a perforated viscus.
- The Inspectorate General for Health carried out an investigation, and two medical expert reports were submitted.
- The investigation found that there were no grounds for disciplinary proceedings against any of the health-care professionals involved except for Dr J.V., who was found to have acted negligently in the medical assistance provided.
- The case was also referred to the Medical Association, which sought opinions from specialist panels. The infectious diseases panel found that the diagnosis of meningitis was inexplicably delayed, and the gastroenterology panel found that the patient's death was caused by peritonitis as a result of the perforation of the duodenal ulcer.

title: CASE OF SZAFRAŃSKI v. POLAND
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant is currently in detention in Wronki and has been serving a prison sentence there since 2010.
- The applicant brought a civil compensation claim before the Szamotuły District Court claiming that the conditions of his detention in many of his cells in Wronki Prison breached Articles 3 and 8 of the Convention.
- He claimed that the cells were not properly heated or ventilated and had no privacy due to low fibreboard partitions separating the toilet facilities from the cells.
- The Szamotuły District Court refused the applicant's request to gather evidence and dismissed his claim based on evidence submitted by the State Treasury that prisoners had access to sports, cultural and educational activities, medical care, personal hygiene items, and appropriate food.
- The court found that the fibreboard partitions provided some privacy, the cells were well-lit and properly ventilated, and the heaters and windows had been repaired.
- The court concluded that the State Treasury had not acted unlawfully and the conditions in Wronki Prison were not so harsh as to amount to a breach of personal rights.
- The applicant appealed the decision, arguing that the court had failed to establish the facts of the case correctly, in particular, a lack of privacy when using the toilet.
- The Poznań Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, stating that the nuisance caused by the fibreboard partitions did not exceed the normal difficulties and harm inherent in serving a prison sentence.

title: CASE OF KHALVASH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lived in St Petersburg until his arrest, he is currently serving his sentence in a correctional colony in the Arkhangelsk Region.
- The applicant was arrested on 31 July 2010 on suspicion of aggravated kidnapping, extortion, and conspiracy. He remained in detention throughout the investigation and trial.
- On 22 June 2012, the Leningrad Regional Court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to nine years’ imprisonment in a high‑security correctional colony with the release to be followed by a year‑long restriction of liberty. On 8 November 2012, the Supreme Court of Russia upheld the conviction on appeal.
- The applicant had a long history of cerebral diseases, including a traumatic cystic arachnoiditis that developed into a growing liquor cyst located in the right frontotemporal part of the brain. The cyst impacted on his acoustic and visual nerves. In addition, the examination revealed moderate internal hydrocephalus.
- The applicant lacked specific medical assistance or examinations regarding his cerebral health during the ten years preceding his arrest.
- After the arrest, the applicant was taken to a temporary detention facility where the resident prison doctor concluded that the applicant was fit to remain in the conditions provided by the detention facility.
- The applicant was seen by a neurologist and diagnosed with hydrocephalus. He was prescribed drug therapy for a month.
- An ophthalmologist diagnosed the applicant with angiopathy. In February 2011, the applicant was diagnosed with tuberculosis.
- Following a large variety of diagnostic procedures, including a magnetic resonance tomography of the brain, the applicant was found to have a liquor cyst in the right frontotemporal part of the brain and to suffer from vicarious hydrocephalus and encephalopathy. The applicant was also found to have several herniated disks and perineural cysts in his cervical vertebrae.
- In September 2011, the applicant complained about headaches, to which the hospital responded by recommending that he undergo an additional neurological medical examination.
- The applicant was examined by Dr K., who recommended chondroprotective therapy and cerebral bypass surgery for the applicant. He was also to wear a cervical collar.
- The applicant alleged that his transfer to a northerly region in which to serve out his sentence had run contrary to the recommendations of his doctor and might have resulted in serious complications of his illness.
- A medical expert commission concluded that the applicant was in satisfactory health and that there were no

title: CASE OF S.A. v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a Russian citizen of Chechen origin.
- He claimed that if he were to be deported or extradited to his country, he would face extrajudicial killing, imprisonment, or death by torture.
- The police arrested the applicant in Istanbul Atatürk International Airport on suspicion of illegal entry into Turkey with a false passport.
- The applicant was detained at the airport police facility for three days without any judicial order to that effect.
- The police took the applicant to the Kumkapı Removal Centre for Foreigners pending his deportation.
- The applicant alleged that he had been detained in unhygienic, unhealthy, and overcrowded conditions at the Kumkapı Removal Centre.
- The applicant’s lawyer lodged a complaint with the Istanbul public prosecutor’s office against police officers.
- The applicant’s lawyer filed petitions with the Ministry of the Interior and the Istanbul governor’s office requesting the applicant’s immediate release, claiming that his detention was unlawful.
- The police released the applicant from the Kumkapı Removal Centre on condition that he applied for the renewal of his residence permit.
- The Istanbul governor’s office decided not to examine the applicant’s complaint regarding his detention.
- The Istanbul Regional Administrative Court quashed the decision, holding that the governor’s office had to decide on whether authorization should be granted for the prosecution of police officers at the Kumkapı Removal Centre.
- The Istanbul governor’s office decided not to authorize the prosecution of the police officers.
- The Istanbul public prosecutor decided to terminate the investigation opened at the applicant’s request.

title: CASE OF S.C. ANTARES TRANSPORT S.A. AND S.C. TRANSROBY S.R.L. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Applicants are commercial companies licensed for providing passenger transportation services in Râmnicu-Vâlcea, Romania
- In 2004 and 2005, Vâlcea County Council adopted public transportation programmes, covering individual routes and a group of seven routes respectively.
- Following a court order in 2006, the council re-analyzed one route and then proceeded to put out all seven routes for public tender separately.
- Applicant companies won the bid for all seven routes but were informed of license withdrawal for the entire group in July 2006, triggering lawsuits.
- The council's decision was challenged in the national courts for not correctly enforcing the court orders.
- A Romanian court ruled in favour of the applicants, partially annulling the decision of license withdrawal, but upholding it only for one route.

title: CASE OF GURBAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently serving a prison sentence in the Kocaeli F-Type Prison.
- He was arrested on 11 October 1996 and taken into custody for being a member of and aiding and abetting the PKK, an illegal organisation.
- He was ordered to be placed in pre-trial detention on 18 October 1996.
- On 25 October 1996, a bill of indictment was filed against him and nine other persons, accusing him of membership of an illegal organisation and taking part in the murder of two persons for the organisation.
- The main witnesses against the defendants were not heard until 27 March 1998.
- The proceedings were adjourned four times because the defendants were not taken to the hearings by the prison authorities.
- On 13 June 2001, he was sentenced to death under Article 125 of the former Criminal Code.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment on procedural grounds and remitted the case to the first-instance court.
- On 27 September 2002, he was convicted under Article 125 of the former Criminal Code and sentenced to life imprisonment instead of the death penalty.
- The Istanbul State Security Court noted that he would serve his sentence until the end of his life.
- On 30 June 2003, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the Istanbul State Security Court.
- Following the entry into force of the new Criminal Code on 1 June 2005, the applicant's case-file underwent re-examination and no changes were made to the previous judgment against him.
- The committal order issued in 2009 indicated that he would not be entitled to conditional release.

title: CASE OF ROMAN PETROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and is serving a prison sentence in the Nizhniy Novgorod region.
- On 27 June 2007 the applicant was arrested on suspicion of having produced and distributed child pornography.
- On 29 June 2007 the Leninskiy District Court of Cheboksary (“the District Court”) authorised the applicant’s detention pending investigation.
- The court considered that it is necessary to remand [the applicant] in custody.
- On 22 August 2007 the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 9 October 2007.
- On 3 October 2007 the District Court extended the applicant’s pre‑trial detention until 9 November 2007.
- On 4 February 2008 the Supreme Court quashed the court order of 25 January 2008 on appeal, citing the applicant’s exclusion from the court hearing, and remitted the matter for fresh consideration.
- On 8 February 2008 the investigator in charge of the applicant’s case reclassified the charges against the applicant and ordered him to be detained for forty-eight hours. On 10 February 2008 the applicant was released.
- On 12 February 2008 the District Court again authorised the applicant’s detention pending investigation until 27 February 2008.
- On an unspecified date the applicant was charged with several counts of child molestation.
- On 27 March 2008 the applicant was released upon expiry of the statutory maximum period for pre-trial detention.
- On 28 March 2008 the District Court dismissed the investigator’s application for the applicant’s detention pending trial and ordered the latter to post bail in the amount of 100,000 Russian roubles (RUB).
- On 12 April 2010 the District Court granted the prosecutor’s request to remand the applicant in custody pending trial.
- On 5 July 2010 the District Court found the applicant guilty of several counts of production and distribution of child pornography, child rape and molestation and sentenced him to twelve years’ imprisonment.
- On 27 October 2010 the Supreme Court upheld the applicant’s conviction on appeal.
- On 5 December 2012 the Bor Town Court of the Nizhniy Novgorod Region granted the applicant’s request for commutation of his prison sentence in view of the latest amendments to the Russian Criminal Code and reduced the applicant’s sentence by one year.
- On 26 May 2011 the Supreme Court of the Ch

title: CASE OF ȘERBAN MARINESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant had an argument with a taxi driver who refused to return his change
- The taxi driver drove the applicant against his will to a police station
- The applicant was insulted, beaten, punched, and kicked by three unidentified police officers
- The police officers handcuffed the applicant to a metal rail for twenty minutes
- The applicant managed to call friends and a lawyer on his mobile phone for help
- The applicant suffered injuries and had blood on his face from a wound near his right eye
- The applicant lodged criminal proceedings against the taxi driver and the police officers involved
- The Mina Minovici Forensic Institute produced an expert medical report noting the applicant’s injuries
- The prosecutor’s office discontinued the criminal investigation against the driver and the three police officers, noting that the applicant was drunk and had been verbally abusive and violent
- The applicant challenged the decision before the higher prosecutor and in the domestic courts
- The courts ordered the prosecutor’s office to reopen the criminal investigation against N.B., V.L.G., and C.P. for abusive behavior, abuse of office, and unlawful deprivation of liberty
- The prosecutor’s office heard testimony from the applicant, witnesses, and police officers, and confronted them in a confrontation
- The investigation continued to gather evidence and clarify the circumstances of the case.

title: CASE OF KARACS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1965, 1967, 1996, 1998, and 2000 respectively and live in Isaszeg.
- The applicants lived as specially protected tenants in a flat owned by the local government of Budapest 12th District.
- Due to the deteriorated condition of the flat, in December 1995, they concluded an agreement with a view to moving to another property of the local government.
- A dispute arose between the parties concerning the applicants’ rights flowing from the tenancy.
- The first applicant challenged the validity of the agreement concluded in December 1995 in a first set of civil proceedings, which was dismissed on 27 March 1996.
- In September 1997, the first applicant brought a new action against the local government in relation to the tenancy agreement, which was also dismissed.
- The first applicant brought a third action before the Budapest High Court in August 2001, claiming damages sustained in connection to the tenancy dispute.
- The second, third, fourth, and fifth applicants joined the first applicant’s action in August 2002.
- Both the Budapest High Court and the Budapest Court of Appeal turned down the applicants’ claims.
- The Kúria confirmed the final judgment on 1 October 2014, and the judgment was served on the applicants on 4 December 2014.

title: CASE OF KRISTIANSEN v. NORWAY
facts:
- The applicant was convicted of attempted rape of Ms. A in a car parked near a petrol station.
- The incident occurred during the night of March 9, 2008, and both the applicant and Ms. A were teenagers at the time.
- The applicant borrowed the car from Ms. A's boyfriend and had called a friend who worked as a taxi driver to pick them up after the car's battery died.
- The High Court found the applicant had attempted to obtain sexual contact with Ms. A by force, even after she had told him she was not interested because she had a boyfriend.
- After a physical altercation between them, Ms. A was in great despair and cried when she returned to the party with her boyfriend.
- Juror J had informed the presiding judge of her previous contacts with Ms. A, but the High Court decided she ought not to withdraw from the trial.
- The minority disagreed with the majority's decision, arguing that J's statement, made after hearing evidence from both the accused and the victim, could easily have been perceived as a positive assessment of the victim's credibility.

title: CASE OF SOBKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and is currently serving a prison sentence.
- On 3 October 2008, the applicant, his wife, and a neighbor were digging potatoes near the applicant's house, and the applicant and neighbor consumed vodka at breakfast.
- The applicant's eleven-month-old daughter and four-year-old stepson were in the house, and the applicant had the key in his pocket.
- After being gone for about twenty minutes, the applicant reported having some beer when he returned to his wife.
- Later that day, the applicant found his stepson dead with a cable around his neck, and the applicant admitted to relocating the body and television due to stress.
- An autopsy confirmed that the stepson had been strangled on 3 October 2008.
- The applicant subsequently confessed to strangling his stepson in a statement of "voluntary surrender to the police," but later claimed that he had been physically and psychologically coerced.
- The applicant was indicted on 30 March 2009 and found guilty of murder on 18 May 2009.

title: CASE OF LYKOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant's son and his friend were stopped by police officers and taken to the police station without any reason.
2. The police officers ordered the two individuals to undress and bound their hands and feet with adhesive tape.
3. One officer began punching both individuals and urging them to confess to all thefts they committed.
4. When faced with silence, one officer violently hit each individual's head against the ground, cupboard, and table.
5. Afterward, one officer ordered another police officer to give one of the individuals a fashionable haircut with a knife.
6. Plastic bags were then placed around the heads of both individuals to suffocate them.
7. One individual confessed to a burglary and was taken to another room, while the other was tortured with electricity.
8. The tortured individual heard the other individual begin to cry out, which lasted for an hour.
9. The tortured individual was eventually taken to a temporary detention center, where he was examined by a doctor and noted several physical injuries.
10. The victim's cousin searched for him and found his corpse in the morgue, where she noted numerous physical injuries.
11. An investigation was opened into the victim's death, and a forensic report was drawn up, which noted that death resulted from multiple fractures from the fall.
12. The investigator twice refused to open a criminal investigation against the police officers involved, claiming that the victim's death was a voluntary act.

title: CASE OF CĂTĂLIN EUGEN MICU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and is detained in Drobeta Turnu Severin Prison
- On 28 October 2009, the applicant was convicted of rape and sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment
- The applicant was diagnosed with an inguinal hernia in June 2011 and underwent surgery
- In October 2012, the applicant was found to be suffering from viral hepatitis C
- The applicant was put on medication and given special diet for people with the disease
- On 21 February 2013, the applicant refused to be hospitalized for his health check-up
- In August 2013, blood tests showed that the ALAT and ASAT enzymes were slightly above the normal level and he was advised to follow a course of medication
- In January 2014, the applicant refused to be hospitalized for re-assessment of his health with regard to the hepatitis C condition
- On 26 February 2014, the applicant was found to be suffering from unstable angina and potentially toxic liver disease
- The applicant's complaint about his physical conditions of detention and a lack of medical treatment for his hepatitis C was dismissed by the judge delegated by the court to supervise the observance of prisoners’ rights in Jilava Prison

title: CASE OF SÜVEGES v. HUNGARY
facts:
1. The applicant is a practicing Catholic and teacher of religion
2. The applicant was arrested on suspicion of misuse of explosives on 2 June 2005
3. The applicant was indicted on charges of incitement to aggravated murder and unlawful possession of firearms and explosives on 11 May 2007
4. There were multiple changes in trial judges
5. The case was joined with another set of criminal proceedings
6. The applicant's pre-trial detention was repeatedly prolonged
7. The applicant's detention was suspended and he was ordered to serve a different prison sentence
8. The applicant was placed in pre-trial detention again on new charges of aggravated murder
9. The applicant filed multiple motions for release or less coercive measures
10. The court granted some requests for leave on specific occasions and destinations
11. The applicant's host complained of interference with her private life and lack of financial means
12. The applicant requested to establish the place of his house arrest at a camping site, which was deemed unsuitable for long-term residence.

title: CASE OF FRUMKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Moscow.
- On 6 May 2012, the applicant was arrested during the dispersal of a political rally at Bolotnaya Square in Moscow.
- The rally was organized to protest against the abuses and falsifications during the elections to the State Duma and the President of the Russian Federation, demanding fair elections, human rights, rule of law, and international obligations of the Russian Federation.
- The Moscow Department of Regional Security approved the alternative route.
- The security plan provided for an 8,094-strong crowd-control taskforce to police the designated security areas and prevent unauthorized public gatherings and terrorist attacks.

title: CASE OF KLEYN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lived in Chelyabinsk prior to his conviction.
- On 29 December 2000, he was arrested on suspicion of double murder and remained in custody pending the investigation and trial.
- On 13 September 2001, the Chelyabinsk Regional Court found him guilty of murder, accessory to murder, and attempted fraud, sentencing him to twenty-three years’ imprisonment.
- On 12 April 2002, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld his conviction on appeal.
- On 23 July 2004, the applicant lodged a supervisory-review complaint challenging the lawfulness of his conviction.
- On 15 June 2005, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation quashed the previous judgments and remitted the matter to the Chelyabinsk Regional Court for fresh consideration, ordering that the applicant be detained pending a new trial.
- On 18 August 2005, the Regional Court opened the trial and found the applicant guilty as charged, sentencing him to twenty-two years and three months’ imprisonment.
- On 23 June 2006, the Supreme Court upheld the conviction on appeal.
- On 13 October 2005, the Supreme Court upheld the decision of 5 August 2005 on appeal.

title: CASE OF MINIKAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a prison sentence for robbery
- On 30 December 2004, the applicant and others broke into a house, assaulted the owner and stole money, a hunting knife and a mobile telephone
- On 22 March 2005, the applicant and others planned to rob another house, but were caught by police officers who had been informed of the plan
- The applicant claims that he was physically assaulted and pressured by police officers to confess to the robberies, and that the confession was forged
- Forensic medical evidence shows that the applicant sustained injuries consistent with physical assault during arrest and police custody
- The applicant was convicted and sentenced to eleven years' imprisonment based on his confession and other evidence, and his claims of ill-treatment were dismissed by the prosecutor's office and investigation authorities.

title: CASE OF MANEROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested in May 2008 on suspicion of fraud.
- He was released after two days on the condition that he would not leave his place of residence.
- In July 2009, he was convicted of fraud and sentenced to four years of imprisonment and was arrested in the courtroom and placed in a remand prison.
- The conviction was quashed on appeal, and the case was ordered for retrial, with custodial measures remaining until the trial.
- The applicant applied for release, but it was rejected on the grounds of the seriousness of the charges and the risk of the applicant absconding and exerting pressure on witnesses.
- The decision to refuse release was not amenable to a separate appeal before the final decision in the case.
- The Garrison Court extended the applicant’s detention until 1 July 2010.
- The applicant lodged an appeal after the three-day time limit for lodging an appeal against the extension order had expired.
- The appeal against the custody order was adjourned until 30 April 2010.
- The applicant was convicted of nine counts of fraud and sentenced to four years’ imprisonment with a dishonourable discharge.
- The appeal proceedings against the judgement of 29 April 2010 were discontinued as the applicant had withdrawn his request for reconsideration.

title: CASE OF GEROVSKA POPČEVSKA v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant is from Skopje and was born in 1954
- The State Anti-Corruption Commission asked the SJC to review a civil case the applicant had adjudicated
- The Civil Division of the Supreme Court stated that there were grounds for professional misconduct proceedings against the applicant
- The SJC instituted professional misconduct proceedings against the applicant and asked for a report on whether her dismissal would be justified
- The plenary of the Supreme Court drew up an opinion endorsing the opinion of the Civil Division and finding grounds for dismissing the applicant for professional misconduct
- The SJC dismissed the applicant from the office of judge for professional misconduct based on evidence from the hearing before the Commission, including the opinions of the Civil Division and the plenary of the Supreme Court.

title: CASE OF JAKŠOVSKI AND TRIFUNOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicants were born in 1959 and 1946, and live in Ohrid and Tetovo, respectively.
- V.V., a member of the State Judicial Council, made enquiries through the President of the court in which the first applicant worked as a judge, following allegations raised by a lawyer that were subsequently withdrawn.
- On 19 April 2008 V.V. requested that the SJC initiate professional misconduct proceedings in respect of the first applicant.
- On 4 June 2008 the SJC set up a Commission for determination of professional misconduct by a judge.
- On 3 October 2008 the plenary of the SJC initiated proceedings for professional misconduct in respect of the first applicant.
- On 17 December 2008 the plenary of the SJC, the composition of which included V.V., dismissed the first applicant for professional misconduct.
- The first applicant challenged that decision at second instance before an Appeal Panel formed within the Supreme Court and on 24 September 2009 the Appeal Panel dismissed the first applicant’s appeal.
- R.P., a member of the SJC, applied to the SJC for professional misconduct proceedings to be instituted in respect of the second applicant.
- On 29 December 2008, the plenary of the SJC initiated professional misconduct proceedings in respect of the second applicant and ordered his temporary suspension.
- On 12 February 2009 the plenary of the SJC, the composition of which included R.P., dismissed the second applicant for professional misconduct.
- The second applicant challenged his dismissal before the Administrative Court by means of an administrative-dispute action on 25 June 2009.
- The second applicant’s action was rejected as inadmissible on 6 October 2010.
- The second applicant produced copies of articles published in local newspapers on 26 January and 13 February 2009 reporting on his case.

title: CASE OF ANDREY ZAKHAROV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and was living with his partner in a privately owned house in Kyiv before his arrest.
- The police received information that a group of people were detaining a man in the applicant's house, and were involved in illegal apartment sales.
- The police arrested the applicant on suspicion of illegally storing a firearm and concealing the deaths of two people in his basement.
- The applicant claimed to have been subjected to physical and psychological abuse by police officers during and after his arrest.
- The government maintained that the applicant voluntarily gave a written statement admitting to keeping the two individuals in his basement in exchange for payment, and burying them after they died of cold.
- The applicant alleged that he was coerced into making the self-incriminating statement under duress.
- The applicant later denied the statement and changed his story during the investigation and trial.
- The court questioned witnesses, including the applicant's lawyer, the investigator, and individuals involved in the case, including the individuals held in the applicant's basement.
- Kr., who had allegedly asked the applicant to keep N., V., and Sh., gave a statement to the court admitting to helping the applicant move and bury the dead bodies.
- Additional individuals, including N. and the applicant's girlfriend, Te., provided testimony about the illegal sales and detention of individuals.
- The trial began in February 2005 and concluded with the applicant being charged with participation in fraud and murder.

title: CASE OF DĀVIDSONS AND SAVINS v. LATVIA
facts:
- First applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Vecumnieki. Second applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Riga.
- The first applicant was suspected of the sale of narcotics and of providing unauthorized objects to imprisoned prisoners leading to a detention order issued by the Valmiera District Court.
- On appeal, the Vidzeme Regional Court upheld the detention order due to the seriousness of the charges and the fact that the first applicant had no permanent residence.
- The first applicant's criminal case was adjudicated by a panel of the Vidzeme Regional Court, with defense challenging the participation of Judge G.K. due to a previous involvement in criminal proceedings. The challenge was rejected, and Judge G.K. remained involved in the case.
- The second applicant was detained on suspicion of robbery and a pre-trial detention was authorised by the Rēzekne Court, which was upheld by a panel of the Latgale Regional Court in an appeal. The court considered the second applicant's personality and tendency to commit crimes as exceptional grounds for applying pre-trial detention.
- The second applicant was convicted by the Rēzekne Court for robbery and theft of personal identity documents, and a subsequent appeal was dismissed by a panel of the Latgale Regional Court composed of the same judges who had previously examined his appeal against the pre-trial detention decision.
- The applicant's appeal on points of law was not accepted for adjudication by the Senate of the Supreme Court, and no violation of the applicable procedural law was found in the composition of the appeal court.

title: CASE OF POPOSKI AND DUMA v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1963 and 1951, and live in Ohrid and Skopje respectively.
- N.H.A., a member of the SJC, requested that the SJC initiate professional misconduct proceedings in respect of the first applicant.
- A commission was set up under section 58 of the 2006 Act, composed of five SJC members, which submitted a report to the SJC in which it sought that it initiate professional misconduct proceedings against the first applicant.
- The first applicant challenged the SJC’s decision before an appeal panel formed within the Supreme Court (“the Appeal Panel”).
- The second applicant was subject to professional misconduct proceedings on the basis of two separate criminal cases.
- The SJC set up a Commission in the second applicant’s case, which did not include the Minister of Justice.
- The plenary of the SJC initiated professional misconduct proceedings in respect of the second applicant and temporarily suspended her from the office of judge.
- The Appeals Panel upheld the dismissal decision for both applicants.
- The second applicant lodged a constitutional appeal with the Constitutional Court, arguing that her dismissal had violated her rights under Articles 9 (equality of citizens) and 16 (freedom of conscience, thought and public expression of thought) of the Constitution.

title: CASE OF VRTAR v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1998 and lives in Vinkovci.
- The Vinkovci Municipal Court ordered the applicant’s father to pay for her maintenance.
- The applicant’s mother applied for enforcement of the judgment.
- The case was transferred from the Vinkovci Municipal Court to the Varaždin Municipal Court.
- The court issued a writ of execution by garnishment of the debtor’s salary.
- The debtor appealed against the writ and claimed he was regularly paying the child maintenance.
- The court invited the applicant’s mother to specify to what extent the debtor had not complied with his obligation to pay.
- The debtor retired and his pension was garnished.
- The enforcement was completed after many years.
- The Varaždin County Court found a violation of the applicant’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time.
- The Supreme Court increased compensation to be paid to the applicant.
- The applicant’s mother instituted proceedings against the applicant’s father to increase the level of child maintenance.
- The court ruled in favor of the applicant and ordered her father to pay.

title: CASE OF PĂȘCOI AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The document contains a table listing the applicants and their relevant details
- The applicants claimed non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions
- The applicants claimed entitlement to various pecuniary amounts and/or State actions in their favor
- Some applicants raised complaints under various articles of the Convention

title: CASE OF BÓDAY AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- List of applicants and their representatives provided in a table
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
- Applicants complained about lack of effective remedy in domestic law

title: CASE OF BAKOS AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details provided in an appended table
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
- Applicants complained about lack of effective domestic law remedy
- In application no. 33213/13, applicant raised complaint under another provision of the Convention

title: CASE OF MAGYAR AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicants' names and representative information is in the table. 
- Applicants claimed inadequate conditions of detention. 
- Applicants claimed there was no effective domestic legal remedy. 
- Additional complaints were raised in application numbers 69916/12 and 73694/12.

title: CASE OF JUHÁSZ AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- List of applicants and their representatives provided in an appended table. 
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions. 
- Applicants complained that there was no effective remedy in domestic law. 
- Applicant in case no. 44056/13 raised complaints under other provisions of the Convention in addition to inadequate detention conditions and lack of effective remedy.

title: CASE OF TAMÁSI AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- A table is appended to the document listing the applicants and relevant application details.
- The applicants complained of inadequate detention conditions.
- The applicants complained of a lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF BOACĂ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
1. The applicants are Romanian nationals of Roma origin and heirs of I.B.
2. I.B. and some of the applicants initiated domestic proceedings, which were still pending at the time of I.B.’s death.
3. I.B.’s heirs pursued the case before domestic courts and lodged a complaint before the European Court of Human Rights.
4. On 30 March 2006, A.N., I.B.’s daughter-in-law, was attacked near I.B.’s home, which led to a confrontation between I.B.’s family and other villagers.
5. I.B.’s sons and C.G.M., the victim’s father, went to the Clejani Police Station to report the assault and were allegedly attacked by a group of fifty villagers.
6. I.B., who arrived at the scene, saw his sons being attacked by villagers with stones, bats, and bricks.
7. Police officers from Clejani police station, accompanied by colleagues from the Giurgiu Rapid Intervention Squad, arrived at I.B.’s home to take him into custody.
8. The police officers made two children from the household, one aged 13 and one 14, lie down on their stomachs and insulted them.
9. The applicants were apprehended by ten masked police officers who kicked them in the stomach and face and called them “disgraceful gypsies.”
10. The interrogations took place in the chief of police’s office, where I.B. was beaten up by police officer T.B. and four masked officers that resulted in I.B. losing consciousness.
11. The first three applicants were ordered to sign confessions concerning the rape of a foreign woman and the theft of pipes, which were written by the police officers.
12. On 9 May 2007, the prosecutor’s office decided not to prosecute any of those involved in the incidents, and it appears the decision was not contested.
13. I.B. and the first three applicants lodged a criminal complaint with the prosecutor’s office attached to Giurgiu County Court against the police officers who allegedly ill-treated them.
14. The prosecutor eventually dismissed the complaint, but the decision was quashed, and the case was sent back to the prosecutor.
15. The prosecutor’s office again refused to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers on the ground that their actions were consistent with their professional duties.
16. I.B. appealed against both decisions before the Giurgiu County Court, but his appeal was dismissed.
17. The Bucharest Court of Appeal

title: CASE OF KHAYLETDINOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and is serving his sentence in correctional colony no. 2 in the Astrakhan Region.
- On 9 May 2012, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder committed during a fight with the victim.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Astrakhan authorised his remand in custody on the grounds of the gravity of the charges, his previous convictions for violent crimes, and his lack of an "official" source of income and dependents.
- The applicant’s detention was extended several times between May 2012 and December 2012 on the grounds of the gravity of the charges, the risk of absconding, interfering with the course of justice, and reoffending.
- In August 2013, the applicant was convicted of murder and sentenced to seven years of imprisonment, taking into account some mitigating circumstances.
- The applicant was diagnosed with stage 4A HIV in January 2004 and was under the supervision of specialists from the Astrakhan Regional Centre for Protection from AIDS.
- The applicant underwent several medical check-ups and treatments for various illnesses that he developed during his detention, including chronic pancreatitis, chronic gastroduodenitis, iron deficiency anaemia, fungal esophagitis, urolithiasis, and hepatic hemangioma, among others.
- The applicant was prescribed antiretroviral therapy, although he experienced several interruptions in the treatment that deteriorated his condition.
- The applicant requested several times to be examined by a medical expert, but his requests were initially denied. His lawyer later managed to obtain the authorisation for a medical examination, but the request was refused by the court.

title: CASE OF SZABÓ AND VISSY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1976 and 1986 and lived in Budapest.
- Applicants were staff members of Eötvös Károly Közpolitikai Intézet, a non-governmental, “watchdog” organisation voicing criticism of the Government.
- One of the applicant's subsequent employers was under financial control measures by the Government in 2014.
- Act no. CXLVII of 2010 defines combating terrorism as one of the tasks of the police.
- TEK's prerogatives in secret intelligence gathering include secret house search and surveillance with recording, opening of letters and parcels, and checking and recording the contents of electronic or computerised communications, without the consent of the persons concerned.
- Authorization process in section 7/E (2) is subject to judicial authorisation, whereas in section 7/E (3), it is authorised by the Minister in charge of justice, in order to prevent terrorist acts or for national security.
- The applicants filed a constitutional complaint, arguing that the sweeping prerogatives under section 7/E (3) infringed their constitutional right to privacy.
- On 18 November 2013, the Constitutional Court dismissed the majority of the applicants’ complaints, but agreed that the decision of the minister ordering secret intelligence gathering had to be supported by reasons.

title: CASE OF BILBIJA AND BLAŽEVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicants’ mother died after being admitted to the hospital
- Autopsy report showed that the cause of death was a respiratory insufficiency leading to cardiac complications
- The first applicant pursued legal remedies concerning her mother's death
- Complaints were made to the Ministry of Health and the Croatian Medical Chamber (CMC)
- The CMC dismissed the first applicant's objection as ill-founded
- The first applicant lodged an administrative action in the Administrative Court
- The administrative action was declared inadmissible by the Administrative Court
- The first applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint as ill-founded
- The first applicant lodged a criminal complaint alleging medical negligence by unknown hospital staff
- The Zagreb Municipal State Attorney’s Office rejected the first applicant’s criminal complaint
- The first applicant instituted criminal proceedings against doctor B.S. on charges of medical negligence
- An expert report found there had been no irregularity in the medical treatment of the applicants' mother

title: CASE OF SALAMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Grozny, Chechnya.
- The Russian Government launched a counter-terrorist operation in the Chechen Republic in early October 1999.
- Military servicemen seized a truck belonging to the applicant’s family on 14 December 1999 without any document authorising the seizure.
- The applicant tried to retrieve the truck and complained to various authorities several times between December 1999 and February 2000.
- The truck was returned to the applicant on 24 April 2000 without its registration documents and number plates.
- A commission evaluated the damage inflicted on the truck and estimated it at 147,650 Russian roubles (RUB).
- A forensic expert examined the truck and stated that its engine number had been erased.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of Grozny granted the applicant's action and recognized him as the owner of a KAMAZ truck.
- The applicant sought compensation and filed a lawsuit against military unit no. 3702 for unlawful seizure of his truck and claimed for the missing parts, the cost of repairs, and the use of the truck by the military.
- The court decided that military unit no. 3702 was not the proper defendant in the case and claimed that damage caused by an unlawful act or a failure to act on the part of the State or municipal bodies or their officials should be compensated at the expense of the federal, regional, or municipal treasury.
- Another check was carried out by the military prosecutor for the North Caucasus Military Circuit attesting that there were no relevant documents about the alleged seizure of the KAMAZ truck by military unit no. 3702.

title: CASE OF MILOJEVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
Facts about the case:

- Applicants were police officers charged with criminal offences and subsequently dismissed from the police force.
- Applicants were acquitted of the charges, but their dismissals were not reversed.
- The Ministry of Interior cited Article 45 of the Ministry of Interior Act 1991 to justify their dismissals.
- Applicants challenged their dismissals in civil proceedings, but were unsuccessful.
- In each case, the applicant was charged with abuse of power and criminal proceedings were instituted against them simultaneously with disciplinary proceedings.
- Applicant was suspended from their police duties pending the decision of the Disciplinary Court.
- Applicant was acquitted of the charges in each case; however, their dismissals remained in force.
- Civil proceedings were instituted by each applicant, requesting to annul the dismissal decisions.
- The Municipal Courts accepted the claim of the applicant and ordered the Ministry of Interior to reinstate them in their former posts.
- The decisions were appealed by the Ministry of Interior and were quashed by the Supreme Court.
- G.M., a co-defendant of one of the applicants in criminal proceedings, was acquitted and remains employed as a police officer.
- The third applicant requested compensation for non-pecuniary damage related to unlawful detention, stress in prison, and loss of reputation caused by imprisonment, and was awarded a sum of RSD 530,000.

title: CASE OF BUTERLEVIČIŪTĖ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and worked as the head of a municipal kindergarten in Panevėžys.
- An investigation was launched against the applicant on suspicion of fraudulent management of accounts, abuse of office, forgery of documents, and misappropriation of property.
- The applicant submitted a request to terminate the criminal investigation due to excessive length but was denied.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to a fine and a prohibition on working for the civil service for a certain period.
- The sentence was reduced on appeal, and the period of prohibition on working for the civil service was further reduced after a final judgment from the Supreme Court.
- The applicant was suspended from her job during the criminal investigation and appealed against the decision but was unsuccessful.
- The suspension was extended by the first-instance court on several occasions, with the applicant and her representative only present at one of the hearings.
- The appellate court overturned the decision to terminate the suspension, and the applicant was suspended again for a period of three months but returned to her job after an appeal.
- The applicant filed a complaint about defamatory and insulting articles and comments in a newspaper and website, partially satisfied by the Inspector of Journalistic Ethics.

title: CASE OF IRMAK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and is serving a sentence in Diyarbakır prison.
- On 11 January 1996 the applicant was arrested and taken into police custody on suspicion of being a member of Hizbullah, an illegal organisation.
- On 24 January 1996 the applicant’s statement was taken by the police. The applicant acknowledged being a member of Hizbullah and gave a detailed account of his activities within that illegal organisation.
- On 2 February 1996, the applicant was brought before the public prosecutor and, subsequently, a judge, who questioned him and recorded his statements. On both occasions, he retracted the statements he had made to the police, claiming that he had signed them under duress. The judge remanded him in custody.
- On 29 February 1996, the public prosecutor at the Diyarbakır State Security Court filed an indictment with that court, accusing the applicant and several other persons of carrying out activities with the aim of bringing about the secession of part of the national territory. The public prosecutor alleged that the applicant had taken part in killing eight persons and the wounding of four persons by Hizbullah.
- On 21 February 2002, the applicant was arrested once again, on suspicion of having been involved in certain armed acts undertaken by Hizbullah. According to the arrest report, the police had had to use force in order to apprehend the applicant, since the latter had attempted to resist arrest and flee.
- On the same day, the applicant was examined by a doctor at the Batman state hospital. The doctor noted, in a police document, that the applicant had signs of physical violence on six areas on his back, bruises on both wrists, two cuts on his left ear and an injury to his right eye.
- On 13 March 2002, the public prosecutor at the Diyarbakır State Security Court lodged a new indictment with that court under Article 146 of the then applicable Criminal Code, accusing the applicant of having attempted to undermine the constitutional order by force.
- On 16 May 2002, the Diyarbakır State Security Court held a hearing in the case initiated by the public prosecutor’s indictment dated 13 March 2002 (case no. 2002/81). 
- On 10 June 2008, the Diyarbakır Assize Court delivered its judgment in the case.
- The Diyarbakır Assize Court found that the applicant had been

title: CASE OF PRUS v. POLAND
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1987 and is detained in Lublin.
• On 1 December 2005, the applicant was arrested and remanded in custody.
• In 2006, he was convicted of three counts of battery and robbery and received prison sentences ranging from two to four years.
• On 28 November 2006, the Lublin Regional Court imposed a cumulative sentence for four criminal convictions.
• On 5 November 2010, the Opole Lubelskie Prison Penitentiary Commission imposed on the applicant the so-called “dangerous detainee” regime.
• On 18 January 2011, the Opole Lubelskie Prison Penitentiary Commission rejected an appeal lodged by the applicant and dismissed his request for leave to examine the appeal outside the statutory time-limit.
