• The applicant was subsequently transferred to the Lublin Remand Centre.
• On 3 February 2011, the Lublin Remand Centre Penitentiary Commission reviewed and upheld the decision to apply the regime to the applicant, considering that he posed a serious threat to the security of the detention centre.
• on 4 April 2011, the Lublin Regional Court dismissed the appeal.
• On 3 March 2011, the applicant lodged a complaint with the Lublin Regional Inspectorate of Prisons.
• The authorities dismissed the complaint, holding that educational activities were not organised for dangerous prisoners.
• On an unspecified date in 2011, the applicant notified the police of his allegedly unlawful classification as a “dangerous detainee” on 5 November 2010.
• On 29 April 2011, the Opole Lubelskie District Prosecutor refused to open an investigation in the case.
• On 28 April 2011, the Lublin Remand Centre Penitentiary Commission revoked its decision to classify the applicant as a “dangerous detainee”.

title: CASE OF KARYKOWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a habitual offender born in 1966, currently detained in Stargard Szczeciński.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of uttering threats and subsequently sentenced to three years and six months’ imprisonment, being first detained in Nowogard Prison and later in Goleniów Prison.
- A note entitled “Protest letter” was found in the applicant's cell on 7 September 2011, signed by 135 prisoners, opposing changes to the Code of Execution of Criminal Sentences.
- On 8 September 2011, the applicant was imposed the “dangerous detainee” regime by the Nowogard Prison Penitentiary Commission, holding him as one of the organizers of a planned collective remonstrance in Nowogard Prison and isolating him from other prisoners.
- The applicant's appeal against this decision was dismissed by the Szczecin Regional Court on 29 November 2011.
- The applicant was transferred to Goleniów Prison on an unknown date and, on 6 December 2011, the Goleniów Prison Penitentiary Commission extended the “dangerous detainee” regime, keeping him in solitary confinement.
- The Szczecin Regional Court on 31 January 2012 quashed the decision and remitted the case to the commission, stating that the new decision was not justified and lacked reasoning.
- On 14 February 2012, the Goleniów Prison Penitentiary Commission lifted the “dangerous detainee” regime, after the applicant had been subjected to it for a total of five months and seven days.

title: CASE OF ROMANIUK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Sokołów Podlaski.
- Arrested and remanded in custody on 8 April 2009.
- Charged with murder, attempted murder, and illegal possession of firearms.
- Convicted of battery and attempted murder on 2 December 2011, and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment.
- The Białystok Court of Appeal upheld the first-instance judgment on 25 October 2012.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s cassation appeal on 8 November 2013.
- Classified as a “dangerous detainee” on 10 April 2009.
- Review of the decision was done every three months between 7 July 2009 and 7 January 2010.
- Commission reiterated the same reason for classifying him as a “dangerous detainee” in the reviews.
- Applicant lodged an appeal against the decision of 30 September 2011.
- The Białystok Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 13 December 2011.
- The application of the “dangerous detainee” regime was extended to the applicant for the eleventh time on 29 December 2011.
- The commission lifted the “dangerous detainee” regime in respect of the applicant on 29 March 2012.

title: CASE OF BORG v. MALTA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1976 and is currently detained at the Corradino Correctional Facility in Paola.
- Maltese law did not provide for legal assistance during pre-trial investigations and specifically during questioning prior to the introduction of the right to legal assistance at the pre-trial stage in 2010.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of importation and trafficking of drugs (heroin) in relation to two episodes in March and April 2003.
- During questioning on 17 April 2003, after being duly cautioned about his right to remain silent, the applicant gave a statement to the police without a lawyer present, which he refused to sign.
- The applicant was arraigned before the Court of Magistrates as a Court of Criminal Inquiry on 17 April 2003 and his statement was exhibited as evidence against him.
- Two other statements implicating the applicant, given by two prosecution witnesses who had also not been legally assisted during the police investigation into their case, were also produced by the prosecution.
- The same magistrate who had conducted the in genere inquiry was also the magistrate who had conducted the compilation of evidence in the committal proceedings.
- The applicant was found guilty of importing, causing to be imported, or taking steps preparatory to the importation, of heroin between February and 15 April 2003; that between February and April 2003 he conspired with other persons to import, sell or traffic heroin, or promoted, constituted, organised or financed such a conspiracy; and that in the same period he had in his possession the drug heroin in circumstances which indicated that it was not for his exclusive use.
- The Criminal Court sentenced him to twenty-one years’ imprisonment and a fine of 70,000 euros (EUR).
- The applicant appealed, claiming an incorrect application of the law (unrelated to legal assistance), a wrong assessment of the facts, and a disproportionate punishment.
- The applicant's appeal was dismissed and the first-instance judgment confirmed by the Court of Criminal Appeal.
- The applicant claimed a breach of his right to a fair trial (Article 6 § 3 (c)) on account of the lack of legal assistance during the investigation and interrogation and that the same magistrate who had conducted the in genere inquiry was also the magistrate who had conducted the compilation of evidence in the committal proceedings.
- The applicant's claims were rejected by the Civil Court (First Hall) in its constitutional competence.

title: CASE OF MOXAMED ISMAACIIL AND ABDIRAHMAN WARSAME v. MALTA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1988 and 1992 and were detained in Hermes Block, Lyster Barracks Detention Centre.
- First applicant entered Malta irregularly by boat on 16 August 2012 and was registered by the immigration police and given an identification number (12U-007).
- She was presented with two documents, one containing a Return Decision and the other a Removal Order, in English. She claimed she could not understand the language.
- She was provided with an information leaflet entitled “Your entitlements, responsibilities and obligations while in detention”. She claimed that the document was provided in a language she could not understand.
- The first applicant was detained in accordance with Article 14 (2) of the Immigration Act.
- Second applicant also entered Malta irregularly by boat on 16 August 2012 and was registered by the immigration police and given an identification number (12U-009).
- Second applicant was presented with two documents, one containing a Return Decision and the other a Removal Order, in English. She claimed she could not understand the language.
- She was provided with an information leaflet entitled “Your entitlements, responsibilities and obligations while in detention”. She claimed that the document was provided in a language she could not understand.
- The second applicant was detained in accordance with Article 14 (2) of the Immigration Act.
- Both the applicants were assisted in submitting the Preliminary Questionnaire (PQ).
- Their applications for refugee status were rejected, and they appealed against the decision.
- No decision was issued, and the applicants were hoping to be released on the lapse of twelve months from their arrival.
- Applicants faced prison-like and basic conditions of detention, which included overcrowding, lack of cleanliness, and poor food and medical care.
- The first applicant was released from detention on 14 August 2013.
- The second applicant was released from detention on 14 August 2013 and her appeal was eventually rejected on 14 July 2014.

title: CASE OF MIRACLE EUROPE KFT v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is a limited liability company registered under Hungarian law, based in Budapest.
- In January 2012, the applicant brought an action in damages against a university regarding a construction project envisaged in public procurement.
- The President of the territorially competent Budapest High Court requested the National Judicial Office (“NJO”) to reassign the case to another court due to the backlog of judges and the high importance of the case.
- The President of the NJO examined the case-load statistics of the Budapest High Court and found that the case could only be ensured to be adjudicated within a reasonable time by reassigning it to another court.
- The case was reassigned to the Zalaegerszeg High Court on 16 February 2012 for judicial economy.
- The Zalaegerszeg High Court heard the case and dismissed the claim on 5 June 2012.
- The National Judicial Council issued guidelines for case reassignment in September 2012.
- The Kúria upheld the decisions of the High Court and the Court of Appeal in review proceedings on 7 September 2013.
- The applicant filed a constitutional complaint on 13 December 2012, which was declared inadmissible on 10 June 2013.
- The Constitutional Court held that the regulations which entitled the President of the NJO to reassign cases among courts had been unconstitutional and in violation of Article 6 of the Convention on 2 December 2013.
- The Constitutional Court did not prescribe any legal consequence of this decision for the ongoing procedures concerned by reassignment.

title: CASE OF ESCALDA FERREIRA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- Bank C. brought enforcement proceedings against the applicant for unpaid debt
- The applicant's mortgaged apartment was seized by the bank
- Judicial enforcement officer was appointed as depositary responsible for enforcement proceedings
- Applicant lodged a complaint about the judicial enforcement officer's inactivity in the proceedings
- Applicant complained to Commission for the Efficiency of Executions about the conduct of the judicial enforcement officer
- Commission initiated disciplinary proceedings against the judicial enforcement officer
- Setúbal Court removed the judicial enforcement officer from his post for professional negligence and appointed a new one
- The proceedings are still pending as of 8 July 2014.

title: CASE OF FREITAS v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Porto.
- On 28 August 1996, the applicant filed an action for the settlement of accounts in inventory proceedings before the Penafiel Court.
- The administrator of the estate was notified, challenged the action, and submitted the accounts between 20 December 1996 to 24 April 1997, which were contested by the applicant.
- The judge set out the established and outstanding matters on 23 February 1998.
- Evidence submitted by the parties was admitted by the Penafiel Court on 17 June 1998.
- The applicant revoked the power of attorney on 17 September 1998 and requested legal aid on 6 November 1998.
- The hearing scheduled for 24 March 1999 was adjourned at the applicant's representative's request on 19 March 1999.
- The hearing was adjourned on 19 October 1999 because the administrator representative failed to appear, and it was rescheduled for 9 May 2000.
- On 2 May 2000, the applicant requested to represent herself in the proceedings.
- The applicant's request was granted on 9 May 2000, and the first hearing was held.
- On 5 June 2000, the court adopted a decision with regard to the factual basis and, on 14 September 2000, it ruled against the applicant.
- The applicant appealed against the decision on 25 September 2000 before the Porto Court of Appeal, which remitted the case to the first-instance court on 5 June 2001.
- The proceedings were analyzed by the first-instance court to which they were remitted twice between 5 June 2001 and 23 June 2010.
- The case was lodged before the Porto Court of Appeal, the Supreme Court of Justice, and the Constitutional Court between 7 July 2010 and March 2013.
- The Constitutional Court adopted the final decision on 10 May 2013.
- The applicant also filed an inventory proceedings before the Porto Court on 23 November 1995.
- On 23 May 1997, a conference between the parties started which was ultimately adjourned on 25 June 1997.
- Between 4 December 1997 and 23 June 1998, procedural steps were taken in view of the continuation of the proceedings against the deceased administrator of the estate.
- The conference of the parties was scheduled for 26 May

title: CASE OF SINDELY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple born in 1952 and 1954 residing in Piliscsaba.
- The first applicant was deliberately shot by a colleague on 7 December 2001, causing severe injuries and making him disabled.
- The applicants filed a damages action against the employer in 2004, which the Pest County Labour Court ordered to be prioritized on 14 June 2005.
- On 19 January 2006, an interim judgment was reached by the Pest County Labour Court that recognized the validity of the legal basis of the claim, and this decision was reaffirmed by Pest County Court on 5 January 2007.
- On 9 November 2010, the Pest County Labour Court determined the exact amount of compensation to be paid by the employer, and this decision was upheld and modified by the final ruling of the Pest County Court on 4 May 2011.

title: CASE OF KARPOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was convicted of a drug offence on 19 December 2005 and sentenced to three years’ imprisonment.
- On 21 December 2006, the Presidium of the Belgorod Regional Court quashed the conviction by way of a supervisory review and ordered a new trial.
- The Presidium authorized the applicant’s release on an undertaking to appear, and a copy of the decision was sent by regular mail and received by the applicant's detention facility on 9 January 2007.
- The applicant was released on 15 January 2007 after receiving a certified copy of the decision.
- On 5 June 2007, the applicant was acquitted of all charges.
- The applicant complained to a court seeking a declaration that the delay in her release from prison covering the period from 21 December 2006 to 15 January 2007 had been unlawful.
- On 25 April 2007, the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Belgorod held that the applicant had been unlawfully detained from 9 to 15 January 2007.
- In August 2009, the applicant sought compensation for the unlawful prosecution, and the Sverdlovskiy District Court awarded her 170,000 roubles (approximately 4,300 euros at the material time) on 15 October 2009.
- The judgment was upheld on appeal by the Belgorod Regional Court on 22 December 2009, and the award was paid in full in April 2010.

title: CASE OF RODZEVILLO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant is serving a life sentence in a correctional colony.
- Applicant was arrested on suspicion of forming a criminal association and committing multiple crimes.
- The court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- Applicant was remanded in custody and detained in a pre-trial detention center.
- Applicant complained of degrading conditions in the detention center. 
- Applicant's requests for medical treatment and a solitary cell were ignored or rejected.
- Applicant wrote to authorities regarding the conditions of his detention which received no response or denial of any breaches of law.
- The Government claimed that the conditions in the detention center were adequate and provided evidence of cell dimensions and equipment.
- Detainees had access to weekly bathing facilities, regulated meals, and medical attention.
- Applicant was moved to the Ladyzhynska Colony and claimed to be denied medical services.
- Applicant lodged complaints regarding breaches of his rights in the Ladyzhynska Colony.
- The Government claimed the conditions were fair and the applicant received regular medical attention.
- Applicant claimed to be severely beaten by guards in 2006, but the prosecutor's office denied receiving any complaints.
- Applicant filed numerous requests for a transfer to a detention facility closer to his hometown for family visits which were denied.
- The Prison Department cited rules and lack of space as reasons for the denial of transfer requests.

title: CASE OF STABROVSKA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Kyiv born in 1950.
- On 22 July 2006, the applicant's son left home and did not return.
- A man with the same surname as the applicant's son was found severely injured and unconscious on the same day in Kyiv. He later died in the hospital on 29 July.
- On 31 July 2006, the applicant reported her son's disappearance to the police.
- The body of the unidentified man found in the street was buried in a municipal cemetery on 18 September 2006.
- In March 2007, the police showed the applicant a photograph of the man found in the street who closely resembled her son.
- Two DNA examinations confirmed with 98.73% certainty that the body found in the street was that of the applicant's son.
- The Prosecutor's Office took several decisions not to open investigations related to the disappearance and death of the applicant's son.
- The decisions were quashed by the supervising courts or prosecutors, and further pre-investigation enquiries were ordered.
- The last decision of 9 August 2012 refused to open criminal proceedings as there was no evidence of violence and the incident did not appear to have had any criminal element.

title: CASE OF BUDAN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1996 and lived in Zhovten village.
- On 21 May 2012, the applicant and his cousin travelled to Donetsk and on 24 May 2012, they snatched a handbag from a lady in Donetsk.
- The police arrested the applicant and his cousin, M., on 25 May 2012 and assigned lawyer L. as the applicant’s defence counsel.
- On 26 May 2012, the applicant was sent to the Donetsk ITT.
- On 28 May 2012, the police charged the applicant with robbery and requested his pre-trial detention.
- On 1 June 2012, the court ordered the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- On 13 June 2012, the Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision of 1 June 2012.
- On 1 March 2013, the Kyivskyy District Court of Donetsk sentenced the applicant to one year of imprisonment for robbery.
- The applicant claimed that the police had forced him to sign documents under duress on 24, 25, and 26 May 2012.
- The Code of Criminal Procedure outlined grounds for arrest (Article 106), purpose and grounds for preventive measures (Article 148), preventive measures (Article 149), and detention and placement in custody of a minor (Article 434).
- A minor can be released under the supervision of parents, guardians, or the administration of a residential facility for children (Article 436).
- Relevant international material is summarised in Korneykova v. Ukraine (no. 39884/05, §§ 25-27, 19 January 2012).

title: CASE OF SHEPELENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicants are spouses, born in 1960 and 1961, respectively, living in a village in the Odessa Region.
- Their son, born in 1982, died in a traffic accident on 18 June 1997, allegedly caused by the driver, D., who compelled him to sit in the vehicle and exceeded the speed limit.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against D. on 20 June 1997, and he was charged with violating traffic safety rules and causing the death of the applicant’s son on 1 October 1997.
- D. was put in custody as a preventive measure on the same day, as his whereabouts were unknown, and later placed on the list of wanted persons.
- In April 1998, D. changed his preventive measure from pre-trial detention to a written undertaking not to abscond.
- In June 1998, the first applicant brought civil claims for damages, which were joined to the criminal case file, and in July 1998, the case was referred to the District Court for consideration on the merits.
- On 14 May 2010, the District Court dismissed the civil claims without considering them on the merits, and the applicants appealed.
- On 22 May 2013, the District Court partly allowed the applicants’ civil claims, awarding each applicant 400,000 Ukrainian hryvnias (UAH) in respect of non-pecuniary damage and a further UAH 16,050 to the first applicant in respect of pecuniary damage. 
- The Odessa Court of Appeal reduced the non-pecuniary damage award to UAH 50,000 for each applicant, and the Higher Specialised Court for Civil and Criminal Matters dismissed a subsequent appeal by the applicants to increase the damages.
- The State Bailiffs Service returned letters of execution to the applicants on 24 June 2014, stating that no funds or property belonging to D. could be found.

title: CASE OF GÜLCÜ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1992 and lives in Diyarbakır.
- On 14 July 2008, there was a demonstration in Diyarbakır to protest about the conditions of detention of Abdullah Öcalan.
- The police had received information that the Diyarbakır branch of the DTP was the organiser of the press statement to be held.
- The police took necessary measures as they suspected that there could be violent protests during the march.
- The crowd chanted slogans praising Abdullah Öcalan and carried banners and flags in support of the PKK.
- The police had to use proportionate force against the group, who were holding an illegal demonstration.
- The applicant was arrested on 21 July 2008.
- According to the video recording of the demonstration by the police, the applicant had thrown stones at the police officers and had been in the crowd which had taken down the Turkish flag in a schoolyard.
- On 22 July 2008, the applicant made statements before the Diyarbakır public prosecutor in the presence of a lawyer.
- On the same day, the applicant was brought before a judge of the Fifth Division of Diyarbakır Assize Court and remanded in custody.
- On 22 July 2008, the Diyarbakır public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment against the applicant.
- The applicant was charged with membership of an illegal organization, resisting the security forces by way of throwing stones, disseminating propaganda in support of the PKK, and denigration of the symbols of the sovereignty of the State.
- On 11 November 2008, the Fifth Division of Diyarbakır Assize Court rendered its judgment in the case against the applicant.

title: CASE OF KALDA v. ESTONIA
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant is serving a life sentence in prison.
- The applicant requested access to the online version of the State Gazette, decisions of the Supreme Court and administrative courts, and the HUDOC database of the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights, but the prison administration refused his request.
- The Pärnu Administrative Court and the Tallinn Court of Appeal dismissed his complaint, but he appealed to the Supreme Court.
- The Supreme Court found that access to Estonian legislation and the Supreme Court’s rulings was available in the paper version of the State Gazette, but the prison had a duty to ensure that detainees had a reasonable possibility of searching for and familiarizing themselves with legal acts.
- The refusal of the prison administration to grant detainees access to the rulings of the administrative courts and the European Court of Human Rights interfered with their right to freely obtain information disseminated for public use, a right enshrined in Article 44 § 1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Estonia.
- The Tartu Administrative Court ordered Tartu Prison to grant supervised access to the Internet site www.coe.ee via a computer adapted for that purpose.
- Both parties appealed, and the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal and upheld Tartu Prison’s appeal.
- The Supreme Court found that section 31-1 of the Imprisonment Act interferes with the right to freely obtain information disseminated for public use.
- The Supreme Court found that the prohibition of detainees’ access to the Internet sites www.coe.ee, www.oiguskantsler.ee and www.riigikogu.ee was justified by the need to achieve the aims of imprisonment and in particular the need to secure public safety.
- Four out of eighteen judges delivered a dissenting opinion concluded that the restriction in question was unconstitutional.

title: CASE OF ALBRECHTAS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and was released from prison in January 2015.
- A businessman named R.G. was killed on 26 May 1995 by a bomb under his car.
- A certain G.B. accused O.L. of ordering R.G.'s murder while being accused of his involvement in the crime on 15 October 1998.
- G.B. changed his testimony on 29 October 1998, claiming that the contract to murder R.G. had been put out by "Alius from Kaunas".
- The prosecutor suspected that the applicant, who had a prior conviction dating from 1985, had been involved in R.G.'s murder from this point in time.
- Some individuals were convicted of R.G.'s murder on 21 October 2001, but O.L. remained in hiding.
- On 1 March 2002, based on G.B.'s testimony, the prosecutor concluded that "Alius" was likely the applicant.
- The applicant was arrested on 25 May 2005, and the prosecutor issued a notice of suspicion that same day.
- The prosecutor requested that the applicant be detained pending trial on 26 May 2005, citing the severity of the penalty that the crime could attract, the need to carry out more investigative steps, and the fact that the applicant had been hiding from the prosecutor for two years.
- The Vilnius City Second District Court granted the prosecutor's request for the applicant's detention on 26 May 2005.
- G.B. identified the applicant as "Alius" in an identity parade on 7 June 2005.
- G.B. was offered a bribe not to identify the applicant as the person who had put out the contract on R.G.'s murder by another prisoner on 15 June 2005.

title: CASE OF AURELIAN OPREA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was a member of the teaching staff at a state university
- The applicant submitted requests for a new professor position, but it was denied
- The applicant was a member of a non-profit organization aimed at stopping the degradation of education 
- A journalist published two articles about corruption at the university, mentioning the applicant and a colleague 
- The applicant disclosed cases of corruption in his own university at a press conference organized by the non-profit organization 
- The defendant lodged a complaint against the applicant for defamation 
- The District Court dismissed the complaint, stating that the defendant did not prove the truth of his statements, but the applicant did not act with the intention to damage the defendant's reputation

title: CASE OF BORIS KOSTADINOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lives in Sofia
- On 28 June 2008, a Gay Pride parade took place in Sofia
- The police protected the parade from extreme right and nationalist groups who had threatened to disrupt it
- The applicant and six friends were crossing a public park when they were intercepted by two police vans
- The police ordered the group to put down their bottles and lie down on the ground
- The applicant alleges that the police hit and kicked him and pressed his head against the ground
- The police made more than 80 arrests
- The applicant and other members of the group were detained in a police bus and taken to a nearby police station
- The applicant was not given food, drink, or allowed to go to the toilet
- The applicant was released at 3.25 a.m. on 29 June 2008
- The applicant was examined by a medical doctor who noted several injuries on him
- The head of the police department gave the applicant an administrative fine for not obeying the police order to disperse, but this decision was later quashed
- The applicant complained to the Sofia Military Prosecutor’s Office of his alleged ill-treatment by the police
- The military investigator obtained written statements from police officers who had taken part in the operation, the applicant, and witnesses suggested by the applicant
- The Sofia Military Prosecutor’s Office refused to open criminal proceedings pursuant to the applicant’s complaint
- The applicant appealed against this decision
- Following a further appeal, the case was referred to the Sofia District Prosecutor’s Office
- Additional inquiries were ordered to ascertain the identity of all police officers who had come into physical contact with the applicant and the origin of all of the injuries noted on him

title: CASE OF IVANOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The Additional Requirement for Public Office Act was passed in 2008, making non-collaboration with the State security services a requirement for holding public office.
- Public officials and candidates for public office were required to submit a declaration stating that they had not collaborated with the State security services in a certain screening period.
- The Lustration Act established a Facts Verification Commission to examine the veracity of these declarations.
- Amendments to the Lustration Act were made in 2009 and 2011, leading to debate and petitions for abstract constitutional review.
- In 2010, the Constitutional Court invalidated certain provisions of the Lustration Act as unconstitutional and suspended their application.
- The applicant, as the President of the Constitutional Court at the time, was found to have submitted a false declaration by the Lustration Commission in 2010.
- The Lustration Act was repealed in 2012 and replaced with a new Lustration Act in 2012.
- The Act Repealing the 2012 Lustration Act was enacted in 2015, allowing the Lustration Commission to complete ongoing proceedings but no longer institute new ones.
- The applicant was a judge of the Constitutional Court and was dismissed as a result of lustration proceedings in 2011.
- The media reported the identification of the applicant as a collaborator with the State security services during the lustration proceedings.

title: CASE OF SIREDZHUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a history professor who conducted research and field studies resulting in a manuscript on the history and archaeology of the Kosiv area.
- A private publishing house published the manuscript under the title The Kosiv Area Antiquities with the intention of distributing it to libraries and local schools.
- The applicant's essay in the book included a text that made unsubstantiated allegations against a local official, who then filed a defamation claim seeking a retraction of the passage and compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The court found the disputed statements to be false and defamatory, and ordered the publishing house to retract them and reprint the book without the passage at the applicant's expense.
- The court also awarded the official compensation in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- The applicant lodged a "cassation appeal" against the judgment but it was dismissed by the regional court.
- The case was remitted to the City Court for fresh examination after a supervisory review, and the applicant lodged a counterclaim against the official in the defamation proceedings.
- The City Court allowed the official's claim in part and dismissed the applicant's counterclaim, and ordered the publishing house to publish erratum sheets retracting the false statements.
- The applicant appealed the City Court's decision, which was upheld by the Regional Court with respect to the official's claim but remitted the applicant's counterclaim for fresh examination by the City Court.

title: CASE OF SAFARYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant owned a plot of land, two houses, and a garage in Yerevan. She shared her household with her four children.
- The applicant built a pavilion on her plot of land without permission and used it for trade. The ownership certificate issued to her referred to the pavilion as a “half-ruined construction”.
- The Government adopted a decree to approve the expropriation zones of the real estate situated within the administrative boundaries of the Kentron District of Yerevan, which included the applicant's plot of land.
- The applicant applied to donate her property to her four children, but the request was refused by the notary office due to the expropriation zone.
- The applicant contested the notary office's refusal before the courts and won the case.
- The applicant applied to the State Real Estate Registry to divide her property into four parts and transfer ownership to her children, but the request was refused due to the expropriation zone and unauthorised constructions present on the plot.
- The applicant contested the refusal before the courts but lost the case. 
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant’s appeal on the same grounds.

title: CASE OF GHUYUMCHYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicants are the son, daughter-in-law, and wife of the late Garegin Ghuyumchyan
- They were born in 1965, 1973, and 1947 respectively and live in Vanadzor, Armenia.
- The third applicant and Garegin Ghuyumchyan ran a printing house and a small spirit factory as a family business.
- On 19 July 2002, Garegin Ghuyumchyan was charged with bribe‑taking and made an undertaking not to leave his residence. A truck and a television set belonging to him were seized.
- On 25 September 2002, the investigating authority decided to dismiss the charge against Garegin Ghuyumchyan for lack of evidence, lifted the seizure and canceled the undertaking.
- In 2004, Garegin Ghuyumchyan and the third applicant sold the family business to a private person.
- On 29 October 2004, Garegin Ghuyumchyan instituted proceedings seeking compensation for wrongful prosecution.
- On 9 January 2006, Garegin Ghuyumchyan supplemented his claim, alleging that as a result of the prosecution, the first and the second applicants had to leave their jobs.
- On 18 May 2006, the Lori Regional Court granted the claim in part, ordering reimbursement of legal costs and part of the transport costs.
- On 27 July 2006, the Chairman of the Chamber of Advocates of Armenia informed him that the Advocacy Act did not provide for legal aid for the type of proceedings in which he was involved.
- On 26 January 2007, the Civil Court of Appeal delivered its judgment upholding the judgment of the Regional Court in respect of the reimbursement of part of the travel costs as well as legal fees, but dismissing the rest of the claim.
- On 22 June 2007, Garegin Ghuyumchyan lodged an appeal with the Court of Cassation against the judgment of the Court of Appeal.
- By a letter of 28 June 2007, the Chief Registrar of the Court of Cassation returned the appeal, informing him that it had not been admitted for examination as it had not been lodged by an advocate licensed to act before the Court of Cassation.
- On 29 October 2007, Garegin Ghuyumchyan and the first and the second applicants lodged an introductory letter with the Court.
- On 3 November 200

title: CASE OF TOVMASYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Yerevan who is unemployed and receives state welfare benefit.
- In 1991, the Mashtots District Council of People’s Deputies allocated a flat to the applicant in a building that was to be constructed by Kanaz Aluminium Factory.
- Construction of the building was stopped due to the collapse of the Soviet Union, and the Factory eventually went bankrupt.
- The applicant requested either a flat or compensation equivalent to its value from the liquidation commission, but her request was rejected due to lack of financial means.
- The applicant lodged a claim seeking to oblige the Factory to allocate a flat or provide her with compensation, which was dismissed by the District Court and upheld by the Civil Court of Appeal.
- The applicant did not appeal to the Court of Cassation due to inability to afford legal representation and lack of access to legal aid.

title: CASE OF BALAKIN v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Chişinău.
- On 21 August 2009, the applicant was arrested and charged with the offence of producing and putting into circulation counterfeit money.
- The applicant remained remanded in custody pending criminal investigation and trial.
- The detention warrants were prolonged every month and then every three months by the Ialoveni District Court.
- The reasons given for the detention were the seriousness of the offence, complexity of the case, possibility of interference with the investigation, collusion with other co-accused, or absconding or re-offending.
- The applicant's appeals against the extensions of detention were rejected by the Court of Appeal.
- The last two extensions of detention before the case lodged with present application took place in May and August 2011.
- The applicant argued that no risk of interference with the investigation, absconding or re-offending.
- Applicant agreed to be under house arrest if not released.
- According to Article 186 § 8 of Code of Criminal Procedure, detention could not last for more than six months once the case referred to court, other than in exceptional cases.
- The Ialoveni District Court dismissed the applicant’s arguments and extended his detention for a further three months, stating the case was exceptional under Article 186 § 9 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 30 January 2012, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment.
- The final outcome of the criminal proceedings is unknown, as the Court has not been informed.

title: CASE OF SALIKHOVA AND MAGOMEDOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are the mother and wife of Mr Sakhrab Abakargadzhiyev.
- Mr Sakhrab Abakargadzhiyev was suspected of illegal activities before his abduction.
- Mr Sakhrab Abakargadzhiyev was abducted by a group of eight armed men who were driving two civilian vehicles, a silver-colored VAZ-21014, and a black VAZ-21099.
- The applicants identified one of the abductors as a CPE officer named "Shakir."
- A burnt male corpse was found about a month after the abduction, which was later identified as Mr Sakhrab Abakargadzhiyev's body.
- The Government did not dispute the facts presented by the applicants but denied any involvement of State agents in the incident.
- The investigation file includes several steps taken by the authorities, including questioning witnesses and collecting evidence, such as fingerprints and call logs.

title: CASE OF R. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained in a special facility for foreign nationals in Moscow.
- The applicant is an ethnic Uzbek who lived in Jalal-Abad Region, Kyrgyzstan, and was present at the barricades raised by ethnic Uzbeks near Suzak village in June 2010.
- The applicant was wounded by a Molotov cocktail during the inter-ethnic clashes of June 2010 and was admitted to hospital on account of severe burns before eventually fleeing Kyrgyzstan to Russia to avoid ethnically motivated violence.
- The Kyrgyz authorities opened a criminal case against the applicant charging him with violent crimes allegedly committed in the course of the riots of June 2010.
- On January 27, 2015, the applicant was arrested in Moscow on an administrative offense related to his entry and stay in the city.
- On March 12, 2015, the applicant was told by officials of the detention centre that he would be expelled from Russia on that day. However, he was later returned to the facility.
- On March 20, 2015, the Moscow City Court upheld the District Court’s decision on appeal and dismissed the applicant’s allegations of the risk of ill-treatment.
- The applicant applied for refugee status on February 4, 2015, which was dismissed by the Moscow FMS on March 12, 2015.
- The detainee has alleged that he was severely beaten by officers of a special police squad in the detention centre on February 24, 2015, and on February 26, 2015, lawyers reported the beatings to the main investigative department of the Moscow Investigative Committee.

title: CASE OF NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in Budapest in 1949.
- On 7 December 1995, the applicant was interrogated after being suspected of breach of duty and other offenses.
- The Budapest Regional Court acquitted the applicant on 5 November 2008, after criminal proceedings and a remittal.
- The Budapest Regional Court of Appeal upheld the acquittal on 26 November 2009, after an appeal was filed.

title: CASE OF KIRIL ANDREEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Pleven.
- He was arrested in Sofia on 25 April 2012 and charged with the unlawful possession of firearms and ammunition.
- He entered into a plea agreement with the prosecution and accepted a suspended sentence of two years’ imprisonment.
- The plea agreement was approved by the court on 7 June 2012, and the court ordered the discontinuation of the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- However, he was not released but was instead taken to a police station where he remained throughout the night and the next day.
- On 9 June 2012, he was transferred to the city of Pleven and was again placed in police custody.
- On 10 June 2012, the investigator brought charges against the applicant in connection with another count of unlawful possession of firearms.

title: CASE OF VASYUNETS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Kalush.
- On 4 November 2006, three individuals, including the applicant's daughter, were found dead in a room where they had been sleeping.
- A committee of five employees of the gas company conducted an internal inquiry into the incident and concluded that it had been caused by a strong wind and the mother's failure to check the heater.
- Between 14 November 2006 and 24 May 2012, the prosecutor's office refused eleven times to institute criminal proceedings in respect of the death, and all decisions were overruled by supervising prosecutors or courts.
- On 25 January 2013, a criminal investigation was initiated into the actions of the employees of the gas company on suspicion of neglect of official duties in connection with the death.
- The police twice discontinued the criminal investigation for lack of corpus delicti in the actions of the gas company's employees, but those decisions were overruled.

title: CASE OF DI TRIZIO v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- The applicant, born in 1977, lives in Rapperswil-Jona, Switzerland.
- She worked as a shop assistant until stopping due to back pain in June 2002.
- In October 2003, she applied for a disability benefit due to her back and spinal pain.
- She gave birth to twins in February 2004, which worsened her back pain.
- In March 2005, an assessment found her capacity to perform household tasks was reduced by 44.6%.
- In May 2006, the Office granted a benefit for a previous period but did not qualify for any benefit from September 2004 onwards.
- The applicant appealed this decision, arguing that the calculation of her degree of disability was unfair.
- The Insurance Court allowed the appeal in part, criticizing the Office's application of the combined method and remitting the case for further investigation.
- The Office appealed the Insurance Court's judgment.
- The Federal Court found that the combined method was not discriminatory but conceded that the interplay between household tasks and paid employment was not taken enough into account.
- The Federal Court ultimately denied the applicant a benefit due to her degree of disability not reaching the required minimum of 40%.

title: CASE OF AYDIN ÇETİNKAYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1964.
- In 1993, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to twenty-four years' imprisonment for murder.
- On March 8, 2002, the applicant was conditionally released from prison.
- On March 23, 2002, at 8.40 pm, the applicant was arrested at his home on suspicion of leading a criminal organization and involvement in the attempted abduction of a certain Ş.H. and his son, H.H.
- Medical examinations were conducted on the applicant on Mar. 24th, 25th, 26th, and 27th, 2002, where multiple injuries were noted on the applicant's body, which rendered him unfit to carry out daily activities for three days.
- The applicant alleged ill-treatment and torture throughout his detention in police custody, including physical assault, electric shocks, being stretched, blindfolded, and handcuffed for five days.
- On March 24, 2002, eight police officers and the applicant signed an incident report according to which the applicant was kept attached to a bed to prevent him from harming himself, during which he hit his head on the floor.
- In August 2003, a medical report was drafted, concluding that the applicant's injuries had occurred as a result of his own conduct.
- On Feb. 15, 2005, the first-instance court adjourned the hearing as the video footage requested during the previous hearing had not been received.

title: CASE OF DRĂGAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and is currently detained in Giurgiu Prison.
- The applicant had been convicted several times and had been detained in various prisons for the last nine years.
- The applicant was convicted by the Arad County Court on two counts of robbery and theft and sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant complained of severe overcrowding, poor quality food and drinking water, as well as lack of necessary clothes, toiletries, and hot water for brushing teeth in Galaţi, Rahova, and Jilava prisons.
- The applicant had periods of detention in different cells, with limited personal space and shared accommodation with up to fifteen people.
- The applicant had various dental and health problems for which he was treated on multiple occasions, mostly symptomatically.
- The applicant received one roll of toilet paper, a razor, and one tube of shaving cream while spending twenty-two days in Jilava Prison.
- Throughout his detention, the applicant received no visits, was considered unfit for work, and did not have any income.
- The applicant lodged numerous complaints with the prison authorities that were rejected as ill-founded.
- The applicant complained of ill-treatment by a prison guard on 14 February 2013 and lodged a criminal complaint, which was not pursued by the prosecutor's office.

title: CASE OF N.TS. AND OTHERS v. GEORGIA
facts:
- Ms N.Ts. is a Georgian national who lives in Tbilisi.
- Her three nephews – N.B., and twin boys, S.B. and L.B. – were born in 2002 and 2006 respectively.
- Ms N.Ts.'s sister started a relationship with G.B. in 2000, and the couple moved in together. They had three children, N.B., S.B. and L.B.
- G.B was convicted of drug abuse and diagnosed with psychiatric and behavioural disorders.
- In 2009 G.B. requested the return of the boys, but the maternal family refused his request.
- G.B's addiction went into remission in February 2010.
- On 5 January 2010, G.B. asked the Tbilisi City Court under Article 1204 of the Civil Code to order the return of his sons.
- The Social Service Agency (“the SSA”) was involved in the proceedings, and an assessment was conducted by the Vake-Saburtalo regional branch of the SSA.
- The boys were diagnosed with separation anxiety disorder and were in need of a stable and safe environment, according to a psychological report.
- The Tbilisi City Court ordered the three boys to be returned to their father.
- The Tbilisi Court of Appeal overturned the decision of the first-instance court and ruled that the children should stay with their maternal family.
- The Supreme Court of Georgia remitted the case to the appeal court for re-examination.

title: CASE OF MAGYAR TARTALOMSZOLGÁLTATÓK EGYESÜLETE AND INDEX.HU ZRT v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The first applicant is an association monitoring the implementation of a professional code of Internet content providing and a code of ethics, operating an arbitration commission whose decisions are binding on its eleven members.
- The second applicant owns one of the major Internet news portals in Hungary.
- Both applicants allowed users to comment on their portals, which were not previously edited or moderated by the applicants.
- Both applicants put in place a system of notice-and-take-down, namely, any reader could notify the service provider of any comment of concern and request its deletion.
- Both portals stated that comments infringing the personality rights of others could not be uploaded on the websites.
- On 5 February 2010, MTE published an opinion under the title “Another unethical commercial conduct on the net” about two real estate management websites, owned by the same company.
- The opinion attracted some comments of users, acting under pseudonyms, amongst which there were some offensive and insulting ones.
- The company operating the websites concerned brought a civil action before the Budapest Regional Court against the applicants and Zöld Újság Zrt.
- The Regional Court partially sustained the claim, holding that the plaintiff’s right to good reputation had been infringed.
- Both parties appealed.
- The Budapest Court of Appeal upheld the first-instance decision but amended its reasoning.
- The Kúria upheld the previous judgments.
- The courts’ rulings held the applicants responsible for the content of the comments and held them liable for enabling their publication.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the constitutional complaint, stating that the liability incumbent on the operator of the webpage obviously restricts freedom of the press, but the legislation pursues a constitutionally justified aim.

title: CASE OF GÜRBÜZ AND ÖZÇELİK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1975 and 1976 and are currently serving their prison sentence in the Tekirdağ Prison. 
- The applicants were arrested on 13 April 1998 on suspicion of membership in an illegal organization. 
- The first applicant gave police statements on 14 and 16 April 1998, without the presence of a lawyer. 
- The second applicant was interrogated by the police on 15 April 1998 and used his right to remain silent. 
- The applicants were examined at the Istanbul Forensic Medicine Institute on 19 April 1998 and there was no trace of ill-treatment on their bodies. 
- In the absence of a lawyer, the applicants were brought before the public prosecutor and investigating judge on the same day. 
- Both applicants gave statements and the second applicant complained of ill-treatment in police custody. 
- The investigating judge remanded the applicants in custody. 
- The Public Prosecutor filed an indictment on 30 April 1998, seeking the death penalty under Article 125 of the Criminal Code. 
- The Istanbul State Security Court held a preparatory hearing on 4 May 1998 and ordered the detention on remand to continue.
- Between 6 July 1998 and 26 May 1999, the Istanbul State Security Court held seven more hearings with two civilian judges and a military judge. 
- After the constitution was amended on 18 June 1999, a military judge was replaced by a civilian judge, and twenty more hearings were held. 
- Throughout the hearings, the applicants claimed they were ill-treated under police custody. 
- The Istanbul State Security Court, consisting of three civilian judges, found the applicants guilty on 24 September 2003 under Article 125 of the Criminal Code and sentenced them to life imprisonment. 
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the Istanbul State Security Court on 24 March 2004.

title: CASE OF KAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lived in Bolu.
- At the time of the incident, he was a military official.
- On 18 February and 24 February 2011, the applicant's superiors imposed disciplinary penalties.
- The penalties included administrative restriction for 8 days and room confinement for 5 days.
- The penalties were enforced on three separate occasions between April and May 2011, totaling 13 days.

title: CASE OF BINDER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Vienna. 
- On 29 January 2004 the applicant applied for rent allowance (Mietbeihilfe) under the Vienna Social Welfare Act (Wiener Sozialhilfegesetz). 
- On 13 July 2004 the Vienna Municipal Authority (Magistrat der Stadt Wien) dismissed the applicant’s request, holding that the applicant was not eligible for rent allowance as his income exceeded the statutory limit (Richtsatzüberschreitung). 
- The applicant appealed and complained that the Municipal Authority had failed to take into account his maintenance obligations towards his two sons. 
- On 10 August 2004 the Vienna Regional Government (Amt der Wiener Landesregierung) dismissed the appeal, holding that maintenance obligations were, according to the Administrative Court’s case-law, not to be considered as income-reducing, as long as no enforcement proceedings were instituted against the applicant’s income. 
- The Constitutional Court granted the applicant’s request for legal aid on 6 October 2004. 
- On 8 November 2004, the applicant filed a complaint with the Constitutional Court. 
- On 1 March 2005, the Constitutional Court declined to deal with the applicant’s complaint, holding that it did not raise any questions of constitutional law and transferred the case to the Administrative Court. 
- On 11 May 2005, the applicant submitted his amended complaint to the Administrative Court. 
- On 23 February 2009, the Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint as unfounded, stating that the applicant failed to argue that he was in a state of emergency due to enforcement proceedings being conducted in connection to his maintenance obligations.  
- The decision was served on the applicant’s counsel on 13 March 2009.

title: CASE OF GROSSMANN AIR SERVICE BEDARFSLUFTFAHRTUNTERNEHMEN GMBH & CO KG v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant company is registered in Austria and has its seat in Vienna.
- In 1998, a public call for tenders was made regarding flight services for delegations of the Federal Government.
- The applicant company complained about the public tender being tailored towards the L. company, and it was revoked.
- An amended public call for tenders was issued, which the applicant company did not submit an offer to.
- The contract was awarded to the L. company on 8 October 1998.
- The applicant company requested to initiate review proceedings to declare the awarding of the contract null and void, which was rejected by Federal Procurement Authority on 4 January 1999.
- The applicant company filed a complaint with the Constitutional Court on 2 March 1999 and asked it to seek a preliminary ruling from the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) on the question of the existence of a legal interest.
- The Constitutional Court set aside the Federal Procurement Authority's decision on 10 December 2001.
- On 14 May 2002, the Federal Procurement Authority requested a preliminary ruling from the CJEU.
- The CJEU issued a preliminary ruling on 12 February 2004, in which a person who did not participate in the public tendering proceedings due to an allegedly discriminatory call may still request their review.
- The Federal Procurement Authority again rejected the applicant company’s request on 30 November 2004.
- On 26 September 2005, the Constitutional Court declined to deal with the applicant company’s complaint and transferred the case to the Administrative Court.
- On 29 October 2008, the Administrative Court set aside the Federal Procurement Authority’s decision.
- On 22 December 2009, the Federal Procurement Authority issued its decision, finding that awarding the contract to the L. company in the public tender proceedings had not been unlawful.
- The applicant company filed a complaint with the Administrative Court on 1 February 2010, which was declined on 25 March 2010.

title: CASE OF HILAL MAMMADOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is a mathematician and physicist who worked at the Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Azerbaijan.
- The applicant was assaulted by plain-clothes police officers on his way home.
- Narcotic substances were found in the applicant's possession during a search at the Narcotics Department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs.
- The applicant was detained in handcuffs and deprived of food and water.
- The applicant's pre-trial detention was extended for a period of four months.
- The applicant complained of ill-treatment during his arrest by the police.
- An investigation into the applicant's complaint of ill-treatment was conducted by a forensic commission.

title: CASE OF MESCEREACOV v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and is currently detained in Cricova.
- In 2002, the Prosecutor’s Office initiated a criminal investigation against the applicant on charges of murder and a detention warrant was issued by the Buiucani District Court.
- Since the applicant had left the country, an international search order was issued. 
- In December 2010, the applicant was arrested in the Russian Federation and extradited to Moldova, where he was placed in detention on the basis of the detention warrant of 14 February 2002. 
- The applicant lodged a habeas corpus request, but it was rejected on the ground that he had been in hiding and that he could abscond again. 
- The detention warrant was renewed several times, and the applicant’s appeals were rejected. The last decision in the proceedings concerning his remand in custody was issued by the Buiucani District Court on 27 May 2011. 
- During his detention, the applicant was jailed in Prison no. 13 in Chişinău between 29 December 2010 and 22 March 2012 and after 10 January 2013. 
- The cells were overcrowded and dirty, with no ventilation system and very small windows. 
- Each inmate only had between 1.5 and 2 square meters of available space in the cells, and the toilets were separated from the rest of the cells. 
- The inmates were allowed to take showers only once a week and were subjected to passive smoking.
- On 14 June 2011, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to eight years’ imprisonment. 
- The Centre for Human Rights in Moldova found that the prisons were overcrowded, with poor hygienic conditions, restricted access to health care and lack of medication, risk of contamination with tuberculosis and other diseases.

title: CASE OF NAZYROVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals who are close relatives of individuals who disappeared after being unlawfully detained by servicemen during special operations.
- The events concerned took place in areas under the full control of the Russian federal forces.
- Official investigations were opened but proceedings were repeatedly suspended and resumed, and have remained pending for several years without achieving any tangible results.
- Relevant State authorities were unable to identify the State servicemen allegedly involved in the arrests or abductions.
- The Government did not challenge the description of the circumstances of the abductions as presented by the applicants.
- Each account is based on statements provided by the applicants and their relatives and/or neighbours to both the Court and domestic investigative authorities.
- Mr Badrudi Nazyrov was abducted from the applicant's house and has not been seen since.
- Mr Muma Babuyev disappeared from a military base and has been missing since.
- Mr Ruslan Kagermanov was abducted by military servicemen from his home and has not been seen since.

title: CASE OF KHACHUKAYEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Ms Elita Khachukayeva, Ms Khadizhat Khachukayeva, and Ms Kheda Khachukayeva, who are the wife and daughters of Mr Islam Deniyev
- Mr Deniyev was abducted along with friends on November 24, 2000, at a roadblock near their village on a major highway
- Witnesses saw them taken to a military unit's headquarters and the applicants never saw Mr Deniyev again
- In August 2001, a blown-up shell of a car belonging to one of the abducted men was found in the north of Chechnya, and in November 2002, remains of three bodies and items of clothing were found in a forest and identified as belonging to the missing men
- The official investigation into the abduction was opened in February 2001, suspended and resumed multiple times, and combined with a murder case in 2008, but there were no significant results or identification of the perpetrators.

title: CASE OF SHLYCHKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a sentence for murder and robbery in IK-4 detention facility.
- On 6 March 2004, Ms E. was robbed and subsequently stabbed to death.
- The investigation revealed that the applicant had called from the victim's phone to a number belonging to Ms A. using his SIM card.
- The applicant was brought in for questioning, where he claimed to have purchased a second-hand phone and won the stolen amount from playing slot machines.
- The applicant was physically assaulted by the officers and made to sign a statement of surrender and confession.
- The trial judge refused to admit the interview record of the first interview on 19 March 2004 without a lawyer present.
- The applicant was convicted of murder and robbery after a trial, where he insisted on his innocence.
- The Supreme Court upheld the first-instance judgment.
- The applicant filed multiple complaints to the Prosecutor General's Office about the alleged ill-treatment.
- The deputy town prosecutor quashed the decision of 18 June 2004 and issued an instruction for an additional pre-investigation inquiry.

title: CASE OF ULYANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were targeted in undercover operations by the police.
- The operations were conducted in the form of a test purchase of drugs. 
- The operations were conducted under sections 7 and 8 of the Operational-Search Activities Act of 12 August 1995 (no. 144-FZ).
- The operations led to the criminal convictions of the applicants for drug dealing.
- Applicants disagreed with their convictions.
- Applicants argued that police had incited them to commit drug-related offenses.

title: CASE OF BALOGH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1971 and lived in Pécs, had been practicing as a lawyer.
- On 22 January 2006, Mr K.I. lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant on charges of abuse of a minor.
- Criminal investigation launched against the applicant around 7 August 2006.
- Public Prosecutor preferred a bill of indictment on 5 March 2007.
- Komárom-Esztergom County Bar Association suspended the applicant's license on 3 July 2007.
- Pécs District Court convicted the applicant of abuse of a minor and sentenced him to one year imprisonment with enforcement suspended for two years on 25 September 2008.
- Baranya County Regional Court quashed the judgment and ordered the first-instance court to try the case again on 10 February 2010. 
- Pécs District Court acquitted the applicant due to the absence of the proof on 2 July 2010.
- Applicant withdrew his appeal in early December 2010.

title: CASE OF BARANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants brought civil proceedings before Russian courts claiming various monetary sums related to their military or police service.
- Domestic courts found in favour of the applicants, and judgments became final and enforceable.
- Defendant authorities applied for supervisory review of those judgments.
- Supervisory review courts allowed authorities' applications and quashed final judgments in applicants' favour.
- Claims were dismissed either by supervisory review courts or lower courts in subsequent proceedings, except in two cases where claims were partially granted.
- In one case, proceedings were concluded after nine examinations by domestic courts.
- In some cases, authorities complied with judgments fully or partially prior to their quashing.
- In other cases, judgments in favour of applicants were never complied with.
- In one case, the authorities complied with the new judgment after a new round of proceedings.
- In one case, the pension paid to the applicant following the quashed judgments was recovered from him after supervisory review.

title: CASE OF POMILYAYKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's date of birth and place of residence.
- Equipment was stolen from the applicant's workplace in November 2008.
- The applicant and a colleague were called for questioning regarding the theft by the Kharkiv Ordzhonikidze District Police Department.
- On 8 November 2008, the applicant was questioned, handcuffed, and taken to an office where officers tried to pressure her into confessing to the theft.
- The applicant was strangled while a plastic bag was placed over her head, and physically abused by officers trying to make her confess.
- After several hours of abuse, the applicant was taken to another office for formal questioning.
- The applicant underwent hospital treatment for head injuries, soft tissue contusions, and bruising of the abdominal wall, and asthenia, a weakened physical state.
- The hospital administration informed the Ordzhonikidze Police Department, and the applicant filed a complaint, as did Ms L.
- The police department initially refused to open a criminal case but later opened one against the police officers.
- A forensic immunological examination of the applicant's trousers discovered traces of her urine on them.
- Two forensic medical expert evaluations of the applicant's injuries were conducted between November 2008 and April 2009.
- Officer T challenged the decision to open a criminal case against him.
- The case against the officers was closed in February 2010 due to a lack of proof of their guilt, but the decision was subsequently quashed on appeal.
- The applicant enquired about the progress of the investigation, but received no answer in March and May 2011.

title: CASE OF HUSEYNLI AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The first, second, and third applicants were members of the main opposition parties or groups in Azerbaijan.
- There were increased numbers of opposition demonstrations in Azerbaijan in 2011.
- The applicants participated in several opposition demonstrations and were arrested during many of them.
- The first applicant was arrested on suspicion of participating in a demonstration.
- The second and third applicants were arrested for minor hooliganism and breaching public order, respectively.
- The applicants were not provided with legal assistance during their arrests and proceedings.
- The courts found that each applicant had committed an administrative offense and sentenced them to seven days' detention.

title: CASE OF IBRAHIMOV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicants were born in 1988, 1989 and 1977 respectively. 
- The Committee for Protection of Rights of Young Political Prisoners decided to hold a demonstration demanding the release of young persons arrested during previous demonstrations without notifying the relevant authority.
- The police dispersed the demonstration shortly after it had begun.
- The applicants were caught, arrested, and taken to a police station.
- Administrative-offense reports were issued by police officer T.R., stating that the applicants had committed an administrative offense under Article 310 of the Code of Administrative Offences.
- All three applicants refused to sign the respective administrative-offense reports.
- Police officer T.R. prepared administrative-arrest reports in respect of the first and second applicants.
- The Sabail District Court convicted all three applicants under Article 310.1 of the Code of Administrative Offences.
- The Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal and upheld the decision of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF KARPYLENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's son, K., was arrested by the police on suspicion of robbery on 26 December 2009 and was subsequently remanded in custody pending trial.
- K. underwent a medical examination on 27 December 2009, which did not reveal any injuries.
- On 22 March 2010, K. complained to the court that the investigator had subjected him to physical and psychological pressure to confess to a crime he hadn't committed.
- On 10 April 2010, K. was hospitalized after being diagnosed with various injuries, including a closed abdominal injury, rupture of the spleen, retroperitoneal hematoma, and a closed chest injury, consistent with physical assault.
- Several investigations were launched between 2010 and 2014 to determine whether K. was ill-treated in police custody.
- On 4 November 2010, K. stated that he had been physically assaulted by police officers on 26 December 2009, and a new investigation was opened in March 2011.
- K. tested positive for HIV in May and June 2010 and was diagnosed with tuberculosis in April 2011, which eventually led to his death on 7 November 2011.
- The investigation into K.'s ill-treatment and subsequent death was ongoing in December 2011.

title: CASE OF ORLIK v. UKRAINE
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant was assaulted on 3 February 2007.
- The applicant sustained haematomas on her jaw, shoulder, and hip, a bruise under her right eye, concussion, and a displaced rib fracture.
- The applicant alleges that Mr and Mrs K. were her assailants, but the domestic authorities found that it was only Mrs K. who had assaulted her.
- The incident occurred in front of the applicant’s two-year-old granddaughter.
- On 4 February 2007, the applicant lodged a complaint with the police.
- On 14 February 2007, the Oleksandrivka police refused to institute criminal proceedings in connection with the incident.
- On 20 March 2007, the Oleksandrivka prosecutor overruled the decision of 14 February 2007 and instituted criminal proceedings in connection with the infliction of bodily harm of medium severity on the applicant.
- On 20 May 2007, the investigator suspended the investigation for failure to identify the perpetrator.
- On 10 December 2007, the Oleksandrivka prosecutor’s office asked the Kirovograd Regional Police Department to have the police officers in charge of the investigation disciplined.
- On 7 April 2008, the investigator decided to ask a forensic medical expert to determine the degree of gravity of the applicant’s injuries.
- On 23 October 2008, the Oleksandrivka Court absolved Mrs K. from criminal liability under an amnesty law, and the Kirovograd Regional Court of Appeal quashed that judgment.
- On 1 July 2009, the investigator refused to institute criminal proceedings against Mr K.
- On 24 July 2009, the Oleksandrivka Court remitted the case against Mrs K. for further investigation.
- On 20 December 2011, the Znamyanka Court convicted Mrs K. of inflicting bodily harm of medium severity on the applicant, sentencing her to restriction of liberty for two years, suspended for a one-year probationary period.
- On 6 March 2012, the Court of Appeal quashed the judgment and discontinued the criminal proceedings against Mrs K. as time-barred.

title: CASE OF DALAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The applicant is the uncle of Mr Apti Dalakov, who lost his parents and brother in a car accident in 1998.
- On 2nd September 2007, Mr Apti Dalakov and his friend Mr I.D. were leaving a computer club when they were shot at by a group of men from two minivans without number plates. Mr Apti Dalakov ran away, but was chased and pursued by the armed men who continued shooting at him. He was hit by a car and fell to the ground, got up and limped into the courtyard of a nursery school, followed by a man who shot him several times with his pistol. After Mr Apti Dalakov was dead, one of the armed men lifted his body and placed a hand grenade under it.
- Shortly after the incident, a group of officers of the local police and the special police force arrived. They recognized that Mr Apti Dalakov had not offered any resistance, was not armed, and that his pursuers had placed the hand grenade under his body. The FSB officers responsible for the shooting were taken into custody by the police officers.
- The government argues that FSB officers had identified themselves as their agents and that they found the victim and his friend, whom they believed to be presumed members of a bandit group, just before shooting Mr Apti Dalakov. They claim that he posed a threat to their lives and those of the other people present in the street, and that their decision to open fire was lawful.
- The crime scene was examined and evidence, such as forty cartridge cases and a grenade, was collected. Witnesses living near the scene were questioned, and some of them reported seeing a young man's body on the ground surrounded by a large number of police who had cordoned off the area.
- Internal inquiries were conducted by both the investigating department and a senior operational search officer of the Internal Investigations Department of the Ingushetia Ministry of the Interior, who concluded that the events were a result of a lack of proper coordination between the law-enforcement agencies carrying out a special task in the Republic of Ingushetia.

title: CASE OF YEVDOKIMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- All applicants were detained in Russian penal facilities at the material time.
- Applicants Yevdokimov, Rezanov, and Morozov lodged defamation claims against private third parties.
- Applicants Makhov, Resin, Anikanov, Lebetskiy, Gromovoy, Gordeyev, and Vinokhodov brought claims seeking compensation for the allegedly inhuman conditions of their detention.
- Applicant Martirosyan lodged a civil claim for compensation, alleging that the criminal proceedings had been instituted unlawfully.
- None of the applicants were able to attend the hearings at which their claims were examined, and the domestic courts refused them the possibility of being present at the hearing on the ground that there was no domestic legal provision for bringing detainees to courts.
- The applicants raised the question of their appearance in court in the appeal statement, and the appeal courts either dismissed their arguments or concluded that their absence from the court was in line with the legislation and did not contravene the principle of fairness.
- The applicants' claims were refused at two levels of jurisdiction.

title: CASE OF ŚWIDERSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1989 and is detained in Opole Lubelskie.
- He was arrested and remanded in custody in the Biała Podlaska Prison on suspicion of having committed a murder on 29 June 2007.
- On 17 December 2009, he was convicted of murder and sentenced to 25 years’ imprisonment, and he appealed.
- The Lublin Court of Appeal quashed the challenged judgment and remitted the case on 10 November 2010.
- On 13 May 2014, the Lublin Regional Court convicted him and sentenced him to 13 years’ imprisonment.
- He was classified as a dangerous detainee by the Biala Podlaska Prison Penitentiary Commission on 14 August 2007, and subsequently, this commission and others extended the classification on numerous occasions until September 2011.
- He was detained in several facilities, had access to a library, and participated in cultural and educational activities.
- He had to wear a red uniform for dangerous detainees, which was not warm enough in winter and was subjected to strip searches every time he left and entered his cell.
- The cell window was covered with a plastic blind, and he had a one-hour outdoor exercise period per day.
- He received some disciplinary measures for his attitude toward prison guards and attempting to assault a public servant.

title: CASE OF PALUCH v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1989 and is currently detained in Lublin.
- Before October 2011, the applicant was convicted of assault and endangering lives through arson and extortion.
- On 14 October 2011, a special dangerous detainee regime was imposed on the applicant due to his aggressive behavior, planned attack on a prison employee, and several disciplinary punishments.
- The applicant did not appeal against the decision to impose the regime on him.
- The decision was reviewed and upheld by the commission every three months.
- On 12 January 2012, the commission reviewed the situation and upheld its decision, finding the applicant a serious danger to prison security. The applicant did not appeal against the decision.
- On 11 April 2012, the commission again reviewed and upheld its decision, and the applicant appealed.
- On 13 June 2012, the Lublin Regional Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the commission's decision.
- On 14 July 2012, the dangerous detainee regime was lifted based on the applicant's good behavior and no longer posing a danger to the prison.
- The applicant was subjected to constant closed-circuit television surveillance, strip searches, and joined shackles whenever outside his cell.

title: CASE OF VIJATOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant and her late husband held a specially protected tenancy for a flat in Zagreb granted by the Yugoslav People's Army.
- The Protected Tenancies (Sale to Occupier) Act enacted by the Croatian Parliament in 1991 allowed the sale of socially-owned flats previously let under a specially protected tenancy, but state-owned flats were excluded.
- The Croatian Government adopted a decree in October 1991, whereby it took all the YPA's property in Croatia into state ownership.
- The Act Amending the Sale to Occupier Act in 1995 allowed the sale of state-owned flats as well, but the time-limit for lodging a request to purchase such a flat was set at sixty days.
- The applicant's husband died on 15 April 2006, and the applicant lodged a request to purchase the flat she was occupying on 7 June 2006. The request was denied as it was outside the accepted time limit of 31 December 1995.
- The applicant brought a civil action, which was dismissed by the Zagreb Municipal Court, as the plaintiff had not lodged her purchase request within the accepted time limit.
- The applicant argued that there was no prescribed time limit and relied on decisions of the Constitutional Court.
- The second-instance court upheld the judgment of the first-instance court, emphasizing that the holders of specially protected tenancies of state-owned flats were obliged to lodge a request for purchasing these flats before 31 December 1995.
- The applicant's subsequent constitutional complaint was dismissed, as the impugned decisions were not seen as arbitrary or unreasonable.

title: CASE OF DOHERTY v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder on 16 September 1982, under the mandatory life sentence law.
- On 26 April 1996, he was released on licence.
- On 7 March 1997, his licence was revoked by the Secretary of State for alleged sexual offences against two of his nieces.
- The applicant’s case was reviewed multiple times by the Life Sentence Review Board, which declined to direct his release on each occasion.
- The applicant sought permission to apply for a judicial review of the Board’s decisions, claiming that the proceedings were unfair and administrative rather than quasi-judicial.
- The Board was replaced by the Life Sentence Review Commissioners in 2000.
- On 29 November 2001, the applicant’s case was referred to a panel of the LSRC.
- An initial hearing took place on 17 June 2002, and the panel concluded that the applicant had committed the alleged sexual assaults.
- The hearing was adjourned, and a new panel was appointed.
