- Ms N.S. gave birth to their child, the second applicant, in May 2007.
- The first applicant and Ms N.S regularly visited the second applicant in St Petersburg Children’s Home no. 3 (“the children’s home”).
- In November 2011, they were provided with a flat in St Petersburg.
- In February 2012, the first applicant was discharged from the care home and moved into his flat.
- In November 2011, the children’s home applied to have the first applicant’s parental authority over the second applicant restricted.
- The children’s home produced undated reports by its staff stating that the second applicant had difficulties in communicating with her parents and that she felt fear, anxiety, and emotional stress in their presence.
- A report by a panel of experts described the first applicant as a fully focused, sociable person with reduced intelligence.
- A report by the custody and guardianship authority described the living conditions in the first applicant’s flat as appropriate for his daughter.
- The District Court dismissed the claim to restrict the first applicant’s parental authority over the second applicant, but considered that it would be “undesirable” for the child to be placed with her parents at that time.

title: CASE OF GÓMEZ OLMEDA v. SPAIN
facts:
- The applicant was sentenced to six months’ imprisonment for serious disobedience to public authority in 2011.
- He was acquitted of false accusation of a crime, defamation, and concealment.
- The judge established that the applicant was the webmaster of an Internet forum on which defamatory messages against the complainants in the proceedings had been published.
- The applicant had deliberately disregarded the request made to him by a police officer within the framework of the criminal investigation not to alter the messages in question.
- The applicant was found guilty of continuous and false accusation of a crime and given a daily fine of 15 euros for a period of eighteen months. He was also required to pay damages.
- Documentary evidence was read and interpreted in the light of the circumstances of the case.
- The applicant’s amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court was declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF PAIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Šibenik.
- On 26 August 2005, the Šibenik Municipal State Attorney’s Office began an investigation against the applicant for suspicion of stealing a mobile telephone.
- On 20 September 2005, an investigating judge heard the applicant, who denied the charges against him.
- On 9 June 2006, authorities in the Czech Republic heard evidence from the victim, who claimed that the applicant stole her mobile phone.
- On 9 November 2006, the Šibenik Municipal State Attorney’s Office indicted the applicant on the charge of stealing a mobile phone.
- During his trial, the applicant denied the charges, and his former wife confirmed his account.
- E.R.’s statement was admitted as evidence without her examination, and on 28 October 2010, the Šibenik Municipal Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to four months of suspended imprisonment.
- The Šibenik County Court dismissed the applicant's appeal on 3 March 2011, and the Constitutional Court declared his constitutional complaint inadmissible on 8 December 2011.

title: CASE OF OKOLISAN v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested in Hungary and extradited to Moldova on suspicion of defrauding a company registered in Moldova.
- The applicant was detained in prison no. 13, first held in a cell designed for prisoners with medical problems due to his prostate cancer and hypertension, then transferred to a dark, damp, and insect-infested cell with no toilet and contaminated yellow water.
- The applicant did not receive adequate medical treatment for his illness, causing his health to worsen to the point where he could no longer control the process of urination and had to endure additional humiliation.
- The applicant's appeal for release due to his poor state of health was refused, and he later requested house arrest instead of detention, which was granted after five months.
- The Moldovan Ombudsman institution found several problems with the conditions of detention in prisons, including insufficient access to daylight, lack of ventilation and medical assistance, overcrowding, and worn-out bed linen, among others.
- The Human Rights Centre recommended the urgent improvement of conditions of detention in prison no. 13 and even its closure to avoid new findings of violations by the Court.

title: CASE OF BULIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1989 and lives in Kresttsy, Novgorod Region.
- The applicant was charged with theft on an unspecified date, and criminal proceedings were discontinued on 16 December 2003.
- On 28 July 2004, the applicant was arrested and charged with murder at the age of 15.
- The Krestetskiy Federal Court of the Novgorod Region authorized the applicant’s pre-trial detention on 29 July 2004.
- The applicant was charged with conspiracy to commit robbery at an unspecified date.
- The Novgorod Town Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention until 8 November 2004 and 8 January 2005, respectively.
- On 7 December 2004, the investigator dropped the murder charges against the applicant due to lack of corpus delicti and reclassified the charge as robbery committed by a group of persons.
- The Novgorod Regional Court upheld the decision to extend the applicant’s pre-trial detention until 28 January 2005.
- The Regional Court fixed the preliminary hearing for the applicant’s case for 24 February 2005, and the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the decision on appeal on 28 April 2005.
- The Regional Court rescheduled the preliminary hearing for the applicant’s case for 4 August 2005 and dismissed the request for his release into his mother’s care pending trial on 20 July 2005.
- The Supreme Court upheld the decision on appeal on 21 September 2005.
- On 17 October 2005 and 24 January 2006, the Regional Court extended the applicant’s detention and two other defendants’ detention, respectively.
- On 13 February 2006, the Regional Court found the applicant guilty of robbery and sentenced him to four and a half years’ imprisonment.
- On 27 September 2006, the Supreme Court of Russia upheld the applicant’s conviction on appeal.
- On 2 August 2007, the Nevelskiy District Court of the Pskov Region released the applicant on parole.

title: CASE OF DZHABAROV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
1. Mr Dzhabarov, Mr Petkov and a friend were travelling in a car in Stara Zagora.
2. They were stopped, arrested and taken to a local police station.
3. The police issued orders for their detention for twenty-four hours.
4. The orders did not mention the factual grounds on which they had been issued.
5. Mr Dzhabarov sought judicial review of his detention and won the case.
6. Mr Petkov also sought judicial review of his detention and won the case.
7. Both men brought claims for damages under the State and Municipalities Liability for Damage Act 1988, but their claims were dismissed.
8. Ms Nikolova was detained by the police on suspicion of accessing confidential data without permission.
9. Ms Nikolova was interviewed without being informed of the reasons for her detention.

title: CASE OF KAREN POGHOSYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The applicant constructed a building without permission on a piece of land that he believed was not being used.
- The applicant instituted proceedings to recognize his ownership right in respect of the building and his right of use in respect of the plot, which were granted.
- The local branch of the State Real Estate Registry issued a certificate confirming the applicant's ownership in respect of the building and his right of lease in respect of the plot of land for a period of 99 years.
- The Yerevan Mayor's Office received a letter from a third person claiming ownership of the same land, leading to the government appealing the district court's decision to recognize the applicant's ownership right in respect of the building.
- The Yerevan Mayor's Office and the General Prosecutor missed the time-limit for appeal but were still granted the appeal.
- The Court of Appeal quashed the original judgment and dismissed the applicant's claim, finding that the building in question was an unauthorised construction on a plot of land belonging to the State.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law, which was returned as inadmissible for lack of merit.
- The authorities instituted proceedings against the applicant seeking annulment of registration of his ownership rights in respect of the building and the plot of land, which were granted.

title: CASE OF DIMITAR YANAKIEV v. BULGARIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant requested compensation for an apartment which had belonged to his ancestor at the time of its nationalisation in 1949.
- The Sofia City Court ruled that the applicant had to be compensated with “housing compensation bonds” as restitution was not possible.
- The court determined that the amount of total compensation due in respect of the property in question was BGN 23,604, and that the regional governor was liable for costs.
- The applicant submitted a certified copy of the court decision of 19 July 2005 and requested that it be enforced, but the deputy regional governor replied that the applicant needed to submit a certified copy of the court decision, as well as a certificate attesting to his status as heir and a declaration certified by a notary.
- The applicant challenged the fine imposed by the regional governor in court and it was quashed.

title: CASE OF ŠANTARE AND LABAZNIKOVS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1960 and 1956 respectively and live in Riga.
- The Bureau for the Prevention and Combating of Corruption received information concerning allegedly unlawful activities of officials of the State Pharmacy Inspectorate.
- The second applicant was summoned by the KNAB to give statements about the activities of certain State officials supervising pharmaceutical matters in Latvia.
- The second applicant offered a bribe to an investigator to cease investigative activities concerning his business and the State officials connected with it.
- The second applicant was charged with bribery, and the first applicant was charged with aiding and abetting.
- A charge was brought against the first applicant and a suspended sentence was given to her.
- The second applicant pleaded guilty and was given a suspended sentence of two years' imprisonment but the prosecutor submitted an appeal contesting the acquittal of the first applicant and asking for an immediate custodial sentence to be imposed.
- The appellate court revoked the suspension of the second applicant's prison sentence.
- The Senate of the Supreme Court dismissed an appeal on points of law in open court, stating that the phone had been tapped in accordance with section 17 of the Law on Operational Activities, and not as a special investigative measure under Article 176¹ of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- The Minister of Justice expressed concern about the actions of some judges in a judges' conference.

title: CASE OF HELMUT BLUM v. AUSTRIA
facts:
1. The applicant is a lawyer from Linz, born in 1959, and has been a lawyer since 1986.
2. Criminal investigation proceedings were initiated against a regional politician and a Moldovan citizen for suspicion of human trafficking and fraud.
3. The applicant was hired by an association, of which the politician was the president, to represent the Moldovan citizen who was in detention pending trial.
4. During the investigation proceedings, the Moldovan citizen accused the politician of accepting money for facilitating the illegal entry or transit of nationals from Moldova to Austria or Italy.
5. The applicant remained in close contact with the politician despite representing the Moldovan citizen and transferred information on the investigation proceedings to him.
6. The applicant prepared an affidavit that the Moldovan citizen signed during a visit to prison, retracting her allegations against the politician. The affidavit was in favour of the politician.
7. The Moldovan citizen was convicted and sentenced to fifteen months' imprisonment, but did not retract her statements to the authorities or submit the affidavit to the court. Instead, the applicant transferred it to the lawyers of the politician.
8. The judge of the Linz Regional Court reported the applicant to the Upper Austrian Bar Association for suspected double representation, transferring information to the politician, and asking the Moldovan citizen to submit an affidavit that was untrue but favoured the politician.
9. The Linz Regional Court instituted a preliminary investigation into the applicant for attempted aiding of the perpetrator, false testimony, and falsifying evidence, upon a request by the Linz public prosecutor.
10. The Linz public prosecutor requested the gathering of further evidence and put the applicant on the stand in the criminal proceedings against him.
11. The criminal proceedings were suspended by the public prosecutor because they were still pending against the politician.
12. The Disciplinary Council of the Bar Association initiated disciplinary proceedings against the applicant, withdrawing his right to represent clients before the Linz courts in criminal cases as an interim measure during the proceedings.
13. The applicant appealed against the interim measure, but it was dismissed by the Appeals Board and the Constitutional Court.
14. The disciplinary proceedings lasted for almost seven years, and the applicant was fined 1,000 euros.
15. The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law and reduced the additional disciplinary fine to 500 euros.

title: CASE OF GUȚĂ TUDOR TEODORESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant requested compensation for a property owned by his ancestors and taken over by the Bulgarian State.
- The County Commission issued a decision proposing payment of compensation in the amount of ROL 2,013,957,441.
- The Central Commission did not issue any decision to validate the County Commission decision within sixty days.
- The applicant brought a court action to oblige the Central Commission to act in accordance with the law and asked for the amounts granted by the County Commission to be adjusted for inflation when payment was made.
- The Bucharest County Court dismissed the applicant's action on the grounds that the sixty-day deadline was advisory and the adjustment of the amounts granted should be made at the time payment was actually made.
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal ordered the Central Commission to issue a decision ratifying or otherwise the County Commission proposal and held that the adjustment of the amounts granted as compensation was to be dealt with during the enforcement stage.
- The Central Commission ratified the County Commission decision.
- The compensation was paid to the applicant.
- The applicant lodged a court action aimed at obtaining an adjustment of the initial amount to take into account inflation from the date on which it was established by the County Commission to the date of actual payment.
- The Bucharest County Court ruled in the applicant’s favour and established that the amounts set by the County Commission had to be adjusted for inflation if they were not paid in the year they were awarded.
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal reversed the decision and ruled that the applicant was not entitled to an adjustment for inflation.
- The appellate court concluded that the entitlement to adjustment for inflation had to be determined on the basis of the date when the Central Commission had ratified the decision of the County Commission and as the payment had been made in the same year as the Central Commission decision, the applicant was not entitled to an adjustment for inflation.
- The failure of the Central Commission to ratify the decision of the County Commission within sixty days could not represent a legal basis for the adjustment of the amount.

title: CASE OF SVETLANA VASILYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant bought a house in Kaliningrad with the help of an authorized representative.
- The applicant's ownership of the house was registered in the Consolidated State Register of Real Estate Titles and Transactions on 18 August 2003.
- The authorized representative, M., was charged with fraud against the Savings Bank of Russia and a private person.
- M. was found guilty of fraud by the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Arkhangelsk and the court ordered the seizure and sale of the house to pay M.'s debt to the victims of the crime.
- The Arkhangelsk Regional Court partly quashed M.'s conviction and remitted the issue of the ownership of the house for fresh consideration in civil proceedings.
- The Tsentralnyy District Court of Kaliningrad rejected the Bank's civil claims and declared that the house was the applicant's property.
- The Kaliningrad Regional Court upheld the Tsentralnyy District Court's judgment on appeal.
- The Presidium of the Kaliningrad Regional Court quashed the Tsentralnyy District Court's judgment and ordered the seizure of the house from the applicant to pay M.'s debt to the Bank, stating that although the applicant was registered as the official owner of the house, it had been bought with funds belonging to M.
- The applicant and M. challenged the judgment of the Presidium of the Kaliningrad Regional Court by way of supervisory review applications, which were rejected.
- The bailiff decided to seize the house in accordance with the judgment of the Presidium of the Kaliningrad Regional Court.
- The Tsentralnyy District Court stayed the enforcement proceedings pending examination of the applicant's case by the Court at the bailiff's request.

title: CASE OF KÖRTVÉLYESSY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is from Budapest and was born in 1965.
- The applicant planned to organize a demonstration against "the persecution of national radicalism" on August 15, 2009.
- The demonstration was supposed to take place in front of Budapest Penitentiary on Venyige Street, Budapest.
- The applicant notified the Budapest Police Department that a maximum of 200 participants were expected to attend the demonstration.
- The Budapest Police Department banned the demonstration on August 14, 2009, citing that it would impede traffic significantly, and there were no alternative routes for traffic.
- The applicant filed for judicial review of the police decision on August 17, 2009.
- The Budapest Regional Court rejected the applicant’s complaint on August 19, 2009.
- The court concluded that the reason for banning the demonstration was the potential disproportionate difficulties caused to traffic by the demonstration, based on the expert opinion provided by the Traffic Division of Budapest Police Department.

title: CASE OF SAVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicants complained of excessive length of criminal and civil proceedings under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
- All applicants obtained decisions from the Constitutional Court of Serbia, finding violation of their right to hearing within a reasonable time.
- Constitutional Court awarded them certain sums in respect of non-pecuniary damage suffered (see appendix to this judgment).

title: CASE OF GRUZDA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Krasnodar.
- On 24 March 2009, the Military Court of Novorossiysk Garrison convicted the applicant of laundering the proceeds of crime and sentenced him to a fine.
- On 21 May 2009, the Military Court of the North-Caucasian Command acquitted the applicant on appeal.
- On 21 July 2009, the Presidium of the Military Court of the North‑Caucasian Command annulled the judgment of 21 May 2009 and remitted the case for fresh consideration to the appeal court on two grounds.
- On 6 August 2009, the Military Court of the North-Caucasian Command reversed the judgment of 24 March 2009 on appeal and remitted the case for fresh consideration to the trial court.
- In 2010, the criminal proceedings against the applicant were terminated due to the decriminalization of his actions under domestic law.

title: CASE OF APARECIDA DE OLIVEIRA NABOR v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Porto.
- On 28 April 2009, the applicant filed a request for permanent disability due to a work-related injury.
- The applicant provided statements and medical reports to the State's Attorney's Office regarding her medical treatment.
- The State's Attorney's Office requested information regarding the evolution of the applicant's medical treatment, staying the proceedings twice while waiting for the applicant to become medically fit.
- The State's Attorney's Office requested the applicant to inform whether she was still being treated in a clinic and her new address, which resulted in a request to the police for information.
- The court requested a medical examination of the applicant by the Forensic Institute, which requested further clinical data and an additional examination. The Institute submitted its final report on 12 October 2011.
- A conciliatory hearing was held on 23 November 2011, adjourned to 24 January 2012, and ended without an agreement between the parties.
- The applicant requested the Porto Labour Court to continue with the judicial stage of proceedings against her employer and the insurance company on 2 April 2012.
- Several procedural steps took place between 8 June 2012 and 21 November 2012.
- The hearing started on 20 February and continued on 28 February 2013.
- On 8 March 2013, the Porto Labour Court ruled against the applicant.

title: CASE OF SIMONYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant owns a house and a plot of land jointly with his mother.
- The applicant lodges a civil claim against relatives residing in the house seeking to terminate their right of use of a part of the house and evicting them.
- The respondents counter-claim seeking to invalidate the ownership certificate and have their ownership recognized in part of the house and plot of land used by them.
- The Shengavit District Court of Yerevan dismisses the applicant's and his mother's claims and grants the respondents' counter-claim.
- The Civil Court of Appeal grants the applicant's claim to terminate the respondents' right of use of accommodation through payment of compensation and dismisses the respondents' counter-claim.
- The respondents lodge an appeal on points of law with the Court of Cassation against this judgment, claiming that it had been adopted in violation of substantive law.
- The Court of Cassation returns the respondents' appeal as inadmissible for lack of merit.
- The respondents lodge another appeal on points of law with the Court of Cassation alleging violations of substantive and procedural law.
- The Court of Cassation grants the appeal, quashing the judgment of the Civil Court of Appeal and validating the judgment of the Shengavit District Court.
- An ownership certificate is issued in the name of the respondents for a part of the house and a plot of land.

title: CASE OF KARAGJOZI AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicants have inherited property rights over a 640,000 sq.m. plot of land.
- The Vlora Commission recognized the applicants' property rights on July 28, 2006.
- The land changed from agricultural land to construction land.
- The decision became final on October 2, 2006.
- The Ministry of Defense affirmed that the land was occupied by the army on February 18, 2013.
- No compensation has been paid to the applicants.

title: CASE OF HALIMI AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicants had inherited property rights over a 10,000 sq. m plot of land.
- The Vlora Commission recognized their inherited property rights on May 30, 1995.
- The plot of land was occupied.
- The applicants were entitled to compensation as per the law.
- Despite being entitled to compensation, no payment has been made to date.

title: CASE OF MATEI AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants provided
- Details of all the applications provided in an attached table
- Applicants highlighted the issue of inadequate detention conditions.

title: CASE OF ALIÇKA AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The Gjirokastra Commission recognised the applicants' inherited property rights over an agricultural land measuring 655,400 sq. m.
- The applicants were to be compensated in the sum of 2,297,398 Albanian leks (“ALL”) in respect of the entire land, but no compensation has been paid.
- The Korça Commission recognised the applicant’s inherited property rights over some land measuring 2,800 sq. m, of which 300 sq. m were restored.
- The applicant and other heirs would be compensated in State bonds in the event the buildings located on the remaining plot of 2,500 sq. m were not privatised.
- The Korça Commission also recognised the applicant’s inherited property rights over another plot of arable land and meadow measuring 19,796 sq. m.
- The applicant would be compensated in State bonds equivalent to a financial amount of ALL 36,890, as the land was occupied.
- The Kavaja Commission recognised the applicant’s inherited property rights over two plots of land totaling 17,500 sq. m. The applicant and other heirs would be compensated in kind in respect of a plot measuring 10,000 sq. m and in State bonds in respect of another plot measuring 750 sq. m.
- The Devoll Commission recognised the applicants’ inherited property rights over an agricultural land measuring 27,200 sq. m. The applicants would be awarded compensation by way of State bonds in the sum of ALL 367,000.
- The Tirana Commission recognised the applicant’s inherited property rights over a plot of land measuring 836 sq. m, of which 513 sq. m were restored.
- The remaining plot of land was occupied, and the applicant would be compensated in one of the ways provided by law.
- The Agency on Restitution and Compensation of Properties amended the Commission decision and decided that the applicant would be compensated in one of the ways provided by law, even in respect of the plot of land measuring 513 sq. m.

title: CASE OF DUMITRU GHEORGHE v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is a professional photographer born in 1944 and based in Bucharest.
- In 1984, the applicant took photographs of landscapes in Călăraşi County for a commercial publication project that was not published.
- In 2004, the applicant discovered that 135 of the 143 landscape photographs from Călăraşi County in an album published in 1999 were the same photographs taken by him in 1984. However, F.G. was credited as the photographer instead of the applicant.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint with the Romanian Copyright Office on 25 February 2004, claiming that F.G. had committed a copyright infringement offence and joined a civil action seeking monetary compensation.
- An investigation by the RCO found that F.G. had infringed Article 140 § 1 let. a) of Law 8/1996 and forwarded the complaint to the police on 5 November 2004.
- A report ordered by the police on 8 November 2004 confirmed the photographs were taken by the applicant.
- The prosecutor’s office did not open a criminal investigation, citing the expiry of the statute of limitations.
- The applicant appealed the decision not to investigate but was denied by the Chief Prosecutor.
- The Călăraşi County Court allowed the appeal on 24 November 2005, finding that the statute of limitations had not yet expired due to the special provisions under Law 8/1996.
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal allowed the prosecutor's appeal on 17 February 2006, finding that the statute of limitations had expired. No reference was made to the civil complaint lodged by the applicant.

title: CASE OF R.B. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is of Roma origin, born in 1988 and lives in Gyöngyöspata.
- Right-wing political party, Movement for a Better Hungary, held a demonstration in Gyöngyöspata on 6 March 2011.
- Between 1-16 March 2011, right-wing groups, Civil Guard Association for a Better Future, Betyársereg, and Véderő, organised marches in the Roma neighbourhood of the village.
- Mr J.F., the president of the local Roma minority self-governing body, informed the police that he and the mayor of the municipality had been threatened by people they did not know.
- Four men passed by the applicant’s house, yelling racist slurs and threatening to build a house out of the blood of Roma people.
- Minor offence proceedings were instituted on the ground of "antisocial" conduct.
- Criminal proceedings were lodged by the applicant against unknown perpetrators for offences of violence against a member of an ethnic group, harassment and attempted grievous bodily assault.
- The applicant identified Mr S.T. and Mr F.W. as having been armed and Mr S.T. as having said that he would "paint the houses with [the applicant’s] blood.”
- Extracts from comments posted on a right-wing Internet portal in which Mr S.T. had been referred to as the man who had “enforced order among the Roma of Gyöngyöspata with a single whip” were attached to the criminal file by the applicant.
- The Gyöngyös District Public Prosecutor’s Office opened a separate investigation into the allegations of harassment on the basis of the applicant’s complaint.
- The prosecutor's office refused a request to investigate "violence against a member of an ethnic group" under article 174/B (1) of the Criminal Code.
- The identities of the persons who had threatened the applicant were established by the investigating authorities, including Mr S.T.
- Gyöngyös Police Department discontinued the investigation into harassment on the grounds that none of the witnesses heard had substantiated the applicant’s allegation that she had been threatened.
- The applicant withdrew the charges due to fear of reprisals.

title: CASE OF PLEŞ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Cluj‑Napoca.
- The applicant’s father was shot on 21 December 1989 while participating in a demonstration organised in Cluj against N. Ceauşescu.
- The applicant’s father suffered serious injuries from the shooting, and was left with a breathing deficit of over 30%, paresis of his right arm, and a permanent disability that prevented him from continuing to work.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the army commanders who had ordered the shooting, and the applicant’s father lodged a civil complaint requesting compensation for pecuniary and non‑pecuniary damage.
- The applicant’s father died on 17 May 2004 and was replaced as a civil party in the proceedings by the applicant.
- The first-instance court convicted five of the officers involved in the events and ordered them to pay compensation jointly with the Ministry of National Defence to all eighty-four civil parties in the case, including the applicant.
- The court granted the applicant ROL 150,000,000 in respect of pecuniary damage and ROL 50,000,000 for costs and expenses, but omitted to grant the claim for ROL 500,000,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage, without providing any reason.
- The applicant, along with other civil parties, lodged an appeal on points of law, with most of the appeals concerning the amount of damages awarded.
- The applicant’s appeal complained that the first-instance court had not granted him the requested compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The High Court of Cassation and Justice dismissed all the appeals lodged by the civil parties, referring to the general provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure and Civil Code concerning compensation for damages in the context of civil actions joined to criminal proceedings.

title: CASE OF M.C. AND A.C. v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicants participated in a gay march in Bucharest organized by the NGO, ACCEPT.
- They were attacked by a group of six young men and a woman wearing hooded sweatshirts while boarding a metro train.
- The victims were punched, kicked, and exposed to offensive remarks during the attack.
- The victims filed a criminal complaint against the attackers, stating that the assault was based on their sexual orientation.
- The police received pictures and statements from the victims, but the investigation was delayed due to a reorganization within the police force.
- The victims sought information on the progress of the investigation several times but received no response.
- The police requested help from the Romanian Intelligence Service to confirm the identity of the attackers.
- The police attended football matches and tried to identify the suspects at metro stations, but the investigation remained without success.
- The police decided to terminate the investigation because the alleged crimes become statute-barred.
- The prosecutor-in-chief dismissed the applicants' objections against the decision.
- The applicants repeatedly sought access to the prosecution file.

title: CASE OF ECATERINA MIREA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The case involves anti-communist demonstrations in Romania in December 1989 that led to the fall of the communist regime.
- The applicants and their close relatives took part in these demonstrations and were injured or killed by gunfire.
- A criminal investigation was initiated in 1990 into the December 1989 crackdown on the anti-communist demonstrations.
- Senior military officers were convicted in some cases concerning the events in Timișoara.
- The investigation into crimes committed by civilians, members of Patriotic Guards, members of militia, and prison staff is still pending before the prosecuting authorities.
- The military prosecutor's office at the High Court of Cassation and Justice decided not to institute criminal proceedings with regard to the acts committed by the military.
- The chief prosecutor at the military prosecutor's office set aside the above decision, and the military prosecutor's office relinquished jurisdiction in favor of the prosecutor's office at the High Court of Cassation and Justice.
- Following the opening of the classified information in the criminal investigation file to the public in 2010, the case was re-registered with a view to an investigation in the light of the newly available data.
- Jurisdiction over the case was relinquished in favor of the military prosecutor's office after the entry into force of the new Code of Criminal Procedure in February 2014.
- The prosecutor's office closed the investigation on October 14, 2015, finding that some of the facts were statute-barred, subject to an amnesty, or ill-founded, and that some of the facts could not be classified as criminal offenses or were res judicata.

title: CASE OF SERGEY DENISOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants were born between 1946 and 1970 and lived in St Petersburg until their arrest.
- A criminal gang named "Shutov's Gang" was operating in St Petersburg in the late 1990s, and its members were involved in serious crimes including murder, kidnapping, armed robbery, and extortion. Mr Shutov, a member of the St Petersburg Legislative Assembly, was accused and convicted of orchestrating the gang's activities.
- The applicants were arrested on suspicion of participating in the gang's activities, and they were placed in pre-trial detention.
- The City Court extended the applicants' pre-trial detention several times, primarily relying on the seriousness of the charges as grounds for the continued detention.
- The trial was delayed numerous times for various reasons, including the absence of lawyers, the applicants' illness, and their disruptive behavior in the courtroom.
- The City Court was composed of a professional judge and two lay judges, Ms I. and Ms M., who had been elected in the 1990s by St Petersburg City Council of People's Deputies. The defense unsuccessfully challenged the judges' credentials and impartiality.
- The trial was moved from the City Court to Kresty remand prison IZ-47/1 in St Petersburg, where the applicants' lawyers had limited access to case documents, and the trial was observed by journalists through a television screen.
- The applicants were convicted of multiple counts of organizing a criminal group, murder and assault, preparing explosive devices, and unlawfully storing and carrying firearms. Mr Denisov, Mr Gimranov, and Mr Shutov were sentenced to life imprisonment, while Mr Filimonov and Mr Dodonov received shorter sentences.
- The applicants appealed their conviction, and Mr Shutov's request to participate in the appeal hearing was denied. The appellate court granted Mr Dodonov's request to participate in the hearing, and the Supreme Court of Russia upheld the applicants' conviction on appeal.

title: CASE OF KARWOWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and is currently in detention in Warsaw.
- On 17 January 2006, the applicant was arrested and detained on remand on suspicion of the murder of two people and of inciting the murder of another person who had intended to testify against him in a separate set of proceedings.
- The applicant was subsequently convicted several times for various offences, including murder on 27 February 2013.
- On 19 January 2006, the commission classified the applicant as a dangerous detainee and assigned him to a designated wing or cell in a remand centre.
- The applicant did not appeal against that decision.
- The commission reviewed and upheld its decision to classify the applicant as a dangerous detainee on several occasions, citing the same reasons.
- On 21 November 2013, the commission lifted the dangerous detainee regime applied to the applicant.
- The applicant was kept in a cell which was constantly monitored via closed‑circuit television and subjected to a body search every time he left or entered the cell.

title: CASE OF BUGARIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant's birth year is 1957 and resides in Novi Pazar.
- Applicant worked at socially-owned company DP "Raška Holding Kompanija" in Novi Pazar.
- Applicant was owed salary arrears and social insurance contributions by the debtor.
- The Novi Pazar Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant on three separate occasions, and the judgments became final on later dates.
- The Novi Pazar Municipal Court ordered enforcement of judgments and debtor to pay for enforcement costs.
- Preliminary insolvency proceedings were opened against the debtor on 11 September 2013.
- Insolvency proceedings were opened against the debtor on 25 October 2013 and are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF STARTSEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Municipal unitary enterprise Sysolskoye proizvodstvennoye obyedineniye “Zhilkomkhoz” was set up by decision of the administration of the Sysolskiy District.
- The company provided maintenance services for municipal housing including heating, water supply, sewage systems maintenance, and renovation and maintenance of the municipal housing stock.
- The company had the right of economic control over the assets allocated to it.
- All of the company's property and profits belonged to the municipal estate.
- Insolvency proceedings were commenced on 3 March 2006, and an external administrator was appointed.
- On 29 September 2006, the Commercial Court of the Komi Republic ordered the insolvency proceedings in respect of the company.
- On 28 August 2008, the Commercial Court of the Komi Republic discontinued the insolvency proceedings and ordered the respondent company's liquidation.
- The applicants brought proceedings against the debtor company seeking salary arrears and other work-related payments.
- On 9 August 2006 and 30 October 2006, the Justice of the Peace of the Sysolskiy Court Circuit of the Komi Republic awarded the applicants salary arrears and compensation for non-pecuniary damage against their employer.
- On 10 October 2006 and 10 November 2006, respectively, the Sysolskiy District Court upheld those judgments on appeal, and they became final.

title: CASE OF OLYUNIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lived in Barnaul.
- The applicant became a suspect and accused of fraud in 2001.
- During the investigation, the applicant had a written undertaking not to leave his place of residence.
- The prosecutor referred the case to the Industrialnyy District Court of Barnaul in March 2003.
- The District Court ordered the applicant's detention on 19 September 2003.
- The applicant's representatives lodged an appeal against the detention order on 22 September 2003.
- The District Court forwarded the appeal to the Regional Court on 6 October 2003.
- The District Court also informed other participants of the criminal proceedings to submit their comments on the appeal by 22 October 2003.
- The victim, Shch., submitted her comments on 22 October 2003.
- The Regional Court received all materials related to the appeal on 19 November 2003.
- The Regional Court rejected the applicant's appeal on 27 November 2003.
- The District Court extended the applicant's detention on several occasions.
- The applicant was released under a written undertaking on 30 September 2004.
- The District Court found the applicant guilty of fraud on 13 December 2005.
- The Regional Court upheld the applicant's conviction on 18 May 2006.

title: CASE OF DOLBIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and participated in the clean-up operation at Chernobyl and later became disabled.
- In 2003, the applicant applied for an increase in social benefits using an adjustment method that was approved by domestic courts, resulting in an increase in benefits in 2002 and the first six months of 2003.
- In October 2003, the approval of the adjustment method from the February 2003 judgment was quashed by a supervisory review court.
- In March 2004, the June 2003 judgment was quashed by domestic courts based on the quashing of the February 2003 judgment.
- Both judgments from February and June 2003 remained unenforced before being quashed.
- In 2006, the applicant filed another claim for arrears and indexation of benefits, which was granted by a district court in June and upheld in July 2006 but remained unenforced for 14 months.

title: CASE OF IVANOVA AND CHERKEZOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants are a couple who have lived together as a family since 1989.
- They reconstructed a dilapidated one-storey cabin into a solid one-storey brick house without obtaining a building permit in 2004-2005 and have been living in it since then.
- The house was built on a plot that the first applicant's mother received 250 shares of after dividing property proceedings, and of which the first applicant received 484.43 shares.
- Other co-owners of the plot brought a claim against the first applicant, and the court found that they were the owners of 140.57 out of the total of 625 shares of the plot and the house built on it, while the first applicant was the owner of the remaining 484.43 shares.
- The house was found to have been constructed illegally without a building permit and is subject to demolition. The first applicant sought judicial review, which was unsuccessful.
- The first applicant was invited to comply with the demolition order, and the regional office of the National Building Control Directorate made a call for tenders from private companies willing to carry out the demolition.
- The Burgas Municipal Ombudsman urged the Minister of Regional Development to halt the demolition due to its disproportionate impact on the applicants, and the Directorate's regional office reiterated its intention to proceed with the demolition.
- The municipal authorities were asked to explore whether they could provide alternative accommodation for the first applicant but had not replied to that query as of the latest information. 
- A social worker interviewed the first applicant and explained the possibilities to request social services, but she stated that she preferred to remain in the house.
- As of March 10, 2016, the demolition had not been carried out.

title: CASE OF CHENGELYAN AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years and live in Plovdiv, except for one who lives in New York.
- The ancestors of the applicants owned a plot of land with a two-storey house in Plovdiv, which was later declared a cultural monument.
- The property was expropriated in 1966, and the applicants' ancestors received compensation.
- After the Restitution Act was adopted in 1992, some heirs applied for the revocation of the expropriation, but it was initially refused and then reviewed by administrative and court decisions.
- In 1998, the Supreme Administrative Court revoked the expropriation, finding that it had been in breach of the law due to the status of the property as a cultural monument.
- To make the restitution effective, the applicants paid back the compensation received by their ancestors at the time of expropriation.
- The applicants obtained a notarial deed naming them as the property's owners in 2001, but the municipality still held and rented a room in the building to an organisation.
- The applicants brought rei vindicatio proceedings against the municipality and the organisation in 2003 but were unsuccessful, as the courts found that the reparation work carried out on the building made it unsuitable for restitution and that the property was being used for public works.

title: CASE OF TOPALLAJ v. ALBANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in the United States of America.
- The landowners had inherited property rights over a plot of land measuring 24 hectares and fuel tanks of a petrol station located on the land.
- The applicant concluded two agreements with one of the landowners to assist in the privatization of installations and fuel tanks on the land; later, he and all landowners appointed the applicant to act on their behalf in proceedings related to the protection of their property rights.
- The landowners lodged a request with the Tirana Commission on Property Restitution and Compensation seeking restitution of the property; on 7 March 1996, the Commission dismissed the request, which was later quashed by the District Court that allocated landowners a plot of land measuring 56,500 sq. m and ordered that objects be restored at no cost; the judgment became final on 7 May 1996.
- The Mortgage Office issued a property certificate, according to which the landowners had registered title to the plot of land, and subsequently, the petrol station and fuel tanks were expropriated in the public interest.
- Between 1996 and 1998, the landowners' property rights were unsuccessfully challenged by various state institutions, and the applicant joined the proceedings as a third party.
- On 18 April 2006, the District Court declared the agreements and contracts null and void, finding them to be fictitious.
- The applicant appealed to the Court of Appeal, challenging the bench, and contended that no good reason had been ascertained for the landowners' nonappearance to supplement the claim.
- On 19 February 2007, the Deputy President of the Court of Appeal requested the Minister of Justice to appoint three judges from other appellate courts to hear the case, since all of its judges had sat in the proceedings.

title: CASE OF CUMHURİYET HALK PARTİSİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant party is a Turkish political party based in Ankara.
- The Turkish Constitutional Court oversees political parties' finances as per Article 69 of the Constitution.
- All political parties need to submit their annual consolidated accounts to the Constitutional Court, which reviews their compliance with relevant laws.
- The applicant party submitted its consolidated accounts for 2007-2009 within six months of the end of each fiscal year for inspection by the Constitutional Court.
- The Constitutional Court found the financial information submitted to be complete and proceeded with examinations for all three years.
- The Constitutional Court requested further information and documents regarding some expenses it deemed problematic.
- The applicant party responded to the Constitutional Court's requests, but it was unable to provide original invoices or supporting documentation for all expenses.
- The Constitutional Court found that some expenses incurred were in violation of the Political Parties Act, fell outside the party's political activities, and were not supported by necessary documentation.
- The Constitutional Court confiscated the applicant party's assets in the amounts corresponding to its unlawful expenditure, and the decisions were published in the Official Gazette.
- Various expenses incurred by the applicant party were deemed unlawful, including food, pharmaceutical, and accommodation expenses, travel expenses, bonuses, litigation expenses, severance packages, and payments made in excess to personnel.
- The Constitutional Court found certain expenses to be against the party's objectives and not in the name of the legal personality of the party.
- The Constitutional Court refused to accept any documentation other than original invoices, freelance receipts or expense notes as proof of payment for certain expenses.

title: CASE OF BAŞBİLEN v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants are parents of deceased Mr Hüseyin Başbilen who worked for a defense contractor.
- Mr Hüseyin Başbilen was reported missing on August 4, 2006.
- Later, his dead body was found in his locked car on August 5, 2006, with cuts on his neck and wrist.
- Suicide note entitled "FAREWELL" was found in the car.
- Initial investigation concluded that Mr Hüseyin Başbilen had committed suicide but there were objections raised by family members.
- In November 2010, a complaint was lodged for reopening the case.
- Investigations began again which found new evidence including missing documents and fingerprints not belonging to the deceased in the car.

title: CASE OF NOVIKOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Marina Novikova staged a demonstration in front of the State Duma in Moscow, holding a poster about psychiatry.
- She was approached by police officers, arrested, and accused of participating in a demonstration without prior notification.
- Viktor Savchenko staged a demonstration, holding a poster critical of Putin, and was arrested by police officers.
- Aleksandr Kirpichev held a solo demonstration at a bus stop, and was arrested for holding a public event without prior notification.
- Valeriy Romakhin held a demonstration in front of a university, and was arrested for violating Article 20.2 of the CAO.

title: CASE OF CANGÖZ AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts are:

1. The applicants' seventeen close relatives were members of an outlawed organization in Turkey known as the Maoist Communist Party (MKP).
2. Criminal proceedings had been brought against the relatives on various dates since the 1970s for membership of a number of outlawed organizations and for carrying out activities on behalf of those organizations.
3. They were killed by the security forces on 17 and 18 June 2005 while they were holding a meeting of their organization in a rural area within the administrative jurisdiction of the town of Ovacık.
4. The names of the seventeen relatives and the applicant's relationship to them are specified.
5. The events which took place on 17 and 18 June 2005 are disputed between the parties.

title: CASE OF SEAGAL v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicant was born in Marseille in 1978 and currently lives in Cyprus.
- He carried out renovation work for building owners in Paphos but was not paid.
- The owners falsely reported him to the police for drugs and he was assaulted and arrested without a warrant.
- He was later assaulted again by police officers in his flat.
- In June 2010 he was assaulted by persons sent by the building owners and taken to hospital by police.
- On 15 December 2010, he was ordered to pay a fine of 500 euros.
- On 10 April 2013, police officers searched his home, seized his passport and other documents, and arrested him without a court order.
- He was interrogated, arrested, and taken to Nicosia Central Prisons.
- On 21 June 2013, after serving his sentence, he was detained in Menoyia Detention Centre and charged with assaulting a police officer.
- He filed complaints with the World Service Authority and the Ombudsman.
- He was arrested and charged with several offences, including forgery, unlawful entry and residence, and resisting arrest.
- He represented himself in court and was found guilty of several offences.
- He was detained for several months before his sentence was suspended.
- He was ordered to be deported and banned from entering Cyprus for ten years.
- He did not have a valid passport and claimed to be a French citizen, but this was not confirmed by the French Embassy.

title: CASE OF İZZETTİN DOĞAN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
A. The background to the case:
- A dispute related to the establishment of a religious public service.

B. Legal and historical background to the creation of a religious public service:
- The Religious Affairs Department's role in regulating religion in the country.
- The different statuses held by religious groups in the country.
- The Alevis, cemevis, and the Alevi initiative.
- The Government's stance on the Alevi faith and the academic opinion provided by them.

title: CASE OF MURRAY v. THE NETHERLANDS
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1953 on the island of Aruba.
- In 1980, the Joint Court of Justice of the Netherlands Antilles convicted the applicant of murder and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- The applicant was diagnosed with terminal cancer while serving his sentence in 2013.
- He was transferred to a nursing home in Curaçao in September 2013 and was released on pardon on 31 March 2014.
- He passed away on 26 November 2014.
- The Kingdom of the Netherlands consisted of the Netherlands and the Netherlands Antilles at the time the applicant was sentenced.
- The legal systems of the countries in the Kingdom may differ from each other.
- The Joint Court of Justice imposed the life sentence on the applicant in 1980.
- The applicant went through several unsuccessful appeals and pardon requests during his incarceration.

title: CASE OF KARDOŠ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Zagreb.
- The applicant was a co-owner of a block of flats on the island of Vir.
- Building inspectors of the Inspectorate carried out an inspection on 2 and 23 March 2006.
- On 31 March 2006, one of the building inspectors ordered the demolition of the block of flats.
- The applicant lodged an appeal and stated that the time-limit was too short and the block of flats was not within the protected coastal area.
- The appeal section of the Legal Department of the Inspectorate dismissed the appeal on 15 May 2006.
- On 4 May 2006, the building inspector issued an administrative enforcement order for the demolition.
- The applicant lodged an appeal against the administrative enforcement order.
- The second-instance body dismissed the appeal as ill-founded on 23 May 2006.
- The co-owners had the block of flats demolished on 27 June 2006.
- On 26 June 2006, the applicant lodged an administrative complaint with the Administrative Court.
- The Administrative Court dismissed her complaint on 22 April 2010.
- The Constitutional Court declared the constitutional complaint inadmissible on 13 December 2010.

title: CASE OF CRISTIOGLO v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lived in Chișinău.
- In 2001, the Comrat Prosecutor's Office initiated a criminal investigation against the applicant for murder, and an arrest warrant was issued by the Comrat District Court as the applicant had left the country.
- The applicant was arrested upon his return to Moldova on 21st January 2011.
- On 4th February 2011, the applicant cut open his abdomen as a sign of protest and was taken to the hospital for treatment.
- The applicant's habeas corpus request was rejected, and he was detained in different prisons.
- The conditions of detention were overcrowded, with limited space, poor hygiene, inadequate ventilation, insufficient light, and low-quality food.
- The applicant alleged he did not receive timely medical attention despite his medical issues.
- The report of the United Nations Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment stated that Institution No. 13 in Chișinău was severely overcrowded.
- The Human Rights Centre in Moldova reported issues with personal hygiene, clothing, bedding, and poor quality and quantity of food.
- The Moldovan prisons did not conform to current national and international standards, with inadequate sanitary equipment, overcrowding, and poor ventilation.

title: CASE OF COSTEL POPA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is born in 1977 and lives in Bucharest.
- On 11 October 2009, the EcoPolis association, co-founded by the applicant, opened proceedings to seek registration in the Register of Associations and Foundations.
- The association's goal is to promote sustainable development principles at the public policy level in Romania.
- The association's objectives include improving the process of sustainable public policies, increasing accountability, ensuring transparency, and defending the right to a clean environment.
- The association's activities include research, public debates, monitoring the implementation of EU directives, opinion polls, training, awareness-raising, networking, and other lawful activities.
- The Bucharest District Court granted the association legal personality and ordered its registration.
- The Bucharest Public Prosecutor's Office lodged an appeal stating that the association's declared goal belonged to the field of activities of a political party, which cannot be registered under Government Ordinance no. 26/2000.
- The Bucharest County Court allowed the appeal and rejected the association's request for registration, stating that the association's objectives could have been interpreted as belonging to the realm of activity of a political party, although that was not allowed under Government Ordinance no. 26/2000.

title: CASE OF KANDA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Hajdúnánás.
- The applicant is a shareholder of a limited liability company registered under Hungarian law, with its seat in Hajdúnánás.
- On 10 October 2001 the Hajdú-Bihar County Regional Court ordered the liquidation of the company.
- On 23 December 2005 the first instance court declared the liquidation proceedings terminated and ordered the dissolution of the company.
- On appeal, the Debrecen Court of Appeal quashed the judgment.
- The first-instance court re-heard the case and on 5 June 2009 it declared the liquidation proceedings terminated and ordered the dissolution of the company.
- On appeal, the Debrecen Court of Appeal quashed the judgment on 2 March 2010.
- The first-instance court re-heard the case and on 12 February 2013 it declared the liquidation proceedings terminated and ordered the dissolution of the company.
- The decision of the court became final on 27 March 2013.

title: CASE OF CUNHA MARTINS DA SILVA COUTO v. PORTUGAL
facts:
• Applicant’s birth year is 1961 and residence is in Porto.
• Too long duration of trials is the complaint.
• Inadequate remedy is alleged in that regard. 
• Full details about the application are tabled.

title: CASE OF VASILEVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Kavadarci.
- In April 2000, Mr I.A. sold a lorry to a company, M., while criminal proceedings were pending against him.
- On 13 June 2000, Mr I.A. was convicted of smuggling nearly 9 tonnes of sugar, which he had transported in the lorry in November 1997.
- The Skopje Court of First Instance dismissed the prosecutor's application to have the lorry confiscated.
- On 17 September 2003, Mr I.A. was convicted in absentia and the Trial Court ordered the confiscation of the lorry and the sugar.
- The company M. sold the lorry to the applicant on 6 September 2004.
- On 12 June 2006, the confiscation order was enforced against the applicant by the Kavadarci Court of First Instance.
- On 15 November 2006, the applicant objected to the enforcement of the confiscation order.
- On 10 May 2007, the first-instance court dismissed the applicant's claim and established that the lorry was confiscated in favor of the respondent State in lawful proceedings.
- The applicant appealed to the Skopje Court of Appeal, which dismissed his appeal on 19 October 2007.

title: CASE OF BALAJEVS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently in detention in Daugavpils.
- On 8 May 2006 the applicant was transferred from the Central Prison to Riga Regional Court and was placed in a holding cell.
- At 11.25 a.m., the applicant asked the detainee escort officers from the State Police to call an ambulance. He had pain around the waist area and was nauseous. The ambulance arrived at 11.35 a.m. It was established that the applicant was suffering from kidney stones and renal colic. He was given painkillers.
- The applicant had pain in the area of the waist and asked his escort officers to call an ambulance again, shouting and cursing while doing so. One of the escort officers, M.P., had entered the cell in order to calm him down. The applicant had attempted to hit M.P. In order to prevent the attack, M.P. had forced the applicant onto the floor, using physical force and a restraint technique.
- At 1.48 p.m. the escort officers called the ambulance for the second time. The ambulance arrived at 2.04 p.m. The applicant informed the ambulance staff that the officers had hit him on his left side. In the ambulance log it was noted that he had no visible injuries. The applicant was taken to the prison hospital in Olaine, where he was diagnosed with a fracture to the third lumbar vertebra and contusion of the left kidney. 
- The Internal Security Office of the State Police commenced criminal proceedings for the offense of exceeding official authority. 
- An expert from the State Forensic Centre examined the applicant’s medical records and concluded that the applicant had sustained a fracture of the third lumbar vertebra which was classified as a moderately severe injury.
- Three rounds of investigation were conducted by the Internal Security Office of the State Police and prosecution services, and it could not be established that the use of force had been unjustified.

title: CASE OF BAGIYEVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1958, divorced her husband in 1992 and was living with her minor daughter in a flat in Kyiv
- Police officers arrested the ex-husband for document forgery
- Conversations between the ex-husband and the applicant suggested that certain documents relating to his driving license and study in the driving school had been kept in her flat
- The investigator applied for search warrants for the two flats including the one belonging to the applicant
- The Shevchenkivskyy District Court of Kyiv issued the search warrants and authorized the search of the applicant's flat
- Police officers called a task force to open the door to the flat as the applicant was not responding
- The police officers seized several items of property while searching the flat and listed them in a report
- The applicant returned home and found the door to her flat damaged and sealed with some items of the property missing
- The applicant made a complaint to the law enforcement authorities regarding the actions of the police officers carrying out the search
- The Kyiv transport prosecutor’s office commenced a criminal investigation with respect to the possible theft of the applicant’s property
- Certain seized items including the missing mobile phones were returned to the applicant
- The investigator terminated the investigation as there was no evidence to suggest that any item was stolen from the applicant’s flat during the search
- The Holosiyivskyy District Court of Kyiv dismissed the applicant’s complaint and considered that the investigator had taken the necessary measures and had lawfully closed the case.
- The Kyiv City Court of Appeal quashed the decisions of the first instance court and the investigator, and remitted the case for further investigation
- On 16 June 2005, the Kyiv transport prosecutor refused to commence criminal proceedings in relation to the possible abuse of power or ultra vires actions by the police officers during the search of the applicant’s flat
- The Holosiyivskyy District Court of Kyiv found that the decision of 16 June 2005 was well-founded
- The Kyiv Court of Appeal upheld the decision of 7 July 2005, finding that the prosecutor had lawfully refused to open an investigation
- The applicant appealed on points of law, which were later dismissed by the Supreme Court

title: CASE OF ČAMANS AND TIMOFEJEVA v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1970 and 1956 and lived in Daugavpils.
- An inquiry by the KNAB revealed information about suspected bribery involving contraband tobacco and alcohol stored on the premises of company M owned by V.K.
- In November 2011, KNAB transmitted this information to VID, which dispatched officers to company M to commence an inspection under Article 2561 of the Code of Administrative Violations.
- The inspection was interrupted when employees refused to open a suspicious container on orders from V.K. over the telephone, but was resumed after officers obtained a prosecutor's authorization.
- The first applicant was handcuffed by officers at the outbuilding of a furnace facility and was not allowed to use his phone. Meanwhile, the second applicant was not allowed to leave the site and was ordered to participate in the inspection. Both applicants were questioned as witnesses the next day.
- The first applicant was declared a suspect and subsequently charged, but the criminal proceedings were terminated due to lack of corpus delicti on his part.
- The applicants lodged complaints against VID officers for restricting their freedom of movement and breach of Article 5 of the Convention. The complaints were dismissed by prosecutor O.R., and the applicants appealed but were unsuccessful. Furthermore, disciplinary proceedings against the officers were not opened by VID.

title: CASE OF CERF v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant’s husband was a member of a political party that was dissolved in 2003.
- The husband and his family were harassed and threatened by police officers prior to his death.
- The husband was shot and killed outside of a cafe, along with a friend who was also a member of the political party.
- Eyewitnesses saw the two assailants running away from the scene.
- The police found spent bullet cases and bullets at the scene.

- A board member of the same political party was killed after being taken to a police station on the pretext of giving a statement.
- Witnesses and individuals involved in the case were subject to harassment and threats from police officers.
- A number of individuals were arrested in connection to the killing, and some later retracted their statements.
- Criminal proceedings were brought against some of the suspects, with varying outcomes.
- Some of the suspects were released from prison and fled the country.
- The applicant’s attempts to obtain information from prosecutors about the investigation were largely unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF ABDI MAHAMUD v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1992 and was detained in Lyster Barracks Detention Centre in Ħal Far at the time of the introduction of the application
- The applicant entered Malta irregularly by boat on 6 May 2012, was registered by the immigration police, and presented with a Return Decision and a Removal Order
- The Return Decision stated that she was a prohibited immigrant and that her stay was being terminated and that she had the possibility to apply for voluntary departure
- The applicant applied for asylum under Article 8 of the Refugees Act, but her application was rejected by the ORC and RAB
- The applicant suffered from several medical problems, anxiety, and depression, and was referred to AWAS for release from detention on the grounds of vulnerability due to physical and psychological ill-health
- The Vulnerable Adult Assessment Procedure operated by AWAS was not adequately regulated by law or by publicly available rules or procedures
- The applicant was hospitalised several times and suffered from various medical conditions
- The applicant was detained in Hermes Block in Lyster Barracks, in conditions she considered prison-like and basic, lacked constructive activities to occupy detainees, overcrowding, limited access to open air, lack of information about their own situations, and lack of proper arrangements for heating and cooling
- The applicant was released from detention on 12 September 2013.

title: CASE OF LETINČIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant's father, a war veteran, killed the applicant's mother and her parents before committing suicide in 1993.
- In 1996, the applicant filed a request for family disability benefit due to his father's suicide, claiming it was caused by mental derangement as a result of his participation in the war.
- The request was initially dismissed but eventually remitted for re-examination in 1997.
- In 2005, the applicant's request was dismissed again for lack of evidence linking his father's suicide to his participation in the war.
- The Ministry ordered an expert report from a medical institution and witness statements to clarify the matter in 2006.
- The expert report concluded in 2007 that there was no link between the father's suicide and his participation in the war.
- The applicant challenged this decision in 2008, arguing that another expert report should be commissioned from permanent court experts in psychiatry.
- The Administrative court dismissed the applicant's challenge as ill-founded in 2008, stating that the defendant acted lawfully in dismissing the appeal against the first-instance decision.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint in 2009, arguing that his right to a fair trial had been violated.
- The Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible in 2010.

title: CASE OF TOPEKHIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lived in Moscow before his arrest.
- The police investigation began on 27 February 2012, relating to fraud resulting in 10,000,000 Russian roubles being taken.
- The applicant was accused of fraud on 24 January 2013 and fled, leading to a warrant for his arrest.
- On 16 July 2013, he was arrested and held in police custody.
- The Tverskoy District Court of Moscow granted his pre-trial detention until 16 September 2013, due to the severity of his charges and absconding risk.
- The City Court upheld this ruling on 19 August 2013.
- On 13 September 2013, his detention was extended until 16 November 2013 by the District Court due to flight risk and lack of stable income or work.
- The District Court authorized the applicant's pre-trial detention until 30 March 2014 on 14 November 2013.
- After his arrest, he was initially held in a Moscow police ward, which measured 12 square metres and usually housed two or three inmates.
- He was taken to remand prison no. IZ‑77/2 in Moscow on 24 July 2013, where he stayed through at least 15 January 2014.
- His cell measured around 11.4 square metres and housed another inmate, but staff had to assist him with his daily needs.
- The applicant's medical condition worsened during detainment, initially requiring inpatient treatment.
- The applicant was diagnosed with paraplegia of unknown origin, headaches and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, and he was subsequently discharged to undergo treatment in a civilian hospital.
- His treatment included antioxidant and neutrophil treatment, muscle relaxants, painkillers, and physiotherapy.
- The applicant's medical condition required enhanced medical attention and inpatient treatment in a neurological medical facility.
- The applicant was taken to the correctional colony on 6 March 2014, and he was granted early release due to his health on 3 July 2014.

title: CASE OF BABAJANOV v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant fled from Uzbekistan in 1999 due to pressure from the police because of his religious beliefs and practices.
- The applicant settled in Iran in 2005 and applied for refugee status.
- In 2007, the applicant and other Uzbek asylum seekers fled Iran due to deportation threats and arrived in Turkey illegally.
- The applicant obtained an asylum seeker certificate and started the domestic temporary asylum procedure.
- The applicant and other asylum seekers were detained and forcibly deported to Iran on 12 September 2008.
- After re-entering Turkey illegally, the applicant went back to Van together with the other Uzbek asylum seekers.
- The deportation of the applicant and other Uzbek nationals was brought to the attention of the national and international public and condemned by various organizations.
- The applicant's asylum claim is still under review by UNHCR and he has been living in hiding in Turkey since 2008.
- The applicant has not received any information from the Turkish authorities regarding his request for asylum.
- The applicant's identity documents were not confiscated according to the government's statement.

title: CASE OF MARTINS SOUSA AND OTHERS v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The document has a table showing the list of applicants and their relevant details 
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings 
- The applicants also complained about the lack of any effective remedy to address the issue.

title: CASE OF GAYSANOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the mother of Ms Zarema Gaysanova.
- The applicant's property at 7 Second Darvina Lane in Kalinin was under reconstruction after being heavily damaged during a Chechen military campaign.
- Ms Gaysanova was at the applicant's property on the day of her disappearance, while the law-enforcement authorities conducted a special operation aimed at eliminating members of illegal armed groups.
- The house caught fire and Ms Gaysanova was pushed into a UAZ vehicle and taken away, while law-enforcement officers recovered a man's body.
- The Chechen President, Mr Ramzan Kadyrov, and the Chechen Minister of the Interior, Mr Ruslan Alkhanov, arrived at the property after the operation.
- The applicant has had no news of her daughter since her disappearance.
- The criminal case file concerning Ms Zarema Gaysanova's disappearance contained information suggesting that a special operation had been conducted in Kalinin, but there was no indication that the applicant's daughter had been arrested in the course of that operation.
- Witnesses were questioned by the investigators, including the applicant, construction workers, police officers, and Ms Gaysanova's colleagues and relatives.

title: CASE OF RĂCHITĂ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Applicant's property rights for 350 square metres of land were acknowledged.
- Unidentified owner of a plot of land across the street built a fence that encroached onto V. Street.
- Applicant requested the Department of Discipline in Constructions to remove the fence.
- Applicant asked the Mayor of Bucharest, Bucharest General and Local Councils to take necessary measures to remove the fence.
- Applicant filed an action against the Mayor of Bucharest, Bucharest General and Local Councils seeking a court order to remove the fence and to arrange for the removal of the fence without the owner’s consent.
- The court dismissed the applicant's action.
- The applicant appealed on points of law against the judgment.
- The Public Domain Administration identified the owner of the fence.
- The court of appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal.
- The office of the Mayor of Bucharest issued the urban planning certificate requested by the applicant.
- The applicant’s son sold the land to a third party.
- The applicant’s son incurred additional damage following the sale of the land.

title: CASE OF YEGORYCHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lives in Moscow.
- Charges of fraud were brought against the applicant on 14 June 2001, and some of his assets were frozen.
- On 21 June 2001, the investigation was terminated, but it resumed on 26 September 2001.
- On 26 September 2001, the Prosecutor General’s Office of Russia placed the applicant in pre-trial detention due to the seriousness of the charges, the risk of his absconding, and the need to “secure the enforcement of the conviction”.
- On 28 September 2001, the applicant was remanded into custody and placed in a specialised detention facility.
- On 8 October 2001, the applicant brought an application for release, arguing that the choice of a custodial measure had not been justified.
- On 24 October 2001, the Moscow Babushkinskiy District Court held that there were no grounds for releasing the applicant.
- The Moscow City Court upheld that decision on appeal on 20 November 2001.
- The applicant's detention was extended several times until 28 June 2002.
- On 26 May 2004, the Moscow Presnenskiy District Court convicted the applicant of fraud and sentenced him to seven years and six months’ imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed, and on 17 August 2004, the Moscow City Court reduced the sentence to six years.
- On 30 December 2004, the Presidium of the Moscow City Court modified the charges the applicant had been convicted on and reduced his sentence to five years six months’ imprisonment.
- On 9 March 2005, the Sukhinichskiy District Court ordered the applicant’s conditional early release.

title: CASE OF NEKRASOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and is currently serving a sentence of imprisonment.
- On 17 November 2004, the applicant was allegedly abducted by the police.
- The applicant was subjected to ill-treatment until 23 November 2004, which included being forced to do the splits and suffocated with a plastic bag.
- On 23 November 2004, the applicant was arrested and taken to be interrogated.
- The applicant was seriously injured, and there were large bruises on both thighs, abrasions on the nasal septum, and limitation of movement in the left hand and both legs.
- The applicant alleged that he had been beaten up by the officers of the Organised Crime Department.
- The investigator ordered a review of the applicant’s medical file by a forensic medical expert.
- The applicant underwent hospital treatment for his injuries for a variety of neurological conditions.
- The decisions of the investigator refused to institute criminal proceedings against police officers.
- The presence of abrasions on the applicant’s body did not indicate torture.

title: CASE OF DŽINIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant is a businessman living in Županja born in 1952.
- On 11 August 2000, the Vukovar County State Attorney's Office requested an investigation of the applicant's alleged economic crimes and the restraining of his real property to secure a probable confiscation order in the amount of approximately €469,475.
- The investigation began on 21 August 2000, and the investigating judge declared the request for seizure of the applicant's property inadmissible on 6 March 2001.
- On 10 May 2002, the applicant was indicted on charges of economic crime and was found guilty of charges of misappropriation of company shares on 8 April 2008.
- On 18 October 2011, the Supreme Court quashed the conviction and ordered a retrial.
