- On 27 June 2012, the Vukovar County State Attorney's Office requested the seizure of the applicant's real property to secure confiscation of approximately €1,060,000.
- On 30 October 2012, the Vukovar County Court ordered the restraint of the applicant's real property by prohibiting its alienation or encumbrance to secure confiscation of the proceeds of crime.
- On 12 July 2013, the applicant appealed the decision of the Vukovar County Court, arguing that there was a gross disproportionality between the alleged pecuniary gain obtained and the value of the seized property. 
- On 17 October 2013, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal, stating that the principle of proportionality had not been breached. 
- On 7 February 2014, the Constitutional Court declared the challenge to the Supreme Court's decision inadmissible.

title: CASE OF KARÁCSONY AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicants were members of parliament and of the opposition party.
- Placards/banners with critical messages were displayed during parliamentary sessions.
- The speaker proposed fines for the conduct of the applicants.
- The fines were approved by the plenary without debate.

title: CASE OF BAKRINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1978 and lived in Kazan. 

• The Novo-Savinovskiy District Court of Kazan acquitted the applicant on four counts of drug-dealing on 24 November 2006 but convicted her on one count and sentenced her to eight years’ imprisonment and a fine.

• On 13 February 2007, the Supreme Court of the Republic of Tatarstan upheld the judgment on appeal with minor changes.

• On 2 July 2008, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Republic of Tatarstan in supervisory review proceedings annulled the judgment on the applicant’s request.

• On 15 October 2008, the Novo-Savinovskiy District Court of Kazan acquitted the applicant on the same grounds after re-calculation of the applicable time-limits for investigative actions.

• On 18 November 2008, the Supreme Court of the Republic of Tatarstan upheld the judgment on appeal.

• On 18 February 2009, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Republic of Tatarstan in supervisory review proceedings annulled the judgments on the prosecutor’s request.

• The case was then sent for reconsideration. 

• On 9 October 2009, the applicant was convicted, sentenced to five years’ imprisonment, suspended for five years, and fined.

title: CASE OF OJCZYK v. POLAND
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is a Polish national currently in detention in Łódź Remand Centre.
- The parties' statements about the conditions of the applicant's detention from July 2008 to January 2010 are contradictory.
- The applicant was detained in Łódź Remand Centre from August 2005 to April 2010, with some periods of temporary release.
- The applicant alleges that he was held in overcrowded cells for seven months during his detention, with less than the minimum statutory standard per person.
- Overcrowding at Łódź Remand Centre during the applicant's detention from 2005 to 2007 ranged from 20.1% to 35.3%, while from 2007 to 2008, the size of the applicant's cells varied, and from 2010 there was no overcrowding.
- The applicant was detained with a person infected with the hepatitis C virus for three weeks in 2005 and with an HIV-positive person from January to April 2007.
- The applicant alleges that the cells were badly ventilated, but he made no other submissions about the conditions of his detention in the subsequent period.
- The applicant had one hot shower per week and one hour of outdoor exercise per day.
- The applicant and the Government dispute whether the applicant was held in Łódź Prison or Remand Centre from July 2008 to August 2009.
- The applicant brought a civil action for infringement of his personal rights in May 2008, which was dismissed by the Łódź Regional Court in April 2010. The Łódź Court of Appeal granted him PLN 6,000 in compensation in September 2010.
- The applicant alleges that he did not receive the legal opinion by his lawyer in February 2011 because he was on a temporary release at that time, which the Government disputes.

title: CASE OF McINNES v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Cres Salisbury East, Australia.
- The applicant sustained injuries in a traffic accident on 19 March 1985.
- The accident was caused by vehicles owned by Danilo Bošković A.D. - Grdelica and Srbijatrans – Niš, both State/socially-owned companies.
- Two separate judgments were rendered on 23 November 2001 and 1 July 2008, ordering the debtors to pay compensation to the applicant.
- Due to the debtors' failure to fulfill obligations from the decisions, enforcement requests were submitted.
- Enforcement orders were issued on 7 October 2005 and 18 October 2010.
- The enforcement proceedings are still pending, and the decisions remain unenforced.

title: CASE OF D.L. v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1999 and lives in Pleven.
- The applicant was admitted to the Open Door children’s crisis centre in Pleven on 2 August 2012 as a protective measure under the Child Protection Act and her placement was ordered by the Pleven municipal director of social assistance at the request of her mother.
- In a decision of 1 October 2012, a criminal bench of the Pleven District Court confirmed the applicant’s placement and extended its validity for a further three months.
- On 16 January 2013, the municipal director of social assistance ordered the extension of the applicant’s placement in the centre, and on 1 April 2013, a civil bench of the District Court confirmed the measure and extended it for a further six months.
- On 10 June 2013, a criminal bench of the District Court ordered the applicant’s placement in the correctional boarding school in Podem.
- In a final judgment of 16 July 2013, a criminal bench of the Pleven Regional Court upheld the first-instance court’s decision.
- On 13 September 2013, the applicant attempted to commit suicide and was admitted to the toxicology department of Pleven Hospital.
- On 15 September 2013, the applicant was taken to the Podem school.
- The applicant continued to be threatened with forced prostitution by her former contacts after being admitted to the Podem school, and attempted suicide for the second time on 19 November 2013.
- The applicant’s telephone conversations were monitored by a supervisor, and the prosecutor’s office ordered an inspection of all secure educational institutions, including the Podem school, on 7 November 2013.
- The applicant was deficient in many areas but showed some interest in schoolwork, achieved an average mark of 3.69 out of 6 at the end of the 2013/14 school year and had moved up to the next class.

title: CASE OF J.N. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Barking.
- The applicant arrived in the United Kingdom on 7 January 2003 and claimed asylum on 15 January 2003.
- The applicant's claim for asylum was refused on 15 March 2003, and his appeal against the decision was refused on 1 October 2003.
- The applicant was convicted of indecent assault on two fifteen-year-old girls on 13 February 2004 and sentenced to twelve months' imprisonment.
- The applicant's license was revoked on 24 September 2004 because he failed to comply with its terms. 
- The applicant was re-arrested on 16 January 2005, and on 31 March 2005 was served with the decision to make a deportation order.
- The applicant was detained on the same day under the Secretary of State's powers under paragraph 2(3) of Schedule 2 to the Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc.) Act 2004.
- The deportation order was signed on 4 August 2005 and served on him on 12 August 2005.
- The applicant was unable to obtain a travel document and remained in detention.
- The applicant commenced judicial review proceedings challenging his continued detention on 13 September 2007.
- On 11 December 2007, the Administrative Court ordered the applicant's release from detention subject to several conditions.
- The applicant refused to sign a disclaimer on 14 December 2007.
- The applicant was released on 17 December 2007 but was once again liable for detention 4 days later when he failed to comply with the conditions for release.
- The applicant made several attempts for bail in 2009, which were dismissed.
- The applicant's solicitors wrote a letter before action on 21 October 2009, and proceedings were issued on 6 November.
- The High Court granted the applicant permission to apply for judicial review on 4 December 2009, and he was ordered to be released on bail within forty-eight hours.
- The judge found that the applicant's detention had been unlawful from 14 September 2009.
- The applicant was awarded GBP 6,150 in damages on 13 May 2011.

title: CASE OF CHUMAK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's wife died in a traffic accident caused by Mr V. on 13 November 2003.
- The police immediately examined the scene of the accident and conducted a medical examination of Mr V.
- The criminal investigation was instituted on 17 November 2003.
- The investigation was terminated on 27 December 2003 due to the inability to establish the responsible party, then resumed on 4 February 2004 on account of its incompleteness.
- There were six more decisions between February 2004 and April 2005 to discontinue the criminal proceedings due to lack of evidence.
- The applicant was recognised as being a victim and a civil plaintiff in the criminal case on 11 July 2004.
- The criminal case against Mr V. was referred to the Shostka Local Court on 5 July 2005, remitted for additional investigation on 29 August 2005, terminated on 18 March 2006 due to lack of evidence, and quashed on 20 March 2007.
- Criminal proceedings against Mr V. were terminated on 19 April 2007 for lack of evidence, then resumed on 1 July 2008.
- On 12 March 2011, Mr V. was sentenced to five years’ imprisonment combined with a driving ban for three years, and ordered to pay pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage to the applicant and other victims.
- On 28 July 2011, the Sumy Court of Appeal quashed the judgment of 12 March 2011, terminated the criminal proceedings, and amnestied Mr V.
- The applicant instituted separate civil proceedings against Mr V. on 29 August 2011.
- The Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court upheld the decision of the appellate court on 29 March 2012 in the criminal case against Mr V.
- On 8 January 2013, the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court of Ukraine upheld the decision of the Sumy Court of Appeal of 15 August 2012 allowing the applicant’s civil claim and ordering payment of pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages in the amount of UAH 10,774.32.
- On 28 November 2014, the decision was partly enforced and the applicant was paid pecuniary and non‑pecuniary damages in the amount of UAH 1,942.

title: CASE OF I.C. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was 14 years and four months old at the time of the event.
- The applicant was attending a funeral wake when she was approached by three boys and taken to a nearby deserted building.
- One man, M.C., had sexual intercourse with the applicant while two others, A.C.L. and V.F., attempted to do the same.
- The applicant complained to her father who then informed the police.
- A forensic examination showed no signs of traumatic lesions, but the applicant was diagnosed with stress-related anxiety, slight intellectual disability, and lice infestation.
- The applicant was admitted to the psychiatric hospital where she received treatment for an emotional disorder, sleep disorder, anaemia, and other conditions.
- The police took statements from all those involved, and the case was transmitted to the prosecutor’s office.
- The prosecutor indicted M.C. for sexual intercourse with a minor and A.C.L. for attempt to commit the same crime.
- The Beiuş District Court convicted M.C. of sexual intercourse with a minor and gave him a suspended sentence of one year and four months. A.C.L. was convicted of attempted sexual intercourse with a minor and given a suspended sentence of one year.

title: CASE OF MAKSHAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1978 and lived in Sarapul, the Republic of Udmurtiya.
2. He was convicted of criminal offenses, including aggravated robbery committed by a criminal group, and sentenced to six years and ten months’ imprisonment.
3. He was first transferred to prison hospital no. IZ-18/1 in Izhevsk.
4. The applicant was detained in different cells (no. 4, no. 1, and no. 20) with different conditions throughout his detention.
5. Daily outdoor exercises were considered dispiriting as the prison yard was gloomy and small.
6. Communal shower facilities were in unsanitary conditions with only fifteen minutes allotted for taking a shower.
7. The quality of food in the prison was considered poor with meat or fish only served on public holidays.
8. The prison hospital administration claimed that the facility had not been overcrowded and that the cells had sufficient lighting and ventilation; the toilets had partitions and proper heating systems.
9. The applicant was diagnosed with infiltrative tuberculosis and received inpatient anti-tuberculosis treatment but failed to recover completely.
10. He lodged complaints to different authorities about the poor quality of medical care but was unsuccessful in obtaining adequate treatment.

title: CASE OF SADRETDINOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former notary, born in 1969, who lived in Moscow until his arrest.
- A criminal investigation was opened on 22 November 2003 relating to attempted murder.
- On 15 April 2005, the case was reopened and joined to criminal proceedings for the killings of Mr Khlebnikov and Mr Sergunin, believed to be connected.
- The applicant was arrested on 24 May 2005 and his detention was authorized by the District Court, citing gravity of charges and risk of absconding.
- The applicant's detention was extended multiple times, citing the complexity of the case and the seriousness of the charges.
- The applicant's detention was challenged by his lawyer under Article 5 § 3 of the Convention, but the court refused to release him.
- The applicant and his co-defendants were acquitted of all charges and released on 6 May 2006.
- The applicant's health conditions, including epilepsy, were disputed between the Government and the applicant's version, with requests for medical examination being refused.
- The applicant was later arrested again and sentenced to eight years' imprisonment for fraud, abuse of position, and property laundering.

title: CASE OF PAUNOVIĆ AND MILIVOJEVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants are Serbian nationals and both former members of parliament (MPs).
- Parliamentary elections in Serbia are based on a proportional representation system where political parties put forward lists of candidates that voters choose from.
- Candidates, including the applicants, were required to sign undated letters of resignation authorizing their party to replace them with other candidates if necessary.
- The first applicant signed a statement declaring his prior resignation letter null and void, which he made public.
- The head of the G17PLUS party group in Parliament dated the applicants’ resignation letters and submitted them to the President of the Parliament after the applicants declared their prior resignation letters null and void.
- Both applicants asserted that they did not intend to resign, but the committee concluded that they had resigned and therefore their parliamentary mandates were terminated.
- The plenary session of Parliament confirmed the committee's decision and replaced the applicants with two other candidates proposed by the party.
- The applicants filed complaints with the Supreme Court and Constitutional Court seeking to annul Parliament’s decisions to terminate their mandates and replace them with other candidates.
- The complaint made to the Supreme Court was dismissed on procedural grounds and the Constitutional Court also ruled against the applicants, noting that their complaint became moot after new parliamentary elections were held in January 2007.

title: CASE OF MANZHOS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant arrested on 7 March 2008 for offensive language
- Applicant claims ill-treatment by police officers
- Bruises, scratches, and injuries noted by doctors and forensic bureau
- Applicant files request for criminal proceedings against police officers
- Multiple decisions to reject request based on witness statements and lack of evidence
- Decisions to reject request repeatedly set aside and pre-investigation inquiries ordered
- Tsentralniy District Court discontinues proceedings to challenge decisions
- Criminal proceedings finally instituted after application is communicated to Russian Government
- Onsite verification and identity parade conducted, but alleged perpetrators cannot be identified
- Investigation eventually suspended due to inability to identify perpetrators.

title: CASE OF BIAO v. DENMARK
facts:
1. The applicants were born in Togo and Ghana, respectively, and lived in Sweden.
2. The first applicant entered Denmark in 1993 and was refused asylum in 1995 but granted a residence permit through marriage to a Danish national in 1996.
3. The first applicant became a Danish citizen in 2002 and married the second applicant in Ghana in 2003.
4. The second applicant applied for a residence permit in Denmark but was refused due to the attachment requirement, which was based on the strength of ties to Denmark over any other country.
5. The applicants moved to Sweden in 2003 and had a son who is a Danish national.
6. The applicants claimed that the refusal to grant a residence permit to the second applicant was a breach of Article 8 of the Convention, alone and in conjunction with Article 14 of the Convention, and Article 5(2) of the European Convention on Nationality.
7. The High Court of Eastern Denmark found that the refusal did not contravene the Convention or the European Convention on Nationality.
8. The applicants appealed to the Supreme Court, which also upheld the decision made by the Ministry of Integration that it is not contrary to Article 8 to refuse the second applicant's application for a residence permit.

title: CASE OF BLAGOJEVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants were former employees of "LETEKS" u stečaju, a company predominantly comprised of socially-owned capital.
- The applicants instituted civil proceedings against the debtor for failing to fulfil contractual obligations towards its employees.
- The Leskovac Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicants specified amounts on account of salary arrears, plus the costs and expenses of the civil proceedings.
- The judgment became final on 3 October 2010.
- The applicants filed separate requests for the enforcement of the judgment between 20 November 2008 and 30 November 2009.
- The Leskovac Municipal Court issued enforcement orders in response to the applicants' requests.
- Insolvency proceedings were opened against the debtor on 25 January 2011.
- The applicants' claims were formally recognized at an unspecified date.
- The insolvency proceedings against the debtor are ongoing.
- A constitutional appeal was lodged on 31 March 2010.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the appeal for all applicants except three, citing a violation of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time.
- The Constitutional Court found a violation of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time for the three remaining applicants, awarded each of them 500 euros as just satisfaction for non-pecuniary damage, and ordered the court in Leskovac to expedite the proceedings.

title: CASE OF MARDARE v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1955 and currently detained in Iași Prison.
- He was convicted of fraud and sentenced to a term of imprisonment in 2013.
- The applicant alleged poor conditions of hygiene, overcrowded cells, poor quality food, and smoking co-detainees.
- The Government submitted that the cells were equipped with own beds, daily disinfected, and regularly cleaned and ventilated to eradicate rodents and insects.
- The applicant received a special diet for his diabetes.
- The applicant was detained in different prisons in various cells shared with different numbers of co-detainees.

title: CASE OF SHEPEL v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lived in Yaroslavl.
- On 15 April 2008, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of fraud.
- He was charged with fraud, attempted fraud, embezzlement, tax evasion and a breach of duties in his work as a tax agent.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Yaroslavl remanded him in custody on 16 April 2008.
- The Yaroslavl Regional Court upheld the detention order on 25 April 2008.
- The applicant remained in detention pending investigation and trial, with extensions granted by the court using the same formula.
- He was committed for trial before the Kirovskiy District Court of Yaroslavl on 16 March 2009.
- He was convicted on 27 October 2009 and sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment.
- The Yaroslavl Regional Court quashed the judgment on appeal and remitted the case to the first-instance court for a fresh examination on 29 December 2009.
- The trial court ordered his release on bail on 25 January 2010.
- The bail was paid on 27 January 2010, and the applicant was released.
- He was convicted of fraud and attempted fraud on 20 July 2010 and sentenced to five years and six months’ imprisonment.
- The Yaroslavl Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal on 19 October 2010.
- On 2 December 2014, the Government submitted a unilateral declaration acknowledging the applicant's unlawful detention.
- They offered to pay him a sum of 1,850 EUR but the applicant rejected the amount.

title: CASE OF ŠLAKU v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1963 and lives in Sarajevo
- Applicant identifies as a member of BiH's Albanian ethnic minority
- Applicant actively participates in social and political life of the country
- Date of an event: On 26 August 2010
- The applicant received written confirmation from the Central Election Commission stating that minority members were ineligible to run for election to the Presidency and the House of Peoples of the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina in accordance with BiH’s Constitution.

title: CASE OF TUCHIN AND TUCHINA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants are from Odessa and were born in 1943 and 1942 respectively.
- The applicants’ daughter was hit by a car driven by P. while crossing the street on 30 April 2002 and died in the hospital.
- At least ten decisions refusing to institute or discontinuing criminal proceedings in respect of P. were delivered between April 2002 and October 2010.
- On 9 July 2009, the first applicant filed a civil claim against P.
- The criminal proceedings against P. were discontinued by the Odessa Suvorivskyy District Court on 26 October 2010 as time-barred.
- The Odessa Regional Court of Appeal and the Higher Specialised Court for Civil and Criminal Matters upheld that decision on 21 December 2010 and 20 November 2012, respectively.
- On 20 November 2012, the Higher Specialised Court identified numerous shortcomings in the proceedings, including a perfunctory and lengthy pre-trial investigation, unfounded refusals by the investigating authorities, and a duration of over ten years for the investigation, in violation of domestic legislation and the Convention. It instructed the relevant authorities to take measures to avoid similar violations in the future.

title: CASE OF GANKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr Vladislav Andreyevich Gankin filed a civil claim to recover excess service fees paid in May 2006. On 3 October 2007, the Volzhskiy Town Court of the Volgograd Region rejected his claim after hearing the case.
- Mr Gankin appealed to the Volgograd Regional Court, which upheld the Town Court's judgment without addressing whether he was notified or not in his absence on 29 November 2007.
- Ms Olga Ivanovna Shevchenok initiated a defamation action against a third party. The Tsentralnyy District Court of Tyumen dismissed her claim on 6 March 2007. She lodged an appeal statement on 18 March 2007 mentioning her post-office box number. The Tyumen Regional Court examined and dismissed her appeal in her absence on 2 May 2007 without examining whether she was notified or not.
- Mr Aleksey Dmitriyevich Belkin filed a civil claim seeking a copy of a vehicle registration certificate against traffic police in April 2009. The Neyskiy District Court of the Kostroma Region satisfied his claim in part on 19 May 2009. The Kostroma Regional Court quashed the District Court's judgment and dismissed his claim in his absence on 19 August 2009, without examining whether he was notified or not.
- Mr Mikhail Viktorovich Kiryushkin initiated a civil action against his employer for wrongful dismissal. On 1 September 2011, the Kirovskiy District Court of Yekaterinburg refused his claim after hearing the case. The Sverdlovsk Regional Court rejected his appeal claim in his absence on 1 November 2011, without examining whether he was notified or not. The court had sent a judicial summons to him by registered mail on 12 October 2011, and he received the postal notice only on 11 November 2011.

title: CASE OF A.N. v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Naujoji Akmenė.
- In November 1989 he started military service in the armed forces of the Soviet Union.
- Medical records, dated 20 June 1990, drafted by a panel of doctors in his military unit in Riazan (Russia), stipulated that at that time he had problems communicating with others and was autistic, though he had a normal memory and level of intelligence. He was diagnosed with sluggish schizophrenia, which he had developed during military service. On those grounds, he was released from military service.
- By 2005 he had been treated in psychiatric institutions no less than fifteen times. In 2004 he was diagnosed with residual and then paranoid schizophrenia.
- In February 2006 the applicant attempted suicide by setting himself on fire. He was admitted to the trauma unit of a hospital.
- The prosecutor's request for information was replied to on 14 November 2006 by the Akmenė District Psychiatric Health Centre, which confirmed that the applicant had been attending there since 1999, and was being treated for schizophrenia. In 2004 episodes of the applicant’s illness had become more frequent. That year the applicant attempted to commit suicide; he did not accept that he was ill. He was admitted to the Šiauliai Psychiatric Hospital, where he spent about a month before being released for outpatient care at his own request. Since July 2005 the applicant stopped attending the Akmenė District Psychiatric Health Centre and taking his medication, because he firmly refused any consultations with the psychiatrists.
- On 24 November 2006, the applicant's mother asked a prosecutor to initiate proceedings with a view to her son being declared legally incapacitated.
- By a ruling of 29 November 2006, the Akmenė District Court ordered an expert examination to ascertain whether the applicant was suffering from mental illness, whether he could understand his actions, and whether he could take part in court proceedings.
- The psychiatrist concluded that he suffered from paranoid schizophrenia. He was also very mistrusting and had strong feelings of persecution. Psychiatrists took into account the letters by his mother and the prosecutor to the effect that the applicant did not take care of his daily needs, and had social and health issues and suicidal thoughts. The psychiatrist thus established that the applicant could not correctly understand or control his actions, and noted that he “could not take part in court proceedings, could not be questioned, and court documents

title: CASE OF BAKANOVA v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant's husband, a mechanic on the private ship Vega, was found dead in his cabin on October 24, 2007, while on a work voyage to Brazil.
- The ship's captain assembled a commission to investigate the death and sent a report to Limarko shipping company.
- A Brazilian doctor gave acute heart attack as the cause of death, and V.B.'s body was embalmed and shipped to Lithuania.
- A criminal investigation was opened on October 25, 2007, but was initially discontinued on December 29, 2007, due to no signs of a crime.
- The decision to discontinue the investigation was later quashed by the Klaipėda Regional Court on February 13, 2008, and the investigation resumed.
- Witnesses who worked on the Vega testified about frequent fires in the machinery section, and the applicant argued that her husband's death could have been caused by dangerous working conditions.
- The State Labour Inspectorate concluded that V.B.'s death was not connected to his work and discontinued its investigation.
- The prosecutor discontinued the criminal investigation again on December 31, 2008, based on expert testimony that V.B. died of a heart attack.
- The applicant appealed the decision, and the Klaipėda City District Court granted her appeal, stating that the investigation had not been thorough enough and that breaches of working conditions needed to be examined.
- The Klaipėda Regional Court upheld the decision, emphasizing the need to continue the investigation and establish the whereabouts of the Vega and any potential impact of breaches in working conditions on V.B.'s death. The prosecutor ordered the Klaipėda Seaport Police to take further investigative action.

title: CASE OF TENCE v. SLOVENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant lodged a civil action against her former employer seeking payment of a specific amount of money and statutory default interest in respect of contributions made by her into the employee share scheme.
- The Nova Gorica Local Court dismissed her claim, and the time-limit for appealing against the judgment expired at midnight on 28 June 2011.
- At 6.54 p.m. on that day, the applicant’s lawyer sent a document of six pages by fax to the Local Court. The next day, the applicant’s lawyer sent the appeal against the first-instance judgment by registered mail.
- The Local Court rejected the appeal as out of time, stating that the applicant had lodged it on 29 June 2011, which was after the time-limit.
- The applicant appealed against this decision, arguing that she had lodged her appeal by fax within the prescribed period. She submitted a fax confirmation page to support her claim.
- The Higher Court dismissed the appeal, stating that the burden of proof was on the applicant to show that the appeal had been lodged in due time.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law, but the Supreme Court dismissed it, stating that proof of the fax being sent did not necessarily mean proof of receipt of the document.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's constitutional complaint for lack of significant disadvantage and not raising an important constitutional question.
- The applicant requested that the Local Court reinstate her case, but her request was dismissed.

title: CASE OF INSTYTUT EKONOMICHNYKH REFORM, TOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant company is the editorial body of the Evening News newspaper in Ukraine.
- The Evening News newspaper was closely associated with political leader Yuliya Tymoshenko.
- Ganna German worked in journalism and became a spokesperson for Prime Minister Victor Yanukovych.
- In 2007, Evening News published an article critical of Ganna German and her perceived motivations for joining Yanukovych's party, including the acquisition of a flat in Kyiv.
- Ganna German filed a defamation claim against the newspaper and the article's author, seeking retraction and compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The district court ruled in favor of Ganna German on the basis that certain statements in the article constituted untrue statements of fact that were negative and insulting to the plaintiff.
- The court ordered the newspaper to retract the statements and pay compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The appeals court upheld the district court's decision.
- The applicant company appealed on points of law, invoking the freedom of expression and citing previous case law on acceptable criticism of politicians.
- The Supreme Court found no grounds to review the case.

title: CASE OF MITROV v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Strumica.
- At the time when the criminal proceedings were initiated, there were four judges working in the criminal section of the Strumica Court of First Instance: Judges M.A., C.K., T.D., and G.M.
- Judge C.K. was a clerk at the trial court from 2002 and appointed as a judge in February 2005.
- Judge M.A. became president of the criminal section of the trial court in 2004.
- On 26 November 2006, the applicant was involved in a traffic accident in which the daughter of Judge M.A. was killed.
- On 19 January 2007, Judge B.B. opened an investigation against him.
- Evidence was heard from five eyewitnesses, two experts, and the victim's representative.
- A fresh expert report was drawn up at the applicant’s request.
- On 12 July 2007, the applicant asked the president of the trial court to exclude the trial court judges who acted in the proceedings.
- The trial court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to four years and six months’ imprisonment on 5 March 2008.
- On 24 September 2008, the appellate court dismissed the applicant’s appeal and increased the sentence to six years’ imprisonment.
- On 13 January 2009, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s request and confirmed the lower courts’ judgments.

title: CASE OF SHIYANOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's daughter was found dead in a field with numerous injuries.
- The autopsy established that she had been strangled and dragged to the crime scene.
- The police inspected the crime scene and collected various items as material evidence.
- A forensic examination showed that it was not the victim who smoked the cigarettes found at the crime scene.
- One of the victim's shoes was found at a distance from the crime scene.
- A witness reported seeing a beige car with two male passengers and a girl resembling the victim near the crime scene on the night of the murder.
- The suspects seen in the car were questioned, but no tangible results were obtained.
- The investigation was unsuccessful and was suspended at least thirteen times for failure to establish who had committed the murder.
- The applicant submitted numerous complaints about the ineffectiveness of the investigation and put forward his own version of events.
- The applicant's requests for access to the case file were rejected on the grounds that he could only have such access after the pre-trial investigation was completed.
- The applicant brought a civil claim against the prosecution authorities, but courts at three levels of jurisdiction found against him.
- There is no information in the case file about any developments in the investigation after 2010.

title: CASE OF YUNUSOVA AND YUNUSOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The first applicant is a human rights defender and civil society activist, and the second applicant is her husband and a researcher of conflict resolution.
- On 30 July 2014, the first applicant was arrested and charged with several criminal offenses related to fraud, entrepreneurship, tax evasion, high treason, and falsification of official documents.
- The first applicant was ordered to be detained pending trial for a period of three months, which was extended by four months on 24 October 2014. Her request to be released on bail or placed under house arrest was also dismissed.
- The second applicant was questioned on 30 July 2014 and charged with large-scale fraud and high treason. He was initially placed under police supervision due to his health condition but was later ordered to be detained pending trial for three months.
- Both applicants appealed against their detention orders, but their appeals were dismissed by the Baku Court of Appeal.
- The first applicant suffers from chronic hepatitis, type 2 diabetes, myogelosis, hypertension, and a single cyst in the left kidney. She underwent eye surgery before her arrest and needs specialist medical care.
- The second applicant suffers from grade 3 chronic hypertension and had been hospitalised before his arrest.
- The first applicant was detained in a cell with four other detainees, experiencing inadequate heating and electricity, and there was a problem with hot water distribution. She was also deprived of necessary diabetic food and medicine after her husband's arrest.
- The first applicant requested a medical examination by a doctor of her own choosing, but her request was dismissed by the investigator.
- The first applicant's cell was searched on 23 September 2014, and she was deprived of her right to make phone calls for one month.

title: CASE OF INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR COMMERCE AND DEVELOPMENT AD AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
A. The bank's shareholders and management
B. The general meetings of the bank's shareholders on 24 and 27 June 2004
C. The Sofia City Court's decisions to register the resolutions adopted at the two general meetings of shareholders
D. The criminal proceedings against Mr Bonev, Mr Panev and Mr Ivanov
1. The proceedings against Mr Bonev, Mr Panev and Mr Ivanov
2. The proceedings against Mr Panev and Mr Ivanov
E. The service contracts between the bank and Mr Panev, Mr Ivanov and Mr Radev and their attempt to take up office
F. The proceedings before the prosecuting authorities
G. The share transfer
H. The legal challenges against the Sofia City Court's registration decisions
1. The requests for revision
2. The claims under section 74 of the Commerce Act 1991
I. Measures taken by the BNB in relation to the bank
J. The bank's winding-up
K. The freezing of Mr Panev's and Mr Ivanov's bank accounts

title: CASE OF DERNOVYY AND DERNOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants' minor son was hit by a bus driven by Mr. S. on 27 May 2006.
- The son was brought to the hospital on the same day with severe injuries, and died on 1 June 2006 due to numerous serious injuries caused by the traffic accident.
- The Komsomolsk Prosecutor's Office initially refused to institute criminal proceedings against Mr. S. on 9 June 2006, but this decision was quashed on 14 June 2006 with instructions to conduct further investigative actions.
- The Poltava Regional Police Department instituted criminal proceedings into the traffic accident on 6 July 2006 and the applicants were recognised as aggrieved parties on 13 July 2006.
- Between May 2006 and April 2007, the police conducted two technical and two medical forensic expert examinations, on-site traffic accident reconstructions, questioned witnesses including Mr. S. and the applicants.
- The investigation was terminated on numerous occasions between April 2007 and October 2009 due to lack of corpus delicti in Mr. S.'s actions, but resumed later with further instructions from higher Prosecutor's Office.
- The police interviewed more witnesses including the direct witness of the accident, conducted one reconstruction on 7 September 2009, and three technical forensic expert examinations between September 2010 and March 2012.
- Mr. S. was officially recognised as a suspect in the criminal proceedings on 5 October 2010.
- The case was referred to the Komsomolsk Court on 26 March 2012 and on 4 April 2013, the court found that Mr. S. had committed the crime of negligence, amnestied him and left unexamined the applicants' civil claim.
- The judgments were upheld by the Poltava Regional Court of Appeal and the Higher Specialised Civil and Criminal Court on 25 June and 31 October 2013.

title: CASE OF KNICK v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant purchased Turkish and German share certificates in Demirbank through the German stock market.
- Demirbank's management and control, and the privileges of its shareholders (except for dividends) were transferred to the Savings Deposit Insurance Fund due to its financial difficulties.
- The Fund also confiscated all properties belonging to Demirbank.
- The Supreme Administrative Court initially dismissed the case brought by the main shareholder of Demirbank against the decision to transfer the bank to the Fund, but later quashed and set aside the decision.
- The agreement entered into by the Fund and HSBC for the sale of Demirbank was annulled by the Ankara Administrative Court.
- The applicant brought compensation proceedings against the Agency before the Supreme Administrative Court but his case was dismissed.
- The applicant requested the restitution of his rights as a shareholder, but his request was refused as restitution was deemed legally and practically impossible by the Fund, and the Ankara Administrative Court dismissed the case.

title: CASE OF LASHA TCHITCHINADZE v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lives in Tbilisi.
- On 19 February 2005, he was arrested as a suspect in a criminal case and charged with multiple episodes of fraud on 21 February 2005. 
- On 22 February 2005, the First-Instance Panel of the Supreme Court of Georgia ordered the applicant’s release under police supervision, rejecting the prosecutor’s request to place the applicant in pre-trial detention. 
- On 25 February 2005, the Appeals Chamber of the Supreme Court of Georgia reversed the lower-instance decision and placed the applicant in pre-trial detention for three months, justifying its decision on the seriousness of the charges. 
- On 25 March 2005, amendments were introduced to Article 151 §§ 1 and 4 of the CCP, providing that pre-trial detention should be the last resort in cases where it is demonstrated that a more lenient restraint would not be sufficient. 
- On 9 July 2005, the Tbilisi District Court released the applicant on bail, taking into consideration the applicant’s good references and full compensation of the injured party.

title: CASE OF GYULEVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was involved in proceedings regarding the restitution of a flat between 1992 and 2000
- The pre-nationalisation owners were found to be the true owners of the flat after the court proceedings
- On 1 February 2002, the pre-nationalisation owners sold the flat to Mr and Mrs P.
- Mr and Mrs P. brought rei vindicatio proceedings against the applicant, who was occupying the property, which was allowed at first instance by the Plovdiv District Court
- Mr and Mrs P. brought another action against the applicant on 4 May 2005 for unjust enrichment, seeking compensation
- The Plovdiv District Court issued a summons, but it was sent back by the mayor of Hrabrino stating that no such person has been registered to live in the village
- On 26 August 2005, the Plovdiv District Court published a notification concerning the proceedings in the State Gazette after concluding that the applicant was of "unknown address"
- The District Court appointed a lawyer to represent the applicant, who the applicant alleges did not adequately defend her interests
- On 6 April 2006, the Plovdiv District Court ordered the applicant to pay BGN 3,573 to Mr and Mrs P.
- On 10 July 2006, the Plovdiv Regional Court ordered the applicant to pay an additional BGN 1,006.21 to Mr and Mrs P.
- The applicant became aware of the proceedings and the judgments against her on 22 February 2008, when she received a notice from a bailiff to pay the sums due
- The applicant paid the sums owed by her in full, amounting to BGN 8,767.07

title: CASE OF MADAUS v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant's father owned property in the Soviet Occupied Zone of Germany which was subject to expropriation measures in 1946 and 1947, after an administrative body classified him as a "Nazi activist," "Nazi criminal," and "person profiting from the war."
- The applicant's application for restitution of the property under the Property Act proved unsuccessful.
- The applicant initiated proceedings under the Criminal Rehabilitation Act on behalf of his late father, claiming that the expropriation and other measures had a penal character, although his father's guilt had been determined not by a court but by an administrative body.
- The Regional Court fixed a public hearing for August 19, 2008, but cancelled it and set a time-limit for written procedure ending on September 15, 2008.
- The Regional Court rejected the applicant's request, holding that the measures taken against the applicant's father were not of a penal character.

title: CASE OF SARANCHOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lived in Komsomolskoye village in the Kharkiv Region.
- The Pavlograd Police placed the applicant on the wanted list in connection with their criminal investigation into a violent burglary in Pavlograd and the infliction of grave bodily injuries on B.’s daughter P.
- The applicant was arrested in Russia on suspicion of having committed an unrelated crime in that country, for which he was subsequently convicted by a Russian court.
- A Russian court ordered the applicant’s retention in custody pending his extradition to Ukraine in June 2004.
- The applicant was extradited to Ukraine and placed in a pre-trial detention facility in December 2004.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of having committed aggravated burglary on 16 January 2005.
- The applicant signed records confirming his knowledge of his rights and that he would defend himself in court, alleging that he was compelled to sign them by the police.
- The trial took place on 1 March 2005 in the absence of the prosecutor and some witnesses, and the court sentenced the applicant to six and a half years’ imprisonment.
- The sentence was appealed, and the Court of Appeal quashed it and sentenced the applicant to twelve years’ imprisonment and ordered to calculate the imprisonment term from 16 January 2005.
- The applicant appealed on points of law, which was rejected by the Supreme Court, but it reduced the sentence to nine years.
- The term of the applicant’s imprisonment was ordered to be calculated from 1 June 2004 on 10 March 2009.
- The applicant was released from prison on 30 September 2011.

title: CASE OF IONIȚĂ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A list of applicants is included in an appended table.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- Some applicants also raised complaints under other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MERABISHVILI v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained in a prison in Tbilisi, born in 1968.
- The applicant was a leader of United National Movement (UNM) and the Prime Minister of Georgia for several months in 2012, and also held the post of Minister of the Interior between 2005-2012.
- The applicant attempted to cross the Georgian Border with an allegedly fake international passport on 30 November 2012.
- A criminal investigation launched by the Border Police of the Ministry of the Interior into the incident on the same day.
- The applicant was arrested on  21 May 2013 accused of embezzlement, abuse of official authority, and vote-buying.
- The Kutaisi City Court decided to release the Kakheti Governor on bail and remand the applicant in custody.
- The applicant’s request to terminate pre-trial detention was rejected by the Kutaisi City Court on 25 September 2013.
- The applicant was convicted on 17 February 2014, found guilty of vote-buying, misappropriation of property, and breach of inviolability of another person’s home.
- The Kutaisi Court of Appeal upheld the applicant's conviction on 21 October 2014.
- The applicant lodged a further appeal on points of law which is currently pending before the Supreme Court.

title: CASE OF BIRŽIETIS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1953 and lives in the village of Patiltė (Utena Region).
- On 20 November 2006 the applicant began serving a prison sentence at the Marijampolė Correctional Facility.
- The prison regulations were explained to him, which included a prohibition on prisoners growing beards.
- On 4 October 2007 the applicant submitted a request to the Prison Department to allow him to grow a beard for health reasons.
- On 23 October 2007 the Prison Department denied the applicant’s request, based on the results of the examination.
- The applicant later submitted another request to grow a beard to the Prison Department, and on 19 November 2007, it was denied on the same grounds.
- On 5 December 2007, the applicant submitted a complaint to the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court.
- On 21 April 2008 the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court upheld the applicant’s complaint.
- However, on 24 March 2009 the Supreme Administrative Court overturned the first-instance judgment.
- On 15 December 2009 the applicant was released from the Marijampolė Correctional Facility on probation.

title: CASE OF KONIUSZEWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant is a journalist working for a motoring magazine.
- In August 2006, a report was published on the official website of the Competition and Consumer Rights Office, which listed petrol stations that did not meet the quality requirements imposed by the regulations.
- The magazine published a series of articles based on the report, including a table entitled “Stations selling counterfeit fuel”.
- One of the stations listed in the table was owned by B.J., who brought a private prosecution against the applicant for defamation.
- The criminal proceedings were discontinued in 2008, but B.J. appealed and the case was remitted for reconsideration.
- In 2009, the applicant was found guilty of defamation and was fined, ordered to pay to a charity, and to reimburse B.J.’s legal costs.
- The court found that the applicant had failed to show proper diligence by publishing the results of the survey uncritically and using offensive language in the articles, which seriously damaged B.J.’s reputation.
- In 2008, B.J. also brought a civil case for the protection of personal rights against the applicant, the editor-in-chief of the magazine, and its owner, and was awarded compensation and an apology.

title: CASE OF PUGŽLYS v. POLAND
facts:
- Applicant born in 1966 and detained in Suwałki Prison
- Arrest warrant issued on 30 April 2003 on suspicion of leading an international criminal group and six counts of kidnapping for ransom
- Applicant arrested in Netherlands on 22 April 2003 and transferred to Poland on 20 October 2003
- Indicted on 8 April 2004 and trial transferred to Lublin Regional Court
- Appeals against detention and subsequent decisions unsuccessful
- Convicted of six counts of kidnapping for ransom and leading an organized criminal gang on 27 January 2010 and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment 
- Applicant classified as a “dangerous detainee” and subject to periodic reviews 
- Phone calls and visits subject to restrictions 
- Held in a metal cage during some hearings before Lublin Regional Court 
- Received disciplinary punishment for verbally threatening a prison guard.

title: CASE OF URAZOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1969 and lived in Astrakhan.
• On June 15, 2004, at approximately 8 pm, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of attempted fraud.
• On June 16, 2004, a record of the applicant’s arrest was drawn up by the investigator indicating that the applicant’s arrest took place at 11.05 pm on 15 June 2004.
• On June 17, 2004, the District Court authorised the applicant’s detention pending investigation, and on June 25, 2004, the Regional Court upheld the above decision on appeal.
• On August 13, 2004, the applicant was informed that the investigation had been completed and that the case file had been submitted to the District Court for trial.
• On August 15, 2004, the two-month time-limit for the applicant’s detention pending investigation expired, but he remained in detention.
• On August 25, 2004, the District Court scheduled a preliminary hearing and ordered that the preventive measure applied to the applicant should remain unchanged until a date for the opening of the trial had been set.
• On September 9, 2004, the District Court ordered that the preventive measure remain unchanged, and on February 16, 2005, extended the applicant’s detention pending trial for two months, until April 16, 2005.
• On April 7, 2005, the District Court dismissed the application for release and extended the applicant’s detention pending trial for another two months, until June 16, 2005. 
• On June 15, 2005, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention for three months until September 15, 2005.
• On June 29, 2006, the District Court convicted the applicant of attempted large-scale fraud in abuse of office and sentenced him to six years and six months’ imprisonment and a fine.
• On January 11, 2007, the Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal and on 27 January 2009, the applicant obtained a conditional early release.
• From June 2004 to January 2007, and from May 5, 2007, to February 25, 2008, the applicant was held in remand prison IZ-30/1 in the Astrakhan Region, where the facility was severely overcrowded and the cells were in a poor sanitary condition.
• On several occasions, the applicant applied for

title: CASE OF BIRULEV AND SHISHKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- First applicant: 
    - Born in 1978, lives in Tsentrelnye Koryaki in the Kamchatka Region.
    - Arrested on June 20, 2005 while driving a stolen vehicle.
    - Confession statement given on the same day.
    - Yelizovskiy District Court authorized detention on June 22, 2005.
    - Charged with theft on June 29, 2005.
    - Sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment on March 1, 2006.

- Second applicant:
    - Born in 1976, lives in Vladimir.
    - Apprehended on April 11, 2005, in connection with rape case.
    - Identification parade held on the same day.
    - Arrested on April 11, 2005, while being held at the police station.
    - Remanded in custody on April 13, 2005, by Gus-Khrustalnyy Town Court.
    - Detention upheld on appeal on May 16, 2005, by Vladimir Regional Court.
    - Charged with aggravated rape on April 19, 2005.
    - Found guilty and sentenced on December 20, 2005.
    - Held in Vladimir Prison T-2 from April 20, 2005, to March 22, 2006.
    - Conditions of confinement reported as overcrowded and unsanitary.

title: CASE OF DRAGOMIR v. ROMANIA
facts:
1. The applicant was hit by a car while crossing the street on 24 April 2002.
2. The police opened an investigation to clarify the circumstances of the accident.
3. The applicant complained that the driver caused her bodily harm and requested 20,000 US dollars (USD) in civil damages on 19 June 2002.
4. The police officer in charge of the investigation ordered a technical expert report on 5 July 2002.
5. The technical expert report was finalized on 25 August 2004, stating that the applicant was to blame for the accident.
6. On 31 January 2005, the Prosecutor’s Office decided not to prosecute the driver since the fault of the accident lay entirely with the applicant.
7. On 4 August 2005, the applicant's appeal was allowed by the Bucharest County Court, which decided to send the case back to the prosecutor for a more thorough investigation.
8. The applicant made inquiries with the prosecutor’s office about the status of the investigation on 29 December 2005.
9. On 23 January 2007, the prosecutor decided again not to prosecute the driver.
10. On 9 June 2008, the Prosecutor’s Office noted that the limitation period for the crime under investigation had expired on 24 April 2007 and decided to close the case.
11. The applicant claimed 25,000 euros (EUR) in respect of non-pecuniary damage from the driver and the Prosecutor’s Office, which was rejected by the Bucharest District Court and the Bucharest County Court.

title: CASE OF KUZMIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- All applicants were engaged in civil proceedings.
- The first instance and appeal courts gave judgments in their favor.
- These judgments became binding and enforceable.
- However, the supervisory review courts quashed the judgments.
- The reason for the quashing was incorrect application of substantive law or incorrect assessment of evidence.

title: CASE OF HARASZTHY AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Six Hungarian nationals filed an application against Hungary under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms
- The applicants' complaints under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention were communicated to the Government
- Five of the six applicants agreed to waive further claims in exchange for a payment to cover any damage and expenses
- The sixth applicant had a significant portion of their severance payment subject to a 98% tax rate

title: CASE OF IGOR TARASOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant had a fight in a local bar on 26 January 2002.
- Injuries were sustained by bar staff and damage was caused to property in the bar.
- The applicant was arrested for an administrative offence of “minor disorderly acts” provided for in Article 173 of the Code of Administrative Offences.
- On 28 January 2002, the District Court found the applicant guilty of the above offence and sentenced him to five days’ administrative detention.
- The investigator of Nakhimosvkyy District Police Department of Sevastopol instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant and I. for disorderly acts in the bar on 26 January 2002.
- The District Court convicted the applicant of two offences: the offence provided for in Article 122 § 1 of the Criminal Code (“intentional infliction of medium-severity bodily injuries”) and the offence provided for in Article 296 § 4 of the Criminal Code (“disorderly acts” with aggravating circumstances).
- The District Court found that on 13 August 2001, the applicant had beaten his wife, intentionally causing injuries of medium severity.
- At about 4.30 a.m. on 26 January 2002, the applicant and his accomplice I., both drunk and armed with wooden chair legs, entered the L.N. bar where they committed a serious breach of public order.
- The applicant, using obscene language, approached a table occupied by N., B., and K. (bar employees) and, using the wooden chair leg, inflicted minor bodily injuries on N. and K.
- The applicant also hit N. on the head with a bottle, hit a table, which was covered with dishes, using the wooden chair leg, broke a mop and threw a beer bottle at the wall, thus causing damage to property.
- The applicant then went up to a waitress, M., kicked her in the hip and slapped her in the face.
- The District Court sentenced the applicant to three years’ imprisonment for the two crimes taken together, combined with mandatory medical treatment in prison.
- The applicant's objection that he had earlier been convicted of an administrative offence as regards the same events of 26 January 2002 was dismissed by the court.

title: CASE OF AHAD MAMMADLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was a deputy chairman of the Youth Committee of the opposition party, Musavat.
- Demonstrations were planned on two occasions in Baku, demanding free and fair elections and democratic reforms in the country.
- The Baku City Executive Authority refused to authorise the demonstrations at the places indicated by the organisers and proposed a different location on the outskirts of Baku.
- The organisers decided to hold the demonstrations in the centre of Baku despite the refusal.
- The applicant attended both demonstrations and was arrested during the dispersal operation.
- Administrative offence reports were issued against the applicant on both occasions for failing to comply with a lawful order of the police.
- The hearings before the respective first-instance courts were very brief and members of the public, including human rights defenders and journalists, were not allowed inside the courtroom.
- The applicant was not given the opportunity to appoint a lawyer of his own choosing in both cases.
- The applicant was sentenced to seven and ten days’ administrative detention for the two separate convictions.

title: CASE OF SOLTANOV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicants were candidates in parliamentary elections on 7 November 2010 and applied for registration.
- Each nomination needed a minimum of 450 voters' support, submitted to their respective Constituency Electoral Commissions (ConECs).
- The ConECs issued decisions refusing the applicants' registration as candidates, claiming signatures on the submitted sheets were invalid or falsified, and fewer than 450 voters supported their candidacy.
- The ConECs did not allow the applicants to participate in the examination of their signature sheets and did not provide the candidates with documents or the opportunity to rectify rectifiable errors in the sheets.
- Each applicant filed a complaint with the Central Electoral Commission, with the complaints summarizing the applicants' claims that the ConEC decisions were unjustified, unlawful, and breached electoral law requirements.
- The CEC dismissed the applicants' complaints and arranged another examination of the signature sheets, in which none of the applicants participated.
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicants' appeals against the decisions of the electoral commissions, and the Supreme Court upheld the Baku Court's decision in each case.
- The applicants argued that their right to stand for election had been violated under Article 3 of Protocol No.1 to the Convention.
- The applicants' representative, Mr. Intigam Aliyev, who also represented other applicants before the Court, was arrested and detained pending trial.
- Search and seizure operations conducted in August 2014 seized documents, including all case files relating to over 100 applications before the Court, from Mr. Aliyev's office and home without an adequate inventory.
- Mr. Aliyev's complaint about the search and seizure operations was dismissed, and some case files relating to the Court proceedings were returned to his lawyer on 25 October 2014.

title: CASE OF GAYA ALIYEV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicants were candidates in the 2010 parliamentary elections in Azerbaijan.
- They submitted sheets containing the signature of more than 450 voters collected in support of their candidacy to their respective Constituency Electoral Commissions (“ConECs”).
- The ConEC working groups found that some of the voter signatures were invalid and that the remaining valid signatures had numbered fewer than 450.
- The ConECs issued decisions to refuse the applicants’ requests for registration as a candidate.
- None of the applicants, except the applicant in application no. 29808/11, were invited to the ConEC meetings where decisions to refuse their requests for registration were taken.
- Each applicant lodged a complaint with the Central Electoral Commission (“the CEC”) against the ConEC decisions.
- The CEC rejected the applicants’ complaints.
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed appeals by the applicants, finding that their arguments were irrelevant or unsubstantiated.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicants’ appeals as unsubstantiated, without examining their arguments in detail.
- Mr Intigam Aliyev, the applicants' representative, was arrested and detained, and his office was searched, and all the case files relating to the pending proceedings before the Court were seized.

title: CASE OF KUZMINA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Kyiv.
- On 30 June 2004, the applicant was found guilty of appropriation of private property by means of fraud or abuse of trust, theft of property, and theft of official documents.
- The court sentenced the applicant to five years’ imprisonment suspended for three years with probation.
- On 23 December 2004, the conviction was upheld by the Kyiv Court of Appeal.
- The applicant appealed on points of law to the Supreme Court.
- On 31 May 2005, the Supreme Court considered the applicant’s appeal on points of law, without notifying the applicant or her lawyer.
- The prosecutor was present and made oral representations during the hearing.
- The panel dismissed the appeal as unsubstantiated.
- The Supreme Court notified the applicant in a letter dated 12 September 2005, enclosing a copy of its decision.

title: CASE OF HACKEL v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Vienna.
- The applicant was a public official working for the Vienna municipality.
- On 2 February 1996, the personnel office of the Vienna municipality accepted the applicant’s resignation and granted her severance pay equal to three monthly salaries.
- On 18 March 1996, the same authority amended its decision and revoked the applicant's entitlement to severance pay.
- The applicant appealed on 1 April 1996, but the appeal was dismissed as unfounded on 3 September 1996.
- The applicant lodged a complaint against the appeal's decision on 9 October 1996, and on 17 October 2001, the Administrative Court set aside the appeal decision.
- On 13 June 2002, the applicant filed a request for transfer of jurisdiction, but by 7 August 2002, the Appeal Panel set aside the decision and ruled that the applicant was not eligible for severance pay.
- On 19 September 2002, the applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court.
- On 1 April 2005, the Vienna Municipal Council rendered a decision declaring that the appellant was not entitled to severance pay.
- The applicant lodged a complaint against that decision, and on 12 October 2005, the Constitutional Court declared that the applicant’s right to have proceedings determining her civil rights conducted within a reasonable time had been violated. 
- On 16 December 2005, the applicant amended her complaint for the proceedings before the Administrative Court, and on 13 March 2009, the Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's complaint as unfounded.

title: CASE OF RAMOS NUNES DE CARVALHO E SÁ v. PORTUGAL
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- Disciplinary proceedings were instituted against the applicant, who was a judge
- The applicant was accused of breaching her duty of propriety, loyalty, and honesty
- Several judicial inspectors submitted reports proposing penalties, including fines and suspension from duties
- The applicant appealed some of the decisions to higher courts, including the Judicial Division of the Supreme Court of Justice
- The higher courts upheld most of the penalties, finding that the establishment of facts was reasonable and the penalties were proportional to the offenses
- The applicant was finally given a single penalty of 240 days' suspension from duty after the penalties from the different disciplinary proceedings were grouped together.

title: CASE OF TCHANKOTADZE v. GEORGIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was the chairperson of the Civil Aviation Agency of Georgia between 2002 and 2004.
- The Constitutional Court of Georgia declared the annual regulation fee for transport activities unconstitutional in 2003.
- The defendant authorities argued for the need for a compulsory regulation fee, but the court dismissed that argument.
- The applicant was charged with repeated abuse of power for signing contracts that included the fee for services, which was deemed to be a disguised form of the unconstitutional annual regulation fee.
- The applicant was arrested and detained pending trial.
- An accountancy expert concluded that the charging of the fees by the Civil Aviation Agency was based on valid legal acts, though the applicant personally profited from them.
- A bill of indictment was served on the applicant, alleging that he had caused pecuniary damage to several companies.
- The applicant challenged the indictment, arguing that the evidence did not support the charges and that none of the State's legal interests had been disregarded.

title: CASE OF EZE v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained in Giurgiu Prison
- The applicant was detained on suspicion of drug-trafficking offences and was sentenced to thirteen years in prison
- The applicant was detained in Rahova Prison and Rahova Prison Hospital
- The applicant was detained in overcrowded cells in Rahova Prison
- The applicant shared a cell measuring twenty-four square metres with nine other detainees, limiting them to half a square metre of living space each
- The applicant complained about sharing a non-smoking cell with inmates who smoked, and about detainee's medical conditions
- Warm water in the shower was only available twice a week for ninety minutes
- Running water was only available six hours a day during the summer and not at all during the night
- The cells measured between 18.8 and 24.6 square meters, excluding the bathroom and toilet areas, and had natural light and ventilation
- The cells had bathrooms, toilets with natural ventilation, furniture, and a bunk bed
- The cells and the sanitary facilities had artificial light and were fitted with radiators
- Detainees had permanent access to sanitary facilities, and running water was always available
- The prison authorities issued inmates with cleaning materials and personal hygiene products, allowing them to also wash their own clothes in the prison laundry room
- Each year the applicant had received two toothbrushes, twelve tubes of toothpaste, twelve rolls of toilet paper, twelve bars of soap, and twelve disposable razors
- Cells were disinfected daily and regularly checked for pests, although the applicant never requested it
- Detainees' diets were determined by their health and religion, and compliance with quality criteria set out by law and suppliers
- Muslim detainees were provided a diet without any pork
- The applicant was allowed to practice his religion and receive visits and parcels

title: CASE OF MUGOŠA v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and currently detained at the Institute for Execution of Criminal Sanctions (IECS) in Spuž.
- The applicant was detained on 19 February 2011 on suspicion of murder.
- On 21 February 2011, the High Court in Podgorica issued a detention order against the applicant, which was extended on 16 March 2011, 17 May 2011, and 18 July 2011.
- On 16 May 2011, the applicant was indicted for murder.
- On 23 September 2011, the applicant requested to be released in the absence of any decision extending his detention after 18 September 2011.
- On 22 September 2011, the three-judge panel extended the applicant’s detention.
- On 26 September 2011, the applicant appealed the decision.
- On 4 October 2011, the Court of Appeals in Podgorica dismissed both appeals.
- On 12 January 2012, the Constitutional Court quashed the decision of the Court of Appeals and ordered that the case be re-examined.
- On 25 January 2012, the Court of Appeals dismissed the applicant’s appeals.
- On 20 April 2012, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional appeal.
- On 22 March 2013, the High Court issued a first-instance decision on the charges against the applicant, but no information on the outcome is available.

title: CASE OF MUTAYEVA AND ISMAILOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicants are the wife and sister of Mr Kamil Mutayev.
- Between 2010 and 2012, Mr Kamil Mutayev was detained on at least three occasions on suspicion of illegal activities.
- On May 2, 2012, Mr Kamil Mutayev and his son were abducted by eight masked men in black uniforms, armed with pistols and machine guns.
- The abduction took place approximately 200 meters from the district police station and the public prosecutor's office.
- The witnesses did not see the abduction, but saw two silver-coloured VAZ Priora cars speeding away from the vicinity of where the incident took place.
- The investigation was opened on May 14, 2012, and the applicants were informed on May 24, 2012.
- The investigation has been suspended and resumed on several occasions, with the last resumption taking place on September 10, 2015.

title: CASE OF IBRAGIM TSECHOYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's brother worked at a water-pumping station in Ordzhenikidzevskaya, Ingushetia.
- The brother was abducted by a group of about ten armed men in camouflage uniforms and balaclavas.
- The abductors beat and tied up the brother and his colleagues.
- The abductors took the brother to a UAZ vehicle and drove away towards Chechnya.
- The applicant reported the abduction to the police, but the duty officer did not believe him initially.
- The applicant went back to the police station with one of the beaten colleagues and an investigator questioned the colleague.
- The applicant found a Lada Niva car's tyre marks a couple of hundred metres from the pumping station.
- The government did not dispute the abduction fact but denied State agents' involvement.
- The investigation took many steps, including questioning witnesses, obtaining evidence, and requesting information from relevant agencies.
- The investigation is still ongoing as of October 2015.

title: CASE OF SEKİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970. 
- On February 13, 2009, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of using drugs and providing drugs to others. 
- The applicant's statement was taken on February 16, and she was released the same day. 
- On February 19, 2009, the public prosecutor objected to the decision, and on February 23, 2009, the applicant was issued an arrest warrant. 
- The applicant was placed in detention on remand on February 24, 2009. 
- On April 4, 2009, the public prosecutor filed an indictment against the applicant for using drugs and providing drugs to others. 
- The applicant's request for release was dismissed on May 15, 2009, and June 24, 2009. 
- The objections lodged by the applicant were dismissed without oral hearings on June 9, 2009, and July 21, 2009. 
- The trial court held its first hearing on October 1, 2009, and released the applicant on the same day.

title: CASE OF AYBOĞA AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years (1947, 1976, 1973, 1983, and 1987) and were being held in Buca F‑Type prison in İzmir.
- The İzmir Assize Court restricted access to the investigation file on July 23, 2007.
- On July 24, 2007, the applicants were arrested on suspicion of being involved with a criminal organization.
- On July 27, 2007, the applicants were questioned by the investigating judge, and they denied being members of the criminal organization but admitted to possessing firearms and accepting transfer of parcels, which were deemed evidence of committing offenses such as threats, fraud, and smuggling.
- The applicants' representative filed for their release pending trial on several occasions, but their applications were dismissed based on the nature of the charges and state of evidence.
- On March 13, 2008, the public prosecutor filed an indictment charging the applicants with several offenses, including establishing a criminal organization, being members of a criminal organization, and committing fraud, making threats, carrying out raids, and smuggling.
- On March 17, 2008, the trial court extended the applicants' pre-trial detention during an interlocutory session in their absence.
- The first court hearing was scheduled for June 24, 2008.
- The applicants' representative objected to the decision and applied for their release on May 2, 2008, but the objection was dismissed by the İzmir Assize Court on May 7, 2008.
- On June 24, 2008, the trial court released the applicants from pre-trial detention during the first hearing.

title: CASE OF G. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a man born in 1955 and suffering from rectal cancer and other illnesses.
- He was arrested on suspicion of committing large-scale bank fraud in November 2006 and detained pending investigation.
- Despite the defense's arguments that his health was fragile and he needed medical attention, the court extended his detention until March 2007, citing the risk of absconding and obstructing justice.
- The defense continued to challenge the detention order, but the court upheld it several times.
- In early 2008, the applicant sought release from detention on medical grounds, and the court agreed that his health condition had become too serious to justify continued detention. He was released with a written undertaking not to leave his home town.
- Throughout his detention, the applicant experienced severe health problems, including a prolapsed bowel, faecal incontinence, and acute pain. The authorities did not provide him with adequate medical care, and he had to rely on hygiene products and even toilet paper supplied by his relatives.
- Despite doctors recommending colorectal surgery, the detention authorities repeatedly insisted that there was no need for urgent surgery, and it was only after the Court applied Rule 39 and drew attention to the urgent necessity of the procedure that the applicant finally received treatment.

title: CASE OF VASENIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 in Perm and was diagnosed with schizophrenia.
- In 2002, the applicant was ordered by a court to be admitted to a psychiatric hospital due to committing criminal offenses, including possession of drugs and aggravated robbery.
- On January 30, 2005, the applicant escaped from the mental institution he was admitted to.
- On September 21, 2005, the applicant was arrested by the Ukrainian border police for attempting to cross the border unlawfully.
- In November 2005, the applicant was arrested in Belgorod by the police for allegedly setting a vehicle on fire and was detained on the charges.
- The court ordered the applicant's placement in custody and admitted him to a temporary detention facility in Belgorod.
- On December 2, 2005, the applicant confessed to blowing up a car with an accomplice on October 5, 2005, among other criminal offenses.
- Psychiatrists confirmed the applicant's diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia and the applier's risk to those around him.
- On May 3, 2006, the applicant was sentenced to high-security psychiatric treatment.
- In 2012, the judgment was quashed due to a violation of the applicant's right to defense.
- The applicant was detained in various psychiatric institutions from 2005 to 2009 and was diagnosed with maniacal schizophrenia.

title: CASE OF FAUR v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently detained in Arad.
- The Arad District Court convicted the applicant of rape of a minor and sentenced him to thirteen years’ imprisonment, which started on 21 January 2001 and lasted until 24 May 2011 when he was released on probation.
- On 11 July 2013, the applicant was again detained following another conviction for rape of two minor girls and incarcerated at Colibași Prison.
- The applicant alleged that he had been kept in overcrowded cells in Arad and Timișoara Prisons, and had to share a cell with smokers.
- The Arad County Court allowed one of the applicant’s complaints about smoking and ordered the placement of the applicant in a non-smoking cell.
- The applicant alleged that he had been transferred from one prison to another in vans with detainees who smoked.
- The applicant spent most of his detention in Arad Prison, and was placed alone in an individual cell of 10.40 square metres for most of his stay.
- The applicant was also detained in Timișoara Prison, and held in several cells of various sizes.
