- The Government did not provide any information concerning either the number of detainees who had occupied the cells or the time spent by the applicant in each cell.
- The prisons had adequate natural and electric lighting and ventilation, central heating, furniture, and daily hot water according to a schedule approved by the prison authorities.
- Prisoners were responsible for cleaning the cells and were provided with cleaning products by the prison administration.
- The applicant had been transferred between prison facilities in vehicles that were fitted with windows, lights, heating, and sunroofs, and had been transported separately from smokers. Smoking was strictly prohibited during transfers.

title: CASE OF IGNAT v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Iași.
- In 2006, the applicant filed a case against a third party to nullify the sale/purchase agreements of an apartment.
- The Iaşi District Court allowed the applicant's action and declared the contracts null and void on 25 January 2007.
- The third party appealed against the decision.
- The Iaşi County Court allowed the third party's appeal, quashed the decision of the district court, and dismissed the applicant's action on 21 November 2007.
- The applicant filed an appeal on points of law against the County Court's decision.
- The Iaşi Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law as inadmissible on 2 June 2008 because the value of the disputed property was RON 9,000 and judgments delivered by first-instance courts on disputes worth less than RON one billion were not subject to an ordinary appeal.

title: CASE OF LOGHIN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1958, 1940 and 1933 respectively and lived in Paşcani.
- On 2 March 2004, a claimant initiated civil proceedings against the applicants seeking the annulment of a sale/purchase agreement.
- On 3 March 2006, the Paşcani District Court dismissed the claimant’s action.
- The claimant appealed against the judgment of 3 March 2006.
- By a judgment delivered on 26 January 2007, the Iaşi County Court allowed the claimant’s appeal and dismissed the applicants’ arguments as to its jurisdiction.
- The applicants lodged an appeal on points of law against the judgment of the Iaşi County Court.
- By a final judgment of 21 June 2007, the Iaşi Court of Appeal dismissed their appeal as inadmissible and also dismissed an extraordinary appeal by the applicants.

title: CASE OF MAMONTOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicants were targeted by undercover operations carried out by the police 
• The operations were in the form of test purchases of drugs 
• The operations were carried out under sections 7 and 8 of the Operational-Search Activities Act of 12 August 1995 (no. 144-FZ) 
• The operations led to the applicants' criminal convictions for drug dealing 
• The applicants believed that the police had incited them to commit drug-related offences 
• The applicants complained about not being able to examine the witnesses who testified against them.

title: CASE OF AL-DULIMI AND MONTANA MANAGEMENT INC. v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- The first applicant was head of finance for the Iraqi secret services.
- The second applicant is a company with registered office in Panama and the first applicant is its managing director.
- UN Security Council passed resolutions calling for a general embargo against Iraq after it invaded Kuwait.
- The Swiss Federal Council adopted an ordinance providing for economic measures against Iraq, freezing assets of the former Iraqi government.
- The applicants' assets in Switzerland had remained frozen since 7 August 1990.
- The Sanctions Committee created by Security Council Resolution 1518 was given the task of listing individuals and entities concerned by Resolution 1483.
- The applicants' names were added to the list of individuals and entities concerned by national measures under Article 2 of the Iraq Ordinance.
- The Federal Council adopted the Confiscation Ordinance on the confiscation of frozen assets and their transfer to the Development Fund for Iraq.
- The applicants challenged the decision on the confiscation and transfer of deposits in their names in Geneva.
- The Federal Department for Economic Affairs ordered the confiscation of several assets belonging to the applicants.

title: CASE OF SHEYMAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are a husband and wife living in Bat-Yam, Israel.
- They emigrated from the USSR to Israel in the 1990s and obtained Israeli nationality.
- Before emigrating, they were receiving old-age pensions from the Soviet authorities.
- The payments were discontinued once they left the USSR, in accordance with the USSR pension law in force at that time.
- The applicants brought civil proceedings against the competent regional department of the Pension Fund of the Russian Federation seeking reinstatement of their right to pension payments.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Astrakhan found in favor of the applicants and ordered the Pension Fund to set up monthly pension payments backdated to June 15, 1998.
- The Astrakhan Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal, which became binding and enforceable.
- The Pension Fund lodged an application for supervisory review seeking to quash the judgments.
- A judge of the Supreme Court requested the case file from the District Court and suspended enforcement of the judgment.
- Another judge of the Supreme Court sent the case for supervisory review to the Astrakhan Regional Court.
- The Astrakhan Regional Court dismissed the supervisory review application and endorsed the judgment of December 4, 2006.
- The Pension Fund lodged another application for supervisory review, again addressed to the President of the Supreme Court.
- A judge of the Supreme Court sent the case for supervisory review by the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court.
- The Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court quashed the judgment of December 4, 2006, as upheld on January 12, 2007, and rejected the applicants’ claims.

title: CASE OF PODDUBNYY AND BABKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in Moscow in 1970 and 1965 respectively
- Accused of fraud and tobacco smuggling, a criminal investigation opened against them on 13 June 2000 by prosecutor's office
- Applicants were arrested on 24 November 2000 and remained in custody until their trial
- Applicants' detention was extended several times
- On 3 February 2005, the jury declared the applicants not guilty, but the verdict was quashed by the Supreme Court on 22 July 2005
- The applicants were ordered to be remanded in custody pending a new trial on 29 July 2005
- On 13 February 2006, the jury again declared the applicants not guilty, and they were released on 16 February 2006
- The first applicant was found guilty of assaulting a trainee investigator and destroying official documents and was sentenced to two years' imprisonment on 30 July 2003.

title: CASE OF KALUGINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and worked as an employee of a municipal unitary enterprise in Petrozavodsk.
- The enterprise, named Auto Transport Column 1126, was established by the town administration to provide commercial public transport services.
- The enterprise had control over the assets allocated to it by the town administration for carrying out its activities.
- The enterprise provided some sections of the population with transport services free of charge, and the town administration was supposed to reimburse the expenses incurred using the budget allocated for this purpose.
- Due to a shortage of funds, the company didn't receive reimbursals and became unable to pay salaries on time, creating a significant amount of unpaid salaries.
- The town administration ordered the restructuring of the company as a spin-off, leaving the unpaid salary debt with the original company.
- The original company was declared insolvent, and proceedings of liquidation started in 2003.
- The Petrozavodsk Town Court awarded the applicant RUB 21,830 in May 2004, out of which the company paid RUB 9,206 to the applicant, leaving the remaining judgment debt unpaid.
- The company was ordered to pay the applicant RUB 614 in non-pecuniary damage, but this award was also left unpaid.
- In October 2006, the Commercial Court of the Republic of Kareliya ordered the liquidation of the company, with creditors' unresolved claims, including the applicant's unsettled claims, being considered settled.
- In March 2005, subsidiary liability proceedings to hold the town administration accountable for the company's debts were refused by the Petrozavodsk Town Court, citing a lack of evidence provided by the applicant.

title: CASE OF I.N. v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant complained about libel in his employment record, and the prosecutor's office requested his placement in a psychiatric facility.
- Psychiatrists studied his letters and decided he needed to be examined.
- The applicant's version of events stated that he was forced to submit to an exam and then taken by ambulance to a hospital. The government stated that he agreed to go.
- After examinations, it was decided that he needed urgent hospitalization.
- The applicant was a patient in various hospitals for several months.
- Upon discharge, he requested information on what legal basis he had been subjected to psychiatric treatment and was refused access to his file.
- The applicant filed a lawsuit against the hospitals and claimed damages.
- The court found that some actions were compliant with regulations but that his transfer to the Svatove hospital was in breach of the law.
- The applicant was awarded UAH 2,000 compensation by the Svatove Hospital.
- The Lugansk Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision.
- The Supreme Court of Ukraine dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law.
- The applicant complained that he had not received a writ of enforcement of the compensation awarded.

title: CASE OF LOVYGINY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1938 and 1939, live in Kherson, Ukraine, and their son was a police officer.
- A police training exercise named "Operation Sirena" was conducted on 14 January 2000, during which the applicants' son, playing the role of a criminal, was accidentally shot dead by another police officer.
- Operation Sirena was approved by police and civil authorities in 1999, and the plan outlined steps to be taken in the event of searching for or arresting dangerous criminals.
- A senior traffic police inspector drafted the training exercise, which included a lack of necessary provisions, and the scenario was approved without correcting these shortcomings.
- The police made serious errors in the organization and conduct of the exercise, and senior officers failed to properly train their personnel to act in emergency circumstances.
- The investigation concluded that five police officers should be dismissed, and others disciplined.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated, and the case was remitted for additional investigation.

title: CASE OF TRUTEN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- 19-year-old K. went missing after attending a party in Novy Sanzhary
- The police established that K. was last seen with her cousin R. and the applicant
- Witnesses saw the applicant with K. and carrying a pennant from a mobile operator company
- The applicant initially claimed to have left K. with two unknown men but later confessed to raping, robbing, and killing K.
- The applicant alleged that he was beaten and threatened by police officers to confess to the crime
- The forensic examination found no evidence linking the applicant to the crime scene
- The applicant was convicted of rape, robbery, and murder and sentenced to fourteen and a half years in prison
- The court dismissed the applicant's claims of ill-treatment and relied on his self-incriminating statements during the trial, despite the initial alleged coercion.

title: CASE OF KULYK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant saw three young men on the premises of the nearby factory and went inside to look for them.
- A police officer, L., arrived at the applicant's house, swore at him, grabbed him by the collar, and hit him on the head with the gun handle.
- The applicant was accused of stealing aluminium sheets from the factory.
- At the police station, L. and another police officer, P., beat the applicant for 15-20 minutes.
- The applicant was fined in administrative proceedings for disobeying a police officer's order to stop.
- The applicant sustained numerous injuries, including a closed brain injury, two broken ribs, post-traumatic pneumonia, and kidney injury.
- The applicant requested the Vinnytsya Regional Prosecutor that criminal proceedings be instituted against the police officers.
- Factory employees and witnesses gave contradictory testimony about the events.
- On several occasions, prosecutors refused to institute criminal proceedings, but the decision was quashed by higher prosecutors.
- On suspicion of abuse of power, police officers P. and L. were charged.
- The investigation was delayed due to disciplinary action against investigating officers and difficulty finding witnesses.

title: CASE OF KRIVOSHEY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence and was born in 1966.
- Several criminal proceedings were instituted in August and September 2001, that were joined into a single criminal case known as "theft proceedings."
- On 15 August 2001, the applicant was arrested as a suspect in these proceedings.
- On 17 August 2001, the applicant was remanded in custody pending pre-trial investigation.
- On 23 August 2001, criminal proceedings were instituted in connection with a premeditated murder of a man.
- On the same day, V.Z. allegedly told the police that the applicant had fatally injured a woman in a traffic accident and had killed her husband in order to cover this crime.
- On 11 February 2002, eleven other individuals, including V.Z., were convicted on various counts of theft in collaboration with the applicant and were sentenced to various penalties.
- On 19 February 2003, the applicant was found guilty on several counts of theft and sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment.
- On 24 September 2003, the applicant's charges were reclassified from premeditated to aggravated murder, and he was re-arrested on suspicion of the premeditated murder of A.G.
- On 21 May 2004, the applicant was found guilty of causing a traffic accident resulting in L.G.’s death and of the aggravated murder of A.G. and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- The term of imprisonment was reduced to fifteen years’ imprisonment by the Supreme Court on 5 October 2004.
- On 24 May 2012, the applicant was found guilty of several counts of theft and sentenced to eight years’ imprisonment, combined with the confiscation of all his property.

title: CASE OF KLEUTIN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Odesa.
- The applicant was arrested and remanded in custody on 22 January 2004 in connection with a robbery committed the night before, and the court extended his detention on several occasions.
- The applicant was found guilty of premeditated robbery as part of a group and of involving minors in a crime and was sentenced to five years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant raised complaints of ill-treatment by police officers, including allegations of physical violence and threats with firearms, both during his apprehension and in custody.
- The applicant was held in several cells during his detention, some of which were intended for more detainees than they could comfortably accommodate.

title: CASE OF BAKA v. HUNGARY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant served as a judge at the European Court of Human Rights and later as President of the Supreme Court of Hungary.
- He had both managerial and judicial roles, including presiding over deliberations that resulted in uniformity resolutions and guiding resolutions.
- He was also President of the National Council of Justice, which involved expressing opinions on parliamentary bills affecting the judiciary.
- The applicant expressed his views on various legislative reforms affecting the judiciary, such as the Nullification Bill, retirement age of judges, and amendments to the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- He challenged an act concerning judicial procedure and the judicial system before the Constitutional Court for unconstitutionality and violation of international treaties.
- The applicant criticized two new Cardinal Bills proposing to abolish the National Council of Justice and replace it with a National Judicial Office and National Judicial Council.
- Some members of Parliament submitted amendments proposing to terminate the applicant's mandate as President of the Supreme Court and a Bill proposing an amendment to the Constitution to elect a new President of the Kúria before the date of entry into force of the new Fundamental Law.

title: CASE OF ÖZÇELİK v. THE NETHERLANDS
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Enschede.
- On 21 May 2010, the applicant was convicted of shoplifting and was placed in a Persistent Offenders Institution for a duration of two years.
- The measure was reviewed on 1 December 2010, but it was not terminated due to the high risk of the applicant reoffending.
- On 19 May 2011, the applicant's personal case officer reported that the measure should be continued, and on 9 June 2011, the measure was prolonged further.
- The applicant appealed against the decision to prolong the measure, and a hearing took place on 12 December 2011, but it was adjourned due to language barriers.
- After a delay of more than ten months, the Court of Appeal delivered its decision on 16 May 2012, deeming that continuation of the measure was no longer necessary.

title: CASE OF SILÁŠOVÁ AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
1. The applicants are owners of land in the cadastral area of Závodie in Žilina.
2. The State put the land at the disposal of an agricultural cooperative in 1948 and designated part of it as an “allotment colony” in 1987.
3. The gardeners were granted tenancy rights over the land in question from the date of the Land Ownership Act’s entry into force in 1991.
4. The Allotments Act introduced a compulsory tenancy arrangement and rent payable by gardeners to owners was determined by law.
5. The annual rent payable by the gardeners was at the lowest limit of the applicable scale, that is to say at a rate of EUR 0.01 per square metre except for one applicant.
6. Regulations were introduced in 2010 and 2011 to adjust the general value of the rent payable to owners in accordance with market rent.
7. Land consolidation proceedings are pending and the compulsory tenancy arrangement persists.
8. The parties disagreed on the amount of rent payable for the land- the applicants estimated the market value to be EUR 2.66 per sq. metre and the government calculated it to be EUR 0.239 to EUR 0.718 per sq metre.

title: CASE OF SKORIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1948 and lives in Belgrade.
- The applicant worked for a socially-owned company named “PIM – bagerovanje i vodni transport”.
- On 30 March 2005, the Belgrade Second Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant certain sums related to salary arrears, social security contributions, and procedural costs. The judgment became final on the same date.
- On 22 June 2005, the Belgrade Fourth Municipal Court issued an enforcement order related to the judgment.
- On 29 March 2012, the Constitutional Court observed that the enforcement proceedings violated the "right to a trial within a reasonable time" and ordered the acceleration of the proceedings, along with compensation for the non-pecuniary damage suffered by the applicant in the amount of EUR 700, to be converted into national currency at the settlement date.
- The enforcement proceedings that started based on the judgment of 30 March 2005 are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF JAKELJIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts are:

- The applicants were born in 1960 and 1970 respectively and live in Split.
- The former Yugoslavia legislation prohibited the acquisition of ownership of socially owned property by adverse possession.
- In 1991, parliament repealed the provision that prohibited ownership by adverse possession.
- The 1996 Property Act provided that the period prior to 8 October 1991 was to be included in calculating the period for acquiring ownership by adverse possession of socially owned immovable property.
- The Constitutional Court invalidated section 388(4) of the 1996 Property Act as unconstitutional and retroactive.
- The applicants bought three plots of land from various individuals that were recorded in the land register in the name of Stobreč Municipality as the legal predecessor of Split Township.
- The applicants brought a civil action in the Split Municipal Court seeking a declaration of their ownership of the plots of land and registration in their names in the land register.
- The Municipal Court ruled in favour of the applicants, but the Split County Court reversed the decision and dismissed the applicants’ action.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicants’ constitutional complaint alleging violations of their constitutional rights to equality before the law, equality before the courts, and fair procedure.

title: CASE OF O'NEILL AND LAUCHLAN v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- R.M. reported his ex-wife, A.M, missing on 16 February 1998
- Police carried out an initial forensic investigation of an apartment
- A.M.’s disappearance was being referred to as “suspicious”
- The applicants were detained by the police and accused of the murder of A.M without being charged
- The case was continued as a live enquiry and periodic reviews were conducted by police
- The applicants were arrested in Spain in connection with the apparent abduction of a fourteen year old boy
- The Crown decided to take “no proceedings meantime” in December 2005
- New evidence came to light concerning the circumstances of A.M.’s disappearance and the applicants’ sexual offending
- The applicants were served with an indictment which contained the same charges as the 2005 petition
- The High Court found that the Crown had acted properly in investigating and reviewing the evidence between 1997 and 2008
- The first applicant appealed against the decision not to dismiss the charge against him
- The Appeal Court accepted that the police had interrogated him “robustly” in 1998
- The applicants’ trial for the sexual offences took place between 19 April 2010 and 13 May 2010
- The murder trial began at the High Court in Glasgow on 17 May 2010 with the Crown leading evidence from over fifty witnesses

title: CASE OF MALEC v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Bibice.
- The applicant married E. in 1997 and their daughter N. was born in 2004.
- The applicant and E. separated in 2008 and agreed on access arrangements for N.
- The applicant lodged a divorce petition with an application for an interim contact order in 2009.
- The court conducted a local assessment to establish N.'s situation and parenting skills of both parents, with the report submitted in 2009.
- A hearing in 2010 did not take place as the case file had not been returned from the Court of Appeal.
- The applicant lodged further applications for interim contact orders with different arrangements in 2009 and 2010.
- The Kraków Regional Court issued an interim contact order in 2010.
- E. asked the court to restrict contact between the applicant and N. in 2011.
- The Kraków Regional Court ordered another local assessment in 2011.
- A hearing scheduled in 2011 was adjourned and the applicant made further requests to the court to impose fines on E.
- The Kraków Regional Court issued a divorce decree in 2012, allowing the applicant to see his daughter with specified contact arrangements.
- The applicant lodged numerous applications for a forcible removal of N. for various visits.
- Both the applicant and E. asked the police to intervene on several occasions.
- The Kraków-Nowa Huta District Court issued an interim contact order in 2012 to modify the access arrangements.
- The court ordered another local assessment and examination of the parents and child by RODK experts.

title: CASE OF JANUSZ WOJCIECHOWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Warsaw.
- The applicant was detained from 15 June 2007 until 21 January 2009, initially at a semi-open facility and later in a closed-type facility.
- The applicant was held in cells which did not conform to the statutory minimum size for 309 days of his detention in the closed-type facility.
- Initial toilet facilities were not separated from the living area of the cells in the closed-type facility, but were later enclosed by concrete walls with a door.
- All of the applicant's cells were well-lit, ventilated, and equipped with bunk beds, tables, stools, and cupboards.
- The Koszalin Remand Centre's day-room was turned into cells in 2009, but detainees continued to have access to a library and various forms of leisure and cultural activities.
- The applicant had one hour of outdoor exercise per day and initially received one hot shower per week, which was later increased to five per month.
- The applicant was assigned a top bed but did not submit any medical documents to support his claim that this was contrary to medical recommendations.
- The applicant was authorized to attend Sunday Mass four times in 2008, and detainees had the option to make individual appointments with the remand center's priest.
- The Koszalin District Court held that the applicant's placement in overcrowded cells for 309 days constituted degrading and inhuman treatment, awarded him PLN 5,000 in compensation, and ordered him to pay the costs of the proceedings.
- The Koszalin Regional Court upheld the lower court's decision, and the applicant's appeal against this decision was rejected as no such appeal was available.

title: CASE OF RADOBULJAC v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant is an advocate representing a plaintiff in civil proceedings.
- On 16 November 2009, the Municipal Court held a hearing and scheduled the next one for 17 December 2009.
- The applicant did not attend the hearing on 17 December 2009 and the court made a decision to suspend the proceedings.
- On 31 December 2009, the applicant lodged an appeal against that decision stating vehicle malfunction as the reason for his absence and criticized the conduct of the judge.
- The first-instance single judge fined the applicant for contempt of court for his statement, and the applicant appealed against that decision.
- The County Court upheld the decision of the first-instance court.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against the decisions of the ordinary courts, which was declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF DIMOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1980 and 1964 respectively, and live in Hajdukovo.
- They were indicted on February 12, 2007, along with their friend S.K., for allegedly stealing a wine press.
- On January 25, 2008, The Subotica Municipal Court acquitted all three defendants of these charges.
- On April 8, 2008, the prosecution lodged an appeal against this judgment, and on May 12, 2008, the Subotica District Court ordered a retrial after quashing the impugned judgment.
- On February 19, 2009, the Municipal Court, relying primarily on S.K.'s statement of January 26, 2006, found the applicants guilty and sentenced them to imprisonment.
- On July 29, 2009, the District Court upheld this judgment on appeal, and on October 7, 2010, the Supreme Court rejected the applicants' further appeal on points of law.
- On September 11, 2009, the applicants lodged a constitutional appeal with the Constitutional Court, alleging that they had never had a chance to cross-examine the witness and that the witness had revoked his testimony subsequently.
- On October 14, 2010, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicants' appeal as manifestly ill-founded, stating that the prior statement given to the police would be accepted, and that they could no longer accommodate the applicants' objection regarding the witness's cross-examination.

title: CASE OF RADOMILJA AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- Applicants and Mr Gašpar Perasovic lived in Stobrec.
- Former Yugoslavian law prohibited the acquisition of ownership of socially owned property by adverse possession.
- Croatian Parliament repealed this provision in 1991.
- The new Property Act of 1996 allowed the period before 8 October 1991 to be included in calculating the period for acquiring ownership by adverse possession of socially owned immovable property.
- A Constitutional Court decision on 17 November 1999 invalidated section 388(4) of the 1996 Property Act.
- Mr Perasović and the applicants brought a civil action against Split Township seeking a declaration of their ownership of five plots of land and registration in their names in the land register.
- The Municipal Court ruled for the plaintiffs, but it was reversed and dismissed by the Split County Court.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the plaintiffs' constitutional complaint.

title: CASE OF ČIČMANEC v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The case concerns real property in Sebedražie that was subject to land consolidation proceedings
- The applicant's father was assigned temporary use of land, which was later transferred to the applicant
- The bone of contention is whether a makeshift field track existed on the land and whether the applicant blocked it
- Courts ruled in favor of the claimant, ordering the applicant to remove the obstruction and allow passage over the land
- The applicant filed complaints challenging the judgments and costs orders, alleging violations of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 and Article 6 § 1 of the Convention
- The Constitutional Court declared both complaints inadmissible, finding no unfairness or arbitrariness in the lower courts' decisions and the underlying proceedings

title: CASE OF TADDEUCCI AND McCALL v. ITALY
facts:
1. Mr Tadeucci and Mr McCall are a same-sex couple residing in Amsterdam.
2. They lived as an unmarried couple in New Zealand until 2003 before settling in Italy.
3. Mr McCall's application for a residence permit was rejected in Italy in 2004.
4. They appealed the decision, leading to a favorable ruling in Florence Civil Court in 2005 but was later overturned by the Court of Appeal.
5. The Court of Cassation dismisses their appeal in 2008, leading them to leave Italy in 2009.
6. In 2010, they got married in Amsterdam for personal reasons.
7. They have since been issued residence permits in the Netherlands.

title: CASE OF HAJIBEYLI AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Applicants were members of opposition political parties or groups.
- BCEA refused to authorise the demonstrations planned by the organisers.
- The demonstrations were conducted peacefully.
- Applicants were arrested during the dispersal operations.
- Administrative offence reports were issued against them.
- Applicants were not given access to a lawyer after their arrest or while they were in police custody.
- State-funded lawyers were invited to represent most of them.
- They were not given an opportunity to appoint lawyers of their own choosing.
- Applicants affirmed their right to freedom of assembly and/or that they were not guilty of failing to comply with a lawful order of the police.
- Police officers who arrested the applicants or issued administrative offence reports on them were only questioned as witnesses in the proceedings. 
- The courts convicted the applicants under Article 310.1 of the CAO and sentenced them to administrative detention which varied from five to thirteen days.
- The Baku Court of Appeal upheld the decisions of the respective first-instance courts.

title: CASE OF DAMIROV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lived in Mingachevir.
- The applicant worked as the executive director at the “Mingachevir Technical Rubber” Joint Stock Company.
- The enterprise was under the control of the Department for Privatization and Management of State Property (“the DPMSP”) of the Ministry of the Economic Development.
- On 15 March 2005, the applicant was dismissed from his job by an order of the DPMSP of the Ministry of the Economic Development.
- The applicant lodged an action against the DPMSP, seeking reinstatement in his previous job and payment of his unpaid salaries.
- Sabayil District Court granted the applicant’s claim, ordering his reinstatement in his previous job on 25 August 2005.
- The court also ordered the DPMSP to pay the applicant his unpaid salary for the period from 15 March 2005 to the date of his reinstatement.
- On 25 November 2005, the Court of Appeal upheld the judgment of 25 August 2005, dismissing the DPMSP’s appeal.
- On 12 April 2006, the Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s judgment and dismissed the cassation appeal lodged by the State Committee for Management of State Property (“the SCMSP”).
- The SCMSP took no action to comply with the judgment in question.
- On 14 July 2006, the Sabayil District Court decided to refer the case to the Sabayil District Prosecutor’s Office for institution of criminal proceedings against the SCMSP’s responsible official for non-execution of an enforceable judgment.
- However, it transpires from the case file that on an unspecified date the prosecuting authorities returned the case to the enforcement officers without taking any formal decision as regards the institution of criminal proceedings.
- At the time of the latest communication with the parties in June 2011, the judgment delivered in the applicant’s favour remained unenforced.

title: CASE OF KRAVCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was a former shareholder in two private companies that were liquidated based on other shareholders' decisions, and the local authorities struck the companies from the list of legal entities.
- The applicant filed several court proceedings seeking the reversal of the liquidation, recovery of his shares, and compensation.
- Around twenty hearings were adjourned, and there were appeals against a procedural decision.
- The case was examined within the framework of civil proceedings instead of commercial proceedings after courts at three levels of jurisdiction examined the question.
- The proceedings lasted for over seven years and eight months, and the final decision was upheld by the Supreme Court on 29 December 2010.
- The applicant brought a civil claim challenging the liquidation of the second company and other decisions in January 2005.
- On 2 June 2006, the court decided not to examine the applicant's claim, and on June 16, 2006, the applicant filed an appeal against that decision.
- The Court of Appeal left the appeal without examination on July 25, 2006, citing a time-limit violation.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal in cassation on 9 October 2006.
- The applicant brought an administrative claim seeking the annulment of the decision striking the second company from the list of legal entities in November 2005.
- The court rejected the applicant's claim on 17 April 2006, citing allegations of the unlawfulness of the shareholders' decision to liquidate the company that could not be examined in the framework of administrative proceedings and that the claim had been brought out of time.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decision on 20 September 2006.
- The Higher Administrative Court quashed the decisions of the lower courts and terminated the proceedings, finding that the claim essentially concerned a property dispute and could be heard under the Code of Civil Procedure of 2004.

title: CASE OF O.G. v. LATVIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and resides in Riga.
- In 2008, the applicant was accused of fraud and relieved of criminal liability, but was ordered to undergo outpatient medical treatment.
- The applicant signed a document stating that he must visit a doctor monthly and attend panel meetings every six months. Failure to do so would result in police intervention.
- In 2013, the court decided to continue the compulsory treatment, but the applicant sent letters asking for revocation.
- The applicant was again accused of fraud in 2008 and ordered to undergo inpatient psychiatric treatment, which was later switched to compulsory outpatient treatment.
- In 2012, the court decided to continue the outpatient treatment, but the applicant showed no improvement and did not comply with the treatment.
- In 2013, the psychiatric hospital contacted the police to bring the applicant to the hospital because he failed to attend appointments. He was involuntarily admitted to hospital for inpatient treatment but was later released following examination by a medical commission.
- The medical commission recommended revoking the compulsory outpatient treatment measures imposed on the applicant.
- The State Police dismissed the applicant's complaint that he was taken to the hospital unlawfully, stating that it was in accordance with the Law on Police. The Office of the Prosecutor General upheld this decision.

title: CASE OF MAMMADLI AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicants' information is given in the Appendix, including their dates of birth and places of residence.
- The applicants participated in parliamentary elections in November 2010 and applied for registration as candidates in various single-mandate electoral constituencies.
- The Constituency Electoral Commissions (ConECs) identified invalid voter signatures and rejected the applicants' requests for registration as candidates.
- None of the applicants were present at ConEC meetings where decisions to refuse their requests for registration were taken, and relevant working group documents and ConEC decisions were either made available to them belatedly or not at all.
- Each applicant lodged a complaint with the Central Electoral Commission (CEC), which also rejected their complaints after an examination of the signature sheets by its own working group.
- None of the applicants were present at relevant CEC or working group meetings, and relevant CEC documents were only made available to them after the CEC decision had been taken.
- Each applicant lodged an appeal with the Baku Court of Appeal against the electoral commissions' decisions, but they were dismissed as irrelevant or unsubstantiated.
- The applicants lodged cassation appeals with the Supreme Court, which were also dismissed as unsubstantiated without examining their arguments in detail.
- A representative for the applicants in some of the cases related to the 2010 parliamentary elections was subject to criminal proceedings in a separate application brought before the Court.
- The investigation authorities seized a large number of documents from Mr. Aliyev's office, including all the case files relating to the pending proceedings before the Court.

title: CASE OF BAŞTOVOI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and is currently detained in Chișinău.
- On 23 December 2013, the applicant was arrested and charged with embezzlement and organizing the attempted murder of two businessmen.
- The applicant has been detained in a cell measuring 6 square meters with five other inmates, leaving very little space for each detainee.
- Due to overcrowding, detainees had to share beds. He was not provided with bedding or a pillow. 
- There was no sink or running water in the cell. 
- The food was of poor quality and inedible.
- The squat toilet was not separated from the rest of the cell and gave off a foul odor. 
- There was also a lack of daylight and poor ventilation.
- The applicant was detained with inmates diagnosed with tuberculosis, HIV/AIDS, and other infectious diseases.
- The applicant complained of inhuman conditions of detention to the Chișinău prosecutor’s office and Court of Appeal.
- The Prisons Department replied that after examining his allegations, it had not found any violation of domestic law.
- The Government submitted that the applicant’s cell (no.130) measured 10 square meters and was designed to accommodate four people. 
- The cell was equipped with a sink and running water. 
- The applicant was provided with bedding, hygiene products tailored to his needs, and hot food three times a day, in accordance with Government Decision no.609 concerning the minimum daily food requirements for detainees. 
- The Government contended that the cell in question had not accommodated people with infectious diseases. 
- The applicant had been provided with medical assistance and submitted evidence of various medical check-ups.
- Reports for 2013, 2014, and 2015 on conditions of detention found serious problems in the prison, including overcrowding, food quality, ventilation, and access to daylight. 
- The Center for Human Rights in Moldova recommended in its reports for 2014 and 2015 that Prison no. 13 be closed or if that was inappropriate, that the conditions of detention be urgently improved.

title: CASE OF BUKOVČANOVÁ AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- Applicants were born between 1947 and 1980 and live in Bratislava.
- They co-own a residential house in Bratislava.
- The house was built in 1929 and was donated to the State under duress.
- The ownership was restored to the applicants under special legislation on restitution.
- The four applicants own different shares of the house.
- At the time the applicants acquired the ownership, there were tenants with regulated rent occupying five flats.
- The rent-control scheme required that the tenants could remain and pay a fixed rent.
- The monthly rent chargeable to tenants was low (between EUR 10 and EUR 17.5) from 1992 to 1999.
- The monthly rent increased to some EUR 73.5 for a two-room flat and approximately EUR 125 for four-room flats in June 2007.
- There are three flats to which the rent control still applies.
- The parties provided differing figures for the market rent of the flats.

title: CASE OF BUZADJI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is a minority shareholder and CEO of a liquefied gas supply company in Moldova, in which the state owned 82% of the shares.
- He was accused of devising a scheme involving the importation of liquefied gas from Kazakhstan and Ukraine that resulted in major financial losses for the company.
- He was accused of acknowledging the debt in court proceedings and was summoned to appear before the investigating authorities, whom he cooperated with.
- His house was searched, his computer was seized, and various documents were extracted from it.
- His sons were also suspects and were subsequently charged.
- He was arrested and charged with attempted large-scale misappropriation of goods belonging to the company where he worked.
- The prosecutor applied for detention warrants, which were partly upheld by the courts on the grounds of the seriousness of the offence, the risk of influencing witnesses, and the risk of reoffending.
- The applicant objected to the warrants and requested a less severe measure, stating that there was no reasonable suspicion that he had committed an offence and that the criminal proceedings pursued an ulterior motive.
- The courts extended his detention on remand several times, citing the gravity and complexity of the case, and the risk of absconding or influencing witnesses.
- He was eventually placed under house arrest, but the decision was later quashed by the Chişinău Court of Appeal, and he was ordered to be detained pending trial.

title: CASE OF O.M. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and currently lives in Budapest.
- The applicant crossed the Hungarian border from Serbia clandestinely in the evening of 24 June 2014.
- After being apprehended by a border guard patrol, the applicant claimed asylum.
- The applicant declared that he had fled from his country of origin, Iran, because of his homosexuality.
- The applicant was ordered to be detained by the asylum authority, relying on section 31/A (1) a) and c) of Act no. LXXX of 2007 on Asylum (the “Asylum Act”).
- The asylum detention was extended by the Debrecen District Court by a maximum of 60 days.
- The applicant requested release or transfer to an open facility but was denied.
- The asylum detention was terminated, and a designated place of residence was ordered for the applicant.
- The applicant was eventually recognized as a refugee.

title: CASE OF JERONOVIČS v. LATVIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1962 and is detained in Daugavpils Prison.
- On 25 April 1998, the applicant and another individual were arrested by the police on suspicion of having committed aggravated assault against P.M.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated, throughout which the applicant and his co-defendant pleaded their innocence.
- On 27 September 2000, the applicant and his co-defendant were found guilty and were sentenced to nine and twelve years’ imprisonment respectively by the Riga Regional Court.
- The applicant complained to the public prosecutor’s office that he had been ill-treated by police officers who had tried to obtain a confession from him.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the police officers for abuse of official power but were discontinued by the Riga police station investigator on grounds of insufficient evidence.
- The applicant lodged an application (no. 547/02) with the Court alleging multiple breaches of the Convention.
- On 30 April 2008, the Government submitted a unilateral declaration recognising the violation of multiple articles of the Convention.
- On 10 February 2009, the Court struck out certain complaints mentioned in the Government’s declaration but declared admissible other complaints concerning the applicant’s conditions of detention and the refusal to grant him leave to attend the Supreme Court hearing.
- On 1 December 2009, the Court found a violation of Article 3 of the Convention and Article 6 § 1 and awarded compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- On 11 October 2010, the applicant requested the public prosecutor’s office to reopen the criminal proceedings in which he had been convicted and the proceedings concerning his alleged ill-treatment by police officers, relying on the terms of the Government’s unilateral declaration and applicable law.
- On 17 November 2010, a prosecutor attached to the Riga Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s request for reopening the criminal proceedings concerning his ill-treatment, finding that the conclusions reached in the Court’s judgment of 1 December 2009 and the Government’s unilateral declaration of 30 April 2008 could not be applied or connected to the criminal proceedings.
- The applicant appealed the prosecutor’s decision on 9 December 2010, arguing that the Government’s unilateral declaration recognised the violation of Article 3 of the Convention, a circumstance which had led the Court to strike out that complaint, and that the judicial authorities had been unaware of the investigation's breach of Article 3 at the time his criminal case

title: CASE OF ZIEMBIŃSKI v. POLAND (No. 2)
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is a journalist and editor-in-chief of a local newspaper.
- In one issue of the newspaper, the applicant published an article critical of local officials and their quail farming initiative.
- The officials who were criticized in the article filed a private bill of indictment against the applicant for defamation.
- The trial court found the applicant guilty of insult committed through the mass media and ordered him to pay a fine and reimburse costs.
- The applicant appealed, but the appeal court upheld the trial court's decision.

title: CASE OF NADERHIRN v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant applied for a license to run a pharmacy in Leonding on 10 July 2001.
- The request was rejected on 25 September 2002.
- The applicant lodged an appeal and a complaint against the Minister’s failure to give a decision.
- The Administrative Court set a time-limit for the Minister to make a decision.
- The Minister dismissed the appeal on 24 March 2005.
- The applicant filed a complaint with the Constitutional Court.
- The applicant lodged a request for re-opening of the proceedings with the Minister.
- The Minister granted the applicant a license to run a pharmacy on 5 December 2005.
- The applicant challenged parts of the Minister’s decision before the Constitutional Court, which dismissed his complaint.
- The Administrative Court quashed the Minister’s decisions of 24 March and 10 May 2005, as well as the decision of 5 December 2005.
- The proceedings were referred back to the Minister.
- On 19 March 2010, the Minister granted the applicant’s appeal against the decision of the Regional Governor of Upper Austria of 25 September 2002.
- The complaint against that decision raised by the owners of an existing pharmacy was dismissed by the Administrative Court.
- The applicant was awarded compensation for costs in the amount of 1,106.40 euros (EUR).

title: CASE OF KURSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a member of the Polish Parliament and a member of the Law and Justice party.
- During a live television programme, the applicant took out a copy of Gazeta Wyborcza and pointed to particular pages, accusing the newspaper of publishing aggressive and clearly one-sided articles financed via advertisements by J&S S.A., a company which had conducted morally doubtful activities.
- Agora S.A., the publisher of Gazeta Wyborcza, brought a civil claim against the applicant for the protection of its rights, claiming that the applicant’s statements during the television programme on 8 May 2006 had harmed its good name and credibility. 
- The Warsaw Regional Court granted the claim and ordered the applicant to issue an apology in Gazeta Wyborcza and TVP2 for the statements he had made, pay PLN 10,000 to a charity, and PLN 2,410 in court fees.
- The Warsaw Court of Appeal upheld the first‑instance judgment and ordered the applicant to pay PLN 270 in court fees for the proceedings at second instance. The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's cassation appeal. 
- The court considered that the applicant had prepared in advance to make the statement in question and had not proved the truthfulness of his statements about the alleged connections between the plaintiff and the J&S S.A. company. It further stressed that freedom of expression was not absolute and that the proportionality of the interference may depend on whether there existed a sufficient factual basis for the impugned statement.

title: CASE OF RAHMİ ŞAHİN v. TURKEY
facts:
- Mr. Rahmi Şahin was born in 1985 and lives in Hakkari.
- On 12 December 2009, the applicant was taken into police custody on suspicion of involvement in a demonstration and subsequent clashes between some of the demonstrators and the police in Hakkari.
- A press conference was held on 11 December 2009 where people gathered in front of the DTP’s Hakkari office and chanted slogans and carried banners praising Abdullah Öcalan and the PKK.
- On 11 and 12 December 2009, security forces intervened in several areas in the city where demonstrators had blocked the traffic, chanted slogans in favour of the PKK and its leader, and burned tyres or attacked cars, shops and administrative buildings.
- The applicant was apprehended after the police had moved against a group of 50-60 people who had been chanting slogans in favour of the PKK and its leader in the cemetery of the Biçer neighbourhood.
- The police officers stated that they had arrested the applicant after he had attempted to avoid arrest.
- The applicant suffered injuries during his arrest: a haematoma on the left eye, swelling between the upper lip and teeth, a bruised lesion with abrasions on the lumbar area at the level of the second vertebra, and sensitivity upon palpation in the left femoral and lumbar regions.
- A forensic doctor noted old yellow-green ecchymosis in the right periorbital area and a mucosal tear of 0.5 cm and oedema on the right side of the upper lip, concluding that the injuries were not life-threatening and required only simple medical care.
- The applicant continuously claimed that he had been beaten by the police officers during the arrest, but the public prosecutor and assize court held that there was no evidence showing that the applicant had been subjected to ill-treatment. 
- Two police officers made statements that the applicant had been with a group of people who had been chanting slogans in favour of the PKK and its leader and who had burned tyres, and the group had attacked the police with stones when the police had moved against the gathering.

title: CASE OF BANDUR v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was accused of theft of goods from a limited liability company.
- Investigations were opened against two individuals on suspicion of forgery of public documents and aggravated fraud.
- The applicant was unreachable at his permanent address, which led to a warrant for his arrest.
- The applicant voluntarily appeared at a police station in June 2012 and was placed in police custody the same day.
- The applicant complained against the measure, arguing that he had not been present at his permanent address as he worked as a truck driver abroad.
- The complaint was dismissed by the Tatabánya district prosecutor’s office.
- The applicant was represented by a lawyer of his choice.
- The Tatabánya Police department filed an application with the head of the Tatabánya District Prosecutor’s Office seeking the applicant’s placement in pre-trial detention.
- The Komárom-Esztergom County public prosecutor’s office applied for the applicant’s pre-trial detention, which was ordered on 9 June 2012 by the Tatabánya District Court.
- The applicant appealed, but the first-instance decision was upheld on 14 June 2012 by the Tatabánya High Court.
- The applicant applied for release from pre-trial detention on 2 July 2012. The request was dismissed by the District Court on 9 July 2012.
- The Tatabánya High Court partly upheld the applicant’s appeal, finding no risk of his absconding, but upheld the first-instance decision to prolong the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- The investigation was closed on 28 August 2012, and the applicant was released from pre-trial detention on 7 September 2012.
- The applicant was acquitted on 25 June 2015.
- The applicant was detained in Székesfehérvár Prison from 9 June to 7 September 2012.

title: CASE OF LAZU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was a bank armoured vehicle driver and was born in 1954 and lived in Chișinău.
- On 12th August 2005, while the applicant was driving an armoured vehicle, he went around an illegally parked bus, and the bus started moving, which made the applicant stop the vehicle abruptly in order to avoid an accident with the armoured vehicle. As a result of this sudden stop, a bus passenger suffered moderately severe injuries.
- A criminal investigation was initiated on 1st September 2005.
- On 7th October 2005, the bus driver was charged with violating traffic rules.
- On 21st October 2005, the applicant was charged with violating traffic rules.
- During the course of the proceedings, the Botanica District Court heard the same witnesses as the prosecutor, and it considered the testimony of the victim and two bus passengers unreliable.
- The court acquitted the applicant in a judgment of 27th March 2006. However, the prosecutor appealed on points of law.
- The Supreme Court of Justice upheld the prosecutor’s appeal on points of law and ordered a rehearing of the case in 2006.
- In 2007, the Chișinău Court of Appeal found the applicant guilty, and he was ordered to pay an administrative fine and damages to the victim.
- The applicant appealed, but his appeal was declared inadmissible in 2008.
- The final judgment was served to the applicant on 24th May 2008.

title: CASE OF RUDOLFER v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Bratislava.
- The applicant's parents built a house in Bratislava-Ružinov in 1937.
- In the 1950s, the applicant was compelled to donate the house to the State.
- On 31 July 1992, the applicant's mother and the applicant were restored ownership of the house.
- The house comprised nine flats subject to rent control.
- Under the rent-control scheme, the applicant had to accept that his flats were occupied by the tenants and could not sell the flats to anyone other than the tenants.
- Between 1992 and 1999, the maximum permissible monthly rent chargeable for the flats was equivalent to some 3 to 8 euros (EUR).
- In 2007, the rent control limits for some flats were lifted. 
- The applicant could charge some EUR 35 for smaller flats and EUR 65 for each of larger once in 2007.
- The parties provided differing figures for the market rent. 
- The applicant relied on data from the National Association of Real Estate Agencies (“NAREA”), whereas the Government submitted its expert valuation.

title: CASE OF KRAHULEC v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant lives in Zvolen and was born in 1945.
- The applicant’s grandfather built a house in Piešťany in 1929 that was passed down to the applicant's family.
- The house has four flats, two of 108 sq. m each and two of 123 sq. m each.
- At the time of application, the flats were occupied by tenants with a regulated rent, with their right to use established by decisions taken by the municipal authorities between 1953 and 1986.
- The applicant was bound by the rent-control scheme under the applicable legislation, and he could not unilaterally terminate the leases.
- The regulated rent was increased several times, and in 2004, the applicant was able to charge €115 for the smaller flats and €124 for the larger ones.
- The applicant contested the regulated rent and led several property disputes with the tenants and the local municipality.
- The parties provided different figures for the market rent, with the applicant claiming it to be €600-€800 and the Government's expert evaluation at €265.50 and €325 respectively.
- As of June 2014, the rent control on all four flats had been terminated, with different dates for each flat.

title: CASE OF ZOSYMOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant and his wife started a family business in 1996 involving digital data replication and sale of storage devices.
- The business was carried out in an office on P. Street in Kyiv owned by the applicant's mother.
- On 20 August 2002, police officers from KECU inspected the applicant's office and seized computers, optical discs, and other items.
- The police also inspected the applicant's garage and car.
- The seized items were stored by the police pending resolution of the case.
- The police questioned the applicant, his wife, and their extended family during the inspection.
- A report was published on the Ministry of Interior's website on 22 August 2002, identifying the applicant and his wife as part of a criminal group.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted on 15 November 2002 against the suspected breach of copyright without naming specific suspects.
- The seized items were declared as physical evidence to be stored by the police pending the investigation of the case.
- The Shevchenkivsky District Court of Kyiv issued search warrants for the applicant's and his wife's flats due to suspicions of breaching criminal legislation regarding copyright protection.
- The flats were searched on 23 November 2002, but no items were seized.
- The applicant repeatedly asked for the return of his seized property, but requests were rejected due to the items being considered physical evidence in a criminal case.
- The applicant and his wife instituted defamation proceedings against police authorities for publishing an inaccurate crime report on their website.
- A district court allowed the claim on 27 October 2003, which was not appealed and became final.
- The applicant requested criminal proceedings to be instituted against KECU officers who had inspected and seized his property, but the request was rejected.
- The applicant lodged a complaint against the Investigative Department of the Kyiv Police, alleging that the inspection of his office, search and seizure of his property, and institution of criminal proceedings on 15 November 2002 had been unlawful.
- The District Court rejected his complaint, finding he lacked standing to bring the proceedings, and that the disputed criminal case had been instituted "into the matter" rather than "against the applicant."
- The Court of Appeal initially quashed the District Court's decision and decided to discontinue the proceedings. 
- The Supreme Court remitted the case to the lower courts for fresh consideration, noting the unconstitutional provisions of Article 234 of the CCP, which had made it impossible to appeal separately against

title: CASE OF A.B. AND OTHERS v. FRANCE [Extracts]
facts:
- The applicants fled Armenia due to fears of persecution related to the first applicant's activity as a journalist and political activism.
- They filed applications for asylum in France, which were rejected by the French Office for the Protection of Refugees and Stateless Persons and the National Asylum Court. Their subsequent requests for re-examination were also rejected.
- The applicants were ordered to leave French territory and were detained in an administrative detention center.
- They challenged their detention but were unsuccessful in obtaining a stay of execution.
- The detention orders were extended, but were later annulled by the Bordeaux Administrative Court of Appeal.
- The first applicant was eventually granted leave to remain as the parent of a sick child, and the family did not leave France.

title: CASE OF ALIYEV AND GADZHIYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr Nizamudin Aliyev and Ms Madina Gadzhiyeva live in Makhachkala, Dagestan.
- Sirazhudin Aliyev and Gazimagomed Abdullayev were driving in Gazimagomed Abdullayev's car in the centre of Makhachkala on 21 January 2012 when they were abducted by a group of several armed men in uniforms of the State Traffic Police.
- The abductors discharged one gunshot, hit Abdullayev's car with their truncheons, handcuffed both of them and drove away in their own cars along with the victims.
- After the abduction, Abdullayev's car was driven away by the abductors. The abduction was witnessed by numerous people.
- The relatives of Aliyev and Abdullayev complained about the abduction to the Dagestan Public Prosecutor and the investigations department of the Leninskiy district prosecutor's office.
- The Government did not dispute the circumstances, but they denied any involvement of State agents in the incident and stated that the allegations of State agents' involvement had been completely unsubstantiated.
- The Investigations Department initiated a criminal investigation into the abduction under Articles 126 and 162 of the Criminal Code and the case file was given the number 20150.
- The applicants requested that the police and FSS officers reveal whether they had participated in the abduction.

title: CASE OF ZDRAVKO STANEV v. BULGARIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was convicted of using a forged document and falsely accusing another person of criminal conduct, and sentenced to two years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant filed an appeal and accused the judge-rapporteur of being biased and seeking revenge.
- The Stara Zagora Regional Court quashed the lower court’s judgment and remitted the case for re-examination due to several breaches of the rules of procedure.
- The judge-rapporteur in the criminal case against the applicant brought a private criminal prosecution against him for making untrue and defamatory written and oral statements in the appeal proceedings.
- The applicant was convicted of defaming a public official and sentenced to a fine and public reprimand, which was later reduced on appeal.

title: CASE OF MUČIBABIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
1. The case concerns the investigation into the death of the applicant’s son.
2. A powerful explosion occurred at the facilities of Grmeč on 23 June 1995.
3. The explosion was caused by the covert production of composite solid rocket fuel under the auspices of the State Intelligence Service.
4. Composite fuel is a broad class of solid chemical fuels that are used as propellants in rockets and require a specialized location with a high level of preventive measures and safety precautions.
5. An Intelligence Service executive had agreed to the production of rocket fuel with a private company, JPL Systems.
6. On 23 June 1995, most of the components were blended together in a batch mixer in another company, transported in aluminum bins to Grmeč in a private car by JPL experts and stored next to the mill.
7. When the mixture was put on the mill and extraction of the sheets of rocket fuel started, an explosion occurred in the presence of more than twenty workers from the two commissioned companies.
8. The explosion resulted in the death of the applicant’s son and ten other people, while ten others were seriously injured.
9. Neither Grmeč nor JPL was licensed and adequately equipped for the production of rocket fuel at the material time.
10. The post-mortem examination of victims’ bodies was carried out between 24 and 26 June 1995 by the Institute for Forensic Medicine of the Faculty of Medicine in Belgrade.
11. On 24 June 1995 the Belgrade police ex officio set up a commission to examine the cause of the explosion.
12. Following site inspections between 23 and 26 June 1995 and computer simulations of the explosions, two experts from the Security Institute submitted their report to the DDPO on 9 August 1995, which stated that the explosion appeared to have been initially caused by the heat generated by the mill’s rollers during the production of composite fuel.
13. The applicant lodged a criminal complaint against a number of senior executives of Grmeč and JPL in March 1996.
14. The experts’ report of 9 August 1995 was served on the applicant on 15 April 1996, and he posed several questions and objections.
15. The court appointed the Belgrade Chemistry Faculty to determine the cause of the explosion, whether it could have been avoided, and the possible liability in that respect.

title: CASE OF PETRYCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1940 and lives in Kyiv.
- In October 2004, the applicant filed a case against the Pension Fund of Ukraine to recover alleged pension arrears and compensation for moral damage.
- The applicant claimed that he was entitled to a pension equal to the minimum living standard under Article 46 of the Constitution.
- On October 25, 2004, the court rejected the applicant's claim for unfounded reasons.
- Kyiv City Court of Appeal and Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine upheld the decision of the first-instance court disregarding the applicant's argument under Article 46 of the Constitution.

title: CASE OF KOTELNIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and lived in a village in the Rostov Region.
- The applicant reprimanded a drunk police officer for making indecent suggestions to a girl, who then made a vague threat.
- The applicant was hit by a car while on the pavement, driven by the same police officer, resulting in severe head and spinal injuries.
- The police officer loaded the applicant into his car and drove him away from the scene of the accident before taking him to a hospital.
- The police officer's father, who was the chief of the local tax police, called his acquaintances to help protect his son, but the government did not comment on the allegation.
- While at the hospital, the applicant was made to sign a report stating that he fell down the stairs of a nearby cafe and injured himself.
- Blood tests showed that the applicant had a high level of alcohol in his blood, while the police officer had a lower level.
- The applicant underwent multiple surgeries and struggled with disabilities after the accident.
- The case file was nine volumes and over three thousand pages long.

title: CASE OF GEDRIMAS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Jonava.
- On 23 April 2008, there was a break-in and robbery in a jewellery store in Jonava.
- Two officers of the Jonava Police Department received an alert about the robbery and called a dog handler to follow traces to a nearby garage complex. The applicant worked as a guard in the garage complex and was on duty that night.
- The police officers arrested the applicant and took him to the police station. The applicant and the police officers presented different accounts of the circumstances surrounding the arrest.
- The applicant alleged that the police officers used physical force, including twisting his arms and kicking him in the stomach, to make him confess to the crime. He was examined by a doctor who found contusions on his abdomen and a sprain of his shoulder joints.
- The prosecutor opened a pre-trial investigation to determine whether the police officers had ill-treated the applicant. The investigation included questioning the police officers, the dog handler, and the applicant, and arranging a confrontation between the applicant and one of the police officers. An expert medical report found that the applicant's injuries constituted negligible health impairment.

title: CASE OF KOROVINA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- All applicants were involved in civil proceedings.
- The first instance and appeal courts ruled in their favor.
- The judgments became final.
- The supervisory review courts later quashed the previous judgments.
- The quashing was due to incorrect application of substantive law or incorrect assessment of evidence by lower courts.

title: CASE OF MARINOVA AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Mrs Marinova complained to the Child Protection Agency that her son's teacher ill-treated and humiliated him, but her complaint was not supported.
- She also complained that the teacher took her son's mobile phone, and the teacher filed a private criminal prosecution against her for these complaints.
- The Tervel District Court found Mrs Marinova guilty of defaming the teacher and ordered her to pay damages.
- Mr Zlatanov alleged that a road traffic police officer behaved aggressively and refused to present himself, smelled of alcohol, and staggered. An internal inquiry exonerated the officer, and the officer filed a private criminal prosecution against Mr Zlatanov.
- The Kavarna District Court found Mr Zlatanov guilty of defaming the officer and ordered him to pay damages.
- Mr Findulov alleged that a traffic police officer solicited a bribe and withheld his documents. A decision by the Road Traffic Police Department of the Burgas Regional Directorate of the Ministry of Internal Affairs found Mr Findulov guilty of a road traffic offence, and Mr Findulov sought judicial review of that decision. The officer then brought a private criminal prosecution against Mr Findulov for his allegations.
- The Burgas District Court found Mr Findulov guilty of defaming the officer and ordered him to pay damages.
- Mr and Mrs Dinchevi complained to the head of the Lovech District Police Directorate against two officers who came to their aid when they believed they were assaulted by their neighbours. The head of the Lovech District Police Directorate found their complaint ill-founded, and the officers then filed a private criminal prosecution against Mr and Mrs Dinchevi.

title: CASE OF KOLKUTIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Chita.
- The applicant was arrested on 2 September 2004 on the charges of fraud and forgery of official documents.
- The Tsentralnyy District Court of Chita authorized the applicant's pre-trial detention on 4 September 2004.
- The Chita Regional Court upheld the decision of 2 September 2004 on appeal on 11 November 2004.
- The applicant remained in custody pending investigation and trial.
- The court extended his pre-trial detention on several occasions, stating that if he was at large, he might obstruct justice, put pressure on victims and witnesses, or continue to commit crimes.
- On 4 June 2007, the District Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to eight years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF PARCHIYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were involved in civil proceedings
- First-instance and appeal courts found in favour of applicants
- Judgments became final
- The supervisory review courts quashed the judgments 
- Quashing was based on incorrect application of substantive law or incorrect assessment of evidence

title: CASE OF BARKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- All applicants were detained in Russian penal facilities at the time of the case.
- Mr Baban, Mr Barkov, and Mr Bogatyrev sought compensation for inadequate conditions and substandard medical care.
- Mr Davydov, Mr Pflyaum, and Mr Yakovlev were involved in contract disputes.
- Mr Fedchenko was the respondent in a divorce claim.
- Mr Starodubtsev challenged the decision by which he had lost the status of a disabled person.
- Mr Shavayev was the defendant in an action for damages brought by the Federal Customs Service.
- None of the applicants, except Mr Yakovlev, could attend the hearings before the courts of first instance.
- Domestic courts refused the applicants' leave to be present during trials, citing a lack of legal provisions to bring detainees to court.
- Some of the applicants were represented by relatives, while others were interviewed in courts near their places of detention.
- Applicants appealed, but the appeal courts either dismissed their arguments or concluded that their absence did not violate the fairness principle.
- None of the applicants were present or represented during the appellate hearings.
- The dates of the final judgments are listed in Appendix I.

title: CASE OF MEČIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Vinkovci.
- The Vinkovci Municipal Court ordered the applicant’s former employer to pay him 20,921.18 Croatian kunas as remuneration for overtime work and HRK 19,495.90 in costs.
- The applicant was found guilty of embezzlement and sentenced to ten months' imprisonment.
- The Đakovo Municipal Court issued a writ of enforcement, but the Osijek County Court quashed it, stating that the judgment had not been stamped with a certificate of enforceability.
- The Đakovo Municipal Court later issued a new writ of enforcement, and the Osijek County Court upheld it.
- The debtor company set off its claim for compensation against the applicant's claim for payment of overtime work.
- The court postponed the enforcement pending the outcome of separate civil proceedings.
- The Osijek County Court quashed and remitted the case, but the Đakovo Municipal Court postponed the enforcement again.
- The court later resumed the enforcement in the remaining part.
- The Domestic Payments Agency transferred HRK 38,306.87 from the debtor company’s bank account to those of the applicant and his legal representative.
- The applicant lodged a request for protection of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time, but it was dismissed by the court.
- The Supreme Court and the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's appeals.

title: CASE OF G.N. v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a Canadian citizen and was married to a Polish national E.N.
- Their son was born in Canada in September 2010 and obtained Canadian nationality at birth.
- The couple went to Poland for a holiday in April 2011 but separated in May 2011 when E.N. refused to return to Canada with their child.
- The applicant lodged an application to have his child returned under the Hague Convention on 31 October 2011, which was registered with the Kielce District Court on 23 January 2012.
- The Kielce District Court decided to obtain an expert report from the Family Consultation Centre to assess whether the child is at a grave risk if returned to Canada, whether physically or psychologically.
- The applicant did not show up for the scheduled interview at the Family Consultation Centre, and the report was based on the statements of the child and mother, along with four volumes of the court's case file.
- The experts concluded that returning the child to Canada would pose a grave risk to his emotional and social development, and it would be against his best interest.
- In January 2013, the Kielce District Court, with Judge I.G. presiding, dismissed the applicant's Hague Convention application.
- The first-instance court held that the child had been wrongfully retained in Poland by the mother within the meaning of the Hague Convention but decided against his return to Canada.
- The appellate court upheld the decision of the first-instance court, with some modifications.
- The appellate court observed that the utmost importance had to be attached to the child's contact with his mother, and separating the two-year-old boy from the mother would be traumatic and hard to bear for the child.
- The applicant lodged an application with the domestic court for arrangements to secure the effective exercise of his right of contact, which was dismissed for being unsubstantiated.
- The Polish family court granted the applicant a right to contact with his child, but the details of this decision are unknown to the Court.
- The divorce proceedings between the applicant and E.N. are pending before the Kielce Regional Court.

title: CASE OF JOVANOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant brought an enforcement action against a socially/State-owned company "FŽV Želvoz a.d. Smederevo" on 28 April 2010.
- On 15 December 2010, the court ordered direct enforcement of the outstanding invoice.
- On 15 June 2011, the Privatisation Agency ordered the restructuring of the debtor.
- The enforcement proceedings were stayed on 25 October 2011 as the debtor was undergoing restructuring.
- On 3 November 2011, the applicant appealed the decision to stay the enforcement proceedings.
- On 10 February 2012, the applicant's appeal was rejected by the enforcement court.
- On 21 March 2013, the applicant urged the court to continue the enforcement proceedings, but the court informed him that the proceedings could not be continued due to the debtor undergoing restructuring.
- The applicant brought another enforcement action against a socially/State-owned company "Vagonka a.d. Niš" on 11 January 2010.
- On 29 January 2010, the court ordered direct enforcement of the outstanding invoice.
- On 4 November 2009, the Privatisation Agency ordered the restructuring of the debtor as part of the privatisation process.
- The enforcement proceedings were stayed on 4 February 2010 as the debtor was undergoing restructuring.
- The applicant did not appeal against this decision.
- On 20 March 2013, the applicant urged the court to continue the enforcement proceedings, but the court informed him that the proceedings could not be continued due to the debtor undergoing restructuring.

title: CASE OF DEVTEROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was charged with accessory to murder on 9 December 2010, and his name was put on the wanted list.
- The applicant was ordered to detain on 16 December 2010 by the Kushchevskiy District Court.
- The applicant reported to the police station on 21 January 2011 and was arrested.
- The District Court remanded the applicant in custody on 29 March 2011, citing concerns of the applicant absconding, committing another offence that threatens witnesses, destroying evidence or interfering in the investigation.
