- The District Court extended the applicant's pre-trial detention on 19 April 2011 due to the evidence confirming his involvement in the crimes and the risk of absconding.
- The applicant stayed in detention, and the courts regularly extended it, citing the above formula and mentioning the applicant's family status, personality, state of health, lack of job, and ability to put pressure on witnesses and interfere with the investigation.
- The applicant was charged with additional crimes on 2 November 2011.
- In October 2012, the applicant, along with two co-defendants, was referred for trial before the Krasnodar Regional Court.
- The applicant was released on 7 June 2013.
- On 19 June 2013, the Krasnodar Regional Court cleared the applicant of all charges and granted him the right to rehabilitation.
- On 30 September 2013, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the ruling of 19 June 2013 on appeal.
- The applicant lodged a lawsuit against the Federal Treasury seeking compensation for pecuniary damage (legal expenses).
- The Regional Court awarded the applicant 680,600 Russian rubles as compensation for legal fees on 3 June 2014.

title: CASE OF MAJTAN v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Košice.
- The applicant has been involved in domestic litigation concerning numerous claims on upbringing and maintenance of the child since 1993.
- The present application concerns three interrelated claims brought before the Čadca District Court on 12 March 2003 and subsequently on 3 July and 16 December 2003.
- Throughout the proceedings, the District Court examined extensive evidence.
- The District Court held nine hearings on the merits, out of which the applicant attended two.
- The District Court twice ruled on the merits of the case, on 20 August 2008, and 31 March 2011, respectively.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint regarding the length of the proceedings held before the District Court.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the applicant’s constitutional complaint on 6 October 2011, on the ground that the matter at stake was complicated.
- On 21 March 2012, the Žilina Regional Court dealt with the applicant’s second appeal and delivered the judgment on the merits of the case.
- The applicant then lodged an application for reimbursement of a court fee he had paid for one of his challenges of the judge for bias.

title: CASE OF E.S. v. ROMANIA AND BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant had a child with a Bulgarian national father in Spain in 2004.
- The child lived with both parents in Spain until 2007, when she was sent to live with her paternal grandparents in Bulgaria. 
- The applicant and the child returned to Romania in 2008 and stayed with the maternal grandmother. 
- The paternal grandparents took the child from Romania to Bulgaria without the applicant's knowledge or consent in 2008. 
- The applicant lodged a request for full custody of the child with the Romanian court in 2008 but faced challenges due to not knowing the whereabouts of the father.
- In 2010 the District Court awarded custody to the applicant, but the decision was overturned by the County Court in 2011, who gave custody to the father.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the District Court's decision in 2012.
- The applicant sought recognition of the Romanian custody decision in Bulgaria, which was granted but then quashed and sent back for re-examination.
- The applicant also lodged a request for the return of the child under the Hague Convention in 2011, and was advised to request her through the Brussels II bis Regulation.

title: CASE OF YEVSTRATOV AND RUDAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were prosecuted in Russia for various crimes.
- They were arrested and detained while the crimes were investigated and pending trial.
- Their detention was ordered and extended by the courts.
- The detention orders were based on the risk of the applicants’ absconding and interfering with the course of justice, without considering alternative preventive measures.
- The detention and extension orders used stereotypical formulae, without addressing specific facts.
- First applicant: Charged with banditry, kidnapping, abuse of power, robbery (four counts), preparing to commit robbery, intentionally damaging another’s property, and stealing and damaging official documents. Convicted of abuse of power and sentenced to three years’ imprisonment and disqualification from holding public office for one year.
- Second applicant: Charged with fraud involving an apartment causing damage in the amount of 440,000 Russian roubles (RUB). Sentenced to eleven months’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF YUDIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are municipal employees in Troitsko-Pechorsk of Komi Republic.
- They worked for a commercial company, Troitsko-Pechorskoye ZhKKh, which was set up in 2003 to perform maintenance and related services.
- Between 2004-2006, certain assets were withdrawn from the company by the district administration and transferred to the municipal district treasury.
- From 2007, the company became subject to supervision and insolvency proceedings, with numerous creditor claims lodged and insufficient funds to settle debts.
- The liquidator lodged an action against the district administration under Article 56 § 3 of the Civil Code of the Russian Federation claiming that the insolvency of the company had been caused by the administration through asset transfers.
- The domestic courts rejected the claim, finding no evidence that the owner’s actions had caused the insolvency.
- On 28 December 2011, the commercial court ordered the company’s liquidation and the company ceased to exist.
- The judgments in the applicants’ favour remained unenforced either in full or in part.

title: CASE OF POPOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lived in Novokuznetsk, the Kemerovo Region.
- On June 14, 2007, police took the applicant to a police station in Pospelikha village in the Altay Region for questioning about a theft.
- The applicant made self-incriminatory statements during questioning.
- During the questioning, the investigator left the office and the applicant attempted to leave but was stopped by a policeman.
- The applicant spent around four hours in the investigator's office.
- Charges of theft were filed against the applicant on June 18, 2007, but were dropped one month later.
- The applicant filed a civil claim for compensation for unlawful criminal prosecution and deprivation of liberty in 2009.
- The Pospelikhinskiy District Court of the Altay Region awarded the applicant 1,000 Russian roubles (RUB) in respect of non-pecuniary damage on October 20, 2009. The court noted that the questioning of June 14, 2007, had not amounted to a deprivation of liberty and could not give rise to any form of compensation.
- The applicant appealed the decision, but the appeal was dismissed on February 10, 2009.
- The judgment of October 20, 2009, was enforced on March 5, 2011.
- In 2007, Ms. I brought a civil action against the applicant, claiming a contractual debt.
- On July 5, 2007, the Justice of the Peace of the Pospelikhinskiy District of the Altay Region granted Ms. I's claim and ordered the applicant to pay RUB 11,311.
- The applicant appealed the decision but was denied leave to appear before the appeal court on September 12, 2007.
- On October 10, 2007, the Pospelikhinskiy District Court upheld the judgment on appeal.

title: CASE OF BADRETDINOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were convicted by Russian courts
- Applicants were given custodial sentences
- Applicants served their sentences in overcrowded penitentiary facilities
- The facilities suffered from a shortage of sanitary installations

title: CASE OF SHAHANOV AND PALFREEMAN v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Mr Shahanov is serving a life sentence in Plovdiv Prison, while Mr Palfreeman is serving a 20-year sentence in Sofia Prison.
- Mr Shahanov made complaints about another inmate in his cell, alleging improper relationships with two prison officers, threats, intimidation, and planning to escape.
- An inquiry was opened into Mr Shahanov's complaints, which found no evidence to support them.
- Mr Shahanov was placed in solitary confinement for ten days for making defamatory statements and false allegations against prison officers.
- Mr Palfreeman wrote a complaint about guards stealing personal items from visitors during a visit and treating them rudely.
- Disciplinary proceedings were opened against Mr Palfreeman for making untrue allegations and he was punished with a three-month deprivation of the right to receive food parcels.
- Mr Palfreeman appealed to the head of the Chief Directorate for the Execution of Sentences and his appeal was dismissed.
- The Sofia District Court held that it could not deal with Mr Palfreeman’s claim for judicial review, as only orders imposing solitary confinement were amenable to such review.

title: CASE OF MIRYANA PETROVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and worked as a system operator for the National Security Service since 1981.
- The applicant had a security clearance that allowed her access to classified information constituting state secrets.
- The Classified Information Protection Act was promulgated on April 30, 2002, which required the heads of organizational units to request the issuance of security clearance for their employees who possessed an access permit and needed access to classified information, and non-compliance would result in the invalidation of existing access permits.
- The Director of the National Security Service refused to grant the applicant security clearance on June 3, 2003, and did not provide any reason for the decision apart from a reference to Section 57 of the Classified Information Protection Act.
- The State Commission for Information Security upheld the refusal on February 5, 2004, which was final and not amenable to judicial review.
- The applicant was dismissed on April 27, 2004, for the reason that possession of security clearance was an indispensable condition for her to perform her duties and she was no longer able to do so.
- The applicant challenged her dismissal in three levels of jurisdiction on the grounds that she had fulfilled all the conditions for the issuance of security clearance and that she had been dismissed on account of a negative personal relationship with her direct supervisor.
- The Sofia District Court rejected the applicant's claims on May 11, 2005, ruling that the refusal of security clearance was a valid administrative act, and her dismissal was inevitable because she could no longer perform her duties.
- The Sofia City Court upheld the lower court's decision on April 6, 2006.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation upheld the rulings on June 19, 2008.

facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their details is attached.
- The applicants complained about the length of their pre-trial detention.
- Applicant 21219/15 complained about the review of his detention being too slow under Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.

facts:

- Applicants complained about excessive length of civil proceedings 
- Some applicants raised additional complaints under Convention provisions

title: CASE OF TOMOV AND NIKOLOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants purchased a plot of land in Kranevo in 1993.
- Other individuals took possession of the land in 2003.
- The land had been collectivized after 1945 and restitution proceedings had been initiated by the heirs of the pre-collectivization owner in 1991.
- The restitution request of Mr. K's heirs was granted in a court judgment of 7 December 1995 and a decision by the local agricultural land commission on 4 April 1996.
- The heirs of Mr. K transferred the land to the individuals who took the possession of the plot.
- The Balchik District Court dismissed the applicants’ claim on the basis of section 10(13) of the Agricultural Land Act.
- The Dobrich Regional Court reversed the District Court's decision and allowed the applicants’ action in 2007.
- In 2008, The Supreme Court of Cassation dismissed the applicants’ claim, taking the view that section 10(13) of the ALA was applicable, and section 18z(3) of the Regulations for the ALA’s implementation was inapplicable to the case.

title: CASE OF PETRESKA v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Skopje.
- The applicant was employed by the State Intelligence Agency.
- On 28 February 2001, she was dismissed from work as redundant due to reduced numbers of employees.
- The internal regulations (the Regulations) of 27 February 2001 provided for a reduced number of employees for posts like the one held by the applicant.
- On 9 April 2001, the applicant challenged her dismissal before the Skopje Court of First Instance.
- Following three remittal orders, on 29 November 2005, the first-instance court dismissed the applicant’s claim.
- The government approved the regulations on 27 February 2001, and they entered into force the same day.
- On 14 December 2005, the applicant appealed, arguing that the Regulations could not have applied to her case, as they could only be adopted after the employer had received the government's approval.
- On 23 February 2006, the appellate court dismissed the applicant’s appeal, finding that the dismissal was lawful.
- On 7 April 2006, the applicant lodged an appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court.
- On 25 October 2007, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law.
- On 15 January 2008, the applicant was served with the Supreme Court’s judgment.

title: CASE OF GERBEY AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- First applicant arrested in 2003, convicted of robbery and imprisoned for 5 years.
- Attempts to obtain documents from domestic case file while detained and after release.
- Second applicant arrested in 2004, convicted of murder and imprisoned for 15 years.
- Requests for access to criminal case file and procedural documents refused.
- Third applicant arrested in 2008, convicted of murder and imprisoned for 15 years.
- Requests for copies of appeals made between 2010 and 2011, received some documents but cassation appeal missing.
- Fourth applicant sentenced to 5 years' imprisonment in 2009 for illegal possession of arms and drug dealing.
- Not allowed to keep copy of Supreme Court decision.
- Court invited fourth applicant to submit copies of various documents from criminal case file, but access to file refused by holding court.

title: CASE OF U.N. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a young Uzbek man from Kyrgyzstan who currently lives in Vladivostok, Russia.
- He left Kyrgyzstan after being charged in absentia with violent crimes related to inter-ethnic clashes that occurred in June 2010.
- He was arrested in Russia in 2014, and his detention was extended several times.
- The Kyrgyz authorities requested his extradition, and the Russian courts eventually granted it despite the applicant's claims that he would face torture and ill-treatment.
- The applicant applied for refugee status in Russia, but his application was rejected by both regional and federal authorities who did not find evidence of persecution based on his ethnic origin.
- The Supreme Court of Russia noted that the applicant belonged to a vulnerable group at risk of torture, but ultimately decided that his extradition would not violate international law.

title: CASE OF VEIGA DA SILVA BRAGA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- Date of enforcement proceedings: May 6, 2011
- Nature of enforcement proceedings: Child support payment
- Amount sought: 3,600 EUR
- Notification of non-attachable assets: February 27, 2013
- Proceedings extinguished due to lack of attachable assets: June 12, 2015.

title: CASE OF ADAM v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- Applicant is of Romani origin and lives in Bidovce.
- A twelve-year-old boy was mugged and his mobile phone was taken from him on 18 December 2010 while walking between two villages in south-eastern Slovakia.
- Three suspects including the applicant, another minor, and a third person were arrested and taken to the county police station.
- The applicant alleges that he was subjected to psychological pressure and physical violence by the police for obtaining his confession, while there was no ill-treatment according to the Government.
- The criminal complaint was sent to the local Control and Inspection Section of the Ministry of the Interior for examination.
- The CIS dismissed the complaint, and the interlocutory appeal and requests for review were eventually dismissed by the OPG.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the complaint as manifestly ill-founded.

title: CASE OF DÉNES v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Budapest
- Applicant was employed as a civil servant at the Prime Minister’s Office from 1 July 2002 to 15 May 2010.
- Under new legislation, applicant's severance pay was subject to a special tax of 98% for any amount exceeding HUF 3,500,000.
- Applicant's severance pay of around HUF 5,511,909 was subjected to special tax, resulting in approximately EUR 18,400 levied on her severance pay.

title: CASE OF MARCHUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant's daughter was admitted to Kovel City Hospital on August 27, 2003, in critical condition, with acute enterocolitis and concomitant illnesses.
- The applicant complained to the prosecutor's office about his daughter's death in the hospital on September 9, 2003.
- The prosecutor's office initially decided not to institute criminal proceedings against the doctors but later ordered further inquiry.
- Criminal proceedings against the doctors were eventually instituted on October 10, 2003.
- The forensic experts found that the resuscitation measures had been delayed, but there was no guarantee that the outcome would have been positive had those measures been taken in a timely fashion. The cause of death was the nature and seriousness of the illnesses.
- The investigators in charge of the criminal case were disciplined on December 3, 2007, for causing delays and failure to take all the necessary measures during the investigations.
- Dr G. was charged with failing to provide medical aid to a patient by a medical practitioner and violation of the right to free medical aid on July 24, 2008.
- The case was referred to court for trial on August 7, 2008.
- The Turiysk District Court returned the case to the prosecutor's office on November 5, 2008, due to non-compliance with procedural requirements.
- The prosecutor's office ordered additional investigative steps on January 8, 2009.
- The Turiysk District Court committed Dr G. for trial on March 30, 2009.
- On October 26, 2009, Dr G. was found guilty of failing to provide the applicant's daughter with medical aid and released from punishment due to the expiry of the time-limit for criminal responsibility
- The Volyn Regional Court of Appeal upheld the judgment of 26 October 2009 as regards Dr G.’s partial acquittal, on February 23, 2010.
- The Turiysk District Court held that Dr G. was guilty of failing to provide medical aid to the applicant's daughter, on June 30, 2010, and sentenced Dr G. to a fine and a three-year ban on medical practice.
- On September 24, 2010, the Volyn Regional Court of Appeal upheld that judgment.
- The applicant initiated civil proceedings seeking compensation for non-pecuniary damage, caused by the hospital's failure to ensure appropriate medical treatment for his daughter, on

title: CASE OF J.K. AND OTHERS v. SWEDEN
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants are a married couple and their son, born in 1964, 1965, and 2000 respectively, who were brought up in Baghdad.
- The first applicant ran a construction and transport business with American clients, with his office at the United States military base "Victoria camp."
- The first applicant was the target of a murder attempt by al-Qaeda in October 2004 and was treated in three different hospitals. He survived but had to remain in the hospital for three months.
- In 2005, the first applicant's brother was kidnapped by al-Qaeda members, who claimed that they would kill him because of the first applicant's collaboration with the Americans. The brother was released through bribery a few days later and immediately fled from Iraq.
- The applicants fled to Jordan and stayed there until December 2006, before returning to Iraq.
- Soon afterwards, al-Qaeda members placed a bomb next to the applicants' house, which was detected by the first applicant's wife. The perpetrator was arrested, and during interrogation, he confessed that he had been paid by al-Qaeda to kill the first applicant and disclosed the names of sixteen people who had been designated to watch the applicants.
- The applicants moved to Syria, although the first applicant continued his business in Iraq. During this time, al-Qaeda destroyed their home and the first applicant's business stocks.
- In October 2008, the first applicant and his daughter were shot at when driving, and the daughter died.
- The first applicant's business stocks were attacked four or five times by al-Qaeda members.
- The applicants had never asked for protection from the domestic authorities, fearing that the authorities lacked the ability to protect them, and might disclose their address, on account of al-Qaeda's collaboration with the authorities.
- The first applicant applied for asylum and a residence permit in Sweden, but his application was rejected since he was registered as having left the country.
- The applicants applied again for asylum and a residence permit in Sweden, submitting several documents, including identity papers, a death certificate for the first and second applicants' daughter, and a medical certificate for the first applicant's injury.
- The Migration Agency rejected the applicants' asylum application, stating that the family had not made a plausible case that the Iraqi authorities lack the capacity and the will to protect the family from being exposed to persecution within the meaning of Chapter 4, section 1, of the Aliens Act or to abuses within the meaning of Chapter 4, section 2, first subsection

title: CASE OF IGOR PASCARI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is a bus driver who was involved in an accident on 14 August 2009.
- The other driver involved in the accident, P.C., was found responsible for the accident by the police and fined.
- P.C. contested the decision but the court upheld the police decision.
- P.C. challenged the court's decision and the court found the applicant guilty of causing the accident because he did not keep a safe distance between his bus and the vehicle in front of him.
- The applicant was not involved in the proceedings and was found guilty by the court.
- The chief inspector of the traffic police issued a new decision finding the applicant guilty based on the court's decision, but no sanction was applied due to the statutory limitation period.
- The owner of the bus recovered the cost of repairs from P.C.'s insurance company, but P.C. was unable to recover the cost of repairs of his car from the applicant's insurance company until the case has been finally determined by the court.

title: CASE OF TURTURICA AND CASIAN v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1962 and 1951 respectively and live in Lunga and Corjova, in the Transdniestrian region of Moldova
- The case concerns the confiscation and/or fining of the applicants for their failure to observe customs rules imposed by the authorities of the self-proclaimed “Moldavian Republic of Transdniestria” (the “MRT”)
- Both applicants used cars registered with the authorities of the Republic of Moldova and had Moldovan registration plates
- On 27 January 2005 the applicant was driving a car from his village to the right bank of the Dniester river when he was stopped by a customs officer of the “MRT”, who seized his car on the grounds that such a car with Moldovan plates had not been registered with the “MRT” customs authorities and no customs duties had been paid for its temporary use on the territory of the “MRT”
- On an unspecified date, the applicant borrowed a car from a friend (the second car), which also had Moldovan number plates and registered it with “MRT” customs authorities by paying customs duties. The registration was due to expire on 30 August 2005. 
- The applicant had his car seized on 28 February 2007 on the grounds that he had failed to leave the territory of Transdniestria before the registration with the “MRT” customs authorities had expired. 
- In a letter dated 7 March 2007, the applicant was informed by the Prosecutor’s Office of the Republic of Moldova that it did not have the necessary means to solve the problem of the seizure of his car by the “MRT” authorities.
- The case is set against the context of the Transdniestrian armed conflict of 1991-1992 and the subsequent events. 
- In 1992, a security zone was created between the conflicting parties and a Joint Control Commission was set up to monitor the implementation of the agreement in the security zone.

title: CASE OF TOPTANIŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was working as a watchman on a construction site located near a military compound.
- The applicant collapsed and was taken to the hospital where it was discovered that a bullet was lodged in his body.
- There were two shooting ranges within the military compound, and a firing practice had been underway at the relevant time.
- The gendarme officers investigating the incident believed the applicant had been hit by a stray bullet that had ricocheted during firing practice.
- The forensic examination conducted on the applicant's jacket had revealed that the shot had been fired from a long distance.
- The public prosecutor's decision was that the applicant had probably been hit by a stray bullet that had ricocheted during the firing practice, which was classified as causing bodily harm through negligence. 
- The investigation was closed because the prosecution of the offence of causing bodily harm through negligence required a formal complaint to be made by the victim, which was lacking in the instant case.
- The applicant's objection was rejected by the İzmir Assize Court.
- The applicant brought an action for compensation, but it was dismissed by the İzmir Administrative Court and the Supreme Administrative Court.
- An internal administrative inquiry was conducted by the military authorities into the applicant's shooting.

title: CASE OF MINDEK v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant accused his neighbor of "stealing" his house and orchard in two articles published in a daily newspaper.
- The applicant was found guilty of two counts of defamation by the Municipal Court and ordered to pay a fine and costs.
- In subsequent civil defamation proceedings, the civil courts found in favor of the plaintiff and awarded him damages.
- The applicant did not pay the debt on time and enforcement proceedings were initiated against his property.
- Two writs of execution were issued ordering the seizure and sale of the applicant's share in the property.
- The court ordered the sale of the applicant's share in the property at two public auctions.
- The property was eventually sold to the plaintiff, who offered the highest bid and met the conditions to be awarded the property.
- The applicant paid off the debt in full after the sale.
- The court issued a decision on the costs of the enforcement proceedings, which were incumbent on the applicant.
- The plaintiff instituted separate civil proceedings against the applicant's wife seeking partition of co-ownership and payment of rent.

title: CASE OF APAP BOLOGNA v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicant is the owner of a two-storey property named "London" in Gzira, Malta.
- The property was requisitioned and allocated to P.S. in 1976 and then to C.C. in 1988, who carried out alteration work without the owner's consent.
- The applicant was meant to receive an annual rent from the Housing Authority but has not been paid since 2003.
- The annual rental value of the property on the market in 1987 was MTL 249 and in 2010 it was MTL 1,223.50 with a sale market value estimated at EUR 95,000.
- The Civil Court found that the applicant had suffered a breach of his property rights due to the low amount of rent compared to the market rental value, but the measure was not abusive.
- The applicant was awarded EUR 21,000 in compensation, which was later reduced to EUR 16,000 due to the delay in instituting proceedings.
- The Constitutional Court refused to annul the requisition order or impose a higher rent for the future, stating that its role was limited to awarding compensation for the violation found.
- The proper defendant was solely the Housing Authority, and not the Attorney General. The applicant had to pay his share of the costs of the proceedings as well as those of the Attorney General and all the parties on appeal.

title: CASE OF MONTANARO GAUCI AND OTHERS v. MALTA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicants inherited a house in Malta in 1997
- C.C. allegedly broke into the house and started living there with his family without legal title
- The applicants' late father instituted judicial proceedings to have C.C. evicted
- The Maltese Government issued a requisition order for the property a few days before the general elections in 1987, which assigned the house to C.C.
- The property was derequisitioned in June 1987, and the applicants' late father instituted judicial proceedings again for C.C.'s eviction
- On 8 June 1988, pending a judgment by the ordinary court concerning the eviction, the Maltese Government again requisitioned the property and assigned it to C.C.
- The Court of Magistrates dismissed the claim lodged by the applicants' predecessor in 1991, stating that since the property had been requisitioned and assigned to C.C., it could no longer take cognisance of the claims put forward by the complainant
- The rent fixed by the authorities for the property was approximately €35 annually until amendments increased it to a maximum of €185 annually
- The applicants refused to receive rent or recognise C.C. as a tenant to avoid prejudicing their case
- The applicants instituted constitutional redress proceedings in 2008, complaining that the requisition breached their property rights under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention and asking for adequate compensation, release of the property or fair conditions and rent, and other orders to ensure their fundamental rights were respected
- The first instance court found in favour of the applicants and awarded €8,000 in compensation, ordered the return of the property free and unencumbered, and considered it had the duty to take such action under domestic law
- The Constitutional Court upheld the first-instance judgment on the preliminary plea and merits, found a violation of the proportionality requirement, increased the compensation to €14,000, but revoked the part of the judgment ordering the release of the property
- C.C.'s daughter, L.B., took possession of the property after his death and was provided with alternative housing by the Department of Social Housing, but returned to the property at an unspecified date according to the applicants' claims, which the Government disputes.

title: CASE OF HUNGUEST ZRT v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant is a Hungarian company.
- The applicant was requested to pay mandate fees of HUF 275 million.
- The Budapest Regional Court ordered the applicant to deposit the security of HUF 275 million.
- The applicant requested the release of the deposited money, which was denied by the authorities.
- The plaintiff succeeded only partly in the litigation, but the applicant had to surrender the whole deposit and pay another HUF 90 million.
- The applicant challenged the provisions of Act no. LIII of 1994, but their complaint was dismissed by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF MIHHAILOV v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant and another man were reported to the police for their behavior.
- Officers S.B. and E.V. responded to the report and found the two men at a public playground.
- The applicant claims he was punched and beaten by Officer S.B. and lost consciousness during the encounter.
- The government disputes the applicant's claims and states that physical force was used to calm down his aggressive behavior.
- The applicant was taken to the police station and continued to be aggressive towards the officers, leading to physical force being used again to make him sit or lay down.
- The applicant complained of ill-treatment and filed a complaint with the police, which was initially refused.
- A criminal investigation was opened in response to the complaint.
- Witnesses and medical records were obtained during the investigation.
- The applicant suffered from physical injuries, including a fracture and a concussion.

title: CASE OF MARC BRAUER v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was arrested for damaging vehicles and resisting a court clerk and was confined to a psychiatric hospital. 
- The Münster Regional Court ordered the applicant’s confinement to a psychiatric hospital and stated that he was mentally ill and could not be held criminally responsible. 
- The presiding judge instructed the applicant on how to appeal the decision. 
- The court-appointed defense counsel advised the applicant on the appellate remedies available to him and terminated the mandate. 
- The applicant misunderstood the instructions for appealing the decision and lodged an appeal letter, which was forwarded late to the Münster Regional Court. 
- The appeal was found belated and dismissed as inadmissible. 
- The Federal Court of Justice found the applicant to be responsible for misunderstanding the oral and written instructions. 
- The applicant filed a constitutional complaint to the Federal Constitutional Court, which declined to consider it without giving reasons.

title: CASE OF MIKHNO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The first applicant is the paternal grandmother of the second applicant, who is also her legal guardian, and both live in Lviv.
- On July 27, 2002, the Ukrainian Air Force organized an aviation show in Lviv commemorating the 60th anniversary of the 14th Air Force Corps.
- The second applicant attended the event with her parents and witnessed their deaths when an SU-27 military aircraft crashed into the static aircraft display site, killing 77 people and injuring over 290 others.
- Various investigations were launched to determine the cause of the accident, and a special commission was set up to investigate the circumstances and coordinate assistance to victims.
- The investigation found that the principal cause of the accident was a technical mistake on the part of the first pilot, who performed a maneuver that was not commissioned, and that the air show was marked by significant shortcomings and procedural breaches.  Disciplinary sanctions were imposed on several officers responsible for the organization of the show, and a criminal investigation of the pilots and ground crew was pending.

title: CASE OF WENNER v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and was detained in Kaisheim Prison at the time of lodging his application, but was released subsequently.
- The applicant has been continuously addicted to heroin since 1973 and has been suffering from hepatitis C since 1975 and has been HIV-positive since 1988. He has been considered 100% disabled and has been receiving an employment disability pension since 2001.
- The applicant has tried to overcome his addiction to heroin with various types of treatment, all of which failed.
- In 2008 the applicant was arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking and taken in detention on remand in Kaisheim Prison, where his drug substitution treatment was interrupted against his will.
- On 3 June 2009, the Augsburg Regional Court convicted the applicant of drug trafficking, sentenced him to three years and six months’ imprisonment and, having regard to a previous conviction, to another two years and six months’ imprisonment.
- In 2010, the Memmingen Regional Court declared the applicant’s detention in the detoxification facility terminated and ordered his retransfer to prison.
- The applicant was still not provided with substitution treatment for his heroin addiction.
- The prison doctors gave him various painkillers for chronic pain resulting from his polyneuropathy, on a daily basis.
- The applicant was examined by an external doctor for internal medicine, H., in October 2010, who suggested that the prison medical service reconsider the possibility of drug substitution treatment.
- An external doctor specialised in drug addiction treatment (B.) considered that from a medical point of view, drug substitution treatment had to be provided to the applicant.
- The prison authorities on 16 January 2012 again dismissed the applicant’s request for drug treatment.
- The Augsburg Regional Court and the Munich Court of Appeal endorsed the reasons given by the prison authorities and dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
- The Federal Constitutional Court declined to consider the applicant’s constitutional complaint.
- The Kaisheim prison authorities rejected the applicant’s fresh request to be provided with substitution treatment in preparation for his release.
- The applicant was released on 3 December 2014 and tested positive for methadone and cocaine when examined by a doctor on 5 December 2014.

title: CASE OF V.M. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant entered the UK illegally with her son in 2003
- Her son was admitted to hospital with serious injuries in November 2003
- The applicant was charged with child cruelty and grievous bodily harm
- She claimed asylum in January 2004 but it was rejected in April 2004
- She was diagnosed with a psychotic illness in May 2004
- Her appeal against the refusal of her asylum claim was dismissed in July 2004
- She pleaded guilty to one count of child cruelty in August 2004 and absconded for over two years
- In March 2005, her son was returned to Nigeria and a residence order was made in favour of his father
- She gave birth to a second child in July 2005
- She was convicted of possession of false documentation with intent to commit fraud in 2007 and sentenced to nine months' imprisonment
- She was convicted of child cruelty in 2008 and sentenced to twelve months' imprisonment
- She appealed against deportation in August 2008 but the Asylum and Immigration Tribunal dismissed her appeal in December 2008
- Her representations to treat them as a fresh asylum claim were refused in December 2009
- She lodged a judicial review claim challenging the lawfulness of her detention and the failure to transfer her to a mental hospital for compulsory treatment in December 2009
- She was assessed multiple times for her mental health and the risk she posed to herself and others
- Monthly detention reviews were conducted throughout her detention.

title: CASE OF CINDRIĆ AND BEŠLIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1973 and 1975 and lived in P, Croatia.
- The first applicant joined the Croatian army and left his home in August 1991.
- The second applicant went to live in Germany in November 1991.
- In November 1991, the Yugoslav People’s Army and Serbian paramilitary forces gained control of A, which became part of the “Serbian Autonomous Region of Krajina”.
- On 6 January 1992, two unknown men took the applicants’ parents, S.C. and P.C., from their home in A.
- On 7 January 1992, the bodies of the applicants’ parents were driven to the front of their house and the applicants’ uncle gave the municipal employees clothes for their burial.
- On 7 January 1992, the A police found an automatic gun, a handgun, and some bullets in a flat occupied by X in A.
- The police officers on duty at a checkpoint in R. Street on 6 January 1992 were interviewed by the A police.
- On 8 January 1992, X and Y, two police officers, admitted that they had taken S.C. and P.C. in X’s vehicle and killed them in the village of J.
- An investigation on suspicion of killing S.C. and P.C. was opened against X and Y by the B County Court in January 1992.
- The case was brought to the C Municipal Court in March 2006 for damages against the state, and on 9 March 2007, the court granted the claim.
- On 3 December 2009, the C County Court reversed the judgment and found that the killing of the applicants’ parents was war-related damage, therefore not the responsibility of the state.

title: CASE OF ERKENOV v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and was detained at the Gaziantep Foreigners’ Removal Centre.
- He fled to Turkey in 2000 due to being searched by the Russian authorities and having lost his leg in a bomb attack in Chechnya.
- He faced criminal proceedings in Russia, which resulted in a detention order being issued against him in absentia.
- He was taken into custody in Istanbul in 2008 in connection with an operation against al-Qaeda and was placed in pre-trial detention at the Gaziantep H-Type Prison.
- He was released from prison in January 2009 but placed back in detention at the Gaziantep Removal Centre later that year.
- The Russian authorities requested his extradition, which was refused by the Gaziantep Assize Court.
- He applied for asylum in 2009, which was rejected in 2010.
- He requested release and a residence permit, both of which were dismissed by the Ministry of the Interior.
- He was released from the Gaziantep Removal Centre in July 2010 on the condition that he leave Turkey within fifteen days.
- He met with his lawyer nine times during his detention at the Gaziantep Removal Centre.

title: CASE OF ALIMOV v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant and his family left Uzbekistan in 2010 to escape religious oppression and entered Turkey legally.

- The applicant's wife was granted a residence permit, but the applicant resided illegally in Gaziantep.

- The applicant was fined and banned from entering Turkey for five years when he left to seek medical treatment for his wife in Ukraine.

- The applicant was detained for 68 days at Sabiha Gökçen Airport in Istanbul, and was not allowed to leave the room or make contact with the outside world.

- The applicant was then transferred to the Kumkapı Foreigners’ Removal Centre in Istanbul, where he shared a room with 30-45 other people and had no access to outdoor exercise.

- The government provided contradictory information about the occupancy rates and conditions of the detention facilities.

title: CASE OF QERIMI AND CANAJ v. ALBANIA
facts:
A. Application no. 12878/10: Qerimi 
- Commission recognised applicant's inherited property rights over 8,000 sq.m plot
- Plot was occupied 
- Applicant and other heirs compensated with an equivalent plot of land

B. Application no. 74858/12: Canaj 
- Commission recognised applicant's inherited property rights over 1,121 sq.m plot
- 598 sq.m of the plot were restored
- Remaining plot measuring 523 sq.m was occupied 
- Applicant and other heirs awarded compensation in the sum of 251,040 Albanian Lek.

title: CASE OF IBRAHIM AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
B. The first three applicants:
- Arrests and interviews conducted with the first three applicants
- Trial of the first three applicants
- Appeal of the first three applicants

C. The case of the fourth applicant:
- Questioning by the police of the fourth applicant
- Trial of the fourth applicant
- Appeal of the fourth applicant

title: CASE OF ANDREY MEDVEDEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant lived in a flat under a social housing agreement with the City of Moscow.
- After the applicant's death, her ex-boyfriend registered as tenant and obtained the title to the flat under the privatisation scheme.
- The ex-boyfriend was found guilty of fraud, and the flat was transferred to the Department for Housing of the City of Moscow.
- The applicant bought the flat from a subsequent owner in good faith.
- The Housing Department brought a civil claim seeking the revocation of the applicant's title to the flat and his eviction.
- The court granted the Housing Department's claims based on Article 302 of the Russian Civil Code, despite acknowledging the applicant was a bona fide purchaser.
- The applicant was eventually evicted and awarded damages against the subsequent owner who sold him the flat.
- Enforcement proceedings for the damages judgment are still pending.

title: CASE OF KIRILLOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Moscow.
- F. bought a 19.3 square metre flat at 22-2-68 Nagatinskaya Naberezhnaya, Moscow on 1 February 1994.
- F. died without heirs and the flat was locked and sealed by the housing maintenance company on 23 July 1997.
- N. brought a civil action to be recognized as F.'s heir-at-law and won the claim on 8 February 2010.
- On 14 May 2010 N. sold the flat to K., who then sold it to the applicant on 6 July 2010.
- On 24 June 2010, the Moscow City Court dismissed N.'s claims, which were granted on 8 February 2010 by the Simonovskiy District Court of Moscow.
- The Housing Department brought a civil action against N., claiming that she had been erroneously recognized as F.'s heir-at-law and that the City of Moscow should inherit his property instead.
- On 8 November 2012, the District Court granted the Housing Department’s claims and ordered the requisition of the flat from the applicant.
- The court considered that the applicant had not demonstrated due diligence when buying the flat from K. and could not be recognized as a bona fide purchaser.
- On 4 February 2013, the Moscow City Court upheld the judgment of 8 November 2012. 
- On 15 April 2015, the District Court granted the Housing Department’s claims against the applicant and ordered her eviction.
- The applicant has not been evicted and continues to reside in the flat.
- On 9 December 2013, the Perovskiy District Court of Moscow granted a claim by the applicant for damages against K. and awarded her 4,060,006 Russian rubles (RUB).
- On 20 March 2014, the judgment of 9 December 2013 was upheld by the Moscow City Court on appeal.
- The bailiff failed to establish K.’s whereabouts or locate any of his assets, and the judgment in the applicant’s favor remains unenforced.

title: CASE OF SIDIKA İMREN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant's daughter worked for a private company engaged in the trade of mineral oil.
- A fire broke out at her workplace which caused the daughter's death.
- The necessary precautions had not been taken at the relevant workplace to prevent and put out fires.
- The owner of the company was indicted for causing Serpil İmren’s death by negligence.
- The Ankara Assize Court convicted the defendants and sentenced each of them to ten months’ imprisonment and a fine.
- The defendants appealed against this judgment.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the Ankara Assize Court’s judgment of 17 November 2006.
- The criminal proceedings were discontinued as the prosecution of the offence had become time-barred.
- The applicant initiated proceedings before the Ankara 13th Labour Court requesting compensation in respect of pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage following her daughter’s death.
- The case was dismissed and the applicant brought compensation proceedings before the labour court against the company in relation to her daughter’s death.
- The labour court held twenty-three hearings and decided to adjourn the case at the end of each hearing pending a judgment in the criminal proceedings.
- The labour court rejected the applicant’s claims in respect of pecuniary damage, except for funeral costs and granted her request in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the labour court.
- The damages ordered by the court against the company could not be collected.

title: CASE OF SEMİR GÜZEL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and was the vice-president of HAK-PAR at the time of the events.
- The party held its first congress in January 2004, where the applicant was elected as the chairman.
- An indictment was filed against 13 members of HAK-PAR, including the applicant, for violating section 81 (c) of Law no. 2820 during the congress.
- The violation was related to the use of banners and speeches in Kurdish language during the congress.
- The applicant acknowledged not intervening when some delegates spoke in Kurdish, stating that it was their mother tongue and he believed in the right to use Kurdish in all areas of life.
- The first-instance court dismissed the application to suspend the proceedings and transfer the case to the Constitutional Court.
- The applicant was convicted and sentenced to one year in prison in February 2007.
- The judgment of the first-instance court was quashed by the Court of Cassation in March 2011.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant and other defendants were terminated in December 2011 due to the expiration of the statutory time-limit prescribed by domestic law.

title: CASE OF KRGOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant is a basketball player from Montenegro.
- Applicant filed a claim against his basketball club, Vojvodina BFC, in Novi Sad, Serbia.
- Novi Sad Municipal Court ruled in favor of the applicant and ordered the club to pay him 110,550 dinars and RSD 8,500 in costs, together with statutory interest.
- A new basketball club, NIS-Vojvodina, was formed in the meantime.
- The court issued an enforcement order, and the applicant proposed that the judgment be enforced by the sale of the debtor's immovable assets situated on the premises of the Vojvodina Sports and Business Centre.
- The debtor's bank account was frozen, and later, the applicant discovered that the assets he intended to enforce did not belong to the debtor but to the basketball club NIS-Vojvodina.
- The Municipal Court ordered enforcement in accordance with the applicant's request, but NIS-Vojvodina appealed against it.
- The Municipal Court suspended enforcement against NIS-Vojvodina.
- After several proceedings, the enforcement judge found that NIS-Vojvodina was not the debtor's legal successor and transferred the case file to the panel.
- The panel upheld the decision, and later, the debtor entered insolvency proceedings.
- As per the restructuring plan, the debtor was supposed to pay the applicant RSD 1,229,332.42 over five years, but it is unclear whether the applicant received any further payments after the initial payment.

title: CASE OF PAPAVASILAKIS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1988 and lives in Ikaria.
- On 30 July 2007, he applied for and was granted permission to defer his enlistment for military service.
- On 24 September 2012, he interrupted the deferral and was required to report to the recruitment center on 23 January 2013.
- On 22 January 2013, he applied for leave to perform alternative service on the grounds that he was a conscientious objector.
- On 27 May 2013, he appeared before the armed forces’ special committee to explain the nature of his conscientious objection.
- The special committee decided unanimously to propose that the applicant’s application be rejected on 27 May 2013.
- On 30 July 2013, the Minister of National Defense rejected the application on the grounds proposed by the special committee.
- On 5 September 2013, the applicant applied to the Supreme Administrative Court for judicial review of the decision by the Minister of National Defense.
- The applicant challenged the composition of the special committee that had adjudicated on his case.
- The applicant argued that the Minister’s decision had not contained sufficient reasons.
- The applicant complained of an infringement of his right to conscientious objection.
- In judgment no. 1289/2014 of 7 April 2014, the Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s application.
- On 19 May 2014, the applicant was ordered to pay a fine of 6,000 euros (EUR) for insubordination.
- On 11 July 2014, the applicant applied to the Mytilene Administrative Court to have the fine set aside. The case is still pending, but the authorities have seized a sum from his bank account.

title: CASE OF KHAMROEV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicants in Uzbekistan on suspicion of sedition and being members of a prohibited organization 
- They were placed on an international list of wanted persons 
- They left Uzbekistan and arrived in Ukraine 
- The first applicant’s asylum application was dismissed but later appealed 
- The police arrested the first applicant as a person appearing on the international list of wanted persons 
- The police applied to the court for the applicant’s arrest 
- Orders for the applicant’s arrest were issued 
- The applicant’s detention was extended several times 
- The courts ordered the applicant’s arrest pending extradition 
- The UNHCR recognized the second applicant as a refugee 
- The second applicant was also arrested as a person appearing on the international list of wanted persons 
- The police requested that the applicant be placed under provisional arrest 
- The applicant was ordered to be detained pending extradition 
- The GPO received formal requests for the first and third applicant’s extradition 
- The GPO requested more information from the Uzbek authorities and the US Embassy 
- The reports recommended that the applicants’ extradition be refused 
- The UNHCR recognized the applicants as refugees 
- The GPO decided not to extradite the third and first applicants to Uzbekistan in view of the fact that they had been granted asylum in the US and Sweden respectively.

title: CASE OF MUSHYNSKYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
• Applicant was born in 1979 and is serving a prison sentence in Ukraine currently
• On 29 October 2004, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder, robbery, and attempted murder
• Applicant alleged that he had been tortured by unspecified police officers between 29 and 31 October 2004, and had confessed to the crimes he was suspected of
• On 1 November 2004, the applicant was taken to court and remanded in custody
• Applicant was transferred to a high-level security cell in the same SIZO for detainees sentenced to life imprisonment by a final judicial decision
• Applicant complained to the courts about the unlawful execution of his sentence, but his plea was refused
• Applicant was placed in Sokalska Correctional Colony no. 47 on 14th December 2005, where the conditions of his detention were debasing
• The applicant raised allegations before the prosecutors about poor conditions, poor quality food and water, inadequate medical assistance, and psychological pressure by colony staff
• According to the medical information submitted by the applicant, he had been medically examined and had been given the necessary treatment while in detention
• The applicant alleged that he was prohibited from corresponding by ordinary mail with his relatives and counsel and from making telephone calls during the trials and investigations
• Between 24 March and 4 August 2005, the applicant had four one-hour visits from his mother and father
• On 24 March 2005, the court found the applicant guilty of aggravated murder with the aim of stealing the victims' property and attempted murder of another person, and was held exceptionally dangerous to society, sentenced to life imprisonment, and the confiscation of all his property
• Applicant's continuing detention was ordered in the Kyiv SIZO
• The Supreme Court upheld the judgment of 24 March 2005 on 4 August 2005, and it entered into force on that date
• Applicant requested a copy of documents from his case file to be submitted to the European Court of Human Rights, but the request was refused

title: CASE OF BURMAGA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was charged with trafficking in firearms and ammunition and arrested in March 2001.
- A second arrest warrant was issued in June 2002, but no time limit was set for his detention.
- The applicant was arrested in Monaco in 2003 and extradited to Russia in 2005.
- Criminal proceedings against the applicant were resumed in May 2005, and his detention was extended until August 2005.
- The applicant complained about his unlawful detention while being held in different remand prisons.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the detention order in August 2005, and the Regional Court found him guilty of attempted murder and leadership of a criminal enterprise in May 2007.
- The applicant's complaint about unjustified delays in criminal proceedings and violation of his right to respect for his family life was declared inadmissible by the court.

title: CASE OF CHERNOYVAN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were prosecuted for various crimes and detained pending trial.
- Detention orders were based on the gravity of charges, with risk of absconding and interfering with justice as primary grounds.
- Stereotyped formulae were used in detention and extension orders, without addressing specific facts or considering alternative preventive measures.
- The first applicant was convicted of sexual assault and sentenced to six years and nine months' imprisonment.
- The second applicant was convicted of bribery and sentenced to one year and six months' imprisonment.
- The third applicant was convicted of drug dealing and abuse of power and sentenced to eight years and six months' imprisonment.
- The fourth applicant was convicted of aggravated murder and sentenced to fifteen years' imprisonment.
- The applicants' complaints about lengthy pre-trial detention were communicated to the government.
- The government did not reply.
- The applicants were invited to submit their claims for just satisfaction but did not reply.

title: CASE OF KARELIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1970 and lives in Naberezhnyye Chelny.
- On 4 March 2012, the applicant was arrested and accused of disorderly behavior in a public place under Article 20.1 of the Federal Code of Administrative Offences.
- Officer Z. compiled an administrative offence record, instituting administrative offence proceedings against the applicant.
- The applicant was accused of using foul language in the presence of other people while being drunk, thus breaching public order.
- The justice of the peace found the applicant guilty and imposed a fine of 500 Russian roubles on him.
- The applicant appealed, but the Town Court upheld the judgment of the justice of the peace, and the appeal court dismissed the argument.
- The Deputy President of the Supreme Court of the Tatarstan Republic upheld the court decisions of 29 March and 16 April 2012. 
- The applicant did not seek further review before the Supreme Court of Russia.

title: CASE OF KONDRULIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lived in Magnitogorsk, in the Chelyabinsk Region until his arrest. 
- The applicant was arrested and remained in custody throughout the investigation and trial. 
- The applicant was sentenced to thirteen years and ten months’ imprisonment. 
- In 2012, the applicant was diagnosed with an enlarged prostate gland and underwent surgery in relation to that condition. 
- In April 2013 the applicant was transferred to the prison tuberculosis hospital in Chelyabinsk for testing of his urogenital system. 
- In February 2014 a biopsy of prostate tissue revealed the presence of cancer cells. The applicant was diagnosed with terminal prostate cancer which had spread to his liver and inguinal lymph nodes. 
- The applicant did not have access to the required medication in the hospital, and therefore his condition worsened. 
- On 30 October 2014 a medical panel confirmed his diagnosis, adding a list of secondary illnesses to it. 
- The applicant’s request for early release on health grounds was rejected by the court. 
- On 7 April 2015 the Chelyabinsk Regional Court upheld the above decision on appeal. 
- On 27 March 2015 the Court decided to apply Rule 39, indicating to the Government that it was desirable in the interests of the proper conduct of the proceedings that the applicant should be immediately examined by medical experts who were independent of the prison system. 
- In an expert report dated 23 May 2015, two independent doctors assessed the quality of the applicant’s medical treatment in detention and concluded that the treatment the applicant was receiving in the prison hospital was inadequate. 
- The medical panel prepared a new report, again recommending the applicant’s early release on health grounds. 
- The applicant died of cancer before the court hearing on the matter. 
- At the request of the applicant’s lawyer, the Investigative Committee carried out a preliminary inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the applicant’s death, which ended with a decision of 15 October 2015 not to open a criminal case. 
- Relevant provisions of Russian and international law on the medical care of detainees are set out in the following judgments: Ivko v. Russia, no. 30575/08, §§ 55-63, 15 December 2015; Amirov v. Russia, no. 51857/13, §§ 50-57, 27 November 2014; Pakhomov v. Russia, no

title: CASE OF MAKHMUD v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr Mokhammed Makhmud is a Somali national who arrived in Russia and obtained refugee status before applying for asylum in the United States of America.
- The applicant was involved in the transportation of four illegal migrants from Russia to Finland, according to Russian authorities.
- The applicant was arrested and formally charged on May 28, 2012, with the Primorsk District Court of St Petersburg remanding him in custody on May 31, 2012.
- The St Petersburg City Court quashed the detention order of May 31, 2012, on appeal and referred the matter back to the first-instance court on July 12, 2012.
- The applicant was ordered to remain in detention on July 19, 2012, until July 28, 2012, by the District Court, even though he had refugee status and a wife and child.
- The St Petersburg City Court upheld the detention orders on September 3, 2012, and September 13, 2012, respectively.
- The applicant's detention was extended on October 14, 2012, and December 4, 2013.
- On April 9, 2014, the District Court sentenced the applicant to two years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF NICHIFOR v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lived in Chișinău.
- The applicant was a shareholder in a limited liability company created in 2002.
- At the time of the events, the applicant owned 50% of the company’s shares, while the other half was owned by A.N.
- A.N. filed an action with the Chişinău Economic Court seeking the applicant’s exclusion from the list of shareholders for not paying for his part of the shares.
- The applicant claimed that the action was time-barred and presented bank documents showing A.N. had not paid his part of the shares.
- The Economic Court of Appeal, however, relied on a forged document, that is, minutes of a shareholders’ meeting dated 20 February 2007, and found in favour of A.N.

title: CASE OF BOCHAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant reported to the police that he had stabbed his girlfriend to death and was charged with her murder.
- The applicant was placed in custody in remand prison no. 3 of Nizhniy Tagil.
- An outpatient psychiatric expert examination established that he had committed manslaughter while in the state of temporary incapacity.
- The district court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention until 2 September 2006 and then again until 2 December 2006.
- The applicant was found guilty of murder and sentenced to eleven years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed but the appeal was dismissed. 
- The delay in examining the appeal was not explained.
- The applicant was released on parole on 2 April 2013.

title: CASE OF VERSHININ v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's house partially burnt in 1997 and he had to live in an attic
- The applicant accused judges of taking bribes and falsifying evidence after a civil case was dismissed
- The applicant was arrested for defamation and false denunciation
- The applicant was remanded in custody and ordered to undergo a psychiatric evaluation
- The experts diagnosed the applicant with paranoid personality disorder and recommended involuntary treatment in a psychiatric facility
- The City Court discontinued criminal proceedings against the applicant due to his insanity and ordered involuntary treatment
- The Supreme Court upheld the decision, and the applicant was transferred to a psychiatric facility in April 2007
- The applicant was released from the hospital in June 2008.

title: CASE OF SERGEY ZAYTSEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and lives in Volgograd.
- The applicant was arrested on 26 October 2002, charged with murder, and authorized for pre-trial detention on 28 October 2002.
- The trial of the applicant, along with seven other defendants, was scheduled for 24 December 2003, and it was ruled that the trial would be held in camera.
- On 26 April 2005, the applicant was convicted of murder committed out of national hatred and sentenced to nine years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant's conviction was upheld by the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation on 22 February 2006, in the absence of the applicant and with his lawyer making submissions to the court.
- The applicant was released on parole on 30 August 2010 but was later remitted for fresh consideration by the Presidium of the Supreme Court on 8 December 2010.
- On 1 February 2011, a new appeal hearing was held, and the court found that the case had become time-barred under the statute of limitations, discharging the applicant from serving a prison sentence.

title: CASE OF RUDENKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details in the appended table.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF USHAKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants provided
- Details of the applications provided in the table
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of pre-trial detention
- Some applicants also raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention

title: CASE OF GRABOVOY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document has an appended table with a list of applicants and their relevant application details. 
- The applicants have complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.

title: CASE OF SAVCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence in Sokyryany Prison no. 67.
- In September 2001, the applicant and an acquaintance decided to carry out a carjacking, resulting in the murder of a taxi driver.
- The applicant threw a grenade at the police and seriously wounded one officer while attempting to flee.
- The applicant alleged that he was ill-treated after his arrest, including being beaten and kicked by police officers seeking to make him confess to the crimes.
- The applicant was examined by a forensic medical expert and found to have injuries on his head, face, and wrists.
- The applicant alleged that he was subjected to various forms of torture, including electric shocks and suffocation, during his detention in the ITT.
- The applicant was held in pre-trial detention after his arrest.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant involved twelve suspects and concerned twelve episodes of criminal activity committed between 1998 and 2001.
- The applicant was found guilty of various criminal offences and sentenced to life imprisonment after multiple trials and appeals.

title: CASE OF M.B. - MAK ČAČAK DOO v. SERBIA
facts:
- In 2005, the Čačak Commercial Court ordered a socially-owned company to pay the first applicant for damages and costs.
- In 2006, the Belgrade High Commercial Court increased the awarded amount for lost profits and costs of proceedings.
- In 2007, the enforcement of the judgments and payment of enforcement costs were ordered by the Čačak Commercial Court.
- In 2009, part of the specified sums were paid by the debtor to the first applicant.
- In 2010, the first applicant's debtor was restructured by the Privatisation Agency, leading to the stay of ongoing enforcement proceedings.
- In 2011, the first applicant lodged a constitutional case, while on 2014 the Constitutional Court found a violation of the first applicant's right to a hearing within a reasonable time and peaceful enjoyment of possessions awarding EUR 1,000 for non-pecuniary damages.
- In 2003, the Kraljevo Commercial Court established the secured property right of the second applicant on commercial premises, which the debtor never finished the construction of, leading to the payment of a certain amount by them in 2009.
- In 2011, the second applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, which resulted in the Constitutional Court awarding EUR 500 for non-pecuniary damages in 2014.
- In 2003, the Belgrade Commercial Court ordered the debtor to pay the third applicant a specified amount on account of damages and costs, which became final in 2003.
- In 2006, the enforcement of this judgment was accepted by the Belgrade Municipal Court and further ordered the debtor to pay enforcement costs to the first applicant.
- In 2011, the third applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, while in 2014, the Constitutional Court awarded them EUR 800 for non-pecuniary damages and ordered the competent court to expedite the proceedings.

title: CASE OF VUKOSAVLJEVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Velika Reka.
- Applicant was employed by a socially-owned company based in Belgrade called Holding Kompanija “Komgrap” – DD “Komgrap gradnja”.
- On 3 February 2006, the First Belgrade Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings.
- On 23 October 2006, the Fourth Belgrade Municipal Court accepted the enforcement of the said judgment and further ordered the debtor to pay the applicant the enforcement costs, upon the applicant’s request to that effect.
- On 24 December 2010 the Belgrade Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor.
- On 22 June 2011 the applicant submitted his respective claims.
- On 31 October 2010 the Belgrade Commercial Court dismissed these claims as out of time and the Commercial Appeals Court upheld that decision on 26 June 2012.
- Insolvency proceedings against the debtor are still ongoing.
- On 23 April 2010 the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed his appeal on 14 July 2011.
- On 13 March 2012 the applicant lodged a new constitutional appeal.
- On 26 January 2012 the Constitutional Court dismissed again his appeal.
- On 28 December 2012 that decision was delivered to the applicant.

title: CASE OF GONTMAKHER v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant is the president of Global Fishing Inc.
- Investigating Committee opened a criminal investigation into crab poaching.
- Global Fishing Inc. was identified as a major purchaser of illegally harvested crab.
- Applicant was arrested and his passport was confiscated in Moscow.
- Applicant was charged with engagement in organised criminal activities, money laundering, and unlicensed fishing activities.
- Applicant's detention was extended multiple times due to gravity of charges, lack of permanent residence in Russia, and potential for absconding or interference with proceedings.
- Applicant completed study of case-file on 26 August 2009.
- Applicant's co-defendants and their lawyers needed further time to study the case-file, leading to extensions of pre-trial detention.
- Applicant was released on 16 December 2010 after a not-guilty verdict was delivered and awarded damages for lost earnings and legal costs in 2013. 
- Media outlets referred to the applicant as the head of an international criminal organisation engaged in illegal fishing activities.

title: CASE OF MIROSHNIKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants participated in the clean-up operation at the Chernobyl nuclear disaster site
- They were registered as disabled and entitled to social benefits
- From 2003 to 2006, they brought proceedings against welfare authorities
- They sought inflation adjustment of their benefits
- Judgments in their favour either remained unenforced or were quashed in supervisory review proceedings

title: CASE OF YAROSLAV BELOUSOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1991 and lived in Moscow.
- He was arrested on 6 May 2012 during the dispersal of a political rally at Bolotnaya Square in Moscow.
- He was found guilty of failure to obey lawful police orders under Article 19.3 of the Code of Administrative Offences and subsequently charged with participation in mass disorder and violent acts against police officers, criminal offences provided for by Articles 212 § 2 and 318 § 1 of the Criminal Code.
- He was detained and tried on these charges and was convicted to a prison term of two years and three months.
- On 23 April 2012, five individuals submitted notice of a public demonstration to the mayor of Moscow to protest against abuses and falsifications in the course of the elections to the State Duma and of the President of the Russian Federation, and to demand fair elections, respect for human rights, the rule of law and the international obligations of the Russian Federation.
- On 4 May 2012, the First Deputy Head of the Moscow Department of Regional Security held a working meeting with the organisers of the demonstration at Bolotnaya Square, at which they discussed the security issues.
- On 5 May 2012, the Tsentralnyy District Prosecutor’s Office of Moscow issued a warning to two of the organisers against exceeding the notified number of participants and against erecting camping tents at the meeting venue.
- On 6 May 2012, the march began peacefully at Kaluzhskaya Square, but the leaders of the protest found that the meeting venue's layout and placement of the police cordon did not correspond to their expectations.
- At 5:16 p.m., the four leaders announced that they were going on a “sit-down strike” and sat on the ground. The people behind them stopped, although some people went past them towards the stage.
- At 5:50 p.m., the crowd around the sit-down protest built up, and the leaders abandoned the protest and headed towards the stage, followed by the crowd.
- At 6:15 p.m., the riot police began breaking into the demonstration to split up the crowd, pushing and arresting some people.
- On 21 February 2014, the Zamoskvoretskiy District Court of Moscow pronounced a judgment in the first Bolotnaya case, in which the applicant was found guilty of participation in mass disorder and of violent acts against police officers during the public assembly.
- On

title: CASE OF T.P. AND A.T. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Mr. T.P. was born in 1981 and is serving a life sentence with no possibility of parole for murder committed with special cruelty and abuse of firearms.
- The Budapest Court of Appeal upheld the judgment with the addition that the murder was committed for "villainous" reasons.
- The Supreme Court dismissed Mr. T.P.'s petition for review.
- The President of the Republic dismissed Mr. T.P.'s request for pardon.
- Mr. A.T. was born in 1985 and is serving a life sentence with no possibility of parole for double murder and abuse of firearms.
- The Debrecen Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court confirmed Mr. A.T.'s conviction and sentencing.
- The President of the Republic dismissed Mr. A.T.'s request for pardon.

title: CASE OF RUBIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals.
- The applicants sued different municipal companies in various unrelated sets of court proceedings.
- The companies provided services in various municipal districts in several regions of Russia.
- The companies had "the right of economic control" over the assets allocated to them.
- Assets allocated to the companies were later transferred back to the administration.
- Insolvency proceedings were opened in respect of the debtor companies and they were subsequently liquidated.
- Domestic courts made pecuniary awards in the applicants' favor, to be paid by the debtor companies.
- The final judicial decisions in the applicants' favor remain unenforced due to the companies' insolvency and subsequent liquidation.
- Several subsequent court actions against authorities and repetitive complaints to the bailiffs' service or the prosecutor's office proved futile.
- One of the applicants died and his widow expressed her willingness to participate in the proceedings before the Court in her late husband’s stead.

title: CASE OF KLIBISZ v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant, Mr Andrzej Klibisz, is a Polish national who was detained in Włocławek Prison.
- He was charged in Lithuania for alleged offences and the Polish authorities took over the case.
- He was suspected of murder, attempted murder and illegal possession of weapons in Vilnius in 1994.
- He was arrested on 8 March 1996 and not served with the prosecutor’s decision ordering his detention.
- His detention was extended numerous times and not all hearings were attended by him or his lawyer.
- He was indicted on 4 March 1997 but his detention was not formally extended after 8 March 1997.
- The compensation for his detention was dismissed on 12 October 2005 and upheld on 1 March 2006.
- The applicant lodged complaints for compensation for the alleged delays in Supreme Court’s examination.

title: CASE OF MAYLENSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder in May 2012 and remained in detention throughout the investigation and trial.
- The applicant was seriously ill at the time of arrest and suffered from advanced HIV, long-term tuberculosis, and chronic hepatitis C.
- The applicant was admitted to a tuberculosis unit of the medical wing of remand prison no. IZ-66/1 in Yekaterinburg for treatment.
- The medical panel ordered highly active antiretroviral therapy for the applicant’s HIV.
- The applicant developed drug-resistant tuberculosis, which required alteration in his treatment.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Nizhniy Tagil denied the applicant’s application for early release on health grounds citing his previous convictions.
- The applicant requested the Court to indicate to the Government that he should be provided with adequate medical care and immediately released.
- The President of the section decided to apply Rules 39 and 41, indicating that the applicant should be examined by independent medical experts.
- The Government submitted that the treatment provided to the applicant was appropriate, but acknowledged the serious deterioration in his condition in 2014.
- The independent medical examination was not carried out by the Government, but two independent doctors assessed the quality of the applicant’s medical treatment in detention and the appropriateness of his further detention in the prison hospital.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Nizhniy Tagil dismissed the applicant’s second application for release on health grounds.
- The Sverdlovsk Regional Court set aside the decision and granted the applicant’s immediate release.
- The applicant was admitted to a civilian hospital in Verkhnyaya Pyshma after his release, where he died on 3 October 2015.

title: CASE OF KLIMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
