- The applicant was convicted of murder, possessing firearms, and aggravated robbery in 2010 and sentenced to fifteen years of imprisonment.
- The applicant was diagnosed with cancer of the left kidney in April 2012 and underwent ablation in the prison hospital.
- A pulmonary fluorography on 18 December 2012 revealed that the applicant had metastases in the lungs.
- Medical panels diagnosed him with stage 3 cancer of the left kidney and later with stage 4 cancer, making him eligible for early release as provided by legislation.
- However, a court quashed the decision for the applicant's release, citing the non-inclusion of his diagnosis in the list of illnesses precluding the serving of sentences in correctional institutions.
- The applicant filed complaints and requests for transfer to specialist hospitals, but the court continued denying them.
- The Court asked the Russian government to ensure the applicant's immediate transfer to a specialist hospital or his release after determining the compatibility of his health with detention in a correctional colony or prison hospital, among others.
- The applicant died on 8 April 2015, and his sister pursued the case before the Court.

title: CASE OF MIROŠEVIĆ-ANZULOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- Applicant owns a flat in Zagreb occupied by a protected lessee.
- The lessee is protected under the Lease of Flats Act, which includes protective measures.
- Applicant refused to recognize the lessee as a holder of a specially protected tenancy and to conclude a lease contract with her.
- Lessee brought a civil action against the applicant seeking recognition of her legal status of a protected lessee and obtaining a judgment in lieu of the lease contract.
- The court found in favour of the lessee and recognized her legal status of a protected lessee and stipulated protected rent in the amount of HRK 190.25 per month.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint alleging violations of her right to equality before the law and her ownership rights.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint.
- The applicant submitted documents showing the protected rent for her flat was set at HRK 178.73 while the government submitted documents showing it was set at HRK 217.57.
- The applicant was not obliged to pay the condominium fee into the common reserve fund for the flat.
- The applicant never paid any income tax on the income generated by renting her flat subject to the protected lease scheme.
- The applicant furnished information about the monthly market rent for flats in the vicinity of hers.

title: CASE OF NUNES LUCAS SARAIVA AND TRIGO SARAIVA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1950 and 1949 respectively and live in Matosinhos
- A.C. and M.L. filed a civil case against the applicants and four others for the payment of 11,843.48 euros 
- Applicants did not challenge the action against them after being summoned 
- Several procedural steps took place including contesting of action by the remaining defendants and a request seeking intervention 
- Matosinho Court stayed proceedings following I.T.'s death 
- Applicants submitted power of attorney and requested case-file on legal platform 
- Applicants requested participation of an expert in the preparation of the expert report sought by the plaintiffs 
- On October 16, 2015, Matosinhos Court ruled in favor of the applicants.

title: CASE OF YUSIV v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Ukrainian national who lives in Kaunas, Lithuania.
- On 22 October 2011, the police received a call about a man being robbed by several young men in the neighbourhood close to the railway station.
- The applicant was walking to see his girlfriend when he was stopped by police officers A.R., Ž.S., and R.A.
- The applicant started running away from the police officers and was subsequently apprehended near a bus stop close to the railway station by several police cars.
- The applicant was handcuffed, put into a police car, and taken to the Panemunė police station where a record of an administrative violation was drawn up, charging him with disobeying lawful orders of the police.
- The applicant's mother complained that her son had been beaten by police officers while being apprehended and filed a complaint with the Kaunas District Police Department and the Kaunas City Prosecutor.
- A court medical expert found several contusions on the applicant's body caused by a hard blunt object of cylindrical shape, from eighteen or more blows, and tear injury on the applicant's left thumb caused by a hard blunt object, and bruised skin on his left wrist which could have resulted from handcuffing.
- The police officers all submitted identically worded reports about the arrest to their superior.
- The applicant admitted to running away from the officers but denied resisting being apprehended near the railway station.
- The Kaunas District Court found the applicant guilty and fined him.
- The Head of the Panemunė Police Department instructed the officers to conduct a preliminary inquiry into the applicant's allegations that he had been ill-treated by police officers while being apprehended.
- An investigation found that injuries were visible on the applicant's forehead, arms and legs, upper chest, and the left side of his back.
- A.R. and R.A. were both questioned as witnesses but provided almost identical statements, denying the allegations of ill-treatment.
- The officer Ž.S. was also questioned as a witness, and the written record of his interview was almost identical to that of A.R.

title: CASE OF CEVRİOĞLU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant's son and his friend drowned in a water-filled hole on a construction site while playing.
- Criminal proceedings were instigated against the owner of the construction site and three officials from the Municipality for causing death by negligence and failing to comply with regulations.
- Three expert reports were obtained during the course of the criminal proceedings to determine liability for the death of the applicant’s son.
- The first expert report indicated shared responsibility between the owner, the Municipality, and the deceased children.
- The second expert report indicated principal liability of the owner and no liability for the deceased children or the Municipality.
- The third expert report indicated shared responsibility between the owner and the Municipality and no liability for the deceased children.
- The Hatay Criminal Court of First Instance held the owner 75% responsible for the incident and the Municipality director 25% responsible. 
- Compensation proceedings were initiated against the owner, his construction company, and the Municipality.
- An expert report found the owner to be 85% responsible for the incident, the deceased children to be partially responsible, and the Municipality to have no responsibility.
- The court ruled that the owner and his construction company were to pay compensation to the applicant and his family for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF PISKUNOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and is currently detained in Krasnoyarsk.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of incitement to murder on 10 December 2010 and authorized to pre-trial detention on the same day.
- The applicant's detention was repeatedly extended during the investigation and trial due to the severity of the charges against him and the risks of absconding, influencing witnesses, and reoffending.
- The District Court found the applicant guilty on 5 May 2012 and sentenced him to five years in a correctional colony, which was later reduced by two months by the Krasnoyarsk Regional Court on 4 September 2012.
- The applicant was diagnosed with hypertension during the admission process at remand prison no. IZ-24/1 in Krasnoyarsk and was prescribed medication for it.
- The applicant was admitted to Prison Tuberculosis Hospital no. 1 in Krasnoyarsk in April 2011 for inpatient treatment for hypertension and diagnosed with a mild case of pneumonia and another chronic condition.
- The applicant had a hypertensive crisis in June 2011, and in August 2012, a medical examination showed a positive development in his hypertension and recovery from pneumonia.
- In April 2013, the applicant complained of pain in the chest, pelvic area, and testicles, hindering his ability to walk. The detention authorities ignored his complaints, and no proper medical examination or treatment was arranged despite his requests for inpatient treatment.
- On 2 September 2013, the applicant requested medical examination and treatment outside the facility due to a severe spine and leg condition. He was sent to a civilian clinic in Krasnoyarsk for an MRI, which revealed a prostate tumour and affection of the bone.
- On 14 February 2014, the applicant was diagnosed with prostate cancer with metastasis to the pelvic bone and certified as having a second-degree disability six days later.
- The applicant remained in detention despite the medical panel's conclusion on 19 September 2014 that his state of health warranted early release on medical grounds.
- On 9 April 2015, the applicant was certified as having a first-degree disability, and in May 2015, he was admitted to the prison hospital for medical examination and treatment.
- The applicant complained of poor detention conditions, including overcrowding, while the government disagreed.

title: CASE OF REZNIK AND GUZEYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1967 and 1970 and lived in Rostov-on-Don
- Applicants were arrested on 26 December 2006 and placed in a detention center operated by the police
- Applicants were transferred to remand prison no. IZ-61/1 on 1 January 2007 and 31 December 2006, where they were held until 23 March 2012
- Mr. Reznik was held in cells 117, 118, 42, 44, 45, and 111, while Ms. Guzeyeva was held in cell 184
- Mr. Reznik's cells had between six to eleven inmates and Ms. Guzeyeva's cell had between ten to twenty-six inmates
- The government provided certificates, photographs, prisoner transfer logs and registration logs to contest the conditions of detention, but the applicants denied their validity
- The Kirovskiy District Court convicted the applicants of illegal banking operations and forgery on 14 December 2010, sentencing them to six years’ imprisonment and a fine, and ordered the forfeiture of their money
- On 13 March 2012, the Rostov Regional Court reduced the sentences and revoked the forfeiture order
- The applicants lodged several claims for the return of their property
- On 21 March 2013 and 10 February 2014, the Kirovskiy District Court ordered the return of part of the money to the applicants
- The applicants' appeals resulted in a final decision on 16 December 2015 ordering the return of the rest of their property, which they recovered on 20 January and 18 February 2016.

title: CASE OF ANNA POPOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1964 and lived in a flat in Chelyabinsk.
- The flat was assigned to someone else under a social housing agreement by the factory which was the owner of the block of flats in 1971.
- P. resided in the flat as a tenant until his death on December 3, 2010.
- Following P.'s death, Chelyabinsk Municipality initiated the process of registering the flat as vacant to assign it to someone else. However, it turned out that according to the documents, the flat was no longer municipal property and belonged to L.
- The prosecutor established that the flat had been subject to several transactions.
- The police opened a criminal investigation in this regard.
- On June 22, 2011, the applicant bought the flat from Ya.
- On June 30, 2011, the prosecutor brought an action against Kh., L. and Ya. to seek repossession of the flat and the annulment of all transactions executed in respect of it.
- On December 23, 2011, the Tsentralniy District Court of Chelyabinsk granted the prosecutor's claims brought on behalf of the municipality.
- On March 5, 2012, the Chelyabinsk Regional Court upheld the judgment of December 23, 2011, on appeal.
- On December 13, 2013, Ya. died; the part of the judgment of December 23, 2011, concerning the monetary award in the applicant’s favor remains unenforced.
- Applicant has not been evicted and continues to reside in the flat.
- The applicant brought an action against the State, alleging that the local authorities' inaction had resulted in her buying a flat from a person who had no right to sell it in 2014.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the judgment of December 19, 2013, on appeal.

title: CASE OF PETAR MATAS v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant owns a commercial building in Split, bought from the State in 2001 with no stated limitations. 
- The Split Department for the Conservation of Cultural Heritage ordered a measure of preventive protection on the building in 2003 due to its apparent cultural value in early industrial architecture. 
- The decision was not communicated to the applicant but was registered in the land registry. 
- Another measure of preventive protection was ordered in 2007, which was also not communicated to the applicant. 
- The applicant challenged the extension of the measure and requested compensation for the pecuniary damage caused. 
- The Ministry dismissed the appeal on the grounds that there was nothing in law preventing the competent authorities from applying the measure twice for three-year periods. 
- The applicant lodged an administrative action in the Administrative Court challenging the measure of preventive protection and asking for compensation of 200,000 euros. 
- The building was eventually found not to qualify for cultural heritage registration and the measure of preventive protection was removed. 
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s action and the Constitutional Court declared the applicant’s complaint inadmissible.

title: CASE OF MÁTYUS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Budapest.
- On 6 January 2000, the applicant brought an action against his parents before the Siófok District Court.
- The court suspended the proceedings on 21 March 2000.
- The court continued hearing the case upon termination of other proceedings on 17 November 2005.
- The court suspended the proceedings again on 25 August 2006.
- The court ordered the continuation of the case on 17 November 2008.
- An agreement was reached between the parties.
- The agreement was acknowledged and incorporated into a judgment by the Siófok District Court on 5 May 2011.

title: CASE OF DO CARMO DE PORTUGAL E CASTRO CÂMARA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant is a university professor and was a columnist for O Independente.
- The applicant acted as vice-president of the Portuguese Meteorological Institute.
- The applicant wrote an article in O Independente about problems faced in the implementation of a project he was coordinating.
- The President of the Institute, A.S., made statements downplaying the applicant's statements and cast aspersions on his ability to lead the project.
- The applicant wrote another article titled "The Liar" containing statements that A.S. lied, was a petty liar and poor wretch.
- A.S. lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant accusing him of defamation.
- The Lisbon Criminal Court reviewed documents and took oral evidence from witnesses establishing that the applicant's professional capacity and expertise in meteorology and climatology were highly recognized.
- The applicant was convicted of aggravated defamation by the Lisbon Criminal Court and sentenced to 250 day fines and ordered to pay damages.
- The applicant appealed but the Lisbon Court of Appeal upheld the first instance decision.
- The court found that the applicant exceeded his right to criticism by making value judgments that were excluded from objective criticism and fell within the scope of a personal attack on the assistant, and objectively defamatory.

title: CASE OF DOLGOV AND SILAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- First applicant convicted of murder, assault on a public official and other crimes in 1996, sentenced to death, then commuted to life imprisonment in 1999.
- First applicant serving his sentence in the IK-2 facility and has changed cell several times. Cells were designed to accommodate up to three prisoners, but he never had more than two cellmates.
- As regards the conditions of his detention, the cell had a toilet located in the corner behind a one-metre-high partition, foul smell stayed in the cell. The window did not open, and access to natural light was restricted.
- In 2009, the first applicant reported improvement in the conditions following major repair works; toilets and ventilation had been repaired, and access to natural light and air had been improved. 
- Second applicant convicted of murder and rape and sentenced to life imprisonment in 1997. Serving his sentence in the IK-5 facility, which had no running water or sewerage in individual cells.
- Supervising prosecutor instituted infringement proceedings against the facility’s management in 2011, seeking to enforce compliance with legal requirements.
- Cells had no ventilation, and prisoners were given buckets for their daily needs; one bucket of water for drinking and washing, and one to use as a toilet. 
- In 2011, Belozerskiy District Court ordered the management of the prison to connect all the cells to the mains, sewers, and a ventilation system within one year and to improve the water quality within six months.
- In 2013, the second applicant sued the Ministry of Finance for compensation for non-pecuniary damage caused by substandard sanitary conditions in the IK-5 facility, but his claim was dismissed as unfounded.

title: CASE OF ŽAJA v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Prague.
- The applicant was granted the right to reside permanently in the Czech Republic but did not de-register his domicile in Croatia.
- The applicant bought a car in Germany and registered it in the Czech Republic, then entered Croatia in his car to de-register his domicile.
- The police authorities impounded the car and reported the matter to the Customs Administration, suspecting that the car had been imported without payment of taxes.
- The Customs Administration instituted administrative proceedings to establish whether the applicant was liable to pay taxes on the importation of his vehicle.
- The Customs Administration impounded the applicant’s car and issued a decision ordering the applicant to pay the customs debt owed on the importation of his car.
- The applicant did not appeal against the decision to pay the customs debt, and the decision became final and enforceable.
- The Customs Administration ordered the sale of the applicant’s car to collect the customs debt as the applicant did not pay the sum.
- The Ministry of Finance dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the decision to confiscate his car and uphold the first-instance decision.
- The High Administrative Court also dismissed the applicant's action to challenge the decision against him ensuing him to pay customs debts.
- The Customs Administration found the applicant guilty of committing an administrative offence under the Customs Act and fined him HRK 5,000.
- The High Court for Administrative Offences quashed the first-instance decision on account of incomplete facts and remitted the case to the Customs Administration, noting contradictory reasons for the decision.

title: CASE OF ABDULKHADZHIYEVA AND ABDULKHADZHIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are from Savelyevskaya, Chechen Republic
- In 1999, a counterterrorist campaign was taking place in Chechen Republic
- The village and surrounding area were under control of federal troops
- On 8 October 1999, applicants and neighbors went to retrieve their cattle, obtained permission from the military, but were fired upon and wounded
- A civilian who approached the servicemen was shot dead
- Applicants and one neighbor were blindfolded and taken to military unit no. 54262
- Head of local administration had detainees released
- First applicant left with permanent disability
- Applicants' cattle were taken by military and never returned
- Criminal case opened in October 2000 but later suspended for failure to identify the perpetrators
- In 2005, first applicant lodged multiple complaints about the delays in the investigation
- Investigation later resumed in 2006 and officer B. was identified through an envelope found by the first applicant.

title: CASE OF MALKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants
- The table contains relevant details of the applications
- The applicants complained about the conditions of their detention
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BEKUZAROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and details of applications in the appended table.
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Application no. 1884/12 had an additional complaint under Article 5 § 4 of the Convention based on the same set of facts.

title: CASE OF MOOG v. GERMANY
facts:
- Mr Claus Moog's son, D., was born in 1998
- Mr Moog and D.'s mother, Ms K., separated in 1999 and have been in dispute over contact and custody since then
- In 2001, contact between Mr Moog and his son was re-established following an expert opinion
- In 2002, the Family Court granted Ms K. custody and the applicant contact with his son for six hours each week, with a contact facilitator appointed
- In 2003, Ms K. refused to comply with contact arrangements citing mental abnormalities experienced by the child after contact with the applicant
- In 2006, the applicant applied for contact again and a witness statement from the director of D.'s kindergarten was obtained
- In 2007, the Family Court imposed a coercive fine on Ms K. for failing to comply with contact arrangements but later suspended the applicant's contact until 31 December 2011 due to the continuing conflict between the parents and Ms K.'s stress disorder
- In 2009, the Family Court and Court of Appeal rejected Mr Moog's application for custody, stating that it was not in the child's best interest but indicating that they should reflect on their behavior as the child would need his father as a counterbalancing authority figure in adolescence. The Court of Appeal upheld the suspension of contact until the end of 2011.

title: CASE OF BRAHIMAJ v. ALBANIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1968 and resides in Vlora.
- Vlora District Court ordered Vlora Construction Police to pay the applicant ALL 2,795,956.
- On June 11, 2008, the Vlora Court of Appeal upheld the decision.
- On September 11, 2008, an enforcement writ was issued.
- From 2009 to 2012, the bailiff was unsuccessful in enforcing the decision from the Vlora Construction Police and the National Urban Construction Inspectorate.
- The final decision remains unenforced up until now.

title: CASE OF KHAMZIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and application details is provided.
- Applicants are complaining about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- In two applications (nos. 5441/11 and 21051/11), the applicants raised additional complaints under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF CHIRYKINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- This is a document about facts of a case.
- The relevant details are in an appended table.
- The applicant has made a complaint regarding the excessively long duration of the civil proceedings.

title: CASE OF BRISKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details of their applications provided in the appended table.
- The applicants complained about the conditions of their detention.

title: CASE OF FILIMONOV AND FAZLUTDINOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and application details provided in a table
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
- Applicants argued that they lacked an effective domestic remedy to complain about poor conditions

title: CASE OF MUZYCHENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their details are in the appended table.
- Applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF YAROVENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1975 and was serving a life sentence in Kherson Prison no. 61 as of October 2013.
2. The applicant was arrested on 24 (or 25 according to the Government) September 2004 on suspicion of robbery and murder.
3. The Court of Appeal found the applicant guilty of aggravated robbery, two counts of murder, and unlawful possession of firearms on 23 November 2005.
4. The applicant was detained in Simferopol ITT, Simferopol SIZO, Dnipropetrovsk SIZO, Kyiv SIZO, Odessa SIZO, and Kherson Prison no. 61 at different periods.
5. The applicant alleged poor conditions of detention, including overcrowding, cold and damp cells, lack of sufficient air and light, poor nutrition, and poor medical treatment, among others.
6. The applicant suffered from active tuberculosis during his detention and had to share his cell with healthy inmates in some cases.

title: CASE OF DRAGOMIR AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A table is appended that contains a list of applicants and their details.
- The applicants have complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- In some applications, the applicants also raised complaints under other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF GORYAYEVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's son suffered from tuberculosis, AIDS, drug addiction, and an infected phlegmon on his right shin.
- On May 4, 2007, the applicant's son was arrested on suspicion of drug-related crimes and placed in a temporary detention center belonging to the Mykolayiv police.
- On May 7, 2007, the Tsentralnyy District Court of Mykolayiv ordered the applicant's son's pre-trial detention.
- On May 23, 2007, an ITT officer heard moaning from the appellant's son's cell, found him alone in the cell with his mouth open, breathing heavily, and repeating that he felt bad and needed air. ITT officers removed him from the cell and took him to the entrance area to get some fresh air, where they carried out first aid. An ambulance arrived at 9.43 p.m. and confirmed that the applicant's son was dead.
- According to the post-mortem examination report, the applicant's son died from ischaemic heart disease, which had been aggravated by acute heart failure. Linear strangulation bruises were found on his neck, which indicated interrupted asphyxiation.
- On more than fifteen occasions between 2007 and 2012, the investigators at the local prosecutor's office, having conducted pre-investigation inquiries, refused to initiate criminal proceedings in connection with the death of the applicant's son.
- On 14 December 2012, the authorities initiated criminal proceedings, in accordance with the 2012 Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 27 March 2013, an investigator at the prosecutor's office of the Zavodskyy District of Mykolayiv terminated the criminal proceedings, finding no elements of a crime on the part of the ITT officers in question.
- On 24 July 2013, the Zavodskyy District Court of Mykolayiv quashed the decision of 27 March 2013 as unfounded, noting that the investigator had failed to take the necessary measures in the case.
- On 3 October 2013, the investigator terminated the criminal proceedings, concluding that there was no evidence to suggest that the ITT staff had caused the death of the applicant's son. He admitted that certain pieces of evidence could not be obtained, such as bed linen and a rope fashioned from bed linen, which had been found in the cell, could not be examined any further.
- According to the latest medical findings, the applicant's

title: CASE OF SHEHU v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1947 and lives in Tirana.
- The Tepelenë District Court ordered the Tepelenë District Council to pay the applicant ALL 530,941 as compensation for the nationalisation of her house by the State in 1967.
- An enforcement writ was issued on 15 July 1998.
- The Gjirokastër District Court ordered the Gjirokastër Regional Council to pay the applicant ALL 1,237,336 as compensation for the delayed enforcement of the Tepelenë District Court decision of 21 June 1996.
- An enforcement writ was issued on 27 June 2008.
- The applicant continuously addressed letters to the authorities for the enforcement of the final judgments from 1996 to 2009 and instituted enforcement proceedings before a bailiff.
- The Constitutional Court acknowledged on 23 January 2009 that there had been a breach of the fair trial as a result of the non-enforcement of the final judgments.
- Both judgments were enforced on 8 December 2009, and the sums were paid to the applicant.

title: CASE OF BARTOK AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The document includes a table that lists the applicants and their application details.
- The applicants have filed a complaint about the extended duration of criminal proceedings.

title: CASE OF CHAKALOVA-ILIEVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and worked as a head teacher in a secondary school in Stara Zagora.
- On 19 July 2002, the head of the REI dismissed the applicant on disciplinary grounds.
- The applicant challenged the order for her dismissal, seeking reinstatement and compensation for lost earnings.
- The Stara Zagora District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, which was upheld by the Stara Zagora Regional Court and the Supreme Court of Cassation.
- The applicant applied to take up her duties following the entry into force of the 2005 judgment but was dismissed again on the same day.
- The applicant challenged the lawfulness of the dismissal through an appeal with the Stara Zagora District Court, but the proceedings were discontinued due to a ruling that the proper defendant in the case was the school, not the REI.
- The Stara Zagora Regional Court quashed the decision and remitted the case to the first-instance court for examination on the merits.
- The District Court allowed the applicant’s claims, which was upheld by the Regional Court but quashed by the Plovdiv Appeal Court.

title: CASE OF STROGAN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant had a fight with his neighbor, who complained to the police that the applicant had injured him.
- The police took the applicant to the police station for questioning and evidence-gathering.
- According to the applicant, he was beaten and tortured by police officers using handcuffs and an electric shock device.
- The prosecutor's office initially refused to initiate criminal proceedings on the applicant's allegations of ill-treatment by police officers, but the case was remitted to the District Court for fresh consideration after appeal.
- The applicant was arrested and charged with attempted murder of his neighbor.
- The applicant was kept in custody during the trial after pre-trial detention was ordered and refused bail.
- The applicant was found guilty of inflicting minor bodily injuries on his neighbor, and sentenced to two years of restriction of liberty after spending time in pre-trial detention.
- The applicant claimed that he was beaten up by police officers during his pre-trial detention, but medical reports suggest that the injuries may have been self-inflicted.
- The prosecutor's office initially refused to open an investigation in relation to the allegations of police brutality against the applicant, citing a lack of evidence.

title: CASE OF PIVOVARNIK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and had been diagnosed with hepatitis C prior to his arrest.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of a drug-related offense and placed in Kirovograd Remand Prison No. 14.
- The applicant appealed his remand, citing his hepatitis C diagnosis, but the appeal was denied, and his pre-trial detention was extended until his conviction.
- The applicant was ultimately convicted of drug-related offenses and sentenced to three years' imprisonment.
- The prison where the applicant was held requested confirmation of the applicant's hepatitis C diagnosis but received no reply.
- The applicant repeatedly consulted with the prison's medical staff about his symptoms and requested a medical certificate to present to the courts examining his case.
- The prison ultimately issued a certificate stating that the applicant was suffering from hepatitis C and had consulted with a doctor about his symptoms.
- Despite the certificate, the prison did not provide the necessary treatment for the applicant's hepatitis C until he was examined by a specialized doctor after a rule 39 request by the applicant.
- The specialized doctor's examination confirmed the applicant's hepatitis C diagnosis and prescribed treatment, which the government implemented.
- Reports by human rights bodies indicate that diagnosing and treating hepatitis in Ukrainian prisons is not a priority, and the medical units of remand prisons are ill-equipped to provide adequate treatment.

title: CASE OF ZUBAC v. CROATIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Bijela, Montenegro
- In 1992 applicant's father-in-law made a contract for the exchange of houses in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina
- In 2001, father-in-law sought permission to register ownership of the house in Bosnia and Herzegovina 
- Applicant's husband brought a civil action in 2002 to have the contract for the houses declared null and void, claiming that it was signed under duress and signature on power of attorney was forged
- Dubrovnik Municipal Court ordered applicant's husband to pay court fees and dismissed the claim in 2005
- County Court and Supreme Court upheld the decision and declared appeal inadmissible in 2009 and 2011 respectively
- Applicant lodged a constitutional complaint in 2011 which was declared inadmissible

title: CASE OF CHUGUNOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and is serving a prison sentence in Donskoy, Tula Region.
- On 27 June 2005, the Zhukov District Court of the Kaluga Region sentenced the applicant to 11 years and one month’s imprisonment for battery and manslaughter.
- On 6 September 2005, the Kaluga Regional Court upheld the applicant's conviction on appeal.
- Prior to the applicant’s arrest and conviction, he suffered from duodenal ulcer, chronic bronchitis, and high blood pressure. In detention, he developed chronic gastritis, hernia of a diaphragm, chronic cholecystitis, lipomas, and pilonidal cysts.
- On 23 January 2012, the applicant was placed in a disciplinary cell that was cold, damp, and had no ventilation system or hot water supply. He was allowed 1.5 hours’ daily exercise and one 30 minutes’ shower per week.
- On 21 March 2012, the applicant started having a fever resulting from an inflamed pilonidal cyst in the coccyx area.
- On 22 March 2012, a prison doctor prescribed him a treatment by antibiotics and painkillers and recommended that the applicant consult a surgeon.
- On 23 March 2012, the head of the correctional colony extended the applicant’s detention in a disciplinary cell for another fifteen days, and the prison doctor concluded that he was fit for detention in the disciplinary cell.
- On 28 March 2012, the applicant was admitted to a prison hospital, and his surgery was scheduled on 10 April 2012.
- On 8-9 April 2012, the applicant’s cyst opened up and the inflammation stopped.
- On 18 April 2012, the applicant was released from the hospital and transferred back to the correctional colony.
- On 25 April 2012, the applicant consulted a surgeon and a neurologist at the hospital of correctional colony no. IK-2 and was prescribed medication for high blood pressure. The surgeon recommended that the applicant undergo surgery in connection with the pilonidal cyst.
- From 14 to 30 August 2012, the applicant underwent additional examination and treatment at the surgical division of the hospital at correctional colony no. IK-5, and according to the doctors who treated the applicant, no surgery was required.
- On 5 June 2012, the applicant was threatened by several officers and advised

title: CASE OF CANO MOYA v. SPAIN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 in Villahermosa (Ciudad Real) and is currently serving a prison sentence in Spain.
- At the time of the facts the applicant was in prison on remand in Foncalent (Alicante).
- On 20 October 2009 the applicant was found guilty of a disciplinary offence by the disciplinary board of Alicante Prison and punished under the General Prison Rules.
- The applicant appealed against the sanction before the Comunidad Valenciana post-sentencing judge no. 2 (Juzgado de Vigilancia Penitenciaria n.o 2).
- The post-sentencing judge found partially in the applicant’s favour and revoked the sanction imposed under Rule 109 (b).
- A State agent in charge of judicial communications attempted unsuccessfully to serve the applicant in person with the post-sentencing judge’s decision.
- The applicant lodged a reforma appeal with the same post-sentencing judge, who on 18 February 2010 confirmed her previous decision.
- The applicant lodged an amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court. He invoked Articles 20 (freedom of expression) and 24 (right to be presumed innocent) of the Constitution.
- By a decision of 30 September 2010 the Constitutional Court declared the applicant’s amparo appeal inadmissible as devoid of any special constitutional significance.
- On 22 December 2010 the applicant asked the post-sentencing judge for a copy of his case file for submission to the European Court of Human Rights.
- On 26 January 2011 the post-sentencing judge refused the applicant’s request for a copy of his case file.
- On 2 February 2011 the applicant sent his application form to the Court. He raised complaints under Article 6 § 2 and Article 10 § 1 of the Convention.
- On 7 April 2011 the applicant informed the Court that the post-sentencing judge had refused to provide him with a copy of his case file.

title: CASE OF BARCZA AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants are co-owners of a vacant plot of land in Leányfalu.
- The land is designated as an inner protection zone within the municipality's water reserve.
- The Hungarian State is obligated to compensate the owners of the plots of land within the protection zone.
- The applicants made several requests for compensation and expropriation to various government bodies.
- The expropriation decision was finally issued on 16 December 2011, and the compensation was received on 27 January 2012.

title: CASE OF BURYKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lived in St Petersburg.
- The applicant was put on a wanted list on suspicion of murder and gangsterism on 20 December 2005.
- The applicant was remanded in custody in absentia by the Vyborskiy District Court of St Petersburg on 17 July 2007.
- The applicant was arrested in Hungary on 20 October 2007, and extradited to Russia on 13 September 2008.
- The St Petersburg City Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention citing the seriousness of the charges and the applicant’s attempt to abscond.
- The applicant’s appeals against the detention orders were rejected on multiple dates.
- The applicant was convicted of murder and gangsterism by the Saint-Petersburg City Court on 29 April 2010, and sentenced to 16 years’ imprisonment.
- The decision was upheld on appeal by the Supreme Court of Russia on 7 October 2010.

title: CASE OF MANDRYKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1951 and lived in Irkutsk before his arrest. 
- Applicant was arrested on 14 May 2008 and charged with three counts. 
- Court remanded him in custody, and on 5 March 2009 he was committed for trial. 
- The District Court extended his detention on multiple occasions citing the seriousness of the crime, risk of absconding, and interfering with the investigation. 
- The Court considered the applicant's character, state of health, and age while extending his detention. 
- The applicant's appeals against the detention orders were rejected. 
- The District Court convicted him on 29 March 2010.

title: CASE OF URMANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and is from Neftekamsk, Bashkortostan Republic.
- On September 4, 2008, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of causing and inciting prostitution of minors and unlawful breaking and entering.
- Witness statements were made implicating the applicant in these crimes.
- On September 5, 2008, the Leninskiy District Court of Ufa remanded the applicant in custody due to the severity of the crimes and the risk of interference with the investigation.
- The applicant was detained pending investigation and trial.
- The district court and Supreme Court repeatedly extended the applicant's detention due to the seriousness of the charges and risk of absconding or interfering with the investigation.
- The applicant was later charged with abuse of power and organizing a criminal gang.
- On December 27, 2010, the Supreme Court of the Bashkortostan Republic found the applicant guilty of causing and inciting prostitution of minors, abuse of power, and unlawful breaking and entering, but acquitted him of one count of causing and inciting prostitution of minors and organizing a criminal gang.
- The applicant’s conviction was upheld on appeal on April 27, 2011.
- The applicant was released on parole on July 21, 2011.
- The applicant was detained in multiple remand prisons from September 2008 until his release on parole.
- In February 2009, the applicant sent a letter to the court alleging a violation of his right to liberty and asking for an application form.
- The Court sent the applicant an application form in April 2009, but it was delayed due to forwarding issues between different detention sites.

title: CASE OF RYZHIKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were prosecuted for various crimes in Russia.
- They were arrested and detained for investigation and trial.
- Detention was ordered and extended by courts based on the gravity of the charges and the risk of absconding and interfering with justice.
- Stereotyped formulae were used for detention and extension orders without considering preventive measures.
- The first applicant was arrested in Ukraine, extradited to Russia and released on bail on 27 December 2010.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Yekaterinburg convicted him of fraud on 22 April 2011.
- The second applicant was arrested on suspicion of fraud on 23 September 2007 and remanded in custody on 25 September 2007.
- The Irkutsk Regional Court convicted the applicant of fraud on 24 June 2010.
- The third applicant was arrested on 16 August 2012 and placed in pre-trial detention a day later.
- The Sverdlovsk Regional Court convicted the applicant of trespass, battery, robbery and sexual assault on 10 October 2013.

title: CASE OF ZAKHAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was a police officer prior to his arrest.
- The applicant was arrested on 5 July 2007 on suspicion of abuse of official powers causing serious damage and subsequently charged with embezzlement on a large scale as part of an organised criminal group.
- The Zamoskvoretskiy District Court of Moscow remanded the applicant in custody on 6 July 2007.
- The applicant's pre-trial detention was extended on several occasions by the District Court with the reasoning that the investigation was still pending, the case comprised 118 volumes and concerned fifteen suspects, the applicant had been suspected of a serious crime, could interact with his accomplices, abscond, destroy evidence, and threaten witnesses.
- The District Court issued collective detention orders in respect of the applicant and other co-accused on 30 December 2008 and 20 April 2009.
- The applicant's appeals against the detention orders were rejected.
- On 9 June 2010, the Moscow City Court acquitted the applicant of all charges.

title: CASE OF LEONID PETROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lived in Cheboksary before his conviction. 
- In April 2006 a criminal case was opened into the theft of money belonging to the applicant’s cousin, Ms G. 
- On 8 September 2006 G. was found dead in her flat with several gunshot wounds. On 9 September 2006 a criminal case was opened into her murder. 
- On 14 September 2006 the applicant, who was suspected of the theft and whose whereabouts were unknown, was placed on a police wanted list. 
- At around 10 p.m. on 6 October 2006 the applicant was arrested on the street. 
- According to Ms P. and two other female witnesses, the applicant had no injuries before his arrest. 
- The applicant was escorted to the police station at around 11 p.m. He was taken in handcuffs to room no. 217 on the first floor (“second floor” in Russian) and interviewed by operative police officers Ch. and F. about the theft and murder. 
- The parties provided different accounts of the events at the police station. 
- According to the applicant, police officers Ch. and F., who were drunk at the time, demanded that he confess to the theft and murder. 
- They allegedly beat him up, delivering blows to his head, ears, body, and legs and threatened him with rape. 
- At about 3 a.m. they shackled a 40 kg weight to his hands, which he was made to hold while they continued to physically assault him. 
- At about 4 a.m. they made him stand on the windowsill of an open window and threatened to throw him out and make it look as if he had attempted to flee or commit suicide if he did not confess to the murder. 
- After refusing to do so, one of the police officers allegedly pushed him out of the window. 
- According to the Government, in the course of the police interview the applicant, who was drunk when he was taken to the police station, suddenly climbed on a table and jumped out of the window. 
- At 6.15 a.m. the applicant was taken to the Cheboksary Town Emergency Hospital handcuffed on a stretcher, accompanied by police officers Ch. and F. 
- Following an examination of the applicant’s hospital records, a forensic medical expert concluded on 14 December 2006 that the information concerning the applicant’s initial examination

title: CASE OF ŠMIGIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Belgrade.
- On 19 September 1996, the debtor was sentenced for fraud and ordered to pay a sum of 18,425 Serbian dinars to PP Reprek, a company owned by the applicant.
- On 17 December 1998, the company requested the District Court in Belgrade to enforce the judgment in the criminal proceedings against the debtor.
- On 29 April 1999, the court adopted a decision on enforcement after asking the company to specify a motion for enforcement.
- On 15 October 1999, the enforcement court ordered the Ministry of Interior to provide the debtor's exact address.
- On 7 February 2000, the bailiff reported that the debtor had moved away to an unknown location.
- On 27 October 2000, the case was adjourned.
- On 7 May 2005, the applicant requested the continuation of the enforcement proceedings on behalf of his company.
- On 4 October 2005, the enforcement court again ordered the Ministry of Interior to provide the debtor's exact address.
- On 21 October 2005, the Ministry informed the enforcement court of the debtor's address, but the bailiff found that the debtor had moved away.
- On 20 January 2006, the enforcement court requested the Ministry of Interior to provide the debtor's exact address and latest known place of residence.
- On 24 October 2006, the court informed the applicant that the Ministry failed to locate the debtor or initiate misdemeanour proceedings against him.
- On 31 May 2007, the insolvency proceedings against the applicant's company "Reprek" were completed, and the company ceased to exist.
- On 31 March 2010, the enforcement court adjourned the case.

title: CASE OF PLOTNIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lived in Cheboksary before arrest and conviction. 
- The applicant was arrested on January 27, 2004, and was kept in custody during investigation and trial. 
- On October 7, 2005, the applicant was convicted of fraud and sentenced to six years nine months imprisonment which was subsequently reduced to five years ten months on appeal on December 13, 2005.
- On June 22, 2007, the case was remitted to a fresh examination by the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic, and the applicant was remanded in custody.
- Pre-trial detention was extended on different occasions by Leninskiy District Court on various grounds including serious crime, health condition, and possibility of absconding.
- On March 27, 2008, the Leninskiy District Court sentenced the applicant to five years and ten months of imprisonment for fraud. 
- On July 1, 2008, the Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic upheld the conviction on appeal.

title: CASE OF MARTOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals residing in Kizel.
- The applicants filed a lawsuit against the municipal unitary enterprise "Gorvodokanal" for salary arrears.
- The company was established by the local administration to provide water supply to the town of Kizel.
- The company was declared insolvent on September 7, 2006, and its liquidation started.
- In 2007 and 2009, domestic courts awarded pecuniary damages in favor of the applicants, to be paid by the company.
- The judgments became enforceable on certain dates listed in the Appendix.
- According to the applicants, the judgments have not been enforced except for the one in favor of Mr. Martov delivered on 16 October 2009.
- The government claims that all the judgments except the one in favor of Mr. Martov have been fully enforced.
- The company's liquidator issued a certificate on February 6, 2012, contending that the judgment of 1 August 2007 in Mr. Martov's favor had been fully enforced, but the execution writ issued in 2009 had never reached the liquidator.
- The applicants submitted a copy of a letter received from the Prosecutor’s office of Kizel dated 3 June 2011, stating that Mr. Martov submitted the execution writ in respect of the judgment of 16 October 2009 to the liquidator in November 2009.

title: CASE OF KASPAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Moscow.
- The applicant was traveling to Samara to take part in the opposition rally “March of Dissent” which had been organised to coincide with the summit.
- The applicant and some activists were prevented from taking flight no. SU0697 from Sheremetyevo airport to Samara, where the rally was being held.
- There are conflicting versions of events as to whether the applicant’s passport was seized.
- The applicant was taken to a police office on the second floor of the airport where he and five others were questioned and ordered to remain.
- At 12.20 p.m. the police officer from the Department of the Interior questioned the applicant about where he had purchased his ticket.
- The applicant refused to give any further explanation based on his right to remain silent.
- The police confiscated twenty tickets bearing signs of forgery and completed a search and confiscation record.
- The applicant complained to the Moscow Transport Prosecutor’s Office about having been unlawfully detained by the police and requested that those responsible be prosecuted.
- The prosecutor’s office decided not to open criminal proceedings against the policemen.
- The applicant challenged this decision in court but was unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF BELYAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Tambov.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Tambov ordered the town administration to pay the applicant social benefits and inflation losses.
- The judgment entered into force on 3 November 2006.
- The District Court clarified the judgment on 7 November 2006.
- The judgment was executed on 29 November 2007.
- The District Court awarded the applicant interest and compensation for non-pecuniary damage due to the delayed enforcement of the judgment.

title: CASE OF TUMANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and is detained in Saint-Petersburg.
- On April 22, 2004, he was arrested on suspicion of murder.
- On April 24, 2004, the Vyborgskiy Federal District Court of Saint-Petersburg authorised the applicant’s pre-trial detention. He remained in custody pending investigation and trial.
- On February 7, 2005, the District Court extended the applicant’s pre‑trial detention. The court referred to the gravity of charges, the applicant’s character, lack of permanent residence in Saint-Petersburg, and risk of absconding or re-offending.
- On April 7, 2005, the District Court returned the case to the prosecutor and extended the applicant’s detention without specifying any reasons.
- On September 15, 2005, October 21, 2005, and December 15, 2005, when extending pre-trial detention, the District Court reproduced the grounds for detention described above.
- On March 2, 2006, the Saint-Petersburg City Court quashed the detention order of December 15, 2005, and remitted the case for a fresh examination.
- On March 16, 2006, March 22, 2006 and June 21, 2006, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention referring to the gravity of charges, absence of permanent residence, his character, possibility of absconding and committing crimes. The applicant and his lawyer did not attend the hearing on June 21, 2006.
- On June 30, 2006, the Vyborgskiy District Court of Saint-Petersburg convicted the applicant of murder and theft.
- On January 31, 2007, the Saint-Petersburg City Court upheld his conviction on appeal. The court discontinued the appeal proceedings finding them unnecessary.

title: CASE OF SEMENOV AND BACHURINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr Semenov was arrested on suspicion of aggravated bribery in 2006 and ordered to be placed in custody.
- His detention was extended several times by the Tsentralniy District Court of Tver and appealed by Mr Semenov.
- The Tver Regional Court dismissed the appeals and upheld the detention orders of Mr Semenov.
- The Russian Supreme Court also upheld the detention orders.
- Ms Bachurina was arrested in 2007 on suspicion of large scale drug trafficking and her detention was authorized by the Zyuzinskiy District Court of Moscow.
- Ms Bachurina appealed against the detention order, but it was upheld on appeal by the Moscow City Court.

title: CASE OF KRYUKOV AND LANTSEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1947 and 1950.
- Mr. Kryukov lives in Kolpashevo, the Tomsk Region.
- Mr. Lantsev, the second applicant, died on October 28, 2007.
- On March 10, 2008, his widow, Ms Raisa Pavlovna Lantseva, pursued the complaint of her late husband before the Court.
- On June 30, 1997, the applicants were dismissed from work on the grounds of redundancy.
- On July 17, 1997, the applicants sued their former employer for reinstatement, salary arrears, and compensation in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- On September 10, 1997, the Kolpashevo Town Court of the Tomsk Region dismissed the applicants’ claims in full.
- On October 17, 1997, the aforesaid judgment was quashed further to the applicants’ appeal by the Tomsk Regional Court, and the case was remitted for fresh examination.
- On January 16, 20 and 22, 1998, the applicants amended their claims.
- On March 18, 1998, the hearing was adjourned until 20 April 1998 at the defendant’s request in view of its representative’s health condition.
- On April 23, 1998, the Town Court allowed the applicants’ claims in part.
- On September 8, 1998, the Regional Court upheld the judgment in part but remitted the claim for salary arrears for a fresh examination.
- On November 25 and December 8, 1998, the hearings were adjourned at the applicants’ request.
- On December 15, 1998, the applicants further amended their claims and asked for a forensic accountant to be appointed.
- The proceedings were adjourned until February 11, 1999, to allow the accountant to prepare his report.
- On February 11, 1999, the applicants lodged a new claim.
- By the judgment of February 11, 1999, the Town Court partly allowed the applicants’ claims.
- On April 23, 1999, the Regional Court quashed the first-instance judgment and remitted the case for fresh examination.
- On August 26 and November 30, 1999, the hearings were adjourned.
- On January 13, 2000, the

title: CASE OF TURYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lived in Ivdel until his conviction for murder and arson.
- In April 2000, the applicant was arrested for murder and arson.
- In July 2000, a local newspaper printed an interview with a town prosecutor, citing details about the murder cases and implicating the applicant and his co-defendant.
- The applicant's lawyer tried to have the prosecutor disqualified due to his apparent lack of impartiality revealed in the interview.
- The court refused to disqualify the prosecutor deciding he didn't cross any lines.
- In January 2003, the court sentenced the applicant to 20 years in prison for arson and the murders of two people.
- In October 2003, the Supreme Court upheld the sentence without addressing the complaint about the press interview.
- In December 2004, the regional prosecutor's office found that the interview had breached its ethics policy, but the applicant didn't receive any tangible redress.

title: CASE OF LYUBIMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and lived in Sibay, Bashkortostan Republic.
- The applicant was arrested on 11 December 2009 on suspicion of drug trafficking.
- He was charged on an unspecified date with three counts of smuggling cocaine into Russia, three counts of transport of cocaine, and three counts of preparation to distribute cocaine, all committed by an organized group.
- The Tverskoy District Court of Moscow remanded him in custody on 12 December 2009, pending investigation, and he remained in detention pending trial.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Saint-Petersburg convicted the applicant on 20 February 2012, and he was sentenced to sixteen years’ imprisonment.
- The Saint-Petersburg City Court acquitted him of the charges concerning the transport of cocaine and reduced his sentence to fourteen years’ imprisonment, upholding the judgment in the remaining part.
- The Presidium of the Saint-Petersburg City Court quashed the judgments on 22 May 2013 and remitted the case for a new examination, while extending his pre-trial detention.
- The Kirovskiy District Court extended his pre-trial detention on 20 June 2013, and the Saint-Petersburg City Court upheld this decision on 20 August 2013.
- The Kirovskiy District Court of Saint-Petersburg convicted the applicant on 10 February 2014.
- The Saint-Petersburg City Court upheld his conviction on 16 June 2014, on appeal.

title: CASE OF RUSLAN MAKAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant assembled explosive devices to extort money from commercial banks, with the purpose of donating the proceeds to orphans. He planted and exploded one device in front of the bank M., causing no casualties.
- The applicant was diagnosed with schizotypal personality disorder, relieving him of criminal liability and ordering his involuntary treatment.
- The applicant moved to another region, where his condition was noted as being in stable remission.
- The applicant was apprehended by the police and taken to a psychiatric hospital due to his refusal to undergo planned outpatient treatment, coupled with stated ideas of revenge and murder against certain regional officials, and his own complaints about the worsening of his condition.
- A medical counseling panel diagnosed the applicant with schizotypal personality disorder in decompensation and a danger to himself and others, requiring involuntary hospitalization.
- The hospital applied for judicial authorization of the applicant’s hospitalization, and the court granted it in a hearing that was held in camera.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal against the lower court’s order, upholding it as well-reasoned and lawful.

title: CASE OF B.A.C. v. GREECE [Extracts]
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Athens.
- While studying in Turkey (1994-1999) the applicant had become a pro-communist and pro-Kurdish political activist.
- In 2000 the Turkish police arrested the applicant for infringing State constitutional order (Article 146 of the Turkish Criminal Code). He was also held in the “white (isolation) cells” in Kandra Prison and went on hunger strike for 171 days, causing him to develop Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.
- In 2002 the applicant fled to Greece and submitted an asylum application, which was rejected at first instance by the General Secretary of the Ministry of Public Order on 18 February 2002.
- On 29 January 2003, the Advisory Board on Asylum issued a favourable opinion in respect of the applicant, but the Minister for Public Order had not taken any decision and therefore had neither ratified nor rejected the Board’s opinion.
- Between 2003 and 2015 the applicant lived in Athens and attended the police station every six months in order to renew his asylum-seeker’s card, which did not secure all the attendant rights.
- On 5 August 2005, the Turkish Interpol Office had issued an extradition request in respect of the applicant.
- On 26 March 2013, the indictment division of Patras Court of Appeal examined the extradition request and unanimously decided to reject it, based on the risk run by the applicant of suffering ill-treatment on account of his political opinions, should he be extradited.
- On 26 April 2013 the Court of Cassation upheld the impugned decision.
- The applicant had been actively seeking to secure a final decision, writing to the Ombudsman of the Republic and to the Minister for Public Order. Correspondence among a number of different authorities on various dates confirmed that the applicant’s asylum application was still pending before the Minister for Public Order.

title: CASE OF KONOVALCHUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1975 and had a permanent address in Odessa.
2. In 2009 the applicant was diagnosed with HIV.
3. In September 2012, she was arrested on suspicion of drug dealing.
4. In December 2012, the applicant started receiving anti-retroviral therapy.
5. On 16 September 2013, she was convicted of drug-related offences and sentenced to six years and six months in prison.
6. On 5 October 2014, the applicant arrived at Zbarazh Correctional Colony No. 63 to serve her sentence.
7. On 17 October 2014, a cytology test revealed indications of cervical cancer.
8. On 15 December 2014, the applicant was diagnosed with stage IV HIV and cervical cancer.
9. On 16 April 2015, the applicant left the Colony under guard and on 22 April 2015 arrived at the Kyiv Pre-Trial Detention Centre to attend appeal hearings.
10. On 25 May 2015, the applicant lodged a request for release on health grounds.
11. On 25 June 2015, the court rejected the applicant’s request for release.
12. On 1 July 2015, the Court indicated the interim measure for the applicant’s medical examination by a specialist doctor, securing immediate treatment, and informing the Court about the measures undertaken.
13. On 16 September 2015, the applicant left the prison for the HIV Treatment Facility.
14. From 24 September 2015, the applicant started a course of examinations and treatment at the HIV Treatment Facility and the Kherson Regional Oncology Clinic.
15. On 5 to 27 October 2015, the applicant underwent radiation treatment at the Kherson Regional Oncology Clinic.
16. On 4 January 2016, the applicant was released on health grounds. 
17. In addition, conditions of transportation for prisoners in Ukraine were found to be cruel and degrading treatment, and information about the treatment of HIV and related diseases was provided in the judgment of Sergey Antonov v. Ukraine.

title: CASE OF KITANOVSKA STANOJKOVIC AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Two persons wearing black masks entered the applicants’ house with an intention to rob them and inflicted severe injuries on the husband and father.
- The husband died as a result of the injuries on 1 November 2011.
- The first applicant was admitted to hospital where she remained in the intensive care unit until 4 November 2011.
- F.T. was remanded in custody on 3 November 2011 on account of the risk of him absconding and interfering with the investigation.
- On 1 December 2011, F.T. was released and ordered to report to the court while his passport was seized.
- On 13 January 2012, the public prosecutor lodged an indictment against F.T. and a certain S.G. They were indicted on charges of aggravated robbery.
- The court found F.T. guilty of aggravated robbery and sentenced him to five years’ imprisonment.
- The Skopje Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court upheld the conviction and sentences.
- F.T. failed to report to the detention facility to serve his sentence and no enforcement judge was appointed to deal with the case for over eight months.
- On 30 June 2014, the enforcement judge ordered F.T.’s arrest, and he started serving his custodial sentence on 11 July 2014.

title: CASE OF ČERVENKA v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
- The applicant was deprived of legal capacity in 2005 due to alcoholic dementia, which is a permanent mental disability.
- The Prague 11 Municipality Office was appointed as the applicant's public guardian in 2009.
- The applicant has attempted unsuccessfully to regain legal capacity several times.
- The District Court limited the applicant's legal capacity in 2012 to prevent him from disposing of funds or entering into contracts exceeding 500 CZK per month.
- The applicant was admitted to the psychiatric hospital several times, and he has repeatedly exhibited problematic behavior related to alcohol abuse and neglect of animals and property.
- The District Court limited the applicant's legal capacity again in 2014 for a period of 12 months.
- In 2015, the District Court initiated ongoing proceedings on legal capacity and guardianship.
- The applicant was involuntarily placed in a social care home in 2011, and he has continually contested his placement and demanded his release.
- The applicant's lawyer and the Mental Disability Advocacy Centre have taken action to challenge the lawfulness of the applicant's detention and advocate for his release.

title: CASE OF RAYKOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant's husband owned a house with a yard and a garage in Sofia.
- On 14 June 1985, the property was expropriated for constructing a school, and the husband should have been compensated with a flat and garage.
- The decision stated the municipality intended to construct a building with a garage and a flat, but the garage was not mentioned in the supplementary decision of 1986.
- After judicial review, a final judgment in March 1987 ordered the mayor to specify the exact garage to be provided, but this was not done.
- In 2004, the municipal authorities transferred a flat to which the husband did not contest.
- The husband passed away in 2005, and all his property was left to the applicant.
- In a letter signed by the chief architect of Sofia, the applicant was informed that the decision of 1986 had not yet been supplemented to specify the garage due to the lack of buildings with garages.
- In August 2009, the applicant challenged the mayor's failure to issue a decision specifying the garage in question before the courts.
- A final judgment of 23 June 2010 dismissed her claim of failure to act; it had to be pursued under a different procedure.
- In parallel proceedings brought in 2009, the applicant sought damages from the Sofia municipality but was declared inadmissible as the courts had already established that there had not been any unlawful failure to act on the administrative authorities' part.

title: CASE OF MIHAYLOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1927.
- The applicant owned a house with a yard in Plovdiv.
- The property was expropriated in 1982 for the purpose of constructing a residential building.
- Compensation to the applicant was to be given with a two-room flat and a garage in the intended building.
- The flat was constructed and delivered to the applicant.
- The applicant never received the garage due to him.
- The applicant complained to the Plovdiv municipality in April 2008.
- The municipality informed the applicant that there were no garages available and that there was a construction of a building with underground garages.
- The construction was not completed as stated in February 2010.
- In 2014, the municipality offered a garage to the heirs of the applicant.
- The heirs refused the garage as it was situated more than ten kilometers away from their residence.

title: CASE OF DOBRODOLSKA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Pernik.
- The applicant's mother owned a house with a yard in the city, which were expropriated in 1978 to construct a highway.
- The expropriation decision stated that the applicant's mother was to be compensated with a three-room flat, and the applicant was to receive a two-room flat.
- The flat due to the applicant's mother was constructed and provided in 1985, and the expropriated house was pulled down in 1986.
- The Pernik mayor indicated the exact flat to be provided to the applicant in a decision of 14 July 2000, measuring 75 square metres and valued at 22,424.84 BGN.
- The applicant paid the municipality BGN 28,000 for the flat's value later in 2000.
- The building where the flat was situated was completed in 2003, but the flat that the applicant was due was never handed over to her.
- The applicant has been living with her parents and does not have another dwelling.
- The applicant and her mother filed complaints with the regional governor, the Prime Minister, and the Parliament, but the authorities have not yet fulfilled their obligation to provide the applicant with a flat.

title: CASE OF PETROVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1952 and 1955 respectively and live in Sofia. 
- The first applicant’s parents owned part of a house in Sofia.
- The house was expropriated in 1986 with a view to constructing a street and a residential building. 
- The expropriation decision provided that in compensation the applicants were to receive a three-room flat.
- A decision was made in 1993 by the mayor indicating the exact future flat to be provided as compensation to the applicants.
- Its value was set at 21,185 old Bulgarian levs (BGL), later amended to BGL 21,231.
- In 1990 the applicants, their children and the first applicant’s parents were accommodated in a three‑room municipal flat.
- They remained in it until 2004. 
- On an unspecified date in 2005 the applicants brought a tort action against the Sofia municipality, claiming pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage on account of its continued failure to build and provide them with a flat. 
- The action was dismissed on 21 February 2006 by the Sofia District Court. 
- Following that judgment, the applicants made a request for a new valuation. 
- In a letter by the municipality dated 2 June 2006 they were informed that they were not entitled to seek such a valuation since they had not been the owners of the expropriated property.
- The flat due to the applicants was built, and they took possession of it on 19 June 2006. 
- In the tort proceedings, in judgments of 14 December 2006 and 8 July 2008, the Sofia City Court and the Supreme Court of Cassation upheld the Sofia District Court’s judgment of 21 February 2006, reiterating its findings. 
- The applicants were ordered to pay 1,200 new Bulgarian levs (BGN, the equivalent to 612 euros – EUR) in court fees.

title: CASE OF TYMCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and is currently serving a life sentence in Ladyzhynska prison no. 39.
- On 17 August 2005, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of two counts of murder and robbery.
- Some items belonging to the victims were found in his luggage.
- The applicant alleged that he was subjected to ill-treatment with a view to extracting his confession to the investigated criminal offences.
- The applicant confessed to one count of murder (of Ms Ch.) and the theft of her belongings.

title: CASE OF IRINA SMIRNOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1940 and lives in Donetsk.
- The applicant was offered to sell her share of a one-bedroom flat for an unusually low price but refused.
- The co-owner of her flat, her son Y. gave his half of the flat as a gift to one of the men who had offered to buy the flat from the applicant.
- The men regularly visited the flat and harassed the applicant, causing damage to her property.
- The men also installed several strangers in the flat who behaved poorly, using and damaging the applicant's belongings and creating insanitary conditions.
- The applicant was physically assaulted multiple times, causing injuries including concussions, bruising, and physical pain.
- The applicant sought legal recourse seeking to evict the man who owned half the flat, but the court only ordered dispossession of his share against payment of compensation.
- The police responded to numerous complaints by the applicant but did not take any action other than issuing warnings and advising the applicant to resolve the issues in civil proceedings.

title: CASE OF ALKAŞI v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Istanbul.
- The applicant was working as a secretary at the Directorate of National Palaces.
- The applicant was demoted following conflict with a colleague and at the request of a certain professor, M.Ü.
- The applicant accepted the offer of her friend M.G. to call professor M.Ü. and seek a reconciliation between the parties and her possible reinstatement.
- M.G. made harassing phone calls to the professor with violent threats to hurt his son, accompanied by a ransom request.
- The professor filed a criminal complaint against both M.G. and the applicant in relation to these threatening calls.
- Charges were brought on 3 December 2002 against M.G. for threatening the professor, and against the applicant for inciting M.G.
- M.G. admitted to having threatened the professor but claimed that he had had no intention of hurting anyone.
- The applicant denied M.G.’s allegations and claimed that she had never instructed him to threaten or otherwise harass the professor.
- The applicant was acquitted on the grounds of a lack of sufficient evidence to corroborate the allegations against her.
- The applicant had been dismissed from the position to which she had been demoted, without receiving payment in lieu of notice or severance pay.
- The applicant brought an action against the Directorate of National Palaces before the Bakırköy Labour Court, claiming severance pay and payment in lieu of notice on grounds of wrongful dismissal.
- The Bakırköy Labour Court rejected the applicant’s application, finding it established that the applicant had incited M.G. to commit the offences of making threats and requesting a ransom, and had breached the relationship of trust with her employer.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the decision of the Bakırköy Labour Court.

title: CASE OF DAVLYASHOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and is detained in Vinzili, Tyumen Region.
- The authorities initiated several criminal proceedings against the applicant.
- On 28 August 2012, she was arrested on suspicion of fraud.
- On 31 August 2012, the Leninskiy District Court of Tyumen remanded her in custody.
- The court extended her detention stating that she was accused of serious crimes, the crimes did not relate to the commercial sphere, another set of criminal proceedings against her was pending, and she had been convicted previously, she did not live at her place of residence, she might put pressure on witnesses, destroy or conceal evidence, re-offend, abscond or in any other way interfere with the investigation.
- It appears that criminal proceedings against the applicant are still pending.

title: CASE OF ZAUSHKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr Zaushkin was held in custody without judicial order from Nov 5 - Nov 19, 2012
- Mr Kornev's transfer from prison to house arrest was delayed from Apr 25 - May 16, 2013
- Mr Butenko remained in custody after court ordered his release on Apr 25, 2013, until higher court overturned release order on Jul 11, 2013.

title: CASE OF RÁCZ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant's personal details: born in 1955 and lives in Kiskunfélegyháza
- Applicant initiated a labour lawsuit against his employer on 1 July 2005 for unpaid remunerations
- Kecskemét Labour Court adopted a judgment on 25 February 2010, partly in favour of the applicant
- Bács-Kiskun County Court and Kúria upheld the judgment on 10 March and 16 November 2011 respectively.

title: CASE OF KÉZDISZENTKERESZTI BÍRÓ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1948 and lives in Budapest. 
- On 9 March 2006, the applicant requested an increase in her disability pension. 
- The Director of Pension Insurance dismissed her claim on 21 August 2006. 
- The applicant appealed the decision on 10 October 2006. 
- The second-instance authority upheld the first-instance decision on 4 January 2007. 
- The applicant sought judicial review of the second-instance decision on 9 February 2007. 
- The first-instance administrative authority was notified of the claim being upheld on 18 March 2010. 
- The applicant's claim was finally dismissed by the Budapest Labour Court on 14 June 2011.

title: CASE OF BAK AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
1. The case originated from an application by eleven Hungarian nationals under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.
2. The applicants were represented by a lawyer, and the Hungarian Government were represented by an agent of the Ministry of Justice.
3. The complaint under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention was communicated to the Government on 31 August 2015.
4. Friendly settlement declarations were received by the Court from the Government and seven applicants, agreeing to waive any further claims against Hungary and for the Government to pay designated amounts to cover any damage, costs, and expenses.
5. The first applicant, Mr Tibor Bak, was employed at the National Development Bank Ltd. and taxed at a 98% rate during termination of his employment.
6. The fourth applicant, Mr András Halász, was employed at the National Export-Import Bank Ltd. and also taxed at a 98% rate during termination of his employment.
7. The fifth applicant, Ms Boglárka László, was employed at MFB Investment Ltd. and taxed at a 98% rate during termination of her employment.
8. The ninth applicant, Mrs Klára Pápainé Armuth, was employed at the National Asset Management Ltd. and was taxed at a 98% rate during termination of her employment. She also received additional special tax on bonuses received after termination of employment.

title: CASE OF TEMESFŐI AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- There are eight applicants involved in the case.
- They were all accused of fraud and forgery.
- Their birth dates and places of residence are listed.
- Each applicant was heard as a suspect on a different date.
- The Budapest Prosecutor's Office preferred a bill of indictment on June 30, 2003.
- They were found guilty on May 18, 2011.
- They received different punishments ranging from reprimands, criminal fines, and probation.

title: CASE OF VUKOTA-BOJIC v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- The applicant was hit by a motorcycle while crossing the road in 1995 and was diagnosed with a cervical trauma and possible cranial trauma.
