- Her injuries resulted in total incapacity for work until the end of the year, and she was examined by doctors who predicted that she could make a gradual return to work.
- The insurance company assessed her health through various medical examinations and declared her fully capable of work with effect from February 1997.
- The insurance company informed the applicant that her entitlement to daily allowances would end on 1 April 1997, which the applicant objected to.
- The Social Insurance Court allowed the applicant’s appeal in 2000 and remitted the case for further clarifications.
- The insurance company ordered a multidisciplinary examination, which concluded that the applicant was totally incapacitated in respect of the duties required in her profession.
- The insurance company challenged this report and ordered another medical report in 2002, which observed the existence of a causal link between the accident and the damage to the applicant’s health.
- In March 2002, the competent social security authority of the Canton of Zurich granted the applicant a full disability pension with retroactive effect.
- The insurance company issued a decision confirming the termination of the applicant’s benefits as of 1 April 1997 in January 2005.
- The Social Insurance Court recognised the existence of a causal link between the accident and the health problems and allowed the applicant's appeal, which was referred to the insurance company for it to decide on the right of the applicant to insurance benefits.
- The insurance company ordered the applicant to undergo a medical evaluation, which she refused. The company then secretly monitored her on four different dates in 2006, which she only became aware of on the last day of implementation.
- The insurance company refused the applicant’s representative access to the surveillance report and refused to grant any benefits to the applicant in 2007 based on the images recorded during the surveillance and her refusal to undergo a neurological examination.
- The applicant lodged an appeal with the Social Insurance Court, which found in her favour in 2009, and the insurance company appealed to the Federal Court in 2010.
- The Federal Court ruled that the surveillance of the applicant by private investigators had been lawful and denied the probative value of the medical reports attesting to the applicant’s incapacity to work. It ordered a reassessment of her ability to work through a critical review of all previous medical reports.
- The applicant lodged a request for interpretation of the Federal Court's

title: CASE OF GAVRILOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant is a resident of Nizhniy Novgorod and was born in 1987.
2. The applicant and two minors were suspected of involvement in several car thefts.
3. The applicant was detained on remand in connection with the car thefts, and the district court upheld the detention order on appeal.
4. The applicant underwent a psychiatric examination, which found her to have a mental deficiency.
5. The district court issued several detention orders, extending the applicant's pre-trial detention.
6. The criminal case against the applicant and her co-defendants was submitted for trial before the district court in February 2008.
7. The district court decided to maintain the applicant in custody until 1 August 2008 due to the serious charges against her and the risk of pressure on co-defendants.
8. The applicant and her co-defendant were released on 11 July 2008, and the applicant was ultimately sentenced to a suspended prison term.
9. The applicant was held in a cell accommodating up to 40 people and was later transferred to a smaller cell.
10. The applicant reported being pressured by a prison staff member to retract her complaint to the court about her detention conditions.
11. The applicant's representative sought permission to visit her in the remand center, but the request was denied by the administration and courts.

title: CASE OF ZHULIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Arzamas.
- The police arrested the applicant on 5 June 2005 at around 3 a.m.
- The applicant was interviewed and taken to the hospital due to self-inflicted injuries.
- The arrest record was drawn up at 6 p.m. on the same day.
- On 7 June 2005, the Lukoyanovskiy District Court remanded the applicant in custody for an initial two-month period.
- On 8 August 2005, the District Court held a hearing on extension of the applicant’s detention and extended the detention period.
- The applicant complained that his detention in the following three days had been unlawful.
- On 23 September 2005, the Regional Court rejected the appeal in a summary fashion.
- On 25 January 2006, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 25 April 2006, without informing the applicant or his representative about the hearing or providing any reasons for the decision.
- The applicant filed an appeal on 30 January 2006, which was dismissed by the Regional Court on 31 May 2006.
- The applicant was found guilty and given a custodial sentence on 25 August 2006.

title: CASE OF MURŠIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and lives in Kuršanec.
- In a judgment of the Čakovec County Court, the applicant was sentenced to two years’ imprisonment for armed robbery in 2008 and one year’s imprisonment for theft in 2010.
- Following a request by the applicant, the Čakovec County Court sentenced him to a single term of two years and eleven months’ imprisonment.
- The applicant was transferred from a semi-open regime in Turopolje State Prison to Bjelovar County Prison in 2009 due to inappropriate behavior and threats of escape.
- The applicant alleged he was placed in overcrowded cells, badly maintained, humid, dirty, and insufficiently equipped with lockers and chairs. The sanitary facilities were in the same living area, and there was a constant smell in the cell. The prisoners were allowed to move freely outside the locked part of the prison between 4 and 7 p.m., and the out-of-cell facilities were inadequate and insufficient. The nutrition was poor, the hygiene conditions were inadequate, and the inmates did not have sufficient access to hot water.
- According to the Government, while in Bjelovar Prison, the applicant had at his disposal an average of 3.59 sq. m of personal space. He was held in four different cells.
- The Government explained that all cells had a toilet fully separated from the living area, and all cells had direct access to drinking water. The cells were constantly maintained and some necessary reconstruction work and improvements to the facilities had been carried out over the years. The inmates were provided with all necessary hygiene and sanitary facilities.
- Bjelovar Prison was equipped with a recreation area located in the courtyard, including a lawn, a gym, a basketball court, a badminton court, and ping-pong tables. The inmates were able to borrow books and use other services of the Bjelovar library, which were regularly available in the prison. Each cell was equipped with cable television and radio receivers, and the possibility of borrowing and watching films from a collection available in Bjelovar Prison. In addition, the inmates were allowed to socialize by playing board games. There was also a room for spousal visits, and the inmates were allowed to obtain various goods from outside the prison. Bjelovar Prison also offered a possibility of education in prison but the applicant had decided not to avail himself of that opportunity.
- On 26 April 2010, the applicant complained

title: CASE OF SEREBRYAKOVA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table containing the list of applicants and their relevant details is provided.
- The applicants asserted that civil proceedings took an unreasonable amount of time and that there was no appropriate solution available under domestic law.
- In application no. 54449/10, the applicant had additional complaints under the Convention's provisions.

title: CASE OF KIN AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table containing a list of applicants and their application details is appended to the document. 
- The applicants in question have raised concerns about the length of civil proceedings being excessive. 
- The lack of any effective remedy in domestic law is also being complained of. 
- One of the applicants in application no. 42373/06 has raised additional complaints as per the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF JENEI AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and relevant application details exists.
- Applicants filed a complaint.
- The complaint was about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.

title: CASE OF MÁTHÉ AND SZABÓ v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The document includes a list of applicants and their application details in an attached table.
- The applicants raised a complaint about the lengthy duration of criminal proceedings.

title: CASE OF SZEBELLÉDI AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with details in an appended table.
- The applicants have made a complaint.
- The complaint is about the excessive length of civil proceedings.

title: CASE OF KHARON KFT AND FREHA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- A table is appended containing the list of applicants and their relevant application details.
- The applicants made a complaint about the length of civil proceedings.

title: CASE OF ARA HARUTYUNYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant confesses to injuring another individual with a knife during a street fight.
- The charge against the applicant is modified to a more severe one following a forensic medical examination.
- The investigator seeks to have the applicant detained, citing the dangerousness of the offence.
- The applicant objects to detention, arguing that a written undertaking not to leave his place of residence is sufficient.
- The Regional Court grants the investigator's motion to detain the applicant.
- The applicant appeals on points of law, which is declared inadmissible for lack of merit.
- The investigator seeks to extend the applicant's detention due to the need for further investigative measures.
- The Regional Court grants the extension of the applicant's detention and dismisses the applicant's motion for release on bail.
- The Criminal Court of Appeal upholds the decision to extend the applicant's detention and to refuse his release on bail.
- The applicant files a motion seeking release on bail, which is dismissed by the Regional Court.
- The Regional Court grants a partial extension of the applicant's detention and finds it possible to replace detention with bail.
- The applicant is released upon the payment of the amount of bail fixed by the Regional Court.
- The charges against the applicant are dropped, and the criminal proceedings are terminated.

title: CASE OF RUSYN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and lives in Lviv.
- On the 29th of January 2007, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder.
- On the 1st of February 2007, the Shevchenkivskyy Court ordered his detention as a preventive measure pending trial, for an initial period of two months.
- On the 28th of March 2007, the Shevchenkivskyy Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention for two more months.
- On the 6th of July 2007, another set of criminal proceedings was instituted against the applicant, for infliction of grievous bodily harm.
- On the 10th of July 2007, the two criminal cases were joined.
- On the same day, the Court of Appeal extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention to six months.
- On the 27th of July 2007, the case was referred to the Shevchenkivskyy Court, which held a preliminary hearing on 31st August 2007.
- The Shevchenkivskyy Court remitted the case for further investigation three times (on 8th October 2007, as well as on 19th May and 18th November 2008).
- On 14th May 2009, the investigation was completed and the case was referred for trial, this time to the Court of Appeal as a first-instance court.
- On 15th June 2010, the Court of Appeal found the applicant guilty of murder and attempted murder and sentenced him to thirteen years’ imprisonment.
- On 22nd February 2011, the Supreme Court upheld that judgment.
- On 29th January 2016, the applicant was released following legislative amendments pertaining to the enforcement of sentences.

title: CASE OF SEMENENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant's personal details (born in 1982 and resides in Vinnytsia)
- Applicant suffers from emotional instability and slight mental retardation
- Ms O., a tobacco kiosk seller, was stabbed to death on 17 July 2007
- Applicant was apprehended by police two times on 19 July 2007 for separate administrative offenses
- Applicant was fined 150 Ukrainian hryvnias for resisting police on 19 July 2007
- Applicant was questioned about the murder on the same day as his apprehension (19 July 2007)
- Applicant confesses to the murder on 21 July 2007 during questioning and reconstruction of the crime
- Applicant later retracts his confession on 21 July 2007, claiming he had invented it out of fear
- Applicant is formally arrested on 23 July 2007 for Ms O.'s murder
- Leninskyy Court orders applicant's pre-trial detention on 26 July 2007
- Case is remitted for additional investigation several times, with the most recent remittal on 31 October 2013

title: CASE OF KIRŠTEINS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1927 and lives in Rīga.
- The Office of the Prosecutor General initiated new criminal proceedings against the applicant's activities during the period from 1948 to 1953.
- The applicant was suspected of having committed genocide, specifically in military operations against members of the Latvian armed resistance, collecting evidence in criminal proceedings against them, arresting them and their supporters, and collecting evidence and arresting people who had possessed anti-Soviet manuscripts.
- The applicant was detained on remand from 29 October 1999 to 28 December 1999.
- The applicant was charged with crimes against humanity and genocide on 25 November 1999.
- Seven different episodes involving thirteen alleged victims were included in the indictment.
- The hearing was postponed indefinitely on 24 October 2002 due to the responsible judge's illness.
- The Riga Regional Court held hearings on 11, 12, and 18 October 2004, and the next hearing was scheduled for 13 December 2004.
- The hearing was postponed to 21 March 2005 due to a protracted examination of another criminal case.
- The Riga Regional Court delivered its judgment on 4 April 2005, acquitting the applicant.
- The prosecutor appealed against the judgment, and the Criminal Cases Chamber of the Supreme Court quashed the first-instance court’s judgment on 19 December 2005 and remitted the case to the first-instance court.
- The Senate of the Supreme Court quashed the appellate court’s decision of 19 December 2005 and remitted the case to the appellate court on 28 April 2006.
- The appeal hearing was scheduled for 7, 8, and 9 February 2007, but the appellate court suspended the case pending an expert medical report on the applicant’s capacity to participate in the hearing and to serve a prison sentence on 7 February 2007.
- The State Centre for Forensic Medical Examination delivered the results of the forensic examination on 28 August 2007.
- The appellate court upheld the judgment of the Riga Regional Court on 7 March 2008.
- The prosecutor appealed against this decision, but the Senate of the Supreme Court upheld the decision of the appellate court on 27 August 2008.

title: CASE OF VINNIYCHUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant lost her right to occupy a flat provided to her under the protected social tenancy scheme, as she had abandoned it.
- The applicant appealed the claim, arguing that she had not abandoned the flat and had been absent from Stryy because she had been serving a prison sentence.
- The Lviv Regional Court rejected the appeal and the Applicant lost the occupancy right in respect of the flat.
- The Stryy Court ordered the eviction of the applicant.
- The Presidium of the Lviv Regional Court quashed the judgments and remitted the applicant's case to the Stryy Court for a fresh examination.
- The Lviv Regional Court of Appeal upheld the applicant's right to occupy the disputed flat, and the Supreme Court of Ukraine upheld the judgment.
- The applicant instituted civil proceedings seeking the invalidation of all the transactions in respect of the disputed flat, O.M.'s eviction and a court order allowing the applicant to move back into the flat.
- The Stryy Court ordered the City Council to provide the applicant with replacement housing unit equivalent to the flat at issue.
- The applicant identified a flat located in Sh. Street, which was vacant following the death of its former owner in January 2008, and moved into it.
- The court awarded the flat to the municipality as intestate property and allotted to the applicant the right to occupy it under the protected social tenancy scheme.
- The applicant acquired the flat from the municipality through a privatisation scheme and registered herself as the owner.

title: CASE OF GUKOVYCH v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points are:

- The applicant was stopped by officers of the municipal guard and brought to the Lviv medical sobering-up centre, in spite of the fact that he was sober.
- The applicant was confined in the centre in order to sober up.
- The applicant's mother was informed on the telephone of her son's whereabouts and invited to pick him up from the centre.
- Before being discharged, the applicant signed a report on his confinement ("the confinement report").
- The applicant complained to a doctor at Lviv Municipal Clinic No. 3 that on 20 February 2002 he had been arbitrarily confined in the sobering-up centre and beaten by officers of the municipal guard in response to his peaceful protests.
- The Lviv Regional Police addressed a letter to the applicant, indicating that the Municipal Clinic's notification to the police of 22 February 2002 concerning the applicant's complaint regarding his alleged beating had been registered in their log.
- The Lviv Prosecutor's Office stated that an inquiry into his complaints concerning the actions of the municipal guard officers and the sobering-up centre paramedic had concluded that those complaints were ill-founded.
- The applicant lodged a civil suit against the Lviv municipal guard, the municipal guard officers who had brought him to the sobering-up centre and paramedic Y.B., seeking non-pecuniary damages, alleging that his confinement had been arbitrary and that he had been ill-treated.
- The court rejected the applicant's claims as unsubstantiated.
- The Lviv Regional Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's appeal, having found that he had failed to substantiate his allegations.
- The Supreme Court of Ukraine rejected the applicant's request for leave to lodge a cassation appeal.

title: CASE OF TEICĂ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their application details is appended.
- The applicants claim that the civil proceedings were excessively long.
- Some applicants also raised complaints under other provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ARPS v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Hamburg.
- On 26 August 2004, the Zagreb Municipal State Attorney's Office indicted the applicant and another person on charges of aggravated fraud.
- The applicant was found guilty in summary proceedings on 11 February 2009 and sentenced to one year's imprisonment, suspended for four years, and to pay damages to the victims.
- The applicant appealed against her conviction and sentence, challenging all legal and factual aspects of the case.
- On 20 January 2011, the Bjelovar County Court upheld the applicant's conviction and sentence without a hearing.
- On 5 April 2011, the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court.
- On 29 September 2011, the Constitutional Court declared the applicant's constitutional complaint inadmissible.

title: CASE OF VERLAGSGRUPPE NEWS GMBH v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant company owns a weekly news magazine, Profil.
- Until 2007, the Land of Carinthia owned almost 50% of the shares of Hypo Alpe-Adria Bank, and a man named Mr. Rauscher was in charge of the treasury department of the bank.
- In 2006, the bank informed the Financial Market Authority (FMA) of its financial difficulties and losses.
- A number of daily newspapers published reports naming Mr. Rauscher as responsible for the speculative transactions in question.
- The applicant company published an article on the Hypo Alpe‑Adria Bank investigations in its news magazine Profil.
- Mr. Rauscher brought proceedings against the applicant company for disclosing his identity in breach of section 7a of the Media Act.
- The Vienna Regional Criminal Court dismissed Mr. Rauscher’s action, finding a public interest in disclosing his name.
- The Vienna Court of Appeal found that the applicant company violated Mr. Rauscher's rights by disclosing his identity, but the Supreme Court ultimately upheld the Court of Appeal's decision.

title: CASE OF OTGON v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
Facts of the Case:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Călărași.
- On 26 October 2005, the applicant and her daughter drank water from taps in their apartment and shortly thereafter they felt unwell.
- On 29 October 2005, the applicant's twelve-year-old daughter was admitted to hospital with a diagnosis of "serious acute dysentery," and the applicant was admitted to hospital with the same diagnosis on 31 October 2005. 
- The applicant sued the local utilities provider for compensation of 100,000 MDL (approximately 6,700 EUR at the time) for the harm caused to her health and for the related inconveniences.
- The Călăraşi District Court found in favor of the applicant on 1 March 2006, awarding her 10,000 MDL (approximately 648 EUR at the time).
- The parties appealed, and the Chişinău Court of Appeal partly accepted the provider's appeal, reducing the award to 5,000 MDL (310 EUR).
- The parties appealed again, but the Supreme Court of Justice upheld the judgment of 26 April 2006.

title: CASE OF CHAUSHEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1977, 1969, and 1975
- The applicants were imprisoned in Kochubeyevskoye and Aleksandria at the time of the case
- They were among 17 people facing assorted charges related to the Karachay-Circassian Jamaat
- The trial was held behind closed doors in remand prison IZ‑26/2 in Pyatigorsk on 12 April 2002
- On 11 July 2002, applicants were sentenced to ten, five, and six years respectively
- The applicants' appeal was dismissed by the Supreme Court on 14 May 2003.

title: CASE OF DZHURAYEV AND SHALKOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are from Perm, Russia and were born in 1966 and 1985, respectively.
- The first applicant was convicted of drug trafficking in 1998 and imprisoned for eight years before his sentence was expunged in 2011.
- The first applicant was involved with the Union of Tajiks in Russia and lived in Russia on temporary residence permits.
- The first applicant left Russia in May 2013 and was denied re-entry at the airport due to an exclusion order and re-entry ban under the Entry Procedure Act.
- The second applicant sent requests for information on the exclusion to multiple Russian government agencies, but none provided clear information on the exclusion order or re-entry ban.
- The applicants filed a complaint with the Leninskiy District Court of Perm that was rejected, and they later filed a complaint against the Regional FSS with the Dzerzhinsky District Court of Perm.
- The Regional FSS claimed that the exclusion and ban were based on a report that the first applicant was a member of an extremist group and incited ethnic tensions, but refused to provide further details or allow access to documents.
- The Regional Court upheld the exclusion and ban, stating that the first applicant's activities threatened State security and that interests of society outweighed private interests.
- The applicants appealed to the Supreme Court, which upheld the decision of the Regional Court, but the government did not provide clear information on the duration of the re-entry ban.
- The first applicant re-entered Russia in January 2015 and was granted a temporary residence permit, while the applicants were ordered to reimburse the Regional FSS for expenses related to the examination of their appeal.

title: CASE OF RADUNOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1982, 1967 and 1978 respectively and lived in Podgorica.
- The applicants were employees of the USA Embassy in Montenegro. 
- The first applicant worked as a protocol specialist/translator, and the second and third applicants as security guards. All the applicants were local staff. 
- The employment contract between the locally employed staff and the Embassy provided the terms and conditions under which their employment was to be conducted. The disputes were to be resolved by the Management Officer; however, the employee could appeal within 30 days of receipt of any decision to the Chief of Mission at the American Embassy.
- The first applicant was responsible for assisting in organizing official receptions, lunches, and dinners. She was also responsible for questions relevant to protocol and local customs, maintaining a contact database, drafting correspondence in English and Montenegrin, interpreting, translating documents, arranging official calls, ensuring press coverage of ceremonial events, and serving as a contact person between the front desk and the host country officials. 
- The second and third applicants’ main duties and responsibilities were continuous surveillance of an area around their fixed posts for security hazards, checking ID cards, screening visitors and vehicles, and controlling parking. They could occasionally be required to work at other locations and for special functions such as VIP visits, receptions and dinners at the Principal Officer’s Residence. 
- The dismissal of the applicants was communicated to them by the Embassy between 14 February 2009 and 28 June 2012.
- The Court of First Instance quashed the decision on the third applicant’s dismissal on 26 July 2010 and ordered his reinstatement. 
- Between 22 November 2010 and 26 July 2012, the applicants instituted separate civil proceedings against the Embassy. All the applicants claimed compensation: the first applicant sought compensation for non-pecuniary damage caused by the wrongful dismissal, and the second and third applicants claimed compensation for loss of earnings. The first and second applicants, in addition, sought reinstatement. 
- In several instances, the Court of First Instance declared that it lacked competence to deal with the applicants’ claims and rejected them, stating that the respondent State (the USA) had immunity provided for by international law, and therefore could not be subjected to the jurisdiction of another State’s court.
- Between 10 January 2013 and 12 July 2013, the applicants lodged separate constitutional appeals. On 18 November 2015, the Constitutional Court dismissed the first and third applicants

title: CASE OF CHKHIKVISHVILI v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant's Georgian nationality was revoked by a presidential decree in 2007.
2. The applicant was sentenced to custody for drug-related offences in Russia three times.
3. On October 8, 2012, the Ministry of Justice declared the applicant's presence in Russia to be undesirable.
4. The Federal Migration Service issued a deportation order against the applicant on October 11, 2012.
5. The Abakan Town Court and the Supreme Court of the Khakassiya Republic confirmed the validity of the exclusion and deportation orders in November 2012 and January 2013, respectively.
6. The Supreme Court upheld detention order but limited the detention until December 31, 2012.
7. The Abakan Town Court extended the applicant's detention to July 1, 2013, as Georgian Interests Section had not confirmed the applicant’s nationality.
8. On January 24 and April 8, 2013, the applicant’s requests for leave to appeal were rejected.
9. On November 11, 2013, the Georgian City Court quashed the decree and granted the applicant Georgian nationality.
10. The applicant obtained a Georgian passport on February 24, 2014.
11. The applicant was deported from Russia on March 3, 2014.

title: CASE OF BAŠIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The State Attorney requested special investigative measures, including phone tapping and covert monitoring, for the applicant and several other individuals suspected of involvement in organized drug trafficking, customs evasion, and abuse of authority.
- The investigating judge granted the request and issued orders for secret surveillance measures on several occasions.
- Based on evidence from the secret surveillance measures, the police accused the applicant and five others of drug trafficking and customs evasion. The applicant was detained and indicted.
- The applicant argued that the evidence obtained by secret surveillance was unlawfully obtained and should be excluded from the proceedings.
- The trial court rejected the applicant's arguments and found him guilty, sentencing him to five years in prison.
- The applicant appealed to the Supreme Court, which upheld the first-instance judgment.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court, which was dismissed as unfounded.

title: CASE OF SHUKUROV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Baku.
- The circumstances of the case are similar to those in Gahramanli and Others v. Azerbaijan.
- The applicant was nominated by the Classic wing of the Popular Front party to stand as a candidate in the parliamentary elections of 7 November 2010 in the single-mandate Zangilan-Gubadly Electoral Constituency No. 125.
- The applicant lost the election in his constituency.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Central Electoral Commission (the “CEC”) concerning a number of irregularities in his constituency that had allegedly taken place during election day.
- The CEC rejected the applicant's claims while the Baku Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeals.
- The Constitutional Court had confirmed the country-wide election results, including the election results in the applicant’s constituency, as final before the Supreme Court delivered its final decision in the applicant’s case.
- Mr Intigam Aliyev was representing not only the applicant in the present case, but also a total of twenty‑seven other applicants in cases concerning the 2010 parliamentary elections and a number of applicants in other cases before the Court.
- On 8 August 2014 criminal proceedings were instituted against Mr I. Aliyev, which are the subject of a separate application brought by him before the Court.
- On 8 and 9 August 2014 the investigation authorities seized a large number of documents from Mr I. Aliyev’s office, including all the case files relating to the proceedings pending before the Court, which were in Mr Aliyev’s possession.
- On 25 October 2014 the investigation authorities returned a number of the case files concerning the applications lodged before the Court, including the file relating to the present application, to Mr Aliyev’s lawyer.

title: CASE OF TER-SARGSYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- S.M. was stabbed by two persons and died on the way to the hospital.
- The applicant and his friend, B.M., were the main suspects.
- Eyewitnesses provided various statements about the incident.
- The applicant was charged with premeditated murder in Armenia.
- The applicant was convicted of murder and sentenced to fourteen years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF VARDANYAN AND NANUSHYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
1. The applicants are a family who lived in Yerevan in a house on a plot of land measuring 1,385.6 sq. m. in total and situated at 13 Byuzand Street.
2. The first applicant lodged a request with the Spandaryan District People’s Court of Yerevan seeking to invalidate an agreement concluded in 1933 between his grandparents and a state agency according to which their house, comprising the house itself and the plot of land, was transferred to that state agency.
3. On 19 August 1994, the Spandaryan District Court granted the claim by annulling the above agreement and recognizing the applicant as the owner of the house and the plot of land.
4. On 9 February 1995 the Civil Panel of the Supreme Court quashed the judgment of 19 August 1994 upon application by the First Deputy to the President of the Supreme Court.
5. On 22 September 1997 the Presidium of the Supreme Court quashed the judgment of 11 December 1995 and decided to grant the claim.
6. The Plenary Session of the Court of Cassation examined the decision of 22 September 1997 upon a supervisory appeal lodged by the General Prosecutor’s Office and decided to leave it in force.
7. On 18 July 2000, the Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan granted the first applicant’s claim.
8. On 1 August 2002 the Government adopted Decree no. 1151-N, approving the expropriation zones of the real estate situated within the administrative boundaries of the Kentron District of Yerevan to be taken for State needs.
9. On 19 May 2005 Tosp Ltd carried out a valuation of the immovable property situated at 13 Byuzand Street.
10. On 15 April 2005 the Agency held a meeting of its governing board, at which it was decided to issue a new type of ownership certificate to the first applicant for the house and the plot of land situated at 13 Byuzand Street.
11. On 22 November 2005 Vizkon Ltd lodged a claim on behalf of the Mayor of Yerevan against the SRER, seeking to invalidate the registration of the first applicant’s ownership of the plot of land.
12. In 2006, the Court of Cassation quashed the judgment of 27 February 2006 and remitted the case for a fresh

title: CASE OF SARKISYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The case was brought by a Russian national named Mr Gayk Levonovich Sarkisyan against the Russian Federation under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.
- The applicant was represented by lawyers from Astrakhan, namely Mr A. Anokhin and Ms M. Gordeyeva. The Government was represented by Mr G. Matyushkin, Representative of the Russian Federation at the European Court of Human Rights.
- Some of the complaints were declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court while complaints concerning Article 5 § 3 and Article 5 § 4 were communicated to the Government.
- The applicant had remained in pre-trial detention for an excessively lengthy period in violation of Article 5 § 3 of the Convention. The Government acknowledged their violation and offered to pay the applicant 1,200 euros.
- The Government invited the Court to strike the application out of the list of cases in accordance with Article 37 § 1 (c) of the Convention.

Note: The bullet point numbers in the response are not sequential with the document's bullet points because the original document skipped some numbers.

title: CASE OF POTEKHIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details provided.
- The applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- The applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KIRILCHUK AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details in appended table.
- Applicants complained of excessive length of pre-trial detention.
- Applicant in case no. 29899/09 complained about failure to speedily examine appeals against detention orders.
- Complaints made under Article 5 § 3 and Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF NAKU v. LITHUANIA AND SWEDEN
facts:
- The applicant worked at the Swedish embassy in Vilnius from 2 March 1992 to 2 January 2006.
- The applicant began as a receptionist and translator and was later promoted to be cultural, information and press officer.
- The applicant complained in a letter to the Swedish ambassador that no adjustment had been made to her contract despite managing cultural affairs and having a high degree of responsibility for financial matters.
- The contract signed by the applicant and ambassador on 19 November 2001 detailed her work description.
- The applicant submitted several letters of recommendation from her Swedish colleagues attesting to her loyalty, dedication, communication skills, and good working record.
- A new routine was introduced in 2003 and 2004 that resulted in the applicant losing her authority to deal with financial support payments. 
- The applicant was "part of the administrative technical staff at the embassy" and "did not enjoy any diplomatic immunities or privileges." 
- The applicant chaired the trade union for locally employed staff at the embassy and made several written complaints about working conditions. 
- A new post of counsellor for cultural affairs was established at the embassy, and the applicant's immediate superior, Mr T. S., considered her a source of conflict at the embassy.
- The embassy drafted a new job description for the applicant, which she did not agree with, and she expressed a wish to involve a neutral person in negotiations over her working duties.
- The embassy presented the applicant with a "letter of caution" and stated that the embassy would take other action if she did not resign.
- The Lithuanian trade union confederation organised a protest against the applicant's dismissal, and the embassy sent a decision to the applicant's home address that stated that a disciplinary sanction would be imposed on her. 
- The embassy dismissed the applicant from her post, effective as of 2 January 2006, and referred to her sick leave and accusations of gross misconduct.

title: CASE OF DZHAVADOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and is detained in Togliatti, Samara Region.
- On 19 October 2006, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of drug dealing.
- On 20 October 2006, the Samarskiy District Court of Samara remanded the applicant in custody.
- The District Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention on 18 December 2006 and 15 February 2007.
- The Samara Regional Court rejected the applicant’s appeals against the detention orders.
- On 1 June 2007, the Bolshechernigovskiy District Court of the Samara Region convicted the applicant of drug trafficking and sentenced him to 11 years’ imprisonment and a fine. On 21 August 2007, the Samara Regional Court upheld his conviction on appeal.

title: CASE OF ADAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Achkhoy-Martan, Chechen Republic. 
- Two soldiers of the Russian federal forces came to the applicant’s house to buy drugs on 13 January 2001. 
- After the applicant sold heroin to them, unknown persons attacked the soldiers and took them to a hide-out where they were kept for five days. 
- On an unspecified date, the authorities opened a criminal investigation into the soldiers’ abduction, and the applicant was the only suspect.
- The applicant was arrested on 4 April 2007 on suspicion of having participated in the abduction. 
- The district court authorized the applicant's detention on 6 April 2007. 
- The investigators questioned the soldiers, who identified the applicant as one of the abductors. 
- On 26 June 2007, the district court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to seven years’ imprisonment. 
- The Supreme Court of the Chechen Republic upheld the applicant’s conviction on appeal on 15 August 2007. 
- The applicant was released from prison on 26 December 2011. 
- M.'s automatic gun was never found. 
- The court relied on the victim's written statement since they were unable to appear in court due to extraordinary circumstances.

title: CASE OF ŠILOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and resides in Beograd.
- On 10 June 2002, the applicant filed a claim for certain benefits with the former Supreme Military Court in Belgrade.
- On 10 August 2007, the Supreme Court of Serbia took over jurisdiction of the Supreme Military Court in Belgrade.
- The Supreme Court of Serbia rejected the applicant's claim.
- The applicant received the judgment on 2 October 2007.

title: CASE OF URBŠIENĖ AND URBŠYS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1963 and 1964 and live in Kaunas
- First applicant was the owner of a private unlimited liability company
- Another company filed a claim against the applicant's company to recover rent arrears for its premises
- The court ordered the first applicant's company to pay a total of 211,883 LTL to the claimant company
- The first applicant appealed, and the Court of Appeal remitted the case to the court of first instance for fresh examination
- The first applicant brought a counterclaim for LTL 167,018, alleging that the claimant company had failed to fulfil its contractual obligations
- The Kaunas Regional Court allowed the claim and a part of the counterclaim, ordering the first applicant's company to pay LTL 211,884 and the claimant company LTL 5,295
- The Court of Appeal increased the sum to be paid by the claimant company to LTL 8,103
- The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision
- The Kaunas Regional Court instituted bankruptcy proceedings in respect to the first applicant's company
- The second applicant asked the domestic courts to reopen the rent arrears proceedings and to suspend the bankruptcy proceedings
- The Kaunas Regional Court refused to reopen the proceedings
- The Court of Appeal returned the case to the court of first instance for fresh examination
- The Kaunas Regional Court decided to reopen the rent arrears proceedings and joined them to the bankruptcy proceedings
- The rent arrears case was examined, and the second applicant's request to have the decision of the Kaunas Regional Court of 8 April 2002 quashed was rejected
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Kaunas Regional Court of 20 June 2005 not to quash the decision of the Kaunas Regional Court of 8 April 2002 regarding the payment of rent arrears
- The applicants appealed against the decision
- The Supreme Court observed that the reopened case concerned only procedural aspects and that the merits had not been examined at all
- Both applicants' requests for legal aid were denied
- The Kaunas Regional Court separated the bankruptcy case from the rent arrears case
- Both applicants requested that the Court of Appeal transfer the bankruptcy and rent arrears cases to the Vilnius Regional Court
- The requests were dismissed by the Court of Appeal
- The applicants submitted two requests for legal aid, which were rejected
- The examination of the rent

title: CASE OF EL GHATET v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- First applicant was born in 1952, lives in Switzerland and obtained Swiss nationality in 2004.
- Second applicant was born in 1990, is the son of the first applicant and lives in Egypt.
- First applicant entered Switzerland in 1997 and applied for asylum, which was rejected.
- First applicant married a Swiss national in 1999 and had a daughter in 2000.
- Second applicant visited his father in Switzerland in 2002 and returned for family reunification in July 2003.
- First applicant requested family reunification with the second applicant in 2006, which was rejected by the Migration Office of the Canton of Aargau.
- The Legal Unit of the Migration Office of the Canton of Aargau granted the appeal in 2007.
- The Federal Office of Migration refused consent for family reunification in 2008.
- The Federal Administrative Court dismissed the appeal in 2010.
- The Federal Supreme Court dismissed the appeal in 2010, citing negative effects on the second applicant's personal and social ties if he moved to Switzerland.

title: CASE OF PROHASKA PRODANIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants complain about the excessive length of civil and criminal proceedings under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
- All applicants received decisions from the Constitutional Court of Serbia, finding a violation of their right to a hearing within a reasonable time.
- The Constitutional Court declared that the applicants were entitled to non-pecuniary damages sought under Article 90 of the Constitutional Court Act.
- Applicants filed requests with the Commission for Compensation for payment of non-pecuniary damages.
- The Commission offered to pay Ms Prohaska Prodanić RSD 60,000 and RSD 25,000 for costs and expenses, but she refused due to the unspecified deadline.
- Applicant V. Tomić contacted the Commission for Compensation several times about non-pecuniary damage payments but received no response.
- The Commission offered to pay Mr D. Trpković RSD 35,000, which he refused to accept as he considered it insufficient.

title: CASE OF PÖNKÄ v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant was convicted of murder by the Harju County Court in Estonia on 19 February 2007.
- The applicant argued that he had shot the victim in self-defence, but the domestic court dismissed his argument.
- The applicant was transferred to Finland to serve his prison sentence.
- The owner of the apartment where the applicant had committed the crime brought a civil action against the applicant.
- The plaintiff claimed compensation for various items damaged or lost as a consequence of the offence, in the amount of 28,259 kroons (corresponding to approximately 1,806 euros).
- The case was dealt with in simplified and written proceedings, and the County Court accepted the plaintiff's claim in part.
- The Tallinn Court of Appeal refused to accept the applicant's appeal, stating that the County Court had examined the case in simplified proceedings and had guaranteed the applicant an opportunity to present his position to the court.
- The Supreme Court decided not to examine the applicant's appeal against the Court of Appeal's decision.

title: CASE OF KRAULAIDIS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
-Facts of the Case-

• The applicant was born in 1985 and is from Vilnius.
• On 28th April 2006, the applicant was involved in a collision with a car driven by M.N. in a Vilnius residential area, resulting in serious spinal injuries.
• The police department opened a pre-trial investigation concerning a possible violation of road traffic safety regulations.
• M.N. was interviewed, stating that he had checked for traffic before overtaking cars and had not seen the motorcycle before the collision.
• The investigator examined the scene of the accident and the vehicles.
• Blood tests were carried out to see if either party had been drinking.
• The applicant was granted victim status in the investigation and questioned about the details of the accident.
• A court medical expert concluded that the applicant’s injuries corresponded to severe health impairment.
• The legal ground for the pre-trial investigation changed to ‘violation of road traffic safety regulations,’ resulting in an accident causing severe impairment to another person’s health.
• Eyewitnesses provided differing accounts of the events leading up to the collision.
• A forensic expert was instructed to examine the circumstances of the accident and establish an account of the events.
• An internal inquiry was opened concerning the absence of the drivers’ signatures from the sketch of the accident.
• Two expert reports concluded that the accident had been caused by the applicant.
• The district prosecutor discontinued the pre-trial investigation on the grounds that M.N.’s actions had not amounted to a crime as provided for by Article 281 § 3 of the Criminal Code.

title: CASE OF MUREŞAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is currently detained in Baia Mare Prison and was born in 1959.
- He was investigated in 2002 for embezzlement, forgery, and abuse of his official position and indicted in 2003.
- In 2011, he was convicted of the crimes and sentenced to seven years of imprisonment.
- He appealed the judgment but it was rejected in 2012.
- He started serving his sentence in Gherla Prison in 2012 and was later transferred to Baia Mare Prison.
- He suffered from type II diabetes, hypertension, ischaemic heart disease, biliary lithiasis, and lumbar discopathy.
- He was allowed to take a glucometer, test strips, needles, and several drugs to his cell when he was admitted to Gherla Prison.
- He was taken to the medical ward eighteen times and had a special diet for diabetics during his stay in Gherla Prison.
- He received medication from the prison infirmary and his glycaemia levels were measured regularly.
- Forensic medical examinations concluded that his diseases could be treated within the prison system.
- In Baia Mare Prison, he was examined at the prison’s infirmary and taken for specialist diabetes and nutrition examinations at the hospital.
- He was given insulin and drugs for his hypertension as well as other medication as needed and according to doctors’ prescriptions.
- He was transferred sixteen times between detention facilities, hospitals, and courts, where he was transported in special vehicles that met the legal comfort requirements.
- He was allowed to take his personal glycaemia kit and medication during transport and was provided with food, water, and bathroom breaks.
- Smoking was strictly prohibited in the vehicles.
- He made no complaints concerning his medical treatment, but alleged that he had been transported in conditions that had not allowed him to take his insulin and that the food provided during transport had not been adapted to his diabetes.
- The prison authorities provided him with a diabetic menu and allowed him to receive food packages that he could take with him during transport.

title: CASE OF SZANYI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was a Member of Parliament and a member of the largest opposition party at the material time.
- During a session, the applicant made remarks and showed his left middle finger in the direction of the Jobbik MPs.
- The Speaker initiated disciplinary proceedings against the applicant and proposed a fine, which was later adopted by the plenary without any remedy available.
- The applicant submitted an interpellation concerning the publication of the list of successful bidders in the national tender for tobacco retail licenses.
- The interpellation was refused by the Speaker, and no remedy lay against the decision. The applicant submitted a further interpellation on the same topic, which was also refused with similar reasoning.

title: CASE OF USTINOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1984 and moved to Russia in the early 2000s.
- In 2008, the applicant started living with A.U., a Russian national, in the Krasnodar Region.
- On 16 March 2012, the applicant and A.U. were married, and on 23 August 2012, their son was born in Russia.
- On 30 March 2013, the Russian Border Control Service handed the applicant a notice informing her that she would not be allowed to re-enter Russia. The notice did not specify the grounds for that decision.
- In April 2013, the applicant's husband obtained a copy of an exclusion order issued on 9 June 2012, which declared the applicant's presence in Russia as undesirable. The exclusion was based on the applicant's positive HIV status, which was reported by the hospital to the Consumer Protection Authority (CPA).
- The applicant's husband challenged the exclusion order before the Russian courts, but all court judgments upheld the order.
- The applicant and her daughter eventually took up residence in Ukraine, while her husband and son lived in Russia.
- On 12 March 2015, the Constitutional Court ruled that migration laws can lawfully restrict access to Russia by non-Russian nationals whose medical condition might jeopardize public health and pose a threat to national security.
- On 22 October 2015, the Krasnodar Regional Court ruled the exclusion order unlawful and directed the CPA to redress the effects of the violation.
- The applicant re-entered Russia on 17 August 2015 and was issued a temporary residence permit on 18 May 2016. The CPA informed the Border Control Service about the annulment of the exclusion order and measures were being taken to remove her name from the list of persons who should be refused entry to Russia.

title: CASE OF MYALICHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1974 and lived in the Sverdlovsk Region.
- On April 6, 2012, the Leninskiy District Court in Nizhniy Tagil issued a detention order against the applicant for murder charge.
- Applicant absconded and the detention order was valid for an initial of two months after arresting him.
- On February 19, 2013, the applicant was apprehended in China and extradited to Russia.
- On April 30, 2013, the Leninskiy district prosecutor asked the District Court to extend the applicant’s detention for a further two months.
- On the same day, the District Court extended the authorized detention period until May 19.
- The applicant filed an appeal, stating that he had been unlawfully detained since the initial two-month detention period had already expired on 19 April 2013.
- On June 10, 2013, the Sverdlovsk Regional Court rejected the appeal.
- On September 26, 2013, a judge refused the applicant leave to appeal to the regional cassation instance.
- On March 4, 2014, a judge of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation refused the applicant leave to appeal to the Supreme Court.

title: CASE OF ZADONSKIY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were convicted by Russian courts.
- They were given custodial sentences.
- They served their sentences in overcrowded penitentiary facilities.
- Penitentiary facilities suffered from a shortage of sanitary installations.

title: CASE OF MAGYAR HELSINKI BIZOTTSÁG v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant NGO, Magyar Helsinki Bizottság, is a non-governmental organisation founded in 1989.
- The NGO conducted a project between 2005 and 2007 aimed at developing and testing a model to overcome shortcomings in the system for the ex-officio appointment of defence counsel.
- In 2008, the NGO initiated a new project entitled “The Right to Effective Defence and the Reform of the ex-Officio Appointment System”.
- The NGO carried out continuous advocacy activities for reform of the ex officio appointments system.
- The NGO assessed that the system of ex officio appointed defenders did not operate adequately.
- The NGO requested the names of the public defenders selected in 2008 from twenty-eight police departments.
- Seventeen police departments complied with the request; a further five police departments disclosed the requested information following a successful legal challenge by the applicant NGO.
- The Hajdú-Bihar County Police Department and Debrecen Police Department refused the NGO's request, citing that the names of defence counsel were personal data.
- The NGO brought an action against the two police departments in 2009.
- In October 2009, the first-instance court found for the applicant NGO, ordering the respondents to release the relevant information within 60 days.
- Both police departments appealed, and the second-instance court overturned the first-instance judgment.
- The applicant NGO's petition for review of the second-instance judgment was dismissed by the Supreme Court on 15 September 2010.

title: CASE OF KOVACHEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Yambol.
- The applicant and his brother had a co-owned property that was expropriated for construction.
- The original decision stated that the brothers would be compensated with flats in a building, which was constructed and delivered to them.
- A modification was made to the decision in 1994, stating that the brothers were also to be compensated with a common garage.
- The applicant's brother renounced his right to compensation with a garage in the applicant's favour.
- The applicant was later compensated with the right to build a garage on municipal land.
- The original decision was modified in 2002 to indicate another municipal plot of land for the garage to be built on.
- The applicant brought a tort action against the municipality in 2010, claiming a wrongful failure to provide him with a garage, but the action was dismissed.
- The applicant eventually agreed to receive compensation in cash in lieu of the garage due to him, and it was paid to him in 2012.

title: CASE OF AVETISYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and was serving a sentence of imprisonment at the time of application.
- The applicant, together with his friends, went to visit a prisoner in a penitentiary institution but were only allowed to hand over a parcel to be delivered to him.
- Inspection of the parcel revealed the presence of a disposable syringe filled with narcotics.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant, and he was charged with illegal acquisition and supply of narcotics in large amounts.
- Witnesses were questioned during the investigation and trial, but some of them did not appear in court, and their pre-trial statements were read out. 
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to imprisonment, and his appeal was dismissed.

title: CASE OF KALEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant's father's house and yard were expropriated in 1987 for the purpose of constructing embassy buildings.
- The decision specified that the applicant's father would receive a two-room flat and the applicant would receive a three-room flat as compensation.
- The flats were to be located in a building to be constructed by the Bureau for Servicing the Diplomatic Corps (BSDC).
- The construction plan for the building was canceled in 1991.
- The applicant's father passed away in 1996, and the applicant was eventually allocated a bigger flat than originally offered.
- The applicant repeatedly requested a suitable flat in lieu of the one originally offered and turned down several proposals from the BSDC.
- The applicant requested compensation from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, successor to the BSDC, in accordance with section 103(5) of the TUPA, which was eventually granted by the Supreme Administrative Court in 2008.
- The mayor never took a decision on the applicant's request for re-compensation.
- The applicant's mother was evicted from her apartment and died in 2007.
- The applicant filed a formal request for re-compensation again in 2014.

title: CASE OF GASIMOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
1. The applicant's daughter, S.J., was married to an officer of the Ministry of National Security.
2. S.J. brought a civil action against her husband for divorce in November 2006 which was pending before the Binagadi District Court.
3. On 15 November 2006, S.J. fell from the balcony of a flat on the seventh floor of a block of flats and was admitted to the Clinical Medical Centre with traumatic brain injury, blunt trauma of the stomach, fractures of various bones, and traumatic shock.
4. S.J. died on 20 November 2006 at the Oil Workers’ Hospital.
5. Criminal proceedings were instituted under Article 125 (incitement to suicide) of the Criminal Code by the Binagadi district prosecutor’s office on 16 November 2006.
6. Various people, including the applicant, S.J.’s husband, colleagues, and relatives, were questioned as witnesses.
7. On 6 February 2007, the criminal case was assigned to the Baku city prosecutor’s office.
8. Forensic reports showed that S.J.’s death resulted from traumatic shock caused by rupture of the bladder and numerous bone fractures, and there were toxic changes in S.J.’s liver and digestive organs.
9. The cause of death was “general poisoning” (ümumi intoksikasiya) which had resulted from endogenic toxic substances developed in the body owing to multiple traumas and toxic substances introduced into the digestive organs.
10. It was confirmed that some of the injuries found on S.J.’s body could not have been sustained as a result of a fall and had been inflicted by a blunt object beforehand.
11. The applicant repeatedly requested that the prosecuting authorities reclassify the case as murder under Article 120 of the Criminal Code, but all requests were rejected.
12. The criminal case was terminated on 28 December 2011, but the decision was overruled by the court on 6 March 2012.
13. The investigator again decided to terminate the criminal proceedings on 30 November 2012 relying on the same grounds.

title: CASE OF KOVACHEVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1948 and lives in Sofia.
- The applicant was one of the co-owners of a house with a yard in the town of Troyan.
- The property was expropriated on 15 March 1983, and the applicant was to be compensated with a three-room flat.
- By a supplementary order of 27 March 1990, the mayor determined the exact location, size, and other details of the future flat to be offered to the applicant.
- The applicant and other owners continued occupying the expropriated house, and she kept some of her possessions there.
- In 2003, the building where the applicant's flat was initially to be located was finished, but no flat could be offered to the applicant.
- In April 2001, the municipality issued a building permit to construct a new building with flats.
- On 13 January 2004, the mayor issued a new decision revoking the previous decision of 27 March 1990, indicating the exact flat in the new building to be provided to the applicant in compensation.
- Even after a final judgment of the Supreme Administrative Court in November 2007, the applicant challenged the decision of 13 January 2004 before the courts.
- In 2005, the applicant sought the revocation of the 1983 expropriation order, which was ultimately dismissed by the Supreme Administrative Court on 24 July 2009.
- The applicant was evicted from the expropriated house in September 2009.
- The house was pulled down, and construction works on the site started in April 2011.
- The building was finished in 2014, and the applicant was invited to receive the keys to her flat, which she refused.

title: CASE OF KURIPKA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and is currently serving a prison sentence.
- At the time of the events, the applicant had previous convictions from 1983 and 1989.
- The applicant cohabited with T.B. in the village of Blahovishchenka, in the Zaporizhzhya Region
- On the evening of 24 April 2006, the applicant stabbed Sh. in the chest.
- The applicant was taken to the police station and confessed to stabbing Sh. twice in the chest and abdominal area.
- The applicant was denied his right to a lawyer during questioning on 28 April 2006.
- The applicant was charged with aggravated murder and sentenced to life imprisonment on 8 August 2006.
- The applicant's sentence was reduced to fifteen years’ imprisonment due to efforts to provide the victim with medical assistance.
- The applicant filed two unsuccessful requests to correspond with his relatives and complained to a prosecutor without receiving a response.

title: CASE OF SITNEVSKIY AND CHAYKOVSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The first and second applicant are serving life sentences in different regions in Ukraine.
- Mr A.B. formed an armed gang consisting of the applicants, other former and active police officers, and two other individuals.
- The gang was convicted of various attacks in four regions and participation in an armed gang.
- The attacks were initially investigated by authorities as unrelated crimes committed by unidentified people.
- The applicants made pre-trial statements, including confessing to various crimes.
- Co-defendants also made statements implicating the applicants in various crimes.
- The co-defendants later retracted their statements, but the trial court ruled that the statements could still be used based on corroborating evidence.
- The court found that the applicants’ pre-trial statements were not obtained under physical or psychological duress.
- Various witnesses and victims could not be brought to court, and their pre-trial statements were read out instead.
- The applicants lodged appeals and supplementary appeals against their conviction, but the Supreme Court upheld their conviction and sentence.

title: CASE OF HOMAN D.O.O. v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant company is a limited liability company incorporated under Croatian law, with its seat in Zagreb.
- The applicant company filed civil proceedings against the Croatian Health Insurance Fund for the unjustifiable seizure of HRK 11,500 from its bank account.
- Sixteen hearings were scheduled for the case, of which six were adjourned upon the applicant company’s request.
- The court suspended the proceedings on 6 November 2006 when the applicant company’s director failed to attend the hearing without any reasons. The proceedings continued upon the request of the applicant company on 21 February 2007.
- By a decision on 2 March 2010, the Municipal Court declared that the applicant company’s action was to be considered withdrawn.
- The Zagreb County Court dismissed an appeal lodged by the applicant company against the first-instance decision.
- The applicant company lodged a request for the protection of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time.
- By a decision of 13 July 2011, the Supreme Court found a violation of the applicant company’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time and awarded it HRK 5,000 in compensation.
- The applicant company appealed against the decision of the Supreme Court, which was dismissed on 6 September 2012.
- The subsequent constitutional complaint lodged by the applicant company was declared inadmissible by the Constitutional Court on 31 January 2013.

title: CASE OF MATIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1936 and lives in Kragujevac.
- On 13 December 2006, the applicant filed a civil claim as an injured party in criminal proceedings.
- On 18 November 2010, the Kragujevac Court of First Instance delivered the first instance judgment.
- On 20 October 2011, the Kragujevac Appellate Court delivered the second instance judgment, which was received by the applicant on 7 November 2011.
- On 18 February 2014, the Constitutional Court of Serbia rejected the applicant’s constitutional appeal.

title: CASE OF GORYACHKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. Applicant convicted of aggravated robbery in 2005 and sent to serve sentence in a correctional colony
2. Multiple episodes of alleged ill-treatment by guards in 2008, including beatings, handcuffing to ceiling, and forced statement denying ill-treatment
3. Applicant suffered from various health issues during detention, treated by prison doctor, and subjected to routine daily check-ups for bodily injuries
4. Complaints of ill-treatment investigated and dismissed multiple times by prosecutor's office, but later overturned for lack of thoroughness
5. Applicant also lodged claims for poor detention conditions and inadequate medical care, but courts dismissed claims and denied his presence at hearings due to lack of legal provision for transporting inmates to civil courts.

title: CASE OF PANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant is currently serving a sentence in a correctional colony in the Tambov region.
• On 17 July 2007, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of robbery, and the Meshchanskiy District Court of Moscow authorised his detention the next day. 
• On September 6, 2007, the Taganskiy District Court extended the detention, which was later upheld on appeal by the Moscow City Court on October 22, 2007. 
• The applicant appealed against two other detention orders on 16 October 2007 and 11 December 2007. 
• On 17 January 2008, the applicant was convicted as charged and sentenced to nine years in prison, while the conviction became final on March 19, 2008. 
• On July 2, 2008, the City Court informed the applicant that his appeal against the detention order of 16 October 2007 was not received by the City Court but later forwarded his appeal statement lodged on October 17, 2007, to the District Court. 
• No further information about the organisation of the appeal hearing against the detention order of 16 October 2007 was provided.

title: CASE OF GORBATENKO AND SHEYDYAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1964 and 1975 and lived in Moscow.
- On 5 April 2005, they were found guilty of extortion and sentenced to a custodial sentence.
- On 31 October 2005, the Moscow City Court upheld their conviction on appeal.
- On 26 January 2006, the Presidium of the City Court quashed the judgment for formal defects and ordered a new hearing, but did not mention the defendants’ detention.
- On 26 July 2006, a new appeal hearing was held, the initial conviction was quashed, and a re-trial was ordered. The preventive measure was maintained.
- On 31 August 2006, the District Court returned the case and extended the applicants' detention, referring to the gravity of the charges, but without setting a time-limit. 
- Further extensions of detention were approved by the District Court on different dates throughout 2007. 
- On 11 October 2007, the District Court found the defendants guilty and sentenced them to a custodial sentence.

title: CASE OF MISIUKONIS AND OTHERS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
1. The first and second applicants are a married couple, born in 1940 and 1942 respectively and living in Kaunas; their daughter, the third applicant, was born in 1977 and lives in France.
2. In 2001, the Vilnius County Administration restored title in respect of 0.728 hectares of land to G.O. that had belonged to his father and had been nationalized by the Soviet regime.
3. G.O. sold his right to restoration of title in respect of that plot of land in equal parts to the three applicants and V.M. (the first and second applicants’ son, and the third applicant’s brother).
4. The applicants and V.M. were provided with four plots of land in Vilnius in June/July 2001. 
5. In August/September 2001, the applicants sold their plots to third parties for LTL 25,000 each. 
6. In October 2001, a pre-trial investigation was opened concerning allegations of fraud in connection with the restoration of property rights in the Vilnius Region. 
7. V.M. was interviewed as a witness during the investigation and made statements which were later retracted.
8. The prosecutor lodged a claim in January 2002 asking for the administrative decisions to be overturned due to the applicants having received priority rights unlawfully.
9. The court found that the applicants had the right to receive one plot of land of up to 0.2 ha, instead of the three plots they had received, and overturned the administrative decisions.
10. The applicants were ordered to return the plots of land they had received, and to pay the State the market value of that land, estimated to be LTL 216,000 (EUR 62,560) each, for a total of LTL 648,000 (EUR 187,680).
11. The applicants appealed against the judgment but their appeal was dismissed by the Vilnius Regional Court.
12. The Supreme Court also dismissed their cassation appeal.
13. The applicants submitted a claim against the State for pecuniary damages but this was also dismissed by the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court and the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF FEDORIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Samara.
- The applicant was apprehended by drug police officers during a test purchase of drugs from him.
- He was brought to their premises where he was detained in a cell with no facilities, such as bed, light, lavatory, and running water.
- He was not provided with food or drink and was not permitted to use the toilet.
- The arrest record was drawn after he was already detained.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of Samara remanded the applicant in custody on 16 October 2009.
- The District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 15 January 2010 on 11 December 2009.
- The Samara Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 22 December 2009, and later upheld his conviction on May 4th, 2010.

title: CASE OF BEGO AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicants are owners of flats in Split occupied by protected lessees
- The applicants brought civil actions seeking compensation for the difference between protected rent and market rent
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicants' constitutional complaints
- Amount of monthly protected rent changed after entry into force of Convention
- Condominium fees have not changed for some applicants
- Applicants never paid income tax on income generated by renting out flats
- Applicants provided information on monthly market rent for flats in their vicinity

title: CASE OF PONYAYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Natalya Sergeyevna Ponyayeva and her two daughters.
- The flat at 83-3-4 Ulitsa Svobody, Moscow, had been owned by the City of Moscow and was given to Ol. under a social housing agreement.
- Ol. was accused of making a fake terror threat, was sent to a psychiatric institution for treatment while someone applied for a new passport and issued powers of attorney for Ol.’s flat.
- Ol.’s title to the flat was transferred to him under a privatisation scheme, which was later acquired by B. and K. who sold it to the first applicant.
- As a result of a civil claim by the inter-district prosecutor on behalf of Ol. and the Housing Department, the court found that Ol.’s signatures had been forged and the title to the flat was given back to the City of Moscow.
- The court recognised Ol.’s right to reside in the flat and ordered the applicants’ eviction but the applicants appealed.
- On appeal, the judgment of 2 July 2010 was upheld and according to the Government, the title to the flat was not transferred to the City of Moscow, and the applicants continued to reside in the flat.

title: CASE OF LELYUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant born in 1979 and lives in Donetsk.
- Applicant found guilty of robbery and sentenced to three years’ imprisonment on 29 May 1997 by Donetsk Kirovskyy District Court.
- Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal granted amnesty to the applicant on 18 July 1997.
- The Regional Court quashed the decision of amnesty on 26 September 1997 and upheld the judgement of 29 May 1997.
- The applicant became aware of the Regional Court’s decision only after his arrest in February 2003.
- The applicant was arrested by Kirovskyy police at his home on 12 February 2003 to serve his sentence.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Kirovskyy Court in March 2003, stating that his arrest and detention had been unlawful and requesting to be released.
- On 23 March 2006, the Kirovskyy Court found the police officers' actions unlawful and released the applicant.
- On 27 April 2005, the Dzerzhynskyy Local Court ordered the applicant’s release on parole.
- The applicant lodged a claim for damages against the Ministry of the Interior.
- On 3 April 2007, the Kirovskyy Court rejected his claim as unfounded, and on 26 June 2007, the Regional Court upheld that decision.
- On 22 August 2007, the applicant’s representative appealed on points of law, and on 6 September 2007, the Supreme Court gave the applicant a deadline to submit the power of attorney.
- On 30 October 2007, the Supreme Court returned the applicant’s appeal on points of law without examination.
- On 3 December 2007, G. requested that the Supreme Court gives reasons for the dismissal of the applicant’s appeal on points of law, and there was no reply.

title: CASE OF PCHELINTSEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals who were owners of flats in Moscow.
- The State authorities reclaimed the flats, and their title to the real property was annulled.
- Some of the applicants have been evicted from the property, while in other cases, eviction proceedings are still pending or were discontinued.
- The case involves several instances where the flat was sold or transferred after the death of the previous owner.
- The City of Moscow brought civil claims seeking invalidation of the property transactions and the eviction of the applicants.
- The courts ruled in favor of the City of Moscow, annulling the applicants' title to the flats and ordering their eviction, except in one case where the applicants continue to reside in the flat under a social tenancy agreement.
- The courts acknowledged that the applicants were bona fide purchasers of the flats but ruled that precedence should be given to the City of Moscow as the previous owner of the property.

title: CASE OF ALENTSEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Moscow.
- Before privatisation, the flat was owned by the City of Moscow and the deceased resided there as a tenant under a social housing agreement.
- The title to the flat was transferred to the deceased under a privatisation scheme.
- Yar. applied to be recognised as the deceased's heir and submitted a will allegedly signed by the deceased on 9 February 1996.
- The notary granted the request and issued a certificate confirming Yar.'s inheritance of the flat.
- Yar. sold the flat to the applicant, who then resided there with her daughter.
- Yar. was found guilty of fraud and sentenced to imprisonment and confiscation of property.
- The prosecutor brought a civil claim seeking the annulment of the will and the applicant's title to the flat, eviction of the applicant, restitution of the flat, and annulment of the purchase agreement between Yar. and the applicant.
- The District Court granted the prosecutor's claims in full but was later overturned by the Moscow City Court due to the applicant not being duly informed of the hearing.
- In the new set of proceedings, the applicant brought a counterclaim seeking to be recognised as a bona fide purchaser of the flat.
- The lower court invalidated the will, found the property to be escheat, ordered its restitution to the City of Moscow, and ordered the applicant's eviction.
- The appeal court upheld the lower court's decision.
- The applicant and her daughter were evicted from the flat.
- The flat was reassigned to someone else on the waiting list for social housing.
- The District Court recognised the City's title to the flat and terminated the applicant's title to the flat.

title: CASE OF LOBODA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a farmer and head of a farming company living in Borzna. 
- A newly-appointed head of a private agricultural company requested an investigation into the suspected misappropriation of their property. 
- The applicant admitted to receiving twenty concrete slabs from another agricultural company in the settlement of a debt to the private agricultural company. 
- The prosecutor instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant on suspicion of fraudulently appropriating slabs. 
- The applicant was indicted for the fraudulent appropriation of twenty concrete slabs. 
- The applicant presented an agreement signed by the directors of three companies that agreed to the transaction. 
- During the trial, the applicant reiterated that he had no fraudulent intent and that the transaction was properly accounted for in paperwork. 
- The District Court found the applicant guilty but granted him amnesty and released him from punishment. 
- The Court of Appeal upheld the applicant’s conviction. 
- The Supreme Court rejected the applicant’s cassation appeal, finding no breaches of the provisions of the criminal-procedure law. 
- The applicant made unsuccessful attempts to challenge various procedural omissions.

title: CASE OF KORNILOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lived in Olekminsk, Sakha (Yakutia) Republic.
- On 23 December 2008, he was arrested on suspicion of murder.
