- On 25 December 2008, he was remanded in custody by the Olekminskiy District Court.
- The court extended the applicant's pre-trial detention on six different occasions.
- On 27 November 2009, the court replaced the pre-trial detention with a house arrest.
- On 10 June 2010, the Olekminskiy District Court convicted the applicant of murder and sentenced him to 8 years’ imprisonment.
- On 10 August 2010, the Supreme Court of Russia upheld his conviction on appeal.

title: CASE OF VASILYADI v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was arrested in 2007 for drug trafficking.
2. Despite being diagnosed with tuberculosis, the applicant was remanded in custody.
3. The court frequently extended the applicant's detention citing the gravity of the charges and the possibility of absconding or re-offending.
4. The applicant's medical condition progressed; and he was taken to the prison hospital in Rostov-on-Don.
5. The applicant was prescribed treatment but his condition continued to worsen.
6. On health grounds, the applicant was released from detention on 10 November 2010, and four days later he died of tuberculosis.

title: CASE OF GVINIASHVILI v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1979 and is currently serving a sentence in correctional colony no. IK-1 in Penza.
• In the early morning of 7 August 2007, the applicant stabbed a man in the leg during a drunken fight. Several hours later, the victim died in the hospital from massive blood loss.
• The applicant was arrested on the same day of the incident, and two days later, he was remanded in custody by the Salsk Town Court, Rostov Region.
• On the day of the incident, a medical expert performed an autopsy of the victim and concluded that the victim died from blood loss between midnight and 4 a.m. on 6 August 2007.
• The next day, without informing the applicant or his lawyer, the investigator asked the expert to carry out a repeat examination of the body, which concluded that the victim had died between midnight and 4 a.m. on 7 August 2007.
• The applicant's defense at trial was self-defense against the unlawful actions of the victim, but the prosecution disputed that version of events with the testimony of six people who had witnessed the incident.
• In 2008 and 2009, the applicant's detention was extended several times due to the seriousness of the charges, negative references about the applicant’s character, and the "need to proceed with the trial."
• On 13 May 2009, the trial court convicted the applicant of unintentional killing and sentenced him to eight and a half years’ imprisonment. The judgment was based on the in-court testimony of six prosecution witnesses, the second autopsy report, and the expert’s testimony.
• In 2012, the applicant developed acute rhinitis, anxiety disorder, and chronic noninflammatory prostatitis, for which he received medical treatment.

title: CASE OF ORTSUYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are close relatives of persons who disappeared as a result of a military operation.
- A large-scale "sweeping-up" operation was conducted by Russian federal military forces in Mesker-Yurt between 21 May and 11 June 2002.
- The circumstances of all the abductions are similar.
- The federal forces had set up checkpoints on the roads leading to and from the settlement.
- The servicemen, who spoke Russian without an accent, checked the residents' identity documents.
- After the check, they took some of the residents away, including the applicants' relatives, under the pretext of needing to carry out further identity checks.
- The majority of the applicants' relatives were taken away between 21 May and 5 June 2002, either from their homes or from the local mosque.
- The applicants have had no news of their missing relatives ever since.
- The military unit conducting the special operation in Mesker-Yurt left the place where they had been stationed as well as the temporary filtration camp in the vicinity of the village.
- Local residents found several pits with blown-up human remains.
- The applicants in Ortsuyeva and Others (application no. 3340/08) furnished the Court with copies of numerous requests for assistance in the search for their relatives lodged by them with various State authorities between 2002 and 2008 and the replies received thereto.
- The Government did not submit their version of the events and did not dispute the circumstances of the abductions as presented by the applicants.
- Between June and July 2002, the Shali district prosecutor's office opened criminal cases concerning the abduction of the applicants' relatives.
- All of the criminal cases opened in connection with the abduction were joined under joint criminal case no. 59113.
- On 19 April 2007 the investigation of the criminal case was resumed. It was then suspended again on 20 April 2007 for failure to identify the perpetrators.

title: CASE OF ANTSIFEROV AND NOVIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were prosecuted in Russia for crimes.
- They were arrested and detained while the crimes were investigated and pending trial.
- The detention orders were based on the gravity of the charges, with the primary grounds being the risk of absconding and interfering with the course of justice.
- The detention and extension orders used stereotypical formulae without considering alternative preventive measures.
- First applicant was arrested on 30 March 2005 on suspicion of fraud and placed in detention.
- The first applicant's detention was extended on 19 April and 14 July 2006.
- The second applicant was arrested on 14 January 2008 and was detained during investigation and trial.
- The second applicant's pre-trial detention was extended on 5 June and 2 September 2009.
- The Vorkuta Town Court of the Komi Republic convicted the second applicant of drug dealing and sentenced him to fourteen years and nine months’ imprisonment and a fine.
- The Court joined the applications and examined them in a single judgment due to the similarity of the main issues under the Convention.

title: CASE OF KOSYANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lived in Rostov-on-Don prior to his arrest.
- On 30 March 2006, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder.
- The Orlovskiy District Court of the Rostov Region found him guilty and sentenced him to seven years’ imprisonment on 16 May 2006.
- On 18 July 2006, the Rostov Regional Court upheld the conviction.
- The conviction was quashed by the Presidium of the Regional Court on 12 April 2007, and a re-trial was ordered.
- The applicant was held in custody without citing grounds or setting a time limit for its application on 12 April 2007.
- On 26 June 2007, the District Court determined that the applicant should remain in custody, and the applicant and his counsel filed an appeal against the extension order.
- On 31 July 2007, the Regional Court annulled the detention order on the ground that the District Court had failed to set a time limit for the applicant’s detention.
- On 7 September 2007, the District Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention for a period of six months starting from 28 April 2007 until 28 October 2007.
- On 15 October 2007, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 28 December 2007.
- On 13 December 2007, the District Court granted the applicant’s request for release but was later quashed by the Regional Court.
- On 20 February 2008, the District Court held that the applicant should be re-detained for a further three months on account of the gravity of the charges against him.
- The applicant was found guilty of murder on 3 March 2008, and the Regional Court upheld the conviction on 23 April 2008.

title: CASE OF BELOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Moscow.
- The Parish brought a civil claim against the applicant and her family claiming title to the land plot.
- The applicant brought a counterclaim seeking annulment of the Parish’s title to the land plot.
- The Butyrskiy District Court of Moscow granted the Parish’s claim and dismissed the counterclaim lodged by the applicant.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the judgment of 23 November 1999 on appeal.
- The Presidium of the Moscow City Court quashed the judgments of 23 November 1999 and 18 February 2000 by way of supervisory review and remitted the matter for fresh consideration.
- Both parties amended their claims several times, with the applicant eventually seeking recognition of her property title to the land plot in question.
- The District Court granted the applicant’s claims in full.
- The City Court upheld the judgment of 4 May 2005 on appeal.
- The judgment of 4 May 2005 was not enforced.
- The Parish asked for supervisory review of the judgments in the applicant’s favour.
- The Presidium of the City Court quashed the judgments of 4 May and 11 August 2005 by way of supervisory review and remitted the matter for fresh consideration.
- The proceedings discontinued on 31 January 2007 due to the absence of the parties.

title: CASE OF ARTEMENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Roslavl, the Smolensk Region.
- He was arrested on suspicion of unintentional manslaughter on 15 June 2003 and was committed to stand trial before the Leninskiy District Court of Smolensk on 30 September 2003.
- Leninskiy District Court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to twelve years’ imprisonment on 26 April 2004.
- The applicant lodged an action with the Leninskiy District Court seeking compensation for non-pecuniary damage, arguing that his detention from 2 to 26 April 2004 had been unlawful as there had been no legal order authorizing his detention during that period.
- Leninskiy District Court dismissed the applicant’s action on 23 September 2005 stating that the applicant’s conviction precludes him from claiming compensation for non-pecuniary damages.

title: CASE OF GREBNEVA AND ALISIMCHIK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are both born in 1943 and live in Vladivostok.
- The first applicant is the editor of a weekly newspaper, Arsenyevskiye Vesti and the second applicant is a journalist and columnist.
- The newspaper has a circulation of 17,100 and is published and distributed in the Primorskiy Region.
- During the campaign for elections to the national parliament, the State Duma, the newspaper published satirical and parodic articles on the course of the campaign in the Primorskiy Region featuring a Russian cartoon character named Masyanya.
- The first applicant published a pretend interview with Masyanya claiming that on her arrival at Vladivostok Airport she had been attacked and injured by local prostitutes, who did not want outsiders competing with them and who had forced her to return to St Petersburg. Masyanya had a particularly fierce fight with a certain Vasilinka, the director of an escort agency called Contact or Image!
- In issue no. 47, the second applicant wrote a column called “Nadezhda Alisimchik’s Hummock of View” and published a pretend interview with Vasilinka. Vasilinka spoke about Contact or Image's services and clientele as well as clients in the State Duma election candidates' list.
- The article was followed by a list of candidates and Vasilinka’s comments on them, using slang words and expressions commonly used in the criminal underworld.
- A picture of a female dressed in a one-dollar banknote was to the left of the article, and the face was a photograph of the then-prosecutor of the Primorskiy Region, Mr V.
- Mr V. in a private prosecution, brought criminal proceedings against the applicants, under Article 130 § 2 of the Russian Criminal Code, alleging that the article had been highly insulting, had aimed at damaging his honour and human dignity and had ascribed negative characteristics to his personality in an indecent, cynical, and defamatory manner.
- By a judgment of 2 June 2004, the applicants were convicted of aggravated insult as it had been published in the media and were fined each 30,000 RUB.
- On 19 July 2004, the Frunzenskiy District Court of Vladivostok upheld the judgment in the appeal proceedings.
- On 23 March 2005, a writ of execution was issued in respect of the first applicant, ordering her to pay the fine and an execution fee of R

title: CASE OF MARYASOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were involved in unrelated civil proceedings.
- Some applicants were present during the first-instance court hearings but all were absent from appeal hearings.
- The appeal courts did not check whether the applicants or their representatives received the summons.
- The appeal courts did not consider whether the presence of applicants was necessary due to the nature of the claims.
- Dates for the final judgments are listed in Appendix I.

title: CASE OF ERMÉNYI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and had been a judge since 1978.
- He was appointed Vice-President of the Supreme Court in 2009.
- The President of the Supreme Court, who proposed the applicant for the post, had his mandate terminated in 2012 because of his views on judicial reforms.
- A proposal to terminate the applicant's mandate as Vice-President was submitted and adopted in November 2011.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint, which was rejected in 2013, justifying the termination of his position as Vice-President because of the reorganisation of the judicial system.
- Seven judges dissented and considered the premature termination of the applicant's term of office insufficiently justified.
- In 2012, the lowering of the judges' mandatory retirement age led to the applicant's release from his duties with effect from the end of that year.
- In 2012, the Constitutional Court declared unconstitutional and annulled the provisions on the compulsory retirement age of judges.
- The termination of the applicant's judicial service was found to be unlawful, and he was reinstated but not in his previous position as President of the Civil Law division benches of the Kúria.
- The applicant opted not to be reinstated and received lump-sum compensation for the termination of post as a judge.

title: CASE OF ABDULLAHI ELMI AND AWEYS ABUBAKAR v. MALTA
facts:
1. The applicants were born in 1996 and 1995 respectively and were detained in Safi Barracks Detention Centre in Malta at the time of application.
2. Mr Burhaan Abdullahi Elmi arrived in Malta on 16 August 2012 in an irregular manner and claimed to be 16 years old, but the government said he was 17 years old.
3. Mr Cabdulaahi Aweys Abubakar arrived on 31 August 2012 and claimed to be 17 years old.
4. Both applicants were presented with Return Decision and Removal Order documents written in English that were not explained to them, and they were provided with an information leaflet in a language they did not understand.
5. Both applicants were detained under Article 14(2) of the Immigration Act and were moved to Block B of Safi Barracks Detention Centre.
6. Mr Burhaan Abdullahi Elmi was referred to AWAS for an age assessment and was found to be a minor, but did not receive a written decision informing him of the outcome, and was still in detention until the application date.
7. Mr Cabdulaahi Aweys Abubakar was also referred to AWAS for an age assessment and was found to be a minor, but did not receive a written decision informing him of the outcome, and was still in detention until the application date.
8. Both applicants complained of difficult and basic conditions of detention and lack of privacy, security, and resources. They reported violent incidents and conflicts with other detainees, and inadequate medical attention and care.
9. Mr Burhaan Abdullahi Elmi was released from detention and placed in an open centre for unaccompanied minors before leaving Malta before the termination of his asylum proceedings.
10. Mr Cabdulaahi Aweys Abubakar was released from detention and placed in an open centre for unaccompanied minors before being granted subsidiary protection.

title: CASE OF GREŠÁKOVÁ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lived in Rudinská.
- The applicant filed a civil action seeking an order for a municipality to transfer a flat in which she resided.
- The District Court scheduled two hearings for the case and granted the action on the second hearing.
- The judgment was quashed by a court of appeal, and the matter was remitted to the District Court.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court contesting the length of the proceedings.
- The Constitutional Court rejected her complaint for not exhausting ordinary remedies and required her to file a complaint with the President of the District Court.
- The District Court scheduled a hearing for 9 September 2015, and the proceedings were still pending at the time of application communication.

title: CASE OF DZHASYBAYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 in Moscow.
- On 6 June 2008, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of multiple fraud counts.
- On 7 June 2008, the Naberezhnye Chelny Town Court remanded her in custody.
- The courts extended her pre-trial detention, stating that she might interfere with investigations, abscond or reoffend, destroy evidence or threaten witnesses.
- On 24 March 2014, the Naberezhnye Chelny Town Court convicted the applicant as charged.

title: CASE OF KISELEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in the Leningrad region.
- On 25 February 2009, the investigator charged the applicant with kidnapping in absentia and put his name on the international list of fugitives from justice.
- On 2 March 2009, the District Court granted the investigator's application for a detention order, citing the seriousness of the charges.
- On 22 July 2009, the applicant was apprehended in the Vologda region and transferred to a remand prison in St. Petersburg.
- On 1 September 2009, the St. Petersburg City Court set aside the detention order due to a "fundamental breach" of criminal procedure rules and ordered a new examination of the detention matter.
- On 18 September 2009, the District Court refused the investigator's request for a detention order and the applicant was released.
- On 21 October 2009, the District Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to custodial time conditional on four years' probation.

title: CASE OF MUSTAFA HAJILI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is a journalist and a member of the Musavat Party
- On April 2, 2011, the applicant was arrested by the police while intending to participate in a demonstration
- The applicant was physically assaulted by the deputy head of the NDPO, S.N., and two other men in the exercise yard of the NDPO temporary detention centre, after the arrest
- The applicant was given a formal warning for participating in an unauthorized demonstration and was released from detention the same day
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint with the Nasimi district prosecutor's office, claiming that he had been ill-treated by S.N. in police custody
- The applicant was examined by a forensic expert who noticed a bruise on the outer side of the applicant’s right calf, measuring 4.5 by 2.5 cm
- Witnesses confirmed that on April 2, 2011, the applicant had been beaten by S.N. in the exercise yard of the NDPO temporary detention centre
- The government denied the allegations of torture or inhuman or degrading treatment
- The prosecutor refused to institute criminal proceedings on the grounds that no appearance of a criminal act was disclosed in the material collected during the inquiry
- The Nasimi District Court dismissed the applicant's complaint and found that the prosecutor's decision had been properly substantiated
- The Baku Court of Appeal upheld the Nasimi District Court's decision.

title: CASE OF MUMZHIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The application details are in the appended table.
- The applicant complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- The applicant also raised a complaint under Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MURADYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Baghramyan village.
- Suren Muradyan was drafted into the Armenian army and assigned to military unit no. 59703 of the Nagorno Karabakh Armed Forces.
- From 24 or 25 July 2002 Suren Muradyan started to feel unwell, and his condition worsened until he was taken to the military hospital of Mekhakavan.
- Suren Muradyan died as a result of acute internal bleeding caused by a ruptured spleen resulting from an internal blunt injury to the left side of the abdomen involving old and new bruises.
- The investigator decided to institute criminal proceedings no. 91204602 under Article 105 § 2 of the old Criminal Code of Armenia.
- Officers V.G. and D.H. were involved in an argument with Suren Muradyan on 21 July 2002 over a watch, and later demanded he find a second watch.
- Suren Muradyan had been summoned to several meetings with officer K.Z., who had ordered him to find the lost watches.

title: CASE OF GALAIDA AND COPOSCIU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- List of applicants provided in the appended table
- Inadequate conditions of detention complained by applicants
- Lack of effective remedy in domestic law complained by applicants

title: CASE OF NOSOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and worked for Sevastopolskyy Morskyy Zavod and its subsidiary, Sevmorremo.
- The applicant sought salary arrears and compensation for late payment of salary.
- The labour disputes commission awarded her salary arrears in June 1997, which she received in two instalments in 2001.
- In May 1998, she brought a claim for compensation for the SMZ's failure to pay her salary arrears in a timely manner, which she won in August 1998.
- However, enforcement proceedings remained unenforced, and the Sevastopol Court allowed a request for supervisory review, quashed the judgment, and remitted the case for fresh consideration in April 2001.
- The applicant lodged a new claim in March 1999, which was rejected in May 1999 but quashed in June 1999 and discontinued in 2001. 
- The applicant lodged another claim in March 2001, which was combined with her May 1998 claim in July 2001.
- The court ordered an expert examination in August 2001 and resumed proceedings in July 2002.
- The court found against the applicant in January 2004, as she had failed to lodge her claims within the three-month limitation period provided by Article 233 of the Labour Code. The decision was upheld by the Sevastopol Town Court of Appeal in May 2004 and rejected by the Supreme Court in November 2006.

title: CASE OF MAYEVSKIY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table of applicants and their relevant details is provided in the document.
- The applicants have complained about excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- In some applications, there are additional complaints raised based on the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a table with a list of applicants and their relevant application details.
- The applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- The applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KLEPIKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table is appended with a list of applicants and relevant details of their applications.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- In applications nos. 15155/13 and 41633/15, the applicants raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF POLIMERKONTEYNER, TOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant company produces containers and packaging items.
- They started regular importation of fabric for their manufacturing activities in 1999.
- The State Customs Office assigned a customs tariff of 5% based on their classification of the imported goods.
- The company challenged each decision in court to recover the overpaid duty, as they claimed the classification code was incorrect and they should have only paid 1% customs tariff.
- The goods were impounded during the judicial proceedings.
- The company won each case and the court ordered the return of overpaid tax.
- The customs office continued to assign the wrong code, undermining the authority of the courts.

title: CASE OF KULYK AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and details of their applications provided in an appended table.
- Applicants complained of the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- Applicants complained of the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF AFANASYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The application is described in an appended table
- The applicant is complaining about inadequate detention conditions
- The applicant has raised a complaint under Article 13 of the Convention

title: CASE OF HUSEYNOV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
• All the applicants were members of the Popular Front Party of Azerbaijan, an opposition party.
• Political sensitivity increased in the country due to elections in 2013.
• Applicants participated in peaceful opposition demonstrations and were arrested during many of them.
• Some applicants intended to participate in upcoming protests planned by Milli Shura.
• Applicants were arrested in either February or March 2014.
• All the applicants were charged with an administrative offense under Article 310.1 of the Code of Administrative Offences.
• Applicants claimed they were never given access to a lawyer after their arrest or while in police custody.
• State-funded lawyers were appointed to assist them, but some refused their assistance.
• The courts disregarded the applicants’ statements regarding the reasons for their arrests and found them guilty of administrative offenses.

title: CASE OF SVYSTORUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's daughter was found stabbed to death on August 11, 2007.
- The Poltava Regional Police started an investigation into the suspected murder on the same day.
- The applicant was called to testify but was not allowed to join the proceedings as an aggrieved party.
- The applicant's other daughter joined the proceedings as an aggrieved party.
- A man called O.T. was arrested and initially confessed, but later retracted his confession.
- The criminal proceedings against O.T. were discontinued due to a lack of evidence.
- The investigation was suspended on October 10, 2007, as no leads had been identified.
- The District Prosecutor's Office quashed the decision to suspend the proceedings and ordered a further inquiry.
- The applicant's daughter's husband was eventually arrested and confessed to the murder, but later retracted his confession.
- The proceedings against the husband were discontinued due to discrepancies between his statements and other evidence.
- The investigative department was reprimanded for poor planning and supervision.
- The Poltava Regional Prosecutor's Office notified the applicant that no leads had been uncovered.
- The Deputy Minister of Interior ordered a renewal of proceedings.
- Several investigators were assigned to the case, but no new leads were uncovered.
- The applicant was admitted to the proceedings as an aggrieved party on April 15, 2013.
- The applicant complained to the Minister of Interior that the investigation had been marred by inactivity and delays.
- The police authorities informed the applicant that no new leads had been uncovered, but his suggestions would be taken into account in further investigation.

title: CASE OF TERENINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The case originated from an application against the Russian Federation made by Yana Aleksandrovna Terenina.
2. The details of the application are included in a table.
3. Terenina complained of the inadequate conditions of her detention and raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.
4. The application was communicated to the Russian Government.

title: CASE OF DIMITROV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Sofia.
- The applicant's father owned a property that was expropriated for constructing a residential building.
- The compensation offered by the municipality was a two-room flat and a garage in a building which was planned to be constructed.
- The specification of the flat was provided in a supplementary decision, but the garage was not mentioned.
- The applicant's father filed requests with municipal authorities to specify the exact garage to be given to him, but he received a response that no buildings with garages earmarked for compensation were being constructed.
- The applicant's father brought an action for damages in 2008, which was dismissed by the Supreme Administrative Court in 2011.
- The applicant's father passed away on 7 April 2008, and the applicant is his only heir.

title: CASE OF MANUCHARYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and is currently detained at Nubarashen Prison.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted on 1 July 2009 on account of the murder of K.S.
- The applicant presented himself to the police later that day and confessed to the murder.
- The applicant was charged on the same day with murder and illegal possession of firearms. 
- K.M., a witness to the incident, stated that it had been the applicant who had started to shoot at K.S.’s car.
- S.S., K.S.’s sister, stated that she had been aware of some problems between her brother and a friend of the applicant.
- K.M.’s parents, S.M. and A.M., stated that on the day of the murder, they had heard gunshots and that shortly after K.M. had run into their house in tears, saying that the applicant had killed K.S. 
- The applicant’s alibi was that on the day of the murder he had visited his father’s friend V.J. at around 10.30 p.m. and had stayed in his house until around 2.30 a.m.
- The prosecution relied on witness statements, results of forensic examinations (including the presence of gunshot residue on the clothes worn by the applicant).
- The Regional Court held multiple hearings trying to compel the witnesses to attend, but they did not appear.
- The Regional Court eventually examined the applicant’s case in K.M.’s absence.
- The Criminal Court of Appeal upheld the applicant’s conviction, relying on the same body of evidence as the Regional Court.
- The Court of Cassation declared the applicant’s appeal on points of law inadmissible for lack of merit.

title: CASE OF SOLOVYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details in an appended table.
- The applicants complained about excessive pre-trial detention.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the Convention.

title: CASE OF KRAVETS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Application details are in the appended table.
- The applicant complained about excessive pre-trial detention.
- The applicant also raised a complaint under Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KOLEVATOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details in an appended table.
- The applicants complained of inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants had other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF CHERNYKH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant's complaint about inadequate conditions of detention.
- Applicant raised a complaint under Article 13 of the Convention.
- Relevant details of the applicant's application are presented in the table.

title: CASE OF BORISENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their application details is included.
- The applicants complained about the length of their pre-trial detention.
- The applicants in applications nos. 18682/09 and 49397/10 raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF CARMEL SALIBA v. MALTA
facts:
- A robbery took place on May 12, 1995, in the home of Mr and Ms Z. 
- Various items were stolen and the victims were injured while they were being held face down in the bedroom. 
- According to Mr Z., one of the robbers said, “Give us the two buckets of gold you told us you had in your possession”. 
- The applicants and his brother had done work for the Z. family as plumbers and electricians. 
- In 1996, Saliba Brothers, the company owned in part by the applicant, instituted proceedings against Mr Z. claiming payment for services rendered. 
- In 2000, Mr and Ms Z. sued the applicant in civil proceedings for the damage resulting from the said robbery as Mr Z. considered that he recognised the applicant as one of the robbers.

title: CASE OF TAMER TANRIKULU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and lives in Iğdır
- On 14 January 2005, he fell from the roof where he was on guard and was diagnosed with a left parietal craniotomy
- He was declared unfit for military service and applied to the Ministry of Defence for compensation for his injury
- The applicant initiated compensation proceedings before the Supreme Military Administrative Court on 1 November 2005, sought TRY 20,000 in respect of pecuniary damage and the same sum in respect of non-pecuniary damage
- An expert report dated 4 October 2007 assessed the applicant’s pecuniary damage at TRY 58,384 (approximately EUR 36,260)
- The applicant requested to increase his initial claim via an amendment on 19 October 2007
- On 28 November 2007, the court ruled in favour of the applicant for TRY 20,000 in respect of pecuniary damage and TRY 12,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage, but dismissed the applicant’s application for an amendment
- The Supreme Military Administrative Court considered the amendment claim out of time and rejected it
- The applicant’s application for rectification of the previous decision was dismissed by the Supreme Administrative Court on 16 April 2008.

title: CASE OF LUPENI GREEK CATHOLIC PARISH AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The three applicants are members of the Romanian Church United to Rome.
- In 1948, the Greek Catholic Church was dissolved, and its assets, excluding parish property, were transferred to the state.
- A committee responsible for determining the allocation of parish property never completed its task, and as a result, the parish property was transferred to the Orthodox Church.
- After the fall of the communist regime in 1989, the Uniate Church was officially recognized, and the legal status of properties belonging to Uniate parishes in the possession of the Orthodox Church was to be determined by joint committees made up of representatives of both denominations.
- The first applicant was legally re-established in 1996 and brought proceedings to have their former properties returned, but without success.
- The second applicant brought proceedings before domestic courts in 2001 to have the church building and cemetery in Lupeni returned to the first applicant, but the court declared the action inadmissible.
- The applicants supplemented their action with a claim for recovery of possession of the properties in question in 2006.
- In 2009, the County Court found in favor of the applicants and ordered that the church be returned to the first applicant.
- In 2010, the Court of Appeal allowed an appeal lodged by the Orthodox parish and dismissed the applicants' action, citing the wishes of the majority of worshippers in Lupeni and the fact that the Orthodox Church had maintained and carried out renovation work on the contested property.
- The applicants appealed on points of law to the High Court, alleging that the Court of Appeal had incorrectly applied the legal provisions governing actions for recovery of possession.

title: CASE OF GERASIMENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are from Moscow and were born in 1990, 1989, and 1990 respectively.
- D.E. was a major in the police force and was born in 1977.
- On 28 November 2008, D.E. was promoted to the chief of the Tsaritsino branch of the Moscow Department of the Interior.
- On 27 April 2009, D.E. committed a series of violent crimes, including shooting and killing two people and injuring several others, including the three applicants.
- D.E. was apprehended by the police and was subsequently convicted of two murders, twenty-two counts of attempted murder, and the unlawful use of firearms. He was sentenced to life imprisonment and was stripped of his rank of major.
- A forensic psychological and psychiatric examination of D.E. revealed that he had emotional instability and excitability but did not suffer from any mental disorder. Additionally, his childhood conditions, coupled with his head injuries, may have contributed to his behavioral deviations, which required psychiatric help.
- The court also noted that D.E.'s handgun was reported stolen from the arms store of the North Caucasus Department of the Interior for the Rostov region and that two officials were convicted of stealing 128 handguns from that arm store in the period between June 1998 and April-May 2000, which included the handgun used by D.E.
- Failures on the part of the agencies of the interior, such as improper performance of duties by staff members of the human resources services and their perfunctory attitude towards recruitment and the promotion of staff, led to persons unfit due to their personal and professional qualities being promoted to senior positions, which contributed to D.E.'s criminal behavior.

title: CASE OF TRAPEZNIKOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are members of Mr. Sergei Antonov's family.
- Mr. Antonov started serving a prison sentence in 2006 and had a history of psychiatric and drug problems.
- Mr. Antonov was hospitalized in May 2006 after swallowing metal objects and cutting himself.
- On July 20, 2007, Mr. Antonov was transferred to a disciplinary cell after smoking outside the designated area.
- On July 23, 2007, Mr. Antonov was found hanging in his cell and was pronounced dead on July 22. An autopsy revealed the cause of death asphyxiation by hanging and noted injuries on his head.
- The correctional colony did not provide Mr. Antonov with sufficient psychiatric supervision or treatment.
- Multiple criminal investigations were launched, and various officials refused to open a criminal investigation.
- Investigative authorities concluded that Mr. Antonov had committed suicide and that his injuries were not related to his death.

title: CASE OF TOMINA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicants were Russian nationals who owned rooms in a dormitory building in Samara.
2. The municipality reclaimed the building and the applicants' title to the property was annulled as a result of civil proceedings.
3. The applicants continued to reside in the rooms they had bought.
4. The applicants submitted that they had never moved into the rooms as they were occupied by others.
5. The building located at no. 61 Yunykh Pionerov Avenue, Samara, was transferred to Stroitel and was considered an administrative building.
6. The title to the building was transferred to the closed joint-stock company, Stroitel-M, and separate rooms were resold to third parties, including the applicants.
7. The Samara Region Commercial Court found the Samaraavtotrans privatisation plan null and void.
8. A prosecutor on behalf of the municipality brought an action against the owners of the rooms, including the applicants, to return the title to the building to the municipality.
9. After a series of court judgments, the title to the building was transferred to the municipality, and the owners of the rooms, including the applicants, were recognized as bona fide purchasers.
10. The applicants' mother sued the person who had sold the rooms to the applicants for damages, and the court awarded damages to each applicant.
11. Enforcement proceedings were initiated but discontinued due to the inability to locate the assets of the person against whom the claim was brought.

title: CASE OF DMITRIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and is detained in the Tomsk Region.
- On 2 December 2007, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder and was placed in remand prison no. IZ-70/1 in Tomsk two days later.
- On 13 November 2008, he was found guilty and sentenced to eleven years’ imprisonment.
- Since 18 February 2009, save for short periods of detention in the remand prison, the applicant has been held in correctional colonies nos. 2 and 4 in the Tomsk Region.
- The applicant had not been examined by a dentist during his pre-trial detention, and he had not received any dental treatment.
- The applicant received dental treatment for the first time on 8 June 2011 in the correctional colony, and he had undergone scaling and cleaning procedures and extraction of teeth.
- During his detention, the applicant lost nine teeth; he was unable to obtain orthodontic treatment even at his own expense.
- The applicant brought the issue of inadequate medical treatment to the attention of various domestic authorities, but all to no avail.
- The applicant's medical file contained several entries on his dental treatment, and he was provided with medical examinations and treatment in each penal facility, according to the government.
- The government did not contest the veracity of the statements made by the applicant's former cellmates.

title: CASE OF BELGE v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lives in Şırnak.
- A demonstration was held in Gemlik district of Bursa on 3 September 2005 by Tuhay-Der.
- On 5 September 2005, a gathering was held in front of the building of the Cizre branch of DEHAP, and the applicant made a speech during that gathering.
- The applicant was charged with disseminating propaganda in favour of a criminal organisation due to his speech on 5 September 2005.
- The case was transferred to the Diyarbakır Assize Court after the Cizre court found that it lacked jurisdiction.
- The court held nine hearings and obtained a report by an expert on video recordings.
- The applicant denied the allegation of disseminating propaganda and noted that he had only thanked those who had made an effort to bring about peace.
- The first-instance court noted that those who disseminated propaganda in favour of PKK were expressing support for methods of terrorism and violence.
- The applicant was convicted of disseminating propaganda in favour of a terrorist organisation and sentenced to ten months’ imprisonment. 
- The Court of Cassation upheld the Diyarbakır Assize Court’s judgment.

title: CASE OF MIKHAIL NIKOLAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. Quarrel between applicant and others leading to police involvement
2. Applicant allegedly assaulted by police officers during transportation and at police station
3. Applicant charged with petty hooliganism and sentenced to two days' detention
4. Applicant receives medical treatment and is diagnosed with various injuries
5. Criminal proceedings initiated against police officers for abuse of power, later terminated 
6. Multiple investigations and complaints filed by applicant regarding handling of case and investigation process.

title: CASE OF TRUTKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was charged with contempt of court and criminal slander in 2003.
- An outpatient forensic psychiatric examination was ordered on the applicant.
- The applicant was apprehended and taken to a psychiatric facility in 2003.
- The Town Court ruled that the apprehension of the applicant was unlawful.
- The prosecution made an application for the court to order an involuntary forensic psychiatric examination of the applicant.
- The Town Court granted the prosecutor’s application.
- The applicant appealed, complaining that she had not been given an opportunity to present her case to the Town Court.
- The proceedings in respect of the two criminal cases were joined, and the applicant charged with criminal slander of certain judges.
- The applicant was apprehended by the authorities and transferred to the Forensic Psychiatry Centre in 2004.
- The Moscow Regional Court held a hearing on the applicant’s appeal and rejected it.
- The City Court terminated the criminal proceedings relating to the contempt of court charges in respect of the events of 22 December 2002.
- The City Court ordered the applicant to undergo compulsory medical treatment in a psychiatric facility.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the lower court’s decisions.
- The applicant was involuntarily admitted to Moscow Regional Psychiatric Hospital.
- The Town Court ordered the applicant’s compulsory treatment to be discontinued.
- The Regional Court dismissed the appeal and upheld the lower court’s decision.
- The applicant was released from the hospital.

title: CASE OF GJERMENI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and lives in Tirana.
- On 18 June 2009, the applicant was dismissed from his position as General Deputy Director of State Social Service at the Ministry.
- On 27 January 2010, the Tirana District Court partially accepted the applicant’s action against his dismissal and ordered his reinstatement and the payment of damages.
- On 23 November 2010, the Tirana Court of Appeal upheld the Tirana District Court’s decision.
- On 6 May 2011, an enforcement writ was issued.
- From 2011 to 2014, the bailiff office unsuccessfully tried to enforce the final judgment.
- On 9 December 2014, the authorities paid the damages to the applicant.
- On 8 April 2016, the State Social Service requested the Ministry to examine the applicant’s reinstatement, and the position of the Deputy Director was made available in a letter to the Department of Public Administration.

title: CASE OF KOLBASOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their relevant details in the appended table.
- Applicants complained of inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.
- The Court rejected the Government's unilateral declarations as insufficient basis for concluding the examination of some applications.

title: CASE OF MOLLA v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant inherited two plots of land in Korça and was recognized as the owner by the Korça Commission on Restitution and Compensation of Properties in 1995 and 1996.
- The defendant, the Korça Regional Company for the Distribution of Electricity, started the construction of a high-voltage line on the applicant's plots of land.
- The applicant sought an injunction to suspend the construction works, and the Korça District Court issued an injunction in 2006 which was upheld by the Korça Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court.
- The applicant brought an action against the defendant to bring the construction works to an end immediately, remove the high-voltage line, and restore the site to its previous state.
- The District Court ordered the immediate termination of the works, removal of the high-voltage line and restoration of the site to its former state, which was upheld by the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court.
- The bailiff unsuccessfully sought to enforce the final judgment from 2008 to 2015 and imposed fines on the defendant.
- The applicant lodged criminal complaints for failure to comply with the judgment but the proceedings were discontinued.
- The applicant brought a civil action against C.E.Z Shpërndarje sh.a, claiming damages and loss of profit, which is still pending before the domestic courts.
- AEC brought a civil action against the applicant to annul the administrative decisions recognizing the applicant's property rights, and the District Court ordered the freezing of the title to the applicant's plots of land, which was later lifted by the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court.
- AEC and DEC brought civil actions to annul the administrative decisions, which were discontinued by the District Court because they failed to attend hearings.

title: CASE OF FRIDA, LLC v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant company is a limited liability company registered in 2004 in Ukraine, with its registered office in Kyiv.
- On April 12, 2005, the applicant company and another company, S., concluded an agreement by which the applicant company undertook to provide information and analytical services to S., and the latter undertook to pay for those services. 
- On November 24, 2005, the parties concluded an additional agreement for supplementary services to be provided to S. by the applicant company.
- On April 27, 2006, the applicant company lodged a claim against S. with the Kyiv Commercial Court, seeking recovery of an alleged debt under the above agreement, as well as the payment of penalties and legal fees.
- On June 9, 2006, the Kyiv Commercial Court opened the proceedings in the case.
- On September 11, 2006, during a hearing in the case, S. submitted a counterclaim, seeking that the agreement be declared void. The court adjourned the hearing until September 14, 2006, without deciding on the admissibility of the counterclaim.
- On September 14, 2006, the judge hearing the case accepted S.’s counterclaim for joint consideration with the original claim by the applicant company. At the same hearing, the judge granted S.’s counterclaim in part and rejected the original claim of the applicant company in full.
- On October 13, 2006, the applicant company lodged an appeal on points of law against the judgment of September 14, 2006, with the Higher Commercial Court of Ukraine (“the HCCU”).
- On November 9, 2006, the HCCU returned the applicant company’s appeal on points of law to it without considering the appeal on the merits, because the relevant court fee had not been paid in full.
- On November 21, 2006, the applicant company resubmitted its appeal on points of law with proof of having paid the full court fee. 
- On December 19, 2006, the HCCU declined to consider the applicant company’s appeal on points of law, relying on sub-paragraph 5 of Article 111-3 § 1. 
- On January 4, 2007, the applicant company challenged the decision of December 19, 2006, before the Supreme Court.
- On February 22, 2007,

title: CASE OF PELESHOK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant lent USD 21,500 to Mrs Sh. and USD 13,400 remained outstanding.
- On 30 July 2002, Mrs Sh. and her husband beat the applicant in public in the front yard of their house.
- The applicant suffered a brain concussion and a bruise on her breast.
- The police initially refused to institute criminal proceedings against Mr and Mrs Sh.
- Conflicting witness statements made it impossible to determine whether the incident occurred on 29 or 30 July 2002. 
- The investigation was terminated and reopened multiple times, with a senior prosecutor repeatedly finding the investigation incomplete.
- The police stayed the criminal investigation until the identity of the person who inflicted the injuries on the applicant could be established.

title: CASE OF SOSNOVSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant, who worked as an investigation officer, was accused of extorting money for a fishing business.
- The applicant was arrested and criminal proceedings were instituted against him and his assistant.
- The Tsentralnyy District Court of Simferopol authorised the applicant's pre-trial detention on the grounds of committing a serious crime and potential escape, hindrance of investigation or continuation of criminal activity.
- The applicant's complaints about his arrest being unlawful were forwarded to various prosecutor's offices and courts.
- The Feodosiya Court maintained the applicant's detention during committal hearings and rejected his request to change the preventive measure to undertaking not to abscond.
- The applicant was found guilty of several counts of bribe-taking and sentenced to six years' imprisonment with confiscation of half of his property.
- The applicant was detained in Simferopol Pre-Trial Detention Centre no. 15 and in the Feodosiya Temporary Detention Centre.
- The applicant filed complaints about the conditions of detention, including overcrowding, lack of windows, limited access to showers and activities, and difficulties with the toilet.
- The Feodosiya Prosecutor's Office and the Leninskiy District Court dismissed the applicant's complaints about the conditions of detention, citing procedural requirements and the prosecutor's supervisory role.
- The applicant later lodged an administrative claim for damages against the Feodosiya ITT authorities but was rejected due to the lapse of the one-year time limit.

title: CASE OF GAVRASHENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
• List of applicants and application details are in the appended table.
• Applicants complained about lengthy criminal proceedings. 
• Applicants complained about the lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.
• Other complaints were raised under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF GUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Cherkasy.
- On 23 August 2001, the Cherkasy Regional Court of Appeal found the applicant guilty of murder, attempted murder, and illegal possession of firearms, and sentenced him to life imprisonment. The Supreme Court upheld that judgment on 12 February 2002.
- Subsequently, in 2009, the Supreme Court changed the applicant’s sentence to fifteen years’ imprisonment.
- During the investigations and trial, the applicant was held in the Cherkasy Temporary Investigative Isolation Unit (“the SIZO”) No. 30. He remained there until 22 September 2004 when he was transferred to Kyiv SIZO no. 13. On 15 October 2004, the applicant was placed in Sokalska Correctional Colony no. 47 in the Lviv Region (“Sokalska Prison”). In November 2007 he was transferred to the Zamkova Correctional Colony no. 58 in the Khmelnytsk Region (“Zamkova Prison”).
- In May 2012, the applicant suffered an ischemic stroke and was taken to a hospital within the Shepetivska Correctional Colony No. 98, in which he underwent treatment as regards the stroke and generally hypertension. On 23 October 2012, the applicant was released from prison.
- The applicant claimed to have been beaten by several guards on the day he arrived at Sokalska Prison (15 October 2004) and suffered an eye injury and several bruises and scratches on his body. He also alleged that he was refused medical assistance.
- On 19 October 2004, the applicant asked the prison authorities to send a complaint about his alleged beating to a prosecutor, which was refused. On 28 June 2006, during an official visit to the prison by a prosecutor in charge of supervising the prison authorities’ compliance with the law, the applicant handed his complaint of beating to that prosecutor. By a decision of 18 August 2006, the prosecutor refused to open a criminal investigation into the applicant’s complaint.
- During his detention in Sokalska Prison between October 2004 and November 2007, the applicant claimed that the cells were unventilated, always damp, and not sufficiently heated in winter; he was handcuffed every time he left his cell and followed by several prison officers with a guard dog, allegedly with a felt-lined bag over

title: CASE OF CHUKANOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table including the list of applicants and application details is appended.
- The applicants allege that the civil proceedings were excessively long. 
- The applicants allege that there were no effective remedies available under domestic law.
- Some applicants had additional complaints based on the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF PASHKEVICH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and was detained in correctional colony no. 14 until his death in 2016.
- On January 29, 2014, the Fokino Town Court convicted the applicant of murder and sentenced him to six and a half years’ imprisonment.
- Prior to his detention, several spinal injuries caused the applicant to lose the ability to walk unaided.
- On his admission to a remand prison in January 2014, the applicant was diagnosed with spinal tuberculosis.
- The applicant was put in an ordinary cell not equipped for wheelchair‑using detainees.
- Several days later, he was seen by a medical specialist, who amended his diagnosis to osteoporosis with compression fractures of two discs of the lumbar spine.
- In February 2014, he was diagnosed with paraplegia, impairment in motor function of the lower extremities.
- In April 2014, the osteoporosis was established to affect not only the applicant’s spine but also his legs.
- On April 9, 2014, the applicant was sent to serve his sentence in correctional colony no. IK-14/7. 
- On his arrival, he was diagnosed with coronary heart disease, angina pectoris, and moderate hypertension disease.
- On July 30, 2014, the applicant was sent to prison hospital no. 1 in Chita, Zabaykalsk Region, for an in-depth medical examination.
- On August 27, 2014, a specialist medical panel of the prison hospital concluded that the applicant was not eligible for early release on medical grounds.
- On October 2, 2014, the Olovyannaya District Court dismissed the applicant’s application for early release.
- Over the months that followed, the applicant was regularly seen by prison doctors and provided with hypotensive drugs and pain relief drugs.
- In the meantime, he brought a civil claim against the medical authorities seeking compensation for damage to his health caused by inadequate medical treatment.
- On June 15, 2015, the Central District Court of Chita dismissed the applicant’s claim.
- On June 27, 2016, the applicant died of a heart attack.

title: CASE OF YUNZEL v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1967 and lived in Menzelinsk
- Applicant convicted and sentenced to correctional colony in 1999
- Further charges brought in April 2008, leading to transfer to remand prison and temporary detention unit
- Poor conditions in cell 512 for most of detention, including vermin, poor sanitation, and lack of ventilation and natural light
- Poor quality of food and limited exercise time in remand prison
- Overcrowding and no outdoor exercise in temporary detention unit
- Dental issues arose and requests made for treatment
- Applicant eventually received dental treatment after significant delay and suffering
- No alternative soft food provided during period of dental treatment when applicant was toothless
- Applicant filed civil claim for dental treatment and compensation, but claim was dismissed.

title: CASE OF TIBA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is a lawyer born in 1974 who lives in Oradea.
- The National Anticorruption Department began criminal proceedings against the applicant and a police officer on December 11, 2008, for traffic of influence.
- The applicant was accused of accepting money from a client in exchange for persuading other judges to make a favorable judgment in the client's case outside of the judicial process.
- A warrant to appear was issued for the applicant on the basis of Articles 183 and 184 of the Criminal Procedure Code.
- The applicant was taken into custody on December 12, 2008, and was questioned by the prosecutor from noon until 4:50 p.m., at which point he was charged with traffic of influence.
- The applicant claimed that the police confiscated his phone, wallet, and watch and that he was guarded by police throughout his custody.
- On December 13, 2008, the prosecutor successfully requested that the applicant be placed in pre-trial detention for thirty days.
- The applicant filed a complaint with the Timisoara Court of Appeal, stating that his detention from 8 a.m. to 5:10 p.m. on December 12, 2008, was unlawful, but the court was unable to address the complaint.
- The applicant appealed the decision, but on December 17, 2008, the High Court of Cassation and Justice rejected the appeal on points of law as being without merit.
- On March 12, 2010, the applicant was found guilty of traffic of influence and given a four-year suspended sentence with final effect.

title: CASE OF IURII v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Chișinău.
- On 2 October 2008, the Chișinău Court of Appeal acknowledged the applicant's entitlement to a disability pension.
- On 1 December 2008, the Ministry of Defence lodged an appeal on points of law.
- On 4 February 2009, the Supreme Court of Justice quashed the judgment of 2 October 2008 and remitted the case for a fresh examination on the merits.
- On 2 March 2011, the Supreme Court of Justice finally acknowledged the applicant's entitlement to a disability pension.
- The Prosecutor General lodged an application for revision with the Supreme Court of Justice, seeking the reopening of the proceedings and redress for the violation of the applicant's rights.
- On 23 June 2011, the Supreme Court of Justice found a violation of the applicant's rights and set aside the judgment of 4 February 2009.
- The court awarded the applicant MDL 15,000 in non-pecuniary damages, MDL 15,000 for legal costs, and MDL 1,000 for miscellaneous expenses.
- The court dismissed the applicant's claims in respect to pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF BÉLÁNÉ NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lived in Baktalórántháza.
- Between May 1, 1975, and July 14, 1997, the applicant was employed and made the statutory contributions to the social-security scheme. 
- The applicant received unemployment benefits from September 15, 1997, until September 9, 1998. 
- The applicant was granted a disability pension in 2001 on the basis of a retrospective finding that she had lost her capacity to work on account of various ailments.
- As of 2008, the legislation on the methodology used to assess health impairment in occupational contexts changed.
- On 1 February 2010, the relevant pension insurance directorate withdrew the applicant's entitlement to the disability pension.
- The Nyíregyháza Labour Court retained the disability score of 40% and dismissed the applicant's action on 1 April 2011. 
- The relevant authority of Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg County refused the applicant's request for a disability allowance on 23 November 2012.
- On 20 June 2013, the Nyíregyháza Administrative and Labour Court dismissed the applicant's case.

title: CASE OF PAPOSHVILI v. BELGIUM
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant arrived in Belgium in 1998 and claimed to be the father of a child, whose paternity was disputed by the government.
- He and his wife were arrested multiple times for theft offenses.
- The applicant was convicted of robbery with violence and threats in 2001 and involvement in a criminal organization in 2005, for which he was sentenced to imprisonment.
- The applicant and his family lodged an asylum application in 1998 and were subjected to a Dublin Convention request for return to Germany before being accepted by Italy.
- The applicant lodged several requests for regularization of his status under the Aliens Act, all of which were refused.
- The applicant was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia and received treatment in prison and afterwards in hospitals, where his condition deteriorated.
- The applicant was deemed to face a significant risk of death if treatment was discontinued, but he did not have a residence permit required for a stem cell transplant.

title: CASE OF RUSU LINTAX SRL v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is a limited liability company.
- On 11 June 2008, the Supreme Court ordered the Public Property Agency to sell a plot of land to the applicant company.
- On 24 December 2008, the Supreme Court quashed the 11 June 2008 judgment citing new evidence.
- On 16 June 2010, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's claims about the plot of land as unsubstantiated.

title: CASE OF DUMIKYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in Armenia in 1970 and lived in Kurgan, Russia until his arrest in 2008
- On 3 August 2008, he stole a car while under the influence of alcohol and crashed, injuring himself
- Hospitalized with multiple injuries, including facial injuries, fractured thighbone, and a dislocated hip
- During police investigation, it was discovered that he was wanted by the Belarusian authorities for a murder allegedly committed in 2003 in Minsk
- Without informing the hospital administration, police arrested him while still recovering and subjected him to detention pending extradition to Belarus
- His extradition was ordered by the Russian Prosecutor General’s Office in August 2009; he was extradited to Belarus in March 2010 and was returned to Russia after the Belarusian authorities closed the criminal case
- In the meantime, he was convicted of car theft and sentenced to four years’ imprisonment and experienced several detention extension orders
- Medical documentation in the court’s possession suggests neglectful medical treatment for his injuries and chronic conditions
- During his detention, he experienced overcrowding, unsanitary conditions, and inadequate living space.
- Applicant was released on 22 September 2012, and it appears that his broken leg had healed in the wrong position, causing him to walk with a limp.

title: CASE OF IDALOV v. RUSSIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Lakha-Varanda, Chechen Republic.
- On 11 July 2008, P. caused a traffic accident while driving and damaged the applicant's car, leading to a dispute over cash for car repair.
- On 16 July 2008, police officers arrested the applicant after a complaint by P, and allegedly found heroin on him after he resisted arrest.
- The applicant was held in pre-trial detention from 18 July 2008 to 11 December 2013, with several extensions granted by courts based on risk of flight and hindering justice.
- During the trial on the applicant's alleged drug offence, he was disruptive in court and threatened interpreters and witnesses.
- The court ultimately found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to four years' imprisonment.
- The conviction was upheld on appeal in April 2010 but reduced to three years and two months' imprisonment by the Presidium of the Moscow Regional Court in December 2013.
- The applicant alleged that he was assaulted by police officers at the Odintsovo police station on 21 May 2009 but no criminal proceedings were brought against the officers until after the case was communicated to the European Court of Human Rights.
- On 25 September 2009, the applicant was placed in a disciplinary cell and allegedly assaulted by guards on the way there.

title: CASE OF NAZAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lived in Oblivskaya, Rostov Region
- He was a police officer when he was arrested on 22 October 2007
- On 24 October 2007, he was authorized to be remanded in custody
- He remained in custody throughout the trial
- Court extended his pre-trial detention several times due to the seriousness of charges and his role as a police officer
- Despite appeals lodged against detention, the Regional Court upheld the decision
- On 17 December 2008, the District Court found him guilty of drug dealing and sentenced him to 14 years in prison
- On 10 June 2009, the Regional Court quashed the judgment and remitted the matter to trial court
- He remained in custody during this process
- Several hearings were scheduled, and his detention was extended multiple times
- On 6 May 2011, he was found guilty.

title: CASE OF KASPAROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The first applicant is a former World Chess Champion and a political activist.
- On 24 November 2007, a group of opposition politicians organized protest rallies in several Russian cities, including Moscow.
- The applicants attended a gathering on Academician Sakharov Prospekt, which had been organized by the second applicant and approved by the authorities.
- On their way to another authorized gathering, the applicants were blocked by the riot police and arrested, allegedly with excessive force used against them.
- The first and second applicants were charged with breaching the established procedure for conducting public events and disobeying lawful police orders.
- Their administrative detention was ordered with reference to Article 27.3 of the Code.
- The first applicant appeared before the Justice of the Peace to plead not guilty, requested witnesses to be called and examined, and photographic material to be admitted as evidence. The Justice of the Peace dismissed his testimony and found him guilty of both charges, sentencing him to five days' administrative detention.
- The second applicant also applied for witnesses to be called and examined but was found guilty and sentenced to five days' administrative detention.
- The Meshchanskiy District Court of Moscow dismissed appeals lodged by the first and second applicant.
- The other applicants were arrested in the same circumstances and were also convicted of administrative offences.

title: CASE OF SHAGABUTDINOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Moscow.
- On 13 October 2006, the Zamoskvoretskiy District Court in Moscow remanded the applicant in custody on the charge of fraud. 
- The District Court extended the applicant’s detention on multiple occasions, each time due to the gravity of the charges against him.
- The Moscow City Court rejected appeals against the detention orders.
- The Supreme Court also rejected appeals against the detention orders.
- In 2008, the case was submitted for trial.
- The District Courts prolonged the applicant’s detention pending trial on multiple occasions, referring mainly to the gravity of the charges.
- The applicant was detained in a severely overcrowded prison.

title: CASE OF BOYCHUK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk.
- On 29 April 2006, the applicant was remanded in custody on suspicion of robbery.
- On 18 July 2006, the Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk Town Court extended the applicant's detention until 27 August 2006.
- On 15 August 2006, the Town Court fixed the date of the first trial hearing and held that the applicant should remain in custody without citing any reasons, or time-limit for it.
- On 4 October 2006, the Sakhalin Regional Court rejected an appeal against that decision.
- On 10 October 2006, the Town Court found the applicant guilty, and
- On 28 February 2007, The Regional Court upheld the conviction.

title: CASE OF SNYATOVSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was in charge of Alfa Bank's branches in the Russian Far East
- A financial audit revealed a shortage of assets
- The applicant was charged with abuse of his position, aggravated embezzlement, and money laundering committed by an organized criminal group
- The applicant was initially not placed in pre-trial detention due to a lack of evidence
- However, the Presidium of the Regional Court quashed the previous decision and remitted for a fresh consideration, resulting in the applicant being remanded in detention
- The applicant's detention was extended several times, based on the gravity of the charges and concerns of reoffending, obstructing justice, or absconding
- The applicant was eventually released on bail after completing collection of evidence
- The outcome of the criminal trial is unknown
- The applicant had a history of heart disease and underwent several medical treatments during his detention, including time spent in a prison hospital
- The applicant's drug regimen was adjusted to manage his hypertension and angina pectoris attacks.

title: CASE OF KUNITSYNA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is a freelance journalist who worked for a newspaper called Tomskaya Nedelya.
- The newspaper published an article by the applicant in 1999 that exposed practical difficulties encountered by a State-owned care home for the elderly where patients were abandoned by their relatives.
- The article mentioned the mother of Mr S., a former deputy of the national parliament, who died in the care home and described her living conditions.
- Mr S., his father, brother, and sister brought defamation proceedings against the applicant claiming that the article contained statements damaging to their honor and dignity.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Tomsk rejected the claims on the grounds that the statements were accurate and socially oriented, and had no link to the claimants or other members of the S. family.
- The Tomsk Regional Court, however, overturned the judgment and ordered the applicant to pay compensation for non-pecuniary damage to each of the three claimants.

title: CASE OF KHLAIFIA AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicants, born in 1983, 1987, and 1988 respectively, left Tunisia on rudimentary vessels for the Italian coast on 16-17 September 2011.
- After several hours at sea, their vessels were intercepted by the Italian coastguard and the applicants were transferred to an Early Reception and Aid Centre (CSPA) on the island of Lampedusa on 17-18 September 2011.
- The applicants were held in an overcrowded and dirty area of the CSPA and were obliged to sleep on the floor because of the shortage of available beds and poor quality mattresses.
- On 20 September 2011, a violent revolt broke out among the migrants at the CSPA, the premises were gutted by fire, and the applicants were taken to a sports complex on Lampedusa.
- On 21 September 2011, the applicants managed to evade police surveillance and walked to the village of Lampedusa, from where, with about 1,800 other migrants, they started a demonstration through the streets of the island.
- On 22 September 2011, the applicants were flown to Palermo, and after disembarking, they were transferred to ships that were moored in the harbor there. All the migrants on each vessel were confined to the restaurant areas, and they slept on the floor and had to wait several hours to use the toilets. They could go outside onto the decks twice a day for only a few minutes at a time. The police allegedly insulted and ill-treated them, keeping them under permanent surveillance, and they claim not to have received any information from the authorities.
- The applicants were released on arrival at Tunis airport.
- Criminal proceedings for abuse of power and unlawful arrest were opened against an unknown person or persons, but the public prosecutor sought to have the charges dropped.
- In his decision of 1 June 2012, the Palermo preliminary investigations judge agreed with the public prosecutor that the facts of the case could not be characterized as a criminal offense.

title: CASE OF VAŠČENKOVS v. LATVIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1986, died on 3 November 2015; proceedings pursued by his grandmother.
- Police investigations opened into incidents of theft and robbery in July-August 2011, later joined.
- Applicant arrested on suspicion of robbery on 12 August 2011, detained until 14 August 2011, then held in relation to theft.
- Pre-trial detention of the applicant was granted on 16 August 2011 by an investigating judge.
- Applicant appealed on 18 August 2011, but it was dismissed by the Latgale Regional Court on 2 September 2011.
- Applicant was charged with robbery, theft, involving a minor in theft, and petty theft on 19 September 2011.
- Applicant’s detention was extended multiple times from 2011 to 2013, and the judge continued the detention as the suspicion of theft and robbery were confirmed by evidence accumulated during the investigation. 
- Ludza District Court did not assess the applicant’s detention in relation to the alleged robbery, and all the detention decisions made by the judge during this period were not subject to appeal.

title: CASE OF M.P. v. FINLAND
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant and her partner cohabited and had a daughter in 2004.
- The applicant feared for her and her child's safety due to the father's violent behavior and strange conduct with the child.
- The father initiated custody and contact rights proceedings in July 2006.
- The Kouvola District Court granted the father supervised meetings with his daughter biweekly, then later unsupervised meetings every other weekend.
- The applicant claimed sexual abuse during unsupervised visits and reported her suspicions to the child welfare authorities.
- A police pre-trial investigation was conducted but found no evidence of crime or abuse.
- After the investigation, the applicant insisted her child was still at risk and reported the father to the authorities again.
- The father accused the applicant of defaming him by making false accusations, which resulted in a defamation charge and a conviction.
- The applicant appealed the conviction but was unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF IGNATOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1989 and lives in Nyzhni Sirogozy.
- On 31 May 2013, criminal proceedings were instituted in connection with a carjacking case by the Solonyansky district police department in Dnipropetrovsk Region.
- On 4 June 2013, the applicant was arrested as a suspect in connection with the incident.
- On 5 June 2013, the investigating judge of the Solonyansky District Court remanded the applicant in pre-trial detention until 4 August 2013.
- On 21 June 2013, the applicant was charged with the robbery of G committed together with V.
- The District Court remanded the applicant in custody until 1 October 2013, noting that he had been suspected of a serious crime and might continue his criminal activities.
- On 27 December 2013, the applicant applied for release to the District Court, complaining about his state of health.
- On 21 January 2014, the District Court examined and rejected that application.
- On 22 April, 17 June, and 15 July 2014, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 20 June, 15 August, and 12 September 2014 respectively.
- On 27 January 2015, the applicant and V. were convicted by the Krasnogvardiysk District Court of robbery and carjacking and sentenced to five years’ imprisonment.
- On 12 June 2015, the Mensky District Court in Chernigiv Region allowed the applicant’s application for early release.

title: CASE OF COLLOREDO MANNSFELD v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant had a restitution claim for movable property in Opočno Castle.
- The property had been confiscated twice, first by the German Secret State Police in 1942 and then by the Czechoslovak State under the Beneš decrees in 1945.
- The expropriation by the Czechoslovak State was quashed in 1947 after it was established that the applicant's predecessor was of Czechoslovak nationality and loyal to the state.
- The applicant's father and his cousin claimed the restitution of movable property in 1992, with the applicant entering the proceedings as his father's heir.
- The case was decided by way of three separate judgments due to a large number of items in question.
- In 1999, the Pardubice District Court returned a collection of paintings to the applicant and his co-plaintiff.
- In 2006, the District Court ordered the National Heritage Institute to return certain movable property to the applicant and his co-plaintiff.
- In 2007, the Regional Court quashed the judgment and dismissed the action, holding that the legislation on restitution did not apply since the property was taken away before 25 February 1948.
- The Regional Court based its decision on a letter of 24 June 1947 and the 1947 decision, which had not been raised with the parties in the course of the hearing.
- The Supreme Court dismissed an appeal on points of law lodged by the applicant, noting that the appellate court had relied on the 1947 decision.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed a constitutional appeal by the applicant as manifestly ill-founded, noting the importance of the 1947 decision.
