- In 2009, the District Court dismissed the rest of the applicant's restitution claim, referring to the judgments of the Regional Court and the Supreme Court.
- In 2011, the Regional Court upheld the first-instance judgment, relying on a letter by the Ministry of Agriculture of 27 May 1957 referring to the 1947 decision.
- The Supreme Court dismissed an appeal by the applicant on points of law in 2011.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed a constitutional appeal by the applicant in 2012, claiming a violation of his right to a fair trial and to his property, as manifestly ill-founded.

title: CASE OF CHERNAYA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was hit in the face by a pellet fired from an air gun while walking in the center of Kharkiv on June 9, 2004.
- The pellet was removed from her face, and the doctors noted a gunshot wound.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint with the police, claiming the shot was fired from a particular flat in a building in the centre of Kharkiv.
- The applicant underwent outpatient medical treatment for her injury from 10 to 26 June 2004.
- Despite the applicant's requests, she was not given access to the police investigation file.
- Police refused to open criminal proceedings, stating that it was not possible to identify the offenders and that the applicant’s allegations were unfounded.
- The decisions were annulled, and the case was returned for further investigation on appeal by the applicant.
- The investigation case file had gone missing as of August 21, 2009.
- The applicant died on November 7, 2009, unrelated to the incident.

title: CASE OF KRYAT v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lives in Novomoskovsk.
- A fight took place on 1st August 2004 involving the applicant, Z. and Sh.
- The applicant was convicted of gang hooliganism against Z. and Sh. and received a three-year suspended prison sentence on 15th November 2005.
- The Novomoskovsk Court, the Court of Appeal, and the Supreme Court upheld the conviction and sentence of the applicant.
- On 1st August 2004, a group of people entered the yard of the applicant’s house and assaulted him.
- The volunteer citizen guards used force against the applicant to take him to the police station in connection with the incident of 1st August 2004.
- The applicant was admitted to Novomoskovsk Central Hospital for his injuries, including bruises, wound, and abrasions on his back.
- The applicant’s complaint was initially rejected by the police and prosecutors, and different courts overturned those decisions.
- The prosecutor opened criminal proceedings related to the applicant’s complaint on 12th March 2009.
- The police terminated the proceedings concerning Z. and Sh. on 17th July 2009, finding that there had been no elements of a crime in their actions.
- The police suspended the investigation of the incident of 1st August 2004 at the applicant’s home on 16th December 2009, finding it impossible to identify any other people involved. No further investigation was carried out.

title: CASE OF COMUNIDAD DE PROPRIETARIOS PANDO NÚMERO 20 v. SPAIN
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts are:

- The applicant is a community of owners of a building located in Madrid.
- L., the co-owner of a house located next to the applicant's building, complained about a dividing wall belonging to the applicant's building and two other buildings located next to it being in poor condition.
- The municipality repaired the wall motu proprio in April 1994 due to the serious risk of harm posed by its condition.
- The applicant received a decree in August 1994 informing it of the repairs and ordering it to pay a provisional amount of 18,030.36 euros (EUR).
- The applicant contested the necessity of the urgent repairs in October 1994 and brought a first set of judicial administrative proceedings against the decree.
- The applicant was asked to pay the remainder of the amount owed in March 1996 and initiated a second set of judicial administrative proceedings contesting the amount of the payment.
- The applicant's request to suspend its obligation to pay was rejected in November 1996 and subsequent appeals to higher courts were unsuccessful.
- The Madrid High Court of Justice ruled against the applicant in December 2004, confirming the costs of the repairs set by the municipality.
- The applicant's cassation appeal with the Supreme Court was declared inadmissible in May 2009.
- The applicant lodged an amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court in December 2009, which was declared inadmissible in April 2010.

title: CASE OF PIRGURBAN v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on 6 March 2010 on suspicion of possessing narcotics.
- Narcotic substances were found on the applicant during a search at the Sumgayit City Police Office.
- On 9 March 2010, the applicant was charged with illegal possession of a large quantity of narcotic substances with intent to sell.
- On 10 March 2010, the Sumgayit City Court ordered the applicant’s detention for two months and acknowledged a violation of the applicant’s right to liberty concerning his arrest.
- The applicant was allegedly subjected to ill-treatment in police custody, specifically torture, multiple beatings, electric shocks, and cigarette burns.
- The applicant’s lawyer made an oral complaint to the court about the ill-treatment, and a written complaint was filed with the investigator.
- The Ombudsman was informed about the ill-treatment, and a forensic examination was ordered on 5 May 2010.
- The applicant’s case was assigned to another investigator in May 2010, and the applicant’s lawyer requested a new forensic examination.
- The first-instance court found on 25 June 2010 that the applicant had been subjected to torture.
- The Sumgayit City Court extended the applicant’s detention four times until 22 July 2010.
- On 11 July 2010, the investigator reclassified the charges against the applicant under Article 234.1 of the Criminal Code.

title: CASE OF LINDSTRAND PARTNERS ADVOKATBYRÅ AB v. SWEDEN
facts:
- The Tax Agency conducted audits of three Swedish companies from 2006-2008
- The Agency suspected that significant amounts of money had been withheld from Swedish taxation through irregular transactions between one of the companies and a Swiss company established solely to evade taxes
- The Agency applied to the County Administrative Court for permission to take coercive measures in the form of search and seizure of certain documents and other material
- The search was conducted at two addresses associated with a person responsible for bookkeeping in the audited companies
- Material of interest to the audit was found at one of the addresses and an interim decision to use coercive measures against another company was taken
- The applicant and one of the audited companies appealed the County Administrative Court’s judgment granting permission for the search, but these appeals were dismissed by the Administrative Court of Appeal and Supreme Administrative Court
- The applicant also requested exemption for certain documents seized during the search, but this request was dismissed on the grounds of lack of legal standing
- The applicant appealed this decision but was again found to lack legal standing by the Administrative Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF RADZHAB MAGOMEDOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a prison sentence in Samara and was suspected of involvement in car thefts.
- The police applied for judicial authorization to intercept the suspects' mobile telephone communications and recorded five audio tapes.
- On 26 December 2004, the applicant was arrested during an attempted car-jacking and claimed to have been beaten by the police officers.
- The applicant was detained in different prisons with overcrowded cells without adequate living conditions, for example, bedbugs, lice, and insufficient lighting or ventilation.
- The applicant was transported to court over 58 times by van, which had poor hygiene and ventilation conditions, and was incapable of using the toilet.

title: CASE OF ZHURAVEL AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table has been appended containing the list of applicants and relevant details.
- The applicants claimed that the duration of civil proceedings was excessively long.
- The applicants alleged that domestic laws did not offer an effective solution to their complaints.

title: CASE OF SHIOSHVILI AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The first applicant is a Georgian national and a mother of four other Georgian nationals
- Identity checks and subsequent arrests and expulsions were carried out on Georgian nationals in Russia between September 2006 and January 2007
- The applicants entered Russia in 1998 and again in 2003 with valid visas
- In October 2006, the applicants moved to another city in Russia to avoid expulsion
- The first applicant was asked to produce identity papers by a police officer and subsequently reported for an administrative offence in October 2006
- An expulsion decision was issued by the court in November 2006 only for the first applicant
- Five applicants left Russia for Georgia in November 2006
- The applicants claim that they were stopped by Russian migration officers on the train to Azerbaijan and detained in Derbent, Russia for several days without proper shelter, food, and medical assistance
- The first applicant gave birth to a stillborn child in Georgia in December 2006
- The first applicant suffered from severe depression and panic attacks after the expulsion, and her fourth child caught pneumonia while the youngest was diagnosed with behavioral disorder
- The first applicant lodged a complaint with the General Prosecutor’s office of the Russian Federation in July 2008, but received no further information from the authorities.

title: CASE OF DZIDZAVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. Identity checks of Georgian nationals were carried out in the end of September 2006 to the end of January 2007 in Russia
2. Georgian nationals were arrested and taken to police stations
3. Administrative penalties were imposed on them and they were expelled from Russia
4. The applicant was a Georgian national, married to a Georgian national who lived in St. Petersburg since 2004
5. The applicant returned to Georgia in May 2006 because her visa expired, while her husband stayed in St. Petersburg
6. On 3 October 2006, the applicant's husband was arrested in St. Petersburg and placed in detention by police officers
7. On 4 October 2006, he was ordered to be expelled from Russia and detained at a special detention centre for aliens
8. On 13 October 2006, he suffered from nausea and a headache and requested for medical assistance
9. On 16 October 2006, he was placed in a bus to Domodedovo Airport and suffered poor transport conditions on the bus
10. On 17 October 2006, he was allowed to leave the bus as his health deteriorated and he collapsed after a few steps and died
11. His death was caused by methadone poisoning according to the Bureau of Forensic Medical Examination of the Moscow Health Department
12. However, in the applicant's medical report, the cause of death was due to suppurative bronchopneumonia because of chronic obstructive airways disease.

title: CASE OF DEVYATOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants is provided in the attached table.
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Some applicants raised complaints under the Convention's provision.

title: CASE OF LYUBIMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- First applicant was found in possession of over 10,000 euros and 8,000 US dollars without reporting it on his customs declaration.
- He was convicted of smuggling and had his foreign currency confiscated. The conviction was upheld on appeal.
- Later, the Presidium of the Moscow City Court cancelled the confiscation order and ordered the confiscated money to be refunded to the first applicant.
- The first applicant sued the Ministry of Finance to recover the interest accrued on the retained amount during the period from 6 May 2003 to 3 June 2009, which he assessed at RUB 458,777.
- The Tverskoy District Court in Moscow granted his claim in part, awarding him RUB 11,719.20 for a specific period.
- Second and third applicants were found in possession of large sums of money without reporting on their customs declarations.
- They were also convicted and had their money confiscated, but later had it refunded by the Presidium of the Moscow City Court.

title: CASE OF BERDZENISHVILI AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points are:

- Identity checks of Georgian nationals were carried out in various places in Russia from September 2006 to January 2007.
- Many Georgian nationals were subsequently arrested and taken to police stations.
- Administrative penalties were imposed on them, and they were given decisions ordering their administrative expulsion from Russian territory.
- Georgian nationals were taken to detention centres for foreigners where they were detained for varying periods of time.
- Some of the Georgian nationals against whom expulsion orders were issued left the territory of the Russian Federation by their own means.
- Several applicants were detained, fined, and subsequently expelled from Russia.
- Some applicants left Russia by their own means, while others were flown to Georgia by aeroplane.
- The arrests, detentions, and court decisions surrounding the expulsions are matters of contention.
- The conditions of detention in the different places of detention are also a matter of contention.

title: CASE OF YUSUPOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a woman born in 1973 and living in Grozny.
- In 2006, she began living with A.A. and gave birth to their son in 2007.
- In 2007, they separated and the child continued to live with the applicant.
- In August 2011, the applicant gave permission for her brother-in-law to take the child to see his father (A.A.) who was visiting from Moscow, but A.A. never returned the child.
- The applicant applied to the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Grozny in September 2011 to determine the child's place of residence with her and to order A.A. to pay child maintenance, but the case was not considered due to the parties' failure to appear.
- The proceedings were resumed in June 2012, and in December 2012, the District Court decided that the child should live with the mother and ordered A.A. to pay child maintenance. A.A. appealed, but the judgment was upheld by the Supreme Court of the Chechen Republic in May 2013.
- Despite the court's order, A.A. refused to comply, and enforcement proceedings began in August 2013 with no success in locating A.A. and the child.
- The applicant attempted to have criminal proceedings instituted against her brother-in-law for abducting the child, but without success.
- The most recent decision, dated 23 October 2014, ordered an additional pre-investigation inquiry to be conducted. No further information was given regarding the outcome of the inquiry.

title: CASE OF MAXIAN AND MAXIANOVÁ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants are a married couple living in Vienna, Austria.
- They have lodged 13 applications with the European Court of Human Rights, most of which concerned their involvement in litigation over real properties.
- The present application concerns an action brought by the applicants before the Dunajská Streda District Court in Slovakia in 2005, which concerned ownership rights over a property they had rented out.
- The main proceedings were interrupted twice due to related auxiliary proceedings and have not been resumed since 2012.
- The applicants have complained about the length and fairness of the proceedings before the Constitutional Court on two occasions, but their complaints were rejected as ill-founded.
- The first set of auxiliary proceedings, concerning the validity of a purchase agreement, ended with a final judgment in 2008.
- The second set of auxiliary proceedings, concerning the same real property, started in 2011 and are still pending.
- The applicants challenged the length of the second set of auxiliary proceedings in a separate constitutional complaint in 2015, but the outcome is unknown.

title: CASE OF KALACHEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a table with a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complain about the length of their pre-trial detention.
- One of the applicants also complains under Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF LJASKAJ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant entered into a sale contract with three individuals to buy a house in Kutina.
- The contract stated that the applicant would pay DEM 47,000 but he only paid DEM 30,000.
- The sellers took legal action against the applicant and won the case. The applicant was ordered to pay the remaining DEM 17,000 as well as interest and court costs.
- The sellers applied for enforcement of the judgment and were granted a writ of execution in 2003 for the seizure and sale of the applicant's immovable property.
- The enforcement court assessed the value of the applicant's house at HRK 384,197 and scheduled three public auctions to sell it.
- The house was eventually sold to a buyer for HRK 70,000, and the enforcement creditors considered their claim to be settled in full.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint, which was declared inadmissible by the Constitutional Court.
- The enforcement court distributed the proceeds of the sale to the enforcement creditors and ordered the applicant's eviction from the house.

title: CASE OF RUIZ-VILLAR RUIZ v. SPAIN
facts:
- On 8 July 1991, the Spanish State filed a case before the Ciudad Real Judge of first instance No. 1, claiming that the Ruidera Lakes were part of the hydraulic public domain.
- The lakes were located on land inherited by the applicant from his mother.
- On 27 March 2002, the Ciudad Real Judge ruled in favor of the applicant's mother and declared that the lakes were part of the private domain.
- On 6 November 2003, the Ciudad Real Audiencia Provincial overturned the earlier judgment and declared that the lakes were part of the public domain.
- The applicant's mother and others appealed to the Supreme Court, which upheld the previous judgment in June 2009.
- On 4 September 2009, the applicant lodged an amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court, citing excessive length of the proceedings.
- On 28 July 2010, the Constitutional Court dismissed the appeal, stating there was no constitutional relevance.

title: CASE OF KACPER NOWAKOWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is deaf and mute, and communicates using sign language.
- The applicant and A.N. married in 2005, but separated in 2007. A.N. has custody of their son, S.N.
- The court granted the applicant specified visitation rights with his son, with the frequency and duration of visits increasing somewhat over time.
- The applicant asked for an increase in visitation rights in 2011, which was denied by the court. Experts recommended that the status quo be maintained due to the child's age, significant health needs, hearing impairment, and strong emotional ties to his mother.
- The court acknowledged the applicant's right to have contact with his son, but noted difficulties in communication and recommended that visits continue to be supervised by the child's mother.

title: CASE OF IONIȚĂ v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Dorina and Viorel-Aurel Ioniță, who live in Brăila, had a son who underwent surgery for the removal of polyps when he was four years and nine months old at the State-run Brăila Emergency Hospital.
- The son's surgery was performed by Dr C.B. and the general anaesthesia by Dr P.A, assisted by P.V.I.
- After the surgery, the child was transferred to the intensive care unit where it was noticed ten minutes later that he was cyanotic and had no pulse. Despite the team's efforts to resuscitate him, the child was declared dead two hours after the surgery.
- The cause of death was the presence of blood that had blocked his airways and flooded his lungs. The child had congenital deficiencies, including myocardia and hepatic dystrophy, and an interatrial septum aneurism, which contributed to post-operative complications.
- A criminal investigation was opened on the same day as the child's death, and both Dr C.B. and Dr P.A. were questioned and gave written statements.
- The disciplinary committee of the Brăila College of Doctors opened an investigation into the patient's death and reprimanded both doctors for their failure to perform necessary pre-surgical medical tests and to seek the applicants' informed consent before surgery.
- The applicants lodged a criminal complaint asking for those responsible to be identified and held accountable for their son's death. They joined the criminal proceedings as civil parties.
- The prosecutor's office of the Brăila District Court decided to institute criminal proceedings against Dr P.A., but P.V.I., who had been in charge of the child's post-operative care in the intensive care unit, could not be questioned as she had left her job at the hospital and was not found despite repeated summons.
- The Brăila District Court acquitted Dr P.A. and dismissed the applicants' civil claim as unfounded, but this decision was later quashed by the Galați Court of Appeal, which noted that the lower courts had not examined the allegation made by the child's parents that they had not given their consent for surgery and the general anaesthesia.

title: CASE OF MEČIAR AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicants own residential buildings subject to the rent-control scheme in Bratislava and Košice.
- Applicants obtained ownership of the flats through various means like restitution, donation, inheritance, or purchase.
- Applicants were obligated to let their flats to tenants at maximum rent fixed by the State without unilaterally terminating the leases or selling the flats.
- The situation of the applicants is structurally and contextually similar to four other previously decided cases regarding the Slovakian rent control scheme.
- The regulated rent was significantly lower than the free-market rent, resulting in pecuniary damage for the applicants.
- The applicants submitted their expert opinions regarding their properties, which calculated the pecuniary damage caused by the rent-control scheme.
- The Government submitted an expert opinion, initially drawn up in 2010, to rebut the applicants' claims. However, they later submitted conflicting expert opinions and a report from the Forensic Engineering Institute in Žilina.

title: CASE OF KORZENIAK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant worked for a Polish company carrying out construction work in Germany from 1997 to 1999.
- He claimed in a civil suit that he should have received a higher rate of pay than what was stated in his employment contract, citing an international agreement between Poland and Germany.
- The Opole Regional Court granted him the rates of pay fixed in his employment contract.
- The Court of Appeal quashed the partial judgment and remitted the case to the lower court, finding that there was no grounds for delivering a partial judgment.
- The Supreme Court examined the case multiple times and ultimately dismissed the applicant's cassation appeal, finding that his remuneration had been set at the minimal level of German employees performing similar work and that the lower courts had properly interpreted the law and evidence in the case.

title: CASE OF RIEDEL AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
1. The applicants are owners or co-owners of residential buildings subject to rent control.
2. The flats were obtained through various means and were occupied by tenants with a regulated rent.
3. The relevant legislation precluded the applicants from terminating leases unilaterally or selling the flats except to tenants.
4. The applicants' situation was structurally and contextually similar to other rent control cases in Slovakia.
5. There was a disagreement over the proportion of the market rent that the regulated rent represents.
6. The government's expert opinion suggested that the regulated rent corresponded to 14-26% of the market rent in 2010.
7. The applicants argued that the regulated rent was disproportionately low compared to similar flats not subject to the rent control scheme.
8. Each applicant provided different sources of information to support their contention.
9. The applicants invested more in repairing the building than they obtained from letting the flats under the rent control scheme.

title: CASE OF MIVES DOO v. SERBIA
facts:
- The Pančevo Commercial Court ordered a socially-owned company, DD Lola Utva Vazduhoplovna industrija, to pay the applicant specified amounts on account of damages for an undelivered airplane and the costs of the civil proceedings.
- The judgments became final on 4 June 1998 and 25 September 1998, respectively.
- Upon the applicant’s request on 5 June 2002, the Commercial Court ordered the enforcement of the judgments and further ordered the debtor to pay the enforcement costs.
- On 29 January 2008, the Privatisation Agency ordered the restructuring of the debtor, causing the Commercial Court to stay the enforcement proceedings until the conclusion of the process.
- The debtor is an active company predominantly comprised of State-owned capital, according to the website of the Serbian Business Registers Agency as of 24 October 2016.

title: CASE OF NOVOSELOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969.
- A criminal investigation was initiated into a theft allegedly committed by the applicant in Uzbekistan on June 27, 2005.
- On September 12, 2005, an investigator ordered the applicant’s arrest and placed him on the list of fugitives.
- The applicant moved to Perm in Russia.
- On January 21, 2007, the applicant was arrested in Perm.
- On January 23, 2007, a prosecutor issued a decision to detain the applicant until the extradition request was resolved.
- The prosecutor relied on Article 61 of the Minsk Convention and did not indicate that it was amenable to appeal.
- On February 19, 2007, the Uzbek authorities requested the applicant’s extradition.
- On March 6, 2007, the prosecutor applied to the court for authorization of the applicant’s detention.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Perm authorized the applicant’s detention pending extradition on March 9, 2007.
- The District Court did not set a limit on the length of the applicant’s detention and referred to Article 108 of the CCrP.
- On March 27, 2007, the Perm Regional Court upheld the decision on appeal.
- The applicant was handed over to the authorities of Uzbekistan on July 10, 2007.

title: CASE OF RODKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant's birth year: 1988
- Reason for detention: suspicion of rape of a minor girl
- Date of arrest: 3 August 2009
- Applicant remanded in custody on: 5 August 2009
- Reasons for pre-trial detention: accused of a serious crime, risk of reoffending, absconding, evidence destruction, witness intimidation or interference with investigation
- Applicant found guilty on: 24 December 2010
- Date of applicant's first letter to court: 4 October 2010
- Applicant provided two powers of attorney on: 4 August and 4 October 2010
- Powers of attorney authorized Mr. Frimu to represent the applicant before the court.

title: CASE OF I.U. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1988 in Margilan, Uzbekistan and arrived in Russia on 2 October 2014.
- The applicant was charged with participation in extremist religious movement Hizb ut-Tahrir al Islami and activities threatening the constitutional order on 5 September 2014.
- The authorities ordered his pre-trial detention and issued an international search and arrest warrant bearing his name on the same day.
- The applicant was arrested in Moscow on 24 December 2014.
- The Cheremushkinskiy District Court of Moscow ordered and subsequently prolonged his detention on 26 December 2014.
- The applicant was further charged with organizing a local branch of Hizb ut-Tahri al Islami in one of the regions of Uzbekistan on 22 January 2015.
- The Uzbek prosecution authorities requested the applicant’s extradition on the above charges on 23 January 2015.
- The applicant challenged the extradition decision in the courts, arguing that he belonged to a vulnerable group and faced a real risk of treatment contrary to Article 3 at the hands of the Uzbek authorities.
- The applicant's appeals were dismissed by a final decision of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation on 13 October 2015.
- The applicant lodged a request for refugee status on 5 June 2015, referring to persecution in Uzbekistan on religious grounds.
- The request for refugee status was refused by a final administrative decision of the migration authorities on 9 November 2015.
- The Meshchanskiy District Court of Moscow ordered the applicant’s expulsion for violating the migration rules on 25 December 2015.
- The applicant applied for temporary asylum on 16 February 2016.

title: CASE OF LAVEYKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lived in the Kyiv Region.
- On 15 August 2006, he got involved in a drunken brawl with a stranger and beat him to death.
- The date of his arrest is uncertain, but according to the applicant, he was arrested on 20 August, while the official record shows that he was arrested on 24 August.
- The Sovetskiy District Court in Omsk remanded the applicant in custody on 25 August 2006.
- The applicant was convicted of murder and sentenced to nine years’ imprisonment in a high-security facility on 28 December 2006.
- The applicant alleged that he was beaten up by police officers after his arrest.
- Multiple decisions were made to investigate the allegations of ill-treatment, but none substantiated them.
- Between 2007 and 2009, the applicant served his sentence in a crammed and poorly maintained correctional institution in Omsk.
- He was then transferred to another correctional facility, where conditions were similarly overcrowded and deprived.
- On 26 March 2010, the applicant was transferred to a medical facility, where he stayed until the end of his sentence on 23 August 2015.

title: CASE OF TRUFANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1961, 1963, and 1966, and lived in Taganrog.
- The applicants were found guilty of various offenses on July 2, 2001, but not required to serve their respective sentences due to the statute of limitations.
- On October 2, 2001, the Rostov Regional Court upheld the prior ruling.
- On January 31, 2002, the Presidium of the Rostov Regional Court quashed the July and October 2001 judgments and discontinued criminal proceedings against the applicants since the case was time-barred.
- Applicants sued the Ministry of Finance of the Russian Federation for compensation, including non-pecuniary damages related to their prosecution.
- On March 1, 2005, the Taganrog Town Court rejected their claims, reasoning that since their guilt was established, the use of restraint was justified, and thus, no compensation could be granted. 
- The Rostov Regional Court on May 11, 2005, upheld the lower court’s decision, stating that the prior judgments cleared the applicants of liability, but the use of restraint was justified as their guilt had been established.

title: CASE OF SHVETS AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their relevant application details is appended.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF IVAN AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
• A table is appended to the document that includes a list of applicants and their relevant details. 

• The applicants claimed that civil proceedings were too lengthy. 

• They also claimed that there was no effective remedy for this issue in domestic law. 

• A few applicants raised complaints based on provisions of the Convention other than the issue of excessive length of proceedings.

title: CASE OF DUDYK AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and application details is attached.
- The applicants claimed that civil proceedings were excessively long.
- The applicants claimed that there was no effective remedy in domestic law.
- Two of the applications (no. 10288/07 and 58461/08) had additional complaints under the Convention.

title: CASE OF YUDINA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table containing details of applicants and their applications is appended to the document.
- The applicants have complained about excessive length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants have complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- In applications nos. 8416/06 and 53941/07, the applicants have raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ARKHIPOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document includes a table listing the applicants and their relevant application details.
- The applicants complain about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- Applicants complain about the lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.
- Some applicants raise other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SOKOLOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with their details appended in this document.
- The applicants complained about the lengthy civil proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of effective remedy under domestic law.
- Some applicants have raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ARVANITIS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
- Applicants detained in Menemeni police station in Thessaloniki either in pre-trial detention or serving prison sentences.
- Applicants are divided into three cells: 1, 2, and 3.
- Detained for periods ranging from one to six months.
- Filthy cells with inadequate access to natural light, no blankets, unhealthy sanitary conditions, and no recreational activities.
- Healthy inmates held with sick detainees, resulting in the spread of contagious diseases.
- Instead of food, prisoners are provided 5.87 euros per day, which is insufficient for their dietary needs.
- The applicants had complained about the situation of their detention to the public prosecutor but received no response.
- The government affirms that the detention facility met quality specifications.
- Two sanitary facilities with hot water were available outside the cells.
- The facility had maintained drug addicts separately from the other detainees.
- Inmates had unlimited access to telephone cards and newspapers and magazines.
- 5.87 euros per day was given to the applicants to order food from restaurants since the police station had no cooking facilities.
- An on-call doctor was available 24/7 at Thessaloniki Police Headquarters, and detainees who needed urgent care were taken to local hospitals.
- Applicants' medical needs were taken care of according to police station records.

title: CASE OF MCNAMARA v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant founded a business in 1966 which later became Arakin Limited
- Arakin became involved in commercial disputes in the second half of the 1980s
- Tods Murray solicitors were retained in relation to those disputes but their fees were not settled in full by Arakin
- Tods Murray commenced legal proceedings against Arakin in the Outer House of the Court of Session for payment of fees in May 1996
- Arakin issued a counterclaim alleging professional misconduct and negligence in January 1998
- The dispute resulted in four sets of overlapping proceedings
- The Outer House ordered a detailed account of fees owed to be produced in 1996
- By March 1997 all accounts had been lodged with the auditor
- The auditor issued his reports in March and October 1998
- The applicant represented Arakin at hearings in early 2000
- The applicant applied for summary decree in the counterclaim and dismissal of the principal action, which was dismissed in 2001
- The Outer House sought to regulate the procedure from June 2001 to April 2002
- The allegations of fraud against Tods Murray were determined in March 2004
- The Outer House finally determined all questions relating to the valuation of the accounts in October 2008
- The Outer House held an eight-day hearing of legal issues in December 2009
- The Outer House held a hearing on the facts in July 2011
- The applicant was found liable in the sum of GBP 86,376.40 in February 2012
- The Outer House granted a further one-week adjournment in July 2013 but the applicant did not appear
- The judge found in favor of Tods Murray on the issue of expenses at an enhanced, punitive rate of expenses in light of the applicant's conduct
- The applicant was found "liable in the expenses" of an appeal in November 2014
- The Lord Advocate applied to have the applicant declared a vexatious litigant in 2009.

title: CASE OF KEBE AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Three applicants born in 1984, 1988, and 1987 respectively.
- The first applicant currently lives in Odessa, while the third applicant left Ukraine for Ethiopia on 23 November 2014, and the second applicant died on 6 March 2015.
- The second applicant left Eritrea for Ethiopia as he feared persecution for his religion and forcible military service in Eritrea.
- The first applicant was forcibly recruited into the army in Eritrea when he was fifteen and deserted after two months. His father was arrested by the Eritrean authorities for complaining about his son's forcible military service.
- The applicants stayed in Djibouti illegally, where they were repeatedly arrested by the authorities allegedly in connection with the armed conflict between Djibouti and Eritrea in June 2008.
- The applicants boarded a commercial vessel flying the flag of the Republic of Malta on 18 January 2012, with the aim of seeking asylum in any country other than Djibouti or their countries of origin.
- The applicants were discovered by the vessel crew when the vessel was passing through the Suez Canal. The vessel's owner and insurer were informed accordingly.
- The border guards later accompanied by an officer from the State Migration Service met with the applicants on 3 March 2012, during which the applicants requested asylum in Ukraine.
- On 19 August 2014, the Odesa Regional Department of the Migration Service rejected the third applicant's asylum application, finding that it was manifestly ill-founded. 
- On 9 December 2014, the ORDMS refused the second applicant's application. He appealed to the Odesa Administrative Court, which terminated the proceedings following the second applicant's death on 6 March 2015.
- On 12 August 2015, the ORDMS refused the first applicant’s application, which he appealed to the Odesa Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF LYKIN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Molodetske, in the Donetsk Region.
- On 28 January 2007, the applicant read out a letter during a meeting attended by over forty party members and inhabitants of the village of Zolotarevka.
- The letter contained allegations of improper behavior by G.Sh., a Deputy President of the Shaktarsk District Executive Committee, with eleven signatures attached, but no indication of full names.
- G.Sh. instigated civil proceedings against the applicant for having disseminated defamatory information about him.
- The Shaktarsk Court found the applicant at fault in defaming G.Sh. and awarded the latter 200 Ukrainian hryvnias (UAH) in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that the Citizens’ Applications Act was not applicable to the case.
- The Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal upheld the judgment of the Shaktarsk Court.
- The Supreme Court of Ukraine rejected the applicant’s request for leave to appeal in cassation.

title: CASE OF KIRINS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested by Inspector S.K. of the Daugavpils City Police on 16 January 1995.
- The applicant was beaten by Inspector S.K., causing him injuries to his head and chest.
- The applicant's eye problems worsened, leading to retinal detachment, and he was granted category 1 disability status for complete loss of vision.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against Inspector S.K. and the applicant was joined as a civil party to those proceedings.
- S.K. was found guilty of abusing his official power in a violent and disrespectful manner and sentenced to three years' imprisonment.
- The applicant claimed compensation for damage caused by the criminal offence committed by S.K., claiming both pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages.
- The applicant was awarded LVL 90,000 in non-pecuniary damages and LVL 4,427.81 in pecuniary damages, which were later reduced to LVL 4,502.81 on appeal.
- The courts found no direct causal link between the applicant's loss of sight and his injuries sustained from the beating.

title: CASE OF B.K.M. LOJISTIK TASIMACILIK TICARET LIMITED SIRKETI v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- Applicant company B.K.M. Lojistik Tasimacilik Ticaret Limited Sirketi has its registered office in Istanbul
- On 13 November 2008, customs officers found packages of unknown content in the applicant company’s lorry, which were revealed to contain heroin
- The police inspected the lorry and trailer and found 105 kg of heroin; the driver was arrested and detained
- The Ptuj District State Prosecutor’s Office charged the driver with the production and trafficking of illegal drugs and requested confiscation of the lorry
- The Ptuj District Court informed the applicant company that the lorry had been seized and could not be returned until a decision on the merits had been made
- The Higher Court ordered the confiscation of the lorry despite the applicant company’s opposition, citing Section 186(5) of the Criminal Code
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant company’s constitutional complaint and initiative for review of the constitutionality of Section 186(5) of the Criminal Code
- The applicant company had the opportunity to buy the confiscated lorry at a public auction, which was subsequently sold for 12,000 euros, though there is conflicting information about who purchased the lorry.

title: CASE OF BOACĂ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants are Romanian nationals of Roma origin and heirs of I.B.
- I.B. died while the domestic proceedings were still pending.
- L.N., who was sixteen at the time, moved in with her boyfriend at I.B.'s home.
- L.N. made a statement expressing her wish to live with her boyfriend, accompanied by the applicants.
- The police entered I.B.'s home to investigate L.N.'s disappearance.
- The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas, caused damage to property, and injured the sixth applicant.
- The police concluded in their report that the use of force had been proportionate and ruled out any racial motive for the operation.
- The prosecutor's office decided not to prosecute and the decision was upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF ULRICH LELL GMBH v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- Applicant company is a limited liability company based in Ansfelden.
- Applied for permission to modify its facility site on May 3, 2000.
- Oral hearing was held on March 1, 2001.
- Lodged application for transfer of jurisdiction on July 12, 2001.
- DAA granted permission and dismissed objections on July 23, 2001.
- Upper Austria Regional Governor lifted DAA's decision on December 18, 2001.
- Applicant company appealed against the decision and it was dismissed by the Minister on August 20, 2002.
- Administrative Court lifted the Minister's decision and held that the Regional Governor was the competent authority on December 17, 2002.
- On October 16, 2003, the Minister lifted the Regional Governor's decision and held that the latter had the authority to make the decision.
- DAA granted permission and dismissed objections on January 14, 2002.
- On December 22, 2003, the Regional Governor granted permission after lifting DAA's decision.
- Neighbors appealed against the decision to the Minister on January 26, 2004.
- Applicant company filed an application for transfer of jurisdiction on September 1, 2004.
- Administrative Court ordered the Minister to make a decision within three months on September 7, 2004.
- Administrative Court refused another request by the Minister for an extension of the time-limit on May 11, 2005, and assumed jurisdiction.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the neighbors' appeal as unfounded by judgment on July 1, 2010.

title: CASE OF PIU AND CÎRSTENOIU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1980 and the second applicant was born in 1981. They live in Jdioara and Darova respectively. 
- On 16 November 2012, the first applicant’s husband, Mr Ciprian Ionel Piu, went to the forest near Jdioara.
- They all took part in an illegal logging operation. 
- The death of the first applicant's husband happened in suspicious circumstances.
- On the same date, the Gavojdia Police Department was informed about the incident by a third party. 
- Police officers C.S. and M.S. carried out an investigation at the scene of the accident in the presence of two assistant witnesses, namely I.M. and V.A. 
- The police opened a preliminary investigation against I.M.R. for involuntary manslaughter.
- The Timişoara Forensic Institute was asked to produce a forensic necropsy report. 
- Statements were taken from I.M.R. and L.D. with regard to the circumstances of the accident. 
- The forensic necropsy report confirmed that the first applicant’s husband’s death had been caused by an acute cardio‑respiratory insufficiency following a cranial cerebral trauma and a resulting haemorrhage. 
- The Lugoj Prosecutor’s Office decided not to open a criminal investigation against L.D., I.M.R. & I.D.D. for murder.
- The investigation was reopened in March 2014.
- On 11 March 2014, the Lugoj Police Department decided to open a criminal investigation against L.D. and I.M.R. for involuntary manslaughter.
- The victim’s mother lodged a challenge against the investigators of the case and asked for the investigation to be carried out by investigators outside Timiş County.
- On 7 April 2014, a prosecutor attached to the Lugoj Prosecutor’s Office dismissed the victim’s mother’s challenge as inadmissible.
- A technical expert was appointed to produce a report that identified the cause of the accident.
- The report concluded that the individuals responsible for causing the accident could not be identified, but the two suspects were not at fault.

title: CASE OF ZYBERTOWICZ v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a publicist and professor of sociology
- The applicant was interviewed by a journalist on the subject of lustration of journalists
- The interview transcript was sent to the applicant with minor corrections
- The applicant's opinion was published in a national daily newspaper
- The applicant referenced a journalist and A.M.'s repeated claim that "I spent so many years in prison, so now I am right"
- A legal representative of A.M. sent a letter asking for an apology, which the applicant refused and published the letter
- A.M. brought a civil action against the applicant for breaching his personal rights
- The Warsaw Regional Court allowed the claim and ordered the applicant to publish an apology and pay damages to a charity
- The court did not take into consideration private expert opinions and considered the phrase a statement of fact, despite no direct evidence of A.M. ever saying it
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decision and confirmed the factual nature of the phrase
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal and confirmed the lower court's decision
- The applicant paid damages and published an apology
- Several thousand people signed a letter defending freedom of expression, while a group of Polish intellectuals published a letter against spreading untrue information.

title: CASE OF TAVARES DE ALMEIDA FERNANDES AND ALMEIDA FERNANDES v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicants are a couple living in Colares born in 1957.
- The first applicant is a well-known journalist in Portugal and editor of Público.
- The first applicant wrote an editorial entitled “The strategy of the spider” criticizing the newly-elected President of the Supreme Court of Justice, Judge N.N.
- The article discussed the alleged wrongs of the Portuguese judicial system and accused Judge N.N. of being a man as intelligent as he is Machiavellian, who manipulates and plays games of shadows and influence.
- The second applicant was not involved in the writing or publication of the article.
- The article was based on information obtained from various sources, including conversations with people from the judiciary and articles in the media.
- Several publications published articles on the system of elections to the post of President of the Supreme Court of Justice, with some of them calling the system into question.
- Judge N.N. brought an action for defamation against the applicants seeking non-pecuniary damages amounting to 150,000 euros.
- The first applicant argued that the article concerned an issue of public interest and was written in good faith.
- Several witnesses, including journalists and people from the judiciary, were heard during the proceedings.

title: CASE OF GAKHARIA v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant lives in Tbilisi and has a daughter named L.G. 
- L.G. was mainly raised by her maternal grandmother while both parents left to work abroad. 
- K.G., the mother, applied for L.G. to be officially registered at her address and, later, for L.G. to be issued an international passport without the father's consent. 
- Summonses were sent to the father's registered address but were not delivered as the house was closed up. Notifications about the proceedings were published in a daily newspaper instead, as provided for in Article 78 of the CCP.
- The applicant claimed that he only learned about the decisions in May 2012, but the domestic courts rejected his application to set the decisions aside, noting that he had been duly informed through the public notifications. The decisions were upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF KIRÁLY AND DÖMÖTÖR v. HUNGARY
facts:
1. The applicants are of Roma origin, one from Devecser and the other from Ajka.
2. Riots broke out between Roma and non-Roma families in Devecser on 25 July 2012.
3. Mr G.F., a Member of Parliament from the right-wing Jobbik party, announced a demonstration on 5 August 2012 in Devecser under the slogan “Live and let live”.
4. Nine far-right groups, known for their militant behaviour and anti-Roma and racist stance, were present at the demonstration according to official sources.
5. About 400 to 500 people participated in the demonstration, and speeches were made by various leaders promoting anti-Roma rhetoric and violence.
6. Demonstrators marched through the Roma neighborhood chanting insults and threats.
7. Some demonstrators were armed with sticks, whips, and other objects and threw pieces of concrete, stones, and bottles into the gardens of Roma people's homes.
8. The police were present during the demonstration but remained passive and did not disperse the demonstration or establish criminal responsibility of the demonstrators.
9. Several criminal investigations were opened against unknown perpetrators.
10. The Office of the Commissioner for Fundamental Rights found that the police had failed to assess whether the event had infringed the rights and freedoms of others and had failed to enforce the limits of freedom of assembly.
11. The police dismissed both applicants’ complaints that they had not taken measures against the demonstrators, thereby endangering their life and limb and their human dignity.
12. The Veszprém Administrative and Labour Court and the Kúria upheld the police's decisions and found that the non-peaceful character of a demonstration could not serve as grounds for its dispersal if the demonstration as a whole remained peaceful. 
13. The Kúria found that the police had been justified in not dispersing the demonstration or taking individual measures against demonstrators, as such actions could have caused more serious prejudice to the Roma community than allowing the demonstration to continue in a controlled manner.

title: CASE OF A.H. AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- US nationals complied with US and Russian adoption requirements from 2010 to 2012.
- Most US applicants received positive decisions from Russian authorities regarding adoption suitability and impossibility of placing the child in a Russian family.
- Russian State Duma adopted federal law no. 272-FZ on 21 December 2012 which banned adoption of Russian children by US nationals, effective 1 January 2013.
- Adoption proceedings were halted for applications not submitted to court before the law.
- Applications submitted by US nationals after 1 January 2013 were rejected on procedural grounds.
- US nationals were removed from the State databank containing information on prospective adoptive parents.
- Prospective adoptive children were transferred for adoption by different families or placed in foster homes after spring 2013.
- The Bilateral Agreement on Adoption between the US and Russia entered into force on 1 November 2012.
- Law no. 272-FZ also known as the "Anti-Magnitsky Law" or the "Dima Yakovlev Law" banned the adoption of Russian children by US nationals, in response to the US Magnitsky Act.
- March Against Scoundrels took place on 13 January 2013 and criticised the law.
- US Congress sent a letter to Russian President Vladimir Putin on 15 January 2013 to request exemption for families in final stages of adoption procedure and invite Russia to re-join the Bilateral Agreement on Adoption.
- The Russian Supreme Court instructed lower courts to allow transfer of adopted Russian children into families of US nationals where adoption decisions had been taken prior to 1 January 2013.
- Adoption proceedings were halted in all cases involving US nationals in which a decision on adoption had not been delivered before 1 January 2013. 
- Application no. 6033/13 was lodged on 22 January 2013 by three groups of applicants, with cases of D.M. and E.G. described in detail.

title: CASE OF JANKOVSKIS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and was serving a sentence in the Pravieniškės Correctional Home.
- The applicant requested information about enrolling in university via distance learning to acquire a second degree in law with a specialization in human rights.
- The Ministry of Education and Science directed the applicant to a website for information on study programs.
- The applicant requested internet access to view the website but was denied by prison authorities.
- The applicant lodged a complaint challenging the decision not to grant him access to the internet.
- The lower court dismissed the complaint, stating that prisoners could only communicate with state institutions via postal correspondence.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that the restriction on internet access affected his right to education and access to information.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the lower court's decision, stating that there was no legal provision permitting prisoners to use the internet and that granting such access could hamper the ability to monitor prisoners' activities.
- The applicant was awarded a diploma in computer skills by the Elektrėnai Vocational Educational Centre and attended English language and computer literacy courses in 2007-2008.
- The applicant also lodged a claim about being held in degrading conditions at Lukiškės Prison, which was dismissed as unfounded, but the court ruled that the applicant's computer had been unlawfully seized by prison authorities.
- The applicant's request for an extended visit by parents was initially granted but later denied due to a disciplinary offense, which was upheld by the courts.

title: CASE OF BARAKHOYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lives in Kartsa, in the North Ossetia-Alania Republic.
- On 10 January 2007 at approximately 10.30 p.m. the applicant and K. were walking down the street when a white Lada car drove up to them and two individuals in plain clothes got out and abducted the applicant.
- The abductors punched and kicked the applicant, insulted him, suffocated him with a plastic bag, and beat him on his heels, and when he lost consciousness, they poured cold water over him to revive him.
- The abductors planted a grenade in the pocket of his jacket and then interviewed him.
- On 11 January 2007, the police officers who carried out the applicant's arrest claimed that they arrested the applicant on the basis of “operative” information received, suspecting him of illegally possessing a grenade and being the leader of a group that disturbed peace in the town and provoked tension between Ingush and Ossetian population.
- On the same day, the police instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant on the charge of illegally possessing a grenade.
- On 12 January 2007, the applicant's parents retained a lawyer to represent him, and the lawyer filmed the applicant's injuries using her mobile phone.
- On 16 February 2007, the prosecutor's office discontinued the criminal investigation against the applicant on the charge of illegally possessing a grenade.
- On 19 February 2007, the deputy municipal prosecutor opened a criminal investigation into the applicant’s unlawful arrest and detention at the police station.
- On 24 December 2014, the decision of 29 June 2012 was quashed and the case was re-opened.
- On 12 January 2015, the deputy regional prosecutor identified the following defects in the investigation: the investigating authorities had failed to complete all the necessary actions in order to clarify the facts in connection with the alleged ill-treatment; no findings had been made as regards the existence of the applicant’s injuries; contradictions in the statements made by the forensic medical expert and the applicant had not been reconciled; the investigating authorities had failed to question the forensic medical expert and the forensic expert who conducted a dactyloscopic examination; the investigating authorities had failed to establish whether the police had conducted an internal inquiry in response to the applicant’s allegations of ill-treatment; the investigating authorities had not conducted a face-to-face confrontation between the police officers and the applicant in order to reconcile the

title: CASE OF CACUCI AND S.C. VIRRA & CONT PAD S.R.L. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Ms Floare Cacuci and S.C. Virra & Cont Pad SRL are the first and second applicants respectively.
- Ms Cacuci was appointed to produce a forensic accounting report by the criminal department of the Bihor County Police regarding pecuniary damage to the State budget allegedly caused by S.C. T.P. SRL.
- Ms Cacuci alleged that she had not been fully paid for the report and only submitted the conclusions of the report, claiming that the report was on her computer and she was not able to print it.
- Ms Cacuci was appointed with two other accounting experts by the Oradea District Court to produce a forensic accounting report in a criminal case concerning tax fraud, forgery, and the use of forged documents. M.G.S. and C.V.C. were acquitted based on their report.
- The prosecutor’s office attached to the Oradea District Court proposed to initiate ex officio criminal investigations against Ms Cacuci and the two other accounting experts in relation to an offence of intellectual forgery in connection with the second forensic accounting report.
- The prosecutor’s office filed an application with the court, asking it to issue a search warrant in respect of Ms Cacuci’s home in connection with the alleged offence of intellectual forgery. The court allowed the prosecutor's application and issued a warrant to search Ms Cacuci's home for evidence concerning alleged intellectual forgery.
- Items seized during the search included the computer’s central processing unit, a printer, files and documents concerning various forensic accounting reports, one CD, forty-two floppy discs, an orange notebook containing several notes written by Ms Cacuci, and an empty printer cartridge box.
- Ms Cacuci filed a complaint against the search, contesting both the search and the manner in which it had been carried out. The head prosecutor dismissed the complaint.

title: CASE OF TSARTSIDZE AND OTHERS v. GEORGIA
facts:
- Jehovah's Witnesses were allegedly subjected to religiously motivated aggression in Georgia at various times.
- The events in cases 1 and 4 were previously examined by the Court in the case of Begheluri and Others v. Georgia.
- Applicants 1-3 were prevented from attending a convention by the police, while extremists led by Father Basil were allowed to continue to attack and damage the site.
- Property belonging to the Jehovah's Witnesses was destroyed, including 1.5 tonnes of religious literature that was burnt in the street, and other items were distributed to local residents.
- The stolen and destroyed equipment and material was estimated to be worth about 9,000 euros, while the stolen and burnt religious literature was worth about 700 euros.
- Applicants 1-3 lodged an administrative complaint seeking compensation for the damages caused by the State's agents, but the courts dismissed the complaint as ill-founded.
- Applicants 4 and 5 were prevented from holding a religious meeting, their religious books and Bibles were confiscated, and they were insulted and threatened by police officers.
- Applicants 6 and 7 were stopped by police officers, had their religious tracts confiscated, and were physically assaulted by the officers.
- The applicants in all cases asked for a public apology, disciplinary proceedings against police officers, and compensation for damages.

title: CASE OF NENCIU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and is currently detained in Giurgiu Prison.
- On 24 June 1999, the applicant was convicted of burglary, rape, and murder and was sentenced to twenty-five years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant’s right to vote and to be elected was withdrawn during his detention.
- The applicant is currently serving his prison sentence in Giurgiu Prison where he has been held since 21 January 2009.
- The applicant described the conditions of his detention, which included issues with water supply, smoking, ventilation, transportation, and bugs.
- The Government presented information about the cells in which the applicant had been held, the number of detainees with whom he shared the cells, and the sanitary conditions.
- The applicant complained repeatedly about the conditions of his detention, and in response to some of his appeals, measures were taken to improve his personal space and prevent his placement with smokers.
- The applicant also complained about conditions during his stay in other prisons, namely Slobozia and Rahova.

title: CASE OF DĂSCĂLESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was sentenced to twenty years’ imprisonment for homicide in 1993.
- Applicant alleged that he had been forced to take his physiological needs together with other prisoners along the fences of the yard, while taking daily exercises in outside yards between 24 November 2004 and 2 October 2008, and had been deprived of access to toilets or running water.
- The applicant had on numerous occasions asked the Arad Prison administration to provide sanitary facilities and running water, but his requests had been consistently ignored or had received the reply that renovation works were planned for the future.
- The post-sentencing judge rejected the applicant's complaint on the same matter, as Law no. 276/2006 on the execution of sentences did not provide for the right to have access to sanitary facilities and water during the prisoners’ daily outside exercise.
- In a final judgment of 28 October 2008, the Arad District Court found that the applicant had been deprived of access to a toilet and drinking water during daily exercise, and that this was in breach of Article 48 of Law 275/2006.
- The Arad Prison authorities were ordered to ensure the applicant’s right to daily exercise in a yard provided with sanitary facilities and drinking water.
- The applicant was placed under a semi-open detention regime on 2 October 2008 and was moved to a different prison wing, where the recreation yard was provided with both toilets and drinking water.
- On 12 November 2008, the applicant was conditionally released from the prison.

title: CASE OF BENES v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Ceske Budejovice, Czech Republic.
- An arrest warrant was issued against the applicant on 26 August 1998, for committing aggravated fraud on a commercial basis and being a part of a criminal organization.
- The applicant was arrested in Germany on 12 September 1998 and extradited to Austria.
- The bill of indictment was filed against the applicant on 14 January 1999, and his objection was dismissed on 26 March 1999.
- The applicant filed a request for the acceleration of proceedings on 13 January 2003 and a first hearing was held on 25 March 2003.
- The proceedings against the applicant were separated from those against other accused on 29 October 2003.
- The applicant requested that the trial against him be resumed on 9 December 2003 and an oral hearing was held on 5 May 2004.
- The applicant filed further requests under section 91 of the Courts Act in March and July 2004.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the European Court of Human Rights on 6 December 2004, concerning the length of criminal proceedings against him.
- The case was resolved through a friendly settlement on 9 June 2008, with the government paying the applicant an amount of 12,300 euros.
- The applicant requested the discontinuation of proceedings against him or a new hearing date on 4 September 2008.
- The Wels Regional Court held another oral hearing on 15 April 2009, where the public prosecutor requested another expert opinion.
- The following oral hearing was set for 21 October 2009 but was canceled as the court-appointed expert had passed away.
- A new expert was appointed on 1 September 2011, and the applicant filed further requests under section 91 of the Courts Act on 1 September 2011, 17 November 2011, and 13 December 2012.
- All three requests were dismissed by Linz Court of Appeal on 7 November 2011, 1 February 2012, and 2 January 2013, respectively.
- On 28 May 2013, the Wels Regional Court acquitted the applicant from all charges.

title: CASE OF S.C. CARBOCHIM S.A. CLUJ-NAPOCA AND S.C. FENEGA IMPORT-EXPORT S.R.L. AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant application details provided in table
- Applicants lost civil proceedings held in their absence
- Court notices served solely by posting on gate/wall
- Applicants argued lack of awareness of court proceedings due to not receiving notifications from the court
- Complaints dismissed by courts due to service by public notice being legal
- Appeals dismissed without examination of case merits.

title: CASE OF KIM AND RYNDINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Korsakov, Sakhalin Region.
- The second applicant was born in 1948 and lives in Moscow.
- The applicants sued the Trest Zhilishchnogo Hozyajstva municipal company in two unrelated sets of civil proceedings.
- The Town Court granted the first applicant's claim for salary arrears and ordered the municipal company to pay him 1,270 euros. The judgment remained unenforced.
- The Town Court granted the second applicant's claim for compensation for the damage to her health sustained as a result of the acts of one of the municipal company's employees. The court awarded the applicant EUR 16,256. The judgment was partly enforced, and the applicant received EUR 11,888.
- The Commercial Court granted the second applicant's claim for compensation for lost income and dismissed the remainder of the applicant's claims. She was awarded EUR 44,044.
- The Commercial Court discontinued the appeal proceedings on the grounds that the municipal company had been liquidated.
- The municipal company was incorporated as a municipal unitary company set up by a decision of the local authority and provided heating supply and maintenance services in respect of municipal housing.
- The municipal company had “the right of economic control” over the assets allocated to it by the local authority.
- On 27 April 2002, the local authority withdrew most of the assets from the municipal company's economic control. The assets were transferred to a newly created company, and the debts remained with the municipal company.
- On 27 September 2005, the municipal company was declared insolvent and put into liquidation. The Commercial Court ended the liquidation proceedings on 7 May 2007.

title: CASE OF WERRA NATURSTEIN GMBH & CO KG v. GERMANY
facts:
- Applicant company purchased land with a limestone deposit and acquired a mining license to quarry.
- Company received permission to use the quarry as a landfill.
- Federal authorities planned a new motorway that would affect the company's quarrying operation.
- Bad Salzungen Mining Authority declined to approve the company's operation plan due to the motorway.
- Company had to stop quarrying limestone, transferred its activity to another nearby mining site, and bore the costs of relocating the plant.
- Land of Thuringia issued a planning decision for the construction of the motorway, modified it after the Federal Administrative Court stated that the relevant part of the planning decision was not sufficiently precise. 
- Federal Government seized the company's land for road construction purposes and initiated formal expropriation proceedings.
- Administrative Office of Thuringia Land expropriated a part of the company's land on which the motorway had been built and decided that the Federal Government should compensate the applicant company.
- On judicial review, the Meiningen Regional Court dismissed the applicant company’s request and reduced the amount of compensation.
- Thuringia Court of Appeal dismissed a prior appeal lodged by the applicant company.
- Federal Court of Justice dismissed an appeal on points of law by the applicant company.
- Federal Constitutional Court declined to consider a constitutional complaint lodged by the applicant company without providing reasons.

title: CASE OF POSEVINI v. BULGARIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The first applicant is a professional photographer who owns and manages a photography studio in Plovdiv.
- French authorities suspect a Turkish national, who has a permit to reside in Bulgaria, of forging Bulgarian identity documents and providing them to Turkish nationals residing unlawfully in France.
- Electronic surveillance reveals that the Turkish national had exchanged email messages with an alleged accomplice whose email account was hosted by a Bulgarian Internet service provider.
- The email account belongs to the first applicant and his company.
- The Bulgarian Border Police investigate and apply for warrants to search the photography studio, the first applicant's car, and the applicants' house, where they suspect evidence connected to the case might be found.
- A judge of the Plovdiv District Court issues three warrants to authorise the searches and seizures.
- The police intercept and handcuff the first applicant outside his house, before searching his house, car, and photography studio.
- They seize a number of items, including SIM cards, identity documents, computers, cameras, memory cards, flash drives, and cash.
- The first applicant is searched himself, without a judicial warrant, and the police seize three flash memory drives and two mobile telephones.
- The first applicant's wife appeals for the return of the seized items.
- The police send the case file to the Plovdiv district prosecutor's office, recommending that the proceedings be discontinued.

title: CASE OF GORODOVYCH v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant underwent outpatient treatment for overactive thyroid between March 1995 and July 1996 at the State Oncology Centre in Lviv.
- The applicant was treated by Dr S.
- The applicant's health deteriorated in July 1996, and she was diagnosed with hypothyroidism.
- The applicant underwent inpatient treatment for hypothyroidism from November to December 1996 at the Endocrinology Centre.
- The applicant claimed that her hypothyroidism resulted from the treatment with a radiopharmaceutical administered by Dr S, which the doctors at the Endocrinology Centre confirmed.
- The applicant lost her thyroid and was recognized as suffering from the second-highest official degree of disability.
- Dr S issued a certificate in October 1997, stating that the applicant's treatment in 1996 included injections of a radiopharmaceutical, but did not specify the dosage or dates of injections.
- The applicant complained to the Lviv Department of the Ministry of Health in May and June 1998, claiming that the radiopharmaceuticals administered by Dr S seriously damaged her health.
- The Department found no data regarding the applicant's treatment with radiopharmaceuticals in the records of the Oncology Centre, and recommended the Centre dismiss Dr S. Dr S retired shortly afterward.
- In July 1998, the applicant complained to the Lviv prosecutor's office, providing the certificate of October 1997 as evidence.
- An official investigation was launched in January 1999 and carried out initially by the prosecutors and later by the police.
- Several forensic examinations were performed.
- The applicant's complaint was principally rejected because it was impossible to establish the cause of the destruction of the applicant's thyroid.
- The most recent decision on 18 January 2016 instructed the police to carry out further investigation in the applicant's case, finding that the police had failed to examine all pertinent evidence and that an additional forensic examination was necessary.
- The investigation is ongoing.

title: CASE OF KULYKOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicants were domestic court judges who were dismissed from their posts.
- The High Council of Justice (HCJ) established that they had breached the judicial oath.
- The HCJ's decisions were submitted to Parliament or to the President of Ukraine for the final decision on their dismissals.
- The applicants challenged their dismissals before the Higher Administrative Court (HAC) or other courts.
- The HAC rejected most of the applicants' claims as unsubstantiated.
- In some cases, Parliament adopted multiple resolutions for their dismissal, and the HAC examined their claims challenging each of them separately.
- In one case, the Acting President of Ukraine reversed the Presidential decree concerning the applicant's dismissal.
- In some cases, the HAC found violations in the parliamentary procedure for the applicant's dismissal and declared the parliamentary resolution concerning the applicant unlawful.
- The HCJ joined some of the proceedings as a third party, and objections raised by the applicants were rejected as unsubstantiated.

title: CASE OF STAMOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
• The applicant rented a municipally-owned shop in Primorsko.
• The applicant applied to the municipal council to purchase the shop under the preferential privatisation procedure for tenants of state and municipally-owned property, expressing her wish to buy the plot of land as well.
• After the lower court rejected her application for judicial review, the Supreme Administrative Court quashed the judgment and referred the case back to the municipal council to open a privatisation procedure.
• The municipal council explicitly refused to sell the shop to the applicant multiple times, leading to several legal proceedings.
• The municipal company managing the shop informed the applicant that she had no lease contract for 1996 and lodged a rei vindicatio claim against the applicant, which was later dismissed by the Supreme Court of Cassation.
• The mayor ordered the demolition of the shop in 1999, which was later revoked by the Governor of the Burgas Region. The municipal company sold the shop to a private company, which prevented the applicant from entering the shop, leading to legal proceedings and a final dismissal of the buyer's claim.
• The municipal council sold the shop to an individual in 2005 and subsequently ordered its demolition, which was carried out with police assistance. The applicant's belongings were either listed and taken for safekeeping or destroyed with the shop, and she suffered from severe depression as a result.
• The applicant sought damages against the municipal authorities for their failure to implement the final court judgments in her favor.
• The Burgas Administrative Court awarded the applicant damages for non-pecuniary damages but rejected her claims for pecuniary damages, which the Supreme Administrative Court upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF KOMAROV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant, a former police officer, and his son were apprehended on suspicion of illegal production, storage and sale of drugs. 
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant and two other people. 
- The applicant was arrested and detained in pre-trial detention. 
- The applicant was represented by a lawyer and his wife acted as his lay representative during the trial. 
- The applicant was convicted and sentenced to eight-and-a-half years’ imprisonment and the confiscation of his personal property was ordered. 
- The applicant's son was taken into custody with him and remained with him for most of the time. 
- The applicant's wife lodged a criminal complaint with the prosecutor's office alleging the unlawful detention of their son. 
- The prosecutor refused to institute criminal proceedings as it had been established that no pressure had been applied to the applicant’s son and that he had not been deprived of his liberty. 
- The applicant and his wife initiated civil proceedings against the SBU claiming damages for the unlawful detention of their son. 
- The applicant was detained in pre-trial detention centre no. 10 and released on 24 February 2009.

title: CASE OF SINGH AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicants were detained in Korydallos prison in Athens.
- The prison was designed to accommodate 700 prisoners, but it had held 2,400 prisoners.
- The cells in wings A, B, D, and E had measured 9 sq. m, including the sanitary facilities, and accommodated four or five prisoners.
- The toilet facilities had been partially separated from the cells, and there had been inadequate natural light, ventilation, heating, and hot water.
- Cells had been dirty and overrun with pests, and sick prisoners had been held with healthy ones, leading to the spread of contagious diseases.
- Inmates had been confined to their cells for sixteen to seventeen hours per day, with poor quality and nutritional value meals served inside.
- The prison had been understaffed, and the safety of prisoners could not be secured.
- The inmates had protested about their conditions of detention on 21 June 2013 but did not receive any reply.
- According to the Government, prisoners had had access to a large yard daily, with a central heating system and hot water available twice a day.
- The cells had a window ensuring sufficient light and ventilation and had been cleaned twice a day. 
- The prison offered recreational activities such as sports, television, and access to jobs, educational courses, and a reading club.
