- The prisoners had access to the prison’s infirmary with twenty doctors of different specialties, including two psychiatrists, offering consultations.

title: CASE OF KOPRIVNIKAR v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and is detained in Dob pri Mirni.
- On 23 April 1999, the 1999 Amendment to the 1994 Criminal Code came into force.
- On 17 September 2004, the applicant was convicted of robbery by the Ljubljana District Court and sentenced to four years in prison. 
- On 1 November 2008, the 2008 Criminal Code came into force.
- On 16 June 2009, the applicant was convicted of having paid with a bad cheque and of fraudulent use of a bank card in the period between 19 January and 19 August 2005, and was sentenced to five months’ imprisonment.
- On 9 April 2009, the applicant was found guilty of murder committed together with another person on 15 September 2002, and was sentenced to thirty years in prison.
- On 28 November 2011, the applicant applied to the Ljubljana District Court to have the three prison terms joined in an overall sentence.
- On 13 January 2012, the Ljubljana District Court joined the three above-mentioned prison sentences, including the one for robbery which the applicant had already completed, in an overall sentence of thirty years’ imprisonment.
- On 29 May 2012, the Ljubljana Higher Court rejected the appeal lodged by the applicant and upheld the first-instance judgment. 
- On 6 December 2012, the Supreme Court rejected the application for the protection of legality, disagreeing with the applicant.
- On 24 April 2013, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint.
- On 24 March 2015, the applicant was convicted of another murder committed and was sentenced to thirty years’ imprisonment, but a new overall sentence of thirty years was imposed.

title: CASE OF VALANT v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former rally driver and owns a car repair shop authorized to remodel cars for competition.
- On 17 December 2002, a search warrant was issued on suspicion of him exchanging the chassis numbers of two cars and smuggling a second car through the border without paying customs duties.
- A racing car and documents were seized during the search. The applicant requested return of the car but was denied.
- On 14 February 2003, the applicant was charged with forgery, certifying false documents as genuine and smuggling before the Novo mesto District Court.
- On 28 March 2003, the applicant paid to lease another racing car for the 2003 season and participated in races in April, May, August, September and October 2003.
- In May and June 2003, the smuggling charge was dropped, and the criminal investigation related to forgery and certification of false documents were transferred to the Trebnje Local Court.
- On 4 July 2003, a decision was made on the amount of customs duties to be paid; on 7 July 2003, the applicant paid the customs duties, and the car was returned to him.
- The applicant filed a claim against the Republic of Slovenia, claiming compensation for the pecuniary losses sustained due to the seizure of his car in the criminal proceedings in March 2005.
- After several court hearings, the applicant's claim was dismissed, and he was ordered to pay the opposing party's costs of EUR 3,462.19 in February 2009.
- The Ljubljana Higher Court and Supreme Court dismissed his appeals in July and December 2009, respectively.
- The constitutional appeal was dismissed by the Constitutional Court in October 2011.

title: CASE OF FRIDMAN v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant signed a contract on lifelong maintenance with an 88-year-old neighbour in March 2009.
- The contract required the applicant to take care of the neighbour by providing her with food, medication, and other necessary assistance until she died, in exchange for the rights to her apartment transferred to the applicant by the neighbour.
- The neighbour lodged an application with a court to terminate the contract in June 2009, alleging that the applicant had not fulfilled his obligations and had not been taking proper care of her.
- The regional court granted the neighbour's application and annulled the contract in January 2010, despite the applicant contesting the termination and arguing that he had complied with the contract terms.
- The applicant appealed the termination to the Court of Appeal, which held an oral hearing in October 2010 in the applicant's absence, noting that he had been notified of the hearing.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the first-instance judgment in its entirety in October 2010.
- The Supreme Court refused to examine the applicant's three cassation appeals on the grounds of raising no important legal questions in November 2010, December 2010, and January 2011, respectively.
- The applicant complained that he had not been duly notified of the Court of Appeal hearing, thereby unable to defend his interests effectively.

title: CASE OF NIKOLIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- In 1961, the applicants' predecessors were deprived of land in favour of the state.
- On 26 January 2006, the Niš Municipal Court ordered PIK Niš to pay compensation to the applicants for the land.
- On 25 October 2006 and 1 February 2007, the enforcement of the judgment was ordered.
- Mr Tomislav Đorđević did not request enforcement of the judgment.
- On 3 June 2009, insolvency proceedings were opened in respect of the debtor.
- Only one applicant, Ms Milica Nikolić Jajčević, submitted her claims in the insolvency proceedings.
- The insolvency proceedings are still ongoing.
- On 2 March 2009, 31 August 2009, and 9 June 2010, respectively, all applicants lodged their constitutional appeals.
- The Constitutional Court found a violation of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time in respect of all applicants, except Mr Tomislav Đorđević, on 17 March 2011, 4 April 2012, and 23 May 2012.
- The court did not award the applicants any damages, stating that they "had not claimed non-pecuniary damages."
- The appeal was dismissed in respect of Mr Tomislav Đorđević.

title: CASE OF KHAMIDKARIYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Uzbekistan.
- The information provided by the applicant's representative and the Government concerning the circumstances of the case is limited and conflicting.
- The applicant fled political persecution in Uzbekistan and moved to Russia on 26 December 2010.
- In 2011, the Uzbek authorities charged the applicant in absentia with crimes related to religious extremism and put his name on an international wanted list.
- On 10 July 2013, the applicant was arrested in Moscow on the basis of the Uzbek warrant, but was released on 9 August 2013 on the grounds that the crimes he had been charged with did not constitute criminal offences under Russian law.
- The applicant applied for refugee status, which was initially rejected by the Moscow FMS but was later approved by the Zamoskvoretskiy District Court of Moscow.
- On the evening of 9 June 2014, the applicant was abducted by two FSB officers and taken to an unidentified house, where he was beaten and kept until the following day.
- On 10 June 2014, the two FSB officers took the applicant to a runway at one of Moscow's airports and handed him over to Uzbek officials.
- The applicant was placed under arrest and detained for two months in Uzbekistan, where he was subjected to torture and other ill-treatment.
- The applicant was found guilty of crimes under Uzbekistan's Criminal Code and sentenced to eight years' imprisonment.
- The applicant's lawyer refused to lodge an appeal against the judgment, but an appeal was later lodged by his representative.
- The Moscow FMS lodged an appeal against the applicant's refugee status, which was upheld by the Moscow City Court.
- The Government informed the Court about the disappearance of the applicant and the indication of the interim measures under Rule 39 of the Rules of Court, but stated that his whereabouts were unknown.
- An investigation into the applicant's kidnapping was opened by the Russian authorities.

title: CASE OF X v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a Sri Lankan national of Tamil origin, born in 1979, residing in Switzerland.
- In the 1990s, the applicant was a member of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and participated in armed resistance against the Sri Lankan Government.
- In 2003, he was detained in Colombo and was ill-treated and threatened.
- In 2007, the applicant left Sri Lanka for Italy and moved to Switzerland illegally in 2009.
- The applicant and his wife applied for asylum on grounds of political persecution in Sri Lanka.
- The FMO rejected the applicant's asylum application in 2011 and ordered his deportation to Sri Lanka, which was later executed in 2013.
- Upon arrival in Sri Lanka, the applicant's family was detained and questioned, and the applicant was incarcerated and ill-treated in Boosa Prison.
- In 2015, the applicant returned to Switzerland on a humanitarian visa and submitted a fresh asylum application, which was granted.
- The reports by Prof. W. Kälin and the UNHCR identified shortcomings in the decision-making process of the FMO.
- The FMO modified its practice and now follows criteria developed by the European Court of Human Rights in all cases involving Sri Lankan nationals.

title: CASE OF TERENTYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a musician and jazz critic who lives in Syktyvkar, the Komi Republic.
- On December 31, 2007, the applicant published an article on his personal website about a local jazz festival and its president, Mr Y, making fun of Mr Y's professional qualities.
- Mr Y. sued the applicant for defamation, claiming that the article was insulting and harmful to his reputation.
- On August 14, 2008, the Syktyvkar Town Court found the applicant guilty of defamation and ordered him to pay 5,000 Russian roubles (RUB) in damages.
- The Supreme Court of the Komi Republic dismissed an appeal by the applicant on October 23, 2008, stating that the applicant's statements on the Internet had undermined the honor and dignity of Mr Y as a person, pedagogue, and musician, and contained negative information about him.

title: CASE OF SURIKOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lived in Simferopol. 
- In 1990, the applicant graduated from the Ukrainian Printing and Publishing Institute with a diploma in technological engineering. 
- The applicant worked as a worker for the Tavrida State Publishing House from August 23, 1990. 
- In 1997, the applicant asked the director of Tavrida to place him on the reserve list for promotion to an engineering position corresponding to his qualifications. 
- The request was refused in March 2000, citing the state of the applicant's mental health. 
- It was said that in 1981, he had been declared unfit for military service due to "psychosis and psychotic disorders connected to organic cerebral lesions with residual moderately manifested deviations in the mental sphere". 
- In 2000, the applicant appealed to the Central District Court of Simferopol seeking to oblige his employer to consider him for an engineering position. 
- The court rejected his claim, and the judgment was upheld by the Supreme Court of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea. 
- In 2002, Tavrida referred the applicant for a medical examination to determine his fitness for employment as an engineer. 
- The applicant obtained a certificate of his fitness for employment as an engineer from six medical specialists, including a psychiatrist and a neurologist in September 2002. 
- In August 2003, the applicant was appointed as a foreman and in April 2006 as an engineer-technologist. 
- In October 2000, the applicant instituted civil proceedings against Tavrida seeking damages and apologies. 
- The applicant modified his claims in January 2001, seeking to oblige the defendant company to promote him to an engineering position and to pay him non-pecuniary damages. 
- The Central District Court rejected the applicant's claim in January 2001 but was remitted by the Supreme Court of the ARC for a fresh consideration. 
- In May 2002, the applicant amended his claim, alleging that the defendant company had processed his health data unlawfully. 
- The Central District Court rejected the applicant's claims in July 2003, and on 1 December 2003, the Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's appeal. 
- On 29 May 2006, the Supreme Court of Ukraine refused the applicant's application for leave to appeal on points of law. 
- In July 2006, the applicant sought civil proceedings

title: CASE OF DZIRNIS v. LATVIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1968 and lives in Riga.
- In 1940, the communist regime nationalised privately owned property in Latvia, including a plot of land and buildings in Jurmala which had belonged to a private person M.G.
- In 1991, property reform legislation came into force in Latvia, allowing former owners or their heirs to reclaim nationalised property by submitting a request to the local municipality by 1 June 1994. If not, a court had to decide on restoring property rights, provided a court claim had been submitted before 1 June 1999.
- In 1995, V.P.E. instituted such proceedings regarding the property in question in the Jurmala City Court, but did not attend the court hearings and in 1997 the court decided to leave her claim without examination.
- The property was divided into two plots by the Jurmala Municipality Land Commission in 1998 and retained as State property by the Ministry of Finance in 2000 via Order No. 349.
- On 20 December 2000, V.P.E. requested the restoration of her property rights to the whole nationalised real estate, and on 2 February 2001, the Jurmala City Court ruled in her favour, establishing that she was the legitimate heir of M.G.
- The judgment was not appealed against and became final on 29 February 2001, after which V.P.E. was registered in the land register as the owner of both plots of land.
- V.P.E. sold the contested property to the applicant for 39,000 Latvian lati in May 2001, after which the applicant was registered as the owner of the property in the land register and paid real estate tax on it.
- On 1 August 2001, the Senate of the Supreme Court quashed the Jurmala City Court judgment of 2 February 2001 and ordered a new adjudication of the case, upholding the Prosecutor General’s objection that the Jurmala City Court had erred in choosing the applicable substantive law and had overstepped the limits of its competence, and that the appellate court had ignored the applicant’s argument that it was necessary to decide on a reversal of the execution of the judgment of the Jurmala City Court.
- In 2002, the Ministry of Finance brought a property claim with Riga Regional Court against the applicant and V.P.E. as defendants, asking that the

title: CASE OF LEONOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicant was born in 1948 and lived in Donetsk, Ukraine. He had a basic education in law and worked as a police officer.
- On 23 August 2001, the applicant had a fight with D. in which blows were exchanged, witnessed by at least three people. The next morning, D. was found dead near the applicant's place of work.
- The applicant was arrested on 24 August 2001 and detained until 25 August 2001. During this period, he alleges he was ill-treated by the police and coerced into pleading guilty.
- On 25 August 2001, the applicant was charged with inflicting grievous bodily harm on D. which resulted in his death.
- Between August and September 2001, a hoe was found near the place where D.'s body had been found.
- The applicant declined legal representation until 2 October 2001.
- In November 2001, investigative steps were taken, including questioning of the applicant and witnesses.
- On 26 November 2001, the indictment was approved by the district prosecutor and sent to the District Court.
- On 10 September 2002, the District Court found the applicant guilty of murder and sentenced him to eleven years' imprisonment.
- On 11 July 2003, the Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal quashed the judgment for the not conclusive evidence.
- On 2 August 2004, after nineteen hearings, the District Court found the applicant guilty of murder and sentenced him to eleven years of imprisonment, taking into account evidence such as medical reports, eye-witness testimonies to the fight, and forensic expert reports.
- On 25 October 2007, the Supreme Court of Ukraine rejected the applicant's appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF VORONTSOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Three applicants born in 1977, 1972, and 1987 respectively.
- The applicants lived in Krasnoyarsk, Cheboksary, and Vologda Region before their convictions.
- One applicant was arrested on May 3, 2013, on suspicion of committing a crime.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of Krasnoyarsk remanded the applicant in custody.
- The applicant's detention was extended several times until the conviction was made on April 4, 2014.
- The conviction was for robbery, and the sentence was three years and six months.
- Applicant was held in a metal cage during the hearings before the district court and appeal court.
- The Krasnoyarsk Regional Court upheld the judgment of April 4, 2014, on June 23, 2015.
- One applicant was convicted of embezzlement and illegal acquisition, storage, transfer, transportation, and possession of firearms on June 30, 2011.
- One applicant was convicted of fraud committed through abuse of position on February 11, 2013, and was sentenced to a fine.
- The Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic reduced the applicant's fine on August 1, 2013.
- The Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic quashed the judgment of February 11, 2013, and the appeal decision of August 1, 2013, on October 18, 2013.
- The District Court convicted the applicant of nine counts of fraud and acquitted him of four counts of fraud on April 29, 2014.
- The applicant was sentenced to seven years in prison and was confined in a metal cage during trial.
- On June 25, 2014, the Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic reclassified the nine counts of fraud and sentenced the applicant to seven years' imprisonment.
- One applicant was arrested on September 16, 2014, on suspicion of committing a crime.
- The Cherepovets Town Court of the Vologda Region remanded the applicant in custody on September 17, 2014.
- The applicant was convicted of inflicting grievous bodily harm on December 12, 2014. 
- The sentence was three years’ imprisonment, and the applicant was confined in a metal cage during trial.

title: CASE OF BOLJEVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant entered Croatia from Montenegro twice in 2009 and deposited EUR 90,000 each time with a commercial bank in Dubrovnik without declaring the amounts to the customs authorities.
- The Money Laundering Prevention Office informed the Financial Inspectorate of the Ministry of Finance that the applicant had transferred EUR 95,000 to a bank account in the United Arab Emirates from his bank account, which had originated from the two cash deposits.
- Administrative offence proceedings were initiated against the applicant for failing to declare the sum of EUR 180,000 while entering Croatia.
- The Administrative Offences Council found the applicant guilty of the administrative offence, imposed a fine of 10,000 Croatian kunas, and confiscated EUR 180,000.
- The Council held that the evidence presented did not corroborate the applicant’s defense, and its decision to apply the protective measure was influenced by the fact that the accused provided insufficient evidence to justify their earlier money transfers.
- The High Court for Administrative Offences dismissed the applicant’s appeal and upheld the Administrative Offences Council’s decision, and the Constitutional Court declared the applicant’s constitutional complaint inadmissible.

title: CASE OF VAKHITOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1986, detained in Sterlitamak, Perm region
- Applicant convicted of drug trafficking on 24 August 2009 
- Conviction quashed by Supreme Court of Bashkortostan Republic on 2 February 2010
- Applicant and lawyer missed 4 March 2010 hearing despite notification sent via ordinary letter post and ordered to appear compulsorily 
- Applicant remanded in custody in absentia on 19 March 2010 after missing hearing
- Applicant arrested on 15 April 2010, placed in temporary detention center in Tuymazynskiy district, and transferred to Ufa
- Applicant released on 25 May 2010 with undertaking not to leave place of residence
- Trial court found applicant guilty of drug trafficking on 15 March 2011 and sentenced him to four years and six months’ imprisonment
- Applicant born in 1973 and detained in Krasnodar, indicted for murder on 25 April 2013
- Applicant’s name placed on international search list on 30 May 2013 and arrested on 11 July 2013
- Applicant’s detention extended on 4 September 2013 and challenged on unspecified date.

title: CASE OF ABUBAKAROVA AND MIDALISHOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are wives of Mr Shamkhan Abubakarov and Mr Badrudi Abubakarov, respectively.
- The three relatives died on 30 September 2002 in a collision with an IFV military vehicle.
- The police station was informed of the incident on the same day.
- The investigation was initiated under the charge of "breach of traffic regulations, causing death by negligence."
- The investigation was suspended and resumed several times.

title: CASE OF ROZHKOV v. RUSSIA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lived in Belgorod.
- The applicant had a university degree in law and made his living as a registered private entrepreneur providing legal services.
- In April 2005, the applicant undertook to provide legal services to a private company in relation to administrative-offence proceedings against it. The company issued two originals of an authority form for the applicant.
- In June 2005, criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on suspicion of forgery of the administrative-offence record (“the offence record”) in the above case.
- Subsequently, the case was reassigned, and the authorities were unable to locate the applicant for some time.
- On 25 January 2006, the police talked to the applicant’s mother and took him into custody.
- The applicant complained about his arrest, but the court held that he had not been arrested, only compelled to appear before the investigator.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant were discontinued on 1 November 2010 due to the absence of corpus delicti.
- It appears that the applicant’s wife managed the Vityaz Arbitration Bureau, and the applicant was appointed as its managing director on an unspecified date.

title: CASE OF NAVALNYY v. RUSSIA
facts:
Facts of the case:
- The applicant is a political activist, opposition leader, anti‑corruption campaigner, and popular blogger.
- The case concerns his arrests on seven occasions at different public events.
- On March 5, 2012, the applicant and others participated in a meeting at Pushkinskaya Square, Moscow.
- The police arrived and arrested the applicant on charges of holding an irregular gathering without prior notification and shouting political slogans.
- On May 8, 2012, the applicant was arrested twice. The first time, he was walking down Lubyanskiy Proyezd and was arrested by the riot police. The second time, he was walking down Bolshaya Nikitskaya Street and was surrounded by riot police and arrested.
- On May 9, 2012, the applicant was arrested for discussing current affairs at Kudrinskaya Square in Moscow.
- On October 27, 2012, the applicant held a static demonstration and was arrested on charges of organizing an irregular march without prior notification.
- On February 24, 2014, the applicant was arrested twice in different locations.

title: CASE OF TRETYAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant complained about inadequate conditions of detention in two separate facilities.
- The Government acknowledged that the conditions of the applicant’s detention in the first facility violated his rights guaranteed by Article 3 of the Convention and offered to settle with a payment of 4,935 euros.
- The Government did not comment on the complaint about the second facility.
- The applicant agreed to the terms of the Government's declaration.

title: CASE OF RASHKOVA AND SIMEONSKA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Applicants born in 1970 and 1935, living in Sofia and Ruse
- Property owned by D.D. and P.R. in Popovo was expropriated in 1988 and 1989
- Compensation was promised: a two-room flat for D.D. and the right to build a house on municipally owned land for P.R.
- Construction work began in 1994 after the expropriated house was pulled down
- D.D., P.R., and D.D.'s wife passed away in 1998, 2002, and 2011 respectively
- Applicants requested revocation of the expropriation in 2005, which was refused
- Court annulled the mayor's tacit refusals several times and instructed the mayor to examine the applicants' request under paragraph 9(1) of the transitional provisions of the Territorial Planning Act
- Mayor failed to take a decision repeatedly
- An expert commission assessed the value of the expropriated property, and the compensation was set at BGN 83,500
- The compensation was paid to the applicants in June 2012

title: CASE OF PETROVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1944, 1964 and 1966 respectively and lived in Razgrad.
- The property of the first applicant and her husband was expropriated by the mayor on 28 June 1988 with a view to constructing a residential building.
- The first applicant and H.P. were to be compensated with a flat and a garage by the decision of the mayor.
- The garage was to be located in a residential building that the municipality planned to construct, and the first applicant and H.P. had to pay for the cost of the garage that was not covered by the value of their expropriated property 4,479 old Bulgarian levs (BGL).
- The flat due to be given to the first applicant and H.P. was constructed and delivered to them, and the expropriated house and garage were pulled down.
- In 1996, the mayor of Razgrad offered the first applicant and H.P. a garage in another part of the city, which they refused.
- The building where the garage offered to them was to be situated was never constructed.
- In 2006, the municipality authorised the construction of another building by a private investor in the same place which did not include garages.
- In 2006, the mayor advised the first applicant and H.P. that they could request financial compensation, but they insisted on receiving a garage.
- In February 2009, H.P. passed away and was succeeded by the three applicants.
- In 2010, the applicants brought an action in tort seeking pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages, which was dismissed in a final judgment on 16 November 2011 by the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF DZHABAROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table containing a list of applicants and the relevant details of their applications is appended.
- The applicants raised complaints about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Application no. 59613/14 also includes other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF PARYZKYY AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The list of applicants and their details are in the table appended.
- The applicants complained about the lengthy criminal proceedings's excessive duration.
- The applicants also complained about the absence of an effective remedy under domestic law.
- In application no. 58058/13, the applicant raised other complaints under Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF GAVRILYAK AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document includes a table with a list of applicants.
- The applicants felt that the civil proceedings were too long.
- The applicants claimed that there was no effective legal recourse for their issue within the domestic law.

title: CASE OF LOPUSHANSKYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was the director of a private joint stock company in Yuzhnoukrayinsk.
- In November 2003, he won a debt recovery lawsuit against Mr Ts.
- In December 2003, Mr Ts's wife authorised the applicant to use their car, but later revoked the power of attorney while the car remained with the applicant.
- The police arrested the applicant in March 2004 over claims of extortion and forcibly retaining Mr Ts's car.
- Mr Ts confirmed receiving a payment of USD 1,700 from the applicant and had no further claims against him.
- The Yuzhnoukrayinsk Court annulled the criminal proceedings against the applicant in April 2004.
- The applicant filed a claim for compensation for his arbitrary prosecution and arrest, the allegedly unlawful search of his company premises, and the seizure of the car.
- He also claimed for pecuniary damage, including the amount owed by Mr Ts and a payment of USD 5,000.
- The court granted the applicant UAH 8,585 in compensation for pecuniary damage and UAH 25,000 in non-pecuniary damage.
- The Mykolayiv Regional Prosecutor's Office, the State Treasury of Ukraine, and the applicant appealed the decision.
- The Court of Appeal allowed the defendants' appeal and awarded the applicant UAH 5,000 in non-pecuniary damage and UAH 1,000 in costs and expenses but found that the state was not required to reimburse the applicant for money paid to a private individual.
- The applicant appealed the decision, claiming he did not receive a notification of the hearing.
- The Kherson Regional Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF FORTUNSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts from the document include:

- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence in Dnipro.
- The applicant and eighteen other persons were found guilty of different crimes committed as a gang in the Odesa Region between 1995 and 1999.
- The applicant's conviction was based mainly on his co-defendant's statements and on objects found in his wife's home during a search.
- The trial court dismissed the applicant's allegations of ill-treatment.
- The applicant was assisted by different lawyers during the trial.
- The applicant refused to give statements and stated he had an alibi. His requests to summon other persons as witnesses were refused.
- The presiding judge on the panel of the Court of Appeal was allegedly not impartial.
- The applicant protested against the unlawful manner of his case by stitching up his lips together and going on a hunger strike.
- The applicant challenged his conviction in an appeal to the Supreme Court.
- The Supreme Court upheld the applicant's sentence but partially changed his conviction.
- The applicant lodged the present application while being detained at Odesa Pre-Trial Detention Centre.
- The applicant alleged persecution by the SIZO authorities and was allegedly beaten by guards and sustained a head injury.
- The applicant was transferred to Dnipropetrovsk Correctional Colony to serve his sentence and alleged that his letters to the Court were blocked or delayed.
- The applicant was under special supervision as he was considered inclined to commit self-mutilation.
- The applicant was disciplined and placed in an isolation cell on several occasions.

title: CASE OF ZAKHODYAKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were convicted of various crimes in Russia
- Most of the applicants and their lawyers were initially refused leave to attend appeal hearings
- Supervisory-review courts quashed the appeal judgments and remitted the cases for fresh examinations before the appellate courts
- In most cases, the applicants and their lawyers were present at the new appeal hearings
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against Mr Zakhodyakin on 12 November 2002 and were suspended and reopened several times
- Mr Zakhodyakin was found guilty of abuse of office on 26 June 2007 and sentenced to one year's imprisonment
- The judgment of 24 August 2007 was upheld on appeal by the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic
- The Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic quashed the judgment of 24 August 2007 on 8 October 2008 and remitted the case for a fresh examination
- The judgment of 26 June 2007 was upheld by the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic on 7 November 2008
- The Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic quashed the judgment of 7 November 2008 on 3 October 2012 and remitted the case for a fresh examination
- The judgment of 26 June 2007 was upheld by the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic on 18 December 2012.

title: CASE OF MAROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were convicted of various crimes in Russia.
- All the applicants except Mr Ryzhenkov appealed their convictions.
- Mr Prasalov requested to appear in person in court but it was submitted belatedly.
- Mr Ryzhenkov and Mr Rakovskiy were not informed and not present or represented at their hearings.
- The other applicants were informed but were not able to attend.
- More information can be found in Appendix II.

title: CASE OF DINU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Șopârlița.
- The applicant’s sister reported that he was causing a disturbance in respect of his family, which led to the dispatch of two police officers to his home.
- The police officers forcibly handcuffed the applicant and immobilised him on the ground and pushed him, even though he was not resisting arrest. They dragged him towards a police car and banged his head against a metal gate owned by a neighbor.
- The applicant was fined 1,000 Romanian lei for offending his father and being inebriated.
- The applicant was diagnosed with a cervical spine injury and a minor cranial cerebral trauma and was in Bagdasar‑Arseni Emergency Hospital in Bucharest from 1 to 3 July 2013.
- The applicant’s father lodged a criminal complaint against police officers for having physically abused his son.
- The forensic report concluded that the applicant’s injury could have been caused on 30 June 2013 and he would have needed seventy to eighty days of medical care from the moment of his injury.
- A prosecutor attached to the Olt prosecutor’s office decided not to open a criminal investigation against the two police officers for abusive behavior.
- The applicant challenged the decision of 10 January 2014 before a more senior prosecutor, who dismissed the challenge.
- The applicant appealed against the decision of 29 January 2014 before the Slatina District Court, which referred the case to the Balş District Court for examination.

title: CASE OF SAYEROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and is currently serving his term of imprisonment in Nizhniy Tagil.
- Since 12 June 2011, the applicant waited trial in remand prison IZ‑21/2 in the Republic of Chuvashiya.
- Between 15 June 2011 and 15 April 2012, the applicant was transported by prison van on approximately one hundred occasions between the remand prison and temporary detention facility of Cheboksary (IVS).
- During transportation, the applicant was placed in a single occupancy cell measuring 0.25 sq. m or had to remain on his feet because there were no free seats.
- There were no toilets in the vans, and prisoners used plastic bottles.
- On the days of transport, the applicant did not receive food rations.
- Lengthy check-in and check-out procedures resulted in a two-hour wait at either facility with inmates staying inside vans.
- The applicant submitted a certificate issued by the remand prison governor showing the dates of his transport.
- The Government provided a description of the applicant’s conditions of transport, relying on transport logs concerning fifty-five trips.
- The Government stated that they could not provide the full information about the conditions of the applicant’s transport.
- The number of prisoners did not exceed the maximum capacity of vans, and an average trip lasted 35-40 minutes.
- Some of the vans were equipped with toilets, and the applicant was provided with dry food rations.

title: CASE OF LASHMANKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
A. Application no. 57818/09 Lashmankin v. Russia 
- Notification of a “picket” in the Northern Administrative District of Moscow 

B. Application no. 51169/10 Nepomnyashchiy v. Russia 
- Notification of a “picket” in the Central Administrative District of Moscow 

C. Application no. 4618/11 Ponomarev and Ikhlov v. Russia 

D. Application no. 31040/11 Ponomarev and Others v. Russia 

E. Application no. 19700/11 Yefremenkova and Others v. Russia 

F. Application no. 55306/11 Kosinov and Others v. Russia 

G. Application no. 7189/12 Zhidenkov and Others v. Russia 

H. Applications nos. 47609/11, 59410/11, 16128/12, 16134/12, 20273/12, 51540/12 and 64243/12 Nagibin and Others v. Russia 
- “Picket” of 12 June 2009 
- Meetings between October 2009 and October 2010 
- Meeting of 31 October 2010 
- “Picket” of 31 December 2010 
- Meeting of 31 March 2011 
- Meeting of 31 July 2011 
- Meeting of 31 August 2011 
- Meetings in October and December 2011 
- Meeting of 31 January 2012 
- Meetings between March and August 2012 

I. Application no. 37038/13 Tarasov v. Russia

title: CASE OF SEKRETAREV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A list of applicants and the relevant details of the applications are provided in the Appendix.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SELMANI AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicants were accredited journalists reporting from the national Parliament.
- Proceedings were held on the Budget Act for 2013, attracting considerable public and media attention.
- Opposition MPs created noise and disrupted the proceedings by slapping the Speaker's table.
- Parliament security officers entered the chamber, forcibly removing the opposition MPs and journalists from the gallery.
- The applicants, together with other journalists, were removed despite expressing their refusal to leave as they believed the public had the right to be informed about the situation.
- The Government alleged that the first applicant had injured a security officer.
- The Association of Journalists claimed that the forcible removal of the journalists violated their rights under Article 10 of the Convention.
- The DCPS informed the applicants that the security officers restored order in the chamber and asked journalists to leave for security reasons.
- A group of MPs had surrounded the Speaker and attempted to physically confront him, owing to which security personnel removed him to a place of safety.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicants’ complaint, finding that their removal from the gallery interfered with their freedom to carry out their professional duties and inform the public, but was necessary to maintain order due to chaotic and dangerous circumstances.

title: CASE OF IGBO AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicants were detained in Chios Prison, in separate cells.
- The prison was overcrowded, with each inmate allocated approximately 2 sq.m of personal space.
- The cells did not have partitioned toilets or hot water, resulting in filthiness and exposure to contagious diseases.
- Inmates were not separated according to health conditions or type of detention.
- Inmates were confined to their cells for 16-17 hours per day, without recreational or educational activities.
- Meals were insufficient and of poor quality, consumed on the beds.
- The Government argued that the cells were sufficiently ventilated, heated and had adequate natural light, were regularly cleaned and disinfected, and had access to medical care.
- The Government also argued that the prison only slightly exceeded its capacity of 120 detainees.
- Detainees had access to work opportunities and educational/recreational activities, and some of the applicants participated in these.
- The Government provided a menu from a week selected at random to demonstrate the variety of meals served.

title: CASE OF MITZINGER v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1940 in Troschenreuth, in the former German Democratic Republic (GDR), and lives in Bayreuth.
- The applicant is the natural and only daughter of Mr A.W., who recognized paternity in 1951.
- The daughter lived in the territory of the former GDR until 1984, while her father lived in the Federal Republic of Germany (FRG), having married.
- After obtaining an exit permit in 1984, the applicant moved to Bavaria and visited her father on a regular basis until 2007 when he died.
- On January 14, 2009, the applicant applied for the right to administer her father’s estate but was denied by the Memmingen District Court on January 28, 2009.
- On February 6, 2009, the applicant appealed to the Memmingen Regional Court and later to the Munich Court of Appeal in March 2009.
- Finally, on July 17, 2009, the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Federal Constitutional Court, which was declined on December 8, 2009, for lack of sufficient substantiation.

title: CASE OF MARTINS O'NEILL PEDROSA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1995 and is currently detained in Lisbon
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant on December 5, 2013, for alleged crimes of coercion, physical assault, rape, and failure to assist a person in danger
- On June 2, 2014, an EAW was issued to secure the applicant's presence before a judicial authority to be questioned
- The applicant was arrested in the United Kingdom on August 28, 2014, and surrendered to the Portuguese authorities on February 27, 2015
- The investigating judge remanded the applicant in custody on February 27, 2015, and on March 19, 2015, the applicant lodged an appeal challenging the lawfulness of the decision
- On July 2, 2015, both the Supreme Court and the Lisbon Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's habeas corpus application and his appeal, respectively, upholding the decision to hold him in pre-trial detention.

title: CASE OF S.K. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and has been kept in a detention center for foreign nationals since February 2015 in Makhachkala, Dagestan Republic, Russia.
- The applicant arrived in Russia in October 2011 and was in possession of a visa indicating the purpose of his visit as business.
- The applicant did not leave Russia, started living with a Russian national, had a child together in November 2013, and married in April 2014.
- The applicant was found guilty of an offense under Article 18.10 of the Code of Administrative Offenses in February 2013 and was found guilty of remaining in Russia after the expiry of the visa in February 2015.
- The Sovetskiy District Court of Makhachkala sentenced the applicant to a fine and a penalty of forcible administrative removal from Russia.
- The District Court ordered the applicant to be placed in a special detention facility, and he lodged an appeal against the judgment.
- The Supreme Court of the Dagestan Republic upheld the judgment and dismissed the applicant’s argument relating to his family life in Russia.
- The penalty of administrative removal was not enforced because the applicant applied for temporary asylum on 5 May 2015.
- The local migration authority and FMS respectively refused his application for temporary asylum and upheld their decision, stating that there were no grounds to consider that his life would be at a higher risk than that of other people living in Syria.
- The applicant sought judicial review of the refusal of temporary asylum, but it was left without examination in the Basmannyy District Court because the applicant had not provided necessary information. On 9 December 2015, the District Court upheld the refusals of temporary asylum, and the Moscow City Court dismissed his appeal on 8 June 2016.

title: CASE OF PENDIUC v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was prescribed Utrogestan medication by a gynecologist to maintain her pregnancy and prevent miscarriage.
- On 31 October 2014, the applicant was summoned by the prosecutor in criminal proceedings opened against her father and others concerning alleged acts of corruption.
- The applicant started feeling unwell on the day of the summon and was referred urgently to the hospital, where she was diagnosed with an inflammation of her uterus and pregnancy complications due to stress and the medication's side effects.
- Despite her medical condition, the prosecutor authorized two police officers to enforce a warrant to appear, forcing the applicant to attend the interview.
- The applicant was interviewed for eight hours by the prosecutor in the absence of a lawyer and after informing the authorities of her health condition and medical documents.
- The applicant was detained in police custody for 24 hours, during which she was not provided with medical treatment she needed for her pregnancy and suitable living conditions.
- The Bucharest County Court dismissed the DNA's request to detain the applicant pending trial for thirty days and ordered her release, on condition that she did not leave the country.
- The detention center coordination department informed the Government that the applicant had access to running cold water, and her cell had been heated at all times.

title: CASE OF MIHĂILESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a prison sentence in Vaslui Prison.
- In 2012, he was convicted of human trafficking and sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment.
- He is complaining about the conditions of his detention in Iaşi Prison and the fact that he had not been assigned a personal care assistant in Rahova and Iaşi Prisons between 2 April 2013 and 30 January 2014.
- He was detained in Iaşi Prison on several occasions, for a period of almost ten months.
- The applicant alleges that he had been kept in conditions of poor hygiene in overcrowded cells.
- According to the information provided by the National Prison Administration and forwarded to the Court by the Government, the applicant was held in different cells.
- He received a special diet for his medical condition.
- The applicant is blind and was classified as a person with a permanent, severe physical disability.
- He alleges that no special arrangements had been made for him as a person with severe visual impairment in Iaşi and Rahova Prisons between 2 April 2013 and 30 January 2014.
- He contended that he had not been assigned a personal care assistant and had been permanently subjected to humiliating and degrading remarks from his cellmates, the same people to whom he had to appeal for assistance.
- He had only received assistance from inmates in the facility in exchange for cigarettes and money.
- The applicant had submitted several requests he had lodged with the prison authorities on 21 May, 21 November and 23 December 2013 and on 20 February 2014 respectively, by which he had asked to be assigned a personal assistant.
- The Government submitted that the administration of both prisons had made diligent efforts to comply with the standards imposed by the Court.
- The Government contended that the medical certificate on his disability had been issued only on 29 October 2013 because the applicant had failed to submit the documents requested by the special commission for disabled persons.
- After the applicant had returned to Iaşi Prison he had lodged a request to be assigned a personal care assistant.
- The complaints were joined and examined together by the post‑sentencing judge on 14 June 2013.

title: CASE OF BARBU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and has served sentences in several prisons.
- On 21 April 2015, he was released from Târgu-Jiu Prison.
- The applicant alleged that he had not had an individual bed and had to sleep on the cold floor in cell no. 5 of Târgu‑Jiu Prison for eight days.
- Because of this, his renal disease was reactivated, and he experienced intense pain.
- He was examined by a prison doctor on 3 October 2013 and was prescribed medical treatment but failed to submit any evidence as the prison authorities rejected his requests for a copy of his medical records.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the post‑sentencing judge asking for an individual bed.
- The post-sentencing judge noted that the applicant's complaint had been withdrawn, as he had eventually been given an individual bed but did not draft an interlocutory judgment.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Gorj District Court seeking compensation in connection with the lack of an individual bed for eight days in cell no. 5 of Târgu-Jiu Prison.
- On 12 November 2013, the Târgu-Jiu District Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint as inadmissible without examining its merits due to the fact that the applicant had not submitted an interlocutory judgment by the post-sentencing judge.

title: CASE OF HOKKELING v. THE NETHERLANDS
facts:
- The applicant was serving a sentence of imprisonment in Oslo at the time of application submission.
- A group transported around three tons of hashish, some of which went missing and was later attributed to E. E's body was found later with signs of torture on it.
- The applicant was arrested and charged with causing E grievous bodily harm resulting in his death, abduction of E resulting in his death, threatening grievous bodily harm, and importing, transporting and possessing three tons of hashish.
- The prosecution sought an eight-year prison sentence for him.
- The Regional Court acquitted the applicant of the charge of abduction resulting in E's death but convicted him of all the other charges and sentenced him to four years and six months in prison.
- Both the applicant and the prosecution appealed the decision.
- The appeal hearing was adjourned multiple times, and the applicant was released after serving two-thirds of the sentence by the Regional Court.
- The hearing was ultimately held on 1 June 2010, and the Court of Appeal declined to adjourn the hearing until the applicant could be present, citing general interest and due process.
- The Court of Appeal convicted the applicant of complicity in causing grievous bodily harm resulting in death, abduction, and transporting and possessing an unspecified quantity of hashish and sentenced him to eight years.
- The applicant filed an appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court, alleging a violation of his right to attend the hearing in person.

title: CASE OF KARAKHANYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's husband was arrested in 2003 and sentenced to eleven years in prison for robbery.
- The applicant's husband was diagnosed with HIV and hepatitis C during his imprisonment.
- The applicant's husband's health was stable until April 2009 when he was diagnosed with tuberculosis.
- The infectious diseases doctor noted the progress of HIV infection due to the lack of antiretroviral therapy.
- The applicant's husband suffered side effects from HIV treatment and refused ART.
- The doctors incorrectly diagnosed the patient with pyelonephritis instead of tuberculosis.
- The applicant's husband lost faith in the doctors and refused to follow their recommendations.
- The patient's overall condition became critical, leading to an ambulance being called for transfer to a civilian hospital.
- The applicant complained about the inadequate medical treatment and requested an in-depth examination.
- The applicant's husband died from HIV and tuberculosis, which led to pulmonary and cardiac failure.
- The investigating authorities obtained the autopsy report and questioned two doctors who attended to the patient but refused to open a criminal case.

title: CASE OF FRANZ MAIER GMBH v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant company produces concrete building materials using crushed stones
- On 29 November 2002, the company requested a licence for dredging on its plot under the Water Act
- The Steiermark Regional Governor issued the licence with conditions on 20 May 2003
- The owner of a mineral water spring appealed against the decision on 31 July 2003
- The Ministry ordered the company to submit information on the projected dredging area and concerned wells/springs on 8 September 2004
- The company submitted plans on 21 September 2004 but did not have information on the spring's location
- On 19 April 2005, the Ministry quashed the decision of the Steiermark Regional Governor due to insufficient information
- On 13 February 2006, the licence was issued again with conditions by the Steiermark Regional Governor
- H.P, the municipality, and the spring company appealed against this decision on 1 March 2006
- The Administrative Court ordered the Ministry to decide within three months on 27 September 2006
- On 17 April 2007, the Ministry rejected the licence due to missing documents
- The Administrative Court quashed the Ministry's decision on 30 October 2008
- The Ministry was ordered to decide within three months on 27 May 2009
- The Bad Radkersburg municipality and spring company submitted written observations on 12 February 2010
- On 20 October, 2010 the Ministry permitted dredging by the applicant company

title: CASE OF LOBKOV AND RASSOLOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- First applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Sharya, the Kostroma Region.
- Applicant was held in remand prison IZ-44/1 in Kostroma in the following cells: Cell no., Surface, sq. m, Dates of stay
- Disagreement between parties on the design capacity of the cells and the actual number of inmates.
- First applicant submitted three-hand written statements from his co-detainees.
- Cell 49 had three two-tier bunk beds with metal sheets welded to beds on upper and lower levels to create additional sleeping places. Cell 49 was used to accommodate between ten and twenty prisoners. Cell 43 contained two two-tier bunk beds and accommodated four prisoners.
- The government submitted that the number of prisoners in the cells had not exceeded the occupancy limit.
- Selected pages from the prison registration log were submitted, which indicate that Cell 49 was designed for four persons and accommodated as many prisoners.
- Second applicant was born in 1958 and has been serving his term of imprisonment in Ivdel, the Sverdlovskiy Region.
- Between 14 July 2009 and 4 July 2010 the second applicant was held in remand prison IZ-59/1 in the Perm Region.
- The facility was overcrowded. In particular, Cell 90 measuring 40 sq. m accommodated up to sixteen inmates.
- The actual number of inmates detained in the cells did not exceed their designed capacity.
- Each inmate had more than 3 sq. m of personal space.
- The government submitted selected pages from registration logs, some of which appear to contain erasures and alterations in the fields showing the number of inmates in Cell 90.

title: CASE OF CEREALE FLOR S.A. AND ROŞCA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant company is a joint-stock company incorporated under Moldovan law, and Ms Roșca lives in Chișinău.
- The Economic District Court ordered the applicant company to pay another company, E., 1,908,145 Moldovan lei (MDL) (equivalent to 152,190 euros (EUR)) on 23 February 2000, and a writ of enforcement was issued.
- E. sought to restart the time-limit for the enforcement of the judgment dated 23 February 2000 on 14 July 2005, claiming inability to initiate enforcement proceedings due to the bailiff losing the original writ of enforcement.
- The Economic Court of Appeal dismissed E.’s application as being ill-founded on 2 May 2006 by a final judgment since a duplicate of the writ had been issued in 2003.
- On 17 December 2008, the Economic Court of Appeal quashed the decision and allowed the statutory time-limit to run anew while upholding E.'s application for a revision of the judgment, without responding to the applicant company's bound-timing contention.
- After communication, E. initiated enforcement proceedings, and the applicant company paid MDL 294,405.37 (equivalent to EUR 18,400).
- The Ciocana District Court acknowledged the applicant’s entitlement to a plot of land on 28 February 2007, and the Tohatin local administration was ordered to grant the applicant ownership of such a plot of land since there was no appeal, and the judgment became final on 20 March 2007.
- The applicant sought enforcement of the judgment of 28 February 2007 to no avail.
- On 22 April 2009, the Ciocana District Court rejected the application for revision, but the Chișinău Court of Appeal allowed it, quashed the original judgment of 28 February 2007, and delivered a new judgment by dismissing her claims as unsubstantiated.
- The applicant brought a civil action for damages for a violation of her right to a fair hearing within a reasonable time on Law no. 87 of 21 April 2011 and was awarded MDL 30,000 (equivalent to EUR 1,895) in respect of non-pecuniary damage and MDL 5,000 (equivalent to EUR 316) for costs and expenses by a final judgment of the Chișinău Court of Appeal on 25 October 2012.

title: CASE OF PĂTRAŞCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lives in Botârlău.
- On 23 February 2007, a plain-clothes police officer approached the applicant in a nightclub, suspecting him of drug trafficking.
- A criminal investigation was opened against the applicant on suspicion of drug trafficking and his telephone conversations were intercepted.
- The prosecutor authorised the use of the police officer as an undercover agent to obtain evidence.
- On the evening of 19 July 2007, the applicant set up a meeting to buy drugs with an undercover police officer and was arrested with drugs found on him and his co-defendants.
- The applicant was indicted and convicted of drug trafficking based on evidence including police reports, phone transcripts, and in-court testimonies.
- The applicant appealed and argued that the undercover police officer had exceeded his authority and incited him to commit the offence under coercion.
- The appeals were rejected, and the applicant's allegations were considered unfounded. The High Court concluded that there had been serious reasons to suspect the applicant was committing a crime and that the officer had acted lawfully.

title: CASE OF NIKITIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Ufa.
- He was severely injured in a traffic accident in February 1996.
- On 24 April 1996, he filed a civil action against the State Unitary Subsidiary Passenger Transport Company of Ufa No. 3.
- On 29 November 2005, the District Court granted the applicant’s claims partially.
- Transport company was declared insolvent and put into liquidation on 15 February 2006.
- On 28 March 2006, the judgment became final, awarding the applicant a sum in compensation for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage sustained and a monthly allowance.
- On 17 June 2006, Commercial Court granted the applicant’s application for aggregation as a lump sum of the amounts of the monthly allowance.
- On 3 March 2009, the Commercial Court granted the applicant’s application for payment as a lump sum of the amounts of the monthly allowance, and he was awarded EUR 203,673.
- On 15 July 2009, the Commercial Court accepted the applicant’s claim for transfer of the transport company’s debt to the Russian Federation.
- The transport company provided public transport services on a commercial basis.
- On 14 October 2004, the Government of the Republic of Bashkortostan issued Decree no. 918-P, transferring all the transport company’s assets to the parent company.
- Liquidation proceedings of the transport company ended on 31 December 2013.

title: CASE OF LAZĂR v. ROMANIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1971 and is currently serving a sentence in a prison in Panama.
• He was arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking following an undercover operation with the help of two agents.
• The prosecutor’s office attached to the Timişoara Court of Appeal committed the applicant and his co-accused for trial for drug trafficking, and the case was registered with the Arad County Court.
• The court refused to hear evidence from the undercover agents based on their anonymity protection.
• The court convicted the applicant of drug trafficking and sentenced him to three years’ imprisonment based on the report drafted by the undercover agents after he had been caught.
• The Timişoara Court of Appeal increased his prison sentence to ten years’ imprisonment.
• The Supreme Court of Justice dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law.
• The applicant alleged that he had been kept in poor hygienic conditions in overcrowded cells, with poor quality water and food, and the Government contended that the records held by the prison authorities were no longer available.

title: CASE OF DENISENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Svetlyy, Kamchatka Region. 
- On 15 July 2004 at around 2 p.m. the applicant was arrested on suspicion of robbery and taken to a police station. 
- According to the applicant, he was kept in unacknowledged detention at the police station from 15 to 20 July 2004. 
- On 20 July 2004 at 5.40 p.m. the investigator drew up a record of the applicant’s arrest as a suspect. 
- According to the Government, the applicant was released on the same date of his arrest under an obligation to appear. 
- On 20 July, the applicant returned to the police station to be questioned. 
- After the interview, the investigator decided to detain the applicant and drew up a record of his arrest as a suspect.

title: CASE OF DOLGANIN v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was arrested at his home without reason given and taken to a police station, where he was beaten by several police officers, handcuffed, had a gas mask put on him with cigarette smoke blown into it, and demanded to confess to crimes he had not committed.
- The Government denied allegations of ill-treatment and could not provide factual information as time limit for keeping relevant documents had expired and the admissions register of the police station was destroyed.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant for a robbery case on 4 May 2005.
- The applicant complained of acute abdominal pain and received medical assistance, and later, surgery.
- The medical care provided to the applicant during his detention at Kharkiv SIZO was inadequate.
- The applicant's complaint of ill-treatment by the police was dismissed as unsubstantiated on the basis of forensic medical reports and inquiries conducted by prosecutors.
- In the appeal, the applicant's allegation of ill-treatment was disregarded by higher courts.

title: CASE OF TKACHENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details provided in the appendix table.
- Applicants argued that civil proceedings were excessively lengthy.
- Lack of effective remedy in domestic law was another complaint raised by the applicants.
- Application no. 15642/07 included additional complaints under Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF GAVRILOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a retired military officer from Simferopol, Ukraine.
- In December 2004, the applicant filed a lawsuit against a local military enlistment office to recalculate his pension.
- The Simferopol Garrison Military Court ruled against the applicant on 20 May 2005.
- The Navy Court of Appeal upheld the ruling on 11 August 2005.
- On 30 August 2005, the applicant filed an appeal on points of law.
- On 17 October 2005, the Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine allowed the applicant a time limit until 1 November 2005 to rectify his appeal on points of law.
- The applicant dispatched the rectified appeal on points of law on 24 October 2005, which was received by the court registry on 27 October 2005.
- On 7 November 2005, the Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine decided that the appeal on points of law should be considered as not submitted and returned to the applicant.
- On 10 November 2005, the Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine decided to leave the appeal without examination as the applicant failed to submit a request for an extension of the time limit for lodging an appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF ARTUR PARKHOMENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant served a prison sentence between 1993 and 1999
- After release, the applicant kept in touch with co-prisoners Lu. and La.
- On 22 August 2000, the applicant attempted to rob Mr and Mrs I. with a TT pistol, but they resisted and he fled
- In June 2001, the applicant was detained by police and allegedly physically mistreated to implicate La. in the attack
- The applicant waived his right to legal counsel and admitted to the attack in writing and during an identity parade
- La. was later found to possess the TT pistol used in the crime and said it was given to him by Lu.
- P. admitted to using the same gun with La. in other crimes
- The applicant was charged with the attack and his accomplices were identified as Lu. and La.
- During questioning with a lawyer present, the applicant recanted his original statements and denied the involvement of Lu. and La.
- The case was remitted for further investigation and ultimately the applicant, Lu., and La. were convicted.

title: CASE OF VIKHAREV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details of applications provided in the appended table.
- Applicants complained about excessive pre-trial detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF CHERNOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• A table is appended which lists the applicants and relevant details of their applications. 

• The applicants complain about the inadequate conditions of their detention. 

• The applicants raise other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF RUBLEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details are in the table.
- Applicants filed complaints about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KHASANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants is provided in an appended table
- Applicants complained about excessive pre-trial detention
- Some applicants also raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KOLOMIYETS AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table containing the list of applicants and their relevant application details is provided.
- The applicants lodged a complaint regarding the substandard conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants also filed other grievances under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BABAK HASANOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was a member of an opposition party.
- The applicant participated in or attempted to participate in peaceful demonstrations.
- The BCEA refused to authorize the demonstration of 17 November 2012 and dispersed both demonstrations.
- The applicant was arrested in both demonstrations and charged with administrative offenses.
- The applicant was not given access to a lawyer after arrest or while in police custody.
- The applicant was appointed State-funded lawyers in court, but none made significant oral or written submissions.
- The first instance court convicted the applicant for both cases and sentenced him to administrative detention.
- The applicant lodged appeals, but the Baku Court of Appeal dismissed his claims and upheld the decisions of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF JAMIL HAJIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Baku.
- The opposition planned to hold demonstrations on 17 November 2012 and 26 January 2013 in Baku.
- The organisers gave notice to the relevant authority about the demonstration of 17 November 2012, but no prior notice was given to the BCEA by the organisers of the demonstration of 26 January 2013.
- The BCEA refused to authorise the holding of the demonstration of 17 November 2012, but the organisers decided to hold the demonstrations in the centre of Baku.
- The demonstrations were intended to be peaceful and were conducted in a peaceful manner.
- The applicant attended both demonstrations, but shortly after they had begun the police started to disperse them. In both cases, the applicant was arrested during the dispersal operation and was taken to a police station, where he was questioned.
- In both cases, an “administrative‑offence report” was issued in respect of the applicant.
- In both cases, the applicant was brought before the Sabail District Court, and the hearing in both cases was brief.
- In neither case, the applicant was given access to a lawyer after the arrest, or while in police custody.
- Members of the public were not allowed to attend the court hearings.
- In both cases, the first-instance court found that the applicant had participated in an unauthorised demonstration.
- In the first case, the applicant was sentenced to five days’ “administrative” detention. In the second case, the court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to a fine of 500 manats.
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal in both cases, upholding the decision of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF ABBASLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was a member of an opposition party, Musavat.
- The applicant attempted to participate in a peaceful demonstration organized by the opposition on 20 October 2012, which had been refused authorization by the relevant authority, the Baku City Executive Authority (“the BCEA”).
- On 6 May 2014, the applicant participated in another peaceful assembly, which was forcibly dispersed by police officers and people in plain clothes, resulting in his arrest.
- An “administrative‑offence report” was issued against the applicant in both cases, the first under Article 310.1 of the Code of Administrative Offences (“the CAO”) and the second under Article 298.2 of the CAO.
- The applicant was not given access to a lawyer after the arrests or while in police custody.
- In both cases, State-funded lawyers were appointed to assist the applicant, and they briefly stated that the applicant was not guilty during the court hearing.
- The only witnesses questioned during the court hearings were police officers, who testified that the applicant had staged an unauthorised protest.
- The first-instance court convicted the applicant in both cases and sentenced him to ten and fifteen days’ administrative detention, respectively.
- The applicant lodged appeals before the Baku Court of Appeal, which were dismissed on 29 October 2012 and 16 May 2014, respectively.

title: CASE OF BAYRAMLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was a deputy chairperson of an opposition party.
- The applicant participated in two demonstrations organized by the opposition, one with prior notice given to the authority, and the other without.
- The authority proposed a different location for the first demonstration, but the organizers decided to hold it in the center of Baku.
- The demonstrations were intended to be peaceful and were conducted in a peaceful manner.
- The police dispersed both demonstrations and arrested the applicant.
- The applicant was charged with administrative offenses in both cases.
- The applicant was not given access to a lawyer after her arrest or while in police custody.
- The court hearings in both cases were very brief and State-funded lawyers were appointed to assist the applicant.
- The courts only questioned the police officers who arrested the applicant and convicted her based on their testimony.
- The applicant was sentenced to administrative detention in one case and a fine in the other case.
- The applicant appealed both convictions, which were dismissed by the Baku Court of Appeal.
- The applicant lodged a complaint of ill-treatment with the General Prosecutor's Office but did not receive any information about the investigation.

title: CASE OF MAHAMMAD MAJIDLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Baku.
- Demonstrations were planned to be held on 31 July 2010 and 10 March 2013 in Baku.
- The BCEA refused to authorize the demonstration of 31 July 2010 at the places indicated by the organizers and proposed three other locations on the outskirts of Baku.
- The organizers decided to hold the demonstrations in the center of Baku.
- In both cases, the applicant was arrested during the dispersal operation and was taken to a police station.
- In the first case, an administrative offense report was issued on the applicant under Article 310.1 of the Code of Administrative Offences.
- In the second case, he was charged with an administrative offense under Article 298.2 of the CAO.
- The applicant was never served with copies of the administrative offense reports.
- The hearing before the court in both cases was very brief.
- In both cases, the applicant was not given an opportunity to appoint a lawyer of his own choosing.
- The court did not question any witnesses in both cases.
- The Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeals and upheld the decision of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF BAYRAM BAYRAMOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Applicants held positions in opposition political parties
- Organisers gave notice to BCEA for conducting demonstrations
- BCEA refused to authorise the locations proposed by organisers
- Demonstrations were conducted in the centre of Baku
- Arrested and taken to police stations
- Administrative offence reports were issued in respect of them
- Applicants were not served with copies of administrative offence reports or other documents in their case files
- None of the applicants given access to a lawyer after the arrest
- First-instance court hearing held on the day of the arrest or the following day
- Applicants were not given an opportunity to hire lawyers of their own choice
- Most of the applicants were assisted by state-funded lawyers
- All the first-instance courts convicted the applicants under Article 310.1 of the CAO
- Most of the applicants lodged appeals before the Baku Court of Appeal
- Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicants’ appeal and upheld the decisions of the respective first-instance courts.
- Applicants received relevant documents after complaining about the court’s failure to serve them.

title: CASE OF KOSTEYCHUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Kyiv.
- In 1995-2002, the applicant was convicted of and served a sentence for aggravated theft and burglary.
- On 27 December 2005 and 6 January 2006, police found the applicant in possession of illegal drugs.
- On 20 January 2006, police arrested the applicant on suspicion of drug manufacturing and possession.
- On the same day, criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant and Mr. I. for armed robbery committed in a group.
- On 23 January 2006, the District Court ordered the applicant's detention on remand until 20 March 2006.
- On 16 March 2006, the District Court extended the applicant's detention until 20 April 2006.
- On 27 June 2006, the District Court held a preliminary hearing in the case and upheld the preventive measure imposed on the applicant without giving any reasons or setting a time-limit for it.
- On 17 March and 14 July 2008, and 19 January and 23 April 2009, the District Court refused the applicant's requests for release.
- On 17 July 2009, the District Court convicted the applicant of drug possession and armed robbery committed in a group and sentenced him to nine years' imprisonment.
- On 27 July 2010, the Kyiv City Court of Appeal quashed that judgment and remitted the case to the District Court for fresh consideration.
- On the same day, the applicant was released against his undertaking not to abscond.
- On 30 September 2013, the District Court sent the case against the applicant to the prosecutor for further investigation.
- On 25 April 2014, charges concerning the armed robbery were separated into a second set of criminal proceedings.
- On 29 April 2014, the bill of indictment for robbery was approved, and on 3 June 2014, the District Court committed the applicant for trial on that charge.
- As of 5 March 2015, proceedings against the applicant were still pending before the District Court.

title: CASE OF MAMEDOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details are provided in a table
- Applicants complained about non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions against GUPs and MUPs 
- Lack of effective remedy in domestic law

facts:
- A table with the list of applicants and relevant details of the applications is included.
- The applicants claim excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Applicants in applications 39399/08 and 23272/16 raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

facts:
- There is a list of applicants with their details in the appended table.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF FEDOROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The document contains a list of applicants and their application details.
• The applicants complained about the excessive pre-trial detention.
• Some applicants also reported other complaints under the Convention's provisions.

title: CASE OF KRYVENKYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a Ukrainian national born in 1934 and lives in Velyki Gadomtsi.
- On March 25, 1997, the applicant obtained a certificate attesting his entitlement to a nominal 3.61-ha share of land belonging to the V.G. collective farm.
- In September 1998, V.G. merged with Kh., a neighboring collective farming company, which was designated as its successor.
- On March 18, 1999, the Parliament of Ukraine ordered the expropriation of 150 ha of Kh.'s land and its transfer to U.C.C. closed joint stock company for the exploitation of kaolin deposits.
- U.C.C. lodged a civil action claiming the 0.6021-ha plot of land allocated to the applicant and seeking annulment of the land-ownership certificate issued to him.
- U.C.C. blocked the road leading to the plot disputed by the U.C.C., and it became impossible for the applicant to access or use it for farming.
- On an unspecified date, several individuals, excluding the applicant, initiated administrative proceedings against the Berdychiv district administration to declare lawful the decision of 17 January 2003, on the basis of which their land-use certificates had been issued.
- On 23 July 2008, the Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine quashed the earlier decision and remitted the case for retrial.
- After several rounds of proceedings, on 14 September 2011, the Berdychiv Court found that the decision of 22 July 2005 had been unlawful.

title: CASE OF KUSHTOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA (No. 2)
facts:
1. The applicants are Russian nationals living in the Republic of Ingushetia.
2. Mr Ibragim Kushtov was abducted on 25 January 2006 near Magas airport.
3. Witnesses claimed that federal security service members carried out the abduction.
4. The applicants believe that the abduction was an attempt to "lure" Mr Isa Kushtov, Mr Ibragim Kushtov's older brother, out of hiding.
5. The investigation was opened immediately after the abduction, but was suspended and then resumed in 2014.

title: CASE OF OVAKIMYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1981 and lived in Yoshkar-Ola before his conviction.
- A.K., who had left home intending to sell his car, was reported missing on 29 August 2007. On the same day, his car was found on the outskirts of Yoshkar-Ola. A criminal investigation was opened in respect of A.K.’s alleged murder.
- According to a record drawn up by investigator A., on 7 September 2007 A.K.’s body was found and the place of its location examined.
