- The applicant was arrested as a suspect in the murder case at 8.55 p.m. on 7 September 2007, and examined as a suspect on the same day.
- The operative police officers claimed that the applicant had confessed to killing A.K. by strangling him in order to steal his car.
- The applicant provided a different version of events, claiming that he was arrested by three men in plain clothes and subjected to ill-treatment before agreeing to cooperate.
- The applicant was placed in a temporary detention facility at 10.45 p.m. on 7 September 2007, where injuries were recorded on him.
- The investigator alleged that the applicant signed a statement of surrender and confession, in which he confessed to participating in a conspiracy to murder A.K. and to stealing his car.
- The applicant's injuries were examined in a forensic expert medical report on 18 December 2007.
- The Yoshkar-Ola Town Court ordered that the applicant be detained on remand on the same day.
- Injuries were recorded on the applicant when he was admitted to pre-trial detention facility IZ-12/1.
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Prosecutor’s Office of the Republic of Mariy El, requesting that investigator G. and the police officers responsible for his ill-treatment be prosecuted.
- Investigators refused to open criminal proceedings in respect of the applicant’s allegations for lack of the event of a crime, and their decision was annulled five times.
- An investigator refused to institute criminal proceedings against investigator G. and police officers D.K., O., S. and Z. on 9 March 2011.
- The Yoshkar-Ola Town Court and the Mariy El Supreme Court dismissed appeals by the applicant against the investigator's decision on 7 October 2011 and 5 December 2011, respectively.

title: CASE OF ORLOVSKAYA ISKRA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a non-governmental organisation that publishes a newspaper in the Orel Region.
- The founders of the organisation were in charge of determining the editorial policy.
- The organisation expressed its intention to accept proposals for publication for a fee during the election campaign for the State Duma.
- The organisation signed a contract with the Communist Party for this purpose.
- Two articles critical of Governor Stroyev were published in the newspaper.
- The Working Group on Informational Disputes of the regional Electoral Committee examined the articles and concluded that they contained elements of electoral campaigning.
- The case was submitted to a justice of the peace who found the organisation guilty of an administrative offence and ordered them to pay a fine.
- The applicant organisation appealed and the appeal was rejected.
- The applicant organisation lodged a supervisory-review application with the President of the Supreme Court of Russia, which was dismissed.
- The applicant organisation introduced an individual application before the Constitutional Court of Russia, which was not allowed.

title: CASE OF DE TOMMASO v. ITALY
facts:
- Angelo de Tommaso, an Italian national from Casamassima, was recommended for special police supervision and a compulsory residence order in 2007.
- The public prosecutor argued that his previous convictions for drug trafficking, absconding, and unlawful possession of weapons showed him to be dangerous and associated with criminals.
- De Tommaso challenged this recommendation, claiming mistaken identity and no new criminal charges since 2002.
- In April 2008, the Bari District Court imposed special supervision for two years, citing de Tommaso's criminal tendencies and means of subsistence through criminal activity.
- The measure included reporting to police, finding legal work, living in Casamassima, avoiding criminal association, and not carrying or using weapons.
- De Tommaso appealed to the Bari Court of Appeal in July 2008.
- The Government acknowledged a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention on account of the lack of a public hearing and proposed a friendly settlement including payment of specified costs.

title: CASE OF KIYASHKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Poltava.
- On 16 September 2004, while undergoing inpatient medical treatment in a psychiatric hospital, the applicant was arrested for fraud.
- On 6 October 2006, he was found guilty of fraud and sentenced to five years' imprisonment.
- The judgment was upheld by the courts of appeal.
- From 4 October 2004 to 2 October 2007, the applicant was detained in Poltava Pre-Trial Detention Centre no. 23 (“the SIZO”).
- During his detention in the SIZO, the applicant was held in various cells of the same type, which were overcrowded and had poor sanitary conditions.
- The cells were infested with rats, mice, bedbugs, lice, spiders, and cockroaches.
- The toilets were not separated from the living area, had no flush, and emitted a foul smell that lingered in the air.
- The food was of poor quality and often made from spoiled products.
- The applicant was allowed to take a shower once every seven to ten days or even once a fortnight.
- The applicant was taken to court on unspecified occasions in 2007 and faced poor transport and hygiene conditions.
- From 2 October 2007 to 22 September 2009, the applicant was serving his sentence in Kremenchuk Correctional Colony no. 69 (“the prison”).
- The applicant suffered from poor living conditions, lack of access to hygiene products and medical care.
- He was placed in the admission ward (карантин) and disciplinary cells several times.
- The cell measured 13 sq. m and accommodated ten to twelve prisoners.
- The applicant spent the remainder of his sentence in the socio-psychological unit of the prison (unit no. 5) in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions.
- He relied on a report by the Ombudsman regarding the general unsatisfactory detention conditions of prisons in Ukraine.

title: CASE OF AUERBACH v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in London.
- The applicant was the CEO of the Central Wechsel- und Creditbank AG from 1997 to 1998.
- The applicant was accused of receiving untaxed remuneration of 35,000,000 Austrian Schilling via the Liechtenstein company Tudor AG.
- Investigations were conducted by the Investigation Department for Criminal Matters and the Vienna Tax Authority.
- The criminal proceedings were interrupted until the submission of the final report by the Tax Authority.
- The applicant's house was searched.
- The applicant lodged a request for the discontinuation of the criminal proceedings and was rejected.
- The Tax Authority issued a decision, assessing the applicant's income tax for the years 1997 and 1998 anew.
- The applicant's appeal with the Vienna Independent Financial Panel was dismissed.
- The applicant lodged a further request for the discontinuation of the criminal proceedings and was dismissed again.
- The decision was confirmed by the Vienna Court of Appeal.
- The Tax Authority submitted the final report.
- The public prosecutor issued a bill of indictment against the applicant.
- The applicant's appeal lodged with the Administrative Court was dismissed.
- The applicant filed an official liability action against the Republic of Austria.
- The Vienna Regional Criminal Court convicted the applicant for tax evasion and imposed a fine.
- The judgment was quashed by the Supreme Court.
- The Vienna Regional Criminal Court acquitted the applicant of all charges.
- Official liability proceedings were continued and were still pending at the date of the last information available to the Court.

title: CASE OF HAMBERGER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was a civil servant employed by the Traun Municipality.
- He declared to resign from his employment as of 31 August 2002, but later revoked his declaration.
- The Traun City Council informed the applicant that they did not accept his revocation, and his employment ended on 31 August 2002.
- The applicant requested that his employment relationship be declared as still valid, which was dismissed by the City Council.
- The applicant appealed and requested retroactive payment of his salary from 1 September 2002.
- The Traun Municipal Council dismissed the appeal and rejected the request for suspensive effect.
- The applicant filed an objection against the Municipal Council’s decision.
- The Upper Austria Regional Government quashed a part of the Municipal Council’s decision and referred it back to the lower instance for a new decision.
- The Constitutional Court declined to examine the complaint and transferred it to the Administrative Court.
- The Administrative Court lifted one decision and referred the case back for a new decision.
- The applicant filed several complaints and requests for transfer of jurisdiction with the Municipal Council and the Regional Government.
- The Municipal Council dismissed the appeal and request for suspensive effect, and the Administrative Court awarded costs to the applicant.
- The Regional Government dismissed one objection and the Administrative Court dismissed a complaint against their decision.

title: CASE OF MANOLI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was a police officer at the time of the events.
- The applicant and another police officer arrested two suspects and allegedly used force to make one of them get into their car.
- The police officers were charged with ill-treating the suspects.
- Charges against the applicant were initially dropped, but he was later charged again.
- One of the victims alleged that the police officers took personal items from them, and that he was kicked in the chest by the police officer.
- One of the victims suffered a fractured rib from the kick.
- The Buiucani District Court acquitted both officers of disproportionate use of force during the arrest but convicted V.G. of kicking a suspect.
- The Chişinău Court of Appeal reversed the judgment and convicted the applicant of ill-treating a suspect; the Supreme Court of Justice upheld the conviction.
- The Court of Appeal did not question witnesses again, but cited some of their statements.
- One member of the Supreme Court panel wrote a dissenting opinion.

title: CASE OF TIMAR AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A list of applicants and their application details are provided in an appended table.
- The applicants lost their court cases which were held in their absence, after being served notices solely by public notice.
- The applicants argued in subsequent appeals that they were not aware of the court proceedings or the relevant summonses.
- Their complaints were dismissed as service by public notice was provided for by law.
- Consequently, their appeals were dismissed without the examination of the merits of the cases.

title: CASE OF TALPIS v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Remanzaccio.
- The applicant married A.T. and two children were born of the marriage.
- The applicant alleged that her husband had started beating her after their marriage.
- On 2 June 2012, the applicant and her daughter were assaulted by A.T.
- The police arrived, and the applicant had a number of bruises and injuries while her daughter had a neck injury caused by a fingernail and injuries to both arms.
- The applicant alleged that she had not been informed of the possibility of lodging a complaint or contacting a shelter for battered women.
- After the assault on 2 June 2012, the applicant took refuge in the cellar of her flat and started sleeping there.
- On 19 August 2012, A.T. attacked her with a knife and forced her to follow him in order to have sexual relations with his friends, and she resigned herself to following him.
- The police merely checked their identity papers and invited her to go home without offering her help, and A.T. was fined for unauthorised possession of a lethal weapon.
- The applicant altered her statements and mitigated the seriousness of her original allegations because of the psychological pressure exerted on her by her husband.
- Proceedings were continued against A.T. for the offence of causing bodily harm.
- On 5 September 2012 the applicant lodged a complaint against her husband for bodily harm, ill-treatment and threats of violence, urging the authorities to take prompt action to protect her and her children and to prevent A.T. from approaching them.
- A.T. was committed for trial on charges of ill-treating family members, inflicting grievous bodily harm and making threats.
- On 25 November 2013, A.T. killed the applicant's son and attempted to kill her.

title: CASE OF YANTSEV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table has been appended to the document containing a list of applicants and relevant details of the applications.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants also complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF VOLCHKOVA AND ZHELEZNOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Case originated from an application against Ukraine under Article 34 of the Convention
- Applicants complained of excessive length of civil proceedings and lack of effective remedy in domestic law
- Friendly-settlement declarations received
- First applicant agreed to waive further claims against Ukraine regarding the complaints mentioned above
- The Government offered to pay the first applicant a certain amount detailed in an appended table as a final resolution of the complaints.

title: CASE OF SITNIK AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and their relevant details included in an attached table.
- Applicants complained about lengthy criminal proceedings.
- Applicants claimed lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Some applicants raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF PALCHIK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was a managing director of a private company that exported ferromanganese to Russia.
- The contracts A. had concluded with four Ukrainian companies were alleged to be fictitious with the purpose of obtaining export VAT refunds.
- A. had bought ferromanganese from private persons, forged certificates of quality, and fraudulently obtained certificates of origin for the goods to export to Russia.
- Managers of the seller companies testified that the contracts had been either forged or fictitious, and no actual shipments of the goods had taken place.
- The court relied on witness statements made during the pre-trial investigation in convicting the applicant.
- The police failed to bring witnesses to court hearings despite orders from the court.
- The applicant was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison with a ban on holding managerial positions for two years.
- The appeals lodged by the applicant and his lawyer were dismissed by the Supreme Court in 2005.
- The applicant was released from detention following a presidential pardon in 2009.

title: CASE OF MOROZ v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1967 and is currently serving his prison sentence.
2. On 1 June 2005, the president of the Ukrainian Dental Association, O., was shot at his office with a rifle brought by the applicant.
3. The applicant was present at O.'s office at the time of the shooting and claimed it was an accident.
4. The applicant was arrested and questioned several times, maintained his innocence, and pleaded not guilty.
5. The Court of Appeal found the applicant guilty of murder and modifying the shotgun, sentencing him to fifteen years in prison.
6. The applicant experienced poor conditions and alleged violations of his rights during his detention at Kyiv pre-trial detention centre no. 13, including the inadequacy of medical care and hygiene, and the denial of religious and family visits.
7. The government denied some of the applicant's allegations and provided documents to support their position, such as the adequate nutrition and disinfection of hairdressing implements at the detention facility.
8. The applicant was eventually diagnosed with hepatitis B and claimed to have contracted it due to the mishandling of hygiene in the detention facility. An investigation by the Health Ministry and prosecutor's office found no evidence to support the applicant's allegations.

title: CASE OF CEROVŠEK AND BOŽIČNIK v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- Two applicants, born in 1962 and 1946, are charged with theft by cutting down and taking trees from another person's forest and appropriating the wood in 2005 and 2006, respectively.
- The first applicant claims that he cut down trees that had been marked for cutting or attacked by bark beetle in his own forest, but witnesses testified that certain trees had been cut down in an unprofessional manner on the injured party's land, and the first applicant was seen transporting trees over the injured party's land.
- The second applicant claims that he mistakenly thought he was cutting down trees on his own land, but witnesses testified that he had been seen in the forest at the time, and another person had been seen transporting the wood.
- Both applicants were tried by a professional judge, A.K., sitting as a single judge.
- Judge A.K. examined witnesses during the main hearing, inspected the place of the alleged offense, and examined a number of documents, including copies of relevant land register maps and estimates of the value of the stolen wood.
- Judge A.K. pronounced an oral verdict in both cases, and after an appeal, written grounds for the verdicts were delivered by different judges based on restored case files.
- Both applicants appealed the judgments, but the Ljubljana Higher Court dismissed their appeals, and the Supreme Court dismissed their applications for the protection of legality.
- The Constitutional Court also refused to admit the applicants' constitutional complaints, finding that their cases concerned neither a violation of human rights nor an important constitutional question.

title: CASE OF VINOGRADOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lived in Slantsy, Leningrad Region.
- He sustained a head injury in 1991 which resulted in disability and epilepsy.
- He was certified as having lost the ability to work, walk without assistance, or look after himself.
- In 2005, he committed homicide and was sentenced to 7 years' imprisonment.
- He experienced difficulties in daily life due to his disability while detained in normal cell blocks.
- He was transferred to a special unit for disabled prisoners offering enhanced housing conditions and a less strict security regime.
- His condition justified early release, but two applications for early release were dismissed due to the gravity of the offense and the stability of the applicant's health in detention.

title: CASE OF POLYAKOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were affected by decisions of the Russian Federal Penal Authority on prisoners’ allocation to post-conviction penal facilities.
- Ms Elvira Vasilyevna Polyakova’s partner, Mr R, was convicted of drug-related crimes and sentenced to ten years in prison in a strict-regime penal facility, and was transferred from the Primorskiy Region to the Krasnoyarsk Region, 5,000 kilometres away from his family home, where he eventually served the remainder of his sentence.
- Ms Natalya Anatolyevna Kibalo’s husband, Mr Kh, was sentenced to twenty years in prison in a strict-regime penal facility in the Amur Region, 8,000 kilometres away from their village in the Chechen Republic. Ms Kibalo requested his transfer to a facility located closer to their home village, but her request was dismissed.
- Mr Ivan Dhzimsherovich Yeliashvili was convicted of robbery and sentenced to eleven years’ imprisonment in a strict-regime facility, and was sent to serve his sentence in Labytnangi, the Yamalo-Nenetskiy Region, located about 3,300 kilometres from his hometown of Noginsk. He requested a transfer to a facility closer to his family, but his request was denied.
- Mr Vladimir Aleksandrovich Palilov was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment. He was sent to serve his sentence in a remote penal facility for those sentenced to life imprisonment in the village of Kharp in the Yamalo-Nenetskiy Region, 2,000 kilometres from his mother’s and sister’s place of residence. He requested a transfer to any detention facility located closer to his family, but his request was dismissed.

title: CASE OF DÖNER AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
• The applicants lived in Istanbul and their children attended public elementary schools.
• The applicants each sent petitions to different Education Directorates with a request for their children to be provided with education in Kurdish in addition to education in Turkish.
• The relevant Education Directorates informed the Istanbul Security Directorate, which brought the matter to the attention of the principal public prosecutor’s office at the Istanbul State Security Court.
• The public prosecutor requested a warrant to search the homes of forty people, including the applicants.
• The public prosecutor considered that the petitions in question had been made on the instructions of the PKK (Workers’ Party of Kurdistan), an illegal armed organisation.
• The applicants were arrested and taken into police custody following the searches.
• The public prosecutor authorised the applicants’ detention in police custody for four days.
• Following questioning, the applicants admitted that they had written the petitions but denied any involvement with the PKK.
• Some of the applicants were released, while others were ordered to be arrested.
• The public prosecutor issued an indictment against thirty-eight suspects, including the remaining applicants, accusing them of aiding and abetting an armed organisation.
• The first-instance court ordered the release of some of the applicants pending the criminal proceedings.
• All the accused, including the applicants, were acquitted.

title: CASE OF STANKA MIRKOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicants filed for compensation for land expropriated from their legal predecessor in 1946.
- The first and second applicants waived their rights in favor of the third and fourth applicants regarding the property of the same legal predecessor.
- The Commission initially ruled in favor of the third and fourth applicants, but the Ministry of Finance quashed that decision.
- The Commission issued a new decision, awarding compensation to all the applicants as they were all heirs of the legal predecessor.
- The competent administrative body and the Administrative Court issued a series of decisions, without ruling on the merits of the initial request for compensation.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Administrative Court’s decision.
- The applicants lodged a constitutional appeal against the decision of the Supreme Court, relying on Articles 6 and 13 of the Convention.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the applicants’ constitutional appeals against the Supreme Court’s decision and later issued another decision dismissing the applicants’ constitutional appeals.
- The proceedings before the Commission were adjourned at the applicants’ request until the Court ruled on their applications.

title: CASE OF KAMENOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Kazakhstan in 1968 and moved to Russia in June 2000
- The applicant lived in Russia with his family under temporary residence permits that were regularly extended
- On 12 April 2014, the applicant was denied re-entry to Russia and banned from re-entering until January 2030, on the basis of a report from the Saratov Region department of the Federal Security Service
- The applicant appealed the exclusion order and ban to the Frunzenskiy District Court of Saratov, which forwarded the appeal to the Saratov Regional Court
- The Regional Court upheld the exclusion order and ban until 2030, citing the report from the Federal Security Service as the basis for the ban, without giving details about the nature of the data or the circumstances of its collection
- The Administrative Cases Chamber of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the Regional Court's decision, without specifying the evidence which had served as the basis for the report by the Federal Security Service.

title: CASE OF BACZÚR v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Nagykozár.
- In 1996, the applicant applied for early retirement on account of disability and was declared to have lost 67% of his capacity to work.
- The disability assessment was maintained in 1999, 2003, and 2006.
- The applicant then underwent a review in 2009 and was found to have lost 50% of his working capacity, resulting in the termination of his disability pension.
- The applicant was granted a monthly rehabilitation allowance until 31 October 2011, extendable once until 30 June 2012 for a maximum of three years.
- The monthly amount payable evolved during this period, reaching HUF 173,980 per month, minus HUF 17,398 in payroll deductions.
- On 29 December 2011, a new law was enacted introducing a new system of allowances for persons with reduced work capacity.
- On 28 March 2012, the applicant applied for a disability allowance under the new law, which was initially granted at HUF 41,850 per month.
- The applicant's initial grant was increased to HUF 55,800 per month on appeal.
- The applicant's petition for review was rejected by the Kúria on 26 May 2014 on the grounds of not relying on any particular breach of the law.
- On 1 April 2014, the applicant became entitled to a disability allowance of HUF 159,100 per month retroactively as of 1 January 2014.

title: CASE OF V.K. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant started attending a public pre-school educational institution in 2004.
- In 2005, the applicant's parents noticed changes in his behavior and nervousness towards school.
- On 7 November 2005, the applicant's mother noticed a bruise on his left temple and was told by a teacher that the children were given eye drops containing antibiotics without her consent.
- The applicant's mother filed a complaint about the incident and ill-treatment by the teachers.
- The applicant was diagnosed with hyperkinesia and developed nervous tics.
- The nursery school director and teachers were disciplined, and the applicant was transferred to another nursery school.
- The applicant described being mistreated by teachers, punished for not sleeping during nap time, and exposed to rats in the toilets.
- The Kirovskiy district prosecutor's office investigated but refused to open a criminal investigation against the teachers due to a lack of evidence.
- The applicant's mother challenged these decisions, and the pre-investigation inquiry was resumed multiple times.
- A child psychiatrist found a causal link between the applicant's prolonged traumatic experience and neurological disorder.
- Criminal proceedings were not opened due to the statute of limitations.

title: CASE OF KUZMENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Chernigiv.
- On 25 January 2007, the police obtained a search warrant for the applicant's flat to search for a stolen Nokia 7270 mobile telephone.
- The police searched the applicant's flat on 30 January 2007 and seized three mobile telephones.
- The applicant did not believe that the seized telephones were related to the theft and the police returned them.
- On 3 March 2007, the applicant filed an administrative complaint with the District Court for an arbitrary search and breaching the inviolability of his home.
- On 5 March 2007, the District Court refused to examine the complaint, stating that complaints regarding the unlawfulness of procedural actions by law-enforcement authorities taken in connection with a criminal investigation had to be lodged within the framework of relevant criminal proceedings.
- On 15 May 2007, the Kyiv Administrative Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's appeal, and on 13 May 2009, the Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine rejected the applicant's cassation appeal.

title: CASE OF ILIAS AND AHMED v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Two applicants born in Bangladesh arrived in Röszke transit zone on 15 September 2015, after travelling through Pakistan, Iran, and Turkey to enter the European Union via Greece and then transit through the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to Serbia.
- They submitted applications for asylum on the same day.
- They alleged that the transit zone was unsuitable for a stay longer than a day, especially in the face of their severe psychological condition, and were effectively locked into a confined area of 110 square meters surrounded by fence and guarded by officers, and were not allowed to leave towards Hungary.
- They claimed that they had no access to legal, social, or medical assistance or any recreational facilities and stayed in a room of some 9 square meters containing beds for five.
- According to the Report of the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture and Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment (“CPT”), the asylum seekers in the Röszke zone were accommodated in rooms of some 13 square meters in ground surface that were equipped with two to five beds fitted with clean mattresses, pillows and bedding.
- The accommodation containers had good access to natural light and artificial lighting, as well as to electric heating. Hot and cold running water and electricity were supplied. Three pork-free meals were available daily to the applicants in a dining-container.
- Medical care was available for two hours daily by doctors of the Hungarian Defence Force.
- On the same day of submitting their asylum applications, the asylum authority rejected their asylum applications, finding them inadmissible on the grounds that Serbia was to be considered a “safe third country” according to Government Decree no. 191/2015. (VII.21.) on safe countries of origin and safe third countries.
- The applicants challenged the decision before the Szeged Administrative and Labour Court, which annulled the asylum authority’s decisions and remitted the case to it for fresh consideration.
- On 30 September 2015 the asylum authority again rejected the applications for asylum, and the court upheld the asylum authority’s decision, finding Serbia generally a safe third country for refugees.
- The final decision was served on the applicants on 8 October 2015, and they subsequently left the transit zone for Serbia without physical coercion being applied.
- On 9 March 2016, the applicants’ petitions for review were dismissed on procedural grounds since the Kúria held that it had no jurisdiction to review such cases.

title: CASE OF MUSCALU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and served a five-year sentence for robbery.
- The applicant was transferred between Bacău Prison, Vaslui Prison, and Focșani Prison between 2012 and 2015.
- The applicant described inhuman detention conditions in Bacău and Vaslui prisons due to overcrowding, poor hygiene, pests, dampness, and poor quality food.
- In Bacău, the applicant was held in three different cells, ranging from 27.12 sq. m. to 39.27 sq. m., with personal space ranging from 2.18 to 2.46 sq. m. All cells had sanitary facilities, but the overall hygiene conditions were inadequate.
- In Vaslui, the applicant was held in cells measuring 14.75 sq. m., shared with three to five other prisoners. The applicant had personal space of 2.03 sq. m. available for several non-consecutive periods and 3.05 sq. m. available for three non-consecutive periods.
- The cells in Vaslui had natural light and ventilation, sanitary facilities equipped with one toilet, one shower, and one sink, and were provided with artificial lighting and necessary furniture.
- The applicant was given a special diet for sick prisoners in both prisons, and the food was always tested by the prison doctor and a representative of the prisoners.
- The applicant was diagnosed with tuberculosis, gastro duodenitis, chronic hepatitis B, and arteriopathy obliterans of the lower limbs during his imprisonment, and was hospitalized several times for follow-up examinations and surgery.
- The applicant received dental treatment but requested adequate dental treatment and prostheses, which would require a personal contribution of 40% of the calculated price.
- The applicant lodged a complaint on the basis of Law no. 275/2006 on the serving of prison sentences with the post-sentencing judge, claiming that his right to medication, medical treatment, and a special diet had been breached by the prison administration. The complaint was rejected as ill-founded, and the applicant withdrew his complaint during the hearing.
- The applicant complained of a lack of hot water and heating in Vaslui Prison, which the prison administration claimed had been due to technical problems that had since been remedied.

title: CASE OF CARNEIRO DA SILVA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant instituted inventory proceedings to obtain the division of property of his great-uncle who died in 1944
- The administrator of the estate gave statements during the proceedings and identified at least fifty people as being J.C.'s heirs
- Two additional groups of heirs sought to intervene in the proceedings as parties
- The administrator of the estate submitted a list of J.C.'s assets to the case-file
- The court requested the administrator of the estate to make additional statements and contact information with regard to some of the heirs was submitted
- J.M.C. lodged a request to be allowed to intervene in the proceedings
- The court managed to summon all heirs
- The parties requested that a time-limit be set for the valuation of the property included in the inventory
- The administrator of the estate requested permission to step down from his post for health reasons
- A meeting of the parties took place and the court appointed an expert to value the immovable property left by J.C.
- The expert submitted two reports which were criticized by J.M.C.
- The expert was asked by the court to give information about the value of the properties
- Procedural steps were taken to identify heirs of deceased parties
- The court stayed the proceedings three times, ordering that they should not continue until information regarding the addresses of some of the heirs was submitted
- As of 10 January 2016, the proceedings were still pending at first instance.

title: CASE OF K.B. AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant and her husband I.B. were married in 2002 and lived together with their two sons in S., on the central Dalmatian coast, until March 2009.
- On 24 March 2009, the applicant contacted the Split Social Welfare Centre expressing fear for her life and her children's lives due to her husband's mental and verbal abuse towards them. She moved with the children to her parents' home in I.
- The police conducted interviews with the applicant and her husband, as well as the children's paediatrician and employees of their schools and kindergarten.
- The Ivanić-Grad Social Welfare Centre submitted a report recommending temporary placement of the children with their maternal grandparents, granting I.B. contact rights, and referring the children for treatment.
- The Ivanić-Grad Municipal Court deprived I.B. of custody temporarily and awarded it to the applicant, granting him contact rights.
- The Velika Gorica County Court dismissed I.B.'s appeal but he subsequently withdrew his request for contact.
- The applicant brought a civil action for divorce and custody, and the court ordered a combined expert opinion recommending custody for the mother and extensive contact rights for the father.
- The court allowed I.B. to keep the children with him in S. during the summer of 2010, and he subsequently requested temporary custody until the conclusion of the divorce and custody proceedings.
- Social welfare centres recommended returning the children to the applicant, and the Split Centre proposed a supplementary expert opinion.

title: CASE OF BARYSHEVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lives in Kharkiv.
- The applicant alleges that she was arrested by police officers in a café, detained without record, beaten, and threatened to obtain false confessions concerning her involvement in drug dealing.
- The Government states that the police officers seized some heroin from the applicant on 31 January 2009.
- The applicant complained about the incident on 10 February 2009, which was rejected as unsubstantiated on 17 April 2009.
- Kyivskyy District Court later ordered a prosecutor’s office inquiry into the ill-treatment complaints.
- The Kyivskyy District Prosecutor’s Office decided not to institute criminal proceedings, stating that the applicant had been ill-treated by police officers and detained without record from 29 January 2009 until 31 January 2009.
- The applicant appealed against this decision to the General Prosecutor’s Office, which forwarded the case-file materials back to the local prosecutor’s office.
- The criminal case against her was referred for additional investigation.
- The applicant sought medical aid in Kharkiv City Clinical Hospital no. 4 with various injuries on 25 June 2009.
- On the same date, she submitted a complaint to the Kharkiv Regional Department of the Interior, alleging that she had been ill-treated by the police officers, which prompted an internal investigation.
- The Kharkiv city prosecutor’s office began a preliminary investigation into the applicant’s complaints.
- On 18 September 2009, the Kharkiv city prosecutor’s office instituted criminal proceedings against “a group of unidentified police officers” suspected of abuse of authority accompanied by violence and the use of arms against the applicant on 24 June 2009.
- On 9 December 2010, the investigator discontinued the second set of criminal proceedings against the applicant and decided to transfer the file of the case against the applicant to the Kharkiv prosecutor’s office in order for it to be joined to the case concerning the applicant’s alleged ill-treatment.
- On 29 August 2011, the Kharkiv prosecutor withdrew the bill of indictment against officer A.A.
- On 12 September 2011, the Kyivskyy District Court of Kharkiv allowed the appeal, referring the case for further preliminary inquiry.

title: CASE OF LITVINCHUK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant concluded a preliminary sale agreement with Mr N. regarding a plot of land with a small house under construction situated in Belgorod Region.
- Mr N. died and his son sold the plot of land to another person who registered her property right.
- Applicant sought to register her property right over the plot of land and found that it already had another registered owner.
- On 9 April 2009, the Starooskolskiy Town Court of the Belgorod Region declared the sale contract of 10 October 2008 null and void.
- On 17 June 2009, the Town Court awarded the applicant 613,280 RUB for unjust enrichment and damages.
- On 4 August 2009, the Belgorod Regional Court decreased the amount of damages to RUB 246,569 and quashed the part relating to unjust enrichment.
- The applicant lodged a supervisory review application.
- On 17 December 2009, the Presidium of the Belgorod Regional Court partly quashed the judgment of 4 August 2009 and sent the case for consideration anew before the second instance court.
- On 19 January 2010 the Belgorod Regional Court restored the judgment of 17 June 2009.
- Mr N.’s son lodged a supervisory review application.
- On 8 July 2010 the Presidium of the Belgorod Regional Court rejected the supervisory review application lodged by Mr N.’s son and restored the judgment of 4 August 2009.
- On 3 November 2010 a single judge at the Supreme Court refused the applicant’s supervisory review application.

title: CASE OF YEVGENIY ZAKHAROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1944 and lived in a state-owned flat with his former wife until 1999.
- After their divorce, the applicant moved in with his new partner but did not apply for deregistration from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife.
- The new partner occupied a room in a three-room communal flat and the applicant and B. lived together in that room for the following ten years. They never married and the applicant was not registered as living in the room.
- B. died in May 2009 and her neighbours locked the applicant out of the flat.
- The applicant instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member on the grounds that they have shared a common household and he had been removed from the register at his previous place of residence.
- The District Court granted the applicant's claim and established that the applicant had cohabited with B. in the room in question and had shared a common household with her.
- The Regional Court quashed the judgment of the District Court and dismissed the applicant’s claims stating that the above circumstances are not in themselves exceptional, in particular given that no irrefutable evidence had been submitted to the court to prove that Ms Brazhnikova L. P. had let Mr Zakharov live in the flat as a family member rather than as a temporary resident.
- The Supreme Court refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review of the decision of 22 September 2010 to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination.

title: CASE OF KAVALIAUSKAS AND OTHERS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1972, 1980, 1937, and 1925 respectively and live in Vilnius.
- L.N. and the third and fourth applicants asked the Lithuanian authorities to restore their property rights to a house in Kaunas, nationalised in the 1940s.
- The authorities asked the applicants for additional documents to proceed with the restoration of their property rights in September 1993.
- The property rights to one room of the house was agreed to be restored to their brother - the third applicant according to an agreement made in 1995.
- The Kaunas City Council restored L.N.’s, the third and the fourth applicant’s property rights to a house in Kaunas in equal parts in a decision made on 11 April 1995.
- L.N. and the fourth applicant asked the authorities to pay them compensation for the part of the house that had not been returned in natura in July 1995.
- L.N., the third, and the fourth applicants refused the property that had already been returned to them in natura and asked for compensation for the entire house.
- The third applicant withdrew the application made in March 1996 in September 1996.
- On 23 September 1996, L.N., the third and the fourth applicants asked the authorities to pay them compensation for the part of the house that had not been returned to them in natura and agreed to partial compensation until the full market-value compensation figure had been calculated.
- The Kaunas City Municipality assessed the value of the entire house and calculated it to be LTL 239,190.
- The decision of the authorities of 11 April 1995 was amended on 1 June 2009, and L.N., the third, and the fourth applicants were paid LTL 30,000 for 22.42 sq. m of the house.
- The Kaunas City Municipality Administration asked the Centre of Registers to assess the value of the house in November 2006.
- In January 2008, the Centre of Registers assessed the market value of the house in 1996 at LTL 855,000 and calculated that the remaining compensation to be paid was LTL 615,809 in total.
- The authorities amended the decision of 11 April 1995 on 19 March 2008, and L.N., the third, and the fourth applicants had to be paid compensation amounting to LTL 615,809.
-

title: CASE OF TEHNOGRADNJA DOO v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant company acquired a debt belonging to Univerzal Banka AD resulting from a court judgment against the debtor company called Mehanizacija
- The Leskovac Commercial Court ordered the enforcement of the judgment
- The debtor company paid part of the judgment debt
- The Leskovac Commercial Court ordered the full enforcement of the judgment on the applicant company’s application
- The applicant company concluded a settlement with the debtor company which was later annulled by the court
- The Leskovac Commercial Court ordered the debtor company to pay the applicant company specified amounts
- The Leskovac Commercial Court ordered the enforcement of the said judgment on the applicant company’s application
- The Leskovac Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor company
- The applicant company reported its claims based on the judgments
- The Leskovac Commercial Court recognised part of the applicant company’s claims and dismissed the remainder
- The contract between the applicant company and the bank entitled the former only to the recovery of the amount paid for the transfer of the debt owed to the bank in question, not the judgment debt itself
- The insolvency proceedings are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF ORLOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are Oleg Petrovich Orlov, Artem Dmitrievich Vysotskiy, Stanislav Valeryevich Goryachikh and Karen Edvardovich Sakhinov from Moscow
- Oleg Petrovich Orlov is the Chairman of Memorial, a human rights organization
- Artem Dmitrievich Vysotskiy is a reporter for REN TV
- Stanislav Valeryevich Goryachikh and Karen Edvardovich Sakhinov are camera operators for REN TV
- They were in Nazran to cover a protest against abuse of authority by security forces
- They were all staying in the Hotel Assa in Nazran
- Oleg Petrovich Orlov was abducted from his hotel room by three masked men who took all his belongings and forced him into a minibus
- Stanislav Valeryevich Goryachikh and Karen Edvardovich Sakhinov were also abducted from their hotel room by five masked men who took their belongings
- Artem Dmitrievich Vysotskiy was also abducted from his hotel room by masked men
- All four applicants were beaten and blindfolded and put into a minibus
- They were threatened with death and taken to a snow-covered field where they were beaten again
- They were left lying in the cold and told not to return to the region
- They eventually made it to a nearby settlement and sought help from local residents
- They reported the incident to the police and made statements about the abduction and ill-treatment
- The investigators opened a criminal case into the incident and took witness statements from the applicants, hotel staff, and others involved

title: CASE OF KOKA HYBRO KOMERC DOO BROYLER v. SERBIA
facts:
- In 2006, Leskovac Commercial Court ordered socially-owned company AD Perper-Agrar to pay the applicant for damages
- The judgment became final in July 2006
- Applicant requested enforcement of the judgment in October 2006
- The court opened insolvency proceedings for the debtor in May 2011
- Applicant submitted a claim, which was recognized in February 2012
- Insolvency proceedings are ongoing
- The debtor was privatised and changed name in 2003 and 2006
- The debtor is still predominantly comprised of socially-owned capital
- Applicant transferred judgment claims to a third person in October 2015
- Contract regarding the transfer of claims was terminated in December 2015.

title: CASE OF KARPESH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1940 and lives in Tambov.
- On 8 August 2003, the Justice of the Peace of the 1st Court Circuit of the Leninskiy District of the Tambov Region ordered Municipal unitary enterprise of housing maintenance No. 1 to pay €348 to Ms. Lisova Aleksandra Semenovna. 
- The award was subsequently index-linked in the course of the enforcement proceedings by the decisions of 02 March 2006, 09 April 2007, 09 January 2008, and 27 March 2008.
- On 11 September 2003, the Bailiffs’ Service initiated enforcement proceedings.
- Following Ms. Lisova’s death, Mrs. Karpesh replaced her as the initial applicant in the enforcement proceedings on 8 July 2005.
- The award has not been paid to the applicant to date. 
- The company was incorporated as a municipal unitary enterprise and had the right of economic control over the assets allocated to it by the administration.
- On 30 May 2008, the debtor company was declared insolvent and liquidation proceedings started, resulting in the company’s liquidation on 27 May 2009.

title: CASE OF MUKAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1977 (1979 in some documents) and was serving a life sentence at an unspecified location.
- On 14 April 2001, a criminal case was opened against the applicant in Grozny, Chechnya. On 14 September 2001, he was charged with aggravated murder in absentia.
- In December 2001, he left Chechnya under a false identity and arrived in Semipalatinsk, Kazakhstan in January 2002.
- In January/February 2006, Russian authorities requested his extradition to Russia. On 23 February 2006, he was handed over to Russian law-enforcement officers at Astana airport.
- On the same day, he was taken to remand prison IZ-77/4 in Moscow and later transferred to Chechen investigators and police officers to be taken to Grozny.
- The applicant alleged ill-treatment by police officers during the journey from Vladikavkaz to Grozny, in ORB-2, and during his time in SIZO 20/1 in Grozny.
- He reported the ill-treatment to supervising prosecutors but was not provided with copies of their decisions.
- Investigator's reports contained conflicting information on his bodily injuries and no evidence was obtained against the officers who were allegedly involved in the ill-treatment.

title: CASE OF MODESTOU v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant is a businessman and chairman of a public limited company.
- On 23 September 2010, the public prosecutor ordered searches at fifteen premises, including the applicant's address, in the context of a police investigation.
- The police conducted a twelve and a half hour search of the applicant's home and seized numerous items.
- In May 2012, the public prosecutor instituted proceedings against the applicant for involvement in a criminal organisation.
- The applicant applied to have the search declared null and void, the seizure order lifted, and the seized items returned.
- The indictment division dismissed the applicant's application to nullify the search and seizure, stating that it was a common tool used to gather evidence during a preliminary police investigation.
- The indictment division also held that the occupant did not necessarily have to be present during a search of their premises.
- The authorities refused to return the seized items, stating that they were crucial for the investigation of the case.

title: CASE OF ÓLAFSSON v. ICELAND
facts:
- The applicant was the editor of a web-based media site
- Two sisters published an article on their website accusing a candidate of sexual abuse
- Pressan published articles about the accusations and A's response
- A threatens lawsuit against Pressan
- Pressan publishes further articles about the matter
- A files defamation proceedings against the applicant
- The District Court finds in favor of the applicant
- The Supreme Court partly overturns the District Court's decision and finds the statements in sections A, B, D, and part of C defamatory
- The Constitution guarantees freedom of expression but restricts it in the interests of public order or the protection of the rights or reputation of others
- The Penal Code lays out provisions for defamation and privacy violations
- The Tort Liability Act allows for non-pecuniary damages to be awarded to the injured party
- The Printing Act holds authors, publishers, editors, and distributors liable for the substance of the publication.

title: CASE OF KOSTOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Sofia.
- The applicant’s father co-owned a plot of land and a house in Sofia.
- The property was expropriated by the mayor on 15 July 1981 with a view to constructing residential buildings.
- The applicant’s father and the applicant were to receive a three-room flat in compensation based on a decision of the mayor.
- By a supplementary decision of 25 March 1987, the mayor determined the exact location, size, and other details in respect of the future flat offered in compensation.
- In 1989 the applicant paid to the authorities the part of the value of the future flat which had not been covered by the value of the expropriated property.
- In 1990 the Sofia municipality settled him temporarily in a flat which was property of the State-owned enterprise B.
- On an unspecified date, the construction of the building where the flat was to be located was commenced.
- However, the construction was not completed within the deadline set.
- In 2005, the building, still unfinished, was sold to another company, which apparently resold the property to a third company in 2006.
- The applicant submitted a certificate of occupancy of the building at issue, dated 5 October 2007, but claimed that it only concerned “certain construction activities” and that the building was not in use.
- The applicant filed several requests with the municipal authorities in Sofia asking them to complete the compensation procedure and deliver the flat due to him.
- The Sofia municipality informed the applicant that the company was responsible for delivering the flat to him in a letter of 13 August 2004.
- In 2007 the applicant was evicted from the flat where he had been temporarily settled, after it had been sold to a private party in the context of the winding-up of the company B.

title: CASE OF KARGASHIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- List of applicants with relevant application details in the appended table.
- Applicants complained of inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Other complaints were raised under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MITROVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1943 and died on 20 October 2014.
- The applicant was detained on remand by the “Police of the Republic of Serbian Krajina” (Policija Republike Srpske Krajine) on 26 December 1993, under suspicion of murder. 
- The investigative judge extended his detention on 29 December 1993.
- The “District Court of Beli Manastir” (Okružni sud u Belom Manastiru) extended his detention on 25 January 1994, 15 February 1994, 8 April 1994 and sentenced the applicant to 8 years of imprisonment for murder on 9 May 1994.
- The Supreme Court of the Republic of Serbian Krajina confirmed the applicant's sentence on 21 July 1994.
- All institutions involved were under the control of the “Republic of Serbian Krajina”, which ceased to exist after the adoption of the Erdut Agreement on 12 November 1995.
- The applicant was transferred to Sremska Mitrovica prison on 20 June 1996, where he remained until 5 February 1999, after which he failed to return to the prison, and a warrant for his arrest was issued.
- The applicant was arrested on 7 July 2010 and sent to Sremska Mitrovica prison to serve the remainder of his sentence until he was released on 15 November 2012.
- The Constitutional Court found that there was no violation of the applicant’s right to liberty on 10 May 2012, and the applicant had access to other procedures available to any other prisoner in Serbia.
- The applicant initiated civil proceedings for compensation for unlawful imprisonment on 7 March 2011, which were rejected by the Belgrade Appellate Court on 16 April 2014, and the applicant's appeal was rejected on procedural grounds by the Supreme Court of Cassation on 8 July 2015.

title: CASE OF MOZHAROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• List of applicants and application details included in the table.

• Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.

• Other complaints raised under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BUJAK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Sarbice Pierwsze.
- On 1 January 1999, the applicant suffered several bodily injuries in a car accident, for which he was treated in Hamburg until 27 February 1999.
- In 1999, the applicant was suspected of several thefts of leased movable goods, in particular, cars, during the period he spent running a company.
- In June 1999, the applicant moved to New Zealand, and the proceedings against him were stayed.
- On 29 March 2004, the Minister of Justice requested the applicant’s extradition to Poland.
- In 2010, the applicant was transported to Poland following an extradition hearing in New Zealand and was arrested on 9 March 2010.
- On 13 March 2010, the Kielce District Court decided to detain him on remand for three months until 9 June 2010.
- The court found that the applicant had a reasonable suspicion of committing the offenses and could obstruct the proceedings or go into hiding until the charges against him became time-barred.
- The applicant’s detention was extended until 7 September 2010 and again until 4 February 2011 and then until 21 December 2011.
- The court cited the high probability of the applicant committing offenses, the severity of the penalty, the risk of him going into hiding or obstructing the proceedings, and his non-cooperation with the court regarding his state of health as grounds for the extension of his detention.
- On 8 December 2011, the applicant was released from detention, and police supervision was imposed.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant were still pending as per the last information available at the time.
- The applicant was hospitalised in January 2016.
- The applicant’s documentation had been handed over to the Polish authorities at the time of his deportation from New Zealand.
- The applicant informed the doctor of his illness only after being detained at the Kielce Remand Centre and had easy access to a shower.
- The applicant was prescribed crutches, advised to continue his pharmacological treatment, and use a hard mattress.
- The neurosurgeon found no grounds for the applicant to undergo a spine operation, advised pharmacological treatment and physiotherapy, and considered it unnecessary to grant the applicant's request for a wheelchair.

title: CASE OF MICHAŁ KORGUL v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and is detained in Lublin.
- The applicant has several convictions for burglary, theft, and robbery.
- From May 2009, the applicant was detained on remand on suspicion of having committed several armed robberies.
- The applicant was indicted in July 2009 on several counts of armed robbery.
- The applicant was confined to a special high-security prison wing and subjected to various measures due to being classified as a "dangerous detainee."
- The regime of the "dangerous detainee" was lifted on March 27, 2013.
- The applicant accumulated PLN 372 in his release savings fund between June 17, 2009, and December 9, 2011.

title: CASE OF POROWSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Otwock.
- The applicant was arrested on 11 July 2000.
- The Jarosław District Court remanded the applicant in custody on 12 July 2000 on suspicion of attempting to extort money from two people by depriving them of their liberty and threatening to kill them.
- The applicant’s detention on remand was extended several times by the Jarosław District Court and interlocutory appeals against those decisions were rejected.
- The Jarosław District Court convicted the applicant on 7 November 2003 and sentenced him to five years’ imprisonment. The Krosno Regional Court upheld the conviction and sentence on 23 March 2004.
- The applicant’s detention was continued by various courts throughout the proceedings, based on the original grounds for his arrest and the risk that he would abscond or obstruct the proceedings.
- The applicant was represented by two lawyers throughout the proceedings.
- The applicant did not lodge a complaint about the length of the proceedings under the Law of 17 June 2004 on complaints of a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time.
- The applicant was also remanded in custody in connection with another criminal case.
- The applicant’s detention on remand was extended several times in the second criminal case, based on the severity of the punishment that could be imposed, strong evidence against him, and the risk of obstruction of the proceedings if released. Interlocutory appeals against these decisions were also rejected.

title: CASE OF WOLTER AND SARFERT v. GERMANY
facts:
- First applicant born in 1943 and lives in Cologne, second applicant born in 1940 and lives in Stuttgart
- First applicant is natural son of Mr H. who recognised paternity several months after birth and the father died on 23 October 2007
- First applicant applied for certificate of inheritance on 6 November 2007 and received it on 7 November 2007, but it was withdrawn on 10 December 2007
- First applicant appealed against the decision and referred to Brauer v. Germany case, but was dismissed on 16 February 2010
- Second applicant is natural son of Mr. B., born in former GDR and in 1949, Mr. B. was ordered to pay maintenance for the applicant
- Second applicant filed Plichtteilsklage in 2009 and was dismissed on 21 January 2010
- Both applicants filed constitutional complaints, which were dismissed on 18 March 2013
- Amended first sentence of section 12(10)(2) of the Children Born outside Marriage (Legal Status) Act was changed retroactively with the Second Inheritance Rights Equalisation Act of 12 April 2011
- The Federal Constitutional Court confirmed the conformity of the amended first sentence of section 12(10)(2) of the Children Born outside Marriage (Legal Status) Act with the Basic Law
- European Court of Human Rights' judgment in Brauer v. Germany case did not necessitate a different interpretation of the relevant provision in the present case.

title: CASE OF SAYENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- There is an appended table containing a list of applicants and relevant application details.
- The applicants complained about lengthy civil proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of effective remedy under domestic law.
- Some applicants had additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SHUST AND SIDORENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document includes a table listing the names and application details of the applicants.
- The applicants have raised complaints regarding their pre-trial detention being excessively long.
- The applicants have also raised additional complaints under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF ŠKORJANEC v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant and her partner were attacked by two men of non-Roma origin.
- The men made racist remarks and attacked the applicant and her partner physically.
- The police arrived at the scene and arrested the attackers.
- The applicant sustained visible injuries and received medical attention.
- The attackers were indicted and found guilty of making serious threats against the applicant's partner and inflicting bodily injury on him, associated with a hate-crime element.

title: CASE OF Z.A. AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Five applicants found themselves staying in the transit zone of Sheremetyevo Airport, Moscow.
- The first applicant, an Iraqi national, was denied entry to Turkey and subsequently stayed in the transit zone. He applied for refugee status in Russia, claiming the risk of persecution in Iraq.
- The second applicant, a Palestinian passport holder, stayed in the transit zone because he was denied entry to Russia due to an expired visa. He applied for refugee status in Russia, claiming the risk of persecution in Palestine.
- The third applicant, a Somali national with refugee status in Yemen, came to Moscow via Cuba and was deported from Cuba to Russia. He applied for refugee status in Russia, claiming the risk of persecution in Somalia.
- The fourth applicant, a Syrian national who had arrived in Moscow on a business visa, applied for temporary asylum in Moscow but was refused. After being denied entry to Turkey and Lebanon, he stayed in the transit zone and applied for refugee status in Russia.
- All applicants described the conditions of their stay in the transit zone as uncomfortable with no access to a shower and basic amenities.
- The Moscow Region FMS repeatedly denied their applications for refugee status, and the applicants appealed to the higher migration authority, the Russian FMS.
- The Basmannyy District Court of Moscow upheld the Russian FMS’s decisions, and the applicants’ lawyers lodged brief statements of appeal pending receipt of a reasoned judgment in written form.
- UNHCR resettled the first, second, and third applicants to Denmark, Egypt, and Somalia, respectively.
- UNHCR resettled the fourth applicant to Sweden.

title: CASE OF FERNANDES DE OLIVEIRA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant's son had a history of mental disorders and was addicted to drugs and alcohol, and had been admitted to the Sobral Cid Psychiatric Hospital on multiple occasions.
- Doctors had advised the applicant to seek a compulsory confinement order for her son in September 1999.
- The applicant's son had been authorised to spend weekends at home during two hospitalisations, but had escaped from the hospital premises several times during both periods.
- On April 1, 2000, the applicant's son was voluntarily admitted to the HSC after attempting suicide.
- Despite the reluctance of his doctor, he was allowed to go home for Easter weekend on April 25, 2000, and returned to the hospital on April 26, 2000.
- On April 27, 2000, the hospital staff noted the absence of the applicant's son during dinner and initiated searches of the hospital and surrounding areas.
- Between 7 p.m. and 8 p.m. on April 27, 2000, the hospital reported the disappearance of the applicant's son to the National Republican Guard and the applicant.
- On April 27, 2000, the applicant's son committed suicide by jumping in front of a train near the HSC premises.
- The applicant sued the HSC for negligence in failing to supervise her son and prevent his suicide.
- The Coimbra Administrative Court and the Administrative Supreme Court both ruled in favour of the HSC, finding that there had been no breach of duty of care on the part of the hospital.

title: CASE OF MARKOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Waldegg, Austria.
- The applicant initiated civil proceedings on 28 September 1994, requesting the division of a certain estate.
- The Ivanjica Municipal Court suspended the said proceedings on 5 January 2009 until conclusion of another civil case.
- The civil proceedings initiated in 1994 are still pending.
- The Constitutional Court found a breach of the applicant’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time on 23 June 2011 and ordered the speeding up of the impugned proceedings. Additionally, the court declared that the applicant was entitled to the non-pecuniary damages sought, in accordance with Article 90 of the Constitutional Court Act.
- The applicant contacted the Commission for Compensation on 11 December 2011 and requested the payment of the compensation awarded, but apparently received no response.

title: CASE OF BLAGOJEVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Kragujevac.
- A civil suit was filed by the applicant and 18 others against Telekom Srbija AD Beograd on 13 July 2006.
- The applicant's initial representative did not attend the first preliminary hearing.
- The preliminary hearing was held on 13 February 2007.
- The proceedings were split into separate proceedings for each plaintiff concerned on 27 August 2007.
- Seven out of eight hearings were postponed for various reasons between 21 October 2008 and 29 April 2011.
- The Kragujevac First Instance Court ruled against the applicant on 29 April 2011.
- The Kragujevac Appeals Court upheld the judgment on 20 February 2012.
- The applicant's appeal was rejected by the Constitutional Court on 27 June 2013.

title: CASE OF GRIGORYAN AND SERGEYEVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Mr Grigoryan and Ms Sergeyeva are life partners who live in Kyiv; Mr Grigoryan is an ethnic Armenian and had refugee status at the time of the incident.
- On the night of 6 April 2010, the applicants were returning from a picnic accompanied by two acquaintances and a taxi driver.
- The police stopped the car, and there are different accounts of what happened next.
- The police accused the applicants of petty hooliganism, arrested them, and took them to the police station.
- Mr Grigoryan was tied up and allegedly beaten while in police custody. Ms Sergeyeva was also tied up.
- The applicants were fined and signed administrative offence reports upon their release.
- The applicants complained about their treatment to various authorities, including the prosecutor's office and the police internal inquiry.

title: CASE OF MARUNIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was the director of a municipal utility company, KD Kostrena, from 2003-2007.
- The mayor of Kostrena municipality criticised the applicant's performance in an article published in a newspaper.
- The applicant responded to the criticisms made by the mayor in a later article published in the same newspaper.
- The applicant was summarily dismissed from her job as director of the utility company due to her statements in the media.
- The applicant filed a request for the protection of her rights, which was not answered, and later filed a civil action for wrongful dismissal against the company.
- The Municipal Court ruled in favour of the applicant, finding that her dismissal was wrongful.
- The County Court upheld the decision of the Municipal Court but on different grounds, finding that the applicant's behaviour did not constitute a serious breach of employment-related duties as envisaged in section 107 of the Labour Act.
- The company lodged an appeal on points of law against the decision of the County Court.

title: CASE OF SHESTOPALOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was invited to answer questions by two police officers and accompanied them to the police station with his mother's permission.
- The applicant was interrogated about a rape case in room no. 306 and denied any involvement.
- The police officers tied him up, punched and kicked him, throttled him with a baton, put a plastic bag over his head, and blocked his access to air.
- Fearing further ill-treatment, the applicant signed a self-incriminating statement.
- The applicant sustained injuries, including a closed head injury, concussion, abrasions, and bruises, and was unable to attend school for weeks.
- The rape victim cleared the applicant of any involvement in her rape.
- The applicant's mother complained to the police about her son's ill-treatment, and six refusals to institute criminal proceedings were issued before a criminal case was brought against the police officers.
- One police officer was identified by the applicant as responsible for the ill-treatment, but the criminal proceedings were later discontinued due to lack of evidence.
- The applicant was granted victim status and later awarded RUB 50,000 in damages by the Sovetskiy District Court of Nizhniy Novgorod for the violation of his rights under Article 3 of the Convention. 
- The Nizhniy Novgorod Regional Court upheld the judgment.

title: CASE OF KEMAL COŞKUN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant, a police officer, was driving a white civilian car in an isolated area outside the city.
- The gendarmerie received a call about a woman crying for help in that car and located the car.
- The woman, Ç.V., claimed that she had been kidnapped and beaten up by the applicant and showed signs of injury.
- The applicant was caught trying to get rid of weapons, including a knife, a hatchet, and a gun, which were confiscated as evidence along with other items found in his car, including handcuffs and duct tape.
- Ç.V. submitted a written statement that falsely accused the applicant but later claimed that her initial accusations had been truthful.
- The applicant was charged with attempted rape, false imprisonment, and robbery, but was acquitted of the latter two charges.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment against the applicant due to the statute of limitations.
- Disciplinary proceedings were initiated against the applicant, and the Supreme Disciplinary Council found him guilty of attempted rape, assault, and threatening violence with a weapon, ordering his dismissal from the police force.
- The applicant appealed and argued that his acquittal in the criminal case should preclude the disciplinary sanction, but his appeal was rejected.

title: CASE OF JOVANOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant's year of birth and place of residence (born in 1968, lives in Kaluđerica)
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of participating in criminal association within the police operation "Customs mafia", along with 43 others (22 December 2006)
- The applicant was released (15 June 2007)
- The investigation against all accused was transferred to the Prosecutor's Office for Organised Crime (31 July 2009)
- The investigation was closed (28 June 2012)
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant were suspended (17 January 2013).

title: CASE OF STURUA v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lived in Tbilisi.
- The applicant was appointed as President of the Abasha District Court for a ten-year term on 15 May 1999.
- On 3 December 2004, disciplinary proceedings were initiated against the applicant for retaining a criminal case file for six months after withdrawing from the case on 29 October 2003.
- On 23 December 2004, the Panel found the applicant guilty of misconduct and removed him from office, taking into account the serious nature of the misconduct and the existence of previous disciplinary measures.
- On 29 December 2004, the applicant appealed to the Disciplinary Council of Judges on points of fact and law.
- On 27 January 2005, the Disciplinary Council upheld the Panel's decision of 23 December 2004.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court, which was dismissed as ill-founded on 11 July 2005.

title: CASE OF VOLCHKOVA AND MIRONOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants owned a plot of land and a house built on it
- They had inherited their shares of the house and land from their late mother and another person
- The municipality adopted a programme for demolishing dilapidated housing and issued draft construction guidelines for the area where the applicants' house was situated
- The municipality agreed to the construction of several blocks of flats, including one on the applicants' land
- The municipality ordered the expropriation of the applicants' house and land for municipal needs, namely the construction of a block of flats under an investment contract
- The applicants were offered compensation in kind and monetary compensation for their expropriated property but turned it down
- The town court held several hearings in the expropriation case and ordered two valuation reports from Expert Centre, which indicated lower market values for the applicants' property
- The municipality's mayor asked the court to speed up the proceedings, arguing that the procrastination was prejudicial to the people who had invested in the construction project.

title: CASE OF NAGMETOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's son participated in a public gathering that alleged corruption by local public officials.
- Officers from the special mobile unit used firearms to disperse the gathering and Murad Nagmetov died from his wounds; five other people were seriously wounded and many others were injured and arrested.
- The investigating authority initiated criminal proceedings and commissioned a ballistics report to determine the type of grenade and rifle used.
- Multiple ballistics reports were commissioned from different expert institutions but were not produced due to lack of technical facilities or compliance.
- The investigating authority later resumed the investigation after it was suspended, but the evidence extracted from the body of the victim was lost, and the investigator in the case died.
- The investigation was ultimately suspended due to a lack of evidence that made it impossible to identify the person who shot the applicant's son.
- The applicant filed an application before the Court alleging that his son died due to an unlawful and excessive use of lethal force, and that the investigations into his son's death were ineffective.

title: CASE OF GRAMMOSENIS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
Bullet points of the main descriptions of facts in this document are:

- The applicants were placed in pre-trial detention at Thessaloniki General Police Headquarters for periods ranging from one to eight months.
- Some of the applicants were released, while it is not clear if others were released or transferred to prisons.
- The conditions of detention at Thessaloniki General Police Headquarters were alleged to be inappropriate due to insufficient lighting, ventilation, and overcrowding.
- Recreational activities were not offered, and detainees had to ask permission from guards to use the restroom, which was shared by seventy people.
- There was insufficient separation between drug users or smokers and other detainees.
- The nutrition was of insufficient quality and quantity and did not include meat. Detainees had to buy water themselves.
- The applicants had lodged a complaint with the public prosecutor about the conditions of their detention but did not receive a reply.
- The conditions of detention at the Thessaloniki Aliens Division and Menemeni police station were essentially the same as those at the police headquarters.
- Thessaloniki General Police Headquarters had nineteen cells with a total capacity of seventy-three people, while the Thessaloniki Aliens Division had ten cells, and Menemeni police station had a cell of 26 square metres accommodating five detainees.
- Detainees had access to newspapers, magazines, payphones, and visits from lawyers and family members.

title: CASE OF STEFANOVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1938, 1940 and 1961 respectively, and are related.
- They bought a flat from the State in Sofia in 1990, measuring 144 square metres, which had been nationalized after 1945.
- The heir of the pre-nationalization owner of the flat sued the applicants in 1992 under section 7 of the Restitution Law, claiming their title was null and void and bringing a rei vindicatio claim.
- The domestic courts allowed both actions against the applicants, finding that their title was null and void since they bought their flat in breach of the law.
- It is unclear what happened with the compensation bonds the applicants applied for.
- In 2005, the applicants brought a tort action against the Sofia municipality, and in 2012, the Supreme Court of Cassation awarded them the equivalent of about 12 euros (EUR), as they were only entitled to receive the price they had paid for the flat in 1990.

title: CASE OF AVAKEMYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant filed a claim against K. for a certain amount of money.
- They settled the debt with an agreement that included a time-frame for payment.
- The court delivered a judgment upholding the settlement.
- K. did not comply with the terms of the settlement, and the bailiff found no funds or property belonging to K. during the enforcement procedure.
- The bailiff informed the applicant that K. inherited a house but did not register the ownership, and advised the applicant to institute proceedings against K. to recognize her ownership.
- The applicant brought a claim to have K.’s ownership of the house recognized, and the court granted the claim and recognized K. as the owner of the house in question.
