- The bailiff requested that the State Committee of the Real Estate Registry recognize K.’s ownership of the house, register it, and issue a copy of the ownership certificate; however, the Real Estate Registry informed the bailiff that it needed an application from K., the original judgment, and receipts for the State fee and other related payments.
- The bailiff made similar requests to the Real Estate Registry and asserted that an application from K. was not required.
- The applicant brought a claim seeking to oblige the Real Estate Registry and the bailiff to respectively register K.’s ownership of the house and confiscate it from her.
- The Administrative Court granted the applicant’s claim.
- None of the three court judgments were enforced.
- The applicant sought the payment of interest by K. via a claim in the District Court and won, but it was refused by the bailiff for lack of action within the time-limit of one year starting from the final judgment. 
- K. submitted a receipt for the payment of the debt to the bailiff, and the enforcement proceedings were terminated.

title: CASE OF MAHARRAMOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant owned a shop at 32 Attarlar Street in Ganja, which was purchased from the state.
- The shop had a total area of 78.3 sq. m and was used for wholesale or retail trade purposes.
- In 2004, the Ganja City Executive Authority decided to renovate and widen Attarlar and Nizami Streets, which meant removal of a number of retail facilities and shops.
- The applicant was asked to vacate the shop but refused, bringing a legal action against the authorities.
- The shop was allegedly destroyed or removed by crane to an unspecified part of the city in December 2004.
- The applicant claimed compensation for the shop's market value, Aysel-M's fee for the expert report, and a state fee.
- Different courts dismissed the applicant's legal actions, accepting the respondent's explanation that the shop was removed in accordance with town-planning policy, and that the applicant had been offered a new plot of land but refused it.

title: CASE OF TEK GIDA İŞ SENDIKASI v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant union represented workers in the food-processing sector
- Some Tukaş company employees joined the union in 2003
- The union applied for certification for representative status in collective bargaining with Tukaş
- Ministry granted union's representative status based on number of members and staff at Tukaş factories
- Tukaş disputed union's representative status and judicial review was conducted
- Expert report found union wasn't representative when including staff at Tukaş head office, but was representative when excluding them
- Labour Court withdrew union's representative status
- Applicant union appealed and Court of Cassation dismissed appeal
- Tukaş dismissed forty union members on grounds of economic or professional shortcomings
- Dismissed employees applied for wrongful dismissal and were found in favour by İzmir labour courts
- Court of Cassation upheld the labour court judgments
- Tukaş did not reinstate employees or pay compensation
- By 2005, applicant union had no members at Tukaş.

title: CASE OF GÜZELYURTLU AND OTHERS v. CYPRUS AND TURKEY
facts:
• The case involves the murder of three Cypriot nationals of Turkish Cypriot origin on 15 January 2005.
• The applicants are the family of the deceased.
• Elmas Güzelyurtlu was a businessman and used to live with his wife Zerrin and daughter Eylül in the “TRNC”.
• The victims were found dead on the back seat of a black Lexus car parked on the hard shoulder of the Nicosia-Larnaca highway, and Elmas Güzelyurtlu was lying dead at a distance of 1.5 metres from the car in a nearby ditch.
• Zerrin Güzelyurtlu had adhesive tape on her neck and two rolls of adhesive tape in her hands. Both Zerrin Güzelyurtlu and her daughter Eylül Güzelyurtlu had redness and bruises on their hands and shins indicating that they had been tied with adhesive tape and had sustained injuries in a struggle.
• The investigation collected evidence, including witness statements, exhibits, DNA tests, and forensic tests on the victims and the crime scene.
• Five suspects were identified, and arrest warrants and European arrest warrants were issued against all of them.
• Three more suspects were later identified and arrest warrants and European arrest warrants were issued against them.
• Interpol was notified and Red Notices were published to arrest and extradite the suspects.
• The “TRNC” authorities requested more evidence and did not clarify whether they would hand over the suspects if they were given video tapes.
• The applicants’ representatives had met with and had been in telephone contact with the Attorney-General.

title: CASE OF LOVRIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant lives in Čaglin and was a member of the hunting association, V. based in Čaglin.
- The association’s executive board initiated internal proceedings against the applicant before its disciplinary commission.
- The executive board sought the applicant’s suspension until the next session of the association’s general meeting for falsely accusing a member of the association of the criminal offence of intimidation, which was a serious breach of his duties as a member according to the association’s internal regulations.
- The disciplinary commission dismissed the disciplinary action against the applicant, but the executive board still referred the matter to the general meeting for re-examination, which ultimately adopted a resolution expelling the applicant from the association.
- The applicant brought a civil action against the hunting association in the Požega County Court, asking the court to declare unlawful the general meeting’s resolution of 20 February 2013 and to reinstate him as a member, but the court declared the action inadmissible, as it was outside the jurisdiction of the courts according to the Associations Act. The applicant appealed to the Supreme Court, which also dismissed his appeal, and then lodged a constitutional complaint which was declared inadmissible by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF ŽIVKOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1941 and lives in Belgrade.
- On 27 June 2001 the Obrenovac Municipal Court ordered a socially-owned company to pay the applicant specified amounts on account of compensation for expropriated real estate plus the costs of the civil proceedings.
- On 18 March 2003, the Obrenovac Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the judgment and further ordered the debtor to pay the applicant the enforcement costs.
- On 23 April 2003 the Privatisation Agency ordered the restructuring of the applicant’s debtor, staying the ongoing enforcement proceedings against the debtor.
- On 29 February 2016, the Belgrade Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor. The applicant duly reported her claims based on the above-mentioned judgment to the insolvency administration.
- The insolvency proceedings are still ongoing, and the said court judgment remains unenforced to the present day.
- According to publicly available information, the debtor is still predominantly comprised of socially-owned capital.
- On 7 October 2011, the applicant lodged an appeal with the Constitutional Court seeking redress, inter alia, compensation for the pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage suffered due to the impugned non-enforcement.
- On 15 May 2012, the applicant specified her compensation claims accordingly.
- On 21 May 2014, the Constitutional Court found a violation of the applicant’s right to a fair trial within a reasonable time, as well as a violation of her property rights and awarded her EUR 1,000 in respect of the non-pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF PAVLOVIĆ AND PANTOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1953 and 1951 respectively and live in Čačak.
- The Čačak Municipal Court ordered a socially-owned company, Fabrika Reznog Alata Čačak AD and its subsidiaries (hereinafter “the debtor”) to pay the applicants specified amounts on account of salary arrears, which became final on 2 July 2008.
- The court ordered the enforcement of the judgment and further ordered the debtor to pay the enforcement costs upon the request of the applicants.
- The Privatisation Agency ordered the restructuring of the debtor on 30 March 2010, which stayed the enforcement proceedings against the debtor.
- The enforcement proceedings against the debtor were resumed on 8 April 2013, upon the applicants’ request to that effect.
- The applicants lodged an appeal with the Constitutional Court on 29 July 2010 and sought compensation for non-enforcement.
- The applicants specified their compensation claims on 19 and 20 March 2013 and requested respective amounts of pecuniary damage and EUR 2,000 each for non-pecuniary damage.
- The Constitutional Court found a violation of the applicants’ right to a hearing within a reasonable time and of their right to the peaceful enjoyment of their possessions, awarded EUR 1,000 and EUR 1,100 respectively as just satisfaction for non-pecuniary damage, rejected their compensation claim regarding the pecuniary damage sought by the applicants, and ordered the speeding up of the impugned enforcement proceedings.
- The Constitutional Court referred to Article 85 § 3 of the Constitutional Court Act and stated that the applicants’ pecuniary damage claim had been lodged out of time in its reasoning.
- The National Bank of Serbia informed the Čačak First Instance Court that the final court judgment of 21 March 2008 had been partially enforced on 14 August 2008, and the applicants had received the sum of 143.707,89 Serbian dinars (RSD) on 10 June 2016.
- The applicants’ representative claimed that they were not aware of the partial enforcement and never received a letter from the National Bank of Serbia related to the enforcement issue. The representative also claimed that the amount of RSD 143.707,89 was paid only to the second applicant.

title: CASE OF GOŠOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and owns a flat in Split.
- The flat has a surface area of 106.90 square meters and is the only real estate in his ownership.
- The housing authorities awarded a specially protected tenancy of the flat to Ms. N.R. and her family in 1971.
- The Lease of Flats Act was passed on 5 November 1996 which abolished the specially protected tenancy and made the holders of such tenancies "protected lessees."
- The applicant refused to enter into a lease contract with N.R under the protected lease scheme.
- N.R brought a civil action against the applicant in the Split Municipal Court on 16 October 1997 to obtain a judgment in lieu of the contract.
- At the hearing, the applicant argued that N.R was not entitled to protected rent.
- The applicant submitted a counter-claim to obtain a judgment ordering N.R. and her family to vacate the flat in question as he intended to move into it.
- The Municipal Court ruled in favor of N.R. and imposed on the applicant a lease contract with protected rent.
- The Split County Court dismissed the appeal by the applicant and upheld the first-instance judgment.
- The courts found that the applicant was not entitled to refuse to enter into a lease contract with N.R. based on the conditions provided in section 40(1) of the Lease of Flats Act.
- The court also found that N.R was entitled to protected rent.
- The applicant's constitutional complaint against the judgments of the Municipal and the County Court was dismissed by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF SALĞIN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1989 and was detained at Tekirdağ prison when the application was lodged. 
- On 9 July 2010, the applicant was taken into police custody on suspicion of membership of a terrorist organisation. 
- On 13 July 2010, the investigating judge at the Istanbul Assize Court ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention after questioning him, considering the nature of the offence, the state of the evidence, and the strong suspicion of the suspect's involvement. 
- On 7 September 2010, the Istanbul public prosecutor filed an indictment charging the applicant with membership of an illegal terrorist organisation. 
- The trial began on 15 February 2011, before the 9th Chamber of the Istanbul Assize Court. 
- The applicant appeared before the court in the hearings held on 21 February 2012 and 3 May 2012, respectively, and the judges ordered his continued detention. 
- The applicant filed objections against these decisions, but on 7 March 2012 and 8 June 2012, respectively, the 10th Chamber of the Istanbul Assize Court dismissed the applicant's objections without holding an oral hearing and based on the public prosecutor's opinion which had not been communicated to the applicant or his representative. 
- During the eleventh hearing held on 30 July 2013, the 9th Chamber of the Istanbul Assize Court ordered the applicant's continued detention on remand.

title: CASE OF MATANOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and currently serves a prison sentence in Lepoglava.
- The applicant was the vice-president of the Croatian Privatization Fund (the Fund), a legal entity established by the State tasked with carrying out the privatization of publicly owned property.
- A businessman named M.M. approached the State Attorney’s Office alleging that he had been introduced to a certain A.P., allegedly an official of the Fund, who had offered assistance in pursuing a business project in Croatia. In return, A.P. had asked M.M. to deposit 2,250,000 euros (EUR) in various bank accounts.
- Special investigative measures were authorized in respect of the applicant, including the tapping of his telephone, covert surveillance, the use of J.K. as an informant, and conducting a simulated purchase operation.
- Following the completion of the investigation, the State Attorney’s Office indicted the applicant and nine other individuals and brought them before the Zagreb County Court on charges of bribe-taking, offering bribes and abuse of power and authority. The applicant was indicted in his capacity as a public official on two counts of bribe-taking and bribery of the President of the Fund related to M.M.’s investment project in the Zadar region, two counts of bribe-taking related to the privatization of the hotels Ž. and P. and the company P.O., and one count of abuse of power and authority related to the privatization of the company B.

title: CASE OF KOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicants complained of excessive length of administrative and civil proceedings
- Constitutional Court of Serbia found a violation of their right to a hearing within a reasonable time
- Mr Nikola Ković has the right to seek compensation
- Mr Ković submitted request for damages, but hasn't received a response
- Mr Zoran Ranković and Mr Ivan Bojanić awarded certain sums in respect of non-pecuniary damage suffered.

title: CASE OF V.K. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant has a history of mental conditions since 1979
- Applicant has been admitted to psychiatric facilities several times
- Applicant has a record of alcohol abuse, suicide attempts, threats of violence, and personality disorders
- Between 1998 and 2007, the applicant was taken to the hospital at least six times for various reasons
- The applicant called for emergency assistance at his home twelve times in March 2007, and behaved aggressively towards medical personnel
- On April 3, 2007, the applicant was admitted without his consent to St Petersburg Psychiatric Hospital no. 3
- On the same day, a panel composed of the hospital's resident psychiatrists examined the applicant and diagnosed him with multiple disorders
- On April 9, 2007, the court granted the hospital's application to admit the applicant to hospital without his consent
- The applicant's appeal against the order was dismissed on August 2, 2007
- Nothing suggests the applicant had a legal guardian or was restricted in his legal capacity

title: CASE OF THUO v. CYPRUS
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Nairobi, Kenya.
2. The applicant entered Cyprus unlawfully through the “Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus” (“TRNC”) on 4 April 2005.
3. On 6 April 2005, the applicant was arrested at Larnaca Airport as he attempted to travel to London on a forged passport.
4. The applicant was sentenced by the Larnaca District Court to nine months’ imprisonment and detained in Nicosia Central Prisons.
5. The applicant appealed to the Supreme Court against his sentence, but it was dismissed.
6. The applicant applied to the Asylum Service for asylum on 21 April 2005.
7. The Director of the Civil Registry and Migration Department issued detention and deportation orders against the applicant on 10 November 2005.
8. On 14 November 2005, the applicant was released after serving his sentence.
9. The applicant’s asylum application was rejected on 31 January 2006.
10. An appeal lodged by the applicant with the Reviewing Authority for Refugees was dismissed on 6 April 2006.
11. The applicant brought a “recourse” before the Supreme Court challenging the Reviewing Authority’s decision.
12. The applicant complained to the Ombudsman concerning the deportation and detention orders.
13. The applicant’s lawyer complained to the Minister of the Interior of the unlawfulness of the applicant’s continued detention following the expiry of his sentence.
14. The authorities issued deportation orders, which were cancelled and reissued under a different name.
15. On 9 March 2007, the applicant was deported.
16. The applicant was insulted, beaten, and ill-treated during the deportation process.
17. The applicant lodged a complaint with the Ombudsman and the Independent Authority for the Investigation of Allegations and Complaints against the Police concerning his deportation and ill-treatment.

title: CASE OF MILISAVLJEVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Serbian national and journalist named Ljiljana Milisavljević.
- Ms Nataša Kandić is a Serbian human rights activist primarily known for her activities in investigating crimes committed during the armed conflicts in the former Yugoslavia.
- The article in question was written in September 2003 and appeared in Politika, a major Serbian daily newspaper.
- The article was titled "The Hague Investigator" and contained quotes and paraphrases from other sources.
- Ms Kandić brought a private prosecution against the applicant claiming that the article was intended to belittle her in the eyes of the public.
- The court found that the applicant had committed a criminal offence of insult when she stated for Ms Kandić "although she has been called a witch and a prostitute" and gave her a judicial warning.
- The applicant appealed the decision, but it was upheld by the Belgrade District Court.
- In separate proceedings, the applicant was ordered to pay Ms Kandić RSD 33,125 in respect of costs and expenses.
- The applicant was later discharged from Politika, and her conviction appeared to have been the cause thereof.

title: CASE OF ANTOSHKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Antratsit, Ukraine.
- In 1996, the applicant was dismissed from the State Enterprise Coal Mine "Yur-Shor".
- In January 1999, insolvency proceedings were opened concerning the mine.
- On 28 October 1999, the applicant was awarded the equivalent of 1,591 euros (EUR) in salary and allowances' arrears against the coal mine.
- It appears that the bailiffs did not take measures to execute the judgment.
- On 27 December 1999, a prosecutor informed the applicant that the judgment in his favour could not be enforced.
- On 3 April 2001, the Town Court ordered the coal mine to pay the applicant EUR 51 for court expenses.
- On 24 April 2002, the Town Court allowed the applicant's claim for index-linking of the award of 28 October 1999, and he should be paid EUR 912 under this head.
- The applicant sued various domestic authorities for non-pecuniary damages and index-linking of unpaid salary.
- On 21 January 2004, the Town Court found that the awarded sums should be transferred by a local branch of the State Treasury to the coal mine.
- On 21 January 2004, the Town Court obliged the coal mine to index-link the unpaid court awards and to pay the applicant EUR 527.
- On 7 December 2004, the Town Court ordered to index-link the awards of 21 January 2004 and held that the Ministry of Energy should pay the applicant EUR 155 and the coal mine EUR 41 respectively.
- It appears that the judgments of 21 January 2004 and 7 December 2004 and the decision of 21 January 2004 have not been enforced to date.
- On 30 November 2005, the applicant's application was rejected by the Town Court as having no grounds in the domestic law.
- On 8 June 2006, the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic in the final instance rejected his request.

title: CASE OF SADKOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
-All applicants were part of civil proceedings
-First-instance and appeal courts ruled in their favor
-Judgments became binding and enforceable
-Supervisory review courts later quashed the judgments
-Quash due to incorrect application of substantive law or assessment of evidence by lower courts

title: CASE OF ELLIS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1941 and lives in Birkerod, Denmark.
- On 11 April 1995, the applicant formed a limited company, N.R. Group Ltd. (“the company”) together with a Turkish partner, N.K., to provide tourist services in Alanya, Turkey.
- On 19 March 1997, the applicant applied to the Alanya Civil Court of First Instance to cancel N.K.’s management authority. On 2 October 1997, the court ordered the cancellation and on 18 May 1998, it appointed a trustee for the company.
- The applicant's partner N.K. fraudulently transferred the company's assets to a new company.
- On 8 July 1997, the applicant brought two civil cases against N.K. before the Alanya Civil Court of First Instance and sought compensation for his loss incurred due to the fraudulent acts of N.K. The court decided to join the compensation cases and to examine them together.
- On 7 June 2005, the Alanya Civil Court of First Instance accepted the applicant’s compensation claim and granted him the equivalent of 203,000 Deutschmarks (DEM) (103,792 Euros (EUR) at the time) with statutory interest for his loss, to be paid in Euros, and DEM 10,000 (EUR 7,158 at the time) in compensation without interest of 40% (inkar tazminatı), to be paid in Turkish Lira (TRY). The court further ruled that the legal costs and expenses of the proceedings were to be borne by N.K.
- The applicant requested that the judgment be served on him in order to commence enforcement proceedings, but the court rejected the request, stating that it was not possible to provide the judgment unless the charge required by section 28(1) (a) of Law no. 492 (Code of Charges) had been paid.
- The applicant was therefore unable to lodge enforcement proceedings to have the above-mentioned judgment executed.

title: CASE OF A.P., GARÇON AND NICOT v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicants were initially regarded as belonging to the male sex.
- The first applicant had always identified as female despite being assigned male at birth.
- The first applicant underwent a transitional phase and hormone treatment under medical supervision.
- The first applicant underwent irreversible gender reassignment surgery in Thailand.
- The first applicant submitted medical certificates from various doctors in support of their request to change their civil status to female.
- The Paris tribunal de grande instance ordered a multi-disciplinary expert assessment to establish the applicant's current state.
- The first applicant refused to submit to the expert assessment.
- The Paris Court of Appeal upheld the judgment rejecting the request to indicate gender on birth certificate but allowed the first applicant to change their forenames.

title: CASE OF KARAJANOV v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was a high-ranking official during the communist era.
- The Fact Verification Commission established that the applicant had collaborated with State security bodies, based on two files from the State Archives.
- The applicant provided information to State security bodies about individuals and collaborated with the State security services in a conscious, secret, organised and continuous manner as a secret collaborator.
- The applicant challenged the decision in the Administrative Court, arguing that the Commission’s findings based on one of the files had been wrong as it concerned another person with the same name.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s claim and upheld the Commission’s decision, stating that it had correctly established the facts and applied the relevant law.
- The Higher Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal and found no grounds to depart from the facts established by the Commission and the Administrative Court.
- The Lustration Act regulated the criterion for limiting the exercise of public office, the publication of information on cooperation with State security bodies, and the powers of the Fact Verification Commission.
- Collaboration was defined as conscious, secret, organised and continuous cooperation and activity with the State security services, established by a written agreement.
- The Commission’s decisions were subject to a court appeal within eight days of the day of service.
- Administrative disputes were decided by the Administrative Court (at first instance) and by the Higher Administrative Court (on appeal).

title: CASE OF KHALILOVA AND AYYUBZADE v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicants were members of opposition parties in Azerbaijan.
- They participated in a peaceful protest outside the Baku Assize Court.
- Police officers and plain-clothes people dispersed the demonstration and arrested the applicants.
- Administrative-offence reports for participating in a public assembly not in accordance with the law were issued against both applicants.
- The applicants were not given access to an attorney, nor copies of the reports against them.
- State-funded lawyers were appointed to represent the applicants.
- The hearing before the Nasimi District Court was very brief, and the applicants were not allowed to choose their own lawyers.
- Both applicants were convicted and sentenced to administrative detention.
- The applicants appealed their convictions and sentences to the Baku Court of Appeal.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decisions of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF ANEVA AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
1. The first and second applicants are both from Sofia and were born in 1981 and 2002 respectively.
2. The first applicant married A.I. in 2001 and their son, the second applicant, was born in 2002.
3. The first applicant alleged that her husband started abusing her psychologically after the marriage, which grew worse after the child was born.
4. The first applicant filed for divorce in 2004 and received custody of the child in May 2005.
5. A.I. took the child back in January 2005 and has kept him ever since, despite court orders.
6. The courts upheld the first applicant's custody of the child and limited A.I.'s contact rights.
7. Enforcement proceedings were initiated in 2005, but A.I. did not cooperate with the bailiff and was fined.
8. A.I. was dismissed from the police for his conduct in challenging the bailiff.
9. The change of custody proceedings brought by A.I. were terminated in June 2013 after he withdrew his application.
10. The third applicant gave birth to a child, P.P., in July 2005 while living with Kh.P.
11. The third applicant obtained custody of the child in July 2010 but Kh.P. refused to hand over the child in September 2011.
12. Various attempts were made to enforce the court order, but they failed due to Kh.P.'s non-cooperation.
13. The child suffered from parental alienation syndrome and rejected the third applicant due to manipulation by Kh.P.

title: CASE OF BASMENKOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1937 and lives in Sofia.
- The applicant’s husband owned part of a house and a yard in Sofia.
- The property was expropriated in 1981, to construct a metro station.
- The applicant’s husband was to be compensated with a three-room flat in a building which the municipality planned to construct.
- In 1989, the applicant and her husband were moved out of the expropriated property and settled in a two-room municipally-owned flat.
- By a supplementary decision of 1 September 1989, the future flat was determined to measure 94 square meters.
- In 1993, the applicant’s husband passed away, after which the applicant became the owner of the future flat allocated in compensation to him.
- The construction of the building in which the flat was to be located did not commence.
- In 2001, the applicant claimed wrongful failure on the part of the Sofia municipality to build and provide her with the flat due to her from January 1993 to September 2001.
- In 2008, the Supreme Court of Cassation awarded the applicant BGN 10,000 in non-pecuniary damage and BGN 44,320 for loss of profit.
- In 2009, the applicant brought a new tort action against the Sofia municipality covering the period after October 2001.
- In 2013, the Sofia municipality informed the applicant that the construction of the building where the flat due to her was to be located was to start in the near future.

title: CASE OF MEHTIYEV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Demonstrations were planned in Baku on four different dates in 2013.
- Organisers did not give proper prior notice to the relevant authority.
- Demonstrations were intended to be peaceful and were conducted in a peaceful manner.
- All applicants were arrested during dispersal operations and were taken to various police stations.
- Applicants were issued with administrative offense reports.
- Applicants were not given access to a lawyer after their arrest or while in police custody.
- Applicants were not given an opportunity to appoint lawyers of their own choosing.
- Most of the applicants were taken to trial courts directly from the police stations.
- Court hearing in each case was very brief.
- Members of the public were not allowed in the courtroom.
- State-funded lawyers were asked to assist some of them.
- According to most of the applicants, they were not given an opportunity to appoint lawyers of their own choosing.
- Applicants were convicted under Article 298.2 of the CAO and sentenced to a period of administrative detention or a fine.
- Applicants lodged appeals with the Baku Court of Appeal.
- On various dates the Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the applicants’ appeals and upheld the decisions of the first-instance courts.

title: CASE OF BAYRAMOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant attended two demonstrations in Baku organized by the opposition without prior notice to the relevant authority. 
- The applicant maintains that the demonstrations were peaceful, but the police started to disperse the gatherings soon after they began.
- The applicant was arrested in both cases and charged with violating Article 298.2 of the Code of Administrative Offenses.
- The applicant was never given access to a lawyer after his arrest or while in police custody.
- The hearings before the courts were brief, and members of the public were not allowed to attend.

title: CASE OF MIKHAYLOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with the list of applicants and their relevant details is appended to the document.
- The applicants claim they were denied a chance to appear in person before the court in a civil proceeding.

title: CASE OF ORLOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and relevant details is included in the document.
- The applicants complained about being denied the opportunity to appear in person before the court.
- The denied opportunity was related to civil proceedings in which the applicants were parties.

title: CASE OF FROLOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A list of applicants is provided with relevant details
- Applicants complain about being denied the opportunity to appear in person before the court in civil proceedings

title: CASE OF BODNAR AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details in an appendix.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings and the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- In two of the applications, there were other complaints raised under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF POBEREZHYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants provided in a table.
- The applicants' relevant details are also included in the table.
- The applicants claimed they were denied a chance to appear before the court in civil proceedings.

title: CASE OF DUDNIKOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants with relevant details provided in appended table
- Applicants complained of excessive length of civil proceedings
- Applicants complained of the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law 
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF DUDNICHENKO AND WAES v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The list of applicants and relevant details are provided in a table
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention under Article 5 § 3 of the Convention
- The applicants further complained under Article 5 § 4 of the Convention
- Applicant in application no. 49507/10 argued that appeals against detention orders were examined without the presence of him and his counsel
- Applicant in application no. 76349/12 submitted that his appeal against a detention order was not examined speedily.

title: CASE OF NOSENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details in an appended table.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.

title: CASE OF BIRYUKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants provided in the appended table.
- Applicants were denied the opportunity to appear in person before the court.

title: CASE OF MALCHENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document contains a table with a list of applicants and their relevant details.
- The applicants alleged inadequate conditions of their detention.
- The applicants claimed that there was no effective remedy in domestic law.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF GÁBOR NAGY v. HUNGARY (No. 2)
facts:
- On 22 March 2013, an armed home invasion took place in Budapest by three men wearing balaclavas.
- The police stopped a car close to the crime scene and seized some of the valuables taken in the robbery along with the applicant's identity card and mobile phone.
- K.I., the driver of the car, was apprehended while the other passenger fled.
- In his testimony, K.I. said that the person who had fled was not the applicant.
- Despite this, on 25 March 2013, the police issued a warrant for the applicant's arrest.
- They turned themselves in on 3 April 2013 and were arrested on suspicion of armed robbery.
- The court found pre-trial detention was necessary because the applicant had fled from the police and then turned themselves in, but only to avoid criminal liability.
- On 15 April 2013, the Budapest High Court dismissed an appeal brought by the applicant, without hearing them in person.
- The applicant’s detention was extended several times, citing risks of absconding, reoffending, and interfering with the investigation.
- The court repeatedly referred to a “professional” nature of the crime as evidence of the risk of reoffending.
- The applicant appealed but their appeal was dismissed on 10 September 2014.
- On 13 November 2014, a third suspect was apprehended.

title: CASE OF MAŽUKNA v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and worked as a welder for the company N.
- The applicant, along with two other workers, fell from scaffolding while working at a construction site in the city of Klaipėda on 17 April 2007.
- The applicant sustained injuries, including a large cut on his head, multiple fractures of his facial bones, and a contusion on the chest.
- The State Labour Inspectorate examined the site of the accident and concluded that the accident had been caused by “the inappropriate organization of dangerous work”.
- The applicant asked the Klaipėda city prosecutor’s office to open a pre-trial investigation into the accident, which was opened on 10 September 2007.
- The prosecutor initially concluded that the accident had been caused by the applicant’s own recklessness, but this decision was later overturned by the Klaipėda District Court.

title: CASE OF BOROVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
• The applicants are complaining about lengthy criminal and civil proceedings.

• All applicants received rulings that their right to a hearing within a reasonable time was violated by the Constitutional Court.

• The Constitutional Court also granted them various sums of money as compensation for non-pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF JEANNEE v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former lawyer who renounced his right to practice law due to his gambling addiction, which led to criminal offenses.
- The applicant applied for an invalidity pension due to his mental illness, stating that he was no longer capable of practicing law.
- The Committee of the Vienna Bar Association partly rejected and partly dismissed the applicant's application, which led to objections and complaints to the Administrative Court.
- The process of decision-making by the Committee and the Plenary took a significant amount of time and involved the submission of several expert reports.
- The Plenary ultimately dismissed the applicant's objection and confirmed that he was not entitled to an invalidity pension.
- The applicant filed a complaint to the Administrative Court about the Plenary’s decision, which was dismissed as unfounded.

title: CASE OF BERGER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Mondsee.
- The Vienna public prosecutor’s office requested the Vienna Regional Criminal Court to institute criminal proceedings against the applicant on 3 October 2000, seeking to obtain information about the outcome of criminal proceedings against him in the United States.
- On 27 November 2000, the applicant was convicted of bond fraud in the United States but subsequently absconded, and an arrest warrant was issued against him.
- The applicant was arrested in Austria on 6 July 2007 and placed in pre-trial detention.
- The applicant made several unsuccessful attempts to be released from pre-trial detention and to be granted access to his case-file.
- The case file was transferred to the prosecutor’s office for further investigation on 27 December 2007.
- On 24 April 2009, the applicant was released from pre-trial detention.
- On 8 September 2010, the applicant filed an application for the discontinuation of the criminal proceedings against him, which was dismissed.
- On 9 October 2016, the prosecutor’s office submitted an indictment against the applicant on suspicion of embezzlement and aggravated fraud on a commercial basis.
- As of 15 November 2016, the criminal proceedings against the applicant were still pending at first instance.

title: CASE OF STREKALEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Moscow.
- The flat at 103-29 Dmitrovskoye Shosse, Moscow, had been owned by the City of Moscow before its privatisation.
- N. and her son B. had resided in the flat as tenants since 1968 under the social housing agreement with the City. N. died in 1993 and B. in 1994.
- On 11 June 2002, a municipal authority authorised an exchange of flats between N. and K. On 21 June 2002, all the documents necessary for K. to move into N.’s flat were issued.
- On 16 October 2002, the title to the flat was transferred to K. under the privatisation scheme. On 11 November 2002, K.’s title was registered to the flat.
- On 18 November 2002, K. sold the flat to the applicant. On 19 November 2002, the applicant’s title was registered to the flat, and he moved in with his family.
- On 14 August 2003, a criminal investigation into the fraudulent acquisition of the flat was opened by the police.
- On 17 April 2006, the court invalidated the exchange of flats between N. and K. and reinstated the City’s title to the flat, ordering the applicant’s eviction.
- On 24 October 2006, the Moscow City Court upheld the judgment on appeal.
- On an unspecified date, the applicant reintroduced his claim against the City of Moscow for damages. On 12 May 2008, the claim was dismissed, and on 18 September 2008, the Moscow City Court upheld the judgment on appeal.
- On 5 February 2007, the bailiff instituted enforcement proceedings. On 1 June 2007, the Timiryazevskiy District Court of Moscow suspended for six months the enforcement of the part of the judgment concerning the applicant’s eviction. The applicant continued to reside in the flat.
- On 5 March 2012, the Registration Committee registered the City’s title to the flat.
- On 29 May 2012, the District Court issued a duplicate of the writ of enforcement.
- On 31 August 2012, the bailiff opened enforcement proceedings in respect of the judgment of 17 April 2006.
- On 28 December 2013, the applicant rented another flat. On 28 March

title: CASE OF MORGUNOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of committing robberies in 2006
- On 18 September 2006, the applicant was taken to the UBOP building and allegedly beaten and ill-treated
- Medical examination revealed injuries on the applicant's forehead, shin, buttocks, and lumbar region
- The applicant complained of physical symptoms including headache, nausea, and pain on the left side of his body when breathing after the alleged ill-treatment
- The applicant's lawyer requested a forensic medical examination, which was ordered on 23 September 2006
- The investigator found no evidence of ill-treatment after a pre-investigation inquiry and refused to institute criminal proceedings
- The district deputy prosecutor ordered a new inquiry after annulling the investigator's decision
- Forensic medical experts found that the injuries could have been caused by the applicant himself or by a fall
- The applicant's complaint was dismissed by the Promyshlennyy District Court and the Orenburg Regional Court
- The applicant was convicted of robbery and sentenced to twelve years and four months' imprisonment
- An appeal against the investigator's decision was also dismissed by the deputy head of the investigation department of the Orenburg town prosecutor's office.

title: CASE OF COSTACHE AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants brought an action to recover property rights over a 1,761 sq.m land in Bucharest.
- The Bucharest County Court allowed the applicants' action on the merits on April 9, 1998, and the decision became final as it was not appealed by the parties.
- The Mayor of Bucharest brought extraordinary appeal proceedings against the applicants on January 27, 1999, based on a report stating that the land was occupied by a marketplace.
- On September 24, 1999, the Bucharest County Court allowed the Mayor of Bucharest's action on the ground that the document was not in the file during the first set of proceedings.
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal allowed the applicants' appeal on January 29, 2002, stating that the submitted document did not comply with the requirements and that the legal situation of the land should have been raised by the authorities during the first set of proceedings.
- The Supreme Court overturned the decision of the Bucharest Court of Appeal in a final decision on January 14, 2003, stating that the concept of "document" had to be interpreted restrictively and the provisions of Article 322 § 5 of the RCCP had to be interpreted as referring to documents used by one party to prove facts generally not known by the court.
- The applicants filed a request for the restitutio in natura of the land on February 12, 2002, pursuant to Law no. 10/2001, which was still pending in 2010 pending further documentation.

title: CASE OF HUSEYNOVA v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant's husband was a prominent independent journalist in Azerbaijan who wrote critically about the government and opposition.
- The journalist had faced multiple civil and criminal proceedings and had received regular threats due to his work.
- The journalist was shot dead outside his apartment building.
- The murder received widespread condemnation and criminal proceedings were instituted.
- A pistol with a silencer and a knitted hat were found near the crime scene.
- Two suspects, both Georgian nationals, were identified and arrest warrants were issued.
- The Georgian authorities refused to extradite the suspects but agreed to cooperate with criminal proceedings against them.
- Various forensic examinations were carried out, including by the FBI.
- The investigating authorities conducted various investigative actions and questioned various witnesses and family members of the suspects.
- The applicant was granted victim status and sought information about the progress of the investigation.

title: CASE OF TAGAYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
A. General information
- Provides an overview of the case

B. The events of 1 to 4 September 2004
- Covers the timeline of events that occured during the hostage-taking
- Situation prior to the hostage-taking on 1 September 2004
- Events of 1 to 2 September 2004
- Storming and rescue operation
- Events of 4 September 2004, identification of bodies and burials
- Assumes responsibility for the terrorist act

C. Criminal investigations
- Covers the different criminal investigations related to the case
- Criminal investigation no. 20/849
- Criminal investigation in respect of Mr Nurpashi Kulayev
- Criminal proceedings against police officers

D. Civil proceedings brought by the victims
- Covers the different civil proceedings brought by the victims
- First group of claimants
- Second group of claimants

E. Parliamentary inquiries
- Covers the different parliamentary inquiries conducted on the case
- Report prepared by the North Ossetian Parliament
- The Federal Assembly report

F. Other relevant developments
- Covers other important developments related to the case
- Humanitarian relief
- Other important public and media reactions
- Victims’ organisations

G. Expert reports submitted by the applicants after the admissibility decision
- Covers the different expert reports submitted by the applicants
- Expert report on counter-terrorism
- Expert report on medical (forensic) aspects of the operation

title: CASE OF CELA AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- Applicants were detained in Korydallos Prison, Athens.
- Applicants were detained in various cells measuring 9 sq. m, which accommodated 3-4 prisoners.
- Prisoners had limited access to recreational or educational activities.
- Poor conditions, including insufficient heating and hot water, dirty cells, pests, and inadequate medical care.
- Inmates were confined to their cells for sixteen hours per day.
- The prison was understaffed and unable to secure the prisoners’ safety.
- According to the Government, cells measured 9.60 sq. m and had sufficient amenities.
- Detainees had access to the prison’s infirmary, and social services took care of detainees’ needs.
- Prisoners were able to spend 4-5 hours in the prison yard every day, practising sports.

title: CASE OF IATROPOULOS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
- Applicants were detained in the Transfers Department of Thessaloniki
- Cells designed for 9 detainees accommodated 12 to 22 detainees
- Insufficient light, ventilation, heating, hot water, soap, and blankets
- Detainees confined to cells with no recreational activities or access to TV or radio
- Inadequate meals costing 5.87 EUR per day
- Complaints lodged with public prosecutor on 22 February 2013 with no reply
- Government claimed applicants had made general complaints without specific references
- Government claimed cells had in-cell sanitary facilities, sufficient light, and ventilation
- Cells accommodated 5 to 15 detainees, and space available for each inmate was never less than 4 sq. m
- Facilities cleaned daily by external contractor
- Food of good quality and quantity provided by private catering company
- Applicants provided no evidence of not receiving needed medical treatment
- Second applicant transferred to hospital for medical check-up on 29 December 2013 according to police station records.

title: CASE OF ZOURNATZIDIS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicants were detained in Ioannina Prison.
- Multiple applicants were released at various times.
- Prison allegedly held 235 prisoners, but only designed for 85.
- Lack of tables, chairs, and recreational or educational activities.
- Insufficient separation between prisoners serving sentences and those in pre-trial detention.
- Lack of adequate medical care.
- Inmates had to wash clothes and underwear in toilet facilities.
- Complaints were filed by prisoners but received no reply.
- The government claims repairs and improvements were made to the prison, including cultural events, a fully equipped gym, and daily disinfection and cleaning.
- Detainees had access to medical care, including doctors and nurses, and were transferred to hospitals in emergencies.

title: CASE OF REZMIVEȘ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years from 1966 to 1976
- Applicants were detained in different prisons such as Timişoara, Pelendava, Baia Mare, Focşani, Gherla, Aiud, Oradea, Craiova, Târgu-Jiu, Rahova, Tulcea, Iași and Vaslui.
- The first applicant complained about the conditions of detention in Gherla, Aiud and Oradea Prisons including overcrowding, lack of natural light, short duration of daily exercise and lack of recreational activities.
- The second applicant was placed in pre-trial detention in Craiova Prison and later transferred to Târgu-Jiu and Pelendava Prisons.
- The third applicant complained about the conditions of detention in Rahova Prison, including overcrowding, lack of ventilation in cells, mould on the walls, poor-quality food and the presence of bedbugs.
- The fourth applicant was held in the Baia Mare police detention facility and Gherla Prison, where he complained of poor hygiene conditions, lack of necessary facilities, overcrowding, lack of ventilation and the presence of pests.

title: CASE OF VASKRSIĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant and his family lived in a house in Litija which was sold in impugned enforcement proceedings
- The applicant was the subject of enforcement claims brought by three different creditors seeking to enforce their own claim against him.
- Company P. had initially requested that enforcement be carried out by seizing the applicant’s house, its claim was subsequently paid from the applicant’s bank account.
- Company J. failed to secure the payment of its claim by the sale of movable property, requested that enforcement action be taken against the applicant’s house.
- The house was ultimately sold at public auction for the purposes of enforcing company J.’s claim.
- Taxes and the outstanding mortgage on the house were also paid from the proceeds. 
- On 18 December 2007, company J. sent the applicant a water bill in the amount of 124 euros (EUR), which was due to be paid on 5 January 2008.
- Company J. instituted enforcement proceedings against him on 28 May 2009 seeking for the principal amount of EUR 124 plus default interest
- On 2 June 2009, the Ljubljana Local Court ordered the seizure of applicant's movable property as requested by company J. after the applicant did not object to it.
- On 2 March 2010, company P. instituted enforcement proceedings seeking payment of EUR 1,576 together with interest accrued as from 10 July 2009 until payment.
- On 15 June 2010 company J. applied to the Litija Local Court for an attachment order in respect of the applicant’s immovable property, namely his house.
- On 17 June 2010, the Litija Local Court granted company J.’s application and issued a decision allowing enforcement to be carried out by means of the sale of the applicant’s house.
- At the second public auction held on 18 November 2010 the house was sold to M.L. for EUR 70,000, namely 50% of its estimated market value.
- Following the applicant’s repayment of the debt on 24 November 2010, company J. on the same day applied to the court for discontinuation of the enforcement proceedings.
- On 12 January 2011, following the full payment of the sale price by M.L., the Litija Local Court transferred the property sold at public auction to him and ordered that his name be entered as the owner in the Land Register.

title: CASE OF SOLOVEY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982.
- The applicant was arrested in Moscow on 10 September 2010.
- The arrest was made on an extradition request from Belarus authorities.
- The Dorogomilovskiy District Court of Moscow ordered his detention the following day.
- The detention was extended by judicial orders on several occasions.
- The applicant lodged his statements of appeal against these detention orders with the Moscow City Court.
- The appeal was upheld on 11 April and 18 July 2011, respectively.

title: CASE OF IGNJATOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lived in Donji Milanovac.
- He was employed by Ðerdap, a company in Kladovo.
- The applicant was reassigned to a lower post on 28 December 1998 and was subsequently dismissed on 20 January 2000.
- The applicant filed a civil claim against the debtor company on 18 February 1999 and another claim seeking reinstatement to a suitable position, salary payments, and social benefits on 26 April 2000.
- On 19 June 2003 the Municipal Court ruled in favour of the applicant and ordered the debtor company to reinstate the applicant to a suitable position and to pay him specified amounts.
- On 16 February 2004, 9 March 2004, 18 and 19 October 2004, respectively, the Municipal Court accepted the enforcement of the said judgment and ordered the debtor to pay the applicant the enforcement costs.
- The National Bank of Serbia was provided with the enforcement orders on 14 April 2004, 20 July 2004 and 11 November 2004, respectively.
- None of the enforcement orders have been enforced to date.
- The Central Bank informed the Zaječar Commercial Court of the suspension of the debtor company’s accounts on 8 April 2010 for three years.
- The Commercial Court opened preliminary insolvency proceedings against the debtor company on 13 April 2010.
- The Commercial Court opened and closed the insolvency proceedings against the debtor company on 30 June 2010, and that decision became final on 10 August 2010.
- The debtor company was ultimately struck from the relevant public register on 31 August 2010.
- The debtor company had been a socially owned company, and in 1991 it was transformed into a limited company that remained mainly socially owned until it was struck off the register.

title: CASE OF ISAYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were involved in civil proceedings.
- The first-instance and appeals courts ruled in their favor, and their judgments were binding.
- The supervisory review courts quashed the judgments.
- The reason for quashing the judgments was the incorrect application of substantive law or incorrect evidence assessment by the lower courts.

title: CASE OF OOO IZDATELSKIY TSENTR KVARTIRNYY RYAD v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant company was the publisher of a newspaper called Kvartirnyy Ryad
- The newspaper published an article by G. about a conflict situation in a commonhold association called Bluebird
- G. suggested that T., the head of the commonhold association, had been behind the misuse of common areas
- T. lodged a defamation claim against the applicant company and G.
- District Court partially allowed the claim and ordered the applicant company to retract a particular statement from the article and pay non-pecuniary damages
- Applicant company and G. appealed to the Moscow City Court but the appeal was upheld
- Enforcement proceedings were terminated as the judgment had been enforced in full.

title: CASE OF SOMMER v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant is a criminal defense lawyer who defended a client in criminal proceedings.
- The client's fiancée transferred the applicant's legal fees of €1,500 from her private bank account to the applicant's professional account.
- In 2010 and 2011, the Bochum public prosecution office investigated several individuals suspected of committing fraud on a commercial basis.
- Bank accounts of several people, including the applicant's client and the client's fiancée, were inspected.
- The public prosecutor requested a list of all the transactions concerning the applicant's bank account from the bank.
- The bank complied with the request and submitted the information to the public prosecution office.
- The information received was analyzed by the police and the public prosecutor, and a list of 53 relevant transactions was included in the investigation file as evidence.
- The applicant was granted access to the investigation file in January 2012 and learned about the investigative measures concerning his bank account.
- The applicant asked the Chief Public Prosecutor to hand over all the data received from the bank and destroy all related data at the public prosecution office.
- The Bochum Chief Public Prosecutor refused the applicant's request and cited Article 161 of the CCP as a legal basis for the information requests.
- The file was transferred to the Bochum Regional Court, where the applicant asked for the return of the data.
- The Regional Court refused the applicant's application but decided to separate the documents in question from the general court file to safeguard the client-lawyer privilege.
- The applicant appealed against the decision of the Regional Court.
- On 13 September 2012, the Hamm Court of Appeal confirmed the decision of the Regional Court.
- On 19 September 2013, the Federal Constitutional Court refused to admit the applicant's constitutional complaint.

title: CASE OF ASATRYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The case involves the applicant's trial and conviction for attempted murder of M.G.
- M.G.'s car exploded on December 29, 2001, but he survived without major injuries.
- The District Prosecutor's Office started an investigation into the matter on the same day.
- M.G. accused the applicant's ex-husband, A.G., of being the possible offender due to disagreements over business-related issues.
- A.G. denied the offense and said he was at home with his son V.G. the night before the incident.
- V.G. was arrested but charges were dropped since his involvement was not established.
- Y.W., a friend of the family, was later arrested for M.G.'s attempted murder and stated he acted on the applicant's orders.
- The applicant was arrested and charged with instigation of attempted murder and property damage.
- At the trial, Y.W. retracted his pre-trial statements, and the applicant denied involvement.
- The District Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced her to nine years' imprisonment.
- The Criminal Court of Appeal upheld the conviction and sentence, citing witness statements of the applicant's annoyance at M.G.'s actions.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law and challenged the use of witness statements that were not examined or read out.
- The Court of Cassation declared the appeal inadmissible for lack of merit, but the applicant later challenged the CCP's provisions.
- The Constitutional Court found the provisions incompatible with the Constitution.
- The applicant requested a re-examination of her appeal, but it was again declared inadmissible for lack of merit by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF ZHERDEV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born on May 12, 1988, and was detained in Toretsk at the time of his communication with the Court.
- Mrs D., a night security guard at a shop in Toretsk, was found dead and partially undressed with injuries on her head and genitals. A grinder tool had also gone missing.
- Two police officers arrived at the applicant’s home and took him and his father to the police station for questioning.
- The applicant was separated from his father and allegedly beaten by police officers who urged him to plead guilty to the murder and theft.
- The police obtained a statement from the applicant’s father and grandfather about the grinder found in their house.
- The police searched the place where the applicant’s father had hidden the grinder and seized it.
- The applicant signed a document explaining his rights as a suspect and was questioned in the presence of his lawyer.
- The applicant was examined by a forensic medical expert who found several light injuries inflicted two to seven days before the examination.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder and most of his clothes were seized for forensic examination.
- The applicant was held in a cell with two adult detainees for three days and was urged to cooperate with the investigation.
- The applicant made a handwritten statement of surrender acknowledging his guilt for murder in “self-defence.”
- The applicant was charged with murder without aggravating circumstances and theft, and his procedural status changed from “suspect” to “accused.”
- The Toretsk Court convicted the applicant of murder without aggravating circumstances and theft and sentenced him to seven and a half years’ imprisonment.
- The Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal quashed the judgment and returned the case for further investigation. The charges against the applicant were reclassified.
- The applicant refused to answer any questions and denied involvement in the crimes he had been charged with.
- The applicant was released from custody, and his case was submitted for retrial.

title: CASE OF SCHMIDT v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1938 and lived in Hamburg.
- The applicant married A.S. on 19 March 1970 and the couple lived together in Hamburg starting in 1980.
- The couple moved to Riga in 1992, where they acquired an apartment, but the applicant maintained her place of residence in Hamburg.
- On 15 December 2000, the applicant and A.S. signed an agreement for the regulation of their separated life, but there is no information on the content of that document.
- A.S. brought divorce proceedings against the applicant on 5 December 2003 before the Riga City Ziemeļu District Court.
- The applicant was summoned to the hearing by notice in the Official Gazette on 27 January 2004 and again on 3 March 2004.
- The divorce was granted on 6 April 2004 after A.S. and A.A. (who later became A.S.'s spouse) offered testimonies that the applicant had not been seen since 2000.
- The applicant learned about the judgment that dissolved her marriage when she came to Riga for A.S.'s funeral.
- The Justice Authority of the Free and Hanseatic City of Hamburg delivered a declaratory decision on 27 July 2004 stating that the requirements for legal recognition of the judgment of the Riga City Ziemeļu District Court had not been met, as the divorced spouse had not been afforded an opportunity to present her case in the divorce proceedings.
- The President of the Supreme Court submitted an application for supervisory review on 8 November 2004 asking for the case to be adjudicated anew, but the Senate of the Supreme Court dismissed the application on 16 March 2005.
- The parties differ on whether A.S. was aware of the applicant's place of residence and on whether the applicant was aware of the divorce proceedings. 
- On 3 November 2005, the applicant brought civil proceedings against A.A. claiming one half of the undivided share of the property that A.S. had acquired during their marriage, and on 30 November 2006, the Riga Regional Court granted her claim in full. A.A. appealed against this judgment.

title: CASE OF VASILICIUC v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
1. The applicant left Moldova in 1997 to work in Greece due to economic difficulties in Moldova.
2. In 2008, the applicant was carrying twenty-nine pieces of jewelry without declaration of their value, leading to seizure by customs officers.
3. The applicant was allowed to leave for Greece, but criminal proceedings were initiated against her for attempted smuggling.
4. The applicant failed to appear before the investigating authorities, leading to a detention order being issued against her.
5. The applicant's habeas corpus application was rejected, and an international arrest warrant was issued against her by Moldova.
6. The applicant was arrested in Greece and held for twenty-three days before being released by the Athens Court of Appeal.
7. The court found that there was no agreement between Greece and Moldova to extradite for suspected offenses in connection with taxes, duties, and customs.

title: CASE OF KONDAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence for manslaughter.
- On 17 April 2009, a man named Mr K. was found with severe bodily injuries and died in hospital several days later.
- The applicant was present at the scene of the incident the following day and admitted to physically assaulting Mr K.
- The applicant was subsequently interrogated by police officers and alleged that he was subjected to ill-treatment, including being punched, kicked, and given electric shocks.
- The applicant was arrested and his injuries were examined by a doctor, who recorded haematomas, swelling, and redness on various parts of his body.
- Despite the applicant's allegations, multiple refusals were issued to initiate criminal proceedings against the police officers accused of ill-treatment.
- The applicant was convicted of manslaughter and his confession served as a mitigating factor.
- The most recent decision by an investigator denied any ill-treatment had occurred and stated that the applicant's injuries could have resulted from falling down a flight of stairs while intoxicated.

title: CASE OF KLIMENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Moscow. 
- Flat at 137A-9-267 Samarkandskiy Boulevard, Moscow had been owned by the City of Moscow. 
- G. was a tenant under the social housing agreement with the City, but he died on 21 February 2007. 
- G.’s daughter, Get., submitted a forged copy of a court’s decision recognizing her as G.’s heir and asked to confirm her title to the flat at 137A-9-267 Samarkandskiy Boulevard. 
- Get. sold the flat to N. on 17 April 2008. 
- N. sold the flat to the applicant on 28 July 2008. 
- On 15 May 2009, the police opened a criminal investigation into the fraudulent acquisition of the flat by Get. 
- The Housing Department brought a civil claim on an unspecified date. 
- On June 19, 2009, The Kuzminskiy District Court of Moscow granted the Housing Department's claims, and the applicant's title to the flat was annulled, and the ownership of the flat was transferred to the City of Moscow. 
- The court also ordered the applicant's eviction, and the applicant appealed. 
- On 29 September 2009, the Moscow City Court upheld the judgment of 19 June 2009 on appeal. 
- On 13 December 2011, the applicant was evicted from the flat. 
- According to the Government, on 16 July 2012, the Housing Department assigned the flat as social housing to a family of four. 
- On 25 April 2014, the ownership of the flat was transferred to them under the privatization scheme. 
- On June 19, 2009, the District Court granted the applicant's claims against N. and awarded him 990,000 Russian roubles in damages. 
- On 12 October 2011, the bailiff opened enforcement proceedings. 
- On 15 March 2006, the bailiff discontinued enforcement proceedings as it was impossible to establish N.'s whereabouts or to obtain information about his assets. 
- According to the Government, the enforcement proceedings are still pending. The judgment in the applicant's favor has not been yet enforced.

title: CASE OF RUPA AND ŢOMPI v. ROMANIA
facts:
- First applicant born in 1992 and currently serving a prison sentence in Aiud Prison, second applicant is his mother and lives in Aiud.
- First applicant arrested in 2008 at the age of 15 on suspicion of multiple thefts, along with several other accused.
- Alba-Iulia District Court granted prosecutor's application for pre-trial detention.
- First applicant's detention continuously extended by interlocutory judgments of the District Court, despite appeals on points of law claiming detention of a minor should be a preventive measure of last resort.
- First applicant's request for pre-trial detention to be replaced with alternative measures denied.
- First applicant convicted of theft and sentenced to five years' imprisonment by the District Court.

title: CASE OF SITNIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant, who was 19 years old at the time, and B. were taken in a police patrol car on 15 August 2007 to the police station for an examination of allegations of assault made against them by two individuals, in particular of the sexual assault of a woman.
- The applicant refused to sign self-incriminating statements and was allegedly subjected to ill-treatment, including kicking, hitting, and spraying gas in his eyes, which he described in detail.
- The police record drawn up showed that the applicant signed the “statement of surrender and confession” at 2.35 a.m. on 16 August 2007.
- Forensic medical examinations found physical injuries sustained by the applicant from the alleged ill-treatment.
- Several complaints and investigations followed, including refusals to open a criminal case against the police officers and investigator N., which were challenged and eventually overruled. The applicant was found guilty of sexual assault and sentenced to four years and three months’ imprisonment. The appeals against the conviction were also unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF OLISOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years and lived in different regions of Russia.
- One of the applicants was accused of planning a murder and was arrested by the police.
- The applicant alleges that he was subjected to ill-treatment during his arrest, including being handcuffed, punched, suffocated, and tied up in a painful position.
- The applicant was placed in a cell after the interrogation and later signed a document in which he gave statements about the incident.
- The applicant complained about his ill-treatment and was diagnosed with fractures and bruises in his body.
- The investigating authority initially refused to initiate criminal proceedings against the police officers accused of ill-treating the applicant, but the decision was later annulled.
- The applicant was eventually convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to imprisonment.
- Later, the applicant was searched at his home for evidence of involvement in extremist organizations, and he was allegedly ill-treated by police officers.
- The police officers beat him up, tied him up with a rope, suffocated him, and punched him in the face.
- The applicant was then formally arrested and questioned as a suspect.
- The applicant was later detained on remand and transferred to a pre-trial detention facility.
- The injuries he suffered were documented by medical professionals, and the applicant lodged a complaint about ill-treatment with the investigative authorities.

title: CASE OF STOWARZYSZENIE WIETNAMCZYKÓW W POLSCE 'SOLIDARNOŚĆ I PRZYJAŹŃ' v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant association represents Vietnamese entrepreneurs who rent retail outlets in a shopping centre that raised rents by 300%.
- The applicant association intended to hold a peaceful demonstration to protest against the business practices of company X, which runs the shopping centre.
- The demonstration was to take place at Nadrzeczna Street in Wólka Kosowska.
- The mayor of Lesznowola commune banned the demonstration on the grounds that it might entail a danger to life or limb, or a major danger to property.
- The applicant association appealed against the decision, but the demonstration planned for 19 May 2008 did not take place.
- The governor overruled the impugned decision and discontinued the proceedings as devoid of purpose.
- The applicant association informed the mayor of Lesznowola about a demonstration planned for 2 October 2008, which was also banned by the mayor.
- The governor overruled the mayor's decision, and the demonstration planned for 2 October 2008 took place.
- The applicant association lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court, which was refused, and the appeal was dismissed as lodged out of time.

title: CASE OF SOKOLOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Shakhty, the Rostov Region.
- On 29 March 2005, the military court ordered certain monetary compensation and allowance for the applicant, which came into force on 15 April 2005.
- The judgment was enforced only in part, with some payments due to the applicant remaining outstanding.
- The applicant requested a duplicate enforcement document after the original was not returned to him, but his application was rejected.
- The applicant applied for an additional decision to be made in his civil case against the military unit in 2005, 2006, and 2008, but all of his claims were rejected.

title: CASE OF LISOVSKIJ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Applicant arrested on 15 December 2009 on suspicion of participating in a criminal organization armed with firearms and possessing and distributing large amounts of narcotic and psychotropic substances.
- Vilnius City First District Court authorized the applicant’s detention on remand for three months on 16 December 2009.
- Applicant’s appeal against the decision was dismissed by the Vilnius Regional Court on 12 January 2010.
- Detention was extended six times and appealed each time, but the courts upheld the decision.
- The Court of Appeal noted that the case was complex and of a large scale, with multiple defendants and hundreds of volumes of evidence.

title: CASE OF MENSHIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant sued a company for salary arrears.
- The applicant was awarded the owed salary by two court judgments, but neither has been enforced.
- The company was set up by the local administration to provide heating supply and housing maintenance services.
- The local administration withdrew several of the company's assets in 2006, and the company was declared insolvent and later liquidated in 2009.
- The company sued the owner in subsidiary liability proceedings, but the court dismissed the action. 
- The applicant brought subsidiary liability proceedings against the owner, but the court dismissed the claim as unfounded.

title: CASE OF JURICA v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant underwent several operations in a public health-care institution for a middle-ear dysfunction between 1987 and 1989.
- Following surgery in October 1989, the applicant's condition deteriorated resulting in paralysis of the left side of her face.
- The applicant took early retirement on grounds of disability.
- In January 1998, the applicant lodged a civil action against the hospital and the relevant insurance company with the Zagreb Municipal Civil Court, claiming damages for alleged medical malpractice.
- Expert reports were commissioned to investigate the alleged medical malpractice.
- The case went through multiple hearings and commissions of expert reports, with experts finding no indications of medical negligence.
- The applicant challenged the findings multiple times and even asked for experts from another European Union State, but her requests were dismissed.
- Ultimately, the Zagreb Municipal Civil Court dismissed the applicant's civil action on the grounds that, on the facts of the case, the deterioration of the applicant's health had been a result of complications in the treatment and not of medical malpractice.
- The applicant appealed and lodged an appeal on points of law and a constitutional complaint, but they were all dismissed.
- The Zagreb County Court found a violation of the applicant's right to a trial within a reasonable time and awarded her compensation.

title: CASE OF NIZOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant had his left leg amputated after developing an arterial embolism from a toxic drug.
- He was certified as having a second-degree disability and was provided with a prosthetic leg and cane.
- The applicant developed deep-vein thrombosis and post-phlebitic syndrome of the right leg in 2010.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking in November 2010, and the police took away his prosthetic leg, which was not noted in police records.
- The applicant was remanded in custody and later admitted to a civilian hospital in December 2010 because of acute deep-vein thrombophlebitis.
- The applicant was convicted of drug trafficking in June 2011 and sentenced to imprisonment, but the conviction was quashed in September 2012 after a re-trial.
- The applicant requested prosthetic leg assistance multiple times throughout his captivity, and on 10 December 2013, he was afforded the necessary assistance.
- The applicant was released from detention in November 2014.

title: CASE OF M. AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
facts:
- S.M., the husband and father of the applicants, was found dead with a gunshot wound to his head on the bank of the river Sava in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
- The applicants’ family witnessed the abduction of S.M. by two Croatian soldiers on 23 September 1991 from their house in Novo Selo, Sisak.
- A police inquiry was launched, resulting in the indictment of several individuals connected to the killing of Serbians in the Sisak area, including members of the Croatian Army stationed in Novo Selo.
- Former Croatian soldiers who were stationed in Novo Selo during the war were interviewed by the police, some of whom confirmed that they had heard rumors of civilians being taken and liquidated.
- One of the individuals accused of involvement in S.M.’s killing, N.S., refused to cooperate with the police and maintained that any actions taken during the war were justified.

facts:

title: CASE OF TRAUSTASON AND OTHERS v. ICELAND
facts:
- Three applicants: born in 1953, 1980, and 1980.
- First and second applicants were on the editorial board of the newspaper DV, and the third applicant was a journalist for DV.
- An Icelandic private limited company was declared bankrupt on 30 September 2010. The company was established in 1960 and is one of the leading industrial companies in Iceland in the production of plastic packaging material.
- Liquidator of the bankruptcy hired an accountancy firm to investigate the company’s accounts in October 2010.
- The accountancy firm finalised a report on 31st January 2011 indicating a suspicion of criminal misconduct by the board members. The chairman of the board, A, who was also one of the owners of the company, was an assistant professor at the University of Iceland at the time.
- The liquidator, a holding company, and a bank reported the suspected criminal misconduct to the police.
- DV newspaper published a picture of A on its front page on 14 March 2011 under the headline “Black report on [the company]: Police investigate Assistant Professor”. An article on the matter was printed on pages 2 and 3. The third applicant was identified as its author.
- A lodged defamation proceedings against the applicants and DV before the Reykjavík District Court and requested that the statements published by DV be declared null and void and that the applicants be ordered to pay compensation.
