- By a judgment of 5 March 2012, the District Court found that both disputed statements had been defamatory and ordered the applicants to pay compensation to A.
-	By judgment of 6 December 2012, the Supreme Court confirmed the District Court’s judgment and ordered the applicants to pay additional compensation.
-	On 31 May 2013, the Special Prosecutor notified another company representative that “the investigation” into the complaints against him and A had been closed, and the case had been dismissed.

title: CASE OF SUCHKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The document includes a table with a list of applicants and their details.
• The applicants complained about the poor conditions of their detention.
• Some applicants raised additional complaints under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF DUDNIKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• Applicants list is in the appended table with relevant details. 

• Applicants complained of inadequate detention conditions.

title: CASE OF CHAP LTD v. ARMENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- Chap Ltd is a private Armenian company established in 1999.
- The company founded Gala TV, a regional television channel, in 2005 to broadcast locally.
- The National Television and Radio Commission granted the company a seven-year license for broadcasting in Gyumri and the neighboring area, making it one of four television stations operating in Gyumri.
- The State Revenue Service conducted an inspection of the company's accounts from 29 October to 12 November 2007, concluding that the company underreported its tax liability and had a high tax liability for the years 2005 to 2007.
- On 12 March 2008, the Administrative Court granted the SRS's claim against the applicant company in part and imposed a total charge of AMD 25,116,700 (approximately EUR 50,000) on the company for VAT, profit tax, and development fund tax, referring to the relevant provisions of the Law on Value Added Tax and the Law on Taxes when imposing the surcharges and fines.
- The applicant company's appeal on points of law was declared inadmissible for lack of merit on 18 September 2008 by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF MUSTAFAYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant's son, who suffered from epilepsy, was held in a cell with one other inmate designed for two inmates.
- The son sent numerous complaints regarding his conditions of detention and ill-treatment by prison guards. He alleged that his life was in danger.
- The son was left as the sole occupant of the cell on 2 December 2006 after his cellmate left for a long-term visit to his mother.
- A fire broke out in the cell early in the morning of 3 December 2006.
- The prison guards did not immediately intervene to extinguish the fire, according to the applicant.
- The son was taken to hospital at 11.45 a.m., arrived at 2.45 p.m., and died at 3:30 p.m. on 3 December 2006.
- A criminal inquiry was launched, and various forensic reports were issued.
- The investigating authorities refused to institute criminal proceedings on numerous occasions.
- The applicant appealed against some of these decisions and was successful in remitting the case for fresh examination.
- There were inconsistencies in the statements provided by prison guards and inmates, and the investigating authorities failed to clarify why the son was taken to hospital almost eight hours after the fire had broken out.
- The investigating authorities also failed to examine whether the son's conditions of detention were appropriate and establish necessary security and medical measures for someone with epilepsy.
- There were complaints that relevant documents were destroyed, and despite several requests, they were not provided to the Court.

title: CASE OF FERGEC v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1971 and 1974 and live in Sesvete.
- On 12 December 1996, a member of the Croatian army exploded a grenade in a pizza parlour in Zagreb, resulting in one death and serious injuries to the second applicant.
- The military police conducted an on-site inspection of the crime scene on the same evening and sent a report on the incident on 3 July 1997 to the Zagreb County State Attorney’s Office.
- The applicants filed a civil suit in 1998 seeking damages.
- In 2002, the claim was granted, but it was overturned and dismissed by the Zagreb County Court in 2011.
- The applicants’ constitutional complaint was rejected in 2014.

title: CASE OF POROPAT v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant and his neighbor R.H. had been in conflict for several years and had both instituted legal proceedings against each other.
- R.H. lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant alleging that he had threatened him with a gun.
- The police did not find any evidence to support R.H.'s allegations.
- Despite this, the district prosecutor lodged charges against the applicant and he was eventually found guilty and sentenced to three months' imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed on various grounds, including the court's refusal to hear evidence from a witness who could have testified to the hostile relationship between him and R.H.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal and the Constitutional Court also dismissed a subsequent complaint.
- The applicant later applied to have the criminal proceedings against him reopened based on new evidence, including testimony from a witness who claimed to have witnessed R.H. influencing witnesses against the applicant.

title: CASE OF PADURET v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and lives in Cocieri.
- The Transdniestrian armed conflict of 1991-1992 and the subsequent events are relevant to this case.
- On August 22, 2010, the applicant was transporting merchandise to an agricultural market in Dubasari in the self-proclaimed "Moldovan Republic of Transdniestria." Two persons claiming to be "MRT" customs officers stopped him, seized his van and the merchandise on account of his allegedly failing to register the vehicle.
- On October 7, 2010, the "MRT" customs authority demanded that the applicant pay a fine of some 1,320 euros (EUR) in return for being able to regain his van and merchandise. The applicant paid the fine.
- The applicant complained to Moldovan authorities about the seizure of his van and merchandise. A criminal investigation was initiated by the Dubasari prosecutor's office.
- On July 21, 1992, the Presidents of Russia and Moldova signed a treaty to establish a security zone and a Joint Control Commission (JCC).
- The JCC is made up of representatives from Russia, Moldova, and the "MRT," and any decisions made by it must have the consent of all parties.
- The relevant domestic law and practice of Moldova and other documents were summarised in Mozer v. the Republic of Moldova and Russia.

title: CASE OF SIMEONOVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant is detained in Sofia Prison, born in 1975.
- On 2 July 1999, an armed robbery occurred in a bureau de change in Burgas, where two staff members were killed and the criminals fled with a sum of money.
- Burgas investigation department instigated criminal proceedings against a person or persons unknown for armed robbery and homicide.
- The investigators quickly made a connection with the applicant and a certain A.S.
- The applicant’s detention was ordered on 9 July 1999 for twenty-four hours, with the right to assistance from a lawyer upon his arrest.
- On 3 October 1999, the applicant was arrested in Sofia and detained for the next two days.
- On 5 October 1999, the applicant was transferred to Burgas, and his detention was extended by a prosecutor.
- The applicant claimed to have submitted four requests for contact with a lawyer from 3 to 6 October 1999, but the authorities did not accede to those requests.
- The applicant was questioned by the officers in charge of the investigation from 3 to 6 October, during which he denied committing the murders.
- The criminal case file contains no written trace of any questioning, but it includes a handwritten statement by A.S. regarding the applicant's involvement.
- On 6 October 1999, the investigator appointed an official lawyer for the applicant, and he was formally charged with the double murder and the hold-up in the bureau de change in Burgas.
- A.S. was questioned on 7 October 1999 and affirmed that the applicant had killed both victims.
- On 21 October 1999, the applicant confessed in the presence of his lawyer, admitting his involvement in the hold-up but claiming that the two victims had been killed by A.S.
- There were several types of evidence gathered, such as witness statements, medical, scientific, physical, and documentary evidence.
- The Regional Court considered the criminal case between 25 July 2000 and 14 June 2001, where the applicant was found guilty of armed robbery, resulting in the murder of two persons.
- On 6 August 2002, the Court of Appeal upheld the judgment of the first-instance court, giving its full backing to the latter’s factual and legal findings.

title: CASE OF JANKOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Bela Crkva.
- The applicant was employed by a socially-owned company called “Betonjerka” - DP, based in Bela Crkva (hereinafter “the debtor”).
- The Bela Crkva Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay specified amounts to the applicant on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions, plus the costs of the civil proceedings. This judgment became final.
- The Bela Crkva Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the judgment and the debtor to pay the applicant the enforcement costs.
- The Government claimed that the judgment had been fully enforced and the applicant did not contest this.
- The Bela Crkva Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant other specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions. This judgment became final.
- The Bela Crkva Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the judgment and the debtor to pay the applicant the enforcement costs. However, the debtor did not pay.
- The Pančevo Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor on 12 May 2009.
- On 22 September 2009, the Pančevo Commercial Court recognized the applicant’s respective claims.
- On 27 August 2012, the Pančevo Commercial Court terminated the insolvency proceedings against the debtor, having decided to continue with the insolvency action against the debtor’s estate.
- The insolvency proceedings are still pending.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal on 8 August 2013 complaining about the fairness of the insolvency proceedings and requesting the Constitutional Court to obligate the State to pay his unpaid salaries.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 31 March 2015, stating that it does not have the power to enable payments of recognized claims in the insolvency proceedings.

title: CASE OF ZIMONIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main bullet points describing the facts of the case:

- The applicants are Russian nationals and were owners of flats in Moscow.
- The State authorities reclaimed the flats, and the applicants’ title to the real property in question was annulled.
- The flats were reclaimed as they were considered bona vacantia due to the owners dying intestate with no surviving kin.
- Several flats were sold fraudulently, with forged wills being used to transfer ownership.
- The applicants continued to reside in the flats despite the judgements made in the City’s favour.

title: CASE OF ROMANESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1948 and lives in Bucharest.
- The applicant participated in the events that led to the fall of the Ceausescu dictatorship in December 1989 as an officer in a sub-unit of the special anti-terrorist unit within the special forces for State security.
- The applicant was arrested by army forces and held in detention from 22 December until 23 December 1989 and then held by the unit’s commander from 25 December 1989 until 2 February 1990. 
- The applicant alleged ill-treatment and illegal detention and filed a complaint with the military prosecutor on 29 April 1990.
- The military prosecutor found that the unit’s commander G.A. had been responsible for the applicant’s deprivation of liberty and injuries on 2 December 1993. However, criminal proceedings could not be initiated because the commander had died.
- The investigation into crimes allegedly committed by three of the defendants was severed and jurisdiction was relinquished to the prosecuting authorities at the High Court of Cassation and Justice in order to be joined to the main criminal investigation into the events of December 1989.
- The prosecutor’s office closed the main investigation on 14 October 2015, finding that the complaints were partly statute-barred and partly ill-founded.

title: CASE OF PADLEWSKI v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant worked as a civil servant for the Ministry of Economics and Labour and was accused of several disciplinary offenses related to a project he was working on.
- The Disciplinary Prosecutor reported the suspected offenses to the Disciplinary Council.
- The applicant contested the accusations.
- The Disciplinary Council decided not to prosecute due to the offenses being time-barred, but this decision was later overturned.
- Criminal investigations against the applicant were discontinued.
- The applicant requested the re-opening of disciplinary proceedings, and the proceedings continued despite his request for a stay.
- The applicant was placed in retirement due to being deemed unfit for service.
- The Disciplinary Council convicted the applicant of the offenses and imposed a disciplinary penalty of loss of all his rights and entitlements from his public employment.
- The Appeals Commission quashed the Disciplinary Council's decision and remitted the case back to the Disciplinary Council due to procedural errors.
- The Disciplinary Council held several hearings and appointed a psychiatric expert to determine if the applicant could be held accountable for his actions.
- The applicant's compulsory retirement became final.
- The Disciplinary Council again convicted the applicant, and this decision was later quashed and remitted back to the Disciplinary Council again.
- The Disciplinary Council ultimately decided that the applicant was not guilty of the offenses, and this decision was upheld by the Appeals Commission after the Disciplinary Prosecutor's appeal was dismissed.
- The proceedings were ultimately discontinued, and the applicant was awarded expenses related to his appeals against the Disciplinary Council's decisions.

title: CASE OF GÜNER v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in Istanbul in 1980.
- The Ankara Magistrates' Court restricted access to the investigation file on December 22, 2009, in accordance with the CCP.
- The applicant was arrested on February 9, 2010, on suspicion of forming a criminal organization and fraudulently using credit cards.
- On February 11, 2010, the police questioned the applicant in the presence of his lawyer, reading out transcripts of intercepted phone conversations.
- On February 12, 2010, the investigating judge ordered the applicant's detention on remand based on strong suspicion, the risk of absconding and tampering with evidence, and the risk of coercing witnesses and victims.
- The applicant requested release pending trial, but the courts dismissed the requests based on the nature of the offense, strong suspicion, evidence, and risk factors.
- The applicant objected to the decisions, but the appeal courts rejected the objections without a hearing.
- The applicant was released on January 19, 2011, by the 26th Chamber of Ankara Criminal Court based on time spent in detention.

title: CASE OF PAKHTUSOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a taxi driver. 
- The applicant was stopped by traffic police on the night of July 25, 2009. 
- He failed to produce his driving license and was suspected of having it withdrawn. 
- Police officers took him to the duty unit of the Ezhvinskiy District police station and kept him in a cell for administrative detainees until the following morning. 
- On July 26, 2009, the applicant was found guilty of driving a vehicle after his driving license was withdrawn and was sentenced to fifteen days of administrative detention. 
- On July 31, 2009, the applicant requested a family visit, which was denied by the head of the detention unit, stating that family visits were not provided for by law. 
- On August 14, 2009, the applicant's representative lodged a complaint alleging that the applicant's right to family life was unlawfully restricted. 
- The police officials argued that the Internal Rules governing Detention Facilities for Administrative Detainees did not provide the right to have a family visit. 
- On September 15, 2009, the Syktyvkar City Court dismissed the applicant's complaint. 
- The applicant's representative appealed, arguing that the restrictions imposed on family visits constituted an interference with the applicant's rights under Article 8 of the Convention. 
- On October 22, 2009, the Supreme Court of the Komi Republic upheld the City Court's decision, stating that a refusal to authorize a family visit should be warranted by circumstances and conditions providing the competent authorities with the right to apply the disputed restriction.

title: CASE OF BAŞTÜRK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Şanlıurfa.
- The applicant was dismissed from her post of officer in the army on 22 July 2008.
- The reason for the dismissal was non-compliance with disciplinary rules and immoral behavior.
- On 14 August 2008, the applicant filed an action before the Supreme Military Administrative Court to annul her dismissal.
- The court dismissed the applicant's case on 16 June 2009, based on "secret documents" submitted by the Ministry of Defence that were not disclosed to the applicant.
- On 29 September 2009, the applicant's request for rectification was rejected by the same court.

title: CASE OF YAGODNIKOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Vladimir.
- Applicant was indicted with fraud in 2008.
- On 21 March 2008, the district court ordered temporary suspension of the applicant from the post of chief accountant of municipal hospital no. 4.
- The district court awarded the applicant an allowance for the period of suspension in the amount of five statutory monthly wages.
- On 11 August 2009, the district court cancelled the suspension of the applicant from the office as no longer necessary.
- On 12 July 2010, the regional court quashed the decision of the district court concerning the monthly allowance and remitted the case for a new examination.
- On 3 August 2010, the district court awarded the applicant a monthly allowance for the period of suspension from the office in the amount of 266,812.92 Russian roubles to be paid from the federal budget.
- The decision of the district court was upheld on appeal on 22 September 2010.
- On 31 January 2011, the amount mentioned above was transferred to the applicant.

title: CASE OF GUMENIUC v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was stopped by traffic police for speeding on 27 July 2005 and fined 60 Moldovan lei.
- The applicant did not pay the fine, and it was converted into thirty days’ administrative detention.
- The applicant was not present or summoned for the hearing at which the decision was made to detain him.
- The applicant was arrested on 12 June 2006 and suffered a heart attack the same day.
- The applicant appealed but was denied by the Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF AYDIN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a Turkish national born in 1983.
- At the time of the introduction of the application, he was detained in Tekirdağ F-type prison.
- The applicant was taken into custody on suspicion of membership of an illegal organization.
- The Istanbul State Security Court ordered the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- The applicant and ten other persons were charged with attempting to undermine the constitutional order.
- The case was transferred to 10th Chamber of the Istanbul Assize Court after a new promulgation.
- The courts examined the applicant’s continued detention at the end of every hearing, either on their own motion or upon the applicant’s request.
- The 10th Chamber of the Istanbul Assize Court ordered the applicant’s continued detention on 25 December 2007, and his objection was eventually dismissed by the 11th Chamber of Istanbul Assize Court.
- On 24 March 2009, the applicant was convicted as charged and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- The decision of the Court of Cassation upheld the conviction, and it became final on 20 January 2011.

title: CASE OF SHERSTNEVA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and their details are given in an appended table.
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- The applicants also complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- In application no. 43076/07, the applicant raised other complaints as well under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SHAMRAY AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant application details in the appended table.
- Applicants have complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- Applicants have complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF PIVDENBUDTRANS, ZAT AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant application details provided in a table.
- Applicants complained of excessive length of civil proceedings.
- Applicants complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- Applicant no. 14819/09 raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF RYBALKIN AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table is appended with the list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complained of the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BOŽE v. LATVIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Riga.
- An official representing the Ministry of Health informed the State police authorities in writing that the applicant was selling unlicensed pharmaceutical products via the internet.
- The police officers responsible for investigating economic crime made a test purchase and met the applicant at a pizzeria near his home.
- Immediately after the test purchase, the same police officers carried out an inspection at the applicant’s apartment.
- As a result of the inspection, a computer, a computer hard drive, and items used in the production of the medicines were seized from the applicant’s apartment.
- The police authorities instituted two sets of administrative offence proceedings on unlicensed business operations and the sale of unlicensed pharmaceutical products.
- The applicant submitted various complaints to the State police authorities concerning the events of 11 June 2004.
- The internal inquiry by the Internal Security Office of the State Police concluded that there had been no violations of law in the conduct of the police officers who had carried out the test purchase and the subsequent inspection of the applicant’s apartment.
- The applicant complained to various branches of the Office of the Prosecutor, alleging that the “search” of his apartment on 11 June 2004 had been unlawful.
- The Pre-trial Investigation Department of the State Police dismissed the allegations that the police officers had carried out a search of the applicant’s apartment on 11 June 2004.
- The applicant was fined LVL 200 and the items he had used in manufacturing the pharmaceutical products were confiscated.
- On the basis of the pre-trial investigation, in which the applicant was questioned as a witness, the criminal proceedings were terminated owing to lack of evidence that a criminal offence had been committed.

title: CASE OF DANILOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table is appended with a list of applicants and their relevant details.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF NIKOGHOSYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and worked for the State Revenue Committee.
- The applicant was dismissed from his job on 27 February 2009 by the Head of the Committee.
- The applicant brought an action on 20 March 2009 in court, requesting reinstatement and compensation.
- On 11 August 2009, the Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan found in favour of the applicant and declared the order of 27 February 2009 void, reinstated the applicant, and awarded him compensation.
- The Committee appealed the judgment, but it was upheld by the Civil Court of Appeal on 7 October 2009.
- The Committee lodged an appeal on points of law, which was rejected by the Court of Cassation on 9 December 2009, and the judgment became final.
- The bailiff initiated enforcement proceedings on 5 February 2010, and the Committee paid the applicant for his forced absence from 27 February 2009 until 9 December 2009.
- The applicant sent letters to the Committee and officials, complaining about non-compliance with the judgment of 11 August 2009.
- The bailiff terminated enforcement proceedings on 18 July 2011, stating that it was impossible to enforce the judgment.
- The applicant contested the bailiff’s decision before the Administrative Court, which ruled in his favour and ordered the enforcement proceedings to be reopened on 5 December 2011.
- The supervising bailiff set aside the bailiff’s decision on 20 January 2012, and enforcement proceedings were reopened.
- The Committee replied on 5 March 2012 that the applicant could not be reinstated in his previous position as it no longer existed due to a Governmental decree of 15 December 2011.
- The bailiff terminated enforcement proceedings again on 26 April 2012, stating that it was impossible to enforce the judgment.
- The applicant contested the decision before the Administrative Court, which granted his claim for the payments for forced absence until 15 December 2011 but rejected his claim for reinstatement.
- The applicant appealed, but the Administrative Court of Appeal dismissed his claim.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law, which was declared inadmissible by the Court of Cassation on 27 March 2013.
- The bailiff reopened enforcement proceedings on 19 April 2013.
- The Committee offered to reinstate the applicant in a similar position with compensation for forced absence but the

title: CASE OF JÓHANNESSON AND OTHERS v. ICELAND
facts:
- Mr Jón Ásgeir Jóhannesson, Mr Tryggvi Jónsson, and Fjárfestingafélagið Gaumur were involved in an audit of their tax returns and bookkeeping by the Directorate of Tax Investigations in 2003. 
- The Directorate of Internal Revenue found that the first applicant failed to declare significant payments and other allowances received from 1998 to 2002, and imposed a 25% tax surcharge. 
- Similar findings were made for the second and third applicants, both of whom were also issued a 25% surcharge. 
- Following an appeal, the Internal Revenue Board upheld the imposition of tax surcharges. 
- The National Police Commissioner indicted the applicants for aggravated tax offences in 2008, based on the same facts as the previous investigations. 
- The Reykjavik District Court dismissed parts of the indictment, citing that the applicants had already been tried and punished by the earlier decisions of the tax authorities. 
- The Supreme Court overturned the District Court's ruling and ordered it to examine the merits of the case. 
- The District Court eventually found that the first and second applicants acted with gross negligence and were convicted on some of the charges against them. 
- The Supreme Court upheld the convictions and imposed prison sentences (suspended for two years) and fines for the applicants.

title: CASE OF ZHIKHAR AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table is appended with a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants raised complaints regarding the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants also had other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MATIOŠAITIS AND OTHERS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
1. First applicant, Kęstutis Matiošaitis, was sentenced to life imprisonment for aggravated murder and violence against other prisoners.
2. The applicant asked the court to reclassify his crimes and commute his sentence, but the Court of Appeal refused to do so.
3. K. Matiošaitis obtained a bachelor’s degree while serving his sentence.
4. The applicant’s character was assessed as satisfactory and he participated in social rehabilitation programs, but committed three disciplinary violations.
5. The applicant submitted a pardon plea to the President of the Republic, which was rejected by the Pardon Commission.
6. The administrative court refused to examine the applicant’s complaint that a law prohibiting life prisoners’ release on parole was unconstitutional.
7. The prison administration refused to provide vocational training to the first applicant.
8. Second applicant, Juozas Maksimavičius, was granted a life sentence pardon after initially being sentenced to death.
9. The Court of Appeal refused to commute the second applicant's life sentence after he asked for reclassification of his crimes.
10. The second applicant participated in social rehabilitation and recreation programs and was commended for good behavior thirteen times.
11. The second applicant submitted a pardon plea, which was rejected by the Pardon Commission.
12. Third applicant, Stanislovas Katkus, was sentenced to life imprisonment for aggravated murder and illegal possession of firearms.
13. The Court of Appeal refused to commute the third applicant's life sentence after he asked for reclassification of his crimes.
14. The third applicant participated in social rehabilitation and recreation programs and had good behavior, but also committed a disciplinary violation.
15. The third applicant had not yet applied for presidential pardon.
16. Fourth applicant, Vladas Beleckas, was sentenced to life imprisonment for theft, robbery, destruction of property of historical and cultural value, and aggravated murder.
17. The Court of Appeal refused to commute the fourth applicant's life sentence after he asked for reclassification of his crimes.
18. The fourth applicant had committed disciplinary violations, but also participated in social rehabilitation programs and was commended for good behavior.
19. The fourth applicant's plea for presidential pardon was rejected by the Pardon Commission.
20. Fifth applicant, Rolandas Lenkaitis, was sentenced to life imprisonment for aggravated murder and other crimes.
21. His crimes were reclassified, but the life sentence for aggravated murder was upheld by the Court of Appeal.
22. The fifth applicant committed disciplinary violations, but was also commended for

title: CASE OF PALUDA v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant is a Supreme Court judge.
- The Judicial Council of the Slovak Republic suspended the applicant from his function and filed disciplinary charges against him for failing to comply with his duties, such as abstaining from behaviour which might cast doubt on the respectability of his judicial office, and abiding by the principles of judicial ethics and enhancing the good reputation of the judiciary.
- The proposed sanction was that the applicant’s post as a judge be revoked and his salary was reduced by 50%.
- The applicant sought protection of his rights by way of an appeal to the Judicial Council, an administrative-law action, and a constitutional complaint, all of which were unsuccessful.
- The decision to suspend the applicant was of a preliminary nature and had no bearing on his fundamental rights and freedoms.
- The disciplinary charges against the applicant were withdrawn by the Minister of Justice and the Supreme Court discontinued the disciplinary proceedings against him.

title: CASE OF BĂLȘAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and married N.C. in 1979. They had four children together.
- N.C. was violent towards the applicant and their children on numerous occasions throughout their marriage.
- Assaults against the applicant intensified during their divorce proceedings, and the divorce was finalized on 6 December 2008.
- The applicant was physically assaulted and threatened by N.C. on 24 June and 3 September 2007.
- The applicant had numerous bruises and injuries that required medical care, and police officers called by the applicant noted that she had been injured in a domestic dispute.
- The applicant lodged complaints with the prosecutor's office and wrote a letter to the police chief, alleging that she had been the victim of repeated acts of violence by her husband.
- N.C. denied hitting the applicant, and the prosecutor decided not to press criminal charges against him and imposed an administrative fine instead.
- The applicant's complaint against that decision was rejected as ill-founded.
- The applicant lodged a complaint against the prosecutor's decisions with the Petroşani District Court.
- The court decided to partially quash the prosecutor's decision in respect of the crime of bodily harm and to examine that part of the case on the merits.
- The court acquitted N.C. of the crime of bodily harm, stating that the applicant had provoked the assaults because of her alcohol consumption and inadequate care of their children.
- The court further dismissed the applicant's claims for damages as ill-founded.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that judgment, which was also dismissed.
- The applicant made several complaints to the Petroşani police concerning new incidents of assault or threats by N.C.
- The prosecutor's office decided not to press charges against N.C. for the new incidents, but he was punished with an administrative fine.

title: CASE OF APCOV v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lives in Tiraspol.
- The applicant was arrested on 21 January 2005 by the authorities of the break-away “Moldavian Republic of Transdniestria” on charges of robbery and was detained in custody until 8 July 2005 when he was released on bail.
- During detention, he was allegedly detained in very poor conditions with persons with HIV and subjected to ill-treatment.
- During the criminal proceedings, two and a half years after the robbery, the victim of the robbery was asked to identify the applicant from a picture without procedural guarantees, and the applicant's alibi was dismissed without any investigation.
- On 29 August 2006, the Tiraspol District Court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to seven years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant was placed in detention in Tiraspol colony no. 2 where the conditions allegedly were very poor, and he did not receive medical attention despite his HIV diagnosis.
- On 26 September 2006, the Supreme Court of the “MRT” dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
- The applicant's mother engaged a lawyer to lodge an application to the Court, but the prison guards refused to allow her to get the signature on the application form.
- The applicant was released from detention on 24 April 2012.
- The applicant never informed the authorities of Moldova about his detention in the “MRT” or about the criminal proceedings against him.

title: CASE OF GRECU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and detained in Vadul lui Voda.
- On 22 February 2002, she was arrested and released the same day after a court found her detention to be abusive.
- The applicant was ill-treated during her detention, including being punched and strangled.
- After release, she was diagnosed with concussion and multiple bruises.
- She filed a criminal complaint but it was unsuccessful.
- She initiated civil proceedings for unlawful detention and ill-treatment.
- The Supreme Court of Justice found a breach of the applicant’s rights under Articles 3, 5, 6, and 13 of the Convention.
- The court awarded her 3,200 euros in compensation.

title: CASE OF VARDANEAN v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Mr. Ernest Vardanean and Ms. Irina Vardanean, Moldovan nationals residing in Chisinau.
- They are journalists and were living in the self-proclaimed “Moldovan Republic of Transdniestria” at the time of the events.
- On 7 April 2010, Mr. Vardanean was arrested by agents of the secret service of the “MRT” on charges of treason/espionage for the Republic of Moldova, and his personal belongings were seized.
- He was sentenced to 15 years’ imprisonment by a tribunal from the “MRT” and released on pardon on 5 May 2011 after international pressure.
- During his detention, Mr. Vardanean was coerced into recording a video of himself admitting to working with the Moldovan secret services, and writing a letter about spying on foreign embassies.
- The second applicant was denied access to visit the first applicant, and lawyers representing the first applicant before the Court were denied access to him.
- The Moldovan authorities made numerous attempts to secure the release of the first applicant, including discussions with the European Union, United States, Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe, and OSCE.
- The Moldovan Government provided financial assistance to the first applicant’s family during his detention in the “MRT” and transferred ownership of a flat in Chisinau to them after his release.

title: CASE OF VLADIMIR NIKOLAYEVICH FEDOROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Yaroslavl.
- On 19 February 2009, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of bribe-taking.
- On 20 February 2009, the District Court remanded the applicant in custody on the grounds that he might pressure witnesses or obstruct justice.
- On 26 February 2009, the applicant was charged with eight counts of bribe-taking.
- On 3 March 2009, the Regional Court upheld the decision to detain the applicant on appeal.
- On 11 March 2009, the applicant was dismissed from his job.
- Between April and June 2009, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention.
- On 16 September 2009, the charges against the applicant were finalised to include twenty-six counts of bribe-taking and forgery of official documents.
- On 17 September 2009, the applicant was released against an undertaking not to leave the city of Yaroslavl.
- On 18 February 2010, the District Court convicted the applicant of twenty-six counts of bribe-taking and imposed a conditional sentence.
- The applicant made several requests to see his family while in custody, which were initially denied and later granted after court intervention.
- The Yaroslavl regional prosecutor’s office criticized the investigator for violating the applicant’s constitutional rights.

title: CASE OF ÓNODI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was married to Ms N.R. and they had a daughter together.
- The couple divorced in 2006, and custody of the child was granted to the mother.
- The father was granted visitation rights every other weekend, holidays, and a portion of the summer.
- The mother moved away and compliance with the visitation agreement became difficult.
- The father pursued enforcement of the agreement through the courts and filed a criminal complaint alleging child endangerment by the mother.
- The courts ultimately reduced the father's visitation to every other Saturday and a portion of weekends, and the parties had difficulty enforcing the agreement.
- The father's requests to decrease child allowance and end his obligation to pay it were eventually granted, but his request for reimbursement of child allowance paid was denied.

title: CASE OF SOYMA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA, RUSSIA AND UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lived in Vinnytsya until his death in 2006.
- The applicant was arrested in the "Moldavian Republic of Transdniestria" in 2001 on charges of murder and was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment in 2002.
- The applicant alleged that he was subjected to ill-treatment during his pre-trial detention to make him confess to the murder.
- The applicant's mother made numerous unsuccessful requests to the Ukrainian and Moldovan authorities to obtain her son's transfer to a Ukrainian prison.
- The applicant broke his leg and was admitted to hospital in March 2006, and on 24 May 2006, he was found hanged in the gym of the prison in which he was being detained.

title: CASE OF DEJNEK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and is detained in Lublin.
- On 10 October 2008, he was arrested on suspicion of the attempted murder of his brother, K.D.
- On 25 March 2009, a bill of indictment was lodged with the Lublin Regional Court against the applicant.
- On 12 December 2011, the Lublin Regional Court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to 10 years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed and on 21 August 2012, the Lublin Court of Appeal upheld the conviction.
- On 7 December 2012, the applicant’s lawyer lodged a cassation appeal with the Supreme Court. On 10 June 2013, the Supreme Court dismissed the cassation appeal as manifestly ill-founded.
- Following his arrest on 11 October 2008, the applicant was remanded in custody in the Lublin Remand Centre.
- His behavior during 2011 varied: he was sometimes rewarded for good behavior and sometimes faced disciplinary measures.
- In 2012, the applicant was seen by a neurologist seventeen times and on two occasions by a neurosurgeon.
- On 16 October 2012, an operation was scheduled for the applicant, apparently for back pain.
- On 22 August 2009, the prison authorities discovered 132 pills of psychoactive drugs hidden in the applicant’s clothes.
- On 26 August 2009, the applicant encouraged other prisoners to start a hunger strike, which lasted until 7 September 2009, and was punished by being placed in solitary confinement for fourteen days.
- On 30 January 2012, the applicant attempted to go for a walk in the prison yard without permission from the supervising officer and was reprimanded on 1 February.
- On 4 February 2012, the applicant was visited by members of his family and tried to pass them an illegal message on a piece of paper. After the visit, he was ordered to undergo a strip search.
- On 5 June 2012, the applicant underwent a strip search which was accompanied by a search of his cell. The inspection of the cell was part of an action plan introduced at the Lublin Remand Centre in 2012 to increase security.
- On 25 August 2012, the applicant had a visit from his sister and brother-in-law and was afterwards ordered to undergo another strip search.
- On 3 November 2012, the applicant received a visit from

title: CASE OF KOŚĆ v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was appointed to investigate the previous local mayor's management of public funds.
- The applicant sent a document to the district mayor with allegations of mismanagement of funds by the previous local mayor.
- The local Commune Council Audit Committee found no grounds for mismanagement of funds by the previous local mayor.
- The previous local mayor filed a civil action against the applicant for violating his personal rights.
- The court found that the applicant's document contained false information and violated the previous local mayor's personal rights.
- The applicant appealed the decision but was unsuccessful.
- The applicant was later elected as the new mayor of Jadwigów.

title: CASE OF MALIK BABAYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant's son was drafted into the army in 2009 and served as a sniper in Gadabay region.
- On 14 November 2009, while on guard duty, the applicant's son left his post and went into the nearby forest, where he talked to his father on the phone and asked for some belongings, including a mobile phone top-up card.
- After the phone call, the applicant's son returned to his post, where a few minutes later, he was found dead.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated under Article 125 (incitement to suicide) of the Criminal Code, and an inspection of the scene of the crime was conducted where a suicide note was found, claiming that the death was a suicide.
- The investigation included questioning soldiers, handwriting and forensic examinations, a reconstruction of events, and a post-mortem psychiatric and psychological examination. The investigation was initially closed, but a complaint by the applicant resulted in the case being remitted for further examination by the investigating authority.

title: CASE OF SHABELNIK v. UKRAINE (No. 2)
facts:
- Applicant born in 1979 and currently in detention in Zhytomyr, Ukraine
- Ms K. found murdered in her flat in October 2001
- Ms S., a minor, kidnapped and murdered in December 2001
- Applicant arrested on suspicion of kidnapping S. in order to extort money from her parents and S.'s murder
- Applicant provided with a lawyer on 17 December 2001
- Mr K., deceased Ms K.'s son, questioned as a witness and confessed to his mother's murder on 25 December 2001, but later retracted his confession
- Applicant questioned as a witness about K.'s death on 15 February 2002 and confessed to the murder without a lawyer
- Applicant was told about his duty to state everything he knew about the case, his privilege against self-incrimination, and that he could face criminal liability for false statements
- Applicant participated in an on-site reconstruction of the attack on K. on 16 February 2002 without a lawyer
- Investigating prosecutor requested opinion from psychiatrists on the applicant's condition and whether he was sane at the time of the alleged crimes
- Criminal proceedings instituted against the applicant for the murder of K. on 25 February 2002 and he was allowed to consult a lawyer in connection with the charges for the first time
- Panel of psychiatric experts concluded that the applicant was sane at the time of the alleged crimes and was sane at the time of the assessment on 5 March 2002
- Applicant stood trial and was convicted of kidnapping, extortion, and the murder of S. as well as the robbery and murder of K. on 11 July 2002, sentenced to life imprisonment
- Shabelnik judgment declared partly admissible on 19 February 2009 finding a violation of Article 6 §§ 1 and 3 of the Convention
- Applicant's conviction for the murder of K. based on incriminating evidence obtained in violation of his rights to remain silent and privilege against self-incrimination and hindered in the effective exercise of his right to defense
- Supreme Court upheld the applicant's conviction on 10 October 2002
- Supreme Court allowed applications for a review of the case and quashed its decision in 2002 on 30 April 2010
- Supreme Court examined the case on 9 September 2010 in the absence of the applicant but in the presence of his lawyer and found the rest of the evidence in the

title: CASE OF KRASTEVA AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years and live in Sofia.
- In 1968, the second applicant and the antecedents of the other applicants bought a plot of land measuring 953 square metres.
- Until 2002 the applicants or their antecedents owned and possessed the land.
- In 2002, the heirs of the previous owners brought a rei vindicatio action, claiming that the land was theirs and had been returned to them by the local land commission in 1999.
- After a legal process, the Sofia City Court allowed the rei vindicatio claim of the heirs and ordered the applicants to surrender possession of the land.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation declined to entertain a cassation appeal by the applicants.
- The applicants surrendered possession of the plot.

title: CASE OF GRABCHAK v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lived in Kiev
- He came to Bulgaria in 1995 and started a relationship with Ms M. in 1996
- They had a son in 1997 and the applicant was granted permanent resident status in 2003
- The applicant's residence permit was withdrawn on 6 November 2006, and he was ordered to leave Bulgaria and subject to a ten-year ban on re-entering it
- The order was based on claims that the applicant was involved in illegal activities, but no evidence was provided to support these allegations
- The applicant attempted to re-enter Bulgaria in 2006 but was denied access and has since been living in Kiev
- The applicant's appeal against the order was dismissed by the Minister of the Interior, and his subsequent application for judicial review was also denied
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the order of 6 November 2006, citing threats to national security as a justification for restrictions on the applicant's rights under the Convention.

title: CASE OF KURILOVICH AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1978, 1980 and 2007 respectively.
- The first applicant came to Bulgaria in 1997 and was granted long-term resident status in 2001 and permanent resident status in 2003.
- In 2005, he married the second applicant, and in 2007, the third applicant, their son, was born.
- On 29 May 2008, the head of the National Security Service withdrew the first applicant’s residence permit, ordered his expulsion, and imposed a ten-year ban on his re-entering Bulgaria on the ground of a serious threat to national security.
- The proposal, drawn up by the National Security Service on 27 May 2008 and initially classified, accused the first applicant of being part of a Russian criminal group implicated in various serious crimes and financing terrorist groups.
- The first applicant applied for judicial review of the order of 29 May 2008 on 12 June 2008, and in a final judgment of 8 January 2009, the Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the application for judicial review, stating that the order was lawful.
- The first applicant was expelled on 24 April 2009, and it is unclear whether the second and third applicants remained in Bulgaria after that.
- In 2012, the first and second applicants had another child.

title: CASE OF GAPAEV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years between 1970 and 2007.
- The first and second applicants ventured to Bulgaria in 1997.
- All members were granted permanent resident permits.
- On 29 May 2008, the head of the National Security Service issued an order withdrawing the first applicant’s residence permit.
- This order is grounded on proposal no. B849, which is an intelligence document alleging that the first applicant was the leader of an international terrorist group.
- The allegations against the first applicant also included extortion, drug trafficking, smuggling, money laundering and other criminal activities.
- No evidence was provided to support these claims.
- The first applicant applied for judicial review of the expulsion order in June 2008.
- The Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the application for judicial review.
- The first applicant was detained pending expulsion from 10 September 2008 to 3 September 2009.
- The other applicants lived in Bulgaria for a longer time, but they left in November 2015.

title: CASE OF AYVAZYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant's brother, Seyran Ayvazyan, was killed by police officers on 6 March 2006.
- At the time of the incident, Seyran Ayvazyan had been suffering from paranoid-type schizophrenia and had just attacked two people with a knife before returning to his home in Armenia.
- Police officers arrived at his house and attempted to persuade him to come out, but he refused and threatened to harm anyone who approached.
- After several hours of trying to negotiate with him, the police officers decided to spray Seyran Ayvazyan with water from a fire engine hose in an attempt to neutralize him.
- When six police officers entered the house, Seyran Ayvazyan stabbed one officer and then attempted to stab another before being shot multiple times by police officers.
- Seyran Ayvazyan died as a result of his injuries.
- The police officers involved were questioned and gave their accounts of the incident.
- A forensic examination revealed that Seyran Ayvazyan had been shot ten times by police officers, with nine of the bullets hitting him in his calves and thighs and one hitting him in the chest.
- Police ammunition was used, and five knives and a medical lancet were discovered at the scene.
- An investigation was launched, and a criminal case was instituted for attempted murder against Seyran Ayvazyan.

title: CASE OF TONYUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant lives in a small village in Ukraine.
- In 1996, a new cemetery was built next to the applicant's house.
- The cemetery was located within the sanitary health protection zone, which was illegal.
- The applicant's family was disturbed by funeral processions, mourning, and unpleasant smells from the cemetery.
- The applicant complained to the authorities about the proximity of the cemetery to her house.
- Burials in the new cemetery were banned in September 2000 and August 2001, but later allowed to continue.
- The applicant instituted court proceedings in 2002 seeking to stop the burials and for damages due to the risks to her health and life.
- In January 2003, the Yaremche Court found the Executive Committee's decision to allow burials in the new cemetery unlawful and ordered them to be stopped.
- Enforcement proceedings were initiated but failed to prevent burials.
- The applicant instituted further proceedings in August 2003 seeking to stop burials and for damages.
- The Yaremche Court found for the applicant in part in March 2004, ordering the Council to take necessary measures to stop burials and rejecting the claim for damages.
- Draft decisions banning burials were discussed by the Executive Committee, but none were approved due to the unavailability of alternative locations for the cemetery.
- The Council was fined by the Bailiffs' Service for failing to comply with court judgments on several occasions.
- The enforcement proceedings were terminated in February 2005 due to the impossibility of enforcement.
- The Council informed the applicant in July 2005 that they were unable to relocate the cemetery due to the unavailability of other suitable land.
- The applicant requested resettlement of her family by the Council in August 2005.
- The Council was ready to consider resettlement as an option, but had no funds to buy a new house for the applicant.
- The Ivano-Frankivsk Regional Bailiffs' Service refused to re-institute the enforcement proceedings in August 2006.
- The new cemetery has not been authorized for burials since 2011 due to the applicant's protests, and the old cemetery has been used instead.

title: CASE OF MINDADZE AND NEMSITSVERIDZE v. GEORGIA
facts:
- Two applicants, born in 1977 and 1979, were living in Tbilisi and Tskaltubo.
- Criminal proceedings were brought against unidentified people following an armed attack on K.G., a member of the Georgian Parliament.
- A photofit image of the attacker was created with the help of the victim's description. 
- A PSM pistol equipped with a silencer was handed to the police by a woman and her child, found in the back yard close to where the member of parliament was attacked.
- The first applicant was arrested in connection with the criminal case and searched, revealing his possession of a Browning pistol. 
- The first applicant confessed to conspiring with the second applicant to kill the member of parliament, furnished by a PSM pistol fitted with a silencer, and offered 10,000 United States dollars (USD) to kill a man whose identity was not specified at the time. 
- The first applicant was taken to Tbilisi police headquarters and put in an office to be questioned by a police officer. During the interview, he made a sincere confession and regretted committing the crime.
- In a formal confrontation, the member of parliament identified the first applicant as the attacker. 
- The investigator showed the first applicant the PSM pistol and silencer, which he had used to attack the victim. 
- The first and second applicants were transferred to prisons to hold their pre-trial detention for three months, until 13 August 2004.
- The Tbilisi Court of Appeal dismissed an appeal by the applicants and upheld the reasons given in the detention order.
- The first applicant submitted a complaint, alleging that he had given his confession of 13 May 2004 as a result of torture, and that those statements had not been true. 
- The investigator rejected the first applicant’s request to check his alibi. 
- On 11 August 2004, the Tbilisi Regional Court granted an application by the prosecutor to extend the applicants' pre-trial detention to 13 November 2004. 
- An expert from the Ministry of Health commissioned by the investigator on 24 June 2004 issued a report on the applicant's physical condition.

title: CASE OF ERDİNÇ KURT AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Duru Kurt exhibited symptoms of heart problems and was taken to the Ankara SSK hospital in 2004.
- She was examined and later underwent a heart surgery in 2006, and her father signed the consent form beforehand mentioning potential risks.
- A leak was discovered around the incision membrane during post-operative check-ups.
- Duru underwent a second operation in 2007, during which she suffered an oedema, brain haemorrhage, liver failure and muscle spasticity while in intensive care.
- The medical board diagnosed her with a severe irremediable psychomotor disability, caused by hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, on 11 July 2007.
- The prosecutor’s office issued a discontinuance decision on 28 September 2008, and the applicants brought an action for damages against the doctors before the Ankara Civil Court of General Jurisdiction on 23 May 2008.
- The board of experts appointed by the court submitted its report on 31 July 2009.
- The report indicated that the doctors were not responsible for Duru's sequelae affecting the child after her high-risk operations.

title: CASE OF BALKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and was convicted of murder and sentenced to thirteen years and six months’ imprisonment in 2009.
- The applicant's eyesight began deteriorating in 2008, and he complained about this to a resident colony doctor in September 2010.
- Eight months later, an ophthalmologist diagnosed the applicant with an “almost mature” cataract of the right eye and a focal cataract of the left eye and recommended an in-depth medical examination in a hospital.
- On 1 July 2011, an ophthalmologist confirmed the presence of cataracts on both eyes, established that the patient had lost his vision in his right eye and prescribed cataract surgery, which was postponed due to the lack of intraocular lenses in stock and overcrowding.
- On 7 April 2012, the applicant complained about the quality of medical assistance he had received and was dismissed by the medical unit of his detention facility, stating that he had been provided with medical assistance in full.
- The applicant was put on a waiting list for admission to the ophthalmological department of the prison hospital for a medical examination and eye surgery in May 2012.
- On 24 October 2013, an ophthalmologist confirmed that the applicant needed cataract surgery.
- Repeated eye examinations on 14 January and 22 June 2014 revealed the need for surgery, which was performed on 1 October 2014.

title: CASE OF NIKOLAYEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1971 and 1994 and live in Moscow.
- The flat was owned by the city and G. and her son were tenants.
- G. and her son died and their tenancies were de-registered by the municipal authorities.
- A. submitted a forged copy of a court judgment to claim the right to reside in the flat.
- The Housing Department entered into a social housing lease agreement with A. and her family, and later transferred the title to A., her husband, and daughter under the privatisation scheme.
- A. and her husband sold the flat to the first applicant in December 2005, and the applicants moved in.
- The Housing Department obtained information that the court judgment submitted by A. might have been forged and requested a relevant inquiry.
- The court invalidated the social housing lease agreement and the privatisation agreement.
- The Housing Department brought an action against the applicants seeking the transfer of the flat to the city and eviction of the applicants.
- The District Court granted the Housing Department’s claims and annulled the first applicant’s title.
- The City Court upheld the judgment of the District Court on appeal, and the bailiff instituted enforcement proceedings.
- The applicants were required to vacate the flat by August 2012.
- The Housing Department entered into a housing agreement with the applicants in August 2013 for a term of five years.

title: CASE OF SİNİM v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant's husband entered into an agreement to transport personal goods and furniture from Istanbul to Antalya on August 5, 2006.
- The truck carrying the goods collided with another vehicle and caught fire, resulting in the deaths of the truck's driver, substitute driver, and the applicant's husband.
- It was later discovered that the truck was also carrying inflammable liquid labeled as "Şenocak chafing fuel."
- An autopsy report indicated that the applicant's husband died as a result of the burns he sustained in the accident.
- The police initially found the driver of the truck responsible for the accident but did not identify them.
- The applicant filed a criminal complaint against the truck's owner, the transport company, and the seller and buyer of the inflammable goods for causing her husband's death.
- The public prosecutor ultimately found only the deceased driver of the truck responsible for the accident but did not pursue charges.
- The applicant continued to urge the public prosecutor to investigate the liability of the other implicated parties, including the transport company, the seller and buyer of the inflammable goods, and the truck's owner.
- The Forensic Medicine Institute could not establish the liability of Şenocak Ltd. Şti., Salihli Ltd. Şti., or anyone else for the accident, based on available evidence.
- The public prosecutor ultimately decided not to prosecute representatives of Salihli Ltd. Şti. and Şenocak Ltd. Şti., but the applicant's objections were rejected without response.

title: CASE OF BARSUKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 in the Tambov Region and lived in St Petersburg before his arrest.
- The applicant was arrested on 23 August 2007 and remained in detention throughout the investigation and trial.
- In 2009, he was found guilty of aggravated fraud, money laundering, and aggravated extortion within an organised criminal group and sentenced to a total of 29 years in prison.
- The applicant had numerous medical conditions, including the loss of his right arm, heart attacks, cancer, and kidney problems, which required a complex drug regimen and hospital treatment every two months.
- On admission to remand prison, the applicant informed the medical authorities of his condition.
- The applicant complained of various symptoms, and in November 2007, a surgeon recommended urinary catheterisation, which was performed approximately 250 times during the first year of detention.
- In December 2008, the applicant was examined by a urologist, who recommended treatment with antibiotics, regular urological supervision, and avoiding catheterisation where possible.
- The applicant's urinary condition persisted throughout 2009, and several consultations with a urologist were required.
- In October 2009, medical experts assessed the capability of the custodial authorities to properly treat the applicant and concluded that he required systematic treatment and periodic admissions to a specialised hospital.
- From 2012 to 2014, the applicant's urinary condition remained stable, and he continued using the suprapubic catheter to remove the urine.
- In December 2009, the applicant brought a court claim against the detention authorities, seeking that the lack of appropriate medical treatment be declared unlawful.
- In June 2010, the Preobrazhenskiy District Court of Moscow dismissed his claim, which the Moscow City Court upheld in March 2011.

title: CASE OF YUGAY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Perm.
- On 22 April 2008, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of drug dealing and placed in pre-trial detention because he was considered a serious offender and a foreign national with no permanent place of residence, job, or income, making him a flight risk.
- The Permskiy District Court extended his pre-trial detention on the same grounds on 18 June 2008.
- The Permskiy District Court issued a conviction on 5 August 2008, but it was quashed by the Perm Regional Court on 14 October 2008, which ordered that the applicant should remain in detention without providing any reasons.
- On 1 November 2008 and 18 March 2009, the Permskiy District Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention based on the same reasoning, stating that he could interfere with the investigation and put pressure on witnesses, and these decisions were upheld on appeal.
- On 20 May 2010, the District Court issued a new conviction but was quashed by the Perm Regional Court on 14 December 2010, and the applicant remained in detention.
- On 26 May 2011, the Perm Regional Court found the applicant guilty of drug dealing and smuggling, and he was sentenced to 10 years’ imprisonment. The sentence was later commuted to 8 years' imprisonment by the Supreme Court of Russia on 25 October 2011.

title: CASE OF PICHUGIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a prison sentence in the Orenburg region and was the head of the security service of the Yukos oil company.
- The applicant was charged with multiple counts of attempted murder and murder in April 2005, including conspiring with others to murder certain individuals and hiring hitmen to commit the murders.
- The investigation into the case was completed by July 2005, and the Deputy Prosecutor General gave an interview to major Russian channels on the same day, discussing the facts of the case that had been established by the investigation.
- The applicant lodged complaints regarding the prosecutor's statements, claiming they breached his presumption of innocence.
- The District Court and City Court rejected the complaints, finding that the prosecutor’s statements did not breach the applicant’s rights.
- The applicant was convicted, and the case was remitted for retrial in 2007.
- During the retrial, the court examined a note containing an address found among the personal belongings of one of the hitmen, which had been attributed to the applicant.
- The court considered multiple expert reports and opinions regarding the note's authorship, and found the applicant guilty of the murder of multiple individuals and attempted murder. The court relied on the expert opinion that confirmed the applicant's authorship of the note in finding him guilty of attempted murder. 
- The applicant's conviction was upheld on appeal by the Supreme Court in 2008.

title: CASE OF URUKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former head of the civil law department in the Cheboksary State University.
- A woman sued the applicant to establish his paternity and to receive alimony for a baby born in February 2004.
- The District Court rejected her claim, but it was later quashed by the Supreme Court, and a new examination was ordered.
- The District Court then gave judgment in the woman's favour, which was upheld on appeal by the Supreme Court.
- The applicant was later arrested on suspicion of large-scale bribery and was detained in remand prison IZ-21/1 in Cheboksary.
- The District Court refused the applicant leave to be present at hearings on his case on the grounds that the Code of Civil Procedure made no provision for bringing detainees to courts.
- The District Court ultimately issued judgment in the woman's favour and mentioned that the applicant did not recognize the paternity and had previously given testimony to the court.
- The applicant was released on bail but was later re-arrested and placed in custody.
- The Supreme Court quashed the detention order and released the applicant.
- The applicant complained to a prosecutor about the unlawful actions of the police during a search of his home, but the prosecutor refused to institute criminal proceedings.
- The applicant sued the Ministry of Finance for compensation in respect of an unauthorised search of his home carried out by the police, but his claim was rejected at both the district court and supreme court levels.
- The applicant was ultimately convicted of forcing students to pay bribes and given a custodial sentence.

title: CASE OF RATKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1966 and lived in the Tver Region before his conviction.
- On 21 November 2000, a prosecutor's country house was set on fire.
- On 8 February 2002, the applicant was accused and arrested for conspiracy with another person to set the prosecutor's country house on fire.
- On 11 February 2002, the applicant was released on an undertaking.
- On 10 December 2003, F. was stabbed to death by I. and A.
- Applicant was arrested on suspicion of being involved in the murder of F.
- On 6 February 2004, the Kashin Town Court found the applicant guilty of arson.
- On 25 May 2004, the applicant's conviction became final.
- On 23 June 2004, Veche Tveri published an article about the case.
- On 15 July 2004, the TV programme “Police unit on duty” covered the applicant’s case.
- The jury trial started on 16 August 2004.
- The court examined the prosecution witness Sh. on 24 August 2004.
- The applicant was excluded from the courtroom due to repeated attempts to influence the jurors.
- The trial court continued the hearing in the applicant's absence.
- The applicant was brought back to the courtroom for the closing statement.
- The jury delivered a guilty verdict, finding that the applicant hired I. and A. to murder F.
- On 2 September 2004, the Tver Regional Court sentenced the applicant to seventeen years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed and complained about the violation of his rights.
- On 9 February 2005, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the judgment on appeal.

title: CASE OF VOLCHKOVA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants with details provided in an appended table.
- Applicants' complaint about excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- Applicants' complaint about the lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SILKĀNE AND OTHERS v. LATVIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their relevant application details is available.
- The applicants have filed a complaint about the excessive duration of civil proceedings.

title: CASE OF KARMANNIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant has been detained in correctional colony no. 36/5 since 30 May 2011
- The applicant's personal space varied between 2.2 and 5.2 sq.m. during different periods of detention
- The applicant complained of overcrowding, insufficient number of toilets and unhygienic conditions

title: CASE OF CÂRSTINA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- There is an appended table listing the applicants and relevant details of their applications.
- The applicants are complaining about the non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions.

title: CASE OF VOLKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Main details of the case application are in the table.
- The applicant complained about inadequate detention conditions and raised other complaints.
- The Government submitted a declaration to resolve the applicant's concerns.
- The Government acknowledged that the detention conditions did not comply with Article 3 of the Convention.
- The Government offered to pay 4,480 euros within three months and invited to strike out the case.
- In case of failure to pay, the Government promised to pay interest equal to the marginal lending rate plus three percentage points.
- The declaration did not address the complaints about the inadequate conditions of detention in two correctional colonies.
- The applicant accepted the terms of the declaration.

title: CASE OF SCHWAB v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and died on 27 May 2014.
- On 24 October 2014, Mrs Schwab was established as his heir.
- The applicant had intermittently received emergency relief benefits from 1987.
- The Vienna Prandaugasse Labour Market Service retroactively revoked the benefits from a particular period and ordered the applicant to refund the payments.
- The applicant claimed that he and his wife had been running separate households since September 2000.
- The Vienna Regional Labour Market Service dismissed the appeal.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's request for legal aid.
- The applicant complained to the Administrative Court and requested an oral hearing.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the complaint as unfounded without holding an oral hearing.
- The Administrative Court's decision was served on the applicant's counsel on 17 June 2011.

title: CASE OF LEITNER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Blumau.
- The applicant and his former partner S.O. have two children, born in 2002 and 2004, respectively. S.O. always had sole custody of the children, and the parents never agreed to joint custody.
- The children lived with their mother during the week, and the whole family usually stayed at the applicant’s house on weekends.
- In April 2008, S.O. and the applicant separated, and the children remained with their mother.
- On 27 June 2008, the applicant lodged an application with the Vienna Inner City District Court to transfer sole custody to him, or to grant him joint custody together with S.O. Additionally, he applied for an interim measure concerning his visiting rights, as he had not seen his children since 20 April 2008.
- On 8 October 2008, an agreement was reached that allowed the applicant to see his children every second Monday and every second Saturday.
- After a few visits, S.O. unilaterally stopped further visits, claiming that they were having a negative influence on the children. Between November 2008 and Easter 2009, the applicant secretly went to see his children at their school and kindergarten a few times.
- On 6 April 2009, the District Court granted the applicant visiting rights on every second Saturday.
- The court dismissed the applicant’s application for sole custody, stating that the children were well cared for by their mother and that there was no risk to their best interest.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that he was discriminated against compared to the mother and that the court had not decided on the question of joint custody.
- On 28 July 2009, the Vienna Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal, stating that there was no indication of a risk to the children’s best interest if the mother maintained sole custody.
- On 1 September 2010, the Supreme Court rejected the applicant’s appeal for lack of an important issue of law.
- The applicant applied again for joint custody or sole custody in the alternative in February 2013, but his requests were dismissed by the Supreme Court on 7 May 2014.
- S.O. moved with the children to the south of Austria shortly after the applicant's new application.

title: CASE OF OVECHKINA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table is appended with the list of applicants and their relevant details.
- The applicants raised complaints about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants also claimed that the domestic law did not provide any effective remedy to address their grievances.

title: CASE OF DROBYSHEVSKIY AND VITT v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were involved in civil proceedings
- First instance and appeal courts granted their claims against welfare authorities
- Claims were for recalculation of periodical payments for social benefits
- Judgments became final
- Judgments were quashed due to new circumstances
- Interpretation of law in quashed judgments was different from that of Supreme Court and/or Constitutional Court of Russian Federation
- Judgments were fully enforced prior to their quashing.

title: CASE OF YAVUZ NAL AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants had to take their husbands’ surnames after their marriage as per the Civil Code.
- They initiated proceedings seeking permission to use only their maiden names.
- Their requests were rejected by first-instance courts.
- Article 187 of the Civil Code was cited as the reason for the rejection.
- The article stated that married women had to bear their husbands' name throughout their marriage.
- The applicants' details and the dates of their applications are listed in the attached table.

title: CASE OF TSAREV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The courts ordered pension authority to recalculate pensions for applicants in 2005 to 2006.
- The judgments made during this time became final.
- In 2008, the district and town courts quashed the previous judgments after discovering new circumstances.
- The courts found that the previous judgments overlooked the interpretation of the Labour Pension Act by the Supreme Court in 2005 and 2007.
- As a result, the applicants' claims were eventually dismissed.

title: CASE OF ĐUKOVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant filed a compensation claim on 25 March 1996 against the Municipality of Bar and a local primary school for damages suffered due to expropriation of his property.
- The applicant informed the Court of First Instance on 11 April 1996 that he initiated another set of proceedings to determine the value of damages.
- The civil proceedings were suspended by Court of First Instance until the resolution of the above-mentioned matter.
- It is unclear whether or not the compensation proceedings have ended.
- On 2 February 2004, the applicant filed a case against his neighbor for demarcation of their land plots.
- The applicant amended his proposal for demarcation on 25 March 2004.
- On 14 September 2004, the applicant and respondent reached a friendly settlement that was approved by the Court of First Instance.

title: CASE OF FOMIN AND SIVAYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- All applicants were involved in civil proceedings.
- The first-instance and appeal courts ruled in their favor.
- These judgments became final.
- The supervisory review courts later found that the judgments were quashed due to incorrect application of substantive law.

title: CASE OF VOLKOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and lived in Voronezh prior to her arrest.
- On 14 July 2007, the applicant and B. travelled to Moscow by car, and the police stopped the car at 3.40 a.m.
- The officers conducted an inspection of their identity documents and luggage, and in the sports bag that the applicant's friend had asked her to take to another friend in Moscow, they found a black plastic bag containing four plastic bags of marijuana weighing almost three kilograms and cash.
- The police drafted a report on the seizure of objects and substances and instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant and B. on suspicion of attempted large‑scale sale of drugs.
- The applicant was charged on 15 July 2007 and detained by the court order on 16 July 2007.
