- The defence claimed that the attesting witnesses present during the opening of the bag were employees of the narcotics unit and both did not appear before the trial court.
- The trial court refused the defence's motion to obtain the visitors journal from the reception of the narcotics unit and allowed the pre-trial statements of the missing witnesses and the driver of the car to be read out.
- The District Court found the applicant and B. guilty as charged and sentenced them each to eight years’ imprisonment in a high-security correctional colony.
- The Moscow City Court rejected her appeal against the conviction on 28 July 2008.

title: CASE OF CHELTSOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a retired woman who receives a monthly pension of 2,440 Russian roubles (RUB) and is the founder and editor-in-chief of an independent weekly newspaper called Fryazinets.
- The Shchelkovo town prosecutor's office opened a criminal investigation against a woman called S.P. for abuse of powers by a person performing managerial functions in a commercial or other organisation.
- The applicant published a statement by the Shchelkovo town deputy prosecutor in the newspaper, and after this publication, the newspaper's editorial department received calls from residents who informed the applicant that S.P. had shown inappropriate behavior when they tried to make an appointment with the mayor.
- The applicant published an article containing information about S.P.'s alleged breach of law, misconduct while serving her official functions, and lack of conscientiousness as head of Strela ZhSK, leading to financial irregularities that members of the association had brought civil proceedings against her.
- S.P. sued the applicant and the newspaper, leading to the Shchelkovo Town Court ordering the newspaper to publish a retraction and awarding S.P. RUB 10,000 in non-pecuniary damages.
- L.K., the wife of the incumbent mayor, brought a defamation lawsuit against the applicant and a local businessman standing for mayor of Fryazino, N. The Town Court found against the two defendants and awarded L.K. RUB 15,000 and RUB 30,000 in non-pecuniary damages from the applicant and N., respectively.
- Both defendants appealed the Town Court's decision, but the Regional Court upheld the judgments on appeal.

title: CASE OF STADNIK v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1976.

• In 1994, the applicant was convicted of theft and given a two-year custodial sentence.

• The court applied a general amnesty act, and the applicant's conviction was spent with immediate effect.

• In 1995, the applicant was convicted of aggravated robbery and sentenced to six years in prison.

• The court ordered the suspended sentence to be activated and increased the total length of the sentence by one year considering the applicant had breached the terms of his probation by committing a new crime.

• In 2001, the Presidium of the Omsk Regional Court acknowledged the 1995 conviction was unlawful.

• The applicant was detained unlawfully for eleven months and fourteen days and sought compensation for his detention.

• He unsuccessfully tried several ways of claiming compensation.

• Rehabilitation didn't apply as he was found guilty.

• The applicant's civil claim for compensation was rejected.

title: CASE OF KRAVCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1945 and lives in Taganrog.
- In 1978, the applicant and her sister inherited a house.
- In 2001, the sisters had a civil dispute over the house, and a court determined that they had equal shares.
- In 2002, the court determined the equal shares of the house and the way to divide it. The Rostov Regional Court upheld this judgment.
- The applicant’s sister lodged a separate claim for some parts of the house, stating that she had invested in their reconstruction in 1989.
- On 17 October 2003, the court held that the attachments to the house belonged to the applicant’s sister, and reduced the applicant’s part to 36/100.
- On 22 October 2004, the court quashed the previous judgment and re-opened the case due to "newly-discovered circumstances."
- The proceedings resumed, but the applicant withdrew her claim on 8 February 2005.
- In March 2005, the applicant’s sister filed another claim for dividing the property.
- On 10 October 2006, the court granted her claims and rendered the judgment in the absence of the applicant.
- On 6 December 2006, the Rostov Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal, stating that the applicant had been properly notified about the hearing.

title: CASE OF SHOROKHOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• All applicants were involved in civil proceedings. 
• They won the case in the first instance and appeal courts. 
• Judgments became binding and enforceable. 
• Judgments were quashed by supervisory review courts on grounds of incorrect application of substantive law or assessment of evidence by lower courts.

title: CASE OF CHAYKA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1967 and resides in Moscow
- Arrested on 8 October 2013 on suspicion of aggravated fraud
- Tverskoy District Court authorized his detention on 10 October 2013
- Detention extended by District Court on 20 November 2013
- Counsel appealed against the extension
- Moscow City Court upheld the detention order on 20 January 2014
- On 5 September 2014, the District Court replaced detention with house arrest

title: CASE OF AKGÜL v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1978, lives in Balıkesir
- Applicant was dismissed from his post as an army officer on 26 May 2010
- Applicant brought an action to annul his dismissal on 22 June 2010
- Chief public prosecutor submitted observations on 9 November 2010
- Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed applicant’s case on 8 February 2011 based on "secret documents" submitted by the Ministry of Defence
- The documents were not disclosed to the applicant
- Applicant's request for rectification was rejected on 26 April 2011

title: CASE OF SVORCAN v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Belgrade, Serbia.
- The applicant and her family members initiated proceedings seeking division of their joint property.
- The Court of First Instance in Herceg Novi discontinued the proceedings and instructed the parties to initiate a separate civil case.
- The applicant's cousins brought a claim against the applicant and her parents before the Court of First Instance in Herceg Novi, and subsequently lodged an additional claim concerning the same matter.
- The Court of First Instance in Herceg Novi ruled against the applicant and her parents, and this judgment was upheld on appeal by the High Court in Podgorica, becoming final.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court of Montenegro, which was initially misplaced and later rejected as unfounded.

title: CASE OF TUNÇ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Ankara
- The applicant was dismissed from his post as an officer in the army due to non-compliance with disciplinary rules on 13 April 2010
- On 16 May 2010, the applicant brought an action before the Supreme Military Administrative Court requesting the annulment of his dismissal
- The court dismissed the applicant's action on 15 February 2011, citing "secret documents" submitted by the Ministry of Defence that were not disclosed to the applicant
- On 3 May 2011, the applicant's request for rectification of the judgment was rejected by the same court.

title: CASE OF TOMAŠEVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- On August 9, 2004, the applicant filed a civil claim about a property issue against 11 people with the Court of First Instance in Herceg Novi.
- On March 15, 2011, the Court of First Instance in Herceg Novi ruled partly in favor of the applicant.
- On March 18, 2011, the applicant appealed the case with the High Court in Podgorica.
- On November 8, 2013, the High Court in Podgorica canceled the judgment and sent back the case to the Court of First Instance.
- On July 6, 2015, the Court of First Instance in Herceg Novi ruled against the applicant.
- On August 3, 2015, the applicant filed an appeal against this verdict. The proceedings are still ongoing at the second instance.

title: CASE OF R.M. v. TURKEY
facts:
1. The applicant left Uzbekistan in 2007 to avoid being subjected to ill-treatment during criminal investigation related to his political activities.
2. The Uzbek authorities issued an international warrant for his arrest in December 2007.
3. He arrived in Turkey and was arrested in September 2009 because he was wanted by Interpol.
4. The Bakırköy Magistrates’ Court ordered his provisional detention for forty-five days on the basis of the Treaty on Mutual Legal Assistance.
5. The first-instance court ordered his extradition in October 2009 but it was quashed by the Court of Cassation due to procedural errors in April 2010.
6. The Bakırköy Assize Court re-started the examination and ordered his detention under Articles 100 and 101 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on 7 June 2010.
7. The court requested information from the Uzbek authorities between July to December 2010 and adjourned the proceedings six times.
8. The UNHCR sent a letter advising the authorities to grant the applicant subsidiary protection status and to refrain from extraditing or deporting him to Uzbekistan.
9. The Ministry of the Interior granted the applicant subsidiary protection status and a temporary permit to reside in Sakarya on 1 June 2011.
10. The Bakırköy Assize Court once again admitted the request for the applicant's extradition on 20 June 2011, which was upheld by the Court of Cassation on 8 March 2012.
11. The Ministry of Justice sent a letter stating that the applicant could no longer be extradited as a result of his subsidiary protection status on 4 May 2012.
12. The applicant was released from the removal center on the basis of his residence permit on 10 May 2012.
13. The applicant acquired Turkish nationality on 10 September 2012.
14. The applicant had appealed against his detention and ordered continued detention several times citing his subsidiary protection status.

title: CASE OF SERGEYEVA AND PROLETARSKAYA v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The first applicant is the sister of Mr B, who died of AIDS in the Botkin Hospital in St Petersburg on 6 May 2008
2. The second applicant is the mother of Mr P., who died of the same disease in the same hospital on 19 June 2009.
3. The applicants live in Moscow.
4. Mr B. was arrested on suspicion of robbery on 13 October 2004.
5. The Frunzenskiy District Court of St Petersburg authorized his detention pending investigation.
6. Mr B was diagnosed with HIV on the twelfth day of imprisonment on 25 October 2004.
7. Transferred to remand prison no. IZ‑47/1 in St Petersburg in November 2004.
8. Mr B was sentenced to seven years in August 2006 and sent to serve the sentence in correctional colony no. IK-5 in the Leningrad Region.
9. Mr B was diagnosed with tuberculosis in March 2007 and was later diagnosed with an advanced stage of the disease.
10. Mr B was discharged from the hospital and transferred from one prison medical facility to another for anti-tuberculosis treatment until April 2008.
11. Mr B was admitted to prison hospital no. RB-2 in the Republic of Karelia on 2 April 2008.
12. The medical authorities applied for Mr B.’s early release on medical grounds on 22 April 2008.
13. The Medvezhyegorsk Town Court of the Republic of Karelia granted the request on 25 April 2008.
14. Mr B. died in Botkin Hospital in St Petersburg on 6 May 2008.
15. Mr P. was diagnosed with infiltrative tuberculosis of the right lung and admitted to prison medical unit no. 4.
16. Mr P. was sentenced to three years’ imprisonment for robbery and his medical condition worsened.
17. Mr P.'s treatment for tuberculosis continued as prescribed, and the change in medication improved the patient’s lung condition.
18. Mr P. was released on parole and taken to Botkin Hospital.
19. Mr P. was diagnosed with HIV, and he died in the hospital on 19 June 2009 from “an illness caused by the HIV infection”.
20. A Russian non-governmental organization Agora complained of the lack of HIV treatment for detainees, including Mr B. and Mr P.
21. The prosecutor’s office acknowledged that the medical care of Mr B

title: CASE OF ŠIMKUS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1975 and lives in Tauragė.
- On 23 July 2006, officers of the State Border Guard Service arrested three individuals who were suspected of smuggling cigarettes from Russia.
- During the arrests, one of the arrested individuals (K.B.) received a gunshot wound.
- The applicant allegedly threatened to murder or seriously injure law enforcement officers and obstructed and verbally abused them in the exercise of their official duties.
- The pre-trial investigation against the applicant was discontinued for lack of evidence but later reopened.
- The applicant was given an administrative penalty for committing the offence of minor hooliganism.
- Criminal proceedings were later instituted against the applicant for the same conduct.
- The prosecutor initially discontinued the criminal proceedings, but the decision was annulled and the proceedings were reopened.
- The applicant's appeal against the decision to reopen the proceedings was initially upheld but later overruled.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant were ultimately terminated as time-barred by the court.

title: CASE OF KOSHEVOY v. RUSSIA
facts:
Key bullet points of the facts of the case:
- The applicant was born in Kazakhstan in 1946, but was granted Russian nationality in 1997.
- In 2002, the applicant was accused of abuse of office while he was deputy head of the government of the Pavlodar Region of Kazakhstan and was placed on the list of wanted persons by the Interior Department of Pavlodar Region.
- The applicant was arrested in Moscow in 2010 and was subjected to a detention order pending extradition, citing legal provisions of the criminal procedure in Russia.
- The applicant's Russian nationality was annulled in 2006 by a court decision.
- The applicant faced health issues including cardiovascular complications, atherosclerosis, ischaemic heart disease, and other illnesses.
- The applicant received medical treatment from the prison authorities and was granted access to an independent medical practitioner in accordance with Rule 39 of the Rules of Court.
- The applicant's request for release from detention was granted by Kazakh investigative authorities on 18 February 2011; however, the Russian court extended the applicant's detention until 23 March 2011, which was later lifted on 3 March 2011.
- The applicant underwent vascular surgery in a civilian hospital in 2011 and lodged a claim against the detention authorities for unlawful refusal to submit to medical examinations and for violations of granting access to medical care and the applicant's medical file.

title: CASE OF BULUT v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1992 and lives in Istanbul.
- The applicant was arrested on 15 February 2009 on suspicion of involvement in terrorist activities.
- The investigating judge ordered the applicant's remand detention on 18 February 2009.
- The applicant was charged with various crimes including membership of an armed terrorist organization and causing damage to public property on 27 March 2009.
- The court decided to continue the applicant's detention on 5 May 2009.
- The court ordered the continuation of the applicant's detention on 2 October 2009.
- The applicant's requests for release from detention were rejected on 16 February 2010 and 8 June 2010.
- The court dismissed the applicant's objections to rejection of his release from detention on 15 March 2010 and 7 July 2010, respectively.
- The applicant was released from detention on remand on 23 November 2010.
- The case was transferred to the Juvenile Court on 17 October 2010.
- The case is still pending before the Istanbul Anadolu Juvenile Court.

title: CASE OF LUNINA AND MUKHAMEDOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were owners of flats in Moscow and Yekaterinburg
- The municipal authorities reclaimed the flats and annulled the applicants' title to the real property in question
- One of the applicants, Ye., died on 12 December 2003
- An unidentified person using the documents in the name of A. had Ye.'s flat registered as her place of residence and moved into the flat
- On 28 August 2007, the Housing Department transferred the ownership of the flat to A. under the privatization scheme
- On 10 October 2007, A. sold the flat to the other applicant
- The police opened a criminal investigation into the fraudulent acquisition of the flat by A. on 15 February 2010
- The Housing Department brought a civil claim seeking invalidation of all the transactions with the flat, transfer of title to the flat to the City of Moscow, and the applicant's eviction on 16 May 2012
- The Izmailovskiy District Court of Moscow granted the Housing Department's claims in full on 19 December 2012, and the applicant appealed
- The City Court upheld the judgment of 19 December 2012 on appeal on 30 May 2013
- The City Court rejected the applicant's cassation appeal on 11 October 2013
- The flat at 10-94 Ulitsa Shchorsa, Yekaterinburg, was owned by the City of Yekaterinburg
- T. resided there as a tenant under the social housing agreement with the city from 1966 until her death on 16 April 2009
- The municipal authorities were informed of her death and annulled her registration in the flat on 5 May 2009
- On an unspecified date, Tikh. applied to the state registration authorities for the registration of the sale of the flat by T. to her
- The sale was verified and registered by the state authorities, and the title to the flat was transferred to Tikh. on 5 February 2010
- On 11 August 2010, Tikh. sold the flat to the other applicant
- The city administration brought an action seeking the invalidation of all the transactions with the flat on 26 November 2012
- The Leninskiy District Court of Yekaterinburg invalidated the privatization agreement and transferred the title to the City of Yekaterinburg on 19 December 2013

title: CASE OF KOSTECKAS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant and his friends were assaulted at a petrol station by a group of men they did not know, resulting in injuries to the applicant and his friend.
- The police opened an investigation and several suspects were identified and charged.
- The district court initially convicted the suspects, but this conviction was later quashed due to breaches of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and the case was remitted for re-examination.
- After further appeals and remittals, the case was ultimately discontinued due to the statute of limitations having expired.
- The applicant then submitted a civil claim against the suspects, which was partially granted.

title: CASE OF INDEPENDENT NEWSPAPERS (IRELAND) LIMITED v. IRELAND
facts:
- The applicant company publishes the Irish daily newspaper, the Evening Herald.
- The newspaper published a series of articles between 30 November and 17 December 2004 about the awarding of Government contracts to a public relations consultant, Ms L.
- Ms L. was accused of being a supporter of a prominent political figure, Mr C., who was also from the same city as her. 
- Ms L. had been hired as a consultant by the Office of Public Works beginning in November 2001 when Mr C. was the minister responsible for the department of Government. 
- Ms L. was later hired as a consultant by the Government Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government where Mr C. was appointed in mid-2002 to a more senior political position.
- The Evening Herald called into question the tendering procedure, qualifications, high level of remuneration, and amount of work done by Ms L.
- The newspaper referred to eight trips abroad Ms L. had taken as part of the ministerial entourage, including a trip to New York to attend a United Nations conference, and questioned Mr C.'s attendance at the conference.
- The articles suggested rumors of an intimate relationship between Mr C. and Ms L. 
- The story was developed in eleven articles published over two weeks and became headline news, forming the subject-matter of an editorial calling for an inquiry.
- The articles were a serious and sustained attack on Ms. L.’s business and personal integrity.
- Ms L. sued the applicant company for defamation.
- The trial jury found that the newspaper had alleged an extra-marital affair between the plaintiff and Mr C.
- The jury assessed damages at EUR 1,872,000 and the trial judge gave judgment in this amount.
- The awarded damages were found to be excessive and must be set aside.
- The majority of the Supreme Court decided to substitute its own assessment of damages (EUR 1.25 million).

title: CASE OF DNGIKYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Los Angeles.
- The applicant's family lived on the second floor of a house in Yerevan that was built by his grandfather in the 1940s.
- The applicant's uncle sold the first floor of the house to M.G. in the 1970s.
- The applicant moved to the United States with his father in 1993, who left all his property to the applicant when he died.
- In 1997, the applicant submitted his father's will to a notary in Armenia, who issued a certificate of inheritance and registered his title in respect of the second floor of the house.
- In 2003, M.G. sold the first floor of the house to E.T., who then built and ran a restaurant on the property, which was modified without permission from the authorities.
- The applicant lodged a civil claim against E.T., M.G., and the State Real Estate Registry seeking to annul E.T.'s title in respect of the first floor and adjacent land, and to oblige her to demolish the buildings constructed illegally and restore the stone wall that had been destroyed.
- By a judgment of 22 August 2003, the Civil Court of Appeal granted the applicant's claims in their entirety and rejected E.T.'s counterclaim.
- E.T. lodged an appeal on points of law, which was dismissed by the Court of Cassation on 24 October 2003.
- The judgment of 22 August 2003 became final and binding on the day of its delivery.
- Enforcement proceedings were instituted by the Department for the Enforcement of Judicial Acts on 4 December 2003.
- E.T. failed to comply with the decisions in favour of the applicant, and the DEJA imposed fines on her.
- Various measures were initiated by the DEJA, but they did not lead to the full enforcement of the judicial acts in question. 
- The applicant sought criminal proceedings against those responsible for not enforcing the judicial acts in question. 
- Criminal proceedings were terminated several times, and the last termination decision was not pursued by the applicant any further. 
- Enforcement proceedings were closed on 5 September 2016 because the enforcement of the judgments was impossible.

title: CASE OF SHALYAVSKI AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants are four individuals who live together in Blagoevgrad.
- The first applicant suffers from muscular dystrophy and requires assistance for most daily activities.
- The first applicant has been involved in criminal proceedings for usury, abuse, and threatening others.
- On 7 April 2011, the first applicant was stopped by police officers while travelling with his care assistant and was brought to the police station. The care assistant was arrested, and the first applicant remained in the car for several hours.
- While the first applicant was in front of the police station, police officers searched several of his properties, including his home, office and pawnshop.
- The first applicant was brought to the Blagoevgrad Regional Court, where he was placed under house arrest, which was later upheld on appeal.
- Between 8 and 14 April 2011, there were no checks on whether the first applicant was complying with the house arrest. 
- Police officers regularly checked on the first applicant between 16 April and 20 June 2011. 
- On 21 June 2011, the first applicant was released from house arrest due to his health and the progress of the investigation against him.

title: CASE OF CENTRE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF ANALYTICAL PSYCHOLOGY v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Dr Marija Arsovska established a private psychiatric practice in 1995 using Carl Jung’s analytical psychotherapy methods.
- In 2004, the practice signed a contract with the State Health Insurance Fund on the funding of treatment provided by the practice to health insurance beneficiaries.
- The Ministry of Health's State Sanitation and Health Inspectorate conducted an on-site inspection in 2006 and ordered the practice to re-register as a private health institution to comply with amendments to the Health Protection Act of 2004.
- The psychiatrist applied to the Ministry of Health to have the practice re-registered and to change its name, as required by the new statutory provisions.
- The Ministry of Health issued a decision on the registration of the Private health institution Dr Marija Karanfilova’s Specialist Psychiatric Practice in 2006.
- On 29 November 2006, the State Health Insurance Fund notified the new practice that it did not intend to sign a new contract after the expiry of the previous one.
- In 2007, the practice changed from being a private health institution to a limited liability company established by a single person.
- The practice initiated compensation proceedings against the Fund in the Skopje Court of First Instance (Основен суд Скопје) for non-adherence to the terms of the contract.
- The Skopje Court of Appeal on 28 January 2009 granted the Fund’s appeal and remitted the case for fresh consideration.
- The Skopje Court of First Instance dismissed the applicant company’s claim, finding that it had no standing in the proceedings.

title: CASE OF ODEROVS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Riga.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant in 2004 for large-scale smuggling of oil products, in which he was declared a suspect in 2005 and appointed O.S. as his defense counsel. 
- Charges were brought against the applicant in 2006, and he was issued a full copy of his criminal case file in 2007, which included transcripts of his telephone conversations with several individuals, including his defense counsel. 
- The first-instance court convicted the applicant of various crimes, including large-scale smuggling of oil products, aggravated forgery, and money laundering in an organized group, and sentenced him to imprisonment for over five years, but later acquitted him on all counts on appeal. 
- The Latvian Constitution Protection Bureau intercepted the applicant’s telephone conversations with several individuals, including O.S., who was appointed as defense counsel in 2005. The parties disagree as to when the applicant learned about those recordings and whether O.S. was the applicant’s lawyer at the time of those recordings. 
- Interception of the applicant’s telephone conversations was authorized on several occasions by the Supreme Court judge in accordance with domestic law on operational activities. 
- The prosecutor informed the applicant of the legal regulation pertaining to the use of such recordings in criminal proceedings and referred to Article 8 of the Convention and the permissible limitations contained therein. 
- The applicant complained about the lawfulness of the recordings and their use as evidence, as well as the playing back of his telephone conversations with his lawyer at a court hearing. 
- The prosecutor refused to institute criminal proceedings against the investigating prosecutor for violating domestic law regarding the interception of the applicant’s telephone conversations with his lawyer. 
- The applicant’s complaint was ultimately rejected, invoking domestic law and Article 8 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF FROLOVS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant is detained in Riga and charged with various crimes against persons and property.
- Two co-accused testified against the applicant, but later claimed they were coerced by police into making statements.
- A trial lasting several months was held with the applicant and his defense present.
- The court ultimately found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to six years' imprisonment.
- The applicant's lawyer lodged an appeal, but the applicant failed to appear at two appeal hearings and was declared wanted by the police. The appeal was later declined for lack of the applicant's presence.
- The co-accused's allegations of coercion were found not credible by the courts.

title: CASE OF BAYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicants were born in 1974, 1984, and 1977 respectively.
- The first and the third applicants live in Moscow, and the second applicant lives in Gryazy, Lipetsk Region.
- The applicants are gay rights activists and were each found guilty of the administrative offence of “public activities aimed at the promotion of homosexuality among minors”.
- On 3 April 2006, Ryazan Regional Duma passed the Law on Protection of the Morality of Children in the Ryazan Oblast which prohibited public activities that promote homosexuality among minors.
- On 4 December 2008, Ryazan Regional Duma passed the Law on Administrative Offences, which introduced administrative liability for public activities aimed at the promotion of homosexuality among minors.
- On 30 March 2009, the first applicant demonstrated in front of a secondary school in Ryazan, holding two banners promoting homosexuality, and he was charged with an administrative offense for doing so.
- On 6 April 2009, the first applicant was found guilty of breaching section 3.10 of the Ryazan Law on Administrative Offences and was ordered to pay a fine.
- On 30 September 2011, Arkhangelsk Regional Assembly of Deputies passed amendments to the Law on Separate Measures for the Protection of the Morality and Health of Children in the Arkhangelsk Oblast which prohibited public activities promoting homosexuality among minors.
- On 21 November 2011, Arkhangelsk Regional Assembly of Deputies passed amendments to the Regional Law on Administrative Offences which introduced administrative liability for public activities aimed at the promotion of homosexuality among minors.
- On 11 January 2012, the second and the third applicants held a static demonstration in front of the children’s library in Arkhangelsk holding banners which promoted homosexuality among minors, and both applicants were arrested and fined.
- On 7 March 2012, St. Petersburg Legislative Assembly passed amendments to the Law on Administrative Offences in St. Petersburg which introduced administrative liability for public activities aimed at the promotion of homosexuality, bisexuality, and/or transgenderism among minors.
- On 12 April 2012, the third applicant demonstrated in front of the St. Petersburg City Administration, holding up a banner with a popular quote from a famous Soviet-era actress Faina Ranevskaya and was arrested and fined.
- The applicants brought proceedings before the Constitutional Court of the Russian Federation challenging the compatibility of the laws

title: CASE OF BOGOMOLOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Summary of the facts:

- The applicant is a single mother living in Berezniki, Perm region with her son.
- At the time, she worked as a physical education teacher in a secondary school in Berezniki.
- In November 2007, she discovered that her son's photograph had been published without her consent on the cover of a booklet entitled "Children Need a Family" that had been prepared by the Centre for Psychological, Medical and Social Support of the Usolskiy District, Perm region.
- The booklet contained information about adoption, and the photograph of the applicant's son was accompanied by the words "Children need a family".
- The applicant alleged that the publication had damaged her and her son's honour, dignity, and reputation, leading to negative attitudes towards them.
- She requested non-pecuniary damages and an apology from the publishing company.
- The district prosecutor advised the applicant to bring court proceedings to protect her rights.
- The applicant instituted civil proceedings against the Centre and the publishing company.
- The district court dismissed the applicant's claims, stating that the publication did not contain any defamatory details.
- The applicant resigned from her job and appealed the decision, but the regional court upheld the decision of the district court.
- The Centre claimed and received legal costs from the applicant.

title: CASE OF AYCAGUER v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicant attended a rally in 2008 organized by a Basque agricultural trade union and by the GFAM.
- Scuffles broke out between the demonstrators and the gendarmerie.
- The applicant was charged with intentional violence against gendarmes and a person exercising public authority.
- The applicant was sentenced to two months’ imprisonment, suspended, for having struck gendarmes with an umbrella.
- The applicant was ordered by the police to give a DNA sample, on the basis of Articles 706-55 and 706-56 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CPP), and was fined for refusing to give the sample.
- The Bayonne Regional Court imposed on the applicant a fine of five hundred euros.
- The Pau Court of Appeal upheld that judgment.
- The applicant appealed on points of law but his appeal was dismissed by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF MAZNEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their application details is provided.
- The applicants complained about the poor conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF PETROVIĆ v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant filed for the restitution of a hotel confiscated in 1948.
- The claim was dismissed by a commission in June 2004.
- The applicant appealed in July 2004, but the appeal was rejected by a higher commission in November 2004.
- The case went back and forth between administrative bodies and courts for several years.
- In July 2014, the applicant filed a complaint to the Supreme Court about excessive length of proceedings.
- The Supreme Court requested the case file from the Administrative Court, which was forwarded in February 2015.
- In April 2015, the first-instance panel of the Supreme Court found that there had been a violation of the applicant's right to a hearing within a reasonable time and awarded him compensation.
- The Supreme Court asked for assistance from the Ministry of Justice in delivering its decision to the applicant, who lived in Serbia.
- The Ministry of Justice of Serbia informed the relevant Ministry of the respondent State about the date of service of the Supreme Court's decision to the applicant.
- The applicant appealed the decision on grounds of the length of time it took for the court to decide and the amount of compensation awarded.
- In March 2016, the second-instance panel of the Supreme Court ruled partly in favour of the applicant, finding that the proceedings had lasted for over ten years and increasing the compensation awarded.

title: CASE OF KONDRATYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The application's details are listed in a table.
- The applicant was detained for an excessively lengthy period in violation of Article 5 § 3 of the Convention.
- The Government offered to pay the applicant 1,700 euros and requested to strike the application out of the list of cases under Article 37 § 1 (c) of the Convention.
- The Government undertook to pay interest if they fail to pay within three months from the date of notification of the Court’s judgement.
- The applicant agreed to the terms of the declaration. 
- The Government's declaration did not address the applicant’s complaint under Article 5 §§ 4 and 5 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF S.M.M. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- The applicant was born in Zimbabwe and lives in London.
- The applicant arrived in the UK in May 2001 and was granted six months’ leave to enter as a visitor.
- The applicant suffered from mental illness and had at least two suicide attempts in or around 2003.
- The applicant was convicted of several driving offenses, including driving without a license and using an uninsured vehicle, as well as resisting or obstructing a police officer and failing to surrender to custody.
- The applicant's first asylum application was refused in 2005 due to non-compliance grounds.
- The applicant did not appeal this decision and subsequently failed to comply with reporting conditions, making him an absconder.
- The applicant was later convicted of drug possession and sentenced to three years’ imprisonment.
- While serving his sentence, the applicant received treatment for his mental illness for the first time.
- The applicant made a second asylum application in 2008, based on two violent incidents he had experienced in Zimbabwe.
- The applicant was served with a notice of liability to automatic deportation.
- The applicant’s mental health deteriorated significantly, leading to hospitalization and sectioning.
- The detention centre where the applicant was held raised concerns about his mental health.
- The applicant withdrew his bail application in November 2010.
- The applicant made a third asylum claim, challenging his continuing detention on several grounds.
- The applicant's second asylum claim was refused in 2011, followed by a deportation order and dismissed appeal.
- The applicant was released on bail by the Upper Tribunal in September 2011.
- In November 2012, the Upper Tribunal allowed the applicant’s asylum appeal on human rights grounds, and the deportation order was revoked.

title: CASE OF TRANDAFIL AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table containing a list of applicants and relevant application details. 
- The applicants made a complaint about the length of civil proceedings. 
- The applicants claimed that there was no effective remedy available in domestic law.

title: CASE OF KIRILOV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
• List of applicants is provided 

• Inadequate conditions of detention were complained by the applicants 

• Lack of effective domestic remedy was complained by the applicants 

• Relevant details of the applications are mentioned in the appended table

title: CASE OF SHYLO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
• A list of applicants and their relevant details are provided in an appended table.
 
• The applicants were dissatisfied with the lengthy duration of criminal proceedings.
 
• The lack of any effective domestic law remedy was also a point of contention for the applicants.

title: CASE OF KALINICHENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table containing the list of applicants and their relevant details is provided.
- The applicants reported non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions.
- The applicants reported that there is no effective remedy in domestic law to address their complaints.
- In application no. 52256/07, the applicants raised a complaint under Article 8 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF CIRNEROVÁ AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- A claim was lodged in 1987 seeking to declare the plaintiffs as owners of grassland.
- Multiple parties entered the proceedings as defendants over the years.
- The first-instance court had a number of hearings, ordered expert opinions, and heard witnesses.
- The Constitutional Court found a violation of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time and ordered the District Court to proceed without undue delay.
- The District Court delivered a judgment on the merits of the case in 2011, but it was not served on the parties until seven months later.
- The Constitutional Court rejected a fresh complaint in 2013, finding no further undue delays.
- The case file was transferred to the Regional Court in 2013 following an appeal.
- The Regional Court partly upheld the District Court's judgment in 2014 and dismissed the claim concerning some of the contested property.
- Some parties lodged an appeal on points of law, but it was discontinued due to their failure to pay court fees.

title: CASE OF IVAN v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant lodged a claim seeking payment of his wages and interest
- The District Court issued a payment order but the matter fell to be determined in ordinary proceedings after it was challenged
- The District Court took more than eight months to deal with an application by the applicant to change the particulars of claim
- The applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court contesting the length of the proceedings before the District Court
- The Constitutional Court rejected the complaint, stating that the applicant should have lodged a complaint with the President of the District Court before lodging a constitutional complaint
- The District Court appointed an expert in economics, accountancy, and tax, and ordered the applicant to pay fees in advance for the expert evidence
- The appointed expert prepared her opinion between June and September 2015
- The District Court delivered a judgment on March 16, 2016, granting the applicant's claim in part and dismissing the remainder
- The written judgment was delivered to the applicant two months later, but the exact date and any possible further development in the proceedings were not specified by either party in their submissions to the Court.

title: CASE OF BIGASHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a retired World War II veteran with a category 2 disability
- He owns two-thirds of a house with outbuildings and an adjacent plot of land in Izhevsk
- The house and plot of land have been submerged by melted snow and groundwater every year since the municipal authorities repaired the highway and raised the level of the road surface between 2000 and 2002
- The house has been seriously damaged and is no longer habitable
- The applicant brought the first set of proceedings against the municipal authorities in 2004, claiming that a drainage pipe had been installed in breach of technical requirements and had resulted in his house being flooded
- The Industrialnyy District Court held that there was no casual connection between the actions of the municipal authorities and the damage
- The Supreme Court quashed part of the judgment and awarded the applicant compensation for the pecuniary damage sustained
- The bailiffs' service initiated enforcement proceedings, which were terminated in 2009
- The applicant brought a new set of proceedings against the municipal authorities in 2010, claiming that his house had been regularly flooded since the enforcement of the judgment in 2009
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court held that the flooding of the house in spring 2007 had been the fault of the town administration and awarded the applicant compensation for pecuniary damage
- The court ordered the municipal authorities to commission a project for the construction of a drainage pipe and carry out construction works
- The Supreme Court upheld the judgment and enforcement proceedings were instituted in 2013
- The applicant's house was flooded again in spring 2014, but repairs were completed in October 2014
- The bailiffs' service terminated enforcement proceedings and the Oktyabrskiy District Court dismissed the applicant's appeal
- The applicant applied to have his house declared unfit for habitation on account of regular flooding, but the Commission held that structural repairs were possible
- The applicant applied for social housing in 2011 but has not been provided with any accommodation up to the date of examination.

title: CASE OF BAJZÍK AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicants own residential buildings subject to rent-control scheme
- They were obliged to let their flats to tenants while charging no more than the maximum amount of rent fixed by the State
- They cannot unilaterally terminate leases or sell flats to anyone other than respective tenants
- The particulars of the flats affected by the rent control are in Appendices 5 and 6 (columns A - F).
- Their situation is similar to other cases concerning the rent-control scheme in Slovakia.

title: CASE OF RAMLJAK v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Sinj.
- M.R. brought a civil action against the applicant before the Sinj Municipal Court seeking that a will be declared null and void, with representation from lawyers V.Lj. and Ž.V.
- On 8 December 2006, the Sinj Municipal Court adopted a judgment in the applicant’s favour.
- The plaintiff appealed to the Split County Court, led by a panel of three judges presided over by Judge D.P, which reversed the first-instance judgment and upheld the appeal.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court, alleging a lack of fair hearing due to Judge D.P's relationship with a trainee lawyer working at the opposing party's law office.
- On 14 September 2011, the Supreme Court upheld the second-instance judgment, stating that there were no circumstances that put the impartiality of Judge D.P. in doubt.
- The applicant filed a constitutional complaint on 29 June 2012, arguing that N.P's involvement with the opposing party's law office may have affected the outcome of the case.
- The Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible on 3 October 2012.

title: CASE OF LAZARENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicants won cases against domestic pension authorities in first-instance courts
- Defendant authorities appealed to Dnipropetrovsk Administrative Court of Appeal
- Judge rapporteur of Court of Appeal issues ruling opening appeal proceedings if formal requirements are met
- Disagreement between Government and applicants on whether appeal documents were sent to applicants
- Court of Appeal quashed judgments in favour of applicants and dismissed claims for pension increases
- Court hearings were held in the absence of the parties in some cases
- Second to sixth applicants did not have a right to further appeal
- First applicant lodged appeal on points of law with Higher Administrative Court, which upheld Court of Appeal's decision
- Applicants claim they were not informed of appeal proceedings by domestic courts
- Government claims applicants were duly informed of appeal proceedings
- Notification letters and rulings opening appeal proceedings were found in some case files, but no postal documents or registers of sent correspondence were found
- Fifth applicant received a summons to attend a hearing on his case and the court quashed the first-instance court's judgment in his presence.

title: CASE OF BALAN AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicants own residential buildings subject to rent control scheme.
- They were obliged to let their flats to tenants while charging no more than the maximum amount of rent.
- The legislation precluded them from unilaterally terminating the leases or selling the flats to anyone other than the respective tenants.
- The particulars of the flats affected by the rent control are set out in Appendices 3 and 4 (columns A - F).
- The situation of the applicants is similar to cases concerning the rent-control scheme in Slovakia.

title: CASE OF MATUSCHKA AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- Applicants are owners of residential buildings subject to rent-control scheme
- Obliged to let their flats to tenants for no more than the maximum amount of rent fixed by the State
- Precluded from unilaterally terminating the leases or selling flats to anyone other than respective tenants
- Particulars of the flats affected by the rent control are mentioned in Appendices 5 and 6 (columns A - F) 
- The situation of applicants is structurally and contextually the same as Bittó and Others v. Slovakia and subsequently decided cases concerning rent-control scheme in Slovakia
- Examples of relevant cases include Krahulec v. Slovakia, Bukovčanová and Others v. Slovakia, Rudolfer v. Slovakia, Riedel and Others v. Slovakia, and Mečiar and Others v. Slovakia.

title: CASE OF SATAKUNNAN MARKKINAPÖRSSI OY AND SATAMEDIA OY v. FINLAND
facts:
- Satakunnan Markkinapörssi Oy collected data from Finnish tax authorities to publish information about natural persons' taxable income and assets in the Veropörssi newspaper.
- Veropörssi appeared 17 times in 2002 and published data of approximately 1.2 million natural persons.
- The first applicant company cooperated with Satamedia Oy and started transferring personal data published in Veropörssi to the latter in the form of CD-ROM discs to start a text-messaging service (SMS service).
- The Data Protection Ombudsman requested to stop publishing such data, but the applicant companies refused, considering the request a violation of their freedom of expression.
- The Data Protection Board prohibited the applicant companies from processing taxation data, but the Administrative Court rejected the appeal.
- The Data Protection Ombudsman appealed to the Supreme Administrative Court, which referred the case to the CJEU for interpretation of Directive 95/46/EC.
- The CJEU found that the activities in question constituted "processing of personal data" and that the journalistic purposes derogation applied broadly.
- The Supreme Administrative Court quashed the impugned decisions and referred the case back to the Data Protection Board to issue an order to prohibit the processing of taxation data by the applicant companies.

title: CASE OF KRNDIJA v. SERBIA
facts:
- Four applicants were dismissed by their employers.
- They brought separate civil claims against their employers for reinstatement and/or pecuniary damages, which were granted.
- The debtor companies were socially or State-owned and subject to insolvency proceedings.
- Enforcement of the court decisions in favour of the applicants was repeatedly rejected or stalled.
- The proceedings are ongoing at the domestic level and the applicant has not responded to the Court's requests for further action.

title: CASE OF GHIULFER PREDESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is an investigative journalist who was working in Constanţa at the time of the events.
- A violent incident took place in Mamaia on the night of 12-13 August 2006, involving approximately fifty to eighty armed persons who severely damaged several locations in Mamaia, including Hotel F., belonging to R.M., the mayor of Constanţa.
- Following the incident, R.M. participated in a television show hosted by A.G. and broadcast on a national television channel. The applicant intervened and made remarks that R.M. considered defamatory, leading him to institute civil proceedings against the applicant.
- During the television show, the applicant expressed her opinion that Constanţa city was divided between two clans or gangs, namely "M.'s men and those who were against M.", and that R.M. had connections with the V. brothers, who were allegedly behind the violent incident in August 2006.
- R.M. filed a civil complaint against the applicant, seeking a public letter of apology, the publication of the final judgment in two newspapers, and non-pecuniary damages of 200,000 RON. The complaint alleged that the applicant's remarks were defamatory and had seriously damaged R.M.'s image as a public person and a locally elected official.
- The Constanţa District Court dismissed R.M.'s claims, holding that the applicant's statements were not of a severe nature as to harm R.M.'s honour, reputation or dignity, that she had expressed her opinions in good faith and based on objective information, and that her opinions concerned a matter of general interest.
- R.M. appealed against the judgment, and the Constanţa County Court allowed the appeal in part, ordering the applicant to pay non-pecuniary damages of 50,000 RON, legal costs, and to publish the judgment and present R.M. with written public apologies. The court held that the applicant's statements were not opinions but allegations presented in bad faith, lacking factual support and severely damaging R.M.'s image.
- The applicant appealed against the judgment, arguing that her statements were her opinions as an investigative journalist, expressed in an honest and ethical manner. She also argued that the sanction imposed by the court was excessive and lacked appropriate reasoning and justifying criteria.

title: CASE OF MEDVEDEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and is serving a prison sentence in Astrakhan.
- In July 2004 the applicant was charged with murder of V.
- The applicant opted for a jury trial.
- Counsel Sh. was appointed to represent him during investigation and trial.
- On 18 February 2005 the jury delivered a guilty verdict.
- On 21 February 2005 the Regional Court found the applicant guilty of murder and sentenced him to fifteen years’ imprisonment.
- On 6 June 2007 the Presidium of the Supreme Court quashed the appeal judgment of 21 July 2005 by way of supervisory review.
- On an unspecified date the applicant was transferred to Moscow. Counsel R. was appointed to represent him.
- On 16 August 2007 the Supreme Court held a new appeal hearing.
- The court upheld, in substance, his conviction.

title: CASE OF HAJILI AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
1. Demonstrations were planned without prior notice to the relevant authority
2. Applicants attended the demonstrations and were arrested during the dispersal operation
3. Administrative-offence reports were issued to the applicants on the day of arrest
4. Applicants were not given access to a lawyer while in police custody
5. The applicants were convicted and sentenced to pay fines
6. The Baku Court of Appeal upheld the decisions of the first-instance courts
7. Mr. Aliyev, the representative of all three applicants, was arrested and detained pending trial
8. The prosecuting authorities seized all the case files relating to the pending applications
9. The files relating to the cases pending before the Court included copies of all the documents and correspondences between the parties
10. The Nasimi District Court dismissed Mr Aliyev’s claim about the search and seizure of documents.

title: CASE OF ALBERTINA CARVALHO E FILHOS LDA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant company has its registered office in Valongo, Portugal.
- On 18 July 2005, the applicant company filed enforcement proceedings against M.C. before the Valongo Court, seeking payment for a debt of EUR 32,992.99, plus interest.
- A judicial enforcement officer was appointed to the case on 12 October 2005, and M.C. lodged an application opposing the enforcement on 14 December 2005. 
- Information was exchanged between the Valongo Court and the judicial enforcement officer between 15 December 2005 and 3 March 2016.
- The proceedings for opposition to enforcement were joined with the enforcement proceedings on 15 December 2005, and on 30 May 2006, the applicant company replied to the opposition to enforcement proceedings.
- Between 6 February 2007 and 15 August 2008, several procedural steps took place regarding the possible freezing of M.C.'s bank accounts, and on 22 February 2008, the court gave a preparatory decision in the proceedings for opposition to enforcement.
- On 29 November 2010, the applicant company’s lawyer withdrew from the case, and on 14 January 2011, the court was unable to contact the applicant company at the address provided.
- A hearing was scheduled for 30 May 2012, but it was postponed several times due to reasons related to the health of M.C.'s lawyer, and it finally took place on 6 March 2013.
- On 3 January 2012, a new judicial enforcement officer was appointed to the enforcement proceedings, and between 25 September and 11 December 2012, discussions took place regarding the transmission of case documents from the previous officer to the new one.
- On 29 April 2013, the Valongo Court adopted a decision against the applicant company in the proceedings for opposition to enforcement, which was upheld by the Oporto Court of Appeal on 20 May 2014.
- The applicant company appealed against that judgment to the Supreme Court of Justice, but it was rejected on 11 September 2014, and the enforcement proceedings were terminated.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDRAVIČIUS AND OTHERS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Five applicants were born between 1971 and 1986.
- Three applicants are currently detained in Pravieniškės Correctional Facility, one lives in Kupiškis, and one is detained in Alytus Correctional Facility.
- The first applicant was held in Lukiškės Remand Prison for three months and had less than 3.6 square meters of personal space for most of the time.
- The second applicant was held in Lukiškės Remand Prison for two years and had less than 3.6 square meters of personal space for most of the time.
- The third applicant was held in Lukiškės Remand Prison for eleven months and had less than 3.6 square meters of personal space for most of the time.
- The fourth applicant was held in Lukiškės Remand Prison for eighteen months and had less than 3.6 square meters of personal space for most of the time.
- The first, second, and fourth applicants argued that cells were overcrowded and unsanitary.
- The first and fourth applicants argued that they were held together with prisoners who smoked and that the toilets were not separated from the rest of the cell.
- The third applicant complained about his conditions of detention.
- The courts awarded the applicants between LTL 800 (approximately EUR 232) and LTL 5,000 (approximately EUR 1,450) in compensation for non-pecuniary damage on account of overcrowding.
- The applicants' complaints about unsanitary conditions were mostly dismissed as unsubstantiated.

title: CASE OF KĄCKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a journalist who conducted an interview with A.R. regarding a "sex scandal" involving Samoobrona (a political party in Poland).
- A.R. told the newspaper that sexual favors were offered and accepted by public figures in the party.
- The article included quotes from prominent Samoobrona activists, including K.Z., B.S., and K.S., who denied the allegations.
- M.C., a Member of the European Parliament, lodged a private bill of indictment against the applicant for defamation.
- The Warsaw District Court found the applicant guilty of defamation with respect to his publication of the statements made by A.R. concerning nepotism but did not find him guilty of suggesting that M.C. was involved in the "sex scandal".

title: CASE OF DERGALEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Novosibirsk.
- On 10 April 2007, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of robbery and abuse of position.
- On 11 April 2007, the applicant was remanded in custody by the Zheleznodorozhnyy District Court of Novosibirsk.
- The applicant was detained throughout the investigation and trial.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of Novosibirsk found the applicant guilty on 13 April 2009 and sentenced him to nine years’ imprisonment.
- The Novosibirsk Regional Court quashed the judgment on appeal and remitted the case for fresh examination.
- On 14 April 2011, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to nine years’ imprisonment.
- On 5 September 2011, the Novosibirsk Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal.
- On 16 January 2015, the Government acknowledged that the applicant had been detained “without well-founded justification” on the basis of decisions rendered by the courts, which did not comply with Article 5 § 3 of the Convention.
- The Government offered to pay 1,500 euros (EUR) to the applicant as compensation for his pre-trial detention from 18 January 2010 to 14 April 2011.
- On 10 March 2015, the applicant rejected the Government’s offer.

title: CASE OF ICHETOVKINA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were prosecuted and convicted of various offences under the Russian legislation between 2004 and 2008. 
- The appeal courts examined their cases in the absence of their respective counsel and upheld their convictions. 
- Mr Chernenko was ordered to pay the legal fees incurred in respect of his representation in the criminal proceedings, but the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation waived the legal fees. 
- The prosecutor lodged requests for supervisory review of the criminal cases of Ms Ichetovkina and Mr Dubrovskiy after the communication of their applications. 
- The domestic courts acknowledged that the four applicants' right to legal assistance in the appeal proceedings had been breached and their cases were remitted for re-examination.

title: CASE OF SHMATKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The list of applicants and relevant details are in the appended table.
- The applicants complain about non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions.
- The applicants complain about lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Applicant in application no. 20857/05 also has other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF LYSENKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
-List of applicants and relevant details provided in table 

-Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions 

-Applicants argued they did not have an effective domestic remedy for complaints about detention conditions.

title: CASE OF KUDRYAVTSEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:

- The applicants complained about the conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants had additional complaints under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF MEMETOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details in an appended table
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BECHT v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and is detained in the centre for persons in preventive detention on the premises of Schwalmstadt Prison.
- In 1987, the applicant was convicted of various criminal offenses including rape, sexual assault, attempted rape, and aggravated robbery and sentenced to thirteen years’ imprisonment. He was also placed in preventive detention in 1988.
- In 2002, the applicant was placed in preventive detention again upon fully serving his term of imprisonment.
- In 2011, the Marburg Regional Court ordered the extension of the applicant’s preventive detention under Article 67d § 3 of the Criminal Code, which was modified by the Federal Constitutional Court’s judgment of 4 May 2011.
- The Regional Court found a high risk that the applicant would commit serious crimes of violence and sexual offenses if released.
- The applicant had not completed any therapies to reflect on his offenses and suffered from a mental disorder.
- In 2012 and 2013, the Frankfurt am Main Court of Appeal and the Federal Constitutional Court respectively rejected the applicant’s appeal and constitutional complaint.
- The applicant refused any specific therapies addressing his offenses throughout his preventive detention.
- In 2012, the Marburg Regional Court dismissed the prosecution’s request to transfer the applicant to a psychiatric hospital for the further execution of his preventive detention.
- In 2013, the Marburg Regional Court again extended the applicant’s preventive detention.

title: CASE OF GORDEYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details are provided in the table.
- Applicants claim they were denied the opportunity to appear in person before the court.
- The denial of the appearance happened during the civil proceedings where they were involved.

title: CASE OF KOZHOKAR AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their application details in table format.
- Applicants have complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- Some applicants have raised additional complaints under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF PETROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The details of the application are in the appended table. 
- The applicant complained of inadequate conditions of detention. 
- The applicant complained of a lack of medical care while in custody. 
- The applicant relied on Article 13 of the Convention. 
- The applicant alleged that no effective domestic remedies were available to him.

facts:
- List of applicants with relevant details provided in an appended table.
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

- Applicants complained about inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

facts:
- Applicants and relevant details listed in a table.
- Complaints of excessive length of criminal proceedings and lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Applicant in application no. 54467/16 raised a complaint under Article 2 of Protocol No. 4 to the Convention.

facts:
- A list of applicants and relevant details are provided in an appended table.

- The applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF CHEPINOGA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:

- A table with a list of applicants and their application details is appended.
- The applicants claimed that they were not given a chance to appear in person before the court during civil proceedings.

facts:

- Applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention

facts:

facts:

title: CASE OF BADALOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The case involves multiple applicants
- Details and information about applicants are listed in an appended table
- The applicants complained about the length of their pre-trial detention
- Some applicants raised additional complaints under the Convention's provisions.

title: CASE OF SADKOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
Facts of the case:

I. Arrest of the applicant
- The applicant, a former police officer, was arrested on 11 June 2004 for suspected robbery.
- The police used "hand-to-hand combat techniques" and handcuffs to subdue him.
- The applicant was taken to Kotovsk police station.
- The police drew up a report on the applicant's arrest, falsely stating he had "behaved aggressively" and "tried to run away."
- The Kotovsk Town Court found the applicant guilty of resisting the police and ordered his administrative detention for twelve days.

II. Alleged ill-treatment of the applicant
- The applicant claims to have been tortured by police officers to extract a confession.
- The alleged torture included beating, electric shocks, suffocation, insertion of needles under his nails, hanging, and attempted sexual abuse.
- The applicant made self-incriminating statements and statements incriminating others.
- He claims that the police officers would have killed him if he did not confess.
- The police officers also allegedly forced the applicant to retract his complaints of ill-treatment and sign a written statement to that effect.
- The prosecutor's office eventually rejected the complaints as unsubstantiated.

III. Allegedly inadequate medical assistance to the applicant while in detention
- The applicant claims to have been denied adequate medical assistance for various health issues, causing his health condition to deteriorate.
- He lodged multiple complaints concerning his allegedly inadequate medical assistance with a prosecutor's office.
- The prosecutor's office rejected the complaints as unsubstantiated, having studied the applicant's medical file.

IV. The applicant's detention prior to his conviction on 30 March 2007
- The applicant was initially detained on the basis of an administrative offense.
- The Town Court ordered his further detention for two months on the grounds that he may evade investigation or commit a new crime.
- The applicant was detained on various grounds over the course of his pre-trial detention.
- Some periods of the applicant's detention were not covered by any decision at all.
- The applicant alleges that some decisions were taken in violation of procedural norms.

title: CASE OF DAKIR v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicant is a Muslim woman who wears the niqab, a full-face veil except for the eyes, in accordance with her religious beliefs.
- She agreed to remove her veil for identification purposes when required by the authorities.
- The Vesdre district administrative authorities proposed an amendment to the district regulations on wearing the burqa in public.
- The municipal councils of three municipalities belonging to the police district enacted provisions of the consolidated by-laws of the Vesdre police district, prohibiting the wearing of clothing concealing the face at all times and in all public places.
- The applicant lodged an application with the Conseil d’État seeking to annul the provision on the grounds that the ban constituted an interference with her rights guaranteed by Articles 8, 9 and 10 of the Convention and discrimination in breach of Article 14 of the Convention.
- The Conseil d’État dismissed the application for annulment of the provision.

title: CASE OF T.G. v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant asked to renew his firearms license for hunting purposes in February 2011.
- The police conducted a background check and found that the applicant had often been under the influence of alcohol when visiting Croatia.
- The police dismissed the applicant's request for renewal of his firearms license on the grounds of alcohol abuse.
- The Ministry of the Interior upheld the decision to dismiss the applicant's request for renewal of his firearms license.
- The administrative court dismissed the applicant's administrative action and upheld the decisions of the administrative bodies refusing to renew the applicant's firearms license.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's constitutional complaint as unfounded.

title: CASE OF Ž.B. v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint against her husband, alleging multiple acts of domestic violence.
- The police found evidence of psychological and physical violence and forwarded the complaint to the State Attorney's Office.
- B.B. was indicted and found guilty by the Municipal Court, but the decision was quashed and remitted for further examination twice by the S. County Court.
- In the final resumed proceedings, the Municipal Court discontinued the proceedings because the criminal offence of domestic violence had been abolished by the 2011 Criminal Code.
- The State Attorney's Office did not challenge the decision, but the applicant lodged an appeal, which was declared inadmissible by the S. County Court.

title: CASE OF M.S. v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant had a relationship with a female student named V. and they had a daughter together.
2. The couple lived together in the applicant’s flat in Sumy with his parents' assistance in bringing up the child.
3. V. and the applicant were absent for work abroad at different times, with the child left in the care of the applicant and his parents.
4. In September 2011, after a quarrel with the applicant, V. moved away from the flat with their child without informing the applicant of their whereabouts.
5. The applicant and his parents conducted their own enquiries to locate the child's whereabouts and later found her in a child-minding center in the village of Bezdryk with bruises on her body.
6. The applicant reported the injuries to the police and attempted to initiate a criminal investigation, but was denied on several different occasions due to a lack of substantial evidence.
7. The applicant's mother requested that an investigation be opened in respect of the alleged child sexual abuse against V. and her uncle, F.
8. The child was interviewed multiple times and testified that F. had touched her genitals and taught her how to kiss in an adult manner.
9. Despite further investigation, the police were unable to substantiate the allegations and the criminal proceedings were closed due to a lack of corpus delicti.
10. The marriage between the applicant and V. was dissolved with the child living with V. in accordance with the court ruling.
11. The court established that both parents provided adequate residential conditions for the child and she had an equal attitude towards both of them.

title: CASE OF ORAVEC v. CROATIA
facts:
1. Applicant arrested on suspicion of trafficking illegal substances
2. Investigating judge orders pre-trial detention for 48 hours
3. Another investigating judge orders detention for one month due to risk of reoffending and lack of lawful means of subsistence
4. Decision on detention upheld on appeal
5. Applicant released following new evidence and re-examination by the investigating judge
6. Osijek County State Attorney's Office appeals and detention is extended
7. Applicant lodges appeal with Supreme Court, but it's declared inadmissible
8. Constitutional complaints lodged, but also declared inadmissible
9. Indictment issued by Osijek County State Attorney's Office
10. Applicant's detention is extended again
11. Charges against the applicant are dropped and he is released
12. Applicant requests settlement for wrongful detention, but it's not reached
13. Applicant brings claim for damages and is awarded non-pecuniary damages

title: CASE OF ŠIDLAUSKAS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant bought an apartment in Jonava in 1994
- In 1998, he lost his job and could not pay for utilities
- In 2000, the utility provider instituted civil proceedings against the applicant regarding his debt of LTL 2,861 (approximately EUR 828.60)
- The bailiff decided to direct enforcement against the applicant's apartment and sold it for LTL 3,390 (approximately EUR 982) in a public auction
- The applicant has not had a permanent home since the public auction
- The applicant claimed damages jointly from the bailiff and the bailiff’s professional liability insurer
- The Jonava District Court dismissed the applicant’s claim
- The Kaunas Regional Court allowed the applicant’s claim in its entirety
- The court held that the bailiff acted in violation of domestic law
- The applicant was awarded damages of LTL 51,000 (approximately EUR 14,770)
- The bailiff’s professional liability insurer appealed the decision
- The Supreme Court upheld the conclusion that the sale of the applicant’s apartment had been unlawful
- The Supreme Court awarded the applicant damages of LTL 12,100 (approximately EUR 3,504) after subtracting his debt and the bailiff’s enforcement expenses.

title: CASE OF NIKOLAY GENOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lived in Pazardzhik.
- The police searched the applicant’s home on 10 January 2007 and found five counterfeit one hundred dollar bills.
- The applicant was charged with acquiring and possessing counterfeit bills under Article 244 §§ 1 and 2 of the Criminal Code.
- The second charge was dropped, and the prosecutor indicted the applicant for acquiring the notes in the period between 2002 and 10 January 2007, knowing they were counterfeit. The applicant denied knowledge of their counterfeit status.
- The Regional Court convicted the applicant of acquiring counterfeit notes between 26 March 2005 and 10 January 2007 and acquitted him of acquiring the notes between 2002 and 26 March 2005.
- The Regional Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to a suspended sentence of two years’ imprisonment for another crime.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that there was no evidence substantiating the conclusion of his knowledge of notes being counterfeit when he bought them in 2002.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the Regional Court’s judgment.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation upheld the Court of Appeal’s judgment without commenting on the applicant’s argument that it wasn't proven that the counterfeit notes were acquired after 26 March 2005.

title: CASE OF VELKOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant signed a contract with a municipally-owned company in 1993 to set up a shop, which was extended numerous times.
- In 1996, the applicant requested to purchase the first floor of the shopping centre but was refused by the municipal council in 1997.
- The applicant challenged the refusal in court, and in 2004, the Kardzhali Regional Court instructed the council to open a privatisation procedure under which the applicant would be offered the option to buy the first floor of the shopping centre under preferential conditions.
- On 8 May 2001, the mayor of Kardzhali terminated the applicant's contract, and on 4 June 2001, ordered the applicant's eviction from the shop. The applicant appealed, and the Burgas District Court suspended the enforcement of the order.
- On 24 September 2001, the mayor issued another order for the applicant's eviction. The municipal council broke into the shop and took possession of it. The applicant complained to the district prosecutor, but they refused to intervene or open criminal proceedings.
- In 2005, the applicant requested the municipal council to open a privatisation procedure, and they did so in 2006, but it was found that the shopping centre had not been divided into separate property units.
- In 2008, the municipal council authorised the sale of a part of the first floor of the shopping centre to the applicant, and in 2014, the remaining part of the first floor was also sold to the applicant.
- On 12 September 2014, the applicant leased one of her recently acquired property units to a third party for 20 years for EUR 50,000.

title: CASE OF JUGHELI AND OTHERS v. GEORGIA
facts:
- Applicants are Georgian nationals born in 1946, 1947 and 1957
- Applicants lived in a residential block near a thermal power plant
- The power plant was built in 1911 and reconstructed later
- Several accidents have occurred at the plant
- The plant emitted toxic substances into the atmosphere, affecting applicants' well-being
- Applicants lodged complaints with municipal authorities about nuisances from the plant, including air, noise, and electromagnetic pollution and water leakage
- City Hall acknowledged the residents had been affected by the nuisances and suggested compensation 
- Applicants brought an action for damages against the plant and reached a friendly settlement in December 2000, which was left unenforced
- Applicants brought a fresh action for compensation for harm caused to their health and well-being
- Court-commissioned expert examinations measured environmental pollution and impact on claimants' health
- Expert opinions revealed the plant did not have appropriate filters and purification equipment, that pollution levels exceeded acceptable limits, and that certain diseases might have been caused by the pollution
- Tbilisi Regional Court dismissed the case, but acknowledged the plant was responsible for the infiltration of water into the building and awarded compensation to two claimants for noise pollution
- The Supreme Court upheld the decision on noise pollution and ordered compensation for the deterioration of health caused by noise to two successful claimants, but dismissed the other complaints as unsubstantiated.

title: CASE OF ALISOY AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Applicants' dates of birth and places of residence listed in Appendix
- Applicants were opposition-oriented activists
- First applicant was a member of Popular Front Party of Azerbaijan and participated in peaceful demonstrations, resulting in arrests and convictions
- İctimai Palata held a peaceful demonstration on 12 October 2013 in Mahsul stadium to protest against alleged irregularities and fraud during presidential elections
- All three applicants participated in the demonstration
- After the demonstration, the applicants were arrested at the entrance to a nearby metro station, Inshaatchilar
