- Circumstances of arrests, custody, and administrative proceedings against them are similar to previous cases (Huseynli and Others v. Azerbaijan and Huseynov and Others v. Azerbaijan)

title: CASE OF ABBAS AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Applicants' personal information provided in the Appendix
- First applicant was chairman, fourth applicant was deputy chairman of opposition party Musavat, third applicant was member of the Popular Front Party of Azerbaijan, and second applicant was a member of the Coordination Council of an opposition group İctimai Palata
- Applicants participated in peaceful demonstrations demanding democratic reforms and free and fair elections, protesting against impediments on freedom of assembly
- Organizers of several demonstrations gave notice to relevant authorities, but authority proposed different location and organizers decided to proceed as planned
- Fourth applicant organized a rally to mark Independence Day and honor the memory of the buried in the Cemetery of Martyrs in the town of Goychay but rally did not take place
- Police began to disperse demonstrations as soon as protesters began to gather, and applicants were arrested and subjected to custody and subsequent administrative proceedings
- Similar circumstances related to the dispersal of demonstrations, arrests, and custody of applicants are mentioned in other cases
- The first and third applicants were subjected to ill-treatment by the deputy chief of the Nasimi District Police Office and submitted evidence of injuries
- Ill-treatment complaints were raised during administrative proceedings but appellate court disregarded them
- Applicants lodged a complaint with the General Prosecutor’s Office to conduct an investigation into alleged ill-treatment, and investigator adopted decisions refusing to open criminal proceedings against the third and first applicants
- Applicants were not informed about any actions taken by authorities to investigate their ill-treatment complaints, and they did not lodge a complaint with a supervising court against those decisions.

title: CASE OF SHULI v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant was convicted of forming a criminal organization, kidnapping an adult, robbery, theft, and illegal possession of a gun in 2007.
- He was represented by a lawyer during the proceedings.
- He expressed his wish to lodge an appeal after the delivery of the judgment and was escorted to the court registry to do so.
- The pre-printed forms for lodging an appeal required the inclusion of reasons for the appeal, which the applicant did not provide.
- The applicant was briefly released from handcuffs to sign the appeal form.
- His appeal was dismissed as inadmissible by the five-member Court of Appeal because it lacked reasons for the appeal.
- The President of the Appeal Court disagreed and believed the applicant was complaining about the erroneous assessment of evidence in the first-instance court.
- The applicant appealed on points of law, arguing that his appeal should not have been dismissed.
- The Court of Cassation dismissed his appeal as unfounded because the content of the appeal was his responsibility.
- The applicant served his sentence until 2015, when he was conditionally released.

title: CASE OF ROOMAN v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and is detained in the Paifve social-protection institution (“the Paifve EDS”).
- In 1997, the applicant was convicted of theft and sexual assault by the Liège Court of Appeal and the Eupen Criminal Court, respectively. The prison sentences were due to end on 20 February 2004.
- In June 2003, the applicant’s preventive detention was ordered pursuant to section 7 of the Law of 9 April 1930 on Social Protection in respect of Mental Defectives, Habitual Offenders and Persons Convicted of certain Sexual Offences (the “Social Protection Act”).
- On 15 January 2004, the Minister of Justice also decided that the applicant was to be detained in a psychiatric institution, pursuant to section 21 of the Social Protection Act.
- The applicant made an initial application for release on a trial basis, which was postponed until March 2006 by the CDS.
- The CDS held that Mr Rooman’s detention was unlawful as no treatment was provided to him, no institution in Belgium could meet the security and language requirements in the applicant’s case and that his preventive detention requires treatment per section 14 (2) of the Act.
- The applicant applied for day release, and the CDS ordered a new expert report accompanied by a plan for release on a trial basis. However, it adjourned examination of the request sine die as treatment was not provided to the applicant.
- The CDS invited the Eupen remand prison to prepare for release on a trial basis and asked to find a clinic that could provide home-based therapy to Mr Rooman.
- The applicant made an urgent application to the President of the Liège Court of First Instance, but failed.
- On 27 May 2010, the CSDS upheld the CDS's decision of 29 April 2010 to maintain the applicant in detention. The Court of Cassation dismissed the appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF ZAKHARKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Surgut, Khanty‑Mansiyskiy Region, Russia.
- The applicant was the leader of a trade union in a private company.
- His co-workers expressed a wish to hold a public assembly on Constitution Day on 12 December 2009 and the applicant decided to help them.
- The applicant distributed banners and explained that it would be more practical to stage solo demonstrations.
- To avoid prosecution for holding a public assembly without notifying the authorities in advance, the applicant suggested that his co-workers position themselves at some distance from each other on different streets.
- The applicant was then arrested and taken to the police station, where he was held for three hours.
- On 18 December 2009 a justice of the peace found him guilty under Article 20.2 § 1 of the Code of Administrative Offences (“the CAO”) and fined him 1,500 Russian roubles (RUB) (35 euros at the time).
- The court considered that the applicant and his co-workers had met in one place and therefore had violated the requirement to lodge a prior notification about this event to the competent authority as required by section 7 of the Public Events Act (“the PEA”).
- The applicant appealed the decision, questioning the legality of considering him as an organizer of a group event.
- On 22 January 2010 the Surgut Town Court upheld the judgment.

title: CASE OF SKLYAR v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975, lived in Novosibirsk and was convicted of aggravated theft and armed robbery in 2010.
- He was sentenced to nine years' imprisonment by the Kalininskiy District Court and represented by a lawyer in those proceedings.
- His appeal against the conviction was dismissed by the Novosibirsk Regional Court, where he appeared without counsel.
- The applicant has been serving his sentence in the IK-8 facility in Novosibirsk, starting from 10 February 2011.
- The Unit where the applicant was detained changed over time, and the conditions varied as follow:
	- from 10-15 February 2011, the applicant was in Quarantine section 50.2, with 6-24 inmates, 24 square meters, and two washbasins and lavatories.
	- from 15 February – 30 May 2011, he was in Unit no. 17, with 219 inmates, 100-108 sleeping places, and eight washbasins and ten lavatories.
	- from 30 May 2011 – February 2013, he was in Unit 7, which the Government does not provide information.
- The Government submitted information indicating that there were a sufficient number of sleeping places, access to cold water, and ten to fifteen kettles to boil water per unit.
- The applicant disputed the hygiene and safety conditions, ventilation, and lighting, dampness, inadequate food, and lack of privacy due to only three lavatories, which had no doors.
- The applicant deemed the buildings as hazardous and submitted fellow inmates' statements to confirm his account about the conditions of detention in IK-8 in Novosibirsk.

title: CASE OF OLÁH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant's birth year is 1970 and lives in Budapest.
- Applicant was employed at the State-owned National Infocommunication Services Ltd.
- Applicant’s employment was terminated on 7 January 2012.
- Severance payment was taxed at a 98% rate.
- Taxation applied on the part exceeding 3.5 million HUF.
- The amount of HUF 3,424,359 (approximately 11,400 EUR) was taxed.

title: CASE OF KÖRTVÉLYESSY v. HUNGARY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant notified the police of a planned demonstration on 10 October 2009.
- A police officer attempted to contact the applicant to arrange a meeting but was unable to reach him.
- The head of the Budapest Police Department banned the demonstration on the grounds of traffic issues.
- The applicant sought judicial review but was dismissed by the Budapest Regional Court.
- The court agreed that the right to assembly is not absolute and can be restricted to avoid violating the fundamental rights of others. The police had adequately established the facts, complied with procedural rules, and made a logical assessment of evidence.

title: CASE OF LENGYEL v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Budapest.
- The applicant was placed in retirement on grounds of disability and received a disability pension as of 1 November 2006.
- The amount of the disability pension was 91,363 Hungarian forints (HUF) (approximately 305 euros (EUR)) per month.
- The entitlement was based on a final decision of the Supreme Court, and the medical board rated her state of health at 46 per cent.
- The methodology for disability assessment changed as of 1 January 2008.
- Act no. CXCI of 2011 on the Benefits Granted to Persons with Reduced Work Capacity was enacted on 29 December 2011 and entered into force as of 1 January 2012.
- The new law introduced a new system of allowances, and beneficiaries of the old scheme were invited to re-apply under the new rules.
- The applicant lodged a fresh application for disability allowance under the new law.
- Pending approval of her new application, she continued to receive a monthly disability allowance.
- On 29 June 2012, the National Rehabilitation and Social Authority assessed the applicant’s state of health at 59 per cent.
- The applicant’s rehabilitation allowance was established at 45 per cent of the minimum wage, given on 19 September 2012 and effective as of 1 December 2012.
- The applicant appealed, and a medical assessment carried out in the course of the second-instance administrative proceedings resulted in the finding that the applicant’s state of health was at 58 per cent.
- The National Rehabilitation and Social Authority upheld the first-instance decision on 17 January 2013.
- On 23 February 2016, the Budapest Administrative and Labour Court dismissed her action.
- On 12 September 2016, the Kúria dismissed the applicant’s petition for review.
- The applicant submitted that, as of August 2015, she no longer received any benefits. The legal or factual circumstances underlying this state of affairs are not known.

title: CASE OF MALAYEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are a father (born in 1981) and his son (born in 2006) who lived in Moscow.
- The flat at 4-1-25, 12-ya Novokuzminskaya Ulitsa, Moscow, was previously owned by the City of Moscow and was rented by V.F. and G.F. under a social housing agreement.
- V.F. applied for the privatisation of the flat, signed the agreement on August 22, 2002, and sold the flat to L.M. (the first applicant's mother) on May 14, 2004, for RUB 300,000 according to the sale contract.
- L.M. died on September 28, 2006, and the first applicant inherited the flat. V.F. continued to live in the flat officially.
- In July 2007, the first applicant gifted the title to half of the flat to his sister.
- On April 22, 2011, V.F. lodged a complaint, claiming that he had not sold the flat to L.M. and that he had not received RUB 2,500,000 from her.
- On July 5, 2011, the prosecutor acting as V.F.'s representative brought a civil action to evict the first applicant's family and to annul their title to the flat.
- On November 15, 2012, the Kuzminskiy District Court of Moscow granted the claims, invalidated all transactions with the flat, and transferred ownership to the City of Moscow. The court ordered the applicants' eviction.
- On January 30, 2014, the applicants were evicted and V.F. was given the keys to the flat.
- On April 16, 2014, V.F. signed a social housing agreement with the Housing Department and owned the flat under the privatisation scheme on November 20, 2014.

title: CASE OF McILWRATH v. RUSSIA
facts:
Facts about the applicant and the family:

- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Sesto Fiorentino, Italy.
- In 1997, the applicant married M.G. in New York, who held joint American and Russian nationality. On 3 October 1997, M.G. gave birth to their son.
- In 1998, the family moved to Italy where three more children were born - two sons and a daughter. All four children have joint American and Russian nationality.
- In September 2007, the applicant and M.G. separated.
- On 18 June 2009, the applicant applied for a divorce.
- While the divorce proceedings were ongoing, on 27 August 2011, M.G. took the children and left Italy for Russia.

Facts related to attempts to bring the children back to Italy:

- Since the removal of the children, the applicant has travelled to Russia over fifty times, trying to bring them back to Italy and maintain contact with them. However, M.G. has prevented him from doing so.
- The case file material indicates that the applicant saw the children on several occasions at their school in 2012 when he taught English there on a voluntary basis.
- While exercising his contact rights in accordance with a judgment of 13 May 2014, on 24 August 2014, the applicant took his second-born son and left Russia for Italy. He never returned the child to the mother and has not seen his other children since.
- Since 2014, the applicant’s eldest son has been living in Israel. The applicant’s daughter and youngest son continue to live with their mother in Russia.

Facts related to interim decisions concerning the children’s placement in care and residence arrangements pending the conclusion of the divorce proceedings:

- On 19 December 2009, the Florence District Court ordered that while the divorce proceedings were ongoing, the four children should be placed in the care of social services, the children should reside with their mother, and the applicant should pay her child maintenance.
- On 6 December 2010, the Florence District Court varied the arrangements related to residence and who had care of the children. It ordered that while the divorce proceedings were ongoing, the applicant should have sole care of the four children and the children should reside with him. It further ordered that the three younger children were to spend weekends with their mother in a specific manner.
- On 25 March 2014, the Florence Court of Appeal quashed the judgment of

title: CASE OF S.A. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Balatonrendes.
- The applicant served as a civil servant from 21 December 1998 until 28 February 2013.
- The termination of his service resulted in severance payment being taxed at a 98% rate.
- The amount of tax was 1,861,703 Hungarian forints (HUF) (approximately 6,200 euros (EUR)).

title: CASE OF M.Z. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant's birth year is 1974 and he lives in Vác.
- The applicant was employed at a State-owned company from January 1, 2010, until February 19, 2013.
- Part of his severance payment was taxed at a 98% rate.
- The taxed amount was 19,349,120 Hungarian forints (HUF), approximately equivalent to 64,500 euros (EUR).

title: CASE OF S.A. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant's birth year is 1973 and he lives in Budapest.
- The applicant worked as a civil servant at a police department from September 15, 1993 until March 17, 2013.
- Upon the termination of his service, part of his severance payment was taxed at a 98% rate.
- The taxed amount was 2,785,866 Hungarian forints (HUF), which is approximately 9,300 euros (EUR).

title: CASE OF LAKICS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Budapest.
- On 15 September 2008, Mr F.G. filed an action against the applicant before the Sátoraljaújhely District Court for dissolution of joint ownership.
- On the same day, the court suspended the proceedings pending the adjudication of a preliminary question in other proceedings.
- The Sátoraljaújhely District Court continued hearing the case on 12 April 2011 upon termination of the other proceedings.
- On 19 November 2012, the Sátoraljaújhely District Court delivered its judgment.
- The first-instance court's judgment became final and binding on 18 December 2012.

title: CASE OF I.B. AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants were all employed at a State-owned limited liability company.
- Their employment was terminated as of 3 July 2012.
- Each applicant received a severance payment that was subject to the 98% special tax.
- The amount of the special tax varied for each applicant.
- The fifth applicant's tax burden was different due to subsequent amendments of the relevant legislation.
- The eighth applicant withdrew their application.
- The overall tax burden imposed on the applicants' severance payments was 30.7%.

title: CASE OF HAZNI BAYAM v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was detained at Gaziantep Prison at the time of the application.
- The Mersin Magistrates' Court decided to restrict access to the ongoing investigation file on 26 December 2011.
- The applicant was arrested on 29 December 2011 for suspicion of being a member of a terrorist organization and making propaganda, and his police statement was taken in the presence of his lawyer. 
- The Mersin Magistrates' Court ordered the applicant's detention on remand on 30 December 2011.
- The Adana public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment against the applicant on 10 September 2012, and the proceedings are still pending before an assize court.

title: CASE OF NINA KUTSENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant's son suffered from chronic alcoholism and opium addiction.
- The son was apprehended on suspicion of drugs-related offence by a police officer.
- The son complained of psychological pressure and physical ill-treatment by the police officers.
- The son was treated for opium addiction in the hospital.
- The son left home and was found unconscious and uninjured in a hospital.
- The son left the hospital without authorization and was found injured and unconscious at the railway station.
- The son had been beaten and kicked by police officers while in detention.
- The son was taken to a hospital where he was diagnosed with closed craniocerebral injury and cerebral contusion and contused wounds to the head.
- The son showed a serious deterioration in his condition, but the medical staff did not react.
- The son slipped into a coma and died due to toxic hypoxic encephalopathy.
- The applicant identified her son from photographs of his body bearing signs of torture.
- The investigation was entrusted to various prosecution and law-enforcement authorities at different times.

title: CASE OF KOROTYAYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals living in different regions of Russia.
- They obtained judicial decisions ordering the State authorities to provide them with housing or perform other obligations in kind.
- The judgments became final on different dates and either were enforced with a delay or have remained unenforced.
- The applicants applied to different Russian authorities to accelerate the enforcement of the judgments in their favour.
- One applicant challenged the lawfulness of his dismissal from military service alleging that the judicial award in his favour had not been complied with.
- The military court established that the judgment of May 28, 2007, had been enforced in full on March 25, 2010.

title: CASE OF YELISEYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant failed to declare his Opel car when entering Russia, infringing Russian customs regulations.
- The applicant was fined for the infringement and his car was impounded.
- The applicant's appeal against the fine was unsuccessful, and subsequent appeals were dismissed.
- The enforcement proceedings were discontinued due to the expiry of the relevant time limit.
- The applicant failed to reclaim his car within the given time period, and it was certified as bona vacantia.
- The regional agency sought to reclaim the applicant's car and was successful in court.
- The applicant participated in an unauthorized rally in March 2012 and chanted slogans against Putin.
- The applicant was fined for violating the established procedure for organizing a public assembly.

title: CASE OF MUSTAFA SEZGİN TANRIKULU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was a member of the Turkish parliament and president of the Diyarbakır Bar Association.
- The National Intelligence Agency of Turkey (“MİT”) had been intercepting the telephone conversations and email correspondence of a number of people on the basis of approximately ninety court decisions over the previous ten years, stopping after March 2005 to wait for the new Criminal Code but continuing after the Kuşadası bomb attack in March.
- The Diyarbakır Assize Court granted the MİT permission, resulting in the interception of all electronic communications for a specific period, including domestic and international telephone calls and communications provided by national telecommunications company Turk Telekom, private mobile network operators, Internet providers, SMS, MMS, GPRS, and fax communications, caller IDs, correspondents’ IP addresses, and communication-related information.
- The applicant filed a criminal complaint against the judge, public prosecutor, and MİT agents involved in obtaining and implementing the decision.
- The prosecution of MİT officials required the Prime Minister’s permission, and subsequently, the Diyarbakır Principal Public Prosecutor decided not to prosecute the MİT officials who had implemented the Diyarbakır Assize Court’s decision.
- The applicant filed an objection, but the Siverek Assize Court dismissed the objection.
- The Ministry of Justice decided not to take action against the public prosecutor and the judge, stating that their acts fell within judicial discretion and that the aim was to locate terrorists and take necessary security measures.

title: CASE OF JOVOVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant lodged a claim for damages with the Court of First Instance in Nikšić on an unspecified date.
- On 23 June 2008, the Court of First Instance ordered the debtors to pay the applicant, jointly, 45,000 euros (EUR) plus statutory interest. 
- On 27 July 2009 the applicant lodged with the Court of First Instance in Podgorica a request for enforcement of the judgment dated 23 June 2008.
- On 24 April 2010, the debtors objected to the enforcement order, but their objections were rejected.
- Between March 2011 and March 2012, the applicant availed himself of two domestic remedies concerning the length of the proceedings. 
- On 6 August 2013, the applicant informed the enforcement court that the second debtor had paid him EUR 31,000 and that he considered the enforcement proceedings in respect of this debtor as final. 
- On 20 October 2015 the first debtor’s father informed the enforcement court that he would pay his son’s debt.
- In December 2015 the applicant was once again invited to take possession of the movable assets belonging to the first debtor, but he explicitly rejected the court’s offer. 
- The High Court in Podgorica ruled against the applicant’s actions for fair redress on 11 May 2011, 24 November 2011, and 10 May 2012.

title: CASE OF VILKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and details included in the appended table
- Applicants complained about inadequate conditions of their detention
- Some applicants also raised other complaints under the Convention provisions

title: CASE OF MIRZAYEV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Applicants' personal information is given in the Appendix.
- The second and third applicants were members of different opposition groups.
- The first and second applicants participated in a demonstration despite the refusal of the Baku City Executive Authority to authorise it at the intended location.
- The second and third applicants participated in three different demonstrations without giving prior notice to the BCEA.
- The demonstrations were meant to protest for democratic reforms, free and fair elections, soldier deaths, police use of force, and commemoration of victims of a terrorist attack.
- The police dispersed each demonstration as soon as protesters gathered.
- The circumstances of the arrests, custody, and subsequent administrative proceedings against the applicants are similar to other cases (Gafgaz Mammadov v. Azerbaijan and Bayramov v. Azerbaijan).

title: CASE OF ANTONOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table is appended with the list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants raised complaints about the poor conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BADALYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Metsamor.
- The applicant was arrested on 23 July 2011 on suspicion of threatening to use violence against the investigator in charge of the criminal case against his ex-wife.
- On 25 July 2011, the applicant was charged with the same crime, and the investigator filed for the applicant to be detained for two months.
- On 11 August 2011, the Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal against the detention order.
- The applicant's criminal case was set for trial on 13 September 2011, and his detention was ordered to remain unchanged.
- On 13 December 2011, the Regional Court dismissed the applicant's motion to be released.
- On 4 June 2012, the Regional Court dismissed another motion by the applicant seeking release.
- On 6 August 2012, the Regional Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to one and a half years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF LORENZ v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant shot his cousin three times in the chest and stomach, then decapitated him and disposed of his head.
- The applicant shot and killed his former girlfriend and her mother with the same gun used in the previous murder.
- The applicant was found criminally responsible for his acts and sentenced to twenty years’ imprisonment in addition to detention in an institution for mentally ill offenders.
- The applicant has been detained in such institutions since 1984.
- The applicant repeatedly applied for release from detention but was refused due to the danger he still poses to society.
- The applicant refused to undergo therapy and did not collaborate with experts and authorities, which made it impossible to prepare him for release.

title: CASE OF GOLIMBIYEVSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The application details are provided in an appended table.
- The applicant complains about the excessive length of pre-trial detention.
- The applicant raises another complaint under Article 6 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BAGNOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The list of applicants and relevant details given in an appended table.
- The applicants complained of inadequate detention conditions.
- In application no. 26708/13, the applicant raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF POLOMKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is an appended table containing a list of applicants and their relevant application details.
- The applicants had complaints regarding the poor detention conditions.
- The applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BILOZOR AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document includes a table with a list of applicants and relevant details of the applications.
- The applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- The applicants complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- In some applications, the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF HOVHANNISYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Yerevan. 
- The applicant is a former deputy head of Vardashen prison in Armenia. According to the applicant, his father is an opposition activist. 
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on the basis of a complaint by an inmate who alleged that he had been beaten by the applicant and two other prison officers. 
- The prosecutor’s office initially imposed a preventive measure of an undertaking not to leave the applicant's place of residence, which was later lifted. 
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of abuse of power accompanied by violence, charged with the same offence, and detained on remand. 
- The applicant’s appeal against the decision to detain him was dismissed by the Court of Appeal. 
- The district court granted the investigator’s application and extended the applicant’s detention. 
- The applicant’s appeal against the extension of his detention was also dismissed by the Court of Appeal. 
- The same charge as the one against the applicant was brought against two other prison officers as a preventive measure of an undertaking not to leave their places of residence. 
- The investigation was concluded, and the case was sent to the Criminal Court of Yerevan, which decided to set the case down for trial. 
- During the trial, the applicant applied to change the preventive measure, which was dismissed by the examining judge. 
- The Criminal Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to two years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF BALANDINA AND ANDREYKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table is appended with a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.
- In application no. 29432/08, an additional complaint was raised under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BABAYEV AND HASANOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
1. The applicants were members of opposition groups and participated in peaceful demonstrations. 
2. They were arrested and convicted multiple times under Article 310.1 of the Code of Administrative Offences for failing to comply with police orders to disperse. 
3. The demonstrations were dispersed by police even though the organizers had given notice to the authorities. 
4. The applicants were not given access to a lawyer after their arrest or during their detention. 
5. The hearings before the first-instance court were brief, and state-funded lawyers were appointed to represent the applicants. 
6. The applicants were found guilty, convicted, and sentenced to various periods of administrative detention. 
7. Their appeals to the Baku Court of Appeal were dismissed, and the decisions of the first-instance court were upheld.

title: CASE OF MAGÁT v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Zákopčie.
- On 28 February 2011, the applicant was sued by his son in proceedings on child maintenance before the Čadca District Court (file no. 10 C 38/2011).
- The District Court asked several public authorities to provide it with information relevant to the case.
- The District Court appointed a guardian to the applicant before revoking the appointment in September 2014.
- The District Court joined the present case file to another set of proceedings for several months.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the applicant’s complaint about a violation of his right to a hearing within a reasonable time in the proceedings held before the District Court as manifestly ill-founded.
- The District Court asked for further information from the applicant's employer.
- The proceedings are still pending, and no judgment on the merits has been delivered by the District Court.

title: CASE OF KUC v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
1. The applicant made homemade explosive devices and sent them to veterinarians and a supermarket chain.

2. The applicant planted one of the devices next to a fast-food outlet with the aim of promoting animal rights.

3. The applicant was arrested on 1 January 2012 and charged with endangering public safety.

4. The Košice I District Court remanded the applicant in custody pending trial to prevent him from continuing his criminal activity.

5. The courts reviewed and confirmed the lawfulness of the applicant’s detention on five occasions.

6. The applicant was committed to the hospital for charged and convicted persons in Trenčín twice.

7. The applicant was indicted and found guilty of the charges, and sentenced to twenty-five years in prison.

8. The Regional Court quashed the judgment following an appeal by the applicant and remitted the case to the District Court for re-examination.

9. The applicant applied for release, but his requests were dismissed by the courts.

10. The applicant lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court, alleging violations of his rights.

11. The District Court asked an expert institute to produce a report on the applicant’s mental condition.

12. The applicant was found guilty of various criminal offences and sentenced to twenty-three years and six months in prison.

13. The applicant was transferred to the hospital in Trenčín after reportedly collapsing.

title: CASE OF AUSTIN AND BUDIARTINI v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicants are a husband and wife living in Dorset, UK.
- Mr and Mrs G initiated civil proceedings against the applicants before the Monção Court with the aim to get ownership recognition of a property and a declaration that the applicants had no right of way over that property.
- On 14 May 2007, the applicants were summoned, and the proceedings were suspended on the same day due to the death of Mr G.
- Mr G.'s eight heirs were admitted as parties to the proceedings, and the case restarted on 19 June 2007.
- On an unknown date in September 2007, the applicants submitted their reply and a counterclaim.

title: CASE OF MATEUS PEREIRA DA SILVA v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Torres Novas.
- Eviction proceedings were instituted against the applicant’s husband, A.S., on 16 February 2004.
- A.S. died on 22 September 2006, and the court suspended the proceedings on 7 November 2006.
- On 18 December 2007, the claimant applied for leave to continue the proceedings against the defendant’s heirs.
- The defendant’s heirs, including the applicant, were admitted as parties to the proceedings on 13 June 2009.
- The claimant died on 26 June 2009.
- The claimant’s heirs were admitted as parties to the proceedings on 22 June 2012.
- One of the defendant's heirs died on 22 January 2010, and their heirs were admitted as parties to the proceedings on 30 April 2012.
- The court gave a preparatory decision on 14 December 2012.
- The applicant’s heirs requested an inspection to the house on 14 January 2013.
- Hearings were held on 18 September, 29 October, and 17 December 2013.
- On 13 March 2014, the court ordered the applicant to vacate the house and pay rent arrears.
- The applicant appealed against the decision, but the appeal was declared inadmissible.
- On 19 January 2015, the claimant instituted enforcement proceedings against the applicant before the Santarém Court.

title: CASE OF BULAVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 in the Altay Region, and was serving a prison sentence for aggravated robbery in correctional colony no. 21 in the Novosibirsk Region.
- He complained of severe back pain to a prison doctor, and was diagnosed with lumbar osteochondrosis.
- Treatment proved to be ineffective, and he was eventually diagnosed with myelopathy.
- He was sent back and forth between the medical unit and the prison hospital, mainly receiving medication for his symptoms, and eventually developed paresis in three of his limbs and started using crutches. 
- Over time, he was confirmed as having a third-degree and then second-degree disability.
- He attempted to obtain surgery through various channels, including the court system and by having detention authorities apply for admission to a prison hospital, but he was repeatedly denied. 
- The applicant was released on parole on 19 July 2013.

title: CASE OF YANKOVSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder and charged four days later.
- The District Court authorized his pre-trial detention for two months, which was later extended multiple times.
- Reasons cited for extension included the seriousness of the charges, potential risk of witness intimidation or obstruction of justice, and the fact that the investigation was not yet complete.
- The defence argued against the extensions citing the applicant's lack of criminal record, family situation, and severe diabetes.
- The court repeatedly found the extensions reasonable and necessary due to the seriousness and complexity of the case.
- The applicant's poor health and need for constant medical supervision were evaluated throughout his detention, with various medical experts and institutions involved.

title: CASE OF PANORAMA LTD AND MILIČIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- Applicant lodged a compensation claim for goods seized during the war
- Court ordered Federation to pay applicant the amount claimed, including default interest
- Federation appealed against the judgment multiple times, but all appeals were dismissed
- Enforcement order issued for the payment, but default interest remained unpaid
- Applicant lodged appeal with Constitutional Court, which held that enforcement proceedings were excessively long and ordered the Municipal Court to conclude the proceedings without delay
- Judgment of 10 May 2007 and Constitutional Court's decision of 12 June 2013 remained unenforced as of the last available information
- Second applicant lodged a compensation claim for destroyed property
- Court ordered Federation to pay the second applicant, including default interest
- Enforcement order issued, but default interest remained unpaid
- Second applicant also lodged an appeal with Constitutional Court, which held that there was a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention due to excessive delay in enforcement and disproportionate burden placed on the appellants
- Constitutional Court ordered the Federation to enforce the final judgments without further delay
- As of the last available information, the judgment of 28 May 2007 (the amount due in respect of default interest) remained unenforced.

title: CASE OF SHVIDKIYE v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are mother and daughter, born in 1973 and 1996, respectively, residing in Blagoveshchensk, Amurskaya Region.
- They moved from Blagoveshchensk to Moscow in 2002 to purchase a flat.
- A person named B. offered to help them in finding a flat.
- The Housing Department of the City of Moscow, on 16 October 2002, signed a social tenancy agreement in respect to a two-room flat at Prospekt Vernadskogo, Moscow, with a certain K.
- K. applied to Moszhilservice on 23 October 2002 to exchange flats with the first applicant.
- The Committee for Exchange of Housing authorised the exchange and the first applicant received an exchange voucher in November 2002 and was registered as living in the flat.
- B. was found guilty of fraud in 2005.
- In 2008, the Housing Department of the City of Moscow brought court proceedings against the applicants, claiming all transactions to be illegal and the applicants to be evicted.
- The first applicant brought a counterclaim in 2009, stating that she was not aware of K.’s falsified documents and that the exchange was approved by competent State authorities.
- The District Court invalidated the exchange and ordered the applicants' eviction in 2009.
- The first applicant appealed, but the City Court upheld the decision in 2010.
- The applicants returned to Blagoveshchensk in 2014 and requested a duplicate of the writ of execution in February 2015.
- The bailiff's office initiated enforcement proceedings in June 2015.

title: CASE OF ANNENKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants owned businesses or worked as vendors at Voronezh municipal market.
- The title to the land on which the market was located was transferred from the town to a private company.
- The applicants and others decided to remain on the market premises permanently, doing “night shifts” to prevent the demolition of the market building.
- The police told the entrepreneurs to leave the premises on 6 August 2009. Some refused to comply.
- On 7 August 2009, some of the applicants were arrested and accused of an offense under Article 19.3 of the Federal Code of Administrative Offences.
- By a judgment of 7 August 2009, Mr Finskiy was convicted of the offense and sentenced to five days’ administrative detention.
- The applicants lodged appeals against the judgments, but the regional court upheld the lower courts’ decisions.
- On 2, 8 and 10 September 2009, the District Court set aside the judgments in respect of the female defendants and Mr Annenkov.
- At 5.30 a.m. on 10 August 2009 the police arrested some twenty people at the market, including certain applicants such as Mr Buzov, Ms Garkavets, Ms Zuravleva, Ms Khavantseva, and Ms Suprunova.

title: CASE OF M v. THE NETHERLANDS
facts:
- The applicant worked for the AIVD and had access to classified information.
- There was suspicion that the applicant forwarded copies of classified documents to unauthorized persons, including individuals under covert investigation for terrorist activity.
- The applicant was arrested and charged with divulging state secret information.
- The applicant was advised that he was still under an obligation of secrecy, and his counsel were warned that they might be prosecuted if they divulged any state secret information to third parties.
- The trial was adjourned several times, and the defense complained about restrictions affecting communication between themselves and the applicant.
- The court ordered the investigating judge to mitigate the handicaps under which the defense labored.
- The head of the AIVD conditionally released the applicant from his duty of secrecy.
- The Regional Court refused to make the exemption unconditional and ordered the investigating judge to hear witnesses.
- Some witnesses refused to answer certain questions because of their duty of secrecy.
- The defense objected to hearing unnamed witnesses at a secret location and challenged two judges of the trial chamber.
- Witnesses were heavily disguised and their voices distorted, and an AIVD official was present to prevent them from answering certain questions.
- The defense requested documents to be added to the file, including those found in the applicant's desk.

title: CASE OF YAKOVENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1961
- Deputy prosecutor in Tashkent issued an arrest warrant against the applicant on 10 October 2003
- Applicant was arrested in Russia on 26 February 2009
- Pechorskiy District Court ordered detention of the applicant without setting a time-limit on 28 February 2009
- Russian Prosecutor General’s office received a request for extradition from Uzbekistan on 16 March 2009
- Deputy Russian Prosecutor General ordered applicant’s extradition to Uzbekistan on 15 May 2009
- Pskov Regional Court found extradition order lawful on 26 June 2009
- Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the decision on appeal on 17 August 2009
- Applicant was extradited to Uzbekistan on 17 October 2009

title: CASE OF SMOLENTSEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant is disabled and lacks legal capacity 
2. Applicant is arrested on suspicion of robbery and allegedly beaten by police during arrest 
3. Ambulance is called twice for applicant, who reports physical assault by police 
4. Applicant is diagnosed with facial and chest contusions, as well as a closed fracture of nose bones 
5. Applicant is ordered to be kept under arrest for an additional forty-eight hours 
6. Criminal proceedings against applicant are discontinued due to a lack of evidence 
7. Applicant’s mother complains to prosecutor’s office that applicant was beaten by police 
8. Forensic medical reports suggest that applicant’s injuries were not caused by falling or self-infliction 
9. Investigation repeatedly suspended and resumed between 2008 and 2012 
10. Witnesses, including Officers S. and Ch., are questioned about alleged ill-treatment of the applicant 
11. Chief of inquiries at investigations department institutes criminal proceedings against unidentified persons for intentional infliction of injury.

title: CASE OF KOROBEYNIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Pyatigorsk.
- The applicant took part in the cleaning-up operation at the Chernobyl nuclear disaster site.
- He was registered disabled by Ukrainian authorities and entitled to social benefits.
- The welfare authorities in Russia rejected re-establishing the disability status.
- The applicant challenged the rejection before the courts.
- The Pyatigorsk Town Court granted the applicant's claim to issue a certificate of benefits.
- The judgment became final on 20 September 2009.
- The defendant authority's application for the supervisory review was allowed by the Presidium of Stavropol Regional Court on 1 November 2006.
- The Pyatigorsk Town Court discontinued the proceedings on 13 December 2006 as the parties failed to appear.

title: CASE OF BABYNIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Staryy Oskol.
- The applicant took part in the cleaning up operation at the Chernobyl nuclear disaster site.
- On 5 July 2002, the Staryy Oskol Town Court granted the applicant’s action against the Belgorod Regional Administration and awarded him and his family a flat in the town of Staryy Oskol and compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The judgment was not appealed against and became final on 15 July 2002.
- On 19 August 2002, the Staryy Oskol Town Court issued a writ of execution and enforcement proceedings were instituted.
- On 9 October 2002, the Belgorod Regional Administration lodged a statement of appeal against the judgment of 5 July 2002.
- On 14 October 2002, the Staryy Oskol Town Court restored the time-limit for lodging the appeal, accepted the Administration’s statement of appeal and stopped the enforcement proceedings.
- On 19 November 2002, the Belgorod Regional Court quashed the judgment of 5 July 2002 and remitted the case for a fresh examination to the Town Court.
- On 20 January 2003, the Staryy Oskol Town Court, in the new examination of the case, accepted the applicant’s action in part.
- The judgment was not appealed against and became final on 31 January 2003.
- On 13 February 2003, a writ of execution was issued, and enforcement proceedings were instituted.
- According to the applicant, from 5 to 12 March 2004, a group of five people, including the applicant, began a hunger strike to protest against the poor level of welfare protection provided for the Chernobyl victims.
- On 16 April 2004, the mayor of Staryy Oskol decided to provide the applicant with a flat.
- On 21 April 2004, the applicant received from the mayor an occupancy voucher in respect of the flat assigned to him.

title: CASE OF CARVALHO PINTO DE SOUSA MORAIS v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant became a patient of the gynaecology department of the Alfredo da Costa Maternity Hospital in December 1993.
- The applicant was diagnosed with bartholinitis on the left side of her vagina and received treatment which included drainages.
- The applicant was offered surgery for the condition at the beginning of 1995.
- On 21 May 1995, the applicant underwent surgery to remove the left Bartholin gland but had both glands removed instead.
- The applicant began to experience intense pain and a loss of sensation in the vagina, as well as suffering from urinary incontinence, difficulty sitting and walking, and the inability to have sexual relations after being discharged.
- The applicant was informed that the left pudendal nerve had been injured during the operation.
- The applicant brought a civil action against the CHLC in 2000, seeking damages of 70,579,779 escudos (PTE), equivalent to 325,050,020 euros (EUR).
- The surgeon was found to have acted recklessly by not fulfilling his objective duty of care, and there was a causal link between his conduct and the injury to the applicant’s left pudendal nerve.
- The Lisbon Administrative Court ordered the CHLC to pay EUR 80,000 in compensation for non-pecuniary damage and EUR 92,000 for pecuniary damage, of which EUR 16,000 was for the services of a maid.
- The CHLC appealed the decision of the Lisbon Administrative Court, but the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the first-instance judgment on the merits.
- The Supreme Administrative Court reduced the compensation awarded for the services of a maid from EUR 16,000 to EUR 6,000 and the compensation for non-pecuniary damage from EUR 80,000 to EUR 50,000.
- The Attorney General’s Office attached to the Supreme Administrative Court applied to have the judgment of 9 October 2014 declared null and void in the part concerning the amount awarded for non-pecuniary damage.
- The Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the appeals by the Attorney General’s Office and the applicant, upholding its judgment of 9 October 2014.

title: CASE OF ESKERKHANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
-Three applicants are born in 1980, 1981, and 1983 and are detained in Moscow.

-The first applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder on 8 March 2015.

-The second and third applicants were arrested on suspicion of murder on 7 March 2015.

-All applicants' pre-trial detention was extended on several occasions.

-The first applicant has been detained in remand prison no. 77/6, except for 21 days in remand prison no. 77/1 in Moscow. The conditions are described as extremely hot, extremely damp, lack of natural light and fresh air, limited access to potable water and hot water, absence of bedding, one ten-minute shower a week, and one hour of daily physical exercise in the fresh air. The conditions for the second and third applicants were not described.

-The first applicant was transported between IZ-77/6 and the Basmanny District Court of Moscow on 25 November 2015 in a prison van with limited personal space, no toilet, no access to food or drinking water, and no access to natural light, fresh air, or drinking water in the convoy cell where he was kept for about 15 hours.

-The second and third applicants were transported from remand prison No. 77/2 in Moscow to the Moscow City Court and back on 12 May 2015 in a prison van under identical conditions as described for the first applicant.

-The Russian Government provided a unilateral declaration offering a compensation of six thousand euro to the first applicant and requested the Court to strike application no. 18496/16 out of its list in a letter of 26 October 2016. On 14 December 2016, the applicant accepted the Government's declaration.

-The applicants in applications nos. 61249/16 and 61253/16 were informed of the Court's decision to communicate their applications to the Government in letters of 12 December 2016, which included information on the strictly confidential nature of friendly-settlement negotiations.

-On 30 January 2017, the applicants' lawyer informed several media outlets that the Court "had found for the applicants and awarded 6,500 euros to each [applicant]."

title: CASE OF RASTORGUYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A contract was signed in 2007 for the construction of residential buildings in Moscow, with 3823 flats to be transferred to the Ministry of Defense and the rest to remain the city's property.
- In 2008, some flats were transferred to the Ministry of Defense following the investment contract.
- In 2009, the city authorities had their title to some of the flats, including those in buildings 8 and 26-1, registered by the state authorities.
- In 2010, the Ministry of Defense assigned five flats to private individuals who successfully applied for recognition of their title to the flats and subsequently sold them to the applicants.
- Police investigations in 2012 and 2013 regarding fraudulent transactions with the flats were not reported on.
- On an unspecified date, city authorities asked the District Court to re-open cases concerning flats privatised by tenants who sold them to applicants in 2011, claiming the flats were the city's property.
- The case saw the court establish that the Ministry of Defense never owned the flats and thus had no right to assign them to private individuals; the court invalidated the Ministry of Defense's decision and ordered eviction of the applicants.
- The allegations fell under one of the two exceptions to the protection of a bona fide purchaser's title, requiring precedence be given to the City of Moscow.
- The applicants' appeals were rejected by the Moscow City Court and the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation.
- The judgments ordering the applicants' eviction were reportedly not enforced.
- Details pertaining to each case are summarised in Appendix II.

title: CASE OF DVORETSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lived in the Arkhangelsk Region before being detained.
- The applicant was arrested on an unspecified date after breaching his undertaking not to leave.
- He was charged with violent acts against a public official and was authorized detention by the Severodvinsk Town Court.
- On 2 September 2010, the applicant asked the Town Court to apply a non-custodial restraint measure to him, but it was dismissed due to his criminal record.
- The applicant appealed, but on 20 September 2010, he was convicted as charged.
- On 12 October 2010, the Arkhangelsk Regional Court upheld the Town Court's decision and rejected the applicant's leave to appear, holding the hearing in his absence.

title: CASE OF TEKIN AND ARSLAN v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicants are the parents of Michael Tekin, who has a criminal record and has been detained in the psychiatric wing of Jamioulx Prison multiple times.
- On August 7, 2009, Michael was once again ordered to be detained under the Social Protection Act.
- On August 8, 2009, Michael was placed in an individual cell under special security measures due to his erratic behavior and demands for release.
- When informed about the security measures, Michael provoked the prison officers by sneezing or spitting on them, and when warned to stop, moved aggressively towards them.
- The prison officers decided to place Michael in an isolation cell, and used a stranglehold technique to immobilize him. Michael complained of choking and was then handcuffed and dragged to the isolation cell, where he was found unconscious and later pronounced dead.

title: CASE OF SINEX D.O.O. v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant is a privately owned company established in 1989 and registered in Belgrade.
- On 9 September 2003, the applicant and Beranka AD concluded a guarantee agreement, and they made Annex No. 1 for the fiduciary transfer of the latter’s property to the applicant.
- The fiduciary transfer of Beranka AD’s property to the applicant was registered by the Real Estate Office in Berane on 31 October 2003.
- The Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings against Beranka AD on 8 April 2004.
- The insolvency administrator for Beranka AD lodged a request with the Real Estate Office in Berane to erase the registration of the fiduciary transfer of property to the applicant on 11 October 2004.
- The Real Estate Department remitted the case for reconsideration on 13 April 2005.
- The Real Estate Department in Berane re-registered the fiduciary transfer on some properties but refused to re-register the fiduciary transfer on some properties on 1 June 2005.
- The Administrative Court quashed the decision of the Real Estate Department in Podgorica and remitted the case to the Real Estate Department in Berane on 6 February 2007.
- The Real Estate Department in Berane ordered the removal of the applicant’s rights on Beranka AD’s property from the public register on 2 October 2008.
- The Real Estate Department adopted a decision allowing the deletion of the applicant’s rights from the public register on 26 October 2011.

title: CASE OF UNCUOĞLU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The first and second applicant owned shares of land in Firuzköy, Istanbul. 

- The 1987 zoning plan designated the land as "university area". 

- Annotations were made in land registry records in 1988, 1989, 1990, and 1991 indicating that the land would be expropriated by Istanbul University. 

- The applicants requested the expropriation or removal of the annotations in 1998. 

- The Küçükçekmece Civil Court awarded compensation for de facto expropriation in 2003, but the Court of Cassation quashed the judgments in 2004. 

- The applicants requested rectification of the decisions in 2004, but the Court of Cassation rejected the requests in 2005. 

- The Küçükçekmece Civil Court dismissed the cases in 2005, and the Court of Cassation dismissed the appeals in 2006. 

- The second applicant received compensation on an unknown date.

title: CASE OF KHALDAROV v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant arrived in Turkey legally on a one-month visa on 25 April 2008.
- On 24 April 2010, he was taken into police custody at Istanbul Atatürk Airport on suspicion of illegal entry and having no valid identity documentation.
- The applicant spent three days in detention at the airport police station before being transferred to an overcrowded centre in Kumkapı Removal Centre, where he faced poor hygiene, insects, poor quality and quantity of food, and no outdoor exercise.
- On 2 June 2010, he applied for release to the Istanbul Magistrates’ Court, which was denied on the grounds of not being detained within the scope of a criminal investigation.
- The applicant made an asylum claim to the Ministry of Interior and lodged an application for refugee status with the UNHCR on an unspecified date.
- On 25 June 2010, he was granted a temporary residence permit in the province of Bilecik and released from Kumkapı Removal Centre on the same day.
- A deportation order was issued against the applicant in 2016, and he has been detained since 20 September 2016 at İzmir Işıkkent Removal Centre pending expulsion.
- Domestic proceedings challenging the deportation order and his application for refugee status with the UNHCR are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF VUČINIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Podgorica.
- The applicant's employer closed its office in Podgorica following the breakup of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
- The applicant founded a trading company with its seat in his former employer’s offices.
- The applicant lodged a civil claim seeking compensation for the pecuniary loss suffered while he was awaiting a certificate.
- The Court of First Instance ruled that it lacked competence to deal with the case and rejected the claim, which was later quashed and remitted.
- The High Court overturned the decision and rejected the applicant's claim, which was later appealed on points of law.
- The Supreme Court quashed the judgement of the High Court and remitted the case.
- The High Court again rejected the applicant's claim, which was later upheld by the Supreme Court.
- The applicant lodged a claim seeking payment of the entitled compensation against the Municipality of Podgorica and the Republic of Montenegro.
- The Court of First Instance rejected the applicant's claim, which was later quashed and remitted by the High Court.
- The Court of First Instance again rejected the applicant's claim, which was later partly quashed and remitted by the High Court.
- The Supreme Court rejected the applicant's appeal on points of law in respect of the upheld part of the judgment.
- The Court of First Instance rejected the applicant's claim in respect of the remitted part of the judgment, which was later upheld by the High Court.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, which was later rejected by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF BĂRBULESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was employed by a Romanian private company as a sales engineer from August 1, 2004, to August 6, 2007.
- The employer asked the applicant to create an instant messaging account using Yahoo Messenger for the purpose of responding to customers’ enquiries.
- The employer’s internal regulations prohibited personal use of company resources.
- The regulations did not contain any reference to the possibility of monitoring employees’ communications.
- The applicant had been informed of the employer’s internal regulations and had signed a copy of them.
- The employer circulated an information notice to all employees warning against personal use of internet, phone or fax machine.
- The applicant acquainted himself with the notice and signed it.
- The employer recorded the applicant’s Yahoo Messenger communications in real-time.
- The employer informed the applicant that his communications had been monitored and that there was evidence of personal use of the internet during work hours.
- The applicant argued that he had used Yahoo Messenger for work-related purposes only.
- The employer informed the applicant that all the correspondence he exchanged during the period between July 5 to July 12, 2007, using the S. Bucharest site ID had a private purpose as shown by the attached transcripts of his Yahoo Messenger conversations.
- The applicant was terminated from his employment on August 1, 2007.
- The applicant challenged his dismissal in court, alleging unlawful monitoring of communications and breach of secrecy of correspondence.
- The court found the employer’s monitoring of communications lawful and that the applicant had breached internal regulations prohibiting personal use of computers.
- The applicant appealed the decision, arguing that there was a conflict between the employer’s right to monitor employees and their right to privacy.
- The court of appeal dismissed the appeal, finding that the employer had the right and duty to ensure smooth running of the company and supervise its employees’ professional tasks, and that the monitoring was necessary to achieve this aim.

title: CASE OF BOZKAYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and was detained on suspicion of membership of an illegal organisation, namely the PKK/KADEK.
- The applicant confessed to committing an armed attack on a prison vehicle in Adana.
- The applicant was required to participate in a reconstruction of the events.
- The applicant was questioned multiple times by police and an investigating judge, and admitted to being a member of the PKK/KADEK and involvement in the armed attack.
- The applicant was examined multiple times by doctors during their period of custody, with no signs of ill-treatment.
- The co-accused had claimed to have organised the armed attack with the applicant.
- The applicant was charged with breaking up the unity of the state and seeking to remove part of the national territory from the state's control.
- The applicant retracted his previous statements, alleging that they had been obtained through coercion and death threats by the police.
- The applicant's lawyer appealed against the conviction on the grounds of the applicant's statements being obtained without notifying him of his rights and as a result of coercion and death threats by the police.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the conviction, and the judgment was pronounced in the absence of the applicant and his lawyer.

title: CASE OF BAYRAM KOÇ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Diyarbakır. 
- On 17 January 2003, the applicant was arrested and taken into police custody on suspicion of membership of an illegal organization. 
- On 18 January 2003, the applicant gave his statement to the police in the absence of a lawyer. 
- The applicant confessed to being a member of the illegal organization and gave a detailed account of its structure and his acts within the illegal organization. 
- On the same day, the applicant denied his police statements in the statements he gave to the public prosecutor and the investigating judge, arguing that they had been taken under duress. 
- The investigating judge ordered that the applicant be held on remand. 
- On 28 January 2003, a public prosecutor at the Istanbul State Security Court filed an indictment with that court, charging the applicant under Article 146 of the former Criminal Code. 
- The case was later transferred to the Istanbul Assize Court. 
- On 10 June 2008, the Istanbul Assize Court found the applicant guilty of committing the offense under Article 314 of the Criminal Code and sentenced him to two years and one month’s imprisonment. 
- On 27 May 2009, the applicant’s lawyer appealed against the judgment, arguing that the applicant had been convicted on the basis of statements taken under duress. 
- On 3 March 2010, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF TÜRK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a life sentence in Antalya.
- The applicant went to the Mersin Security Directorate headquarters and found out that a warrant had been issued for his arrest by the Antalya Security Directorate.
- The applicant confessed to his involvement in the shooting of K.G. in 1992 and identified his accomplices.
- The applicant participated in a reconstruction of the events and was questioned by the police without being advised of his rights.
- The case was transferred to the Izmir Assize Court and the applicant was found guilty under Article 125 of the Criminal Code and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment and remitted the case to the first-instance court, which once again found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- The applicant's lawyer submitted that M.N.A.'s statements should not have been taken into consideration due to his mental state and that the applicant had been deceived by the police.

title: CASE OF BUDNIK v. POLAND
facts:
- Applicant is a Polish national who was born in 1980 and lives in Leszno.
- The applicant was detained in Łowicz Prison from 27 January 2007 to 19 April 2009.
- The applicant was held in overcrowded cells in which the space per person had been below the Polish statutory minimum standard of 3 sq. m.
- The applicant was placed in a solitary confinement cell for fourteen days as part of a disciplinary measure, where the toilet was not separated from the living space.
- Applicant brought a civil action over an infringement of his personal rights on account of the inadequate living conditions in Łowicz Prison from 27 January 2007 to 19 April 2009.
- On 20 July 2012, the Łódź Regional Court granted the applicant PLN 3,000 (EUR 750) in compensation and dismissed the remainder of his claim.
- On 1 March 2013, the Łódź Court of Appeal increased the compensation to PLN 7,000 (approximately EUR 1,750) and dismissed the remainder of the action.

title: CASE OF GOLDNAGL v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1939 and lives in Vienna.
- On 28 July 1965, the applicant married T.G.
- On 29 February 1996, the applicant sued for a divorce which was granted due to the sole fault of T.G.
- On 19 September 2005, the matrimonial property was divided.
- On 2 August 1991, the applicant lodged a claim for spousal maintenance and requested an interim order for provisional maintenance.
- On 15 February 1992, the District Court issued an interim order requiring T.G. to pay the applicant provisional maintenance which became binding and enforceable.
- On 26 March 1997, the District Court issued a judgment partly granting and partly dismissing the maintenance claim which was quashed by the Regional Court.
- On 9 June 1999, the District Court ordered T.G. to pay the applicant 20,000 Austrian Schillings per month.
- On 10 July 2003, private insolvency proceedings against T.G were opened.
- On 14 October 2003, the District Court lifted the ban on the pay-out of money from T.G.’s pension fund and his redundancy money, but dismissed the liquidator’s request to lift the order of provisional maintenance payments.
- On 30 March 2010, the District Court partly dismissed and partly refused the applicant’s claim regarding maintenance until the opening of the insolvency proceedings.
- On 27 October 2011, the applicant requested the continuation of the maintenance payments proceedings concerning the period starting from 10 July 2003.
- On 28 December 2011, the applicant filed a fresh maintenance claim with the Salzburg District Court against the liquidator as he had refused to acknowledge the applicant’s claim in the insolvency proceedings.
- The private insolvency proceedings of T.G are still pending. 
- Several hearings and appeals have taken place in the main maintenance proceedings and the fresh maintenance claim.

title: CASE OF MIRZASHVILI v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and was serving a prison sentence at Rustavi Prison no. 2.
- On August 9, 2005, the applicant was arrested for armed robbery, robbery, and theft of a vehicle, mobile phone, and money, while maintaining his innocence and providing an alibi.
- The Mtskheta District Court granted the prosecutor's request to place the applicant in pre-trial detention for three months on August 11, 2005.
- The applicant was found guilty of the charges and sentenced to ten years in prison on October 18, 2006.
- After the applicant appealed to the Tbilisi Court of Appeals, it upheld the applicant's conviction and sentence but amended the judgment of October 18, 2006.
- The tumor in the applicant's right testicle was removed in 1998, and he underwent chemotherapy on an irregular basis. He had another operation in 2003 when the disease returned. He also had chronic hepatitis C (HCV).
- In August 2005, shortly after being imprisoned, the applicant was transferred to the prison hospital, where he was diagnosed with chronic HCV and recently treated for cancer of the right testicle, and his specialized medical examination was recommended.
- Despite the requests of medical personnel in September 2005, the applicant was not transferred to the NCO or examined by a urological oncologist. He stayed in the prison hospital until February 4, 2006, where he received pain medication for his symptoms.
- The applicant returned to the prison hospital on February 25, 2006. After the examination on March 7, 2006, the oncologist concluded that the cancer had returned.
- In August 2006, a group of independent experts issued a report diagnosing the applicant with cancer of the right testicle and stating that his health could be considered serious.
- The applicant was sent back to Tbilisi Prison no. 5 on September 2, 2006. The authorities refused to send the applicant back to the prison hospital despite objections from his lawyer and medical personnel.
- The Court of Appeal ordered that the applicant be examined at the NCO in the context of the criminal proceedings.
- The applicant was admitted to the NCO on June 19, 2007, where he underwent chemotherapy until July 13, 2007.
- The applicant was transferred back to the prison hospital on July 13, 2007, with a recommendation for another

title: CASE OF RITZ v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant was the managing director and 80% shareholder of Ritz Baugesellschaft m.b.H.
- Insolvency proceedings were opened in respect of Ritz Baugesellschaft m.b.H. on 12 October 1998 but were discontinued on 14 June 2013.
- On 15 April 2002, the applicant initiated official liability proceedings against the Republic of Austria for allegedly unlawful acts and shortcomings of the Regional Court in the course of the insolvency proceedings.
- The applicant and the company requested a declaratory judgment concerning the future liability of the Republic of Austria for any further damages arising from the insolvency proceedings.
- The applicant’s claim filed in the name of the company was rejected on 13 November 2002. 
- The Graz Court of Appeal granted the applicant’s appeal and referred the case back to the Regional Court on 28 January 2003. 
- On 2 March and 19 July 2005, the applicant filed requests to accelerate the proceedings. 
- The Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s request under Section 91 on 11 August 2005. 
- On 29 June 2006, the Regional Court submitted the file to the public prosecutor to examine whether criminal investigations should be instituted against unknown offenders ex-officio and the proceedings stayed until such proceedings were terminated. 
- The proceedings were partially dismissed and partially rejected as inadmissible by the Regional Court on 31 May 2010.
- The Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal on 15 February 2011 and the Supreme Court rejected the applicant’s appeal on points of law on 28 April 2011.

title: CASE OF KARZHEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former prosecutor who served as district prosecutor for Sofia and got into a conflict with subordinates.
- A commission was appointed to look into the prosecution office’s work under his management, which led to the opening of criminal proceedings against the applicant.
- The applicant made statements in an interview published in Trud, where he criticized some prosecutors, including by calling one of them "Prosecutor Rushvetchiyski," which allegedly insulted two of his former subordinates, B.K. and G.C.
- B.K. and G.C. initiated a private prosecution against the applicant, alleging that he insulted them through the media and in their capacity as "public officials."
- The first-instance court acquitted the applicant, but the Plovdiv Regional Court reversed the decision, convicted the applicant of insult in an aggravated form, and imposed a fine and damages payment.
- The applicant paid the amounts indicated in the judgment.
- B.K. and G.C. discussed the applicant's conviction in an interview published in Trud.

title: CASE OF STOLLENWERK v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was suspected of drug trafficking and arrested on 27 August 2010.
- He was detained on remand between 27 August 2010 and 6 December 2010 when he was convicted of drug trafficking and sentenced to two years and six months’ imprisonment.
- Despite several appeals, the court ordered the continuation of the applicant’s detention until 3 February 2011 when his appeal was dismissed.
- The applicant’s counsel requested a subsequent hearing on 10 February 2011, but the request was dismissed on 25 February 2011.
- On 7 April 2011, the applicant lodged a complaint with the Federal Constitutional Court alleging a violation of his right to be heard.

title: CASE OF EZGETA v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Novigrad.
- A contract in 1971 between G.P. (the claimant) and the Novigrad Municipality gave certain plots of land to the former for its permanent use.
- The claimant built residential buildings on the land and sold them.
- The Novigrad Municipality objected to the claimant's applications for land register correction proceedings in one instance, leading to the initiation of civil proceedings.
- The claimant brought a civil action against the Novigrad Municipality seeking to correct the data concerning certain plots of land in the land register of the Buje Municipal Court.
- The applicant and the claimant concluded a purchase agreement in December 1999 in respect of the plots of land surrounding the residential buildings that were the subject of the proceedings instituted on 6 October 2000.
- The applicant asked to join the claimant as an intervener on 23 October 2000.
- The Buje Municipal Court established that the claimant had raised the value of the claim to HRK 105,000.
- The Buje Municipal Court allowed the claim on 25 February 2005, but the Pula County Court quashed the first-instance judgment and remitted the case for a fresh examination after an appeal by the defendant on 5 February 2007.
- The first-instance court dismissed the claim as ill-founded on 26 May 2009.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on the basis that the case had been heard and decided by a court administrator who was not authorised to conduct the impugned proceedings.
- The Pula County Court upheld the first-instance judgment on 18 October 2010.
- The Supreme Court declared the applicant's appeal on points of law inadmissible on 14 October 2011, citing that the value of the claim did not meet the statutory threshold.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's constitutional complaint as manifestly ill-founded in March 2012.

title: CASE OF KARATAŞ AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are 10 individuals who are related to Bülent Karataş, who was killed on September 27, 2007, in Tunceli.
- The first applicant is Bülent Karataş's wife, and the second and third applicants are their children. The fourth and fifth applicants are the parents of Bülent Karataş, and the sixth to ninth applicants are his siblings. The tenth applicant was injured in the same incident.
- The incident involved an armed clash between members of a terrorist group and the military that resulted in several injuries and deaths.
- The Hozat public prosecutor and crime-scene investigators were informed about the incident and arrived to investigate the scene the next day.
- During the prosecutor's investigation, several objects were found at the scene and were secured as evidence.
- A post mortem examination was carried out on Bülent Karataş's body, which revealed the cause of death as a result of hypovolemic shock caused by the laceration of the left great saphenous vein.
- Statements were taken from military personnel and witnesses who were present during the incident, and an investigation was ongoing.

title: CASE OF BOZZA v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Torre del Greco.
- The applicant's mother was granted a disability pension and a special allowance for partial blindness in January 1990.
- In October 1994, the applicant's mother filed a request for a re-evaluation of her pension and interest on the arrears, which was dismissed by the District Court in March 1998 as out of time.
- The applicant, as the heir of her mother, filed an appeal on March 1999, which was granted in December 2002 for a total of EUR 12,240.26.
- The applicant filed a payment order on June 2004 to the National Social Security Agency (INPS) for the claimed amount, with interest and re-evaluation.
- On January 2005, she obtained a garnishee order for her claim.
- On May 2005, the applicant filed an appeal with the "Pinto" Division of the Rome Court of Appeal, complaining about excessive proceedings length, which was later declared inadmissible as out of time in May 2006 by the same court.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the decision in September 2008 and dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF MATEVOSYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was serving a prison sentence at Nubarashen penal facility and was drafted to the Armenian military.
- On 29 April 2006, the dead body of a fellow serviceman, A.H., was found in the forest next to the applicant's military unit.
- The applicant and another serviceman, R.H., were subjected to disciplinary punishment for beating up A.H. the previous month.
