- During their detention, the applicant and R.H. were questioned about the criminal case, and R.H. confessed to the murder.
- The applicant alleged that he was subjected to severe beatings and torture by military police officers and investigators to force him to confess and was denied legal representation.
- The investigator decided not to institute criminal proceedings against the officers accused of ill-treating the applicant and R.H.
- The applicant and R.H. alleged that they were ill-treated during the trial, and a forensic medical examination was ordered.
- The Syunik Regional Court found the applicant guilty of non-aggravated murder and breaching military discipline rules and sentenced him to nine and a half years' imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed against the judgment, but the Criminal Court of Appeal dismissed all appeals and upheld the judgment.

title: CASE OF RANĐELOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- Around seventy Roma boarded the boat "Miss Pat" on the Montenegrin coast with the intention of reaching Italy. The boat sank a few hours later due to the large number of passengers.
- By 30 August 1999, one passenger had been found alive, and thirty-five bodies had been found in the sea, thirteen of which were identified by their relatives. The cause of death was drowning according to forensic specialists.
- An investigation was initiated against seven individuals on suspicion of illegally crossing the State border in connection with reckless endangerment by the Court of First Instance in Bar on 1 September 1999.
- By the end of 2002, the court decided that two defendants who were still at large would be tried in their absence and appointed representatives for them. The remaining five defendants appeared in court.
- The High State Prosecutor requested that an investigation be opened against the same seven people and another individual on suspicion of committing reckless endangerment on 26 May 2004.
- The High Court charged eight defendants with reckless endangerment under Article 338 § 2 in connection with Article 327 §§ 1 and 3 of the Criminal Code on 31 October 2006.
- The High Court acquitted all the accused for lack of evidence on 24 July 2014.
- The Roma Centre complained to the Ombudsman, asking for the criminal proceedings to be expedited and the responsible persons punished, as well as for a DNA analysis of the bodies that had been buried on an unspecified date prior to 7 December 2009.
- The Ombudsman issued a report on 7 December 2009, recommending that the High Court undertake all necessary steps to terminate the proceedings as soon as possible.

title: CASE OF SEVERE v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant lives in Rochefort, France, and had joint custody of his twin sons with C.B., a French and Austrian national. 
- On 10 December 2008, C.B. left their home with the children following a dispute and went to stay with her parents in Golfe-Juan. 
- On 17 December 2008, C.B. notified the police in Fréjus that she intended to move to Vienna, where she had already taken her main residence. 
- On 7 January 2009, an interim injunction was issued at the applicant’s request, ruling that he and C.B. had joint custody, but that the children’s main residence was with their father. 
- C.B. was later convicted of child abduction and sentenced to one year's imprisonment. 
- The case involved proceedings under the Hague Convention and the Brussels IIa Regulation regarding the return of the children to France, with allegations of sexual abuse and concerns for the children's safety.

title: CASE OF DZHANTAYEV AND YAKUBOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple residing in Grozny.
- The flat in question (located at 35-122, Ulitsa Starosunzhenskaya, Grozny) was owned by M.'s husband but was sold to A. in 1996.
- M.'s family moved out of Grozny in an unspecified date, leaving the flat behind but applied for compensation due to the loss of the flat.
- On 14 November 2008, the police refused to charge M.'s husband with fraud in relation to the flat sale.
- In 2010, A. sold the flat to the second applicant, which was duly registered with state authorities.
- A civil action was lodged against A. and the first applicant to invalidate the flat sale by the Housing Department of Grozny. This claim was rejected by the District Court in 2010.
- In 2011, Mur. claimed that the municipal authorities had assigned the flat to her under the social housing agreement and lodged a civil action against the applicants seeking their eviction.
- In June 2011, the District Court invalidated the assignment of the flat to Mur. under the social housing agreement and rejected her claims.
- The District Court dismissed Mur.'s claims in May 2014, and ordered the applicants' eviction, finding that the flat was the property of the Town of Grozny.
- The Supreme Court of the Chechen Republic upheld the District Court's decision on appeal in November 2014.
- According to the Government, the applicants were not evicted and remain in the flat.

title: CASE OF KHAZIYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant lives in Ufa and was born in 1963. 

• A new block of flats was commissioned on 26 December 2006 by the Ufa Town Administration. 

• On 30 September 2010, the Ordzhonikidzevskiy District Court of Ufa recognized T.’s ownership of the flat at 66/2-54, Ulitsa Kommunarov, Ufa. 

• On 28 October 2010, T. sold the flat to M., and the transaction was registered by the state registration authorities. 

• On 13 January 2011, M. sold the flat to the applicant, and the transaction was registered by the state registration authorities. 

• The Housing Foundation of the Republic of Bashkortostan filed a civil claim against the applicant seeking the invalidation of her title to the flat and eviction. 

• On 23 July 2013, the District Court granted the claims and refused to recognize the applicant’s purchase in good faith. 

• On 17 November 2013, the Supreme Court of the Republic of Bashkortostan upheld the judgment of 23 July 2013 on appeal. 

• On 4 April 2014, the Supreme Court rejected the applicant’s cassation appeal. 

• On 9 July 2014, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation rejected the applicant’s second cassation appeal. 

• The eviction order was not enforced, and the applicant continues to reside in the flat according to the Government.

title: CASE OF VITANIS AND ŠUKYS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1976 and 1978 and detained in Vilnius Correctional Facility and Kybartai Correctional Facility.
- The first applicant was detained in Šiauliai Remand Prison from 11 January 2011 to 3 November 2011 in four different cells.
- The first applicant instituted proceedings for damages in 2012 due to degrading conditions of detention and violation of hygiene norms in cells.
- The Šiauliai Regional Administrative Court held that the first applicant's right to adequate conditions of detention had been breached but dismissed his claim for compensation due to the lack of evidence.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the first-instance decision.
- The second applicant was detained in Šiauliai Remand Prison from 15 December 2009 to 8 February 2012 in several different cells.
- The second applicant also instituted proceedings for damages and submitted a complaint in January 2012.
- The Šiauliai Regional Administrative Court held that the second applicant’s right to adequate conditions of detention had been breached but dismissed his claim for compensation due to lack of evidence.
- The court held that the applicant had proven that conditions in cell no. 101 had been unsanitary and awarded him with 300 Lithuanian litai (approximately 87 euros) for non-pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF KOLAR v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Beloljin, Republic of Serbia.
- In 1997, several decisions were issued by the Maribor Unit of the Surveying and Mapping Authority concerning the delimitation of real estate belonging to the applicant and to company D., and ordering changes in respect to the use of land.
- The applicant appealed against some of those decisions of the aforementioned unit.
- On 28 September 2000, the Ministry for the Environment and Spatial Planning granted the applicant’s appeal in part and annulled a decision issued on 12 February 1997 while it dismissed the appeal concerning two decisions issued on 31 January 1997.
- On 23 November 2000, the applicant challenged the Ministry's decision in the part dismissing his appeal by instituting proceedings before the Administrative Court.
- On 6 November 2003, the Administrative Court granted the applicant’s appeal, annulled the challenged part of the decision of 28 September 2000, and referred the case back to the Ministry who, in turn, referred it to the Maribor unit. The applicant appealed again.
- On 24 May 2006, the Supreme Court dismissed the appeal and upheld the Administrative Court's judgment.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint regarding the decision of the Supreme Court.
- On 19 December 2007, the Constitutional Court dismissed the constitutional complaint.
- On 10 July 2015, the State Attorney's Office sent the applicant a settlement offer in accordance with section 25 of the 2006 Act.
- The applicant did not accept the settlement offer.

title: CASE OF MAKEDON v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document involves an application that has relevant details listed in a table.
- The applicant has made a complaint. 
- The complaint concerns the length of civil proceedings being excessive. 
- The complaint also concerns the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF BARSKYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The application involves a complaint made by the applicant.
2. The complaint is about the excessive length of pre-trial detention.
3. The details of the application are provided in a table.

title: CASE OF TURAL HAJIBEYLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1992 and lives in Baku.
- A demonstration was planned to be held on 12 March 2011 in Baku.
- The BCEA refused to authorize the demonstration at the place indicated by the organizers.
- The organizers decided to hold the demonstration in the center of Baku.
- The participants were protesting against, inter alia, corruption and demanding the resignation of the President of the State.
- The applicant attended the demonstration and was arrested during the dispersal operation and taken to three different police stations consecutively.
- He was charged with administrative offenses under Article 298 and Article 310.1 of the CAO.
- The applicant was brought before a first-instance court and sentenced to eight days’ administrative detention.
- He appealed and the case was remitted to the first-instance court for re-examination.
- The applicant was not given an opportunity to appoint a lawyer of his own choosing during the re-examination.
- He was sentenced to seven days’ administrative detention again.
- He appealed again and requested witnesses and examination of photographs and video recordings, but the court dismissed his appeal.
- The case files relating to the pending applications before the Court, including the present case, were seized during the search of Mr Aliyev’s home and office.

title: CASE OF ZELENKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A list of applicants and their application details is appended.
- The applicants complain about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raise complaints under Article 13 of the convention.

title: CASE OF DINU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Applicant's details are specified in the appended table
- The applicant raised a complaint about the excessive length of civil proceedings
- The applicant also raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention

title: CASE OF ALEXANDRU ENACHE v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant is a lawyer who was born in 1973 and lives in Bucharest.
- On 25 May 2011, he was convicted of embezzlement and forgery by the Bucharest Court of First Instance and sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant filed two applications for a stay of execution of sentence under Article 453 § 1 b) and c) of the former Code of Criminal Procedure, both of which were rejected.
- The applicant was detained in various prisons in Romania, including Bucharest police detention facility, Bucharest-Rahova Prison, Mărgineni Prison, and Giurgiu Prison.
- The applicant alleged poor conditions of detention in all prisons, such as overcrowding, lack of natural light, dirty toilets, and limited access to running water.
- The Government disputed the applicant's allegations and stated that cells in all prisons were equipped with basic facilities and in good condition.

title: CASE OF N.D. AND N.T. v. SPAIN
facts:
- The first applicant left his village in Mali due to the 2012 armed conflict, arrived in Morocco in March 2013 and stayed in the makeshift camp for migrants on Gurugu Mountain for approximately nine months.
- The second applicant arrived in Morocco in late 2012 and also stayed in the camp on Gurugu Mountain.
- In August 2014, the applicants attempted to enter Spain via the Melilla border crossing, comprising three successive fences, and witnessed violence against sub-Saharan migrants by the Spanish Guardia Civil and Moroccan law-enforcement officials.
- As soon as they reached the ground in Spain, they were apprehended by members of the Guardia Civil, handcuffed, and sent back to Morocco without identity check, legal or medical assistance.
- The applicants were transferred to Nador police station, where they requested medical assistance, which was refused, and were later taken to Fez, where they were left to take care of themselves.
- The applicants had video footage to substantiate their claim, and some non-governmental organisations lodged a complaint with the Melilla investigating judge seeking the opening of an investigation.
- Both applicants succeeded in entering Spanish territory by the Melilla border crossing in October and December 2014, respectively, and orders were issued for their expulsion, which was later carried out.
- The first applicant's asylum application was rejected, and he was returned to Mali on 31 March 2015, while the second applicant's current situation is unknown.
- Both applicants were represented by lawyers during the proceedings.

title: CASE OF DMITRIYEVSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was executive director of the Russian-Chechen Friendship Society and chief editor of a monthly newspaper with a circulation of 5,000.
- In 2004, the applicant obtained two articles from the website Chechenpress.
- The first article contained an address by Akhmed Zakayev, Vice Prime Minister of the Government of the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria, to the People of Russia, calling for peace and a resolution to the conflict.
- The second article contained an address by Maskhadov, President of the Chechen Republic Ichkeria, to the European Parliament, condemning the Russian-Chechen war and calling for international recognition of the deportation of 1944 as an act of genocide.
- The regional prosecutor's office instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant for public appeals to extremist activity through the mass media.
- Linguistic expert reports found that the articles contained no appeals to extremist activity, but rather aimed at inciting racial, ethnic and social discord.
- The proceedings were suspended due to the inability to identify those responsible for the publication of the articles online.

title: CASE OF MEDVEDEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and lives in Murmansk.
- On 24 September 2004, he was arrested for robbery and given an undertaking not to leave his place of residence.
- On 21 February 2005, he was convicted of robbery and forgery and given a sentence of seven years and four months with detention pending appeal proceedings.
- On 3 May 2005, the Murmansk Regional Court quashed the judgment on appeal and sent the case back to the Town Court with the applicant ordered to remain in custody.
- On 3 June 2005, the Town Court extended the applicant’s detention and ordered the elimination of certain procedural deficiencies preventing the case's examination.
- The applicant’s detention extended again on 16 August 2005. The applicant challenges the presiding judge but the Regional Court found no grounds as per Articles 61 and 63.
- On 18 November 2005, the Town Court extended the applicant’s detention which was contested by the parties over its receipt.
- The hearing in the applicant's case was adjourned multiple times with the applicant appearing before the court but not receiving the detention order.
- On 10 April 2006, the Town Court convicted the applicant of extortion and sentenced him to three years’ imprisonment and a fine of 3,000 Russian roubles (RUB).
- The Regional Court upheld the conviction on 5 September 2006 but reduced the sentence.

title: CASE OF SEMENOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lived in St Petersburg until her arrest.
- The applicant was arrested on 6 February 2013 on suspicion of drug trafficking and remained in detention throughout the ensuing investigation and trial.
- The Krasnogvardeiyskiy District Court of St Petersburg found her guilty on 28 March 2013 and sentenced her to one year in prison. Regard being had to her previous convictions for similar offences, the applicant was ordered to spend four years and one month in a correctional colony.
- At the time of her arrest, the applicant suffered from HIV and chronic hepatitis C.
- She underwent a routine medical examination by a general practitioner on admission to her remand prison. Several days later, on 18 February 2013, she was examined by a gynaecologist, who diagnosed cervical erosion and carried out basic tests.
- In late April 2013 the applicant was sent to correctional colony no. 2 in St Petersburg. She had the necessary treatment for HIV and other illnesses in the correctional colony. She was examined by various doctors, including a gynaecologist.
- On 22 September 2015, the custodial authorities asked a gynaecological cancer specialist to examine the applicant. The doctor noted that her cancer had progressed to such an advanced stage that it could not be cured by surgery. Radiotherapy was prescribed.
- On 30 October 2015, the prison hospital’s medical board authorized the use of narcotic pain relief for the applicant who suffered from “unbearable pain” which ordinary painkillers could not alleviate.
- In November 2015, the head of the prison hospital applied for the applicant’s early release on medical grounds. 
- The court dismissed the application for her early release. 
- On 1 March 2016, the St Petersburg City Court quashed the decision of 25 November 2015 on appeal and remitted the case for fresh examination. 
- On 2 March 2016, the Court indicated to the Government, under Rule 39, that the applicant should immediately be given access to the entire range of medication available for cancer patients in accordance with Russian laws, including appropriate pain relief drugs. 
- The applicant died on 9 April 2016.

title: CASE OF KÖRTVÉLYESSY v. HUNGARY (No. 3)
facts:
- The applicant planned to organize a demonstration on 17 April 2010 in front of the Venyige Street prison in Budapest to draw attention to the "situation of political prisoners".
- The head of the Budapest Police Department banned the demonstration on the grounds that traffic could not be diverted to alternative routes, citing Article 21 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 11 of the Convention and Decision no. 55/2001.AB of the Constitutional Court.
- The applicant sought a judicial review of the decision and it was dismissed by the Budapest Regional Court.
- The police reckoned that the participation of 200 demonstrators would lead to an obstruction of lawful parking and traffic circulation in the neighborhood.
- The court agreed that the right to assembly can be restricted if it causes a violation of the fundamental rights of others, and that the police had adequately established the facts and complied with the procedural rules.

title: CASE OF GANEYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lived in Ufa.
- A new block of flats was commissioned by the Town of Ufa at 66/2, Ulitsa Kommunarov, Ufa on 26 December 2006.
- On 19 July 2010, the Ordzhonikidzevskiy District Court of Ufa recognized U.'s title to the flat and the state registration authorities registered U.'s title.
- On 30 October 2010, U. sold the flat to M. and the state registration authorities registered the transaction.
- On 12 February 2011, A. sold the flat to the applicant according to a contract signed with the applicant and Z. acting on M.'s behalf through a power of attorney.
- On an unspecified date, a third party brought a civil action challenging U.'s sale of the flat to M. and the latter's title to the flat.
- On 28 February 2011, the Ordzhonikidzevskiy District Court of Ufa issued an injunction in respect of the transactions with the flat.
- On 3 March 2011, the state registration authorities informed the applicant that her application for the registration of the transfer of the title to the flat could not be granted pending the outcome of the civil proceedings concerning the title to the flat.
- On 24 December 2012, the Supreme Court of the Republic of Bashkortostan dismissed the third party's claims in respect of the flat in full.
- On an unspecified date, the Housing Foundation of the Republic of Bashkortostan brought a civil claim, seeking, inter alia, the invalidation of M.'s title to the flat and the applicant's eviction.
- On 23 August 2013, the District Court granted the claims in full, invalidated the purchase of the flat by M. and ordered the applicant's eviction.
- On 7 November 2013, the Supreme Court of Republic of Bashkortostan upheld the judgment of 23 August 2013 on appeal.
- On 12 May 2014, the Supreme Court rejected the applicant's cassation appeal.
- On 28 August 2014, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation rejected the applicant's second cassation appeal.
- On an unspecified date, the District Court stayed the eviction proceedings for three months, but on 24 February 2015, the applicant was evicted after failing to acquire the title to the

title: CASE OF VILENCHIK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is from Minneapolis, Minnesota and was born in 1978
- The applicant married S., a Ukrainian national, in Minneapolis on 24 July 2009
- Their son M. was born in Minneapolis on 28 August 2009 and was issued a US passport
- S. obtained permanent residency status in the USA in May 2010
- The family went on holiday to Ukraine in June 2011
- The applicant returned to the USA on 13 July 2011, whereas the child remained in Ukraine with S.
- The permanent residency card of S. expired in May 2012
- In June 2012, the applicant filed for divorce and sole custody of M. in Minnesota District Court
- The court reserved the issue of custody since it found that it lacked jurisdiction because the child had been in Ukraine for more than six months
- The applicant spent a vacation in Ukraine with S. and M. in July 2012
- The applicant petitioned the Ministry of Justice of Ukraine on 14 August 2012 for M.’s return to the USA under the Hague Convention
- In March 2013, M.’s Ukrainian citizenship was confirmed
- The applicant filed a claim in April 2013 with the Desnyansky District Court of Chernihiv for wrongful retention of M. under the Hague Convention
- S. argued that there was no wrongful retention and that the applicant asked her to stay in Ukraine with the child
- The Desnyansky District Court ordered M.’s return to the USA in June 2013
- S. appealed the decision under the Article 13(b) exception of the Hague Convention stating that the child would be exposed to psychological harm
- The Chernihiv Regional Court of Appeal dismissed the claim in August 2013, citing the risks of psychological harm to the child
- The Cassation Court quashed the Court of Appeal’s decision and upheld the Desnyansky District Court’s decision in November 2013
- S. failed to comply with the writ of execution in November 2013 and incurred fines
- S. requested review of the case from the Supreme Court in February 2014
- The Supreme Court referred the case to the Cassation Court in April 2014
- The Cassation Court quashed the Court of Appeal’s decision in July 2014 on the grounds of procedural errors and the failure to establish all the facts
- The Court of Appeal took up the case again

title: CASE OF KRAMARENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1992 and lived in Voronezh before his arrest.
- On 9 October 2011, the applicant stabbed and killed S. and Z. after an altercation with S.
- On 10 October 2011, the police took the applicant to the police station for questioning and he alleged being beaten, electrocuted, and deprived of food and water.
- An expert medical examination showed injuries on the applicant's body which could be the result of blows from blunt objects and self-harm but did not confirm police beating.
- The investigator reported the applicant's injuries but refused to pursue criminal proceedings against the police officers.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Voronezh and the Voronezh Regional Court upheld the investigator's decision.
- The applicant was charged with two counts of murder and declared insane in the Voronezh Regional Court.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the jail sentence for the applicant in the Voronezh Regional Court.

title: CASE OF D.M.D. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 2001 and lived in Bucharest with his mother.
- The applicant and his mother reported domestic abuse to the Bucharest Child Protection Authority.
- The Child Protection Authority certified that the applicant was included in a psychological counselling programme.
- The applicant's father was indicted for abusive behavior towards his son.
- The Bucharest District Court acquitted the father due to not severe enough behavior to constitute a crime.
- The County Court heard evidence from the applicant and convicted the father of ill-treatment inflicted on a minor, giving a suspended sentence of one year's imprisonment and suspending his right to be elected and his parental rights during the sentence and for two additional years.
- The court did not give any explanation for not awarding compensation to the applicant.
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal increased the sentence to three years' imprisonment and maintained the additional penalty of restricting the father's right to be elected and his parental rights.
- The County Court was right in not awarding damages on its own initiative as both the prosecutor's office and the injured party had limited their appeals to the criminal aspects of the case.

title: CASE OF VIKTOR NAZARENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The Kryviy Rih Dovgyntsivskyy District Court ruled in the applicant's favour, ordering an increase in his pension based on rising average wages in the country since his retirement.
- The first-instance court amended the judgement, making it immediately enforceable.
- The defendant pension authority appealed to the Dnipropetrovsk Administrative Court of Appeal.
- The applicant was informed by the first-instance court on 23 November 2011 that an appeal had been lodged in his case. He requested information about the date of the hearing, but received no response until 22 February 2013.
- The Court of Appeal's final decision, dated 26 June 2012, quashed the first-instance court's judgement.
- The domestic case file contains copies of the Court of Appeal's judge ruling and a notification letter informing the applicant of the upcoming examination of his case in camera, but it is unclear if they were sent or delivered to the applicant.

title: CASE OF ČOVIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Hadžići.
- On 22 November 2011, the applicant was arrested and detained on suspicion of having committed war crimes.
- The State Court extended his detention on the risk of him obstructing justice by pressurizing witnesses or destroying evidence.
- On 29 December 2011, an indictment was issued against the applicant and seven other co-suspects.
- The applicant's detention was regularly examined and extended every two months by the State Court.
- On 23 February 2012, the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal on the grounds of arbitrary and excessive detention without relevant and sufficient reasons.
- On 13 July 2012, the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina rejected the applicant's appeal.
- On 1 November 2012, the State Court released the applicant and imposed preventive measures on him.
- The preventive measures were regularly reviewed and extended every two months.
- At the latest available information (22 July 2016), the criminal proceedings against the applicant were ongoing.

title: CASE OF VOROBYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants lived in a dormitory in Lipetsk, Russia mainly inhabited by students and staff of the Lipetsk Metallurgy College.
- In 2000, the joint-stock company "NLMK" registered its title over the dormitory as a result of privatization.
- The applicants sued the Company seeking title to the rooms they lived in, claiming that the privatization violated the law and the Company couldn't be declared the sole owner.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court of Lipetsk initially found for the applicants on April 19, 2010.
- The appeal court upheld the judgment on June 2, 2010, after which the applicants registered their title to the dormitory rooms and sold them.
- On April 12, 2011, the Company requested that the proceedings were reopened citing newly discovered documents.
- On May 12, 2011, the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Lipetsk quashed the initial judgment of 19 April 2010.
- On August 31, 2011, as a result of the fresh consideration of the case, the Oktyabrskiy District Court rejected the applicants' claims and ordered the reversal of execution of the previous judgment.
- The Lipetsk Regional Court upheld this judgment on October 26, 2011.

title: CASE OF RADULOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Bor.
- The applicant was employed by the bank called Borska banka AD, (“the debtor”), which was predominantly comprised of socially-owned capital.
- On 13 February 2004, the Zaječar Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor.
- On 8 February 2005, the Zaječar Commercial Court recognized the applicant’s claims concerning salary arrears.
- The applicant was paid 8,533 Serbian dinars (RSD) on account of the debt in question but the remainder of the debt has not been paid until the present day.
- The insolvency proceedings are still pending.
- On 14 December 2006, the applicant applied to the Zaječar Commercial Court for enforcement of the court’s decision of 8 February 2005, which was recognized the applicant’s claims.
- The Zaječar Commercial Court declined its jurisdiction ratione materiae and transferred the case file to the Bor Municipal Court.
- On 7 May 2007, the Bor Municipal Court dismissed the applicant’s enforcement request on the ground that the Commercial Court’s decision was not suitable for execution.
- On 23 November 2007, The Zaječar District Court upheld the first instance court’s decision stating that the debtor had been subject to the pending insolvency proceedings.
- On 18 March 2008, the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal against the Zaječar District Court’s decision.
- On 4 November 2010, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicant’s constitutional appeal, stating that the applicant had failed to properly seize the Constitutional Court, having lodged her appeal against “the wrong” decision.

title: CASE OF EILDERS AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Leverkusen, Germany. She is the daughter of the second and third applicants who were born in 1943 and 1942 respectively and lived in Tambov, Russia. The second applicant Ms Galina Zabelina died in 2013.
- The brother of the first applicant, Mr P.Z. was charged with large-scale fraud on 25 April 2007 and accused of embezzling the assets of the companies under his management.
- A senior operational officer from the Federal Security Service sent a letter to the investigator on 12 May 2007, stating that the real estate property owned by the first and second applicant had been purchased at the expense of their close relative P.Z.
- On 22 May 2007, the investigator asked the Basmannyy District Court in Moscow to authorise attachment of the applicants' property, including three flats owned by the first applicant, a flat owned by the second applicant, and a car owned by the third applicant.
- On 24 May 2007, the District Court issued the requested writs of attachment, as it had been lodged in the framework of a criminal case by the competent official and with the prosecutor’s approval.
- The applicants filed an appeal explaining that they had paid for the impugned property out of their pocket and that there were no legal grounds for attaching their property.
- On 13 August 2007, the Moscow City Court rejected their appeals, stating that the District Court had reached the justified conclusion that there were sufficient grounds for seizing the listed property.
- The attachment of the applicants’ property has remained in place to date.

title: CASE OF POSTNOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the widow of Mr Vitaliy Sergeyevich Postnov
- On 5 December 2000, the District Court ordered the Administration of the Ulyanovsk Region to pay Mr Postnov 228,000 Russian roubles (RUB) and RUB 810 for an expert examination.
- In January 2001, Mr Postnov obtained two writs of execution and forwarded them to the bailiffs' service in Ulyanovsk.
- On 26 April 2002, Mr Postnov passed away.
- In June 2003, the applicant joined the enforcement proceedings in her late husband's stead.
- In 2003, the applicant and the bailiff applied for changing the method of execution of the judgment, which was refused.
- On 22 December 2004, the writ of execution in respect of RUB 228,000 was returned to the applicant from the bailiffs' service without enforcement.
- On 13 November 2003, 13 July 2004, and 20 May 2005 the District Court awarded the applicant RUB 169,846.46, RUB 17,401.28, and RUB 36,517.69 respectively.
- In June 2005, the applicant obtained the writs of execution in respect of the three above decisions, and a new writ of execution in respect of the judgment of 5 December 2000.
- On 31 May 2006, the applicant submitted all the writs of execution to the bailiffs' service.
- On 2 June 2006, the bailiffs initiated the execution proceedings. On 6 June 2006, the proceedings were terminated.

title: CASE OF NOVAYA GAZETA AND MILASHINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant company is an editorial and publishing house in Moscow that publishes a national newspaper.
- The Novaya Gazeta is a newspaper with a circulation of 500,000.
- On 12 August 2000, the K-141 Kursk, a nuclear cruise missile submarine of the Russian Navy, sank in the Barents Sea during a naval exercise. Most of the crew died.
- 23 crew members survived the explosions and wrote a note to report the events but died before the rescue team arrived.
- The Chief Military Prosecutor's Office launched an official investigation after the incident.
- The investigation was terminated on 22 July 2002, and B.K. challenged the decision in court.
- The Military Court of the Moscow Garrison confirmed the decision of the Chief Military Prosecutor's Office in April and June 2004.
- The second applicant, who lives in Moscow, wrote a series of articles on the Kursk catastrophe and the investigation into it in the newspaper between 2000 and 2005.
- B.K.'s application to the Court on behalf of R.K. alleging a violation of D.K.'s right to life was lodged in late 2004.
- On 24 January 2005, the newspaper published an article entitled "The Kursk case is now before the European Court," written by the second applicant.
- On 27 January 2005, the newspaper published another article by the second applicant, entitled "The prosecutor's office is worried about the prospect of the Kursk case being examined by the European Court. All reasonable offers welcome?".
- After the publication of the two articles, V.K., A.E., A.S., and the Chief Military Prosecutor's Office of Russia as a legal entity launched civil actions for defamation against the applicants.
- The Basmannyy District Court of Moscow awarded each claimant compensation for non-pecuniary damage and the retraction of certain statements appearing in the articles.
- The applicants appealed, arguing that the contested information amounted to value judgments and reflected the opinions of R.K. and B.K. but were unsuccessful.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the District Court's judgment in full.
- The bailiffs' service commenced enforcement proceedings against the applicant company, and on 22–25 June 2006, the newspaper published the retraction regarding V.K.

title: CASE OF STASZUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was arrested in Kyiv on suspicion of unlawfully importing equipment for covert surveillance and intercepting private telephone conversations.
- The SBU investigator lodged a request for the applicant to be remanded in custody pending the investigation.
- The District Court held a hearing and remanded the applicant in custody, citing the risk of absconding and interference with the investigation.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the decision to remand the applicant in custody on several occasions.
- The applicant was charged with additional offences and his detention was repeatedly extended until his conviction in March 2012.
- The Court of Appeal later quashed the conviction, remitted the case for additional investigation, but ordered the applicant's continuing detention without giving reasons.
- The applicant was later released on bail, and the District Court approved his plea bargain and sentenced him to two years and eight months' imprisonment, which was to be considered fully served in view of the time the applicant had spent in pre-trial detention.

title: CASE OF KALĒJA v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant worked as an accountant and cashier for a building management company.
- Illicit cash withdrawals from the company’s cash registers were reported, allegedly made by the applicant and a colleague.
- Internal and external audits found manipulation of data in the company’s cash registers to conceal illicit cash withdrawals.
- The applicant gave a written explanation to the police admitting to annulling three cash transactions and making three cash withdrawals at the request of the deputy head of the company; she denied taking any additional cash.
- The police instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant and B.E. for misappropriation of funds.
- The police interviewed the applicant six times as a witness, during which her rights and obligations as a witness were explained but no mention of a right to legal assistance was made.
- The case was referred to the prosecutor’s office four times before charges were brought against the applicant in 2005.
- The applicant was convicted of nineteen episodes of misappropriation of property and given a three-year suspended prison sentence, which was later reduced to a two-year suspended sentence with one year’s probation.

title: CASE OF SUKHANOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Kyiv and was the director of a private company.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against him in 2002 on charges of tax evasion and forgery in office. The tax-evasion charges were later dropped.
- In December 2004, he was found guilty of forgery in office, specifically, knowingly entering false data in the tax returns of the company he was directing.
- The applicant was sentenced to one year's restriction of liberty, suspended on probation for one year, with a ban on holding administrative posts for one year. He was also under undertaking not to leave the town until the judgment became final.
- The applicant appealed the judgment on the grounds that his actions did not constitute a crime, and he had not received a fair trial.
- On 17 March 2005, the appellate court rejected the applicant's appeal, despite the absence of both the applicant and his lawyer.
- The applicant appealed on points of law, citing the examination of his case on appeal in his and his lawyer's absence as being in breach of his defence rights.
- On 23 January 2007, the Supreme Court upheld the decisions of the lower courts.

title: CASE OF VOSKOBOYNIKOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1940 and lives in Odesa.
- The applicant was the director general of a joint venture V. (“company V.”) located in the premises of a joint stock company Y. (“company Y.”).
- The new management of company Y. questioned the legality of the use of its premises by company V.
- Company Y. no longer allowed access to its premises to company V.
- Company V. brought commercial proceedings against company Y. seeking compliance with the lease contract but it was rejected.
- A criminal case was opened accusing suspected forgery of a lease contract of 12 January 1999.
- Documents were seized from company V.'s office, which was the applicant's flat.
- A search was ordered and carried out in the applicant's flat in his presence resulting in the seizure of documents.
- Seizure of company V.’s constituent documents from the company’s office was carried out in the applicant’s flat.
- The criminal proceedings were discontinued due to lack of evidence of a criminal offense.
- The applicant resumed his duties in company V.
- The applicant brought a lawsuit against the Prymorskyy Prosecutor’s Office claiming compensation in respect of non-pecuniary damage allegedly caused by its unlawful actions.
- The applicant's claim was rejected by the court. 
- The applicant appealed, but the Odesa Regional Court of Appeal rejected his appeal. 
- The Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' decisions.

title: CASE OF AVIAKOMPANIYA A.T.I., ZAT v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of facts:

- The applicant company was a Ukrainian joint-stock company registered in Kyiv that operated a commercial air carrier business.
- The company brought a claim for damages against the State Aviation Safety Department for delaying the issuance of a safety certificate required by a court judgment since 2001.
- The Kyiv City Commercial Court allowed the claim in part, but the Kyiv Commercial Court of Appeal quashed the judgment and rejected the claim. The Higher Commercial Court reversed the ruling of the Court of Appeal and upheld the judgment of the first instance court. The Supreme Court quashed the ruling of the Higher Commercial Court and upheld the ruling of the Court of Appeal.
- The Government acknowledged a breach of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention and offered to pay the applicant company a sum to cover any pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages and any costs and expenses. They requested the Court to strike out the application in accordance with Article 37 § 1 of the Convention.
- The applicant company objected to the striking out of its application, arguing that the unilateral declaration wouldn't restore its rights under domestic law. The Government informed the Court of the relevant domestic legislation and submitted a letter from the Supreme Court informing the Government Agent that there was no relevant domestic case-law on the matter.
- The applicant company's shareholder informed the Court that the applicant company had been declared bankrupt and liquidated, and requested that any just satisfaction award be paid to the shareholder. The Government did not object to the request.

title: CASE OF BERÁNEK v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
- The applicant is born in 1965 and lives in Smědčice.
- On 9 November 2006, the applicant requested a building permit for temporary stables for horses.
- On 6 January 2011, the request was dismissed by the Rokycany Planning Office.
- On 26 May 2011, the Plzeň Regional Office upheld the decision.
- On 29 March 2013, the Plzeň Regional Court dismissed a complaint lodged by the applicant.
- On 31 July 2013, the Supreme Administrative Court dismissed an appeal on points of law lodged by the applicant, and the decision was served on the applicant on 28 August 2013.
- On 29 October 2013, the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint.
- On 31 March 2014, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicant’s appeal as being lodged out of time.
- On 8 April 2014, the applicant wrote to the Constitutional Court urging it to set aside its decision.
- By a letter of 11 April 2014, the Registrar of the Constitutional Court acknowledged that the time-limit had been complied with, but advised the applicant to lodge an application with the European Court of Human Rights.

title: CASE OF OSTROVEŅECS v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant and his co-accused were charged with the aggravated murder of a fifteen-year-old girl and the intentional destruction of property.
- The applicant was held in detention on remand in Riga Central Prison and transported to the Riga Regional Court for the hearings.
- The applicant alleged that he was insulted and physically assaulted by the detainee escort officers to make him confess to the crimes during the trial days.
- The applicant’s mother lodged a complaint with the prosecution service, stating that the escort officers had assaulted her son.
- The Internal Security Office conducted an internal inquiry into the alleged ill-treatment, but refused to institute criminal proceedings three times, prompting the prosecution service to intervene and order further investigation.

title: CASE OF GLAVAK v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Donji Kraljevec.
- The applicant brought a civil action against a private person in the Čakovec Municipal Court seeking that a contract for lifelong maintenance be declared null and void, that certain entries in the land register be altered, and that certain property be included in his deceased father’s estate.
- The Čakovec Municipal Court declared the applicant’s action inadmissible, and the Čakovec County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal and upheld the first-instance decision.
- The Supreme Court accepted the applicant’s appeal on points of law, examined it on the merits and quashed the decisions of the lower courts and ordered a fresh consideration of the case. However, in the subsequent proceedings, the Čakovec County Court reversed the first-instance judgment, and the applicant’s appeal on points of law was later declared inadmissible by the Supreme Court.
- A constitutional complaint subsequently lodged by the applicant was declared inadmissible by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF ĀBELE v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained in Jēkabpils Prison and is a person with special needs.
- The applicant is deaf and mute since birth and has poor knowledge of sign language.
- The applicant has been recognised as being category 3 disabled on 2 March 2001 and re-categorised as category 2 on an unspecified date.
- On 7 May 2008, the applicant was convicted of aggravated murder and sentenced to fifteen years and six months’ imprisonment. 
- The applicant was transferred to Brasa Prison on 23 December 2011.
- The applicant was held in cell no. 301 (from 1 January 2012 to 26 February 2013) and cell no. 303 (from 26 February to 30 October 2013) in the medium regime and cell no. 203 in the most restrictive “lower” regime (from 30 October 2013 until 16 February 2015).
- On 24 February 2016, the applicant was placed in the least restrictive “higher” regime.
- The applicant claims that he was unable to communicate with other inmates or prison management due to his disability.
- The applicant complained about the inadequate heating in the cells.
- The applicant’s complaints were examined by the Prisons Administration and concluded that there had been no real threat to the applicant’s life or health in Brasa Prison.
- The applicant’s medical care was carried out in accordance with domestic law.
- The applicant attempted to appeal against the above-mentioned refusals, but his appeal did not appear sufficiently clear.
- On 31 August 2016, a panel in Brasa Prison examined the possibility of the applicant’s transfer to a more lenient prison regime and concluded that it was possible to transfer him to a partly closed prison.
- On 7 September 2016, the applicant was transferred to a partly closed prison in Jēkabpils.
- The relevant parts of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the Interim Report of 28 July 2008 are cited in the case.

title: CASE OF BECKER v. NORWAY
facts:
- The applicant is a journalist for DN.no, a Norwegian Internet-based version of the newspaper Dagens Næringsliv (“DN”), published by the company DN Nye Medier AS.
- Mr X was indicted for market manipulation and insider trading under the 1997 Act on the Trade of Financial Assets (verdipapirhandelloven).
- Mr X had requested Mr Y, an attorney, to draft a letter concerning the Norwegian Oil Company (“DNO”), giving the impression that it had been written on behalf of a number of bond holders who were seriously concerned about the company’s liquidity, finances and future. In fact, it had been written only on Mr X’s behalf. He had owned only one bond, which he had acquired the same day as he had asked attorney Y to draft the letter.
- Mr X sent a copy of the letter by fax to the applicant and in a telephone conversation with her, and the following day the applicant wrote an article expressing strong concerns about the content of Attorney Y’s letter, a central feature in the article.
- The price of DNO stock fell by 4.1% on the first trading day after the content of the letter became known in the press, and the Oslo stock exchange (Oslo børs) suspected market manipulation.
- The applicant was questioned by the police, informed that Mr X had given her the letter, and handed a signed statement from Mr X in which he confirmed this.
- During the criminal case against Mr X, the applicant was summoned as a witness and refused to answer questions about possible contacts between her and Mr X and other sources related to the publication by DN.no.
- By a decision, the City Court held that the applicant had a duty to give evidence about her contacts with Mr X as a source.
- The Borgarting High Court rejected the applicant's appeal against the City Court’s order, finding that it had been established beyond reasonable doubt that Mr X had been the applicant’s source.
- An appeal by the applicant to the Supreme Court was rejected by three votes to two.

title: CASE OF ARTUR PAWLAK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and is currently in detention in Rzeszów.
- On 19 April 2005, the applicant was arrested and placed in detention in Chełm Prison. He faced multiple charges for murder, rape, assault, robbery, fraud, and handling stolen goods.
- The Lublin Regional Court convicted him on 4 August 2010, and the Lublin Court of Appeal upheld the first-instance judgment on 8 February 2011.
- Chełm Prison requested that the Lublin Regional Court order the applicant to take part in a rehabilitation programme for convicted drug addicts while he served his sentence.
- On 14 September 2009, the Chełm Prison Penitentiary Commission classified the applicant as a "dangerous detainee."
- Over the years, the Lublin Remand Centre Penitentiary Commission extended the period of the dangerous detainee regime imposed on the applicant based on his violent behavior towards other inmates and prison guards.
- Owing to an improvement in the applicant’s behavior and his progress in understanding the need to undergo therapy for drug addicts, the dangerous detainee regime ended on 12 February 2014.
- In detention, the applicant wore a red uniform designated for dangerous detainees, underwent strip searches frequently, and wore handcuffs whenever he was outside his cell.
- The applicant was detained in several detention facilities and cells, including solitary confinement, with a sanitary facility that was either separated from the rest of the cell or not separated at all.
- The cells were constantly monitored via closed-circuit television, and the windows were covered by a plastic blind, limiting access to daylight and fresh air in the cells.
- The applicant had access to sports facilities, a laptop, television, a computer game console, press publications, and the library while in detention.
- He participated in sports and art competitions before the dangerous detainee regime was lifted, but he refused to participate in any activities after that.
- The applicant had to wear joined shackles (handcuffs and fetters joined by chains) on his hands and feet whenever he was outside the prison, and the shackles caused him discomfort.

title: CASE OF NEDIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Podgorica.
- In 2003, the applicant requested restitution of the property expropriated from his father in 1969.
- The applicant submitted another application in 2005 to the newly established Commission for Restitution and Compensation requesting compensation.
- The applicant filed an appeal with the Appeals Commission in 2009 due to the Commission's inactivity.
- The Appeals Commission ordered the Commission to decide on the applicant's request within 30 days in December 2013.
- The Commission ruled against the applicant in 2014, which was upheld by the Appeals Commission later that year.
- The applicant filed a claim with the Administrative Court but was rejected in 2015 as unfounded.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal in June 2015, which was rejected by the Constitutional Court in July 2015 due to failure to make use of other available domestic remedies.

title: CASE OF FELLNER AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants bought different amounts of Turkish and German share certificates in Demirbank through the German stock market.
- The Banking Regulation and Supervision Board decided to transfer the management and control of Demirbank to the Savings Deposit Insurance Fund.
- Demirbank’s management and control, and the privileges of its shareholders except for dividends, were transferred to the Fund.
- On 6 December 2000 Board of Directors of the Fund decided to take over the shares of Demirbank in exchange for paying Demirbank’s loss corresponding to its paid-up capital.
- All equities of Demirbank were transferred to the account of the Fund.
- The Supreme Administrative Court set aside the Board’s decision of 6 December 2000, holding that the takeover had been illegal.
- The Fund entered into an agreement with HSBC Bank and sold Demirbank to the latter. 
- Ms S. Cıngıllıoğlu brought administrative proceedings against the Fund before the Ankara Administrative Court seeking the annulment of the agreement to sell Demirbank to HSBC, and the court annulled the agreement on the ground that the transfer of Demirbank to the Fund has been found illegal. 
- The administrative courts dismissed the applicants' cases who applied to the Board claiming compensation that they lost their shares in Demirbank, since they failed to initiate the proceedings on time. 
- Following the annulment of the decision concerning the transfer of Demirbank to the Fund by the domestic courts in 2005, the applicants applied to the administrative courts, but their requests were rejected. 
- The applicants brought a third set of proceedings against the Fund and claimed compensation for their lost shares in Demirbank, but their claims were dismissed for being out of time.

title: CASE OF FATIH TAŞ v. TURKEY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was the owner and editor-in-chief of a publishing house that published a periodical called Vesta.
- The article titled "On the Kurdish Intellectual" was written by Mr M.Ş. and was published in Vesta in 2004.
- The public prosecutor charged the applicant with disseminating propaganda in favor of a terrorist organization.
- The applicant was convicted by the Istanbul Assize Court in 2008 for propagandizing on behalf of the PKK.
- The court considered certain passages of the article as propaganda for the PKK and sentenced the applicant to imprisonment and fines.
- The court withheld the sentence on the condition that the applicant did not commit another intentional offense for five years.

title: CASE OF GRIGOLOVIČ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1941 and lives in the village of Bajorai in Vilnius Region.
- Between December 1999 and September 2000, the national authorities allocated plots of land to six third parties who later transferred their property rights to another person in accordance with previous requests they had lodged, thereby compensating for their or their parents' property nationalised by the Soviet regime.
- The land allocated to these third parties was in the same area as the applicant's father's land, which had been nationalised.
- The applicant requested the Lithuanian authorities to restore his property rights to his father's land in July 2000, and in 2002, changed his request to be restored under the same form as before nationalisation.
- The applicant's request was complicated as the land in question was State redeemable, and the authorities asked for further documents to proceed.
- In 2009, the authorities decided to restore the applicant's property rights but only to 0.18 hectares, and the applicant filed a claim with the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court to annul the decisions of the authorities and award him compensation for pecuniary damage; however, the court rejected his claim.
- In 2012, the authorities informed the applicant that he could receive monetary compensation for the land, and in 2014, they asked if it was possible to demarcate any vacant and non-State redeemable land to return to the heirs of the applicant's father.

title: CASE OF GÜLER AND TEKDAL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are two individuals who live in Ecemiş village near the town of Lice in the province of Diyarbakır.
- The first applicant's brother and the second applicant's nephew, Murat Tekdal, was 30 years old and living in the same village.
- On 12 September 2008, Murat Tekdal was returning home from visiting his uncle when he left his home to walk to the nearby Şenlik village.
- Villagers in Ecemiş village heard gunfire on the same day between 5 and 7 p.m.
- The next day, it was reported that a person had been killed, and the headman of the village and the villagers went to Lice and were handed the body of Murat Tekdal.
- According to a report by seven members of the military, soldiers encountered three to four persons in the area whom they considered to be members of the PKK. The soldiers asked the persons to surrender, but the persons opened fire. The soldiers returned fire and a clash ensued for approximately five minutes.
- The soldiers later conducted a search in the area and found the body of Murat Tekdal in Karaçay hill area with a hunting rifle still loaded with two unexploded cartridges.
- The seven soldiers concluded that Murat Tekdal had been a "terrorist posing as an ordinary citizen."
- An autopsy was carried out, and the doctor observed two bullet holes on Murat Tekdal's lower left abdomen. The internal examination of the body revealed injuries to the stomach, liver, diaphragm, spleen, intestines, and lungs, all caused by bullets. It was determined that death was caused by bullets that had either entered or exited from the lower left abdomen and that he was shot at close range.
- The Lice prosecutor sent the investigation file to the Diyarbakır prosecutor, who concluded not to bring any criminal proceedings against Murat Tekdal.
- The applicants sent a letter to the Diyarbakır prosecutor, stating that their relative had not been a member of the PKK, and asked for those responsible for his killing to be identified and prosecuted.
- The applicants lodged an objection, which was rejected by the Malatya Assize Court.

title: CASE OF PALİTKIRAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1989 and lives in Manisa.
- Applicant was dismissed from the Expert Gendarmerie School on 7 July 2009.
- Dismissal was due to non-compliance with disciplinary rules.
- Applicant appealed to the Supreme Military Administrative Court on 28 July 2009 to annul the decision.
- On 6 January 2010, the Supreme Military Administrative Court rejected the applicant's appeal, considering "secret documents" submitted by the Ministry of Defence that were not disclosed to the applicant.
- On 5 May 2010, the applicant's request for rectification was also rejected.

title: CASE OF BAĞLAR v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1989 and lives in Istanbul.
- The applicant was taken into police custody on suspicion of being a member of an illegal organization on 14 January 2009.
- The investigating judge ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention on 17 January 2009.
- The Istanbul public prosecutor filed an indictment on 24 June 2009.
- The first preparatory hearing for the trial was held on 4 November 2009.
- Between 17 February 2010 and 3 November 2010, the applicant appeared before the court and was ordered to remain in detention.
- The applicant filed an objection against the decision of 3 November 2010.
- The objection was dismissed without an oral hearing, based on the public prosecutor's written opinion, which was not communicated to the applicant or his representative.
- The applicant was released on 13 February 2013 from detention on remand.
- The proceedings against the applicant are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF TARJÁNI v. HUNGARY
facts:
Main descriptions of facts in bullet points:

- The applicant is a person who was born in 1976 and lives in Budapest.
- On 20 July 2015, a quarrel ensued between the applicant and his common-law wife, leading to the latter calling an ambulance due to the applicant's odd and violent behavior under the influence of alcohol.
- Instead of an ambulance, police officers arrived and took the applicant to the Orosháza police department, where he alleges that he was assaulted by one of them while handcuffed and in the room for short-term arrestees.
- He suffered injuries, including a broken tibia, and was hospitalized following examination.
- There were conflicting reports from witnesses and police, and the Central Investigation Office investigated but ultimately discontinued the criminal proceedings due to a lack of conclusive evidence.

title: CASE OF KHADZHIMURADOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Twenty-one relatives of the applicants (spouses, children, brothers, and an uncle) were allegedly killed by State servicemen on 5 February 2000 in the Novye Aldy settlement.
- A criminal investigation was opened on 5 March 2000, and it is still ongoing.
- Only one applicant was present in Novye Aldy at the time of the events, while the others were out of the district or Chechnya.
- Several documents were submitted in support of the claims, including death certificates, statements from witnesses, and press and NGO reports.
- Some applicants' health deteriorated due to stress and anguish, and the authorities' insufficient response worsened their condition.
- The case is related to the Musayev and Others v. Russia case, in which 11 of their relatives were killed by unidentified servicemen on the same day in the same place.
- The investigation revealed that more than 50 people were killed by unidentified servicemen using automatic weapons, APCs, and military Ural trucks, who also looted and burnt down houses.
- The authorities failed to carry out an effective investigation, and one applicant was found to be a victim of inhuman and degrading treatment in breach of Article 3 of the Convention.
- Some applicants were granted victim status in criminal investigation file no. 12011 on various dates between March 2000 and June 2012.
- The investigation was adjourned and resumed multiple times and identified a suspect, S.B.
- The investigators collected additional information about the suspects and questioned dozens of servicemen, but no one was identified with a snake-shaped tattoo mentioned by one of the witnesses.
- Several reminders were sent to identify and question commanders and members of the military units involved in the operation.

title: CASE OF DAŞTAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1975 and is detained in Turkey.
- Applicant was arrested on 22 August 2004 on suspicion of PKK membership.
- Applicant gave a lengthy statement admitting his membership and providing detailed information about the organization and its members.
- Applicant confirmed membership but denied involvement in armed operation when brought before the public prosecutor.
- Applicant was charged with seeking to destroy the constitutional order and unity of the Turkish State under Article 125 of the former Criminal Code.
- Applicant was accused of causing injuries to soldiers through explosions of remote-controlled land mines and time bombs.
- Several witness statements, including D.T.'s, were considered during the trial.
- The trial court sentenced the applicant to life imprisonment.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF S.S. YENİKÖY KONUT YAPI KOOPERATİFİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a housing construction cooperative under Turkish law.
- In 1993, a third party cooperative bought a plot of land measuring 12,000 square metres and the title deed of the land was registered in its name. 
- Construction works started on the land in 1995.
- In 2000, the forest administration initiated proceedings before the Menderes Civil Court of First Instance for the annulment of the title deed to the land, alleging that it was part of the public forest area.
- The third party cooperative had merged with the applicant cooperative and the land was registered in the name of the latter.
- On 26 December 2002, the Menderes Civil Court of First Instance ordered that 9,322 square metres of the land be registered in the name of the Treasury as it was part of the public forest area. It also ordered that the buildings constructed on this part of the land be demolished. 
- The applicant sought pecuniary damages from the Treasury for the loss under Article 1007 of the Civil Code.
- The Menderes Civil Court of First Instance awarded the applicant 138,917,600,000 Turkish Liras in compensation.
- The decision was quashed by the Fourth Civil Division of the Court of Cassation on the ground of no illegal act or action taken by land registry officials.
- The applicant brought the case to the Menderes Civil Court of First Instance again, claiming that there was a decision of the First Civil Division of the Court of Cassation that supported their case.
- The court dismissed the applicant's claim and the decision was upheld by the Fourth Civil Division.
- The decisions of the courts did not explain why they reached a different conclusion from the First Civil Division of the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF TAŞÇI v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Ankara.
- Applicant was serving as a non-commissioned officer in the army.
- Applicant was dismissed from the army in 1995.
- The applicant filed a case for annulment of his dismissal decision and asked for pecuniary compensation.
- On 20 December 2005, the Supreme Military Administrative Court accepted the applicant's compensation claims in part and annulled the dismissal decision.
- On 18 April 2006, the court rejected the applicant's rectification request for the remaining compensation claims.

title: CASE OF GENÇ AND DEMIRGAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1971, 1953, and 1976 respectively and live in Bergama, İzmir.
- The company received an authorization to begin gold prospecting in 1989 and was later authorized to use cyanide leaching in the gold extraction process by the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources.
- In 1994, the Ministry of the Environment issued an operating permit to the company for the Ovacık gold mine.
- In 1997, the Supreme Administrative Court annulled the operating permit due to the risk posed to the local ecosystem and to human health and safety by sodium cyanide use.
- In 2000, the Prime Minister's office drew up a report concluding that operations at the mine could be authorized.
- In 2001, the İzmir Administrative Court set aside the report and held that the decision in question was incompatible with the principle of the rule of law.
- In 2004, the İzmir Administrative Court set aside the provisional permit issued by the Ministry of Health and concluded that the issuing of the permit in question had been incompatible with the principle of the rule of law.
- In 2006, the Supreme Administrative Court annulled the decision of the Cabinet of Ministers, allowing the gold mine to continue operations.
- Various sets of proceedings were brought between 2006 and 2012 by other residents of Bergama against various administrative authorities and the company before the administrative courts.

title: CASE OF ADYAN AND OTHERS v. ARMENIA
facts:
Facts of the case:

- The applicants are four Jehovah’s Witnesses who were found to be fit for military service.
- The applicants refused to perform military or alternative service based on their religious beliefs.
- The alternative service available in Armenia was supervised by the military authorities and violated their rights guaranteed by Article 9 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
- Charges were brought against the applicants under Article 327 § 1 of the Criminal Code (evasion of regular conscription).
- The first, second, and fourth applicants were detained and sentenced to prison.
- The third applicant was also charged and later sentenced to prison.
- The applicants argued that their opposition to military and alternative service was based on their religious beliefs protected by Article 9 of the Convention.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the lower courts’ judgments and found that the alternative service in Armenia was of a genuinely civilian nature.
- The applicants’ appeals on points of law were declared inadmissible by the Court of Cassation.
- The applicants were released from prison following a general amnesty.

title: CASE OF TIZIANA PENNINO v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant was driving her car on 2 April 2013 when she was stopped by the police officers.
- An argument arose between the applicant and the officers due to her nervous and hostile attitude, which led the officers to suspect that she was intoxicated.
- The officers did not have the necessary equipment to perform a breathalyser test, so they requested the assistance of the road police.
- The applicant was dragged out of her car by one of the police officers, who fractured her right thumb and caused other injuries to her wrists in the process.
- When the applicant reached the municipal police station, she repeatedly requested to use a telephone to let her family and lawyer know of her whereabouts, but her requests were denied. One of the officers hit her when she tried to pick up the phone, handcuffed her and threatened her.
- The applicant was charged with a number of offenses in connection with the events of 2 April 2013, including driving under the influence of alcohol, insulting a public official, and resisting a police officer.
- The applicant suffers from chronic post-traumatic stress disorder, which has evolved into a major depressive disorder, and also from a disorder characterised by mood swings, which are exacerbated in times of particular stress or by the consumption of alcohol or sleep deprivation.

title: CASE OF GABAIDZE v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant was a judge at the Khulo District Court.
- The Supreme Council of Justice initiated disciplinary proceedings against him on the grounds of unlawfully detaining a defendant in a criminal case for 14 days in September 2004.
- A panel of the Disciplinary Council found the applicant guilty and removed him from judicial office.
- The applicant appealed to the Disciplinary Council and the Supreme Court, but both upheld the decision.
- The Supreme Court found the punishment appropriate, and the composition of the benches legal.

title: CASE OF KAHRIMAN v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1935 and lives in the United States
- On August 18, 2003, the applicant filed a civil proceeding against private individuals related to some contracts
- On June 6, 2007, the Bijeljina Court of First Instance gave a judgment
- On April 10, 2009, the Bijeljina District Court invalidated the first judgment, and the case was sent back to the first-instance court for a retrial
- On May 19, 2011, the Bijeljina Court of First Instance delivered a new judgment
- The Bijeljina District Court changed the verdict on September 23, 2011
- The Supreme Court of the Republika Srpska ratified the judgment on August 16, 2012
- The applicant filed a claim before the Constitutional Court, arguing that the proceedings took too long, and requested financial compensation
- On June 17, 2015, the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina ruled that the applicant's right to a fair trial within a reasonable period was violated, but no damages were awarded.

title: CASE OF BATIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

First Applicant:
- Born in 1958 and lives in Vranje.
- Ordered payment by the court on 19 January 2004, which became final on 15 March 2004.
- Enforcement of judgment ordered on 27 May 2004.
- Ongoing enforcement proceedings were stayed due to insolvency proceedings.
- Constitutional appeal lodged on 23 January 2013.
- Violation found by the Constitutional Court on 28 May 2015; just satisfaction awarded.

Second Applicant:
- Born in 1956 and lives in Niš.
- Settled with the debtor company on 22 December 2005, and ordered payment by the court on 17 December 2010.
- Another payment ordered on 5 September 2008 and enforced on 28 December 2010.
- Republic Agency also ordered payment on 30 June 2007 and 15 October 2007, which were enforced on 27 December 2010 and 28 December 2010, respectively.
- Insolvency proceedings were initiated on 23 May 2012, and enforcement was stayed.
- Claims were recognized on 24 December 2015.
- Constitutional appeal lodged on 11 February 2013, which was dismissed on 18 June 2015.

Third Applicant:
- Born in 1953 and lives in Kragujevac.
- Settled with the debtor company on 13 May 2002, and ordered payment by the court on 27 August 2002.
- Insolvency proceedings were initiated on 5 March 2010, and claim was recognized on 25 October 2010.
- Paid 13.12% of the recognized claim on 2 August 2012.
- Insolvency proceedings are still ongoing.
- Constitutional appeal lodged on 10 May 2013, which was dismissed on 28 December 2015.

title: CASE OF KHUSEYNOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Summary of Facts:

- The applicant was born in 1975 in Vladikavkaz, the Republic of North Ossetia-Alania.
- On 21 January 2013, he was arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking and taken to remand prison no. 20/1 in Grozny, the Chechen Republic.
- On 17 July 2014, he was convicted and sentenced to thirteen years’ imprisonment.
- During a medical check-up upon his admission to the remand prison, a doctor noted an area of pigmentation on the applicant’s face and ordered a biopsy.
- On 27 February 2013, the biopsy showed melanoma, a type of skin cancer.
- Advanced medical care, such as radiotherapy and surgery, was prescribed, and a special programme offered to the applicant.
- In October and November 2013, he was transferred to the Regional Cancer Hospital in Rostov, where surgical removal of the melanoma was recommended, but he refused the treatment.
- On 3 June 2014, the Rostov Institute of Cancer Research recommended surgical removal of the melanoma, but further consultations had been planned to take place at the facility, which the detention authorities failed to ensure his presence.
- On 20 June and 5 September 2014, a panel of doctors recommended surgical removal of the melanoma, which the applicant agreed to but later withdrew his consent due to no confidence in the doctors.
- On 22 September 2014, he was admitted to the Town Hospital in Groznyy for cancer surgery, but refused it the next day.
- On 2 April 2015, a further biopsy showed another type of skin cancer, basal cell carcinoma.
- In October 2015, the applicant applied for early release from detention on medical grounds but was refused.
- On 11 January 2016, he lodged a request for interim measures under Rule 39 of the Rules of Court, complaining of his inability to undergo the complex cancer surgery.
- On 25 January 2016, the Court indicated to the Russian Government about examinations by medical experts.
- On 4 March 2016, the Government responded with a scheduled date for surgery.
- On 10 March 2016, the applicant was transferred to the prison medical unit no. 61 in Rostov-on-Don for surgery.
- In April 2016, it was discovered that the surgical unit in the prison medical unit was undergoing renovation and the applicant was not operated

title: CASE OF AMIROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1954 and was the mayor of Makhachkala between 1998 and 2013. 

• He was arrested in June 2013 and placed in custody pending criminal proceedings against him. 

• He suffered from several illnesses and was confined to a wheelchair, and had to use catheters and enemas to urinate and defecate. 

• He complained about the lack of adequate medical assistance and the Court indicated to the Russian Government that he should be examined by medical experts. 

• The Court found violations of Articles 3 and 34 of the Convention on account of the authorities' failure to provide the applicant with adequate medical care. 

• The authorities were ordered to admit the applicant to a specialised medical facility or a specialised prison medical facility. 

• After November 2014, the applicant continued being detained in the remand prison pending the completion of his trial. 

• The prison was equipped to take account of his needs as a wheelchair user. 

• In 2015 he was examined by various doctors and underwent basic medical tests and received the treatment he had been prescribed. 

• The applicant's lawyers noticed, however, that his state of health had worsened. 

• On several occasions, doctors recommended that he be admitted to a specialised hospital for long-term treatment and urological surgery. 

• The applicant was sentenced to life imprisonment in a high-security correctional colony in August 2015. 

• He spent the first two weeks of his detention in an ordinary cell in the quarantine wing. 

• He was examined by several prison doctors who ordered blood and urine tests, and prescribed treatment, comprising of a special diet and drugs. 

• He was regularly visited by the prison general practitioner in the quarantine wing and underwent blood and urine tests. 

• On 14 April 2016, the applicant was moved to medical unit no.56 and placed in cell no. 12. 

• On several occasions, a special medical board of highly qualified civilian and prison doctors examined the applicant and concluded that there was no need to admit him to a specialist medical facility. 

• The applicant's lawyer complained to the Ombudsman of the Russian Federation of the applicant's detention conditions and the poor quality of his medical treatment. 

• According to a letter from the chairman of the Committee for Civil Rights sent to the applicant's lawyer, the cell was not adapted to the needs of a wheelchair prisoner. 

• The applicant depended on his fellow inmates, who assisted him

title: CASE OF MAKSOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
