Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant provided heating installation services to a socially-owned company.
- The debtor company went into insolvency proceedings in December 2010.
- The applicant submitted his claim, which was rejected in March 2011.
- The applicant lodged a separate civil claim and won his case in December 2011.
- The judgment was acknowledged in the insolvency proceedings at an unspecified date.
- The Commercial Court ordered the payment of approximately 10% of the total debt to the applicant in July 2013.
- The debtor company was struck from the public register in July 2014.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal in December 2013, which was dismissed by the Constitutional Court in March 2015.

title: CASE OF STOKIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Smederevo.
- The applicant lodged a claim against his employer on 26 March 2007.
- The claim sought payment of certain benefits.
- On 23 April 2012, the Žabari Court Unit ruled in favour of the applicant.
- On 4 October 2012, the Belgrade Appellate Court rejected the applicant's claim.
- The applicant received the judgment on 5 November 2012.
- On 12 November 2014, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicant's constitutional appeal.

title: CASE OF BILIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was employed by HK Komgrap and Komgrap-Makiš doo.
- The company was predominantly socially-owned.
- The applicant brought a civil claim seeking payment of salary arrears and social security contributions.
- The Belgrade Second Municipal Court ordered the debtor to pay the applicant certain sums in respect of salary arrears and various social security contributions.
- The judgment became final and enforceable on 25 July 2005.
- The applicant applied to the Belgrade Fourth Municipal Court for enforcement of the judgment.
- The court ordered the enforcement of the judgment and awarded the applicant the costs incurred in enforcement proceedings.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal seeking redress for the non-enforcement of the judgment.
- The Constitutional Court held that the applicant had suffered a breach of the "right to a trial within a reasonable time" with regard to the enforcement proceedings.
- The court ordered the acceleration of these proceedings and awarded the applicant compensation for the non-pecuniary damage suffered in the amount of 800 EUR.
- The constitutional appeals were premature in so far as they concerned the pecuniary damage and were dismissed in that regard.

title: CASE OF Á.R. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Forráskút. At the time of lodging the application, he was detained at Márianosztra Prison.
- On 29 January 2014 the applicant was convicted of possession of narcotics and sentenced to five years’ imprisonment. On appeal, on 14 October 2014 the Budapest Court of Appeal upheld the judgment.
- The applicant began serving his sentence at Szeged Prison on 15 January 2015 and was transferred to Márianosztra Prison on 26 January 2015. He was released on parole on 8 September 2015.
- While the applicant was held at Szeged Prison, the per capita space available to him was about 3.2 sq. m; the gross ground surface of the cell was 16 sq. m for five occupants but included the in-cell sanitary facility.
- At Márianosztra Prison, the per capita cell space available to the applicant was about 2.67 sq. m; the gross ground surface of the cell was 8 sq. m for three occupants but included the in-cell sanitary facility.
- The applicant submitted that he suffered from epilepsy and a personality disorder. In his own submissions he stated that prior to his conviction he had cultivated and consumed cannabis partly because it alleviated his symptoms.
- As regards the medical care in prison, the Government submitted that, during the first examination at Szeged Prison, the applicant had stated that he suffered from epilepsy without presenting any relevant documentation.
- During his first medical examination at Márianosztra Prison, the doctor noted that the applicant’s aptitude for work could be assessed only after external medical records concerning his illness had been obtained.
- The applicant suffered an epileptic seizure on 24 April 2015, whilst in his cell. Following medication, his condition improved but he refused the neurological examination recommended by the doctor and any further treatment.

title: CASE OF NAVALNYYE v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants Aleksey and Oleg Navalnyy were born in 1976 and 1983 respectively.
- Aleksey is a political activist, opposition leader, anti-corruption campaigner and popular blogger, and lives in Moscow.
- Oleg is an entrepreneur and a former employee of the Federal State unitary enterprise Russian Post who is serving a three-and-a-half year sentence in a correctional colony in the Oryol Region.
- In 2008, Alortag Management Limited, owned by the applicants and their parents, set up a Russian limited liability company, Chief Subscription Agency (GPA), which was active in offering logistical services to Russian Post and its clients, such as printing, sorting, and the transfer of parcels and electronic equipment.
- The prosecution accused the applicants of setting up a "fake company" with the intention of using it for fraud against two clients of Russian Post, Multidisciplinary Processing (MPK) and Yves Rocher Vostok; the prosecution alleged that they took advantage of inside information, misled clients about GPA’s pricing policy and its relationship with Russian Post, and had promoted its services while knowing that it would have to subcontract the work to other companies. The prosecution further stated that GPA retained the difference in price between what MPK and Yves Rocher Vostok paid for its services and what GPA paid to its subcontractors – and that this amounted to money laundering and stealing from the two clients.
- On 30 December 2014, the applicants were found guilty of money laundering and fraud related to MPK and Yves Rocher Vostok and were convicted under Articles 159.4 §§ 2 and 3 and 174.1 § 2 (a) and (b) of the Criminal Code. The first applicant received a suspended sentence of three and a half years and the second applicant a prison sentence of the same duration, to be served in a correctional colony. They were also fined RUB 500,000 each and had to pay jointly RUB 4,498,546 in damages to MPK.

title: CASE OF KRIVOLUTSKAYA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was present at Domodedovo airport during a bomb attack on 24 January 2011, which killed 37 people and injured more than 160.
- The explosion was caused by a suicide bomber, and a militant group operating in North Caucasus was responsible for organizing it.
- The applicant sustained multiple injuries, including wounds, contusions, and fractures, which resulted in further complications, such as cerebral oedema, coma, respiratory and cardiac insufficiency, and a traumatic shock.
- The investigative authorities arrested four persons in connection with the bombing, three of whom were sentenced to life imprisonment, and the fourth received ten years of imprisonment.
- The applicant was granted victim status but did not bring a civil action for damages against the convicted persons.
- Criminal investigations were initiated against the airport managers, employees, and policemen who were deployed at the airport for negligence.
- The applicant was granted a victim status in the negligence proceedings but was later withdrawn.
- The applicant brought a civil claim against the airport seeking damages but was dismissed by the court.

title: CASE OF STEMPLYS AND DEBESYS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Two applicants: Mr Stemplys and Mr Debesys
- Mr Stemplys was detained from 6 April 2005 to 28 August 2015 and submitted a civil claim on 19 December 2012 for being detained in overcrowded and unsanitary cells that caused a deterioration of health 
- The initial claim was allowed in part by the Kaunas Regional Administrative Court and plaintiff was awarded LTL 1,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage. The first-instance court’s judgment was upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court 
- Mr Stemplys submitted a new civil claim against the State concerning the conditions of his detention after 19 December 2012 and was awarded LTL 400 in respect of non-pecuniary damage. First-instance court’s judgment was upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court
- Mr Debesys was detained from 19 May 2001 to 20 December 2013 and also submitted a civil claim on 28 June 2012 for being detained in overcrowded and unsanitary cells that caused deterioration of health
- The initial claim was allowed in part by the Kaunas Regional Administrative Court and plaintiff was awarded LTL 1,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage. The first-instance court’s judgment was upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court 
- Mr Debesys submitted a new civil claim against the State concerning the conditions of his detention after 28 June 2012 and was awarded LTL 500 in respect of non-pecuniary damage. First-instance court’s judgment was upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF SOMOGYI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant born in 1974 and lives in Százhalombatta
- On 11 April 2009, the Pest Central District Court ordered the applicant's pre-trial detention on charges of terrorist acts and other related offenses involving abuse of firearms and explosives
- Detention measure extended on 8 May and again on 7 August 2009, citing risk of collusion and reoffending
- Further extension ordered on 9 November 2009, stating the applicant was being prosecuted for terrorist acts committed as an associate of an organized criminal group
- On 9 February 2010, applicant's detention was extended again
- On 7 April 2010, the measure was renewed, with special reference to the fact that the case was concerned with a series of crimes committed over a long period of time by a criminal organization.
- On 9 June 2010, the Budapest Regional Court ordered that the applicant be held under house arrest.
- On 7 July 2010, the Budapest Court of Appeal again ordered the applicant's detention.
- The measure was extended on 4 August 2010, with additional reasons.
- On 24 November 2010, the Budapest Court of Appeal ordered the applicant's house arrest.
- On 20 September 2012, the applicant's house arrest was replaced by a restraining order.
- On 22 April 2015, the applicant was again detained on remand for the purposes of prosecution for a new offense.
- On 18 December 2015, the applicant was released from detention and put under house arrest.
- On 30 August 2016, the applicant and his accomplices were convicted.

title: CASE OF ÖZGÜR KESKİN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lived in İzmir.
- On 18 June 1998, the applicant started working for a company owned by İzmir City Council.
- On 19 March 2007, he resigned from his job to perform his military service.
- On 12 April 2007, the applicant was paid severance pay and signed a release discharging the City Council from all liability.
- Following his discharge from the military on health grounds, the applicant requested his reinstatement in his job on 20 April and 31 May 2007. However, his requests were rejected by the City Council.
- On 28 June 2007, the applicant initiated proceedings before the İzmir Labour Court, seeking reinstatement.
- On 12 September 2007, the İzmir Labour Court found in favour of the applicant and held that the applicant was entitled to be reinstated in accordance with the terms of the collective agreement.
- On 18 September 2007, the City Council appealed against the decision and reserved its right to submit additional observations once the reasoned judgment of the first-instance court had been served on it.
- On 15 October 2007, the registry of the first-instance court forwarded the file to the Court of Cassation for appeal on points of law.
- On 23 October 2007, the City Council submitted its additional observations.
- On 21 July 2008, following an examination based on the case file and without holding a hearing, the Court of Cassation quashed the first-instance court’s judgment and found in favour of the City Council.
- No appeal was possible against this decision.
- This decision was served on the applicant on 22 September 2008.

title: CASE OF GACHMA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former military officer born in 1955 and residing in Budenovsk, the Stavropol Region of the Russian Federation
- The applicant sued his former employer military unit at an unspecified date
- On 3 May 2001, the Military Court of the Pyatigorsk Garrison issued a judgment ordering the head of the military unit to re-calculate and pay the applicant some additional payments and field allowance for certain periods
- The judgment came into force on 14 May 2001
- The applicant obtained the writ of execution in March 2002 and submitted it to the Department of the Federal Treasury, but it was returned to him due to the military unit not having an account there and the judgment not containing specific awarded amounts
- The applicant submitted the writ of execution to the bailiffs' service on 21 March 2002, and the enforcement proceedings were initiated
- The enforcement proceedings were terminated on 19 February 2003, and the writ was returned to the applicant without enforcement following his request to withdraw the writ
- The applicant's requests to the domestic courts for clarification of the initial judgment were dismissed in 2004-2005 as being lodged out of time, and the courts noted that the matter concerning the awarded amounts should have been resolved by way of an additional decision
- The judgment of 3 May 2001 remained unenforced in the part concerning the payment to the applicant of the second salary and the field allowances for the periods specified in the judgment
- On 24 March 2016, the Ministry of Finance of Russia calculated the amount due to the applicant under the judgment of 3 May 2001, which amounted to 80,220.74 Russian roubles.

title: CASE OF TITOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Lisichansk-18, the Lugansk region of Ukraine.
- In 1972, the applicant suffered 100 per cent disability due to a traffic accident.
- In 1994, the State Health Care Institution of the Sanitary and Epidemiology Monitoring of the Ministry of Railways of the Russian Federation was found responsible for the accident by the Lisichansk Town Court of the Lugansk Region of Ukraine.
- The institution was ordered to pay compensation and reimburse medical expenses to the applicant.
- Since then, the applicant has been involved in several proceedings for various types of allowances and compensation due to him.
- The Lisichansk Town Court ordered an increase in monthly payments in favor of the applicant for compensation, allowances, and medical expenses.
- The debtor institution complied with the judgment in part and discontinued payments in May 2000.
- The applicant's request for compulsory execution of the judgment in Russia was allowed by the Perm Regional Court of Russia on 31 March 2006 and enforced on 30 March 2007.
- The applicant acquired several judgments by Russian courts in his favor and sued the defendant institution for medical expenses, different types of allowances and compensation, index-linking, and arrears in payments.
- The defendant institution was replaced by legal successors of Federal Health Care Institution "Hygiene and Epidemiology Center of the Perm Region."
- Despite complaints to various authorities, including the Ministry of Finance and prosecutor's office, the judgments were not enforced fully.
- Some of the judgments have not been enforced, as indicated in Appendices I and II.

title: CASE OF DRACI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Toronto, Canada.
- The applicant was the director of a company (D.) registered in Ukraine.
- In 1996, in the name of D., he concluded a contract with a collective farm (N.), situated in the self-proclaimed “Moldovan Republic of Transdniestria” (the “MRT”).
- N. sent the paprika, but according to the applicant some of it was of poor quality and D. suffered financial losses as a result. Consequently, D. refused to send the diesel fuel.
- The applicant was accused of fraud by the “MRT” authorities.
- On 30 December 1999, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment by the Ribnita People’s Court, which was under the jurisdiction of the “MRT”.
- While in detention pending trial and after his conviction, he was initially held in solitary confinement for more than two years.
- According to the applicant, after his transfer to an ordinary cell and until his release, he was detained in cells with persons who were ill with tuberculosis. During his detention several detainees died from tuberculosis.
- On an unknown date in 1997 the applicant’s lawyer complained to the Moldovan Prosecutor General’s Office of the unlawful detention of his client ordered by the “MRT” authorities.
- In reply to a complaint concerning his client lodged on an unknown date with the Russian President, on 25 September 2002, the applicant’s lawyer was informed that the complaint had been forwarded to the Moldovan Supreme Court of Justice.

title: CASE OF BRAGA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Râbniţa.
- The applicant was arrested on 28 July 1999, in Râbniţa by virtue of a decision of a prosecutor from the "Moldavian Republic of Transdniestria."
- The reason for the arrest was that he was charged with fraud and incitement to bribery.
- On 17 May 2000, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to five years' imprisonment and initially served his sentence in Tiraspol Prison no. 2.
- On 25 October 2001, he was transferred to Pruncul Prison Hospital, which was under the control of the Moldovan authorities.
- On 20 November 2001, a lawyer from Lawyers for Human Rights (LHR) informed the Moldovan Prosecutor General’s Office that the applicant and seven other people were being held in Pruncul Prison Hospital on the basis of an unlawful conviction by "MRT" courts.
- On 21 November 2001, all eight detainees, including the applicant, were allegedly transferred back to "MRT" prisons.
- On 22 January 2002, the applicant was released from prison on the basis of an amnesty act.
- The applicant described his detention conditions in the "MRT" as having no medication, food served only once a day, and of very poor quality. He was detained in a cell with several people suffering from tuberculosis, and he was affected by parasitic insects.

title: CASE OF LEBOIS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and moved to Sofia in 2013.
- On 24 January 2014, the applicant was arrested for breaking into cars with the intent to steal.
- The applicant was placed in police detention, handcuffed to a bench in the station’s corridor, and not given any food, drink, or use of the toilet or telephone.
- The applicant was taken to a pre-trial detention facility at approximately 10 p.m. on 24 January 2014.
- The cell where he was placed was dirty, cold, poorly ventilated, infested with cockroaches, overcrowded, and had a toilet which was not properly separated from the rest of the cell.
- The applicant was not able to maintain personal hygiene due to a lack of toiletries and denied access to a shower for two weeks.
- Food was unhygienic, and the space for out-of-cell exercise was too small.
- The applicant was given a dirty mattress, pillow, and blanket but no bedlinen in the pre-trial detention facility.
- The applicant saw a medical doctor three days after arriving at the pre-trial detention facility.
- The applicant lost twenty-three kilogrammes during his stay.
- The applicant was allowed two visits a month that could each last up to twenty minutes.
- The applicant was visited by a lawyer twelve times and consular staff twice.
- The applicant was able to communicate with his parents in France through correspondence.
- On 17 April 2014, the applicant accepted a plea agreement and was sentenced to three months’ imprisonment.
- The applicant spent six days in Sofia Prison, which had similar or worse conditions than the pre-trial detention facility.

title: CASE OF KNEŽEVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Split.
- On 19 May 2011, the applicant and several others were arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking and detained under Article 123 § 1(2), (3) and (4) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- The investigating judge extended the pre-trial detention in respect of the applicant and other suspects under Article 123 § 1(2), (3) and (4) multiple times during the investigation.
- On 16 May 2012, the applicant and nine other individuals were indicted on charges of drug trafficking in the Split County Court.
- Pre-trial detention in respect of the applicant and other accused was extended several times under Article 123 § 1 (3) and (4) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 20 February 2013, the Supreme Court found that the applicant’s detention should be extended only under Article 123 § 1 (3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 20 April 2013, the pre-trial detention in respect of the applicant and other accused was extended under Article 123 § 1 (3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- On 17 May 2013, the maximum two-year statutory time-limit for the applicant’s pre-trial detention was extended for a further six months relying on section 35(2) of the Office for the Suppression of Corruption and Organised Crime Act.
- On 7 June 2013, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
- On 18 June 2013, the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court.
- On 11 July 2013, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint as unfounded.
- The applicant’s pre-trial detention was extended until the maximum period expired on 19 November 2013 when he was released.

title: CASE OF NAWROT v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a sentence of imprisonment in Nysa Prison.
- The applicant was convicted of robbery and sentenced to ten years’ imprisonment in May 2001 by the Kielce Regional Court, and the sentence was amended by the Cracow Court of Appeal on 5 December 2001.
- The applicant was charged with murdering an Italian citizen, a certain P.A on 9 August 2005, and also charged with one count of robbery committed on 8 August 2005 and possession of 0.2327gr of MDMA (commonly known as extasy) on 17 August 2005.
- Psychiatrists concluded that he should undergo a psychiatric assessment to determine whether he could be held criminally responsible for the alleged murder.
- The court ordered that the applicant should undergo a psychiatric assessment in a psychiatric facility.
- Two psychiatrists confirmed that he had been suffering from a chronic psychotic disorder of a delusional type related to organic lesions in his central nervous system, and also from a personality disorder, at the time the offences had been committed, and that he would not have been aware of and could not have controlled his actions.
- The court decided to discontinue the proceedings against the applicant on the basis that he cannot be held criminally responsible.
- The applicant was placed in Branice Hospital.
- The applicant was diagnosed with delusional disorders related to organic lesions in his central nervous system. He should continue treatment in a secure facility, as there was still a risk that he might commit criminal offences of significant harm to the community.
- The Katowice Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s application to be released from hospital, and he attempted to commit suicide by overdosing on his medication.
- The applicant was transferred to Cracow Psychiatric Hospital (a hospital with enhanced security).
- The Katowice Regional Court decided to continue the applicant’s detention in a psychiatric facility, as there was a risk that the applicant would commit a similar offence of significant harm to the community as a result of his psychiatric condition.
- Psychiatrists confirmed that the applicant had a severe dissocial personality disorder, and it was still likely that he would commit similar offences of significant harm to the community again as a result of his psychiatric condition.

title: CASE OF PANAHLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Baku.
- He was the chairman of the Azerbaijani National Statehood Party.
- The applicant sold his car to E.R. but E.R. encountered technical problems with it and requested his money back.
- During their meeting, the applicant got angry, insulted E.R., and assaulted him with someone named C.
- A passerby intervened, and E.R. reported the incident to the police, who charged the applicant under Articles 127.2.3 and 221.3 of the Criminal Code.
- On 10 January 2011, the court ordered the applicant's detention for two months because of the gravity of the charges, the risk of reoffending, and the likelihood of absconding.
- The applicant appealed, but the Baku Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal.
- The prosecutor applied for and received an extension of the applicant’s pre-trial detention until 8 April 2011 because more time was needed to complete the investigation, and the case was complex.
- The applicant appealed, but the Baku Court of Appeal upheld the decision.
- On 17 June 2011, the applicant was found guilty on all counts and sentenced to six years’ imprisonment.
- He was released by presidential pardon on 17 March 2016.

title: CASE OF VANCHEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former police officer.
- The applicant was placed under house arrest from 6 March 1996 to 3 April 1996, and again from 1 July 1996 to 30 September 1997.
- The applicant was deprived of his liberty for a total of one year six months and twenty-five days.
- In 1998, the Sofia Military Court found the applicant guilty of failing to perform his duties and sentenced him to a one-year suspended prison sentence.
- In 2003, the Supreme Court of Cassation convicted the applicant of fraud and sentenced him to one year in prison.
- The court ordered that the applicant should serve a single sentence of one year in prison for all his offences.
- The applicant was detained on 1 July 2003 and served his sentence until 18 September 2003.
- The applicant later sued the prosecution authorities for non-pecuniary damage for his detention and imprisonment.
- The Sofia City Court awarded the applicant BGN 10,000 for non-pecuniary damage, finding that his detention in 1996-97 had been unjustified and his imprisonment in 2003 had been unlawful.
- The Court of Appeal upheld the judgment and ordered the prosecution authorities to pay default interest on the amount awarded.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation reduced the award to BGN 3,000, plus default interest, citing the nature of the offences, the regime under which the sentence had been served, and socially acceptable criteria for justice.
- It is unknown whether the amount was ever paid to the applicant.

title: CASE OF DICKMANN AND GION v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The communist regime in Romania nationalized buildings and agricultural land.
- Laws were introduced after the fall of the communist regime to redress the breaches of property rights.
- Law no. 112/1995 and 10/2001 established restitution and compensation principles for nationalized residential property.
- Law no. 247/2005 aimed to harmonize the administrative procedures for property restitution.
- The Court adopted a pilot judgment in 2010, indicating deficiencies in the restitution mechanism.
- Law no. 165/2013 set out various procedures available to petitioners seeking settlement of their restitution claims.
- Law no. 165/2013 offers effective remedies for those claimants whose complaints referred to certain situations.
- Law no. 165/2013 does not contain any provisions capable of affording redress on concurrent titles to property and no procedure available to former owners for compensation.
- Dora Dickmann claimed restitution of immovable property, which was nationalized unlawfully, and where the judgment was not appealed.
- Dora Dickmann’s sale contract was dismissed, and Law no. 10/2001 was applied for restitution.
- Ms and Mr. Gion’s property was seized by the State under Decree no. 223/1974, following the applicants’ decision to leave the country.
- The applicants lodged claims for reparatory measures under Law no. 112/1995, which was later dismissed, and the flat was sold to other tenants.
- Applicants challenged the enforcement of the judgment, and it was found that the sale contract had been validly and lawfully concluded by the tenants.
- Applicants lodged an action to recover possession of their flat, which was allowed but later appealed, and the court considered that the sale of the flat had been lawful.

title: CASE OF TAŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1992 and lives in Istanbul.
- The applicant was arrested on December 7, 2009.
- The applicant was placed in detention on remand on December 9, 2009.
- The applicant was suspected of committing crimes on behalf of an illegal terrorist organization, disseminating propaganda for the same organization, storage of hazardous materials, and damage to public property.
- The Istanbul public prosecutor filed the indictment on December 30, 2009.
- On May 6, 2010, the first hearing was held, and the court ordered the continuation of his detention in the applicant's presence.
- The applicant filed an objection against the decision.
- On May 20, 2010, the objection was dismissed by the 10th Chamber of Istanbul Assize Court without an oral hearing.
- The court took into account the written opinion of the public prosecutor, which was not communicated to the applicant or his representative.
- The applicant was released from detention on remand on December 10, 2010.
- At the time of the application, the proceedings against the applicant were still pending before the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF DURMUŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Antalya.
- The applicant is a teacher in a high school and a member of the local branch of the trade union of Education and Science Workers.
- Disciplinary proceedings were instituted against the applicant in May 2009 for distributing a notice encouraging participation in a press statement published by his Union.
- On 30 September 2009, a disciplinary sanction was imposed on the applicant in the form of a reprimand under Article 125 of the Law no. 657 on Civil Servants.
- On 6 October 2009, the applicant objected to this decision and requested its annulment.
- On 15 October 2009, the Disciplinary Board of the Kepez district governor dismissed the applicant’s objection.

title: CASE OF ÖZDEMİR GÜRCAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a teacher in primary school and a member/secretary of the local branch of the trade union
- The applicant participated in a demonstration against violence against women
- The District Directorate reprimanded the applicant under Article 125 of the Law no. 657 on civil servants
- The applicant objected to the decision and requested its annulment, which was dismissed by the Disciplinary Board of the Yenişehir district governor.

title: CASE OF FRANČIŠKA ŠTEFANČIČ  v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant is the mother of Branko Štefančič, who suffered from paranoid schizophrenia and depression.
- In 2007, Branko lodged a criminal complaint against multiple parties, but the prosecutor’s office decided not to pursue it.
- In June 2008, Branko made delusional accusations to the prosecutor's office about murders that went unpunished "since the age of Christ,"
- Due to concerns about Branko's behavior, the head of the prosecutor's office contacted the Idrija Psychiatric Hospital and Ajdovščina Community Health Centre so they could refer him for involuntary confinement.
- Medical staff requested police assistance with Branko's involuntary confinement as he could become aggressive.
- The police officers used physical force, handcuffs, and a police dog to restrain Branko when he refused to go with them.
- After Branko received two doses of medication, he calmed down but vomited shortly after.
- Medical staff started resuscitation quickly after Branko was found unresponsive.
- Branko was pronounced dead at 8.45 p.m., and the investigating judge ordered a forensic examination of his body.
- Police officers and medical staff made statements about the incident, including their use of force and the events leading up to Branko's death.

title: CASE OF KAYA AND GÜL v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants' personal information (age, place of residence, occupation)
- Applicants were members of a trade union affiliated with KESK
- Disciplinary investigations were initiated against the applicants for participating in a statement to the press organized by their trade union
- Disciplinary sanctions were imposed on the applicants for their participation in trade union activities
- Applicants objected and requested the annulment of the decisions
- The Disciplinary Board dismissed the applicants' objections, stating that the decisions were in accordance with the law and there were no grounds for annulment.

title: CASE OF DEVYATKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant and his brother were stopped by police officers in the Adygeya Republic in 2003.
- The police officers subjected the applicant and his brother to physical violence, including strangling, hitting their heads on the ground and car, punching, and dragging.
- The police officers disregarded the brothers' requests to inform their parents and take them home.
- The applicant's father was initially found guilty of an administrative offense related to the incident but successfully appealed.
- The applicant received medical attention for his injuries, including abrasions, bruises, and a fractured hyoid bone.
- The investigators initially refused to bring criminal charges against the police officers.
- The applicant's mother lodged a complaint, seeking criminal charges against the police officers, but the application was dismissed on procedural grounds.
- The decisions of the investigators and courts regarding the incident were contested by the applicant's family.

title: CASE OF CIRINO AND RENNE v. ITALY
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Turin. The second applicant was born in 1975 and was detained in Turin up to the time of his death on 10 January 2017. 
- In 2004 the applicants were detained in the Asti Correctional Facility. 
- On 10 December 2004 the second applicant intervened in a fight that had broken out between the first applicant and a prison officer. 
- Following an altercation with a prison officer, the first applicant was beaten by a group of prison officers, stripped of his clothes, and led to a cell in the solitary confinement wing without adequate access to sanitation, heating, and bedding. 
- During the detention in solitary confinement, the first and second applicants were subjected to repeated physical violence, deprivation of food, water, sleep, and clothing. 
- The impugned conduct was found to be a generalised practice of ill-treatment systematically inflicted on prisoners considered to be problematic, as part of which detainees were routinely subjected to physical violence, sleep and food deprivation, and denied access to sanitary facilities. 
- Although the windows in some cells had no panes and others had windows covered by metal plates with small perforations, the cells were nonetheless used during the winter months. 
- C.B. and M.S. were found responsible for most, if not all, of the acts of physical, psychological, and “material” abuse at issue, but the proceedings against them were discontinued due to the expiry of the applicable time-limit as laid down in the statute of limitations. 
- The four prison officers underwent disciplinary proceedings in connection with the impugned events and were subject to disciplinary sanctions.

title: CASE OF ZHIVKO GOSPODINOV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants are serving life or whole-life sentences in different prisons in Bulgaria
- One applicant is serving a whole-life sentence in Belene Prison, where he has been under the "special regime"
- He has described poor living conditions in his cell, including lack of running water and toilet facilities, infestations of pests, and inadequate lighting and ventilation
- The applicant was transferred to Belene Prison from Varna Prison in 2009, where he continued to serve his sentence under the "special regime"
- The applicant has gone on hunger strikes and is identified as aggressive and hostile, and considered prone to attempting to escape
- The applicant's cell in Belene Prison is secured by a locked door and grill, with handcuffs used when leaving the cell
- Another applicant has been serving his sentence under the "special regime" in Bobov Dol Prison, where he was kept in a permanently locked-up cell
- The applicant was later transferred to Pazardzhik Prison upon his request
- One applicant was transferred from Austria to Bulgaria to serve his life sentence, and has been in a permanently locked cell in Vratsa Prison under the "special regime" since 2011
- Another applicant has been serving a whole-life sentence in Stara Zagora Prison, where he is in a permanently locked cell located in the high-security wing
- The applicant was placed under the "severe regime" and later the "strict regime" in Pleven Prison, where he is serving a sentence of whole-life imprisonment since 1999
- The applicants complain that their sentences have amounted to inhuman and degrading punishment and that they lack an effective remedy in this connection
- The government provides details of the prisoners' routines and activities while in prison, as well as the legal provisions governing their detention.

title: CASE OF M.F. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant, a Roma born in 1990, was apprehended by police on suspicion of stealing goods from a nearby summer house on August 12, 2010.
- He was allegedly ill-treated by police officers who hit and kicked him, used a paper bag to cover his head, forced him to his knees, insulted him, and made reference to his Roma origin.
- The ill-treatment allegedly involved six officers and two security guards and lasted for over two hours.
- The applicant eventually signed a record of questioning, which falsely admitted to at least three counts of theft, in the hopes the beating would stop.
- The applicant was released the same day and examined by a general practitioner who identified sore ribs but no external injuries.
- The applicant went to the hospital that same evening and was issued a medical certificate indicating numerous contusions inflicted by other individuals.
- A forensic expert stated the injuries were sustained within a 24-48 hour timeframe preceding medical care.
- The Miskolc Investigating Prosecutor’s Office discontinued the case after finding the applicant’s version of events implausible.
- The applicant filed a substitute private prosecution against the eight presumed perpetrators, dropping charges against three, and ultimately two were acquitted for want of sufficient evidence.
- Criminal proceedings were conducted against the applicant for false accusation, resulting in a conviction of 180 days of community work.

title: CASE OF ČINGA v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Zujūnai.
- In 1988, the applicant was provided with a plot of land of 0.15 hectares for residential purposes.
- In 1992, the authorities allocated him an additional plot of land of 0.05 hectares, and similar additional plots were allocated to another twenty-four people.
- On April 15, 1993, the applicant purchased a total of 0.2 hectares of land from the State, which was approved by the county’s chief architect, although there was no detailed plan of Vilnius County at that time.
- The applicant obtained an official permit for the construction of a house on the land and has been living there since 2004.
- The plot of land of 0.05 hectares allocated to the applicant in 1992 (see paragraph 7 above) is where waste water treatment equipment, the gas and water supplies, and an electricity meter were installed.
- In 2006, two neighbors started court proceedings against the applicant, claiming that 0.05 hectares of the applicant’s land occupied part of a street and that the applicant had built a concrete fence around it, making it impossible to use the street, and asked the court to establish an easement (servitutas) for access to it.
- On September 26, 2006, the Vilnius District Court held that the neighbors’ rights had not been breached, but the applicant was ordered to give one of the neighbors access to an electricity meter.
- The applicant’s neighbors appealed, but on January 4, 2007, the Vilnius Regional Court upheld the decision of the court of first instance.
- In October 2007, the prosecutor’s office started court proceedings and asked the domestic courts to annul the decisions of the national authorities and the purchase agreement that had entitled the applicant to 0.05 hectares of land, to apply restitution, to return the plot of land of 0.05 hectares to the State, and to pay the applicant 15 Lithuanian litai (LTL, approximately 4.34 euros (EUR)) in compensation.
- On April 11, 2008, the Vilnius District Court held that the land had been sold to the applicant in breach of the provisions of domestic law and ordered the applicant to return the plot to the State, with the State having to repay him the LTL 15. The parts of the order allocating the additional plot

title: CASE OF KRAJNC v. SLOVENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and lives in Celje.
- He was a professional truck driver until he became unable to work due to epilepsy.
- He was certified as having a “category III work-related disability” as a result of his condition
- He was entitled to be reassigned to a suitable position of employment where he and others would not be at risk because of his condition.
- He was granted a waiting period allowance from 8 October 2004, which was subsequently discontinued under the 1999 Act.
- He requested a reassessment of his level of disability in October 2010, which was granted in February 2011.
- He was granted a disability allowance from February 2011 onwards.
- He appealed against the decision on disability allowance, arguing that it reduced his benefit by half despite his disability worsening.
- The Celje Labour and Social Court dismissed his claim, finding that the 1999 Act did not contain the right to a waiting period allowance and that his benefit had been correctly determined.
- The Higher Labour and Social Court upheld the lower court’s decision, and the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on points of law.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against the Supreme Court’s judgment, which was refused for consideration on the merits by the Constitutional Court.
- The applicant fulfilled the conditions for a retirement pension in May 2013, and his disability allowance was discontinued.
- His income from pension and disability insurance decreased significantly after the impugned change in his allowance.

title: CASE OF DAMJANOVIĆ AND EUROMAG D.O.O. v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- First applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Belgrade, Serbia.
- Second applicant is a privately owned company founded by the first applicant in 1990, located in Ilijaš - Podlugovi, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
- On 19 December 2001, the second applicant requested a license to build a petrol station on the main highway in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
- On 28 March 2003, the second applicant initiated proceedings for judicial review before the Supreme Court of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (“the Supreme Court”).
- Relevant proceedings lasted eight years and five months in total.

title: CASE OF TANASOV v. ROMANIA
facts:
-Facts of a case:
 
• The applicant was travelling on a passenger bus from Moldova to Ireland, with a stop at the Albiţa border crossing.
 
 • Romanian custom officers searched and found two silver ingots in the applicant’s pockets.
 
• A customs officer confiscated the ingots and fined the applicant for not declaring them, based on Article 653 (a) of the Customs Regulations.
 
• The applicant filed an administrative complaint, which was dismissed by the Huşi District Court and appeal dismissed with final effect on 3 June 2009
 
• The relevant provisions of the Romanian Customs Regulations and Government Ordinance No. 2/2001 on the legal system concerning offences in force at the relevant time apply to this case.
 
• The Commission Regulation (EC) No. 1214/2007 mentions that silver in unwrought or semi-manufactured forms or in powder are not subject to customs duties.

title: CASE OF DRAGOŞ IOAN RUSU v. ROMANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The Bacău police division was informed of suspicious envelopes containing prohibited substances, which had been returned unopened.
- Similar envelopes were discovered and seized by the police in the following months.
- The prosecutor issued orders authorising the seizure of the envelopes under the urgent procedure and started criminal investigations in the matter against unidentified perpetrators.
- With the help of audio and video-surveillance, the applicant was identified as the person who had deposited two other suspect envelopes to be sent abroad.
- An expert concluded that the writing on the seized envelopes belonged to the applicant, who had obtained medical products classified as drugs without prescription and had tried to sell them abroad.
- The applicant was acquitted, but the High Court of Cassation and Justice found that the lower courts had erred when they had set aside the evidence obtained from the seized correspondence and sent the case back to the County Court for re-examination.
- The County Court convicted the applicant of drug trafficking and relied on various evidence, including the seized envelopes, expert evaluation, audio and video-surveillance, witness testimony, and bank reports of money transfers received by the applicant from abroad.
- The court dismissed the applicant’s argument of the unlawfulness of the interception of the correspondence and found that the interference with his right to respect for his privacy had been proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.

title: CASE OF KAMENOS v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1949, is a lawyer, and lives in Nicosia.
- The applicant was appointed as an IDC judge on 1 October 1997 and as its President on 6 December 2001.
- Trade unions and employers' federations submitted a complaint to the Supreme Court alleging misconduct by the applicant in the exercise of his judicial functions.
- The Supreme Court appointed an investigating judge to look into the allegations against the applicant.
- The investigating judge provided the applicant with statements collected during the investigation and invited him to submit a supplementary statement.
- The investigating judge submitted a report summarizing the investigation to the Supreme Court, which decided to bring disciplinary charges against the applicant.
- The charges included two charges of misconduct, one related to behavior towards lay members of the court and the other related to behavior towards lawyers, litigants, and witnesses.
- The applicant pleaded not guilty to the charges.
- Hearings were held in which witnesses confirmed the contents of their statements and were cross-examined by the applicant's lawyer.
- After concluding the witness statements and hearing the applicant's defense, the SCJ found by a majority that the applicant's alleged misconduct had been proved and removed him from office.

title: CASE OF K.I. v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1980 and arrived in Russia in 2003.
- He was charged in absentia in Tajikistan on 3 May 2011 with participating in an extremist religious movement, and an international search and arrest warrant was issued in his name.
- The Tajik authorities ordered his pre-trial detention on 6 May 2011.
- On 3 November 2013, the applicant was detained in Moscow and the District Court ordered his detention pending extradition on 4 November 2013.
- The Tajik prosecution authorities requested the applicant's extradition on 4 December 2013, and the District Court extended his detention until 3 May 2014.
- The applicant's extradition was refused by the Deputy Prosecutor General of the Russian Federation on 9 October 2014, owing to the absence of culpable actions under Russian criminal law.
- The applicant was released from detention on 13 October 2014, but was immediately rearrested for violating migration regulations.
- He was found guilty of violating migration regulations, fined, and ordered his administrative removal by the District Court on 14 October 2014.
- The claims by the applicant regarding a real risk of ill-treatment were dismissed, and he was detained pending expulsion.
- The applicant lodged a request for refugee status on 18 December 2013, referring to persecution in Tajikistan and a real risk of ill-treatment.
- His request was refused by a final administrative decision on 15 September 2014, and his appeals were dismissed by a final decision of the City Court on 12 November 2015.

title: CASE OF KONSTANTIN MOSKALEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was a police officer with the Economic Crimes Department of the Department of the Interior of the Krasnoyarsk Region.
- The applicant was accused of extorting money in exchange for assisting a person in obtaining a license for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages.
- The police intercepted the applicant's telephone communications without judicial authorization using the OSAA.
- The police conducted an "operative experiment" where the person made the bribery claim, Mr. P, was given marked banknotes and a recording device, which were used to record the meeting with the applicant.
- The applicant was arrested after the meeting and the banknotes were seized.
- The Investigations Committee opened criminal proceedings against the applicant for attempted fraud.
- The investigator stated that the evidence collected proved the applicant's guilt for the criminal offence.
- The Tsentralnyy District Court declared the audio and video recordings admissible as evidence stating that the police had sufficient reasons to carry out these measures.
- The District Court convicted the applicant, and he was sentenced to two years and two months' imprisonment, and stripped of his rank in the police.
- The Krasnoyarsk Regional Court upheld the applicant's conviction on appeal, stating that the evidence gathered was correctly declared admissible as evidence and that the recordings were authentic.

title: CASE OF DORIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952 and lives in Sarajevo.
- The applicant instituted civil proceedings against his employer in 1999, seeking his reinstatement and damages.
- The claim was rejected after several legal proceedings.
- The Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina found a breach of the applicant's right to a trial within a reasonable time on 10 April 2013.

title: CASE OF ANAMARIA-LOREDANA ORĂȘANU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The facts of the case are similar to a previously adjudicated case in Romania.
- The applicants and their close relatives were involved in anti-communist demonstrations between 21 and 27 December 1989, which led to the fall of the communist regime in various cities, and were injured or killed by gunfire during the demonstrations.
- The military prosecutor's office opened investigations into the events of December 1989 in Bucharest and other cities, with file no. 97/P1990 being the main criminal investigation.
- In some cases, the prosecutor chose not to initiate an investigation or discontinued proceedings, but the prosecutor continued to examine the cases in the main criminal investigation.
- The main criminal investigation is still ongoing, and several procedural steps have been taken so far.
- The case has been relinquished to the military prosecutor's office following the new Code of Criminal Procedure in February 2014.
- On 14 October 2015, the prosecutor's office closed the investigation, finding that the applicants' complaints were partly statute-barred, partly subject to an amnesty, and partly ill-founded. However, the investigation has since been reopened.

title: CASE OF KABARDOKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants participated in the clean-up operation at the Chernobyl nuclear disaster site and were registered disabled.
- They received social benefits and compensation but considered them insufficient.
- They sued the Russian Ministry of Finance for additional compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The Nalchik Town Court awarded each claimant compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The judgments became final and were not appealed within the statutory time-limit.
- The domestic courts extended the time-limit for appeal and subsequently quashed the judgments based on retrospective application of the law.
- The applicants lodged a supervisory review application.
- The Presidium of the regional Supreme Court partially quashed the appeal judgments as regards the applicants’ obligation to reimburse the sums paid.

title: CASE OF VOROKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants participated in the clean-up operation at the Chernobyl nuclear disaster site in 1986-87.
- As a result, they were registered disabled and entitled to social benefits and compensation.
- They sued the Russian Ministry of Finance for additional compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The Nalchik Town Court allowed their claims in part and awarded each claimant compensation ranging from RUB 1,200,000 to RUB 1,600,000 for non-pecuniary damage.
- The judgments became final, but the defendant authority never executed them.
- The Town Court granted the defendant authority's request to extend the time-limit for appeal on the grounds of non-receipt of a copy of the judgment in due course.
- The regional Supreme Court quashed the judgments on the grounds of retrospective application of the law.

title: CASE OF LEUSKA AND OTHERS v. ESTONIA
facts:
1. First and second applicants’ son was killed in a traffic accident on 17 July 2010 in which the fourth applicant sustained serious injuries. 
2. The third applicant is the fourth applicant’s mother. 
3. The applicants joined the criminal proceedings concerning the accident as victims. 
4. The applicants lodged a civil action within the criminal proceedings against the suspect, J., claiming compensation for non-pecuniary damage and reimbursement of the legal costs incurred in the criminal proceedings. 
5. The applicants concluded an out-of-court settlement with J. 
6. The applicants withdrew their claim for non-pecuniary damage against J. but had not given up their claim for reimbursement of the legal costs incurred in the criminal proceedings. 
7. The Harju County Court committed J. for trial and scheduled a hearing. 
8. The applicants’ consent to the application of the settlement procedure was recorded in a report signed by the prosecutor and the applicants’ representatives. 
9. J. gave his consent to the application of the settlement procedure. 
10. The Harju County Court convicted J. of violating traffic and driving regulations and sentenced him to a suspended prison term. 
11. The victims had given up the civil claims they had lodged within the framework of the criminal proceedings. 
12. The applicants lodged an appeal against that judgment. 
13. The Harju County Court refused to examine the appeal, finding that the applicants had not been parties to the court proceedings and did not, therefore, have the right to appeal. 
14. The Tallinn Court of Appeal examined the appeal and dismissed the applicants’ appeal and upheld the Harju County Court’s decision. 
15. The Supreme Court refused to examine the appeal on points of law because the Court of Appeal’s decision had been final and not amenable to appeal.

title: CASE OF JOKSIMOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Belgrade.
- On 15 June 2004, the applicant was injured in a traffic accident and suffered serious injuries.
- An investigation into the incident was initiated in November 2004 and terminated in May 2005 with no criminal charges being brought.
- On 10 June 2005, the applicant lodged a civil claim for non-pecuniary damages with the Second Municipal Court in Belgrade against the Belgrade City’s Transportation Company.
- On 27 December 2007, the Second Municipal Court ruled in the applicant’s favor, but on 3 July 2008, the District Court quashed the decision and remitted the case to the First Instance.
- On 23 October 2009, the Second Municipal Court adopted a partial decision (delimičnu presudu) against which both the applicant and the defendant appealed in December 2009.
- On 30 September 2010, the Court of Appeals in Belgrade quashed the decision and remitted the case to the Court of First Instance for a re-trial.
- Moreover, on 22 December 2009, the applicant lodged an appeal with the Constitutional Court complaining about the overall fairness of domestic proceedings and their length.
- The Constitutional Court’s decision was rendered on 4 November 2010, and no violation in respect of the applicant’s complaints was found.
- Due to the change in the value of the dispute, the Court of First Instance ruled that it had no further jurisdiction to examine the applicant’s complaint.
- On 31 October 2010, the case was sent to the High Court in Belgrade.
- On 20 June 2013, the High Court adopted a partial judgment against which both the applicant and the defendant appealed to the Court of Appeals in Belgrade.
- On 6 June 2014, the Court of Appeals partly quashed the impugned judgment.
- The case is still pending before the High Court.
- Additionally, on 28 October 2014, the applicant lodged a new submission with the Constitutional Court concerning the length of the impugned proceedings.

title: CASE OF KOVALEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Three applicants, a family from Svetlograd, Stavropol Region.
- The first applicant was allegedly beaten by police officers on 8 August 2003.
- The first applicant went to the hospital, was diagnosed with multiple injuries and was admitted to in-patient treatment.
- An investigation was conducted and dismissed several times due to lack of evidence and incomplete findings.
- A criminal investigation was opened against the first applicant for beating their neighbor in 2004.
- The applicants were found guilty of vigilantism in 2005 and sentenced to two and a half years, suspended on eighteen months’ probation.

title: CASE OF MOSKALEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1960 and is from Omsk.
- The applicant served as deputy head of the Omsk Regional Department for the Execution of Sentences.
- The Novosibirsk Regional Court authorized the interception and recording of the applicant's telephone conversations and postal communications and the collection of data from technical channels of communication for 180 days, due to suspicion of bribery and abuse of power.
- The Novosibirsk Regional Court authorized audio surveillance of the applicant's office for 180 days.
- The applicant was never charged with bribe-taking or abuse of power, but was charged with the disclosure of state secrets for warning a convict's relative that the convict was under covert surveillance.
- The applicant was found guilty of disclosure of state secrets and was sentenced to three years of imprisonment, suspended for two years.
- The applicant claimed that the interception of his communications was unlawful and unjustified and that the recording of his conversation with Ms L. was inadmissible as evidence.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the conviction on appeal, stating that all the evidence had been collected in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law and was admissible.

title: CASE OF DUDCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was suspected of leadership of a criminal armed gang and several criminal offences in Murmansk and Moscow.
- Interception and recording of the applicant’s telephone communications were authorized and carried out on two different mobile phone numbers.
- The applicant’s legal representative was removed from the case due to suspicion of unlawful actions and the use of intercepted conversations as evidence.
- The trial was postponed multiple times for various reasons, including the transfer of prosecution witnesses from Moscow.
- The applicant’s detention was repeatedly extended due to the gravity of the charges and the risk of obstruction of justice.

title: CASE OF ZUBKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. Audio and video recordings of the applicant and others were sent to the local investigations committee by the police in the course of covert “operational-search” measures authorised by the President of the Novgorod Regional Court.
2. Applicant was arrested and charged with several counts of drug trafficking committed by an organised criminal group.
3. The Novgorod Regional Prosecutor’s Office ordered the applicant’s placement in custody pending trial.
4. The applicant was found guilty of drug trafficking and sentenced to nine years and six months’ imprisonment.
5. Applicant was arrested and charged with aiding and abetting bribery.
6. The criminal case file contained audio recordings of the applicant’s telephone conversations during the period from November 2003 to March 2004. 
7. The applicant’s detention was further extended on several occasions, and he was held in four different remand prisons.
8. The applicant requested a copy of the interception authorisation, but the investigator refused his request, stating that the police were not required to send the interception authorisation to the investigator. 
9. On 19 February 2007, the Frunzenskiy District Court rejected the applicant's complaint about the interception of his telephone communications, holding that the refusal to give him a copy of the interception authorisation had been lawful. 
10. On 3 April 2007, the Vladimir Regional Court upheld the decision of 19 February 2007 on appeal, finding it lawful, well reasoned and justified.

title: CASE OF AKHLYUSTIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lived in Ivanovo.
- The applicant was a member of the Ivanovo Region electoral commission.
- Surveillance was carried out on the applicant's office from 27 Oct to 5 Nov 2003, with a hidden camera.
- The applicant was charged with abuse of power under Article 285 of the Criminal Code.
- The video recordings were discovered by the applicant while studying the criminal case file.
- The applicant claimed that the video recordings were inadmissible as evidence and challenged their authenticity.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Ivanovo declared the video recordings admissible as evidence.
- The court relied on statements of witnesses, physical evidence, expert reports and the video recordings of the applicant’s telephone conversations.
- The Court found that the video recordings were authentic and obtained in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law.
- The applicant appealed but the conviction was upheld by the Ivanovo Regional Court.

title: CASE OF TURISHCHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant brought civil proceedings against the Administration, a private person, and a private company claiming title to a flat, damages, and eviction of the private person from the flat.
- The district court refused to consider the action since there had been a previous decision concerning the same dispute.
- The Supreme Court overruled the refusal and remitted the case for a new examination since the action included a new co-defendant.
- The district court ordered eviction of the private person and her family from the flat and dismissed the claim against the Administration.
- The Supreme Court quashed the judgment on appeal since the lower court failed to address issues related to the private person's property rights.
- The district court ordered an expert examination to determine the market value of the flat.
- The applicant amended his claims seeking compensation for his belongings allegedly stolen in 1999, non-pecuniary damage, legal costs, travel expenses, and reimbursement of the rent he had to pay after his eviction from the flat.
- The district court awarded the applicant 800,000 Russian rubles in respect of the flat's market value and dismissed the remainder of his claims.
- The judgment was upheld on appeal by the Supreme Court, and the bailiffs initiated the enforcement proceedings.
- The enforcement of the judgment was suspended until 15 January 2005 due to financial difficulties encountered by the debtor, which was granted by the district court.
- The Presidium quashed the judgment and the decision and remitted the case for a fresh examination, finding that the courts had incorrectly applied the material law and failed to join the appropriate financial body as a co-defendant.
- The district court suspended the proceedings due to the private person's illness and asked the applicant to clarify his claims.
- The district court joined the Ministry of Finance as a co-defendant and suspended the examination of the case due to the private person's poor state of health.
- The case was assigned to a different judge of the district court for the sake of the court's impartiality.
- The applicant's action was dismissed, and the judgment was upheld on appeal except for certain parts, which were remitted for a fresh examination.
- The proceedings were suspended due to the private person's return from vacation, and the court ordered the applicant to clarify his claims and scheduled a new hearing.
- The district court dismissed the action as unfounded since the applicant had other remedies to use under the civil law to protect his property rights.
- The district court discontinued the proceedings for the applicant's statutory interest claim since the

title: CASE OF PUKHACHEV AND ZARETSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants
- Relevant details of the applications are provided in a table
- The applicants complained about inadequate conditions of detention
- The complaints were made during their transport

title: CASE OF T.M. AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are nationals of Uzbekistan.
- They were charged in Uzbekistan with religious and politically motivated crimes.
- Their pre-trial detention was ordered in absentia, and international search warrants were issued by the authorities.
- The Russian authorities decided to remove them to Uzbekistan.
- The applicants consistently claimed that they would face a real risk of treatment contrary to Article 3 of the Convention in the event of removal.
- The Appendix contains the applicants' initials, dates of birth, application numbers, particulars of the domestic proceedings, and other relevant information.

title: CASE OF EGILL EINARSSON v. ICELAND
facts:
- The applicant was a well-known person in Iceland known for publishing articles, blogs, and books under pseudonyms.
- He was accused of rape and sexual offenses by two women, but the cases were dismissed due to insufficient evidence.
- The applicant spoke in an interview about the rape accusation and criticized the media's coverage of the case.
- X, an Instagram user, published an altered picture of the applicant with the caption "Fuck you rapist bastard" and claimed that it was only for his followers.
- The picture was accessible to all Instagram users, and an online article was published about the post.
- The applicant sued X for defamation and requested a punishment, apology, and damages.
- The District Court and the Supreme Court (with a majority of two out of three judges) found that X's statement was a value judgment and within the bounds of freedom of expression granted by law.
- The majority also found that the applicant had launched a public debate by the interview, and X had the right to express himself about the applicant's opinions.
- The minority disagreed, stating that X's statement was a grave insinuation and unacceptable, regardless of the applicant's public persona and controversial statements.

title: CASE OF TRIPCOVICI v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants were born in 1949 and 1923 respectively and were co-owners of two adjacent plots of land in Montenegro.
- A metal fence was built partly on their property, dividing the plots and making it impossible to access one from the other.
- The fence had been erected in February 2009, and the first applicant noticed it on 13 June 2009.
- The applicants instituted civil proceedings for trespass against their neighbor on 15 July 2009, which the court of first instance ruled in their favor, ordering the fence to be removed and the applicants to be paid €1,435 in legal costs.
- On 20 December 2011, the High Court quashed the previous judgment and rejected the applicants' claim as submitted out of time, stating that the 30-day period within which the applicants could institute proceedings was mandatory and had expired on 13 July 2009, as the last day fell on a day when the courts did not sit.

title: CASE OF FUCHSHUBER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The document contains information about a specific case
- The details of the applicant are listed in a table
- The applicant has lodged a complaint
- The complaint pertains to the excessive length of criminal proceedings

title: CASE OF GROMOVOY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a table containing a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants claimed that they were not given the chance to appear in court in the civil proceedings in which they were involved.
- One of the applicants raised a complaint under Article 3 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SCHWABEL v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The case involves an applicant and a table with relevant details of the application.
- The applicant filed a complaint regarding the length of civil proceedings.

title: CASE OF MEDVEDEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document contains a table with a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants also raised complaints under Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BELYAYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table of applicants and relevant application details is provided.
- The applicants complained about the duration of their pre-trial detention.

title: CASE OF ĻUTOVA v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was sued for a debt of 320 Latvian lati owed to a residential building maintenance services provider.
- Civil proceedings were instituted on 25 November 2005.
- The first hearing was scheduled to take place on 21 April 2006 but was postponed to allow both parties to prepare documents.
- The hearings continued over the next two years due to the plaintiff increasing the amount of the claim, submitting more documents, and the court changing judges taking over the case.
- On 28 October 2008, the City Court dismissed the plaintiff’s claim against the applicant as unsubstantiated.
- On 22 December 2010, the Riga Regional Court partially allowed the plaintiff's claim and ordered the applicant to settle the debt in the total amount of LVL 2,854.
- The decision was appealed on points of law but the Supreme Court refused to institute proceedings on points of law on 3 April 2012.

title: CASE OF SOBOLEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their details are in the appended table.
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF PEREKRESTOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and application details in the table.
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of pre-trial detention.
- Applicant in application no. 45912/16 raised a complaint under Article 5 §4 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF HENTSCHEL AND STARK v. GERMANY
facts:
- Two applicants, one born in 1969 and one born in 1989, attended a football match in Munich on December 9, 2007.
- 227 police officers, including two squads of the Munich riot control unit, one squad of the Dachau public-order support force battalion, and "video officers," were deployed due to an increased risk of clashes between rival football supporters.
- After the match, the police cordoned off the stands of one team's supporters, including both applicants, to prevent them from leaving the stadium and encountering supporters of the other team. The cordon was lifted after around fifteen minutes.
- The first applicant was hit with a truncheon on the head while walking between the exit of the stands and the exit of the football stadium, resulting in a bleeding laceration behind his ear. The second applicant was doused with pepper spray in the face and struck on his left upper arm with a truncheon, resulting in swelling and redness of his face and arm pain.
- Both applicants were able to identify their attackers as police officers, but were not able to distinguish them further due to their identical uniforms and the lack of identifying signs or name tags.
- The public prosecutor's office conducted an investigation, but the investigation was discontinued twice due to insufficient evidence to establish criminal conduct by specific police officers.
- The applicants filed criminal complaints of assistance given in an official capacity in avoiding prosecution or punishment and suppression of evidence. The investigation against the five police officers involved was discontinued.

title: CASE OF D.S. v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Relevant details of the application are in the appended table.
- The applicant complained about the inadequate conditions of detention.
- The applicant complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF ÜNAL AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were cadets in military schools.
- The applicants were expelled from their schools.
- None of the applicants had access to the classified investigation reports.
- The applicants filed actions against the Ministry of Defence with the Supreme Military Administrative Court.
- The applicants requested annulment of the impugned decisions.
- The Supreme Military Administrative Court rejected the applicants’ requests.
- The Supreme Military Administrative Court also rejected their subsequent requests for rectification on different dates as shown in a detailed list.

title: CASE OF UĞURLU AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are Turkish nationals who own plots of land in different cities of Turkey.
- Their plots of land were designated for public use following local land development plans.
- The applicants initiated compensation proceedings before the civil courts due to the decrease in the market value of the land and the long-term uncertainty about the fate of their plots of land.
- The applicants submitted a decision given by the Plenary Chamber of the Court of Cassation (civil divisions, numbered E.2004/5-555 K.2005/17) to the domestic courts.
- The applicants’ claims for compensation were dismissed by the domestic courts on the ground that their plots of land were not actually seized by the authorities.
- Neither the courts of first instance nor the Fifth Civil Division of the Court of Cassation expressed any reason as to why they had reached a different conclusion from the plenary Court of Cassation.
- The details of the proceedings can be found in the appended table.

title: CASE OF IŞIKIRIK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was a student at Dicle University at the time of the events.
- A funeral of four militants of the PKK took place on 28 March 2006.
- An incident report was prepared by the police describing events from 28 March 2006 to 1 April 2006.
- On 5 March 2007, a demonstration was held at Dicle University to protest against the conditions of Abdullah Öcalan’s detention.
- The applicant was arrested on 9 March 2007 and denied participation in the events.
- The applicant was convicted of disseminating propaganda in support of the PKK and membership of an illegal organisation, the PKK.
- The court found the applicant played an active role in the illegal demonstration at the funeral.
- The applicant's participation in the events was considered to be on behalf of the organization.
- The applicant was acquitted of one charge and the case against him was suspended under law no. 6352.

title: CASE OF YİVLİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Hatay.
- The applicant was an officer in the Army.
- Based on classified investigation reports, his contract was terminated.
- He had no access to the classified reports.
- On 8 June 2009 the applicant initiated proceedings against the Ministry of Defence with the Supreme Military Administrative Court to have annulment of the impugned decision.
- Relying on the classified investigation reports, and the written opinion of the public prosecutor, which were not communicated to the applicant, on 16 March 2010 the Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s case.
- On 18 May 2010 the applicant’s request for rectification was also rejected by the Supreme Military Administrative Court.
- The final decision was notified on the applicant on 8 June 2010.

title: CASE OF DELİBAŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant's daughter died in an earthquake in 1999.
- Criminal proceedings were brought against the contractor and architect of the building, and later against a civil engineer and Head of Technical Services of the Municipality.
- Experts identified structural problems with the building including poor quality concrete and improperly fastened metal brackets.
- Applicant requested to join the proceedings as a civil party and requested an investigation into the responsibility of municipal officials who authorized the construction and occupation of the building.
- Three defendants were convicted and sentenced to 10 months' imprisonment and a fine, with execution of sentences suspended multiple times.
- A new expert report found the defendants jointly bore 75% responsibility for the collapse of the building, and municipal officials bore 25% responsibility for their failure to inspect the building properly.
- Criminal proceedings were eventually discontinued due to the prosecution of the offence in question becoming time-barred.
- The applicant and his family instituted compensation proceedings against the Ministry of Public Works and Settlement, the Düzce governor's office, and the Municipality of Düzce.
- Expert reports commissioned for the compensation proceedings found that the municipality had been 50% responsible for the collapse of the building in question.
- The Sakarya Administrative Court partially accepted the applicant's claims against the Municipality and awarded non-pecuniary damages. The Municipality appealed and ultimately paid compensation to the applicant and his family.

title: CASE OF KUNIĆ AND OTHERS v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- Multiple judgments were issued in favor of the applicants concerning unpaid work-related benefits.
- The Zenica-Doboj Canton was ordered to pay the applicants different sums in respect of unpaid work-related benefits, default interest at the statutory rate, and legal costs.
