- Writs of execution were issued by the Zenica Municipal Court and the Tešanj Municipal Court and transferred to the competent bank for enforcement.
- On several occasions, enforcement was not possible because the budgetary funds intended for that purpose had already been spent.
- The first applicant complained of the non-enforcement to the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which found a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention.
- The Constitutional Court ordered the government of the Zenica-Doboj Canton to take the necessary steps to secure the payment of the cantonal debt arising from the final judgments within a reasonable time.
- The government of the Zenica-Doboj Canton did not identify the exact number of unenforced judgments and the aggregate debt, hindering the enforcement of the claims.
- The current situation did not give any guarantees to the appellants that their claims against the Zenica-Doboj Canton would be enforced within a reasonable time.
- The final judgments in the applicants’ favor have not yet been enforced.

title: CASE OF SPAHIĆ AND OTHERS v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The Central Bosnia Canton was ordered to pay unpaid work-related benefits, legal costs and default interest to the applicants through five judgments issued by the Travnik Municipal Court on different dates, which became final on different dates.
- The writs of execution issued by the Municipal Court were transferred to the bank, but the enforcement was not possible as the budgetary funds were already spent.
- The Ministry of Finance of the CB Canton informed the bank on two different dates that no funds for enforcement were provided in the cantonal budget for 2013 and 2014.
- However, later, the Ministry informed the applicants that the canton had designated funds for the enforcement of judgments.
- The applicants complained of the non-enforcement to the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which found a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention in their and five other cases.
- The Constitutional Court ordered the government of the CB Canton to take steps to secure the payment of the cantonal debt arising from the final judgments within a reasonable time.
- Section 138 of the Federal Enforcement Procedure Act 2003 provides that final judgments against the Federation and the cantons shall be enforced within the amount of budgetary funds designated for that purpose.
- The adoption of section 138 of the Enforcement Procedure Act 2003 had a legitimate aim, but the limitation of enforcement in the present case is contrary to the principle of proportionality.
- Mr Jasmin Hodžić and Ms Jasmina Mezildžić concluded out-of-court settlements with the government of the CB Canton, but the final judgments in favour of the rest of the applicants have not yet been enforced.

title: CASE OF TIMOFEYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lived in Moscow before his arrest and conviction.
- He was arrested and charged with unlawful purchase and possession of firearms and aggravated murder.
- Sh. witnessed Ch.'s murder and identified the applicant as the perpetrator.
- On 10 April 2007, the jury returned a guilty verdict and sentenced the applicant to eighteen years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant lodged an appeal alleging that Sh.'s statement had been read out during the trial in contravention of the applicable rules of criminal procedure.
- The presiding judge had entered the room where the jurors had been deliberating and advised them to declare him guilty.
- The Supreme Court of the Russian Federation rejected the applicant’s complaint about the presiding judge’s interference with the jury deliberations and upheld the conviction on appeal.
- Sh. did not appear in court and her statement was read out, but the defence did not object to this.
- The Moscow city prosecutor’s office rejected the applicant’s complaint concerning the presiding judge's actions.

title: CASE OF ILGAR MAMMADOV v. AZERBAIJAN (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence.
- The applicant has been involved in various political organisations and local and international non-governmental organisations.
- The applicant co-founded a political organisation named the Republican Alternative Movement (“REAL”) in 2009, which opposed proposed changes to the Constitution.
- In 2012 the applicant became REAL’s chairman and expressed views opposing the current government.
- The applicant intended to stand as a candidate in the 2013 presidential elections but was unable to do so due to the events giving rise to the case.
- Another member of the REAL board, Mr Rasul Jafarov, was arrested.
- One of the applicant's co-defendants was Mr Tofiq Yaqublu.
- The Ismayilli events of January 2013 involved rioting in the town of Ismayilli.
- The applicant made a trip to Ismayilli to get a first-hand account of the events and posted about it on his blog.
- A day before posting on his blog, the applicant gave a live interview to Azadliq Radio.
- On 28 January 2013, the applicant posted more information on his blog concerning the events, citing the official websites of the Ministry of Culture and Tourism and the Ministry of Taxes and publishing screenshots of those sites.
- On 29 January 2013, the Prosecutor General’s Office and the Ministry of Internal Affairs issued a new joint press statement concerning the events in Ismayilli.

title: CASE OF BOUKROUROU AND OTHERS v. FRANCE
facts:
- The first applicant is the victim's brother and the rest of the applicants are the victim's family members.
- The victim had psychiatric disorders and habitually went to a pharmacy to collect his medicine.
- An argument ensued when he asked to exchange his medicine for another and became angry.
- The pharmacy staff called the police who arrived shortly after and attempted to remove the victim from the location.
- Despite resisting, the victim was handcuffed, placed in a police van, and forced to the ground.
- The victim continued to struggle in the police van, and three police officers restrained him, including standing on his buttocks and shoulders while handcuffing him.
- The victim's heart stopped beating, and he died in the pharmacy before medical help arrived.
- The cause of death was likely a result of heart failure and natural causes, although there were traumatic injuries consistent with third-party action.

title: CASE OF "ORTHODOX OHRID ARCHDIOCESE (GREEK-ORTHODOX OHRID ARCHIDIOESE OF THE PEĆ PATRIARCHY)" v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The Ohrid Archdiocese was abolished by the Turkish Sultan in 1767.
- The territory that had fallen under the jurisdiction of the Ohrid Archdiocese had come under the jurisdiction of the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, which in 1918 issued a canonical release of those territories to the benefit of the Serbian Orthodox Church (SOC).
- In 1943 it was decided that the Ohrid Archdiocese would be restored and continued by an autonomous Macedonian Orthodox Church (MOC).
- In 1959 the MOC seceded from the SOC and in 1967 it declared autocephaly. The Head of the Holy Synod of MOC is designated as “Archbishop of Ohrid and Macedonia”.
- In negotiations which have been continuing, on 17 May 2002, the two churches signed a draft agreement (the Niš agreement) which provided for ecclesiastical union between them. Due to strong public reaction, the Holy Synod ultimately rejected this agreement.
- Mr J. Vraniškovski was dismissed from the Holy Synod of MOC on 5 July 2002, for his unilateral accession to the SOC. The SOC later declared the dismissal null and void and appointed him “exarch of the Peć Archbishop and the Patriarch of Serbia for all eparchies of the Ohrid Archdiocese”.
- The applicant association constituted its own Holy Synod and appointed Mr Vraniškovski as its President on 25 December 2003.
- On 6 September 2004, the applicant association submitted an application seeking that it be registered as a religious group under the name “Orthodox Ohrid Archdiocese”. On 3 November 2004, the Commission dismissed the application on several grounds.
- On 9 November 2005, the Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s claim. It held that the applicant association’s name implied creation of a parallel religious community, rather than a religious group, and that its determination to operate as an autonomous church in canonical union with the Peć Patriarchy was contrary to section 9 (2) of the 1997 Act.
- On 20 September 2007, a new Act on the legal status of churches, religious communities and religious groups (“the 2007 Act”) was adopted. It entered into force on 1 May 2008.
- From 11 November 2008 onwards, the MOC was recorded in the court register as “Maced

title: CASE OF TSALIKIDIS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
- Mr Costas Tsalikidis was found dead on 9 March 2005. 
- He was the Network Planning Manager for V., a mobile phone operator. 
- He was found hanged with a rope tied to pipes above the bathroom door, and a chair was knocked over nearby. 
- There were no signs of forced entry or struggle, no suspicious items, and no suicide note. 
- The coroner concluded that the cause of death was hanging. 
- The wiretapping case involved spyware that had been implanted in the network of phone operator V., which targeted more than 100 of Greece’s State officials. 
- Mr Tsalikidis had been responsible for accepting the software from E. and met representatives from E. on a monthly basis. 
- V. was informed about the wiretapping on 4 March 2005, and the software was removed on 8 March 2005. 
- Mr Tsalikidis’ death occurred the day after the spyware had been removed. 
- The investigation was widely reported in the media, suggesting an association between his death and the wiretapping affair. 
- In 2012, the applicants requested that the case file be reopened for the purposes of initiating criminal proceedings or launching a supplementary preliminary investigation into possible crimes committed against Mr Tsalikidis.

title: CASE OF MOVSESYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Yerevan and had a daughter named K.M.
- On September 7, 2007, K.M. was in the early weeks of pregnancy when she fainted and began to have convulsions.
- An ambulance was called, and upon arrival, the doctor administered two injections and took her to the hospital.
- K.M. died on September 14, 2007, in the hospital without regaining consciousness.
- An inquiry was conducted into her death, including an autopsy and multiple forensic medical investigations.
- The inquiry resulted in multiple decisions to reject the institution of criminal proceedings due to lack of corpus delicti.
- The applicant sought a new forensic medical investigation in which he would be allowed to participate.
- The medical personnel involved, including the emergency care specialists who had provided first aid assistance, were questioned, and the ambulance crew was penalized for poor performance of their duties.
- The applicant lodged a complaint and appealed against the decisions, but they were dismissed, and the Court of Cassation refused to examine the appeal.

title: CASE OF MANSOUR v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Dublin, Ireland, and has two Irish national children.
- In January 2011, the wife traveled to Slovakia with the children, violating their custody agreement, and did not return to Ireland.
- The applicant filed a case in Slovakian courts on 31 January 2011 under the Brussels II Bis Regulation and the Hague Convention to return the children to Ireland.
- On 1 July and 26 October 2011, respectively, the Bratislava I District Court and the Regional Court ordered the return of the children to Ireland.
- However, the mother did not comply with the order, and the enforcement of the decision was stalled.
- The enforcement court deemed the return order unenforceable on two grounds: first, because there was already a previous decision regarding provisional measures and, second, because the return order had failed to specify to whom it was directed and to provide a time frame for its implementation.
- The applicant challenged the enforcement court's decision, and the Constitutional Court declared the decision unconstitutional.
- After one more appeal, the courts refused to enforce the order on the basis of newly obtained evidence regarding the children's welfare and stability.
- There was a second constitutional complaint regarding the four-year-long proceedings, which were deemed inefficient by the Constitutional Court.
- The District Court was ordered to pay compensation for non-pecuniary damages and reimburse legal costs to the applicant.

title: CASE OF AMIZHAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Groznyy in the Chechen Republic.
- On 23 June 2012, the applicant was arrested for a drug-related offence and placed in custody.
- On 14 August 2012, the Oktyabrskiy District Court of Groznyy found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to one year’s imprisonment.
- On 14 November 2012, the Supreme Court of the Chechen Republic quashed the conviction and ordered a retrial.
- On 30 May 2013, the Oktyabrskiy District Court convicted the applicant again and sentenced him to one year’s imprisonment.
- The court stated that the “preventive measure [should] remain unchanged until the conviction [had become] final”.
- On 24 June 2013, the applicant's counsel asked the director of the remand prison to release the applicant since he had already served the one-year sentence.
- A judge of the District Court faxed a letter to the director, informing him that the applicant should not be released until the Supreme Court had examined the matter on appeal since the District Court ordered the preventive measure to remain unchanged.
- On 3 July 2013, the Supreme Court upheld the conviction and the applicant was released.

title: CASE OF KAIMOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Ms Damani Kaimova, Ms Maryam Moldyyevna Kaimova, and Ms Zarina Tamiyevna Maskhurova.
- Mr Kaimov was arrested on 23 September 2006, in the Chechen Republic.
- He was accused of being a member of an illegal military organization, and subsequently also charged with attempted murder of law enforcement officials, making an explosive, and additional offenses.
- Mr Kaimov remained in detention throughout the investigation and trial.
- On 1 November 2006, he was found guilty of charges related to the illegal military organization and illegal acquisition of weapons and was sentenced to two and a half years’ imprisonment.
- He was later convicted of the other charges and sentenced to six and a half years’ imprisonment.
- Mr. Kaimov had a history of tuberculosis, for which he had been receiving outpatient treatment in a local hospital prior to his detention.
- On admission to a remand prison, a chest X-ray examination revealed signs of tuberculosis.
- In March 2009, he was admitted to prison medical institution no. 1 in Nizhnekamsk, where his tuberculosis was cured.
- In 2010, Mr Kaimov's health deteriorated, and he was diagnosed with tuberculosis of the right lung at the stage of tissue destruction.
- Despite being prescribed treatment with second-line drugs, Mr Kaimov refused to take his medication, according to medical records and statements made by doctors and prison staff.
- On 1 July 2010, Mr Kaimov died of heart failure caused by tuberculosis.
- The investigating authorities carried out a criminal inquiry into the circumstances of Mr Kaimov’s death, but multiple decisions not to open a criminal case were made.
- In 2015, the decisions refusing to open a criminal case were overruled by higher-ranking officials, and additional investigative measures were ordered. The criminal investigation was still pending as of July 2015.

title: CASE OF PANYUSHKINY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are a single mother and her son who were born in 1971 and 1997 respectively and live in St Petersburg.
- They were granted the status of “forced migrants” for an initial period of five years in 1995 after leaving Uzbekistan for Russia and settling in St Petersburg.
- In 1998, the Federal Migration Service provided the applicants and the first applicant’s mother with a room in a three-room flat under a social tenancy agreement.
- In November 2001, the first applicant was deprived of her status as a forced migrant because she failed to apply in due time for it to be extended, which she claims not to have been informed of until 2003.
- The first applicant was excluded from the social tenancy agreement in 2002 due to the loss of her forced migrant status.
- The applicants were ordered to vacate the room in July 2009, and in May 2012, were ordered to vacate the disputed housing without the provision of any alternative accommodation by the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg.
- The enforcement proceedings were terminated on 11 March 2015 on the grounds that the applicants had voluntarily vacated the room.
- The second applicant has been registered as living in the flat belonging to his father and paternal grandmother since March 2016.
- The first applicant is currently renting a room in a shared apartment at her own expense as her application for social housing had been removed from the waiting list.

title: CASE OF SCHESZTÁK v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Ercsi.
- On 28 February 2007, the applicant filed an action against his former employer for unlawful dismissal.
- On 6 June 2008, the Székesfehérvár Labour Court ruled in favour of the applicant and ordered the respondent to pay him a severance payment, outstanding wages, a lump sum in compensation, and default interest.
- On 25 February 2009, the Fejér County Regional Court changed the judgment in part.
- On 16 June 2010, the Supreme Court, sitting as a review court, reversed the previous decisions and dismissed the applicant’s action stating the applicant had not filed any comments on the petition for review.

title: CASE OF LAMBIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and is currently detained in a correctional colony in Russia.
- On 21 April 2005, the applicant was convicted of murder and sentenced to imprisonment.
- The conviction was upheld on appeal in a public hearing on 18 August 2005.
- On 30 July 2010, the appeal judgment was quashed due to a breach of the applicant's right to defense during the appeal hearing.
- The case was sent for fresh examination on appeal, and the applicant was given five days to study the six-volume case file while being held in a metal cage.
- The applicant and his lawyer filed appeals, and the case was examined by the Supreme Court of Russia over four hearings, three of which were held in camera.
- On 16 December 2010, the Supreme Court upheld the judgment of 21 April 2005.

title: CASE OF MKRTCHYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and resides in Yerevan.
- The applicant was charged with fraud in Armenia on 16 August 2004, and the Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court in Yerevan issued an arrest warrant.
- On 8 November 2006, the applicant was arrested in Ufa, Russia, after an extradition request was received from the Armenian counterpart.
- The Kirovskiy District Court in Ufa remanded the applicant in custody on 27 December 2006 without setting a time limit for his detention, and the Supreme Court of Bashkortostan upheld the detention order on appeal.
- On 23 March 2007, the extradition request was granted by the deputy Prosecutor General, and on 17 July 2007, the Supreme Court of Russia upheld the decision in the final instance.
- The applicant was extradited to Armenia on 24 August 2007, where he was acquitted of all charges and released.
- On 16 February 2008, the applicant was detained by Russian border control when attempting to return to Russia, and remained in custody until 22 February 2008, without any record of the arrest or judicial decision authorizing the detention being provided by either party.

title: CASE OF REDAKTSIYA GAZETY ZEMLYAKI v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant company is a limited liability company registered in the town of Kstovo, in the Nizhegorodskiy Region.
- The applicant company is the founder, editor and publisher of a local newspaper, Zemlyaki, printed in Kstovo and distributed in the Kstovskiy District.
- In 2004 the applicant company published a series of articles commenting on the professional activity of Y.L., the then head of the Kstovo District Administration (“the District Administration”).
- In an article published in issue 11 (400) dated 6 March 2004, N.G. contested the validity of the District Administration’s policy concerning spending and property management in respect of 2003.
- In another article concerning the same subject matter, this time in issue 13 (402) dated 20 March 2004, the newspaper published a photo collage depicting Y.L. as Osama bin Laden.
- On 11 May 2004 Y.L. complained about the articles to the Kstovo City Court, claiming that they contained defamatory and damaging material.
- On 31 August 2004, the court issued a judgment in favour of Y.L. in part.
- The court declared the information in question erroneous and defamatory, and ordered the applicant company to pay a symbolic amount in damages and publish a retraction.
- The applicant company appealed against the judgment of 31 August 2004, but it was upheld on appeal on 22 October 2004.
- Further attempts by the applicant company to have the case reviewed by way of supervisory review procedure were unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF GRBA v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and was serving a prison sentence in Croatia at the time of the introduction of his application.
- Complaints were received by the Istria Police Department regarding the use of counterfeit euro banknotes.
- Video surveillance recordings revealed that a certain C.M. had paid using several counterfeit 100 euro notes.
- Investigative police work identified the applicant as the person who had supplied a total of 3,000 counterfeit euros to C.M.
- Special investigative measures were authorized by Pula County State Attorney's Office after the investigating judge found that the investigation couldn't be efficiently carried out by any other means.
- The applicant was questioned, remained silent, and was remanded in custody by the investigating judge.
- The case was forwarded to the Pazin Municipal State Attorney’s Office for further examination and indictment.
- The Pazin Municipal State Attorney’s Office indicted the applicant in the Pazin Municipal Court on charges of currency counterfeiting.
- The trial bench examined secret surveillance recordings, commissioned a psychiatric expert report on the applicant's mental condition at the time of the offense, and questioned undercover police agents.
- The applicant had full mental capacity at the time of the offense, according to the expert witness's report.

title: CASE OF TADIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was caught in the act of attempting to rob an exchange office in Zagreb by two police officers.
- The police officers applied force against the applicant, using the armlock technique.
- The applicant complained of shoulder pain and was taken to the hospital where it was discovered that his shoulder was broken.
- An internal investigation into the use of force was initiated by the Zagreb police.
- The use of force was deemed lawful and justified by the internal investigators and the head of the Zagreb police.
- The applicant later lodged a criminal complaint against the police officers.
- The ZMSAO obtained statements and medical documentation concerning the incident.
- The ZMSAO attempted to contact the applicant multiple times with no response.
- The investigation is still ongoing.
- The applicant also filed civil proceedings against the State for damages related to the alleged ill-treatment.

title: CASE OF DORNEANU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and was serving a sentence for economic offences when he lodged his application.
- He was charged with involvement in a criminal network operating in the economic field and fraudulent appropriations were granted to companies.
- The applicant was convicted on conspiracy charges and sentenced to three years, four months’ imprisonment.
- He was diagnosed with prostate cancer in November 2012, which had already reached an advanced stage.
- The applicant was admitted to multiple hospitals for treatment and underwent surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.
- A medical board issued him with a certificate of severe disability, and one of the judges considered that his continued detention was in breach of the proportionality principle and reduced his chances of survival.
- The court ordered a three-month interruption of his sentence, but the prosecution appealed and his request was dismissed.
- He was eventually released on the most favourable possible detention regime but was unable to move and was suffering from severe bone pain, depression, and complete loss of sight.
- The applicant died on 24 December 2013, and he had been held in various cells with other prisoners throughout his imprisonment.

title: CASE OF N. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and is currently detained at Săpoca Psychiatric Hospital.
- He has been receiving a second-degree disability allowance since 1993.
- He was charged with incest and sexual corruption of his two under-age daughters, aged 15 and 16, on 29 January 2001.
- The applicant was questioned by the police in the presence of a lawyer and placed in police custody for twenty-four hours before being questioned by a prosecutor regarding the same charges.
- On 30 April 2001, the prosecution ordered the applicant’s provisional detention in a psychiatric hospital to assess his capacity for discernment. 
- The applicant underwent psychiatric examinations which found him to have paranoid impulsive tendencies with high conflict potential, irritability, suspicion, interpretative tendencies, and potential aggression.
- A forensic medical report established that the applicant suffered from chronic paranoid schizophrenia and lack of discernment.
- The preliminary investigation against the applicant for the rape of his wife was instigated, and the prosecution heard the applicant’s wife and two daughters.
- The prosecution closed the criminal proceedings against the applicant for incest but concluded that he had committed offenses of sexual corruption of minors. The prosecution referred the case to the competent court for confirmation of the preventive measure of medical detention.
- Bucharest District Court 6 upheld the medical detention order and confirmed the provisional medical detention order.

title: CASE OF MERABISHVILI v. GEORGIA
facts:
- Incident at Tbilisi Airport on 30 November 2012
- Criminal proceedings against the applicant in relation to the State Programme for Job Seekers and the house in the village of Kvariati, including:
  - Initial phase of the proceedings
  - Applicant’s arrest and placement in pre-trial detention
  - Two adjournments of the pre-trial conference hearing
  - Applicant’s request for release during the pre-trial conference hearing
  - Applicant’s request for release of 7 October 2013
  - Applicant’s conviction and sentence and his appeals against them
- Other criminal cases against the applicant
- Alleged covert removal of the applicant from his prison cell on 14 December 2013 and investigations into that allegation, including:
  - Applicant’s allegations
  - Authorities’ initial reaction to those allegations
  - Inquiry by the Ministry of Prisons’ General Inspectorate (December 2013 – January 2014)
  - Developments after the end of the inquiry
  - Investigation by the Chief Public Prosecutor’s Office (June 2016 – February 2017)
- Criminal cases against other members of UNM’s leadership, including:
  - Statements by Georgian Dream government ministers in connection with those cases
  - Statements by foreign governments, international organisations and non-governmental organisations in relation to those cases
  - Refusals to extradite former UNM officials to Georgia
  - Interpol’s deletion of information about Mr Saakashvili and Mr D.K.

title: CASE OF CHANTURIDZE v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 in the Georgian SSR of the USSR.
- In 1996, his parents divorced and he moved with his mother to Kaluga in Russia.
- In 2003, the applicant began studies at the Finance and Economics Institute.
- On 4 May and 17 October 2005 the applicant was convicted of various offences and given a custodial sentence. 
- Upon his release on 29 February 2008, he returned to Kaluga.
- On 12 January 2012, the police charged him with illegal residence in Russia.
- On 13 January 2012, the Kaluzhskiy District Court found the applicant guilty of the administrative offence under Article 18.8 § 1 of the Code of Administrative Offences and sentenced him to a fine of 2,500 Russian roubles (62 euros) and administrative removal from the Russian Federation.
- The applicant asked the District Court to postpone the enforcement of the removal order, but it was refused.
- The applicant was held in the administrative detention centre operated by the Kaluga regional police.
- He shared Cell 13 measuring 8.7 square metres with five Uzbek nationals awaiting deportation. 
- The cell had no ventilation and only one window. 
- The toilet bowl was located 40 centimetres from the nearest bed and was cleaned with cold water without detergent.
- Prisoners were given three litres of water per day, it was not allowed to boil it. 
- Once a week prisoners were taken to the shower room. 
- There was no calendar, clock, radio, television, books, or newspapers. 
- Board games were forbidden. 
- Prisoners were taken outdoors in groups of thirty. 
- In May 2012 the applicant developed pulmonary tuberculosis. 
- In January and March 2012 two members of the Kaluga public monitoring commission visited the facility. 
- Their report corroborated the applicant’s description of his conditions of detention. 
- In January 2013 the applicant returned to the detention centre. 
- On 31 January 2013, the applicant was placed on board a Tbilisi-bound flight and left Russia.

title: CASE OF MAC TV S.R.O. v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant company is a television operator and broadcaster, established in 1991 and based in Bratislava, Slovakia.
- The case concerns a commentary made during a TV programme broadcast on 12 April 2010, after the crash of a plane carrying the late President of Poland, Lech Kaczynski.
- The commentary expressed criticism and sarcasm towards the reaction of politicians, including Slovak russophile politicians, to the tragedy, as well as towards Lech Kaczynski himself, who was described as representing extreme Polish conservatism and being a symbol of a country where people who are not white, heterosexual, Catholic Poles were born as a punishment.
- The Broadcasting Council initiated administrative proceedings against the applicant company for breaching its obligations under the Broadcasting Act and fined it €5,000.
- The conflict between the applicant company's freedom of expression and the protection of the late President's human dignity was assessed by the Broadcasting Council, which found that the last two sentences of the commentary, expressing a lack of regret for the President's death and envy of the Poles, contravened the duty to respect his human dignity.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Broadcasting Council's decision, rejecting the applicant company's argument that it had been sanctioned for voicing its political opinion and confirming the defamatory character of the commentary and the interference with the late President's human dignity.
- The applicant company challenged the decisions of the Broadcasting Council and the Supreme Court before the Constitutional Court, alleging arbitrary, unfair, and insufficiently reasoned decisions that breached its freedom of expression, but the Constitutional Court rejected its complaint, considering that the domestic authorities had duly explained their conclusions and that the impugned commentary had interfered with the late President's right to respect for his human dignity.

title: CASE OF ÇALAR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lives in Diyarbakır.
- The applicant was an army officer.
- His contract was terminated based on classified investigation reports.
- The applicant initiated proceedings against the Ministry of Defence with the Supreme Military Administrative Court.
- The Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's request, relying on classified investigation reports and the written opinion of the public prosecutor, which were not communicated to the applicant.
- The applicant's request for rectification was also rejected by the Supreme Military Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF KÖK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and lives in Afyonkarahisar.
- The applicant was a student in a military school.
- The applicant was dismissed from his school based on classified investigation reports.
- The applicant initiated proceedings against the Ministry of Defence with the Supreme Military Administrative Court to have annulment of the impugned decision.
- The Supreme Military Administrative Court relied on the classified investigation reports and the written opinion of the public prosecutor, which were not communicated to the applicant.
- On 9 January 2008, the Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s request.
- On 10 November 2010, the applicant’s request for rectification was also rejected by the Supreme Military Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF KOLESIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and detained in Nizhniy Tagil.
- On 20 January 2009, the Verkh-Isetskiy District Court in Yekaterinburg remanded the applicant in custody on fraud charges.
- The authorized detention period was extended on several occasions after determining that the case was not ready for trial.
- The Sverdlovsk Regional Court heard an appeal against the detention order and initially decided to release the applicant on bail, but this decision was not effective due to technical reasons.
- On 12 May 2010, the District Court held that the applicant must be re-detained for his failure to comply with the bail conditions.
- On 2 June 2010, the Regional Court ordered the applicant's release after finding that the detention lacked a basis in fact.
- The conditions of detention in various cells ranged from overcrowding with 20-25 persons sharing a 30 square meter space to 14 inmates sharing a 12-15 square meter space.

title: CASE OF İNAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Bursa.
- The applicant was an officer in the Army.
- The applicant's contract was terminated based on classified investigation reports.
- The applicant had no access to the classified reports.
- On 8 September 2008, the applicant initiated proceedings against the Ministry of Defence with the Supreme Military Administrative Court to have annulment of the impugned decision.
- On 15 September 2009, the Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s request for annulment based on the classified investigation reports and the public prosecutor's written opinion, which were not communicated to the applicant.
- On 26 January 2010, the applicant’s request for rectification was also rejected by the Supreme Military Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF BOUDRAA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Yalova.
- The applicant married his wife in Turkey in 2003 and in the same year, he was deported to Algeria by Turkish authorities.
- Between 2003 and 2006, the applicant was imprisoned in Algeria, where he alleges he was subjected to various forms of ill-treatment.
- The applicant founded a political organization called the Rachad Movement in Algeria which opposes that country’s government through non-violent means.
- In August 2013, the applicant arrived in Yalova, Turkey, where his wife and children lived and was taken into police custody on 3 November 2013 as he did not have a passport.
- The applicant was detained for over 2 months, from 3 November 2013 to 7 January 2014 in a custody cell in a police detention facility, which he alleged was inhumane.
- During detention in the cell, many people were detained in the room, at times as many as 10-12 people. The room was around 10 sq. m and there was no heating or ventilation and natural light.
- The only facilities provided were a mattress and a blanket, and he slept on the floor. He was never taken out of the detention facility and did not have access to exercise in the open air, and he had to wash himself in the toilets.
- The Government submitted that the custody facility measured approximately 92 sq. m and consisted of two detention rooms of 12.8 sq. m and 17.6 sq. m, two toilets of 3.5 and 5.7 sq. m respectively.
- In their observations dated 23 May 2017, the Government submitted that at the time the Turkish nationals had been kept locked in one of the detention rooms and that the applicant and other foreign nationals had access at all times to the hall in the centre of the facility.
- The Constitutional Court found that the administrative authorities had taken the necessary measures to protect the applicant’s physical and psychological health, so the applicant's complaint that the conditions of his detention at the Yalova police headquarters had amounted to ill-treatment was dismissed.
- The Standards of the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture and Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment concern the conditions of detention of foreign nationals and recommend that in those cases where it is deemed necessary to deprive persons of their liberty for an extended period under aliens legislation, they should be accommodated in centers specifically designed

title: CASE OF ANTOVIĆ AND MIRKOVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicants were informed that video surveillance had been introduced in the auditoriums where they taught.
- The Dean issued a decision introducing video surveillance in seven amphitheatres and in front of the Dean’s Office citing safety and surveillance reasons.
- The applicants complained to the Personal Data Protection Agency (Agencija za zaštitu ličnih podataka) about the video surveillance without their consent and requested that the cameras be removed and data erased.
- Agency inspectors found that the video surveillance was in accordance with the Personal Data Protection Act; however, the Council of Personal Data Protection Agency has ordered the School of Mathematics to remove the cameras within fifteen days as the video surveillance was not in accordance with the Personal Data Protection Act.
- The Court of First Instance has ruled against the applicants stating that the installation and use of video surveillance and the collection of data thereby had not violated the applicants’ right to privacy.

title: CASE OF KAVKAZSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant is a human rights activist and lawyer
- May 6, 2012: public event at Bolotnaya Square protesting against allegedly rigged presidential elections
- Peaceful march followed by clashes between police and protesters at Bolotnaya Square
- Moscow city department of the Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation opened criminal proceedings on the same day
- Applicant arrested on July 25, 2012
- Applicant charged with participation in mass disorder accompanied by violence and accused of having kicked a police officer
- Applicant's pre-trial detention extended multiple times, denied alternative preventive measures
- Applicant's medical history includes: organic lesion of the central nervous system, hypertensive syndrome, tonsillitis, chronic gastritis, atopic dermatitis, osteochondrosis, and dorsopathy
- Applicant placed under house arrest until October 2, 2013, after Spervisory appeal by Ombudsman
- Criminal proceedings terminated on December 19, 2013, under the Amnesty Act
- Applicant's health was checked regularly during detention, but he complained of inadequate medical assistance
- Court proceedings began on June 6, 2013, for 11 defendants held in glass cabins

title: CASE OF SOKOLOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Yekaterinburg. 
- On 13 May 2009, he was arrested on suspicion of armed robbery. 
- On the following day, Verkh-Isetskiy District Court in Yekaterinburg remanded him in custody and set the time-limit until 12 July 2009. 
- On 13 July 2009, the District Court granted a two-month extension of the detention period. 
- On 31 July 2009, the Sverdlovsk Regional Court quashed the extension order, and ordered the applicant's release. 
- The applicant was re-arrested on the charge of theft and was not allowed to leave the police ward. 
- On 4 August 2009, the District Court issued a detention order that did not set a time-limit for the applicant's detention or give any assessment to the existence of a "reasonable suspicion" against the applicant. 
- The applicant was held in a metal cage throughout the trial. 
- On 13 May 2010, the applicant was found guilty of theft and armed robbery and sentenced to five years' imprisonment. 
- On 24 June 2010, the applicant's mother died, and his request to attend the funeral was rejected. 
- On 18 August 2010, the Regional Court upheld the conviction but reduced the sentence to three years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF ÜÇEL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Denizli.
- On 13 June 2009, the applicant was dismissed from the Expert Gendarmerie School because of non-compliance with disciplinary rules.
- The applicant initiated proceedings before the Supreme Military Administrative Court.
- The applicant requested the annulment of the dismissal decision.
- On 15 April 2009, the Supreme Military Administrative Court rejected the applicant's request due to the "secret documents" submitted by the Ministry of Defence.

title: CASE OF ÖZSOY AND YILDIRIM v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1987 and 1986 and live in Ankara.
- The applicants were cadets in military schools.
- They were expelled from their schools based on classified investigation reports.
- None of the applicants had access to these classified reports.
- They filed actions against the Ministry of Defence with the Supreme Military Administrative Court.
- The court rejected their requests for annulment and rectification, relying on the classified investigation reports.

title: CASE OF YAŞAR AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- List of applicants in the appendix
- Applicants taken into police custody on 21 November 1994
- Statements were taken without a lawyer, and all confessed to the crimes
- Charged under Section 125 of the former Criminal Code on 24 January 1995
- Military judges replaced with civilian judges on 18 June 1999 due to a constitutional amendment
- Convicted on 4 December 2001 and later acquitted by the Court of Cassation on 20 November 2002
- State Security Courts abolished on 16 June 2004 and case transferred to Diyarbakır Assize Court
- Applicants convicted again on 22 February 2007 and sentenced to life imprisonment
- Convictions upheld by the Court of Cassation on 6 February 2008

title: CASE OF TIMISHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant is a practising lawyer born in 1950 who lives in Nalchik, the Ingushetiya Republic.
- On 10 October 2006, while travelling in a taxi, the applicant was stopped by a police officer who found the signature in his passport was made in red ink and threatened him with an administrative offence for using an invalid identity document.
- The police detained the applicant and took him to two different police stations before releasing him.
- The applicant requested an investigation, but the prosecutor's office refused institution of criminal proceedings multiple times.
- The Nadterechnyi District Court set aside one of the decisions refusing institution of criminal proceedings, stating that the administrative detention of the applicant was unnecessary.
- Subsequent decisions refusing institution of criminal proceedings contained serious shortcomings, including a failure to establish why the report could not have been drafted at the checkpoint and why the applicant was escorted to Goragorsk, the lack of information about the forwarding letter, a failure to prepare reports required under the Code, and a lack of details about the exceptional circumstances within the meaning of Article 27.3(1) of the Code.
- The court was unconvinced that the applicant had asked the police to take him to the Nadterechnyi office to file a complaint and criticised the investigator's assumption that the applicant had committed an administrative offence.
- The investigator issued a further decision refusing institution of criminal proceedings without addressing the areas of concern identified in the District Court's judgment.

title: CASE OF IBRAGIMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant's son, Mr R., died of tuberculosis in a prison hospital.
- Mr R. was diagnosed with pneumonia and then tuberculosis combined with pneumonia.
- Treatment with five first-line drugs was prescribed, but had no effect on Mr R.’s health.
- Mr R.’s tuberculosis was resistant to four antibiotics being used in his treatment.
- Mr R.’s health continued to deteriorate, and he died of cardio-respiratory insufficiency caused by tuberculosis.
- The applicant alleged that the authorities responsible for protecting Mr R.’s life and well-being had failed to comply with their obligations.
- The Primorskiy Inter-District Prosecutor’s Office refused to open a criminal case, but the applicant continued to insist that the custodial authorities bore responsibility for his son’s death.
- The Isakogorskiy District Court of Arkhangelsk overruled the prosecutor’s decision, finding that the criminal inquiry had not been thorough, but the decision was later upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF GÜRAKIN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were a husband and son of a deceased woman
- They brought a compensation case against a hospital for alleged medical negligence
- They requested legal aid due to their poor financial situation
- Their legal aid claim was rejected twice by the Izmir Administrative Court
- The court ordered them to pay 1,683 Turkish liras (TRY) (approximately 870 Euros (EUR)) in court fees within one month to continue the proceedings
- As the applicants failed to pay the court fees within the time-limit, the İzmir Administrative Court sent a further warning letter to the applicants and ordered them to pay the court fees
- The applicants made a second request for legal aid and asked the court to reconsider its former decision
- The second request for legal aid was also rejected by the court
- The court decided to discontinue the proceedings due to non-payment of court fees.

title: CASE OF BİLGİÇ v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1987 and lives in Bursa.
- On 26 April 2006, the applicant was dismissed from the Air Force non-commissioned officer vocational high school.
- The reason for dismissal was due to non-compliance with admission pre-conditions.
- On 22 June 2006, the applicant brought an action before the Supreme Military Administrative Court.
- The applicant requested the annulment of the dismissal decision.
- On 23 May 2007, the Supreme Military Administrative Court rejected the applicant’s request.
- The court considered “secret documents” submitted by the Ministry of Defence.
- These documents were not disclosed to the applicant.
- The decision was served on the applicant on 5 June 2007.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDR KONOVALOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a prison sentence in Valuyki, the Belgorod region
- Ms I., a university student, disappeared on 14 June 2006
- The police searched the applicant's flat and car on 17 June 2006
- The applicant was taken to the Severnyy police department and beaten by police officers
- The applicant confessed to the murder of I. and was taken to the place where he had allegedly hidden her body
- The applicant was detained from 17 June 2006 until 10.40 a.m. on 19 June 2006 and then taken to the Sovetskiy police department where he was allegedly beaten and given electric shocks
- The applicant's self-incriminating statements were recorded in his "explanation" given to the investigator of the Sovetskiy district prosecutor's office on 19 June 2006
- The applicant was arrested on 20 June 2006 and questioned in the presence of a State-appointed lawyer and police officers
- The applicant showed where he had hidden the victim's mobile telephone and was then ordered a forensic medical examination
- The investigator refused to institute criminal proceedings into the applicant's complaints against the police officers from both Severnyy and Sovetskiy police departments
- The District Court convicted the applicant of aggravated murder on 25 October 2006 and sentenced him to twelve years' imprisonment
- The applicant's appeals for supervisory review of his case were dismissed by the Regional Court.

title: CASE OF ÖZMURAT İNŞAAT ELEKTRİK NAKLİYAT TEMİZLİK SAN. VE TİC. LTD. ŞTİ. v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a construction company.
- The company opened a mine in its owned land in 2005 after obtaining a permit.
- An audit commission inspected the mine on 31 January 2006 and found that it had violated the terms of its license. 
- The commission recommended that the applicant pay a fine of TRY 131,250.
- The Tarsus Provincial Administration informed the applicant of the decision to impose the administrative fine.
- The president of the applicant company filed a complaint, accusing an auditor of asking for a bribe.
- The Mersin Public Prosecutor’s office filed an indictment against the auditor and another official for extortion.
- The Mersin Assize Court found the officials guilty of extortion.
- The applicant filed an objection to the fine and requested a stay of execution and an oral hearing.
- The Tarsus Magistrates’ Court rejected the applicant’s requests for an oral hearing and on-site examination.
- The Tarsus Assize Court rejected the applicant’s objection without holding a hearing.
- The administration seized the plot of land due to the applicant’s failure to pay the administrative fine.

title: CASE OF GÜNEŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and is currently detained in Diyarbakır.
- On 8 March 1995, the applicant was taken into police custody on suspicion of membership in an illegal organization, Hizbullah.
- During his police custody, the applicant’s right of access to a lawyer was restricted according to the now defunct Law no. 3842.
- On 16 March 1995, the applicant participated in an identification parade with other accused persons and identified certain persons as members of the organization and confessed to committing a murder, in the absence of a lawyer.
- On 26 March 1995, the applicant participated in the reconstruction of the events in which he had confessed, in the absence of a lawyer, to carrying out an arson attack.
- On 29 March 1995, the applicant was questioned by the police officers in the absence of a lawyer.
- On 5 April 1995, the applicant was brought before the public prosecutor and the investigating judge respectively, again in the absence of a lawyer.
- On 12 April 1995, he was examined by a doctor at his own request claiming that he had been subjected to torture while in police custody.
- On 2 May 1995, the applicant gave evidence as complainant before the public prosecutor and stated that he had been subjected to various forms of torture.
- On 23 May 1995, the public prosecutor at the Diyarbakır State Security Court filed a bill of indictment against the applicant and several other persons.
- On 19 October 1995, the State Security Court held the first hearing in the case.
- By Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004, State Security Courts were abolished, and the case against the applicant was transferred to the Diyarbakır Assize Court.
- On 31 March 2005, the Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicant of attempting to undermine the constitutional order and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- On 11 December 2006, the Court of Cassation quashed the judgment of 31 March 2005 in respect of some of the accused, including the applicant, and remitted the case to the Diyarbakır Assize Court.
- On 9 November 2007, the Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicant again of attempting to undermine the constitutional order and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- On 19 January 2009, the Court of Cassation upheld

title: CASE OF SYARKEVICH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lived in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk until his arrest.
- On April 3, 2003, the applicant was apprehended in possession of unregistered firearms with four tied and beaten persons, including Mr P., in a closet in the flat where he was caught.
- The applicant was charged with various crimes, including the formation and leadership of an armed gang, multiple counts of aggravated kidnapping, extortion, robbery and fraud, as well as illegal possession of firearms.
- Despite repeated requests for release on bail and unsuccessful appeal complaints against detention orders, the courts extended the applicant's detention on thirteen occasions until his conviction.
- On April 6, 2006, the Regional Court found the applicant and six accomplices guilty as charged and sentenced the applicant to twenty-one years' imprisonment.
- The applicant was found guilty of an extensive fraud, robbery, kidnapping, and extortion in connection with Mr L., a businessperson from the Moscow region.
- The applicant disappeared with approximately 600,000 RUB that Mr L. had transferred to an account indicated by the applicant in May 2001.
- In October 2002, the applicant contacted Mr L. again, claiming that he had returned from Japan with his car and invited him to come to Sakhalin for it. On 13 October 2002, Mr L. was met by Mr K., one of the applicant's accomplices, at the Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk airport, and then held hostage and subjected to beatings and extortion until November 6, 2002, by the applicant and his gang.
- The court did not hear testimony by Mr K. or Mr L., but their incriminating pre-trial statements were read aloud.
- The jury discovered that the applicant organised several armed robberies of eight other victims in September and October of 2002 and March of 2003, which resulted in the kidnapping of Mr P.

title: CASE OF SHMELEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the mother of Denis Aleksandrovich Vyrzhikovskiy.
- On 1 October 2010, the applicant's son and his friend were arrested by police officers and taken to the Moskovskiy District Department of the Interior of St Petersburg without any record of their arrest being drawn up.
- The applicant's son was ill-treated by police officers for approximately six hours, being repeatedly punched and subjected to the "swallow" method of torture.
- The applicant's son was then taken to another police station with his friend, and his friend later testified to seeing a bruise on his forehead and having difficulties getting into a police car.
- On 2 October 2010, Vyrzhikovskiy was taken to a hospital and died there eight days later due to severe fat pulmonary embolism along with multiple injuries, including comminuted humeral head fracture, soft tissue injuries, bruises covering hands, chest, upper back, neck, armpits, and face, abrasions and bruises on buttocks, left hip, right palm, right part of stomach, right thigh, left knee, both calves.
- Criminal investigation was initiated on 12 October 2010, and several police officers were charged with manslaughter and abuse of powers entailing a substantial violation of individual rights, committed using violence.
- On 26 March 2014, the officers were found guilty as charged, and on 1 October 2014, St Petersburg City Court partially quashed the judgment and acquitted officers of manslaughter for lack of evidence.
- The City Court did find the injuries inflicted intentionally and remanded the case for additional investigation to identify those responsible for Vyrzhikovskiy's death.
- The investigation was suspended on 2 March 2015, and the decision was upheld as lawful on 12 November 2015, becoming final on 27 January 2016.

title: CASE OF LITVINOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their relevant details is provided in the document.
- The applicants have filed complaints about the domestic courts' failure to facilitate their participation in hearings.
- The hearings in question are civil proceedings in which the applicants were parties.

title: CASE OF AȘTILEANU AND AXENTE v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The application details are in the appended table
- The applicants complained about the length of civil proceedings
- The applicants agreed to waive further claims in exchange for a payment by the Government
- The payment amount is detailed in the appended table and will be converted to the currency of the respondent State at the applicable rate
- The payment must be made within three months of the Court's decision
- In case of failure to pay, the Government must pay simple interest at the European Central Bank's rate plus three percentage points
- The payment will resolve this part of the application finally.

facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their application details is provided.
- The applicants were involved in civil proceedings.
- The domestic courts failed to ensure the applicants' participation in hearings. 
- The applicants have made complaints about the aforementioned failure.

- The applicants claim that civil proceedings took an excessive amount of time.
- The applicants argue there is a lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF LADYUK AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA

- The domestic courts failed to ensure the participation of the applicants in the hearings, leading to the complaints.

title: CASE OF KLIMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table is appended with the list of applicants and the relevant details of the applications.
- The applicants were convicted of drug offences.
- The applicants claimed that they were unfairly convicted.
- The applicants alleged that they were entrapped by State agents.

facts:
