- Applicants complain about lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Additional complaints raised in applications 2887/05, 68256/12, and 66389/16 under provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KOVALEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document contains a table with a list of applicants and their relevant application details.
- The applicants alleged inadequate medical care in detention.
- The applicants claimed there was no effective remedy for the medical care issue.
- Some applicants raised complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF HAMIDOVIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
Main facts described in the document:

- On 28 October 2011, Mevlid Jašarević attacked the United States Embassy in Sarajevo. One police officer was severely wounded.
- Mr Jašarević, a member of the local group advocating the Wahhabi/Salafi version of Islam, was convicted of terrorism and sentenced to fifteen years’ imprisonment.
- Members of the community in Gornja Maoča, to which the applicant belonged, opposed the concept of a secular State, democracy, free elections, and any laws that are not based on Sharia.
- The applicant was summoned to appear as a witness on 10 September 2012, but he refused to remove his skullcap, was expelled from the courtroom, convicted of contempt of court, and sentenced to a fine of 10,000 BAM.
- The court found that the witness’s behaviour was connected to a number of other identical cases before it and was producing dangerous criminogenic effects, presenting a specific threat to society.

title: CASE OF PRAZINA v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- First applicant is the grandfather of the second applicant who lives in Sarajevo.
- Second applicant requested recognition of veteran status of his late father on 10 November 2005.
- Second applicant's request was rejected on 12 December 2005 and appealed in December 2005 or January 2006.
- Competent Ministry upheld the first-instance decision on 26 January 2006.
- On 21 January 2008, Sarajevo Cantonal Court quashed the decisions of 12 December 2005 and 26 January 2006, and remitted the case to the first-instance body.
- In new proceedings, second applicant's request was again rejected on 25 September 2012 by Sarajevo Cantonal Court.
- On 10 October 2012, Constitutional Court found a breach of the second applicant's right to a trial within a reasonable time without awarding any damages.

title: CASE OF ALKOVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant is a Roma and a Muslim living in Montenegro.
- The applicant's apartment and car were subject to constant attacks by unknown perpetrators, which led him to install a camera outside his apartment.
- On 26 May 2009, the applicant's next-door neighbor made threats against a Bosnian kickboxer and his Muslim coaches, and gunshots were fired towards the applicant's terrace.
- On 9 September 2009, three of the applicant's neighbors were overheard making derogatory and threatening remarks towards him and his family based on their ethnicity and religion.
- On 22 September 2009, a large cross was drawn on the applicant's apartment door with a threatening message, which led him to lodge a criminal complaint against the families of his neighbors.
- Despite lodging complaints, the applicant received no protection from the authorities and faced additional attacks, including vandalism and physical assault.
- The applicant was found guilty of recording a neighbor without authorization and eavesdropping.

title: CASE OF RIBAĆ v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1942 and lives in Maribor
- The SFRY was a federal State composed of six republics: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Serbia, Slovenia, Montenegro and Macedonia, with dual citizenship and freedom of movement within the federal State.
- The SFRY had two pension systems: military and civil.
- The SFRY broke up between 1991 and 1992 starting with Slovenia's declaration of independence on 25 June 1991.
- The Slovenian Government issued the Ordinance on the payment of advances on military pensions in 1992, regulating the payment of military pensions to former YPA military personnel residing in the Republic of Slovenia, while in 1998, a new Act on the Rights Stemming from the Pension and Disability Insurance of Former Military Personnel was put in place.
- In 1994, the YPA Fund was transformed into the Social Insurance Fund of Military Personnel of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, continuing to pay YPA pensions to the citizens of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
- As for the inter-State level, the agreement on Succession Issues entered into force in 2004 outlining the payment of pensions to military personnel who had acquired or applied for pensions with the YPA Fund under the SFRY military rules.
- The applicant was a citizen of the Republic of Serbia and then Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
- On 13 November 1991, the YPA Fund found him to be entitled to an old-age pension under the SFRY military rules as from 1 October 1991.
- The applicant applied for Slovenian citizenship in 1991, and it was rejected in 1992 because of a security threat concern. After several unsuccessful attempts and court proceedings, he acquired Slovenian citizenship in 2003.
- In 1992, the applicant applied for an advance on his military pension under the Ordinance.
- Due to the Institute's requirements, the applicant requested the YPA Fund to discontinue the payment of his pension and lodged a request for an advance on his military pension, which was later suspended in 1998.
- The applicant appealed the suspension, arguing that in the legally relevant period, he had been a foreigner with no rights to a pension or benefits.
- The higher courts upheld the earlier decisions, holding that the applicant had not met the requirements for any of the categories of beneficiaries under the 1998 Act.
- A constitutional complaint by the applicant was rejected in 2010, finding

title: CASE OF MAGOMETKHOZHIYEV AND AMALAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:
- The applicants complained of a breach of their property rights through the actions of Russian military forces in Chechnya in 2000 and the failure of the competent domestic authorities to provide them with effective remedies in respect of those breaches.
- Two applicants had their vehicles seized by Russian military forces, with no explanation or documentation provided, and the vehicles were not returned despite efforts to locate them.
- One applicant had their lorry destroyed by gunshots from an army personnel carrier, and the criminal investigation failed to identify the perpetrators or provide a conclusive proof that state agents were involved.
- Both applicants' claims for compensation were dismissed by domestic courts due to the absence of conclusive proof of state agents' involvement in the crimes.
- One applicant left Chechnya and moved to Germany in March 2013.

title: CASE OF MOMČILOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants complained about domestic courts not enforcing judgments in their favour.
- Applicants received decisions from the Constitutional Court stating violation of their right to a hearing.
- Applicants were awarded sums in compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- Domestic proceedings are still pending for the first applicant.
- Proceedings have been terminated for the second and third applicants on different dates.

title: CASE OF S.F. AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The five applicants are Iraqi nationals who fled to Switzerland in 2015.
- The applicants attempted to cross the Turkish-Bulgarian border covertly in August 2015 with four other families, intending to continue towards Western Europe.
- The applicants' vehicle was intercepted by Bulgarian border police about 15 km south of Bregovo, close to the Serbian border, and were taken into custody with other migrants.
- The applicants were taken to a detention facility in Vidin, Bulgaria, and searched. Their belongings were taken away, and they were split into two groups between two cells.
- The conditions of the cell were reportedly poor, with the video provided by the applicants showing a small, run-down cell, lacking basic hygiene facilities and with insufficient access to food and water.
- Following their arrest, the first and second applicants were digitally fingerprinted and interviewed in English. The second applicant was hospitalized for examination with her toddler after a young child in the adjacent cell received an electric shock due to an electrical wire. 
- Orders for the first and second applicants' removal from Bulgaria and detention pending removal were served. 
- The applicants were taken to an immigration detention facility in Sofia and sought international protection in Bulgaria, but their proceedings were discontinued after they vanished from the facility.
- The applicants then sought international protection in Switzerland, where they were initially refused examination but eventually granted asylum in July 2017.

title: CASE OF CUŠKO v. LATVIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1970 and lives in Riga.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted on 23 April 2003.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of attempted bribery on 29 April 2003.
- The applicant was detained on remand on 2 May 2003.
- Bill of indictment was served on the applicant and his two co-accused (D.E. and V.M.) on 27 November 2003.
- The first hearing was scheduled to take place from 1 to 4 August 2005.
- The hearing was adjourned for an indefinite period owing to D.E.’s poor state of health and the fact that the applicant’s defence lawyer was on vacation.
- The new Criminal Procedure Law entered into force on 1 October 2005.
- On 22 February 2006, the hearing was adjourned because one of the judges of the Riga Regional Court had to recuse herself from the trial.
- On 31 July 2006, the hearing was adjourned because the prosecutor and the applicant’s defence lawyer were due to go away on holiday.
- On 15 November 2006, a judge from the Riga Regional Court requested the hospital in which D.E. was being treated to provide information about her state of health.
- The hearing was adjourned on 27 February 2007 for unspecified reasons.
- The hearing was adjourned on 26 June 2007 owing to D.E.’s poor state of health, but she was later deemed able to participate in the proceedings after a medical examination.
- The next hearing was scheduled for 27 December 2007 but was adjourned as the prosecution needed to replace the charge against the applicant with a more lenient one.
- On 11 January 2008, the Riga Regional Court started to hear the parties’ arguments regarding the merits of the case.
- On 15 January 2008, it convicted the applicant of attempted bribery and sentenced him to three years’ imprisonment.
- On 4 February 2008, the applicant submitted an appeal.
- On 1 December 2008, the appellate court upheld the lower court’s judgment.
- On 30 December 2008, the applicant lodged an appeal on points of law, arguing that his right to a trial within a reasonable time had been breached.
- By a final decision of 26 January 2009, the Senate of the Supreme Court refused the applicant leave to appeal on points

title: CASE OF YONCHEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was a police officer since 1977.
- In 2001, he applied for a position as a police observer but was not included due to a negative psychological assessment.
- After the negative outcome, the applicant retired in 2002 and would not have been able to work another position in the same Ministry of the Interior.
- The applicant underwent a fresh psychological assessment in 2002 as part of a second application, but the result was the same.
- The applicant requested access to his personnel file but was initially refused.
- The refusal to access his personnel file was quashed and then reconsidered, but access was again denied.
- The denial of access was upheld by the Bulgarian Supreme Administrative Court in a final judgment in 2008.
- The Government submitted copies of the applicant's psychological assessments, which had no security markings.

title: CASE OF KRSTANOSKI AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- In 1957, several plots of agricultural land were expropriated from the applicants' legal predecessors.
- The applicants sought restitution proceedings to restore the land that currently forms part of a campsite on the shore of Lake Ohrid to their possession.
- In 2003, the Restitution Commission granted the applicants' claims and awarded them compensation.
- The Second-Instance Administrative-Procedure Commission dismissed the applicants' appeal in 2005 stating that the land was of public interest and could not be restored to the applicant's possession.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicants' claim in 2008, upholding the findings of the administrative authorities.

title: CASE OF KILIÇ v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1961 and 1960 respectively and live in İzmir.
- Applicants initiated compensation proceedings after their son's death during military service.
- Supreme Military Administrative Court composed of 5 members, including 3 military judges and 2 military officers.
- The court dismissed the case on 20 October 2010.
- The judgment was notified to the applicants on 29 November 2010.

title: CASE OF IALAMOV v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lived in Chisinau.
- On 6 April 2009, he was arrested for murder and later charged with several counts of theft.
- The applicant was held in pre-trial detention until 21 January 2011.
- He was acquitted of murder charges but convicted for theft and was sentenced to one year and six months’ imprisonment.
- During the trial, the applicant’s detention was extended periodically, including one extension that was applied for two days before the expiry of the detention period.
- The prosecutor’s application was accepted by the court on 29 September 2009, and the applicant’s pre-trial detention was prolonged by twenty-five days, despite his argument that it was not allowed due to the prosecutor's failure to comply with the provisions of Article 186 § 6 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

title: CASE OF DİK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and lives in Van.
- The applicant applied for compensation due to forced evacuation from his village.
- His request for compensation was rejected by the commission.
- He initiated legal proceedings to have the decision annulled.
- The applicant requested legal aid to pay the court fees.
- The administrative court rejected his legal aid request.
- He was ordered to pay 604 Turkish Liras (TRY) (approximately 330 euros (EUR)) in court fees within one month.
- The applicant failed to pay the court fees within the time-limit.
- The Van Administrative Court sent further warning letters and ordered the applicant to pay the court fees.
- On 29 December 2006 the court decided to discontinue the proceedings.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the judgment on 17 December 2008.
- Subsequently, the administrative court decided to discontinue the proceedings.

title: CASE OF ÖZÇAYIR AND ÇİÇEK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1982 and 1981 respectively.
- The police officers, acting on court order, searched the premises of a cooperative of which the applicants were members.
- The police seized several documents and CDs containing propaganda materials related to the youth branch of the PKK.
- The applicants were taken into custody on suspicion of being members of a terrorist organization.
- The Urfa Magistrates’ Court ordered the applicants’ detention on remand on 24 April 2006.
- The courts rejected the applicants' requests for release without holding a hearing.
- The magistrates’ court examined the necessity of applicants’ continued detention every thirty days without holding an oral hearing.
- The applicants filed objections against their continued pre-trial detention, which were examined on the basis of the case file and rejected by the domestic courts.
- The Diyarbakır Public Prosecutor filed an indictment with the Diyarbakır Assize Court charging the applicants, along with twenty-three others, with aiding and abetting a terrorist organization.
- The applicants were released pending trial on 30 November 2006.
- The Diyarbakır Assize Court acquitted the applicants of the charges against them on 4 November 2008. The judgment became final on 12 November 2008 in the absence of an appeal.

title: CASE OF KAYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Diyarbakır.
- The applicant was an officer in the Army.
- On 1 August 1989, the applicant’s contract was terminated and he was dismissed from his office based on classified investigation reports.
- At the time of the dismissal, the applicant did not have access to the classified reports, and there was no remedy available.
- In 2011, the applicant applied to the Ministry of Defence for reinstatement but was rejected.
- On 4 August 2011, the applicant initiated proceedings before the Supreme Military Administrative Court to have the annulment of the decision of the Ministry of Defence.
- The defendant party submitted classified documents for the court's consideration during the proceedings.
- On 24 April 2012, the Supreme Military Administrative Court rejected the applicant’s case.
- The decision was served on the applicant on 15 May 2012.

title: CASE OF ÇULHAOĞLU v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1961, 1990 and 1960 respectively and live in Denizli.
- Applicants’ relative, Mr Ahmet Aziz Çulhaoğlu, died during his military service.
- Applicants initiated compensation proceedings alleging that the death was caused due to negligence of military authorities.
- Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed the case.
- The court comprised of 5 members, including 3 military judges and 2 military officers.
- The court stated that the death could not be attributed to the military authorities.
- The applicants' rectification request was rejected by the court on December 7, 2011.

title: CASE OF ZADUMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant and Mr A. were invited to the apartment of Mr X. by Ms K. on 15 October 2010.
- The applicant and Mr A. attacked Mr X. by violently kicking him until he stopped breathing due to his refusal to give the applicant his passport.
- Ms K. was voluntarily hospitalized for alcohol-induced psychosis and seizures after witness the attack on Mr X.
- Ms K. alleged that the applicant and Mr A. attacked Mr X. and kicked him until he died.
- The applicant and Mr A. were arrested and detained on suspicion of manslaughter.
- The District Court allowed the reading out of Ms K.’s testimony under Article 281 of the Code of Criminal Procedure despite objections from the defense.
- The District Court convicted the applicant and Mr A. of manslaughter and sentenced them to ten and eight years’ imprisonment respectively.
- The Tver Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal and confirmed the involvement of the applicant in the committed crime based on Ms K.’s testimony.

title: CASE OF YUMUŞAK AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants were cadets or officers in the army
- Expelled from school or had contracts terminated based on classified investigation reports
- Applicants file actions against the Ministry of Defence with Supreme Military Administrative Court
- Court relied on classified investigation reports and written opinions of public prosecutors not communicated to applicants
- Court rejected applicants’ cases and subsequent requests for rectification.

title: CASE OF ŞAHİN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Adana.
- The Adana Magistrate’s Court ordered the detention of the applicant in absentia on 11 July 2000.
- On 20 July 2000, the applicant was questioned by the gendarmerie in the absence of his lawyer and gave a detailed description of his involvement in an illegal organization.
- The applicant was brought before the public prosecutor at the Adana State Security Court and stated, again in the absence of a lawyer, that his statements made to the gendarmerie had been correct.
- On 15 September 2000, the investigating judge at the Mardin Magistrate’s Court ordered the applicant’s pre-trial detention, again in the absence of a lawyer.
- On 24 October 2000, the public prosecutor lodged an indictment before the Adana State Security Court, charging the applicant under Section 125 of the former Criminal Code with carrying out activities with the aim of bringing about the secession of part of the national territory.
- On 25 October 2005, the Adana Assize Court convicted the applicant as charged.
- On 26 April 2006, the Court of Cassation quashed the conviction.
- On 6 November 2007, the Adana Assize Court convicted the applicant again based on his statements to the gendarmerie and the public prosecutor and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- On 12 November 2008, the Court of Cassation upheld the conviction.

title: CASE OF INDERKINY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are a family living in Samara with specific birth years.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court ordered the management of the 16th Military Plant to provide suitable housing to the applicants.
- The judgment came into force on May 11, 2004.
- The enforcement proceedings were opened on May 28, 2004, but were later terminated as the company had no available residential accommodation.
- Due to the reorganization of the company, the enforcement file was sent to the Department of the Bailiffs’ Service for the Engelsskiy District of Saratov Region.
- The bailiffs ruled that it was impossible to enforce the judgment related to housing as the new debtor had no available accommodation.
- The District Court replaced the debtor in enforcement proceedings from FGUP 9 TSARZ to OAO 9 TSARZ.
- The Oktyabrskiy District Court clarified the judgment to provide the applicants with an apartment in Samara.
- The parties made several failed attempts to modify the judgment and change the mode of enforcement.
- The company was incorporated as a municipal unitary enterprise before being joined to FGUP 9 TSARZ and later becoming OAO 9 TSARZ following a series of government decrees.

title: CASE OF KUMBARACIBAŞI v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1939 and lives in Ankara.
- The applicant brought a case before the Ankara Administrative Court against the Çankaya Municipality and the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality for the annulment of the construction permit pertaining to a neighboring building which was being built opposite his apartment.
- On 14 December 1999, the Ankara Administrative Court revoked the construction permit based on a breach of height restrictions.
- On 17 February 2000, the Çankaya municipal executive committee ordered the demolition of the illegally constructed part of the building but did not implement the said decision.
- On 19 November 2001, the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the administrative court's judgment.
- On 3 August 2001, the Çankaya municipal council amended the zoning plan and sent its decision to the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality for approval.
- On 26 October 2001, the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality withheld its approval.
- On 5 December 2001, the Çankaya municipal council insisted on its previous decision, and the amended zoning plan thus came into force.
- On 31 December 2001, the applicant brought a case before the Ankara Administrative Court for the annulment of the Çankaya municipal council's decision of 5 December 2001.
- On 31 March 2003, the Ankara Administrative Court annulled the said decision.
- On 21 February 2005, the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the administrative court's decision.
- On 18 October 2005, it rejected the Çankaya Municipality's rectification request, which was served on the applicant on 13 December 2005.

title: CASE OF M.M. v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was arrested in 2005 and accused of murder.
2. Allegedly, the police officers coerced him into confessing to the murder.
3. In 2007, the Verkh-Isetskiy District Court of Yekaterinburg convicted and sentenced him to ten years’ imprisonment.
4. The applicant tested positive for HIV in 2005.
5. The applicant alleged that in 2005, Z. (deputy district prosecutor) gave G. (sister of the murder victim) access to the file concerning the criminal charges against the applicant.
6. The applicant sought the institution of criminal proceedings against G. for the disclosure of private information.
7. Refusals to prosecute G. were issued multiple times between 2006 and 2009.
8. The applicant was held in different cells in Yekaterinburg Remand Centre no. 66/1 from January 2005 to July 2007, with living conditions being cramped or unacceptable in most cells.
9. The applicant lodged numerous complaints about the living conditions, but they were not satisfactorily addressed.

title: CASE OF KSENZ AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- In August 2005, the applicant was travelling in a car that was stopped by police officers F. and K. He did not have his ID card and was taken to a police station where he alleged ill-treatment by the officers, including verbal and physical insults, as well as punching and attempts to knock him down.
- Later that night, the applicant was taken to an addiction-treatment clinic for a medical examination, which did not reveal any injuries.
- The applicant was released at about 5 a.m. and examined by a forensic-medical expert that day, who found several injuries but concluded that they were not harmful to the applicant's health.
- The police refused to institute criminal proceedings against the applicant for hooliganism or insult of a public official.
- In August 2007, the applicant was driving a car without a licence plate when he and three other young men were stopped by police officers, who allegedly punched and kicked them. The applicant sustained numerous injuries, including a closed craniocerebral injury and brain contusion, and was exempted from attending school for three weeks due to his temporary disability.
- The police officers later reported that the young men had tried to run away and that the police had used force to overcome their resistance.
- The applicant's mother complained to the prosecutor's office, and a pre-investigation inquiry was carried out. The police brought administrative proceedings against the applicant for driving without a licence and not stopping on a police officer's repeated order.
- Investigators of the Novyy Toryal district prosecutor’s office thrice refused to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers for lack of the elements of a crime in their actions.
- In the most recent decision of 22 June 2007, the investigator found that the police officers had acted lawfully in apprehending the applicant and that the injuries were a result of the lawful use of physical force.

title: CASE OF DIMITRIJEVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1946 and lives in Čačak.
- On 7 September 2005, the applicant filed a lawsuit in the Court of First Instance in Kotor regarding contractual disputes.
- On 4 December 2008, the Court of First Instance in Kotor ruled in favor of the applicant.
- On 17 November 2009, the High Court in Podgorica upheld this judgment on appeal.
- On 20 May 2010, the previous judgments were overturned by the Supreme Court and remanded for a re-trial.
- On 12 August 2011, the Court of First Instance in Kotor ruled against the applicant.
- This judgment was upheld by the High Court and the Supreme Court on 6 April 2012 and 12 September 2012, respectively.
- On 20 October 2012, the Supreme Court's decision was communicated to the applicant.
- The applicant filed a constitutional appeal on 28 November 2012.
- On 30 June 2015, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicant's appeal.
- The applicant was informed of this decision on 25 September 2015.

title: CASE OF JOANNOU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The case concerns complaints arising from the Turkish military intervention in northern Cyprus in July and August 1974.
- The applicant was gifted five plots of land, or shares in them, by her aunt in 1997, and later an additional share of one of the plots of land by her mother in 2008.
- The Department of Lands and Surveys of the Republic of Cyprus confirms the applicant as the sole owner of four plots of land and a 9/16 share of the fifth plot.
- The land is situated in the village Koma Tou Yialou (Kumyali) in the “TRNC”, while the applicant lives in Enfield, United Kingdom.
- The applicant obtained valuation reports for her properties from Turkish Cypriot chartered surveyor in 2007, from a Republic of Cyprus chartered surveyor in 2011, and from the Land Registration Office of the Republic of Cyprus in 2017.
- On May 2008, the applicant filed a claim with the IPC under Law no. 67/2005, claiming restitution of her property and/or compensation at the property’s current market value and damages for loss of use of the property. The total compensation sought was GBP 100,000 per dönüm (GBP 1,800,000 or approximately EUR 2,285,000).
- The Attorney General’s Office submitted an opinion to the IPC in 2010, arguing that the applicant had failed to demonstrate that she was the legal heir of the two registered owners of the property, and further considered that the applicant’s compensation claim was excessive and unfounded.
- The IPC held a series of preliminary hearings between May 2010 and March 2017. The applicant requested a formal hearing to be opened to respond to arguments raised by the “TRNC” representatives, and the proceedings are still pending.

title: CASE OF M.S.A. AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Syrian nationals who were detained at detention centres for foreign nationals run by the FMS in various towns in Russia
- The applicants breached immigration regulations by staying in Russia after their visas expired
- Domestic courts found some applicants guilty and others had expulsion orders quashed upon appeal
- All applicants sought refugee status and/or temporary asylum in Russia, only one was granted temporary asylum
- Six of the applicants left Russia on their own volition to settle in third countries
- M.S.A. and R.K. were detained in severely overcrowded cells measuring around 9 square metres and designed to hold six people, but occupied by more during their entire detention
- Food was of poor quality, with no alternatives offered for religious reasons or when arbitrary restrictions on food parcels were imposed
- Detainees had limited access to drinking water and were not allowed to switch on lights after 10 p.m. 
- The applicants and other inmates had limited access to sanitary facilities, and some detainees controlled the storey with violent and extortion tactics
- Outdoor exercise was sporadic and lasted around 15-20 minutes, and the facility did not offer any activities or library access
- H.R. was not represented by a lawyer during his administrative hearing concerning his removal from Russia, and one lawyer was not allowed to meet with three applicants in the detention centre.

title: CASE OF VARGA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant details.
- Applicants complain about inadequate conditions in detention.
- Some applicants raise additional complaints according to the Convention.

title: CASE OF POCA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details in an appended table
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
- Some applicants had other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

facts:
- The document contains a list of applicants and their details.
- The applicants complained about the conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants also raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details provided in table
- Applicants complained of inadequate detention conditions
- Some applicants raised other complaints under Convention provisions

title: CASE OF KOTOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with details provided in an attached table.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KOLCHANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document contains a table with a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants also mentioned other complaints under the Convention.

title: CASE OF ORLANDI AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicants met and entered into committed relationships with each other.
- They attempted to register their marriages in Italy, but their requests were rejected.
- Some couples attempted to enter civil unions or symbolic registrations instead.
- Following the entry into force of a new law, some applicants requested to have their marriages transcribed as civil unions, which was eventually granted in some cases.
- The Court of Cassation rejected an appeal by one couple regarding the registration of their marriage.

title: CASE OF KOROTEYEV AND SITARSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details in the appended table.
- Allegation of applicants: inadequate medical care in detention.
- Applicants claimed there was no effective remedy for their medical care.
- Additional complaints raised by applicants under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ANCA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their details provided in the table
- Applicants complained about inadequate conditions of their detention
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention

title: CASE OF BALOGH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant born in 1939, residing in Remeteszőlős
- Legal proceedings for division of matrimonial property and related issues lasted for ten years and eight months
- Legal proceedings took place in the Budapest XX/XXI/XXIII District Court, the Budapest High Court and the Kúria
- Applicant complained about the excessive length of the legal proceedings

title: CASE OF GRYB v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was a judge of the Radomyshl District Court.
- The applicant was convicted of abuse of office for exploiting Mr I. on the renovation of his father’s house.
- The exploitation involved sentencing I. to fifteen days’ imprisonment for false charges of disorderly conduct, and having him taken to the construction site where he was to work under the direction of the site manager.
- In November 2007, a police officer conspired with the applicant in drawing up a report falsely accusing I. of another episode of disorderly conduct, and I. was convicted and sentenced to another fifteen days’ detention. 
- The applicant denied his involvement in the exploitation and stated that I. had worked voluntarily and for remuneration. 
- The trial court relied on statements by I. and other witnesses, expert evidence, and the fact that the applicant had regular telephone contact with the site manager at the relevant time.
- The applicant appealed to the Supreme Court, which ordered that references to Sh.’s statement be struck from the judgment but upheld the remainder of the conviction.

title: CASE OF ARTYUSHKOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their details are provided in the table
- Applicants complained about non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions
- Applicants complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law 
- Applicant in case no. 20435/09 raised other complaints under Article 6 of the Convention

title: CASE OF NOVINSKIY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The case involves a group of applicants.
- A table is provided with details of the applicants and their applications.
- The applicants complained about the conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF DAKUS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Kalush.
- The applicant’s future husband and his parents living in corporate housing owned by the K.T. company were offered the chance to exchange accommodation for larger corporate housing accommodation owned by the same Company.
- In 1998, the applicant’s and V.D.’s son was born. Along with the applicant, he was registered by the local authority as a co-tenant of flat A on the grounds that both of them had become members of the original tenants’ family.
- In 1999 the K.T. company transferred ownership of flat A to the municipality.
- At various subsequent dates, the applicant’s husband and parents-in-law moved out into flat B while, according to the applicant, she and her son remained residents in flat A.
- On 20 July 2005, the K.T. company decided to reallocate flat A to the family of R., its employee, who lived in an accommodation hall.
- In October 2005, the K.T. company lodged a claim in the Kalush Town Court, seeking, in particular, to evict the applicant and her son from flat A.
- On 25 July 2006, the court dismissed the claim for the eviction of the applicant and her son.
- On 14 September 2006, the Ivano-Frankivsk Regional Court of Appeal ordered the applicant’s and her son’s eviction “without provision of any other accommodation”.
- On 16 November 2006, the Supreme Court of Ukraine rejected the applicant’s request for leave to appeal in cassation.
- On 21 December 2006, the State bailiffs had the applicant vacate flat A.
- After her eviction, the applicant sought emergency refuge in the home of a colleague and subsequently rented odd accommodations at various places according to her submission.

title: CASE OF URZHANOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- There is a table that contains relevant details of the application.
- The document is focused on providing facts about a case.

title: CASE OF KRASNYAKOVY AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
• A table appended listing the applicants and their relevant application details.
• Complaints raised by the applicants regarding the excessive length of civil proceedings.
• Applicants also complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
• Some applicants had other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF LOPES DE SOUSA FERNANDES v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant's husband underwent minor surgery for removal of nasal polyps and died following a series of medical problems.
- He was admitted to the ENT department of Vila Nova de Gaia Hospital for a nasal polypectomy.
- He was prescribed tranquilisers and discharged the next day, but taken to the emergency department the following day due to headaches and later found to have bacterial meningitis.
- He was then diagnosed with duodenal ulcers, discharged but readmitted for the ulcer again in December and then in January with infectious ulcerative colitis.
- During his treatment, he suffered from severe abdominal pain and diarrhea and died from septicaemia caused by peritonitis and a perforated viscus.
- The case was referred to the Ministry of Health, the regional health authority, and the Medical Association by the applicant after she received no response from hospitals.
- An expert medical report found that the treatment administered was appropriate and there was no medical negligence found.
- The applicant appealed, stating unclear points and the possibility that bacteria present in the operating theatre may have caused her husband's death and requested a fresh expert medical report.
- Disciplinary proceedings were initiated against one of the doctors involved in the care of the applicant's husband due to his negligence in providing adequate medical assistance.

title: CASE OF MILOVANOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Čurug.
- On 2 August 2002, the applicant and a colleague filed a civil suit against their employer for payment of salary arrears and other employment-related benefits.
- After two remittals, on 8 February 2013, the First Instance Court ordered payment of specific sums for salary arrears but rejected the remainder of their claims.
- The Court of Appeal upheld parts of the judgment and reversed others, served on the plaintiffs on 6 June 2013.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the plaintiffs’ appeal on points of law on 29 January 2014.
- On 9 April 2013, the plaintiffs filed a constitutional appeal, alleging a violation of their right to a hearing within a reasonable time.
- By its decision of 9 December 2015, the Constitutional Court found a violation of their right to a hearing within a reasonable time and awarded each of them EUR 800 in respect of the non-pecuniary damage suffered.

title: CASE OF KRSMANOVIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The Serbian Prime Minister was assassinated by a criminal group called the Zemun Clan.
- The assassination led to the declaration of a state of emergency and a large-scale police operation called Operation Sabre.
- Approximately 10,000 people were arrested during Operation Sabre and placed in pre-trial detention.
- The applicant was a member of a criminal group linked to the Zemun Clan and was arrested during Operation Sabre.
- The applicant was allegedly subjected to physical and verbal abuse by members of the Special Anti-Terrorist Unit during his arrest and subsequent detention.
- The applicant was questioned about his involvement in various crimes, including the Prime Minister's assassination, murders, abductions, and drug trafficking.
- The applicant was examined by a prison doctor who documented extensive injuries.
- The applicant was charged with illegal production and trafficking of drugs, abduction, and unlawful deprivation of liberty.
- The applicant's mother filed a complaint alleging that her son had been tortured by members of the police during his arrest and detention.
- The complaint was initially rejected by the Inspector General's Service for lack of evidence.
- The applicant took over the criminal proceedings as a subsidiary prosecutor and appealed the decision not to open an investigation.
- The investigating judge and pre-trial chamber found there was not enough evidence to prove that the accused police officers had committed the crime they were suspected of.
- The applicant appealed the decision, but his appeal was rejected.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, which was also rejected.

title: CASE OF PEŇARANDA SOTO v. MALTA
facts:
1. The applicant is serving an eight-year sentence in a Maltese prison for drug-related offenses.
2. He was attacked by another inmate on July 12, 2013, resulting in leg and facial bone fractures.
3. The applicant was placed in solitary confinement after the incident and allegedly did not receive immediate medical treatment for his injuries.
4. The applicant endured poor living conditions in the isolation unit, including inadequate ventilation, unbearable heat, and limited access to water.
5. The applicant suffered from asthma and reported breathing difficulties.
6. The applicant was held in isolation for 22 days and became suicidal.
7. The applicant was transferred to a different unit for his safety but alleged that he was still at risk.
8. The applicant claimed he did not receive proper medical treatment for his injuries, and the government refuted this claim.
9. The applicant experienced poor living conditions in his cell, including difficult-to-open windows, small size, and poor ventilation.
10. The applicant alleged that he was treated differently from Maltese inmates due to his nationality.
11. The government claimed that inmates were responsible for maintaining their cells and that they had access to potable tap water and bottled water for purchase.
12. The applicant alleged that the prison authorities were interfering with his correspondence with the Court.

title: CASE OF MANDIĆ AND POPOVIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicants in the case are Orijana Mandić, Drago Popović, and Predrag Popović.
- They were born in 1975, 1942, and 1962 respectively.
- They reside in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
- Two judgments were made by the Banja Luka Court of First Instance on 17 October 2008 and 29 May 2009, which ordered Republika Srpska to pay damages and legal costs to the applicants.
- The judgments became final on 12 February 2009 and 30 October 2009.
- Writs of execution were issued on 9 June 2009 and 31 March 2010 by the Banja Luka Court of First Instance.
- The judgment in favor of Orijana Mandić was fully enforced in cash on 30 July 2014.
- The judgment in favor of Drago and Predrag Popović was fully enforced in cash on 14 December 2015 and 16 December 2015.

title: CASE OF KHAYRULLINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's husband was identified as a possible eyewitness in a murder investigation of a person (G.) on 7 September 2002
- The applicant's husband was taken to the Tukayevskiy police station for identity verification on 13 September 2002 and was released at 1.30 p.m.
- Later, he was interviewed twice by field officers and gave a written statement affirming that the suspect (V.) had punched the victim during a quarrel
- V. was taken to the police station on the same day (13 September 2002) and confessed to the murder
- The applicant alleged that V. was beaten up and ill-treated while in custody and that the applicant's husband was found unconscious and admitted to the hospital on the same day after attempting suicide on a balcony located on the fifth floor of the police station
- A pre-investigation inquiry was opened and the district prosecutor issued a decision not to initiate criminal proceedings against any officers for the attempted suicide, which was later annulled by the higher prosecutor
- The victim (applicant's husband) died on 13 December 2002 and a forensic medical examination found that he died of asphyxia resulting from strangulation
- The criminal investigation was opened against unspecified officers, but it was discontinued several times due to the absence of a criminal event or other reasons
- The discontinuation decisions were quashed and the investigation was resumed several times, and the circumstances leading to the victim's attempted suicide and death were not fully clarified.

title: CASE OF SASHCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lives in Nizhniy Novgorod.
- On 25 October 2002, the Military Court ordered the head of the military institute to re-calculate the period of the applicant’s service and awarded additional allowances and payments for certain periods.
- The judgment came into force on 5 November 2002.
- The enforcement proceedings were terminated on 19 September 2003 and the writ of execution was returned to the applicant as the debt could not be recovered.
- On 13 November 2003, the head of the respondent military institute issued Order No. 463 requiring payments for the judgment, but no payments or calculations were made at that time.
- On 4 February 2005, the applicant submitted the writ of execution to the Federal Treasury.
- On 18 May 2005, the writ was returned to the applicant on the ground that it should be submitted to the bailiffs’ service.
- On an unspecified date in 2005, the applicant submitted the writ of execution to the bailiffs’ service.
- On 14 April 2006, the writ of execution was returned to the applicant without enforcement, and the bailiffs explained the necessary steps to obtain the payments.
- The defendant military institute calculated the total amount due to the applicant as RUB 341,061.95, including compensation for a supplementary ration, allowance for special regime of service, and a special allowance.

title: CASE OF PLESHCHINSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant is a Russian national born in 1954 and lives in Solnechnogorsk, Moscow Region. 
- Applicant was detained in Solnechnogorsk Police’s temporary detention centre at various times in 2003-2004. 
- The cells were overcrowded, with no access to water, proper light, or area for outdoor activities. 
- Applicant had to relieve himself in a bucket in the presence of other detainees. 
- Applicant made numerous journeys between Volokolamsk remand centre and the temporary detention centre in Solnechnogorsk, which took three to four hours in an overcrowded van. 
- On 11 July 2005, applicant sued the State for compensation in respect of non-pecuniary damage caused by the conditions of his detention. 
- The Solnechnogorsk Town Court rejected the applicant’s claims on 14 November 2005, citing insufficient funding. 
- On 22 November and 6 December 2005, the applicant lodged appeals against the decision of 14 November 2005. 
- On 30 January 2006, the Moscow Regional Court upheld the decision of 14 November 2005 in the applicant’s absence. 
- The applicant was not notified of the appeal hearing as the summons contained an error in the address. 
- In December 1992, the applicant and his son obtained ownership of a flat in Solnechnogorsk through privatisation. 
- The son later sued the father for the ownership of the flat. 
- The Solnechnogorsk Town Court granted the plaintiff's claim in a hearing on 4 May 2005, which was upheld by the Moscow Regional Court on appeal on 14 June 2005.

title: CASE OF KUVEYDAR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and is currently serving a prison sentence in Edirne.
- İ.Y. and his son M.Y. claimed that they had been threatened by members of a criminal organisation, including the applicant, who had acted under his boss, O.K., and that they had had to give them a substantial amount of money and property as a result.
- The Public Prosecutor requested the Bursa Security Directorate to investigate the matter within the context of an investigation concerning a bigger criminal organisation.
- The applicant was arrested after the search made by police officers from the Bursa Security Directorate at his house, during which they found an unlicensed semi-automatic weapon.
- The applicant was taken to the Bursa Directorate of Forensic Medicine, where he was examined by a doctor who noted that there were no signs of ill-treatment on his body.
- The applicant underwent medical examination several times, but there were no signs of ill-treatment on his body.
- The applicant described the course of the events in detail and admitted to threatening İ.Y. and taking money from him.
- The Public Prosecutor filed an indictment accusing the applicant of armed robbery, membership of a criminal organisation, and illegally carrying weapons.
- İ.Y. testified against the applicant at the first hearing, stating that the applicant had threatened him to obtain more money.
- At the second hearing, the applicant retracted his previous statements and argued that he had been subjected to ill-treatment while in police custody, but without giving any details about his allegation.
- The court found the applicant guilty as charged, based on an overall assessment of the evidence at its disposal, without specifying which particular evidence it relied on.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment after holding a hearing, during which the applicant was not present.
- The applicant was not represented by a lawyer at any stage of the proceedings.

title: CASE OF MESKHIDZE v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and was serving a prison sentence at the time in question.
- The applicant was sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment for murder.
- The applicant was diagnosed with viral hepatitis C, chronic cholecystitis, and radiculitis.
- The applicant was transferred to the prison hospital after his ingrowing toenail operation was infected and he had artery-related issues.
- The applicant underwent a Tc PO2 test, and the microcirculation in his lower limbs was found to be very low.
- The applicant made an application for his sentence to be suspended on health grounds.
- The Tbilisi City Court initially dismissed the applicant’s request, but it was later granted.
- The applicant’s gangrene had progressed to the final stage, and his condition was worsening daily.
- The applicant’s doctor said that he could not be cured at the prison hospital but required constant medical treatment.

title: CASE OF SHESTOPALOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lived in Melitopol.
- The applicant was head of Melitopol City Council’s Disadvantaged Persons’ Welfare Centre from 2004 to 2006.
- The applicant was dismissed as part of a reorganization of the Centre.
- The applicant instigated civil proceedings to seek reinstatement, salary arrears, and compensation in May 2006.
- The first-instance court and the Zaporizhzhya Regional Court of Appeal rejected the applicant's claim.
- The Supreme Court of Ukraine quashed the previous decisions and remitted the case to the first-instance court for a fresh hearing.
- The applicant instituted administrative proceedings before the Melitopolskyy Court in accordance with the Supreme Court's decision.
- The Melitopolskyy Court rejected the applicant's claim again.
- The Dnipropetrovsk Administrative Court of Appeal quashed the decision of the Melitopolskyy Court and decided that the case fell under the civil justice procedure rather than administrative proceedings.
- The Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine upheld this decision.
- The applicant lodged another civil claim seeking reinstatement, salary arrears, and compensation in March 2011.
- The Melitopolskyy Court refused to examine the merits of the applicant’s civil claim as the applicant had sought to have adjourned previous court hearings in respect of her case on numerous occasions without good reason.
- The Zaporizhzhya Regional Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF FELDMAN AND SLOVYANSKYY BANK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1958 and was vice-president, founder, and majority shareholder of the applicant bank.
- The applicant bank was a commercial joint-stock bank based in Ukraine with its registered office in Zaporizhzhya.
- In February and March 2000, criminal proceedings were instituted against the management of the applicant bank for tax evasion and abuse of office.
- In June 2000, the National Bank of Ukraine suspended the applicant bank's licence due to its deteriorating financial position and risky operations.
- On 11 January 2001, the NBU issued a resolution "On the Liquidation of Slovyanskyy Commercial Joint-Stock Bank," which revoked the applicant bank's operating licence and was ordered to be liquidated.
- The first applicant challenged the NBU's decision in court, but it was dismissed.
- The liquidation process of the applicant bank was completed on 30 November 2012.

title: CASE OF KADUSIC v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is currently detained in Bostadel Prison, in Menzingen.
- In 2005, the Criminal Court found the applicant guilty of several crimes and sentenced him to eight years in prison.
- The applicant appealed the judgment but the appeal was dismissed by both the Court of Appeal and the Federal Court.
- The applicant requested a relaxation of the conditions of his sentence, which was denied by the intercantonal commission.
- A psychiatrist diagnosed the applicant with moderate paranoid and narcissistic personality disorders, with full criminal responsibility.
- The intercantonal commission found that the applicant represented a danger to the public and recommended either an expert psychiatric assessment or indefinite detention if necessary.
- The Court of Appeal ordered the applicant's subsequent indefinite detention under Article 65 § 2 of the Criminal Code, which was partly upheld by the Federal Court.
- The Federal Court also suggested the consideration of an institutional therapeutic measure.
- The Court of Appeal eventually ordered an institutional therapeutic measure, suspending the execution of the part of the sentence remaining to be served.
- The applicant claims he is not receiving any treatment, while the Government asserts that he has refused to undergo any psychiatric treatment.

title: CASE OF LÓPEZ RIBALDA AND OTHERS v. SPAIN
facts:
- Applicants were working as cashiers for M.S.A., a Spanish supermarket chain.
- Employer noticed irregularities between stock levels and what was sold.
- Surveillance cameras installed to investigate employee theft.
- Applicants were caught on video admitting to involvement in theft.
- Applicants were dismissed on disciplinary grounds based on video recordings and witness statements.
- Applicants brought proceedings for unfair dismissal, objecting to the use of covert video surveillance.
- Employment Tribunal ruled against the applicants based on evidence from covert video surveillance.
- Applicants appealed to the High Court of Justice of Catalonia, which upheld the rulings of the Employment Tribunal.
- Cassation appeals were declared inadmissible, and amparo appeals were declared inadmissible due to the "non-existence of a violation of a fundamental right."
- Applicants signed settlement agreements committing not to bring proceedings against their employer for unfair dismissal.
- Applicants brought proceedings despite the settlement agreements, alleging invalid consent due to duress.
- Employment Tribunal declared the settlement agreements valid and dismissed the applicants' case.
- High Court of Justice of Catalonia upheld the ruling of the Employment Tribunal and analyzed the legality of covert video surveillance, finding it authorized.
- Cassation appeal was declared inadmissible, and amparo appeal was declared inadmissible due to the "non-existence of a violation of a fundamental right."

title: CASE OF ADIYAMAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and was serving a prison sentence at Bolu F-type prison.
- The applicant wrote a letter to the Ministry of Justice on 25 January 2008, praising the imprisoned PKK leader, Abdullah Öcalan.
- The Bolu F-type prison Disciplinary Board found the applicant guilty of breaching prison order, based on regulations on the administration of penitentiary institutions and execution of sentences.
- On 1 February 2008, the Board sentenced the applicant to 11 days of solitary confinement for his statements in the letter.
- On 26 February 2008, the Bolu Enforcement Judge rejected the applicant’s objection.
- On 11 March 2008, the Bolu Assize Court upheld the judgment of 26 February 2008.

title: CASE OF TUMELIAI v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants purchased a plot of forest land in 2003.
- They obtained a building permit in 2005 to construct a summer house on the plot, which was registered as 97% finished in 2007.
- In 2011, the prosecutor's office initiated court proceedings to revoke the building permit and ask the applicants to demolish the building.
- In 2012, the Molėtai District Court dismissed the prosecutor's complaint, but the Panevėžys Regional Court allowed the appeal and ordered the applicants to demolish the building.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Regional Court's decision in 2013, finding that the construction had been illegal and had to be demolished.
- The applicants requested suspension of the execution of the judgment pending a decision by the European Court of Human Rights, which was granted by the Utena District Court in 2015.
- The Panevėžys Regional Court upheld the decision again in 2016.

title: CASE OF GRA STIFTUNG GEGEN RASSISMUS UND ANTISEMITISMUS v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
- The applicant is an NGO that promotes tolerance and condemns racially motivated discrimination, registered in Switzerland.
- In November 2009, the youth wing of the Swiss People's Party held a demonstration in the town of Frauenfeld supporting a ban on minarets in Switzerland.
- The party's president spoke about stopping the expansion of Islam and preserving Switzerland's guiding culture based on Christianity, which led the applicant to publish an article under the section "Chronology - Verbal racism".
- The constitutional amendment banning the construction of new minarets was introduced following a referendum in November 2009.
- The president of the party's local branch filed a case for the protection of his personality rights, seeking to have the impugned Internet article removed and replaced with the court's judgement.
- The first-instance court dismissed the president's case, citing the publication's focus on a matter of public interest.
- The high court reversed the judgment, stating that the classification of the speech as "verbally racist" was a mixed value judgment that could only be justified if it was based on actual fact.
- The Federal Supreme Court also dismissed the applicant's appeal, finding that the classification of a person's statements as "verbal racism" violated that person's honor and that the impugned Internet article could not be justified by an overriding public interest.

title: CASE OF BOGOSYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a police captain born in 1981 and residing in Sochi.
- He was arrested for soliciting a bribe on 27 November 2010 and taken into custody.
- His detention was extended on multiple occasions until the case was submitted for trial on 4 July 2011 in the Tsentralnyy District Court of Sochi.
- On 8 July 2011, the District Court postponed the trial and extended the applicant's detention until 10 August 2011.
- The director of the applicant's remand prison reported on 9 August 2011 that he would need to release the applicant in the absence of an order extending his detention. The prosecutor replied that no grounds for release existed because the prosecutor's appeal was scheduled for 17 August 2011.
- The applicant was not released on 10 August and complained about his unlawful detention to the head of the Investigations Committee and the regional head of the Ministry of the Interior but did not receive any response.
- On 17 August 2011, the Krasnodar Regional Court quashed the District Court's order on the appeal, stating that no custody extension was necessary.

title: CASE OF NICHOLAS v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lives in Larnaca.
- The applicant was dismissed from Cyprus Airways Ltd as a trainee pilot.
- The applicant brought a civil action for wrongful dismissal and defamation against the defendant company. The company was represented by a law firm.
- The District Court of Nicosia dismissed the civil action.
- The applicant lodged an appeal with the Supreme Court.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal unanimously.
- The son of one of the judges sitting on the bench and the daughter of Mr P.G.P. were married and both worked at the law firm representing the defendant company. The applicant discovered this after the appeal proceedings had ended.

title: CASE OF REVTYUK v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and lives in Toksovo.
- The applicant was arrested on 2 October 2009 on suspicion of raping K., who was employed at the Vasileostrovskiy District Court in St Petersburg.
- On 4 October 2009, the Vasileostrovskiy District Court remanded the applicant in custody after rejecting a challenge for bias raised by the applicant’s lawyer in respect of the entire composition of the District Court.
- On 26 October 2009, the St Petersburg City Court upheld the detention order on appeal, rejecting a challenge by the applicant as unsubstantiated.
- Several extension orders were granted by different courts, with one such decision found to be invalid by the Supreme Court of Russia.
- On 11 March 2010, the case against the applicant was referred to the Vasileostrovskiy District Court for trial and allocated to its President, Judge Sh. On 23 March 2010, Judge Sh. allowed the applicant’s challenge for bias in respect of the entire composition of that court.
- Continuing the same decision, Judge Sh. extended the applicant’s detention until 12 May 2010, and the Presidium of the City Court extended the detention until 12 August 2010.
- On 31 March 2011, the Petrogradskiy District Court found the applicant guilty of rape and sentenced him to five years and six months’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF MAKHLYAGIN AND BELYAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr. Makhlyagin and Mr. Belyayev were held in different detention facilities.
- Officials of the facilities inspected and/or opened letters that the applicants exchanged with the Court.
- Mr. Makhlyagin, while detained in a correctional colony, lodged several letters with the Court, which were accompanied by cover letters and registration stamps from the colony.
- The applicant lodged a claim, alleging that the colony's staff impeded his correspondence with the Court.
- The Tagilstroyevskiy District Court of Nizhniy Tagil dismissed his claim.
- The applicant lodged an appeal with the Sverdlovskiy Regional Court, which rejected his appeal, stating that it should be lodged through the first-instance court.
- The applicant lodged his appeal with the first-instance court, but it was refused to be examined as belated.
- The applicant appealed against this decision, but he once again lodged his appeal with the Regional Court instead of the first-instance court, without including a request for a missed time-limit to be re-set.
- The Sverdlovskiy Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
- Mr. Makhlyagin received a letter from the Court, which was opened by a member of the remand prison staff.
- The applicant lodged a claim for compensation, which was dismissed by the Tver Regional Court, stating that Russian law did not prohibit opening incoming correspondence from the Court.

title: CASE OF GHINCEA v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lived in Voluntari.
- In 2002, the applicant was the legal secretary of Voluntari City Hall in charge of registering applications for restitution of land based on Law no. 18/1991.
- An unspecified date in 2003, the prosecutor attached to Buftea District Court initiated a criminal investigation in respect of the applicant and two other individuals, M.C.I. and N.G.
- The injured party, M.M., maintained that, in December 2002, N.G. had, at the request of the applicant, antedated the registration of six applications for title submitted by M.C.I.
- The applicant denied having asked N.G. to falsify the date of registration of the applications.
- An expert report confirmed that N.G. had antedated the registration of the six applications. 
- The prosecutor charged N.G. with committing intellectual forgery and the applicant with acting as N.G.’s accomplice. 
- N.G. initially stated that the applicant had asked her to antedate the registration of the applications, but later changed her statement to say that the applicant had only called her and asked for her help.
- The district court changed the legal classification of the offence with which the applicant had been charged to inciting intellectual forgery.
- N.G. was convicted of intellectual forgery, whereas the applicant was acquitted. 
- An appeal against the decision was lodged by the prosecutor’s office but was dismissed as unfounded by the Bucharest County Court.
- The prosecutor lodged an appeal on points of law which was allowed by the Bucharest Court of Appeal. 
- The Bucharest Court of Appeal convicted the applicant of inciting intellectual forgery and imposed a suspended sentence of six months’ imprisonment, placing him on probation. 
- The appellate court based its reasoning on the evidence in the file, without questioning the applicant or other witnesses. 
- The final written decision containing the court’s reasoning became available on 20 March 2006.

title: CASE OF VASILE VICTOR STANCIU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant stored personal items in the common space of their apartment building.
- The police arrived at the applicant's door and asked for his identification papers without giving their names or informing him of the purpose of their visit.
- The applicant refused to present his papers, and the police officers immobilized him, threw him to the ground, and then handcuffed him.
- The police officers beat the applicant at the police station, causing him to suffer injuries.
- The applicant was fined 100 Romanian lei (RON) for "refusal to present data necessary for his identification."
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint against the two police officers, accusing them of unlawful deprivation of liberty, unlawful investigation, and torture, and sought compensation.
- The prosecutor's office decided not to prosecute, and the head of the prosecutor's office upheld the decision.
- The applicant contested the decision, and the county court dismissed the complaint and upheld the prosecutors' decisions.

title: CASE OF MAKARSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1989
- Arrested on drug-related charges and placed in custody on 27 December 2010
- Case submitted for trial to Voronezh Regional Court on 14 December 2012
- Court returned the case to the deputy Prosecutor General for remedying certain procedural defects on 11 July 2013
- Investigations Department of the Federal Drug Control Service received the case file and forwarded it to its regional branch in St Petersburg on 20 September 2013
- Investigator asked St Petersburg City Court to extend applicant's detention for a further four months on 1 November 2013
- St Petersburg City Court granted the application on 8 November 2013
- Applicant filed an appeal pointing out the maximum statutory time period for keeping him in pre-trial detention had expired and any further extensions were unlawful.
- St Petersburg City Court rejected his appeal summarily on 27 November 2013

title: CASE OF DRAHOŠ AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicants own residential buildings or apartments that were subject to a rent-control scheme. 
- They were obliged to let their flats to tenants while charging no more than the maximum amount of rent fixed by the state. 
- They were precluded from unilaterally terminating the leases or selling the flats in question to anyone other than the respective tenants. 
- The particulars of the flats affected by the rent control are set out in Appendices 10-17. 
- The situation of the applicants is structurally and contextually the same as that of the applicants in Bittó and Others v. Slovakia. 
- Two residential buildings were acquired by a religious organization - Cirkevný zbor Evanjelickej cirkvi Augsburského vyznania na Slovensku Bratislava. 
- The property was conveyed to the Old Town Evangelical Church by way of donation. 
- The Old Town Evangelical Church gave notices of termination of their lease to the two tenants residing in flat no. 11. 
- The Old Town Evangelical Church applied to the Bratislava I District Court for an eviction order against the occupants of this flat. 
- The tenants residing in flats nos. 1 and 9 on 22 Moyzesova St. in Žilina moved in 2002 into flats nos. 5 and 12 within the same building owing to rebuilding of the original flats. 
- Flat no. 5 was rebuilt and its area was changed from 110.27 sq. m to 59.18 sq. m. 
- A similar situation arose in the residential building on 33 Pražská St. in Bratislava where in 2014 the tenant residing in flat no. 16 moved to flat no. 9, and in the residential building located on 15 Vrbovská cesta St. in Piešťany, where the tenant living in the flat no. 14 moved to flat no. 25.

title: CASE OF HRUSTIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicants' personal details and case facts are in the Annex
- Applicants complained about excessive length of civil and administrative proceedings (Article 6 § 1)
- First and fourth applicants had their constitutional appeals rejected
- Second and third applicants had a violation of right to a trial within reasonable time, but received no damages.

title: CASE OF İNCİN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are closely related to Kerim İncin, who was allegedly killed after being taken into custody by soldiers.
- The applicants submitted a petition to the prosecutor in 2005, requesting an investigation and official complaint about the killing of Kerim İncin, and provided the names of eyewitnesses.
- The prosecutor conducted an investigation and questioned numerous witnesses, some of whom confirmed that Kerim İncin was taken by soldiers and later killed.
- The prosecutor found that Kerim İncin had indeed been killed and buried in a village cemetery.
- The prosecutor repeatedly requested security updates from the military in order to exhuming the body, and was finally able to do so in 2009.
- DNA analysis confirmed that the exhumed body was Kerim İncin's, and forensic examinations showed that he had suffered from numerous firearms injuries.
- The prosecutor decided not to prosecute ten suspects for lack of evidence, but charged Y.K., the commander of the military station where Kerim İncin was allegedly taken, with murder.
- Y.K. was acquitted for lack of evidence by the Hakkari Assize Court in 2014.
- The applicants appealed the acquittal, and the proceedings before the Court of Cassation are still pending.
- The criminal proceedings against Y.K. are not expected to become time-barred until 2025.

title: CASE OF X v. SWEDEN
facts:
- The applicant is currently in Sweden.
- The applicant was granted temporary and permanent residence permits in Sweden based on family ties, but he was not granted Swedish citizenship.
- In 2009, the applicant married a non-Swedish national who held a permanent residence permit in Sweden.
- The Swedish Security Service requested the applicant's expulsion in March 2016.
- The applicant applied for asylum, claiming that he needed international protection, and contested the Security Service's request, alleging that he would risk torture and imprisonment in Morocco and would be forced to confess to an act of terrorism he did not commit.
- The Migration Agency granted the Security Service's request to expel the applicant and rejected his demand for asylum and international protection.
- The applicant appealed to the Government, which upheld the decision and ordered his expulsion to either Morocco or another specified country.
- The appellate court and the Government found that there was nothing to support that the applicant, at that point in time, was known by the Moroccan authorities and of interest to them.
- The Government stayed the enforcement of the expulsion order until further notice.

title: CASE OF STĂNCULEANU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lives in Voluntari.
- A criminal investigation was initiated against several persons for money laundering and fiscal fraud, and on 3 December 2014, the investigation was extended in respect of thirty-two other persons, including the applicant.
- Several police officers carried out a search of the applicant's home on 4 December 2014, and the search ended at 2 p.m.
- The applicant was taken by police officers to the Bucharest police headquarters immediately after the search and was questioned about her involvement in fiscal fraud. She was informed that she was a suspect in the ongoing criminal investigation.
- The applicant was denied the opportunity to consult her lawyer and to familiarize herself with the contents of the criminal case file in which she was a suspect.
- During her stay in the police station, the applicant's phone conversations were tapped, and she was not allowed to communicate with her lawyer or family.
- At 7:32 p.m., the applicant was taken by ambulance to the hospital, accompanied by police officers. She remained in the hospital until 00:10 a.m. the next day.
- At 00:22 a.m. the applicant's questioning began in the presence of her chosen lawyer. The applicant still refused to give a statement.
- The prosecutor decided to remand the applicant in custody for twenty-four hours, which was later extended for thirty days by the Bucharest County Court.
- The applicant complained about the conditions of her detention, including the small and unhygienic cell that she shared with three other detainees.
- The proceedings on the merits are still pending.

title: CASE OF FIDANYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lived in Yerevan
- The applicant was employed by the State Revenue Service, division no. 2
- On 23 February 2009 the head of the Service decided to terminate the applicant’s employment
- On 2 April 2009 the applicant initiated proceedings in the Administrative Court against the Service seeking to 1) have the decision of 23 February 2009 annulled; 2) be reinstated in her previous position; and 3) recover her average salary starting from the moment of her dismissal until her reinstatement to the previous position
- On 17 September 2009, the Administrative Court granted the applicant’s three claims
- This judgment was upheld in the final instance by the Court of Cassation and became final on 4 November 2009
- On 29 November 2009, the Service paid the applicant 1,197,748 Armenian drams as compensation for her unemployment during the period from 23 February to 29 November 2009
- On 11 December 2009, the Administrative Court issued a writ of execution
- On 25 February 2010, the Department for the Enforcement of Judicial Acts initiated enforcement proceedings, which stopped on 18 July 2011
- On 18 July 2011, the bailiff decided to discontinue the enforcement proceedings
- On 29 May 2012, the applicant asked the DEJA to resume enforcement proceedings
- On 1 June 2012, the bailiff granted the applicant’s request and decided to resume the enforcement proceedings
- On 2 July 2012, the bailiff decided once again to terminate the enforcement proceedings

title: CASE OF COLLOREDO MANSFELDOVÁ v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
- The applicant had a restitution claim for movable property located in Opočno Castle
- The property was confiscated from a predecessor of the applicant during the German occupation of Czechoslovakia in 1942
- The property was again confiscated in 1945 by the Czechoslovak State under the Beneš decrees
- The expropriation was quashed on appeal in 1947 after it was established that the applicant's predecessor was of Czechoslovak nationality and loyal to the state
- What happened to the property afterwards is disputed
- Domestic courts consecutively issued three judgments, upholding the first part of the claim but rejecting the second and third
- The courts based their decisions on the 1947 decision without informing the parties or allowing them to comment
- The situation of the applicant is similar to that in Colloredo Mannsfeld v. the Czech Republic.

title: CASE OF PAPOYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant owned a small kiosk on a piece of land in Yerevan that was expropriated by the Government.
- The applicant was granted the right to lease a different plot of land to construct and run her kiosk on by the Mayor of Yerevan.
- The applicant initiated proceedings in Administrative Court against the Mayor and Kentron district to implement the lease agreement, which was granted by the court and became final.
- Despite multiple inquiries and enforcement proceedings, the agreement was not enforced.
- The DEJA discontinued enforcement proceedings on the grounds that it had become impossible, and the applicant initiated multiple proceedings against the DEJA seeking to enforce the lease agreement.
- The Administrative Court granted some of the applicant's claims, while others were terminated due to lack of jurisdiction or insufficient grounds.
- The proceedings regarding some of the claims are still pending.
