- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Some applicants also raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ARZUMANYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former Minister of Foreign Affairs and headed a political movement called “Civil Disobedience.”
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant in May 2007 for money laundering.
- The applicant was arrested on May 7, 2007.
- The Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court ordered the applicant’s detention for two months on May 10, 2007, based on the nature and dangerousness of the offense and the risk of the applicant absconding and obstructing the investigation.
- The Criminal Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the District Court to continue detaining the applicant. Detention time was extended several times.
- On September 6, 2007, the investigator decided to replace the applicant’s detention with a written undertaking not to leave his residence and to release him.
- The Criminal Court of Appeal decided to leave the applicant’s appeal of September 3, 2007, unexamined since he was released on September 6, 2007.

title: CASE OF SAGATINOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants is presented in a table

- Applicants raised concerns about non-enforcement of domestic decisions 
- Lack of effective remedy in domestic law is also mentioned by the applicants

title: CASE OF KIRIL IVANOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1942 and lives in Blagoevgrad.
- The banning of the two rallies at issue in the present case has previously been explained in detail in several related cases.
- The applicant is related to Mr Yordan Kostadinov Ivanov, who was involved in other related cases regarding an unregistered association called the United Macedonian Organisation Ilinden.
- The applicant notified the mayor of Blagoevgrad of his intention to stage a rally on Macedonia Square on 30 September 2006 to commemorate the anniversary of "the day of the genocide of Macedonians in Bulgaria".
- The mayor refused permission for the rally due to a parallel event already planned for that date and location, and the applicant sought judicial review of this decision.
- The Blagoevgrad District Court found that the mayor's decision was lawful because holding the rally alongside the municipality's event was inappropriate and could risk infringing the rights and freedoms of others.
- A similar rally organized by the United Macedonian Organisation Ilinden on 12 September 2007 was also banned by the mayor, and members were arrested when they attempted to participate.
- The members of Ilinden appealed their punishment for taking part in the banned rally, resulting in annulled fines and clarification that every person, regardless of their political convictions, has the right to honour the memory of national heroes in peace.
- The applicant acted on behalf of Ilinden in its dealings with the authorities regarding the 12 September 2007 rally.

facts:

title: CASE OF YORDAN IVANOV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants are members of Ilinden, a Bulgarian organization seeking registration as an association.
- Ilinden's aims, as defined in its articles of association, were contrary to the State's security and sought to stir up national hatred.
- The Blagoevgrad Regional Court refused to register Ilinden, noting several deficiencies in the registration papers and the unlawfulness of its aims.
- The applicants appealed, but the Sofia Court of Appeal upheld the refusal to register Ilinden, stating that its aims were political and contrary to the unity of the nation.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation refused to accept the appeal on points of law, citing provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure.
- The applicants lodged a procedural appeal against that decision, contesting the court's interpretation of the new Code.
- Another three-member panel of the Supreme Court of Cassation upheld the first panel's decision, confirming the earlier interpretation of the Code.

title: CASE OF LIŢĂ AND S.C. GEORGIANA IMPORT EXPORT S.R.L. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Applicants filed an application
- Relevant details of the application are listed in a table
- Applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings

title: CASE OF THE UNITED MACEDONIAN ORGANISATION ILINDEN AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA (No. 3)
facts:
- The background to the refusal to register Ilinden has been detailed in several previous cases.
- Ilinden's board of management applied to the Blagoevgrad Regional Court for registration as an association.
- The court refused the application citing the organisation's aims and statements as reasons for creating national and ethnic hatred.
- Ilinden's founders appealed, stating that the court had misconstrued the association's aims and activities.
- The Sofia Court of Appeal upheld the refusal to register Ilinden.
- The dissenting judge believed that the registration regime should not hinder the exercise of the fundamental right to associate with others and that the refusal was disproportionate and unjustified.
- Ilinden's founders sought to appeal, but their appeal was dismissed by the Supreme Court of Cassation.

facts:
- The document contains a table with a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants had complaints about the length of their pre-trial detention.

title: CASE OF SHARXHI AND OTHERS v. ALBANIA
facts:
A. Background to the case: 
- The case involves the seizure and expropriation of a building owned by the applicants 

B. Judicial proceedings concerning the interim measure and proceedings for its enforcement:
- An interim measure was ordered by the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) 
- Proceedings were initiated to enforce the interim measure  

C. Complaint to the Ombudsman:
- A complaint was made to the Ombudsman

D. Proceedings concerning the merits of the case related to the seizure of the building:
- Proceedings were initiated concerning the merits of the case 

E. Administrative and judicial proceedings concerning the expropriation and demolition of the applicants’ building: 
1. Administrative proceedings: 
   - Administrative proceedings were initiated concerning the expropriation of the building 
2. Judicial proceedings: 
   - Judicial proceedings were initiated concerning the demolition of the building 

F. Criminal proceedings against State officials:
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against State officials 

G. Other information submitted by the parties:
- Other information was submitted by the parties.

title: CASE OF TASEVA PETROVSKA v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant is a professor of law with a doctoral degree in criminal law.
- She requested recognition as having the same status as a person who passed the BAR exam.
- The Ministry rejected her request, stating she did not meet the criteria, as she did not hold a bachelor's degree in law, which was a condition necessary for the recognition sought.
- The applicant challenged the refusal in the Administrative Court.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's action, stating that she did not meet the criteria.
- The applicant lodged an appeal with the Higher Administrative Court.
- The Ministry submitted observations to the Higher Administrative Court, stating that the recognition sought by the applicant was dependent on her having a bachelor's degree in law, which she did not possess, and this was not communicated to the applicant.
- The Higher Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's appeal, reiterating the reasons provided by the Administrative Court.
- The decision was served on the applicant on 19 May 2014.

title: CASE OF SERGIYENKO AND SACHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
• A table is appended, containing the list of applicants and their relevant details.

• The applicants complained about the long duration of criminal proceedings.

• The applicants complained about the lack of effective remedies in domestic law.

• The applicant in application no. 78377/13 raised an additional complaint under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF STROKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a table with a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complained about inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some of the applicants raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MIKHAYLOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and details of their applications is provided.
- The applicants complained about their pre-trial detention being excessively long.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MÜSLÜM YALÇINKAYA AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are Turkish nationals.
- They sent letters to the Halfeti public prosecutor`s office in July 2008.
- The letters contained a statement that is considered an offense.
- The public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment against the applicants in September 2008.
- The applicants were charged with praising an offense and offender and found guilty in March 2009.
- The court sentenced them to two months and fifteen days’ imprisonment but this was commuted to a fine of 1,500 TRY (in accordance with Article 50 of the Criminal Code).
- The applicants appealed but their request was dismissed by the Court of Cassation on 20 June 2012.

title: CASE OF CUENCA ZARZOSO v. SPAIN
facts:
- The applicant lives in Valencia since 1962 and in San José, a residential district of Valencia since 1962
- Licensed premises were allowed to open in the vicinity of applicant's home since 1974, causing noise problems 
- Valencia City Council resolved not to permit any more licensed premises to open in the area, but the resolution was never implemented
- Noise levels in the San José district were notably higher than the legally accepted norm
- The applicant became the president of the neighborhood association of his district in 1994 and lodged various claims against the City Council to improve the noise-pollution situation 
- The City Council issued the municipal Ordinance on noise and vibrations in 1996 and the area where the applicant lives was designated as an "acoustically saturated zone"
- The applicant replaced his windows with double glazing and installed air conditioning to alleviate the high temperatures caused by having the windows permanently closed in summer
- The applicant brought a preliminary State liability claim before the City Council in 1999, asking for compensation for expenses incurred and compensation for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage 
- The High Court dismissed the complaint and found no evidence that in his particular flat, the level of noise pollution exceeded the established limits
- The applicant lodged an amparo appeal before the Constitutional Court, which was initially dismissed but later declared admissible 
- The plenary of the Constitutional Court dismissed the amparo appeal, arguing that both cases were not identical and the applicant had not proved that in his particular case the noise at his flat was above the permitted level 
- Three judges out of twelve issued a dissenting opinion, holding that there had been a violation of Articles 10 § 2, 18 §§ 1 and 2 of the Constitution, stating that prolonged exposure to high levels of sound that could be classified as avoidable and unbearable deserved the protection of the court.

title: CASE OF NEDESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
1. Mrs and Mr Nedescu sought assisted reproduction at a private clinic.
2. The S. Clinic was not authorized to function as a cell and tissue bank when the applicants underwent assisted reproduction.
3. After giving birth, four of the embryos were frozen and stored at the clinic.
4. The clinic was closed by authorities on 24 July 2009 as part of a criminal investigation, and all stored embryos were seized, then transferred to the IFM.
5. The applicants were initially allowed to retrieve their embryos but were later unable to do so as they had no approval from the Transplant Agency.
6. The Transplant Agency later rejected the applicants' request to transfer their embryos, stating that the IFM did not have prior permit to act as a tissue and cell bank.
7. The High Court of Cassation and Justice allowed the transfer of the embryos on 20 December 2011.
8. P.S. Hospital was appointed as the new legal custodian of the embryos in October 2011.
9. The applicants were required to comply with various administrative and legal requirements to retrieve their embryos, including obtaining approval from the Transplant Agency and providing a certified specialist embryologist and a special container with liquid nitrogen. 
10. The applicants were unsuccessful in their attempts to be appointed custodians of their embryos. 
11. Various individuals involved in the S. Clinic and Transplant Agency were found guilty of association for the purposes of creating a criminal group following a criminal investigation.

title: CASE OF GEDİKLİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Kocaeli.
- The applicant initiated compensation proceedings following a dispute with a private third party.
- The Tuzla Civil Court of General Jurisdiction granted the applicant compensation amounting to TRY 386,464.75 (approximately EUR 174,000), but the defendant party did not pay the court fees.
- The court rejected the applicant's request to commence enforcement proceedings as court costs had not been discharged by the defendant party.
- At the time of application, the applicant was unable to execute the judgment unless she paid the court fees that the defendant party had failed to pay.
- After the introduction of the application, the domestic legislation was amended, and the judgment was served on the applicant.
- The debt amounts to TRY 812,648.94 (approximately EUR 193,500), including the initial compensation awarded by the domestic court plus interest.

title: CASE OF BEKTAŞOĞLU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and lives in Erzincan.
- The applicant was a civil servant in the Erzincan Provincial Directorate of Environment and Forestry.
- The applicant was a member of the local branch of a trade union affiliated to KESK.
- On 27 November 2004 and 12 December 2004, the applicant participated in a press statement and a demonstration organised by his trade union.
- A disciplinary investigation was initiated against the applicant for his participation in the above mentioned trade union activities.
- On 31 August 2005, a disciplinary sanction in the form of a reduction in salary was imposed on the applicant for having participated in trade union activities.
- On 27 October 2005, the applicant filed a petition with the Sivas Administrative Court and requested the annulment of the disciplinary sanction that had been imposed on him.
- On 18 May 2006, the Sivas Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s request, considering that the administrative decision was in accordance with law and there were no grounds for its annulment.
- On 20 October 2008, the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the judgment of the Sivas Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF LISOVAIA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984, living in Chisinau, and worked as an unpaid intern at a law firm.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against T., a lawyer with whom the applicant worked, on charges of trading in influence. T. was accused of receiving 10,500 euros (EUR) from D. to pass on to the judges examining a criminal case.
- The police lodged with an investigating judge a request for a warrant to search the applicant’s apartment with the aim of finding and seizing EUR 10,500 received from D. and documents concerning the criminal case.
- A prosecutor lodged a request with the Buiucani District Court for a warrant to be issued for the search of the applicant’s apartment.
- The police searched the applicant’s apartment in the presence of her elderly mother, and they did not find anything.
- The applicant lodged a request for access to the evidence which had been presented to the judge to justify the search.
- The criminal proceedings against T. ended with the latter’s acquittal.

title: CASE OF ČEFERIN v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant represented a defendant charged with three murders and protested his client's innocence throughout the proceedings.
- Three certified experts were appointed to assess the accountability of the defendant and the probability that he had committed the crimes.
- The applicant requested the exclusion of all evidence obtained by alleged violations of his client's human rights and that he be given the results of a lie-detector test performed during the police investigation, but his request was refused.
- At the final hearing, the applicant requested that a new expert psychiatrist be appointed, pointing out deficiencies with respect to the available expert opinion.
- The court rejected the applicant’s proposal to appoint new experts and concluded the evidence-taking procedure.
- The applicant’s client was convicted and sentenced to thirty years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant lodged an appeal, arguing that the date of the murder could not have been as established, the public prosecutor had not submitted the results of the lie-detector test, and his client had not been psychologically capable of committing the alleged crime.
- The applicant strongly criticised the work of the experts, public prosecutor, and the court.
- The Ljubljana District Court issued a decision, fining the applicant for contempt of court for making insulting value judgments about the expert witnesses’ professional qualifications.
- The applicant appealed the decision, arguing that he had not intended to insult anyone and that punishing defence counsels often interfered with freedom of expression.
- The Ljubljana Higher Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal, finding that his remarks had constituted insulting value judgments and were damaging to the honour and reputation of the experts.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, arguing that his punishment violated his freedom of expression.

title: CASE OF SAYGILI AND KARATAŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1966 and 1976 respectively.
- Fevzi Saygılı owned a daily newspaper and Ali Karataş was the editor-in-chief.
- An article was published on 8 January 2000 about Metin Göktepe's case.
- The applicants were charged with disclosing the identities of public officials involved in the fight against terrorism.
- The Istanbul State Security Court convicted the applicants as charged and sentenced them to heavy fines, as well as temporary closure of the newspaper.
- The applicants lodged an appeal, stating that the purpose of the article had been to raise concern over the fact that some high-ranking officials had not been tried.
- The Court of Cassation rejected the request for a hearing and upheld the judgment.
- The closure order for the newspaper was executed from 20 to 27 March 2001.

title: CASE OF ÇABUK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and was serving a prison sentence in the Bolu F-type prison.
- On 3 December 2007, the applicant wrote a letter praising Abdullah Öcalan, the imprisoned leader of the PKK, to the Ministry of Justice.
- The applicant was found guilty of breaching prison order by the Bolu F-type Prison Disciplinary Board.
- On 12 December 2007, the applicant was sentenced to 11 days' solitary confinement due to his statements in the aforementioned letter.
- The Bolu Enforcement Judge rejected the applicant’s objection on 25 December 2007.
- On 15 January 2008, the Bolu Assize Court upheld the judgement of 25 December 2007.

title: CASE OF AYDIN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were serving prison sentences in Muş E-type prison.
- Applicants sent letters to the Ministry of Justice referring to PKK leader Abdullah Öcalan with the honorific "sayın".
- The applicants were found guilty of breaching prison order by the Erzurum H-type Prison Disciplinary Board.
- The applicants were each sentenced to 12 days' solitary confinement on account of the statements in their letters.
- The Erzurum Enforcement Judge rejected the applicants' objections on 17 April 2006.
- The Erzurum Assize Court upheld the judgment of 17 April 2006 on 30 June 2006.
- The first applicant was banned from receiving visitors for two months as a disciplinary sanction for protesting detention conditions of Öcalan.
- The appeal requests of the first applicant were rejected by the Erzurum Enforcement Court and the Erzurum Assize Court on 21 October 2005 and 14 November 2005, respectively.

title: CASE OF HEALY v. IRELAND
facts:
- The applicant has a pituitary brain tumor and has been receiving treatment since 1982.
- In 1995, the applicant became the patient of Dr B, a consultant endocrinologist.
- On August 2000, at the request of Dr B, the applicant underwent another MRI scan which indicated that the tumor was still large and that there had been no significant change since 1995.
- Dr B spoke to the applicant and prescribed a newly-available drug to be injected by her General Practitioner on a monthly basis from September 2000.
- In January 2001, the applicant was hospitalized due to severe side effects caused by the drug.
- In May 2004, the applicant filed a case in the High Court against Dr B and the hospital, citing negligence and lack of sufficient information.
- The High Court ruled against the applicant on all grounds.
- The applicant appealed against the judgment and raised numerous grounds.
- On 17 November 2015, the Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal on both issues.
- The Supreme Court refused the applicant's request for leave to appeal on 8 March 2016.

title: CASE OF OLLER KAMIŃSKA v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a woman born in 1973 living in Galway, Ireland.
- She has a daughter called A, born in 2000 to her then-husband, M.K., while they lived in Poland. The couple also had a son from the applicant's previous relationship.
- The family moved to Ireland in 2006, but M.K. moved back to Poland in January 2009 after the couple separated.
- In June 2009, M.K. took A to Poland for the summer holidays, and the applicant was concerned that he would not return the child.
- On 29 June 2009, the applicant began legal proceedings in Ireland seeking to declare A's habitual residence as Ireland and to order her return by 15 August 2009.
- Although a court order was issued in favour of the applicant, M.K. failed to return A to Ireland.
- In December 2009, a Polish court rejected the applicant's application under the Hague Convention to return A to Ireland, citing concerns for the child's safety and noting her preference to remain in Poland with her father.
- A subsequent Irish court order in 2011 granted joint custody to the parents, but ordered A's return to Ireland by November 2011. M.K. appealed, and his refusal to comply with the order led to a later Polish court ruling that the order was no longer enforceable.
- The applicant eventually removed A from Poland herself in September 2012 and returned with her to Ireland.
- Further legal proceedings in Poland and Ireland resulted in an agreement that the applicant would have sole custody of A, with M.K. having specified access rights.

title: CASE OF SHEHOVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Smolyan.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation awarded the applicant pecuniary damages of BGN 75,902.93 (equivalent to EUR 38,000) against the National Centre for Recreation, Rehabilitation and Sport – Ministry of Education and Science for breach of construction works contract.
- The Minister of Education closed down the Centre and established a State-owned joint‑stock company with part of the Centre’s property, including the real estate in which the applicant had carried out the construction works.
- The applicant was issued with two writs of enforcement and presented them to the Ministry of Education for payment. The Ministry replied that it was not the successor to the Centre and did not owe payment to the applicant. The applicant brought judicial review proceedings, which were rejected by the Supreme Administrative Court.
- As of 19 March 2015, no change in the above circumstances had been reported.

title: CASE OF DELINA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1938 and lives in Sofia. 

- Sofia Municipal Council approved exchange of a municipal flat for a smaller flat owned and occupied by the applicant in December 2005. 

- Mayor of Sofia did not issue necessary order or sign contract for the exchange. 

- Applicant challenged the Mayor’s refusal in a judicial review proceeding. 

- Sofia Administrative Court quashed the Mayor’s tacit refusal in a judgment of April 1, 2010. 

- Sofia Municipal Council revoked its December 2005 decision in a decision of March 25, 2010. 

- Applicant lodged a challenge against that decision. 

- Supreme Administrative Court declared the March 25, 2010 decision null and void in a final judgment of March 7, 2011. 

- Mayor issued a decision refusing to issue an order for the exchange of the flats on April 18, 2011. 

- Supreme Administrative Court declared that decision null and void. 

- Mayor ordered the flat exchange on March 6, 2013, and the applicant signed a contract for the exchange on June 25, 2013.

title: CASE OF GAVRILOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lives in Kyustendil.
- The Sofia District Court awarded the applicant BGN 2,120.28 in damages and BGN 200 in costs and expenses against the National Centre for Recreation, Rehabilitation and Sport.
- The Centre was a State body subsidised by the Ministry of Education and the damages were awarded for loss of salary following the applicant’s unlawful dismissal from work.
- On 25 May 2005 the Minister of Education ordered that the Centre be closed down and its remaining property be managed by the Ministry of Education.
- The Ministry established a State-owned joint-stock company with part of the Centre’s property.
- The judgment became final on 11 February 2008.
- On 26 November 2008 the applicant was issued with a writ of enforcement for the amount awarded against the Centre in the final judgment of 11 February 2008.
- On 18 March 2009 he filed a request with the Minister for Education for payment of that amount.
- The Ministry of Education replied in May 2009 that neither the Ministry, nor the State-owned joint-stock company, was the successor of the Centre and that the amount claimed was not due by them.
- No change in the circumstances had been recorded as of 23 March 2015, the date of the applicant’s last communication to the Court.

title: CASE OF HUSEYNOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and worked for the Bizim Yol newspaper as a journalist.
- The applicant wrote a series of articles criticizing the Ministry of Labour and Social Security, which resulted in meetings with the head of the Ministry's administration, R.A.
- During these meetings, R.A. demanded that the applicant stop writing articles about the Ministry and threatened him.
- R.A. proposed to pay the applicant in exchange for stopping writing the articles, which the applicant initially rejected but eventually accepted due to financial hardship.
- During a meeting in a restaurant, the applicant received $3,500 from R.A., after which the agents of the Ministry of National Security arrested him.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on the same day for bribe-taking.
- The applicant was ordered into detention pending trial.
- The applicant appealed against the detention order, but it was dismissed by the Baku Court of Appeal.
- The prosecutor lodged an application for an extension of the applicant's detention, which was granted by the Nasimi District Court.
- The applicant appealed against the decision, but it was dismissed by the Baku Court of Appeal.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to five years in prison.
- A television program was broadcast concerning the applicant's arrest.

title: CASE OF NEDILENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1956, 1962, and 1974 respectively and reside in Ivano-Frankivsk.
- First and second applicants are spouses.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the first applicant in March 2001 on suspicion of abuse of authority, forgery of official documents, and negligent conduct in concluding loan agreements resulting in damage to the bank.
- The second applicant's flat was searched along with the first applicant's flat, where the third applicant was temporarily living with her minor daughter.
- The search orders were approved by the Ivano-Frankivsk regional prosecutor.
- Personal and financial papers of the first applicant, bank deposit certificates, suits, and bottles of perfume belonging to the first applicant were seized from both flats during the search.
- The first applicant was found guilty of forgery and acquitted of all other charges in February 2004 by the Ivano-Frankivsk Court of Appeal.
- The first applicant filed a cassation appeal alleging the searches and seizure of belongings were arbitrary, which was not taken up in the ruling by the Supreme Court of Ukraine in June 2004.
- In July 2004, the applicants filed a civil suit for compensation against the State of Ukraine and its various agencies in the Ivano-Frankivsk Town Court.
- The first applicant claimed compensation for unlawfully seized personal belongings, loss, deterioration of some of the seized items, and lengthy retention of the belongings by the police.
- The Town Court dismissed the first applicant's claims on the grounds of lawful conviction.
- The Court of Appeal quashed that judgment on the loss and deterioration of some seized items and inadequate storage arrangements by the police, ordering restitution of the retained items to the first applicant and payment of UAH 3,750 in pecuniary damage and UAH 3,500 in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- The second applicant's complaint of an unlawful search was dismissed by the Town Court for having no standing to lodge claims.
- The third applicant's complaint of an arbitrary search of the flat was discontinued by the Town Court, and the Court of Appeal upheld that decision.
- The first applicant was awarded UAH 20,000 from the Ivano-Frankivsk State Auditing Department by the Town Court for irregularities in their reports on his work, which was upheld by the Court of Appeal but stayed by the Supreme Court following a cassation appeal.

title: CASE OF MAGYAR KÉTFARKÚ KUTYA PÁRT v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant political party has its registered seat in Budapest.
- A referendum related to the European Union’s migrant relocation plan was held in Hungary on 2 October 2016.
- The applicant political party made available a mobile telephone application to voters on 29 September 2016 called “the cast-an-invalid-vote app”.
- A private individual lodged a complaint with the National Election Commission about the application on 29 September 2016.
- In a decision of 30 September 2016, the National Election Commission found that the application infringed the principles of fairness of elections, voting secrecy, and the proper exercise of rights.
- The Kúria upheld the Commission’s decision on the infringement of the principle of the proper exercise of rights but overturned the remainder of the Commission’s decision.
- On 3 October 2016, the same private individual lodged a new complaint with the National Election Commission.
- In a decision of 7 October 2016, the National Election Commission reiterated its previous finding and fined the political party.
- The Kúria upheld the Commission’s decision as to the finding of an infringement of the principle of the proper exercise of rights but overturned the remainder of the Commission’s decision as to a violation of the fairness and voting secrecy and the principle of the bona fide exercise of rights.
- The applicant organisation lodged a constitutional complaint against the decision of both 10 and 18 October 2016.
- The Constitutional Court declared the complaints inadmissible on 24 October 2016, with identical reasoning.

title: CASE OF SEVEN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was a chief police officer in Ankara at the time of the events.
- A woman named S.K. accused the applicant of raping her in a police car on April 12, 2002.
- Both the applicant and S.A. were called in for questioning.
- The applicant claimed that S.K. had acted in a sexually inviting manner and that he had ejaculated in his own hand but had not touched her.
- S.A. confirmed the applicant's version of events.
- S.K. initially claimed that the officers had raped her but later withdrew her complaint.
- A forensic expert report showed that the applicant's underwear had both his and S.K.'s DNA on it, and that napkins found in the trash bin had traces of the applicant's semen.
- The Ankara Assize Court acquitted the applicant and S.A. of all charges, stating that there was no evidence of force on S.K.'s body, and that the act of sexual intercourse itself could not be established beyond doubt as non-consensual.
- A preliminary disciplinary investigation was launched against the applicant and S.A.
- The Supreme Disciplinary Council found the applicant guilty of abuse of authority as a police officer and of sexually assaulting S.K., and dismissed him from the police force.
- The applicant challenged his dismissal before the Ankara Administrative Court and the Supreme Administrative Court, but his appeals were dismissed.

title: CASE OF İZZET ÇELİK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was arrested in 1998 on suspicion of being a member of an illegal organization.
- He was questioned by police officers and gave a confession about his involvement in the organization.
- On October 2, 1998, he confirmed his confession to the public prosecutor and reiterated it to the investigating judge.
- The applicant alleged that he gave statements under duress.
- The applicant was charged with separatist activities against the Republic of Turkey.
- The trial court consisted of a bench that included a military judge.
- During the trial, some co-accused gave evidence but did not incriminate the applicant.
- The applicant retracted his confession at a hearing and maintained that he had not been involved in the offenses attributed to him.
- The trial court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to thirty years' imprisonment.
- The decision was upheld by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF CHORBOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant is a lawyer practicing in Sofia, born in 1950.
- The applicant signed a contract with the Bulgarian Ministry of Agriculture and Forests on July 15, 2004.
- The Ministry paid half of the agreed amount when the contract was signed, with the other half to be paid at the end of the proceedings.
- The applicant requested payment of the balance due in December 2005, but the Ministry did not reply.
- The Sofia District Court issued a writ of enforcement against the Ministry in February 2006, which was served by a notary to the Ministry.
- The Ministry did not pay the balance owed, instead, it filed a claim against the applicant in July 2006 seeking damages for failure to carry out duties under the contract.
- The Sofia City Court rejected the Ministry's claim in a first-instance judgment of August 3, 2009.
- The Sofia Court of Appeal rejected the Ministry's claim for damages and awarded the applicant a penalty of BGN 5,102.88 in April 2010.
- The SCC did not allow a cassation review, making the judgment of the Sofia Court of Appeal final on June 28, 2011.
- The applicant requested payment of the outstanding amount again in July 2011, and the Ministry asked for the original writ of enforcement.
- In August 2013, the Ministry stated that they could not trace what had happened to the writ of enforcement.

title: CASE OF ENVER ŞAHİN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was seriously injured in an accident in 2005 which left his lower limbs paralyzed.
- The applicant requested the faculty to adapt the university premises in order to enable him to resume his studies for the 2007‑2008 academic year.
- The faculty replied to that request by letter of 25 May 2007 pointing out that the faculty building had been designed and built with several floors and could not be adapted.
- On 16 August 2007, the applicant sent formal notice to the administration of the university and the faculty dean inviting them to carry out the redevelopment work requested. 
- The administration replied to that formal notice by letter of 10 September 2007 stating that the redevelopment work mentioned should be considered in the light of compliance with the regulations on public property which could take some time. 
- On 15 November 2007, the applicant filed an action for annulment of the university’s replies of 25 May and 10 September 2007 and to provide compensation for the pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage.
- On 18 January 2011, the Supreme Administrative Court delivered a judgment dismissing that appeal on points of law and upholding the first-instance judgment as being in conformity with the procedure and laws.

title: CASE OF SEKMADIENIS LTD. v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Here are the main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant company is a limited liability company established under Lithuanian law with its registered office in Vilnius.
- The company ran an advertising campaign in 2012 introducing a clothing line by designer R.K.
- The campaign featured three visual advertisements displayed on twenty advertising hoardings in public areas in Vilnius and on R.K.’s website.
- The first advertisement showed a young man with long hair, a headband, a halo around his head and several tattoos wearing a pair of jeans.
- The second advertisement showed a young woman wearing a white dress and a headdress with white and red flowers in it.
- The third advertisement showed the man and the woman together, wearing the same clothes and accessories as in the previous advertisements.
- On 28 September and 1 October 2012, the State Consumer Rights Protection Authority (SCRPA) received four individual complaints by telephone concerning the advertisements.
- The SCRPA asked the Lithuanian Advertising Agency to give an opinion on the advertisements.
- The LAA decided that the advertisements breached the General Principles and Articles 1 (Decency) and 13 (Religion) of the Code of Advertising Ethics.
- The SCRPA received a complaint from a law firm in Kaunas concerning the advertisements and forwarded the complaints and LAA opinion to the State Inspectorate of Non-Food Products.
- The Inspectorate informed the applicant company that the advertisements were possibly in violation of Article 4 § 2 (1) of the Law on Advertising as being contrary to public morals.
- The applicant company submitted written explanations to the Inspectorate.
- The Inspectorate drew up a report of a violation of the Law on Advertising against the applicant company.
- The SCRPA asked the Lithuanian Bishops Conference for an opinion on the advertisements.
- The Bishops Conference submitted an opinion that the advertisements degraded religious symbols and offended the feelings of religious people.
- The SCRPA adopted a decision against the applicant company concerning a violation of Article 4 § 2 (1) of the Law on Advertising.
- The applicant company brought a complaint before an administrative court.
- The Vilnius Regional Administrative Court dismissed the applicant company’s complaint.

title: CASE OF EDINA TÓTH v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant and H.B. got married in the US in 2000
- On February 9, 2003, their son was born and acquired dual citizenship
- In 2004, H.B. took their son and left for an unknown destination
- The applicant filed for divorce, and a District Court placed the child with the applicant in November 2005
- The divorce was granted to the applicant in February 2007 with sole custody of the child and child maintenance ordered from H.B., with no visiting rights granted
- The investigation into child abduction against H.B. was suspended due to his unknown whereabouts in 2006, but a warrant was later issued in 2007
- The applicant lodged other criminal complaints against H.B. regarding failure to provide child maintenance and unlawful change of a minor's residence
- The child’s location was established in May 2014 after H.B. was apprehended in Budapest

title: CASE OF STEPAN ZIMIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant participated in the “March of Millions” demonstration on 6 May 2012 in Bolotnaya Square to protest against the allegedly rigged presidential elections.
- The demonstration had been approved by city authorities and was to end at 7.30 p.m., but clashes occurred between protestors and police due to barriers installed by the police and a limited space allocation for the meeting.
- On the same day, criminal proceedings were opened to investigate acts of mass disorder and violence against the police, and the applicant was later arrested on suspicion of participating in these acts and using violence against the police during the demonstration.
- The applicant was ordered to be placed in pre-trial detention until 8 August 2012 and was subsequently charged under Articles 212 § 2 and 318 § 1 of the Criminal Code.
- The applicant was held in detention until 24 February 2014, when he was found guilty of his charges and sentenced to three years and six months’ imprisonment, partially concurrent with a term of one year and four months.

title: CASE OF POLIKHOVICH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1990 and lived in Moscow until his arrest.
- The demonstration at Bolotnaya Square took place on 6 May 2012.
- The event was a march followed by a meeting protesting against the allegedly rigged presidential elections.
- When the marchers arrived at Bolotnaya Square, police had installed barriers that allegedly restricted the space allocated for the meeting, leading to clashes between protestors and police.
- The Moscow City Department of Investigative Committee opened criminal proceedings on the same day, investigating acts of mass disorder and violence against police.
- The applicant participated in the march and was later arrested on 26 July 2012 on suspicion of having participated in acts of mass disorder.
- On 27 July 2012, the Basmannyy District Court ordered that the applicant be placed in pre-trial detention until 26 September 2012.
- The applicant was charged with participation in acts of mass disorder accompanied by violence and resisting police officers.
- The District Court granted several extensions of the applicant's detention, refusing requests for alternative preventive measures.
- The applicant was held in IZ-77/2 throughout his pre-trial detention under poor conditions.
- The trial began on 18 June 2013, and the alleged victim of the applicant's assault testified on 5 September 2013.

title: CASE OF CASSAR v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicants are two individuals born in 1945 and 1951 respectively, who live in Sliema.
- A house in Sliema was rented out to J.G. under a temporary sub-emphyteusis contract in 1962.
- The contract was converted to a lease in 1987, and the applicants purchased the property in 1988 with full knowledge of the lease.
- J.G. and his wife occupied the property until their deaths in 2004 and 2008 respectively.
- P.G., J.G.'s daughter, returned to live with her parents in the property in 2003 and refused to vacate when asked by the applicants in 2008.
- The applicants claimed a violation of their property rights under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention, due to Maltese laws that allowed the tenant to enjoy a title of lease over their property and made it impossible for them to regain possession of it.
- The Civil Court found a violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 and ordered the tenant's eviction in 2011.
- The Constitutional Court reversed the decision in 2013, finding that the applicants had entered into the contract with full knowledge of the legal situation.
- The applicants were later given notice to vacate a property they had been leasing since 1996.
- The applicants claim to have moved to a different property.

title: CASE OF BARABANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant participated in a peaceful protest against the allegedly rigged presidential elections on 6 May 2012 in Moscow.
- The police had installed barriers, allegedly restricting the space allocated for the meeting, which led to numerous clashes between protestors and police.
- The police ordered the meeting to finish early and began to disperse the participants, taking about two hours to clear the square.
- The applicant was arrested and sentenced to detention of twenty-four hours for non-compliance with a lawful order by a police officer and throwing objects at police officers.
- The applicant’s flat was searched, and he was subsequently detained on suspicion of participating in acts of mass disorder and of committing violent acts against the police on 6 May 2012.
- The applicant was placed in pre-trial detention until 6 July 2012, with his detention extended several times until 24 February 2014, based on the gravity of the charges and necessity to secure the aims and goals of the judicial proceedings.
- Court proceedings began on 6 June 2013, and the defendants, including the applicant, were held in glass cabins in hearing rooms equipped with metal cages during the hearings.
- Witnesses testified that the applicant had resisted arrest, had planted his feet firmly, shouted obscenities, and had participated in a group assault on a police officer.

title: CASE OF BRAJOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years and live in Golubovci.
- The applicants sought compensation for legal costs in criminal proceedings against X.
- The High Court ordered X to pay the applicants 505.70 euros for legal representation.
- X and the High State Prosecutor appealed.
- The Court of Appeal ruled on the appeals and the applicants learned about it on 27 May 2010.
- The applicants complained to the President of the Supreme Court that the Court of Appeal had failed to rule on their appeal.
- The Court of Appeal did not rule on the applicants' appeal.
- The applicants filed a compensation claim against the State.
- The Court of First Instance rejected the claim, citing res iudicata.
- The High Court upheld this judgment.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicants' appeal, stating that res iudicata prevented further proceedings.
- The High Court issued a final decision to pay the applicants' representative the awarded sum.

title: CASE OF KORNIYCHUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a Ukrainian politician born in 1966 who has held various high-ranking positions in government, including as a Member of Parliament and as First Deputy Minister of Justice.
- In February 2009, the applicant, acting in his capacity as First Deputy Minister of Justice, sent a letter to Naftogaz, a State-owned company, informing it of exceptional conditions for purchasing legal services from a law firm without inviting bids from other firms. The letter was subsequently used as the basis for Naftogaz to contract further legal services from the same law firm, causing losses to the State budget.
- The applicant was accused of abuse of office and forgery by officials at the Ministry of Justice.
- The applicant was arrested and detained in December 2010, and his arrest and detention were later extended to three months in February 2011.
- The applicant was released under an undertaking not to abscond in February 2011, and was later amnestied in December 2011.

title: CASE OF KOÇHAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Istanbul.
- On 20 January 2009, the applicant was arrested and taken into custody.
- On 22 January 2009, the Edirne Magistrates' Court ordered the applicant's detention on remand on suspicion of forming an organized criminal organization to commit offenses and illegal possession of firearms.
- On 3 July 2009, the Edirne public prosecutor charged the applicant with membership of an organized criminal organization and other offenses.
- On 8 July 2009, the Edirne Assize Court referred the case file to the Istanbul Assize Court and ordered the continuation of the applicant's detention.
- On 4 May 2010, the Istanbul Assize Court prolonged the applicant's detention on remand.
- On 11 October 2011, the Istanbul Assize Court released the applicant from detention on remand.
- At the time of the application, the proceedings against the applicant were still ongoing before the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF MAKARENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The dispute between Ukraine and Russia on gas supplies in 2008-2009 caused Russia to cut off supplies, affecting Ukraine and European states.
- An agreement was reached between Ukraine and Russia to resolve the dispute on January 18, 2009.
- A gas supply contract was signed on January 19, 2009, providing for a new approach to gas pricing and direct contractual relations.
- A contract was also signed regarding the terms of natural gas transit signed on January 20, 2009.
- The applicant was appointed as chief of the State Customs Service of Ukraine on January 28, 2009.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on June 23, 2010, on suspicion of neglect of his official duties and causing substantial damage to the prestige of the state and to RosUkrEnergo AG's interests.
- The applicant was remanded in custody for two months, despite appeals against the custodial measure.
- The applicant's detention was extended several times while his lawyers studied the case file.
- The applicant was released under an undertaking not to abscond on July 5, 2011.
- The applicant was found guilty as charged and given a suspended sentence of four years' imprisonment on July 20, 2012.

title: CASE OF YİGİN v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant participated in a gathering on the anniversary of the arrest of Abdullah Öcalan.
- A press statement was read out in front of a building of a political party.
- Clashes occurred between police officers and some demonstrators.
- Police officers entered the political party's building and arrested 223 people, including the applicant.
- The applicant was charged with membership of the PKK and was detained on remand.
- The applicant was released pending trial.
- The applicant was convicted under section 7(2) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (Law no. 3713).
- Applicant was sentenced to ten months' imprisonment.
- The pronouncement of the conviction was suspended on condition that the applicant did not commit another intentional offence for a period of five years.
- Applicant's objection was dismissed by the court.

title: CASE OF AKSOY v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and was serving a prison sentence in Bolu F-type prison.
- On 3 December 2007, the applicant wrote a letter praising the imprisoned leader of PKK, Abdullah Öcalan, using the honorific "sayın."
- Breaching the prison order, the applicant was found guilty by the Bolu F-type Prison Disciplinary Board.
- The applicant was sentenced to 11 days' solitary confinement on the orders of the Board on 12 December 2007.
- The Bolu Enforcement Judge rejected the applicant's objection on 25 December 2007.
- The Bolu Assize Court upheld the judgment of 25 December 2007 on 15 January 2008.

title: CASE OF BOYETS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant worked as a passport registration officer.
- M. went to the office to apply for a passport for her son and heard rumors that the applicant was known for taking bribes, specifically $100.
- M. alleged that the applicant agreed to help her speed up the procedure with the higher authority, where she would need to pay $100 to the official in charge.
- M. made a written statement to the police that the applicant had asked for a bribe of $100 to speed up the passport issuance procedure.
- M. provided the police with a banknote of $100 and other smaller banknotes to mark them.
- The applicant initially admitted to taking $100 from M. but later changed her account of events, saying M. put a banknote on the table and that she decided to keep it.
- The criminal case was opened against the applicant on suspicion of incitement to bribery.
- The applicant was found guilty of fraud and incitement to bribery and sentenced to a fine of UAH 5,000.

title: CASE OF KAPLAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and is detained in Tekirdağ.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of membership of an illegal organization on 9 September 1995.
- The applicant's detention in police custody was prolonged for up to 15 days on the same day.
- On 13 September 1995, the applicant confessed to being a member of an illegal organization and being involved in a murder, without a lawyer present.
- On 14 September 1995, a reconstruction of the events was organized by the police in the absence of a lawyer.
- On 22 September 1995, the applicant was examined by a doctor, where a collective medical report stated no traces of ill-treatment.
- On 9 October 1995, the applicant was charged with attempting to undermine the constitutional order.
- The applicant was heard by the trial court for the first time in the presence of his lawyer.
- On 13 September 2007, the Istanbul Assize Court sentenced the applicant to life imprisonment based on his and his co-accused's police statements.
- On 1 December 2008, the Court of Cassation upheld the above judgment.

title: CASE OF AYMELEK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was a lieutenant-colonel serving in the Turkish Army.
- The applicant was interrogated and then placed in detention on remand based on suspicion of embezzlement.
- The applicant's brother, who was also a lawyer, was also placed in detention on remand.
- The applicant and his siblings were charged with embezzlement, involvement in trade activities as a soldier, and breaching the law on disclosure of assets and corruption.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to imprisonment but the judgment was later quashed by the Military Court of Cassation.
- The applicant was eventually found guilty and sentenced to imprisonment for embezzlement and being involved in trade activities as a soldier.
- The applicant requested to reopen the criminal proceedings, but his request was rejected.

title: CASE OF HADZHIEVA v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1988 and lives in Varna.
- The applicant and her family moved from Turkmenistan to Bulgaria in late 2001 due to her father's political activity and persecution of family members in Turkmenistan.
- On 22 October 2002, the applicant's parents were charged with embezzlement and subjected to detention and extradition requests by Turkmen authorities.
- The applicant's parents were represented by a friend and neighbor throughout the legal proceedings.
- The applicant, aged fourteen at the time, was alone at home when police officers arrived to arrest her parents on 4 December 2002.
- The applicant was not provided with social worker or psychologist during her interrogation.
- The applicant's parents were eventually released on bail and their extradition request was ultimately refused.
- The applicant brought proceedings for damages against the authorities for failing to provide her with care during her parents' detention.
- A psychiatric and psychological report indicated that the applicant suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder as a result of her parents' detention and the ensuing uncertainty.

title: CASE OF V.C. v. ITALY
facts:
- Applicant born in 1997
- After grandmother's death in 2010, applicant showed signs of distress and psychiatric diagnosis of emotional instability, bipolar disorder, attention deficit disorder, borderline, and anti-social personality was made
- On 19 April 2013, the applicant attended a party with drugs and alcohol and was caught by police
- Criminal investigation initiated by public prosecutor concerning applicant's risky behavior and involvement with drugs and theft
- Parents informed prosecutor that their daughter had been approached for pornographic photographs and might be in danger of prostitution
- Prosecutor requested urgent proceedings to place the applicant in a specialist institution
- Youth Court appointed a judge to hear evidence and take measures to protect the applicant
- Social services did not appear for the hearing and parents testified that their daughter did not wish to testify and refused placement in a specialist institution
- Youth Court decided to place applicant in the care of social services for 12 months and in a specialist institution for rehabilitation of drug addiction and behavioral issues
- Applicant consented to placement in January 2014
- Applicant was raped by two individuals on 30 January 2014 and was examined at a hospital
- Youth Court requested updates from social services on measures taken to assist the applicant, but there was no response
- Applicant left the treatment center in September 2015 and returned to live with her parents
- Criminal investigation into prostitution ring and the applicant's involvement was conducted with her testimony in December 2013; two individuals were convicted in 2014
- The case was set down for preliminary hearing on 6 November 2015 before the Rome District Court and proceedings are still pending

title: CASE OF ASANI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicants are currently serving life sentences for murder.
- An incident occurred on 18 May 2006 in which three children were killed and six people were seriously injured by gunfire outside an internet café in Skopje.
- The investigating judge heard oral evidence from multiple witnesses, including some victims and eye-witnesses who did not identify the applicants as the perpetrators.
- B.H. alleged that the applicants and two others were in the car from which the shots were fired and that they were targeting him due to his alleged involvement in the killing of the applicants’ brother.
- Several witnesses testified under the pseudonyms “Korab” and “Vodno,” who identified the applicants as having fired weapons in the incident.
- F.S. testified under the pseudonym “Vardar” that Mr Ramiz Asani had bought the car used in the incident from M.M. and had confessed to him that he was seeking revenge for his brother’s killing.
- The applicants were sentenced to life imprisonment based primarily on the testimony of the anonymous witnesses and F.S.

title: CASE OF RADCHENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a sentence of life imprisonment.
- Two violent robberies were committed at scrap metal collection points in Odesa in December 2005, resulting in one employee being shot dead.
- The police organized an ambush during the investigation, which led to the arrest of the applicant and an acquaintance, Mr. D.
- Before his arrest, the applicant had pointed a loaded gun with the safety catch released at a police officer.
- The applicant had free legal counsel appointed for him during the pre-trial investigation and the proceedings before the first-instance court.
- The Odesa Regional Court of Appeal found the applicant guilty of several crimes and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed in cassation without legal representation and complained about the absence of free legal assistance.
- The Supreme Court upheld the judgment against the applicant on 30 January 2007 without his presence or representation.
- The applicant requested the Supreme Court ensure his presence in its hearing on 11 June 2007.
- A copy of the Supreme Court’s ruling of 30 January 2007 was sent to the applicant on 17 August 2007.

title: CASE OF VALDGARDT v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant moved in with her partner, N., in his flat in St Petersburg in 1994.
- In 1998, N. borrowed 18,000 USD from the applicant and promised to give her the flat if he failed to repay her. The applicant was registered as living in the flat in 1998 and lived there with N. until his death in 2013.
- The applicant instituted court proceedings in October 2013 seeking to have her property rights over the flat acknowledged. However, the courts dismissed her claims on account of usucaption.
- The district administration claimed that the flat was an heirless estate and, as the new owner of the flat, sought the applicant’s eviction in 2015.
- The District Court refused to evict the applicant in 2015 as N. had let the applicant live in the flat as a family member, and until his death had shared a common household with her. 
- On appeal, the City Court held that the applicant’s right to use the flat had come to an end following the transfer of the property rights in respect of the flat to the city of St Petersburg pursuant to Article 292 of the Civil Code of the Russian Federation.
- The applicant lodged a cassation appeal, which was refused by the City Court and the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation.
- The District Court issued a writ of execution in 2017, and the bailiffs informed the applicant of the forced eviction if the writ of execution was not enforced by 8.30 a.m. on 26 July 2017.

title: CASE OF SALIHIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1951 and lived in Sarajevo.
- On 3 August 2004, the Sarajevo Municipal Court instituted proceedings for the applicant’s placement in a psychiatric facility.
- On 18 August 2004, the Sarajevo Municipal Court decided to keep the applicant in the Psychiatric Clinic for a maximum of 45 days.
- On 22 September 2004 the Social Care Centre placed the applicant in the Drin Social Care Home.
- On 7 January 2005, the Sarajevo Municipal Court deprived the applicant of his legal capacity.
- On 10 March 2005 the Social Care Centre placed the applicant under the guardianship of D.M.
- By its decisions of 25 February 2010 and 25 December 2014, the Social Care Centre decided that the applicant should remain in the Drin Home.
- On 16 September 2015, the Constitutional Court held that the applicant's detention had not been "in accordance with a procedure prescribed by law."
- On 7 December 2015, the Sarajevo Municipal Court restored the applicant’s legal capacity.
- The applicant was released from the Drin Home on 14 December 2015.
- At the applicant’s request, the Social Care Centre admitted him to the Drin Home again, between 1 January 2016 and 31 March 2016.
- The applicant was granted an extension of his stay in social care, which was placed in the Social and Health Care Home on 1 April 2016.
- The applicant died on 26 September 2016, while in the Social and Health Care Home.

title: CASE OF AKIMENKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and lives in Moscow.
- A public demonstration called the “March of Millions” was held in central Moscow on 6 May 2012 to protest against allegedly rigged presidential elections.
- When the marchers arrived at Bolotnaya Square, there were barriers installed by the police, which allegedly restricted the space allocated for the meeting, leading to numerous clashes between the police and protestors.
- The applicant took part in the demonstration and was arrested and charged with participation in mass disorder but was subsequently exempted from liability under the Amnesty Act.
- The applicant was detained and held in several cells in IZ-77/5 in Moscow, with varying degrees of ventilation, light, and access to outdoor exercise. The applicant had health issues related to his eyesight that were regularly monitored by doctors.

title: CASE OF PAUL POPESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant brought proceedings against a private company and a third party to recover property rights pertaining to land.
- The Ploiesti District Court held numerous hearings in the case and ordered the applicant to provide the home addresses of the other co-owners on whose behalf he had brought the proceedings.
- The court adjourned the proceedings on procedural grounds to allow the applicant to add relevant documents proving that he and the other plaintiffs were entitled to claim the land and that he was authorized by the other plaintiffs to represent them.
- The court suspended the proceedings on the grounds that four of the six other plaintiffs had died prior to 2005 and the applicant hadn't taken any steps to identify their heirs and enable the court to summon them as parties to the proceedings.
- The County Court allowed the applicant’s appeal against the District Court’s decisions and ordered the reopening of the proceedings, but the District Court adjourned the proceedings on several occasions to allow for further evidence and clarification of the plaintiffs' status. Eventually, the District Court declared the proceedings barred by limitation due to the applicant's inaction. The County Court upheld this decision by a final judgment.

title: CASE OF S.C. TEXTINC S.A. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- S.C. Textinc S.A. is a Romanian company with its registered office in Timişoara.
- Timişoara Finance Inspectorate instituted enforcement proceedings against the company on 12 December 2008, claiming outstanding tax liability for the year 2008 amounting to RON 237,128.
- The company challenged the decision in Timişoara District Court, submitted evidence and proved that it had no outstanding tax liability.
- At the first hearing, T.F.I acknowledged its mistake and invoked Article 275 of the Romanian Code of Civil Procedure to avoid paying the costs.
- The District Court allowed the company's challenge and ordered T.F.I to pay RON 9,893 to the company representing lawyer's fees and trial tax.
- T.F.I appealed on points of law but the Timiş County Court upheld the decision of the District Court and awarded RON 7,596 in legal costs to the applicant company in August 2009.
- T.F.I. requested the judgment of August 2009 to be set aside, and the County Court granted the request, allowing the appeal lodged by T.F.I. against the judgment of February 2009.
- The County Court re-examined the amount paid by the applicant company in lawyer’s fees, reduced it from RON 9700 to RON 700, and disallowed the stamp duty and trial tax of RON 193.

title: CASE OF BUTORIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1970 and lives in Belebey, Republic of Bashkortostan.
- The applicant and his family moved from Uzbekistan to Russia in October 2007.
- In December 2007, Uzbek authorities charged the applicant with large-scale drug-trafficking committed in October 2007 and issued a detention order and an international search warrant.
- The Dragomilovskiy District Court of Moscow ordered the applicant's detention on July 14, 2008, pending extradition, without setting any time-limit.
- On December 9, 2008, the Russian Prosecutor General's Office ordered the applicant's extradition.
- On January 28, 2009, the Moscow City Court confirmed the lawfulness of the applicant's arrest and detention, and upheld the extradition.
- On August 21, 2009, the extradition order was enforced, and the applicant was transferred to Uzbekistan.
- On August 28, 2009, the applicant's lawyers requested an interim measure under Rule 39 of the Rules of Court to stay the removal. On 1 September 2009, the Court indicated the relevant measure to the Russian Government, but the interim measure was lifted on October 7, 2009.
- The applicant joined his family in Russia on an unspecified date.

title: CASE OF LADA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was the head of Khorly Village Council at the time of the events.
- He signed a permit for a businessman to set up game machines in the village without an official stamp, and is alleged to have requested a bribe of 20,000 UAH to provide the stamp.
- The businessman complained to the police and the applicant was arrested and charged with taking a bribe.
- The applicant was first released on bail, then remanded in pre-trial detention twice, before being released on bail again.
- The applicant was ultimately sentenced to five years' imprisonment for taking a bribe.
- The applicant served his sentence in poor living conditions.

facts:

- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MITRYUKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's name is Aleksey Nikolayevich Mitryukov.
- He is a Russian national born on 6 May 1979.
- Mr Mitryukov submitted three applications, as detailed in the appended table. 
- He complained about the inadequate conditions of his detention during different periods.
- Mr Mitryukov raised concerns under Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ŽIROVNICKÝ v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1968 and is serving a prison sentence in Mírov Prison.
2. On 8 April 2004, the applicant initiated civil proceedings for protection of his personality rights (“the main proceedings”) against the Czech Republic in the person of the Ministry of Justice.
3. The Prague Municipal Court dismissed the applicant’s action on 28 March 2008.
4. On 12 June 2007, the applicant claimed compensation under the State Liability Act.
5. On 18 December 2009, the Prague 2 District Court acknowledged that there had been delays in the main proceedings and awarded the applicant 30,000 Czech korunas (CZK) in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
6. On 15 September 2010, the Prague Municipal Court dismissed the whole financial claim, leaving the rest of the judgment intact.
7. On 30 November 2011, the Supreme Court quashed the Municipal Court’s judgment and remitted the case to it.
8. On 19 September 2003, the applicant brought a civil action against the Czech Republic–Ministry of the Interior before the Prague 7 District Court.
9. The District Court dismissed the applicant’s action on 21 December 2009 after a hearing on 16 December 2009.
10. On 28 July 2004, the case was referred to the Prague Municipal Court as the court competent to deal with it at the first instance.
11. On 18 March 2010, the District Court dismissed the applicant’s action for compensation.
12. On 13 December 2007, the applicant brought a civil action before the Prague 2 District Court.
13. On 20 January 2012, the District Court dismissed the action.
14. On 15 October 2004, the applicant brought an administrative action against the Ministry of Justice before the Prague Municipal Court.

title: CASE OF SLAVA JURIŠIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant is a local political figure in Slavonski Brod.
- The applicant accused the mayor of being involved in irregularities in the employment of civil servants in local public institutions, including appointing an employee with invalid documents, Z.B.
- Z.B. had presented a certificate confirming her Croatian citizenship to obtain employment at the kindergarten where the applicant was the head administrator, thus making Z.B. the applicant's subordinate.
- Z.B. later became head of administration for all kindergartens in Slavonski Brod.
- Z.B. instituted a private prosecution against the applicant for defamation, and the applicant was acquitted in the first trial but found guilty in the retrial.
- The applicant appealed the verdict to the Slavonski Brod County Court, which upheld the first-instance judgment.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court, which declared the complaint inadmissible.
- The parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe adopted Resolution 1577 in 2007, urging member states to abolish prison sentences for defamation.

title: CASE OF NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant's birth year is 1967 and he lives in Budapest.
- The civil proceedings in his case lasted for six years and four months.
- The duration of the proceedings spanned between November 26, 2007, and April 2, 2014.
- There were two levels of jurisdiction in the proceedings.
- The applicant complained that the length of the proceedings was excessive.

title: CASE OF RAMKOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1947 and 1971, live in Skopje, and are father and son
- They were arrested on 23rd and 24th of December 2010
- They were held in pre-trial detention for thirty days
- They were suspected of criminal conspiracy and tax evasion
- On 21st January 2011, their pre-trial detention was extended by a three-judge panel of the trial court
- They were charged with money laundering, criminal conspiracy, tax evasion, and abuse of office on 22nd March 2011
- Their pre-trial detention was extended until their conviction by the trial court
- The Court of Appeal upheld their conviction on 25th February 2013

title: CASE OF KOLESNIKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document contains a list of applicants with relevant details in a table.
- The applicants claimed that they did not receive sufficient medical care while being detained.
- Some of the applicants also made other complaints under the Convention.

facts:
- List of applicants and relevant application details set out in the appended table.
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions during transport.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF PIHONI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant witnessed a violent altercation between two individuals and tried to intervene to calm them down.
- The verbal altercation escalated to physical violence and a special police unit intervened to stop it.
- The applicant claims to have sustained injuries as a result of police intervention and was taken to the local police station.
- Two investigations were opened into the criminal offence of the commission of arbitrary actions by a person vested with public powers in the exercise of his duties.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint against the RRF officers who allegedly beat him with a rubber truncheon on the shoulder, leg and head.
- The applicant submitted a forensic medical report to support his criminal complaint, which found that he had been injured by a hard, blunt object, causing a wound requiring stitches and resulting in his inability to work for nine days.
- Procedural actions were taken, including questioning the applicant and other witnesses, inspection of police and hospital registers, and examination of video footage from a nearby bank. 
- Witnesses gave conflicting statements about the use of rubber truncheons by RRF officers, with some denying their use.

title: CASE OF GALEA AND OTHERS v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicants have held the utile dominium of a land in Malta since 2002.
- The property had a shop which was rented out for commercial purposes.
- In 1965, part of the land was declared to be needed for public purposes under the Land Acquisition (Public Purposes) Ordinance, and the government took possession of the entire property and demolished the shop to build a civic center and service roads.
- In 1972, changes were made to the plan to build a new shop on a nearby plot of land belonging to the applicant, which was leased to the same third party for use as a snack bar.
- Extra-judicial requests to obtain the return of the property used for the snack bar were to no avail until constitutional redress proceedings were instituted in 2010.
- The court found that the taking had not been in public interest and had violated the applicants’ property rights as they had received no compensation for 45 years.
- The first-instance court ordered the annulment of the declaration, return of the property, and compensation of EUR 40,000.
- The Constitutional Court allowed the appeal in part and quashed the first-instance judgment in part but found a violation of the applicants’ property rights and ordered compensation of EUR 10,000 without prejudice to any claim for pecuniary compensation.
- The Commissioner later deposited the award in court, and the government sent a reminder for evidence of title in 2015.

title: CASE OF KEŠELJ AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- On 28 February 1996, a settlement was reached before the Cetinje Municipal Court, regarding the payment of specified amounts in respect of pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage.
- The settlement became final on the same date.
- The debtor paid only part of the amounts determined in the settlement.
- On 26 May 1997, the Podgorica Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings against the debtor.
- On 19 August 1997, the applicants submitted claims based on the settlement.
- The Podgorica Commercial Court acknowledged the applicants’ claims in the insolvency proceedings.
- On 23 December 2009, the Podgorica Commercial Court terminated the insolvency proceedings against the debtor but continued the proceedings against the debtor’s estate.
- This decision was upheld by the Appellate Court on 9 April 2010.
- The court settlement remains partly unenforced to the present day.
- At the time the settlement was concluded, the debtor was a company predominantly comprised of State-controlled capital. The Government did not refute this or provide any evidence to the contrary.

title: CASE OF IVASHCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant is a photographer who writes texts occasionally for print and Internet media outlets.
• In August 2009, he traveled with Ms D. to Abkhazia to prepare a report with photographs on "the life of this unrecognized republic."
• Upon their return to Russia, customs officers examined the applicant’s luggage and decided to copy data from his laptop for fear of banned printed and/or audio and video material with extremist content.
• The customs officers copied data present in approximately 34 folders with names like In motion, Miscellaneous, Desktop, Foto_projects, On the road, Isolation, Drawings, 1 May, 9 May, 14 February, Law, and Extremism (for RR).
• The officer made a copy of an electronic folder labeled "Extremist" as well as some other folders containing photographs and texts concerning two ethnic groups allegedly under pressure from the Krasnodar regional administration.
• The data was copied from the laptop to six DVD RW disks.
• The applicant claims that the officer copied some 26 gigabytes of data, including his personal correspondence, photographs, and FTP-type passwords.
• The customs authorities claimed that Decree no. 310 on combating fascism and political extremism justified their action.
• The sampling of data was carried out in compliance with Presidential Decree no. 310 on combating fascism and political extremism.
• According to the Prikubanskiy District Court of Krasnodar, laptops, storage devices, photo and video cameras should be considered goods, and the customs authorities are authorized to take samples of goods for examination by using technical devices.
• In the appeal, the applicant argued that the seizure of electronic devices adversely affects the maintenance of professional secrecy and interferes with the constitutional right to the protection of the secrecy of correspondence and other communications.

title: CASE OF ANDREY SMIRNOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant and his classmate were arrested for causing grievous bodily injuries to a boy from their school, but later retracted their confessions.
- The applicant was placed in custody on 16 November 2009, and the court upheld the detention order on appeal, citing the seriousness of the charges and the risk of obstruction of justice.
- The District Court extended the detention period, stating that the change in the applicant's attitude and denial of the charges implied a risk of interfering with justice if released.
- The investigator refused the parents' request to visit their son, alleging that the father of the applicant's co-defendant was interfering with the proceedings and could negatively influence the defendant.
