- The court issued further extension orders, citing the gravity of the charges and the need to secure the enforcement of the conviction.
- Both the applicant and his co-defendant were found guilty of attempted murder and sentenced to five years' imprisonment.
- The applicant's parents visited him 16 times in prison under supervision and separated from their son by a glass partition.

title: CASE OF TYUTINA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document includes a list of applicants (see appended tables).
- The applicants were awarded monetary court awards against MUP Kotlas Passenger Transport Company on specific dates (as indicated in the appended tables).
- Some of the judgments in favour of the applicants have been partially enforced during insolvency proceedings, while others remain unenforced.
- MUP Kotlas Passenger Transport Company was a municipal unitary enterprise set up by the municipality of Kotlas, providing transport services in the town with economic control over allocated assets.
- Prices for transport services in Kotlas were regulated by the Administration of Arkhangelsk region.
- Insolvency proceedings started on 28 September 2007.
- The company was declared insolvent on 18 September 2012 and subsequently liquidated.

title: CASE OF ZENGİN AND ÇAKIR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1987 and 1986 and live in Gümüşhane and Erzincan respectively.
- On 18 May 2007, the applicants participated in reading out a press statement in commemoration of İbrahim Kaypakkaya, the leader of the TKP/ML[1] (Turkish Communist Party – Marxist/Leninist), who had died allegedly under torture in police custody.
- On 7 January 2008, the Erzurum public prosecutor initiated criminal proceedings against fifteen people, including the applicants, charging them with disseminating propaganda in favour of the TKP/ML, under section 7(2) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (Law no. 3713).
- The applicants were found guilty and sentenced each of them to ten months’ imprisonment pursuant to section 7(2) of Law no. 3713.
- The court suspended pronouncement of the applicants’ conviction on the condition that they did not commit another intentional offence for a period of five years, under Article 231 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (hükmün açıklanmasının geri bırakılması).
- The applicants filed an objection against the decision of 31 March 2009, stating that their prosecution had constituted a breach of Article 10 of the Convention.
- On 20 July 2009, the Diyarbakır Assize Court rejected the applicants’ objection without examining the merits of the case.

title: CASE OF BUTKEVICH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a journalist from Ukraine.
- The applicant volunteered to cover the G8 summit in St Petersburg, Russia.
- The applicant was observing a protest in St Petersburg when he was arrested by the police.
- The police accused the applicant of refusing to cease his "unlawful actions" and of resisting the police officers.
- The applicant was subjected to administrative arrest under Article 27.3 of the CAO.
- The applicant was interviewed and said that he was a journalist, but the administrative case file contained no photocopies of any document confirming his status as a professional journalist.
- The applicant was sentenced to three days of detention under Article 19.3 of the CAO.
- The applicant's conviction was upheld on appeal, and his request for a supervisory review of the judgments was denied.

title: CASE OF ZELIK AND KEL v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were convicted of criminal offences between 2005 and 2008

- Their cases were examined by the appeal courts without their legal counsel

- Their convictions were upheld

- Personal details and information related to the criminal proceedings are provided in the appendix.

title: CASE OF ULAY v. TURKEY
facts:
1. The applicant was a minor at the time of the crime.
2. A certain H.A. was found dead on 17 August 2002 in a junkyard and police launched an investigation into the matter.
3. On 20 August 2002, the applicant was brought to the police headquarters, where he was searched and went through a medical examination.
4. On 26 August 2002, the applicant turned eighteen years of age.
5. On 20 September 2002, the applicant was questioned by the police once again.
6. On 14 October 2002, the applicant confessed to having killed H.A.
7. The applicant alleged that he had been subjected to ill-treatment and psychological duress by the police.
8. The police found a tile-cutting machine with bloodstains matching the sample tissues taken from the deceased at the applicant's house and subsequently arrested him.
9. During a reconstruction of events, the applicant confessed to killing H.A. and described in detail how he had disposed of the body.
10. The applicant was placed in detention on remand on 20 September 2002 and later sentenced to twenty-one years' imprisonment for murder and robbery.

title: CASE OF MSKHILADZE v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and arrived in Russia in 1988.
- He had a history of criminal convictions and was released from prison on 3 December 2014.
- On 2 December 2014, an exclusion order was issued, declaring the applicant's presence in Russia undesirable and prohibiting his return until 2020.
- A deportation order was later issued, and he was detained for several months until his release on 30 August 2015.
- On 14 December 2015, he was accused of being present in Russia without necessary documents and was convicted of an offense under Article 18.8 § 3 of the Code of Administrative Offences.
- He was ordered to be removed from Russia without specifying a destination country and was placed in a detention center for foreigners.
- He lodged an appeal arguing that administrative removal could not be enforced as he was stateless, but the appeal court upheld the judgment.
- The applicant was kept in the detention center from 15 December 2015 to 22 June 2017, during which he was mostly locked in his cell.
- The detention center had no courtyard for detainees, and the cells had fixed partitions for toilets, which were not high enough, causing discomfort.
- Food quality was mediocre, and detainees had to eat on their beds as there were no tables.
- The applicant was prohibited from entering other cells, and there were no radio, television, newspapers, or similar amenities provided in the detention center.

title: CASE OF HRISTOSKOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and is currently detained in Kremikovtsi Prison Hostel near Sofia.
- In 2009, the applicant was convicted of murder and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment.
- From 2009-2010, the applicant was placed in a group that was housed in several cabins with cement floors, damp and broken windows and doors, and less than 2 square meters of floor space per inmate.
- Basic hygiene necessities were not provided and there was no canteen or eating space.
- On 28 October 2010, the applicant was transferred to a better cell and started working in the hostel’s canteen.
- In 2014, the applicant was placed in a cell outside the guarded area of the hostel with improved sanitary facilities and better living conditions.
- Health care in custody was inadequate with no qualified doctors available.
- Kremikovtsi Prison Hostel suffered from severe overcrowding, poor hygiene, and unsanitary living conditions.
- The number of inmates detained in the facility was higher than the official capacity.

title: CASE OF ŠAĆIROVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- Applicants' personal details and case facts are in the appendix.
- Applicants complained of excessive length of civil proceedings under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
- Constitutional Court found a violation of the first applicant's right to a hearing within a reasonable time but awarded no damages.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the third applicant's appeal.
- The other two applicants did not raise a complaint about the length of their proceedings.

title: CASE OF VUJOVIĆ AND LIPA D.O.O. v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Cetinje. The second applicant was founded in Cetinje in 1990. The first applicant is the founder, the sole owner, and the executive director of the second applicant.
- On 1 July 2013, insolvency creditor X requested the Commercial Court to open insolvency proceedings in respect of the second applicant.
- The second applicant was represented by the first applicant and a lawyer duly authorised by him.
- On 27 December 2013, the Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings and appointed an insolvency administrator.
- On 23 January 2014, the second applicant lodged an appeal against the Commercial Court decision.
- On 18 March 2014, the Court of Appeals rejected the appeal as having been submitted by an unauthorised person.
- The court relied on sections 75 and 76 of the Insolvency Act.
- On 12 May 2014, the applicants lodged a constitutional appeal.
- On 23 July 2014, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicants' constitutional appeal for "not having been lodged by a party to the domestic proceedings or by a person authorised to appeal on behalf of the person whose rights and freedoms were violated".

title: CASE OF X v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was diagnosed with schizotypal personality disorder and was undergoing voluntary treatment for his condition.
- On 24 April 2014, the applicant was apprehended by police on the street in the Bibirevo district of Moscow and taken to the local police station.
- He was later transferred to the Central Clinical Psychiatric Hospital of the Moscow Region (ГКУЗ МО «Центральная клиническая психиатрическая больница») (“the Hospital”).
- A psychiatric ambulance service reported he had been sexually harassing and stalking an underage teenager.
- The hospital diagnosed the applicant with organic delusional disorder and applied for judicial authorization of the applicant’s involuntary hospitalization. 
- The applicant refused treatment and demanded to be discharged, however, his request was denied.
- The applicant was examined and diagnosed by the medical counselling panel composed of the resident psychiatrists.
- On 5 May 2014, the Savyolovskiy District Court of Moscow authorized the applicant’s involuntary hospitalisation. 
- The applicant’s father appealed the decision but was dismissed by the Moscow City Court on 18 July 2014. 
- The applicant was discharged from the Hospital on 20 May 2014.

title: CASE OF BOPKHOYEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was abducted with intent to be married on 11 December 2009.
- The applicant was kept locked in a room without communication and treated poorly, complaining of health issues, and lost consciousness on several occasions.
- On 2 February 2010, the applicant did not regain consciousness and was diagnosed with post-hypoxic encephalopathy and vegetative state.
- The applicant's mother complained to the local police on 23 September 2010, but criminal proceedings were refused on multiple occasions.
- The district deputy prosecutor ordered a new inquiry on 28 February 2015, and the outcome is not mentioned.

title: CASE OF BOYKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the owner and CEO of a large dairy producer, born in 1959 and living in Moscow.
- On 24 November 2006, he was charged with large-scale fraud and money laundering, and summoned for questioning. He did not show up for initial interviews, and the investigator put his name on the list of fugitives from justice.
- On 26 January 2007, the investigator asked the Ostankinskiy District Court in Moscow for a detention order, which was granted on 1 February 2007 by the appointed legal-aid counsel to represent the absent applicant.
- The detention order was later extended on nine occasions, with the applicant lodging statements of appeal against each of them.
- The most recent detention order was quashed on appeal by the Supreme Court on 2 October 2008, as the proceedings had been unreasonably long.
- The applicant requested visits from his mother, wife, children and Orthodox priests while in custody, but the investigator refused most of them, citing potential negative influence on the investigation.
- The Tverskoy District Court pronounced the refusal of pastoral visits to be lawful and justified, while granting part of the applicant's complaint regarding restrictions on family visits.
- On 15 February 2008, the District Court dismissed the applicant's representative's complaint that she should have been allowed to visit him without restrictions, and the Moscow City Court upheld that decision on appeal.

title: CASE OF ALPHA DORYFORIKI TILEORASI ANONYMI ETAIRIA v. GREECE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is the owner of the Greek TV channel ALPHA.
- ALPHA broadcast a show named “Jungle” on 24 January 2002, which included three hidden-camera videos.
- One video showed A.C. (a member of the Hellenic Parliament) entering a gambling arcade and playing on two machines; another video showed A.C. meeting with associates of the television host of “Jungle” and the third video showed a meeting between A.C. and the television host.
- The National Radio and Television Council held a hearing in which the applicant company acknowledged the use of hidden cameras.
- The National Radio and Television Council ordered the applicant company to pay a fine and broadcast the content of the decision.
- The applicant company lodged an application for annulment, which was dismissed by the Supreme Administrative Court.
- The Supreme Administrative Court laid down the conditions under which it is legitimate to broadcast an image that has been filmed with the method of hidden camera, and stressed that broadcasting of a secretly recorded image can only be justified if the legitimate broadcasting of such news is completely impossible or particularly difficult without broadcasting the image.
- The Court dismissed the applicant company’s argument that it had legitimately transmitted the news concerning A.C. in view of A.C.’s capacity as a public figure.
- The Court ruled that the decision of the National Radio and Television Council had been fully reasoned.
- There were two dissenting opinions.

title: CASE OF RAZUMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The document includes a table listing the applicants and details of their applications. 

• The applicants of the case complained about the unsatisfactory conditions of their detention. 

• Additional complaints were made by some applicants under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF POPOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and application details provided in the table.
- Applicants complained about the inadequate detention conditions.
- Some applicants raised complaints under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF SMIRNOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their relevant details is provided.
- The applicants reported inadequate detention conditions.
- Some applicants also cited violations of Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF LOGINOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table containing a list of applicants and relevant details is provided.
- The applicants have mainly complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.

title: CASE OF ACHILOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a table appended that lists the applicants and relevant details of their applications.
- The applicants have complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- One of the applicants (in application no. 4215/17) has also raised a complaint under Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF YAKOVLEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their details are provided in a table.
- The applicants filed a complaint about the inadequate detention conditions.
- Some applicants filed complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MALYGIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details provided in appended table
- Applicants complain of inadequate detention conditions
- Some applicants raised other complaints under provisions of Convention

title: CASE OF SURZHANOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with their respective details appended in a table.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF PARAMONOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants provided along with details of their applications.
- Applicants were convicted of drug offences. 
- Applicants claim they were entrapped by State agents.
- Applicants consider their convictions to be unfair.

title: CASE OF KOKHANOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table is appended to the document containing a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complained about their detention conditions.
- Some applicants raised complaints under the Convention.

title: CASE OF SOLONENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
-List of applicants and relevant details provided in a table
-Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
-Applicants raised other complaints under the Convention provisions

title: CASE OF GRYTSENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- There is an appended table listing applicants and relevant details of their applications.
- The applicants complained about the length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- One of the applicants (no. 56576/08) raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MAĞIN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in Istanbul in 1977.
- On 16 June 1999, the applicant was detained for belonging to an illegal organization, Hizbullah.
- On 21 June 1999, the applicant confessed to being a member of the Hizbullah during interrogation by the police.
- On 22 June 1999, in front of both the public prosecutor and the investigating judge, the applicant denied the accusations and claimed his statements had been given under duress.
- On 30 June 1999, an indictment was filed against the applicant for being a member of an illegal armed organization.
- On 9 November 1999, the applicant was released pending trial.
- The State Security Courts were abolished by Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004, and the case was transferred to the Diyarbakır Assize Court.
- On 12 June 2008, the applicant was convicted of violating Article 314 § 2 of the new Turkish Criminal Code and sentenced to six years and three months’ imprisonment.
- The Diyarbakır Assize Court considered various pieces of evidence, including the applicant's statements to the police, information on computer hard disks and print-outs seized from an illegal organization's house, and witnesses' testimonies during conviction.
- On 4 June 2009, the Court of Cassation upheld the initial court's judgment.

title: CASE OF SHVEDOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicants were charged and convicted of different criminal offenses between 2005-2012.
• The appeal courts examined their cases in their absence and that of their lawyers.
• The convictions were upheld.
• The information relevant to the criminal proceedings is provided in the table below.

title: CASE OF RAJAK v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1961 and lives in Bijela, Montenegro.
- On 1 March 2012, the Herceg Novi First Instance Court ordered the applicant’s employer to carry out a re-allocation of plots for the construction of apartments.
- On 15 January 2013, the applicant requested enforcement of the above judgment and the Herceg Novi First Instance Court issued an enforcement order on 31 January 2013.
- On 12 June 2015, the Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor.
- The Herceg Novi First Instance Court transferred the case to the Commercial Court for further action.
- The Commercial Court suspended the enforcement due to the opening of the insolvency proceedings in March 2016.
- The judgement in question remains unenforced.
- On 8 February 2013, the applicant instituted administrative proceedings seeking the removal of competing titles from the Land Register.
- The administrative proceedings were terminated on 29 July 2015, and the applicant submitted an objection against the above decision.
- The administrative proceedings are still pending.
- In 2003, the applicant instituted separate civil proceedings against the debtor, as his former employer, seeking reinstatement and damages.
- On 3 March 2014, the Herceg Novi First Instance Court rendered a judgment in the applicant’s favour.
- On 22 September 2015, the High Court upheld this judgment on the merits but quashed it as regards the costs.
- On 31 October 2016, the Herceg Novi First Instance Court transferred the case to the Commercial Court for further action due to the commencement of the insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor.
- The Commercial Court ruled partly in favour of the applicant regarding the costs on 22 February 2017, but information on when the decision became final and was served on the applicant is unknown.

title: CASE OF VELLA v. MALTA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1932 and lives in Siġġiewi.
- Applicant is the owner of 14 Kirkop Square, Kirkop, a two-storey tenement with a surface area of around 175 sq.m.
- Property was requisitioned in 1955 by means of a requisition order and was allocated to the San Leonard Band Club.
- Rent was paid to the owners by the competent authority (then the Director of Social Housing, today the Housing Authority) amounting to 30 Maltese Lira per year (less than EUR 6 per month).
- Band club carried out extensive structural alterations without obtaining consent from the owners or the relevant permits.
- Band club repeatedly breached the tenancy agreement which it had signed, by manufacturing fireworks on the premises and conducting commercial activities.
- Applicant instituted constitutional redress proceedings in 2007.
- Civil Court (First Hall) in its constitutional jurisdiction upheld the applicant’s claims.
- The requisition was held to be in public interest by the Constitutional Court.
- The order to vacate was revoked.
- Compensation of EUR 60,000 was awarded to the applicant.
- Band club appealed, but the Constitutional Court upheld the first-instance judgment in part.

title: CASE OF TERGE v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and is detained.
- On 19 July 2012, the applicant was transported from pre-trial detention to the Budapest Main Police Department for questioning where he showed no sign of injuries.
- The applicant was questioned by police officers A and B until approximately 11:30 a.m, during which the applicant chose not to give a statement.
- The applicant was released after the interrogation and handed over to the guards of Budapest Prison who asked whether he had been ill-treated, to which he replied in the negative.
- After being transported back to Budapest Prison, the applicant declared to have been ill-treated and underwent a medical examination during which certain injuries were noted.
- The applicant was again transported back to the Budapest Main Police Department for questioning and taken to the military hospital by the police officer who had conducted his interrogation.
- A police report filed on 19 July 2012 by officer A stated that the applicant had not been ill-treated.
- In a criminal investigation, the applicant gave a testimony on 14 November 2012, stating that he had been punched by the police officer several times.
- Two prison escort officers did not remember the circumstances of the applicant's medical examination, but one stated that detainees were under constant supervision while waiting for medical examinations.
- A forensic expert opinion stated that the applicant's account was implausible and that the location of the injuries did not correspond to his description of the incident.
- The investigations were discontinued on 8 May 2014, and the applicant complained seeking the continuation of the investigations.

title: CASE OF SINKOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
1. The applicant belonged to a provocative artistic group called the St Luke Brotherhood.
2. On 16 December 2010, the applicant and three other members of the group went to the Eternal Glory Memorial and fried eggs and sausages over the Eternal Flame at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.
3. The act was recorded and posted online with a statement protesting against the waste of natural gas caused by the burning of the Eternal Flame.
4. Complaints were made to the police and the applicant was later charged with desecration of the tomb.
5. The applicant was found guilty by the court and sentenced to three years’ imprisonment, suspended for two years.
6. The applicant appealed her conviction, arguing that her actions were a form of protest and did not meet the definition of desecration under the Burial and Funeral Business Act.
7. The prosecutor also appealed, considering the sentence to be too lenient.

title: CASE OF TAŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Muş.
- On 19 April 2003, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of membership of an illegal organisation.
- On 20 April 2003, the applicant’s statements were taken by the police in the absence of a lawyer.
- On 22 April 2003, the applicant was heard in the absence of a lawyer and placed in pre-trial detention.
- On 6 May 2003, the public prosecutor filed an indictment accusing the applicant of membership of an illegal terrorist organisation under Article 168 of the former Criminal Code.
- The State Security Courts were abolished by Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004, and the case was transferred to the Istanbul Assize Court.
- On 19 September 2006, the Istanbul Assize Court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to six years and three months’ imprisonment.
- On 19 November 2007, the Court of Cassation quashed the judgment on procedural grounds.
- On 30 December 2008, the Istanbul Assize Court convicted the applicant again and sentenced him to six years and three months’ imprisonment.
- On 20 March 2012, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the Istanbul Assize Court.

title: CASE OF ISAYKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and is detained in Belovo, Kemerovo Region.
- Following the applicant's arrest on suspicion of drug trafficking, he was placed in temporary detention for more than two years.
- The applicant was detained in several different cells that measured approximately twenty meters, housing between 10 and 14 inmates.
- The toilets in most of the cells were merely a hole in the floor, while a lavatory pan was installed in three cells, separated from the living area by a fence.
- The applicant was provided with an individual sleeping place during most of his detention.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Tomsk found the applicant guilty of attempted drug trafficking on 30 December 2009 and sentenced him to nine years and six months in prison.
- The applicant's lawyer lodged an appeal and requested his presence at the hearing.
- The Tomsk Regional Court upheld the conviction on appeal on 25 March 2013, with the presence of the applicant and his lawyer.

title: CASE OF SERTKAYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Muş.
- On 30 October 2001, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of membership of the PKK.
- The applicant was questioned by the police on 1 November 2001 without a lawyer and confessed to being a member of the PKK.
- On 3 November 2001, the applicant was brought before a public prosecutor and the investigating judge in the absence of a lawyer and denied the accusations.
- On the same day, the applicant was put in pre-trial detention as per the order of the investigating judge.
- On 6 November 2001, the Public Prosecutor filed an indictment charging the applicant under Article 168 of the former Criminal Code with membership in an illegal armed organization.
- Later on, state security courts were abolished, and the case was transferred to the Istanbul Assize Court.
- On 6 October 2006, the Istanbul Assize Court convicted the applicant of membership of an illegal organization and sentenced him to seven years and six months in prison.
- On 15 December 2009, the Court of Cassation upheld the verdict of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF HULPE AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The list of applicants and their application details are in the appended table.
- The applicants had lost court cases in their absence.
- The notices of court proceedings were served only through public notice by posting them on a gate or fence.
- The applicants argued in their subsequent appeals that they were not aware of the court proceedings as they had never received a court summons.
- Complaints made by the applicants were dismissed by the court due to service by public notice being provided by the law, resulting in dismissals of appeals without examination of the case merits.

title: CASE OF GUJA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant is a journalist who sent letters to a newspaper containing information about pressure put on the Prosecutor General's Office by a high-ranking politician.
- The applicant was subsequently dismissed by the Prosecutor General for violating internal regulations.
- The domestic courts found in favour of the employer, stating that the applicant breached his duty of confidentiality.
- The European Court of Human Rights ruled in 2008 that the applicant's dismissal infringed his right to freedom of expression.
- Moldova was ordered to pay damages and expenses.
- The applicant was reinstated in 2008, but was dismissed again on the grounds of a new Prosecutor General's appointment.
- The applicant contested the order of dismissal, but his action was dismissed by both the Court of Appeal and Supreme Court of Justice.
- The applicant alleged that his being dismissed again amounted to a failure by the State to comply with the Court's judgment of 2008.
- The procedure for supervising the execution of the 2008 judgment is ongoing before the Committee of Ministers.

title: CASE OF MOCKUTĖ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and grew up in Šiauliai.
- In 1992, the applicant was diagnosed with acute paranoid reaction disorder.
- She was treated at various psychiatric institutions between 1992 and 1996 for acute paranoid psychosis, paranoia, and moderately severe endogenous depression.
- In May 2002, the applicant’s father became ill with cancer, causing her distress and sleep problems.
- In February 2003, the applicant visited the Ojas Meditation Centre, where she started meditating and found inner spiritual and emotional healing.
- On 7 May 2003, the applicant suddenly became agitated and stressed at work, resulting in her being forcibly taken to Vilnius Psychiatric Hospital.
- From 8 May to 5 June 2003, the applicant was placed under strict patient and care regimes at the hospital.
- From 13 May to 26 June 2003, she was allowed to take walks on her own within the hospital grounds at certain times.
- The applicant attended the Ojas Meditation Centre according to her medical record dated 26 May 2003.
- The Srovės programme was aired on 17 June 2003, alleging that the Ojas Meditation Centre had a destructive influence on the applicant’s mental health.

title: CASE OF IŞIK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977.
- On 25 April 1999, the applicant was arrested and placed in police custody on suspicion of membership of an illegal organisation and the murder of thirteen persons, and underwent a medical examination.
- On 26 April 1999, the police officers took statements from the applicant in the absence of a lawyer, where she confessed and admitted to the charges.
- On 27 April 1999, the applicant was required to confront with two other co-accused before the police, again in the absence of a lawyer, and admitted to carrying out the attack on the shopping center.
- On the same day, an identification parade took place, and one of the eyewitnesses identified the applicant.
- On the same day, the applicant was also required to participate in a reconstruction of the events, where she described in detail what steps she had taken before the attack on the shopping center.
- On 30 April 1999, the applicant was seen by a doctor at the Forensic Medicine Institution who noted in his report that the applicant bore no traces of ill-treatment and was detained on remand.
- On 6 May 1999, the public prosecutor filed an indictment and charged the applicant with carrying out activities for the purpose of bringing about the secession of part of the national territory.
- The state security courts were later abolished by Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004, and the case was transferred to the Istanbul Assize Court.
- On 7 May 2007, the Istanbul Assize Court convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced her to life imprisonment, relying on several items of evidence, such as the applicant’s statements to the police, public prosecutor, and investigating judge, video recordings, written records of the crime scene visits, autopsy reports, eyewitness identifications, and the statements given by some of the accused persons.
- On 7 May 2009, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first instance court.

title: CASE OF AYDEMİR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and is detained in Tekirdağ.
- The applicant was arrested for possession of a fake identity card during an operation against the PKK on 13 February 1999.
- The applicant was interrogated by police officers at Istanbul Security Headquarters on 15 February 1999 in the absence of a lawyer.
- The applicant confessed to being a member of the PKK and participating in armed activities during the interrogation.
- The applicant was questioned by the Istanbul public prosecutor on 18 February 1999 and made a statement admitting to being a member of the PKK and engaging in activities to collect money for the organization in Istanbul. However, he later claimed that he made the confession under duress.
- The applicant was questioned by the investigating judge on the same day and confirmed the statement made to the public prosecutor, but withdrew the one made to the police. The investigating judge ordered the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- The Diyarbakır State Security Court filed an indictment against the applicant on 19 March 1999 under Article 125 of the former Turkish Criminal Code with membership of an illegal organization and involvement in separatist activities.
- The case was transferred to the Istanbul State Security Court by the Diyarbakır State Security Court on 5 June 1999.
- The applicant complained of not being able to prepare his defense because he was not allowed to see his lawyer on 18 February 2000.
- The applicant denied all the charges against him during a hearing on 1 September 2000.
- The applicant stated in a hearing on 14 November 2001 that he was a member of the illegal organization, but had engaged in only political activities for the organization and not armed activities.
- Another set of criminal proceedings against the applicant, pending since 1994, was merged with the one initiated in 1999 on 1 July 2003.
- The State Security Courts were abolished by Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004, and the case was transferred to the Istanbul Assize Court.
- The Istanbul Assize Court found the applicant guilty of committing an offense under Article 125 of the former Criminal Code and sentenced him to life imprisonment on 16 September 2004.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the decision on 3 May 2005 due to insufficient details in the decision and lack of necessary official reports.
- The applicant was retried before the Istanbul Assize Court, and his request to examine a witness was rejected on

title: CASE OF SHATOKHIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lived in the Altay region.
- At the time of the incident, the applicant was serving a sentence for robbery in correctional colony no. LIU-8 in the Altay region.
- The applicant attempted suicide on three separate occasions in 2004.
- A prison psychiatrist diagnosed the applicant with mental health issues in July 2004, and recommended against solitary confinement.
- Despite the recommendation, the applicant was placed in a punishment cell for thirteen days in May 2005.
- The applicant went on a hunger strike in protest against his solitary confinement.
- The prison doctor on duty examined the applicant and found him fit for confinement as long as he was not left alone.
- Despite the doctor's recommendation, the applicant was left alone in his cell and went on to open his veins with his teeth.
- The applicant requested the initiation of criminal proceedings against wardens on duty but was refused by the deputy prosecutor of Barnaul.
- The prosecutor's office found that the applicant was lawfully placed in a punishment cell but the wardens had disrespected the doctor's recommendation.
- The prosecutor of Barnaul conducted an additional inquiry and also refused to initiate criminal proceedings against the wardens.
- The applicant challenged the prosecutor's decision before the Tsentralniy District Court of Barnaul but the decision was upheld.
- The Altay Regional Court also upheld the decision on appeal.

title: CASE OF SELAMI AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- On 26 August 2002, police detained Mr S. Selami and severely beat him, causing serious injuries to his head including a brain haemorrhage and coma.
- Mr S. Selami was taken to Skopje Hospital for brain surgery, where he remained in a coma for two weeks.
- The applicants contacted the Ministry of the Interior seeking information about Mr S. Selami's whereabouts and were informed that he had been admitted to Skopje Hospital.
- Mr S. Selami was ordered to pre-trial detention on 31 August 2002, and his detention was extended on three occasions until 18 October 2002.
- Mr S. Selami was indicted for membership of a terrorist group but released on bail due to the serious deterioration of his health on 10 December 2002.
- The trial court discontinued the criminal proceedings against Mr S. Selami on 9 September 2003, and he contacted the Ministry of Justice for an out-of-court settlement and payment of damages.
- Mr S. Selami and the applicants submitted lawsuits claiming pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages in relation to his unlawful detention and physical ill-treatment by the police.
- The Gostivar Court of First Instance awarded Mr S. Selami the equivalent of EUR 18,000 in non-pecuniary damages for unjustified detention and rejected the remaining claims.
- The Skopje Court of Appeal awarded Mr S. Selami the equivalent of EUR 9,800 in non-pecuniary damages for the unjustified detention and rejected the remaining claims.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicants' appeal on points of law, finding no grounds to depart from the established facts and reasoning of the lower courts.

title: CASE OF PARAZAJDER v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former lawyer from Zagreb born in 1950.
- Secret surveillance measures were used by the authorities in intercepting and recording the applicant's telephone conversations and messages in relation to the Croatian Privatisation Fund's vice-president.
- The surveillance was authorized through orders issued by an investigating judge of the Zagreb County Court.
- On June 16, 2007, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of corruption involving officials of the Fund and others.
- On February 12, 2008, the State Attorney’s Office indicted the applicant and nine others in the Zagreb County Court on charges of bribe-taking, offering bribes, and abuse of power and authority.
- The applicant challenged the lawfulness of the secret surveillance orders during the hearings.
- On May 15, 2009, the Zagreb County Court found the applicant guilty as charged and sentenced him to three years' imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed the trial court’s ruling to the Supreme Court on September 24 and 28, 2009.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal on February 17, 2010.
- The applicant filed a constitutional complaint before the Constitutional Court on April 22, 2010.
- On February 21, 2012, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s complaints, and the decision was served on February 23, 2012.

title: CASE OF LITVINYUK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Simferopol, she is a single mother and has a son.
- The applicant was knocked down by a trolley bus on 24 July 1995, which resulted in an open craniocerebral injury and contusion of the brain.
- In January 1996, the applicant initiated a legal proceeding to claim compensation for the damages incurred due to the accident.
- The applicant claimed compensation for medicines, additional nutrition, treatment in a sanatorium, transport expenses, and compensation for loss of earnings.
- On 25 February 2003, the applicant submitted a complaint to the court, alleging a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, due to the lengthy examination of her case by the domestic courts.
- On 1 February 2007, while the proceedings were still pending before the national courts, the Court delivered a judgment on the applicant’s first application, finding that the length of the proceedings had been excessive.
- The compensations for the applicant's loss of earnings and for expenses sustained as a result of her poor health were of undeniable importance for the applicant.
- On 10 November 2009, the Simferopolskiy District Court left the applicant's case without consideration because she had failed to appear in court without giving plausible reasons on 28 October 2009 and 10 November 2009.
- The applicant lodged an appeal against this decision stating that she had not been aware of the above-mentioned hearings.

title: CASE OF CHUMAK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Stryzhavka, born in 1968.

- On 12 September 2006, as the chairman of the Chumatskyy Shlyakh civic youth association, the applicant submitted a written notice to the mayor of Vinnytsia for holding a picket in front of the regional authority building.
 
- The Association started the picket as planned on 14 September 2006. 

- The Leninskiy District Court allowed the claim and prohibited the Association from organizing and carrying out peaceful assemblies in the streets and squares of Vinnytsia.

- The protesters were dispersed by the police on 15 September 2006. 

- On 22 November 2006, the Vinnytsia Regional Court of Appeal upheld the findings of fact of the District Court but found that the sanction imposed on the protesters had been disproportionate. 

- On 1 April 2009, the Higher Administrative Court of Ukraine dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law.

title: CASE OF MIKHAYLOVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant had appeared before the Nova Kakhovka Court in previous cases either as a party or representative.
- In December 2006, one of the judges of the court ordered the applicant to pay damages to the municipal utilities company’s in-house lawyer Ms S. for defamation.
- In 2007, the municipal utilities company instituted proceedings against the applicant seeking recovery of utilities arrears.
- On 1 June 2007, a preliminary hearing in that case was held before Judge M, sitting in a single-judge formation, which was audio-recorded at the applicant’s request.
- At the opening of the hearing, the applicant challenged the judge and accused her of delivering unlawful judgments and making unlawful actions, as well as demonstrating clear contempt for the court.
- The applicant was charged with contempt of court and found guilty, resulting in a five-day administrative detention.
- The case was reviewed by the First Vice-President of the Kherson Regional Court of Appeal, who upheld the judgment.
- The article entitled “Father for son, brother for brother” was published in the Delovye Novosti newspaper and was referred to by the applicant in her challenge of Judge M.

title: CASE OF PATALAKH v. GERMANY
facts:
1. Arrest warrant issued against the applicant on 30 October 2013 on suspicion of committing crimes worth several million euros.
2. The applicant was married to a co-accused and did not have any significant ties with Germany, hence the risk of him absconding and collusion.
3. The District Court ordered his detention on remand on the same day he was arrested.
4. Several additional charges were included in the arrest warrant on 11 September 2014.
5. Criminal proceedings were brought against the applicant on 19 December 2014 and the main proceedings commenced on 8 June 2015.
6. The applicant was convicted on five counts each of aiding fraudulent conversion and tax evasion and sentenced to four years and six months’ imprisonment on 14 July 2016.
7. The Frankfurt am Main District Court set aside the arrest warrant of 30 October 2013 on 26 October 2016.
8. The applicant challenged the lawfulness of his remand detention without success.
9. The Frankfurt am Main Court of Appeal extended the applicant’s remand detention in July 2014, and the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint which was refused.
10. The applicant lodged a complaint of bias against two of the three judges concerned, which was eventually rejected as ill-founded.
11. The applicant lodged three constitutional complaints with the Federal Constitutional Court, which were all refused without providing reasons.

title: CASE OF ILIAȘ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
• List of applicants including relevant details are provided in the appended table.

• Applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.

title: CASE OF CHIRIAC AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants and details are provided in an appended table
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
- Some applicants raised other complaints under Article 3

title: CASE OF DANDAYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants and their applications with details available
- The applicants complained of the inadequate conditions of their detention
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KHLYSTOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document contains a table with a list of applicants and relevant details of their applications
- The applicants were parties to civil proceedings
- The domestic courts failed to ensure their participation in hearings
- The applicants filed complaints about the courts' failure to ensure their participation in the hearings.

title: CASE OF DIMITAR MITEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant had previous convictions for theft.
- A neighbour of the applicant's parents, a seventy-five-year-old lady, was murdered in her house, and some of her personal possessions were stolen from the house.
- The applicant was suspected of having committed the offence and was arrested.
- During his arrest, force was used, and the applicant suffered bruises and haematomas.
- The applicant confessed to the murder and stealing some personal possessions; he also confessed to stealing a gun on a separate occasion.
- The confession became one of the pillars of the indictment as there was no other evidence showing the course of events inside the victim's house.
- The murder investigation continued over the following months, and the applicant was charged in connection with the two offenses - murder and theft.
- The Regional Court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
- The Varna Court of Appeal upheld the conviction and sentence.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation also upheld the Court of Appeal's judgment.

title: CASE OF ZALIZKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Relevant details of the application are in the appended table.
- Applicant complained of non-enforcement of domestic decisions against unitary enterprise and lack of effective remedy.
- Assets of the unitary enterprise were transferred to federal treasury enterprise without debts transfer as per government's decree and orders of the ministry.

title: CASE OF MOROZOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant application details provided in attached table.
- Applicants lodged complaint regarding excessive length of civil proceedings.
- Applicants raised concerns about lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- Additional complaints made under the Convention in applications 2318/07 and 65272/12.

title: CASE OF EBEDİN ABİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant has multiple health conditions and requires specific diets and living conditions
- Applicant is serving a term for terrorist offenses from 2008-2009
- Applicant had medical tests done in Erzurum hospital in July 2008
- Erzurum hospital’s health board issued a report pointing out that the prison should offer a wide choice of daily menus to meet the applicant’s dietary requirements
- Applicant complained about the quality of meals served in prison and requested the prison authorities to send samples to the Ministry of Justice and the Human Rights Commission of the Grande National Assembly of Turkey
- Prison disciplinary board rejected the complaint
- The applicant appealed against the decision and was dismissed by the Erzurum judge responsible for the execution of sentences and the Erzurum Assize Court
- Applicant lodged a complaint about the refusal of prison authorities to provide him with meals compatible with his medically prescribed diet and difficulty in obtaining medication
- Judge responsible for the execution of sentences allowed the applicant’s request to examine the standard menu by a dietician
- The prosecutor appealed against the decision and was successfully able to quash the decision given by the judge responsible for the execution of sentences
- Weekly lists of standard menus for the weeks of 24 February 2009 and 3 March 2009 show that the meals served to prisoners did not meet the applicant’s dietary requirements.

title: CASE OF MIROVNI INŠTITUT v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant institute is a private institute that carries out research in the field of social sciences.
- In 2003, the Ministry of Education made two calls for tenders for scientific research projects.
- The applicant institute submitted a tender for research in the field of social sciences.
- The Ministry decided that the applicant institute would not be awarded any funding.
- The applicant institute applied to the Administrative Court, seeking the setting aside of the Ministry’s decision.
- The action was granted by a decision of 4 April 2007, and the case was remitted to the Ministry for reconsideration.
- The Ministry again decided that the applicant institute would not be awarded any funding, and the applicant lodged another action before the Administrative Court on account of the Ministry's failure to adopt a decision within the prescribed time-limit.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the applicant institute's action without a hearing.
- The court dismissed the applicant's claims, citing section 71(2) of the Administrative Dispute Act.
- The Supreme Court rejected the applicant's appeal as inadmissible.
- The applicant then lodged a constitutional complaint that was dismissed by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF GİRİŞEN v. TURKEY
facts:
1. The applicant was born in 1979 and is detained in Diyarbakır.
2. Arrest on 23 December 2001 on suspicion of being a member of an illegal organization, Hizbullah.
3. Alleged ill-treatment by police officers during detention, including electric shocks to testicles.
4. Confession during interrogation on 25 December 2001, in the absence of a lawyer.
5. Applicant's denial of confession statement given to the police while giving a statement to the public prosecutor on December 26, 2001.
6. Applicant alleges ill-treatment and coerced statements while being questioned by the investigating judge on the same day.
7. Medical report from Bağlar Health Clinic dated the same day stated that there was no sign of violence.
8. The court ordered pre-trial detention at the end of the hearing on the same day.
9. On 9 January 2002, the public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment under Article 146 of the former Turkish Criminal Code.
10. First hearing on the merits of the case on 19 March 2002.
11. Criminal complaint filed against police officers by the applicant on 27 January 2004.
12. State Security Courts abolished by Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004.
13. The case was transferred to the Diyarbakır Assize Court.
14. On 25 June 2004, the criminal proceedings were discontinued against the police officers due to a lack of evidence.
15. First-instance courts ordered the applicant to be kept in detention while examining the case.
16. Applicant convicted on 12 June 2008 and sentenced to life imprisonment, which was reduced to twenty years due to being a minor at the time of the offense.
17. Court of Cassation quashed the decision on 18 January 2010.
18. Applicant's application for release dismissed on 9 April 2010.
19. On 30 September 2010, jurisdiction was transferred to the Diyarbakır Juvenile Court.
20. Applicant was released pending trial on 2 November 2010.
21. Applicant found guilty on 5 June 2012 and sentenced to sixteen years and eight months of imprisonment.
22. The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment on 17 June 2014.

title: CASE OF CANŞAD AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1974, 1973 and 1972 respectively.
- On 4 May 1995, a group of about fifteen individuals marched in a street in the Küçükçekmece district of Istanbul, carrying banners from the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and throwing Molotov cocktails at various shops. Three girls were killed in one of these shops.
- The first applicant was arrested on the same day, and evidence was obtained from several witnesses.
- Three witnesses identified the first applicant as having thrown Molotov cocktails at the shop where three people were killed.
- The first applicant admitted his involvement in the march but denied having thrown Molotov cocktails.
- The second applicant was arrested and admitted his participation in the events of 4 May 1995, including throwing a Molotov cocktail at a shop.
- The applicants denied the charges against them during the criminal proceedings before the Istanbul State Security Court.
- The trial court heard several witnesses, and the trial court decided to continue the applicants' detention at the end of each hearing.
- The applicants were initially sentenced to death, but the judgment was quashed twice on procedural grounds.
- A.A. retracted his previous testimony and stated that he had not identified anyone.
- The applicants were ultimately found guilty of the offense provided for in Article 125 of the Criminal Code and sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: CASE OF GREGURIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant lives in Kutina.
- The applicant worked for C.N.S Ltd. from 1 January 2001.
- The applicant had been in continuous employment for more than seven years and seven months.
- The employer returned the applicant's employment registration book on 5 June 2009 without any written or oral notice of termination.
- The applicant filed a civil action on 20 July 2009 asking the court to recognize that he had an open-ended contract of employment and to order his reinstatement.
- The first-instance court dismissed the claim as time-barred on 22 January 2010.
- The Velika Gorica County Court quashed the first-instance decision and remitted the case for fresh consideration on 16 February 2011.
- The Ivanić Grad Municipal Court declared the applicant's action inadmissible due to exceeding the time limit on 6 May 2011.
- The Velika Gorica County Court upheld the first-instance decision on 26 July 2011.
- The applicant's appeal on points of law was dismissed by the Supreme Court on 25 September 2012.
- The applicant filed a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court on 14 March 2013.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's constitutional complaint as manifestly ill-founded on 6 May 2013.

title: CASE OF SMOLIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1934 and lives in Stari Mikanovci.
- The applicant was an employee of the State’s railway company, Hrvatske željeznice, who suffered a work-related accident and became unable to work.
- On 26 April 1977, the Osijek County Court awarded the applicant a lump sum in compensation and ordered Hrvatske željeznice to make monthly payments to him in respect of the difference between his disability pension and the salary he would have been earning if he were able to work.
- On 5 May 1988, the Vukovar Municipal Court increased the monthly payments but established that the applicant’s inability to work was only 50% due to his work-related accident and 50% due to a pre-existing illness.
- On 24 December 1990, the applicant instituted civil proceedings against Hrvatske željeznice, seeking an increase in monthly payments.
- The first-instance court allowed the claim partly on 24 April 1991, but the second-instance court overturned the decision and remitted the case to the first-instance court.
- The first-instance court commissioned a report from an accounting expert, and at a subsequent hearing, the expert witness gave oral evidence.
- After the Croatian Pension Fund adjusted the applicant’s pension on 22 December 2003, the expert witness submitted an additional report.
- On 3 May 2005, the Vukovar County Court quashed the first-instance judgment of 23 January 2004, 
- The first-instance court commissioned another report from an accounting expert, but later dismissed the applicant’s claim on the ground that he failed to pay for the costs of the expert report.
- The second-instance court upheld the first-instance judgment, and the Supreme Court declared the applicant’s appeal inadmissible.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court, which declared it inadmissible.

title: CASE OF TEYMURAZYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Yerevan.
- The applicant was found guilty of indecent acts with minors in 1983 and 1988 and sentenced to prison.
- In 2001, the Court of Cassation quashed the two judgments and terminated both sets of criminal proceedings against the applicant on the grounds of absence of corpus delicti.
- The applicant lodged two civil claims against the state in 2001 seeking compensation, and both claims were allowed in 2001 and 2005.
- The applicant was suspected of assaulting two traffic-police officers in 2005, and he was arrested and charged under the same article.
- The two police officers were recognized as victims, and a forensic medical examination of the applicant found that he had suffered injuries, including concussion and a fractured cheek bone.
- The applicant's lawyer alleged that it had been the applicant who had been assaulted instead of the other way around.
- The Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan acquitted the applicant in 2006 and found that police officers V.S. and G.G. had exceeded their authority by acting violently against the applicant.
- The applicant lodged a complaint seeking to annul the investigator’s decision of 21 June 2005.
- The Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan and the Criminal Court of Appeal both dismissed the applicant's civil claims seeking further compensation.
- The applicant lodged another civil claim against the state in 2009 seeking compensation for pecuniary damage suffered as a result of his ill-treatment.

title: CASE OF FALZON v. MALTA
facts:
-Facts related to the applicant's background as a former member of parliament and government minister, as well as his current career in media and opinion writing.
-The deputy leader of the Malta Labour Party claimed to have received threatening letters and an anonymous email, which he reported to the Commissioner of Police.
-The applicant published an opinion article expressing concerns about the way political parties perceive the police force and criticized the deputy leader's use of the police to investigate a trivial matter.
-The deputy leader of the MLP sued the applicant for defamation and sought damages.
-The Court of Magistrates found the applicant guilty of defamation and fined him.

title: CASE OF IGRANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants were detained in Russian penal facilities 
- They were claimants in separate sets of civil proceedings 
- Applicants were seeking compensation for various aspects of their detention or lack of medical care 
- None of the applicants were able to attend their claim hearings 
- The domestic courts at both levels of jurisdiction refused to allow them to be present 
- Claims were refused at two levels of jurisdiction.

title: CASE OF NOVAKOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1925, 1927, and 1930, respectively.
- They live in Budva.
- The applicants lodged a civil claim with the Court of First Instance in Kotor seeking compensation for nationalised property in 1948.
- The Court of First Instance ruled against the applicants on 16 July 2008.
- The High Court in Podgorica upheld the decision of the First Instance Court on appeal, which was made on 2 October 2009.
- The Supreme Court of Montenegro rejected the applicants' appeal on points of law on 19 January 2011, and the decision was served on the applicants on 15 March 2011.

title: CASE OF MONTEMLIN ŠAJO v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant company is a privately owned company registered in Danilovgrad, Montenegro.
- A call for tender for hotel "Otrant" in Montenegro was issued in July 2004, and the deadline for submitting bids was October 2004.
- The applicant company, along with three other companies, participated in the tendering process.
- On 30 November 2004, the applicant company was informed that the tender was awarded to another bidder.
- The applicant company objected to this decision in December 2004, but the Commercial Court in Podgorica rejected the objection on 29 December 2004.
- The Court of Appeal quashed this decision on 28 January 2006 and remitted the case to the first instance.
- On 15 June 2006, the Commercial Court ruled against the applicant company, and this decision was served on the applicant company on 8 September 2009.
- On 26 March 2010, the Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Commercial Court.
- The applicant company lodged an initiative urging the Supreme Public Prosecutor's Office to file a request for the protection of legality on 15 July 2010, but this motion was rejected on 21 July 2010.
- The applicant company lodged a constitutional appeal on 30 July 2010, which was rejected as being lodged out of time on 14 October 2010 by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF ŞAHİN ALPAY v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a journalist who had been working for a newspaper viewed as part of the "Gülenist" network.
- He had been known for his critical views on the serving government's policies prior to the attempted military coup of 15 July 2016.
- During the attempted coup, soldiers under the "Peace at Home Council" bombarded State buildings, attacked the hotel where the President was staying, held the Chief of General Staff hostage, attacked television channels, and fired shots at demonstrators.
- The national authorities subsequently blamed the network linked to Fetullah Gülen for the coup and several investigations were initiated.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of belonging to an illegal organization on 27 July 2016.
- Despite denying the accusations in court, he was ordered to pre-trial detention by a magistrate based on the contents of his articles.
- The criminal proceedings are currently pending before the Istanbul 13th Assize Court.
- The applicant lodged an individual application with the Constitutional Court, which held that there had been a violation of his right to liberty and security, and his right to freedom of expression and of the press.
- The Constitutional Court found there was no strong evidence that the applicant had committed an offence and that his pre-trial detention was disproportionate to the strict exigencies of the situation.

title: CASE OF MALIMONENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Kharkiv, Ukraine.
- In 1999, he obtained a Russian passport.
- On 29 December 2006, the Leninskiy District Court of Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine, ordered to arrest and bring the applicant to the court in order to determine the preventive measure during the investigation of his alleged robbery. 
- The applicant’s name was put on the international list of wanted persons.
- On 26 September 2007, the applicant was arrested in Moscow. As the applicant was a Russian national, he was released. 
- On 14 October 2007, the Ukrainian authorities sought the applicant’s extradition from Russia in relation to the criminal proceedings against him. 
- On 21 December 2007, the Russian Federal Migration Authority concluded that the applicant had fraudulently obtained his Russian passport by falsifying a number of documents. They ordered to seize his passport and put his name on the federal wanted list. 
- The applicant’s subsequent attempts to challenge the Federal Migration Authority’s decision on his Russian passport were unsuccessful. 
- On 13 May 2008, the applicant was arrested. 
- On 15 May 2008, a prosecutor authorized his detention considering that the decision of 29 December 2006 of the Leninskiy District Court of Dnepropetrovsk had authorized the applicant’s “placement into custody”, as mentioned in Article 61 § 1 of the Minsk Convention. 
- On 24 June 2008, a district prosecutor decided that the applicant should be “placed in custody” considering that the decision of the Leninskiy District Court of Dnepropetrovsk of 29 December 2006 authorized “placement into custody”, as required under Article 466 § 2 of the Russian Code of Criminal Procedure (“the CCrP”). 
- On 6 June 2009, a Ukrainian court refused to order the applicant’s detention pending the investigation. 
- The applicant was released. 
- On 3 October 2008, the Russian Prosecutor General’s Office granted the extradition request. 
- On 18 November 2008, the Moscow City Court confirmed the decision of 3 October 2008. 
- On 29 January 2009, the Supreme Court of Russia upheld the judgment of 18 November 2008 on appeal.
- On 20 May 2009, the applicant was transferred to the Ukrainian authorities in the town

title: CASE OF MEHMET HASAN ALTAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is an economics professor and journalist who presented a political discussion programme on a TV channel that was closed down after the attempted military coup in Turkey in 2016.
- The attempted military coup of 15 July 2016 aimed at overthrowing the democratically elected parliament, government, and President of Turkey, resulting in over 300 deaths and 2,500 injuries.
- The national authorities blamed the network linked to Fetullah Gülen, a Turkish citizen living in Pennsylvania, and leader of a terrorist organization known as FETÖ/PDY.
- The government declared a state of emergency for three months, which was subsequently extended.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of having links to the media wing of the FETÖ/PDY terrorist organization.
- The applicant was refused access to his lawyers during his first five days in custody, and police officers searched his home without his lawyers being present.
- The applicant was questioned on suspicion of attempting to overthrow the government, being a member of a terrorist organization, and other accusations.
- The applicant's pre-trial detention was ordered based on strong suspicions, the nature of the alleged offences, the risk of absconding, and the risk that alternative measures to detention might be insufficient to ensure his participation in the criminal proceedings.
- The applicant repeatedly challenged his pre-trial detention, but all applications were rejected by the magistrates' courts.
- The applicant was sentenced to aggravated life imprisonment for attempting to overthrow the constitutional order.
- The Constitutional Court gave a judgment that there had been a violation of the right to liberty and security and the right to freedom of expression and of the press, and his pre-trial detention was disproportionate to the strict exigencies of the situation.

title: CASE OF ÖZTOP AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants are Turkish nationals serving prison sentences in various establishments
- Applicants were found guilty of breaching prison order by decisions of the respective disciplinary boards of prisons in which they were held.
- Applicants were sentenced to solitary confinement for between 11 to 15 days on the orders of the board.
- Objections to the sentences were rejected by Enforcement Judges and Assize Courts without hearing the applicants or their lawyers, pursuant to Law no. 4675 on Enforcement Judges, dated 16 May 2001.

title: CASE OF LEBEDEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant lodged a claim for a housing subsidy and compensation of non-pecuniary damage against the Government of the Republic of Sakha (Yakutiya).
- The Town Court dismissed the claims in February 2001, which was upheld on appeal by the Supreme Court in April 2001.
- Following supervisory review appeals in April 2005 and January 2006, lower courts misjudged the facts of the case and erred in the application of national law.
- The case was remitted for new examination multiple times as lower courts misapplied national law and the applicant had not been duly summoned to the hearing.
- Eventually, the Town Court ordered the payment of RUB 1,812,838.10 from the federal budget funds allocated for housing subsidies for persons leaving high north regions in September 2008.
- The writ of execution was repeatedly sent to different bodies, but the enforcement proceedings were terminated as the debtor had no property to recover the debt from.
- The applicant lodged a claim for compensation under the Compensation Act, but it was dismissed as the court stated that the proceedings ended before the Act's entry into force.

title: CASE OF VOYKIN AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1978 and was a district police officer at the time of the events.
- The second applicant is the wife of the first applicant, born in 1984, and her mother, the third applicant, was born in 1951.
- The fourth applicant, the mother of the first applicant, was born in 1948 and died on 5 December 2010.
- The second applicant had a conflict with a police officer, M., who was a colleague of her husband, in June 2008.
- The second applicant alleged that M. had strangled and hit her twice in the head, and that he referred to the presence of a local prosecutor as a guarantee of his impunity.
- M. denied these allegations and stated that the second applicant had insulted and pushed him.
- The Kalyninskyy police refused to institute criminal proceedings in respect of the second applicant’s complaint initially but quashed that decision after investigation.
- The prosecutor's office subsequently refused to initiate criminal proceedings against M. after holding that there were no constituent elements of a crime discernible in his actions and relying on the forensic medical expert evaluations.
- The first applicant was later accused of abuse of power and forgery and was declared wanted by the police in September 2008.
- The first applicant submitted requests related to his case to the prosecutor's office.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDR ALEKSANDROV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and lives in Cheboksary.
- The Chertanovskiy District Court found the applicant guilty of kicking a police officer while intoxicated.
- The offence is an offence under Article 318(1) of the Criminal Code.
- The court sentenced the applicant to one year’s imprisonment.
- The court took into account the nature and degree of the social danger of the offence, all the circumstances of the case, and the information regarding the defendant’s personality when making the sentencing decision.
- The court did not find any grounds for sentencing the applicant to probation or imposing a fine on him.
- The applicant appealed, claiming that he had been discriminated against by the trial court’s refusal to impose a non-custodial sentence.
- The Moscow City Court dismissed the appeal.

title: CASE OF SHIMOKHIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants and their relevant details in an appended table.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention. 
- Some of the applicants raised additional complaints under Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SMOLKO v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Trnava
- The civil proceedings were initiated on 5 May 2008 before the Bratislava I District Court
- The proceedings concern alleged discrimination in remuneration and the claim for compensation for non-pecuniary damage
- The proceedings have been processed before two levels of jurisdiction
- The applicant complained of the excessive length of the proceedings which are still pending

title: CASE OF PROKHORENKO AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
-There is a table with a list of applicants and details of their applications. 

-The applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions. 

-One of the applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF LASTOCHKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table listing the applicants and relevant application details was provided.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Some of the applicants also had other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

facts:

- Relevant details of applications
- Complaints about inadequate conditions of detention.

title: CASE OF BOLDIJAR AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
• A table is appended which contains a list of applicants and the corresponding application details.
• The applicants complained about the insufficient conditions of their confinement.

facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and their relevant details is provided.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

facts:

- The applicants complained about inadequate conditions of their detention.

facts:

- The applicants raised concerns about the lengthy civil proceedings.
- The applicants also complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF RASHITOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details are provided in a table
- Applicants complain about excessive length of criminal proceedings
- Lack of effective remedy in domestic law
- Additional complaint raised by one applicant under provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BELKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their application details provided in the appendix.
- Applicants complained about the prolonged pre-trial detention.
- Specifically, in application no. 8344/12, the applicant filed a complaint under Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF NICHEPORUK AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document contains a list of applicants with their relevant details.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- The conditions were incompatible with their disabilities.
- In application no. 35782/12, the applicant raised additional complaints under the Convention.
- One of those complaints was regarding the lack of an effective remedy to complain about the poor conditions of detention.

title: CASE OF ARSENTYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants mentioned.
- A table is appended with relevant details of the applications.
- The applicants have filed a complaint.
- The subject of the complaint is the length of their pre-trial detention.
- The applicants are claiming that the pre-trial detention was excessive.

title: CASE OF ORLOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A list of applicants and their relevant application details are present in an appended table.
- The applicants have lodged a complaint about delayed enforcement of domestic decisions.
- The applicants have also expressed concern over the absence of an effective remedy in the domestic law.

facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details are given in a table.

facts:

- The applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
- Some applicants also made other complaints under Convention provisions.

facts:
- List of applicants and application details are provided in a table.
- Applicants complained of non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic judgments.

title: CASE OF S.C. POLYINVEST S.R.L. AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants and related details provided in a table
- Applicants complained about non-enforcement of domestic judgments
- One applicant specifically complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law

title: CASE OF DANILCZUK v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1965 and was detained in Czarne Prison in Poland.
- The applicant was placed in detention on remand at Nicosia Central Prisons on 14 September 2010 pending criminal proceedings against him before the Limassol District Court.
- On 11 January 2011, the applicant was convicted of a number of offences, including burglary, theft, various road traffic offences, and unlawful residence.
- The applicant was released on 18 May 2012 following the suspension of his sentence by virtue of a decree issued by the President of the Republic concerning a number of prisoners.
- The applicant had been held in overcrowded cells at Nicosia Central Prisons, where there was only 0.5 to 1.7 sq. m of personal space for each detainee.
- The applicant sometimes had to wait two to three hours to use the toilet and had to urinate into a bottle and defecate into a waste bag.
- The applicant was detained from 14 September 2010 until his release on 18 May 2012 in three different parts of Nicosia Central Prisons.
- Block 5 could accommodate up to sixty-eight remand prisoners and had thirty-four double occupancy cells measuring 6.21 sq. m, eight toilets and eight showers.
- Block 2B, where the applicant was detained between 24 January 2011 and 5 October 2011, had twenty-six double occupancy cells measuring 9.98 sq. m, two large cells measuring 19.55 sq. m, and a common room.
- Block 2A, where the applicant was transferred on 5 October 2011, had forty-one double occupancy cells, accommodating eighty-two prisoners.
- Detainees were free to move outside their cells in the closed prison, including the yard, workshops, kitchen, and school from 6 a.m. to 5 p.m. (winter time) or to 6 p.m. (summer time).
- Following the 2012 report of the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture, the prison administration discontinued the practice of switching off cell bells during the night, hence detainees had access to the toilets during those hours.

title: CASE OF ARČON AND OTHERS v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- Applicants were employed in Kombinat aluminijuma Podgorica.
- Applicants brought civil claims against employer for unpaid salaries.
- Claims were based on Collective Labour Agreement.
- First instance court joined and dismissed cases.
- Applicants lodged an appeal with the High Court.
- High Court upheld the decision of the first instance court.

title: CASE OF DUDIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant, Mr Sergey Marksovich Dudin, is a Russian national, born in 1962 and represented by a lawyer.
