- On 23 July 2007, he was apprehended by police for robbery and transferred to Krestsy, Novgorod Region.
- The Krestetskiy District Court of Novgorod Region ordered pre-trial detention on 25 July 2007, subsequently extended on 20 September and 2 November 2007.
- On 2 November 2007, the District Court authorised extension of the applicant’s detention “until and including 24 December 2007”.
- On 11 December 2007, the District Court scheduled a preliminary hearing for the applicant’s trial in order to decide on his further detention, with the measure of restraint - pre-trial detention - unchanged.
- On 25 December 2007, the District Court held a preliminary hearing ordering the criminal case to be sent to trial and the applicant’s further detention.
- The applicant and his representative objected to the lawfulness of the detention between 24 December 2007 and the time of the hearing, but the District Court dismissed it without specific reasons.
- The Novgorod Regional Court upheld the lower court’s decision, and the applicant was convicted of aggravated robbery and sentenced to six years’ imprisonment on 27 May 2008.
- The period of the applicant’s pre-trial detention between 23 June 2007 and the day of conviction was fully counted towards the execution of his sentence.
- On 2 March 2011, the applicant was released before serving his full sentence on probation.
- The applicant lodged a civil action seeking non-pecuniary damages for his allegedly unlawful detention between 24 and 25 December 2007.
- The Novgorodskiy Town Court of Novgorod Region found that the applicant’s detention was unlawful between 24 December 2007 and 11.00 a.m. on 25 December 2007 and awarded non-pecuniary damages of 2000 Russian roubles (50 euros).
- The Novgorod Regional Court adopted a new judgment dismissing the applicant’s claim, arguing that the decision of 11 December 2007 essentially ordered the detention until 25 December 2007 as it left it “unchanged”.

title: CASE OF MATVEYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lived in Naberezhniye Chelny prior to his conviction of an unrelated criminal offence.
- The applicant notified the executive committee of Naberezhniye Chelny of his intention to hold a public event in the form of a hunger strike in front of the local prosecutor’s office beginning from 21 April 2008.
- The head of the public relations department of the local executive committee informed the applicant that his planned public event amounted to a “picket” within the meaning of the Public Events Act (PEA).
- On 22 April 2008, the applicant held a solo demonstration at noon and continued it until 4 p.m., when he was arrested by the police.
- On 24 April 2008, the justice of the peace of the 8th Court Circuit of Naberezhniye Chelny found the applicant guilty under Article 20.2 § 1 of the CAO and imposed a fine of 1,000 Russian rubles (RUB), equivalent to 27 euros (EUR) at the time.
- The applicant appealed to the Naberezhniye Chelny Town Court. By a decision of 7 May 2008, the Town Court upheld the judgment of the justice of the peace.
- In separate proceedings, on 7 May 2008 the justice of the peace of the 1st Court Circuit of Naberezhniye Chelny found the applicant guilty under Article 19.3 § 1 of the CAO.
- The court sentenced him to seven days of administrative detention.
- The applicant appealed against the judgment to the Naberezhniye Chelny Town Court. On 8 May 2008, the Town Court upheld the judgment in a summary manner.
- On 3 June 2008, the applicant lodged a supervisory-review appeal against the judgment of 7 May 2008.
- On 8 July 2008, the Deputy President of the Supreme Court of the Tatarstan Republic dismissed the appeal, fully endorsing the findings of the lower courts.

title: CASE OF TREPASHKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a former FSB officer born in 1957 and living in Moscow.
- On May 19, 2004, the applicant was found guilty of disclosing state secrets and possessing illegal ammunition and was sentenced to four years in prison.
- On September 13, 2004, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the conviction on appeal.
- The applicant was ordered to serve his sentence in a correctional facility 1800 km away from his family home.
- The applicant was released on parole on August 19, 2005, but his release was challenged by the prosecution.
- On September 16, 2005, the Sverdlovsk Regional Court dismissed the applicant's appeal against the prosecutor's request to challenge his release on parole.
- The applicant was arrested on September 18, 2005, in his apartment in Moscow and was taken back to the correctional facility on September 22, 2005.
- The applicant was detained in a disciplinary cell measuring 8 sq. m and equipped with four sleeping places.
- The applicant was allowed two hours' exercise per day, provided with an individual sleeping place, and bed sheets, and the cell had windows with opening vents.
- According to the applicant and other inmates' statements, the cell housed between 3 and 7 inmates, had no bed linen or soap or detergent for cleaning the toilet, and was infested with mice and woodlice.
- The inmates did not receive newspapers, and food was of very poor quality and scarce. The daily outdoor exercise lasted between fifteen and forty minutes.
- The applicant complained to the prosecutor that his detention was in contravention of the applicable laws, but the complaint was dismissed.

title: CASE OF BOYAN GOSPODINOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested and placed in pre-trial detention on 30 August 2002 for the unlawful possession of cannabis.
- By judgment of 22 May 2003, he was sentenced to three-and-a-half years’ imprisonment by the Stara Zagora Regional Court but the Plovdiv Court of Appeal reduced it to one year’s imprisonment.
- Following his appeal, the judicial supervision was ordered, and the applicant was released on 7 April 2004.
- The applicant claimed damages of 11,500 Bulgarian Lev in 2004 for the excess period spent in pre-trial detention.
- The Sofia City Court initially adjourned the compensation case until the end of the second set of criminal proceedings and finally dismissed the applicant’s claims.
- On 14 October 2004, the Stara Zagora regional prosecutor’s office indicted the applicant for narcotics trafficking during the period from 21 March 2000 to 14 March 2002.
- In the trial, the applicant’s counsel requested the withdrawal of all the regional court judges, and the request was dismissed.
- By judgment of 3 October 2005, the regional court sentenced the applicant to sixteen years’ imprisonment for the unlawful purchase, possession, and sale of cannabis between March 2000 and March 2002.
- The applicant appealed, and the Plovdiv Court of Appeal reduced his sentence to ten years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law, and the Supreme Court of Cassation set the sentence to three years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF AGANIKYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1953 and lives in Yerevan.
- Investigator instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant for alleged usury on 30 December 2004.
- Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court ordered a search of the applicant’s apartment on 10 January 2005.
- Applicant was formally charged under Article 213 § 2 (1) and (2) of the CC with performing usury as a profession and preventive measure was taken on 20 June 2005.
- Investigator decided to confiscate for security the applicant’s property on 23 June 2005.
- Prosecutor refused to approve the bill of indictment on 15 August 2005.
- Investigator initiated another set of criminal proceedings on 15 October 2005.
- Handwriting examinations were conducted on 8 and 29 December 2005.
- Applicant received new charges on 7 March 2006.
- Applicant was detained for a period of two months on 28 March 2006.
- Applications for search warrant and to confiscate information were granted on 29 and 31 March and 13 April 2006.
- Supervising prosecutor approved the bill of indictment on 14 July 2006.
- Court held twelve hearings between 25 August 2006 and 11 October 2007.
- Applicant was released on bail on 9 July 2007.
- Powers of the judge in charge of the applicant’s case were suspended on 15 October 2007.
- Between 21 November 2007 and 23 December 2010, the court held forty hearings.
- Prosecutor decided to amend the charges and/or to bring new charges against the applicant on 28 August 2009 and 12 October 2010, respectively.
- The District Court gave judgment on 31 January 2011.
- The Criminal Court of Appeal rejected the appeals and upheld the District Court’s judgment on 3 October 2011.
- The Court of Cassation declared the appeal inadmissible on 21 November 2011 for lack of merit.

title: CASE OF CHRISTIAN BAPTIST CHURCH IN WROCŁAW v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant is a legal entity, a local community of the Christian Baptist Church.
- The property in question is a four-storey building and another building dedicated to sacral purposes in Wrocław.
- Property number 1077/42 measured 0.785 ha and was used by the Baptist Commune before World War II.
- The property was subject to the applicant church’s management in 1946 and then registered under the number 945 as its owner in 1956.
- In 1959, the District Residential Buildings Board ordered that the property pass into the ownership of the State, with the exception of the part dedicated to sacral purposes.
- A new land-register entry 35905 was opened for the property in 1966, and in 1968 it was registered under the land-register number 35905 and given a new plot number 9, which comprised only the building dedicated to sacral purposes.
- The remaining part of the original property was given new plot numbers 39 and 33/5, measuring 0.325 ha and transferred to the City of Wrocław in 1977.
- The applicant church requested a decision confirming ownership in 1996 and was refused on the basis of section 39 of the 1995 Act.
- The applicant church made various appeals and complaints about the delay in the decision-making process, which continued until 2008.
- The Governor's office finally gave a decision on the merits in 2007, refusing to return the property to the applicant church, which was upheld by the Minister of the Interior and Administration and the courts.

title: CASE OF DOKTOROV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Varna.
- The applicant and his wife divorced on 21 August 2006, and he agreed to pay child support to their two children and his wife kept his family name after the divorce.
- The applicant learned that the younger child born during the marriage was not biologically his and sought to contest his paternity in court.
- His request to contest paternity was dismissed by the Varna Regional Court due to time-barred limitations.
- The applicant sought to stop paying child support for the second child, but his claim was rejected by the Varna District Court.

title: CASE OF TILOCCA v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was caught carrying 563,300 euros which he had failed to declare while crossing the border between Serbia and Croatia.
- The customs authorities seized 560,000 euros and instituted administrative-offence proceedings against the applicant.
- The applicant explained that the money came from a company of which he was the director, and from the sale of their house in France.
- The Ministry requested information from relevant authorities in Serbia, France, and Italy, and found that the applicant was guilty of the offence and fined him 5,000 Croatian kunas.
- The Ministry imposed a protective measure confiscating EUR 318,500 under section 69(2) of the Foreign Currency Act.

title: CASE OF LIU v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and resides in Sovetskaya Gavan, Khabarovsk Region.
- On 22 October 2009, the applicant was arrested and taken to Khabarovsk Administrative Detention Centre where he stayed until 27 November 2009.
- The applicant was detained in a cell designed for 12 individuals, with over 12 inmates, mandated to take turns sleeping, later transferring to a cell shared with one inmate.
- The detention centre had no shower facilities, no outdoor activities, no mattresses covering iron banks, and no separation of the toilet from the living area. The food supply was insufficient, served once per day, and without drinking water accessible within the cell.
- The government stated that the detention centre consisted of two cells and that there was no overcrowding. The toilet was cordoned with a shoulder-length fence, and detainees could take a weekly shower. Kettles with boiled water were available in the cells, and the temperature was set at 23oC.
- On 26 October 2009, the applicant's wife attempted to visit him but was denied access. On 6 and 10 November 2009, she filed complaints with the Prosecutor's Office but did not get a response.
- In August 2010, the applicant filed a civil claim for compensation because the conditions of his detention had been inhuman and degrading, and that the prohibition on family visits was illegal.
- On 9 February 2011, the Industrialnyy District Court of Khabarovsk rejected his request, citing the lack of provisions for family visits in the administrative detention centre's Internal Rules.
- On 18 May 2011, the Khabarovsk Regional Court upheld the decision above on appeal.

title: CASE OF RUBTSOV AND BALAYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are residents of Moscow, born in 1965 and 1966 respectively.
- One applicant arranged for the sale of his company to another company, of which he was one of the indirect beneficial owners.
- The applicant was arrested on 1 October 2013 for suspicion of executing a sham sales contract, and that the company purchasing the applicant's company also belonged to the applicant.
- The Taganskiy District Court dismissed the applicant's argument against detention under Article 108 § 1.1 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the detention order on 21 October 2013 and on appeal, extensions of the applicant's detention.
- The Ostankinskiy District Court extended the applicant's detention on 28 March 2014, dismissing the applicant's argument that the offence was committed within the sphere of his business activity.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the detention extension order of 28 March 2014 on appeal.
- The applicant was granted bail on 10 April 2015 and released on April 17, 2015.
- A criminal investigation was opened on 15 September 2014 for the misappropriation of the funds of an insolvent bank.
- The applicant, who owned the bank, was arrested on 23 September 2014 on suspicion of transferring money out of the bank's account by acquiring unsecured promissory notes.
- The Tverskoy District Court authorised the applicant's detention on 25 September 2014 and rejected the argument that the offence was committed within the sphere of his business activity.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the detention order on appeal on 10 November 2014, dismissing the applicant's argument that the offence was committed within the sphere of his business activity.

title: CASE OF BISTIEVA AND OTHERS v. POLAND
facts:
- Ms Zita Bistieva and her three minor children were born in 1976, 2006, 2008 and 2013, respectively.
- In 2012, Ms Bistieva’s husband and two elder children arrived in Poland and applied for asylum for the family.
- On 6 March 2013, the head of the Aliens Office (Szef Urzędu do Spraw Cudzoziemców) decided not to grant refugee status to the family and ordered their expulsion from Poland. The decision was upheld by the Refugee Council on 10 May 2013.
- The family fled to Germany and had their case transferred back to Poland under the Dublin II Regulation.
- On 9 January 2014, Ms Bistieva and her children were placed in administrative detention at a guarded centre for aliens in Kętrzyn, Poland, pending their expulsion.
- The Kętrzyn centre was assessed to have good living conditions and adequate medical care, and provided education for children and adults.
- The detention was extended several times until 29 June 2014. Ms Bistieva appealed her detention, but her appeals were unsuccessful.
- The enforcement of the 2013 expulsion decision was temporarily suspended on 5 June 2014, and the applicants were released on 29 June 2014.
- The applicants left Poland for Germany, and their asylum proceedings in Poland were discontinued in October 2014. They did not bring an action for compensation for their detention.

title: CASE OF ELITA MAGOMADOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant gave birth to a son whose father was her partner.
- After their separation, they agreed that the son would live with the applicant and the father would visit regularly.
- The father took the boy to Grozny and prevented the applicant from seeing the child.
- The applicant applied for a residence order for the child, but the court granted it to the father instead.
- The childcare authorities found both parents suitable for raising the child but recommended the father to have the residence order.
- The applicant appealed but it was dismissed, and she was prevented from seeing her son.
- The report of the childcare authority of Grozny was later found to be based on incorrect and incomplete information.
- The applicant applied for the return of her child in 2015.
- The court granted her application, but the child and his paternal grandmother could not be found.
- The grandmother and child were placed on the list of wanted persons.
- The child was eventually returned to the applicant by the police.

title: CASE OF TSVETKOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Svetlana Ivanovna Tsvetkova lodged an application on 20 October 2008.
- On 1 January 2008, Officer S. escorted the applicant to the police station on suspicion of shoplifting. 
- The applicant was subjected to a humiliating body search and was kept in a small cell with no seats and no toilet.
- The applicant was released at different times according to her and the Government's claims.
- The applicant was not subsequently prosecuted for an administrative offence or a criminal offence.
- Aleksandr Vitalyevich Bgantsev lodged an application on 16 June 2008.
- On 30 August 2010, the applicant was taken to the police station on suspicion of using foul language at his work place.
- The applicant was sentenced to five days of detention and was held in small cells with no beds or bedding.
- Pavel Vladimirovich Andreyev lodged an application on 1 February 2013.
- The applicant was taken to the police station on suspicion of evading military service, but was charged with an administrative offence on account of an unpaid fine.
- The applicant was not released after the administrative-offence record had been drawn up and was placed in a detention centre.
- Aleksey Olegovich Dragomirov lodged an application on 5 September 2014.
- The applicant was arrested on 9 June 2008 for being intoxicated in public and was held in cells with no toilet or shower facilities.

title: CASE OF VLADIMIROVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is the founder, owner, and director of a grocery retail trade company called Akvilon.
- Akvilon purchased 5 tonnes of granulated sugar on credit in November 2001 to resell to Mr P. and Mr Pr. for 55,000 Russian roubles.
- Mr P. and Mr Pr. paid in cash and took possession of the sugar but claimed they had to fetch more cash to pay the balance.
- Mr V., the applicant's husband and a deputy director of Akvilon, reported the misappropriation of the sugar to the authorities.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted, and the investigators found the sugar with Mr P. and Mr Pr. but did not attach it formally, instead leaving it with the two men for safe storage.
- The prosecutor's office later ordered the attachment and seizure of the sugar, and eventually, it was transferred back to Akvilon for safe storage.
- Investigations were carried out into the negligent actions of the investigator, resulting in several complaints and court cases filed by Akvilon seeking compensation for pecuniary damage and damage to its business reputation.
- The court granted Akvilon's claim for pecuniary damage, and the Russian Ministry of Finance transferred the awarded amount to Akvilon's bank account in 2007.

title: CASE OF SIDORIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Three applicants born in 1985, 1988, and 1984 respectively.
- The first and second applicants lived in Moscow, while the third lived in Moscow region and died on 10th December 2007.
- On 11 March 2007, the applicants came to a polling station and disturbed the work of the station by unrolling banners, turning on smoke jets, and distributing leaflets.
- The applicants were arrested and brought to the Odintsovo police station around 10:35 am on the same day.
- The prosecutor’s office opened criminal proceedings against the applicants at around 3:30 pm on the same day.
- The police started to draw up arrest records in respect of the applicants at 6:30 pm on the same day.
- The applicants were remanded in custody on 13th March 2007 by the Odintsovo Town Court.
- The applicants filed an appeal against the detention orders and asked the detention facility administration to dispatch them.
- The investigator asked the Odintsovo Town Court to remand the applicants in custody on 13th March 2007.
- The Odintsovo Town Court found that the prosecutor’s applications had been supported by evidence showing the necessity of placing the applicants in custody.
- Counsel for the applicants lodged additional appeal submissions on 20th March 2007, complaining about the belated access to the case file.
- On 11 April 2007, the Moscow Regional Court held an appeal hearing and quashed the detention orders of 13th March 2007.
- On 12th April 2007, counsel asked the director of the detention facility to release the applicants, referring to the Regional Court’s order to release them.
- The appeal decisions were received by the detention facility on 13 April 2007, and the applicants were released on the same day.

title: CASE OF LESNIKOVICH v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was taken to the police station after his neighbors called the police reporting loud screams coming from his flat.
- The applicant was released on February 16, 2006, and summoned to appear before the investigator the next day at 2 p.m.
- The applicant was under constant supervision of police officers between 6 a.m. and 11 p.m. on February 16, 2006, and was not allowed to leave the police station.
- The Noyabrsk Town Court of the Yamalo-Nenetskiy Region dismissed the applicant's claim for compensation for unrecorded detention.
- The applicant became a suspect of rape, the investigator arrested him, and he was kept in the temporary detention center of the Noyabrsk police station between February 18, 2006, and June 22, 2006.
- The conditions in the temporary detention center were poor, with overcrowding, lack of light and ventilation, inadequate sanitation facilities, and infestation of bugs, lice, cockroaches, and rats.
- The Noyabrsk Town Court convicted the applicant of rape and sentenced him to six and a half years' imprisonment in a "strict-regime correctional colony."
- The dormitory where the applicant lived during his imprisonment in the correctional colony was infested with rats, and the sanitary facilities were extremely busy.
- The applicant was not represented in his civil proceedings against the Noyabrsk police station and the Russian Ministry of Finance, seeking compensation in respect of non-pecuniary damage resulting from the poor conditions of his detention.

title: CASE OF BEKTASHI COMMUNITY AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The Bektashi Order has practiced its religion in the respondent State for many centuries.
- The applicant association’s headquarters were at the “Teke Sersem Ali-Harabati Baba” in Tetovo.
- The applicant association was refused registration in 2010.
- The applicant association had previously practiced its religion in full compliance with relevant legislation at the time.
- On 31 July 1997, the Religious Communities and Groups Act entered into force and provided that the Commission for Religious Communities and Groups would be responsible for dealing with religious matters.
- On 25 August 1997, the Commission requested that the applicant association submit a copy of its application to be listed in the register of the Ministry and the related certificate of registration.
- On 4 September 1997, the applicant association contacted the Ministry, seeking a copy of all relevant documents related to its application submitted in 1993.
- On 23 June 2000, the Commission issued a certificate, attesting that the applicant association had filed “an application (пријава) in accordance with the 1997 Act”.
- By a decision of 18 July 2000, the State Statistics Office specified the applicant association’s main activities.
- In 2003, a local non-governmental organisation published the “Directory of Religious Communities in Macedonia”, which included the religious entities recorded in the Commission’s register.
- On 28 September 2007, the Legal Status of Churches, Religious Communities and Religious Groups Act 2007 entered into force.
- On 2 October 2009, the registration court dismissed the applicant association’s request to recognize its continuing legal status and record it in the court register.
- On 20 December 2010, the court refused to register the applicant association on the grounds that the intended name “Bektashi Religious Community of the Republic of Macedonia” contained the term “Bektashi” which had already been used by another religious entity.
- In a hearing held in private on 17 November 2011, the Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal and upheld the lower court’s decision.
- On 20 February 2012, the applicant association and the second applicant lodged a constitutional appeal with the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF CHIM AND PRZYWIECZERSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The first and second applicants were born in 1950 and 1946, respectively.
- The Foreign Debt Service Fund (FOZZ) was established in 1989 to collect and manage funds for Poland’s foreign debt repayment.
- The FOZZ was managed by its Director General, who had statutory authority to enter into contracts on its behalf.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the first and second applicants following a complaint by a German national.
- The first applicant was charged with misappropriation of FOZZ property and failure to perform her duties, while the second applicant was charged with misappropriation and theft of FOZZ property.
- The trial started in October 2000 before Judge B.P., who was later appointed Minister of Justice.
- The trial had to be restarted, and Judge A.K. was transferred from the 10th Appellate Division to the 8th Criminal Division to preside over it.
- The trial court convicted the first applicant of misappropriation of FOZZ property and failure to perform her duties, sentencing her to a cumulative term of six years’ imprisonment and a fine.
- The trial court convicted the second applicant of misappropriation and theft of FOZZ property and sentenced him to a cumulative term of three and a half years’ imprisonment and a fine.
- The applicants lodged appeals with the Warsaw Court of Appeal, alleging breach of procedural rules and lack of impartiality on the part of Judge A.K.
- The Supreme Court held that there had been a violation of the CCP in assigning Judge A.K. to the case, but it did not consider the violation to render the court “improperly constituted”.

title: CASE OF NAUMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants and their application details appended.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- Some applicants mentioned other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BOZHKOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document includes a list of applicants.
- Details of their applications are provided in the appended table.
- The applicants claimed that they were not given a chance to appear in person before the court in the civil proceedings where they were involved.
- Some of the applicants had additional complaints related to the Convention.

title: CASE OF KHAKIMOVY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants is provided in an appended table.
- Applicants' complaints of non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions.
- Applicants' complaints about a lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF ANGIROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were members of the National Bolsheviks Party. 
- On 14 December 2004, around forty members of the party, including the applicants, entered a waiting area in the President’s Administration building in Moscow, locked themselves in an office on the ground floor, and asked for a meeting with the President, the deputy head of the President’s Administration, and the President’s economic advisor. 
- The intruders stayed in the office for approximately one hour and a half until police broke through the door and arrested them. 
- The applicants were charged with participation in mass disorders, an offence under Article 212 § 2 of the Criminal Code. 
- On 20 June 2005, thirty-nine persons, including the applicants, were committed for trial before the Tverskoy District Court of Moscow. 
- During trial hearings, defendants were held in metal cages, making it difficult for confidential consultations with their counsel. 
- The trial resulted in a conviction for participation in mass disorders, and various terms of imprisonment for the defendants, ranging from one year and six months to three years of probation, up to three years and six months without remission. 
- On 29 March 2006, the Moscow City Court upheld the conviction on appeal.

title: CASE OF OSTANINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Prokopyevsk, Kemerovo Region.
- The applicant published an article titled "A need for new approaches" on 19 November 2009 in the newspaper "Rossiya" and on 27 November 2009 in the newspaper "Kemerovo".
- In the article, the applicant mentioned the dependence of Kuzbass on the federal budget and stated their assumption that some financial resources provided by the centre to Kuzbass are redirected back to Moscow under kickback schemes. The applicant also accused some officials in the centre of being corrupted.
- The Electoral Commission of the Kemerovo Region, Kemerovo Region Administration, and the Kemerovo Regional Branch of the United Russia Party initiated defamation proceedings against the applicant on 30 November 2009.
- The Tsentralnyy District Court of Kemerovo allowed the claim of the Electoral Commission of the Kemerovo Region, Kemerovo Region Administration, and the Kemerovo Regional Branch of the United Russia Party on 16 August 2010. The court held the applicant responsible for prejudicing the reputation of the claimants and found the applicant guilty of failing to provide relevant evidence confirming their statements in the article. The court ordered the applicant to publish a retraction and to pay 486,146 Russian roubles (about 7,018 euros) in non-pecuniary damage and legal expenses.

title: CASE OF KARACHENTSEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
• The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in St. Petersburg.
• On 4 June 2010, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of robbery committed in an organized group.
• On 5 June 2010, the Vyborgskiy District Court of St Petersburg remanded the applicant in custody.
• On 24 August 2010, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 24 November 2010.
• On 11 October 2010, the St Petersburg City Court found that there were no reasons to vary the preventive measure, and it upheld the decision of 24 August 2010 on appeal.
• On the same date, 11 October 2010, charges in respect of two counts of large-scale robbery committed in an organized group were brought against the applicant.
• On an unspecified date in November 2010, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 24 February 2011.
• On 22 February 2011, reiterating the reasons which had prompted the application of the custodial measure in the applicant’s case, the District Court extended the applicant’s detention until 24 May 2011.
• On 6 April 2011, the City Court found that there were no reasons to vary the preventive measure, and it upheld the decision of 22 February 2011 on appeal.
• On 30 May 2011, the District Court further extended the applicant’s detention until 24 August 2011.
• On 11 January 2013, the City Court acquitted the applicant of all charges in a jury trial.
• Between 5 June 2010 and 29 July 2011 the applicant was held in remand prison IZ-47/4 in St Petersburg. The prison was overcrowded.
• On 6 April and 28 June 2011 respectively, the City Court examined the applicant’s appeals against the decisions of the District Court of 22 February and 30 May 2011 extending his detention. He participated in the appeals by means of a video link from the remand prison, where he was confined in a metal cage.

title: CASE OF TSUKANOV AND TORCHINSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are from Moscow, born in 1984 and 1979 respectively.
- A draft law prohibiting adoption of Russian children by US citizens was adopted at first reading on December 14, 2012.
- The applicants decided to hold solo "pickets" in front of the State Duma to express their opposition to the draft law.
- They were arrested by the police a few minutes later and accused of organizing and holding a group public event without prior notification.
- The first applicant was released at 1.20 p.m. and the second applicant was released at 1.10 p.m.
- The second applicant was found guilty and sentenced to a fine of RUB 20,000 on January 15, 2013.
- The first applicant was found guilty and sentenced to a fine of RUB 20,000 on February 6, 2013.
- Both applicants appealed but their appeals were rejected by the Tverskoy District Court of Moscow.
- The second applicant appealed for review of the court decisions and his fine was reduced to RUB 10,000 on June 28, 2013.

title: CASE OF LAZORIVA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant is a school teacher who has been living in Magadan, Russia, since 1984.
- K.T.O., the applicant's sister, gave birth to K.L.S. in 1993, and later in 2007 gave birth to K.O.S.
- The grandparents of K.L.S. raised her for about ten years before moving with her to Ludinovo in 2004.
- K.L.S. moved back to Magadan in August 2007 to live with the applicant, who was appointed her legal guardian in December 2007.
- K.O.S. was placed in an orphanage in November 2008 and again in March 2012; in July 2012, he was put on the list of children available for adoption.
- The applicant attempted to become K.O.S.'s legal tutor but was informed that a couple had been allowed to establish contact with the child and had submitted an adoption application for him.
- S.S.V. and S.O.V. were granted permission to adopt K.O.S. by the Pershotravnevyy Court in October 2012, and the applicant lodged an appeal against the decision in February 2013, which was ultimately rejected.
- In December 2015, the government submitted a verbatim record of an interview with K.O.S. where he expressed his desire to continue living with his adoptive parents.

title: CASE OF GULIYEV AND SHEINA v. RUSSIA
facts:
A. Background information 
- The applicants are a married couple who were born in 1975 and 1988 respectively. 
- The first applicant arrived in Russia in 2002 or 2003, but it is unclear on what legal basis he resided there. 
- The first applicant was fined in April 2007 for living on Russian territory without a valid residence permit.
- The applicants had two children born in 2007 and 2011.

B. The first applicant's expulsion and the relevant proceedings 
- On 13 December 2013, the first applicant was detained for a breach of Article 18.8 of the Code of Administrative Offences for failing to apply for a renewal of his authorized stay. 
- The Sverdlovsk District Court ordered that the first applicant be fined and subjected to administrative removal (expulsion) from Russia to Azerbaijan, which implied a subsequent five-year entry ban.
- The first applicant appealed against the decision, alleging that his removal and five-year re-entry ban would violate his right to respect for his family life. 
- The Perm Regional Court examined the appeal and upheld the decision of 13 December 2013. 

C. Subsequent developments 
- The applicants officially registered their marriage on 21 February 2014.
- On 6 March 2014, the first applicant was expelled from Russia. 
- On 23 July 2014, the applicants' third child, R.Sh., was born with a congenital heart condition. 
- On 11 August 2014, the applicants requested the Court to lift the first applicant's re-entry ban so he could visit the child in the hospital. 
- On 12 August 2014, the Court refused to grant the interim measure and asked for factual information from the Government. 
- On 18 August 2014, the Government informed the Court that domestic legal provisions did not provide for any exceptions to the five-year re-entry ban.

title: CASE OF OTTAN v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicant is a lawyer from Lunel who acted as a civil party's lawyer in a judicial investigation following the death of his minor son by a gendarme.
- The gendarme was committed for trial on a charge of manslaughter.
- The trial at the Assize Court resulted in the acquittal of the gendarme, which caused an outcry in society and among the victim's family.
- In response to journalists' questions after the verdict, the applicant made statements accusing the French justice system of racism and xenophobia and of being a two-speed society with certain communities underrepresented in the criminal justice system. He also commented on the possibility of the Principal Public Prosecutor appealing against the verdict.
- The Principal Public Prosecutor sought to initiate disciplinary proceedings against the applicant for his remarks, but the disciplinary board of the Bar associations acquitted him on the basis of the right to freedom of expression under Article 10 of the Convention.
- The Principal Public Prosecutor appealed against the disciplinary board's decision, and the Court of Appeal found the applicant guilty of breaching the duties of discretion and moderation and imposed a warning on him as the "lightest possible disciplinary penalty."

title: CASE OF DIMITRAS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant is the executive director of the non-governmental organisation “Greek Helsinki Monitor”.
- Greek Helsinki Monitor published press releases welcoming the concluding observations of the UN Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) for Greece and criticised the domestic authorities’ responses to them.
- E.T., in her capacity as General Secretary for Gender Equality of the Ministry of Interior, Public Administration and Decentralisation, gave an interview published in a magazine, responding to Greek Helsinki Monitor's accusations against her with regard to Roma women and minority women’s rights.
- The applicant lodged a criminal complaint with the public prosecutor at the Athens First-Instance Court, accusing E.T. of slander committed through the press.
- The public prosecutor at the Athens Court of Appeal ordered E.T.’s criminal prosecution for slander made through the press despite the initial dismissal of the complaint.
- E.T. objected to the trial court's competence.
- The case was referred to the three-member Athens Court of Appeal for misdemeanours. The hearing was postponed multiple times.
- The Court of Appeal suspended the criminal prosecution against E.T. until the Greek Parliament had granted leave and, if leave were not granted or no action were taken within three months from the submission of the prosecutor’s request to the Greek Parliament, until her status as a parliamentarian ended.
- The request for leave to continue the criminal proceedings was dismissed by the Plenary of the Greek Parliament.
- The Court of Appeal considered that the offence of which E.T. was accused had become time-barred and the criminal prosecution ended.

title: CASE OF MAMMADLI v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is a well-known civil society activist and human rights defender.
- He is the chairman and co-founder of the Election Monitoring and Democracy Studies Centre, a non-governmental organisation that monitors elections.
- He was involved in the preparation of various reports on election organization and human rights in Azerbaijan.
- Following the dissolution of the Election Monitoring Centre, he founded the Centre, which made unsuccessful attempts to obtain state registration through applications to the Ministry of Justice.
- The Centre conducted both short-term and long-term observations of the last presidential elections held on 9 October 2013.
- On 29 October 2013, the Prosecutor General’s Office instituted criminal proceedings in connection with alleged irregularities in the financial activities of the Centre and the Public Union, a partner organization.
- On 31 October 2013, a search was conducted at the Centre’s office, during which all the organization’s documents and electronic data storage devices were taken away.
- On 16 December 2013, the applicant was arrested and charged with illegal entrepreneurship, large-scale tax evasion, and abuse of power.
- His detention was extended several times, and the prosecutor brought additional charges of high-level embezzlement and forgery in public office against him.
- The applicant was found guilty on all counts and sentenced to five and a half years’ imprisonment.
- The applicant’s arrest and institution of criminal proceedings against him attracted significant public and media interest both inside the country and internationally.
- The arrest of the applicant and other human rights activists led to comments by politicians from the ruling political party, describing them as spies or traitors.

title: CASE OF TKACHEV v. UKRAINE
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant, born in 1977, is currently serving a life sentence in Dnipro.
- The applicant was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder and other crimes by the final domestic judgment of 16 July 2002.
- The applicant was detained in the Cherkassy pre-trial detention center until September 2004, in which cells had been overcrowded and lacked basic amenities.
- In October 2004, the applicant was transferred to Sokalska Correctional Colony no. 47 in Zhvyrka, where he remained until 15 November 2007.
- During his detention in Sokalska Colony, the applicant shared a cell with a former applicant to the Court, Mr V.M. Guk, with whom he had been sharing for three years. Mr. Guk's application to the Court was already examined, and it was found that the conditions of his detention in the Colony violated Article 3 of the Convention.
- According to the applicant, during his stay in the Colony, he was held in a cell, in which the living space was "extremely insufficient."
- The cell lacked basic amenities such as furniture for storage of personal belongings and food; a very small table; no rubbish container; and no toilet cleaners.
- The tap water was of poor quality, and water filters were not provided. The heating was inadequate, and the air was damp and cold, with walls covered with mold.
- The washing unit in the Colony had no changing facilities, and prisoners had to first undress in their cells. Guards watched them wash and hurried them up. Prisoners had to shave with poor-quality razors.
- Sick and healthy prisoners washed in the same unit without disinfection measures. Sick and healthy prisoners walked in the same dark, damp and small courtyard.
- Whenever the guards opened the cell, the prisoners had to retreat to its far corner, squat and put their arms behind their heads. When taken out of the cell, the applicant was handcuffed; he was required to walk in a squat or some other unnatural position; his head was covered with a black bag; handcuffs were not disinfected.
- Searches of personal belongings left them in disorder and often damaged.
- The applicant was regularly beaten by the guards in 2004-2005. Family visits were not adequately organized in 2004-2006, and his correspondence with relatives had been reviewed, and some letters had disappeared.

title: CASE OF HAJIBEYLI AND ALIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicants are civil society activists and lawyers specializing in human rights protection.
- They were practicing law on the basis of a special permit issued by the Ministry of Justice.
- In 1999, a new Law on Advocates and Advocacy Activity was adopted, which regulates the legal profession in the country.
- The Law provides for the establishment of the ABA, and the exclusive domain of legal counsel in criminal proceedings.
- The transitional provisions of the Law granted existing lawyers a right to be founding members of the ABA without passing a qualification examination.
- Some lawyers, including the applicants, were not invited to participate in the ABA's constituent assembly and their right to be founders was not recognized.
- The applicants signed a petition alleging that the constituent assembly was held illegally and instituted court proceedings.
- Amendments to the Law were made in 2005, providing for the admission of all lawyers holding a special permit to the ABA.
- The first applicant applied for admission to the ABA and was rejected by the Presidium.
- The second applicant also applied for admission and was rejected by the Presidium.
- The first applicant brought an action in the court alleging that the Presidium's decision was unlawful.
- The Nasimi District Court dismissed the complaint.
- The first applicant appealed to the Court of Appeal, which also dismissed the appeal.
- The first applicant lodged a cassation appeal, reiterating his complaints.

title: CASE OF LOZOVYYE v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals who live in Belomorsk, Karelia
- Applicants’ son, Mr M. Lozovoy, was killed in St Petersburg on 1 December 2005
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against a Mr O. on the charge of murder
- The investigator, Ms L., failed to take sufficient steps to find relatives of the deceased
- The investigators’ steps were formalistic in character, and a representative of the municipal authority was assigned as the victim
- Applicants contacted Ms L. stating their intention to participate in the criminal proceedings, but the criminal case file was sent to the Primorskiy District Court for trial without any notice to the applicants
- Applicants were subsequently invited to take part in the criminal proceedings in the capacity of victims
- The Primorskiy District Court found Mr O. guilty of murdering Mr M. Lozovoy and sentenced him to six years’ imprisonment
- The District Court issued an interim decision in respect of the investigator, Ms L, in which it was found that the victims’ rights envisaged by the law in force were substantially violated during the preliminary investigation
- The applicants lodged an action in 2007 against the Prosecutor General’s Office and the Ministry of Finance, seeking compensation for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage
- On 5 February 2008, their claim was dismissed by the Tverskoy District Court of Moscow, due to lack of evidence
- On 20 May 2008, the Moscow City Court upheld the judgment of the District Court.

title: CASE OF TONELLO v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant lives in Vigonza (Padua) and met his partner, K.S., a Hungarian national, in 2008. 
- They had a daughter in 2011 and after her birth, the relationship between the applicant and K.S. deteriorated. 
- K.S. traveled twice to Hungary with their daughter, intending not to return to Italy. 
- The applicant filed an application with Venice Minors Court and requested that parental authority over their daughter be stripped from K.S. 
- The Pest Central District Court ordered the child’s return to Italy, which was subsequently upheld by the Budapest High Court and the Supreme Court. 
- K.S. did not comply with the return order, and multiple attempts were made to serve the enforcement order on her with no success. 
- K.S. was pursued under criminal proceedings initiated by the Padua public prosecutor and an arrest warrant was issued against her. 
- The judgment of the Venice Minors Court was declared enforceable by the Szolnok District Court. 
- The Mezőtúr district prosecutor’s office ordered an investigation against K.S. for unauthorised custody of a minor and child endangerment. 
- Despite multiple attempts, the return order was still not enforced as of February 2018.

title: CASE OF BARTULIENĖ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant requested the authorities to establish her father's ownership of 7.06 hectares of land in Kaunas Region before nationalisation, and attached a document proving his ownership of 6.79 hectares.
- The authorities issued a decision to return 0.66 hectares to the applicant in natura and the remaining 2.74 hectares by paying compensation.
- The applicant was later given eleven plots measuring 0.06 hectares each, but in 2003 was informed of changes in the restitution process for urban land.
- The applicant requested monetary compensation for the remaining 2.74 hectares of land, and later asked for this compensation in a "convertible currency at market prices".
- The authorities informed the applicant that compensation at market prices was not possible, and that the value of 2.5469 hectares of land was assessed at LTL 20,167 for acquiring land in another area, or at LTL 32,267 for compensation in securities.
- The applicant's property rights to the remaining 2.74 hectares of land were eventually restored by giving her two plots of land measuring 0.0807 hectares and 0.1124 hectares respectively.
- The applicant started court proceedings, demanding compensation in respect of pecuniary damage from the Kaunas municipality, alleging that she was prevented from using the returned land because of electricity and gas equipment installed on it and asked for the removal of underground telecommunications cables installed on her plot within two months of the court decision becoming final.
- The court dismissed the applicant's claim, stating that the State was not obliged to restore her property rights to land with no restrictions regarding its use, and that the cables had been installed in accordance with domestic law. 
- A plot of land measuring 0.0498 hectares, sold to another person in 1994, was found to have been illegally provided to the buyer, and court proceedings were initiated to annul the relevant administrative acts and agreements. 
- The applicant brought a claim for non-pecuniary damage relating to the length of the restitution proceedings and asked for property rights to be restored or fair monetary compensation to be paid. The court found that the applicant's property rights had not been restored because of her inactivity and left her complaint about restoring property rights unexamined. 
- The Supreme Administrative Court returned the case to the Regional Administrative Court for fresh examination.

title: CASE OF GELETEY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and lives in Berehove.
- M. was robbed and killed in Berehove in August 2004.
- The applicant, K.A., and St. were arrested on suspicion of robbing and killing M. on the same date.
- The applicant alleged that he was beaten and threatened by the police to confess the crime.
- The applicant was questioned as a suspect by the investigator and acknowledged his guilt.
- The applicant directed the police to the hiding spot of the weapon used during the murder.
- Other suspects admitted to participating in the robbery but not in the murder.
- The regional court convicted the applicant of murder and robbery and sentenced him to fifteen years’ imprisonment.
- The Supreme Court upheld the applicant’s conviction and sentence.

title: CASE OF BENEDIK v. SLOVENIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the case facts:

- In 2006, the Swiss law-enforcement authorities conducted a monitoring exercise of users of the "Razorback" network where child pornography was circulated.
- Among the dynamic IP addresses recorded by the Swiss police was a certain dynamic IP address, which was later linked to the applicant.
- Based on the data obtained by the Swiss police, the Slovenian police requested an Internet service provider to disclose data regarding the user to whom the above-mentioned IP address had been assigned without obtaining a court order.
- The police proposed that the ISP disclose both the personal data of the subscriber and traffic data linked to the IP address in question.
- The investigating judge of the Kranj District Court issued an order to carry out a house search of the applicant's family home where four computers were seized.
- The police changed the suspect to the applicant after reviewing the hard disks, which contained files with child pornography material.
- The applicant argued that he had not been aware of the content of the files in question and that the ISP had unlawfully passed his data to the police without a judicial warrant.
- The court found the applicant guilty of the criminal offence of displaying, manufacturing, possessing, and distributing pornographic material and sentenced him to a suspended prison term of eight months with a probation period of two years.
- The appellant alleged that the subscriber information the Slovenian police had acquired without a court order, and thus unlawfully, should have been excluded as evidence, but the Ljubljana Higher Court rejected this appeal.
- The applicant's constitutional complaint was also dismissed by the Constitutional Court, holding that his constitutional rights had not been violated.

title: CASE OF FATİH TAŞ v. TURKEY (No. 4)
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was the owner and editor-in-chief of Aram Basım ve Yayıncılık.
- The applicant’s company published two books, “Dağlarda Yaşamın Dili” and “Tufanda 33 Gün”.
- The public prosecutor filed an indictment charging the applicant with aiding and abetting the PKK due to the publication of “The Language of Life in the Mountains”.
- The applicant was convicted as charged and the judgment was upheld on appeal.
- The public prosecutor requested a revision of the judgment as the law had been amended.
- The case was transferred to the Istanbul Assize Court due to the abolition of state security courts.
- The applicant was charged with aiding and abetting the PKK due to the publication of “33 Days in the Deluge”.
- The cases were joined and the applicant was convicted of disseminating propaganda in favor of the PKK.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment on appeal and the applicant was convicted again, this time under section 7(2) of Law no. 3713 and sentenced to a fine.
- The judgment was later quashed and the execution of the sentence suspended.
- The applicant was convicted under section 7(2) of Law no. 3713 for disseminating propaganda in favor of the PKK due to the publication of “33 Days in the Deluge” and sentenced to ten months’ imprisonment.
- The Court of Cassation discontinued the proceedings concerning the publication of “33 Days in the Deluge”.

title: CASE OF FATİH TAŞ v. TURKEY (No. 3)
facts:
- The applicant was the owner and editor-in-chief of a publishing house.
- His company published a book entitled Patika – Gerilla Anıları IV (“The Path – Guerrilla Memoirs IV”).
- The book consisted of memoirs of seventeen members of the PKK.
- The book was seized by authorities as it contained propaganda in favor of the PKK.
- The applicant was charged with disseminating propaganda in favor of a terrorist organization.
- Despite multiple convictions and retrials, the criminal proceedings were finally discontinued based on the statute of limitations.

title: CASE OF SADRETTİN GÜLER v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and lives in Istanbul. 
- The applicant was a civil servant in the Metropolitan Municipality of Istanbul and a member of the local branch of the Tümbel-Sen trade union.
- Two of the largest trade unions, namely the DİSK and the KESK announced in April 2008 that they were planning a large scale demonstration in Istanbul for 1 May 2008.
- The applicant participated in a demonstration organised by his trade union on 1 May 2008. 
- The applicant was given a warning as a disciplinary sanction for being absent without leave on 1 May 2008 which he objected and the Disciplinary Board of the Istanbul Municipality dismissed the applicant’s objection.

title: CASE OF SEPCZYŃSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and lives in Łomża.
- The applicant had a motorcycle accident on 7 August 2010, in which he broke his right arm and right thigh.
- Between 13 and 22 December 2010, the applicant underwent an arthroscopy on his right knee.
- Between 25 January and 15 February 2011, the applicant underwent rehabilitation treatment in Łomża Regional Hospital and during this stay no dysfunction was diagnosed in his right foot. 
- The applicant was detained in Białystok Remand Centre from 28 March to 26 July 2011.  
- The orthopaedist observed that the applicant required physical therapy in the light of a limitation of his knee-joint movement, the atrophy of a thigh muscle, and an injury to a peroneal nerve. 
- The applicant never received any physical therapy during his imprisonment. 
- On an unspecified date in which the applicant brought a civil action against the State Treasury/Białystok Remand Centre for infringement of his personal rights. 
- On 20 January 2014, the Białystok Regional Court granted the applicant PLN 23,000 and dismissed the remainder of his action. 
- The court held that the applicant had suffered physical pain of significant seriousness, which, in turn, had had negative psychological consequences.
- The claim concerning the alleged overcrowding and inadequate sanitary conditions was dismissed in full.
- The Białystok Court of Appeal amended the judgment, reduced the compensation granted to the applicant to PLN 13,000, and upheld the first-instance court’s findings of fact and law.

title: CASE OF HOTI v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and is of Albanian origin.
- His parents fled Albania as political refugees and settled in Kosovo in 1960.
- The applicant came to Croatia in 1979 and settled in Novska, where he has lived ever since.
- The applicant has no family in Croatia, and his parents have died in Kosovo.
- In 1987, the applicant applied for a permanent residence permit in Novska but was instructed to regularize his status in Kosovo.
- He was provided with a temporary residence permit for the period between 4 January and 30 June 1988.
- The Novska police informed the Ministry of the Interior in 1989 that the applicant refused SFRY citizenship.
- In 1992, the applicant applied for Croatian citizenship, which was forwarded to the Ministry of the Interior by the Novska police with a suggestion that it be granted.
- The Ministry assured the applicant of granting Croatian citizenship if he provided evidence of renouncing his Albanian citizenship within two years.
- On 3 August 1995, the Ministry dismissed the applicant’s application for Croatian citizenship on the grounds that he did not have a registered residence in Croatia for an uninterrupted period of five years.
- On 13 November 2001, the applicant asked the Ministry to grant him a permanent residence permit.
- On 3 July 2003, the Ministry dismissed the applicant’s application on the grounds that he did not meet the necessary statutory requirements.

title: CASE OF TSARPELAS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and is a carrier of thalassemia disease. He contracted non-reversible ischemia resulting in the amputation of his right leg at the hip.
- He was arrested on May 1, 2013, and detained in Omonoia police station until May 28, 2013, for a total of twenty-seven days.
- On November 13, 2013, he was convicted of buying and selling drugs.
- The applicant claims that the conditions of his detention in Omonoia police station were poor, and he was not provided with basic needs such as hygiene and medical care.
- The applicant was transferred between several prison facilities until his release on November 26, 2014.
- The government argues that the conditions of the applicant's detention were adequate and he received proper medical care and social support.
- The applicant's medical record shows that he received assistance twenty-seven times either in-house or at the city hospital.
- The applicant benefited from a beneficial calculation of the days served, owing to his disability.

title: CASE OF ČAKAREVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Rijeka
- On 10 December 1995, the applicant's employment as an unqualified worker was terminated due to her employer's insolvency
- The applicant has a psychiatric condition of depression and neurosis since 1993 and is continuously unable to work as per medical documents
- On 5 November 1996, the applicant was granted unemployment benefits in the amount of HRK 410.89 for 468 days, starting from 11 December 1995
- The Rijeka Employment Bureau renewed her entitlement to unemployment benefits until further notice on 27 June 1997, subject to legally prescribed conditions and HRK 441 per month.
- In December 1997, two additional pensionable years of service were entered into the applicant's employment book. 
- On 27 March 2001, the Rijeka Employment Bureau terminated the applicant's entitlement to unemployment benefits, and established that she had to repay HRK 19,451.69
- The applicant appealed against both decisions but they were dismissed by the Central Employment Bureau as well as the Administrative Court.
- On 3 August 2015, the Rijeka Employment Bureau brought a civil action against the applicant for unjust enrichment, seeking repayment of HRK 19,451.69.
- On 25 February 2009, the Rijeka County Court allowed the Rijeka Employment Bureau's appeal and reversed the lower court's judgment, ordering the applicant to pay HRK 19,451.69 plus statutory interest 
- The applicant lodged both an appeal on points of law and a constitutional complaint but both were dismissed as unfounded.
- The enforcement proceedings for the repayment are ongoing.

title: CASE OF RAMIKHANOV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The case involves multiple applicants.
- A table is provided containing relevant details of the applicants' applications.
- The applicants are complaining about the non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions.

title: CASE OF ZELENTSOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document includes a table listing the applicants and the relevant details of their applications.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants complained about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- One of the applicants raised another complaint under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF NICULA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A table was appended containing a list of applicants and details of their applications.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.
- One of the applicants (in application no. 31497/14) also raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF YALANSKYY AND GALUNKA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table is appended with the list of applicants and relevant application details.
- The applicants complained of excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- The applicants complained of a lack of effective remedies in domestic law.
- In application no. 36543/17, the applicant raised a complaint under Article 2 of Protocol No. 4 to the Convention.

title: CASE OF MATVEYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants and their application details provided in the document
- Applicants have complained about the conditions of their detention
- Some applicants have raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention

title: CASE OF MEIANU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants provided in an appended table.
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.
- Applicant in case no. 53018/15 raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MARINAȘ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A list of applicants and their details are provided in an appended table.
- The applicants complained about the poor conditions of their detention.
- Some applicants raised other complaints related to provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF PLETOSU-HALUNGESCU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A list of applicants and their application details are provided in a table.
- The applicants made a complaint about the insufficient conditions of their detention.
- One of the applicants lodged additional complaints under Article 3 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KOVALENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The case involves a list of applicants and their corresponding application details.
- The applicants filed complaints about the civil proceedings being excessively long.
- The applicants also claimed that there was no effective remedy provided by domestic law.

title: CASE OF KRASYUKOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table appendix contains a list of applicants and their application details.
- The applicants complained about lengthy pre-trial detention.
- Some of the applicants raised other complaints based on the Convention's provisions.

title: CASE OF STOMAKHIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was a journalist and civil activist.
- He identified himself as a member of an informal liberal democratic movement called Revolyutsionnoye Kontaktnoye Obyedineniye.
- He was the founder, owner, publisher, and editor-in-chief of a monthly newsletter called Radikalnaya Politika.
- The newsletter's articles covered events in the Chechen Republic and included commentary on the case of a high-ranking Russian officer charged with torture and murder.
- The applicant expressed support for the Chechen resistance and its leaders, including those involved in the Dubrovka Theatre hostage-taking and Salman Raduyev.
- He advocated for the destruction of Russia as a state and supported retribution for the genocide of the Chechen people.
- Articles in the newsletter condemned the actions of the Russian army in the Chechen Republic, accused them of extra-judicial executions, and described them as a frenzied gang of looters and murderers.

title: CASE OF MURUZHEVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Moscow.
- Married R.M. in May 2008 and had two children with him on 23 July 2008 and 31 May 2012.
- In January 2014, they decided to separate, and R.M. took the children to the Republic of Ingushetiya without the applicant's knowledge on 14 January 2014.
- The marriage got dissolved on 4 March 2014
- The applicant applied for a residence order in respect of the children and child maintenance from R.M. on 11 March 2014.
- District Court ordered R.M. to return the children to her and pay child maintenance on 25 June 2014, but he refused to comply.
- The enforcement proceedings began but failed multiple times due to various reasons from both parties.
- The enforcement file returned to Izmaylovskiy District Bailiffs’ Service on 17 September 2015.
- Multiple administrative fines imposed on R.M. for failure to comply with the judgment.
- The Commission for the Affairs of Minors and the Protection of Their Rights imposed an administrative fine on R.M. of RUB 2,000 on 14 January 2016.
- The bailiff suspended the enforcement proceedings after R.M. refused to provide explanations for his non-compliance with the judgment of 25 June 2014. 
- The enforcement proceedings were scheduled multiple times but failed because of the absence of the applicant or her representative.
- The judgment of 25 June 2014 remains unenforced to date, and the children are staying with their paternal grandparents in the Republic of Ingushetiya.

title: CASE OF MAINOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Tajikistan in 1967 and came to Russia in 1993. He is stateless.
- He was arrested for vagrancy on 31 July 2014 and sentenced on 2 August 2014 to a fine and administrative removal from Russia. He was also directed to be detained until expulsion in the detention facility for aliens in Krasnoye Selo.
- The applicant was requested to be issued with a laissez-passer document by the Federal Migration Service on 11 August and 18 November 2014, but no reply was received from the Tajikistan Embassy in Moscow.
- The applicant was fingerprinted and discovered to have been registered in the police database under a different name. The Federal Migration Service requested a laissez-passer from the Tajikistan Embassy in Moscow, but no response was received in February 2015.
- Further attempts were made to obtain a travel document for the applicant on 10 September 2015, but the embassy did not respond.
- The governor of the detention centre asked the Kalininskiy District Court to discontinue the enforcement of the judgment on 28 July 2016, and the District Court granted the application on 29 July 2016. The applicant was released on 13 August 2016.
- The applicant was held in different cells throughout his detention, including a closed cell, with poor living conditions and inadequate healthcare.
- The applicant complained about poor conditions and a lack of medical assistance, while the Government disputed these allegations and provided evidence to the contrary.

title: CASE OF LIPAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and was detained in Vladivostok at the relevant time.
- The applicant was arrested on charges of fraud on 18 April 2016.
- The Pervorechensky District Court of Vladivostok authorised his pre-trial detention.
- The detention was further extended on 15 June and 14 September 2016.
- On 25 April, 20 June and 16 September 2016 the applicant appealed against the detention orders.
- The Primorye Regional Court dismissed the appeals on 1 June, 5 July and 25 October 2016, respectively.

title: CASE OF TITOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are Russian nationals who owned flats in Moscow.
- Municipal authorities reclaimed the flats and annulled the applicants' title to the property.
- Flats in a residential building were assigned by the City of Moscow to the Ministry of Communications in 1977 and were later transferred to Rostelekom Open Joint Stock Company in 1991.
- In 2008-2009, a group of people, including a police officer, a lawyer, a notary, and several Rostelekom employees, forged documents and sold three flats to private parties, which were subsequently bought by the applicants.
- Criminal investigation was opened into the case in 2012, and on 9 December 2013, the Perovskiy District Court found nine defendants guilty of fraud.
- The Housing Department of the City of Moscow was recognized as a victim of the crime in December 2012, and brought civil actions seeking restitution of the flats in 2014.
- The Cheremushkinskiy District Court invalidated the transactions in respect of the flats and ordered the eviction of the applicants.
- The Moscow City Court upheld the judgments of the District Court on appeal and refused to grant the applicants leave to bring a cassation appeal against the judgments.
- The Government claims that the applicants were not evicted and continue to reside in the flats.

title: CASE OF TARKHANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 in Abakan, the Khakassiya Republic.
- The applicant faced accusations of theft and murder.
- On 22 November 2004, the Sayanogorsk Town Court in Khakassiya set the trial's opening date and extended the applicant's pre-trial detention, without his attendance during the hearing.
- On 2 December 2004, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to prison.
- On 22 March 2005, the Constitutional Court's decision established the defendant's right to be present during the trial's detention matter hearing, make submissions to the court and produce evidence.
- On 8 August 2013, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Khakassiya Republic declared the District Court's decision to extend the applicant's detention unlawful since he was not given a chance to participate during the hearing or make any submissions.
- The applicant sought compensation from the Ministry of Finance for his wrongful detention, but his claims were rejected by the Abakan Town Court, as he was found guilty and sentenced to prison.

title: CASE OF UNIFAUN THEATRE PRODUCTIONS LIMITED AND OTHERS v. MALTA
facts:
- The first applicant is a company that produces theatrical performances, and the second and third applicants are the directors of the company.
- The fourth applicant is the artistic director of the production of “Stitching” and the fifth and third applicants are two actors engaged to perform in the play.
- The play was originally published in the United Kingdom by the publishing house Methuen Drama and was licensed to the first applicant by the author and agent.
- The first applicant submitted an application to the Board for Film and Stage Classification for a rating certificate for the play.
- The Board issued a certificate stating that the play was banned, but did not provide any reasons for the decision.
- The first applicant sent an email and letter to the chairperson of the Board inquiring about the decision and requested a reconsideration, but the original decision was reconfirmed with no reasons provided.
- The chairperson of the Board later provided reasons for the ban, citing blasphemy against the State Religion and references to the abduction, sexual assault, and murder of children.
- The applicants filed a judicial protest against the chairperson, the Commissioner of Police, and the Attorney General claiming that the actions of the Board were illegal and a violation of their rights under the Maltese Constitution and the European Convention on Human Rights.
- The applicants were warned by a police inspector that they would face immediate arrest if they attempted to stage the play.
- The court heard witness testimony from various individuals, including the author of the play, and witnesses who had read the script and/or watched rehearsals.
- The witnesses who supported the play testified that it was a tragic love story and that there was nothing pornographic about it, while those who opposed the play found it offensive and dehumanizing.

title: CASE OF LUTSKEVICH v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant participated in a public demonstration at Bolotnaya Square on 6 May 2012
- The demonstration was peaceful until clashes broke out between the police and the protestors
- The applicant was accused of using violence against a police officer and tearing a protection helmet off of an officer's head
- The applicant was detained on 9 June 2012 until his conviction
- The applicant was held in remand prison and claimed that the conditions were inadequate
- The trial against the applicant and ten others began on 6 June 2013 for acts of mass disorder and violence against police officers.

title: CASE OF IBROGIMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1992 and lived in Bukhara, Uzbekistan.
- The applicant's family moved to Vladivostok in Russia and acquired Russian nationality.
- The applicant continued living with his grandfather in Bukhara and visited his family in Russia in summer.
- The applicant joined his family in Russia after his grandfather died and he finished secondary school.
- The applicant took a mandatory blood test for obtaining a health certificate and was found to be HIV-positive.
- The Consumer Protection Authority declared the applicant's presence in Russia undesirable based on his HIV status.
- The Sovetskiy District Court rejected the applicant's challenge to the exclusion order.
- The Primorskiy Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal.
- The applicant left Russia to comply with the exclusion order.

title: CASE OF MEREUTA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Opaci.
- On 29 July 2009, the applicant and his friends were attacked by S. who was intoxicated and carrying a hunting rifle.
- S. was angry because the applicant and his friends had allegedly ill-treated his uncle earlier.
- The applicant sustained serious injuries to his right leg which led to amputation of his leg above the knee.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against S. on charges of hooliganism with the use of a firearm resulting in the causing of severe harm to the applicant’s health.
- Between 1 and 10 August 2009 twenty-five witnesses were questioned and by 12 September 2009 most of the investigative measures were completed.
- S. was indicted on 29 December 2009 and on 12 January 2010, he was heard as an accused.
- On 30 December 2010 the prosecutor’s office decided to discontinue the criminal proceedings against S. due to an unlawful indictment.
- On 18 February 2011, the prosecutor general’s office decided to resume the criminal investigation on the ground that new facts had been discovered.
- On 31 March 2011 the Rascani District Court upheld S.’s objection against the prosecutor’s decision of 18 February 2011, ordering its annulment. The applicant and his representative were not summoned or informed about the proceedings.

title: CASE OF TAŞARSU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Adana.
- On 8 March 2002, she was arrested on suspicion of being a member of an illegal organization.
- On 9 March 2002, her statements were taken by the police without the presence of a lawyer.
- On 11 March 2002, she partially retracted her previous statements before the prosecutor and investigating judge at the Istanbul State Security Court in the absence of a lawyer and was placed in pre-trial detention on the same day.
- On 18 March 2002, she was accused of membership in an illegal terrorist organization under Article 168 of the former Criminal Code by the public prosecutor at the Istanbul State Security Court.
- On 31 May 2002, she gave her statement in person with a lawyer, denying her previous statements and claiming to have left Turkey on her own and traveled to various countries. 
- On 16 April 2008, she was convicted and sentenced to six years and three months' imprisonment under Article 314 § 2 of the new Turkish Criminal Code, based on her statements to the police.
- On 23 December 2010, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the Istanbul Assize Court.

title: CASE OF DARSIGOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lived in Grozny, Chechen Republic.
- The applicant was provided with a housing allocation order no. 842 by the administrative authorities of the Leninskiy District of Grozny in 1999, entitling her to occupy a one-room municipal flat in Grozny.
- In 2005, the applicant was registered as living in the aforementioned flat.
- In 2007, the authorities conducted an examination of all allocation orders granting occupation of municipal accommodation, and found the applicant's housing allocation order suspicious.
- An expert verified that the allocation order was a forged document, not printed at the printing office.
- The administration of Grozny brought court proceedings against the applicant seeking to declare the allocation order null and void and to evict her from the flat in question.
