- On 24 February 2009, the Leninskiy District Court of Grozny declared the housing allocation order of 7 February 1999 null and void and issued an order to evict the applicant, as the order was not made typographically and was a forged document.
- On 9 June 2009, the Supreme Court upheld that judgment.
- After her eviction, the applicant returned to living in her mother's flat and was registered as living in that flat in 2011.

title: CASE OF AGARKOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant's son was taken to the hospital on January 17, 2007, with severe head trauma.
- The son died on February 1, 2007.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against a certain V., who had inflicted fatal bodily injuries on the son during a fight.
- The investigation repeatedly examined the circumstances of the son's death, including the involvement of police officers.
- The investigator's lengthy inactivity and refusals to inform the applicant and to conduct certain expert examinations were found to be unlawful.
- The criminal proceedings were discontinued and resumed multiple times, with some decisions being set aside as unsubstantiated or illegal.
- Eventually, in August 2012, the investigator discontinued the proceedings, citing the statute of limitations for criminal prosecution.

title: CASE OF PAȘA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and lives in Bălți.
- On 5 February 2011 at 1.30 p.m. the applicant was arrested for trafficking in human beings and placed in detention for seventy-two hours.
- On 8 February 2011 at 10.20 a.m. the prosecutor asked for the applicant’s remand in custody and at 2 p.m. the applicant was brought before a judge who ordered his custody for thirty days.
- The applicant filed an appeal alleging unlawful detention exceeding seventy-two hours and lack of access to the case-file materials, which was dismissed.
- On 5 March 2011, the prosecutor applied for a prolongation of the applicant’s detention for another thirty days, which was upheld on the same date.
- On an unspecified date, a judge modified the date of the applicant’s remand in custody from 6 March to 6 April 2011.
- On 16 March 2011, the Bălți Court of Appeal quashed the decision and ordered the applicant’s immediate release, stating that the second decision modifying the date was not taken in accordance with the procedural rules.
- The applicant has been convicted at first instance and is currently wanted by the authorities.

title: CASE OF PANKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was stopped by the police for an identity check and informed that he was wanted for suspicion of having committed a crime.
- The applicant was placed in a cell where he was allegedly subjected to ill-treatment by a police officer named P.
- The applicant was interrogated by an investigator and released after his questioning.
- The applicant complained of having been beaten by P immediately after his release and sought medical attention.
- The investigator decided not to institute criminal proceedings against P due to lack of evidence, but the decision was challenged by the applicant and eventually overturned by the courts.

title: CASE OF YAMAN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- Three applicants were born in 1956, 1967, and 1977 respectively.
- On 20 June 1999, they were arrested during a military operation in Şırnak, and interrogated in the absence of a lawyer.
- They gave detailed statements of their involvement with an illegal organisation, the PKK.
- On 23 June 1999, they were brought before the Diyarbakır Public Prosecutor and denied the charges against them, claiming that they had signed their statements without reading them.
- On 2 July 1999, an indictment was filed against them for activities with the aim of bringing about the secession of part of the national territory, under Article 125 of the Criminal Code.
- On 7 May 2002, the Diyarbakır State Security Court found the applicants guilty and sentenced them to life imprisonment. The court relied on their statements to the gendarmes.
- On 25 March 2003, the judgment was quashed by the Court of Cassation because of a procedural error.
- On 16 June 2004, State Security Courts were abolished, and the case was transferred to the Diyarbakır Assize Court.
- On 7 March 2005, the court read out witness statements and repeated the judgment, and again, the applicants were found guilty and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- On 17 June 2005, the case was once again examined by the Diyarbakır Assize Court in view of the recent legislative changes.
- On 25 October 2005, the court convicted the applicants under Article 125 of the former Criminal Court, finding that it was more favourable to them than the corresponding provision of the new criminal code.
- On 30 May 2006, the Court of Cassation once again quashed the judgment, this time on procedural grounds.
- On 24 April 2007, the Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicants under Article 125 of the former Criminal Code and sentenced them to life imprisonment.
- On 11 December 2007, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF SERGEY IVANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1966 and lived in Nizhniy Novgorod. He is currently serving a prison sentence in the Nizhniy Novgorod region.
- On 24 April 2004, a robbery took place at the offices of a company in Nizhniy Novgorod.
- The police officers subjected the applicant to various forms of violence to force him to confess to the robbery, including punching and kicking him, blocking his airway by covering his mouth and nose with a rag, and tying him up in a painful position.
- On 22 June 2004, the police officers again subjected the applicant to ill-treatment to force him to give confession statements.
- During his detention in IK-14, the applicant was beaten unconscious, to make him confess to a series of armed robberies, by several convicted prisoners acting on the police’s instructions and with the connivance of the administration of IK-14.

title: CASE OF ZABELOS AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
- Applicants detained in Korydallos Prison Hospital due to HIV infection or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
- Different dates of detention and use of legal remedies by each applicant.
- Overcrowded conditions in the Hospital, resulting in poor sanitary conditions and inadequate health care.
- Lack of personal space and furniture hindering free movement within the wards.
- Insufficient meals, poor quality, and the absence of recreational activities affecting psychological health.
- Lack of medical staff and properly equipped laboratories affecting medical examinations.
- Improvement in conditions from mid-2016 onwards.
- Complaint lodged by applicants in 2014 without any reply received to date.
- Official capacity of the Hospital was 60 patients, but it held between 180 and 220 patients during applicants' detention.
- Separation of patients by disease and adequate facilities for ventilation, heating, natural light, and hot water.
- Regular cleaning and disinfecting by cleaning crews and specialist companies.
- Supervised meals designed to ensure necessary nutrients.
- Recreational activities organized, and detainees granted days of leave.
- Significant improvements made in the Prison Hospital from 2015, including reducing overcrowding and improving facilities and medical equipment.

title: CASE OF SADOVYAK v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Four applicants: born 1966, 1971, 1993, and 1996
- Second applicant is former spouse of first applicant, third and fourth applicants are their children
- First, third, and fourth applicants live in Lviv, second applicant's whereabouts unknown
- In August 2001, second applicant (then a military officer) was provided with a two-room flat in an accommodation hall owned by the Lviv Military Academy; all four applicants obtained residence registration as tenants
- Second applicant was dismissed from military service on grounds of redundancy in November 2003, eligible for priority allocation of social housing from waiting list managed by Ministry of Defence
- First and second applicant divorced in 2005 and first applicant and her children were placed on the waiting list for social housing managed by the municipal authority
- In August 2011, Lviv garrison military prosecutor instituted eviction proceedings against the applicants, citing that the accommodation hall was designed for temporary housing of military personnel and none of the applicants had any connection to the military or Military Academy that owned the building
- In November 2012, Frankivskyy District Court in Lviv dismissed prosecutor's claim, finding that the applicants had lawfully obtained tenancy in connection with second applicant's previous military service
- In September 2013, Lviv Regional Court of Appeal quashed this judgment and ordered the applicants' eviction, finding their occupancy to be unlawful ab initio because they settled without building owner's formal decision authorizing their occupancy or occupancy order ("ордер") in their favor
- Applicants lodged a cassation appeal, citing their income level was insufficient to acquire housing, their eviction would leave them homeless, and eviction became time-barred in 2004 (three years after they moved in)
- Higher Specialised Court of Ukraine dismissed applicants' cassation appeal in November 2013
- Enforcement proceedings instituted with a view to evicting the applicants; unknown whether eviction order has been enforced.

title: CASE OF ZELENCHUK AND TSYTSYURA v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The first applicant inherited a share of land in 1999 and obtained ownership in 2000
- The Zdolbuniv District State Administration allocated a plot of land to the first applicant in 2006, which she obtained a property certificate for in 2007
- The first applicant has rented out portions of her land to companies since 2015
- The second applicant inherited the right to a share of land in 2004 and was allocated land in 2008
- The second applicant's land is rented by a limited liability company and he has received rent since 2010
- The applicants' land is subject to legislative restrictions on alienation and change of designated use
- Prior to 1990, all land in Ukraine was owned by the state
- Local councils were authorized to transfer land to individuals and non-state entities under the Land Code, but there was a ban on selling or disposing of the land for six years after acquisition
- A large proportion of agricultural land was held by collective farms, which were dissolved through the issuance of shares of land in the 1990s
- Millions of new owners were issued ownership certificates to specific plots of land after a large-scale conversion process
- The Land Code was amended multiple times to restrict the sale and transfer of certain types of land, commonly referred to as the "land moratorium"
- Amendments to the Land Code were made with the goal of creating a transparent and fair land market, but the moratorium was extended due to the need for additional legislation and technical work.

title: CASE OF GAFÀ v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicant is currently detained at the Corradino Correctional Facility, Paola.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of murdering his former partner on the 11th of December 2010.
- On the 13th of December 2010, the applicant was charged with wilful homicide and remanded in custody by the Court of Magistrates, as a Court of Criminal Inquiry.
- The applicant filed ten requests for bail, which were all rejected until August 2012.
- On 10th April 2012, the applicant instituted constitutional redress proceedings before the Civil Court (First Hall) in its constitutional competence, claiming a violation of Article 5 § 3 of the Convention.
- By a judgment of 27 June 2012, the Civil Court rejected the applicant’s claims, which was then confirmed by the Constitutional Court on 23 November 2012.
- After being held in custody for the maximum period allowed by law, the applicant became entitled to bail in accordance with Article 575(6)(a)(iii) of the Criminal Code.
- The Court of Magistrates granted the applicant bail on 22 August 2012, subject to various conditions.
- The Attorney General appealed against the decision, and the applicant objected and made various requests to reduce the amount of deposit he needed to pay.
- The court rejected the applicant’s requests.
- On 22 July 2013, the applicant requested the court to accept his mother as surety in lieu of the deposit, which was eventually accepted by the court on 2 August 2013.
- On 6 August 2013, the applicant was released from custody after being detained for thirty-two months of pre-trial detention.
- Throughout this time, committal proceedings and hearing of witnesses continued.
- On 6 February 2013, the applicant instituted a new set of constitutional redress proceedings, complaining of a violation of Article 5 § 3 of the Convention in connection with the “exorbitant sum” requested.
- The Civil Court (First Hall) in its constitutional competence rejected the applicant’s claims, which was then confirmed by the Constitutional Court.
- The onus of proving that the amount of deposit was too high for the applicant when considering his financial means lay with the applicant himself.
- The applicant must provide information to the court on his financial situation and on the real possibility of finding a surety able to guarantee the observance of the conditions imposed.

title: CASE OF M.R. AND D.R. v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The first applicant and B. got married in Prague in October 2003 and had a son, the second applicant, in May 2004. They lived as a family until 2007 when they divorced.
- In 2008, the first applicant and B. were granted alternating custody of the second applicant by the Prague 10 District Court, but in June 2009 B. took the child to Ukraine without the first applicant’s consent and settled there.
- The first applicant initiated a Hague Convention procedure for the return of the second applicant to the Czech Republic. In 2010, the Ivano-Frankivsk Town Court ordered B. to return the child to the first applicant in the Czech Republic, which she refused to comply with.
- The Czech court then granted sole custody of the child to the first applicant, and in 2011, the Supreme Court of Ukraine dismissed B.'s appeal on points of law.
- In 2013, the Halych District Court of Ivano-Frankivsk Region decided that the child should live with B. at her place of residence in Ukraine, which was upheld by the Ivano-Frankivsk Regional Court of Appeal.
- The bailiffs tried to enforce the judgment ordering the return of the child, but B. refused to comply and was fined several times. The bailiffs also requested that the child be placed in temporary care and put on the search list, but some of their requests were denied by the courts.
- The bailiffs eventually discontinued the enforcement proceedings in 2013 and 2014, citing insufficient enforcement measures and fines imposed on B.

title: CASE OF UNITED CIVIL AVIATION TRADE UNION AND CSORBA v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The United Civil Aviation Trade Union is a trade union registered in Budapest, and Mr A. Csorba is the President of the Union.
- Mr Csorba applied for authorisation to hold a demonstration on the road leading to Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport on 12 October 2012.
- The declared objectives of the demonstration were to draw public attention to the precarious financial situation of airport employees if salary cuts were carried out by the airport management.
- The Monor police department forbade the demonstration on 14 October 2012, considering that the planned demonstration would endanger traffic, make the airport inaccessible, and infringe passengers’ right to leave the country.
- The Budapest Surroundings High Court dismissed the applicants' complaint on 19 October 2012, endorsing in essence the police department's reasoning.

title: CASE OF HYSI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Qesarat, Tepelenë, in 1977 and is currently serving a prison sentence.
- On 14 January and 10 November 2005, the Gjirokastër District Court and the Court of Appeal convicted the applicant of attempted theft resulting in death in collusion with others and sentenced him to seventeen years’ imprisonment.
- The decision became final on 9 February 2007 after the Supreme Court dismissed an appeal by the applicant’s lawyer, who was appointed by his family throughout the court proceedings.
- The applicant was extradited from Greece to Albania on 30 March 2007.
- On 3 May 2007, the Gjirokastër District Court allowed a request by the applicant to appeal out of time and he lodged an appeal against his conviction in absentia.
- By a final decision of 7 October 2009, the Supreme Court upheld the applicant’s conviction as decided in the Gjirokastër District Court’s decision of 2005, ruling that it had become res judicata and that the facts and law in the case had been examined previously.

title: CASE OF MALO v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and is currently serving a prison sentence.
- On 9 July 2002, he was convicted of attempted armed robbery, negligent homicide, and premeditated murder and sentenced to 25 years in prison in his absence.
- He was represented by a court-appointed lawyer.
- On 7 October 2002, the Gjirokastër Court of Appeal upheld the decision in his absence.
- In 2007, the applicant applied for leave to appeal out of time, stating that he had not been aware of his conviction due to living in Italy.
- He lodged an appeal, requesting his case to be re-examined separately from his co-defendants, fresh examination of evidence, and maintenance that the authorities failed to inform him of judicial proceedings.
- On 17 December 2007, Gjirokastër Court of Appeal upheld his conviction in absentia.
- He lodged an appeal against the Court of Appeal’s decision, complaining of a breach of his right to have witnesses questioned and evidence re-examined.
- On 5 March 2010, the Supreme Court dismissed his appeal.
- On 21 February 2011, he lodged a constitutional appeal with the Constitutional Court, which was later declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF MUCA v. ALBANIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1970 and lives in Tirana.
- Criminal proceedings were brought against the applicant and two other co-accused on account of premeditated murder.
- The applicant addressed a letter to the Kavaja District Court and prosecutor stating that he had engaged a lawyer to represent him.
- The District Court later found the applicant not guilty but the other co-accused and prosecutor appealed.
- The Durrës Court of Appeal quashed the District Court’s decision and remitted the case for re‑examination.
- The Supreme Court rejected the applicant’s appeal.
- The applicant was later convected in absentia and sentenced to twenty-three years’ imprisonment.
- The Supreme Court rejected his application for review and his subsequent appeal.
- Judges who were part of the previous decisions were also part of the rejections.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint, which was also dismissed.

title: CASE OF TOPI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Peqin in 1977 and is currently serving a prison sentence.
- In 1998 the applicant was implicated in committing criminal offences, including setting up and being a member of an armed gang.
- On 4 February 1999, the prosecutor charged the applicant with the offences of membership of an armed gang, attempted intentional murder, and other crimes.
- Throughout the investigation, the applicant was represented by an officially appointed lawyer.
- The Elbasan District Court ordered the applicant's arrest on 12 February 1999, but it could not be enforced as he could not be traced.
- On 19 February 1999, the Elbasan District Court declared the applicant a fugitive from justice.
- On an unspecified date, the prosecutor decided to commit the applicant for trial.
- On 28 May 1999, the Supreme Court transferred the case to the Durrës District Court for examination.
- On 2 June 1999, the applicant's father appointed a lawyer to represent him.
- The trial proceedings against the applicant were conducted in absentia, and he was represented by a lawyer appointed by his family.
- On 15 February 2000, the Durrës District Court convicted the applicant in absentia of establishing and participating in an armed gang and attempted intentional murder.
- The applicant's family-appointed lawyer and other co-accused appealed against the conviction to the Durrës Court of Appeal.
- On 19 April 2000, the Court of Appeal declined to examine the applicant's appeal but convicted him of the same offences as before and sentenced him to thirteen years' imprisonment.
- On 7 December 2000, the Supreme Court dismissed appeals by the applicant and other co-accused against the Court of Appeal's decision of 19 April 2000.
- On 16 September 2005, the applicant was arrested by the Czech authorities on the basis of an arrest warrant issued by Albania.
- On 25 January 2006, the applicant was extradited to Albania.
- On 1 March 2006, the applicant was officially informed of his conviction in absentia.
- On 13 September 2007, the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal against the conviction in absentia.
- On 24 October 2007, the Constitutional Court declared the appeal time-barred as the two-year time-limit had started to run on 7 December 2000.

title: CASE OF GÜLBAHAR ÖZER AND YUSUF ÖZER v. TURKEY
facts:
- Two children of the applicants were killed by soldiers in south-east Turkey in 2005 along with three other young people.
- The applicants took the bodies to bury them in Siirt, where they wanted to bury them in their family cemetery, but the governor of Siirt issued a decision to bury them in two other villages instead.
- The vehicles carrying the coffins were stopped by gendarme soldiers and despite the objections of the applicants, soldiers confiscated the bodies of the children and took them away.
- The governor amended his decision allowing the children to be buried in the municipal cemetery in Eruh, without any religious ceremony, and the applicants brought a case to the Diyarbakır Administrative Court to annul the decision.
- The Diyarbakır Administrative Court rejected the case, citing the duty of the governor to maintain peace and public order in his province and that the decision was in compliance with restrictions under Turkish Constitution and Articles 8 and 9 of the Convention.
- The applicants appealed the decision, maintaining that incidents at the cemetery began only after the people found out about the authorities' refusal to allow them to bury their children in Siirt, and their request for an interim measure was rejected by the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF KOVYAZIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lives in Kostino, Kirov Region.
- On 6 May 2012, a public demonstration called the “March of Millions” was held in central Moscow.
- The applicant took part in the demonstration of 6 May 2012 at Bolotnaya Square and was later arrested for participation in mass disorder.
- The applicant was detained and tried on those charges but subsequently exempted from liability under the Amnesty Act.
- The applicant's criminal case was transferred to the Zamoskvoretskiy District Court of Moscow.
- The State Duma passed the Amnesty Act, which exempted persons suspected and accused of criminal offenses under Article 212 §§ 2 and 3 of the Criminal Code from criminal liability.
- On 19 December 2013, the Zamoskvoretskiy District Court granted the applicant's request to terminate the criminal proceedings against him, and he was released from detention.

title: CASE OF GORIUNOV v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
1. The applicant is serving a life sentence in a prison in Rezina.
2. A mobile phone was found in the applicant's cell, which is prohibited by prison rules.
3. As a result, the prison administration sanctioned him with a reprimand.
4. The prison board decided that the applicant should always be handcuffed when moving outside his cell without offering a reason, and the length of time for which the measure would be in place was not specified.
5. The measure was revoked five months later.
6. The applicant asked why he should be handcuffed, but received limited information about government orders.
7. The prisoner challenged the decision before the investigating judge, arguing that he had been sanctioned twice for the same offense, contrary to the express legal requirements, and that he had not been informed of the reasons for the decision to handcuff him.
8. The prison administration argued that the sanction had been lawfully applied and that the applicant had been properly informed.
9. The Rezina District Court dismissed the applicant's complaint as unfounded, finding that the measure was justified.
10. The applicant attempted to have the decision quashed by using an extraordinary remedy, but the Supreme Court of Justice refused his request.
11. The use of handcuffs and other restraints is authorized by the Regulation Concerning the Serving of Sentences (adopted by Government Decision no. 583 of 26 May 2006).
12. Instruments of restraint shall not be applied for any longer time than is strictly necessary according to the European Prison Rules under Recommendation Rec(2006)2.
13. The European Committee for the Prevention of Torture and Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment (CPT) calls on its members to review their treatment of life-sentenced prisoners to ensure that it is tailored to the individual risks they pose, both in custody and to the outside community, and not simply in response to the sentence that has been imposed on them.

title: CASE OF MİHDİ PERİNÇEK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Diyarbakır.
- Police received intelligence that two members of the PKK would go to Adana to carry out terror attacks.
- Police chased the two suspects on a motorbike and “Küçük Şiyar” drew his pistol and pointed it at a police car.
- The police car hit the motorbike and “Küçük Şiyar” fell to the ground and fired at the police officers.
- “Küçük Şiyar” was shot and admitted to the hospital.
- Police found 900 US dollars and a handwritten note in his pockets.
- The driver of the motorbike, M.N.B., was arrested.
- The pistol found next to “Küçük Şiyar” was used in another armed attack in Adana on 18 March 2004.
- “Küçük Şiyar” died at the hospital on 30 May 2004.
- The applicant identified the body of "Küçük Şiyar" as his son, Şiyar Perinçek.
- The clothes of Şiyar Perinçek were taken away by plainclothes police officers and were not returned to the prosecutor’s office.
- Seven of the eight police officers questioned denied ill-treatment and firing their weapon.
- The applicant joined the criminal investigation as an intervener.
- A security guard stated that the clothes of Şiyar Perinçek were taken away by plainclothes police officers.

title: CASE OF SALAKHBEKOV AND ABUKAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants applied for a recalculation of social benefits in 2008.
- Applicants were entitled to social benefits as clean-up workers.
- Domestic courts granted the applicant's claims.
- The appendix outlines further developments in the case.

title: CASE OF POCASOVSCHI AND MIHAILA v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants convicted by Moldovan courts and serving sentences in prison #8 in Tighina
- Prison #8 situated in Transdniestrian region of the Republic of Moldova, under control of Moldovan peacekeepers
- Prison #8 disconnected from electricity, water, and heating supplies by Bender local administration on 23 Sept 2002
- Detainees deprived of basic hygiene and received low-quality food
- Prison authorities informed various organizations for assistance in resolving the problem
- Bender prosecutor's office informed Helsinki Committee for Human Rights in Moldova about the reconnection of the prison to the electricity and water supply systems on 23 Feb 2003
- Some of the detainees were ill with tuberculosis, and on 10 July 2003, the last of those ill with tuberculosis were transferred to another location
- Local authorities disconnected prison #8 from electricity and water supply systems again on 10 July 2003 without a warning
- Applicants' representatives asked the Moldovan Prosecutor General's Office to take legal action against those responsible for disconnecting prison #8 from utilities systems
- Bender District Court ordered prosecutor’s office to initiate criminal proceedings against those responsible for the disconnection from utilities supply
- Applicants lodged a civil action against the Ministry of Justice, asking for finding of a violation of the rights guaranteed under Article 3 of the Convention
- The case transferred from Bender District Court to Buiucani District Court in Chişinău, before shifting to Anenii-Noi District Court
- Appeal courts ordered increase in compensation of each appellant from €200 to €1,266
- The right to a trial within a reasonable time breached, requiring additional compensation of €358.

title: CASE OF DORNEAN v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant lives in an annex to the same house as his ex-wife and their children.
- He has a hostile relationship with them and his former in-laws.
- He has been lodging complaints with various authorities about ill-treatment by his ex-wife and children, destruction of his property, and police inaction.
- He has been examined by medical experts who found injuries, including a broken elbow allegedly caused by his ex-wife and children.
- The investigation into the alleged ill-treatment has been discontinued and resumed multiple times due to insufficient evidence, contradictions in witness statements, and poor quality X-ray images.

title: CASE OF AL NASHIRI v. ROMANIA
facts:
A. Terrorist attacks: USS Cole bombing, MV Limburg bombing
B. HVD Program:
    1. Establishment and expansion of the program
         a. US President's memoranda
         b. Abu Zubaydah's capture and transfer
         c. CIA program setup for detention and interrogation
    2. Enhanced interrogation techniques
    3. Procedures and treatment of high-value detainees
    4. Conditions of detention at CIA black sites
    5. Scale of HVD program
    6. Closure of the HVD program
C. United States Supreme Court's judgment in Rasul v. Bush
D. Role of Companies in CIA rendition operations:
    1. Jeppesen Dataplan Inc.
E. Military Commissions
    1. Military Order of 13 November 2001
    2. Military Commission Order no. 1
    3. The 2006 Military Commissions Act and the 2009 Military Commissions Act
    4. Concerns over the procedure before the military commission
F. Review of the CIA’s activities involved in the HVD Program by the US Senate:
    1. Course of the review
    2. Findings and conclusions
G. Applicant's capture, transfer, secret detention, and transfers between 2002-2009
    1. Al Nashiri v. Poland case in court
    2. Transfers and detention between his rendition from Poland on 6 June 2003 and alleged rendition to Romania on 12 April 2004 
    3. Applicant's alleged secret detention at a CIA black site in Romania
    4. Applicant's further transfers during CIA custody
    5. Applicant's detention in Guantanamo Bay and military commission trial
H. Psychological effects of the HVD Program on the applicant
I. Identification of the location of the color code-named CIA detention sites in the 2014 US Senate Committee Report
J. The parliamentary inquiry in Romania and criminal investigation

title: CASE OF ABU ZUBAYDAH v. LITHUANIA
facts:
A. The “High-Value Detainee Programme”

- Establishment of the HVD Programme
- Enhanced Interrogation Techniques
- Standard procedures and treatment of “high value detainees” in CIA custody
- Conditions of detention at CIA “Black Sites”
- The scale of the HVD Programme
- Closure of the HVD Programme

B. The United States Supreme Court's judgment in Rasul v. Bush

C. Role of Jeppesen Dataplan, Richmor Aviation and other air companies in CIA rendition operations

- Jeppesen Dataplan Inc.

D. Review of the CIA’s activities involved in the HVD Programme in 2001-2009 by the US Senate

- Course of the review
- Findings and conclusions

E. The applicant’s detention and transfers

- Restrictions on information
- Capture and transfer to CIA custody
- Secret detention and transfers from March 2002 to September 2003
- Transfers and detention between September 2003 and February 2005
- Alleged secret detention at a CIA “Black Site” in Lithuania from 2005 to 2006
- Alleged rendition to Lithuania in February 2005 and rendition from Lithuania in March 2006
- Detention and treatment to which the applicant was subjected
- Further transfers during CIA custody until September 2006
- Detention at the US Guantánamo Bay facility since September 2006 to present

F. Psychological and physical effects of the HVD Programme on the applicant

G. Identification of locations of the colour code-named CIA detention sites in the 2014 US Senate Committee Report by experts

H. Parliamentary inquiry in Lithuania

- The Seimas investigation and findings
- Extracts from transcripts of the Seimas’ debates on the CNSD Findings

I. Criminal investigation in Lithuania

- Investigation conducted in 2010-2011
- Reopening of the investigation on 22 January 2015 and further proceedings

title: CASE OF SHAKULINA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicant was declared legally incapable by the Vyborgskiy District Court.
2. The Constitutional Court of Russia declared the practice of divesting people of their legal capacity in their absence unconstitutional.
3. The St Petersburg City Court quashed the judgment of the Vyborgskiy District Court and remitted the applicant's case for a fresh examination.
4. The applicant was involuntarily confined to a psychiatric hospital after being diagnosed with schizophrenia.
5. The applicant's request to discharge and challenge her involuntary confinement was dismissed by the Primorskiy District Court.
6. The Petrodvortsovyy District Court declared the applicant legally incapable.
7. The applicant's request for the restoration of legal capacity was dismissed by the Kochubeyevskiy District Court.
8. The applicant was stripped of legal capacity by the Koptevskiy District Court and the Dmitrovskiy District Court.

title: CASE OF SIDEA AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The case is similar to a previous case, Association “21 December 1989” and Others v. Romania.
- The applicants or their close relatives were injured or killed during the events of December 1989 in Bucharest, Brașov, and Vișina which led to the fall of the communist regime.
- Criminal investigations were opened by military prosecutor’s offices from several cities in 1990 regarding violence against demonstrators and the applicants’ injury or close relatives’ death during these events.
- The main criminal investigation was recorded in file no. 97/P/1990 (current no. 11/P/2014), and some cases were examined in this file despite a decision to not open an investigation or to discontinue proceedings.
- The military prosecutor’s office closed the main investigation on 14 October 2015, finding complaints were partly statute-barred, subject to amnesty, or ill-founded, and that some occurrences could not be classified as offenses.
- The decision of 14 October 2015 was annulled by a Prosecutor General’s decision of 5 April 2016, confirmed by the High Court of Cassation and Justice on 13 June 2016.
- On 1 November 2016, the military prosecutor ordered the initiation of a criminal investigation for the offense of crimes against humanity.
- Further steps were taken in gathering information up to February 2017, including contacting civil parties, questioning members of the political party, verifying the activity of relevant units, and reviewing audio/video recordings.
- As of April and May 2017, the criminal investigation was still ongoing.

title: CASE OF IORDAN v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants are residents of Dumbrăvița, Timiș County, born in 1939 and 1944 respectively.
- The case concerns their son's killing by gunfire on 23 December 1989 during anti-communism demonstrations in Timișoara.
- The military prosecutor's office opened investigations into the December 1989 crackdown, including a main investigation involving violence against civilians in Bucharest and other cities.
- The investigation regarding the events in Timișoara led to the conviction of senior military officers but did not include the death of the applicants' son.
- The applicants lodged a civil claim regarding their son's death, which was dismissed due to lack of substantiating documents.
- Both applicants are parties to the main criminal investigation file.
- The main criminal investigation was closed in 2015 due to statute-barred offences but was subsequently quashed, and to date, it is still ongoing.

title: CASE OF FARCAȘ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1935, 1945 and 1956 respectively and live in Ploieşti.
- In 1975, a group of engineers patented an invention concerning a method for separating hydrocarbon. The first applicant is one of the inventors. The second and third applicants are heirs of the other members of the group.
- On 26 January 1995, the applicants lodged an action for compensation against company R.
- On 24 June 2002, the Braşov County Court allowed in part the action lodged by the applicants against company R.
- On 10 March 2004, the applicants and company R. signed an agreement for the payment of the compensation awarded by the court.
- On 5 May 2005, the High Court of Cassation and Justice concluded that company R. had withdrawn its appeal on points of law against the decision of 8 November 2002.
- On 31 March 2004, company R. had sought its judicial reorganisation under a procedure provided for by Law no. 64/1995 on judicial reorganisation and bankruptcy.
- On 28 April 2004, the Bacău County Court allowed the application, started the reorganisation proceedings and nominated a judicial administrator.
- In 2006, company R. paid its debts in accordance with the plan.
- On 11 October 2007, the Braşov County Court held a hearing on the objections to the register of claims lodged by the applicants.
- On 23 January 2008, the judgment of the County Court was published in the Bulletin of Insolvency Proceedings (Buletinul Procedurilor de Insolvenţă, “the Bulletin”).
- On 17 April 2008, the Court of Appeal dismissed the applicants' argument that their appeal had been lodged out of time. 
- On 21 June 2010, the County Court closed the insolvency proceedings and noted that company R. had complied with all the obligations set out in the reorganisation plan.

title: CASE OF CEAICOVSCHI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant is the CEO of a company specialized in importing medical equipment.
- He was arrested in April 2015 in connection with a criminal investigation into bribery in public auctions.
- Searches were conducted at his home and company.
- He was the only accused who was kept in custody and was detained for several months.
- Prosecutors argued that his detention was justified because he could abscond, influence witnesses, and collude with other accused persons, and the offense was punishable with imprisonment.
- The applicant argued every time that he was ready to give up his passport and that there were no reasons to hold him.
- The court relied on similar reasons for prolonging his detention.
- The court ordered the applicant’s house arrest in October.
- The applicant requested a revocation of the house arrest, which was accepted, and he was released in November.
- The applicant experienced acute pain during detention and was diagnosed with several conditions but was not immediately hospitalized.
- He underwent spine surgery and remained in the hospital until he was moved to a prison hospital in April.
- In June, he was diagnosed with cholecystitis and frequent biliary colic and recommended surgery, but his transportation to a normal hospital was only approved in August after his condition deteriorated.

title: CASE OF BOTNARI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and is currently detained in Chișinău.
- On 17 March 2010, the applicant was arrested and charged with fraud and forgery of official documents. She was placed in the detention centre, which offered substandard conditions of detention.
- The applicant was transferred to Prison no. 13 where she was detained in a cell with sixteen other inmates and subjected to passive smoking. She was not provided with bedding and was not able to sleep normally.
- According to the Government, the applicant was transferred from the detention facility of the Ministry of the Interior to Prison no. 13 on 29 March 2010, and on 30 March 2011 was released from detention and was placed under house arrest. On 26 January 2012, after having been declared a wanted person, the applicant was again arrested and placed in detention in Prison no. 13. 
- According to the Government, during her detention in Prison no. 13 after 5 June 2013, the applicant was held in cells designed to hold a certain number of detainees and regularly disinfected.
- On 26 February 2003, the applicant was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma (“NHL” – a type of blood cancer), which affected her organs.
- The applicant was not provided with the medical assistance required for her condition.
- While in detention, the applicant's state of health deteriorated. In both detention facilities there was no specialist oncologist and chemotherapy was unavailable.
- According to two extracts from the applicant’s medical records dated 26 June 2014 and 9 July 2015, the applicant was in need of specific medical treatment from the Institute of Oncology and her medical condition was qualified as being of medium seriousness.
- The Centre for Human Rights in Moldova (“the Human Rights Centre”) found serious problems in Prison no. 13, notably concerning overcrowding, food quality, ventilation, and access to daylight. 
- The Moldovan prison population had increased by some 1,300 inmates and stood at approximately 7,770, representing an incarceration rate of some 220 per 100,000 inhabitants – one of the highest among Council of Europe member states. The national standard of at least 4 m2 of living space per prisoner was far from being met in most of the prison establishments visited.

title: CASE OF GOREMÎCHIN v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Chişinău.
- The applicant was charged with robbery, taking of hostages and blackmail in Ukraine in 1997 and 1998 while he was residing in Brussels, Belgium.
- The applicant was arrested on November 18th, 2008 in Brussels at the Moldovan authorities' request and was placed in Belgian prison pending extradition to Moldova.
- The applicant was extradited to Moldova on October 5th, 2009, and was ordered to be detained on remand by a judge.
- The applicant's detention was prolonged every three months with reasons provided for each extension citing that it was an exceptional case, there was a reasonable suspicion that he had committed serious offenses punishable by imprisonment, the criminal case was complex and if released, the applicant could interfere with the investigation, influence the witnesses and victims, reoffend or abscond.
- The applicant made a habeas corpus request on May 20th, 2010, asking for his detention to be replaced with a preventive measure other than deprivation of liberty but was denied on June 17th and his detention warrant was prolonged for another 90 days.
- The applicant was acquitted and ordered to be released from detention by the Bălți Court of Appeal on February 22nd, 2012.
- However, the Prosecutor’s Office lodged an appeal on points of law against the judgment, and it was upheld by the Supreme Court of Justice leading to reopened proceedings.
- The applicant was detained in several detention facilities from October 2009 until his release in February 2012.
- The applicant's detention conditions varied, but he endured poor living conditions, lack of proper sanitation and hygiene, insufficient food and bedding, and exposure to parasitic insects.

title: CASE OF ARTUR IVANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Novocheboksarsk.
- The applicant was ill-treated in police custody.
- The ill-treatment was established in a judgment of the Novocheboksarsk Town Court of the Chuvash Republic and upheld on 11 November 2008 by the Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic.
- The ill-treatment included Officer M. from the Novocheboksarsk town police station, who wore a police uniform, threatening the applicant, grabbing him, violently pushing him against a wall several times, and punching his left ear.
- The applicant had a traumatic rupture of the left eardrum with a haemorrhage, which caused a short-term health disorder.
- Officer M. was convicted under Article 286 § 3 (a) of the Criminal Code (abuse of power with the use of violence) and sentenced to three years’ imprisonment and a two‑year ban on exercising official power.
- The applicant brought a civil claim against the Ministry of Finance of the Chuvash Republic in respect of non-pecuniary damage, arguing that the ill‑treatment by the police had amounted to inhuman and degrading treatment proscribed by Article 3 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”).
- The domestic courts were to apply the Convention in accordance with the case-law of the European Court of Human Rights (“the Court”).
- The Town Court held that RUB 20,000 would be just and reasonable satisfaction for the mental suffering of the applicant as a result of his ill-treatment by the police officer, treatment which had undermined his honour and dignity and caused him insignificant health damage.
- The Supreme Court of the Chuvash Republic upheld the judgment on appeal, fully endorsing the Town Court’s calculation of the amount of compensation in respect of non‑pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF BATYRKHAIROV v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1980 and is detained in Atyrau, Kazakhstan.
- He left Kazakhstan in 2008 and lived in Saudi Arabia and Syria until June 2011.
- The applicant arrived in Turkey in June 2011.
- Two entry bans were issued against him on the grounds of suspected involvement in terrorism-related activities.
- The applicant was taken into police custody and transferred to Kumkapı Foreigners’ Removal Centre.
- On 28 October 2011, he was released pending the determination of his asylum application.
- On 4 November 2011, he lodged his asylum application with the Denizli Governor’s Office.
- On 28 November 2011, the applicant was notified that his asylum application had been rejected.
- On 29 November 2011, he objected to the rejection.
- On 26 December 2011, the embassy of Kazakhstan requested the Turkish Interior Minister to extradite the applicant.
- On 19 January 2012, the applicant was taken into police custody at Istanbul Atatürk Airport.
- On 28 February 2012, the Bakırköy Assize Court rejected the extradition request submitted by the Kazakhstan authorities.
- The applicant was released from prison on 28 February 2012 but was immediately transferred to the Kumkapı Foreigners’ Removal Centre in Istanbul.
- On 7 March 2012, the Deputy Director of General Security ordered the Istanbul Police Headquarters to deport the applicant.
- On 12 March 2012, the applicant was deported to Kazakhstan.
- Between 28 February and 12 March 2012, the applicant was detained at the Kumkapı Foreigners’ Removal Centre.
- The centre had a capacity of 300 persons, and a total of between 100 and 140 persons had been held during the period of the applicant's detention.
- Detainees were accommodated on three floors, with separate floors for male and female detainees.
- The detainees had some access to medical care, but the applicant claimed there were hygiene problems and poor quality of food.

title: CASE OF AMERKHANOV v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1989 and detained in Atyrau, Kazakhstan.
- Between January and November 2010, he was harassed, taken into police custody, and ill-treated by police in Kazakhstan.
- The applicant left Kazakhstan on November 27, 2010, and arrived in Turkey.
- The applicant was detained in Istanbul on June 9, 2011, and transferred to the Kumkapı Foreigners’ Removal Centre.
- On unspecified dates, the applicant applied for refugee status with the UNHCR and the national authorities in Turkey.
- On June 15, 2011, the applicant was interviewed by a police officer concerning his application for asylum.
- On June 28, 2011, the applicant was informed that his asylum application had been rejected.
- On September 13, 2011, the applicant was released from detention and ordered to go and live in the province of Sakarya.
- On March 15, 2012, the applicant was detained and informed that his asylum application had been rejected, and he was banned from entering Turkish territory.
- On March 19, 2012, the applicant was deported to Kazakhstan.
- The Ankara Administrative Court rejected the applicant's requests for a stay of execution and annulment of the decision to deport him on May 11, 2012, and February 13, 2013, respectively.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the judgment of February 13, 2013, on April 27, 2016.
- The applicant was detained at the Kumkapı Foreigners’ Removal Centre between June 9 and September 13, 2011, in allegedly overcrowded and unhygienic conditions.

title: CASE OF FATİH ÇAKIR AND MERVE NİSA ÇAKIR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The first applicant lost control of his car on a sharp bend, crashed into a barrier, and fell into an empty canal, resulting in the death of his wife and injuries to his daughter.
- The traffic accident report indicated that the barrier had been damaged prior to the accident, and there was a warning sign for a sharp bend ahead.
- The first applicant admitted to losing control of his car on the bend in his statements to the police and the public prosecutor.
- The İzmir Assize Court decided there was no need to subject the first applicant to a criminal penalty for causing death and bodily injury by negligence as he had already been aggrieved by the accident.
- The first applicant applied for a declaratory judgment to establish the condition of the road and the crash barrier, and an expert report found that the barrier had not been repaired after being damaged.
- The first applicant applied for compensation from the General Directorate of Highways and the Municipality of İzmir, but both denied responsibility.
- The applicants brought an action for compensation before the İzmir Administrative Court against the Municipality, which denied responsibility and argued that sole responsibility lay with the first applicant.
- The Administrative Court found the first applicant solely responsible for the accident and rejected the applicants' claims against the Municipality.
- The applicants appealed against the judgment, arguing that a technical expert opinion was required to ascertain whether the first applicant had lost control of his car due to an anomaly in the road, and that the Administrative Court had not taken the damaged barrier into account in assessing the Municipality's responsibility for the accident.
- The Supreme Administrative Court upheld the judgment of the İzmir Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF A.S. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant's personal information: born in 1968 and lives in Budapest.
- Applicant was employed by a state institution.
- Applicant's employment terminated in 2013.
- Applicant's severance payment was taxed at a 98% rate.
- The tax amount was 5,648,101 Hungarian forints (HUF) (approximately 18,800 euros (EUR)).

title: CASE OF E.B. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Balatonalmádi.
- The applicant was employed by the State from 1978 until 2013.
- Upon termination of employment, a section of her severance payment was taxed.
- The tax applied to the amount of 7,961,222 Hungarian forints (HUF), approximately 26,500 euros (EUR) and was at a rate of 98%.

title: CASE OF KHANI KABBARA v. CYPRUS
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1984 and lives in Canada.
- On February 27, 2011, the applicant was attacked by a police officer while in front of an ATM.
- He was illegally arrested without a warrant and taken to the police station where he was detained for six hours with handcuffs behind his back.
- During the detention, he was repeatedly beaten with a wooden stick, a metallic chair, and punches and kicks to various parts of his body, causing injuries, including a broken tooth.
- The police officers tortured him to confess to the offense of theft through the use of a forged credit card, accompanied by death threats.
- The officers refused to give him asthma medicine and delayed his access to medical treatment.
- He was later arrested on suspicion of various forgery and theft-related offenses and was detained on remand for eight days, and eventually, he was detained pending trial.
- The applicant reported the alleged ill-treatment to the High Commission of Canada, and an administrative investigation was conducted.

title: CASE OF ROMAN CATHOLIC ARCHDIOCESE OF VRHBOSNA v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant is a Roman Catholic community based in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina
- The Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina had discriminated against the applicant's right to freedom of religion
- The Human Rights Chamber for Bosnia and Herzegovina had ordered the relocation of public schools from the Archdiocese High School building in Travnik
- The Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina had agreed to reinstate the applicant in the premises by 1 July 2006
- The Travnik Municipal Council had issued a writ of execution on 23 June 2010, but it was quashed by the Travnik Cantonal Court and later rejected by the Travnik Municipal Court
- On 30 October 2012, the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina determined that the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina had not yet fully enforced the decision of 9 May 2003
- On 17 February 2017, the applicant initiated civil proceedings against the public school remaining in its premises, requesting its relocation as well as damages for the use of the premises between 1 February 2014 and 1 June 2017
- On 14 July 2017, the Municipal Court in Travnik rendered a judgment in the applicant's favour, awarding 270,360 convertible marks for pecuniary damages and 6,713 BAM for costs and expenses
- The respondent was ordered to vacate the applicant's premises within 30 days from receiving the judgment
- As of 20 February 2018, the Central Bosnia Canton had submitted a revision petition to the Supreme Court of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina against the final judgment in these proceedings
- The public school has still not been relocated.

title: CASE OF SEJDIJI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1968 and lives in Kumanovo.
- The applicant had been in pre-trial detention since 21 October 2008, in connection with proceedings related to a suspicion of criminal conspiracy and abuse of office when, on 26 December 2009, a new investigation was opened in respect of him and fourteen other people.
- The new investigation related to allegations of criminal conspiracy, abuse of office, extortion, and money laundering.
- The applicant lodged an appeal, arguing that the reasons provided by the investigating judge were not relevant and sufficient to justify another detention order.
- The appeal was dismissed, and further extensions of pre-trial detention were ordered, based on the gravity of the charges, the potential penalty, the circumstances under which the alleged offences had been committed, and the links between the suspects.
- The appeals were dismissed by the Court of Appeal, which found that the panels had given sufficient reasons for the applicant’s continued detention.
- The applicant made several unsuccessful applications for release on bail, as the guarantees offered were not sufficient to ensure his presence during the proceedings, given the gravity of the charges, the potential penalty, and the complexity of the proceedings.
- The applicant was convicted of charges against him and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment, and the conviction was upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF KARTVELISHVILI v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of manslaughter in 1998.
- In 2000, he was convicted of murder and sentenced to nine years’ imprisonment.
- In 2004, he was convicted of refusing to comply with an order of a prison officer and had his initial sentence extended by one year.
- In 2006, the applicant was placed in Tbilisi prison no. 7 to serve his sentences.
- On 8 August 2006, prison officers searched the applicant’s cell and found a penknife under the mattress on his bed.
- The applicant was charged with possessing a prohibited item in prison.
- In February 2007, the trial began, and the prison officers who conducted the search were summoned as witnesses for the prosecution.
- The applicant requested to have all of his cellmates examined as witnesses, which was denied by the court.
- In March 2007, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to three years in prison.
- The applicant's appeal against the judgment was rejected in October 2007, and his sentence was increased to four years.
- In November 2007, the applicant was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and viral hepatitis C.
- He underwent treatment for tuberculosis and was declared cured in 2008.
- In 2010, the applicant was prescribed anti-HCV drugs, but he postponed the treatment due to possible neurological side-effects.

title: CASE OF NOVOTNÝ v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
Main Descriptions of the Facts:

- The applicant was born in 1942 and lives in Batelov.
- In 1965 he had a sexual relationship with a woman who gave birth to a daughter, Z., on 2 March 1966.
- Z.’s legal guardian brought proceedings on her behalf in the Jihlava District Court for a declaration of paternity because the applicant denied he was the father.
- After giving birth to Z., but before initiating the aforementioned proceedings, the mother married another man.
- On 23 April 1970 the District Court found that the applicant was Z.’s father and ordered him to contribute to her maintenance.
- The court reached its finding after hearing evidence from several witnesses and a blood test known as a “bio-hereditary test”.
- The Brno Regional Court eventually upheld the judgment of the District Court, which became final on 10 June 1970.
- In 2011 the applicant requested that the Prosecutor General challenge his paternity in court, but his request was denied because the requirements of Article 62 of the Family Code to initiate such proceedings had not been met.
- An unequivocal DNA report on 19 April 2012 confirmed that the applicant was not Z.’s father.
- The Prosecutor General informed the applicant that the determination of his paternity had been decided by the Jihlava District Court under Article 54 of the Family Code and that therefore the prosecution service could not initiate proceedings under Article 62 and 62a of the Family Code.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint, stating that the competence of the Prosecutor General could only apply if all the legal requirements had been fulfilled.

title: CASE OF RASHAD HASANOV AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- Applicants are civil society activists and members of NIDA.
- Peaceful protests were organized against the death of soldiers in non-combat situations in January and March 2013.
- Three members of NIDA were arrested for planning to incite violence during the unlawful demonstration scheduled for 10 March 2013.
- The applicants were arrested on charges of illegal acquisition, transfer, sale, storage, transportation and carrying of arm, its accessories, supplies, explosive substances and devices by an organised group.
- The courts ordered their detention for a period of three months.
- The applicants appealed against the decisions ordering their pre-trial detention and their appeals were dismissed.
- The prosecutors requested extensions of pre-trial detention for the applicants and the courts extended their detention pending trial.
- The applicants requested house arrest in place of pre-trial detention which was dismissed.

title: CASE OF BEINAROVIČ AND OTHERS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicants or their relatives applied for property rights restoration on various dates in 1991 for land nationalised by the Soviet regime.
- Courts acknowledged the applicants' property rights in plots of land in Kryžiokai and Vaidotai.
- The administrative boundaries of certain municipal areas, including Kryžiokai and Vaidotai, changed in 1996.
- The Government approved a plan of forests of national importance in 2002, which included forests in Kryžiokai and Vaidotai.
- The prosecutor lodged a claim seeking to have I.B.'s property rights annulled, as the forest on his land was considered to be of national importance and could only be owned by the State.
- The court annulled I.B.'s property rights and the applicants' property rights to the part of the land covered by forest of national importance.
- The applicants, VCA and Ministry of Environment lodged appeals, but they were dismissed.
- The prosecutor lodged a second claim seeking to have I.B.'s property rights to another part of land annulled for the same reason.
- The court annulled I.B.'s property rights and the applicants' property rights to the part of the land covered by forest of national importance.
- Applicants were informed by the NLS that there was no more vacant land in Kryžiokai and I.B.'s property rights could be restored through various means.

title: CASE OF GASPAR v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and lived in Prague.
- In 2004, the applicant arrived in Russia and got married to a Russian citizen with whom she had a daughter in 2009.
- The applicant lived in Russia with regularly extended residence permits.
- On 15 October 2013, the applicant applied for Russian citizenship but on 28 March 2014, her application was rejected on the grounds of posing a threat to national security by the FSB.
- On 21 July 2014, the FMS revoked the applicant’s residence permit, referring to the FSB’s recommendation.
- The applicant was asked to leave Russia within fifteen days of the decision.
- The applicant tried to obtain a judicial review of the decision to revoke her residence permit but was unsuccessful.
- The City Court believed that the adequate legal basis for the decision was examined, and the decision had been lawful and reasonable.
- The Supreme Court examined the case in camera, upheld the decision of the City Court, and concluded that the decision was lawful and substantiated.

title: CASE OF T.K. v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant is serving a prison sentence in Vilnius and lived with V.K., raising two boys born in 2002 and 2004 respectively.
- The family was put on the list of families at social risk and warned about not fulfilling their parental duties properly.
- The applicant was convicted of causing physical pain to the boys and attempting to influence a witness. The court established that he had been physically violent towards them in 2009.
- V.K. lodged a complaint alleging that the applicant had shown pornographic films to their children and had sexually abused them in their home during a period between 2009 and 15 October 2009.
- Ro.K. stated during questioning that he had been told by his mother that they had to remain silent or she would go to prison and that their father would be released.

title: CASE OF ZEZEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant moved from Kazakhstan to Russia to live with his Russian family.
- He married a Russian national and had a child.
- He requested a document certifying he had no criminal record in Kazakhstan in order to apply for Russian nationality.
- The Federal Security Service (FSB) decided he posed a threat to national security and issued an exclusion order prohibiting his re-entry until 2014.
- The applicant appealed the exclusion order, stating it was arbitrary, based on undisclosed information, and would disrupt his family life.
- The Regional Court examined the appeal in camera, rejected it, and upheld the exclusion order.
- The Supreme Court upheld the Regional Court’s judgment and stated the FSB decision was taken owing to the real threat the applicant posed to national security.
- The FMS issued an order for the applicant’s deportation in 2010, but it was not enforced.
- In 2013 the applicant was fined and detained for a violation of immigration regulations, and he was deported from Russia later that year.
- The applicant attempted to re-enter Russia, was banned until 2014, and a criminal case was opened against him in 2014 for suspicion of involvement in computer fraud.

title: CASE OF ALPEYEVA AND DZHALAGONIYA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant is a Russian national who was born in 1951 and lives in Volzhskiy, in the Volgograd Region.
- In March 1994, the first applicant was granted Russian citizenship, which was stamped in her Soviet passport by the Russian embassy in Bishkek.
- In 2006, the first applicant's passport was seized by an official of the Federal Migration Service, who declared it invalid as she had not properly acquired Russian citizenship.
- The Volzhskiy Town Court found in favour of the first applicant in 2007 but the decision was quashed.
- The first applicant was granted Russian citizenship under a simplified procedure in 2009.
- The second applicant had a Soviet Union passport issued on 21 December 1981 by the Chkhorozkuskiy Department of the Interior of the Republic of Georgia.
- On 19 February 2002, the second applicant was issued with a Russian passport by the Passport and Visa Directorate of Police Office no. 1 of Taganrog, in the Rostov Region.
- The Kostroma Region FMS issued a decision in September 2010 that the second applicant was not a Russian citizen.
- The Sverdlovskiy District Court of Kostroma upheld the decision of the FMS in October 2010.
- The Kostroma Regional Court upheld the decision of the FMS in December 2010.
- The second applicant applied for Russian citizenship in March 2013.

title: CASE OF M.T.B. v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and lived in Istanbul.
- On 10 May 1999, a criminal complaint was lodged against him for issuing an uncovered cheque.
- The trial court ordered a summons to be served on the applicant during a preparatory hearing held on 2 September 1999.
- The summons was returned undelivered, and attempts were made to locate the applicant through police, the neighborhood mayor and enquiries to his secondary address.
- The trial court authorised his detention in absentia on 14 February 2000, in the first hearing held in his absence.
- Between that date and 13 October 2004, the court waited for the detention order to be executed.
- In the absence of an appeal, the court convicted and sentenced the applicant to a fine of TRL 500 million on 13 October 2004.
- In 2006, police officers went to the applicant’s apartment with an arrest warrant and informed him of the charges and conviction against him.
- Upon examination of the case file, the applicant discovered the charges, and subsequently lodged an appeal against the judgment.
- The appeal was dismissed as it was lodged out of time.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the lower court’s decision and rejected the applicant’s application to set aside the decision.
- The applicant was imprisoned on 24 November 2006, for failure to pay the fine imposed on 13 October 2004, and conditionally released on 26 November 2006.
- The application lodged under Article 308 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was rejected on 1 December 2008.

title: CASE OF GORCHAKOVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were employees of a municipal education institution and sought recovery of unpaid wages and taxes.
- The Kolomna Town Court issued a first-instance judgment on the merits of the case on 13 July 2004 which was later quashed by the Moscow Regional Court on 22 September 2004 and remitted the case for a fresh examination.
- On 7 July 2005, the Town Court granted the applicants’ claims awarding each of them a certain amount against their employer (see Appendix I), and the judgment was later upheld on appeal by the Moscow Regional Court on 28 September 2005.
- The court hearings were adjourned twenty-five times between 26 June 2001 and 7 July 2005 due to various reasons, of which one year was attributable to the authorities.
- The employer institution was liquidated on an unspecified date in 2005, and the relevant record was made into the State Register of Legal Entities on 18 October 2005.
- The judgment of 7 July 2005 was partially enforced in respect of certain applicants on 30 June 2006, as specified in Appendix I.

title: CASE OF EUROMAK METAL DOO v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant company was set up in 1998 as a limited liability company, trading in scrap metal by purchasing waste metals and processing them for sale.
- The applicant was registered for VAT and complied with rules of the “tax credit” system, periodically requesting VAT deductions from the State.
- Until the audit in 2009, the applicant submitted regular tax returns without indicating wrongdoing.
- After an audit, the IRO concluded that the applicant had failed to meet necessary conditions for VAT deductions due to suppliers that had not declared or paid VAT.
- The IRO issued two decisions in November 2009 for incorrect calculation of VAT, ordering the applicant to pay an additional MKD 3,827,546.00 for the period 2005-2007.
- The applicant appealed without suspensive effect, but the appeal was dismissed by the Minister of Finance in February 2010.
- A written reprimand to pay full amount, including interest, was received by the applicant in March 2010.
- The applicant lodged an administrative action with the Administrative Court in April 2010, but the IRO blocked their bank account in April 2010 as well.
- The Administrative Court remitted the case to the Ministry of Finance in March 2011 and dismissed the action in March 2013. The Higher Administrative Court upheld the findings of tax authorities in March 2014, and the applicant company ceased to exist in February 2017.
- The applicant's bank account remained blocked until it closed in April 2017, and several individuals were indicted for criminal enterprise, abuse of office, and tax evasion in connection to some of the applicant company's suppliers.
