title: CASE OF KULA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was a professor of translation in the Faculty of Science and Literature of the University of Mersin.
- The applicant was invited to Istanbul to take part in a television programme on 31 March 2001.
- The director of the translation course expressed doubts about the applicant's invitation being in keeping with the university's principles.
- The dean of the faculty decided that the applicant's participation in the programme was not appropriate, but he took part anyway.
- The applicant was disciplined for twice taking part in the programme without the university's authorization, resulting in a reduction of his salary by one-eighth.
- The applicant appealed the decision, citing his academic freedom and claim that the regulation was wrongly applied.
- The Administrative Court dismissed the application, upholding the university's decision to impose a sanction.
- The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law, which was also dismissed by the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF SARITAŞ AND GEYİK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants attended a concert by a band called "Grup Yorum" in Hozat, where they chanted slogans.
- The slogans included "Revolutionary prisoners are immortal" and "Revolutionary prisoners are our honour."
- The applicants were charged with disseminating propaganda in favour of the DHKP/C.
- The Malatya Assize Court convicted the applicants and sentenced them to ten months' imprisonment each.
- The court considered that the concert was a propaganda activity in favour of the DHKP/C.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the first-instance court's judgment.
- The applicants served their prison sentences after being summoned to do so.

title: CASE OF ERBEK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1991 and lives in Mersin.
- On 30 December 2011, the applicant was taken into custody.
- He was suspected of being a member of a terrorist organization and making propaganda for them.
- The investigating judge ordered his detention on remand on the same day.
- The applicant's lawyer lodged an objection and requested his release on 28 March 2012.
- On 29 March 2012, the Mersin Magistrates' Court dismissed the objection without a hearing.
- On 16 April 2012, the applicant's lawyer filed another objection.
- On 17 April 2012, the Mersin Criminal Court with General Jurisdiction dismissed the objection without a hearing.
- The applicant was released from detention on 5 September 2012.
- On 10 September 2012, a bill of indictment was filed accusing the applicant of being a member of a terrorist organization and making propaganda.
- Proceedings against the applicant are still pending before an assize court, according to the latest information in the case file.

title: CASE OF JASAVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Podgorica.
- Several articles about a human trafficking case in Montenegro were published in the daily newspaper Dan between 3 December 2002 and 15 September 2003.
- The applicant's name was mentioned in various contexts in the articles.
- On 22 October 2004, the applicant sued the publisher of the newspaper for non-pecuniary damage due to violation of his honor and reputation caused by the publishing of untrue information about him.
- On 4 June 2010, the Podgorica First Instance Court partly ruled in favor of the applicant and ordered the publisher to pay the applicant 8,000 euros (EUR) in non-pecuniary damages and to publish the judgment in Dan.
- On 22 October 2010, the Podgorica High Court amended the judgment and awarded the applicant EUR 4,000 as compensation for the non-pecuniary damage suffered.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal on 14 January 2011.
- On 7 April 2011, the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's appeal.

title: CASE OF KAHADAWA ARACHCHIGE AND OTHERS v. CYPRUS
facts:
- Three Sri Lankan applicants went to Cyprus for employment purposes.
- Each applicant was granted a temporary residence permit.
- The first applicant left Cyprus twice, got married in Sri Lanka during his second visit, and his wife joined him in Cyprus.
- The first applicant’s wife abandoned her work and residence and did not apply for the renewal or extension of her temporary residence permit.
- The police arrested all nine Sri Lankans, including the applicants, on reasonable suspicion of taking part in a public fight and other offenses.
- The Attorney General decided not to prosecute the applicants but to deport them instead, and their residence permits were revoked.
- The deportation and detention orders were issued against the applicants, and they were released on 14 January 2011.
- The applicants were re-arrested and deported soon after.
- The first applicant’s wife stayed in Cyprus illegally and was later arrested.

title: CASE OF BAYAR v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was the editor-in-chief of Ülkede Özgür Gündem newspaper.
- On 6 July 2004, an article titled "Analysing the Kurdish dynamic correctly" was published in the newspaper, written by Mr B.G.
- The article expressed views on Abdullah Öcalan and its role in regional and international politics and political developments in Turkey, and a photograph of Abdullah Öcalan shaking hands with a group of armed men was published next to the article.
- The public prosecutor charged the applicant on 8 July 2004, with disseminating propaganda in favour of KONGRA-GEL under section 7(2) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (Law no. 3713) on account of the article published on 6 July 2004.
- The applicant argued that the article was a news article and had not contained propaganda inciting to violence during the proceedings.
- The Istanbul Assize Court convicted the applicant of disseminating propaganda and sentenced him to six months' imprisonment and a fine on 24 May 2005.
- The applicant appealed the decision.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the decision of the Istanbul Assize Court on 18 November 2009.
- As per the document signed by the President of the Istanbul Assize Court and Istanbul public prosecutor on 15 January 2010, the applicant was required to pay a fine of TRY 1,802.

title: CASE OF TALU v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in Siirt.
- On 9 January 2009, the applicant was taken into custody on suspicion of membership of a terrorist organisation and disseminating its propaganda.
- On 13 January 2009, the applicant was ordered detention on remand by the Siirt Magistrates’ Court.
- On 3 August 2009, the applicant’s lawyer filed an objection against the decision on the applicant’s detention and requested release.
- On 6 August 2009, the Diyarbakır public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment against the applicant.
- On 10 August 2009, the Diyarbakır Assize Court decided to prolong the applicant’s detention.
- On 8 September 2009, the Diyarbakır Assize Court decided to extend the applicant’s detention on remand.
- On 1 October 2009, the applicant was released pending trial after the preparatory hearing.
- On 31 December 2009, the Diyarbakır Assize Court acquitted the applicant of all charges.

title: CASE OF HÜLYA EBRU DEMİREL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant took an exam to become a civil servant in 1999 and was appointed to the post of security officer in a State-run electricity company.
- TEDAŞ informed the applicant that she would not be appointed to the post because she was a woman and had not completed military service.
- The applicant filed an action against TEDAŞ and won the case in the Gaziantep Administrative Court. She was offered a contract by the Kilis branch of TEDAŞ but later the Supreme Administrative Court overturned the decision.
- The applicant argued that the Supreme Administrative Court's decision ran counter to the principle of equality and the State’s positive obligation to ensure non‑discrimination between men and women.
- The Twelfth Division of the Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s case and held that the post was reserved for male candidates only because of the requirement of having completed military service. The decision was later rectified but the previous decision was held to be in accordance with the law and procedure.

title: CASE OF MIHALEVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in different years and live in different cities in Bulgaria.
- The father of the first applicant and grandfather of the second owned a machinery factory that was nationalized in 1947 and allocated to a State-owned enterprise.
- After the Restitution Act came into force, the first applicant and his brother requested the factory building to be stricken out of the register of State properties in 1992.
- In 1994, the first applicant and his brother entered into a rent agreement with the State-owned company, which was later extended multiple times.
- In January 1998, the first applicant and his brother applied for compensation under the Compensation Act for moveable properties but not for the building.
- The Minister of Economy awarded them compensation for moveable properties, stating that no compensation was due for the factory building because it had been subject to restitution.
- Company T. was privatized in 2003, and after that, it claimed to be the owner of the factory building, which led to legal proceedings.
- The Gabrovo Regional Court dismissed the claim against the applicants in 2009, but on appeal, the Veliko Tarnovo Court of Appeal allowed the claim in 2010.
- In 2011, the applicants applied for compensation under the Compensation Act, but their request was dismissed as it had not been submitted within the time-limit provided for under that Act.

title: CASE OF SEMACHE v. FRANCE
facts:
- The applicant's father and another individual were driving erratically after consuming alcoholic beverages.
- The police officers waved the car down and attempted to arrest the applicant's father.
- The applicant's father resisted arrest and was forcibly handcuffed.
- While in the police car, the other individual insulted and spit at one of the officers, leading to immobilization.
- During the journey to the police station, the applicant's father was held in a "double-seated embrace" for the rest of the trip.
- Upon arrival at the police station, the applicant's father was extracted from the vehicle and fell to the ground.
- The applicant's father and the other individual were both placed in a transit room and laid out flat, on their stomachs and in a safe lateral position, with their hands cuffed behind their backs.
- Both individuals vomited multiple times and were taken to the hospital half an hour later.
- The applicant's father suffered a state of cardiac arrest and eventually died.

title: CASE OF AVISO ZETA AG v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant company, a bank in Vienna, has been in liquidation since November 2016 and the proceedings are ongoing. 
- The company purchased and held shares in deposit, mostly in the IF company, for third parties. 
- Due to a significant loss in value, court proceedings were filed against the bank. 
- Two individuals, after consultations with an investment advisor, ordered the bank to purchase and hold shares in IF. 
- In 2012, a court ordered the bank to repay the two individuals for their share purchase, which the bank appealed. 
- The Vienna Court of Appeal granted the bank's appeal, but the Supreme Court granted an ordinary appeal on points of law, restoring the Commercial Court's decision. 
- The bank filed an action for nullity, claiming that Judge N., who was one of the five judges in the panel that ruled against the bank, was biased due to his own purchase of shares in IF, and had previously declared himself biased in similar cases. 
- The Supreme Court excluded Judge N. from the proceedings, but rejected the bank's action for nullity, holding that bias of a judge did not constitute a ground for nullity under the Code of Civil Procedure. 
- In other proceedings, the applicant company challenged Judge N. for bias, and the Supreme Court granted the challenge and declared Judge N. biased.

title: CASE OF S.Z. v. GREECE
facts:
- Applicant is born in 1984 and lives in Athens
- Arrested on 21 September 2013 for possession of a fake French passport
- Sentenced to ten months’ imprisonment on 24 September 2013
- Arrested again on 25 September 2013 and put in administrative detention with a view to being expelled from the country
- Director of the Aliens Subdivision of Attica ordered the applicant’s expulsion on 28 September 2013
- According to the applicant, he was informed of those decisions on 30 September 2013
- On 18 October 2013, the applicant was transferred to the Attica Regional Asylum Service and reiterated his asylum request
- On 12 November 2013, the applicant was granted refugee status and was released the next day
- Detention facilities at Zografou police station were located in the basement of the police station
- The cell had been filthy and overcrowded
- Food provided had been of very poor quality
- Medical treatment had not been provided
- Applicant had been examined by a psychiatrist and did not present any major active psychopathology.

title: CASE OF PETROV AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants are serving either life sentences or a lengthy period of imprisonment in different prisons in Bulgaria
- One applicant was sentenced to twenty years imprisonment in November 2011 and was placed in isolation in Burgas Prison under poor conditions
- Another applicant was sentenced to life imprisonment in a final decision by the Supreme Court of Cassation of 10 November 2005 and complained about poor conditions in Plovdiv Prison, including the lack of running water and toilet in his cell
- This applicant had also been kept under a very impoverished and restrictive “special regime” between 2007 and 2011, alone in a cell
- A third applicant was sentenced to whole-life imprisonment on 26 July 2004 in a final judgment of the Supreme Court of Cassation and complained about the “special regime” and inadequate material conditions of detention in which he has been serving his sentence since 24 January 2012 in Varna Prison
- This applicant has been serving his sentence in isolation from the surrounding world, namely in a permanently locked cell without any contact with prisoners who are serving sentences lighter than life imprisonment
- As to the material conditions in which he has been kept since 24 January 2012, the applicant submitted poor conditions, with cockroaches and rats roaming about
- The hygiene in the cell and the common spaces has been extremely poor, with the toilet standing about 45cm from his bed and no hygienic products for cleaning
- One applicant has been kept in a permanently locked cell in Pazardzhik Prison, isolated from the rest of the prison population and only allowed to communicate with other life prisoners during the one-hour daily physical exercise he took outside his cell.

title: CASE OF D.R. v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant has been diagnosed with several mental disorders since 1999 and has been admitted to psychiatric hospitals multiple times.
- The applicant received administrative penalties for insulting another person, threatening a teenager with an electroshock device, and scaring a minor.
- The applicant sprayed tear gas at a fifteen-year-old and was investigated for breach of public order.
- The court ordered the applicant to undergo a psychiatric assessment and concluded that she had a chronic mental disorder, rendering her incapable of understanding and controlling her actions.
- The court ordered compulsory inpatient treatment for the applicant at Rokiškis Psychiatric Hospital.

title: CASE OF INDUSTRIAL FINANCIAL CONSORTIUM INVESTMENT METALLURGICAL UNION v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Cabinet of Ministers decided to privatize Kryvorizhstal in August 2003.
- Kryvorizhstal included in a list of State-owned assets to be privatized in November 2003.
- The applicant company was founded in April 2004.
- State Property Fund announced a bidding competition for the purchase of 93.02% of Kryvorizhstal's share capital in May 2004.
- Applicant company declared the winner of the bidding competition in June 2004 and paid for the shares.
- Lawfulness and transparency of the privatization was contested by the political opposition.
- President Yushchenko and Prime Minister Tymoshenko made public statements that the privatization was unlawful in 2005.
- Cabinet of Ministers revoked decision to privatize Kryvorizhstal and declared the contract with the applicant company invalid in June 2005.
- State took control of Kryvorizhstal in June 2005 and launched the procedures for resale.
- The applicant company challenged the authorities' decrees before the commercial courts and courts of general jurisdiction.
- ArcelorMittal Duisburg GmbH became the new owner of Kryvorizhstal's share capital in October 2005. 
- The Prosecutor General lodged a cassation appeal in the interests of the State with the Supreme Court in February 2005, which was allowed in March 2005.

title: CASE OF FORTALNOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants' details and hours spent in custody are listed in the appendix.
- The applicant was arrested on 18 July 2005 and subjected to a body search and questioning.
- A criminal case was opened against the applicant on 19 July 2005, and an arrest record was drawn up at 7.10 a.m.
- The Dzerzhinskiy District Court ordered the applicant to be remanded in custody on 20 July 2005.
- The St Petersburg City Court found the above-mentioned decision lawful on 9 August 2005.
- The applicant threatened a taxi driver with a knife on 28 June 2007 and was later arrested at about 4 a.m. that day.
- The Norilsk District Court ordered the applicant's detention on 30 June 2007.
- The police arrested the applicant on 8 July 2011, and an arrest record was drawn up at 9.25 p.m. on 10 July.
- The applicant was arrested on 11 October 2010, and an arrest record was drawn up at 2:25 a.m. on 12 October.
- The applicant was arrested on 7 September 2011, and an arrest record was drawn up at 5:25 p.m. on 8 September.
- The applicant was taken to a police station on 26 November 2010, and a record of his arrest was drawn up on 30 November 2010.
- The applicant was taken to a police station on 15 January 2010, and an official arrest record was drawn up on 16 January 2010.

title: CASE OF KIPS DOO AND DREKALOVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The first applicant was founded in 1990 and is based in Podgorica. 
- The second applicant is the founder, executive director, and owner of 99.2698 % of the first applicant's shares, while the remaining 0.7302% belongs to the second applicant's wife and son.
- The first applicant entered into two contracts with the Development Land Social Fund in 1998 to obtain the right to use four plots of development land. 
- The four plots of land were later combined into one and became the ownership of the first applicant in 2011. 
- The Property Administration divided the cadastral plot of land no. 2090/1036 into two in 2005, one of which retained the number 2090/1036 and the other became registered as no. 2090/1220. 
- The cadastral plot of land no. 2090/1036 was split again in 2016, resulting in two pieces - one of which kept the same number and the other registered as no. 2090/1581. 
- The first applicant registered its plan for a shopping center and office building in the Detailed Urbanistic Plan in 2004. 
- The DUP changed in December 2004, joining the second applicant's adjacent plot of land with the first applicant's into one urban plot. 
- The President of the Municipality signed a ban on construction for the next 90 days from 6 June 2005, with an exception for investors who had already obtained a building permit. 
- A further ban on construction was introduced for up to one year at most until there was a newly-adopted DUP. 
- In 2006, a new DUP was issued that planned the construction of two buildings instead of the shopping centre planned by the first applicant. 
- The Commercial Court ruled in favor of the first applicant on April 7, 2006, ordering the Agency to calculate the communal charges. 
- The Court of Appeals and the Supreme Court upheld the decision on April 18, 2008, and December 29, 2008, respectively. 
- The Agency calculated the charges on August 6, 2008. 
- The Administrative Court dismissed the first applicant's claim on December 29, 2005, and the Supreme Court upheld the decision on March 2, 2006.

title: CASE OF GÎRLEANU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was a local correspondent for România liberă, covering various fields including investigations into the activities of the armed forces and police.
- Secret documents leaked from a Romanian unit in Afghanistan in the summer of 2004.
- O.O., along with other journalists, criticized authorities for allowing leaks of secret sensitive military information on a television show in January 2006.
- România liberă and Ziua newspapers published articles on leaked confidential information.
- The prosecutor’s office opened an investigation and instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant and four others for disclosing classified information on national security.
- The applicant was sanctioned with an administrative fine of ROL 800 (EUR 240) and ordered to pay part of the judicial costs incurred in the investigation.

title: CASE OF KRYUTCHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1960 and lives in Orsk.
- On 28 May 2005, the applicant was stopped and assaulted by police officers while walking home drunk.
- The police officers kicked the applicant in the stomach, and he lost consciousness, but they did not call an ambulance when he demanded one.
- The applicant was released the next morning but was hospitalized on the evening of 29 May 2005 with internal bleeding.
- According to the forensic medical report, the applicant suffered blunt abdominal trauma with a ruptured intestine, which had caused him serious health damage.
- The applicant also suffered abrasions on his back, forearms and wrist joints, which originated from impact with hard, blunt objects but did not cause him any health damage.
- The Orsk police were informed about the applicant's hospitalization on 29 May 2005.
- A criminal case was opened against the perpetrators on 14 June 2005, but it was suspended on 14 October 2005, owing to the inability to identify the individuals to be charged.
- The preliminary investigation was restarted several times to take additional measures.
- The applicant filed a civil claim against state authorities seeking compensation for his ill-treatment at the police station and the lack of effective investigation.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Orsk granted the applicant's claim in part and awarded him RUB 150,000.
- The Orenburg Regional Court upheld the judgment on appeal.

title: CASE OF LAKATOS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1986 and lives in Gyál.
- On 26 February 2011, the Pest Central District Court remanded the applicant in custody on suspicion of aggravated murder.
- The court found it necessary to detain the applicant to prevent him from tampering with evidence and threatening witnesses.
- An appeal against that decision was dismissed on 3 March 2011.
- The Buda Central District Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention on 21 March 2011 and 23 May 2011.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that the conditions for pre-trial detention had not been fulfilled because there was no risk of his absconding or influencing witnesses.
- The first-instance decision was upheld on appeal by the Budapest Regional Court.
- The applicant’s pre-trial detention was extended on a number of occasions by various courts based on the risk of absconding and risk of collusion.
- The Budapest High Court released the applicant from pre-trial detention and placed him on bail under house arrest on 22 February 2013 but he was placed in detention again on 28 March 2013.
- The Budapest High Court found the applicant guilty of aggravated murder and sentenced him to 18 years’ imprisonment on 29 October 2014.

title: CASE OF MIRKOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants were prison employees eligible for certain benefits under Serbian law.
- Pension and work-related issues for prison staff were regulated by specific laws.
- Employees in correctional facilities were entitled to an accelerated accumulation of pension rights and a personal coefficient increase of up to 30%.
- A directive provided for a 10% increase in personal coefficients between 2007 and 2011, but this was later found unconstitutional.
- Some courts granted compensation claims while others rejected them, leading to inconsistent domestic case-law.
- Some claimants were successful in other courts of appeal.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation set aside a judgment by the Novi Sad Court of Appeal.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the applicants' appeals between 2012 and 2014, alleging a breach of the principle of legal certainty.
- Each applicant lodged a separate civil claim and a constitutional appeal, and their cases were decided on different dates.

title: CASE OF MAYSTRENKO v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The document contains details of a case
- The details are outlined in a table
- The applicant complained about inadequate conditions of detention
- The applicant complained about lack of effective remedy in domestic law
- The applicant raised complaints under Articles 6 § 1 and 13 of the Convention
- The complaints were related to the excessive length of criminal proceedings

- The applicant in application no. 52321/14 raised a complaint under Article 3 of the Convention regarding the conditions of his detention.

title: CASE OF SHISHKINA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- List of applicants and details of the applications are in the appended table.
- Complaints of applicants about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- Complaints about the lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.
- Raising other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF G.I.E.M. S.R.L. AND OTHERS v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant companies have registered offices in different cities in Italy.
- The applicant company owned a plot of land in Bari suitable for building.
- Bari municipal council approved a site division and development plan submitted by Sud Fondi S.r.l.
- The applicant company informed the Bari municipal authority that it wished to participate in a site development agreement.
- Sud Fondi S.r.l. was issued a building permit by the Bari municipal authority and began the construction work, which was mostly completed by 17 March 1997.
- In April 1996, the public prosecutor of Bari opened a criminal investigation.
- The Bari District Court acknowledged the illegality of the buildings erected at Punta Perotti as they had been built in breach of Law no. 431 of 8 August 1985.
- The Bari District Court ordered the confiscation of all the developed land at Punta Perotti, including that belonging to the applicant company, together with the buildings thereon, and the incorporation of the property, without compensation, into the estate of the municipal authority of Bari.
- The Heritage Minister prohibited any building in the coastal area near the city of Bari, including at Punta Perotti, on the ground that it was a site of significant natural interest.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the Court of Appeal’s decision and ordered the confiscation of all the buildings and plots of land.
- The Bari municipal authority informed the applicant company that the ownership of the land at Punta Perotti had been transferred to the municipality.
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant company’s appeal on points of law that sought the return of its land.
- In 2013, the Bari District Court revoked the confiscation measure and ordered the return of the land to the applicant company.

title: CASE OF KAYMAK AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A list of applicants is provided in the appended table.
- The table also includes relevant details of the applications.
- The applicants lodged a complaint about their detention conditions.

- The applicants have complained about the poor detention conditions.
- In two of the applications, there were also complaints under Article 13 of the Convention.

facts:

facts:
