title: CASE OF OSOVSKA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicants obtained judgments ordering higher pension rates
- State Bailiff’s Service executed judgments
- Defendant pension authorities lodged appeals outside the limitation period
- Authorities requested renewal of time-limit for appeal without good reasons
- Administrative courts renewed time-limit, quashed judgments, and rejected claims or discontinued proceedings. 
- Additional relevant information in Appendix I.

title: CASE OF TCHOKHONELIDZE v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Tsereteli, Marneuli Region, Georgia. 
- A certain individual, Ms K., applied for a permit to construct a petrol station on a plot of land. 
- The applicant, serving as the deputy of the Governor, was assigned to examine the application. 
- During a meeting, the applicant allegedly requested a bribe of USD 30,000 to be shared with other representatives. 
- Ms K. reported the incident to the Department of Constitutional Security of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. 
- The Tbilisi City Court authorized secret video surveillance and phone tapping. 
- Ms K. bought a plot of land to construct the petrol station on and brought the sales agreement to the applicant. 
- In a second meeting, the applicant reiterated his request for a bribe and asked for a down payment of USD 10,000. 
- Ms K. brought USD 10,000 in cash, which had been marked by the DCS, and the applicant was arrested on the spot. 
- The applicant was charged with the crime of requesting a bribe in a large amount. 
- Ms K. testified that the applicant had requested her to pay USD 30,000 for promised assistance with the construction project with USD 20,000 meant for the Governor. 
- The notary and head of the Land Registry confirmed that the applicant had urged them to expedite the registration of the land. 
- Ms K. indicated that the sales agreement had been annulled by the DCS and that Ms N. had collaborated with the agency. 
- Ms N. was requested to appear before the court but failed to do so as her whereabouts were unknown. 
- The Bolnisi District Court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to seven years’ imprisonment. 
- The applicant lodged an appeal, alleging entrapment and reasserting his version of events. 
- The Tbilisi Court of Appeal granted a request for Ms N. to appear but was unable to secure her attendance. 
- Ms N. submitted a written statement indicating difficulties with her family situation. 
- The Prosecutor’s Office presented a handwritten letter from Ms N.'s neighbours stating that her whereabouts were unknown.

title: CASE OF PARASKEVOPOULOS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant is a taxi driver from Thessaloniki born in 1964.
- In December 2007, the applicant published an article in a local newspaper, Chortiatis 570 titled “The ludicrousness of power”.
- The article accuses certain individuals of abusing their political power to serve personal interests, including the head of the local council, E.P. It alleges that E.P. built a gazebo with a tiled roof jutting out onto the street, constructed a pavement and planted trees in public spaces, and threatened to sue those who parked in those areas.
- E.P. filed a criminal complaint against the applicant for slanderous defamation via the press.
- The first-instance criminal court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to a six-month suspended prison sentence, which was later reduced to four months on appeal.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment for lack of reasoning and remitted the case to the Court of Appeal.
- The Court of Appeal held a new hearing and found the applicant guilty of insult via the press instead of slanderous defamation, sentencing him to a two-month suspended prison sentence.
- The Court of Cassation dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law, confirming the judgment of the Court of Appeal.
- E.P. also lodged a civil action for damages, which resulted in the applicant being ordered to pay EUR 2,500 in compensation.

title: CASE OF VOYNOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Oryol. He is currently serving his sentence in IK-7 in the village of Areyskoye, Krasnoyarsk Region.
- The applicant, his partner, and his mother were living in Oryol when the applicant was charged with drug-related crimes.
- On 2 December 2009, Russia's Federal Penal Authority sent a telegram to the FSIN department for the Oryol Region instructing the latter to send each month up to forty detainees to a strict-regime detention facility in Krasnoyarsk Region.
- On 7 December 2009, the applicant was convicted of drug-related crimes and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment in a strict-regime post-conviction detention facility by Sovetskiy District Court in Oryol. The sentence was upheld by the Oryol Regional Court on 2 February 2010.
- The applicant was transferred to IK-7 in Krasnoyarsk Region on an unspecified date, with reference to the overcrowding in the post-conviction detention facilities in the Oryol Region, and has been detained there since 20 April 2010.
- The applicant has repeatedly asked the penal authorities to transfer him to a detention facility located closer to Oryol so that he could maintain family ties while serving his sentence.
- On 12 November 2010, the FSIN of Russia rejected the applicant’s request, stating that under Article 81 of the CES, he must serve his sentence in its entirety in the same detention facility in the absence of exceptional circumstances.
- The applicant brought a civil lawsuit against the Oryol FSIN for transferring him to Krasnoyarsk in violation of his right to serve his sentence in his home region under Article 73 § 1 of the CES, which adversely affected his capacity to maintain family and social ties.
- On 3 August 2012, the Zavodskoy District Court of Oryol dismissed the claims for damages, citing Article 73 § 2 of the CES and Ruling No. 1700-O-O of the Constitutional Court of Russia. The court did not address the applicant’s argument regarding his difficulties in maintaining family ties because of the distance between his family home and detention facility.
- In total, the applicant's partner made six long-term family visits to IK-7 between July 2011 and October 2013.

title: CASE OF BĂNUȚOIU AND STEFOGLU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1965 and 1954 and live in Bucharest.
- Both applicants were ill-treated and injured on 21 December 1989.
- First applicant needed eight days of medical care and the second applicant was beaten by militia forces.
- The military prosecutor's office opened investigations into the illegal detention, ill-treatment, and injury suffered by the applicants in 1990.
- An ex-officio investigation culminated in the referral to court and subsequent conviction of senior military and public officials by the Supreme Court of Justice in May 1991. The injured parties did not participate in that procedure.
- The military prosecutor decided not to open a separate investigation in respect of the offence of abusive conduct as it fell under the amnesty law.
- No decision was taken in respect of the applicants' injury.
- The prosecutor heard the applicants who reiterated their complaints regarding the offences of illegal deprivation of liberty and homicide as an attempt raised on account of their ill-treatment and injury.
- On 14 October 2015, the military prosecutor's office issued a decision in respect of the second applicant by closing the main criminal investigation.
- The decision was subsequently quashed on 1 November 2016, and a criminal investigation regarding the offence of crimes against humanity was initiated.
- The main criminal investigation is still ongoing.

title: CASE OF VOLOKITIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The case concerns the 1982 State internal premium loan bonds (облигации государственного внутреннего выигрышного займа 1982 года - “1982 premium bonds”) which are in the applicants’ possession.
- The bonds had nominal values of 25, 50 and 100 Soviet roubles (SUR). Their period of circulation was set at twenty years, from 1 January 1982 to 1 January 2002, and they were redeemable at any time during the term of the loan with interest at 3% per annum.
- In January 1991 the USSR Government freed 40% of prices and carried out a monetary reform eliminating the largest banknotes in circulation and restricting the withdrawal of money from bank deposit accounts to SUR 500 a month.
- On 22 March 1991, the USSR President issued Decree no. UP-1708, ordering a one-time increase to savings instruments, including the 1982 premium bonds, of 40% to offset the price rise.
- On 19 February 1992, the Russian Government issued Resolution no. 97, recognising its succession in respect of the obligations of the former USSR under the 1982 loan.
- Between 1995 and 2000, a series of Russian laws and regulations were passed which provided for the conversion of Soviet securities, including the 1982 premium bonds, into special Russian promissory notes nominated in “promissory roubles” (DOR).
- Their claims were rejected on procedural and substantive grounds. Mr Ruzanov’s claim was allowed at first instance but the judgment was later overturned on appeal. On 5 May 2014, Mr Israfilov obtained a decision from the Leninskiy District Court in Makhachkala, requiring the Russian Government to convert his bonds into special promissory notes.
- Mr Losyakov and Ms Losyakova’s claim was referred by the Supreme Court to the Constitutional Court. By decision no. 632-O of 3 April 2012, the Constitutional Court declared it inadmissible.

title: CASE OF SMIČKOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The applicant was involved in a physical altercation at a night club which resulted in injuries to another individual, R.
- The police were called to the scene and an official note was drawn up by them.
- The investigating judge opened an investigation against the applicant, with oral evidence provided by the applicant, R., and witnesses J. and K.
- The applicant claimed to have acted in self-defense, with an eyewitness, P., proposed to back up his statement.
- The injuries suffered by R. were classified as “grievous bodily injury” by an expert.
- The applicant was indicted for causing “grievous bodily injury” and objected, but the objection was dismissed.
- Evidence was given by the applicant, R., J., and K. during a public hearing.
- The defense's request to question eyewitnesses and for a fresh expert examination was refused.
- The trial court found the applicant guilty and sentenced him to a suspended prison sentence of one year.
- The applicant submitted two appeals, both of which were dismissed by the appellate court, which confirmed the trial court's judgment.

title: CASE OF ZIELIŃSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of homicide on 2 January 2007.
- The Gdynia District Court remanded the applicant in custody on 5 January 2007.
- The applicant's detention was repeatedly extended by the Gdańsk Regional Court and the Gdańsk Court of Appeal throughout the proceedings.
- On 6 June 2013, the Gdańsk Court of Appeal partly allowed the applicant's appeal and reclassified the offence as involuntary manslaughter, leading to the applicant's release on the same day.

title: CASE OF BOYADZHIEVA AND GLORIA INTERNATIONAL LIMITED EOOD v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1954 and lives in Sofia.
- The second applicant was registered in 1992 and has its registered place of business in Sofia.
- At the time of the events, the main commercial activity of the two applicants was trade in medicaments.
- The first applicant sold medicaments to a company called K., for which she was paid 22,043.23 Bulgarian levs (BGN), the equivalent of 11,275 euros (EUR), in total.
- The second applicant sold medicaments to K. and received a total of BGN 33,344.05 (the equivalent of EUR 17,055) by way of payment.
- Other companies which were creditors of K., including E., applied for the commencement of insolvency proceedings against K. in September 2006.
- The Regional Court declared company K. insolvent, opened insolvency proceedings and appointed a trustee.
- Company E. brought proceedings against the first applicant seeking to have the payments K. had made to her during the “suspect period” declared null and void and the sum received by her returned to the insolvency estate.
- The action was allowed in a judgment of the Regional Court of 31 October 2007, which was upheld by the Plovdiv Court of Appeal on 12 March 2008.
- The Court of Appeal’s judgment was enforceable, and a bailiff opened enforcement proceedings against the first applicant for the sums due to the insolvency estate, which the first applicant paid in December 2008.
- Company E. also brought proceedings against the second applicant seeking to have the payments K. had made to it declared null and void.
- The action was allowed in a judgment of the Regional Court of 23 January 2008, which was upheld by the Court of Appeal on 10 June 2008.
- The second applicant settled the debt owed to the insolvency estate in October 2008.
- The insolvency proceedings against K. continued until 2014 when the company was wound up.

title: CASE OF VASILEVSKIY AND BOGDANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Mr. Vasilevskiy was wrongfully detained because the court did not count his time spent in pre-trial detention towards his overall duration of sentence.
- He sought compensation for the 472 days of wrongful detention.
- The Blagoveshchensk Town Court awarded him 150,000 Russian roubles in damages, which he appealed.
- The Amur Regional Court dismissed his appeal and upheld the compensation, stating that it was in line with Russian law.
- Mr. Bogdanov was wrongfully imprisoned because the police had incited him to commit some of the offences.
- His conviction was voided in part, and his sentence was reduced to six years from twelve.
- He spent 119 days more in custody than the actual sentence and sought damages for wrongful imprisonment.
- The court awarded him RUB 80,000, which was reduced to RUB 15,000 by the Novgorod Regional Court on the grounds of the circumstances of his case and the category of offence he was charged with.

title: CASE OF ŠČENSNOVIČIUS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1980 and detained in Pravieniškės Correctional Facility.
- Pre-trial investigation into alleged armed criminal organisation active in Vilnius Region started on 11 May 2009.
- Applicant arrested on 23 February 2010 on suspicion of involvement in the criminal organisation.
- Applicant's detention on remand authorized by Vilnius District Court for two months on 24 February 2010, and extended multiple times.
- Grounds for detention: risk of committing new crimes, risk of absconding, risk of interfering with the criminal investigation, complexity and large scale of the case.
- Applicant appealed against some extensions but was unsuccessful.

title: CASE OF MĂTĂSARU AND SAVIȚCHI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple living in Chișinău, born in 1970.
- On 29 Jan 2008, they were arrested and detained for 6 hours 45 minutes due to their involvement in a street protest.
- On 18 Dec 2008, the first applicant was again involved in a street protest and was arrested and detained for about 4.5 hours, both later acquitted.
- On 29 Jan 2009, the first applicant was involved in another street protest and was arrested and detained for 6 hours, later acquitted.
- In a case filed under Law 1545, the applicants sought compensation for the three street protests, citing breaches of their rights guaranteed by Articles 5 and 11 of the Convention.
- A final judgment by the Supreme Court of Justice on 6 Feb 2013 acknowledged the breach of the applicants’ rights under the Convention, and awarded the first applicant EUR 900 and the second applicant EUR 270.

title: CASE OF CUCU AND OTHERS v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicants are three individuals from Chișinău born in 1990, 1988, and 1957.
- The first and second applicants were detained for ten and seven days respectively following a mass protest in Chișinău after the elections of 5 April 2009, and later the charges against them were dropped.
- The third applicant was detained for nine days pending trial on fraud charges, and later the charges against him were dropped. The Government disputed one of the dates when he was detained.
- All three applicants brought civil actions under Law No. 1545 seeking compensation for non-pecuniary damages caused by their unlawful detentions.
- The Supreme Court of Justice concluded that the applicants’ detentions had been unlawful and awarded them compensation for damages caused.
- The first and second applicants were part of a group of victims of the events of April 2009 and were awarded compensation by two Government decisions.

title: CASE OF KUMITSKIY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The list of applicants and their relevant details are in the appended table.
- The applicants alleged that they were unfairly convicted of drug offences after being entrapped by State agents.
- Application no. 48523/15 raised additional complaints under the Convention.
- In application no. 3436/15, the applicant was found guilty of attempted drug sale, as well as unlawful purchase and storage of drugs, resulting in a ten-year prison sentence.
- The conviction was overturned for two episodes of drug sale but upheld for one episode after a review by the Presidium of the Stavropol Regional Court.
- The Code of Criminal Procedure was amended in 2010, 2013, and 2014.
- The CCrP permits the reopening of proceedings in a criminal case if a violation of a Convention right is found by the European Court of Human Rights.
- The Russian Supreme Court has issued summaries of the Court's case-law and has authorized the reopening of criminal proceedings in cases of police entrapment.

title: CASE OF DÜNDAR AND AYDINKAYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants represent Abdullah Öcalan, leader of the PKK at the time of the events
- Interviews with applicants are published in Ülkede Özgür Gündem on two occasions in April 2004
- The interviews cover a range of issues discussed with their client including his health, political opinions, and views about the conflict in Turkey involving Kurdish organizations.
- The public prosecutor charges the applicants with disseminating propaganda for PKK/KONGRA-GEL under the Prevention of Terrorism Act.
- The Istanbul Assize Court sentences the applicants to 10 months imprisonment each for disseminating propaganda in favor of PKK/KONGRA-GEL while representing Abdullah Öcalan.

title: CASE OF IURCOVSCHI AND OTHERS v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1969, 1977, and 1980 and absconding from the Moldovan authorities.
- The applicants were police officers at the time of the events.
- Applicants apprehended P. in the staircase of an apartment, severely beaten him, and carried him away.
- P. was never seen alive after that, and his body was found in a well several years later.
- Applicants claimed that P. was a criminal, and they intended to take him to the police station for questioning.
- Applicants were arrested and charged with kidnapping, murder, and abuse of their authority as police officers.
- The public prosecutor applied to the Centru District Court for a warrant for the applicants’ detention in custody.
- The Centru District Court issued a detention order for thirty days.
- Chișinău Court of Appeal dismissed the applicants’ appeals.
- Centru District Court extended the applicants’ detention by thirty days.
- Chișinău Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Centru District Court for extension.
- The charges of murder were dropped in respect of all applicants because the victim’s body was not found.
- Prosecutor applied for the extension of applicants’ detention by ninety days.
- Applicants lodged a habeas corpus request, arguing that there were no grounds for detention.
- Rîșcani District Court extended the applicants’ detention by 90 days.
- Chișinău Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Rîșcani District Court for detention extension.
- Judge V. withdrew from the case.
- Another habeas corpus request was lodged, noting that the previous request had still not been examined.
- Judge M. from the Rîșcani District Court extended the applicants’ detention by ninety days.
- The Chișinău Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Rîșcani District Court to detain them.
- The Rîșcani District Court acquitted the applicants of all charges and released them.
- The Chișinău Court of Appeal quashed that judgment, convicted the applicants, and sentenced them to seven years of imprisonment.
- A new set of criminal proceedings based on murder charges was initiated against the applicants.

title: CASE OF ARSLAN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants (six individuals) were born between 1973 and 1986 and were serving prison sentences for criminal convictions at the time of the application.
- In June 2005, 17 members of an illegal organization called MKP were killed by members of the security forces.
- On 21 June 2005, university students, including the applicants, gathered in front of a building to protest the alleged unlawful killings of the MKP members.
- On 8 July 2005, one of the applicants attended another gathering where a press statement was read out regarding the killings of June 2005, the arrest of individuals after the press statement on 21 June, and the alleged unlawful killing of a detainee by police.
- In February 2007, the Ankara public prosecutor initiated criminal proceedings against 23 people, including the applicants, for disseminating propaganda in favor of the MKP.
- The applicants were found guilty on 31 March 2009 and sentenced to prison terms ranging from 10 to 20 months.
- The Ankara Assize Court concluded that the applicants had not exercised their democratic rights but had glorified terror by chanting slogans that praised terrorist organizations and incited terror.
- The applicants served their prison sentences at unspecified dates.

title: CASE OF ALTUN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
Main descriptions of facts:

- The applicants were born in 1964, 1957, and 1947, respectively.
- The first and third applicants live in Ankara.
- The second applicant left Turkey after a criminal conviction.
- On 21 August 2006, the applicants participated in a religious ceremony paying tribute to three members of the PKK who were killed by security forces.
- The ceremony was held at the Altındağ district branch of the Party for a Democratic Society (DTP) in Ankara.
- The second applicant was the head of the DTP's Ankara branch, while the third applicant was a DTP member and a friend of the first applicant, whose nephew was among the deceased.
- On 23 November 2007, the Ankara public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment, charging the applicants and others with dissemination of propaganda in favor of the PKK under section 7(2) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act.
- The charges were related to their participation in the ceremony of 21 August 2006, during which photographs of the deceased and the PKK's flag were displayed, and a film about the lives of the deceased was shown.
- The second applicant made a statement expressing the hope for peace and fraternity.
- On 24 September 2008, the Ankara Assize Court convicted the applicants and sentenced them to ten months' imprisonment.
- The court found that the ceremony was held in memory of members of a terrorist organization and that the venue had been turned into a propaganda venue in favor of the PKK.
- Following an appeal, their conviction was upheld by the Court of Cassation on 8 March 2010.
- The first and third applicants served their prison sentences.

title: CASE OF ÇEKİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and was detained at Kırıkkale F‑type prison when the application was lodged.
- On 1 October 2004, the applicant was taken into police custody on suspicion of being a member of a terrorist organization.
- On 5 October 2004, the applicant was placed in detention on remand after being brought before the judge at the Ankara Assize Court. 
- On 15 March 2005, the applicant was charged with membership of a terrorist organization.
- On 31 January 2008, the applicant was sentenced to 15 years’ imprisonment by the Ankara Assize Court.
- On 6 May 2009, the Court of Cassation quashed the judgment.
- On 10 November 2009, the court ordered the continuation of the applicant’s detention.
- On 10 December 2009, the applicant’s lawyer filed an objection against the decision of 10 November 2009.
- On 21 December 2009, the 12th Chamber of the Ankara Assize Court dismissed this objection without holding a hearing.
- On 28 August 2012, the Ankara Assize Court convicted the applicant for the second time and sentenced him to 15 years’ imprisonment.
- On 8 July 2013, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first instance court.

title: CASE OF ERDEM v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1959 and lives in İzmir.
- The applicant, who was working as a civil servant, was dismissed in March 2002 due to gross misconduct.
- In September 2005, the criminal proceedings against him ended with his conviction of abuse of office.
- In July 2006, Law no. 5525 granting amnesty to civil servants who had been subjected to disciplinary proceedings was enacted.
- Following the entry into force of the amnesty law, the applicant asked to be reinstated but his request was refused on 19 December 2006.
- The Ankara Administrative Court annulled the decision of the authorities and decided to reinstate the applicant on 8 January 2008.
- The decision was quashed by the Supreme Administrative Court on 25 May 2009, referring to a leading case that stated the amnesty law did not impose obligations on the administration to reinstate the applicant.
- The case was remitted to the Ankara Administrative Court, which adhered to the judgment of the appeal court and dismissed the applicant's case on 9 October 2009.

title: CASE OF KESKİN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Kayseri.
- The applicant had a traffic accident in 2007 and was declared "disabled" (Adi malül).
- The applicant requested the General Directorate of Pension Fund to modify his retirement statute as service-disabled ("vazife malülü"), but the fund rejected the request.
- On August 9, 2007, the applicant filed a case before the Supreme Military Administrative Court to annul the Fund's decision.
- On May 22, 2008, the Supreme Military Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's request.
- On September 11, 2008, the applicant's rectification request was rejected.
- During the proceedings, the Public Prosecutor at the Supreme Military Administrative Court filed lengthy written opinions on the case but did not communicate them to the applicant.

title: CASE OF İSHAK SAĞLAM v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was a lawyer practicing in Diyarbakir.
- The applicant was accused of membership in Hizbullah.
- The public prosecutor relied on a computer disk with personal information and police statements of four people.
- The applicant denied affiliation with Hizbullah and contested the accuracy of the evidence presented.
- The applicant was detained on remand and subsequently arrested.
- The court held that the applicant should be released pending trial.
- M.S.B.'s police statements were read out, and the court noted that M.S.B. had denied those statements at a later point.
- The public prosecutor argued the applicant's guilt was proven by various items of evidence.
- The applicant's lawyer challenged the credibility of the witnesses' statements.
- The court refused the application for the expansion of the investigation.
- The applicant applied to benefit from the Reintegration of Offenders into Society Act (Law no. 4959).
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to six years and three months' imprisonment.
- The court relied on certain information obtained from the computer disk and the statements of N.S. and Ş.A.
- The appeal was unsuccessfully against the judgment.

title: CASE OF ABDULKADYROV AND DAKHTAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
1. The applicants were arrested in Grozny in September 2002 and taken to a temporary detention facility.
2. During their unrecorded detention, they were repeatedly ill-treated by officers of ORB-2 and forced into confessing to being members of an illegal armed group in Grozny.
3. The officers of ORB-2 punched and kicked them, beat them up with truncheons, administered electric shocks while putting gas masks or plastic bags over their heads and threatened them with rape and blackmail.
4. Once the applicants’ arrests were formalised, they reiterated their confession statements, confirming that they had made their statements voluntarily.
5. The Government failed to submit the applicants’ medical documents for the period between September and December 2002.
6. The applicants complained to the Prosecutor’s Office of the Chechen Republic of their having been subjected to torture while in police custody at ORB-2, but the institution of criminal proceedings was refused.
7. The applicants were convicted and sentenced to twenty-five years’ imprisonment based on self-incriminating statements given during pre-trial investigation and other evidence obtained under torture.
8. On appeal, the Supreme Court of Russia upheld the judgment and reduced the applicants’ sentences.
9. The applicants lodged requests for transfer to penal facilities in regions adjacent to their home region but their requests were rejected.

title: CASE OF İMRET v. TURKEY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1958 and lives in Batman. He was the head of the Batman branch of the People’s Democratic Party (DEHAP) and subsequently the Party for a Democratic Society (DTP).
- The Batman public prosecutor’s office initiated at least four criminal investigations against the applicant on unspecified dates in 2005 and 2006 in relation to his attendance at a number of public meetings.
- During the investigations, the applicant denied disseminating propaganda in favour of the PKK or praising its leader, Abdullah Öcalan.
- On 23 March 2006, the applicant was brought before the Batman Magistrates’ Court and questioned in respect of his involvement in a demonstration held on 16 February 2006 in Batman. He was ordered to be remanded in custody.
- On 24 March 2006, the Batman public prosecutor decided to transfer the investigation to the Diyarbakır public prosecutor’s office.
- On 26 April 2006, the Diyarbakır public prosecutor filed an indictment charging the applicant and a certain M.G. with disseminating propaganda in favour of the PKK on ten occasions.
- On 30 May 2006, the Diyarbakır Assize Court held the first hearing on the merits of the case.
- On 26 September 2006, the Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicant and his co-accused of membership of an illegal organisation under Article 314 § 2 of the Criminal Code finding it established that the applicant had knowingly and willingly aided the PKK. The applicant was sentenced to six years and three months’ imprisonment.
- On 13 April 2010, the Court of Cassation upheld the first-instance judgment.
- By Law no. 6352, which entered into force on 5 July 2012, paragraph 7 of Article 220 of the Criminal Code was amended. The applicant applied to the Diyarbakır Assize Court requesting it to examine whether the amended version of that provision could be considered to be in his favour and, if so, whether the execution of his sentence could be suspended.
- On 16 August 2012, the Diyarbakır Assize Court decided to reduce the applicant’s sentence to five years, two months and fifteen days’ imprisonment. The court rejected the applicant’s request to have the execution of his sentence suspended.

title: CASE OF BAKIR AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were taken into police custody on suspicion of aiding and abetting the MLKP.
- The applicants were charged with membership of an illegal organization and disseminating propaganda in favor of a terrorist organization.
- The applicants participated in legally organized demonstrations but were alleged to have chanted illegal slogans or slogans in favor of an illegal organization.
- The court found that the ESP and SGD had an organic relationship with the MLKP and were carrying out activities in line with the strategies of the MLKP.
- Some of the applicants were convicted as members of the MLKP because they had aided that illegal organization, while others were convicted of propaganda in favor of the MLKP.

title: CASE OF DAOUKOPOULOS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and was serving a life sentence for drug dealing at Diavata Prison.
- The applicant was transferred multiple times between Diavata and Malandrino prisons.
- The applicant alleged being initially detained in overcrowded cells with less than 3 sq. m living space.
- The conditions of detention were poor including inadequate access to natural light and ventilation, old and broken sanitary facilities, insufficient heating, hot water and personal hygiene supplies.
- Detainees had minimal access to cultural, recreational, and sports activities, suffered from poor-quality nutrition, and lack of access to newspapers or magazines.
- The applicant's detention reportedly led to several cardiac arrests.
- The prison exceeded its capacity by accommodating 460 to 500 detainees.
- The living space afforded to the applicant ranged from 3.14 to 4.4 sq. m.
- The living conditions and care provided to detainees were disputed between the applicant and the Government.

title: CASE OF HANYECZ AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A table with list of applicants and relevant details provided
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions
- One applicant raised another complaint under Article 3 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF RUSU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details provided in table
- Applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions 
- In some applications, applicants raised additional complaints under Convention provisions

title: CASE OF CAZAN AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The document is about a case.
- There is a list of applicants.
- The details of their applications are in the appended table.
- The applicants complained about the inadequate conditions of their detention.

title: CASE OF SINYUSHKIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is an appended table that lists the applicants and the relevant details of their applications.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention. 
- Some of the applicants also raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF WOŁOSOWICZ v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1976 and lives in Bielsk Podlaski.
- The applicant was detained in Siedlce Prison on two separate occasions.
- The applicant was held in cells where the amount of space per person was below the Polish statutory minimum standard of 3 m².
- The applicant was held in cells with smokers and faced problems with humidity, lack of hygiene, and warm water, as well as limited access to make telephone calls.
- During the applicant's detention in Siedlce Prison from 15 July to 15 October 2009, he was held in an overcrowded cell (15.94 m²) with 5 other prisoners (2.65 m² per person).
- The toilet areas were separated from the rest of the living space in the cells in compliance with the relevant law, but with only cold running water.
- The applicant brought a civil action against the State Treasury for infringement of his personal rights and for compensation on account of his detention in an overcrowded cell in Siedlce Prison.
- The Siedlce District Court dismissed the applicant's action but confirmed that the applicant had been detained temporarily in an overcrowded cell from 15 July to 15 October 2009.
- The Siedlce Regional Court dismissed the applicant's appeal.

title: CASE OF OLEKSA v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and is detained in Strzelce Opolskie Prison.
- The applicant was detained in Mysłowice Remand Centre from 20 April 2010 to 12 January 2011 and in Wojkowice Prison from 12 January 2011 to 9 March 2012.
- The parties’ statements relating to the conditions of the applicant’s detention from 20 April 2010 to 9 March 2012 are to a large extent contradictory.
- The applicant had been held in overcrowded cells in which the space per person had been below the Polish statutory minimum standard of 3 m².
- The domestic courts established that he had been detained in overcrowded cells from 20 April 2010 to 9 March 2012.
- Regarding the conditions of detention in Mysłowice Remand Centre, the domestic court established that the overall conditions in cells were adequate.
- The domestic courts also established that the toilets were separated from the cell’s living area, every prisoner had his own bed, a stool and access to cold running water. 
- On 24 February 2012, the applicant brought a civil action for the infringement of his personal rights on account of inadequate living conditions.
- On 18 December 2012, the Katowice Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s action.
- On 27 June 2013, the Katowice Court of Appeal overruled the lower court’s judgment and allowed the applicant’s action.

title: CASE OF MATELJAN v. CROATIA
facts:
- Applicant awarded specially protected tenancy of a socially-owned flat in Gajeva Street in Split in 1961
- Applicant married in 1969 and moved into the flat in Šimićeva Street with her husband and children in 1973
- Applicant applied for permission to exchange flats in 1982, which was refused by the Croatian Pension Fund
- Lengthy administrative and judicial proceedings followed, with multiple appeals and remittals
- Applicant withdrew application for exchange of flats in 1992, citing changed circumstances including divorce
- First-instance housing authority ordered applicant to vacate Gajeva Street flat in 1992, with decision upheld on appeal
- Applicant lodged multiple actions for judicial review, including a constitutional complaint, but all were dismissed
- Applicant was evicted on 16 May 2012 and currently resides in the flat in Šimićeva Street owned by her former husband
- Applicant is co-owner of multiple properties in the Split area.

title: CASE OF PYLAYEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- First applicant born in 1976 and serving a sentence of imprisonment in the Sverdlovsk region
- Second applicant born in 1950 and lives in Vladivostok
- In July 2012, the prosecutor's office provided a flat to the first applicant and concluded a tenancy agreement with him, including the second applicant as a member of his family
- In August 2012, the second applicant was classified as having a first-degree disability
- On 7 October 2014, the first applicant retired from the prosecutor's office and applied for transfer of the flat to him
- On 8 October 2014, criminal proceedings were initiated against the first applicant
- On 21 November 2014, the transfer of the title to the flat was refused
- In December 2014, eviction claims were brought against the applicants
- On 27 February 2015, the District Court dismissed the eviction claims
- On 8 June 2015, the Regional Court ordered eviction of the applicants with no alternative accommodation provided, and the first applicant was represented by a lawyer, K.
- On 22 July 2015, a judge of the Regional Court refused to refer the first applicant's appeal to the Civil Chamber of the Regional Court for examination on the merits
- On 22 September 2015, the second applicant was evicted from the flat
- In June 2015, the first applicant's brother initiated court proceedings for the second applicant to be deprived of legal capacity and for him to be appointed as her guardian
- On 11 May 2016, the second applicant was declared to lack legal capacity due to mental handicap since 2010
- On 29 June 2016, the first applicant's brother was appointed as the second applicant's guardian by the local public health department.

title: CASE OF ABDILLA v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and is detained in the Corradino Correctional Facility in Malta.
- He is serving a sentence of sixteen years for drug-related offences.
- The Division 2 of the facility, where he has been placed, is around 200 years old and in need of maintenance.
- The applicant's cell lacked light and air, had triple-barred windows, and was exposed to heat from a nearby bakery.
- The food was of poor quality and caused food poisoning, and access to water was limited and often not potable.
- The showers were insufficient and often had no hot water or were dirty.
- The cost to make telephone calls was high, and the prison allowance was too little to buy basic necessities.
- The emergency buzzer in the cell did not work, and medical assistance was slow to arrive.
- Several petitions and constitutional cases had been filed, but no change had been made.

title: CASE OF SHULMIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their details are in the appended table.
- Applicants were confined in metal cages during criminal proceedings.
- Applicants complained about their confinement in the cages.
- These are the main descriptions of the facts presented in the document.

title: CASE OF VOROSHILOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1991 and lives in Orenburg.
- The applicant was arrested by police officers of the criminal investigation unit and taken to a police station in Orenburg.
- From 8 p.m. to midnight on 30 August 2009, and from 12 noon to 6 p.m. on 31 August 2009, police officers subjected the applicant to physical and psychological violence in order to obtain a confession from him.
- K. placed a plastic bag over his head, closing off his access to air, while M. held him down.
- Officers K. and M. punched the applicant numerous times on the head and threatened to detain him.
- The applicant was formally arrested on suspicion of possession of drugs and placed in a temporary detention facility.
- The applicant sought medical help at a traumatology centre and had abrasions and bruises on his body.
- The applicant made a complaint to the Orenburg regional investigative committee regarding his ill-treatment.
- The applicant had injuries resulting from being struck repeatedly with a hard, blunt object with a limited surface area on the day of the alleged incident.
- Officers K. and M. were convicted under Article 286 § 3 (a) of the Criminal Code.
- Criminal proceedings against the applicant under Article 228 § 2 of the Criminal Code were terminated for absence of a crime.
- The applicant brought a civil claim against the Russian Ministry of Finance seeking compensation for his unlawful detention and ill-treatment.
- The Leninskiy District Court of Orenburg awarded RUB 20,000 compensation to the applicant.
- The Orenburg Regional Court increased the amount of compensation to RUB 80,000.

title: CASE OF MARIYA ALEKHINA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Three applicants, members of a feminist punk band called Pussy Riot, were arrested and charged with hooliganism motivated by religious hatred.
- The band members had performed several songs critical of the Russian government and the Russian Orthodox Church in various public places, including on the roof of a detention facility, Red Square, and two different cathedrals.
- The applicants argued that their performances were a response to the ongoing political situation in Russia and to the criticisms of large-scale street protests and minorities by the Russian Orthodox Church.
- The applicants performed in disguise, wearing brightly coloured balaclavas and dresses, in various public places chosen to amplify their message.
- The band's performances were recorded and uploaded to the internet.
- Cathedral staff members and guards complained of the band's conduct and initiated criminal proceedings, leading to the arrest and detention of the applicants.
- The applicants' detention was repeatedly extended, and the courts refused to accept personal written assurances given by fifty-seven notable individuals.
- Experts commissioned by the state concluded that the performances were not motivated by religious hatred or intended to incite it; however, a third opinion requested by the investigators concluded the opposite.

title: CASE OF MAZEPA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are the family members of Anna Politkovskaya, a well-known investigative journalist.
- Anna Politkovskaya was shot and killed in her block of flats in Moscow in 2006.
- A criminal investigation was opened under Article 105 § 2 (b) of the Russian Criminal Code.
- Ten people were arrested in connection with the investigation, and four were charged with contract killing and conspiracy.
- In 2009, the Basmannyy District Court of Moscow ordered the placement of an individual named D.P. in custody, who later entered a guilty plea.
- The criminal case against D.P. was severed from that of the other co-accused, and a separate investigation was created.
- The case file against the other co-accused was transferred to the City Court for trial in 2013.
- In 2014, the co-accused were found guilty of Anna Politkovskaya’s murder and sentenced to imprisonment.
- The defendants appealed against the conviction, but it was upheld by the Supreme Court of Russia in 2015.
- The investigation into Anna Politkovskaya’s killing has not been terminated.

title: CASE OF FEFILOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1979 in Izhevsk.
- On 18 February 2005, police searched applicant's flat in connection with the murder of a law-enforcement officer.
- Applicant interviewed by police on 3 March and 10 March 2005 without any suspicions raised.
- Applicant apprehended on 22 March 2005 and allegedly beaten into confessing to the murder of the officer. He signed a record of his surrender and confession.
- Between 23 March 2005 and 25 July 2005, the applicant consistently denied his confession was given under duress or without a lawyer present.
- On 22 April 2005, the applicant complained of ill-treatment by police, but it was ignored.
- On 19 December 2005, the applicant was sentenced to twelve years in prison for murder, as there were claims that he confessed voluntarily, without violence applied to him.
- On 14 June 2006, the Supreme Court of Russia dismissed the applicant's appeal claiming his confession was obtained through duress and in the absence of a lawyer.
- On 25 October 2006, the applicant was transferred to a penal institution for drug addiction treatment.

title: CASE OF SANDU AND OTHERS v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The 1,646 applicants live in several Moldovan villages on the left bank of the Dniester in the region of Dubǎsari.
- The applicants obtained titles to these plots of land from Moldova as part of the “Pamântul” (Land) privatisation programme.
- Part of the land belonging to the applicants is situated in areas near these villages, across a road which links the northern and southern parts of the self-proclaimed “Moldovan Transdniestrian Republic” (the “MRT”).
- The road is controlled by the authorities of the “MRT”.
- The applicants' main source of income is the working of the land owned or rented by them, but they have to cross the road controlled by the authorities of the “MRT” to reach their land.
- From 1998 onwards, the "MRT" authorities set up checkpoints to monitor the movement of agricultural products across the “border” coinciding with the above-mentioned road. 
- In August 2004, the “MRT” authorities declared the land owned or rented by the applicants was the property of the “MRT”. 
- The applicants refused to sign rental contracts because they were already the lawful owners (or renters) of that land, as a consequence, all access to their land was blocked, and the harvest was lost.
- Some of the agricultural machines belonging to those who tried to work their land were also seized.
- The applicants made numerous complaints to the “MRT” authorities, asking for a right of passage.
- The applicants also complained to the Moldovan authorities, who replied that they had no means to compel the “MRT” authorities to allow them free passage. 
- The applicants complained to the Russian embassy in Moldova and to the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (the “OSCE”), to no avail.
- The applicant companies have submitted documents, showing that they rented large areas of land from villagers to work on, but faced obstructions from the “MRT” authorities.
- The Moldovan Parliament passed a number of laws aimed at compensating the inhabitants of villages under Moldovan control on the left bank of the Dniester (in the area concerned by the present cases) for losses caused by various actions of the “MRT”.

title: CASE OF SERGEY RYABOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is currently serving a prison sentence in Bezhetsk, Tver Region.
- B., a police driver with the Ruza District Police Department of the Moscow region was found dead on 10 July 2005.
- On 11 July 2005 at night, the applicant was arrested and ill-treated by the police officers demanding him to confess to B.'s murder.
- The applicant was examined as a suspect on 11 July 2005 and confessed to the crime in the presence of a State-appointed lawyer.
- On 12 July 2005, the applicant was placed in pre-trial detention and his lawyer submitted that he had been subjected to ill-treatment by police officers from the moment of his arrest.
- The applicant's injuries from ill-treatment by the police officers were confirmed by a forensic medical expert on 14 July 2005.
- A pre-investigation inquiry into the applicant's allegations of ill-treatment was conducted, and the decision was annulled on 16 August 2005 for additional inquiry.
- On 22 August 2005, two police officers were reprimanded by the head of the Ruza district police department for lack of diligence during the applicant's detention.
- A jury trial began on 28 February 2006, and the applicant was found guilty on 11 April 2006.
- The applicant's appeal against the judgment was dismissed by the Supreme Court of Russia on 13 July 2006.
- The criminal case was re-opened on 12 October 2007 on account of newly discovered circumstances but was terminated on 25 October 2007, and this decision was upheld by the Supreme Court on 18 February 2008.

title: CASE OF MANGÎR AND OTHERS v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA AND RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are police officers born between 1964 and 1979.
- Five officers were arrested during a criminal investigation in Tiraspol.
- Two officers who went to clarify the situation were also arrested.
- The applicants were placed in Tiraspol Remand Centre without charge.
- Three officers were released without charge, while one was allegedly beaten and injected with an unknown substance and detained for 30 days.
- The applicants were accused by the MRT media of being members of "black squadrons" created for kidnapping politicians and other persons causing nuisance to Moldovan authorities.
- The applicants claimed to have been forced to declare that in Tiraspol they were trying to kidnap MRT politicians.
- Officers were allegedly beaten and threatened with the killing of family members, being transferred to cells occupied by common criminals, and being ill-treated or even killed.
- The applicants were held in basement cells with no natural light, ventilation, or proper hygiene.
- They were not allowed daily exercise, access to a shower, parcels containing food from their relatives, bed linen, or medical care.
- Two sets of criminal proceedings were initiated, but the investigation was later discontinued.
- Medical check-ups found no signs of violence on their bodies, except for one applicant who suffered from the consequences of a concussion.

title: CASE OF ALEKSANDAR SABEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and held the rank of major in the Military Intelligence Service at the time of the events.
- On 27 May 2005, the applicant's security clearance to access classified information at the national level was withdrawn, based on section 59 (1) (2) of the Law on the protection of classified information.
- The applicant lodged an administrative appeal against the decision, which was dismissed on 15 July 2005 by the State Commission on Information Security.
- The applicant was relieved of his duties in the Military Intelligence Service on 8 August 2005 and transferred to the Intelligence Unit at the Army Headquarters on 30 September 2005.
- On 23 March 2007, the Defence Minister terminated the applicant’s contract for failure to satisfy the legal conditions for his post.

Regarding access to classified information:

- Security clearance is necessary to access classified information.
- Clearance can be withdrawn if the person has infringed the Law.
- No reasons have to be given for decisions to withdraw security clearance.
- Persons from whom clearance has been withdrawn are debarred from holding a post enabling them to access classified information for three years following the withdrawal.

Regarding dismissal of regular members of the armed forces:

- The Defence Minister can dismiss a regular member of the armed forces if he or she fails to satisfy the conditions for the post in question.
- Dismissal orders can be contested before the CAS.

title: CASE OF ZAGALSKI v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and lives in Warsaw.
- On 29 November 2012, the Warsaw-Wola District Court ordered the applicant's detention on remand on suspicion of drug dealing, facilitating and benefiting from prostitution, committed in an organised criminal group.
- The Warsaw Regional Court dismissed the applicant's appeal against the decision.
- The applicant's detention on remand was extended by the Warsaw Regional Court on multiple occasions.
- The Warsaw Court of Appeal upheld the decision to extend the applicant's detention on remand.
- The bill of indictment against the applicant was lodged on 30 December 2013, and the applicant was charged with ten offences committed in an organised criminal group.
- The applicant's detention pending trial was further extended by the courts on multiple occasions.
- The applicant's appeals against decisions extending his detention and all his applications for release were unsuccessful.
- On 9 May 2016, the trial court ordered the applicant's release on bail for 80,000 Polish zlotys.
- On 25 May 2016, the Warsaw Court of Appeal upheld the decision and underlined that the amount of bail had to take into consideration not only the financial situation of the applicant, but also the gravity of the charges against him.
- On 30 May 2016, the Warsaw Regional Court again ordered the applicant's release on bail of PLN 80,000.

title: CASE OF HOVHANNISYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant is a civil servant suffering from cardiac problems.
- On 10 January 2012, the applicant was allegedly assaulted, insulted, and forcibly deprived of a document by her head of division and his deputy.
- The applicant underwent a medical examination and was diagnosed with acute bronchitis and a heart rhythm disorder.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the accused, but the prosecutor refused to bring charges against them.
- The decisions of the prosecutor, the district court, and the criminal court of appeal were upheld against the applicant, and her appeal on points of law as declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF MAKRADULI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
Main descriptions of facts:

- The applicant was vice-president of the SDSM opposition party and a member of parliament at the time of the events.
- The criminal libel proceedings concern statements made by the applicant at press conferences held at his political party's headquarters.
- The impugned proceedings were brought by Mr S.M., who was a senior member of the ruling political party and head of the Security and Counter Intelligence Agency at the time.
- The applicant made statements suggesting that Mr S.M. abused his powers in order to influence the Macedonian Stock Exchange and had used police wiretapping equipment for trading on the Stock Exchange.
- The trial court found the applicant guilty of defamation and fined him EUR 1,500 with seventy-five days' imprisonment in default.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, which was dismissed, and was ordered to pay compensation for non-pecuniary damage in civil proceedings brought by Mr S.M.
- The applicant also made defamatory allegations regarding the public sale of State-owned building land in Skopje, accusing a company of being supported by a local holding company with close ties to the Prime Minister.
- Mr S.M. brought private criminal charges against the applicant for these defamatory allegations as well, which led to a trial where the defence did not submit any evidence.

title: CASE OF YORDANOVA AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1937, 1934 and 1941 respectively
- The applicants’ fathers owned printing houses in Sofia, which were nationalised by the Communist authorities 
- The assets were taken over by a State-owned printing house, which was later registered as ‘Obrazovanie i nauka’ EAD, managed by the Minister of Education
- In 1997 Parliament adopted the Compensation of Owners of Nationalised Real Property Act
- In March 1998 the applicants applied for compensation under the Compensation Act through shares in ‘Obrazovanie i nauka’ EAD
- In a decision of 14 June 1999, the Minister allowed the request
- However, the Minister rejected the request in another decision dated 3 July 2000
- The Supreme Administrative Court quashed that decision in a final judgment of 24 June 2002
- An expert prepared a valuation of the nationalised property in 2003 and the Minister confirmed compensation for 57,932 Bulgarian levs for the first and second applicants and their mother
- On 26 August 2003, the Minister adopted another decision, stating that the applicants were to receive compensation bonds instead of shares; this decision was quashed by the Supreme Administrative Court in a final judgment of 18 October 2004
- The third applicant, her mother and her sister applied under the Compensation Act to receive compensation for the nationalised printing house in August 1998, and their request was allowed by the Minister of Education in a decision of 22 December 1998
- An expert drew up three valuations of the expropriated property and the last of them was confirmed by the Minister of Education on 6 June 2003
- On 26 August 2003, the Minister stated that the third applicant was to receive compensation bonds instead of shares; this decision was quashed by the Supreme Administrative Court in a final judgment of 31 March 2004
- The Ministry of Education requested the Privatisation Agency to authorise the transfer to private parties of shares in ‘Obrazovanie i nauka’ EAD in 2007
- The Council of Ministers authorised the sale by ‘Obrazovanie i nauka’ EAD of real properties owned by the company in a decision of 5 March 2013
- The compensation procedures had not been completed with the actual transfer of shares to the applicants in accordance with the law

title: CASE OF KIRJAŅENKO v. LATVIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1947 and lives in Riga.
- The Medical Commission granted the applicant a disability status of category 3 on 17 October 2000.
- The Medical Commission declined the applicant’s request to prolong her disability status on 16 October 2001.
- The decision was upheld by the State Medical Commission and by an extended composition of that Commission on 9 November 2001 and 5 December 2001, respectively.
- The Riga City Zemgale District Court declined the applicant's claim on 22 April 2002.
- The Regional Administrative Court annulled the decision of 5 December 2001 and ordered a new examination on 30 July 2004.
- This judgment was upheld by the Administrative Cases Division of the Supreme Court on 30 November 2004.
- The Commission again refused to grant the applicant the status of a disabled person on 11 January 2005 after a new examination.
- The applicant brought a claim to the Administrative District Court challenging the decision and requesting to be granted the status of a disabled person from 16 October 2001 on 9 January 2006.
- The Administrative District Court and the Regional Administrative Court both declined the applicant's claim on 29 September 2006.
- The Administrative Cases Division of the Supreme Court quashed the judgments of the Regional Administrative Court two times for its failure to follow the interpretation of the domestic law given by the Supreme Court.
- The Regional Administrative Court declined the applicant’s claim on 24 November 2010, and the Administrative Cases Division of the Supreme Court refused to institute cassation proceedings on 14 March 2011.

title: CASE OF SARISHVILI-BOLKVADZE v. GEORGIA
facts:
1. The applicant’s son fell off a crane and was admitted to hospital with serious injuries. 
2. The son had a fractured skull and brain damage, and developed gastrointestinal bleeding shortly after admission. 
3. The son’s condition improved for a short period before deteriorating rapidly and he was moved to the intensive care unit again, where it was determined he had suffered from a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Surgery was performed but the son died four days later. 
4. Report no. 9-k by the Forensic Bureau cited a medical error in the timing of the surgery caused by an incorrect assessment of clinical data, and noted that an autopsy had not been performed, so the exact cause of death was unknown. 
5. Criminal medical negligence proceedings were opened against the relevant doctors, with the applicant as a victim, but the case was closed because without an autopsy of the body, no causal link between the medical negligence and the son’s death could be established. 
6. The hospital’s director dismissed a neurosurgeon in charge of the son’s care and reprimanded two intensive care specialists and a surgeon based on the findings of report no. 9-k. 
7. A claim by the applicant for compensation was lodged with the Batumi City Court, which found in favour of the applicant after consulting experts who confirmed medical negligence had occurred. 
8. The Kutaisi Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court upheld the findings of the lower court that the hospital had been responsible for medical error and had been carrying out unlicensed medical activities in various fields.

title: CASE OF SHAKIRZYANOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Kazan.
- On 4 June 2002, the applicant was convicted of disorderly acts and was given a suspended two-year custodial sentence that was conditional on two years’ probation.
- On 14 November 2003, the court changed the suspended sentence to an unconditional one because the applicant had failed to report to probation authorities.
- The Supreme Court of the Tatarstan Republic upheld the decision on appeal on 16 December 2003, and the applicant served the full two years of the custodial sentence.
- On 13 July 2016, the Presidium of the Supreme Court of the Tatarstan Republic nullified the decision of 14 November 2003 and the appeal decision of 16 December 2003, as the offence of disorderly acts had been decriminalised on 11 December 2003, and the original sentence was unenforceable.
- The Presidium, however, rejected the applicant's compensation claim for unlawful detention since he had been found guilty initially, and the "right to rehabilitation" did not include ex post facto decriminalisation cases.

title: CASE OF GAZIZOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1978 and lived in Naberezhnyye Chelny.
- The applicant was a police officer and was arrested on 1 November 2004 on suspicion of taking a bribe.
- On 10 November 2005, the Supreme Court of the Tatarstan Republic convicted the applicant and sentenced him to imprisonment with the condition that he not leave his place of residence until the conviction became final.
- The applicant, along with several other parties, appealed against the conviction. The case was forwarded to the Russian Supreme Court, but the applicant did not receive any summons to the appeal hearing due to a mistake in the postal code.
- On 28 February 2006, the conviction was upheld by the Russian Supreme Court, but the applicant and his lawyer were not present.
- In 2011, the applicant lodged a compensation claim for poor conditions of detention, but his claim was dismissed by the Bugulminskiy Town Court of the Tatarstan Republic.
- The first-instance judgment was upheld on 4 July 2011 by the Supreme Court of the Tatarstan Republic, and the applicant was notified of the hearing after it had already taken place.

title: CASE OF PROFESSIONAL PUBLIC NOTARY ORGANISATION 'ETICA' v. ROMANIA
facts:
- On 13 December 2007, around thirty police officers dressed as civilians entered the applicant organization's premises.
- The police officers refused to leave the premises and eventually identified themselves as police officers.
- The police officers seized an original sale contract and documents related to two private parties suspected of being part of an organized criminal group involved in immovable property fraud.
- The police officers also seized the fees and taxes paid to the applicant organization by the private parties.
- The applicant organization filed criminal proceedings against the two police officers for unlawful home intrusion and abuse of office against private interests but was later dismissed by the prosecutor's office and the court.
- The applicant organization filed an appeal, which was also dismissed by the court.
- The applicant organization lodged a complaint against the acts and measures taken by the police officers and joined as a civil party the criminal proceedings opened against the organized criminal group.
- The criminal group was convicted on 30 November 2010, and the sale contract validated by the applicant organization was annulled.
- The applicant organization's requests for the return of the original documents and relevant fees and taxes were dismissed by the Bucharest County Court and the Bucharest Court of Appeal.

- The applicant worked as a civil servant from 1 August 1990 until 24 October 2013.
- A certain part of the applicant's severance payment was taxed at 98%.
- The amount of tax was HUF 4,477,518 (approximately EUR 14,900).

title: CASE OF VYSHNYAKOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and lives in Mykolayiv.
- In 2006, the applicant married O. and their daughter S. was born in March 2007.
- In August 2007, the couple separated and O. continued to live with the child at a different address in Mykolayiv.
- On 15 April 2009, the couple's divorce was granted. 
- On 4 June 2009, the applicant was granted rights of access to his daughter with dates and times to be fixed by mutual agreement in advance.
- In the autumn of 2009, O. and S. moved to Selydove which is about 600 kilometers away from Mykolayiv.
- The applicant attempted to see his daughter on several occasions, but O. refused to let him take the child overnight.
- The police refused to open criminal proceedings against O. due to the absence of the constituent elements of a criminal offense.
- In 2013, the applicant brought a claim for damages against O. for obstructing the enforcement of the judgment of 4 June 2009, but the courts dismissed the claim for lack of proof.
- In 2015, the Donetsk Regional Court of Appeal partly allowed the applicant's claim and ruled that he should be given the opportunity to spend one month with his daughter during the summer and one week during the winter school holidays every year until she attained the age of majority.
- The applicant argued that it was dangerous for the child to continue to reside in the proximity of a theatre of armed conflict and sought a declaration that the child's place of residence should be his home in Mykolayiv.
- The courts rejected the applicant's claim, stating that he had failed to prove that O. had no independent income or had failed to perform her parental duties or was engaged in unlawful or immoral conduct.

title: CASE OF DRIDI v. GERMANY
facts:
- The applicant was convicted of assault and sentenced to forty day-fines of 25 euros each by the Hamburg District Court. 
- The court authorized Mr. Arif to act as defence counsel for the applicant, who appealed the conviction along with the public prosecutor. 
- The Hamburg Regional Court withdrew Mr. Arif's authorization and served the summons to the applicant, who had moved to Spain, via public notification. 
- The applicant's lawyer learned of the appeal hearing one day prior and requested adjournment citing scheduling problems, which was rejected. 
- The Regional Court dismissed the applicant's appeal without an assessment of the merits, resulting in the applicant's subsequent applications being denied by higher courts. 
- In 2016, the Government acknowledged violations of multiple articles and offered compensation, which the applicant declined due to his pursuit of a reopening of the criminal proceedings against him.

title: CASE OF BARTAIA v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1938 and lives in Tbilisi.
- The applicant was dismissed from his job and brought proceedings against his employer.
- The preparatory hearing was attended by the applicant and his lawyer.
- The applicant’s lawyer wrote to the court requesting that the hearing be adjourned, but no reply followed.
- The District Court held the hearing as planned and issued a default judgment rejecting the applicant’s action without examining it or giving any reasons.
- The applicant’s lawyer filed an application to set aside the judgment, but the judge confirmed his own decision.
- The applicant appealed against the decision, and the Regional Court found that there were grounds for setting aside the decision.
- The applicant’s former employer lodged an appeal against the appeal judgment.
- The Supreme Court found that the applicant had been sufficiently informed of the consequences of his conduct and set aside the Regional Court’s judgment.
- The Regional Court followed the Supreme Court’s reasoning and upheld the decision.
- An appeal on points of law by the applicant was dismissed by the Supreme Court.
- No appeal lay against the above decision of the Supreme Court.

title: CASE OF VIZGIRDA v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in Lithuania in 1980 and lived in Ljubljana, Slovenia.
- On March 2, 2002, the applicant left Lithuania for Slovenia.
- On March 13, 2002, the applicant and three others were arrested for being involved in a bank robbery in Radovljica, Slovenia.
- The robbery involved four masked men, one of whom carried a handgun and held three bank clients at gunpoint while the others overpowered the employees and emptied the tills.
- The police found the robbers' abandoned car with some of the stolen money, a handgun, and two masks, one of which had biological traces belonging to the applicant and another man.
- All four men were Lithuanian nationals.
- The applicant was immediately informed of the reasons for his arrest and his rights by an interpreter and refused to sign the document acknowledging receipt.
- The applicant and six other suspects were questioned by the investigating judge, and the applicant cried and expressed concern for his child.
- The court ordered the detention of all seven suspects, and the decision was translated into Russian and notified to the applicant.
- The applicant's counsel appealed against the detention and subsequent prolongations but was unsuccessful.
- The court examined witness statements and identified one witness who saw the applicant visiting the bank two days before the robbery.
- The applicant denied participation in the robbery and was sentenced to eight years and four months in prison for robbery and acquisition of unlawfully gained property.

title: CASE OF SEYCHELL v. MALTA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1961 and is currently detained at the Corradino Correctional Facility, Paola
- Applicant's residence was searched on 25 June 2004 and a quantity of cannabis plants was found
- Applicant was charged with cultivation and aggravated possession of cannabis
- A court-appointed expert found that the weight of the dried cannabis leaves found amounted to 3,416.20 grams, from which 6,832 cannabis ‘reefers’ could be made or 11,382 ‘sticks of cannabis’
- Applicant suffered from chronic depression and severe back pain and admitted to the first charge during the trial by jury
- Applicant was found guilty of both charges and was sentenced to a term of twelve years’ imprisonment and a fine of 25,000 euros (EUR)
- Applicant instituted constitutional redress proceedings, complaining under Article 6 § 1 about the discretion of the Attorney General as public prosecutor to decide in which court to try an accused
- Request to add a complaint under Article 7 in connection with the discretion of the Attorney General was rejected by the Civil Court (First Hall)
- The Constitutional Court rejected an appeal by the applicant and confirmed the first-instance judgment

title: CASE OF SOMORJAI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant, born in 1939 and living in Vác, was awarded a disability pension on 6 May 1995
- His pension was established accordingly, both under the Act no. LXXXI of 1997 on Social Security Pension Benefits (“the 1997 Pensions Act”) and the Social Security Agreement between Hungary and Austria, since he had accrued service periods in both countries
- On 1 May 2004, his monthly pension was 74,361 Hungarian forints (HUF) (approximately 250 euros (EUR))
- On 18 April 2006, he requested a review of his pension rights in accordance with Article 94(5) of Regulation 1408/71/EEC of the Council of the European Communities
- The applicant’s pension was increased to HUF 134,566 (approximately EUR 449) per month with effect from 1 May 2004 by the Budapest and Pest County Pensions Board on 1 September 2006
- The applicant appealed against that decision on 7 September 2006, and despite the appeal, the decision was implemented immediately and he received HUF 1,996,104 (approximately EUR 6,650) in arrears
- On 16 January 2007, the Central Hungary Regional Pensions Board increased the applicant’s monthly pension to HUF 135,450 (approximately EUR 452) with effect from 1 May 2004
- The applicant challenged the final administrative decision in court and requested that a question concerning the correct interpretation of the Regulation be referred to the Court of Justice of the European Union (“CJEU”) for a preliminary ruling
- On 3 June 2009, the Supreme Court reversed the Budapest Labour Court’s judgment and ordered new proceedings, insisting that the EU law principle concerning the prevention of overlapping of benefits be taken into account
- The Labour Court quashed the decision of the pension authority and instructed it to recalculate the applicant’s pension in accordance with EU rules (without counting the overlap period as a mere Hungarian service period)
- On 7 July 2010, the Central Hungary Regional Pensions Board adopted a new decision in accordance with the instructions of the Budapest Labour Court and increased the applicant’s monthly pension to HUF 139,545 (approximately EUR 465) with effect from 1 May 2004
- The Appeals Department of the National Pensions Administration conducted a repeated second-instance review and, in a decision dated 5 November

title: CASE OF CABRAL v. THE NETHERLANDS
facts:
- The applicant was charged with robbing three supermarkets and mugging someone outside a discotheque.
- The accomplice V. admitted his participation in the robberies and implicated the applicant in all four crimes.
- V. was summoned as a witness by the defence in the trial before the Regional Court, but his statement disculpating the applicant was not believed by the court and he was subsequently charged with perjury.
- The Regional Court convicted the applicant of all four crimes and sentenced him to four years' imprisonment.
- The Court of Appeal convicted the applicant of all four charges, sentenced him to six years' imprisonment, and ordered the execution of a two-week suspended sentence of juvenile detention.
- The evidence on which the conviction of the fourth charge was based included the supermarket manager's report, a statement made to the police by a cashier, and V.'s confession.
- The applicant complained under Article 6 § 3 (d) of the Convention regarding the use made by the Court of Appeal of V.'s statements to the police to ground his convictions.
- The Advocate General expressed the view that V.'s evidence was "sole and decisive" in respect to the fourth charge but not for the first three charges.
- The Supreme Court dismissed the applicant's appeal on points of law, finding that he had had sufficient opportunity to cross-examine V. or have him cross-examined and that the use in evidence of V.'s statement to the police was not excluded by Article 6 § 3 (d) of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SAVVA TERENTYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant lived in Syktyvkar in Russia and had a blog hosted by livejournal.com.
- Police conducted an "unplanned inspection" at a local newspaper office during an election campaign and seized hard disks.
- A regional non-governmental organization issued a press release linking the search to the election campaign.
- The President of Memorial posted the press release on his blog, and the applicant left a comment on a friend's blog, expressing his hatred for police officers and suggesting they be burnt in public.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant under Article 282 § 1 of the Russian Criminal Code in connection with the comment he made on the Internet.
- The applicant was found guilty under Article 282 § 1 for "inciting hatred and enmity" towards police officers by the Town Court.
- The Supreme Court of the Komi Republic rejected the applicant’s appeal and endorsed the Town Court’s conclusions that the experts had acted within the scope of their competence, and that the applicant’s statement had publicly called for violence against police officers.

title: CASE OF ALIKHANOVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The case involves the abduction of Amirkhan Alikhanov on December 23, 2004.
- The abductors were individuals who introduced themselves as officers from the Dagestan Organised Crime Unit.
- The abductors had been waiting for someone to go through the checkpoint before seizing Alikhanov and his car.
- A ransom demand was made, with the amount originally set at $25,000 and later increased to $250,000.
- Alikhanov's relatives found his clothing covered in blood and penetrated by bullet holes near a cemetery in Zamay-Yurt, Chechen Republic.
- Six bodies were discovered in the same location, with each having a broken right collarbone and a single execution-style shot to the head.
- The local residents claimed the federal forces were responsible for the killings of the six individuals.
- The state could not provide information concerning Alikhanov's whereabouts after the abduction.

title: CASE OF IBRAGIM IBRAGIMOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant is the founder and CEO of a non-profit organization. 
- The second applicant publishes the Risale-I Nur Collection, used for religious and educational purposes in Russian mosques and medreses. 
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against members of the Nurculuk religious movement for distributing books from the Risale-I Nur Collection.
