- The prosecutor applied to ban certain books from the collection, based on expert opinions about their subconsciously influencing readers to form irrational values and opinions, encouraging hatred and enmity towards those of other faiths, and advocating the idea of superiority or inferiority based on religion. 
- The second applicant and the Council of Mufti of Russia participated in the proceedings, submitting letters and expert opinions arguing against the ban and stating that the books did not contain extremist statements, but rather taught moral and religious values, promoted peaceful coexistence of religions, and discouraged extremism and radicalism.

title: CASE OF ENGELHARDT v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1969 and lives in Bílovice nad Svitavou (the Czech Republic). 
- On 30 December 1992 the applicant’s legal predecessor and two others applied for the restitution of some plots of land.
- The proceedings would end in relation to part of the property but continue in relation to the remainder.
- By a decision of the Land Office of 17 May 1999, the proceedings in respect of another part of the property ended. 
- On 23 May 2003 the relevant part of the proceedings was reopened. 
- On 12 July 2013 the Land Office stayed the restitution proceedings. 
- On 11 September 2015 the Land Office dismissed part of the applicant’s claim. 
- On 19 October 2015 the Land Office stayed the examination of the remainder of the claim. 
- The remainder of the applicant’s claim is still pending. 
- On 18 June 2011 the Bratislava Regional Land Office acknowledged that there had been unjustified delays in the proceedings. 
- On 20 December 2011 the applicant brought an action in the Bratislava Regional Court for acceleration of the proceedings. 
- On 19 April 2012 the Regional Court dismissed the action. 
- The decision of 19 April 2012 was quashed by the Constitutional Court. 
- On 12 November 2013, the Bratislava II District Office of the Public Prosecution Service informed the applicant that the PPS had reprimanded the Land Office. 
- On 21 August 2014 the applicant lodged a fresh action with the Regional Court. 
- On 27 May 2015 the Regional Court allowed the action. 
- On 4 July 2012 the applicant lodged two constitutional complaints. 
- The first complaint was rejected for lack of jurisdiction. 
- The second complaint was directed against the Regional Court. 
- In a constitutional judgment of 16 January 2013, the Constitutional Court allowed the relevant part of the applicant’s complaint.

title: CASE OF BALOGH AND OTHERS v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- Claim lodged for land restitution on 23 December 2004
- Claim dismissed by Land Office on 27 May 2010
- Nitra Regional Court upholds decision on 21 November 2011
- Supreme Court quashes judgment on 29 January 2014 and remits case to Regional Court
- Regional Court invites claimants to clarify legal representation and rules that they will be jointly represented by a lawyer
- Supreme Court upholds Regional Court decision on 25 May 2016
- Constitutional Court rejects complaint about length of proceedings before Land Office and Regional Court on 21 January 2015, citing non-exhaustion of ordinary remedies and four and a half years of reasonable duration for appellate proceedings.

title: CASE OF ÖMER GÜNER v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was arrested by the police in connection with an operation conducted against an illegal organisation.
- Eighty-eight left-wing books and periodicals in his room were seized by the police.
- The applicant participated in an identity parade in the absence of a lawyer and identified a co-accused.
- The applicant was questioned by the police and admitted to expressing his wish to be involved in the activities of the illegal organisation but was not affiliated with it.
- The applicant was convicted of aiding and abetting a terrorist organisation and sentenced to ten months’ imprisonment and a fine.
- The Court of Cassation quashed the judgment, and the case was transferred to the İzmir Assize Court.
- The public prosecutor requested the acquittal of the applicant, but the İzmir Assize Court convicted him again.

title: CASE OF ÇELİK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Şanlıurfa. 
- The applicant sent a letter to the Halfeti public prosecutor’s office on 17 July 2008. 
- In the letter, the applicant stated that he used the word “Sayın Abdullah Öcalan” and committed the offense. 
- On 9 October 2008, the public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment and charged the applicant with praising an offense and offender. 
- On 29 December 2008, the Halfeti Magistrates’ Court found the applicant guilty of praising the imprisoned leader of the PKK and sentenced him to two months and fifteen days’ imprisonment. 
- The prison sentence was commuted to a fine of 1,500 Turkish Liras in accordance with Article 50 of the Criminal Code.

title: CASE OF ALKAYA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and was detained at Tekirdağ F-type prison.
- On 9 April 2003, the applicant was taken into police custody on suspicion of being a member of a terrorist organization.
- On 13 April 2003, the Istanbul State Security Court placed the applicant in detention on remand.
- On 23 July 2003, the Istanbul public prosecutor filed an indictment charging the applicant with membership of a terrorist organization and attempting to undermine the constitutional order of Turkey by force.
- The court ordered the continuation of the applicant's detention on 10 November 2008, followed by an objection filed by the applicant's lawyer.
- The 13th Chamber of the Istanbul Assize Court dismissed the objection on 27 November 2008, considering the written opinion of the public prosecutor, which was not communicated to the applicant or his representative.
- On 4 May 2011, the applicant was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by the Istanbul Assize Court.
- On 25 September 2012, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first-instance court.

title: CASE OF BABAYİĞİT v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1983 and was serving a prison sentence in Bolu F-type prison.
- On 10 December 2007, the applicant wrote a letter praising the imprisoned leader of the PKK.
- The applicant was found guilty of breaching prison order by the Kocaeli F-type Prison Disciplinary Board.
- On 24 December 2007, the applicant was sentenced to 13 days of solitary confinement.
- On 17 January 2008, the applicant's objection was rejected by the Kocaeli Enforcement Judge.
- On 14 February 2008, the Kocaeli Assize Court upheld the judgment of 17 January 2008.

title: CASE OF TIRAMAVIA S.R.L. AND OTHERS v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts include:

- The applicants are companies specializing in air transportation.
- Each of the companies had a valid air operator certificate (an “AOC”) issued by the Moldovan Civil Aviation State Authority (the “CASA”).
- On 1 June 2007, the CASA issued an order banning all flights of aircraft registered in Moldova to Iraq and Afghanistan, with effect from 15 July 2007.
- The European Union Safety Committee conducted checks on Moldovan aviation companies and identified irregularities concerning compliance with European norms in the field of aviation safety. The CASA failed to demonstrate the ability adequately to enforce and implement the relevant safety standards.
- The CASA required companies to present their response to the findings in the report by 22 June 2007, and a decision was to be taken on whether or not to ban those companies from entering European Union airspace.
- On 21 June 2007, the CASA issued order no. 102/GEN withdrawing the applicant companies’ AOCs, and thereby terminating their activity.
- The CASA relied on irregularities found with the first applicant company and three other companies, which are not applicants in the present case, and the fact that the second and third applicant companies flew to destinations such as Iraq, Afghanistan, Congo, Sudan, Sierra Leone, Kosovo, New Zealand and United Arab Emirates.
- The applicant companies challenged the decision before the Chişinău Court of Appeal, which rejected their action. The Supreme Court of Justice dismissed the applicant companies’ appeal and upheld the judgment of the Court of Appeal.

title: CASE OF MIRON v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and is detained in Chișinău.
- On 24 August 2011, the applicant was taken into police custody on charges of murder and unauthorized possession of a firearm. He was subsequently remanded in custody.
- The grounds for his detention included the seriousness of the charges against him and the fear that he might abscond, re-offend and interfere with the investigation.
- The applicant did not appeal against the decisions of the court to extend his detention every thirty days.
- On 17 January 2012, the applicant’s case was committed for trial, and his detention was extended every three months.
- In his appeals against the decisions of 12 April, 10 June, and 10 July 2013, the applicant complained about the length of his detention.
- Approximately three years after his initial arrest, the applicant was found guilty on all charges, sentenced to twenty-three years of imprisonment, and transferred to prison no. 13 in Chișinău.
- During his detention, the applicant was subjected to poor prison conditions, including overcrowding, insufficient lighting, damp walls, and inadequate ventilation, heating, and bedding. Additionally, some inmates had tuberculosis or HIV, and the squat toilet was not separated from the rest of the cell.
- The applicant’s lawyer complained about the conditions of his detention, but the Department of Penitentiary Institutions denied these complaints.

title: CASE OF ÇALAĞAN AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were serving their prison sentences at the time of the applications.
- The applicants were found guilty of breaching prison orders.
- The applicants were sentenced to 11 to 15 days of solitary confinement.
- The objections of the applicants were rejected.
- The Enforcement Judges and the Assize Courts made their decision based on case files, without hearing the applicants or their lawyers.

title: CASE OF DOGOTAR v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was a pensioner receiving a small amount of money per month.
- The applicant asked the Minister of Social Protection about the calculation of his pension, and the Minister responded in a way that angered the applicant.
- The applicant cursed and slapped the Minister in the face.
- Criminal proceedings were initiated against the applicant for hooliganism.
- The applicant was ordered to undergo a psychiatric examination to determine his fitness to plead.
- A commission of psychiatrists speculated that the applicant might suffer from dementia or amnesia but did not reach a final conclusion.
- An in-patient psychiatric forensic examination was ordered, which the applicant challenged unsuccessfully.
- The applicant was arrested and taken to a psychiatric hospital where he signed several pre-printed documents, one of which he later stated he did not consent to being subjected to a psychiatric examination.
- The applicant was released from the hospital after his son employed a lawyer who took measures to have him released.
- The applicant was found guilty of hooliganism and sentenced to a criminal fine.

title: CASE OF ÇETİN AND GEDİK v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants are Turkish nationals
- Applicants were serving prison sentences
- Applicants were found guilty of breaching prison order
- Applicants were sentenced to 11-12 days solitary confinement
- Objections were rejected by Enforcement Judges and Assize Courts
- Objections were rejected without hearing from applicants or their lawyers
- The decisions were made pursuant to Regulations on administration of penitentiary institutions and execution of sentences and Law no. 4675 on Enforcement Judges.

title: CASE OF CRISTIAN CĂTĂLIN UNGUREANU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was married to I.M.U. and they had a son together.
- On 13 September 2012, I.M.U. filed for divorce and custody of the child due to conflicts about their son's education.
- On 19 October 2012, I.M.U. took the child and moved in with her parents and grandmother.
- On 2 November 2012, the applicant filed for an interim injunction seeking sole or shared custody of the child or the right to visit according to a schedule.
- The court ruled that changing the child's residence during the proceedings would not be in the child's interest.
- The Prahova County Court upheld the ruling and ordered the applicant to pay I.M.U.'s legal costs.
- The applicant was removed from the school premises where his son studied, and I.M.U. stopped allowing him further contact with the child.
- The district court gave its final judgment in the divorce proceedings on 22 January 2014, granting the applicant the right to have the child stay at his home every other weekend and for two weeks during summer holidays.
- Both parties appealed the County Court’s decision, and the Bucharest Court of Appeal delivered the final decision in the case on 2 November 2016, upholding the ruling of the District Court with some amendments to the visiting schedule.
- On 19 February 2018, the child moved in with the applicant according to an agreement signed by both parents after the mother decided to move to another town.

title: CASE OF ŠTITIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Karlovac
- Police spotted the applicant with another man, V.P., in a vehicle parked in the car park of a supermarket
- Applicant was already known to the police as a convicted drug dealer
- Police approached V.P., who tried to throw away a plastic bag containing heroin
- Applicant ran away but was caught by the police officers
- Applicant resisted arrest and police officers had to apply force (leg sweep technique)
- Applicant alleged that he was beaten by the police officers while he was lying on the ground
- Applicant was taken by the officers to the premises of the Zadar police
- Medical documentation showed that the applicant sustained injuries, including a haematoma below both eyes and a perforated left eardrum
- Criminal complaint was lodged against the applicant on charges of substance abuse
- Police officers compiled a report on the force they had used against the applicant, which was later forwarded to the chief of the Zadar police, expressing their opinion that they had lawfully used force against the applicant
- Applicant lodged a complaint with the Ministry of Interior about the force used against him by the police officers
- Applicant lodged a criminal complaint with the Zadar Municipal State Attorney’s Office, alleging that police officers had hit and kicked him all over during his arrest and had pushed him down the stairs
- The State Attorney’s Office asked the police to interview officers and other officers involved in the incident, including the officer whose badge number the applicant had remembered
- Zadar police asked the Prison Service for the identity of the officer with badge no. 4374, but it turned out that none of the officers had that particular badge number
- The State Attorney’s Office informed the applicant that his allegations were unfounded and he was informed of his right to complain to the Zadar County State Attorney’s Office
- Applicant replied to the State Attorney’s Office, stressing that his submission was a criminal complaint rather than a petition and asked that a decision concerning the merits of his allegations be adopted
- Applicant took over the prosecution and lodged an indictment with the Zadar Municipal Court against officers B.R., B.M., and S.K.
- An investigation was requested, and the applicant requested that the accused, V.P., and the security guards of a supermarket on duty at the critical time be questioned, and that a forensic report be ordered to establish how his injuries had been caused.

title: CASE OF BUVAČ v. CROATIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points:

- The applicant was born in 1971 and lives in Zagreb.
- On 28 April 2008, the daily newspaper B. published an article describing the applicant as an extortionist.
- On 27 May 2008, the applicant’s representative asked the publisher to publish a correction of that information, which was neither replied to nor published.
- On 9 July 2008, the applicant brought a civil action against the publisher in the Zagreb Municipal Civil Court (Općinski građanski sud u Zagrebu) for non-pecuniary damage.
- On 10 July 2009, the publisher replied stating, among other things, that the applicant had failed to submit a power of attorney with his request.
- At a hearing held on 31 January 2012, the Zagreb Municipal Civil Court declared the applicant’s claim inadmissible for not providing proof of authorization in accordance with the Media Act.
- On 19 November 2012, the Šibenik County Court dismissed the applicant's appeal and upheld the first-instance decision.
- On 14 March 2013, the Constitutional Court declared a constitutional complaint lodged by the applicant inadmissible.

title: CASE OF UZUNOVA AND SEID v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicants co-owned a plot of land that was expropriated by the Council of Ministers to build a motorway.
- The expropriation decision was declared null and void by the Supreme Administrative Court due to a failure to specify the actual owners of the plot to whom compensation was due.
- The case was referred back to the administrative authorities and the Road Infrastructure Agency requested re-opening of the judicial review proceedings.
- A final judgment of the Supreme Administrative Court found that compensation was due to the applicants and it had to be increased according to the expert report obtained in the course of the proceedings.
- The Council of Ministers issued a new decision for expropriation, which was declared null and void by the Supreme Administrative Court for failing to take account of the binding effect of the previous court judgment.
- The Road Infrastructure Agency eventually paid the compensation due to the applicants.
- The applicants sought interest on the amount determined in the judgment for the period of non-enforcement but their claim was dismissed by both the Sofia Administrative Court and the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF KOPANKOVI v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The first, second, and third applicants were born in 1941 and 1974, respectively, and lived in Kazanlak. The fourth applicant was born in 1967 and lived in Sofia.
- Maria Kopankova and the fourth applicant co-owned a house with a garden in Kazanlak, where Kopankova lived with her sons and their families, including the applicants.
- The property was expropriated in 1988 to construct a residential building, and the owners were to be compensated with flats in the building.
- The compensation was never provided, and the property was demolished. The applicants repeatedly petitioned for compensation with no response.
- In 2009, the applicants requested the revocation of the expropriation order, which was granted by the Administrative Court in 2010.
- The applicants sued the municipality for damages, including the value of the house and other objects destroyed, but their claims were deemed inadmissible under the Territorial Planning Act of 2001. The decision was upheld by the Supreme Administrative Court.

title: CASE OF DADAYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and resides in Yerevan.
- S.T. and H.O. were arrested in Georgia while trying to sell 15 g of enriched uranium, which they had transported from Armenia.
- National Security Service of Armenia received information that S.T. and H.O. had received the radioactive substance from the applicant.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of aiding and abetting S.T. and H.O. in the offense of selling uranium.
- The applicant was charged with aiding and abetting S.T. and H.O. in the offense.
- H.O. had borrowed money from the applicant in the past.
- H.O. stated that the applicant gave him 1 g of radioactive substance in 2002 or 2003.
- S.T. and H.O. had asked the applicant to obtain radioactive substances.
- The bill of indictment relies on witness statements, forensic examination, telephone correspondence, and applicant's passport.
- The applicant requested the temporary transfer of S.T. and H.O. from prison in Georgia so that they could be examined at the trial.
- The request was denied, and the applicant's representative allowed the court to continue with the examination of the case.
- The presiding judge informed the parties of the reply from the Ministry of Justice of Georgia.
- The trial court rejected the application to summon a conductor of the train as a witness.
- The Regional Court convicted the applicant and sentenced him to seven years' imprisonment and ordered the confiscation of his property.
- The applicant lodged an appeal, which was upheld by the Criminal Court of Appeal.
- The Court of Cassation declared the applicant's appeal on points of law inadmissible for lack of merit.

title: CASE OF SAPUNDZHIEV v. BULGARIA
facts:
- The applicant lived in Silistra and had a printing company installed near his house in 2003.
- The printing company caused constant unpleasant smells and vibrations from its machines.
- The applicant's daughter developed an allergy he believed was caused by chemicals used in the printing process.
- The applicant contacted several State institutions between July 2006 and August 2007 to complain about the printing company's operations and legal violations.
- The public health agency inspected the printing company on 10 August 2006 and determined it was operating legally.
- The applicant complained again on 17 August 2006, expressing dissatisfaction with how measurements of noise and air pollution had been taken during an inspection on 18 August 2006.
- The applicant and his neighbors complained to the building inspectorate on 23 August 2006 about the printing company's violation of relevant construction norms.
- The Ministry for Health issued an instruction to the printing company on 29 August 2006 to bring the noise levels generated by its business within legal limits.
- The printing company was found to be operating legally by the regional inspectorate for the environment and water on 30 August 2007.
- The applicant produced posters to express support for the termination of the printing company's operations, which led to V.V. bringing defamation proceedings against him.
- The applicant was found guilty of libel by the Silistra District Court on 5 June 2007.

title: CASE OF JANSEN v. NORWAY
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- A was born in 2011 to a mother and father who had been engaged but had ended their relationship.
- The mother and child stayed at a parent-child institution due to being thrown out of the maternal grandfather's home after just under three weeks.
- The maternal grandfather stabbed a neighboring couple who were friends with the mother, believing they helped her move to the parent-child institution.
- The child was later placed in an emergency foster home due to the risk of abduction by the mother's family and network.
- The Child Welfare Service issued a care order for the child due to serious deficiencies in terms of personal contact and security, and the mother's inability to benefit from assistance measures.
- The Board ordered that the parents are not entitled to have contact with A, citing the risk of abduction.

title: CASE OF DIMITAR YORDANOV v. BULGARIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts in bullet points are:

- The applicant owns half of a plot of land and a house in Golyamo Buchino, which he lived in until 1997, as well as two smaller buildings (which no longer exist).
- A coalmine was created near the village in the late 1980s or early 1990s, and in 1990 the local mayor expropriated the applicant's land and buildings, stating that he would receive compensation (another plot of land in the village and a sum of money).
- The compensation was not provided within the statutory time limit, so the applicant requested the expropriation be cancelled in 1992 - which was granted, with instructions for him to pay back the monetary compensation he had received.
- The mine gradually approached the applicant's house, with daily detonations from which he claimed the walls of his house cracked, and his barn and pen collapsed.
- The applicant sought compensation from the mine, but negotiations failed.
- He brought a tort action against the mine in 2001, which was dismissed by the Regional Court in 2003, and then by the Court of Appeal in 2007, both courts finding that he had not proven a causal link between the mine's detonation works and the damage to his property.
- The Supreme Court of Cassation upheld the Court of Appeal's judgment in 2008. Meanwhile, the applicant's house collapsed and the property was abandoned.

title: CASE OF B. TAGLIAFERRO & SONS LIMITED AND COLEIRO BROTHERS LIMITED v. MALTA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- Two companies were the owners of a one third undivided share of three corner properties in Valletta, Malta.
- The Government declared its intention of acquiring the properties for public purposes in 1993.
- The purpose of the taking was to use the properties, together with other properties also expropriated, as government offices, in particular, as the Office of the Attorney General.
- The properties were not vacated until 2007, and the Government took over their possession.
- The two applicant companies instituted separate constitutional redress proceedings complaining that the taking had not been in the public interest, that there had been a delay in the payment of compensation and that they had had no access to an impartial and independent tribunal in the meantime.
- The courts found a violation of Article 6 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention in connection with the delay resulting from the expropriation proceedings, highlighting the slowness of the authorities in taking steps to vacate the premises and in offering the applicant companies compensation.
- The courts also found a violation of Article 6 in so far as the applicant companies had not had access to court between 1993 and 2009, given that access to the Land Arbitration Board (LAB) was limited solely to the CoL.
- The Constitutional Court confirmed the violations of Article 6 and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention in connection with the delay in the payment of compensation, and the lack of independence and impartiality of the LAB, both before and after amendments were made to the law.
- The applicant companies were awarded non-pecuniary damage in the amount of EUR 15,000 each, and the courts ordered the applicant companies to pay a portion of the costs.
- As of 2018, the applicant companies' property remained designated for public use, while the Government had identified another building to use as the Office of the Attorney General.

title: CASE OF BIG BROTHER WATCH AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
facts:
- Case involves secret surveillance schemes by GCHQ and NSA
- Domestic proceedings in three joined cases
- IPT issued judgments on December 5, 2014, February 6, 2015, and June 22, 2015
- Section 8(4) issue was raised in the first judgment
- December 5, 2014 judgment was the first in the case
- June 22, 2015 judgment was later amended by a July 1, 2015 letter

title: CASE OF SOLSKA AND RYBICKA v. POLAND
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1937 and lives in Sopot. The second applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Gdańsk.
- On 10 April 2010, an aircraft carrying a Polish State delegation crashed, killing all ninety-six people on board.
- The applicants are the widows of two victims of the crash, Mr Leszek Solski, an activist of the Katyń Families Association, and Mr Arkadiusz Rybicki, a member of parliament.
- The Polish Committee for the Investigation of State Aviation Accidents published its report on the causes of the crash, concluding that it was due to the descent below the minimum descent altitude at an excessive rate of descent in weather conditions which prevented visual contact with the ground, as well as the delayed execution of the go-around procedure.
- The Warsaw Regional Military Prosecutor’s Office opened an investigation into the crash on 10 April 2010, and both applicants were granted victim status in the investigation.
- On 7 October 2016, a prosecutor of the State Prosecutor’s Office decided to appoint a team of international and national forensic experts with a view to carrying out autopsies on the bodies of eighty-three victims of the crash, and ordered exhumations of their bodies.
- On 6, 7 and 21 December 2016, the applicants lodged interlocutory appeals against the prosecutor’s decision with the Warsaw Regional Court.
- On 3 April 2017, the Warsaw Regional Court decided to refer a legal question to the Constitutional Court on the constitutionality of Article 210 of the CCP.
- The proceedings before the Warsaw Regional Court have been suspended until the Constitutional Court issues a decision on the matter.
- On 24 May 2017, the applicants again urged the State Prosecutor’s Office to revoke its decision on exhumation, but the prosecutor replied in the negative on 7 June 2017.
- The exhumation of the applicants’ husbands had initially been planned for 24 and 26 April 2018. The bodies of those victims whose families had not complained had been exhumed first, while the bodies of those victims whose families had complained against the prosecutor’s decision would be exhumed at a later stage.
- On 13 April 2018, the prosecutor issued two orders setting the dates of the exhumation of the bodies of the applicants’ husbands for 14 and 16 May 2018.

title: CASE OF ANDRONACHE AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their relevant details are given
- Applicants have made a complaint 
- The complaint is about inadequate detention conditions

title: CASE OF BANU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants and their relevant details in the appended table.
- The applicants complained about their detention conditions being inadequate.

title: CASE OF GULYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1942 and lives in Yerevan.
- S.V. was shot dead on 9 May 2007 in front of a restaurant owned by the applicant’s son.
- A team of law-enforcement officers arrived at the scene, including police officers, investigators, and two officers of the Principal Department for Criminal Intelligence.
- Levon Gulyan was taken to the police station in connection with the incident and was questioned by PDCI Officers H.T. and G.T. for several hours.
- Levon Gulyan was released on condition he return to the police station on 12 May 2007.
- Levon Gulyan was taken to the PDCI headquarters by PDCI Officers V.G. and S.M. on 12 May 2007 at around 2 p.m.
- Levon Gulyan was found dead in the courtyard of the police headquarters with multiple injuries at around 3.20 p.m on 12 May 2007.
- The cause of death was a massive blunt-force trauma to the head and chest.
- An investigation was conducted, including forensic examinations and witness statements from various individuals, including Levon Gulyan and law enforcement officers.
- The examination found multiple lesions on Levon Gulyan’s head and body, but no typical defence lesions.
- It was found that the fingerprints on the window belonged to Levon Gulyan, but there was also a palm print and a fingerprint which did not belong to him.
- Foreign natural and chemical fibers were found on Levon Gulyan’s clothes and under his fingernails, which were fit for further comparative examination.
- The smears found on the windowsill had the same generic origin as the samples taken from the soles of Levon Gulyan’s shoes.
- The palm print and the fingerprint found on the window did not belong to PDCI Officers G.T. or A.M. or to the cleaning lady.

title: CASE OF GREBENICHENKO AND POLYAKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants and their details in the appended table. 
- The applicants have raised concerns about non-enforcement of domestic decisions. 
- The applicants believe there is a lack of any effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF ANTIPIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details of applications included in appended table.
- Applicants claim they were denied an opportunity to appear in person before the court in civil proceedings.
- Applicant in application no. 28590/11 raised other complaints under Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF CHERNYKH AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The document contains a list of applicants and their relevant details in an appended table.
- The applicants were involved in civil proceedings but were not given the chance to participate in the hearings.
- They complained of the failure of the domestic courts to ensure their participation.

title: CASE OF JISHKARIANI v. GEORGIA
facts:
Main descriptions of facts in bullet points:
- The applicant is a psychiatrist and founder/director of an NGO called "Rehabilitation Centre for Victims of Torture Empathy"
- The NGO signed an agreement with the Ministry of Justice to create a psychosocial rehabilitation office in Tbilisi Prison no. 1
- The applicant became a member of the Public Monitoring Commission overseeing the implementation of inmates' rights
- An Inmates' Mental Health Research and Monitoring Commission was created, including the applicant, to address mental health issues among prisoners
- Incidents occurred, including an inmate assaulting the prison hospital staff and others waiting for medical care, attracting media attention
- An investigation was opened into the alleged abuse of official power and the director of the Medical Department was accused of corruption and mismanagement
- The Minister of Justice made public statements accusing the applicant of exceeding her powers and engaging in corrupt activities in relation to the transfers of inmates to the hospital, among other accusations
- The applicant instituted civil-law defamation proceedings against the Minister, claiming false allegations had a negative impact on her reputation as a mental health professional
- The Tbilisi City Court found against the applicant, concluding that the Minister's statements fell within acceptable criticism as he had the freedom of expression to voice his opinion about the state of affairs within his Ministry.

title: CASE OF GASPARI v. ARMENIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1957 and lives in Yerevan.
- Applicant is an ethnic Armenian born in Iran and living in Armenia.
- Presidential election held on February 19, 2008, followed by protests and clashes between protesters and police resulting in numerous arrests.
- Applicant taken to police station on March 1, 2008, for suspicion of assaulting a police officer and giving false information about his identity.
- Applicant's pre-trial detention ordered for two months on the grounds of danger of absconding, obstructing justice, committing another offence, and evading criminal responsibility.
- Applicant's appeals for release dismissed by the District Court and Criminal Court of Appeal.
- Applicant found guilty as charged and sentenced to one year's imprisonment, which he serves in various cells of Nubarashen Remand Prison.

title: CASE OF MUSHEGH SAGHATELYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1950 and lives in Yerevan.
- A presidential election was held in Armenia on 19 February 2008.
- The main contenders were Prime Minister Mr Sargsyan and the main opposition candidate Mr Ter-Petrosyan, who the applicant supported.
- After the announcement of the preliminary results, Mr Ter-Petrosyan called on his supporters to protest against the alleged irregularities in the election process at Freedom Square in central Yerevan, where nationwide daily protest rallies were held.
- On 1 March 2008, the police arrived at Freedom Square and violently dispersed the demonstrators, allegedly due to information about the possession of weapons by protesters.
- Following the events at Freedom Square, protests spread throughout the city of Yerevan, resulting in ten deaths and numerous injuries.
- Criminal cases were instituted against participants in the protests, including the applicant.

title: CASE OF MAINSTREET-AUTOMATEN GMBH v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with relevant application details in the appended table.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- In application no. 72662/14, the applicant company raised a complaint under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SHCHERBAKOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant broke a window in a home and threw a jar of petrol with a burning fuse, causing serious injuries to the inhabitant.
- The applicant was arrested and allegedly ill-treated by police officers in order to force a confession.
- The applicant admitted to the crime under police questioning and later refused to give evidence.
- Forensic medical examination showed injuries likely to have been caused by ill-treatment.
- The applicant was convicted of attempted murder, intentional infliction of grievous bodily harm and arson and sentenced to fifteen years' imprisonment.

title: CASE OF PANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A list of applicants and their application details are included.
- The applicants complained about their inadequate detention conditions.
- Some applicants had additional complaints under the Convention's provisions.

title: CASE OF YELISEYEV AND KNYAZKIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants provided in an appended table.
- Applicants complained about poor detention conditions.
- Complaints raised under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF IVANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and their application details provided in a table
- Applicants complain about the inadequate conditions of their detention
- Other complaints raised by some applicants under the provisions of the Convention

title: CASE OF CANER v. AUSTRIA
facts:
- The applicant complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings and lack of effective remedy
- The complaint relied on Article 6 § 1 of the Convention
- The Court assessed the reasonableness of the length of proceedings based on complexity of the case, conduct of the parties, and what was at stake
- Previous similar cases have been found in violation of the Convention
- The Court found a breach of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention
- Another complaint was submitted and found admissible with violation of the Convention
- The Court ordered the respondent State to pay the applicant for damages, costs, and expenses
- The amount awarded for pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage, as well as costs and expenses, were specified in the appended table.

title: CASE OF ŞTEFĂNESCU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- There is a list of applicants with details in an appended table.
- The applicants complained about inadequate detention conditions.

title: CASE OF LUNGU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- A table has been appended containing the list of applicants and their relevant application details.
- Applicants complained about the insufficient conditions of their detention.
- Two of the applicants (nos. 5470/16 and 12412/16) made additional complaints under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF ALIYEV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- The applicant is a well-known human-rights lawyer and civil-society activist.
- He is the chairman of the Legal Education Society (“the Association”), a non-governmental organisation specialising in legal education.
- The applicant has collaborated with various international organisations on human-rights-related projects.
- On 24 June 2014, the applicant delivered a report on human-rights abuses in Azerbaijan.
- Following his participation at the above event, a smear campaign was launched against him and other human-rights defenders by the pro-government media.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted in connection with alleged irregularities in the financial activities of a number of non-governmental organisations, including the Association.
- On 7 July 2014, the Sabail District Court ordered the freezing of the applicant’s and the Association’s bank accounts.
- On 8 August 2014, the applicant was invited to the Prosecutor General’s Office for questioning as a witness in connection with the above‑mentioned criminal proceedings.
- The investigator issued a decision charging the applicant under several articles of the Criminal Code.
- On the same day, the Nasimi District Court ordered the applicant’s detention for a period of three months.
- On 12 September 2014, the Nasimi District Court dismissed the applicant’s application to substitute remand with either house arrest or release on bail.
- On 12 December 2014, the Prosecutor General’s Office charged the applicant de novo under several articles of the Criminal Code, including high-level embezzlement and tax evasion on a very large scale.
- On 29 December 2014, the Prosecutor General’s Office drew up a bill of indictment, and the case went to trial. 
- On 7 August 2014, the prosecutor in charge applied to the Nasimi District Court to have a search of the office of the Association and “other places of storage” authorized.

title: CASE OF DENISOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was born in Kyiv in 1948.
- He began his judicial career in 1976 as a judge of a district court and was later elected as president in several courts.
- In 2005, he was elected as judge of the Kyiv Administrative Court of Appeal and was appointed as acting president in 2006 and as the president in 2009.
- In February 2011, the Council of Administrative Court Judges reviewed the functioning of the Kyiv Administrative Court of Appeal and found significant shortcomings, omissions, and errors.
- On May 2011, the Council of Administrative Court Judges proposed the applicant's dismissal from the position of president of the court to the High Council of Justice.
- The HCJ scheduled hearings on May and June 2011, but the applicant was absent as he was on holiday until July.
- On June 2011, the HCJ examined the case in the applicant's absence and dismissed him from the post of the president of the court.
- The applicant challenged the decision of the HCJ before the Higher Administrative Court, claiming that the HCJ had failed to comply with the requirements of an independent and impartial tribunal.
- On August and October 2011, the Higher Administrative Court rejected the applicant's claim.
- The applicant continued to work as a regular judge in the same court until his resignation in June 2013.

title: CASE OF ONAT v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1988 and lives in Istanbul.
- On 12 May 2009, Access to the investigation file was restricted.
- On 31 October 2009, the applicant was arrested on suspicion of membership in a terrorist organization.
- On 1 November 2009, a police statement was taken from the applicant in the presence of his lawyer. 
- On 2 November 2009, the judge ordered pre-trial detention and the applicant's lawyer asked the court to lift the restriction of access to investigation files.
- On 4 November 2009, the applicant's lawyer filed an objection against the decision on the applicant's detention.
- On 25 November 2009, the Istanbul public prosecutor filed an indictment.
- On 4 December 2009, the indictment was accepted and the restriction on the file was lifted.
- On 26 February 2010, the applicant was released.
- The criminal proceedings against the applicant are still ongoing.

title: CASE OF DÜZEL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is from Diyarbakır and was born in 1960.
- On 30 September 2007, a protest was held in Diyarbakır about the alleged poisoning and conditions of detention of Abdullah Öcalan.
- The applicant, as a member of the Democratic Society Party (DTP), participated in the protest, including a press statement and a march, where she was seen carrying a banner that said “The humanity is being poisoned” and applauding with other demonstrators in police video footage.
- On 9 October 2007, the applicant was detained by police and later detained on remand.
- On 17 October 2007, the Diyarbakır public prosecutor charged the applicant with disseminating propaganda in favor of a terrorist organization for the content of the banner she carried during the protest.
- On 4 December 2007, the applicant was released pending trial.
- On 18 March 2008, the Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicant and sentenced her to ten months’ imprisonment.
- On 9 January 2012, the Court of Cassation upheld the conviction.
- At an unspecified date, the applicant began serving her prison sentence.
- On 17 July 2012, the applicant was released from prison upon her request, in accordance with Law no. 6352, which had amended certain provisions of Law no. 3713.

title: CASE OF ĆORIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicant born in 1951 and lives in Novi Sad.
- Proceedings began on 19 November 1999 for tenancy rights of a flat owned by a respondent.
- Applicant acted as an intervener on the side of the respondent.
- On 8 April 2003, the first instance court suspended the proceedings (mirovanje postupka).
- On 20 August 2003, 20 October 2005, and 13 May 2009, the first instance court terminated the proceedings.
- On 29 March 2012, the first instance court rendered a judgment in favour of the respondent and the applicant.
- On 22 August 2012, this judgement was upheld on appeal.
- On 28 September 2012, the applicant lodged another appeal with the Constitutional Court.
- On 10 February 2015, the Constitutional Court found a violation of the applicant’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time.
- The claim for non-pecuniary damage was rejected.
- The applicant significantly contributed to the length of proceedings.

title: CASE OF OSKIRKO v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant was born in 1973 and is detained in Kybartai.
- The applicant was arrested on 22 December 2011 and detained in Klaipėda police station and later in Šiauliai Remand Prison until 13 March 2013 when he was convicted of murder and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment.
- From 13 March 2013 to 5 May 2014, the applicant was held in five different cells in Lukiškės Remand Prison, where he was sometimes alone and sometimes with other inmates.
- The applicant complains of overcrowding, low temperatures, damp, lack of proper partitions between toilets and cells, minimum time spent in the open air, insufficient nutritional value of the food, and lack of visits.
- The applicant filed a complaint with Vilnius Regional Administrative Court on 3 June 2014, asking for immediate termination of inhuman and degrading treatment, transfer to a cell where he would have no less than 4 square metres of personal space, and compensation.
- The Vilnius Regional Administrative Court allowed the applicant’s claim in part, and the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the decision, awarding the applicant compensation of EUR 1,200 from Šiauliai Remand Prison and EUR 200 from Klaipėda police station.
- The applicant never asked the prison administration if he could receive long-term conjugal visits from his partner.

title: CASE OF LANIAUSKAS AND JANUŠK v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1972 and is detained in Vilnius.
- The second applicant was born in 1982 and is detained in Pravieniškės.
- The first applicant has been detained in Lukiškės Remand Prison since 17 March 2008.
- The first applicant lodged a civil claim against the State on 27 July 2012, alleging overcrowded and unsanitary cells and claiming non-pecuniary damages.
- Vilnius Regional Administrative Court allowed in part the first applicant's claim, finding that the personal space afforded to him during the detention period did not comply with the domestic requirements and some cells' temperature and natural light did not meet domestic hygiene norms.
- The first applicant was awarded LTL 1,500 (approximately EUR 434) in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- The Supreme Administrative Court dismissed the first applicant's appeal against the Vilnius Regional Administrative Court's decision in its entirety.
- The second applicant was detained in Vilnius Correctional Facility from 8 June 2012 to 5 February 2016.
- The second applicant lodged a civil claim against the State on 4 October 2013, alleging overcrowded dormitory-type rooms and claiming non-pecuniary damages.
- Vilnius Regional Administrative Court allowed in part the second applicant’s claim, finding that for seventy‑nine days the applicant had had 2.9 sq. m of personal space, in breach of the domestic requirement of 3.1 sq. m applicable to dormitory‑type rooms, and for eighteen days, when the applicant had been kept under stricter disciplinary regime, he had had 3.34 sq. m of personal space, in breach of the domestic requirement of 3.6 sq. m applicable to such cells. 
- The second applicant was awarded EUR 130 in non-pecuniary damages by the Supreme Administrative Court on 15 May 2015.

title: CASE OF KALTAK v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Sanski Most.
- The Republika Srpska was ordered to pay the applicant 42,767 convertible marks on account of pecuniary damage together with default interest calculated from 23 May 2005 until final payment.
- On 1 February 2010, the applicant submitted a request for the issuance of the writ of execution in his case, which request he amended on 30 August 2010.
- On 18 October 2010, the applicant submitted a request for the acceleration of the proceedings before the Banja Luka Court of First Instance.
- On 15 November 2010, the Banja Luka Court of First Instance issued the writ of execution.
- On 18 March 2011, the Banja Luka Court of First Instance rejected the objections against its decision of 15 November 2010, as well as the applicant’s request for the payment of the costs of the enforcement proceedings.
- On 15 December 2011, the Banja Luka Court of Second Instance quashed the decision of the Banja Luka Court of First Instance of 18 March 2011 and remitted the case for reconsideration.
- On 12 April 2012, the Banja Luka Court of First Instance partially granted the objection of the Republika Srpska against the writ of execution.
- On 21 January 2013, the Banja Luka Court of Second Instance rejected the applicant’s appeal and upheld the decision of 12 April 2012.
- On 7 October 2014, the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina ruled in favor of the applicant that the enforcement proceedings before the Banja Luka Court of First Instance had not been finalized within a reasonable time and ordered the Banja Luka Court of First Instance to urgently expedite the enforcement proceedings in the applicant’s case.
- On 8 November 2016, the final decision in question was enforced in cash, regarding the principal amount and the statutory default interests.
- On 5 July 2017, the costs of the enforcement proceedings and related statutory default interests were also fully paid to the applicant.

title: CASE OF JOSIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1963 and lives in Tuzla.
- A judgment was made on 18 June 2009 ordering company R. to reinstate the applicant in his previous employment, pay him a total amount of 16,314 BAM, legal costs of 2,641 BAM, and cover pension-related contributions from 1 January 2003 to 17 January 2007.
- A writ of execution was issued on 17 October 2011.
- The Municipal Court amended its decision of 17 October 2011 by changing the object of enforcement on 23 February 2012.
- The Municipal Court requested that the respondent indicate why it had not reinstated the applicant on 16 January 2012 and fined the respondent on 23 January 2012.
- The enforcement proceedings were joined with an earlier enforcement procedure against the respondent by the Municipal Court on 1 February 2013.
- The Constitutional Court found a violation of the applicant’s right to enforcement within a reasonable time on 25 June 2014 and ordered the Municipal Court to urgently finalise the enforcement proceedings.
- The Municipal Court ordered the sale of the respondent’s property on 18 March 2015.
- The Mostar Cantonal Court quashed the decision of the Municipal Court of 27 April 2015 and remitted the case for reconsideration on 29 March 2016.
- As of 28 July 2017, the enforcement proceedings in the applicant’s case were still pending.

title: CASE OF MARTINOVIĆ v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1955 and lives in Assemini (Italy).
- The applicant was granted the reimbursement of costs which she had incurred as a witness by a decision of 4 December 2006 of the Cantonal Prosecutor of the Hercegovina-Neretva Canton.
- The Mostar Municipal Court rejected the applicant's request for enforcement of the decision on 29 February 2008.
- The Mostar Cantonal Court quashed this decision and remitted the case for reconsideration on 18 September 2008.
- The Municipal Court issued a writ of execution on 19 November 2008.
- The Municipal Court upheld the objection lodged against this decision on 19 June 2009.
- The Cantonal Court quashed this decision and again remitted the case to the Municipal Court on 1 April 2010.
- The Municipal Court partly accepted the objection against the writ of execution specifically as regards the interest on the main debt calculated from 4 January 2007, and the interest on the total costs of the enforcement proceedings on 18 February 2011.
- The Cantonal Court upheld this decision on 2 December 2011.
- The Supreme Court of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina dismissed the applicant's request for revision as inadmissible on 19 September 2013.
- The Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina partially accepted the applicant's appeal and ordered measures to be taken to enforce the decision within a reasonable time on 23 December 2013.
- The final decision was enforced and the applicant was paid in cash on 18 December 2014.
- The Municipal Court ordered P.M. to pay the applicant the costs of civil proceedings in the amount of BAM 1,959 by a judgment of 3 April 2009.
- The applicant submitted a request for enforcement of this judgment on 31 October 2010.
- The applicant submitted requests for the acceleration of the enforcement proceedings on 14 September 2011, 4 November 2011, and 5 October 2012.
- The Municipal Court issued a writ of execution on 5 December 2012.
- The Municipal Court dismissed the objection lodged against its decision of 5 December 2012 on 13 June 2013, and P.M. subsequently appealed this decision to the Cantonal Court.
- The Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina found a violation of the applicant's right to a trial within a reasonable time on 17 September 201

title: CASE OF VARHAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Adıyaman.
- On 21 March 2007, the applicant participated in the Newroz celebrations held in Malatya.
- An indictment was filed against the applicant and twenty other people for disseminating propaganda in favor of the PKK.
- The Malatya Assize Court convicted all accused, including the applicant, based on evidence and sentenced him to ten months' imprisonment on 6 March 2008.
- On 31 May 2011, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of 6 March 2008.
- The applicant started serving his prison sentence on 21 December 2011.
- The Malatya Assize Court ordered the applicant's release from prison on 12 July 2012, in accordance with Law no. 6352.
- On 12 December 2012, the Malatya Assize Court decided to suspend the execution of the applicant's prison sentence for three years, on the condition that he did not commit a terrorism-related offense during that period.

title: CASE OF YILDIRIM v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant attended a concert performed by a band called “Grup Yorum” in the Hozat district of Tunceli on 5 April 2007.
- The applicant was charged with disseminating propaganda in favour of the DHKP/C, an illegal armed organisation, under section 7 (2) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act.
- The public prosecutor noted that the applicant had chanted slogans supporting the DHKP/C during the concert.
- The applicant stated that he had attended the concert and chanted different slogans, and that he had been on the concert’s organising committee.
- The applicant was convicted and sentenced to ten months’ imprisonment, and his appeal was unsuccessful. He served his prison sentence between 6 October 2011 and 1 August 2012.

title: CASE OF KINIK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was the head of the district branch of the Democratic People’s Party (DEHAP) in the Ergani district of Diyarbakır.
- The Ergani district branch of DEHAP organised a gathering in front of the district branch office in order to read out a press statement.
- The applicant and twenty-five others were charged with breach of the Marches and Demonstrations Act (Law no. 2911).
- They were accused of participating in the gathering and carrying banners with slogans such as “The solution is in İmralı”, “Solitary confinement is a crime against humanity”, “Not EU, not US, Öcalan has the solution” , “The youth is Öcalan’s fedai”, and “Freedom to Öcalan”, as well as posters of Abdullah Öcalan.
- They were also accused of chanting slogans such as “To the sun, to freedom”, “Long live the brotherhood of peoples”, “May those hands which aim to damage peace be broken”, “A tooth for a tooth, blood for blood, we are with you” and “AKP, be careful, do not abuse our patience”.
- The Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicant of disseminating propaganda in favour of a terrorist organisation under section 7 (2) of Law no. 3713, and sentenced him to ten months’ imprisonment but decided to suspend the pronouncement of the judgment for a period of five years.

title: CASE OF YÜKSEL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant attended Newroz celebrations in Buca, İzmir on 21 March 2007.
- She addressed the crowd in Kurdish and invited them to observe a minute’s silence in memory of “Newroz martyrs” and martyrs for freedom and democracy.
- On 10 April 2007, the İzmir Assize Court issued a warrant for her arrest and a search of her residence.
- She was arrested on 11 April 2007 at her house.
- On 13 August 2007, the first‑instance court ordered her release.
- On 10 September 2008, she was convicted under section 7(2) of Law no. 3713 and sentenced to one year’s imprisonment.
- She served her prison sentence between 13 January and 22 June 2012.
- On 22 June 2012, the Diyarbakır Assize Court ordered her conditional release.

title: CASE OF AYAYDIN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant participated in a march and the reading out of a press statement held by the DTP in Kızıltepe on 30 March 2006.
- The protesters chanted slogans during the march.
- The public prosecutor filed an indictment charging the applicant with disseminating propaganda in favour of the PKK under section 7(2) of Law no. 3713.
- An expert observed that the applicant had acted together with the crowd, but it could not be established whether he had chanted a specific slogan.
- The applicant was convicted and sentenced to ten months’ imprisonment, which was upheld by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE OF POLAT AND TALİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were members of a research cooperative called the East Scientific Research Cooperative.
- The cooperative organised an exhibition entitled “Witnesses of War Talk” which displayed photographs of deceased members of the PKK, deceased members of the security forces, persons who had lost their lives in prison, victims of enforced disappearances and victims of assassinations by unknown assailants in south-east Turkey.
- The exhibition also included statements from family members of deceased and disappeared individuals.
- A criminal investigation was launched against the applicants and five others for disseminating propaganda in favor of the PKK.
- The applicants denied the accusation and maintained that the exhibition was organized for purely sociological reasons.
- Both applicants were convicted of disseminating propaganda in favour of an illegal organization.
- The second applicant's case was reviewed following Article 231 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and the judgment was suspended under certain conditions.
- The first applicant served their sentence, and the trial court's judgment became final in their case.

title: CASE OF SHENOYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1971 and is serving a life sentence in a correctional colony in Russia.
- The applicant was arrested on charges of illegal possession of firearms, two armed robberies of local post offices, murder of three Russian Post Service cash messengers and attempted murder of the fourth one on 27 March 2003.
- The case was sent to the Supreme Court of the Buryatia Republic (“the Regional Court”) for trial on 14 October 2003.
- Twice, on 20 April 2004 and 22 May 2007, the applicant was convicted as charged, but both convictions were set aside by the Supreme Court of Russia.
- During the third round of jury trial, the Regional Court closed proceedings to the public on 12 September 2008 in response to a request by a representative of the Russian Post. The Presiding judge referred to the case-file documents containing information about security measures and equipment in post offices.
- The Regional Court found that the information was a trade secret protected by the Commercial Secrets Act (Federal Law no. 98-FZ of 29 July 2004) and that its disclosure could have harmed public interests. Every hearing after 12 September 2008 was held in camera.
- On 14 December 2008, the jury convicted the applicant as charged, and he was sentenced to life imprisonment in the last days of December. On 4 June 2009, the Supreme Court quashed the conviction on one count and upheld the remainder of the verdict and sentence.

title: CASE OF KAREMANI v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and is currently serving a prison sentence
- On 17 April 1999, the District Court convicted the applicant and his co-accused of criminal offenses and sentenced him to death in absentia
- The Court of Appeal upheld the District Court's decision on 1 June 1999
- The Supreme Court sentenced the applicant to life imprisonment in May 2001
- The applicant was extradited to Albania from Italy on 1 December 2006 and was officially informed of his conviction in absentia the same day
- The District Court dismissed the applicant's application for leave to appeal out of time on 25 January 2007
- The Court of Appeal and Supreme Court both upheld this decision on 8 June 2007 and 2 July 2010, respectively
- The applicant lodged a constitutional appeal against the Supreme Court's decision in June 2011, which was rejected by the Constitutional Court in September 2011
- The applicant also lodged a constitutional appeal in 2007 against the District Court, Court of Appeal, and Supreme Court's decisions, which was dismissed as being out of time on 21 September 2007.

title: CASE OF CAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Adıyaman.
- She sat an examination on 17 October 1999 to become a public servant and was appointed to the post of security officer in the Kilis branch of TEDAŞ on 27 June 2000. 
- On 4 September 2000, she was told that she could not be appointed to the post due to not being a man and not completing military service. 
- The applicant lodged an action against TEDAŞ with the Ankara Administrative Court to annul the decision. 
- The general directorate of TEDAŞ argued that the requirement of having completed military service applied only to male candidates.
- The Ankara Administrative Court annulled the decision of the Kilis branch of TEDAŞ, but TEDAŞ lodged an appeal against the judgment. 
- The high court declared that the requirement for military service meant that the post was reserved for male candidates and dismissed the applicant's case. 
- The applicant was dismissed from her post on 19 March 2004, and the Supreme Administrative Court dismissed her appeal on 7 May 2007.

title: CASE OF MUTU AND PECHSTEIN v. SWITZERLAND
facts:
A. Facts relating to application no. 40575/10:

- The applicant was a Belarusian professional cyclist who tested positive for a banned substance at the 2008 Tour de France.
- The International Cycling Union (UCI), the governing body of the sport, referred the case to the Anti-Doping Commission (ADC) of the International Olympic Committee (IOC).
- The ADC issued a two-year suspension to the applicant, although it was later reduced to 18 months.
- The applicant challenged the decision before the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), arguing that the testing procedures were flawed and that he was denied a fair hearing. 
- The CAS upheld the suspension, finding that the applicant had not established any irregularities that could invalidate the test results or the disciplinary proceedings.

B. Facts relating to application no. 67474/10:

- The applicant was a German athlete who competed in athletics.
- He was provisionally suspended by the German Athletics Federation (DLV) in 2009 after a positive test for a banned substance.
- The DLV referred the case to the disciplinary committee of the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF), which handed down a two-year suspension to the applicant.
- The applicant appealed to the CAS, arguing that the substance was unintentionally ingested and that the sanction was disproportionate.
- The CAS reduced the sanction to one year, taking into account the athlete's fault and his cooperation with the anti-doping authorities.

C. The operation of international sports arbitration:

- The International Council of Arbitration for Sport (ICAS) is the governing body of the CAS, responsible for the appointment and supervision of arbitrators.
- The ICAS has specific rules on the appointment of its members, which were in force at the time of the applications.
- The ICAS also has rules on the designation of CAS arbitrators, which determine the eligibility and selection criteria for their appointment.
- These rules have been subsequently amended, reflecting the evolution of the CAS and its jurisprudence.

title: CASE OF A.B.V. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant lived in an extramarital relationship with A.D. from 2008 to autumn 2009
- A.D. became pregnant in autumn 2009 and they separated shortly after but maintained contact
- On July 6, 2010, A.D. gave birth to a baby girl, P, and the applicant had regular contact with the child
- In January 2011, A.D. began avoiding communication with the applicant and preventing him from visiting the child
- On June 6, 2011, the applicant sought to establish paternity of the child and determine contact with the child
- The court discontinued the examination of the claim for contact rights, but established the applicant's paternity of P
- The judgment establishing the applicant's paternity was quashed on appeal on December 20, 2012
- The case was remitted for fresh examination on appeal on October 4, 2013
- The applicant challenged the registration of A.K. as the child's father and sought his own paternity to be established and contact rights determined on November 11, 2013
- The District Court granted the applicant's claims on January 24, 2014, which were upheld on appeal on July 28, 2014
- The applicant applied for enforcement proceedings in December 2014, but the bailiff declined due to the judgment not obligating A.D. to carry out certain actions
- The District Court dismissed the applicant's claim challenging the lawfulness of the decision on February 18, 2015
- The City Court quashed the decision on July 6, 2015, and enforcement proceedings were instituted on August 10, 2015
- The bailiff confronted A.D. and involved a psychologist in the proceedings, but A.D. continued to avoid compliance
- The enforcement proceedings were suspended pending another case initiated by A.D. on March 14, 2016
- The decision to suspend the enforcement proceedings was found unlawful on appeal on September 30, 2016
- A fine was imposed on A.D. for non-compliance on November 3, 2016, and her travel was temporarily restricted on December 12, 2016
- The applicant met his daughter in February 2017, but subsequent attempts to see her were prevented by A.D.
- A.D. sought to recover child maintenance from the applicant, terminate his parental rights, and restore A.K.'s parental rights on March

title: CASE OF KOŽEMIAKINA v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant is a resident of Klaipėda, born in 1969.
- The victim, V.M, was assaulted on 19 February 2012 by the applicant's son, A.K, and another teenager, V.O.
- V.M suffered bruises and swelling on his face, concussion, contusions in the chest area, a resulting inflammation of the right lung, and a compression fracture of the spine.
- V.M had tried to remove the teenagers from the building, and A.K refused to leave.
- A.K punched V.M, followed by V.O trying to hit him as well.
- V.M had tried to grab A.K by the coat and shake him but fell down the stairs after getting punched and kicked by A.K and V.O.
- During the criminal proceedings, A.K confessed to hitting V.M and pushing him down the stairs in self-defence.
- V.O was convicted of causing minor health impairment and breach of public order, while A.K was a minor and not criminally liable.
- The victim lodged a civil claim against the applicant and her son, seeking compensation for non-pecuniary damage.
- The Klaipėda District Court allowed V.M's claim in part and awarded him LTL 2,000 (approximately EUR 580) for non-pecuniary damage and LTL 1,500 (approximately EUR 435) in legal costs.
- The applicant and her son appealed against this decision, but the appeal was dismissed.
- The Klaipėda Regional Court increased the award in respect of non-pecuniary damages to LTL 8,000 (approximately EUR 2,320) and ordered the applicant and A.K to pay legal expenses.

title: CASE OF FEDCHENKO v. RUSSIA (No. 5)
facts:
- The applicant is the editor of a weekly newspaper.
- Prosecuting authorities found fifteen breaches of fire safety rules at the Tymoshkovykh shopping centre in June 2010.
- The prosecutor requested the owner to rectify the breaches, which was allowed by the court.
- Fifty violations of fire safety regulations were found in September 2011.
- The prosecutor sought new court proceedings against the shopping centre and asked the court to temporarily close it. The court ordered the shopping centre to close temporarily.
- The shopping centre reopened on March 30, 2012, after the prosecutor's office withdrew its complaint.
- The applicant published an article criticizing officials who took the side of the shopping centre.
- Mikhail Klimov brought a defamation suit against the applicant in April 2012.
- The Bryansk District Court allowed the claim and ordered the applicant to publish a retraction and pay damages of RUB 5,000.
- The Bryansk Regional Court and the Bryansk Regional Court refused leave to the applicant to lodge a cassation appeal.

title: CASE OF FEDCHENKO v. RUSSIA (No. 4)
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicant is the editor of a weekly newspaper, Bryanskiye Budni, since he founded it in 1999.
- On August 9, 2012, the applicant published an article in Bryanskiye Budni, in which he discussed criminal proceedings that were pending against two men called Maksim Kosenkov and Ruslan Pogulyayev on charges of obtaining land by fraud. He also referred to witness statements in criminal proceedings against Anna Stregeleva, the former head of the regional department of the Federal Agency for State Property Management, which had concerned the misappropriation of other plots of land and ended with Ms Stregeleva's conviction.
- The article had a photograph next to it of Mr Simonenko and Mr Denin, the governor of Bryansk Region, in a room with other people.
- Mr Simonenko brought an action for defamation against the applicant and sought damages of 300,000 Russian roubles (RUB).
- On September 26, 2012, the Bryanskiy District Court of the Bryansk Region dismissed the claim.
- Mr Simonenko appealed.
- On November 27, 2012, the Bryansk  Regional Court set aside the judgment, allowed the claim against the applicant, ordered him to publish a retraction within fifteen days of the judgment's entry into force, and awarded the claimant damages of RUB 5,000 (approximately 125 euros).
- On an unspecified date Mr Denin also instituted defamation proceedings against the applicant.
- On April 23, 2013, the Bryanskiy District Court granted the claim.
- The applicant appealed.
- On October 22, 2013, the Bryansk Regional Court quashed the judgment on appeal and dismissed the claim.

title: CASE OF FEDCHENKO v. RUSSIA (No. 3)
facts:
- The applicant is the editor of a newspaper
- The applicant published an article about a politician's switching parties and wealth
- The politician brought an action for defamation against the applicant
- The court ordered an expert examination of the impugned passages
- The court allowed the claim in part and found the applicant and newspaper jointly liable for damages
- The court ordered the newspaper to publish a retraction.

title: CASE OF TSAKOYEVY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are parents of Rasul Tsakoyev
- Rasul Tsakoyev was suspected of membership of an illegal armed group, "Yarmuk"
- Rasul Tsakoyev was unlawfully detained on several occasions and beaten by State agents
- A special antiterrorist operation against Yarmuk members was carried out in which Rasul Tsakoyev disappeared
- Rasul Tsakoyev was severely beaten and tortured by UBOP officers, resulting in his death

title: CASE OF KRIVOLAPOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Journalist Mr. Igor Aleksandrov was beaten to death in the local television company.
- The police arrested V. on suspicion of Mr. Aleksandrov’s murder, who had no means of subsistence and later confessed to the crime.
- B. had convinced V. to play that role in exchange for several benefits and alleged law-enforcement officials were involved in the agreement.
- The case was joined to several other criminal cases against the applicant and others.
- The applicant was accused of abuse of office, falsification of the criminal case against V., selling material evidence, perjury, B.'s murder as well as several counts of kidnapping and aggravated murder.
- The applicant was arrested, and his pre-trial detention was extended many times, and he was released in 2009 after being acquitted of several charges and having served the sentence on one of the charges.
- The case was referred to the Lugansk Regional Court of Appeal, which found the applicant guilty of abuse of office leading to grave consequences, perjury, and abuse of office concerning the illegal sale of material evidence charges.
- The applicant was released in 2012 after the only remaining charge against him became time-barred.
- A documentary "The Deadly Agreement" was broadcasted on national television, in which the applicant was named as B.'s murderer and the person who proposed the agreement.
- The applicant was detained in Lugansk SIZO with poor material conditions of detention, according to the applicant.

title: CASE OF POKUSIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of facts:

- There is a list of applicants and their application details provided in an appended table.
- The applicants were confined to a metal cage during their criminal proceedings.
- Some applicants raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF KOMPANIYETS AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table is appended which lists down the applicants and their relevant application details.
- The applicants complain about the lengthy criminal proceedings.
- They also complain about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.
- One applicant in application no. 76577/17 raises another complaint under the Convention provisions.

title: CASE OF KUKLÍK AND OTHERS v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
facts:
- The Czech rent control system was unconstitutional and violated the right of property of owners protected by Article 1 of Protocol No. 1.
- A “legal vacuum” existed between 1 January 2002 and 30 March 2006, and no legal basis existed for rent control measures either in the period between 31 March and 31 December 2006.
- The interference was considered by the Court to be unlawful in this period of time.
- The case involves multiple applicants who are owners of residential buildings or apartments subject to the rent control system.
- One of the applicants lodged a claim against a tenant seeking to be paid outstanding rent and services fees.
- The various courts made multiple decisions and appeals regarding the claim.
- The applicant brought an action for damages against the tenant for concealing information during the earlier proceedings.
- Other applicants sought damages from the State for loss of profit due to a lack of deregulating legislation for the rent control system.
- The court found the State liable for a portion of the claimed damages and ordered compensation to be paid.

title: CASE OF KRUCHKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table with details of the applicants is appended to the document.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of civil proceedings.
- The applicants also complained about the lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.
- One of the applicants (in application no. 52227/10) raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF BASMANOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
• List of applicants and application details provided in a table
• Applicants complained about excessive pre-trial detention
• Complaints about poor detention and transport conditions

title: CASE OF GORKOVLYUK AND KAGANOVSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants are a married couple from Odessa
- The first applicant was an accountant at a private food-processing company and the second applicant was a private entrepreneur supplying the company with raw materials
- A criminal case was opened against the officials of the company on suspicion of forgery of quality certificates for the company’s goods
- The police conducted a search on the company’s premises and seized a considerable volume of foodstuffs belonging to the second applicant
- The first applicant had an altercation with the police and was handcuffed and dragged out of her car, which collided with another car parked nearby
- The Prymorskyy Court quashed the prosecutor’s decision as unlawful
- The first applicant complained about ill-treatment by the police and asked the court to declare the officers’ actions unlawful
- The prosecutor’s office refused to institute criminal proceedings against the police officers for lack of the constituent elements of a criminal offence in their actions
- The first applicant challenged the ruling before the Suvorivskyy Court, but the court dismissed her complaint as introduced out of time 
- The first applicant was accused of inflicting minor bodily injuries on the police officers and an obligation not to leave her town of residence was imposed on her as a preventive measure pending her trial
- The first applicant was found guilty by the Suvorivskyy Court, but the judgment was later quashed and the first applicant was acquitted
- The first applicant was sued by the owner of the car she collided with, and the case went through multiple rounds of proceedings before the first applicant was ordered to pay an amount in damages 
- The second applicant brought a commercial claim against a private company for the return of his property, and the court ordered the company to pay him an amount in compensation
