- The bailiff’s service failed to enforce the court’s ruling, and the applicants filed a claim against the service seeking compensation.

title: CASE OF KULMINSKIY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- List of applicants and relevant details in a table
- Applicants were confined in a metal cage during criminal proceedings
- Some applicants raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention

title: CASE OF VNUCHKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant complained of inadequate conditions of detention during transportation. 
- Applicant complained of poor conditions of detention in a remand facility. 
- Applicant raised other complaints under the provisions of the Convention. 
- Relevant details of the application are provided in the attached table.

title: CASE OF MAROUGGAS v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and was serving sixteen years sentence for attempted murder, being a member of an organized criminal group, and other offenses when he submitted his application to the court.
- The applicant was detained in Diavata Prison in Thessaloniki, initially in isolation for fifteen days and subsequently moved to overcrowded cells.
- The cells in which the applicant was detained were overcrowded and very poorly maintained, measuring only 24 sq. m for ten prisoners, leaving the living space for each prisoner less than 3 sq. m.
- Overcrowding of cells exposed the applicant to infectious diseases and suffering from passive smoking.
- The applicant's access to natural light and ventilation, as well as sanitary facilities, and supplies, were inadequate.
- There was no sufficient supply of heating and hot water for all prisoners. In addition, there was a lack of access to cultural, recreational, and sports activities.
- The applicant also complained about the quality and quantity of food.
- The Government did not submit a description of the conditions of the applicant’s detention.

title: CASE OF VOJNOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant lived in a decayed building in Zagreb that attracted the interest of real-estate investors.
- A bullet was shot into the applicant's flat in December 2005.
- Criminal complaints were lodged against an unknown perpetrator in relation to charges of endangering life and property through dangerous acts or means.
- Fires broke out on December 22, 2010, and January 4, 2011, involving the applicant's building and neighbouring apartments.
- An investigation was carried out, and the police identified suspects, but no arrests were made.

title: CASE OF KOBAŠ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1977 and lives in Županja.
- On 5 July 2011, the applicant was charged with causing a road accident under Article 272 of the Criminal Code before the Zagreb Municipal Criminal Court.
- The applicant was tried in summary proceedings and convicted as charged on May 4, 2012.
- The conviction resulted in a suspended sentence of four months’ imprisonment with two years’ probation.
- On May 23, 2012, the applicant appealed against his conviction and requested to appear at the session of the appeal panel.
- On January 15, 2013, the Zagreb County Court dismissed the appeal without holding a hearing, and without informing the applicant or his lawyer.
- The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court, alleging that he had not been allowed to appear at the session of the appeal panel.
- The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant’s constitutional complaint on September 18, 2013, as manifestly ill-founded.

title: CASE OF BATKIVSKA TURBOTA FOUNDATION v. UKRAINE
facts:
- In 1936, the USSR government entrusted the management of recreational facilities for workers to the Union-wide Council of Trade Unions
- The Ministry of Healthcare of the Ukrainian SSR was obliged to transfer functioning sanatoria and recreational resorts to the Republican Council for free use in 1960
- In 1990, the Ukrainian trade unions declared their independence from the State and commercial bodies of the USSR, and founded the Federation of Independent Trade Unions of Ukraine
- In 1991, the assets and financial resources of civic organizations, including trade unions, located on the territory of Ukraine were declared State property of Ukraine
- The Federation founded UPO, a joint-stock company, and transferred assets including the Sanatorium to it
- The State Property Fund of Ukraine brought a claim against UPO, arguing that the assets belonged to the Union-wide Council
- In 1997, the Higher Arbitration Court of Ukraine rejected the claim, stating that the assets had been transferred lawfully to trade unions and their title had not been challenged
- In 2011, a prosecutor claimed the disputed property was State property, leading to a court case
- In 2014, the Kyiv Commercial Court of Appeal found there were no legal grounds to conclude the disputed premises belonged to the State and allowed the applicant's claim
- The Higher Commercial Court of Ukraine upheld the prosecutor's claim in the same case
- The Supreme Court rejected the applicant's request for a review, stating the Sanatorium had belonged to the State and could only be alienated with the State's consent.

title: CASE OF SERGUNIN AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants were owners of plots of land
- The municipal authorities claimed the plots of land and annulled the applicants' title to the real property in question
- In the first case, the local council transferred the title to a plot of land to G., who sold it to M., who sold it to N., who sold it to the applicant
- On 13 March 2013, the Privolzhskiy District Court of Kazan found Gib. guilty of having committed fraud in respect of the transfer of the plot of land to G.
- On 5 July 2013, a prosecutor brought an action seeking invalidation of the applicant's title to the plot of land and the return of the plot of land to the municipality
- In the second case, the applicant bought a plot of land and a share in another plot of land in Sloboda Solomintsy, Kirov, from S. and T. respectively
- On 14 May 2014, the Novovyatskiy District Court of Kirov delivered two judgments, allowing the prosecutor's claims in full
- The court recognised the town's title to the plots of land and ordered their transfer to the town administration
- In the third case, the applicant bought six plots of land from different sellers in Sloboda Lyangasy, Kirov
- On 9 and 10 June 2014, the Novovyatskiy District Court of Kirov delivered six judgments, granting the prosecutor's claims in full
- The court recognised the city's title to the plots of land and ordered their transfer to the council.

title: CASE OF FAKHRUTDINOVA v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Kazan.
- In 1969, an artificial lake was created by damming the Shumelka river in Tveretinovka, Republic of Tatarstan.
- The original owner of the plot of land containing the lake was a State fur farm.
- In 2003, the fur farm sold the land and the lake to a private limited liability company through a public sale by tender.
- The private company sold the land and the lake to the applicant in 2008 through a public sale by tender.
- In 2011, following bankruptcy proceedings, the private company was de-registered as a legal entity.
- In 2012, the regional agency for management of State property sought to reclaim the plot of land and the lake through a civil action against the applicant.
- On 5 May 2012, the Pestrechinskiy District Court granted the agency's claims, stating that the lake could not be owned by a private entity and should be returned to the State.
- On 5 July 2012, the Supreme Court of the Republic of Tatarstan quashed the judgment of 5 May 2012 on appeal and rejected the claims in full, stating the plot of land with the lake could be owned by a private party and that the agency's claim should be dismissed for its failure to bring the action within the three-year time-limit.
- On 14 September 2012, the Supreme Court referred the matter for a review of points of law.
- On 10 October 2012, the Presidium of the Supreme Court quashed the appeal judgment of 5 July 2012 and upheld the judgment of 5 May 2008, by way of a points-of-law review, rejecting the applicant's request to apply the statute of limitations.
- On 22 February 2013, the plot of land was registered as federal property in the State land register.
- On an unspecified date, the applicant challenged the imposition of a fine on her in 2011 as the owner of the plot of land.
- On 19 April 2013, the Vakhitovskiy District Court of Kazan dismissed the applicant's claims.

title: CASE OF ARISTOV AND GROMOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant (Mr Aristov) was born in 1986 and lives in Moscow. The second applicant (Mr Gromov) was born in 1983 and lives in Moscow Region.
- A public demonstration called the “March of Millions” was held on 6 May 2012 in central Moscow to protest against the allegedly rigged presidential elections. The event had been approved by the city authorities in the form of a march followed by a meeting at Bolotnaya Square which was supposed to end at 7.30 p.m.
- The march was peaceful and held without any disruptions initially, but when the marchers arrived at Bolotnaya Square it became apparent that barriers installed by the police had narrowed the entrance to the meeting venue, allegedly restricting the space allocated for the meeting.
- There were numerous clashes between the police and protesters, and at 5.30 p.m. the police ordered that the meeting finish early and began to disperse the participants. It took them about two hours to clear the protestors from the square.
- The applicants (Mr Aristov and Mr Gromov) took part in the demonstration and were arrested and charged with administrative offenses. 
- Both applicants were accused of having disobeyed a lawful order of the police, an offense under Article 19.3 § 1 of the Code of Administrative Offenses.
- The first applicant stated that he did not cause disorder but was detained by the police. The government stated that he was arrested for participating in breaking the police cordon and disregarding police orders. 
- The second applicant stated that he was arrested by riot squad officers rather than the two police officers who gave written statements. The court found him guilty on the basis of the police officers’ statements and reports.

title: CASE OF AYDEMİR AND KARAVİL v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1957 and 1981 and live in Diyarbakir and Adana respectively. 
- The applicants and five other persons were charged with praising an offence and an offender under Article 215 of the Criminal Code. 
- The applicants had signed a petition in September 2005 which had been drafted in order to be sent to several institutions. 
- The Adana Magistrate’s Court decided that it lacked jurisdiction in the case due to the possibility of application of section 7(2) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (Law no. 3713) proscribing disseminating propaganda in favour of a terrorist organisation. 
- The Adana Assize Court convicted the applicants of disseminating propaganda in favour of a terrorist organisation under section 7(2) of Law No. 3713 and sentenced them each to two years’ imprisonment. 
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of 24 March 2008. 
- The Adana Assize Court decided to suspend the execution of the applicants’ prison sentence in accordance with Law no. 6352. The suspension was for a period of three years, on condition that they did not commit an offence through the press, media, or other methods of expressing ideas and opinions.

title: CASE OF GÜL v. TURKEY
facts:
Facts of the Case:

- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Adana.
- At the time of the events giving rise to the application, the applicant was a member of the Socialist Democracy Party (Sosyalist Demokrasi Partisi).
- On 21 March 2007, the applicant made a speech on behalf of his political party during Newroz celebrations in Adana.
- In his speech, the applicant stated that the military forces should comply with the ceasefire declared by the PKK and that a general amnesty should be declared.
- The applicant contended that people were being detained for referring to Abdullah Öcalan, the leader of the PKK, as “Sayın (Esteemed) Öcalan” whereas the Prime Minister also referred to him as “Sayın Öcalan”.
- The applicant further stated that Abdullah Öcalan should not be kept in isolation in prison and that independent doctors should visit him.
- The police report of 21 March 2007 stated that songs with Kurdish lyrics were played, and some demonstrators waved PKK flags after the applicant's speech.
- On 18 April 2007, the Adana public prosecutor charged the applicant with membership of the PKK and disseminating propaganda in favor of the PKK for his speech and participation in the demonstration of 21 March 2007.
- On 24 March 2008, the Adana Assize Court convicted the applicant of disseminating propaganda in favor of the PKK under section 7(2) of the Prevention of Terrorism Act and sentenced him to ten months’ imprisonment.
- On 19 July 2011, the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of 24 March 2008.
- On 11 January 2012, the applicant started serving his prison sentence; and on 29 May 2012, he was granted early conditional release starting from 3 June 2012.

title: CASE OF GÖKTAŞ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are a family consisting of a husband, wife, and their child.
- The second applicant was admitted to a State Hospital in Niğde on 9th August 2001 and gave birth to the third applicant, who had irreversible injuries caused by medical staff during labor.
- The Forensic Medicine Institute report found two members of the medical staff who tended during labor equally and solely at fault for the third applicant’s injuries.
- On 1st December 2004, the first and second applicants submitted a claim to the Ministry of Health.
- The applicants claimed TRY 30,000 in respect of pecuniary damage and TRY 100,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- The expert assessed the amount of pecuniary damage suffered by the applicants to have been TRY 194,916.
- The court awarded the applicants TRY 30,000 plus interest in respect of pecuniary damage and a total of TRY 50,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage and interest.
- The applicants’ appeals were dismissed by the Supreme Administrative Court on 16 June 2009 and 28 December 2010.
- The Ministry of Health paid the applicants a total of TRY 144,144, which included the principal judgment award and interest accrued on it.

title: CASE OF ISENI v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1954 and lives in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
- In 1990, the local authorities expropriated a flat in Belgrade that belonged to the applicant. The flat size was 31.80 square metres.
- On 16 December 2010, the Constitutional Court of Serbia gave an order to the local authorities to assign a suitable replacement flat to the applicant or pay compensation, not less than the market value of the flat, in accordance with the Expropriation Act 1995. 
- This decision achieved legal effect on 23 February 2011. 
- Even though certain actions had been taken, such as the tax authorities assessing the market value of the flat at 209,015 Serbian dinars (RSD) per square metre on 3 February 2017, and the applicant approving that evaluation on 1 June 2017, the conclusions of the Constitutional Court's judgment have not been performed yet.

title: CASE OF LEKIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- The applicants were born in 1949 and 1950 and lived in Podgorica.
- The applicants' mother instituted civil proceedings against Podgorička banka Societe Generale Group ad Podgorica seeking the payment of her savings.
- The applicants continued the proceedings after their mother passed away.
- The First Instance Court ruled partly in favour of the applicants.
- The High Court reversed the first-instance judgment and dismissed the applicants' claims.
- The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision.
- The applicants lodged a constitutional appeal.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the applicants' appeal.

title: CASE OF GOLUBYATNIKOV AND ZHUCHKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- Two applicants were born in 1979 and 1978 and lived in Tikhoretsk, Krasnodar region.
- On 3 January 2005, a young woman (S.) died from serious head injuries near a block of flats in Tikhoretsk.
- Criminal investigation was conducted by investigators and police officers from the Tikhoretsk Police Department.
- B. was arrested on 20 January 2005 and gave a statement incriminating the first applicant.
- On 21 January 2005, the first applicant was arrested and allegedly subjected to ill-treatment, including physical violence and lack of access to air.
- On 23 January 2005, the Tikhoretsk Town Court ordered the first applicant's detention on remand and charged him with causing grievous bodily harm to S. leading to her death.
- On 25 March 2005, the applicant's mother lodged a complaint with the inter-district prosecutor’s office, submitting that the applicant had been subjected to violence by police officers.
- On 16 May 2005, the applicant retracted his confession statements, asserting that they had been made under coercion exerted by police officers.
- On 2 June 2005, an investigator from the regional prosecutor’s office refused to institute criminal proceedings against O. for lack of evidence of a criminal event in his actions.

title: CASE OF CORALLO v. THE NETHERLANDS
facts:
- The applicant was suspected of tax evasion, money laundering, embezzlement, and membership of a transnational criminal organization.
- A warrant for the applicant's arrest was issued on November 21, 2016.
- On December 13, 2016, the Italian authorities requested the applicant's provisional arrest via a "Red Notice" issued through Interpol.
- The applicant was arrested on December 13, 2016, in Sint Maarten and detained at Philipsburg Police Station.
- A doctor visited the applicant multiple times and found that he was in good health, with no medical impediments to his detention.
- On December 19, 2016, the applicant requested the suspension of his detention under Article 5 § 1(f) of the Convention, but the Procurator General opposed it.
- On January 4, 2017, the Joint Court rejected the applicant’s request for the suspension of his detention.
- On January 12, 2017, a formal request for the applicant's extradition was received by the Minister Plenipotentiary of Sint Maarten.
- On February 7, 2017, the applicant filed a fresh application with the Joint Court, requesting the termination or suspension of his detention.
- On March 21, 2017, the applicant lodged a new petition with the Joint Court, requesting either termination or suspension of his detention, or a transfer to the sickbay at Point Blanche Prison in Sint Maarten.
- On June 20, 2017, the Joint Court declared the applicant’s extradition permissible.
- The applicant withdrew his appeal in cassation on July 21, 2017.
- The Governor of Sint Maarten approved the applicant’s extradition on August 4, 2017.
- The applicant was extradited to Italy on August 16, 2017.

title: CASE OF KNEŽEVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
Main Descriptions of the Facts:

- The applicants complained of the excessive length of enforcement proceedings under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
- The first, second, third, and fourth applicants lodged separate civil complaints against the same socially owned-company, requesting the payment of salary related damages.
- The fifth applicant lodged her civil complaint against the company, requesting the payment of allowance.
- The Čačak Municipal Court ruled in favour of the applicants.
- The judgments subsequently became final, and enforcement requests were lodged.
- The Čačak Municipal Court accepted the enforcement requests.
- The Čačak District Court upheld the judgments on appeal.
- Applicants petitioned the Constitutional Court and complained about the length of proceedings and the ultimate non-enforcement.
- The Constitutional Court awarded compensation for non-pecuniary damage suffered due to the length of the enforcement proceedings.
- The amount of compensation awarded by the courts was challenged, but the appeals were rejected.
- The Constitutional Court found a violation of the applicants' right to the peaceful enjoyment of possessions and awarded them pecuniary damages.

title: CASE OF GYRLYAN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant sold a plot of land and cottage in Moscow for 4,600,000 Russian roubles.
- He exchanged RUB 3,605,000 for 100,000 United States dollars (USD).
- He travelled to Odessa with the entire USD 100,000 in his handbag.
- He was accused of smuggling foreign currency, but the investigator refused to initiate criminal proceedings.
- The applicant was charged for failing to make a written declaration of the USD 100,000 he was carrying on him.
- The court issued a confiscation order for USD 90,000.
- The applicant appealed, arguing the punishment was not fair and proportionate.
- The appeal was dismissed in a summary fashion.
- An appeal on points of law was also dismissed.

title: CASE OF S.V. v. ITALY
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Ostia Lido as a male, with the forename L
- The applicant identified as a female named S and underwent treatment with feminizing hormones in 1999.
- In 2000, the applicant sought authorization for gender reassignment surgery under section 3 of Law no. 164 of 1982.
- In 2001, the District Court authorized the applicant to undergo surgery to match her female gender identity.
- While awaiting surgery, the applicant applied to change her forename under Article 89 of Presidential Decree no. 396 of 2000 but was refused.
- The applicant underwent mammoplasty in 2001 and gender reassignment surgery in 2003, after which she applied for legal recognition of her gender reassignment.
- In 2003, the Rome District Court granted the applicant's request and ordered the authorities to alter her gender from male to female and change forename L to S.
- The Regional Administrative Court dismissed the applicant's appeal against the prefect's decision to refuse to change her forename in 2008 as the amendment of civil-status records had to be ordered by the court ruling on gender reassignment.

title: CASE OF OSMANYAN AND AMIRAGHYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- Applicants are a family of five living in Teghout village
- They jointly owned a plot of arable land measuring 0.383 ha
- Copper-molybdenum deposit discovered near Teghout village in the 1970s
- A private company granted a mining license for the exploitation of the deposit for 25 years
- Government approves expropriation zones of territories, including the applicants' plot of land, for State needs in 2007
- Oliver Group LLC delivers an evaluation report of the applicants' plot of land in 2008
- Teghout CJSC offers to buy the land for AMD 216,200 which the applicants reject
- Teghout CJSC lodges a claim with the Regional Court to oblige the applicants to sign the agreement for taking their property for State needs
- The applicants claim the market value of their land was underestimated and request a forensic expert examination to determine the real market value
- Regional Court grants Teghout CJSC's claim in 2008, but the judgment is quashed in appeal in 2009
- Regional Court grants Teghout CJSC's claim again in 2009, but the judgment is quashed in appeal in 2010 with a new forensic expert examination ordered
- The Regional Court orders two forensic expert examinations in 2010, with the second expert report confirming the previous reports' results
- The Regional Court grants the applicants AMD 264,500 compensation in 2011 based on the evaluations and expert reports
- The applicants lodge an appeal on points of law, which is declared inadmissible in 2011 by the Court of Cassation.

title: CASE GIURCANU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The facts of the case are similar to a previous case.
- All applicants were ill-treated and injured on the night of 21/22 December 1989.
- The military prosecutor opened investigations into the illegal detention, ill-treatment and injury suffered by the applicants and others.
- The investigation resulted in the conviction of senior military and public officials for several offences, including illegal deprivation of liberty, illegal arrest and abusive investigation.
- The military prosecutor's office decided not to open a separate investigation into improper conduct and communicated this to one of the applicants in 2008.
- The applicants reiterated their complaints about illegal deprivation of liberty and assault and battery during the main criminal investigation.
- The main criminal investigation was closed in 2015 on the grounds of res judicata and amnesty law, but later annulled and reopened.
- A criminal investigation in rem was ordered for the offence of crimes against humanity.
- The main criminal investigation is still ongoing.

title: CASE OF TAMAŠAUSKAS AND RADZEVIČIUS v. LITHUANIA
facts:
Main Descriptions of the Facts:

- Two applicants, Tamašauskas and Radzevičius, are detained in Vilnius.
- Tamašauskas was detained in Šiauliai Remand Prison from 28 September 2012 until 4 September 2014, and lodged a civil claim for being held in overcrowded and unsanitary cells, claiming EUR 48,493 in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- Šiauliai Regional Administrative Court allowed in part Tamašauskas’ claim and found that his right to adequate personal space may have been breached, but dismissed his allegations of unsanitary conditions.
- Tamašauskas was awarded EUR 3,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage, and he appealed against the decision, but the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the decision in its entirety.
- Radzevičius was detained in Alytus Correctional Facility from 22 November 2012 until 17 September 2014, and lodged a civil claim for being held in overcrowded and unsanitary dormitory rooms, claiming EUR 16,611 in respect of non-pecuniary damage.
- Kaunas Regional Administrative Court allowed in part Radzevičius’ claim and found a violation in the reduction of his personal space, insufficient natural light, and related ailments, but dismissed his claim for non-pecuniary damages.
- Radzevičius appealed against the decision, but the Supreme Administrative Court upheld the decision in its entirety.

title: CASE OF MATEESCU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1943 and lives in Bucharest.
- The case refers to the same context and domestic criminal proceedings as another case.
- The applicant’s son was killed by gunfire in Bucharest during the events which led to the fall of the communist regime on the night of 21/22 December 1989.
- The military prosecutor's office opened several investigations in the 1990s relating to the anti-communism demonstrations and the use of violence against civilians in Bucharest and other cities.
- The applicant raised civil claims in the main criminal investigation and asked that the perpetrators of the offence of homicide committed against her son be identified and punished.
- Public officials, members of the ruling political party, were convicted by the Supreme Court of Justice of complicity in seriously aggravated homicide and complicity in attempted seriously aggravated homicide, committed against a large number of persons, including the applicant’s son.
- The main criminal investigation was closed on 14 October 2015, but the decision was subsequently annulled and a new criminal investigation was ordered on 1 November 2016 for the offence of crimes against humanity in respect of the same factual circumstances.
- The main criminal investigation is still ongoing as of Bănuțoiu and Ștefoglu v. Romania [Committee], nos. 64752/13 and 54607/14, § 12, 3 July 2018.

title: CASE OF CHICHEANU v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1974 and lives in Bucharest.
- In December 1989, during the events that led to the fall of the communist regime in Bucharest, the applicant suffered injuries that required 50 days of medical care.
- In 1990, the military prosecutor's office opened investigations into ill-treatment and injuries suffered by those participating in the events of December 1989.
- An investigation was opened regarding the applicant, and she gave a statement as a witness in 1994.
- The most important procedural steps were described in previous cases and decisions.
- On 14 October 2015, the military prosecutor's office closed the main investigation, finding that the complaint regarding the offense of attempted homicide committed against the applicant was statute-barred.
- This decision was annulled by a Prosecutor General’s decision of 5 April 2016, confirmed by the High Court of Cassation and Justice on 13 June 2016.
- It was noted that the investigation was incomplete, and the facts could not be established based on the evidence gathered up to that date.
- On 1 November 2016, a criminal investigation in rem was ordered for the offense of crimes against humanity in respect of the same factual circumstances.
- The investigation was ongoing as of the latest information available to the Court.

title: CASE OF ZAHIROVIĆ AND OTHERS v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
facts:
- Applicants born between 1954 and 1968, residing in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
- Employers of the applicants, manufacturing weapons and military technology, were ordered to pay them various sums in respect of unpaid work-related benefits together with default interest at the statutory rate and legal costs.
- The judgments became final but were not enforced which resulted in winding-up petitions being rejected, and the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina becoming liable for the debts of the applicants’ employers.
- The Sarajevo Municipal Court issued enforcement orders against the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, who were designated as a debtor. However, enforcement was not possible due to the budgetary funds intended for that purpose had already been spent.
- Applicants complained of the non-enforcement to the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina and a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention was found.
- The Constitutional Court ordered the government of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina to take necessary steps in order to secure the payment of its debt arising from the final judgments within a reasonable time.
- Final judgments were fully enforced in 2017, including the reimbursement of the costs sustained for the enforcement procedure.

title: CASE OF SIROKI v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and resides in Meszlen.
- The applicant worked as a civil servant until December 31, 2013.
- After his service was terminated, a part of his severance payment was taxed at a rate of 98%.
- The taxed amount was HUF 3,939,763 (equivalent to approximately EUR 13,000).

title: CASE OF DAINELIENĖ v. LITHUANIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1944 and lives in Vilnius.
- The applicant was officially notified on 17 April 2009 that she was suspected of having organised the embezzlement of property of high value.
- On 7 May 2009 the applicant was charged with the relevant offences.
- The Vilnius Regional Court held on 22 July 2011 that the legal classification of the charges against the applicant was incorrect, because the total value of the allegedly embezzled property was not high.
- The Court of Appeal quashed the decision and remitted the case to the Vilnius Regional Court.
- On 10 June 2013 the Vilnius Regional Court found the applicant guilty of the charges against her.
- She was given a fine of 12,000 Lithuanian litai (LTL) and was ordered to pay some of the damages claimed by a company, amounting to LTL 2,800.
- The Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant's appeal on 18 October 2013 and upheld the lower court’s judgment in its entirety.
- On 7 January 2014, the applicant submitted an appeal on points of law to the Supreme Court, which the court refused to examine on 17 February 2014.

title: CASE OF VISY v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
1. The applicant is a businessman associated with a major Austrian financial and industrial group and had an office in Bratislava. 
2. An investigation was carried out in Austria on suspicion of various transactions involving the applicant, including investment fraud, breach of confidence, and insider trading. 
3. The Austrian prosecution service asked their Slovakian counterparts to search the premises of the applicant and other entities belonging to the group and seize relevant documents.
4. The search took place in 2009, and business documents and electronic storage media were seized, including from the applicant’s office, and later handed over to the Austrian authorities. 
5. The Constitutional Court found that the warrant for the search and seizure did not extend to the applicant and his office and that the terms of the warrant had therefore been exceeded, violating the applicant’s rights to the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions, respect for his private life, and judicial and other legal protection. 
6. The PPS was ordered to stop violating the applicant’s rights and to ask the Austrian authorities for the return of the unlawfully seized items with a view to their restitution to the applicant.
7. The applicant received the items, but they were re-seized in 2012 by the PPS with reference to a letter rogatory from the Vienna office of the Prosecution Service of Austria. 
8. The applicant claimed that the items contained legal advice protected by lawyer-client privilege. 
9. The applicant lodged complaints with all levels of the PPS, challenging the execution of the Constitutional Court’s judgment of 2010 and the re-seizure of 2012. 
10. All complaints were dismissed, and the applicant was informed by letters of the Office of the Prosecutor-General. 
11. The applicant lodged a fresh complaint under Article 127 of the Constitution, which was declared inadmissible by the Constitutional Court in 2013. 
12. A complaint challenging the re-seizure of 2012 by the applicant’s then lawyer was also declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF KÖNYV-TÁR KFT AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicants are schoolbook distributors.
- The Hungarian school system was reorganized in 2011 and 2012, and acts were published containing provisions amending Act no. XXXVII of 2001 on the Schoolbook Market.
- Prior to the New Regulations' entry into force, the schoolbook distribution sector was an unregulated market.
- Schoolbook distributors' clients were schools.
- The task of distributors included provision of logistical services, processing of orders, management of customized billing, and handling of returns.
- The New Regulations introduced a new system of schoolbook distribution in Hungary, and "schoolbook supply" became a public-interest responsibility of the State.
- The State-owned non-profit book distribution company Könyvtárellátó became the sole entity responsible for schoolbook supply.
- The New Regulations gave the State-owned schoolbook distributor a guaranteed margin of 20% and effectively barred former market participants.
- The applicant companies filed a constitutional complaint against the New Regulations, but the Constitutional Court terminated the proceedings because subsequent legislation had repealed the New Regulations.
- Act no. CCXXXII of 2013 removed any schoolbook distribution based on the free market and introduced an entirely State-organized form of schoolbook supply to the Hungarian public education system.
- The applicant companies did not file a constitutional complaint against Act no. CCXXXII of 2013.

title: CASE OF SHKITSKIY AND VODORATSKAYA v. RUSSIA
facts:
Main descriptions of the facts:

- First applicant (born in 1975) was elected as a member of the council of the Irkutsk Regional Bar on 20 February 2009, second applicant (born in 1960) issued an order appointing herself acting President of the Bar on 25 November 2010.
- The Commercial Court of the Irkutsk Region granted the request of a group of lawyers to enjoin the second applicant from fulfilling the functions of acting president pending the outcome of the proceedings.
- On 19 January 2012, the Commercial Court discontinued the proceedings and the final decision was taken by the Supreme Commercial Court on 26 September 2012.
- Several members of the Bar, including the applicants, lodged complaints on different dates in 2011, alleging irregularities in the appointment, claiming that the ultimate goal of the acting president had been to get rid of his opponents in the Council, and that he had personal connections with the Deputy President of the Regional Commercial Court who was instrumental in ensuring a favorable outcome in the proceedings against the second applicant’s appointment.
- On 31 October 2011, the council of the Bar disbarred the first applicant due to the violation of relevant legislation and the Code of Professional Conduct for Lawyers.
- On 16 December 2011, the council of the Bar disbarred the second applicant for the same reasons.
- Both applicants filed complaints against the decision, but they were dismissed by the Kirovskiy District Court of Irkutsk and the Irkutsk Regional Court.

title: CASE OF FOKS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1967 and lives in Moscow.
- S. owned a one-room flat located at 6-60, Smolenskaya Street, Moscow.
- S. died on 7 February 2008.
- An unidentified person claiming to be S.'s sister and heir presented a passport in the name of M. to a notary seeking recognition of her rights to the flat.
- On 18 March 2009, the notary issued a certificate confirming M.'s title to the flat.
- An unidentified person posing as M. sold the flat to the applicant on 19 May 2009.
- On an unspecified date, it was discovered that the birth certificate presented by M. had been forged.
- The police opened a criminal investigation into the fraudulent acquisition of the flat.
- On 1 December 2009, the Housing Department brought an action seeking the transfer of the applicant's flat to the City of Moscow.
- On 27 December 2010, the Presnenskiy District Court of Moscow allowed the Housing Department's action, and annulled the applicant's title to the flat, ordering its transfer to the City of Moscow.
- On 14 July 2011, the Moscow City Court upheld the judgment of 27 December 2010.
- On an unspecified date, the judgments were enforced.
- On 12 October 2017, the criminal investigation was reopened.

title: CASE OF MAKHLOYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was the father of Mr Maskhud Makhloyev and they lived in a family home in the village of Ordzhonikidzevskaya, Ingushetia.
- On 26 December 2006, Mr Maskhud Makhloyev was arrested and detained on suspicion of involvement in an attack on local policemen and his passport was seized during a search of the family house.
- The Sunzhenskiy District Court declared that the search had been lawful, and criminal proceedings were later terminated for lack of evidence against Mr Maskhud Makhloyev.
- The applicant's house was searched again on two occasions on different dates in 2008 and 2009.
- Mr Maskhud Makhloyev was wounded in an attack on the street in August 2009, and the police officers threatened him and his family members in the hospital.
- On the night of 29 October 2009, unidentified armed men in masks and camouflage uniforms broke into the applicant's house, inflicted bodily injuries on some family members, and kidnapped Mr Maskhud Makhloyev.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted later, but the whereabouts of Mr Maskhud Makhloyev remained unknown, and the measures taken thus far had not been able to establish the identity of the alleged perpetrators.

title: CASE OF BURŻA v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1988 and is currently detained in Warsaw Służewiec Remand Centre.
- On 26 November 2010, the applicant was arrested by the police.
- On 27 November 2010, the Warsaw Wola District Prosecutor charged the applicant with possession of a significant amount of drugs, and requested that the Warsaw Wola District Court detain him on remand.
- On 28 November 2010, the court decided to detain the applicant on remand for a period of three months.
- On 21 February 2011, the Warsaw Regional Court extended the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- Between 18 March and 12 April 2011, the applicant partially served a prison sentence ordered in another set of criminal proceedings against him.
- On 23 May, the Warsaw Regional Court extended the applicant’s detention on remand.
- On 22 August 2011, the Warsaw Regional Court again extended the applicant’s detention on remand.
- On 16 September 2011, a bill of indictment against the applicant and fourteen other persons was lodged with the Warsaw Regional Court.
- The applicant’s detention on remand was extended by the Warsaw Regional Court on 26 September 2011 until 30 March 2012.
- Between 24 October 2011 and 24 October 2012, the applicant served the remaining part of the prison sentence ordered in case III K 203/09.
- In the meantime, the Warsaw Regional Court extended the applicant’s detention on remand on 13 March, 4 July and 20 September 2012.
- The Warsaw Court of Appeal extended the applicant’s detention on 4 October 2012, 15 January, 13 June, and 28 October 2013, 13 March, 29 July and 30 December 2014, 25 June and 22 October 2015, and on 26 January 2016.
- The relevant decisions were often phrased in general terms, and no particular instances of the applicant’s conduct during the investigation or at the judicial stage were provided to substantiate the extension of detention on remand.
- The applicant’s appeals against those decisions were unsuccessful.
- On 4 March 2016, the Warsaw Regional Court gave judgment.
- The applicant was convicted of multiple offences and sentenced to six years’ imprisonment and to a fine of 8,000 Polish zlotys (PLN).
- On the same date, the applicant’s

title: CASE OF WALASEK v. POLAND
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Łatanice.
- The applicant was detained in Kielce Remand Centre from 6 September to 4 October 2012 (28 days).
- The applicant was held in overcrowded cells in which the space per person had been below the Polish statutory minimum standard of 3 m².
- The Government admitted that the applicant had been detained in an overcrowded cell, but emphasized that the space in each cell had exceeded 2 m² per person, and that the hardship caused by staying in an overcrowded cell had been compensated by adding 30 minutes to his daily walk as well as additional cultural and educational classes, or sports activities. 
- In the course of civil proceedings, the domestic courts established that for twenty-eight days the applicant had been detained in an overcrowded cell.
- The overall conditions in cells were adequate; cells were equipped in compliance with the relevant law; they were properly ventilated, and the toilet area had been separated from the rest of the living space in the cells.
- The applicant brought a civil action against the State Treasury for infringement of his personal rights and for compensation on account of his detention in overcrowded cells in various penitentiary facilities.
- The Warsaw Regional Court dismissed the applicant's action, but confirmed that temporarily (from 6 September to 4 October 2012) the applicant had been detained in cells in which the space per person had been below the Polish statutory minimum standard of 3 m², but not below 2 m². 
- The Warsaw Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal.

title: CASE OF VOSKERCHYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was the head of the election headquarters of the main opposition candidate in the presidential election held in 2008 in Armenia.
- Daily protest rallies were held in Yerevan’s Freedom Square by the supporters of Mr Ter-Petrosyan from 20 February 2008 onwards.
- On 1 March 2008, the assembly at Freedom Square was dispersed by the police, causing mass protests throughout Yerevan.
- On 8 March 2008, the applicant was summoned to a local police station and questioned about the leaflets that he had prepared and distributed among the demonstrators during the rallies.
- The applicant was charged with organising mass disorder and an attempt to usurp State power on 11 March 2008.
- On the same date, the Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan ordered the applicant’s pre-trial detention for a period of two months, namely until 8 May 2008.
- The District Court refused the applicant’s request to be released on bail.
- The applicant’s detention was extended on 4 May, 2 July, 3 September, and 30 October 2008 on the same grounds.
- The applicant’s appeals against the extension of detention were dismissed on 19 May, 18 July, 19 September, and 16 November 2008.
- On 10 December 2008, the trial court decided to set the case down for trial and ruled that the applicant’s detention was to remain unchanged.
- On 22 June 2009, the District Court found the applicant guilty of making public calls inciting a violent overthrow of the government and imposed a two-year sentence.
- The applicant was immediately released from detention due to the general amnesty declared by the Armenian parliament on 19 June 2009.

title: CASE OF AYVAZYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1956 and lives in Jrvezh.
- On 19 February 2008, presidential elections were held in Armenia, followed by daily protest rallies held by supporters of the opposition candidate from 20 February onwards.
- On 1 March 2008, the police dispersed the assembly at Freedom Square, arresting and charging the applicant under Article 316 § 1 of the Criminal Code (CC) with assaulting police officers.
- On 4 March 2008, the applicant was ordered to be pre-trial detained by the Kentron and Nork-Marash District Court of Yerevan.
- On 10 March 2008, the applicant lodged an appeal, arguing for the lack of evidence to substantiate detention.
- On 21 March 2008, the Criminal Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, finding the probability of the applicant evading criminal liability and punishment to be high.
- On 29 April 2008, the applicant’s case was sent to court for trial, and he remained in detention.
- On 13 May 2008, the District Court decided to set the case down for trial with the applicant’s detention remaining the same.
- On 11 June 2008, the applicant was found guilty under Article 316 § 1 of the CC and sentenced to a suspended term of one and a half years’ imprisonment.

title: CASE OF SAFRONOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
-There is a list of applicants.
-The details of the applications are mentioned in an appended table.
-The applicants filed complaints.
-The complaints are related to non-enforcement or delayed enforcement of domestic decisions.
-The applicants also complained about the lack of effective remedy in domestic law.

title: CASE OF ARROZPIDE SARASOLA AND OTHERS v. SPAIN
facts:
- The applicants were born in 1948, 1956 and 1953 respectively
- The first applicant was detained in Topas Prison when his application was lodged
- The third applicant is detained in Zuera Prison
- The second applicant was living in Ciboure (France) when his application was lodged
- On 30 September 1987 the first applicant was arrested and on 3 October 1987 he was placed in detention in France for belonging to the ETA terrorist organization
- The Paris Regional Court sentenced him to ten years’ imprisonment on charges of criminal conspiracy, breach of the law on arms and explosives, breach of the Electronic Mail and Communications Code and an offence related to individual or collective action aimed at creating public disorder through intimidation or terror
- The first applicant served his sentence up until 3 October 1995
- The first applicant then remained in detention in France, for the purposes of extradition, until 21 December 2000 when he was surrendered to the Spanish judicial authorities pursuant to an extradition request
- In Spain, the first applicant was sentenced to more than three thousand years’ imprisonment after eleven separate sets of criminal proceedings before the Audiencia Nacional
- The Audiencia Nacional fixed the maximum term to be served by the first applicant in respect of all his prison sentences in Spain combined at thirty years
- On 27 June 2006 an initial calculation was carried out for the purposes of fixing the date on which he would have finished serving his sentence
- At the first applicant’s request, the period of detention in France for the purposes of extradition (from 3 October 1995 to 21 December 2000) was deducted
- Following the Del Río Prada judgment, the first applicant sought and ultimately obtained a recalculation of his prison term
- On 25 March 2014 the first applicant requested the deduction of the prison sentence imposed by the French judicial authorities and served in France from the maximum thirty-year term established in Spain
- By decision of 2 December 2014 the Audiencia Nacional agreed to deduct the prison term served in France from the maximum term of thirty years’ imprisonment
- On 10 March 2015 the Supreme Court allowed the appeal on points of law lodged by the public prosecutor’s office for the purposes of clarifying the law
- Referring to the reasoning set out in its leading judgment no. 874/2014 of 27 January 2015, the Supreme Court reiterated all the applicable case-law and legislation concerning the consideration

title: CASE OF MUSA TARHAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant owned real property in Hadim, covering an area of 107 m².
- The Water Directorate General decided to expropriate the plot of land on 19 December 2008.
- The relevant authority estimated the value of the property at TRY 843.58 on 20 July 2008.
- The Hadim Regional Court authorized the takeover of the land and ordered the authorities to make a down-payment of TRY 866.09 to the applicant on 28 September 2009.
- The HRC ordered the transfer of the property deed to the authorities and set the award in compensation at TRY 2,515.38 on 22 September 2014.
- The applicant appealed to the Constitutional Court on 25 July 2016, alleging his rights, particularly that to peaceful enjoyment of his property, were breached.
- The appeal was dismissed on 29 November 2016 by a two-judge committee.
- Section 8 of Law no. 2942 on Expropriation provides for a purchase procedure, where a committee of experts appointed by the expropriating authority estimates the value of the property, and the owner is invited to negotiate the amount of the compensation awarded.
- Section 10 of the Law provides for compensation and registration of the property in the name of the authority in return for a cash payment.
- Section 27 of the Law allows for urgent expropriation, where the authorities must apply to a court for authorization to take possession of the property.
- Section 29 of the Law states that costs and expenses incurred under the Law must be borne by the expropriating authority.
- Article 326 of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that costs and expenses must be borne by the losing party, and article 330 stipulates that the losing party must reimburse the legal fees payable to counsel for the opposing party.
- By the judgment of the General Assembly of Civil Chambers of 25 February 2004, both the expropriated party and the authority should have their legal fees reimbursed.

title: CASE OF BITSAYEVA AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are Russian nationals living in Chechen Republic.
- They are close relatives of individuals who disappeared after allegedly being unlawfully detained by servicemen during special operations.
- The events concerned took place in areas under the full control of the Russian federal forces.
- The applicants have not seen their missing relatives since the alleged arrests.
- The applicants reported the abductions to law-enforcement bodies, and official investigations were opened.
- Proceedings were repeatedly suspended and resumed, and have remained pending for several years without any tangible results being achieved.
- Perpetrators have not been identified by the investigating bodies.
- Mr Vait Askhabov was allegedly forcibly taken into custody by servicemen on March 12, 2001.
- Mr Shamkhan Murdalov, his relative, Mr R.B. and acquaintance, Mr Kh.Z., were allegedly abducted by armed police officers on May 21, 2004.
- Mr Rustam Makayev was allegedly taken from his home by armed servicemen on December 1, 2001.
- Mr Adam Sadgayev, his common-law partner, Ms M.Shch., and his mother, Ms A.S., lived in the town of Shali.

title: CASE OF MEHMET DUMAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1975 and is serving a sentence in Diyarbakır prison.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of membership in an illegal organization, Hizbullah and was allegedly subjected to torture during the police custody that lasted twenty-two days.
- The applicant was questioned by the police and a prosecutor in the absence of a lawyer, confessed to his membership in the illegal organization and other activities.
- The applicant participated in on-site inspections and reconstructions of events and confessed to committing some offenses in the absence of a lawyer.
- A medical report was prepared twenty-two days after the arrest stating no traces of ill-treatment on the applicant’s body, and the applicant's confession was retracted, alleging that it was made under duress.
- The applicant was allegedly subjected to torture again for three more days while in the custody of the anti-terrorism branch due to a lack of prison places.
- Charges were brought against the applicant and others by a prosecutor, and the proceedings commenced before the Diyarbakır State Security Court, which had a military judge sitting on the bench initially and then replaced by a civilian judge after June 1999.
- The applicant was charged with taking part in the killing of nineteen people and injuring eight others on behalf of Hizbullah in various indictments.
- The Diyarbakır Assize Court convicted the applicant under Article 146 § 1 of the former Criminal Code and sentenced him to life imprisonment based on the applicant's statements, reports of the reconstruction of events and on-site inspection, statements of co-accused, and the witness F.E.
- The conviction was upheld by the Court of Cassation, who also dismissed the applicant's request to correct his age and informed that all the documents prepared in 1994 had been destroyed in 2004.

title: CASE OF AVCI AND DERELİ v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicants were born in 1980 and 1986 and were detained at the Tekirdağ F-Type prison at the time of application.
- Applicants were arrested on 28 and 29 October 2005 on suspicion of being part of a terrorist organization.
- On 31 October 2005, they were detained on remand by the Istanbul Assize Court.
- An indictment was filed against the applicants on 23 December 2005, accusing them of various crimes.
- Despite regular hearings, the applicants were kept in detention throughout the proceedings, with no release.
- On 11 November 2008, the 13th Chamber of the Istanbul Assize Court dismissed the objection, without holding an oral hearing, and based on the written opinions of the public prosecutor.
- The applicants were convicted and sentenced to imprisonment on 23 December 2009, while the court ordered the continuation of the first applicant's detention and the release of the second applicant.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the judgment of the first instance court on 24 March 2011.

title: CASE OF GRBIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and worked as a police officer in Bečej.
- On 24 January 2003, the Municipal Court started judicial proceedings against the applicant for alleged criminal offenses concerning his duty.
- On 26 May 2003, the applicant was dismissed from the police force based on Article 45 and Article 34 of the Ministry of Interior Act 1991 because criminal proceedings were pending against him.
- The applicant appealed the decision but was rejected on 30 June 2003.
- On 23 July 2003, the applicant lodged a claim with the Municipal Court for reinstatement.
- On 31 October 2003, the Municipal Court ended the criminal proceedings against the applicant because of the applicable procedural prescription period.
- On 12 November 2003, the remainder of the criminal proceedings were discontinued because the public prosecutor withdrew the charges.
- On 30 December 2003, the Municipal Court annulled the previous decision on the applicant's dismissal and stated that a broad interpretation of Article 45 could only be detrimental to those not found guilty.
- On 17 June 2004, the District Court upheld the reinstatement judgment, and the applicant was re-employed by the Ministry of Interior on 13 January 2005.
- On 9 March 2005, the Supreme Court reversed the reinstatement judgment, and the applicant was again dismissed from his job.
- The applicant began legal proceedings for the annulment of his second dismissal, but the Municipal Court, the District Court, and the Supreme Court all ruled in favor of his dismissal based on Article 45 and Article 34 of the Ministry of Interior Act 1991.
- On 14 March 2008, the applicant lodged an appeal with the Constitutional Court concerning the outcome, fairness, and length of the legal proceedings regarding his dismissal, the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty, and the "right to work."
- On 17 February 2011, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicant's appeal.

title: CASE OF MIJATOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- Applicants complained about failure to enforce court decisions
- All applicants obtained decisions from Constitutional Court
- Constitutional Court found violation of right to a hearing within reasonable time
- The Constitutional Court awarded certain sums to applicants for non-pecuniary damage suffered
- Further details available in the appendix to the judgment

title: CASE OF MEZHIDOVY AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are Russian nationals living in the Chechen Republic.
- They are close relatives of individuals who disappeared after allegedly being unlawfully detained by servicemen during special operations.
- The events took place in areas under the full control of the Russian federal forces.
- The applicants have not seen their missing relatives alive since the alleged arrests.
- The applicants reported the abductions to law-enforcement bodies, and official investigations were opened.
- The proceedings were repeatedly suspended and resumed and have remained pending for several years without achieving any tangible results.
- The first applicant is the mother, and other applicants are brothers of Mr Magomed-Emin Mezhidov, who was born in 1980.
- Between 13 and 20 May 2002 a military unit of the Russian federal forces in Chechnya under the command of General Bronivitskiy conducted a special operation in the village of Avtury.
- On the morning of 15 May 2002, Mr Magomed-Emin Mezhidov was at home with the first and second applicants. Another relative, Mr M., and a neighbor were also present.
- At around 10 a.m. two armoured personnel carriers (“APCs”) arrived at the applicants’ house located in the centre of the village.
- The applicants are close relatives of Mr Akhyad Shakhidov, who was born in 1964, and of his brother, Mr Khamzat Shakhidov, born in 1968.
- At about 10.30 a.m. the servicemen entered the applicants’ house.
- On the morning of 14 May 2002, a group of about thirty armed military men in camouflage uniforms arrived in APCs and military lorries in the village of Makhkety to carry out an identity check on residents.
- On their way out of the village, the military convoy passed a broken‑down UAZ vehicle.
- The applicants are close relatives of Mr Magomed Israilov, who was born in 1980.
- At around 3 a.m. on 16 August 2002 (in the documents submitted the date was also referred to as 17 August 2002) the family was at home when two APCs and a Ural lorry with a group of about forty to fifty armed servicemen arrived at their house.
- The first, second and third applicants are respectively the mother, sister and daughter of Mr Razambek Isiyev, who was born in 198

title: CASE OF COTEȚ v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant had an altercation on 15 June 2014 with two persons, during which one person received a serious head trauma.
- The applicant was arrested and remanded in custody pending trial.
- The applicant appealed against the detention order but the appeal was dismissed.
- The District Court found no reasons to detain the applicant under judicial control, but the decision was overturned on appeal by the Court of Appeal and the applicant was remanded in custody for another 30 days.
- The applicant lodged a habeas corpus request, but it was upheld by the court and prolonged for another 30 days.
- The Public Prosecutor’s Office applied several times for the prolongation of applicant’s detention.
- The applicant was released from detention on 20 November 2014.
- The applicant was held in overcrowded and poorly ventilated cells with insufficient food and bad water quality during his detention.
- The applicant was convicted for hooliganism and unintentional infliction of severe bodily harm and sentenced to a suspended sentence of two years’ imprisonment on 9 March 2017 by the Supreme Court of Justice.

title: CASE OF BRADSHAW AND OTHERS v. MALTA
facts:
- The applicants are joint owners of a four-storey building in Valletta known as the King's Own Band Club.
- The property was initially owned by the applicants' ascendants and rented out to the KOBC voluntarily for 500 pounds sterling annually.
- By law, the applicants are obliged to renew the lease annually and cannot demand an increase in rent.
- Part of the property is operated as a profitable restaurant and bar.
- In 2011, the applicants claimed that their right to peaceful enjoyment of the property was being breached and that the law was discriminatory in violation of the Convention.
- In 2013, the Civil Court found that the interference with the applicants' property rights was not proportionate and awarded damages to the applicants.
- In 2015, the Constitutional Court overturned the judgment and ordered the costs of proceedings to be paid by the applicants.
- The Constitutional Court found that the applicants did have title of ownership but could not allege a violation of their rights due to the voluntary agreement.
- The Regulations introduced in 2014 provided for increases in rent payable to owners by band clubs holding property under lease, including a 10% increase annually until 2016 and a 5% increase annually until 2023.

title: CASE OF PRODUKCIJA PLUS STORITVENO PODJETJE D.O.O. v. SLOVENIA
facts:
- Applicant company is a private media company registered in Ljubljana
- Competition Protection Office initiated proceedings against applicant company following a complaint of abusing its dominant position
- Office issued order to inspect premises; warned obstruction would result in a fine
- Inspectors arrived the next day but met obstruction by the applicant company's employees
- Applicant company comments denying obstruction
- Office imposed a fine of €105,000 for obstruction
- Applicant company brought an action against the order and complaint against the inspection report; requested oral hearing
- Supreme Court dismissed the action and upheld the fine
- Constitutional Court refused to accept a constitutional complaint for consideration
- Tax authorities enforced collection of the imposed fine
- Office issued summary of relevant facts indicating that applicant company abused its dominant position in the TV advertising market
- Applicant company commented on the summary
- Agency found that applicant company restricted competition by requesting exclusivity in advertising from customers and offering conditional loyalty discounts
- Agency order applicant company to end the infringement and imposed a fine of €4,994,491
- Applicant company brought an action against the infringement decision; requested oral hearing
- Supreme Court dismissed the action and refused to hold a hearing
- Constitutional Court refused to accept a constitutional complaint for consideration
- Agency initiated minor-offence proceedings against applicant company and three individuals for violating competition rules
- Agency found them guilty and imposed a fine
- Local Court granted their application for judicial review and stayed the minor-offence proceedings
- Higher Court upheld the first-instance judgment

title: CASE OF ATROSHENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant was born in 1963 and lived in Moscow
- The owner of two rooms in flat 10 signed a deed of gift for Ya
- The deed was registered and the title transferred to Ya
- An investigation was opened into M's actions of tricking the owner into signing the deed of gift
- Ya sold the rooms to the applicant for 300,000 RUB
- The Preobrazhenskiy District Court issued a seizure order for the rooms in connection with the criminal investigation against M
- Registration Service registered the sale agreement between Ya and the applicant
- M was found guilty of fraud regarding the room sold to the applicant
- N, the lawful owner of the rooms, died intestate and without heirs
- The Department of Housing sought restitution of the title to the rooms to the City of Moscow and the applicant's eviction
- The Presnenskiy District Court granted the Housing Department's claims and transferred the title to the rooms to the City of Moscow, ordering the applicant's eviction
- The Moscow City Court and the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation upheld the judgment
- Information regarding enforcement of the judgments was not provided by the parties.

title: CASE OF SECRIERU v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Nicoreni.
- In January 2012, the applicant promised to help a person ("X") apply for a Spanish visa using 520 euros obtained from X.
- X lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant for fraud, and criminal proceedings were initiated in March 2012.
- The prosecutor applied for a detention warrant for the applicant due to being unable to locate him.
- On 8 February 2013, the applicant was ordered to be remanded in custody for 30 days by the Râșcani District Court.
- On 9 October 2015, the applicant returned to Moldova and was informed of being wanted by the police at the border.
- On 13 October 2015, the applicant was arrested and placed in detention.
- On 15 October 2015, the applicant appealed against the order of 8 February 2013.
- On 2 November 2015, the Chișinău Court of Appeal dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
- The applicant’s detention was prolonged several times, and he was detained in an overcrowded cell with poor living conditions until 16 March 2016.
- On 12 July 2017, the applicant was convicted of fraud and given a suspended sentence of four years imprisonment.

title: CASE OF PETROV AND X v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant and his son, X, live in different regions of Russia.
- The first applicant lodged a complaint asking for assistance in finding his son and returning him to St Petersburg.
- The first applicant has been allowed to visit his son six days per month for two hours each time.
- The second applicant's mother, M, instituted divorce proceedings and asked for a residence order in favor of X to reside with her in Nizhniy Novgorod.
- The first applicant asked that the request for the residence order be rejected and that X be returned to him in St Petersburg.
- Both the St Petersburg and Nizhniy Novgorod childcare authorities issued differing opinions on the best residence for X.
- The court granted the residence order to the mother, M, and X currently resides in Nizhniy Novgorod.

title: CASE OF ILIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant filed a civil suit for damages against the Kragujevac Clinical Centre on 14 December 2006.
- In total, there were 11 hearings held during the proceedings, and five more were scheduled but did not take place.
- The initial claim was rejected as unfounded by the Kragujevac Court of First Instance on 20 May 2011, but this decision was later quashed by the Appellate Court on 26 December 2011.
- There were two recusal requests made by the applicant during the resumed proceedings in the first instance court, both of which were rejected.
- The case was transferred to the Kragujevac High Court on 4 October 2012, and the applicant made two more recusal requests during that time.
- Ultimately, the High Court rejected the damages claim as unfounded on 20 March 2013, which the applicant appealed, but the decision was upheld by the Appellate Court on 21 August 2014.
- On 7 February 2013, the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint regarding the length of the proceedings, which was transferred to the Appellate Court, but the court later found it no longer had jurisdiction to deal with the complaint.
- The Constitutional Court rejected the applicant's appeal regarding the length of proceedings on 21 October 2015, stating that despite the lengthy process, the courts acted efficiently and the applicant's contributions prolonged the proceedings.

title: CASE OF LJAJIĆ v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1964 and lives in Štitare.
- On 30 May 2000, the Belgrade Third Municipal Court ordered KMG Trudbenik to pay a specified amount to the applicant on account of salary arrears, plus the costs of the civil proceedings (judgment no. P1 863/99).
- The judgment became enforceable on 19 June 2000.
- On 13 March 2002, the Fourth Belgrade Municipal Court ordered the enforcement of the said judgment and further ordered the debtor company to pay the applicant’s enforcement costs (enforcement order no. I-VIII 101/2002).
- On 7 October 2003, the enforcement proceedings were suspended due to the institution of compulsory settlement proceedings before the Commercial Court.
- On 9 December 2011, the Commercial Court opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor company.
- On 6 March 2012, the applicant submitted his request for enforcement of the 30 May 2000 judgment (“enforcement request”) to the insolvency manager.
- The insolvency manager neither rejected the applicant’s claim nor forwarded it to the Commercial Court.
- On 24 February 2014, the applicant thus submitted his enforcement request with the Commercial Court, and on 1 October 2014, he supplemented it.
- On 6 August and 27 October 2014, the applicant complained about the inactivity of the acting judge in the insolvency proceedings.
- On 13 October 2014, the Commercial Court rejected the applicant’s enforcement request as having been lodged out of time.
- On 28 January 2015, the Commercial Appellate Court rejected the applicant’s appeal, and upheld the Commercial Court’s decision of 13 October 2014.
- On 24 March 2015, the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal, complaining of the decision of 28 January 2015.
- However, on 19 May 2016, the Constitutional Court rejected the applicant’s appeal as unfounded.

title: CASE OF A.N. AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are nationals of Tajikistan and Uzbekistan
- They were charged with religious and politically motivated crimes in their home countries
- Pre-trial detention was ordered in absentia and international search warrants were issued
- Russian authorities decided to remove the applicants
- There were consistent claims that removal would lead to a real risk of treatment against Article 3 of the Convention. 
- Details of the applicants such as initials, date of birth, and the dates of application introduced are provided in the Appendix. 
- The particulars of the domestic proceedings and other relevant information are also provided in the Appendix.

title: CASE OF SCHRAM v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1985 and lives in Bratislava.
- On 20 December 2014, the Bratislava IV District Court ordered the applicant’s pre-trial detention.
- The reason for his detention was the risk of reoffending.
- On 3 March 2015, the applicant submitted a request to the District Prosecution Office for release from pre-trial detention.
- The request was dismissed on 5 March 2015 and transferred to the District Court for a judicial determination.
- On 26 March 2015, the District Court held a hearing and dismissed the applicant’s request for release.
- The applicant’s lawyer lodged a written interlocutory appeal with the District Court on 24 April 2015.
- The applicant’s appeal was dismissed in chambers by the Bratislava Regional Court on 7 May 2015.
- On 1 June 2015, the applicant filed a constitutional complaint.
- On 30 March 2016, the Constitutional Court declared part of his complaint in respect of the proceedings held before the District Court admissible and the remainder inadmissible.
- On 21 June 2016, the Constitutional Court found a violation of the applicant’s right guaranteed under Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF MANANNIKOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicant charged with verbal insult of traffic police officers in 2006, found guilty and sentenced to a fine.
- Applicant charged with contempt of court and criminal libel of judge in 2010.
- Travel restrictions were imposed on the applicant in both criminal cases.
- Applicant’s flat was searched in the second criminal case and some of his electronic devices were taken by the investigator.
- The applicant’s lawyer was removed from the case as a witness, and a legal-aid lawyer was appointed to represent him.
- Applicant’s right to choose his own lawyer was violated.
- Applicant was placed for an in-patient psychiatric assessment.
- Applicant went on a hunger strike in protest against his placement.
- The Novosibirsk Regional Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal in a summary fashion.

title: CASE OF PROVENZANO v. ITALY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1933 and was detained in Milan until his death in 2016.
- He was a fugitive on the run from authorities for over forty years and was sentenced to several terms of life imprisonment for various offences.
- In 2012, he underwent surgery for a subdural haematoma, which caused him to display reduced consciousness and responsiveness to his surroundings, as well as a limited ability to express himself.
- The preliminary hearing against him was suspended due to his cognitive impairment.
- He suffered from a number of chronic medical conditions, including vascular encephalopathy, hepatopathy linked to HCV, Parkinson's disease, and arterial hypertension.
- He was frequently monitored and examined by medical and nursing staff, took various diagnostic tests, and underwent regular medical treatments and consultations.
- On various occasions, he fell or displayed cognitive deterioration that was attributed to degenerative and vascular causes.
- He was provided with a personalised care plan and underwent physiotherapy sessions to improve his mobility.
- He remained hospitalised for an extended period on account of bacterial and yeast infections.
- Reports showed that his cognitive situation remained unchanged over time, and he was completely dependent on others for everything.

title: CASE OF KABOĞLU AND ORAN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are university professors specializing in human rights protection and were born in 1950 and 1945 and live in Istanbul and Ankara respectively.
- On 5 February 2002, they were appointed as members of the Consultative Council on Human Rights.
- The Consultative Council provides the Turkish Government with opinions, recommendations, proposals, and reports on human rights promotion and protection.
- Mr Kaboğlu was elected as chairman of the Consultative Council, and Mr Oran was elected as chairman of the Working Group on Minority and Cultural Rights.
- The report presented to the Deputy Prime Minister on 1 October 2004, dealt with the concept and definition of minority and cultural rights in the world and Turkey, relying on the Treaty of Lausanne, national legislation and practice, and higher court case-law. It proposed revising the citizenship concept, adopting a multicultural, democratic, liberal, and pluralist societal model, and ratifying international treaties.
- The report received criticism from ultranationalist newspapers, political leaders, and senior officials.
- The applicants received death threats from ultranationalist groups and individuals, and Mr Kaboğlu was granted personal protection.
- The applicants brought civil proceedings against those who made insulting and threatening statements against them, but their claim was dismissed, and the Court of Cassation upheld the first-instance judgment.
- The Consultative Council's term of office ended on 5 February 2005, and the Government has not reconvened it since that date.

title: CASE OF KURŞUN v. TURKEY
facts:
- Applicant lives in Batman and owns a property in Toptancılar Sitesi, an industrial park area.
- An underground explosion occurred in Toptancılar Sitesi on May 3, 2004, resulting in three deaths and many injuries, plus property damage.
- A number of administrative commissions were established to determine the cause of the explosion and the damage caused by it.
- Fact-finding commissions determined that the explosion was caused by an underground oil leak, but the source of the leak could not be identified.
- A damage assessment commission identified six heavily damaged, ten moderately damaged, and 31 slightly damaged businesses in the area, plus two slightly damaged residences, and declared their owners "disaster victims." The applicant's property was not among the identified properties.
- Technical commissions were formed to determine the source and extent of the oil leak, and to make proposals for cleaning up the affected area, with limited success.
- A high-level commission was established to take more concrete steps to tackle the environmental disaster and determine its causes.
- The Batman public prosecutor's office filed a bill of indictment in December 2004 against a number of serving Tüpraş executives for causing unintentionally an explosion that resulted in death, injury, and damage.

title: CASE OF O.R. AND L.R. v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- Applicants born in 1979 and 1987.
- Protests against electoral fraud on 6 and 7 April 2009.
- Applicants returning home on 7 April 2009 when their minibus was stopped by armed men.
- ill-treatment during arrest and detention at police headquarters.
- Applicants held in a cell until 9 April 2009 without food.
- Taken to court on 9 April 2009 and sentenced to five days’ detention.
- Applicants and others transported to another police station on 13 April 2009 without explanation.
- Applicants too afraid to leave their homes for a week after their release.
- Criminal investigation launched against police officers on 2 February 2019 for ill-treatment.
- Officers V.D. and M.T. found guilty of ill-treating and sentenced to five and six years imprisonment, respectively, conditionally suspended for five years with community service.
- Officer A.C. investigated but no further information provided.

title: CASE OF BAKCHIZHOV v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was found guilty of inflicting bodily injuries on another individual and sentenced to five years’ imprisonment.
- The Kyiv Regional Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court upheld the applicant’s conviction.
- The applicant served his sentence in Boryspil Correctional Colony.
- The applicant complained of poor detention conditions, including overcrowded cells, inadequate food and water, unsatisfactory hygiene, and insufficient medical assistance.
- The applicant alleged ill-treatment by guards, arbitrary solitary confinement, and interference with his correspondence.
- The government denied most of the applicant’s allegations and provided evidence in support of their version of events.
