- The applicant brought these matters to the attention of different authorities, including the prosecutor’s office, but his complaints were either not dispatched or were ignored.
- The applicant requested copies of different documents from his case file, including judgments, appeals, and refusals for copies.
- The Brovary Town Court refused the applicant’s request for a copy of his entire criminal case file.
- The applicant was eventually provided with a copy of the Supreme Court’s judgment in his criminal case and given full access to his criminal case file after his release from prison.

title: CASE OF BAZANOVA AND MUKHACHEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- First applicant, Ms Bazanova, was arrested in 2009 on charges of abuse of power and bribery.
- The trial in her case opened in November 2010.
- Two individuals, K. and Ts., complained to the court in March 2011 that publications about the trial had damaged their reputation, leading to a request to hold the trial in camera.
- The Regional Court found the first applicant guilty in 2011 and sentenced her to 7.5 years’ imprisonment and a monetary fine, but the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation quashed part of the decision and remitted the matter for fresh consideration.
- In 2013, the Regional Court found the first applicant guilty as charged and sentenced her to 7 years and 3 months’ imprisonment and a monetary fine.
- Second applicant, Mr Mukhachev, was arrested in 2009 on charges of extremism and fraud.
- The trial in his case was fixed for April 2011 and held in camera for security reasons.
- The District Court found him guilty in 2011 and sentenced him to 9 years’ imprisonment, a decision which was upheld on appeal.

title: CASE OF PICU AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The case resembles another case involving demonstrations and violent acts in Romania.
- The applicants or their close relatives were injured or killed during the December 1989 events in several cities, which led to the fall of the communist regime.
- In 1990, criminal investigations were initiated regarding the use of violence against demonstrators, and the applicants' injuries and deaths were included in these investigations.
- The criminal investigation was recorded in file no. 97/P/1990 (current no. 11/P/2014).
- In 2016, a criminal investigation was initiated for crimes against humanity, and various steps were taken to gather information and take evidence from military officers and other participants in the events.
- From March 2017, the military prosecutor examined archives, audio/video recordings, and questioned witnesses and military personnel involved in the December 1989 military operations.
- At the latest update (29 March 2018), the criminal investigation was still ongoing.

title: CASE OF K.C. v. ROMANIA
facts:
- The applicant was a student in Belgium studying in Constanţa in April 2008
- An investigation was opened against a fellow student for drug trafficking on April 3, 2008
- The fellow student was caught trying to send drugs to an undercover agent on April 18, 2008, and implicated the applicant as the source of the drugs
- A search of the applicant’s room on April 18, 2008, resulted in the discovery of cannabis and LSD
- The applicant admitted to buying drugs from a friend in the Netherlands and selling LSD to the fellow student, but claimed he did not know about the LSD until he unpacked his luggage
- The applicant was informed of his rights on April 19, 2008, and was represented by a lawyer and interpreter during questioning
- The applicant was convicted of unlawful possession, importing, and trafficking drugs by the Tulcea County Court and sentenced to three years suspended and fined
- The applicant appealed, citing procedural irregularities and a violation of his rights, and was denied by the Constanţa Court of Appeal and High Court of Cassation and Justice

title: CASE OF Z.T. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- Applicant's date of birth is 1975 and resides in Telki.
- Applicant worked for State-owned company from February 1, 2008, to February 25, 2014.
- A part of applicant's severance payment upon termination was taxed at 98%.
- The amount of HUF 28,016,796 was taxed at 98% (approximately EUR 91,000).

title: CASE OF KHALAF AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and relevant details included
- Applicants complained about their detention extended beyond maximum time period
- Applicants also complained about excessive length of their detention
- Complaints made under Article 5 § 1 and Article 5 § 3 of the Convention

title: CASE OF S.E.F.T. TRAFIK KFT AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The first and second applicants are Hungarian limited liability companies partly owned by the fourth applicant, all with their seat in Budapest.
- The third, fourth, fifth and sixth applicants are Hungarian nationals, close family members who reside in Budapest.
- The first and second applicants operated 39 tobacco shops in Hungary, with the help of the third, fourth, fifth, and sixth applicants and other employees.
- The Parliament enacted Act no. CXXXIV of 2012 on the Repression of Smoking of Youth and on Tobacco Retail on 11 September 2012.
- The Act made tobacco retail a state monopoly, denying entities or persons involved in tobacco retail from previous years any privileges in the concession tender advertised on 15 December 2012.
- Legal persons could not apply for concessions, and each individual could apply for a maximum of five concessions.
- The third, fourth, fifth, and sixth applicants applied personally for concessions, but none were successful.
- They submitted a total of 155 tenders for concessions but only five were successful.
- Currently, they are involved in tobacco retail businesses of a distant family member who was granted a concession.

title: CASE OF T.K. v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1952.
- The applicant is a resident of Budapest.
- The applicant served as a civil servant until 14 April 2013.
- A certain part of the applicant's severance payment was taxed at 98%.
- The amount of the tax was HUF 3,513,447 (approximately EUR 11,500).

title: CASE OF NAGY v. HUNGARY
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Gyor.
- The applicant was employed at a State-owned institution from 1 July 2007 until 21 June 2010.
- Part of the applicant's severance payment was taxed at 98%, in the amount of HUF 5,051,012 (approximately EUR 16,800).
- The employer deducted HUF 2,094,624 as special tax, but the applicant failed to pay the remaining special tax.
- The National Tax Authority carried out a tax audit for the year 2010 and required the applicant to pay HUF 2,569,831 as outstanding special tax and 10 percent tax penalty.
- The applicant challenged the decision before the Győr Administrative and Labour Court, which found the decision lawful but quashed the tax penalty.
- Tax enforcement proceedings are currently being pursued against the applicant in respect of the outstanding special tax and late payment interests.
- Until May 2017, HUF 615,238 (approximately EUR 2,000) were collected from the applicant.

title: CASE OF MILIĆEVIĆ v. MONTENEGRO
facts:
- The applicant reported X for threatening him on 29 or 30 January 2013.
- On 1 February 2013, X attacked the applicant causing him injuries with a kitchen hammer, resulting in the applicant lodging a criminal complaint.
- X had previous indictments and had been a long-term psychiatric patient for schizophrenia, with a history of aggression towards neighbours and incidents of setting his flat on fire.
- X was found guilty of the attacks and required mandatory psychiatric treatment.
- The applicant sought compensation from the State claiming negligence in taking any preventive measures against X, but the courts ruled against him.

title: CASE OF BURLYA AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicants are Ukrainian nationals of Roma ethnicity.
- In 2002, a 17-year-old ethnic Ukrainian was murdered in Petrivka, alleged to have been committed by a Romany man who was convicted afterward.
- On September 8, 2002, villagers demanded the expulsion of Roma residents from the village.
- On September 9, 2002, the village council met and decided to support the expulsion of persons of Gypsy ethnicity from the village.
- On the evening of September 9, the mayor and the local police advised the applicants to leave the village as a “pogrom” was about to start.
- Over the night, a crowd of several hundred people, led by a certain Mr O.M., ransacked the houses belonging to the Roma.
- Police officers were present but did not intervene to prevent the looting, and electricity and gas supplies to Roma houses were cut.
- The applicants allege that after the attack, they had to move to another town and live with family and friends in overcrowded and inadequate conditions.
- A criminal investigation was initiated and then suspended multiple times over the years, with little progress towards identifying the culprits besides disciplinary sanctions on police officers at fault.

title: CASE OF HAKİM AKA v. TURKEY
facts:
- Two sons Aykut and Aykan went missing on November 19th, 2007, after leaving for their secondary school, and did not return home in the evening as expected.
- The mother informed the father, who then enquired about their whereabouts from family and friends. When unsuccessful, he informed the police.
- On the same day, the police registered the sons as missing persons, and the prosecutor instructed them to take statements from anyone who might have information on the missing boys.
- On November 23rd, three fishermen found a male corpse near Emirgan coast, and the victim was wearing a school uniform and rucksack filled with heavy stones; the student identity card in his pocket identified him as Aykan Aka.
- On November 30th, the father requested an underwater search, and Aykut's body was found in the sea fifty meters from the coast. Like Aykan, he was wearing a rucksack filled with heavy stones, and the cause of death appeared to be drowning.
- Autopsy reports confirmed that the cause of death for both boys was drowning, and no toxic substances or signs of violence were found in their bodies.
- In February 2008, the prosecutor decided not to prosecute as there was no evidence of a crime, and the Bakırkoy Assize Court dismissed the father's objection as the prosecutor had followed the procedure and law.

title: CASE OF RAMOS NUNES DE CARVALHO E SÁ v. PORTUGAL
facts:
- The applicant is a judge living in Barcelos
- The High Council of the Judiciary opened three sets of disciplinary proceedings against the applicant
- The applicant requested a performance appraisal before starting maternity leave, but it was not carried out before she went on leave
- The judicial inspector responsible for the appraisal was relieved of his responsibility after the applicant allegedly made disrespectful remarks about him
- Disciplinary proceedings were opened against the applicant for insulting the judicial inspector
- The applicant appealed against the indictment and a new judicial investigator was appointed
- Various documents were examined and witnesses were questioned during the investigation
- The applicant was found to have acted in breach of her duty of propriety and was ordered to pay twenty day-fines
- The applicant appealed to the Judicial Division of the Supreme Court, which upheld the decision of the CSM
- A second set of disciplinary proceedings was opened against the applicant for the use of false testimony in the first set of proceedings.

title: CASE OF OTEGI MONDRAGON AND OTHERS v. SPAIN
facts:
- The applicants were born in specific years as listed in the appendix.
- The first applicant was sentenced to two years' imprisonment for encouragement of terrorism and acquitted of other charges.
- The first applicant challenged the impartiality of the presiding judge in a cassation appeal before the Supreme Court.
- The Supreme Court found that the presiding judge had expressed a prejudice against the first applicant, and the judgment was declared void.
- A new panel formed of different judges acquitted the applicant of the charge of terrorism.
- Criminal proceedings were brought against all applicants on the grounds that a political party they intended to create was controlled by ETA, a terrorist organization.
- The presiding judge of these proceedings had previously shown signs of partiality and bias to the first applicant.
- The first applicant challenged the impartiality of the panel in charge of the proceedings, but the challenge was denied by the Audiencia Nacional.
- The panel sentenced the applicants to imprisonment and disqualification from taking part in elections.
- The applicants brought a cassation appeal before the Supreme Court, challenging the impartiality of the panel.
- The Supreme Court partially upheld the appeals and reduced the sentences but rejected the arguments concerning the alleged violation of the applicants' right to an impartial tribunal.
- Two judges of the Supreme Court issued dissenting opinions stating that the applicants' right to an impartial tribunal had been violated.
- The third applicant lodged a separate appeal against the judgments, contesting the sufficiency of the evidence.
- The applicants lodged an amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court, arguing that the panel of the Audiencia Nacional lacked impartiality.
- The Constitutional Court ruled against the applicants, finding that doubts about the presiding judge's impartiality were not justified.

title: CASE OF VICENT DEL CAMPO v. SPAIN
facts:
Facts of the case:
- The applicant worked as a teacher and head of department in a public school.
- A colleague filed a complaint against him for psychological harassment in the workplace, but it was dismissed.
- The colleague filed an administrative claim seeking redress for the malfunctioning of the public administration and requested compensation and reinstatement.
- The Regional Administration of Castilla-León contested the claims and requested the dismissal of the application.
- The High Court of Justice of Castilla-León ruled against the Regional Administration of Castilla-León, ordering it to pay compensation to the plaintiff.
- The applicant requested access to the file and to become a party to the proceedings, which was refused.
- The applicant lodged an appeal against the decision, which was dismissed.
- The applicant lodged an amparo appeal with the Constitutional Court, but it was declared inadmissible.

title: CASE OF VERKHOGLYAD AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table is appended to the document containing information about the applicants and their applications.
- The applicants complained that their pre-trial detention was excessively long.
- Some of the applicants had additional complaints that fell under the Convention's provisions.

title: CASE OF SHEPILOV AND PASICHNYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A list of applicants with relevant application details is provided in a table.
- The applicants complained about the excessive length of their pre-trial detention.
- The applicant in application no. 10395/14 raised additional complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF GARMASH v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The details of the application are given in a table.
- The applicant complained about the inadequate conditions of his detention.
- The applicant complained about the lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.
- The applicant had other complaints under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF LEVCHENKO AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table of applicants and their details is appended to the document.
- The applicants claim that the civil proceedings take an excessive amount of time.
- The applicants claim that there is no effective remedy in domestic law for their complaints.
- One of the applicants (in application no. 6966/13) raises another complaint under the provisions of the Convention.

title: CASE OF SOZONOV AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
• List of applicants is provided in the appended table.
• Relevant details of the applications are provided in the same table.
• Applicants claim that they were not given a chance to comment on the appeals lodged by the defendants in their respective cases.

title: CASE OF NARODNI LIST D.D. v. CROATIA
facts:
- Narodni List is a joint stock company incorporated under Croatian law, which published a weekly magazine with the same name.
- A photojournalist at Narodni List was accused of secretly taking photos of a judge in front of the Municipal Court building, which led to the police searching through the camera used by him and seven computers belonging to the company to find photographs of the judge. However, they found no photos of the judge.
- Index, a web portal, reported on the search, criticised it and satirically expressed its support for the photojournalist.
- The criminal complaint against the photojournalist was later dismissed due to the absence of incriminating evidence.
- Almost two years later, Narodni List published an article entitled “Judge B. should be put in the pillory”, which led the judge to bring a civil action for defamation against the applicant company before the Benkovac Municipal Court, and it ruled for the plaintiff, ordering the applicant company to pay him compensation for non-pecuniary damage in the form of his tarnished reputation.
- The applicant company lodged a constitutional complaint alleging violations of its freedom of expression and its right to fair procedure, both guaranteed by the Constitution, which was dismissed by the Constitutional Court.

title: CASE OF FREZADOU v. GREECE
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1962 and is a kindergarten teacher in Greece.
- She was appointed as an educational coordinator at the General Consulate of Greece in Chicago for two years.
- After the end of her term, a call for applications for the next two-year period was published, and she applied but was not appointed despite the ranking.
- The applicant lodged an application for annulment of the ministerial decisions of 22 and 29 August 2008 on appointing the selected educational coordinators with the Athens Administrative Court of Appeal.
- The court proceedings were delayed several times, and the two-year term for educational coordinators and the contested ministerial decision had already expired.
- The applicant argued that she still had a special interest in pursuing the annulment process because it would credit her with two more years of experience, which would improve her chances of being selected as a deputy coordinator of education in a future selection procedure.
- The Athens Administrative Court of Appeal rejected her arguments, as she had already been awarded the maximum number of points allowed by law for experience abroad, and it was not a lawful reason to continue the procedure in court. The contested act was no longer in force, and there was no need to adjudicate. The right to judicial protection remained intact if the individual could prove that they still suffered from unfavourable consequences that could be removed only by the annulment of the contested act.

title: CASE OF MALLIAKOU AND OTHERS v. GREECE
facts:
A. The applicants jointly acquired ownership of land, buildings, and mechanical equipment for the extraction of inert material through a contract in 1980. Ownership was transferred to different heirs and owners over time. 

B. The land in question was home to a quarry that was operated by a company named Latomeia Parnassidos EPE from 1974 onwards. In 1976 a hill named Glas in the Fokida region was nominated as an “archaeological area”. On 3 March 1981, the Prefecture issued license no. 205/3-3-1981 permitting the applicants and their predecessors to operate a quarry, provided they did not harm the monuments in the area. Complaints and warnings were issued by the Ephorate regarding their activities.

C. The applicants signed a lease contract to rent the quarry to another company in 1991. In 1993, the license to operate the quarry was revoked due to excessive damage to antiquities in the area. In 2000, the applicants requested compensation for the value of their land, quarrying equipment, and lost income. The request was denied by the Athens Administrative Court of First Instance, with the Athens Appeal Administrative Court and the Supreme Administrative Court confirming this decision in later appeals.

title: CASE OF PECHENIZKYY AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:

- Relevant details of applications

- Cases

title: CASE OF WCISŁO AND CABAJ v. POLAND
facts:
- Mr Wcisło owns a majority of shares in an apartment building in Cracow.
- The adjacent building was extended upwards, using a wall belonging to Mr Wcisło's building.
- Mr Wcisło requested the District Inspector of Construction Supervision to institute proceedings against the neighbouring building's owners for illicit extension.
- Several proceedings were instituted and remitted between 2000 and 2015, with various decisions and appeals made by both parties.
- Delays and inactivity by the District Inspector were repeatedly complained about by Mr Wcisło.
- The proceedings are still pending.
- Ms and Mr Cabaj requested a decision on the division of their land in Garwolin in 1996.
- The Garwolin District Office approved the land division and expropriated four plots designated for road construction.
- The applicants sought compensation from the Garwolin City Office for the expropriated land, but disputed the amounts offered.
- Several proceedings were initiated between 2001 and 2015, with decisions being made and remitted on multiple occasions.
- Delays and procedural errors were noted throughout the proceedings.
- The case was eventually transferred to the Mayor on 26 August 2013, with a decision being made in 2014, which was appealed and eventually set aside in 2015.
- The applicants lodged a cassation appeal in 2015.

title: CASE OF ROSTOMASHVILI v. GEORGIA
facts:
- The applicant and two other men were arrested on charges of murder and illegal possession of firearms. 
- The charges against them were based on the victim's father's statement claiming to have witnessed the crime and other evidence such as a hand grenade seized from the brothers' home and forensic reports. 
- Three witnesses testified that they found the victim dead and that they had not seen the victim's father at the farm. 
- Several testimonies and forensic reports were presented, implicating the brothers in the crime. 
- The applicant argued that he had an alibi and that the evidence did not implicate him, but his arguments were dismissed, and he was sentenced to fifteen years' imprisonment. 
- The applicant's conditions of detention were reportedly poor, and he was diagnosed with various health conditions, including tuberculosis. 
- The applicant successfully completed treatment under the DOTS programme on 21 September 2009.

title: CASE OF BEUZE v. BELGIUM
facts:
- The applicant is serving a life sentence for premeditated murder of his former girlfriend, committed in 2007.
- He was arrested by French gendarmerie and taken into custody under a European arrest warrant.
- A neighbor of the victim had identified the applicant as the murderer, and he had a history of violence.
- The applicant waived his right to consult with a lawyer during his arrest interview.
- He was surrendered to the Belgian authorities and interviewed by the criminal investigation police.
- He claimed he was present at the scene of the crime but denied committing the murder.
- During subsequent interviews, he changed his version of events and accused other people of the crime.
- The applicant was not allowed to communicate with a lawyer until the investigating judge decided to remand him in custody.
- He was charged with premeditated murder and other offenses.
- The applicant requested to annul the records of interviews conducted without legal assistance, which was dismissed by the Assize Court.

title: CASE OF ŞİMŞEK v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is detained in Sivas and was born in 1973.
- The applicant was taken into police custody on 19 November 2002 on suspicion of being a member of an illegal organization, Hizbullah, following an armed conflict with the police officers during which he had resisted and fired back at the police officers.
- The applicant was examined by doctors on the same day and they observed some injuries on his body.
- On 22 November 2002, the applicant was allegedly physically and psychologically ill-treated by police during his interview.
- On 23 November 2002, the applicant was examined again, but the police officers allegedly intervened with the medical report.
- The applicant gave statements on 23 November 2002 before the investigating judge and public prosecutor in the absence of a lawyer in which he accepted most of the accusations against him.
- The applicant claimed that he had admitted to being a member of Hizbullah due to duress and intimidation from the police.
- On 27 November 2002, the Diyarbakır public prosecutor filed a bill of indictment against the applicant.
- On 19 March 2003, the first hearing was held where the applicant denied the accusations and stated that he had been subjected to pressure while in police custody.
- On 18 September 2003, the applicant claimed again without providing details that he had been tortured.
- By Law no. 5190 of 16 June 2004, State Security Courts were abolished, and the Diyarbakır Assize Court acquired jurisdiction over the case.
- On 22 June 2007, the Diyarbakır Assize Court found the applicant guilty of committing the offence under Article 146 of the former Criminal Code and sentenced him to life imprisonment. The court also rejected the applicant’s claim that he was tortured by relying on the medical report dated 23 November 2002.
- On 10 April 2008, the Court of Cassation upheld the trial court's judgment.

title: CASE OF DIRAMA v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant brought an enforcement order against her former husband to collect alimony in arrears and accrued interest.
- Her former husband objected to the order and requested the court to declare it null and void.
- The court scheduled a hearing and appointed an expert to determine whether the payments made by the former husband corresponded to the alleged debt.
- The applicant's representative requested to be excused from a hearing due to another court appointment.
- In the final hearing, the court ruled against the applicant based on the expert report.
- The applicant's representative lodged an appeal, arguing that he was not given sufficient notice for the hearing.
- The Court of Cassation upheld the decision without responding to the applicant's arguments.
- The applicant's rectification request was rejected.

title: CASE OF LITSCHAUER v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
facts:
- The applicant ran an erotic video-chat business in Chișinău with young female models providing erotic shows through webcams to customers outside Moldova in exchange for payment.
- On 3 March 2015, the applicant was arrested and faced charges of pimping (proxenetism).
- The applicant argued that his detention lacked reasonable suspicion and that the existing case-law did not allow for his activities to be deemed as pimping.
- The Chișinău Court of Appeal dismissed his appeal and prolonged his detention on 16 March 2015 and 7 April 2015.
- The applicant was released on 27 April 2015 following his habeas corpus request.
- The applicant was found guilty by the Centru District Court but his criminal proceedings were terminated based on an amnesty law that required him to admit his guilt and express remorse.
- The Court sought an opinion from the State Agency for the Protection of Morality, which found that the applicant's activity could be considered pimping as the models' actions could be deemed acts of prostitution.

title: CASE OF A.T. v. ESTONIA
facts:
- The applicant is a life-sentenced prisoner born in 1977.
- The prison director assigned escort teams to take the applicant to the hospital for medical examinations in 2010 and 2011.
- The applicant was restrained by handcuffs and ankle cuffs during the medical examinations.
- The applicant was not allowed to wear his own clothes during the visits.
- The prison officers remained in the room during the medical examinations and could overhear the conversation between the applicant and the doctor.
- The applicant was granted a visit to see his newborn daughter in the hospital in 2012 and requested to wear his own clothes during the visit. He was restrained by handcuffs and ankle cuffs and the visit was escorted by a six-member team equipped with firearms and ammunition.
- The visit with the daughter took place at a time outside of general visiting hours and lasted only 10 minutes. The prison officers remained with him at all times, and he was not allowed to touch his daughter.
- The applicant lodged complaints against the prison conditions and circumstances with the Tartu Administrative Court in 2012 and a claim for compensation for non-pecuniary damage in 2013.
- Both the Tartu Administrative Court and the Tartu Court of Appeal dismissed the complaints.
- The Supreme Court refused to examine the applicant’s appeal on points of law in 2015.

title: CASE OF ZHANG v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was an undergraduate economics student in Ukraine in 2009.
- A fight broke out between a group of Chinese students and four Ukrainian men, including the victim.
- The victim was stabbed in the back with a metal skewer during the fight and died later in hospital.
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder and eventually found guilty and sentenced to twelve years’ imprisonment.
- The conviction was based primarily on the statements made by the victim’s friends, which were contradictory and inconsistent.

title: CASE OF PAUL AND BORODIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicants are two lawyers from Voronezh, born in 1977 and 1964, respectively.
- They provided legal services to several municipal organizations between 2008 and 2010, but were not paid for their services.
- The applicants filed a lawsuit to recover the debt, and on 22 June 2010, the Sovetskiy District Court of Voronezh granted their claim against the municipal transport company and awarded them 40,020,000 Russian rubles.
- The judgment was executed at the expense of the municipal budget.
- On 9 January 2013, the prosecutor of the Voronezh Region applied to the district court for an extension of the time-limits for an ordinary appeal against the judgment of 22 June 2010.
- On 13 June 2013, the district court refused to extend the time-limits, and the prosecutor appealed.
- On 8 August 2013, the Voronezh Regional Court quashed the decision of the district court and extended the time limit for an ordinary appeal, citing public interest concerns since the judgment had been executed through the municipal budget.
- On 12 November 2013, the Voronezh Regional Court granted the appeal lodged by the prosecutor and quashed the judgment of 22 June 2010, ordering the reversal of execution. The judgment became final and was partially executed.

title: CASE OF ARZHIYEVA AND TSADAYEV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The first applicant was born in 1949 and lives in Strasbourg, France. The second applicant was born in 1984 and lives in Grozny, Chechnya, Russia. 
- The applicants were residents of Grozny, Chechnya when their property was damaged in the course of a counterterrorist operation in 1999-2000. 
- The applicants sought to obtain no-fault compensation provided for by Government Decree no. 404. 
- The first applicant’s flat was damaged during the hostilities in 1994‑1995, and then destroyed in 1999-2000. 
- The second applicant owned flat no. 12 in an apartment block at 53 Kavkazskaya Street, Grozny. The building was destroyed during the hostilities in 1999-2000.

title: CASE OF NAVALNYY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant is a political activist, opposition leader, anti-corruption campaigner, and popular blogger.
- The case concerns his arrests on seven occasions at different public events.
- On March 5, 2012, the applicant took part in a protest at Pushkinskaya Square, Moscow, to protest against the allegedly rigged presidential elections in Russia.
- At 10.45 p.m. on the same day, the police arrived and arrested the applicant, among many others.
- On May 8, 2012, the applicant was walking down Lubyanskiy Proyezd with about 170 people when they stopped for a group photograph and he was arrested by riot police.
- On May 9, 2012, the applicant arrived at Kudrinskaya Square in Moscow to take part in an informal meeting with a State Duma deputy and was arrested at around 6 a.m.
- On October 27, 2012, the applicant held a static demonstration at Lubyanskaya Square, which resulted in his arrest at 3.30 p.m.
- The applicant was charged with a breach of the established procedure for conducting public events in all these cases, fined or sentenced to administrative imprisonment, and his requests for video evidence, eyewitness statements, and cross-examination of police officers were refused in most cases.
- The Justice of the Peace dismissed the applicant's objections and found him guilty of the charges based on the evidence provided by the police officers in most cases.

title: CASE OF U.M. KERESKEDELMI KFT AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
facts:
- There is a list of applicants.
- Relevant details of the applications are included in the list.
- The applicants complained about the length of civil proceedings.
- Some applicants raised a complaint under Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF VUKOVIĆ v. CROATIA
facts:
- The applicant's vehicle was seized by the police in 2000 suspecting that it had been stolen by an unknown perpetrator.
- The police examined the applicant's vehicle to confirm its authenticity, and also asked Canadian Interpol to check if the vehicle was being sought by the police in Canada.
- The Zagreb State Attorney's office ordered the police to ask for relevant information from Canadian Interpol, which was not furnished.
- The Zagreb State Attorney's office ordered the car be returned to the applicant on May 2, 2002. 
- The applicant filed a civil action for compensation against the state, claiming that the car had been returned to him in a state of disrepair, and the police had kept it for an unreasonably long time.
- The applicant wasn't successful in his compensation claim against the state, as the courts held that the temporary seizure of the car had been lawful.
- The applicant lodged an extraordinary appeal on points of law with the Supreme Court and a constitutional complaint with the Constitutional Court.
- The Supreme Court found the appeal on points of law inadmissible, and the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's constitutional complaint.

title: CASE OF GEVEL AND OTHERS v. UKRAINE
facts:
- A table with a list of applicants and details of their applications is appended to the document.
- The applicants have complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.
- The applicants have complained about the lack of an effective remedy in domestic law.
- In application no. 6314/18, one of the applicants raised an additional complaint under the provisions of the Convention.

facts:

- The applicants filed a complaint regarding the excessive length of civil proceedings.

facts:

- The applicants complained about the excessive length of criminal proceedings.

facts:
- A list of applicants and their details is provided in an appended table.
- The applicants complained about the duration of civil proceedings.
- Some applicants also lodged a complaint under Article 13 of the Convention.

title: CASE OF ASLANOV v. AZERBAIJAN
facts:
- First applicant was born in 1955 and second applicant was born in 1986
- First applicant suffered from end-stage kidney failure, cardiovascular diseases, severe type 2 diabetes and had very limited physical mobility
- First applicant was arrested on 20 June 2007 by agents of the Ministry of National Security on suspicion of planning to murder Z.F.
- On 22 June 2007, first applicant’s state of health significantly deteriorated and he was urgently transferred to the medical facility where he remained until his death on 22 January 2008
- Criminal inquiry into the first applicant’s death was launched by the Nizami District Prosecutor’s Office, and a post mortem report concluded that the death had resulted from acute heart failure
- First applicant’s family filed a civil action with the Sabail District Court, complaining of incompatibility of the first applicant’s detention with his state of health and inadequate medical treatment, and also requested discontuation of pre-trial detention which was dismissed by the Assize Court
- On 16 November 2007, the Assize Court found the first applicant guilty under Articles 29 and 277 of the Criminal Code and sentenced him to eleven years and three months’ imprisonment, which was upheld by the Supreme Court on 28 October 2008.

title: CASE OF SELAHATTİN DEMİRTAŞ v. TURKEY (No. 2)
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1973 and was a co-chair of the HDP, a left-wing pro-Kurdish political party. 
- He was a member of the Turkish Grand National Assembly from 2007 onwards. 
- In the presidential elections of 2014 and 2018, he received 9.76% and 8.32% of the vote respectively. 
- In 2014, there were armed clashes between Daesh and YPG in the Syrian town of Kobani, resulting in a series of demonstrations in Turkey. 
- The applicant and HDP called upon people to protest non-violently against the AKP government's embargo over Kobani. 
- Clashes during the demonstrations resulted in 50 deaths, 772 injuries, and significant damage to buildings and vehicles. 
- The applicant was opposed to the use of violence during the protests. 
- In 2015, a peace process known as the "solution process" was initiated to find a peaceful solution to the "Kurdish question", but it ended after a series of terrorist attacks. 
- In the same year, self-governance was proclaimed in nineteen different towns in Turkey, and several curfews were imposed in various towns. 
- The applicant's party polled 10% of the vote in the 2015 elections, and the AKP regained its majority in the National Assembly.

title: CASE OF S.N. v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was allegedly repeatedly forced to have oral and anal sex with eleven men over a period of almost two years from October or September 2010 to June 2012.
- The men had filmed the events and had threatened to disclose this information to the public should the applicant refuse to comply with their demands.
- Following a complaint by the applicant's father, a preliminary inquiry was conducted, during which the applicant provided a detailed account of the events and underwent a gynecological examination that did not detect any traces of sexual assault on her body.
- The investigator who questioned the alleged perpetrators found no evidence to support the applicant's allegations of rape, and decisions to decline opening a criminal investigation were issued and quashed several times.
- A criminal investigation was eventually opened, but the investigation was ultimately discontinued, as the allegations were only confirmed by the applicant and her parents, and they contradicted the statements of many witnesses and forensic evidence.

title: CASE OF GORBULIN v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1982 and is detained in Labytnangi, Yamalo-Nenetskiy Region.
- On 22 May 2008, the applicant arrived at the IK-8 correctional colony, Yamalo-Nenetskiy Region.
- On 31 March 2008, the applicant's wife instituted divorce proceedings.
- On 9 April 2008, the Justice of the Peace of Circuit no. 2 of the Krasnosulinskiy District of the Rostov Region sent a letter rogatory to the courts of Tyumen Region.
- On 22 April 2008, the Tyumen Regional Division of the Judicial Department received the letter.
- On 4 July 2008, a Justice of the Peace in Labytnangi fixed an interview with the applicant for 18 July 2008, which he did not attend.
- On 10 September 2009, the Tyumen courts informed the Justice of the Peace that it had been impossible to reach the applicant.
- On 18 September 2008, the Justice of the Peace granted the divorce.
- On 20 November 2013, the applicant learnt of the judgment of 18 September 2008 and asked for an extension of the time-limit for lodging an appeal against it.
- On 26 December 2013, the Justice of the Peace held a hearing and refused the applicant’s application to extend the time limit for lodging an appeal.
- On 15 May 2014, the Krasnosulinskiy District Court of Rostov Region upheld the decision of 26 December 2013.

title: CASE OF SAMESOV v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1987 and lived in St Petersburg before his arrest.
- Criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant for fraud allegedly committed against Ms R.
- On 4 July 2013, the applicant was arrested on the street by masked police officers and taken into custody.
- On several occasions between 4 July and 5 July 2013, the applicant was allegedly ill-treated by police officers in an effort to force a confession.
- On 5 July 2013, the applicant was questioned by an investigator at the St Petersburg Investigative Committee in the presence of a State-appointed lawyer.
- On 5 July 2013, the applicant was remanded in custody by the Vyborgskiy District Court of St Petersburg and taken to a different police station where his injuries were recorded.
- On 7 August 2013, the applicant lodged a formal criminal complaint concerning his alleged ill-treatment.
- Pre-investigation inquiry was carried out by the St Petersburg Investigative Committee, who refused to initiate criminal proceedings against the police officers and the investigator on several occasions.

title: CASE OF TORANZO GOMEZ v. SPAIN
facts:
- The applicant was a member of an activist group occupying a social center in Seville.
- The owners of the building initiated legal proceedings to recover their property, and a court ordered the eviction of all occupants on 29 November 2007.
- On the day of eviction, the applicant participated in a protest against their removal.
- During the eviction, it was discovered that the occupants had dug a tunnel and attached themselves to the floor using chains and tubes.
- Negotiations took place, but eventually, the police immobilized the applicant and his fellow protester R.D.P. with ropes on 30 November 2007.
- On the same day, R.D.P. voluntarily released himself, and the applicant followed suit around an hour later.
- The applicant and R.D.P. were arrested and underwent a forensic examination. The report stated that the applicant suffered a contusion of the right wrist.
- The applicant spoke at a press conference on 1 December 2007, where he accused the police and fire fighters of torturing him and his fellow protesters.
- Complaints were filed, and the applicant was charged with slander and defamation.
- The criminal judge found the applicant guilty of slander and sentenced him to a fine and ordered him to compensate the police officers. The judge also ordered him to publish the judgment in the media at his expense.
- The judge concluded that the applicant's accusations of torture were untrue and exceeded his right to freedom of speech.

title: CASE OF PULFER v. ALBANIA
facts:
- The applicant is an Albanian national who purchased a house from S.N.
- S.N. had unlawfully built the house and had lodged an application for the regularisation of the house’s unlawful status.
- The applicant deposited just under half of the sale price as a down-payment (kapar), and moved into the house on the basis of the down-payment agreement.
- On 12 January 2012, S.N. asked the applicant to vacate the house and destroyed some of the applicant’s movable property.
- S.N. lodged a civil action on 1 February 2012, requesting that the down-payment agreement be declared null and that he be allowed to retake possession of the house.
- The Vlora District Court dismissed the action on 3 May 2012 and found that the down-payment agreement was valid and lawful.
- On 8 September 2012, S.N. forced his way into the house and assaulted the applicant, causing injuries that temporarily rendered her unfit for work for a period of nine days.
- Following the alleged assault, the applicant lodged several criminal complaints against S.N. for various offences, including bodily harm, self-administered justice, theft, threat, and destruction of property.
- An investigation was opened against S.N. and E.N. for the offences of self-administered justice and theft, but the proceedings were discontinued due to an amnesty granted by the General Amnesty Act.
- The applicant appealed the prosecutor's decision to discontinue the proceedings, but her appeal was dismissed by domestic courts.
- The applicant made another criminal complaint against S.N. for theft, and the proceedings were discontinued due to an amnesty granted by the General Amnesty Act.
- The applicant also made a complaint against the forensic medical report, alleging that it was based on forged documents and that the offence of grievous bodily harm had been committed. The prosecutor initially decided not to send the case for trial, but the decision was later quashed by the Tirana District Court, which ordered the prosecutor to continue the investigation.

title: CASE OF OGNEVENKO v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1972 and was a locomotive driver with Russian Railways in the Moscow region.
- The trade union, Rosprofzhel, sought a general pay raise and the introduction of long-service bonuses for the relevant staff.
- The trade union organized a strike that the applicant participated in.
- The strike caused delays in train circulation and was deemed to have violated the rights and lawful interests of citizens.
- The applicant was dismissed for two breaches of disciplinary rules, with one of them being his refusal to take up his duties during the strike.
- The District Court confirmed the lawfulness of the applicant’s dismissal, citing Railway Acts that prohibited strikes of railway workers responsible for the circulation of trains, shunting, and services to passengers.

title: CASE OF AVAGYAN v. ARMENIA
facts:
- The applicant knew one of the sisters found dead and had been bequeathed her apartment in a will drawn up in 2006.
- The sisters were found dead, and forensic medical examinations were ordered to determine cause of death.
- Initial opinions stated that the sisters' death had not been intentional or caused by negligence.
- A niece of the sisters later alleged that the applicant had submitted a forged will claiming ownership of the same apartment.
- Additional post-mortem examinations were ordered to determine if the sisters had died as a result of poisoning.
- Experts later confirmed the presence of phosphorous compounds in the bodies of the sisters.
- The applicant was charged with two counts of murder for gain and fraud.
- The trial relied on expert opinions, statements of neighbors and relatives, and material evidence seized from the applicant's apartment.
- The applicant was found guilty and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- The applicant appealed, arguing that he was deprived of the opportunity to examine the experts with regard to their contradictory opinions. However, his appeal was rejected.

title: CASE OF BOSYY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- The applicant was sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment for aggravated robbery in 2006.
- He was detained in a pre-trial detention center from May 2005 to October 2006 and in two correctional colonies until his release in 2012.
- The applicant alleged inadequate living conditions, ill-treatment, torture, persecution, and denial of access to his criminal case file by the prison authorities, which the Government denied.
- The applicant complained numerous times to diverse domestic authorities and sent more than sixty letters to and received letters from various public entities.

title: CASE OF SOYTEMİZ v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant was arrested on suspicion of aiding an illegal organisation.
- The applicant requested a lawyer before his police statement was taken and one was appointed.
- The lawyer was present during the police interview but was removed by police officers after allegedly interfering with the applicant's free will.
- The applicant was coerced into signing self-incriminating statements.
- The applicant was released pending trial and later acquitted by the Erzurum Assize Court but was convicted on appeal by the Court of Cassation.
- The applicant lodged a complaint of unlawful interference with the questioning against the police officers involved.
- The police officers were later accused of ill-treatment and misconduct in office, but the case was discontinued on the grounds of being time-barred.

title: CASE OF URAT v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicants are brothers born in 1964 and 1962, respectively, and were primary school teachers employed by the Ministry of Education.
- They were taken into custody in January 2000 on suspicion of membership of an illegal organisation, Hizbullah.
- Their profiles, in the format of CVs, were found among the documents of the organisation's safe house in Istanbul.
- Both applicants denied the allegations and claimed that errors and inaccuracies in the profiles demonstrated that they had been prepared by someone else without their consent.
- The criminal proceedings against them were suspended due to Law no. 4616, which provided for the suspension of criminal proceedings in respect of certain offences committed before 23 April 1999.
- The first applicant's involvement with the organisation was limited to handing in his CV and attending its indoctrination sessions, which fell within the scope of aiding and abetting rather than membership, resulting in the suspension and eventual discontinuation of the proceedings.
- The second applicant was reclassified as aiding and abetting and was acquitted of the remaining charges for lack of sufficient evidence, and the proceedings against him were eventually also discontinued.
- The Ministry of Education initiated a disciplinary investigation against the applicants and other civil servants, resulting in their dismissal from public service on the grounds of disrupting the peace, tranquillity, and working order of the institution for ideological and political purposes, based on the investigators' report.
- The applicants challenged their dismissals in administrative courts, but to no avail, with the courts relying on the disciplinary investigation and the recommendations for the applicants' dismissal.

title: CASE OF ALEKSEYEV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants submitted notices of LGBT public assemblies from 2009-14
- Local authorities denied approval of proposed dates and locations
- Applicants challenged decisions in domestic courts under Chapter 25 of the Code of Civil Procedure
- Domestic courts upheld the decisions of the local authorities
- Judicial decisions were taken after the respective dates of the originally proposed assemblies.

title: CASE OF MİKAİL TÜZÜN v. TURKEY
facts:
- The applicant is a traffic control officer born in 1960 living in Istanbul. 
- On December 11, 1995, he was hit by a car while on duty, resulting in bodily injuries. 
- The official disability report indicates that he had a reduced working capacity of 60%. 
- The applicant made an initial request for compensation of TRY 20,000 in pecuniary damages and TRY 5,000 in non-pecuniary damages to the Ministry of Interior. 
- The Ministry dismissed the claim, and the applicant filed a case for compensation with the Istanbul Administrative Court for the same amounts requested initially. 
- The court ordered an expert report to determine the exact amount of pecuniary damage suffered by the applicant, which reported the damages at TRY 157,077. Despite this, the applicant did not increase his initial claim, and the court only awarded him the initial requested amounts.

title: CASE OF KĽAČANOVÁ v. SLOVAKIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1953 and recognized as severely disabled in 2006.
- She claimed restitution of a suite of real property in 2004.
- On 20 December 2011, she lodged an action against the Land Office, seeking an order for acceleration of the restitution proceedings.
- She claimed legal costs with respect to five acts of legal assistance.
- The Regional Court granted the action and made an order for costs with respect to three acts of legal assistance.
- The Regional Court did not provide reasons for not allowing her claim for costs with respect to the remaining two acts of legal assistance.
- The Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible, stating that no exceptional circumstances had been established.

title: CASE OF SAKHNOVSKIY v. RUSSIA
facts:
- The applicant was born in 1979 and lives in Novosibirsk.
- The applicant was charged with and found guilty of murdering his father and uncle.
- The applicant complained of the unfairness of the criminal proceedings against him, alleging he had not been provided with legal assistance in the appeal proceedings.
- The Court found a violation of Article 6 §§ 1 and 3 (c) of the Convention in that the applicant had not received effective legal assistance during the appeal proceedings in his criminal case.
- The case was referred to the Grand Chamber and the applicant was granted a new hearing with a State-appointed lawyer.
- The Supreme Court upheld the applicant's conviction with counsel K. present.
- The applicant was detained in different cells with varying conditions.
- The applicant brought a civil action against the remand prison for inhuman and degrading conditions.
- The District Court dismissed the claims, but the Regional Court granted them in part and awarded the applicant compensation for non-pecuniary damage.

title: CASE OF POPOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
facts:
- Applicants are from four families.
- Employer of adult male applicants provided them with accommodation in a dormitory building in Moscow.
- Adult female applicants started residing in the dormitory building with their husbands since their marriages in 2002, 2004, 2003, and 2005, respectively.
- Applicants 2, 6, 7, 9, and 12 were born and started living in the dormitory building with their parents between 2003 and 2009.
- Third and fifth applicants resigned from the security service in 2004 and 2009, respectively, but continued to live in the dormitory building.
- The applicants are registered as living in the dormitory building on a permanent basis, and each family occupies a room in the building.
- Treasury brought court proceedings against applicants 4, 8, 11, and 13 seeking their eviction from specific rooms which they occupied in the dormitory building.
- District Court ordered their eviction without providing them with any alternative accommodation.
- In 2009, the Treasury brought new eviction proceedings against the adult female applicants, seeking to evict them from the dormitory building.
- The adult male applicants and minor applicants brought court proceedings seeking to have their right to occupy the dormitory building indefinitely under a social tenancy agreement recognized.
- District Court granted the claims of the adult male applicants and the minor applicants in part.
- City Court upheld the District Court's judgment.
- Applicants informed the Court of changes in their family situations.

title: CASE OF STANIVUKOVIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
facts:
- The applicants' personal details are outlined in the Annex to the judgment.
- The applicants filed complaints about the lengthy duration of their labor disputes.
- The applicants claimed that the lengthy disputes violated their rights under Articles 6 § 1 and 13 of the Convention.
- The Constitutional Court did not find any infringement of the right to a fair trial within a reasonable time in any of the cases, and no compensation was awarded to any of the applicants.

title: CASE OF CHURCH OF REAL ORTODOX CHRISTIAN AND IVANOVSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- The second applicant was born in 1957 and lives in Prilep.
- On 8 November 2008, the applicant association was founded by seven persons, including the second applicant.
- The applicant association adopted a charter specifying its aims and activities.
- The applicant association sought registration as a religious entity under the Legal Status of Churches, Religious Communities and Religious Groups Act (“the 2007 Act”).
- The Registration Court rejected the application as incomplete.
- The court held that the applicant association would operate as an association of citizens to which the Association of Citizens and Foundations Act applied.
- The court found that the applicant association's aims and activities were not in line with the 2007 Act.
- The registration of the applicant association could violate the freedom of religion of other physical persons-believers and the lawful legal status of other registered voluntary associations of physical persons and their managing bodies.
- The Skopje Court of Appeal upheld the lower court's decision, finding that the reasoning contained therein was clear and consistent.

title: CASE OF STAVROPEGIC MONASTERY OF SAINT JOHN CHRYSOSTOM v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
facts:
- Three former nuns in the Macedonian Orthodox Church founded an applicant association.
- The founding members of the applicant association created official documents including a charter.
- The applicant association applied for registration as a voluntary non-profit Christian association that does not belong to any religious community, specifically the Macedonian Orthodox Church.
- The registration court refused to register the applicant association.
- The registration court found that the application did not meet the requirements laid down in the 2007 Act on the legal status of a church, religious community, and association.
- The Skopje Court of Appeal upheld the lower court's decision.
- O.M. lodged an appeal with the Constitutional Court, which rejected the constitutional appeal.

title: CASE OF GRABOVSKIY v. UKRAINE
facts:
- Applicant is detained in Italy on charges unrelated to the present case
- A sales clerk was attacked in Kharkiv on 22 July 2005 and suffered multiple cuts
- Applicant was convicted of aggravated robbery for attacking the sales clerk and taking cash from the shop
- Applicant maintained that the sales clerk owed him money and that he had hit her in self-defense
- The applicant was arrested on 22 July 2005 and allegedly denied a lawyer
- The trial court relied on the applicant's admissions, the victim's testimony, the confiscated money and clothes, and witness statements to convict the applicant
- The applicant appealed to the Kharkiv Regional Court of Appeal and requested a lawyer, which was not provided
- He was transferred to different detention centers during his sentence and had periodic health issues treated
- The applicant requested certain documents from the domestic authorities to prove his innocence, but the quality of the copies he had prevented him from submitting them to the Court.
